title: Ethiopia Wins Border War Against Eritrea
description: Ethiopia declared ''total victory'' over Eritrea today in their border conflict after a four-day offensive dislodged the Eritrean army from a craggy piece of borderland both sides conceded all along was not worth very much.

title: Memory Lapse Brings Defeat
description: The oldest ''rule'' in the game is more than a century old, but experts sometimes forget to use it. It is the Rule of 11, which was devised independently about 1890 by a Scot, Robert Foster, and an Englishman, E. M .F. Benecke. After a fourth-best lead, the number of higher cards in the other three hands can be determined by subtracting the size of the spot card led from 11.

title: Clintons' Poor Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Tourism / In Laos, English Menus and New Opium Dens : Westerners Flock East for an 'Asian Trip'
description: VANG VIENG, Laos  With a ring of opium grease starting to bubble around the pinhole on the end of his pipe, the emaciated old man reclining on a pile of dirty white pillows nods slightly to signal the liquid will soon vaporize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIRING, RUTH M.
description: FEIRING-Ruth M. 87, Sarasota, died February 20, 1999. She was born September 7, 1911 in New York City and went to Sarasota 27 years ago. She taught history and economics at Richmond Hill and Martin Van Buren High Schools and was a college adviser to graduates. She received a bachelorsdegree from Hunter College in New York. She was a member of Hadassah of Sarasota, O.R.T., B'nai B'rith Aurel Rosen Lodge and Temple Beth Sholom. Survivors include her husband William of Sarasota; a sister, Anne Rosenthal of Sarasota; and two nephews, Steven and Eugene Rosenthal. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, FL. 34238.

title: At the Heart of Purcell's Wit, a Fondness for Q. and A.
description: Henry Purcell might be closer to our musical hearts at the end of the 20th century were we not so hopelessly removed from the world in which he functioned. The music itself is fresh, witty and filled with an easy yet profound sophistication. Astonishingly, it rises above its ''oldness''; we are made to feel intimately at home despite the gap of 300 years.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; Dragon Systems, a Former Little Guy, Gets Ready for Market
description: Dragon Systems, a developer of speech-recognition software in Newton, Mass., that is scheduled to sell shares to the public sometime in the next few weeks, is not your typical software debutante. Its two 50-something founders can remember when computers filled entire rooms, not just entire briefcases. It has no debt, and real revenue. It even has profit.

title: Artful Workout on the Stairmaster
description: This city declared a snow emergency on Thursday, and the opening of a four-day engagement by Mark Morris's company was canceled at the Wang Center for the Performing Arts. Such are the vagaries of living in a car culture.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Personal information is like gold in the Internet economy, and the rush is on to both exploit it and protect it.
description: FOR the last few weeks, the data privacy battle has been waged with such fury that privacy advocates have not known whether to cry, cheer or simply assume the fetal position.

title: U.S. Says It Caught a Chinese Smuggler Seeking Gyroscopes That Can Guide Missiles
description: Federal agents in California quietly arrested a Chinese citizen last week and charged him with trying to obtain a component vital to missile guidance systems. Officials said the arrest shed light on what many in Washington say is an effort by China to smuggle American technology to improve the accuracy of its weapons.

title: The Science of Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert to Help Devise Format For Delivering Music on Net
description: The recording industry, anxious for a way to move safely and profitably into the era of Internet delivery of music, has taken a major step by putting an influential digital architect in charge of the effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, FRANKLIN
description: NELSON-Franklin. 67. Passed away suddenly. Beloved son of the late Faye and Max, father of Ted (Arelis) and Julie, brother of Joel (Midge), uncle of Nicole (Bill) and Jennifer. Also survived by loving companion Rosemary Provenzano and former wife Eileen. May he rest in peace. Services Wednesday, February 24, 1999, 11am at Gutterman's, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Let Good Owners and Good Dogs Patrol the Parks; Hounded in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ugly Truth about Hate
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Field of Options, All Younger and Cheaper
description: The primary field here is filled every day with Yankees stars, Derek Jeter and Bernie Williams and Paul O'Neill and Roger Clemens. But Manager Joe Torre likes to slip away at least once a day to Field No. 2, to spy on the organization's top prospects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, IRA, M.D.
description: MINTZ-Ira, M.D. The Officers and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the death of their esteemed member and colleague, Ira Mintz. A ground-breaking pioneer in the field of psychosomatic medicine, he authored numerous original papers and co-edited three outstanding books including what has become a classic work on anorexia nervosa and bulimia. His brilliant scholarship and patient understanding will be deeply missed. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nancy, his children, Karen, Susan and Robert, and his grandchildren. Daniel Papernik, M.D., President Arthur Lew, M.D., Secretary

title: RUTGERS 79, MIAMI 53
description: Rutgers was up by 24 points late in the second half last night when the sophomore Linda Miles tried to play to the crowd a little bit too much, passing up an easy layup and throwing away an ill-advised pass on a fast break. On a stoppage in play seconds later, Miles knew that her stay in the game was over, and when a teammate handed her a towel as she came into the game for her, Miles hid her face in it, then tried to rush to her seat on the bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, DR. WILLIAM
description: ETKIN-Dr. William. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of our renowned Professor Emeritus of Anatomy and Structural Biology, who joined the founding faculty of our medical school in 1955 and served with great distinction as a teacher and researcher for more than forty years. His contributions to our institution, and to the advancement of anatomy and zoology, will be long remembered. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean

title: Restaurants Split on Seizing Drinkers' Cars
description: A few days ago, Marc Sherry, co-owner of the Old Homestead restaurant in Chelsea, overheard a comment that sent a chill down his spine. After perusing the menu, he said, one customer told another, ''Maybe we shouldn't have that bottle of wine due to that Giuliani thing.''

title: The Leaven of Malice Among American Intellectuals
description: Norman Podhoretz is not one of my ex-friends. Over the years, in many wide-ranging conversations, we have not had any stormy arguments. Though I have written for Commentary, which he edited for 35 years, I never pulled a piece from the magazine in outrage. I have never attacked him in print or conversation. We have never wrestled over issues involving anti-Communism, anti-anti-Communism or anti-anti-anti- Communism. We don't avoid each other at parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALESI, PETER
description: ALESI-Peter. Of Manhasset, New York. On February 26. Beloved husband of Caroline (nee Quadrino) and brother of William. Devoted uncle of nine nieces and nephews. Visitation March 1 at Fairchild's Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset, Tuesday at 10:45. Interment Saint John's Cemetery. Contributions may be made to Hospice, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Behind Olivetti's Move: Cellular Explosion
description: As any traveler here knows, the tribe of Italians who do not walk around with a cell phone hanging from one ear is quickly facing extinction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HEPNER, RITA
description: COHEN-HEPNER-Rita. 74, on Friday, February 26. Wife of Morton Hepner and the late Irving Cohen. Survived by her daughters Barbara Weingarten of Hartsdale, NY, Gail Tupper of New York City, her grandchildren Marisa and Alison Weingarten and Jordan and Dustin Tupper, her brother Arthur Katz and brother-in-law Greg Kayne. Services were held on Sunday, February 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBUS, ANDRE
description: DUBUS-Andre. Rest in peace. Comfort to your family. Bunny Dell, Ardent Fan

title: Phelan Nears His 800th As Mountaineers Win
description: Mount St. Mary's advanced to the final of the Northeast Conference tournament by edging St. Francis of Brooklyn, 68-66, in a semifinal last night at the Spiros Sports Center at Wagner College.

title: Once Promising Nets Have Fizzled Into Duds
description: Just three weeks ago, the Nets were being touted as one of the best teams in the National Basketball Association. Fueled by young talent and an up-tempo offense, they were hailed as a potential conference champion, the new hoop darlings of the metropolitan area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRACH, JOYCE
description: AVRACH-Joyce, age 73, died peacefully on February 20, 1999. Beloved widow of David, she is survived by her brother, Buddy Sertner, three children Linda, Robert and Donna and her five grandchildren, Pamela, Andrea, Matthew, David and Jamie. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Let Good Owners and Good Dogs Patrol the Parks; Overstating Their Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, DR. ISRAEL A.
description: SCHILLER-Dr. Israel A. of N. Branford, CT. Beloved husband of the late Anne; devoted father of Daniel and Paula, Joel and Helen; loving grandfather of Johanna, Jennifer, Harry, Cordelia. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday 12 noon. (1-800-378-1892)

title: INSIDE
description: Chinese Citizen Arrested By U.S. in Arms Smuggling

title: Nigeria's Presidential Election
description: Olusegun Obasanjo, a former general, will be the next president of Nigeria, according to preliminary election results. His selection reflects the complexities of power in Nigeria today. When the country's current leader, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, took over last June, he promised a transition to civilian rule after 15 years of disaster under general after general. Mr. Abubakar has kept his promise. But the transition is incomplete. Military officers, who largely bankrolled Mr. Obasanjo's candidacy, will continue to loom over his government. Mr. Obasanjo will have to break with them to have any success in improving life in Africa's most populous nation.

title: Patents; Two men have developed a magnetic videotape that records both analog and digital signals.
description: WHEN confronted with the advent of the digital, high-definition television age, many people often immediately want to know whether they will still be able to watch their collections of videotapes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ROBERT, JR.
description: CAMPBELL-Robert, Jr. The Officers and Board of Managers of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of NY express their deep sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member and former President. Our profound sympathy to his entire family. Sean Stewart Macpherson, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUALA, ROBIN E.
description: MAUALA-Robin E. G. Passed away on February 21. Beloved wife of Nusi and cherished mother of Mele. Her vivacious character, endless enthusiasm, and generous nature will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service will be held at the U.N. Chapel, February 26th beginning at 5:30PM. The family respectly requests that in lieu of flowers a donation be made in her name to the American Humane Society or any organization that supports wildlife or animal causes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIG, ALAN
description: ZEIG-Alan. Beloved husband of Marge. Devoted father of Tammy. Cherished son of the late Morris and Fanny. Dear brother of the late Lillian Mahler. Beloved nephew of Martha Silver, Sonia Rosenberg and the late Rebecca Greenberg. Dear uncle of Marilyn Konoson, Charlotte Wachsman and Howard Mahler. Services today, 12 Noon, ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: New Infield Duo Gets Started
description: Second baseman Edgardo Alfonzo and shortstop Rey Ordonez of the Mets worked on turning double plays for about 20 minutes today in the first intensive session for the new combination. Alfonzo is switching from third base to second base this season and is reuniting with Ordonez, who was his double-play partner at Class AA Binghamton in 1994. ''We're only four days into spring training,'' Alfonzo said. ''We have a long time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, MICHAEL J.
description: CUNNINGHAM-Michael J. Born February 23, 1919, in New York City and passed on February 26, 1999. He was a highly decorated WWII veteran whose patriotism spanned his lifetime. A winner of Major Bowes Amateur Hour at the age of 17 (radio's equivalent to Ed Sullivan), Mr. Cunningham excelled as a vocalist, corporate president, lawyer and became notable in 1973 as a veterans' advocate with the proposal to the city that veterans and elderly needed homes with dignity. His proposal to the City of New York singlehandedly gave the City its solution in the highly controversial Forest Hills Housing Project on 108th St in Queens. He was shortly thereafter appointed as an administrative law judge with the City's Consumer Affairs Agency. Michael Cunningham is survived by his wife of 57 years Virginia, daughters Constance, Virginia and Catherine, son Paul and grandchildren Patrick, Mary, Eleanor, Matthew, Kaitlin and Alexander. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Forest Hills, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Tuesday, March 2, 9:15 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Victims of Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: Inept Getaway From Fight Leaves Man Badly Hurt
description: A dispute on the dance floor of a Queens nightclub early yesterday led to a shooting, a carjacking and what law enforcement officials said could only be described as one of the more inept getaways in recent history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORN, LUCILLE
description: OSBORN-Lucille. The Administration and Staff of Long Island College Hospital mourn the passing of Lucille Osborn, beloved sister of our friend and colleague, Harold Osborn, M.D., Chairman of the Department of Emergency Medicine. To Harold, the entire Osborn family, and all of Ms. Osborn's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Wren, Chairman of the Board of Regents Peter Kelly, Interim President Daniel D. Ricciardi, M.D., President, Medical Staff

title: Death Taboo Weakening, Japan Sees 1st Transplant
description: For the first time in Japan, doctors performed a legal heart transplant today, striking at a taboo on taking organs from patients whom Japanese traditionally do not consider dead.

title: Essay; Taxpayers: Revolt!
description: A half-century ago, government at all levels controlled a fourth of our economy. Today it's up to a third; this is the wrong direction.

title: WHITMAN DISMISSES STATE POLICE CHIEF FOR RACE REMARKS
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ousted Col. Carl A. Williams as Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police yesterday after a published report quoted him as saying it was naive to think that race was not an issue in drug crimes and that cocaine and marijuana traffickers were most likely to be members of minority groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELION, GERTRUDE B.
description: ELION-Gertrude B. The Hunter College Foundation mourns the passing of Gertrude Elion, a Nobel Prize winner in Medicine whom Hunter College also knew as a loyal alumna. A longtime trustee of The Hunter College Foundation, she supported her alma mater throughout her long and productive life and served as a role model to generations of Hunter students-especially women-who aspired to a career in science. She was instrumental in the development of a host of drugs to combat some of the most virulent diseases known, and she was active in the professional community: she was president of the American Association for Cancer Research, a member of the National Cancer Advisory Board, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences, among others. Though officially retired for a number of years, she continued to teach and conduct research. She received more than 25 honorary doctorates, including one from Hunter College, which will always remember her for both her scientific accomplishments and her generosity to her College. Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair Floria V. Lasky, Co-Chair The Hunter College Foundation

title: Sports of The Times; After a Week Full of Upsets, Maggert Chips In for the Ranking
description: IT won't endure in golf history like Gene Sarazen's double-eagle at the 1935 Masters or Tom Watson's chip-in at the 1982 United States Open, but Jeff Maggert's winning chip-in on the 38th hole yesterday at least made the Andersen Consulting Match Play Championship memorable for more than its $1 million jackpot. Even Andrew Magee thought so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur. On February 24, 1999. Loving son of Pauline and Jacob. Devoted brother of Morty, Moey, Goldie, Sylvia and Mimi. Loving uncle. Graveside service Sunday 11am at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMS, GERHARD
description: HARMS-Gerhard. Montefiore Medical Center and its Board of Trustees are deeply saddened by the death of Gerhard Harms, 92, a respected friend and benefactor of the medical center. Through his support of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, he leaves a legacy to children and their families that will live for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear friends, Lee and Vincent Affinito. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Getting Along in Congress
description: Congress has long had a famously unhealthy tendency toward coziness. Senators and representatives assail each other in public, but voters wonder whether they then retire to their racquetball courts, watering holes and dinner parties to make mutually beneficial deals, especially when it comes to rules on ethics and gifts. But today the clubby old atmosphere of Congress is looked on with something approaching nostalgia. The public seems more worried these days by its culture of partisanship, pettiness, revenge and the resulting paralysis. Some lawmakers have begun talking like apostles for a new 12-step program to restore healing and civility.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON the Friday before Valentine's Day, Ricardo Aguero walked into the Madison Avenue Bookshop and picked up ''Here Is My Heart,'' a book of poetry, as a gift for his wife, Lynn Hackstaff. When she joined him for a late lunch, she, too, handed him a gift, nicely wrapped, obviously a book. A researcher at a surgical clinic, she had gone to the bookstore between patients that day and bought the same volume for him. The couple, who met in an on-line chat room, had been married for only five months and both were surprised, and pleased, that they knew each other's tastes so well. Should they return one of the books? If so, which one? The result: the twin volumes are cozily nudging each other on the bookshelf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROSTEN, ANNE BELKIN
description: TROSTEN-Anne Belkin, who died February 27, 1999, in Chatham, NY, was born in Torrington, CT, in 1901. She graduated in 1922 from the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital School of Nursing. Mrs. Trosten is the widow of the late David Trosten of Brooklyn, NY. She is survived by her sons, William Trosten of Manhattan and Chatham, NY, and Leonard Trosten of Savannah, GA; two granddaughters, Amanda Trosten-Bloom of Golden, CO, and Jessica Forrest of Media, PA; and two great-granddaughters, Hannah Joy Bloom of Golden, CO, and Kirstie Forrest of Media, PA; two sisters, Florence Smith of Nashua, NH, and Frances Morse of Philadelphia, PA; and several nieces, nephews and other family members. Mrs. Trosten has long supported the work of Hadassah Medical Relief Association, Manhattan Beach Chapter, and memorial contributions may be sent to that organization.

title: Continents Apart, Williams Sisters Make History
description: Venus and Serena Williams became prodigies and then top-25 players together, traveling and playing as part of a family campaign that kept its distance from the tennis establishment. But the sisters had to travel almost 5,000 miles apart to make history.

title: Building on Borrowed Cachet; Cathleen Black Shakes Up the Culture at Hearst Magazines
description: It was the closest you could get to a debutante party in the mud-slinging, ego-bruising, advertising-hungry world of magazine publishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARMAK, ETHEL
description: JARMAK-Ethel. Age 86, West Palm Beach, died February 26, 1999. Formerly of White Plains. Pre-deceased by her husband Jack in 1991. Beloved mother of Michele and Alison (Mrs. Richard Reider). Services 2 PM, Monday, March 1, 1999, Palm Beach Memorial Park, Boynton Beach. In lieu of flowers, Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Amid Political Interference, The Euro Has Yet to Foster A Unified Monetary Policy : Initial Luster Of New Money Begins to Fade For Europe
description: Two months after its rollout into the market, the euro is well into the process of becoming a no-longer-new-currency. The long haul is setting in.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZARKIN, RUTH
description: ZARKIN-Ruth. Age 85, of Tamarac, FL. Passed away February 28, 1999, at her residence. She is survived by her husband Philip and her sons, daughter-in-law and grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Tuesday at 1:30 at the Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. For information contact Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC, 212-362-6600.

title: The Whitney Goes Outside For Curators Of Biennial
description: For the first time in its 68-year history, the Whitney Museum of American Art will be producing its mammoth Biennial with a team of outside curators, representing different regions of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNES, BENEDICT
description: MAGNES-Benedict, 84. Of White Plains, N.Y. died Friday, February 12th, 1999. He is survived by his loving family; his wife Frances, his sons Jeff and Carol Magnes, Joel and Candice Magnes, also three grandchildren John, Andy & Jason Magnes. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 25, 1999 at 2PM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

description: BAUMGART-Seraphina Stella. On February 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Robert P. Loving mother of Beth Gralnick and Richard Baumgart. Grandmother of Bob, Kate and Sarah. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, 10:00 AM at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. Interment is private. Memorial donations to the Baumgart Scholarship Fund, care of Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY 10538. For further information call John J. Fox Funeral Home 914-834-0144

title: Taking Center Stage, Nedved Stars in Thriller
description: The Rangers were in need of a stand-in, someone capable of being great until the Great One's neck mends.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYE, ROBERT DOUGLAS
description: KAYE-Robert Douglas. It's been three years, and we still love you and miss you. Mom, Dad and Andy

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the At the Movies column of Weekend on Feb. 5 referred incorrectly to the film career of Schuyler Fisk, the 16-year-old daughter of the actress Sissy Spacek. Ms. Fisk's first credited film role was in ''Hard Promises'' in 1992; the film she is about to make in Canada will not be her first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CURTIS
description: CARLSON-Curtis. The Board and staff of the Children's Museum of Manhattan mourn the passing of Curtis Carlson, grandfather of the Museum's Vice Chairman, Diana Nelson, and father of our wonderful friend, Marilyn Nelson. His devotion to family and community is evident in the work of his entire family and a tribute to his lifetime of accomplishment. We express our deepest condolences to the entire family. Judith Hannan, Chairman Andrew Ackerman, Exec Director

title: Lord Eccles, 94, Dies; Tories' 'Smarty Boots'
description: Viscount Eccles, a bookish British businessman turned Conservative politician who served in the Cabinets of four Prime Ministers without quite breaking through to the top ranks he had seemed destined for, died on Wednesday. He was 94 and had ended his public career as head of the independent British Library he had helped create.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MARTIN
description: ROSS-Martin. Died Saturday, February 20. Husband of the late Ida (nee Rifkin). Survived by daughter and son-in-law Margot and Allen London of Manhattan. Grandsons Benjamin and Zachary. Funeral was held Monday, Scranton, Pa.

title: Huskies Speed Ahead
description: When the Connecticut women's basketball team is playing its racehorse best, with an intimidating fullcourt press that leads to steals and fast breaks, it is close to unbeatable. But that explosiveness is not a push-button thing, although Shea Ralph stoked enough full- ignition spurts yesterday to let the Huskies ease by a pesky St. John's, 82-58, in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament at Piscataway, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERELSON, PAUL
description: PERELSON-Paul. Passed away peacefully on February 21, 1999, his 98th birthday would have been on April 18. Devoted husband for 61 years of the late Hannah (Nee Michaelson.) Beloved father of Samuel (Ruth) and Helen (Julian) Levine; adoring grandfather of Lois Perelson (Stewart) Gross and Lila (Keith) Adwar; loving greatgrandfather of Hannah, Sarah Alice, Benjamin Perelson Gross and Mikaela Adwar. Also survived by sisters Gerry Pulaski and Blanche Klores of Miami, Fl. and brother Morris Perelson of Queens. Private graveside service held on February 22. Shiva observed at the Levine home, 303 West 66 Street, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106 Street, NYC 10025

title: German Leader Is Popular, but Grip Seems Unsure
description: There he was last week, the German Chancellor, no less, on a television talk show being asked if he would submit to a test that would determine if the color of his abundant dark brown hair was real. Yes, Gerhard Schroder said with a coy grin, ''This is all genuine, really everything.''

title: Pinter's Dark Side Peeks Through His Comedy
description: What's with the boss? He can't get through two sentences without contradicting himself. He sees murder and insurrection in the blandest faces of his subordinates. And all those fancy words and phrases he keeps piling on with such assurance, wallowing in the sound of his voice: do you think he has any idea what they mean?

title: University to Be Home for Anti-Apartheid Group's Archives
description: The archives of the African National Congress, which were buried in backyards and otherwise hidden in three dozen countries during the party's underground struggle against apartheid, will be collected and opened to the public here and in South Africa under an agreement to be signed Monday.

title: New York, New York, It's Henderson's Town
description: Rickey Henderson has had disagreements with George Steinbrenner, he has delighted the fickle fans in left field at Yankee Stadium as a Yankee, even as an opponent, and he has been mired in traffic on the George Washington Bridge. Henderson knows New York. New York knows him. It is a marriage that worked well with the Yankees over a decade ago and should work splendidly with the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABAK, GERTRUDE
description: KABAK-Gertrude (nee Katowitz). Of Edison, New Jersey, formerly of Bronx, New York. Wife of Dr. Irwin Kabak. Mother of Michele Weisman, Cindy Weissman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, MARJORIE C.
description: MARKS-Marjorie C. Of Wellesley, MA, formerly of Brooklyn, on February 27. Beloved wife of Allen Carney. Loving mother of Jacob and Caitlin Carney, both of Wellesley. Adored daughter of Ruth (Gurlitz) and Stanley Marks of Brooklyn. Dear sister of Dr. Andrea Marks of New York. Services at Temple Beth Elohim, 10 Bethel Road, Wellesley, MA, on Monday, March 1, at 10 AM. Graveside services at the Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY, on Tuesday, March 2, at 11 AM. Remembrances may be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney Street, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Helping Guatemala Find the Truth
description: Along with a certain degree of shame, the United States can take pride in the report released last week by the Historical Clarification Commission of Guatemala, which investigated the civil violence that racked that country for more than four decades.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Early Losses Raising Doubts in a Short Season; Knicks Limit Hill, But Their Emotion Is Missing on the Road
description: During Detroit Pistons games, the technicians in the rafters of the Palace like to shine a spotlight on the energetic creatures who are acting the craziest in the stands. And everyone in the place looks at the attention-getting guys jumping up and down, and everyone responds with an emotional roar.

title: 10 Perfect Minutes Lift Huskies
description: The Connecticut Huskies waited for the last hours of February to reassert themselves as contenders in the coming National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, and the result was a perfect 10. In the 10 minutes that opened the second half, the Huskies shot 10 of 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, F. EDWARD JR.
description: SPENCER-F. Edward Jr. 96, of Bethlehem, CT, on February 20, 1999 in Bethlehem, CT. Former Bronxville, NY resident. Beloved husband of the late Jane Emily Graham Spencer. Father of Graham and Lucile. Father-in-law of Diane. Brother of William. Grandfather of three. Great grandfather of four. Services February 25, 11:00 AM at the First Church of Bethlehem, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the Old Bethlem Historic Society in care of Carol Ann Brown, Flanders Rd., Bethlehem, CT 06751

title: A New Offensive in Britain's War of Words
description: Are interviewers on British television and radio programs too rude? Are British newspapers too obsessed with trivia? Are reporters irresponsible scandal-mongers who overlook important policy questions?

title: Who Needs A Name? Maggert's Got a Wedge
description: It ended the way a million-dollar match should end, not with a blunder, but with a birdie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERO, ADOLPH
description: SPERO-Adolph. On February 13, 1999, age 98. Husband of the late Frances (nee Postman). He is survived by his son Richard. After many years as a merchant he turned to executive recruitment. A private service has been held.

title: Soldiers of the Drug War Remain on Duty
description: Late on a chilly October night three years ago, Larry Harper told his family that life was no longer worth living and headed out the door with a handgun. He had slipped back to using crack cocaine after being in drug treatment and was ashamed to face his wife and brother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILCHRIST, HEATHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FYBISH, PEGGY ROMANO
description: FYBISH-Peggy Romano. On January 26, 1999, at her Manhattan home. Dearly loved wife and companion since 1971 of Stephen Fybish. Beloved mother of Emily Prager and Nora Elcar, loving grandmother of Lulu Prager. In her chief career as actress Peggy Romano, she combined outward beauty and grace of movement with a voice ranging in tone from gently poetic to powerfully expressive. Born on September 19, 1929, Peggy was first onstage at age five with her British-born actor father, Charles Romano, in ''The Great Waltz'' and with her actress mother, Mary Ricard, in ''The Old Maid''. As a child, she enjoyed the company of such family friends as Leslie Howard, Ruth Gordon, Noel Coward, the Lunts, Basil Rathbone, Judith Anderson and Margalo Gillmore. Her favorite playwrights and producers were Moss Hart, George Kaufman, and Max Gordon. A teenage star in both ''Junior Miss'' and ''Dear Ruth'', she went from Broadway to California with the national touring companies of these plays, performing in theatres in all 48 states during the 1940's. Married and a mother at age 18, she maintained her stage career less intensively through the 1960's. Peggy's brilliant, inquiring mind, keen sense of humor, and numerous talents were a rare combination. She was a painter of colorful landscapes, flowers and portraits, author of two novels, gifted costume designer, cartoonist, puppeteer and dancer. Her letters, diaries, and tape recordings delightfully conveyed her almost photographic memories of her favorite people, places and events, such as the 1991 solar eclipse at Oaxaca, Mexico, described at her memorial service on January 29, 1999. She cared passionately about her family, her country, and the survival of the earth's endangered animals, native cultures and natural habitats. Her knowledge of archaelogy and history enriched her travels to Europe, Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean Isles. In the 1990's, her summer vacations with her husband, Steve, by the tropical seashore of Isla Mujeres, gave her great pleasure. She listened joyously to birdsongs from the trees of Mexico and Manhattan, and the ballet music of Prokofiev's ''Cinderella''. The inspiration she gave to the lives and accomplishments of her two daughters, grandchild, Lulu, and her three husbands-Arthur Prager, Dana Elcar and Stephen Fybish-will always be remembered and cherished.

title: AMERICAN LETTERS; Questions of Character: There's No Ego as Wounded as a Wounded Alter Ego
description: One -- not the only one -- of the spiritual burdens of being a New Yorker is an undue reverence for The New York Times; when a minion of that sacrosanct rag approached this above-signed ancient penman and asked him to interview, not for the first time, a writer a tad less ancient but inconveniently resident hundreds of miles up the Atlantic Seaboard, I could not find it in my heart to say no. John Updike was the name of my designated victim, on the slender but penetrating excuse that he had chosen to perpetrate, in his impudence and ignorance, a book ostensibly about me -- ''Bech at Bay,'' five tales full of fantastic details concerning the latter-day life of a Jewish-American prosist bearing my name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, DR. JOHN
description: DONNELLY-Dr. John. West Hartford, CT. Died on February 18, 1999. Born in 1914 and educated in England, he received his medical degree at the University of Liverpool Medical School in 1938. At the end of WWII he entered psychiatric training at the University of London and received his diploma of Psychological Medicine in 1948. In 1949 he joined the staff of The Institute of Living in Hartford and in 1965 was named Psychiatrist-inChief and Chief Executive Officer of the Institute. He retired in 1979, continuing at the Institute until 1984 as Senior Consultant. An eminent psychiatrist with a national and international reputation he was President of the Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry and of the National Association of Private Psychiatric Hospitals. He is survived by his wife, Mabel C. Donnelly, and by his children, Mavis J. Donnelly, M.D. and James M. Donnelly, M.D. and three grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CURTIS L.
description: CARLSON-Curtis L. Minnesota entrepreneur. Founder of Carlson Companies. Mr. Carlson died Friday, February 19, after suffering a stroke on February 10. He was 84. He retained and enjoyed an active role as company chairman until his last day. Born July 9, 1914, in Minneapolis, Mr. Carlson was recognized for his generosity, integrity and entrepreneurial spirit. Known worldwide as the ''ultra-entrepreneur'', he founded the Gold Bond Stamp Company in 1938 with a $55 loan and a desire to succeed. After World War II, the business grew dramatically. Two-thirds of American households saved stamps, and Gold Bond captured about one-third of the market. Mr. Carlson's ''Horatio Alger'' qualities were key to the continued expansion of his business, which has become one of the largest privatelyheld companies in the world. To reflect its global expansion and diversification, the corporation became Carlson Companies, Inc., in 1973. Today, Carlson Companies is an international leader in providing hospitality, travel and marketing services and solutions to corporate clients and consumers. The company operates in more than 140 countries. Its brands employ 160,000 people worldwide and generated more than $22 billion in systemwide revenues in 1998. Carlson Companies brands and services include Regent International Hotels, Radisson Hotels Worldwide, Country Inns & Suites By Carlson, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, T.G.I. Friday's restaurants, Carlson Leisure Group (leisure travel) and Carlson Marketing Group, the largest relationship marketing company in the world. In 1997, Mr. Carlson was instrumental in establishing a global partnership with Accor of Paris, which combined the business travel interests of both companies under the name Carlson Wagonlit Travel. A 1938 graduate of the University of Minnesota, Mr. Carlson was a staunch supporter of his alma mater. In 1986, he made a $25 million gift to the university, at that time the largest single gift ever given to a public university. To recognize his contributions, the university renamed its school of management the Curtis L. Carlson School of Management. He and Arleen (Martin) met at the university and were married in 1938. Together, the couple was devoted to strengthening family bonds with their children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Carlson's honors include the prestigious Linnean Medal, Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, presented by H.M. Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden; the Viking Baron Award from the American Swedish Cultural Foundation; the Horatio Alger Award; the Swedish-American of the Year Award, Stockholm, Sweden, in 1981; the Town and Country magazine ''Philanthropist of the Year'' Award, 1987-1988; the International Citizen of the Year

description: A picture caption yesterday about a woman sentenced to prison on charges related to crack cocaine sales misspelled her surname in some copies. She is Monica Boguille.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, WAYNE, FAIA
description: BERG-Wayne, FAIA. An enormous talent, a colleague of exquisite professionalism and a dear friend. He joined us in 1987 as design principal and has been an inestimable force in our lives and work. His achievement as an architect is reflected in his many important design awards, the extent of his published work, his election to 40 Under 40 and Emerging Voices, and his wide ranging service to the profession. His absence will leave a hole in our hearts and our world that will be impossible to fill. We extend our sympathy to his wife Ann, his son Alex, and his family. Arvid Klein Henry Stolzman And the staff of Pasanella + Klein Stolzman + Berg, Architects, PC

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the Microsoft antitrust trial referred incorrectly to testimony by Robert Muglia, a company executive who described a conversation with William H. Gates about a license for the Java programming language that Microsoft had received from Sun Microsystems. In that conversation, according to the testimony, it was Mr. Muglia -- not Mr. Gates -- who said that Microsoft could meet its licensing obligation by posting Sun's version of Java on Microsoft's Web site rather than including it in Microsoft's Windows software.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRABKIN, STEVEN WAYNE
description: DRABKIN-Steven Wayne. 10/19/61-2/23/81. Time will never dim his memory. He lives in the hearts of those he left behind. Loving Family

title: Thousands Flee to Kosovo Border to Escape Army's Surge
description: More than two thousand people fled villages during heavy fighting in southern Kosovo today and swamped a major border post in a desperate effort to cross to safety in neighboring Macedonia.

title: Let Good Owners and Good Dogs Patrol the Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Does the Microsoft Trial Verdict Really Matter?
description: There have been at least a dozen trials of the century in the past 100 years, many of them soon forgotten. But the Microsoft trial now nearing an end deserves that label for the light it sheds on where the real power lies as the 20th century ends.

title: Let Good Owners and Good Dogs Patrol the Parks; Dog Runs Can Be Noisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Raises $75,000 At Appearance in Florida
description: In a brief but lucrative visit, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised about $75,000 for his political action committee at a fund-raising luncheon here today, then called for more school choice programs in a speech to a Jewish group.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

description: GOOZMAN-Clara. Wife of the late Max. Died Saturday, February 27. She was beloved by four children, five grandchildren, three greatgrandchildren and a sister. Burial is today at Star of David in Broward County, Florida.

description: WYATT-Patricia A. A Memorial Service for Patricia A. Wyatt, who died on February 15, 1999, will be held on Saturday, March 13, at 2PM, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to a charity of your choice.

title: 10,000 Welfare Recipients Hired by Federal Agencies
description: Federal agencies have hired more than 10,000 former welfare recipients in the last two years, meeting a goal set by the White House 19 months ahead of schedule, Administration officials said today.

description: SLINGLUFF-Charles H., Jr. of Rumson, NJ on February 21, 1999. Husband of Gail Grant Slingluff. Father of Charles H. Slingluff, III, Melissa S. Morley and Jennifer S. Robinson. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be sent to Slingluff Cancer Research, P.O. Box 10005, University of Virginia Medical Center, Charlottesville, VA 22908.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Charles M. Beeghly, 90, Ex-Steel Executive
description: Charles M. Beeghly, a steel executive who began his career as a salesman and rose to be chairman and chief executive of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, died on Feb. 18 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Johnson Lands With the Dodgers, Managing Some Very High-Priced Talent
description: He's back, after yet another year of involuntary leave. Well, officially he resigned from his job with the Baltimore Orioles, but Davey Johnson opted for that path rather than wait to be fired, which would inevitably have happened.

title: Rava-Ruska Journal; The Border Is So Near, the Smuggling So Easy
description: When Andrei needs a few things from the market and he always needs a few things from the market -- he does what a lot of people around here do: he climbs into the car and drives to Poland.

title: Compressed Data; Linux.com Doesn't Go To the Highest Bidder
description: When Fred Van Kempen registered the linux.com Internet domain in June 1994, nobody but a handful of programmers around the world had heard of Linux -- the precocious software operating system, written by a graduate student named Linus Torvalds and released free on the Internet.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAST, JERRY
description: LAST-Jerry. Survived by his wife, Terry and three children David, Linda, and Robert. We will all miss him.

description: BAYER-Berta A. 83. On February 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman S. Loving and devoted mother of Les of East Meadow and Arlyne of Manhattan. Services 12 noon Wednesday from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, (76th Road) Forest Hills, NY

title: Fibers and Spider Webs but No Answers in Boulder
description: PERFECT MURDER, PERFECT TOWN

title: In Book, Unabomber Pleads His Case
description: From prison, Theodore J. Kaczynski, who pleaded guilty to the Unabom killings, has a message for his brother, who turned him in to the Government.

title: For Schumer, a Shift In Style as a Senator; Former Congressman Is Broadening His Approach as He Settles In
description: Charles E. Schumer says his personal life has not changed that much since he became New York's junior Senator. He still buys suits at a discount clothier, stays at budget hotels and urges people to call him Chuck.

title: Many in Fractious G.O.P. Find a Point to Agree On: Bush in 2000
description: The Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, an uncompromising conservative who heads a national group called the Traditional Values Coalition, has built his career on denouncing homosexuals. But Mr. Sheldon may back a prospect for the Republican Presidential nomination whose oratory on the subject has been decidedly tame: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Researching the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: As Albright Arrives in China, Congress Is Watching Closely
description: Every time a Secretary of State comes to China, Congress watches closely. And perhaps no more so than on a brief visit this week by Madeleine K. Albright, who arrived here this evening.

title: A Preacher's Faithful Back Both Sinner and Felon
description: The minister who had preached to Hillary Clinton, who had been courted by politicians and corporate leaders eager to tap his influence in black communities nationwide, now awaits his sentencing for convictions on racketeering and grand theft charges. Yet even as a bailiff pressed the Rev. Henry J. Lyons's ink-stained fingertips on a white card, supporters inside and outside the Florida courthouse prayed, cried, sang and swore support for the man they saw as a persecuted prophet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, ALICE Z. (NEE ZACK)
description: BANKS-Alice Z. (nee Zack). Of Brookline, MA, on Saturday, February 27, at 92 years old. Beloved wife of Dr. Benjamin M. Banks, they were perfect partners for 70 years. Devoted mother of Joanne and Norman Matthews, and Dr. Peter and Naomi Banks. Grandma Alice to Gary and Lisa Matthews, Dr. Jeffrey and Dr. Joan Matthews, Pam and Seth Farber, Daniel Banks and Deborah Banks. Adoring great-grandmother to Craig, Scott, Jake, Jonathan, David, Adam, Allison, Andrew, Michael and Matthew. Services at Temple Israel, Brookline MA, Monday, March 1. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Boston Museum of Fine Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADIEROS, RONALD RICHARD
description: MADIEROS - Ronald Richard. Born Jamestown, R.I. July 14, 1937. Died Manhattan, Feb.14, 1999. Studied music at the Boston Berkely Conservatory. A poet, musician and dear friend of Joyce Lechner and Robert Rambusch. Loving brother of Mary Anne Stalter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, RITA
description: TRACHTENBERG-Rita. Beloved wife of Leo Trachtenberg, cherished mother of Daniel Trachtenberg, revered mother-in-law of Cari Pokrassa, loving grandmother of Allie Trachtenberg, died February 19, 1999. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, Ceremonial Hall, 4th Floor on Friday, February 26 at 12 noon.

title: David H. Smith, 67, Developer Of Vaccine Against Meningitis
description: David H. Smith, a researcher and entrepreneur who helped figure out a way to coax even the immature immune system of an infant into mounting a defense against a bacterium that causes meningitis, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 67 and also lived on Martha's Vineyard and in Rochester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KULICK, JOYCE
description: KULICK-Joyce. The Board of Governors and Members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member on Saturday, February 20, 1999. She will be missed. Services were held February 22, 1999 at Forest Lawn Cemetery, Pompano Beach, FL. Melvin Michaelson, President

title: New Data Pipeline Holds Promise of a Better Internet
description: The promise of a super-fast, highly reliable Internet moved a step closer to reality last week when three dozen universities across the United States were linked to a new national research network that moves data 1,600 times faster than the T-1 lines that universities and businesses use today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, SYLVIA
description: TRACHTENBERG-Sylvia. Of Delray Beach, FL. Passed away on February 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Judy (Michael) Leinwand, Jane (Gene) Toscani, Marilyn (Peter) Zutty, Robert (Margaret) Bernstein and David (Mary Beth) Trachtenberg. Cherished grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of one. Dear sister of Richard Simon. Services Wednesday, February 24, 1999, Gutterman - Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, Florida. Phone (1-800-992-9262).

title: Journalism's Greatest Hits: Two Lists of a Century's Top Stories
description: Sometime, somewhere, some anthropologist must have explored that tribal ritual: the greatest-hits list. These lists date back at least to the seven wonders of the ancient world. They reflect the importance of some area of tribal endeavor -- monumental architecture, say, or rock-and-roll. And they establish hierarchies; how better to show your pre-eminence in the pecking order than to rank everyone else?

title: 2 Are Sickened By Mixing Drug With Liquor
description: Two women were hospitalized Saturday night after they drank a combination of alcohol and a muscle enhancer at a party on the Upper West Side, the police said yesterday.

title: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Kazan's Oscar Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Fitzgerald Regains Aruba Account
description: The Aruba Tourism Authority, in an unusual reversal of the outcome of a review, has decided to return its account to Fitzgerald & Company in Atlanta after dismissing the agency two weeks ago to hire the Martin Agency in Richmond.

title: Op-Art; More New York City ''Get Tough'' Policies
Jagge Wins Second Race
description: Finn-Christian Jagge won his second World Cup slalom race of the season in Ofterschwang, Germany, yesterday, while a fellow Norwegian, Kjetil Andre Aamodt, moved above Hermann Maier into first place in the overall World Cup standing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESMOND, TRUDY
description: DESMOND-Trudy. Peacefully at Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, February 19, singer Trudy Desmond, loving sister of Ellen and Jeffrey, beloved daughter of Ethel and the late Raphael Salwen. She will be dearly missed by all those who experienced the joy of knowing her personally and professionally. Shiva will be at Trudy's home between Tuesday, February 23 and Friday, February 26 at 174 Dewbourne Ave, Toronto. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 28, for time and place call 416-466-5020

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNE, DOROTHY VILAS
description: TOWNE-Dorothy Vilas. Greensboro, NC, formerly of New York City. On February 22. Widow of John D. C. Towne, Jr. Mother of Diana Towne Knox and Daphne Towne Witsell. Grandmother of five and great-grandmother of ten. Private memorial service in July in the Adirondacks.

title: As U.S. Buyers Age, Designers of Autos Make Subtle Shifts
description: Engineers at the Lear Corporation, the world's largest independent supplier of automotive interiors, labored for months last year to come up with a vehicle that would meet all the needs of older Americans. The seats swivel out for easy access, the dashboard controls and displays are unusually large and the trunk floor partly rolls out at the back for easy loading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, EVAN WELLING II
description: THOMAS-Evan Welling II. Died in Hilton Head, SC. He was 78. He is survived by his wife Anne D.R. Thomas of Hilton Head, SC, his sisters Polly Miller of Cheshire, CT, and Frances Gates of Huntington, NY, his children Wendy Zara of Sheldon, SC, Louisa Hargrave of Cutchogue, NY, Evan W. Thomas III of Washington, DC, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions should be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, LI Chapter, PO Box 11365, Hauppauge, NY 11788 or the South Carolina Environmental Law Project, PO Box 279, Pawley's Island, SC 29585.

title: Omnipoint May Eliminate Roaming Fees
description: Following in the footsteps of communications giants, the Omnipoint Corporation, a small wireless phone carrier that operates mainly in the Northeast, is expected to announce new calling plans today that eliminate long-distance and ''roaming'' charges, according to executives close to the company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Two Alliances Seek New Routes to Internet

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLY, CARL J.
description: ALLY-Carl J. A memorial service will be held at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street on Thursday, February 25th at 3PM. A gathering of his friends and family will follow at the Wings Club, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, NYC.

title: Trinity Tops Harvard for Title
description: Trinity College of Hartford became the first Division III school to win the national collegiate team squash championship yesterday when it beat Harvard by 8-1 in Cambridge, Mass. Trinity's victory ended a five-year reign by Harvard, which had won 7 of the last 10 national team titles, and marked the first time in 32 years that a non-Ivy League school had captured the championship. JACK CAVANAUGH

title: State Will Transfer Control Of Armory on Park Avenue
description: In a major move to halt the deterioration of the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, the Pataki administration has decided to transfer control of the building and oversight over the cultural and art shows held there to a private company or a nonprofit organization.

title: A Surprise Victory Creates a Surprise Derby Contender
description: Desert Hero, a son of the 1993 Kentucky Derby winner Sea Hero, making only his second lifetime start, won today's $200,000 San Rafael Stakes at Santa Anita by a neck in an upset that surprised even his trainer, Wallace Dollase.

title: Senator's Efforts Threaten Wine Makers' Celebration
description: When the Federal Government said on Feb. 5 that wine makers could put educational labels on their bottles, there was rejoicing in the nation's vineyards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, BERNARD
description: RICHMAN-Bernard. Park East Synogogue mourns the passing of our devoted member and former Trustee Bernard Richman who with his beloved wife Sheila was a Founder of the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School. A caring man of integrity he was a loving father to his children, Hope and Jeffrey Halpert (members of Park East) and to Scott and Jane, Kenny and Gail. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PONS, EDUARDO R. JR.
description: PONS-Eduardo R. Jr., MD. Passed away on February 19, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of the late Carmen Bergnes. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, February 24, 8:30-10:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, February 24th at 11 A.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Media Talk; Web Publications Break Away From Print
description: What's the difference between reading a newspaper or magazine on the Internet or in print? The articles tend to be the same in both versions, and aside from saving a few dollars, the only real difference is that one can be read on the subway and the other cannot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELDOCH, HONEY
description: BELDOCH-Honey. Died peacefully in her ninety-sixth year. My best friend and mother-in-law for fiftysix years. The matriarch of the Hochfelder family. We will all miss this elegant, wise, strong, courageous, gracious lady. She will be especially missed by her loving and respectful son-in-law. Gene

title: As Rampart Field Dwindles, Banshee Breeze Rolls
description: The Rampart Handicap fell apart as a prime test for star fillies today when Harpia was withdrawn because she didn't seem frisky, and later when the speed filly Lines of Beauty was scratched and Angel of a Mom unseated her jockey during the post parade and was also withdrawn.

title: Israeli Planes Strike at Guerrillas in Southern Lebanon
description: Israel conducted an aerial bombardment tonight of what it said were four Hezbollah guerrilla strongholds deep inside Lebanon, stung into action by a week of attacks that culminated in the killing of a general and three other Israelis in southern Lebanon earlier today.

title: Devils Take Away Any Coyote Advantage
description: The Devils found themselves two men short for 68 seconds early in the final period this afternoon at Continental Arena. To make matters worse, Scott Stevens, their captain and cornerstone of the penalty-killing unit, was sitting in the penalty box, next to Krzysztof Oliwa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, JACK
description: SEGAL-Jack. In his 90th year. Beloved husband of 65 years of Rose (nee Leventhal). Devoted father of Elinor Hirsch and Howard and the late Norman. Dear grandfather of Karen, Elizabeth, Eric, Jeffrey, Stephanie, Phoebe, Alexis and Sophie. Ecstasic great-grandfather of Ethan. Good and dear friend of Bernice Young. Father to Robert Hirsch and Gail Clott. Grandfather to Brian Hartman and Kyle Halmrast. Adored uncle to his nieces and nephews. Dear brother of William, Essie Mate and the late Miriam Schulman. Services today at 10AM Gutterman-Musicant corner Passaic and Park Street, Hackensack. Contributions to Jewish Community Center on the Palisades, Tenafly, N.J. would be appreciated.

title: Kazan's Oscar Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Howie Haak, Baseball Pioneer In Latin America, Dies at 87
description: Howie Haak, a pioneer of baseball scouting in Latin America and a key figure in the Pittsburgh Pirates' snaring of the future Hall of Famer Roberto Clemente from the Brooklyn Dodgers' farm system, died on Feb. 22 in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 87 and a baseball scout for nearly a half-century.

title: 2 Alliances Aim to Create PC Alternatives
description: Two separate industry alliances to be announced today share a similar target: creating alternatives to the personal computer -- and to the Microsoft Corporation's operating systems -- for Internet access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRU, MALCOLM S.
description: BRU-Malcolm S. 84. Died February 18. Of White River Junction, VT. Devoted husband to Dorothea. Loving father to Ronald, Georgina and Elizabeth. Brother to Robert.

title: Police Say Driver Tried Bribe to Save Car
description: A New Jersey man who was stopped on drunken driving charges on the Upper East Side early yesterday got into bigger trouble by trying to bribe officers into letting him keep his car, the police said.

title: Let Good Owners and Good Dogs Patrol the Parks; Take Fido Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Work on Hudson Park Is Stalled As Officials Lag in Naming Board
description: On a Hudson River pier on a sunny morning in early September, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a law to create a 4.5-mile park along Manhattan's western edge. With the stroke of a pen, he appeared to end a generation of bickering about what to do with the waterfront from Battery Park City to 59th Street.

title: St. Peter's Continues Its Run
description: St. Peter's occupies only one square block on each side of Kennedy Boulevard in Jersey City and even less space in the region's sports consciousness. But St. Peter's guard Jamar Hunter said he believed the Peacocks' surprising run in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament in Buffalo could change that.

title: Kidnappers Free Check-Cashing Worker for $40,000 in Ransom
description: An employee of a check-cashing store in Brooklyn was kidnapped on Friday evening and held overnight until her husband, who works at another check-cashing store, paid a $40,000 ransom to her abductors, the police said yesterday.

title: Large Gift to Education School Raises Hopes a Trend Is Starting
description: Schools of education have long struggled as the fund-raising also-rans on university campuses, since even the most successful teacher is likely to have far less to give back to alma mater than, say, a grateful mogul or surgeon. So there was as much astonishment as gratitude last week when the University of Connecticut announced the largest gift in its history -- $23 million, with all but $2 million of it bound for the School of Education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, ELBRIDGE T.
description: GERRY-Elbridge T. Died on February 26, at the age of 90, following a short illness at his home in Delhi, NY. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Marjorie Kane, two sons Elbridge T. Jr., of Locust Valley, NY, and Peter G. of Hopewell, NJ, a daughter Marjorie G. Ryland of Beverly, MA, two brothers Edward H. Gerry and Henry A. Gerry, 11 grandchildren and seven great - grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Wednesday, March 10, 1999, at Trinity Church, Wall St and Broadway, NYC, at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Lake Delaware Boys Camp, or The Harness Racing Museum and Hall of Fame, or the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HAZZAN LOUIS
description: KLEIN-Hazzan Louis. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a revered colleague of more than four decades. A graduate of the Conservatorium of Ospend Belgium, he studied Hazzanut with Hazzan B. Rabinowitz of Antwerp. He served as cantor in London, England, Brooklyn, N.Y. and Congregation B'naiMoshe of West Bloomfield, MI. We extend our sympathy to his children and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, Pres. Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Exec. VP Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Exec. Administrator

title: Time Arrives for Seaver to Meet the Mets
description: It seemed fitting that Jason Isringhausen was the first person Tom Seaver approached in Seaver's new, part-time role as an ad-hoc pitching coach with the Mets.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE REAL FALLS. The Brazilian currency fell to its lowest level since January as traders anticipated a scramble for dollars by companies repaying debts. In New York, the real traded at 2.13 to the dollar, down from 2.07 on Friday.

title: 9 Die at Indonesian Mosque When Police Fire at Rioters
description: Nine people died today in a provincial capital when the police opened fire on a crowd outside a mosque, several witnesses told Reuters.

title: Racial Attitudes in Jersey's State Police
description: New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, did the right thing in dismissing Col. Carl Williams as superintendent of the state police because of comments he made in an interview with The Star-Ledger of Newark. Colonel Williams had asserted that certain crimes were associated with certain races, and he specifically linked minorities with drug trafficking. His remarks betrayed pernicious racial stereotyping that cannot be allowed to guide a police force that must deal fairly with all members of a diverse society.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the presidential election in Nigeria on Saturday described the election incorrectly. It was not Nigeria's first presidential vote in 16 years. A presidential election was held in 1993; its results were annulled by the military government.

title: Caution on Faith and Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZER, ELEANORE
description: SELZER-Eleanore. Beloved wite of Gabriel, devoted mother of Herbert and wife, Roberta, and Richard and his wife, Eileen. Loving grandmother of Jordan, Lauren, Brian, Amy, and Brooke. Survived by her sister, Irene Applebaum. Services are today, 9:30 A.M., at Boulevard Chapels, Hewlett.

title: March May Soon Be Coming In Like a Lamb
description: Separate studies using different methods in the last three years have found that as the earth's atmosphere warms, spring warmth is arriving earlier and autumn coolness is coming later in the Northern Hemisphere. But much of the evidence has been indirect, and now a direct examination of the actual behavior of plants across Europe appears to confirm the earlier findings.

title: Doctors' Group Merges With a Larger Union
description: The Doctors Council, a union representing 2,500 salaried doctors at New York City hospitals, announced yesterday that it was merging with the larger Service Employees International Union as part of a plan to accelerate efforts to unionize doctors nationwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIG, ALAN
description: ZEIG-Alan. Beloved husband of Marge. Devoted father of Tammy. Cherished son of the late Morris and Fanny. Dear brother of the late Lillian Mahler. Beloved nephew of Martha Silver, Sonia Rosenberg and the late Rebecca Greenberg. Dear uncle of Marilyn Konoson, Charlotte Wachsman and Howard Mahler. Services today, 12 Noon, ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Building a Lifeline on Mars

title: On Changing The Mayors In Midstream
description: DO you recall how Bill Bradley, the former Senator, kept insisting during the Senate impeachment trial that a special election for President be held if Bill Clinton were convicted? Remember the way he complained that Vice President Al Gore's automatic ascension to the White House would give him an unfair leg up in next year's national election?

title: L-3 to Acquire Aydin for $72.3 Million
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., a spinoff from the Lockheed Martin Corporation that went public in May, agreed to buy the Aydin Corporation for $72.3 million in cash to expand its military and communications business, L-3 said yesterday.

title: CMGI to Acquire Internet Profiles
description: CMGI Inc., an Internet venture capital concern, said today that it would buy the closely held Internet Profiles Corporation for an undisclosed price and would use it for expansion into the Internet traffic-tracking business.

title: Who's Needlessly Prolonging Life?; No Medicaid Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, DR. JOHN
description: DONNELLY-Dr. John. West Hartford, CT. Died on February 18, 1999. Born in 1914 and educated in England, he received his medical degree at the University of Liverpool Medical School in 1938. At the end of WWII he entered psychiatric training at the University of London and received his diploma of Psychological Medicine in 1948. In 1949 he joined the staff of The Institute of Living in Hartford and in 1965 was named Psychiatrist-inChief and Chief Executive Officer of the Institute. He retired in 1979, continuing at the Institute until 1984 as Senior Consultant. An eminent psychiatrist with a national and international reputation he was President of the Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry and of the National Association of Private Psychiatric Hospitals. He is survived by his wife, Mabel C. Donnelly, and by his children, Mavis J. Donnelly, M.D. and James M. Donnelly, M.D. and three grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRADO, RITA M. (NEE HARRINGTON)
description: CORRADO-Rita M. (nee Harrington). On Saturday, February 27, 1999, Widow of Jack Healy and Anthony of Greenwood Lake, NY. Formerly of Brooklyn. Sister of Michael, James, John, Mrs. Mary Jane Tarone, Mrs. Maureen Del Vecchia, Mrs. Anne Balsamo and Mrs. Elizabeth Hafner. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Richards Funeral Home, 1440 Union Valley Road, West Milford, NJ. Funeral Liturgy 10 AM Wednesday at Our Lady Queen of Peace Church, Hewitt. Interment St. Johns Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations to American Lung Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, BERNARD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDORFER, SEYMOUR
description: RUDORFER-Seymour. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are profoundly saddened by the passing of Seymour Rudorfer, a cherished friend, beloved leader, and dedicated supporter, who left a legacy of hope for all those touched by his extraordinary generosity and concern. Mr. Rudorfer played a vital role as chair and one of the founders of UJA-Federation's Long Island Program Services Cabinet. He was instrumental in forging a strong partnership between UJA-Federation and our agencies. A devoted leader deeply committed to Jewish causes, he was a member of UJA-Federation's Board of Directors and Long Island Cabinet, and was involved in numerous aspects of our organization. He also served as a member of the board of directors of The Rosalind and Joseph Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center of Long Island, and as former president of the Sid Jacobson Jewish Community Center, both beneficiary agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Anita; his children, Linda Lefton, and Linda's husband, Steven, Janet Irlander, and Janet's husband, Sam, and Henry, and Henry's wife, Dara; and his grandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Martin Rosenman, LI Cabinet Chair Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: UGI STOCK PLUNGES AFTER OFFER FOR UNISOURCE
description: Shares of the UGI Corporation, the largest American seller of propane, fell $4.375 yesterday, to $15.9375, after the company announced that it would buy Unisource Worldwide Inc., the largest American distributor of paper and janitorial supplies. Shares of Unisource rose $1, to $8. To acquire Unisource, which is based in Berwyn, Pa., UGI will issue $815 million in stock and assume $710 million in debt; Unisource shareholders will own about 55 percent of the combined company. Analysts said investors questioned the terms as well as the value of uniting two companies in such different businesses. UGI, of Valley Forge, Pa., also said it would sell its UGI Utilities Inc. unit, valued at more than $220 million; cut its dividend by 49 percent, and buy back as much as 20 percent of its common stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, DR. WILLIAM

His contributions to our institution, and to the advancement of anatomy and zoology, will be long remembered. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FYBISH, PEGGY ROMANO
description: FYBISH-Peggy Romano. On January 26, 1999, at her Manhattan home. Dearly loved wife and companion since 1971 of Stephen Fybish. Beloved mother of Emily Prager and Nora Elcar, loving grandmother of Lulu Prager. In her chief career as actress Peggy Romano, she combined outward beauty and grace of movement with a voice ranging in tone from gently poetic to powerfully expressive. Born on September 19, 1929, Peggy was first onstage at age five with her British-born actor father, Charles Romano, in ''The Great Waltz'' and with her actress mother, Mary Ricard, in ''The Old Maid''. As a child, she enjoyed the company of such family friends as Leslie Howard, Ruth Gordon, Noel Coward, the Lunts, Basil Rathbone, Judith Anderson and Margalo Gillmore. Her favorite playwrights and producers were Moss Hart, George Kaufman, and Max Gordon. A teenage star in both ''Junior Miss'' and ''Dear Ruth'', she went from Broadway to California with the national touring companies of these plays, performing in theatres in all 48 states during the 1940's. Married and a mother at age 18, she maintained her stage career less intensively through the 1960's. Peggy's brilliant, inquiring mind, keen sense of humor, and numerous talents were a rare combination. She was a painter of colorful landscapes, flowers and portraits, author of two novels, gifted costume designer, cartoonist, puppeteer and dancer. Her letters, diaries, and tape recordings delightfully conveyed her almost photographic memories of her favorite people, places and events, such as the 1991 solar eclipse at Oaxaca, Mexico, described at her memorial service on January 29, 1999. She cared passionately about her family, her country, and the survival of the earth's endangered animals, native cultures and natural habitats. Her knowledge of archaelogy and history enriched her travels to Europe, Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean Isles. In the 1990's, her summer vacations with her husband, Steve, by the tropical seashore of Isla Mujeres, gave her great pleasure. She listened joyously to birdsongs from the trees of Mexico and Manhattan, and the ballet music of Prokofiev's ''Cinderella''. The inspiration she gave to the lives and accomplishments of her two daughters, grandchild, Lulu, and her three husbands-Arthur Prager, Dana Elcar and Stephen Fybish-will always be remembered and cherished.

title: Sprewell Gets Nod to Practice
description: Latrell Sprewell was cleared to practice by team doctors yesterday, and the shooting guard said he could be back in the Knicks' lineup as early as Friday night in his hometown of Milwaukee, when New York will face the Bucks.

title: When Long Hair Was a Crime
description: New Jersey is in an uproar and its State Police Superintendent is out of a job over the issue of driver profiling, the practice by which the police arbitrarily single out members of specific groups, stopping and searching them in the hope of uncovering crimes.

title: Search for New Planets Yields Confusion
description: The discovery of planets around other stars has made Epicureans of astronomers. Not that they now put out the fine silver, pop the cork and dress for dinner by candlelight every long night under the observatory dome; they are still unwrapping their tired sandwiches and tearing open the corn chips, thank you. But nowadays their tastes run to the cosmic musings of the eponymous founder of Epicurean philosophy.

title: New Gas Pipeline Planned
description: The Coastal Corporation said today that it was planning to build a 700-mile pipeline that would carry natural gas from the Gulf of Mexico to the growing energy market of southern Florida. Coastal, based in Houston, said the first deliveries were scheduled for 2002. Heading southeast across the Gulf of Mexico from near Mobile, Ala., the proposed Gulfstream Natural Gas System would reach as far as West Palm Beach on Florida's east coast. Demand in Florida for electricity, the primary use for natural gas, increased 700 percent in the last 35 years.

title: Evening Links The Familiar And the New
description: How does a conductorless orchestra decide what to play? The concert that Orpheus gave at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night managed to begin and end in the 18th century and in B flat, the works being a Boccherini symphony and Mozart's last piano concerto. But it was a strange route that took the program through a new composition by Peter Lieberson, his Horn Concerto, and Martinu's little-known Serenade. Perhaps the criterion of choice was simply that each was a piece the musicians wanted to present, as one could easily believe, given the liveliness with which they did so.

title: $9.50 for the Movies? Vallone Urges a Boycott
description: The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, asked New Yorkers yesterday to stage a one-day boycott of movie theaters on Friday as an expression of anger over ticket prices that were raised to $9.50 last week at some Manhattan theaters.

title: No Medical Insurance Means Tough, and Creative, Choices
description: Peggy Parraga, a part-time massage therapist from Queens, divides her life into two phases: the time when she and her family had health insurance, and now, when they do not.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 16 about a new autobiography by F. W. de Klerk, the former President of South Africa, misstated publication plans in the United States because of erroneous information provided by a publicist. Macmillan, which has published the book -- ''The Last Trek: A New Beginning'' -- in Britain and South Africa, informed The Times last week that the book is in fact to be published in the United States, by its St. Martin's Press division on June 1.

title: Human Nature: Some Fear Everything, Even Fear Itself
description: Not long ago, I had another episode of a recurring nightmare: the going-back-to-the-Bronx dream. In reality, my childhood apartment building on Creston Avenue has long since burned to the ground. In my dreams, though, I must get back to it, no matter how dangerous the journey. I must walk along dark streets where batterers and murderers loiter in every doorway. I must travel on subways that invariably run in the wrong direction. And when I finally arrive, the apartment is deserted, with no lock, no lights, no furniture, no family to protect me. I'm all alone in the Bronx, and I'm terrified right out of my id. At which point, I bolt awake -- and the real nightmare begins.

title: Alcatel Agrees To Buy Xylan For $1.7 Billion
description: Expanding its presence in the computer networking market, Alcatel of France, one of the world's biggest makers of telephone equipment, has agreed to acquire the Xylan Corporation for more than $1.7 billion in cash, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: GILEAD SCIENCES TO ACQUIRE NEXSTAR PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Gilead Sciences Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $550 million in stock, bolstering its portfolio of drugs to treat infectious diseases and cancer. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., markets Vistide, which is used to treat an infection that harms the vision of people with AIDS. Nexstar, based in Boulder, Colo., sells Ambisome, used in the treatment of fungal infections, and Daunoxome, used to treat Kaposi's sarcoma, another condition often found in connection with AIDS. Shares of Nexstar rose $1.3125, to $15.125, while Gilead fell 50 cents, to $40.75.

title: Collins Survives a 15-Minute Grilling
description: Kerry Collins made his first public appearance at Giants Stadium today, a 15-minute, stand-in-the-pocket performance that had the new Giants quarterback earnestly answering questions about his drinking habits, his passion for football, accusations that he once used a racial slur and how he felt being the highest-paid backup in the National Football League.
