title: Giving Cheever Country Its Guilty Pleasure
description: A LITTLE more than a year ago, Diane Straus Tucker had never met her stepsister-to-be, a woman she had heard of only as Monica. But it did seem odd to Ms. Tucker when she heard that Monica, who seemed to have a good job at the Pentagon, was looking for a public relations job at Revlon in New York.

title: A 1960's Party With Twyla Tharp
description: Experimental dance in the 1960's was largely conceptual and in love with natural movement. No one summed up the end of that dance decade better than Twyla Tharp in 1970 with ''The One Hundreds.''

title: CORNING TO BUY CABLE BUSINESSES FROM BICC OF BRITAIN
description: Corning Inc., one of the largest makers of fiber optic cable, said yesterday that it planned to acquire the telecommunications cable businesses of BICC P.L.C., a British engineering concern, for about $133 million in cash. The deal includes BICC's 50 percent stake in Optical Waveguides Australia, a fiber optic business already half-owned by Corning. Separately, Corning, based in Corning, N.Y., said it expected to report an increase of 20 percent to 25 percent in first-quarter earnings because of a rise in demand for a new product that provides high data rate optical fiber service. The shares rose $3, to $56.50.

title: A Subpar Exhibition For U.S.
description: The United States women's team's performance in the 2-0 exhibition victory over Finland on Saturday was far below the standard necessary to win the World Cup, which will be staged in seven communities in the United States from June 19-July 10. The tournament will open at Giants Stadium and close at the Rose Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, IRA, M.D.
description: MINTZ-Ira, M.D. The Officers and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the death of their esteemed member and colleague, Ira Mintz. A ground-breaking pioneer in the field of psychosomatic medicine, he authored numerous original papers and co-edited three outstanding books including what has become a classic work on anorexia nervosa and bulimia. His brilliant scholarship and patient understanding will be deeply missed. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nancy, his children, Karen, Susan and Robert, and his grandchildren. Daniel Papernik, M.D., President Arthur Lew, M.D., Secretary

title: Naturalists' New Tools Are Delicate and Dazzling
description: Natural historians are trading in their calipers for computer imagers and using new microscopes that are gentler on fragile specimens yet expose unprecedented detail.

title: In Wall St. Computer Test, New Year Arrives in March
description: Wall Street is going back to the future. On Saturday, about 400 brokerage firms, banks, exchanges and other institutions will push the clocks on their computers forward to Dec. 29 as the first stage in a full-scale test of their readiness to trade stocks, bonds and other securities in the Year 2000.

title: UConn 77, Georgetown 42
description: The formula was no mystery to Pat Knapp. The Georgetown women's basketball coach knew what his team had to do tonight against Connecticut in the first semifinal.

title: Surprise Finding on Tamoxifen and Citrus
description: In trying to explain why fruits and vegetables help prevent cancer, some researchers cite flavonoids, which are chemical ingredients that inhibit cancer cell growth. But a new study suggests that tangeretin, a flavonoid in citrus fruits and certain processed foods and dietary supplements, may sometimes be harmful because it negates the benefits of tamoxifen, the breast cancer drug. The finding came as a surprise, since in vitro studies showed that tangeretin acted like tamoxifen to inhibit mammary cancer cells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, HY

title: Adobe Sees 'Quark Killer' Putting New Life in the Company
description: When Adobe Systems Inc.'s shares hit a four-year low last year, Quark Inc. floated an informal, and unwelcome, offer to buy the company. On Tuesday, Adobe will return the favor with the introduction of a new program long known by its code name, K2, now called InDesign, but referred to by nearly everyone in the publishing industry as the Quark killer.

title: Winning on the Road: Easy to Say, Not Do
description: Basketball is a simple game. Any pro will tell you that. Such was the case last night in Madison Square Garden. And Chris Childs, a New York point guard, succinctly explained the Knicks' 85-78 victory over the Cavaliers after two straight losses on the road. ''Enough,'' Childs said, ''was enough.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHRACH, HAROLD H.
description: BACHRACH-Harold H. Died on February 22, 1999, age 89. Beloved husband of the late Etta. Loving father of Loretta & Cantor Marvin Antosofsky. Cherished grandfather of Karla and Kevin, Marilyn and Craig, Adam and Monica. Adored great grandfather of Sam, Max and Jamie. Dear brother of Edith Roth. Special friend to Harriet Levin. Retired Vice President of Chase Manhattan Bank for more than 50 years, a leader, consultant and lecturer in the field of consumer credit and bank credit cards. Honorary life member of the International Consumer Credit Association. Past President of Friendship Lodge, Executive Board member of Free Sons of Israel. Past Chancellor of Delta Sigma Tau. Services today, 11:00 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: To the Editor:

title: About the Tables
description: To accommodate growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is making its daily mutual funds table more concise, starting today.

title: Amazon.com Site Tells Users Of Book Promotion Payments
description: Responding to complaints from customers, Amazon.com retooled its popular on-line bookstore yesterday so that it would disclose when publishers pay money to subsidize titles that are highlighted or featured with favorable reviews.

title: DUKE REALTY INVESTMENTS TO BUY WEEKS, A RIVAL REIT
description: Duke Realty Investments Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival real estate investment trust, the Weeks Corporation, creating a company with 90 million square feet of industrial and commercial space and 46.6 million square feet of developable land. The Indianapolis-based Duke, one of the Midwest's largest commercial real estate developers, said it would swap 1.38 of its shares for each Weeks share, valuing Weeks stock and partnership units at $815 million, or $30.10 a share. Duke will also assume $254 million of preferred stock and $654 million of debt. Weeks, based in Norcross, Ga., has commercial properties throughout the Southeast. The combined company will have annual revenue of more than $500 million. Shares of Duke fell 87.5 cents, to $20.9375. Shares of Weeks rose $1, to $28.

title: Paper Details Lewinsky Interview a Day Before Broadcast
description: In a move that compromises the exclusivity of what is expected to be the biggest television interview of the year, The Daily News today printed large portions of ABC's highly anticipated interview with Monica S. Lewinsky, which is scheduled to be broadcast tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBACH, SOL
description: SCHOENBACH-Sol. The Board, staff, faculty and students of the Settlement Music School of Philadelphia join with thousands of colleagues and students who mourn the passing of Sol Schoenbach. Named Executive Director Emeritus upon his retirement in 1981 after 24 years as Executive Director of the School, Dr. Schoenbach was a figure of international renown as a performer, educator, adminstrator, and thinker about the roll of music in the community and the power of musical study to transform lives. The School will host a memorial celebration of Dr. Schoenbach's life and accomplishments and those of his late wife, Bertha, a distinguished artist, in the late Spring of this year.

title: Stevia: a Sweetener That's Not a Sweetener
description: For centuries, sweet has meant sweet as sugar. Now a growing number of diet-conscious Americans are turning instead to stevia, a shrub native to South American containing sweeteners that are essentially calorie free.

title: Making Goethe the Glue To Bind a Lieder Recital
description: Goethe's effect on his contemporaries and their progeny is like no other in cultural history. ''The Sorrows of Young Werther'' inspired copycat suicides among European youth, and the people on whom the characters of ''Werther'' were based became the Biedermaier equivalents of rock stars: followed on the streets and mobbed at their hotels. (See Thomas Mann's ''Lotte in Weimar.'')

title: A Chamber Group Unbridled With the Boss Out Front
description: James Levine is the driving force behind the concerts of the Met Chamber Ensemble even when he's not onstage participating in a performance. And for the two largest works on Sunday afternoon's sold-out program at Weill Recital Hall, the third and last in the ensemble's inaugural season, Mr. Levine was sitting in the audience, looking proud and just enjoying himself like everyone else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOTZER, ALBERT
description: GLOTZER-Albert. Died on February 18th, 1999. He will be long remembered for his commitment to human rights, equality and democracy, and for his historic book about Leon Trotsky (Prometheus Books, Amherst, NY). Al's articulate speaking style and his warm friendship will be missed. From his friends on the national committee. Social Democrats, USA

title: Whitman Defends Response to Claims Of Bias by Troopers
description: A day after firing the head of the New Jersey State Police for what she called racially insensitive remarks, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today defended her administration's response to charges that state troopers single out black and Hispanic drivers in searching for drug traffickers.

title: U.N. Panel Urges Tribunal For Khmer Rouge Leaders
description: A United Nations panel has recommended that a new international tribunal be convened to try about a dozen senior Khmer Rouge officials on charges of crimes against humanity while they ruled Cambodia, according to diplomats and senior Administration officials.

description: After a woeful season fraught with internal strife, Manhattan College fired Coach John Leonard yesterday.

description: A new approach combining an antidepressant, nicotine replacement and counseling is sharply increasing the chance of success among people who are trying to give up smoking.

title: Slowly Breaking the Silence on AIDS
description: They baptize people, confirm them, preach to them, marry them, bury them, and now, like it or not, in the face of AIDS, priests, ministers and other members of the clergy are teaching parishioners about sex.

description: Thirteen foreign tourists and an unknown number of Ugandans were kidnapped early this morning while tracking mountain gorillas in a forest near Uganda's southwestern border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFET, SIMEON, M.D.
description: TAFFET-Simeon, M.D. Born March 23, 1929 in Brooklyn, New York. Died on March 1, 1999. Associate Clinical Professor of Opthalmology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Director of Department of Opthalmology, Mount Vernon Hospital from 1985-1993; Director of Ocular Motility Clinic, Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, 1975-1992. Received his Bachelor of Science from Purdue University in 1949 and his medical doctorate from the University of Geneva in 1955. He served his patients in private practice in Mount Vernon, N.Y. from 1960-present. A widower of Renate K. Taffet, he is survived by his three beloved sons, Jerome Taffet, M.D., Robert Taffet, M.D. and David Taffet, five grandchildren, Zachary, Elizabeth, Rebecca, Charles and Caroline; and his companion, Nora Johnson. Funeral will take place at Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York at 1 P.M., March 2, 1999.

title: Mirror Rejects Trinity's Sweetened Bid
description: The Mirror Group P.L.C., which owns one of Britain's oldest tabloids, rejected a sweetened offer of $1.53 billion today from Trinity P.L.C., the country's biggest regional newspaper group, and said it was talking with a rival suitor.

title: Kanell Eyes Falcon Backup Job
description: Danny Kanell met with Dan Reeves yesterday at the Falcons offices to discuss a free-agent contract that would make Kanell the backup to Atlanta's often-injured starting quarterback, Chris Chandler.

title: Van Horn's Shot at Buzzer Stops Nets' Long Slide
description: There had to be drama. There had to be high anxiety. There had to be a heart-stopping ending. How else could the Nets have shaken the demons that have haunted them over last six games, the ones that had them questioning their abilities and nearly everyone else questioning their coach.

title: Detectives in Hot Pursuit Of Homicides Grown Cold; Squad Combines DNA and Shoe Leather To Crack Old Cases With Loose Ends
description: Fernando Leon, this numbers runner with the nickname Benny tattooed on his arm, was getting madder and madder at Grace Meullins. The woman kept bothering him for the $700 that she said he owed her daughter. Then she hit him over the head with a flashlight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Palestinian Gets Life Sentence For Planning to Bomb Subway
description: A Palestinian immigrant convicted of plotting to bomb the New York City subway was sentenced yesterday to life in prison, after bitterly denouncing Israeli treatment of the Palestinian people and United States support for Israel.

title: Bucks Offer Nets Brandon
description: The Milwaukee Bucks have made the Nets an offer that would give New Jersey its first All-Star point guard since Kenny Anderson.

title: Nassau Guard Beat Inmate, A Jury Finds
description: A Federal jury found yesterday that a Nassau County Jail guard had beaten a mentally retarded inmate in 1993, leaving him with broken ribs and spinal fractures. The decision clears the way for a broader civil rights trial against Nassau County and other jail guards.

title: A Rocket Substitute For Shuttles Falls Short
description: An experimental rocket that is at the heart of NASA's plans to develop a low-cost, re-usable vehicle that may eventually replace the space shuttle has fallen more than a year behind schedule for its first flight because of mounting technical problems.

Shiva observed at the Levine home, 303 West 66 Street, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106 Street, NYC 10025

title: Man in the News; Nigerian Question Mark: Olusegun Obasanjo
description: Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, who will soon become Nigeria's first elected President after 16 years of military dictatorships, is an anomaly in this country's recent history, and a man of contradictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, SMITH, HUGHIE
description: LEE-SMITH-Hughie. The Board and staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem mourn the loss of the outstanding painter, Hughie LeeSmith. Mr. Lee-Smith was a painter of consistent excellence and sustained commitment to Modernism. His exhibition at The Studio Museum in Harlem in 1973 provided New York audiences with a rare and important look at this significant artist. His work is in the permanent collection of the museum and other institutions around the country. He will be deeply missed. Our condolences to his family and friends. George L. Knox, Chairman Kinshasha H. Conwill, Director

title: Knicks Find the Perfect Elixir For Their 2-Game Losing Streak
description: Larry Johnson took the ball in the low post with a chance to seal the game. He wheeled to his right and then to his left before softly depositing a five-foot jump shot from the middle of the lane. He felt a fleeting sense of satisfaction that was replaced by a sobering thought.

title: Mall Opponents Don't Give Up Easily
description: When the Palisades Center mall opened here in March 1998, the developers might have thought that their long battle with neighbors was finally over. They would have been wrong.

title: Velvet Fisticuffs; High Fashion, High Stakes in LVMH-Gucci Showdown
description: As the fashion set gathers in Europe this week to preview fall collections, cashmere sweatshirts and fur ponchos will dominate the runways. But looming in the background is a nasty battle that has erupted as one luxury goods maker, LVMH, tries to gain control of a smaller rival, Gucci.

title: S.& P. Downgrades 5 Large Chinese Banks
description: The China International Trust and Investment Corporation, or Citic, China's biggest investment company, and the Bank of Communications had their credit ratings cut to BBB, a junk-bond rating, by the Standard & Poor's Corporation as concern rose over the quality of their loans. Standard & Poor's said yesterday that Chinese financial institutions would face an increasingly difficult environment ''as a result of slowed economic growth and corporate restructurings.'' Ratings for three of China's largest banks, the Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, were lowered even further, to BBB-, the lowest investment grade. Standard & Poor's rated the outlook for all five banks as ''negative.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the blurring of distinctions between advertising and editorial content on the World Wide Web referred incompletely to two Web sites. On CNNfn's site, the travel page presents services and promotions from a travel agency along with news articles, but its editors say they feel the distinction is clear. On Baby Center, where search results include promotions for advertisers, the company notes that each result is labeled as editorial content, sponsored information, or an opportunity to make a purchase.

description: MUFSON-Joanna. 8/16/69-2/23/83. Death devours all lovely things. Miss you every day. Mom and Abb

title: Fatal Crash Reveals Inhalants as Danger to Youth
description: The impact of the car crash tore bark off a tree along U.S. 1, and now sad words are written there as a memorial to the five girls who were killed.

title: Now, a Food Pyramid To Guide the Elderly
description: Many ailments that afflict older Americans are directly caused or indirectly worsened by poor nutrition -- an inadequate intake of essential nutrients, dietary fiber and water. Health problems like heart disease, osteoporosis, diabetes, kidney disease and even cancer are influenced by the foods consumed, or not consumed, especially in older people.

title: Crisscrossing Sounds of East and West
description: In 1969, when the Japanese composer Maki Ishii, then 32, participated in an academic exchange program in Berlin, his German friends kiddingly called him the ''Pendulum Man.'' This was because of his frequent migrations, both geographical and musical, between the East and the West. An attempt to reconcile the two strikingly different traditions has defined the music of Mr. Ishii, who at 62 is now one of Japan's leading composers. A program of his works was performed on Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall by an impressive roster of American and Japanese musicians, the first of two concerts over the weekend sponsored by Music From Japan.

title: Shifting Gymnastic Shapes And Punctuation With Gongs
description: Jodie Oberfelder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUTZKY, GOLDYE
description: SLUTZKY-Goldye, 88. Of Hunter. Died February 27, 1999 at her residence. She was born on May 2, 1910 to Michael and Tillie Frank Honigsbaum in Tannersville. She was a member of the Sisterhood of the Hunter Synagogue and the Daughters of Hadassah, and was an active fundraiser for the United Jewish Appeal. She was a graduate of Tannersville High School and was captain of their basketball team for more than four years. She did charity work for the American Heart Association. She was a champion golfer at the Windham Country Club, accumulating 18 golf trophies. She was an avid skier for more than twenty years and was a senior finalist in the NASTAR finals in 1975 in Sun Valley, Idaho. She was predeceased by her son, Michael on October 23, 1983, and two brothers, Philip on March 4, 1962, and Pitz Honigsbaum on February 20, 1988, and also a sister, Jean Weber on December 13, 1991. She is survived by her husband, Israel Slutzky; two sons, Charles B. Slutzky of Elka Park, and David John Slutzky and his wife Jean of Hunter; grandchildren William Scott Slutzky, Rebecca Ann Slutzky, Tiffany Alexis Slutzky and Zachary West Slutzky, and many cousins. Funeral services were held on March 1 at the family residence on Route 296 in Hunter. The Reverend Daniel Fried officiated. Interment followed in the Kol Ansche Israel Cemetery in South Jewett. Memorial donations may be made to the Community Hospice of ColumbiaGreene, 47 Liberty St., Catskill, N.Y. 12414. For information, contact the Aston-Basagic Funeral Home, Main Street, Hunter, NY

title: Judge Delays Ruling On Tiger Preserve
description: An Ocean County Superior Court judge yesterday gave a Jackson Township woman who runs a tiger preserve a two-day reprieve before ruling on a state request to close down the preserve and to seize and disperse the 17 tigers there.

description: To the Editor:

description: The International Management Group announced yesterday that it has taken legal action against its former vice president of racquet sports, Jeffrey Schwartz, who resigned on Feb. 19 in order to open a private law firm in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Proposes Uranium Waste Plants
description: The Energy Department plans to announce this week that it wants to build two plants, at a cost of nearly $200 million each, that will gradually turn 1.5 billion pounds of depleted uranium into marketable products or waste that can be safely stored.

title: Bond Prices Plunge Again; Stocks Mixed
description: Fresh signs of strong economic growth preyed on the bond market again yesterday, pulling down stock prices early, but major market gauges pared their declines and closed narrowly mixed on unusually light volume.

title: Mouths at Risk When Guards Are Out
description: Although mouth guards can prevent dental injuries that occur during contact sports, a University of Minnesota study says that few athletes are wearing them.

title: In the Pit Without Antivenin
description: If it sometimes appears as if all good plays book passage to New York on British Airways, then take heart from the all-American flight plan of ''Snakebit,'' David Marshall Grant's finely observed, beautifully acted comedy-drama about the flaming out of friendship and marriage in a deceptively sunny precinct of Los Angeles.

Stevenson Memorial Fund, C/O Solomon Smith Barney, 1050 Connecticut Ave., N.W., Suite 225, Wash., D.C. 20036.

description: KABAK-Gertrude (nee Katowitz). Of Edison, New Jersey, formerly of Bronx, New York. Wife of Dr. Irwin Kabak. Mother of Michele Weisman, Cindy Weissman.

title: MCI Plans to Spend $6.5 Billion To Expand Overseas Operations
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance phone company in the United States, said today that it would spend $6.5 billion this year to expand globally and planned to bolster its presence in Asia, where markets are opening to competition for the first time.

title: U.S. Olympic Panel Suggests Bid Reform
description: A commission of the United States Olympic Committee investigating improper payments in the bid for the 2002 games said Salt Lake City officials joined a culture of gift-giving already flourishing under the International Olympic Committee. The panel suggested reforms that included asking President Clinton to declare the I.O.C. a ''public international organization'' and thus make bribing its officials punishable under law.

title: State Panel to Examine Reading Test Problems
description: The State Education Department named an independent panel yesterday to look into irregularities surrounding the administration last January of the new fourth-grade reading test.

title: Scandinavian Merger Unites 2 Food Makers
description: The Danish food and packaging group Danisco A/S and the Cultor Corporation, a Finland-based food-products concern, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a transaction that valued the Finnish group at 7.6 billion markkaa, or $1.41 billion. The partners did not specify how control of the merged group's equity would break down. Net sales will total around $4.44 billion, and staffing will stand at about 19,400.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Friday about a performance by the pianists Emanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday described their tour together incorrectly. The concert was their final appearance, not their first, in a four-city tour that also included Milwaukee and Madison, Wis., and Purchase, N.Y.

title: Foreign Affairs; Is Kosovo Worth It?
description: Should the U.S. get involved in Kosovo? The answer is a qualified ''yes.''

title: Newly Merged Chrysler Loses 2 Executives To Rival Ford
description: Two senior executives from the DaimlerChrysler Corporation joined the Ford Motor Company today, the latest of several departures by executives of the former Chrysler Corporation since its merger last November with Daimler-Benz A.G.

title: Contractor Fined $10,000 in School Death
description: The construction company responsible for a brick that fell off the roof of a school building in Brooklyn last year and killed a 16-year-old girl was fined $10,000 yesterday by a judge, the District Attorney's office said.

title: Israelis on Border Are Anxious, but Area Is Quiet
description: The morning after an Israeli bombardment of guerrilla targets in Lebanon, the northernmost residents of Israel awoke today to a strange lull, unsure whether the conflict would intensify or fade away.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIALS TO CALL FOR END TO COUNSEL LAW
description: The Justice Department will declare on Tuesday that it considers the independent-counsel law so ''fundamentally flawed'' that it ought to be scrapped this year, two Administration officials said tonight.

title: Youth Chief Is Expected To Head Unit For Homeless
description: The city's Department of Homeless Services, which is about to regain the status of a separate agency, will be headed by Martin Oesterreich, a veteran of city government, the Giuliani administration is expected to announce today.

title: By Design; Under Wraps
description: Scientists say the polar icecap is melting, but designers on both sides of the Atlantic are under the impression that next winter will be cold and blustery. At least it seems so because they are showing styles that swathe the throat in toasty warm fabric.

title: A Military Problem Money Can't Solve
description: While members of the armed services are underpaid and overworked, the bill recently passed by the Senate that gives them a pay raise doesn't address the real problem: keeping skilled officers and noncommissioned officers from leaving in mid-career.

title: Political Battle Threatens To Destabilize Paraguay
description: This small landlocked country in the heart of South America has just reached a major milestone in the life of any nation, its first 10 years of uninterrupted democracy.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES ADDING 2 FRENCH BOTTLERS
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two privately owned Coca-Cola bottling operations in southern France for about $100 million. Together, the companies had net operating revenue of $70 million in 1998. One, Sud Boissons S.A., operates around the city of Toulouse, and the other, Societe Boissons Gazeuses de la Cote d'Azur, covers the areas around Nice and Cannes. Coca-Cola Enterprises, based in Atlanta, is the world's largest bottler of soft drinks. If the deal closes as expected in the spring, the company will have bottling rights for all of France except Corsica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, JAMES J.
description: McDERMOTT-James J. Jr. Of Bronxville, N.Y. On February 22, 1999. Husband of Sue (Zyra). Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. on Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday, February 25 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Jansen Memorial Hospice, Tuckahoe, New York 10707.

title: Living to Tell About the Horror of Stalin's Camps
description: Half a century ago, the Soviet gulag was still thriving, with jammed freight cars carrying political prisoners from Moscow and Leningrad on a long journey to the mines and factories on the eastern borders of the empire. For many the sentence proved fatal, but in ''Stolen Years,'' a few of those who survived return tonight with memories of their time in the merciless cold and demoralizing conditions, doing long days of back-breaking labor with no prospect of release.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, THOMAS W.
description: WILLIAMS-Thomas W., 68, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, on February 27, 1999. He worked in the printing business for many years. Funeral Service March 6th at 9:30am at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. Visitation March 5th, 7-9pm. Donations to the Franklin Lakes, NJ Fire Dept.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ALIMENTATION COUCHE-TARD INC., Laval, Quebec, agreed to buy Silcorp Ltd., Scarborough, Ontario, for $220 million (Canadian), or $144.5 million (United States), in stock and cash, in a deal joining Canada's two largest convenience-store chains.

title: An Undeserved Oscar?
description: To the Editor:

In lieu of flowers contributions to the National Wildlife Federation, 8925 Leesburg Pike, Vienna, VA. 22186 will be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; On-Line Bank Gets Cash
description: Wit Capital Group Inc., an on-line investment bank, said yesterday that Capital Z Financial Services Fund II L.P., which counts the insurance industry executive Steven Gluckstern as a partner, had taken a $25 million stake.

title: Eartha Kitt, Living Her 9 Lives to the Fullest
description: She slithers across the stage at the Cafe Carlyle, catlike, 72 years old, with the muscles of an adolescent boy -- Eartha Kitt, whom Orson Welles called ''the most exciting woman in the world'' and the C.I.A. reportedly called ''a sadistic sex nymphomaniac'' after she stood up at a White House luncheon and criticized the war in Vietnam.

title: Centers Publish Breast Cancer Guide
description: When a woman finds out that she has breast cancer, fear and depression may be quickly followed by overwhelming confusion. There are so many decisions to make about surgery, radiation, types of chemotherapy and hormonal treatment that women may wonder how to make sure they really are getting the best, most up-to-date advice.

title: ALBRIGHT DEBATES RIGHTS AND TRADE WITH THE CHINESE
description: Trying to infuse the troubled relationship between the United States and China with a new sense of direction, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke sternly today to the authorities here about human rights but also encouraged them to move forward on joining the organization that governs world trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, DAVID
description: LESSER-David. Beloved husband of Shirley. Dear father of Michael. Dear father-in-law of Mindy. Cherished grandfather of Katie and Jake. Formerly of Manhattan Beach and currently of Boca Raton. Services Tuesday, 10:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Absent Witness Spurs Judge to Delay Trial of 2 in Organ Sales Plan
description: A Federal judge has delayed the trial of two men who were charged in a scheme to arrange the transplant of organs taken from executed Chinese prisoners, questioning whether the defendants were entrapped in the case, and expressing concern over the absence of a crucial witness.

title: Index of Manufacturing in U.S. Shows First Increase in 9 Months
description: Manufacturing expanded in February for the first time in nine months, adding fuel to an economy already benefiting from rising incomes and increased construction spending, new reports showed today.

title: Patriot American Agrees To Investor Bailout Plan
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said today that it had agreed to a financial bailout plan led by the investors Leon Black and Thomas Lee, that its chairman and chief executive had resigned and that it would convert from a real estate investment trust into a traditional corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELDOCH, HANNAH
description: BELDOCH-Hannah. She was ''Grandma Honey'' to the five Hochfelder boys and their wives: Jim and Ellen, Tom and Lynda, John and Janet, Andrew and Patricia, Peter and Stacy; and ''Great-Grandma Honey'' to Amy and Scott, Adam and Amy, Lauren, David, Jason, Julie, Josh, Alyssa, Robyn, Jake, Harrison and Charles; and great-great-grandmother to Samantha. After our mother Patricia Beldoch Hochfelder died in 1981, Honey was our surrogate mother, advisor, mentor and best friend to five generations at the same time. Her beautiful legacy will endure forever. The Hochfelder Family

title: Ralph Lauren Buying Casual Clothing Retailer
description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, the fashion design and retail company, said yesterday that it would acquire Club Monaco Inc., a Canadian-based specialty retailer that sells designer lookalike casual apparel, for $52.5 million in cash.

title: He Puts on a Nose, but He's Still No Cyrano
description: From the moment the two characters in ''Dream City Twosome'' meet, there is no doubt about how the play will end. The only question is how it will get there. And the answer is: dully.

title: Russia's Stubborn Strains of Anti-Semitism
description: With their black uniforms and barely disguised swastikas, the followers of Aleksandr P. Barkashov's Russian National Unity party are hard to miss, which is one reason their march in Moscow a few weeks ago attracted so much attention.

title: Editorial Observer; Guess What California Is Dreaming Of Now
description: People who covet their neighbors' goods always overestimate how much happier they would be if they got them. This rule is particularly true when applied to spouses, and perhaps giant TV satellite dishes. But it also works for Presidential primaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, DANIELLE
description: THALER-Danielle. Of New Rochelle, N.Y. On February 28, 1999. Wife of Peter, mother of Hanna and Logan, daughter of Natalie and the late Salvatore Malucci. Daughter-in-law of Donald and Cabot Thaler. Sister of Connie and Sharon. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Notice of funeral later.

description: GOLDWATER-John. The members of the Board of Directors of the New York Society for the Deaf mourn the passing of our dear friend and former president, John Goldwater, who provided us with the benefits of his leadership and counsel for over 30 years. His memory and legacy will always form a part of the fabric of the Society. To his wife, Gloria, his sons and grandchildren, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Stephen E. Adler, Chairman Paul L. Kohnstamm, President Pearl I. Johnson, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEININGER, ANDREAS
description: FEININGER - Andreas. The Trustees and Staff of the International Center of Photography remember with fondness and respect the pioneer photojournalist who for over six decades used the camera to share his curiosity and wonder with the world. We were honored to know him as a friend and will greatly miss his talent and generosity of spirit. Cornell Capa, Founder Willis Hartshorn, Director

title: Earnings Rise 23 Percent At Major French Bank
description: Banque Nationale de Paris raised its profit in 1998 despite a hefty increase in bad-debt provisions linked to emerging-market lending. The bank said yesterday that its net income climbed 23 percent, to 1.11 billion euros, more than analysts had expected, and that earnings per share were 5.16 euros.

title: Siena Gains Berth in N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: All that Siena Coach Paul Hewitt asked of his players after an embarrassing 15-point loss to Iona in last year's Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament championship game was that they return to the final.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, RITA
description: TRACHTENBERG-Rita. Beloved wife of Leo Trachtenberg, cherished mother of Daniel Trachtenberg, revered mother-in-law of Cari Pokrassa, loving grandmother of Allie Trachtenberg, died February 19, 1999. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, Ceremonial Hall, 4th Floor on Friday, February 26 at 12 noon.

title: Canada Growth Tops Estimates
description: Canada's economy grew at a greater-than-expected 4.6 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter of 1998 as auto makers increased exports and manufacturers built up depleted inventories, Government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKIR, EUGENE D.
description: SKIR-Eugene D. On February 22, 1999, of East Northport, L.I. Beloved husband of Lenore. Devoted father of Linda, William and Robert. Dear brother of Leo. Services Wednesday, 1:30 PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP IN DEAL FOR EMERALD FINANCIAL
description: Fifth Third Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Emerald Financial Corporation for about $204 million in stock. Fifth Third, based in Cincinnati, said it would pay 0.3 share for each share of Emerald Financial. Emerald Financial, of Strongsville, Ohio, is the parent of Strongsville Savings Bank, which has $670 million in assets and 15 branches in the Cleveland area. Fifth Third said it would merge Strongsville into its northeastern Ohio unit, creating an 80-branch subsidiary. Shares of Emerald Financial rose $4.125, or 28 percent, to $18.625, while Fifth Third rose 6.25 cents, to $66.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CURTIS L.
description: CARLSON-Curtis L. Minnesota entrepreneur. Founder of Carlson Companies. Mr. Carlson died Friday, February 19, after suffering a stroke on February 10. He was 84. He retained and enjoyed an active role as company chairman until his last day. Born July 9, 1914, in Minneapolis, Mr. Carlson was recognized for his generosity, integrity and entrepreneurial spirit. Known worldwide as the ''ultra-entrepreneur'', he founded the Gold Bond Stamp Company in 1938 with a $55 loan and a desire to succeed. After World War II, the business grew dramatically. Two-thirds of American households saved stamps, and Gold Bond captured about one-third of the market. Mr. Carlson's ''Horatio Alger'' qualities were key to the continued expansion of his business, which has become one of the largest privatelyheld companies in the world. To reflect its global expansion and diversification, the corporation became Carlson Companies, Inc., in 1973. Today, Carlson Companies is an international leader in providing hospitality, travel and marketing services and solutions to corporate clients and consumers. The company operates in more than 140 countries. Its brands employ 160,000 people worldwide and generated more than $22 billion in systemwide revenues in 1998. Carlson Companies brands and services include Regent International Hotels, Radisson Hotels Worldwide, Country Inns & Suites By Carlson, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, T.G.I. Friday's restaurants, Carlson Leisure Group (leisure travel) and Carlson Marketing Group, the largest relationship marketing company in the world. In 1997, Mr. Carlson was instrumental in establishing a global partnership with Accor of Paris, which combined the business travel interests of both companies under the name Carlson Wagonlit Travel. A 1938 graduate of the University of Minnesota, Mr. Carlson was a staunch supporter of his alma mater. In 1986, he made a $25 million gift to the university, at that time the largest single gift ever given to a public university. To recognize his contributions, the university renamed its school of management the Curtis L. Carlson School of Management. He and Arleen (Martin) met at the university and were married in 1938. Together, the couple was devoted to strengthening family bonds with their children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Carlson's honors include the prestigious Linnean Medal, Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, presented by H.M. Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden; the Viking Baron Award from the American Swedish Cultural Foundation; the Horatio Alger Award; the Swedish-American of the Year Award, Stockholm, Sweden, in 1981; the Town and Country magazine ''Philanthropist of the Year'' Award, 1987-1988; the International Citizen of the Year

title: Legend Dons Cap at Legends Field
description: Yogi Berra visited Legends Field today and the first thing Joe Torre did was place a Yankees cap on the Yankee legend's head. It looked right and it also enabled Berra to shield the sun while he sat between Torre and Coach Don Zimmer during an intrasquad game. The Yankees were on the field and so was Berra. Perfect.

title: In 3d Day of Strikes, U.S. Jets Hit Iraqi Air Defense Sites
description: A day after mounting an attack that Iraq said had disabled an oil pipeline, American jets attacked a dozen targets in northern Iraq today. It was the most intense flurry of strikes since four nights of American and British raids in December, Pentagon officials said.

title: French Defy U.S. and Join Iranian Oil Plan
description: Disregarding the American opposition to investments in Iran, a consortium of French, Italian and Iranian oil companies announced today that they had signed a $998 million 10-year contract to redevelop a giant oil field there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, DAVID CHARLES
description: TISCHLER-David Charles (55) who fought a brave and valiant battle with cancer died peacefully on February 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Leslie Brill. Devoted and loving father of Katy, Daniel, Sarra and Alison. Loving son of Edmund and the late Sara Tischler. Loving and cherished twin brother of Susan. David remains in the hearts of the many who love him as they remain in his. Services are on Wednesday, 12 noon at The ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELION, GERTRUDE B.
description: ELION-Gertrude B. The Hunter College Foundation mourns the passing of Gertrude Elion, a Nobel Prize winner in Medicine whom Hunter College also knew as a loyal alumna. A longtime trustee of The Hunter College Foundation, she supported her alma mater throughout her long and productive life and served as a role model to generations of Hunter students-especially women-who aspired to a career in science. She was instrumental in the development of a host of drugs to combat some of the most virulent diseases known, and she was active in the professional community: she was president of the American Association for Cancer Research, a member of the National Cancer Advisory Board, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences, among others. Though officially retired for a number of years, she continued to teach and conduct research. She received more than 25 honorary doctorates, including one from Hunter College, which will always remember her for both her scientific accomplishments and her generosity to her College. Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair Floria V. Lasky, Co-Chair The Hunter College Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, FRANKLIN
description: NELSON-Franklin. 67. Passed away suddenly. Beloved son of the late Faye and Max, father of Ted (Arelis) and Julie, brother of Joel (Midge), uncle of Nicole (Bill) and Jennifer. Also survived by loving companion Rosemary Provenzano and former wife Eileen. May he rest in peace. Services Wednesday, February 24, 1999, 11am at Gutterman's, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Sports of The Times; This Scandal Has No Life In the Pubs
description: BEFORE a single page of another special report on the Lewinsky-long Olympic scandal was unveiled yesterday in New York, one could hear Bud Greenspan editing it all out of his next documentary film.

title: Old-Timers Help Dallas Come of Age
description: The Dallas Stars are so old that ''Remember the Alamo'' is not merely a figurative expression. The veterans don't mind that the National Hockey League will expand to 30 teams in two years because they remember how hard it was for them to earn a job in the six-team league. When the Stars signed a free agent named Hull last summer, one of them said, ''Bobby may have lost a step, but his slap shot will help us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRU, MALCOLM S.
description: BRU-Malcolm S. 84. Died February 18. Of White River Junction, VT. Devoted husband to Dorothea. Loving father to Ronald, Georgina and Elizabeth. Brother to Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFAN, BARBARA
description: LANGFAN-Barbara. Sutton Place Synagogue extends sympathies to our devoted members William and Marion Langfan on the loss of Bill's beloved sister and our longtime member. Condolences to the bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMS, GERHARD
description: HARMS-Gerhard. Montefiore Medical Center and its Board of Trustees are deeply saddened by the death of Gerhard Harms, 92, a respected friend and benefactor of the medical center. Through his support of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, he leaves a legacy to children and their families that will live for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear friends, Lee and Vincent Affinito. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Who's Needlessly Prolonging Life?
description: To the Editor:

title: HARROW INDUSTRIES TO BE ACQUIRED BY INGERSOLL-RAND
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, which makes construction machinery and industrial equipment, said yesterday that it would buy Harrow Industries, a maker of doors, hardware, bath fixtures and electronic security systems. Ingersoll-Rand said it would pay $160 million in cash and assumed debt, but did not provide a breakdown. The company, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., will merge Harrow, of Grand Rapids, Mich., into its Architectural Hardware Group, a leading provider of locks and door products.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUNGES. Sugar futures fell almost 4 percent amid signs of weakening demand from India and Russia, the world's biggest consumers. In New York, sugar for May delivery fell 0.24 cent, to 6.02 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TROWBRIDGE, HARRY NOBLE
description: TROWBRIDGE - Harry Noble. Died December 17, 1998. Services at Manhattan College, Thomas Hall, Saturday, February 27, 1999, 2 PM-5 PM.

title: Who's Needlessly Prolonging Life?; More Community Care
description: To the Editor:

title: An Old Rite Is Invoked To Protect Park's Bison
description: As a few hundred people watched beneath the snow-dappled peaks on the northern edge of this park, Gary Silk, a Lakota Sioux, stripped to the waist. As he stood in the numbing wind, in the shadow of the giant stone arch that greets visitors here, other members of his tribe made two incisions in his back with a surgical scalpel, inserted a stick in each wound, and tied a buffalo skull to each stick with ropes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISSAUER, MARGARETE, NEE NEIDER
description: LISSAUER-Margarete, nee Neider, 96. February 28, 1999. Born April 24, 1902 in Lampertheim, Germany. Devoted wife and mother. Loving Nana to Karen and Arthur Cohen; Lauren and Allison Reddington; Susan Cohen; Hanni and Caroline Silverman; Debra and Jeigh Duran; Jennifer Schlosser; Rochelle, Mark, Charles, William and Henry Rosenberg; Katherine, Edward, Kate and Emily Horowitz. Private services. To our dear Nana, Guten Abend, Gute Nacht (good night).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUALA, ROBIN E.
description: MAUALA-Robin E. G. Passed away on February 21. Beloved wife of Nusi and cherished mother of Mele. Her vivacious character, endless enthusiasm, and generous nature will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service will be held at the U.N. Chapel, February 26th beginning at 5:30PM. The family respectly requests that in lieu of flowers a donation be made in her name to the American Humane Society or any organization that supports wildlife or animal causes.

title: GENERAL CHEMICAL TO BID FOR NOMA INDUSTRIES OF CANADA
description: General Chemical Group Inc. said yesterday that it would offer $220 million, or $6 a share, for Noma Industries, a Toronto-based maker of electrical wire and components for the automotive, appliance and electronic industries. Noma would be integrated into General Chemical's manufacturing and performance-chemicals division, which the company plans to spin off to its shareholders. General Chemical, based in Hampton, N.H., said it planned to take its offer directly to Noma shareholders next week; the deal requires approval by at least two-thirds of them. Class A shares of Noma, which had $265 million in sales last year, fell 35 cents (Canadian) yesterday, to $9.05, or nearly $6 (United States); General Chemical fell 37.5 cents, to $15.

title: Report Says Schools Lack Math and Science Needs
description: Five years after the New York City Board of Education set tough new standards to improve student performance in high school mathematics and science, the system is plagued by shortages of qualified teachers and adequate laboratories, according to a report released yesterday by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, ELBRIDGE T.
description: GERRY-Elbridge T. Died on February 26, at the age of 90, following a short illness at his home in Delhi, NY. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Marjorie Kane, two sons Elbridge T. Jr., of Locust Valley, NY, and Peter G. of Hopewell, NJ, a daughter Marjorie G. Ryland of Beverly, MA, two brothers Edward H. Gerry and Henry A. Gerry, 11 grandchildren and seven great - grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Wednesday, March 10, 1999, at Trinity Church, Wall St and Broadway, NYC, at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Lake Delaware Boys Camp, or The Harness Racing Museum and Hall of Fame, or the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

title: Inquiry Cites Olympic 'Culture' of Impropriety
description: Citing a ''culture of improper gift-giving'' that has enveloped the Olympic movement, an independent United States Olympic Committee commission yesterday recommended a menu of reform that ranged from democratizing the election of International Olympic Committee members to public disclosure of its finances.

title: China's Human Rights Record
description: A disturbing pattern is developing in the Clinton Administration's relationship with China. The more Washington seeks to broaden its agenda with Beijing, the more harshly China treats its democrats and dissidents. In the face of a new wave of political repression in China, President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright must do more than repeat stale complaints and then change the subject to trade. Americans will not support a policy of engagement and improved relations with China if the price is American inaction on human rights abuses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONLAN, REV. THOMAS, O.P.
description: DONLAN-Rev. Thomas, O.P. On February 26, in Paris. His talents and radical goodness shown in his teaching of Thomist theology; editing the Catholic Digest; serving the Catholic News Agency from Rome; working with Catholic Relief Services; the perennial chaplain of the Catholic Actors' Guild and, finally, priest of St. Agnes Church. The priests of the church regret their loss but do so within the Providence that sent him to us and our people. A Months Mind Mass will be offered for Father Donlan at St. Agnes (143 East 43rd St) 6:30 PM, Thursday, March 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PONS, EDUARDO R. JR.
description: PONS-Eduardo R. Jr., MD. Passed away on February 19, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of the late Carmen Bergnes. Reposing at Frank E. description: LANE-Marcia Huhn. 61, of heart failure, February 24, in Greenwich. Service Christ Church, Thursday, 10:30 AM. Burial in Stonington, CT

title: ADVANCE PARADIGM ACQUIRING ANOTHER BENEFIT MANAGER
description: Advance Paradigm Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the pharmaceutical management business of Foundation Health Systems Inc. for $70 million in cash. The combined company would be the nation's largest independent pharmacy benefit manager. Advance Paradigm, based in Irving, Tex., also said it had signed a contract to provide services to Foundation Health, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., one of the largest American managed care companies, for 10 years. Shares of Advance Paradigm jumped $7.4375, or 21 percent, to $43.50. Foundation Health rose 43.75 cents, to $8.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, EILEEN R.
description: SHIELDS-Eileen R. Beloved daughter of Henry Richard and the late Frances. Loving cousin of Sandy Storfer, Ronald and Dennis Shields. She was a psychotherapist for over thirty years and will be sorely missed by her family, friends, colleagues and clients. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Staving Off Blindness in the Tiniest of Infants
description: As a nurse holds the hands and head of one of the seven surviving octuplets born in Houston in December, a doctor peers at the back of the eyes through an ophthalmosocope. In assembly line fashion, the eye doctor examines each child. The aim is to seek the earliest sign of a condition known as retinopathy of prematurity, resulting from abnormal blood vessel growth, and to use a laser to prevent a detached retina, which can cause blindness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Credit Card Consolidation Holds Some Surprises

title: Study Cites Fatal Design Of Sport Utility Vehicles
description: The height and stiff frames of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans are making them unusually lethal to people in the cars they collide with on the nation's roadways, and caused about 2,000 deaths in 1996, Federal regulators said here today.

title: Kajiado Journal; Sometimes a Girl's Best Friend Is Not Her Father
description: Naataosim Mako fiddled with the edge of the desk and fluffed up her skirt, more than a little embarrassed to talk so barely about her young life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, HELEN F.
description: CUNNINGHAM-Helen F., 75. Of Crestwood Village, Whiting, NJ, died Sunday, February 28, 1999 at Community Medical Center, Toms River, NJ. Born in New York City June 6, 1923, she lived in Norwalk, CT prior to moving to Whiting, NJ in 1998. She worked for the Social Security Administration in Norwalk, CT for 5 years, retiring in 1987. She previously worked for the City of Norwalk, CT. She was a 1945 graduate of Cornell University, NY, with a degree in French Literature. She is survived by one sister, Caroline Cunningham of Whiting, NJ; two nieces, Frances Reeve of Whiting, NJ and Angela David of Hamburg, Germany; one nephew, Benjamin Reeve of Hamburg, Germany; and three loyal friends, Josephine Ryan of Germantown, NY, Anne MacDonald of Florida, and Cynthia Bullen of Whiting, NJ. For information, call Manchester Memorial Funeral Home, Whiting, New Jersey.

title: Ebay Stock Falls On U.S. Inquiry
description: The on-line auction site Ebay, which has already gained the attention of New York City consumer officials, now says it is under Federal investigation for ''possible illegal transactions.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURER, RICHARD F.
description: MAURER-Richard F., of NYC. Beloved father of Scott and David Maurer and Melinda A. Sawyer. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave., NYC, Thursday, 12-3 PM. Funeral service private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, ELIZABETH PEACH
description: LEONARD-Elizabeth Peach, 87. On February 22, in Albuquerque, N.M. She was preceded in death by her husband Richard Anthony Leonard. Born in Emporia, KS, a graduate of the University of Kansas, she lived for many years in New York City and Larchmont. She was a board member of the Riverdale Children's Association, Candlelight Concerts benefiting the Wilton Library Association, and Senior Warden of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church. She is survived by her sons Anthony Charles of Albuquerque, NM, Amb. John Peter of Falls Church, VA and Richard William of New York City, seven grandchildren and one great-grandson. Burial service will be at St. Matthew's, Wilton, CT on March 13, at 11AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday in Business Day about how the International Business Machines Corporation is addressing privacy concerns raised by a traceable serial number on Intel Corporation's new Pentium III computer chip misstated Intel's response to those concerns. Intel has suggested that computer manufacturers install an on-off switch in each computer that allows the user to hide the chip's serial number when the switch is turned off. Intel has not suggested that manufacturers leave the switch turned off.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOWELL, HAROLD OSGAR, SR.
description: HOWELL-Harold Osgar, Sr. Beloved partner and friend, died February 28, 1992. Sorely missed. Tommy and Vi

title: QUANTUM SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF TRACKING STOCK PLAN
description: Shares of the Quantum Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives, rose 19 percent yesterday after the company announced a plan to expand its computer network storage unit and split its shares into separate stocks to ease the tracking of its two businesses. Shares of Quantum rose $3.125, to $19.5625. Disk drives ''tend to trade at more of a discount,'' said Michael A. Brown, the chief executive of Quantum, whereas more stable businesses like tape and storage media ''trade at a higher multiple.'' The tracking stocks, he said, are ''an opportunity to value two different businesses in their own way.'' The plan requires the approval of shareholders and regulators. Quantum is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: Notre Dame Turns Back Rutgers Rally
description: The game was still far from over as Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw sent her team onto the floor midway through the second half. But in the middle of shouting out instructions, she looked as if she was about to cry when she spotted Niele Ivey making her way to the bench, struggling on crutches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, PAUL
description: SCHMIDT-Paul. Died on Friday, February 19, 1999. Poet, teacher, actor, multi-lingual translator of works by Rimbaud, Chekov, Khlebnikov, Euripides, Plato, and Brecht, among many others. Through his contributions to the game, not only as a player, but as Davis Cup coach, author and as Tournament Director, and driving force behind the U.S. Open, he was affectionately known as ''Mr. Tennis.'' A warm, gracious and committed supporter of tennis, Billy will be deeply missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his sons, W. Pike and W. Pike, and family.

The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dear friend, a highly respected member of the Jewish community, and member of a family associated with the University's growth for some four decades. She and her late husband, Hyman, brothers Leon A. Miller and the late Ira I. Miller, and other family members established YU's Andrew N. and Rose Miller Chair in the History of Zionism and Modern Israel in memory of their parents, initial Founders of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINN, RICHARD R.
description: SHINN-Richard R. The directors, officers and employees of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company express sadness at the death of our former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, Richard R. Shinn. In true Horatio Alger fashion, he rose from the mail desk in 1939 to head the company. He spent a distinguished forty-nine year career at MetLife, where his dynamic leadership and personal warmth are legendary. Mr. Shinn was elected president in 1969 and assumed the additional position of chief executive officer in 1973. He became chairman of the board and chief executive officer in 1980. He retired in 1983 and continued service to the company as a director until 1988, and thereafter as a valued advisor. Ever a modest man, he attributed his success to good luck and timing. Mr. Shinn guided the company through a decade of tremendous change. Under his direction, MetLife entered multi-line marketing, established regional offices around the country and formed new subsidiaries. Mr. Shinn was known for his energy and common touch. Widely respected for his business acumen, his guidance was sought by corporations, business and charitable organizations. A member of many boards and commissions, he gave generously of his time and talent. His commitment to New York City in good times and bad was unwavering. He earned the respect of business and civic leaders for his wisdom and his gift as a problem solver. His untiring devotion to civic and community activities left us in awe of his drive and ability. The MetLife family extends its sympathy to his wife, Marion, two daughters, Kathleen Clark and Patricia Grossthanner, and his son, John, a MetLife vice president, and his grandchildren and greatchildren. We will miss our friend and colleague, Dick Shinn. We are richer for the privilege of having known him.

title: Roman a Gripe Stirs Flames Among French
description: Michel Houellebecq is an unlikely new star of French letters. Slightly built, with thinning hair and a melancholic mien, he chews nervously on a succession of cigarettes, mumbling when he is not sighing or silent. He describes himself as a manic-depressive who becomes excited only when he is writing. His fiction, which he concedes is fairly autobiographical, reflects a bleak and loveless world.

title: XYLAN SHARES RISE 33% ON ALCATEL ACQUISITION
description: Shares of the Xylan Corporation rose $8.8125, or 33 percent, to $35.75, yesterday as investors reacted to the news that it had agreed to be purchased by Alcatel S.A., the big French maker of phone equipment, for $2 billion in cash. Alcatel, which already owns 6 percent of Xylan, will pay $37 for each remaining share, a 37 percent premium over Xylan's closing price on Monday. Boards of both companies have approved the offer. The acquisition gives Alcatel sophisticated Internet equipment and expansion in the American computer-networking market. Shares of Xylan had already risen 40 percent in the last two weeks as investors speculated that it might be acquired.

title: Unexplained Strategies on Iraq
description: Without ever saying as much, the White House seems to have shifted its military strategy in Iraq to advance the goal of toppling Saddam Hussein. The change has become clear in recent days as Washington escalated its air strikes against Iraq. The bombing raids appear designed to punish the Iraqi military in hopes that disgruntled officers will lead a rebellion against Mr. Hussein rather than suffer further losses of men and equipment.

title: Republicans Fight Counsel Law Challenge
description: Several House Republicans challenged an assertion by the Clinton Administration today that the independent counsel law should be permitted to fade into extinction, using a hearing into the law's future to pose pointed questions about what other safeguards exist against unlawful conduct by high-ranking Federal officials.

title: True Love, or Love's Truths, Circa 1788
description: ''La Molinara'' (''Th Mill Girl'') by Giovanni Paisiello came out in 1788, the year after ''Don Giovanni,'' and was one of the hit shows of the time, performed across Europe, including in Vienna, where Beethoven presumably saw it before dashing off a set of piano variations on its catchiest number. But it seems not to have been done in this country until last Sunday, when the American Opera Musical Theater Company offered a production to inaugurate a series of Sunday afternoon opera performances at Town Hall.

title: Brooklyn Jury Rejects Charge Of Murder in Officer's Killing

title: Big Money, No Oversight

Although he accepted some donations after he resigned from office, he paid the bulk of his legal debts himself. Benefiting from cash gifts while in the White House apparently was unthinkable even to our most disgraced President.

title: As America's Meat Changes, So Must the Cook; Today's Marinades: Just for Flavor
description: ANCIENT Romans lucky enough to have game to eat knew just what to do with it. First, they hung it up to age and tenderize it. Then they may have bathed the meat in wine, honey, herbs and spices intended not only to soften the tough, sinewy meat but also to flavor it, and perhaps to obscure the funky smell that develops from old-fashioned aging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELION, GERTRUDE B.
description: ELION-Gertrude B. The Hunter College Foundation mourns the passing of Gertrude Elion, a Nobel Prize winner in Medicine whom Hunter College also knew as a loyal alumna. A longtime trustee of The Hunter College Foundation, she supported her alma mater throughout her long and productive life and served as a role model to generations of Hunter students-especially women-who aspired to a career in science. She was instrumental in the development of a host of drugs to combat some of the most virulent diseases known, and she was active in the professional community: she was president of the American Association for Cancer Research, a member of the National Cancer Advisory Board, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences, among others. Though officially retired for a number of years, she continued to teach and conduct research. She received more than 25 honorary doctorates, including one from Hunter College, which will always remember her for both her scientific accomplishments and her generosity to her College. Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair Floria V. Lasky, Co-Chair The Hunter College Foundation

title: Opulence Redolent Of France

title: DHL AND U.S. POSTAL SERVICE TO MAKE DELIVERIES IN EUROPE
description: DHL Worldwide Express Inc., the closely held package-delivery company, plans to make deliveries in the United States and Europe with the United States Postal Service, charging less than Federal Express or United Parcel Service. The arrangement was reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday. The service will deliver packages as heavy as 70 pounds, guaranteeing two-day deliveries and telephone and Internet service for tracking the packages. It will be available in mid-April at post offices in Boston; Charlotte, N.C.; Chicago; Houston; Miami; Minneapolis; New York; Philadelphia; Phoenix; San Francisco; San Jose, Calif., and Washington.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Arkansas Roots, New York Panache; Clintons Seem Suited to Local Political and Social Scenes
description: They cause traffic jams of epic proportions. They hold so many Manhattan fund-raisers that even their Democratic allies complain. They have endorsed policies that have infuriated labor unions, hospital officials, advocates for the poor, immigrants and, oh yes, Republicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSBERG, FRANCES
description: GLASSBERG-Frances. March 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Nat Glassberg, dear mother of Andrew (Leslie) Glassberg, loving grandmother of Hope Glassberg. Our dear Aunt and friend.

title: Raise Leaves a Bitter Taste With Posada
description: Jorge Posada was escorted into Brian Cashman's office at Legends Field after an intrasquad game today, knowing that he was about to learn how much the Yankees will pay him to be their starting catcher this season. Posada entered the fourth-floor office feeling hopeful and exited it feeling bitter.

title: DNA Trick Leads to Arrest in 3 Murders
description: A man arrested 10 days ago in Miami after he fled there with a teen-age girl was charged yesterday with three unsolved murders, in part through a DNA sample that was secretly taken from him while he was in custody, law enforcement officials said.

title: Boston's Police Solution
description: As the current furor over New York City policing has shown, African-Americans today face few dilemmas more painful than the tension between the need to safeguard their neighborhoods and the need to safeguard their rights.

title: Ethiopia Is Celebrating, But Perhaps Too Soon
description: Tesfay Hadush, a Government health inspector, rode eight hours in a bus today to celebrate one of the defining events in his nation's history: On this date in 1896, Ethiopian soldiers crushed the Italian Army near Adwa, a rare victory by an African army over a European one.

title: Academic Jargon Is a Cover; Ugly May Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry L. Rossoll, Who Drew Smokey Bear, Is Dead at 89
description: Harry L. Rossoll, a Forest Service illustrator whose ''Smokey Says'' newspaper cartoons helped make Smokey Bear almost as famous as Santa Claus and an almost universally recognized symbol of forest fire safety, died last Thursday at a hospital near his home in Atlanta. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the play ''Snakebit'' misidentified the actor at the right and the character he portrays. He was David Alan Basche in the role of Jonathan -- not Geoffrey Nauffts, who does play Michael.

description: Ninth-seeded John F. Kennedy High School of the Bronx ousted top-seeded Paul Robeson of Brooklyn from the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs last night in what most would term an upset. But not Kennedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRACTENBERG, HARRY

He was predeceased by his beloved wife Lillian, and is survived by his daughter and sonin-law, Monica and Jonathan Kantrowitz of Fairfield, CT., two grandchildren, Bethany and Ralph, & by several nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday (today) March 3, 1999, at 12:00 noon from the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: Tapioca Moves Beyond Its Pudding Phase
description: THE appetizer was a vision in shades of pink and green. Chunks of coral-tinged Alaskan king crab and matchstick cremini mushrooms topped a frothy sea of moss-colored bubbles. The flavors of the buttery, slightly briny crab and the earthy, sweet mushrooms were delicious and familiar. But as for the satiny bubbles, if it did not say so on the menu, would anyone have guessed they were tapioca?

title: NATO Said to Rule Out Kosovo Reaction
description: Although NATO remains poised to act, the United States and its NATO allies have no intention of launching punitive strikes against Yugoslav military targets at this point despite an army buildup and renewed fighting in Kosovo, Administration officials and NATO diplomats said today.

title: Horace Tapscott, Jazz Pianist And Community Advocate, 64
description: Horace Tapscott, whose accomplishments as a jazz pianist and band leader were matched by his legacy as a local community organizer, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 64.

title: A Man of Two Names And at Least Two Moods
description: David Johansen's career has traveled back through time: from the 1970's protopunk of the New York Dolls to the straightforward rock of his solo albums, and then, as Buster Poindexter, in rediscoveries of old rhythm-and-blues and party songs. (Lately, Buster Poindexter has led a Latin-tinged band, Buster's Spanish Rocketship.) Under his own name at the Bottom Line on Thursday night, Mr. Johansen looked back another few decades, strumming an acoustic guitar and singing blues and hillbilly songs that date back as far as the 1920's.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Technology Issues Clearly In a Correction
description: Any doubts that technology stocks were undergoing a correction evaporated yesterday as yet another prominent maker of computer equipment, the 3Com Corporation, announced that its sales and earnings would fall short of expectations.

title: COLUMBIA/HCA TO SELL HOSPITAL ASSETS TO NET $65 MILLION
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the largest American operator of hospitals, will sell its half of the joint operation of three hospitals in Cleveland and a fourth in Canton, Ohio. Columbia/HCA operates the hospitals with the Sisters of Charity of St. Augustine Health System through the Caritas Healthcare Partnership and Canton Healthcare Partnership. Its stake will be purchased by the sisters and the Cleveland-based University Hospitals Health System. The company is also selling its portion of Ohio Health Choice, a preferred provider organizations. Columbia/HCA, which is under a Federal investigation into its Medicare billing practices, will net about $65 million from the transaction.

title: MICROSOFT BUYS 5% STAKE IN DIALOGIC AND EXPANDS PACT
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it would buy a 5 percent stake in the Dialogic Corporation for $24.2 million and enter a $20 million licensing and service pact with Dialogic to expand in telecommunications. Dialogic, which electronically links telephones and computers, will receive the $20 million over four years for product development, support and licensing of its products. The agreements expand the companies' previous joint development of standards for Internet voice transmission and could make it easier for software developers to write programs for voice transmissions over the Internet, voice recognition and call centers, analysts said. Shares of Dialogic rose $3.125, to $34, while Microsoft fell $3.1875, to $148.5625.

title: In a Glove Compartment, New Clues To 'Lear'
description: Put off by the prospect of any more radio blather about Monica Lewinsky or Latrell Sprewell, I decided before setting out on a recent drive to rummage through the glove compartment for any books on tape I might have stored for future listening. There I found a recording of a BBC radio production of ''King Lear'' with Alec Guinness as Lear that had arrived with a Modern Library edition of Shakespeare's tragedies. Having always been intrigued by ''Lear'' as supposedly Shakespeare's most difficult play to stage and having once promised myself to understand its text completely, I stuck the first of its two cassettes into the tape deck and started off on my trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEVILLE, ANN ADAMS
description: MANDEVILLE-Ann Adams. Buffy Mandeville died peacefully at her home in Fairfield, Connecticut on the evening of March 1, in her seventy-second year. She is mourned by her daughter Meredith Hollis and sons Christopher, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, & William Mandeville, her son-in-law James Hollis, and daughters-inlaw Claire, Olivia, Nancy, Anne & Maribel Mandeville, her brother Dean Adams and her former husband Hubert T. Mandeville. She will also be missed by her devoted grandchildren Erinn, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Elizabeth, Courtney, Kempton, Turner, Allison, Willie, Adelaide, Ariel, Paulina, Carlos, Miguel, Henry and Estelle. A graduate of Dana Hall & Vassar College, she will be remembered for her loyal and effective handson service to many institutions, including the Fairfield Women's Exchange, the Garden Club of America (for whom she was a widely respected judge), Trinity Parish and the Pequot Library of Southport, CT, Bridgeport Hospital, the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County, and the Dana Hall and Fairfield Country Day Schools. She was a member of the Colony Club and the Country Club of Fairfield. A person of exceptional character, probity and steadfastness, she loved and enjoyed her family, her friends and their children. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Southport, CT., on Saturday, March 6th, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to Bridgeport Hospital or the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County.

title: The Struggles Between Something Old and Something New
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: THE CHEF
description: MAYBE you've had this experience. You're still half asleep, waiting in line to get your morning coffee and bagel. You wait and wait, just taking in all the great aromas, and then the guy behind the counter calls out, ''Next!'' with typical New York impatience, and it's you, you're next, and all of a sudden you're confused. ''Give me an everything bagel,'' you say -- it was the only thing you could think of -- and it turns out to be perfect. It always is. It's got a ton of flavor, and a taste that goes on forever.

title: INTUIT TO ACQUIRE COMPUTING RESOURCES FOR $200 MILLION
description: Intuit Inc., the maker of personal-finance software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Computing Resources Inc. for $200 million in cash and stock, to expand its product offerings for small businesses. Intuit makes popular titles like Quicken and Quick Books. Computing Resources manages payroll services. Intuit has been using Computing Resources to support the payroll function of its Quick Books accounting software since October, and the acquisition advances its goal of being ''an essential resource for small businesses,'' said the company's chief executive, William H. Harris Jr.
