She was ''Grandma Honey'' to the five Hochfelder boys and their wives: Jim and Ellen, Tom and Lynda, John and Janet, Andrew and Patricia, Peter and Stacy; and ''Great-Grandma Honey'' to Amy and Scott, Adam and Amy, Lauren, David, Jason, Julie, Josh, Alyssa, Robyn, Jake, Harrison and Charles; and great-great-grandmother to Samantha. After our mother Patricia Beldoch Hochfelder died in 1981, Honey was our surrogate mother, advisor, mentor and best friend to five generations at the same time. Her beautiful legacy will endure forever. The Hochfelder Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINN, RICHARD
description: SHINN-Richard. It is with heartfelt sadness that the Board, Staff, and friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Richard Shinn. A dear friend and tireless leader, Mr. Shinn served us as an esteemed member and Vice-Chairman of the Board of Directors, as Director Emeritus, and Co-Chair of the Directors Emeriti Council. He was also the Chairman and CEO of MetLife and the Executive ViceChairman of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Shinn generously gave of himself through his service on numerous Lincoln Center committees, including the Committee for the Future, the Steering Committee for the 25th Anniversary Celebration, and the New Building Committee. Mr. Shinn's warmth, faith, energy, and fierce dedication to this institution have been a source of inspiration for us all. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Marion, his daughters, Kathleen Clark and Patricia Grossthanner, his son, John, and his seven grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by us and all who knew him. Beverly Sills, Chairman Martin E. Segal, Chairman Emeritus Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Ex-Police Chief Recounts His Beating of Anwar
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Abdul Rahim Noor, the police chief who beat Anwar Ibrahim in September, offered for the first time his account of the incident in testimony Tuesday that sharply contrasted with that of police officers who witnessed the beating as well as with Mr. Anwar's account.

title: Nassau to Pay $500,000 In Jail Beating
description: One day after a Federal jury found a veteran Nassau County jail guard liable for the beating of a mentally retarded inmate, Nassau officials abruptly agreed yesterday to pay the former inmate $500,000 to settle his civil rights lawsuit against the county.

title: Going Live, for Once
description: ''All That,'' a sketch comedy and variety show that anchors the Saturday night lineup on Nickelodeon, has often been called '' 'Saturday Night Live' for Kids.'' This weekend, it will be exactly that.

title: CISCO TO ACQUIRE 400 ACRES FOR NEW SILICON VALLEY SITE
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the Internet networking company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire more than 400 acres in the North Coyote Valley in San Jose, Calif., for a new site that may house up to 20,000 employees. The new location will nearly double Cisco's landholdings in Silicon Valley. The company, based in San Jose, currently employs more than 10,000 people in Silicon Valley and more than 17,000 others at sites around the world. The new location will be Cisco's largest business site, with about seven million square feet of office space.

But when Hillary Rodham Clinton arrives in New York today to give speeches, meet with supporters and tour schools, the visit will instantly be seen as the first exploratory trip of a potential Senate candidate from New York.

Blue,'' because the first five episodes this season all involved the illness and eventual death of the character played by Jimmy Smits.

title: LUCENT IN $50 MILLION DEAL FOR LOCAL AREA NETWORK UNIT
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy the Ethernet local area network business of the closely held Enable Semiconductor for about $50 million. A local area network is a group of computers connected with coaxial cables, optical fibers or standard telephone lines. The deal will give Lucent expertise in Ethernet's technology for these networks. Lucent will make the purchase through its Microelectronics Group, which manufactures integrated circuits and electronic components for the computer and communications industries. Its shares fell $2.9375 yesterday, to $99.9375.

title: Topics of The Times; Living On at Riverdale High
description: There is no immortality quite like the immortality of the comics. John Goldwater, the man who in 1941 invented Archie, Betty, Veronica, Jughead and the other denizens of Riverdale High, died last Friday at the age of 83. Bob Montana, the artist who gave those characters faces, died in 1975. Yet life in Riverdale goes on, updated but otherwise almost unchanged.

title: RJR Nabisco Selling International Assets
description: An official of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that the company was seeking to sell its international tobacco operations and had received bids from at least five other companies, including the Philip Morris Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, DR. JOHN
description: DONNELLY-Dr. John. West Hartford, CT. Died on February 18, 1999. Born in 1914 and educated in England, he received his medical degree at the University of Liverpool Medical School in 1938. At the end of WWII he entered psychiatric training at the University of London and received his diploma of Psychological Medicine in 1948. In 1949 he joined the staff of The Institute of Living in Hartford and in 1965 was named Psychiatrist-inChief and Chief Executive Officer of the Institute. He retired in 1979, continuing at the Institute until 1984 as Senior Consultant. An eminent psychiatrist with a national and international reputation he was President of the Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry and of the National Association of Private Psychiatric Hospitals. He is survived by his wife, Mabel C. Donnelly, and by his children, Mavis J. Donnelly, M.D. and James M. Donnelly, M.D. and three grandchildren.

title: Business Travel; A rising number of airlines are making the case that a picture can be worth a thousand words.
description: IT'S a bird. It's a plane. It's . . . Strauss? Pokemon cartoon characters? The Union Jack? Actually, it is all three -- or soon will be at airports around the world, as more and more airlines discover that a picture can indeed be worth a thousand words.

title: There's Only So Much You Can Swallow
description: SOME might consider it unladylike, but the Baroness Philippine de Rothschild does it. I know that May-Elaine de Lencquesaing does it because I've done it with her. And Serena Sutcliffe does it all the time.

title: Earnings Top Expectations At Two Large Retailers
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Dayton Hudson Corporation, two large retailers, reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were higher than expected, aided by the economy's strength, which spurred sales of home goods and clothing.

title: About New York; The Draperies Try to Match The Shoppers
description: DESPITE the promise of Orchard Street's sylvan name, who needs trees lining its sidewalks? This Lower East Side shopping paradise is a bargain-hunter's Garden of Eden, with dozens of leather jackets and bags dangling from awnings and waiting to be plucked. And while it isn't exactly a pastoral symphony, the kinetic come-ons from hawkers provide a steady sound track for a stroll.

title: $50,000 Offered to Tall, Smart Egg Donor

title: A Winner in the Pop Lottery; Nurturing an 'Overnight' Success, 9 Years in the Making

Mr. Mullins, a Georgia-based singer-songwriter, grinned while Regis Philbin quizzed him about his recent Grammy nomination. In his worn brown jacket and rumpled blond hair, Mr. Mullins looked as if he would be more comfortable discussing poetry in a Village bar.

Giuliani's more ambitious political goals: to establish a voucher program in which tax dollars would be used to send children to private schools.

title: The Fight in George Bush's Future
description: Since so many Republicans have proclaimed Gov. George W. Bush of Texas as their choice for President, it came as no surprise yesterday when Mr. Bush announced that he would form an exploratory committee. But moving from someone widely mentioned to someone actively running for the job is a huge leap in American politics, especially with a party in such disarray. A clear sign of the troubles Mr. Bush would be stepping into also came yesterday, as Patrick Buchanan announced his candidacy. Mr. Buchanan's full-throated opposition to free trade and immigration is certain to be challenged by Mr. Bush if he runs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CURTIS L.
description: CARLSON-Curtis L. Minnesota entrepreneur. Founder of Carlson Companies. Mr. Carlson died Friday, February 19, after suffering a stroke on February 10. He was 84. He retained and enjoyed an active role as company chairman until his last day. Born July 9, 1914, in Minneapolis, Mr. Carlson was recognized for his generosity, integrity and entrepreneurial spirit. Known worldwide as the ''ultra-entrepreneur'', he founded the Gold Bond Stamp Company in 1938 with a $55 loan and a desire to succeed. After World War II, the business grew dramatically. Two-thirds of American households saved stamps, and Gold Bond captured about one-third of the market. Mr. Carlson's ''Horatio Alger'' qualities were key to the continued expansion of his business, which has become one of the largest privatelyheld companies in the world. To reflect its global expansion and diversification, the corporation became Carlson Companies, Inc., in 1973. Today, Carlson Companies is an international leader in providing hospitality, travel and marketing services and solutions to corporate clients and consumers. The company operates in more than 140 countries. Its brands employ 160,000 people worldwide and generated more than $22 billion in systemwide revenues in 1998. Carlson Companies brands and services include Regent International Hotels, Radisson Hotels Worldwide, Country Inns & Suites By Carlson, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, T.G.I. Friday's restaurants, Carlson Leisure Group (leisure travel) and Carlson Marketing Group, the largest relationship marketing company in the world. In 1997, Mr. Carlson was instrumental in establishing a global partnership with Accor of Paris, which combined the business travel interests of both companies under the name Carlson Wagonlit Travel. A 1938 graduate of the University of Minnesota, Mr. Carlson was a staunch supporter of his alma mater. In 1986, he made a $25 million gift to the university, at that time the largest single gift ever given to a public university. To recognize his contributions, the university renamed its school of management the Curtis L. Carlson School of Management. He and Arleen (Martin) met at the university and were married in 1938. Together, the couple was devoted to strengthening family bonds with their children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Carlson's honors include the prestigious Linnean Medal, Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, presented by H.M. Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden; the Viking Baron Award from the American Swedish Cultural Foundation; the Horatio Alger Award; the Swedish-American of the Year Award, Stockholm, Sweden, in 1981; the Town and Country magazine ''Philanthropist of the Year'' Award, 1987-1988; the International Citizen of the Year

title: An ARCO Push in Alaska
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it would increase production in Alaska when its new Alpine field begins operating in mid-2000. Despite low oil prices, ARCO expects to produce 317,000 barrels of oil a day in Alaska this year, 325,000 barrels a day in 2000 and 347,000 barrels a day in 2001, said Kevin Meyers, president of the company's ARCO Alaska unit. ARCO Alaska said it will cut capital spending to $450 million this year, down $120 million, or 21 percent, from 1998. Alpine accounts for almost half of the budget, the company said. Alpine holds estimated proven and potential reserves of 365 million barrels.

For decades now movie stars and their body doubles have been making naked or near-naked cinematic love, skinny-dipping in blue lagoons and showering on screen, all the better to show off their glistening, washboard-flat abdomens, firm derrieres and gym-sculptured or surgery-enhanced chests. The human body is a beautiful thing, our culture suddenly proclaimed.

description: A split emerged in court today among a group of black farmers who had sued the Federal Government charging that the Department of Agriculture had discriminated against them in denying or delaying approval of loans.

title: Lonesome Ranch

This time, among the major broadcast networks, the dubious distinction will go to a UPN period drama, ''Legacy,'' about a horse-ranching family in Kentucky in the 1880's. While it earned some critics' praise, few viewers were interested. It clocked a 1.1 average Nielsen rating for the February sweep period, or 1.09 million homes, and a 2 share, meaning 2 percent of sets in use. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Latest Discovery in Scholarly Journals Is Runaway Subscription Costs
description: Trying to keep up with the newest advances in microbiology? You may want to consider taking out a second mortgage. A year's subscription to the academic journal FEMS Microbiology Letters now costs $5,005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FYBISH, PEGGY ROMANO
description: FYBISH-Peggy Romano. On January 26, 1999, at her Manhattan home. Dearly loved wife and companion since 1971 of Stephen Fybish. Beloved mother of Emily Prager and Nora Elcar, loving grandmother of Lulu Prager. In her chief career as actress Peggy Romano, she combined outward beauty and grace of movement with a voice ranging in tone from gently poetic to powerfully expressive. Born on September 19, 1929, Peggy was first onstage at age five with her British-born actor father, Charles Romano, in ''The Great Waltz'' and with her actress mother, Mary Ricard, in ''The Old Maid''. As a child, she enjoyed the company of such family friends as Leslie Howard, Ruth Gordon, Noel Coward, the Lunts, Basil Rathbone, Judith Anderson and Margalo Gillmore. Her favorite playwrights and producers were Moss Hart, George Kaufman, and Max Gordon. A teenage star in both ''Junior Miss'' and ''Dear Ruth'', she went from Broadway to California with the national touring companies of these plays, performing in theatres in all 48 states during the 1940's. Married and a mother at age 18, she maintained her stage career less intensively through the 1960's. Peggy's brilliant, inquiring mind, keen sense of humor, and numerous talents were a rare combination. She was a painter of colorful landscapes, flowers and portraits, author of two novels, gifted costume designer, cartoonist, puppeteer and dancer. Her letters, diaries, and tape recordings delightfully conveyed her almost photographic memories of her favorite people, places and events, such as the 1991 solar eclipse at Oaxaca, Mexico, described at her memorial service on January 29, 1999. She cared passionately about her family, her country, and the survival of the earth's endangered animals, native cultures and natural habitats. Her knowledge of archaelogy and history enriched her travels to Europe, Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean Isles. In the 1990's, her summer vacations with her husband, Steve, by the tropical seashore of Isla Mujeres, gave her great pleasure. She listened joyously to birdsongs from the trees of Mexico and Manhattan, and the ballet music of Prokofiev's ''Cinderella''. The inspiration she gave to the lives and accomplishments of her two daughters, grandchild, Lulu, and her three husbands-Arthur Prager, Dana Elcar and Stephen Fybish-will always be remembered and cherished.

title: Bronx Girl, Missing for Days, Is Found Slain in Garbage Bin
description: A 13-year-old Bronx girl whose family reported her missing last week was found dead Sunday morning in a garbage bin behind a video store in Co-op City, the police said yesterday.

title: Gamesmanship and Polyphony in Paradise
description: Pomerium's concerts of early choral music typically address both the mind and the heart. In this chamber choir's performances, an analytical listener can focus on the details, innovations and structural niceties of a composer's style, with ample technical support from the program notes by Alexander Blachly, the group's founder and director. But the blend of these 14 singers is such that however analytical one might want to be, it is impossible not to be swept into the sound, or to admire it for its sheer beauty and balance.

title: In a Revolution of Rules, Campuses Go Full Circle
description: Three decades after American college students defiantly threw off the vestiges of curfews, dress codes and dormitory house mothers, a revolution is under way in undergraduate life that may be quieter but no less significant.

title: Abrosimova Comes Alive For UConn
description: For Connecticut's first two Big East tournament games, Svetlana Abrosimova, a 6-foot-2-inch sophomore forward, had been almost in hiding. She scored only 8 points against St. John's and 4 against Georgetown, far below her 17-point average. Some people, forgetting that UConn won those games by 24 and 35 points, wondered why Abrosimova was named last week as the Big East player of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, DR. WILLIAM
description: ETKIN-Dr. William. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of our renowned Professor Emeritus of Anatomy and Structural Biology, who joined the founding faculty of our medical school in 1955 and served with great distinction as a teacher and researcher for more than forty years. His contributions to our institution, and to the advancement of anatomy and zoology, will be long remembered. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean

title: Millionaire Convicted of Murder in Gas Station Fraud Scheme
description: An immigrant from India who prosecutors said built and protected a chain of lucrative gasoline stations with fraud and violence was convicted in Brooklyn yesterday of murder charges that could bring the death penalty.

title: Manhattan Bridge Closed After Drain Cover Breaks
description: The Manhattan Bridge was closed to Brooklyn-bound traffic during the morning rush yesterday after officials discovered a broken drain cover on the upper level of the bridge, city transportation officials said.

title: Top Ad Post Changes Hands At The Times
description: Daniel H. Cohen, the senior vice president for advertising at The New York Times, is resigning to start a television production company that will work in tandem with the Times Electronic Media Company, developing programming to attract an audience of young people more wedded to television than to print journalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALBERT, WILLIAM F.
description: TALBERT-William F. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International records with deep sorrow the death of William F. Talbert, a long-time member of our Board of Directors and Board of Chancellors. Bill was a mentor and friend to many of us when diabetes entered our lives and a loyal supporter of diabetes research for many years. Fighting his own battle with the disease, he maintained a successful career as a professional tennis player, and was a winner of the Davis Cup and a winner for all of us. We will all miss Bill very much and we extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. James M. Lurie, President

title: Fat, in Ducks, Is Beautiful
description: THE part of the duck that scares most people -- the thick layer of fat under the skin -- is actually its best feature, one that makes roast duck a nearly foolproof dish, absolutely suitable for a weeknight meal. The fat keeps the meat juicy even when it's well done -- a distinct advantage, because the breast is best medium rare, but the legs must be cooked through, or nearly so, to be palatable.

title: GERMAN TRAVEL GUIDE PUBLISHER BUYS A U.S. MAP MAKER
description: Langenscheidt K.G., the German publisher of Insight travel guides, said yesterday that it had acquired Hammond Inc., one of the oldest American map companies, to gain Hammond's digital maps and expand its own product line. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Langenscheidt, based in Munich, bought Hammond, which is based in Maplewood, N.J., through its Langenscheidt Publishers Inc. unit in Maspeth, N.Y. Langenscheidt owns the Chicago-based American Map Corporation and regional map brands based in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, ESTHER
description: BERKLEY-Esther, 77 on March 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph, devoted mother of Alan, Janet and Linda; loving grandmother of Joshua, Sara, Sammy, Shannon, Benji and Brett. No wife could have given more; no mother could have loved more. She was adored by her children and grandchildren. She was a blessing and an inspiration to all who knew her and her spirit. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association. Services Thursday 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: He's Got the Moves Off Court, Too; St. John's Point Guard Conquers a Road Fraught With Danger
description: Erick Barkley and Tyrone Grant, their low voices spiked with bravado, had a conversation recently that turned civic pride on its head -- debating which one of them came from the worse Brooklyn neighborhood. Grant -- from Brownsville, ''a few blocks from Mike Tyson,'' he noted -- brought the debate to a quick conclusion when he conceded that Barkley's was ''the worst neighborhood in the world.''

title: Growing Compatibility Issue: Computers and User Privacy
description: The Intel Corporation recently blinked in a confrontation with privacy advocates protesting the company's plans to ship its newest generation of microprocessors with an embedded serial number that could be used to identify a computer -- and by extension, its user.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LLOYD
description: GOLDSTEIN-Lloyd. 86, son of Arthur and Itta. Services Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, Wednesday, March 3, 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, WAYNE
description: BERG-Wayne, FAIA. Costas Kondylis & Associates extend its deepest sympathies to his family and to his colleagues at Pasanella + Klein Stolzman + Berg.

title: Lewinsky Strongly Criticizes Prosecutor
description: In a book to be published later this week, Monica S. Lewinsky is so critical of the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr that several of her friends and associates say they fear that Mr. Starr will become angry and try to revoke her immunity agreement and prosecute her.

title: Garden Tourney Looms As a Feast for the Fans
description: The Big East tournament starts today at Madison Square Garden, and it is expected to be one of the most competitive in years, an extension of a regular season that saw what can best be described as a higher level of parity, with only Connecticut at the top and Boston College at the bottom separated from the rest of the league. That's great news for fans. On the other hand, this tournament will likely have little impact on most of the teams participating.

title: America's Meat Has Changed, And Now It's the Cook's Turn; Where's the taste? One man's answer
description: BRUCE AIDELLS was doing his Cro-Mag non shuffle before the display case at Florence Meat Market in Greenwich Village. Sporting a large leather newsboy cap, jeans and a denim jacket emblazoned with the logo of his sausage company, the bearded and Bunyanesque meat maven shifted from one size 14E foot to the other. A self-described throwback who claims to ''personally consume at least 20 times the national per capita average of beef a year,'' he could barely keep from salivating.

title: Bogota Journal; Garcia Marquez Embraces Old Love (That's News!)
description: He has already won a Nobel Prize, says there are still books he needs to write and is about to celebrate his 72d birthday. So it came as something of a shock to Colombians when the novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez recently bought a money-losing newsmagazine here and then promptly joined the ranks of its reporting staff.

title: No Margin of Error: Cepeda Elected to Hall
description: Five years after he missed election to the Baseball Hall of Fame by 7 votes on the writers' ballot, Orlando Cepeda gained election today with not many more votes than that.

title: A Poetic Concerto Turned Energetic Showpiece
description: A great piece of music, it is good to be reminded, can be many things. Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, with its connection to the Orpheus legend seemingly on again, thanks to persuasive arguments by the musicologist Owen Jander, tends to be presented as a subdued tone poem, shrouded in antiquarian reverence. But it is a concerto, after all, and thus also something of a showpiece.

title: Sports of The Times; No Gretzky, But the Show Does Go On
description: WHEN Nicole Kidman came down with a bronchial infection last week and could not display her acting skill to eager Broadway throngs, the producers closed ''The Blue Room'' a bit early. Miss Kidman regrets, and all that.

title: In America; Working on Poverty
description: Courage is a quality in short supply with politicians of any era, and especially now. So it seemed odd at lunch this week with Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to hear him insist, passionately and un-self-consciously, that now is the time to move on behalf of the perennial underdogs in our society -- the families living in squalor and hopelessness on Indian reservations, or in the economic and social wreckage that has defined Appalachia for decades, or in the worst of our inner cities, which continue to be dangerous and isolated crucibles of despair.

title: BASEBALL: ROUNDUP
description: TORONTO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERO, ADOLPH
description: SPERO-Adolph. On February 13, 1999, age 98. Husband of the late Frances (nee Postman). He is survived by his son Richard. After many years as a merchant he turned to executive recruitment. A private service has been held.

title: High-Rolling Chefs
description: For the first time, Forbes magazine is recognizing chefs as business moguls. The March 22 issue, out on Monday, will include five chefs in the annual Celebrity 100, a listing of the highest paid and most powerful people in various professions. Jean-Georges Vongerichten, Daniel Boulud, Nobu Matsuhisa, Emeril Lagasse and Wolfgang Puck are the top earners.

title: Eye on the Prize (2d, That Is)
description: In a ratings sweep month marked by success for ''event'' programs at most of the networks, the final outcome remains in some doubt until two last events are figured into the total numbers: the opening of an Egyptian tomb on Fox last night and, potentially the biggest event of all, the Barbara Walters interview with Monica S. Lewinsky on ABC tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. 8/16/69-2/23/83. Death devours all lovely things. Miss you every day. Mom and Abb

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFET, SIMEON, M.D.
description: TAFFET-Simeon, M.D. Born March 23, 1929 in Brooklyn, New York. Died on March 1, 1999. Laid to rest on March 2, 1999. Associate Clinical Professor of Opthalmology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Director of Department of Opthalmology, Mount Vernon Hospital from 1985-1993; Director of Ocular Motility Clinic, Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, 1975-1992. Received his Bachelor of Science from Purdue University in 1949 and his medical doctorate from the University of Geneva in 1955. He served his patients in private practice in Mount Vernon, New York from 1960-present. A widower of Renate K. Taffet, he is survived by his dear brother, Bertram Taffet, and his three beloved sons, Jerome Taffet, M.D., Robert Taffet, M.D. and David Taffet, five grandchildren, Zachary, Elizabeth, Rebecca, Charles and Caroline; and his companion, Nora Johnson. In lieu flowers please make donations in his memory to the charity of your choice.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PENN TRAFFIC INC., -- Syracuse, which operates Big Bear, Bilo, Quality and P&C supermarkets in Ohio, West Virginia, Pennsylvania and New York, listed assets of $1.51 billion and liabilities of $1.70 billion as it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on March 1.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sweet Potato To the Rescue
description: FORGET most of what you think you know about sweet potatoes. They aren't yams. They come in more than one variety. And they definitely don't have to be candied to be good.

title: Hewlett Plans To Split in 2 In Revamping
description: Responding to the ever-shifting fortunes of high-technology industries, the Hewlett-Packard Company, the cornerstone of California's Silicon Valley, announced today that it would split into two independent companies, one focusing on computers, printers and scanners, the other on electronic test equipment and medical technology products.

title: Victims Sought the Exotic
description: The American couple killed in the Bwindi Impenetrable Forest in Uganda on Monday had been so captivated by the idea of going to see rare mountain gorillas that they persuaded another couple to accompany them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIN, RITA
description: SCHEIN-Rita. Died on March 1, 1999, in the Bronx, New York. Beloved wife of the late Max Schein, devoted mother of Jack Schein, mother-in-law of Barbara Schein, grandmother of Adam and Evan and friend to Hannah and Eddie Grossman.

Survived by wife of 42 years, Susan (Gray) Chamberlain of New London, NH; 4 daughters, Lisa C. Schimmel of Wayland, MA, Cynthia C. Wright and Stephanie S. Chamberlain both of Watertown, MA., and Heather Chamberlain of Brooklyn, NY; four grandchildren, Sarah A., Jeffrey D., and Kelly L. Schimmel, Robert Gavin Murray Scott; a brother, Willard T. Chamberlain of Pasadena, CA; nieces, nephews, and cousins. Memorial services on Monday, March 8, 1999 at 1:00PM at the Kearsarge Community Presbyterian Church, New London, New Hampshire. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Norris Cotton Cancer Center, One Medical Center Drive, DartmouthHitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH 03766. For information call Chadwick Funeral Service of New London, New Hampshire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERELSON, PAUL
description: PERELSON-Paul. Passed away peacefully on February 21, 1999, his 98th birthday would have been on April 18. Devoted husband for 61 years of the late Hannah (Nee Michaelson.) Beloved father of Samuel (Ruth) and Helen (Julian) Levine; adoring grandfather of Lois Perelson (Stewart) Gross and Lila (Keith) Adwar; loving greatgrandfather of Hannah, Sarah Alice, Benjamin Perelson Gross and Mikaela Adwar. Also survived by sisters Gerry Pulaski and Blanche Klores of Miami, Fl. and brother Morris Perelson of Queens. Private graveside service held on February 22. Shiva observed at the Levine home, 303 West 66 Street, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106 Street, NYC 10025

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEILER, DAVID
description: SEILER-David, 98. On Monday, March 1, 1999 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Shirley. Loving father of Judy Teller and Jane Saltoun. Loving father-in-law of Munir Saltoun. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Teller and Andrew Saltoun. Services Thursday, March 4th, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 12:15 PM.

title: Mastercard Renews World Cup Pact
description: Mastercard International said yesterday that it had renewed its sponsorship of the World Cup soccer tournament with FIFA (Federation Internationale de Football Association), the world governing body for soccer, in an agreement that is estimated to total $140 million over four years for advertising, marketing promotion and sponsorship fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, ALLEN
description: WARDWELL-Allen, 64. Died March 1 of a heart attack while vacationing in Colorado. He was a preeminent specialist in the art of the Northwest Coast Indian shaman, and a senior consultant in American Indian Art and Tribal Art at Christie's in New York. Wardwell, who was educated at Groton, Yale, and New York University, decided against joining the law firm of Davis, Polk and Wardwell, founded by his grandfather and in which his father was a partner, choosing instead to make a career of his passion for fine art. After receiving his Master's in Art History, Wardwell served as head of the Primitive Art Dept at the Art Institute of Chicago from 1960-1973, and was director of the Asia Society Gallery, New York, from 1974-1984. From 1986 to 1990 Wardwell was director of the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in New York. He also taught university courses at various times and, among his many consulting activities was curatorial consultant for African and Oceanic Art at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. Wardwell was the author of several books and catalogues within his fields, including the recently published study of Northwest Coast shamanic Indian art, ''Tangible Visions''. Wardwell was also passionate about music and dancing, went frequently to the Rainbow Room, and could be seen dancing on his roller skates almost every weekend in Central Park. Allen leaves his wife Sally, a daughter Lelia, his sons William and Alexander, his granddaughter Sarah, two sisters Lelia Seidner and Helen DuBois, and his aunt Clarissa Pell. He was the father-in-law of Deborah Wardwell, Henriette Wardwell, and Edmund Mander. He is also survived by several cousins, nieces and nephews and many, many friends. For details about a celebration of Allen's life, please call Edmund Mander 212-665-5373.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBB, PETER JOHN
description: WEBB-Peter John of Los Angeles, CA. On February 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Joanne. Father of Kingsley, grandfather of James, Charlie and Thomas. Brother of Barbara and Cheryl. An Englishman who moved to America in 1983, Peter will always be remembered for his deeply generous heart and his joy in helping others. In lieu of flowers and in support of Peter's love of music, donations may be made to Corporation Jazz America, 900 East Sierra Bonita, LA, CA 90036

title: Brazil Intervenes as Inflation Fear Sends Currency Down
description: Weakened by uncertainty about revisions in the Government's agreement with the International Monetary Fund and growing fears of a rise in inflation, the Brazilian currency continued its slide to a record low against the dollar today, forcing the central bank to intervene for the fourth time in a week.

title: Quakers Stop Tigers' Run of Ivy League Titles
description: PENN 73, PRINCETON 48

Beloved husband of Halo Wines Bauer; devoted father of Libby Bauer of Kensington, MD and Christopher Michael Bauer of Brooklyn, New York; brother of Thomas J., Daniel J., and John F. Bauer. Grandfather of Ryan A. Brown. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street, N.W. on Thursday from 1-4 and 6-9 PM. Funeral liturgy will be held at St. Dominic's Catholic Church, 630 E Street, S.W., Washington, D.C. on Friday, March 5, 1999 at 1:00 PM. Interment Rock Creek Cemetery.

description: SCHMIDT-Paul. Died on Friday, February 19, 1999. Poet, teacher, actor, multi-lingual translator of works by Rimbaud, Chekov, Khlebnikov, Euripides, Plato, and Brecht, among many others. Funeral Mass at St. Francis Xavier Church, 30 West 16 Street, 11AM Tuesday, February 23rd followed by interment at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KULICK, JOYCE
description: KULICK-Joyce. The Board of Governors and Members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member on Saturday, February 20, 1999. She will be missed. Services were held February 22, 1999 at Forest Lawn Cemetery, Pompano Beach, FL. Melvin Michaelson, President

title: Isles Play for Pride as Trade Rumors Swirl
description: As another dreary season nears its merciful end, some of the Islanders are playing for more than pride. Some of them must prove they deserve to stay on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNES, BENEDICT
description: MAGNES-Benedict, 84. Of White Plains, N.Y. died Friday, February 12th, 1999. He is survived by his loving family; his wife Frances, his sons Jeff and Carol Magnes, Joel and Candice Magnes, also three grandchildren John, Andy & Jason Magnes. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 25, 1999 at 2PM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, MYRON E.
description: SCHOEN-Myron E. The Officers, Trustees, and staff of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations note with profound sadness the death of our dear friend and former staff member. A deeply devoted Reform Jew, for some thirty years Myron ably directed the office of Synagogue Administration with rare and caring devotion. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife Charlotte, his children, brother, and all his loved ones. Jerome H. Somers, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Emeritus

title: Topics of The Times; Death of a Catalogue
description: The word ''bankruptcy'' has an air of finality, but the reality often does not. Companies go bankrupt, then re-emerge with former creditors as the owners. Customers may not even notice.

title: Six Whose Path to Excellence Was on the Mean Streets of Adversity
description: It is no small feat to earn a 95 average at the Humanities Preparatory Academy in Greenwich Village and to graduate at the top of a class of 158. It is almost unheard of to pull it off in two years.

title: Political Memo; Bush Gives Texans Campaign Scoop
description: Under the hottest sun of the year and with a stiffening wind whirling the leaves into a frenzy, Gov. George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, sat on patio chairs behind the Governor's Mansion today before several dozen reporters from Texas and almost made the announcement that everyone has been waiting for.

title: Choreographer Who Demands and Receives Much
description: The performance of ''Esplanade'' that opens the Academy Award-nominated documentary ''Dancemaker,'' about the Paul Taylor Dance Company and its celebrated choreographer, is filmed from the wings of the stage. There the dancers can be seen preparing to spring into action, and they can be heard breathing heavily afterward, moaning in relief. That signals the mostly blisters-and-all approach of this vivid group portrait, which extends beyond Mr. Taylor's creative processes to offer an overview of lives utterly devoted to dance. Opening today at the Film Forum, it's a must for anyone who reveres modern dance with even an iota of the passion seen onscreen.

title: The Big East Belongs to Abrosimova
description: For Connecticut's first two Big East tournament games, Svetlana Abrosimova, a 6-foot-2-inch sophomore forward, had been almost in hiding. She scored only 8 points against St. John's and 4 against Georgetown, far below her 17-point average. Some people, forgetting that UConn won those games by 24 and 35 points, wondered why Abrosimova was named last week as the Big East player of the year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Feb. 12 about a Federal appeals court ruling that upheld the tax-exempt status of a charity that hired fund-raisers who kept most of the money they collected referred incompletely to the involvement of a lawyer, Thomas Troyer. Besides being a nonprofit law specialist at the firm of Caplan & Drysdale in Washington, he has been counsel of record for a group that filed a brief opposing the charity's position.

title: Richard R. Shinn, Retired Metropolitan Life Chief, Dies at 81
description: Richard R. Shinn, a retired chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who was active in the arts and civic affairs and helped stave off New York City's fiscal crisis in the 1970's, died Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., after a long battle with leukemia. He was 81.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. on Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday, February 25 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Jansen Memorial Hospice, Tuckahoe, New York 10707.

title: Man Admits He Defied The Embargo on Iran
description: A Perth Amboy businessman admitted in Federal court yesterday that he exported automobile parts to Iran despite an embargo imposed in 1995, officials said.

description: BURMAN-Frederick. Adored husband of Marilyn. Loving father, friend and mentor of Steve (Alexandra) and the late Rick. Beloved son of Faye. Dearest brother of Don. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin who he only knew shortly but loved unconditionally. Services Thursday, 9:45 AM, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St.

title: Revelation Meets Millennium Madness
description: APOCALYPSE PRETTY SOON

Loving mother - in - law of Seymour Schwartz, Susan Retzky and George Peppas. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Thursday 11:00 AM at Mount Judah Cemetery, Cypress Hills Avenue, Ridgewood, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, IRA, M.D.
description: MINTZ-Ira, M.D. The Officers and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the death of their esteemed member and colleague, Ira Mintz. A ground-breaking pioneer in the field of psychosomatic medicine, he authored numerous original papers and co-edited three outstanding books including what has become a classic work on anorexia nervosa and bulimia. His brilliant scholarship and patient understanding will be deeply missed. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nancy, his children, Karen, Susan and Robert, and his grandchildren. Daniel Papernik, M.D., President Arthur Lew, M.D., Secretary

title: Inquiry Finds Queens Superintendent Misled Parents About Pupil's Gun
description: A Queens school superintendent deliberately misled parents about an incident last year in which a gun was confiscated from a third grader by claiming the weapon looked like a toy, according to a report yesterday by a school investigator, who recommended that the superintendent be fired.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column on Jan. 13, about French wines that acquired an ''off'' taste from contamination by an insecticide used on wood in some wineries' cellars, included several erroneous references to the origin of the problem. A correction appears today on page F9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESMOND, TRUDY
description: DESMOND-Trudy. Peacefully at Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, February 19, singer Trudy Desmond, loving sister of Ellen and Jeffrey, beloved daughter of Ethel and the late Raphael Salwen. She will be dearly missed by all those who experienced the joy of knowing her personally and professionally. Shiva will be at Trudy's home between Tuesday, February 23 and Friday, February 26 at 174 Dewbourne Ave, Toronto. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 28, for time and place call 416-466-5020

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEININGER, ANDREAS
description: FEININGER - Andreas. The Trustees and Staff of the International Center of Photography remember with fondness and respect the pioneer photojournalist who for over six decades used the camera to share his curiosity and wonder with the world. We were honored to know him as a friend and will greatly miss his talent and generosity of spirit. Cornell Capa, Founder Willis Hartshorn, Director
