description: LACK-Herbert. An elegant gentleman in the classical sense, a loving devoted husband, a truly solicitious father, a loyal, warm and affectionate friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Margery, Joanne and Penny. We share your great loss and envy the wonderful years you enjoyed with him. Larry Strauss & Esther Schwinger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, ROSEMARY, M.D.
description: STEVENS-Rosemary, M.D. Of Sarasota, Florida. A retired Optomologist. Widow of John Martin Stevens, formerly of New York, N.Y. Passed away in her sleep on 1 March 1999 after a lengthy illness. She was born in Berlin, Germany as Rose Marie Czellitzer, on 23 December 1907. Surviving are sons Michael (Marilyn) and Thomas (Marny), five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Friday, 5 March, noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, New York.

title: AT&T PLANS TO DIRECT CAPITAL SPENDING TO THE INTERNET
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it wanted to stop investing in traditional long-distance telephone systems by next year. In a conference call with reporters, Frank Ianna, president of AT&T's network operation, said the company intended to stop buying long-distance switches for traditional telephone calls made by Lucent Technologies Inc. and would redirect its annual capital spending of about $6 billion toward products based on Internet technology. He added that the company would continue to buy other Lucent products. AT&T also said yesterday that it would participate in a group formed by Lucent, Motorola and other companies to promote new uses for the Internet, such as services that read E-mail over the phone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURER, RICHARD F.
description: MAURER-Richard F., of NYC. Beloved father of Scott and David Maurer and Melinda A. Sawyer. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave., NYC, Thursday, 12-3 PM. Funeral service private.

title: Reassuring Data and High Yields Help Treasury Prices Post Gains
description: Bond prices rose yesterday for only the second time in almost a week as market participants covered short positions after a benign report on new-home sales.

title: New Nigeria Leader Brandishes His Broom
description: Pledging to rebuild Nigeria but also urging caution, the President-elect said today that he would bring together this fractious country, where years of military dictatorships have heightened ethnic tensions.

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend on Friday misidentified the chef at Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He is Junnajet Hurrapan; James Chew was a consulting chef before the restaurant opened.

title: The Euro Falls, And Some Find Economic Fault
description: In the two months since the European single currency was introduced, pretty much the only direction it has moved is down.

title: Court Weighs the Meaning of 'Gratuity'
description: Somewhere between bribing a Federal official and bestowing an innocent gift on one lies an illegal gratuity. Federal law punishes giving a gratuity with two years in prison, but, as a Supreme Court argument today demonstrated, it defines the offense so imprecisely that the search for meaning is almost as much an exercise in metaphysics as in law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMS, GERHARD
description: HARMS-Gerhard. Montefiore Medical Center and its Board of Trustees are deeply saddened by the death of Gerhard Harms, 92, a respected friend and benefactor of the medical center. Through his support of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, he leaves a legacy to children and their families that will live for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear friends, Lee and Vincent Affinito. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Bill Would Subject Guns To Federal Safety Controls
description: As cities and states prepare to battle the gun industry in the courts, advocates of toughened gun control have opened a new front by introducing a bill in Congress to end gun makers' exemption from Federal health and safety regulation.

title: FLOWSERVE ABANDONS BID TO BUY ITS RIVAL, WEIR GROUP
description: The Flowserve Corporation, a maker of pumps and valves, said yesterday that it was giving up its effort to acquire its Scottish rival, the Weir Group P.L.C. Weir had rejected Flowserve's $1 billion offer on Feb. 5. Flowserve, which is based in Irving, Tex., was created in a 1997 merger of Durco International Inc. and BW/IP Inc. The company said it would continue to look for acquisitions and cost savings to increase growth. Both Weir and Flowserve have sought to expand in the valve and pump businesses.

title: State's Jobless Rate Is Lowest Since 1989
description: The state's revised unemployment rate for 1998 was 4.6 percent, the lowest it has been since 1989, and well below the 1997 rate of 5.1 percent, officials said yesterday.

title: Advice for the Olympics
description: The ethics commission empaneled by the United States Olympic Committee has provided an excellent template for reforming the International Olympic Committee and eliminating its graft-friendly culture. The recommendations, which the commission chairman, former Senator George Mitchell, released Monday, champion structural changes that can help inoculate the I.O.C., national Olympic committees and competing cities against the kind of vote-buying that helped Salt Lake City boosters win the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, NATHANIEL
description: SAMUELS-Nathaniel. The Officers, Directors and shareholders of 775 Park Avenue, Inc. mourn the passing of Nathaniel Samuels, who served for many years as a dedicated member of the Board. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and loved ones.

title: Cheating Death Has Never Been Easier
description: CHEATING is big business in video games. To Interact, the company that manufactures Game Shark ''enhancement devices,'' it's worth $40 million a year.

title: Suicide Law Gone Awry
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Hillary in New York: Return of the Neo-Native?
description: Memo to future Presidential spouses: If you're feeling overlooked, float a rumor that you might run for the Senate. So many people were dying to pay $150 or more to hear Hillary Rodham Clinton's luncheon address at the Plaza yesterday that hundreds were exiled from the main dining room, eating lunch with a public address system. The place was abubble with incipient feminist triumphalism and plain old Democratic opportunism.

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: The Total Cycling Encyclopedia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, HENRY C.
description: WHEELER-Henry C. Age 82, a resident of Westport, CT, former chairman and chief executive officer of Acme United Corporation, Fairfield, CT, died March 2, 1999. Funeral services, Friday, March 5, 2 PM, Southport Congregational Church, 524 Pequot Avenue, Southport, CT.

title: Ruling Party, at 70, Tries Hard to Cling To Power in Mexico
description: Hanging on a wall at the hulking downtown headquarters of Mexico's governing party are dusty oil portraits of nearly all the 37 politicians who have headed the party since its founding in 1929.

title: President Helps Torricelli Raise $2.1 Million
description: On a day when millions tuned in to see Monica S. Lewinsky on television and thousands turned out to see Hillary Rodham Clinton in New York City, President Clinton stayed quietly out of the limelight, flying to New Jersey to help raise campaign money for Senator Robert G. Torricelli.

title: Economic Scene; Banking legislation puts fiscal heavyweights in rival corners.
description: A CONTINUING spat between Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, over modernizing bank regulations threatens to bury legislation that comes before House and Senate committees today. They agree that laws from the 1930's and 1950's that keep banks out of the securities and insurance markets should be scrapped. But they disagree how banks should be structured to handle their new responsibilities.

title: Senate Takes Partisan Turn On Education Legislation
description: Eager to show that education is foremost on their minds, Senate Democrats and Republicans began a debate on Federal education policy today that they hope will resonate with voters weary of impeachment and partisan warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, L. CATHERINE
description: COLE-L. Catherine. Died February 28th, 1999 at Memorial SloanKettering. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Raymond M. Cole. Loving mother of Christopher, Joseph and Eydie. Funeral services will be held at St. Thomas Moore Church in Darien, CT on Saturday, March 6 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to City Harvest, 159 West 25 St., 10th Flr., NY NY 10001.

title: Pirro Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Tax Fraud Charges
description: Albert J. Pirro Jr., the powerful real estate lawyer and husband of the Westchester County District Attorney, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of tax fraud and accused prosecutors of trying to short-circuit his wife's political aspirations.

title: Seton Hall's Modest Freshman Leads Way to a Modest Upset
description: They lost twice to the Irish in the regular season, and needed a victory to stay in contention for the National Invitation Tournament. Seton Hall's crafty point guard, Shaheen Holloway, was battered. His backup, Ty Shine, was a freshman. Quite talented, but still only a freshman.

title: Donnelly Plans Job Cuts
description: The Donnelly Corporation, a maker of automobile windows, plans to cut as many as 200 jobs in Europe and take a charge of $8.6 million to streamline its business and trim operating costs in the region. Donnelly said today that the cuts, which represent 8.3 percent of its work force in Europe, were part of its plan to consolidate two German factories and renegotiate labor contracts to slow growth in labor expenses for the company, which also makes anti-glare rear-view and side-view mirrors. The jobs will be cut in the next 12 to 18 months, mostly through early retirements and some dismissals in Germany and Ireland.

title: Broadway Musical 'Titanic' to Close
description: The producers of the musical ''Titanic'' announced yesterday that they would close the $10 million production, one of the most expensive in Broadway history, on March 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JACOB M.
description: GOLDMAN-Jacob M. Died peacefully at his home on March 3, 1999, at age 91. Beloved husband of 57 years of Dorothy (nee Goldrosen). Loving father of Leonard and Lesley Goldman, William Goldman and Jill Lesser, and Daniel Goldman and Sonja Mezic. Adored grandfather of Michael, David and Richard. Founding partner of the law firm Goldman, Horowitz and Cherno, founding president of Sterns Park Civic Association and former general counsel of the Pastel Society of America. Services Friday, 11:15AM at ''Gutterman's Inc. '', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Crane Loses Appeal On Coltec Lawsuit
description: The Crane Company's lawsuit aimed at preventing Coltec Industries from accepting a buyout offer from B. F. Goodrich was dismissed by a Federal appeals court, Goodrich said.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by the singer David Johansen at the Bottom Line last Thursday misspelled the surname of the band member who played the Dobro. He is Larry Saltzman, not Salzman.

title: I.B.M. and 3 Others Develop Copy Guard for Audio DVD's
description: I.B.M. and three other companies said today that they had developed a way to prevent illegal copying of a new music format.

title: Devils Right at Home In Leafs' New Arena
description: Years from now the Devils will be the answer to a trivia question as the team that beat the Maple Leafs for the first time in Toronto's new home, the modern Air Canada Center, which replaced historic Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Opoku Ware II, King of Asante, Is Dead at 89
description: Otumfuo Opoku Ware II, the traditional King of the Asante people, has died in his palace in Kumasi, Ghana, the ancient capital of the Asante, who once ruled a powerful and complex political confederation in West Africa. He was 79.

title: Sharpton Among 28 Arrested in Rally on Diallo Killing
description: Twenty-eight people, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, were arrested yesterday when a noon rally by more than a thousand people against the police shooting of Amadou Diallo blocked traffic on Wall Street.

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: UNTIL Greg LeMond showed that an American could win the Tour de France, following professional cycle racing from the United States was a desperate business. Race results from the tour and other races like the Giro D'Italia and the Tour of Flanders typically came weeks, if not months, late through the pages of outrageously overpriced European magazines like the old Miroir du Cyclisme.

title: LANDRY'S SEAFOOD TO PICK UP CONSOLIDATED RESTAURANT
description: Landry's Seafood Restaurants Inc., the No. 2 casual seafood chain, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Consolidated Restaurant Companies, a closely held company that owns the El Chico, Spaghetti Warehouse and Cool River restaurants, for $84 million in stock and $80 million in assumed debt. The purchase will raise Landry's annual sales by almost 40 percent, to $550 million, and almost double its restaurants to 291. E. Gene Street, Consolidated Restaurants' president and chief executive, will replace Tilman Fertitta as Landry's chief executive after the transaction. Mr. Fertitta will remain chairman. Landry's shares fell 62.5 cents, to $6.

title: Suited-Up Sofas: Shoes and Bag To Match?
description: NOT since the resourceful Scarlett O'Hara fashioned a moss-green gown from Tara's velvet drapes has fashion enjoyed such an intimate affair with the decor tastes of the day.

title: Frierson Mee Gets Coty Account
description: Coty Inc. said yesterday that it had expanded its agency roster by awarding Frierson Mee & Kraft in New York the account for a number of undisclosed new fragrance brands. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVAN, ORA M.
description: GAVAN-Ora M. Of Bronxville, NY, on March 2, 1999. Wife of the late John. Mother of Sarah and John. Grandmother of Elizabeth and Caroline Ruby. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Imposes Tariffs And Vows to Ban Concorde

title: Sports of The Times; He Made Music of His Own
description: WHEN Antonio Levane immigrated to America from Naples early in this century, he was 10 years old. To help out his family, he played a mandolin for pennies on the streets of Brooklyn. He went on to play the double bass in renowned orchestras, such as at the Metropolitan Opera House, and for such classical luminaries as Caruso and Toscanini. Of course, Antonio Levane wanted his six children to play musical instruments. But some of his children, particularly the one that the nation would come to know as Fuzzy, had other notions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPERCQ, PAUL
description: LEPERCQ-Paul. The partners, associates and staff of Lepercq, de Neuflize & Co. are profoundly saddened by the loss of Paul Lepercq, who died in Paris on February 27 of lymphocytic lymphoma. Mr. Lepercq was born in France, raised in Prague until age seven, and later educated in France. He emigrated to America in 1948 to attend the Harvard Business School and in 1949 joined Andre Istel & Co., which became Istel, Lepercq & Co. and later, Lepercq, de Neuflize & Co. He has been a resident of Bermuda since 1985. Mr. Lepercq served on the Boards of Director of Schlumberger Limited, American Saint Gobain, Groupe Danone, Gaumont S.A., Chargeurs, and Pathe. He also served as Chairman of the Board of the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) from 1971 to 1976. The Lepercq Space in BAM's main building was named in his honor in 1973, in acknowledgment of his early role in helping BAM develop into one of the world's foremost centers for contemporary performing arts. A funeral service will be held in Paris on Monday, March 8 at 11:00 A.M. at the Church of Saint Sulpice. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Francoise Stoll-Lepercq, and daughter, Edmee. He will be sorely missed by all of us. Francois Letaconnoux, President Lepercq, de Neuflize & Co. Inc

title: PUTNAM AND ALLSTATE JOIN TO OFFER INSURANCE PRODUCT
description: The Allstate Corporation, the insurer of homes and autos, said yesterday that it had agreed to form a joint venture with Putnam Investments to sell a type of stock-linked retirement saving plan that has become a top-selling form of life insurance. The companies will sell variable annuities, a hybrid of mutual funds and insurance policies that let people make tax-deferred investments in the stock market, starting in May.

title: Mother and Daughters As Therapy Candidates
description: Outside the spic and span Mihalovic homestead in bucolic Ankeny, Iowa, a tornado swirls. Inside the house, things are spiraling out of control as well. The Mihalovic sisters arrive for a party, and each tracks in family skeletons along with the rain. Here comes Carol with the drinking problem, Anne with the bad marriage, Brenda with the lesbian lover, Susan with the outstanding arrest warrant.

title: G.M. Joins Rivals in Posting Robust Sales for February
description: The General Motors Corporation, which today reported higher February sales, finally appears to be rebounding from last summer's strike and joining its rivals in the robust auto market.

title: Tieto of Finland to Buy Enator, a Swedish Rival
description: Tieto Oyj of Finland agreed to buy its Swedish computer services rival Enator A.B. for $1 billion in stock to increase its competitiveness in a region that has the world's highest rate of Internet and telecom use.

title: Office for Silicon Valley
description: Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, the investment banking arm of the BankAmerica Corporation, plans to open an office in Silicon Valley for about 40 of its investment bankers who focus on computer-related industries, its chief executive said. Lewis W. Coleman, the securities firm's chief executive, said the San Francisco-based company would keep its technology research operations and the rest of its business in San Francisco. It is opening a Silicon Valley office to be closer to some clients. Several investment banks have expanded in Silicon Valley, including Goldman, Sachs & Company, which announced a move there last month.

title: Terror Suspect Said to Anger Afghan Hosts
description: The suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden and the Taliban, his protectors in Afghanistan, have had a violent falling-out, raising the possibility that his days of refuge may be numbered, senior American officials said today.

title: Gay Publications Gain Ad Spending
description: Advertising spending in publications aimed at gay and lesbian consumers rose for a fourth consecutive year, an annual survey reported.

title: MIFFED AT EUROPE, U.S. RAISES TARIFFS FOR LUXURY GOODS
description: The United States heated up two politically contentious trade disputes with Europe today, slapping 100 percent tariffs on $520 million in European products and threatening to ban Europe's supersonic pride, the Concorde, from landing in the United States.

title: Roche Cleared For H.I.V. Test
description: Roche Holding A.G., Europe's fifth-largest drug maker, said today that it had won United States Food and Drug Administration clearance to sell a new, more sensitive version of its Amplicor test, designed to measure the amount of H.I.V. in a patient's blood.

title: High Winds Blow Metal Plates Off High-Rise at Port Authority
description: A storm carrying wind gusts of up to 40 miles per hour burst through the metropolitan region last night, blowing two 55-pound metal plates from an office building next to the Port Authority Bus Terminal and causing several floors of a vacant building in Harlem to cave in, the authorities said.

title: Lectures, Gardening And Shows
description: Modern Classics

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROSETTA
description: WEINSTEIN - Rosetta. Passed away Tuesday, March 2, 1999 at the age of 92. Services will be held at Riverside, 21 West Braod Street, Mt. vernon Friday, March 5 at noon. Mrs. Weinstein founded in 1928 the first private vocational school for medical and dental technicians. She served as President of Sutton Place Chapter of Hadassah, where she was known for her outstanding abilities as speaker and fundraiser. She is survived by her daughter, Dr. Aileen Kass; grandchildren Madeline June, Dr. Robin May Banks, Michael R. Banks and Sharon September; and great-granddaughter, Paige Daniela Banks.

title: Executive Leaving Ammirati Puris
description: Howard Lesman, executive vice president and managing director at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, said yesterday that he would depart on May 31 after working for the agency and a predecessor, Ammirati & Puris, for 18 years.

title: ADVANTA CORPORATION TO JETTISON AUTO LOANS BUSINESS
description: The Advanta Corporation, a home-equity and mortgage lender, said yesterday that it was closing its auto-lending business and combining others to cut costs and focus on more profitable businesses. Advanta also said Carl Forsythe, president and chief executive of its Advanta Mortgage unit, had left the company and would not be replaced. Dennis Alter, Advanta's chairman; Bill Alter, vice chairman, and Olaf Olafsson, president, will direct the unit. Company officials were not immediately available for comment. Advanta said it had stopped originating auto loans and would consider winding down or selling its portfolio of such loans. Until a decision is reached, an outside firm, Nuvell Inc., will service the loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, IRENE (RUSTY)
description: SOBEL-Irene (Rusty). Of Woodmere, New York. Died on March 3. Beloved wife the late Paul Sobel. Loving mother of Barbara Goetz Gelb (Joe) and Richard Sobel. Adored grandmother of Andrew Goetz, Lucy Leung, Jane Goetz and Lindsay Sobel. Irene was a career woman most of her life and a community volunteer in her later years. She was strong, feisty and beautiful throughout. Graveside services on March 5 at 10:15am at Mt. Lebanon cemetery. For directions to the cemetery please call Joseph Gelb at 516374-1387.

title: 50 Years of Perps, With Speed and Flash
description: JUST a sampling of the ''perp walks'' that Marty Lederhandler has known and loved as The Associated Press's longest-working photographer:

title: 18 Wheels, G.P.S. and Radar
description: THE air outside the TA Trucking Center was laced with more than diesel fumes from the hundreds of 18-wheelers parked in neat rows at this interstate crossroad. As drivers finished their dinners, they rumbled out of the parking lot, but not out of touch, because their satellite dishes and computers kept them linked to headquarters with radio waves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENSIK, FRIEDA K.
description: WILENSIK-Frieda K. On March 2, 1999. Beloved mother of Norman and Robert. Devoted sister of Joseph, Solomon and the late Max Klapper. Dearest daughter of the late Sigmund and Anna Klapper. Loving aunt and friend. Services Thursday, 1PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Rutgers Survives Opener, but Now Gets St. John's
description: Intrigue bubbles up from the lower half of the Big East tournament bracket, with the two biggest threats to Connecticut's dominance in line for a showdown and two other teams battling to keep their National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament chances alive. Last night in the tournament's first round, one of those dreams crumbled in the waning seconds of a game and the other lived on with renewed vigor for at least one more day.

title: Dog Owners Sound Cavalry Alarm
description: It was 9 A.M., give or take a minute or two, and a dozen dog owners at 91st Street in Riverside Park grimly snapped leashes in place yesterday, remembering the scene the morning before, when mounted officers had given chase and apprehended those who had missed the on-the-leash deadline.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: What Ails Camellia?

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: Velo News Interactive

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile yesterday about Ernest A. Conrad, an engineer who is helping to modernize the mechanisms of a historic downtown building referred incorrectly to its name and nickname. It is officially the Woolworth Building. The unofficial name, bestowed upon the building at its opening, is the Cathedral of Commerce, not the Temple of Commerce.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Mommy made a big mistake.''

title: INSIDE
description: A Battle of Capital Rallies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOSEPH FOSTER, M.D.
description: ROSS-Joseph Foster, M.D. Born October 11, 1910, in Azusa, CA. Passed away Friday, February 25, 1999. Dedicated physician, husband, father and friend. Dr. Ross was Professor Emeritus of the University of California, Los Angeles Medical School, where he was Associate Dean and Chief of the Division of Hematology. He was a founding member of the American Board of Nuclear Medicine, for which he served as President from 1973-1976 and as an executive director through 1998. He was awarded the Certificate of Merit by President Harry S. Truman for his work on blood preservation desperately needed for transfusions during World War II. Survived by his sister, Virginia Geller; one son, Joseph (Jane) Ross; four daughters, Louisa Moore, Elisabeth (Andrew) Schutz, Jeanne (Richard) Waite, Marianne (George) Blackmar, and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the David Cheever Scholarship at Harvard University School of Medicine, Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTZER, CARL
description: MALTZER-Carl. 83. Of Lauder Hill, FL, formerly of Linden, NJ, on March 2. He is survived by his wife Pauline (nee Josephson), two daughters Harriet Botwinick of Corona Del Mar, CA and her husband Michael and Gene Berry of Clark, NJ and her husband Dennis and four grandchildren, Jonathan, Daniel, Michele and David. Funeral services will be held on Friday, March 5 at Menorah Chapel, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ 908964-1500

title: Stooped, Gray and Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Typing or Keyboarding?
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Says New York Voters Would Reject Bid by First Lady
description: While studiously avoiding the word, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey suggested today that Hillary Rodham Clinton was too liberal to prevail in New York's Senate race should the First Lady decide to enter that campaign in 2000.

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager Is Shot to Death in Dispute With a Rival Group
description: A high school student was shot to death and two other teen-agers were wounded on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon after the youths and some friends were accused by a rival group of having stolen a gold chain, the police said.

title: Union Leader Is Suspended After an Audit
description: In a new action against the troubled leadership of the largest union representing New York City municipal workers, Albert A. Diop, one of the union's most powerful figures, was suspended yesterday after an audit found that he and three associates had spent more than $2 million without providing any documentation.

title: Nets, With New Look, Trying to Change Luck
description: The Nets are looking for anything that can shake up their fortunes. With each loss, the panic seems to set in a little deeper, and the solution could be as drastic as a trade or a change in the lineup. But for today it was as simple as unveiling their new V-necked, cool-metal gray uniforms.

title: Why Can't Doctors Also Be Mothers?
description: To the Editor:

title: WELSH, CARSON TO BUY CONCENTRA MANAGED CARE
description: Concentra Managed Care Inc., a provider of health care cost-control services, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe for $772 million in cash, plus the refinancing of $328 million in Concentra debt. Concentra shareholders will receive $16.50 for each share, a 42 percent premium over Tuesday's closing price. Concentra said Welsh, Carson planned to acquire 93 percent of the company's outstanding shares and would seek an outside investor to buy the remaining 7 percent. Shares of Concentra, based in Boston, have fallen more than 60 percent in the last 12 months; yesterday, they closed at $14.6875, up $3.0625.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil prices jumped 3.2 percent after reports indicated that inventories had plunged, reducing a surplus in supplies. In New York, crude oil for April delivery rose 42 cents, to $12.93 a barrel.

title: Access to Lots of Gadgets Could Be at Your Fingertips
description: People using new Siemens technology will need the right touch to unlock their laptops, power up their P.D.A.'s and make calls on their cellular phones. Specifically, each user will need to touch the device with a finger so it can recognize the fingerprint as being the correct one.

title: Stooped, Gray and Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Dining section yesterday about butchers in New York who dry-age their beef, with an article on modern meat cookery, referred incompletely to the procedure at Balducci's. Beef sold at the store is dry-aged on the premises; beef sold through the store's catalogue is dry-aged by a wholesaler.

title: Telephones Pass Year 2000 Test
description: The telephone companies that form the backbone of local voice and data communications in the United States said yesterday that extensive testing had demonstrated that their networks would operate smoothly in 2000.

title: Buzz Miller, 75; Danced on Broadway And in the Movies
description: Buzz Miller, a dancer who was equally at home on Broadway and in contemporary ballet and modern dance, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the killing of eight tourists in Uganda referred incorrectly in some copies to the headquarters location of the two American victims' employer, the Intel Corporation. While the two worked in Oregon, the company headquarters is in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Blacklist Destroyed Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandela, After Wrangling, Announces June 2 Is Election Day
description: After months of wrangling over how to conduct the second post-apartheid elections in South Africa, President Nelson Mandela announced today that the voting would be on June 2.

title: Norman, Back From Surgery, Has New Slant on Life
description: At this time last year, Greg Norman was in severe pain, struggling with a left shoulder injury that required surgery last April. Seven months of recovery followed, and today Norman's shoulder is sound and he has returned to the game with a more appreciative perspective.

title: National News Briefs; Three of Texas Octuplets Go Home From Hospital
description: Three of the seven surviving Chukwu octuplets were given a clean bill of health and went home today.

title: Armstead Is Absent From Workouts
description: The Giants' two-time Pro Bowl linebacker Jessie Armstead, a team leader who is usually a devoted participant in the Giants' off-season conditioning program, has not attended any of the team's winter workouts that began this week. Several Giants have said privately that Armstead is boycotting the workouts because he wants his contract renegotiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERMAN, MINNIE
description: LIEBERMAN-Minnie. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a valued friend and Chai Founder who continued the legacy of her parents, the legendary ba'aley tzedokah and chesed, Andrew and Rose Miller. Mrs. Lieberman, together with her late husband, Hyman, and brothers Leon Miller and the late Ira Miller, both Boys Town Board Members and loyal supporters, ensured that the lofty Torah ideals of her father's namesake, the sainted Reb Nochumke of Grodno, would be perpetuated. May the family be comforted together with the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Milbury Announces Club Plans
description: Since Mike Milbury stepped down as the Islanders' coach and slipped into the sheltered world of his general manager's office, he has rarely been seen or heard in the locker room or in the newspapers.

title: Desks That Are Just Right
description: CHILDREN spend a lot of time at their desks, even if parents don't think so. And what better way to encourage good habits than a well-thought-out computer desk?

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: Official Tour de France

title: At a Match in The Hague, Everyone's Busy Till the End
description: In North America, major team events are invariably knockouts, with half the players departing after each round. At world level, teams start in round-robin pools leading to knockout playoffs. The Dutch have a different idea, which keeps everyone busy until the finish. At the Forbo Teams played in The Hague during the weekend, 64 teams were divided into round-robin pools of eight. The eight winners and runners-up went into a Swiss-team final, and the rest into round-robin groups according to their standing.

title: In Painters' Poetic Homes, the Soul of a Nation Emerged
description: NOW that the cactus fence around his house near Mexico City has been replanted, its vivid colors restored and offending additions removed, Diego Rivera can easily be imagined on the third-floor bridge leading from his red studio to Frida Kahlo's blue studio, pounding at her glass door and asking his wife's forgiveness. The life of Rivera, a Rabelaisian omnivore, was a legend wrapped in scandal surrounded by myth that played against the backdrop of brightly colored buildings, as if he were a figure walking through one of his own heroic canvases.

title: For Neighborhoods in Many Cities, Virtual Community Centers
description: FOR staying in touch with neighbors around the corner or even next door, it may come to this: the World Wide Web.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMCAST CORP., Philadelphia, an operator of cable-TV systems, said it would split its stock 2 for 1 and eliminate its quarterly dividend after its stock almost doubled in the last year. The last dividend of 23 cents a share will be payable on March 25 to shareholders of record on March 4.

title: Why Can't Doctors Also Be Mothers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Defers a Ruling in LVMH-Gucci Dispute
description: An Amsterdam court has put off until April 22 a decision as to whether an attempt by Gucci Group N.V. to dilute the stake of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. in Gucci is allowable.

title: A Wrist Aquarium For Sea Monkeys
description: Before Pokemon, there were Sea Monkeys. These creatures (really hybridized brine shrimp extravagantly anthropomorphized in 1960's comic-book advertisements) can now accompany their human masters in Exploratoy's Sea Monkey Digital Watch. The five-function LCD watch has a detachable 8 cc aquarium where sea monkeys can live for up to 24 hours, according to George C. Atamian, a vice president at Exploratoy's parent company, Educational Insights. After that, they should be wrangled (using the trademarked ''acqua leash'') and returned to their permanent aquarium. The watch can hold one or two sea monkeys but, once they reach adulthood, it becomes difficult to wrangle just one because, said Mr. Atamian, ''they're almost constantly mating.'' So it is an educational toy, after all.

title: Gadgets, Gizmos and Gear: New Snow Stuff
description: Flashy new shaped skis or lightweight snowboard boots can add pizzazz to a trip to the slopes. But other innovations -- ones you may not know to look for -- can be as enticing as a fast chairlift on a slow day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON LIEBIG, WILLIAM J.
description: von LIEBIG-William J., an honored inventor, entrepreneur and philanthropist died on Sunday, February 21, 1999 at Mayo Hospital in Scottsdale, Arizona. Born in Huntingdon, Pennsylvania, William von Liebig earned a Bachelor of Science degree from Juniata College, a Masters of Science degree from the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Sciences and a Masters of Business Administration from New York University. During World War II, he served as Alternate Lead Pilot with the 8th Air Force in Europe. The operations officer to whom he reported was Lieutenant Colonel Jimmy Stewart with the famous 389th Bomb Group. He received the Distinguished Flying Cross Medal with three Oak Leaf Clusters and a Presidential Citation for his military service. After the war, he embarked on a career in textile sales and manufacturing which coupled with his interest in medicine, led to the development of Meadox Medicals, Inc. in 1961. Meadox Medicals manufactured and distributed vascular grafts and other devices designed to treat cardiovascular disease. Mr. von Liebig holds 33 patents for vascular prostheses and his inventions have made significant contributions to the field of vascular surgery, particularly to the technological advancement of textile vascular grafts used in the reconstruction and replacement of human arteries. Over the years, he received a host of achievement awards including the Gold Hektoen Award from the American Medical Association, the 1995 Independent Inventor of the Year Award from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and the Carothers Medal from the Textile Institute in England. In 1991, Mr. von Liebig received the national Alumni Achievement Award from Juniata College in Huntingdon, Pennsylvania. In 1975 he established The von Liebig Foundation which generously supports medical research, primarily for the treatment of vascular and cardiovascular diseases. In 1981, the Foundation established an award for Residents and Fellows to be granted annually to encourage and recognize research among young trainees interested in a career in vascular surgery. The von Liebig Foundation and the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute jointly funded a grant to the Lifeline Foundation in 1998 to sponsor the Mentored Clinical Scientist Development Awards for the benefit of vascular surgeon scientists in the early stages of their research careers. The purpose of the award is to support the development of clinician research scientists. In 1990, William von Liebig and his wife, Suzanne, relocated to Naples, Florida. They have continued their philanthropic efforts expanding their mission to affect an even broader population. Together they have supported the arts and education with substantial gifts to Juniata College and, in their community, the Naples Philharmonic, the von Liebig Art Center and the Naples Depot. Surviving family include his loving wife, Suzanne, of Naples, Florida, his sister, Edith Liebig of Huntingdon, Pennsylvania, his daughter and son-in-law, Barbara and Bill Thomashower of New York City, and his grandchildren, David and Charley. Memorial services will be held in New York City on March 23, 1999 at the Campbell Funeral Chapel at 4:00pm and in Naples, Florida on March 31, 1999 at the Daniels Pavilion of The Naples Philharmonic at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions be made to the von Liebig Art Center Endowment Fund. Mailing address: The von Liebig Art Center, 585 Park Street, Naples, FL 34102.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ISIDORE ''TIBBY''
description: COHN-Isidore ''Tibby''. AMIT is profoundly grieved by the untimely passing of a dear friend and supporter, beloved husband of our devoted National Membership Chairwoman, Florence Cohn. Isidore Tibby Cohn's loving kindness and special devotion to our AMIT children in Israel was a model for all. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: An Icon Falls On Hard Times; In India, the Ambassador Car Fights to Survive Competition
description: Streets in India are an extraordinary sight for two reasons, one of them the cows that wander sacredly and indifferently through traffic, the other an antiquated-looking automobile with a bowler hat of a roof called the Ambassador.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, MATHILDA
description: TERNER-Mathilda, 88, of Palm Beach, Fla., and Oakhurst, NJ, on the 3rd of March. Cherished and beloved wife of the late Emanuel M. Terner for 67 years. A loving mother to Nancy Behrman, Elaine Cooper and Carol Lederman. Mother-in-law to Stanley and Mark. Devoted grandmother of Peter (Josephine) Grayson, Alan (Kimberly) Mnuchin, Steven Mnuchin, Amy (Jeff) Verschleiser, and Judy Lederman. Adoring great-grandmother of Bradley Louis Grayson and Joshua Terner Verschleiser. Friends may call Thursday evening, 5-7 PM. Services 10 AM, Friday, March 5, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Burial service private. Donations in her memory to St. Mary's Hospital, 901 45th St., West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEVILLE, ANN ADAMS
description: MANDEVILLE-Ann Adams. Buffy Mandeville died peacefully at her home in Fairfield, Connecticut on the evening of March 1, in her seventy-second year. She is mourned by her daughter Meredith Hollis and sons Christopher, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, & William Mandeville, her son-in-law James Hollis, and daughters-inlaw Claire, Olivia, Nancy, Anne & Maribel Mandeville, her brother Dean Adams and her former husband Hubert T. Mandeville. She will also be missed by her devoted grandchildren Erinn, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Elizabeth, Courtney, Kempton, Turner, Allison, Willie, Adelaide, Ariel, Paulina, Carlos, Miguel, Henry and Estelle. A graduate of Dana Hall & Vassar College, she will be remembered for her loyal and effective handson service to many institutions, including the Fairfield Women's Exchange, the Garden Club of America (for whom she was a widely respected judge), Trinity Parish and the Pequot Library of Southport, CT, Bridgeport Hospital, the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County, and the Dana Hall and Fairfield Country Day Schools. She was a member of the Colony Club and the Country Club of Fairfield. A person of exceptional character, probity and steadfastness, she loved and enjoyed her family, her friends and their children. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Southport, CT., on Saturday, March 6th, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to Bridgeport Hospital or the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAGAM, MELVIN H.
description: SHAGAM-Melvin H., 83. Of Lake Worth, FL. Formerly of Rockville Centre, NY passed away March 2, 1999. Adored husband of Adele; Devoted, loving father and grandfather. Funeral service at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, Florida today at 2:30PM at 1-800-94-Shalom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, WILLIAM D., PH.D.
description: KATZ-William D., Ph.D., 83, of West Palm Beach, FL on Monday, March 1, 1999. He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Betty, his children, Alan E. Katz and Barbara Lynne, his daughter-in-law Laura Katz, his stepchildren, Ruth Wiener and Micky Goldfarb, his grandchildren, Danielle, Melissa, Oren, and Jessie. Dr. Katz was a Diplomate of the American Academy of Behavioral Medicine and the American Board of Medical Psychotheraphy, past Master, Freemasons; life member, Knights of Pythias; professor of psychology, Long Island Univ. A memorial service was held March 3, 1999 in West Palm Beach, FL and graveside services will be held Thursday, March 4, 1999 at 2:30PM at New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. We shall miss you.

title: Thais Show Albright the Fruits of American Aid: Meaningful Jobs and Legal Crops
description: Madeleine K. Albright put a human face on foreign policy today, listening to a group of young Thai women explain how American aid money had helped turn them away from drugs and prostitution and toward meaningful jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEILER, DAVID
description: SEILER-David, 98. On Monday, March 1, 1999 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Shirley. Loving father of Judy Teller and Jane Saltoun. Loving father-in-law of Munir Saltoun. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Teller and Andrew Saltoun. Services Thursday, March 4th, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 12:15 PM.

title: With a Job, Without a Home; Low-Wage Workers Turn to Shelters to Bridge the Gap
description: Kenneth Lindo walks with bond traders and bankers through the gleaming lobbies of Wall Street during the day, his canvas messenger's bag heavy with checks and stock certificates from the longest bull market in memory. But at night, he beds down at the 30th Street Men's Shelter in Manhattan, rolling his winter jacket in the sheet under his head.

title: New Program Is Introduced To Ease Use of Linux System
description: The free software movement today took its most significant step yet toward a direct confrontation with the Microsoft Corporation by introducing software that gives the powerful and free Linux operating system the ease-of-use found on Windows and Macintosh computers.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against Japan's currency as the Japanese central bank pumped money into the nation's financial system. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.77 yen, up from 120.23 on Tuesday.

title: Court Says Schools Must Pay For Needs of Disabled Pupils
description: Students with disabilities who require special care during the school day are entitled to that care at public expense, the Supreme Court ruled today, as long as the services can be provided by someone other than a doctor.

title: Disney and Hong Kong Confirm Talks on a Theme Park
description: Confirming weeks of breathless rumors, Hong Kong and the Walt Disney Company said yesterday that they were in early negotiations about building a theme park in the former British colony.

title: Progress in Security Earns Tiger Preserve a Reprieve
description: A Jackson Township woman who owns 17 tigers won what her lawyer called ''a small victory in an ongoing battle'' yesterday when a judge gave her a reprieve from state regulators who sought to seize her tigers and disperse them to zoos and preserves.

title: Bonds Rally, Driving Yield To New Lows In Japan
description: Japanese bonds rallied today, driving the yield of the benchmark issue to its lowest in more than two months as expectations grew that the central bank would extend its efforts to guide down short-term interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, GILBERT
description: FEINMAN-Gilbert, 81, of Delray Beach, Florida. Dear husband of Martha, devoted father of Anita and Michael; father-in-law of Elisa. Loving grandfather of Ian, Jordan, Heath, Lauren, Jessica, Jacqueline and Alexandria; great grandfather of Hannah. Service will be held Friday, 12:15PM at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: RESIGNATIONS PILE UP IN MANAGEMENT CHANGE AT KELLOGG
description: The Kellogg Company announced a sweeping management shake-up yesterday as it prepared for Carlos M. Gutierrez to take over as chief executive officer next month. Kellogg, which has been suffering from drooping market share, collected the resignations of John R. Hinton, chief financial officer; Richard M. Clark, general counsel, and Robert L. Creviston, vice president for human relations. The cereal maker also said Jean-Louis Gourbin would resign as executive vice president for the parent company and president of Kellogg Europe, effective March 15, and would be replaced by Alan F. Harris. Donald W. Thomason, executive vice president for services and technology, will retire.

title: It's Tax Time: for Some, Gorilla Hunting Season
description: THE GREEDY HAND

title: Yet Another Scandal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, BERDIS EMMA JONES
description: BALDWIN-Berdis Emma Jones, 95, on Saturday, February 27. Mother of author James Baldwin; survived by two sons, five daughters, 18 grandchildren, 23 great grandchildren; seven great great grandchildren; a host of nieces, nephews and friends and admirers worldwide. Viewing March 4, 1999, Unity Funeral Chapel, 2353 8th Avenue, NY, 5:30-8:30pm. Funeral services Friday, March 5, 10:30am, Abyssinian Baptist Church, Odell Clark Place, 132 West 138th St.

title: In This Brand-New City, No Shortage of Elders
description: The residents of the Leisure World retirement community here voted on Tuesday to transform their gated patch of ''God's country'' into California's newest city, with surely one of its oldest populations.

title: Kingstown Journal; An Outpost in the Banana and Marijuana Wars
description: When American troops helped destroy more than one million marijuana plants in December in the rugged northern regions of this island, growers were outraged. They protested on radio and in front of Government offices. They appealed to business and political leaders. They even started a petition drive to ask President Clinton for damages.

title: France Playing Catch-Up In the Arts?
description: Delacroix, Cezanne, Manet, Monet, Matisse . . . and, and? While people around the world are lining up to see French masters, not to mention expatriates like van Gogh and Picasso who spent most of their careers in France, the country's contemporary artists are not exactly carrying on the tradition.

title: Hong Kong Plans Shifts in Reserves
description: Hong Kong said today that it would change the way it managed $118 billion of reserves, increasing the amount of United States dollars and equities in the portfolio and taking more risk in search of better returns.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Merriment Blends With Serious Moments In Taylor's Works
description: That Paul Taylor is one of our greatest, and most varied, choreographers was beautifully demonstrated on Tuesday night when the Paul Taylor Dance Company opened an engagement running through March 14 at City Center. The program, a benefit for the company, was a special one, for in addition to the New York premiere of ''Oh, You Kid!'' it offered this season's only performances of two major, stylistically dissimilar works, ''Airs'' and ''Sunset.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITCHINGS, THOMAS E.
description: HITCHINGS-Thomas E. On March 2, 1999. Cherished and adored father of Andrew, beloved husband of Katherine, loving brother of Laramie and loving brother-in-law of Robert Brown. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, March 5 and Saturday March 6 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: MANAGEMENT IS REORGANIZED AT UNOCAL TO HELP CUT COSTS
description: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it had reorganized its top management to better handle its oil and natural gas reserves and help it reduce cash costs by as much as $200 million a year. A four-member management committee was named to set company strategy and investment priorities, Unocal said. Roger C. Beach, the company's chief executive, is chairman of the committee. Unocal's reserve base, including potential reserves, is more than eight billion barrels of oil equivalent, Mr. Beach said. That is five times its current size. The other three members of the management committee are John F. Imle Jr., Timothy H. Ling and Charles R. Williamson, Unocal said.

title: Accounts
description: * Green Point Bank, New York, a unit of Green Point Financial Corp., to Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, New York, to handle its account, previously at Brouillard Communications, New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson Co. unit of the WPP Group P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $5 million. Della Femina/ Jeary already handles other Green Point units like Green Point Credit and Green Point Mortgage.

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: Union Cycliste Internationale

title: The Big City; A Peace Plan To Calm Barks And Shouts
description: THE dog war rages on, and the stories from the front line are not pretty. This week an elegant woman who lives on Riverside Drive arrived half an hour late for a dinner party and explained her tardiness in two words: ''Dog patrol.'' She grimly displayed her hands.

title: The Growing Business of Helping Elders Cope
description: When an 86-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease broke her hip, Deborah Newquist was the person who stayed with her at the hospital here. Years earlier, Dr. Newquist had arranged 24-hour home care for the woman and her bedridden husband, and she also took care of everything from having their house painted to getting their cat to the veterinarian.

title: Met's Next Season to Include 'Gatsby' Premiere
description: The 1999-2000 season of the Metropolitan Opera will include the world premiere of John Harbison's ''Great Gatsby,'' new productions of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' and Boito's ''Mefistofele,'' and three complete cycles of Wagner's ''Ring.'' The season details were announced yesterday by Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBLIN, DENIS R., M.D.
description: GIBLIN-Denis R., M.D. The administation, faculty, staff and students of The State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn mourn the passing of Denis R. Giblin, M.D., husband of Susan Schwartz-Giblin, Ph.D., Dean of the School of Graduate Studies. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the entire family and their colleagues and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D. Interim President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, MONA
description: KAPLAN-Mona. It has been one year since your life was taken suddenly by a drunk driver. I feel your presence in my life every day. You have been my guardian angel. I will miss and love you always. Love, your daughter, Kary

title: Eclipse Trading Signs 2
description: Eclipse Trading Inc. said yesterday that Discover Brokerage and the institutional brokerage firm Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities had agreed to subscribe to Eclipse's planned after-hours stock trading system for individual investors. The agreements insure that Eclipse will have a flow of investor orders when its system, known as Indivex, goes into operation in the middle of the year. That gives Eclipse an edge over the Wit Capital Corporation, which also plans an after-hours market for individuals. Wit Capital has yet to announce any brokerage firms that plan to participate in its after-hours market, which it also hopes to start in the middle of the year.

title: Bristol-Myers Shifts Two Accounts
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company has reassigned to roster agencies two accounts that had been handled by Intuition Group in New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C. The company and Intuition agreed last month to end a contract under which Intuition had handled several Clairol hair-care brands with billings estimated at $35 million.

title: No. 2 Official Out at Mattel In Shake-Up
description: Two top executives, including the chief operating officer, are leaving Mattel Inc. as part of a sweeping management reorganization announced today by the struggling toy maker.

title: Exuberance And Power In a 'Giselle' Made New
description: The Ballet Nacional de Cuba, founded and directed by Alicia Alonso, closed a United States tour with ''Giselle'' tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here. New York's loss is Newark's gain: a new generation of young Cuban dancers led by the vivacious Lorna Feijoo in the title role was deservedly cheered to the rafters.

title: Metro Business; Big Raise at Equitable
description: The Equitable Companies paid $5.8 million in salary and bonuses last year to its president and chief executive, Edward D. Miller, the company reported in a Federal filing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNDAGE, DORIS
description: BRUNDAGE-Doris. The Officers and Board of Governors of The Women's National Republican Club express their deep sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member and former President during the years of 1980 to 1983. Lila Prounis, President

title: Tyner Tries to Break the Mold of Top Met Draft Picks
description: There is a dark cloud hanging over Jason Tyner in his first big-league training camp, and he does not even know it's there.

title: Whales in the Minnesota River
description: TOURISTS drove six hours to Mankato, Minn., in search of underground caves and hot springs mentioned on a Web site. When they arrived, there were no such attractions.

title: Authorities Learn Identity Of Victim in '81 Slaying
description: A woman whose bludgeoned body was found wrapped in a shower curtain beneath a highway overpass in Jackson in 1981 has been identified more than 17 years later as a New York City prostitute born in Maine, officials said yesterday.

title: High Intensity Distress
description: LAURIE CRIBBS bought her new Lexus LS 400 for its luxurious appointments, but what really impressed her were its trendsetting super-bright headlights. ''I noticed them right away, because I didn't like to drive at night before,'' Ms. Cribbs said recently from the offices of Marriott International in Potomac, Md., where she works as a senior financial manager. ''In my car now, it's like night and day. The headlights light up everything so much, it's very noticeable. With the brights on, it's like daylight.''

title: Ewing Show Is Desperate For Co-Stars
description: Patrick Ewing was bobbing his head like one of those dashboard dolls while grooving to the music circulating through his headphones. Perched on a locker room chair just two feet from a television set, the Knicks center suddenly broke his rhythm and laughed out loud.

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: The Tour Saga

title: Some Foreign Funds Oppose Olivetti Bid
description: Standard Life Investments, one of Telecom Italia S.p.A.'s largest shareholders, and other investors said today that they opposed the $58 billion hostile takeover offer for the phone company by Olivetti because it would saddle the company with debt and hamper growth.

title: Sonat to Take a Charge
description: Sonat Inc., an oil and natural gas exploration company, said today that it would take a first-quarter charge of about $200 million to write down the value of reserves because of low energy prices. Sonat was not immediately available to comment on whether the charge of about $1.81 a share would result in a loss. Sonat had been expected to earn 30 cents a share before the charge, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. Sonat said it was taking the charge because natural gas prices had continued to fall.

title: Women's Groups Urge More Breast-Feeding
description: Increased breast-feeding could save the lives of up to 1.5 million of the roughly 12 million children under the age of 5 who die every year around the world, according to initial findings presented here this week by a group of women's organizations.

title: Dusty Springfield, 59, Pop Star of the 60's, Dies
description: Dusty Springfield, the smoky-voiced English torch singer whose interpretations of pop ballads were suffused with a heartbroken wistfulness, died on Tuesday at her home in Henley-on-Thames, near Oxford, west of London. She was 59.

title: Digital Rescuers Penetrate Snow
description: IN what is shaping up to be one of the snowiest winters on record, with about 65 feet covering parts of the West and dozens of people dying in avalanches in Europe, back-country skiers, snowshoers and snowmobilers are welcoming new digital technology used in searching for avalanche victims.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, JOAN
description: GROSS-Joan. We keep on loving you. Your gang

title: Aviall Is Considering Takeover by Nolan
description: The aviation-parts distributor Aviall Inc. said today that it was considering a friendly takeover bid from Nolan Acquisition Partners valued at $15.50 a share, or more than $282 million.

title: Hearing Ordered to See If a Jury Was Tainted
description: Six years after a jury convicted Robert Bisaccia of conspiracy and other charges as a captain in the Gambino crime family, an appellate panel ordered a hearing yesterday into whether the trial was tainted by disruptions that included a juror's car being riddled with bullets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHANE, AGNES M.
description: McSHANE-Agnes M. A longtime Public Affairs manager for Borden, Inc. in New York City, Agnes M. McShane died at the age of 78 at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY on March 3, 1999. Ms. McShane was an active parishioner of St. Matthew R.C. Church of Hastings-on-Hudson, where she was a Eucharistic Minister; Past President and Treasurer of the Altar Society; Past President of the Legion of Mary; member of the Third Order of St. Francis; the Woman's Club of Hastings and the Busy Bees organization. She worked in many charitable causes. Ms. McShane also produced a long term radio series for station WFAS entitled, ''The Legion of Mary Program.'' She was a graduate of Elizabeth Ann Seton College and took her Masters Degree at Pace University. Ms. McShane was the fond sister of Mrs. Mary A. Garcia, Mrs. Elizabeth M. Sullivan, Mrs. Margaret M. Edwards, Edward A. McShane, Jr., Ms. Alice V. McShane, Arthur E. McShane, Joseph E. McShane, Thomas E. McShane and the late Mrs. Catherine E. McLoughlin. Friends may call on Friday, March 5, 1999 at the Hastings Funeral Home, 15 Spring St., Hastings-onHudson, NY from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, March 6, 1999 at St. Matthew R.C. Church, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, at 10:15 AM. Interment follows at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: TLC Returns From the Brink
description: It has been five years since the attitude-laden rhythm-and-blues pop harmony group TLC released a follow-up to its 10-million-selling album ''Crazysexycool.'' But yesterday its new record, ''Fan Mail'' (Arista/LaFace), went to No. 1 on the pop charts. To the band and its label it was unexpected news after four years in which business threatened to overwhelm music.

title: SOUTHWEST TO ADD NEW DESTINATION: RALEIGH-DURHAM
description: Continuing its expansion on the East Coast, Southwest Airlines is expected to announce today that it will begin flying from the Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina later this year. The airport would be the second destination added to Southwest's network in 1999. The airline is scheduled to begin service from MacArthur Airport on Long Island next week. A spokesman for Southwest declined to confirm the announcement. But Mike Blanton, the spokesman for Raleigh-Durham International Airport, said Southwest would announce the new service at a news conference scheduled for this morning.

title: R. J. Reynolds Will Place A Disclaimer on Winston
description: In 1997, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company settled on ''No bull'' as an advertising slogan for its Winston cigarettes, which it said were 100 percent tobacco with no additives. The Federal Trade Commission, however, detected at least a little confusion among consumers and announced yesterday that the company, a unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, would start including disclaimers with its Winston advertising.

title: Jones Apparel's Stock Falls 12% Over Nine West Deal
description: The stock of Jones Apparel Group Inc. declined 12.2 percent yesterday, as the market frowned on the company's planned acquisition of Nine West Group, the shoe retailer and manufacturer.

title: Book Reveals Kazan's Thoughts on Naming Names
description: Throughout the emotional controversy over the decision to give him an honorary Academy Award, Elia Kazan has remained silent in the face of critics who still condemn him for naming names during the Congressional hunt for Communists in the entertainment industry in 1952.

title: LIBERTY FINANCIAL AND SOCIETE GENERALE CANCEL MERGER
description: The Liberty Financial Companies said yesterday that it had agreed with the Societe Generale Asset Management Corporation to terminate a $216 million merger agreement. In August, Liberty agreed to acquire the New York-based Societe Generale for stock and cash. Societe Generale is the United States mutual fund unit of the French bank Societe Generale S.A. Poor performance by the four mutual funds managed by Societe Generale and subsequent investor redemptions reduced the funds' net assets to just over $3 billion at the end of January from the $4 billion reported when the deal was first announced.

title: A magazine for investors reaches out to Madison Ave. and the public with its first big campaign.
description: BLOOMBERG PERSONAL FINANCE, the monthly magazine for private investors, is running its first major ad campaign to increase its awareness among both the advertising community and the general public.

title: New Monica Emerges, Feelings First
description: The promotions that ran for days showed Monica Lewinsky wiping a tear from her eye, as if in a parody (or a promise) of the inevitable: Barbara Walters always gets her subjects to cry. The weeping Monica image came near the end of last night's two-hour extravaganza, but the teasers were misleading in their traumatic tone.

title: Mozart and the S.A.T.'s
description: Almost daily we hear that the arts make kids smarter. Last week's issue of Parade magazine, for example, reported that children who studied the arts in high school got higher S.A.T. scores. And at the Grammy awards last week, Michael Greene, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, said that children who studied the arts scored higher on tests in math and science.

title: Stooped, Gray and Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INFANTOLINO, COSMO JOHN
description: INFANTOLINO-Cosmo John. The Board of Directors, staff and membership of the United Better Dress Manufacturers Association mourn the passing of its Director. Our sympatyhy is extended to his wife Marie and the entire family.

title: Metro Business; Con Ed to Sell Orion Three Power Plants
description: Consolidated Edison Inc., New York's largest electric company, said yesterday that it would sell three power plants for $550 million to the closely held Orion Power Holdings, in its last auction under a state deregulation plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ANNA REARICK (NAN)
description: ALLEN-Anna Rearick (Nan). Died March 2, 1999 in Exeter, N.H. She was born on May 7, 1913 in Summit, N.J. and graduated from the Kent Place School and Vassar College. She earned an M.A. from Columbia Teachers' College and, 25 years later, an M.S. in Library Science from Rutgers. She worked as a librarian in Monmouth Co., N.J. and Brooksville, ME. For the past 30 years, she lived in Brooksville, ME., and recently moved to Exeter. She was pre-deceased by her husband Joseph W. Allen and is survived by her four daughters, Nancy Allen of Surry, ME., Sarah Allen of Brooklyn, N.Y. Martha Mihara of Seattle, WA., and Susan Patlove of Charlemont, MA., nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren.

title: Foreign Paper? Try Its Site
description: WHEN I was growing up a newspaper buff, there was no greater joy than taking my allowance money to what was known as the Out-of-Town newsstand in Times Square. Spilling out of this kiosk, now long gone, were newspapers from Topeka to Tokyo.

title: Essay; After Indy Counsels
description: Back in the Bush Administration, press reports revealed the corrupt use of U.S. Government grain guarantees to help Saddam Hussein build his war machine before he surprised us by invading Kuwait. When the Justice Department shyly turned away, the need arose for independent counsel to explore ''Iraqgate.''

title: On the Horizon; Trying to Get Drowsy Drivers Off the Highway
description: SOME truck drivers drink coffee when they start to feel drowsy during long hours on the road. Others pull over and take quick laps around their trailers, naps in the back of their cabs or, in some cases, amphetamines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, JOYCE
description: BLOCH-Joyce. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of our friend and long-time supporter, Joyce Bloch. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Ephraim, and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Williams's 20 Spark Cardozo
description: Last season, the Cardozo forward Brian Woodward was averaging 33 points a game when he tore a knee ligament in the third game. Without its star, Cardozo lost in the first round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOWKSKI, MOSES
description: JANOWKSKI-Moses, 87 on February 28. Beloved husband of the late Roza Janowksi, father of Aaron, Benjamin, and Batyah, grandfather to Daniel, Larry, Lisa, David, Peter, and Ephraim, brother of Berl, Rachel and Hannah. His humor, enthusiasm, respect for scholarship, integrity, dignity and caring for others will live on in the memory of all who knew him.

title: In Television Interview and in Book, Lewinsky Seizes Initiative
description: Finally free to seek self-justification and personal profit, Monica S. Lewinsky opened a double-fronted campaign today to explain the sexual affair that led to the impeachment of President Clinton and put the nation through a harrowing year of scandal tracking.

title: McEnroe Pulls Out Of Tournament
description: The Nuveen Masters, the season-ending event to decide the champion of the men's senior circuit, has hit hard luck for the second year in a row.

title: Stooped, Gray and Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Assail Strike on Iraq That Disabled Oil Pipeline
description: Turkey today criticized the air war over Iraq and declared that the American strike that disrupted a pipeline to Turkey this week was unacceptable.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Goldman, With New Card, Plans a Summer Dance
description: Like a once-spurned debutante eager to get back in contention, Goldman, Sachs & Company, the last big private investment bank in the nation, is throwing another coming-out party, but this time it may not be as lavish.

title: Victory Gallop Gallops to Victory
description: Victory Gallop, who prevented Real Quiet from sweeping the Triple Crown last year when he won the Belmont Stakes, made his 1999 debut yesterday after a four-month layoff and won an allowance race at Gulfstream Park by 2 lengths.

title: A Roof That Glitters and Glows
description: ''Convention centers are no-brainers for architects who don't want to think of all that they can be,'' the architect Rafael Vinoly said. Last week, Mr. Vinoly won the competition to make Pittsburgh's new convention center swoopingly striking. Mr. Vignoly's energetically engineered design was chosen over those by such heavy-hitters as Arquitectonica, Cesar Pelli and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.

title: Man Admits Trying to Sell Missile Parts to Iran
description: A New Jersey arms dealer admitted in Federal District Court in Newark yesterday that he tried to sell missile parts to Iran, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: '98 Heineken Net Up, But Outlook Drops Stock
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken N.V. posted stronger-than-expected 1998 results yesterday, but its stock fell sharply as the company said the pace of profit growth would slow in 1999. Although Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer after the Anheuser Busch Companies, said net profit would grow in 1999, it said the increase would not be as high as in 1998, when net profit rose by 29 percent, to 981 million guilders ($485 million). The increase topped expectations by both analysts and the company itself. Analysts had estimated net profit at 952.9 million to 973 million guilders, while Heineken had predicted the full-year rise at 28 percent. The company's stock fell 2.55 euros, to 44.85.

title: How to Separate Good Data From Bad
description: THE first rule when it comes to information found on the Web (and many other places as well): be skeptical. You would not buy a stock, write a check or believe a contentious statement from an unknown source off line -- so bring the same challenging attitude to information found on line. And don't be shy about going off line to check something: go to a library or pick up a phone to check.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: New York's Job Growth in '98 Was Best Since '84, State Says
description: Companies in New York State added jobs in 1998 at the fastest pace since 1984, and the number of jobs in the private sector continued to grow in January, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday.

description: JOSEPHSON-Jean C. (McCall) of Monroe Twp., NJ, died Tuesday, March 2. Wife of the late Emanuel Josephson, M.D. Former comptroller of United Cerebral Palsy Association, NY. The great great niece of King Christian IX of Denmark & granddaughter of Prince John of Denmark, she held the title of Princess Dagmar. Services 11 A.M., Friday at Lester Memorial Home, 16 West Church Street, Jamesburg, NJ. Interment at Mount Olivet, Queens, New York. Memorials to Assoc. Humane Society of NJ or ASPCA of NY.
