In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in Bill's name to The International Tennis Hall of Fame, 100 Park Ave, New York, NY 10017 or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, NY Chapter, 381 Park Avenue South, NY NY 10016.

title: Is the Internet a Web of Deceit?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEISSNER, MARION W.G.
description: PLEISSNER-Marion W.G., 97, of Manchester, Vermont, died Sunday, February 28, 1999 at her home in Manchester. A memorial celebration of Mrs. Pleissner's life will be held on Saturday March 6, 1999 at 11am at the First Congregational Church of Manchester in the small chapel. Committal will be private. There are to be no calling hours. For those who wish, memorial gifts in Mrs. Pleissner's memory may be made to the Manchester Rescue Squad or the Southern Vermont Art Center, c/o Brewster Funeral Service, PO Box 885, Manchester CTR, VT 05255.

title: Hunter to Join Yanks' Opener
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter, the Hall of Fame pitcher who has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, arrived here this afternoon and will participate in pre-game ceremonies as the Yankees open their exhibition season Thursday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Strand of Hair May Point To Who Has Breast Cancer
description: X-ray analysis of a single hair may lead to a simple test to detect breast cancer, Australian researchers suggest in the current issue of the journal Nature.

title: You Say You Want Evolution?
description: COMPUTERS based on the new Pentium III microprocessor are now in the stores, and that is happy news indeed for anyone shopping for a new PC -- not necessarily because the Pentium III is a such a great chip, although this third iteration does have its charms. Rather, the arrival of the Pentium III is welcome because it means that prices for most PC's with lesser chips are going to come down soon.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about opposition to the Palisades Center mall in West Nyack, N.Y., misstated the outcome of a series of lawsuits against its developer, the Pyramid Companies, by Karl S. Coplan, co-director of the Pace Environmental Law Clinic. The developer prevailed in two suits, not all five. Mr. Coplan prevailed in two suits and one was dropped.

title: Occidental Upheld on Award vs. Chevron
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that the Oklahoma Supreme Court had upheld a $742.2 million judgment against the Chevron Corporation.

title: Report Says Buyers Can Choose Clean Cars or Clean Factories
description: For environmentalists in the market for a new car, the choice is not an easy one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HARRY J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Harry J. On Wednesday, March 3, at Middletown, NJ. Beloved father of Lynne Goldman and Norman I. Friedman, cherished brother of Ben Friedman, adoring grandfather of three. Services at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 1-800-247-5235.

title: Operator Replaced for Hotel at 55 Wall St.
description: Regent International Hotels will replace the Cipriani family as operator of the historic building at 55 Wall Street that is being converted from a bank headquarters to a hotel, Regent is expected to announce today.

title: Queens Prosecutor Will Drop Drug Charges Against Minister
description: Prosecutors moved yesterday to drop drug charges against the Rev. Frank Almonte, a popular television evangelist from Corona, Queens, who faced prison and deportation for bringing 300 steroid pills that he said he believed to be ''appetite enhancers'' into the country.

title: New Cellular Phone Batteries Are Called Tough but Gentle
description: While cellular telephones radiate a sort of cordless chic, anybody who owns one knows that usually sooner rather than later, they must be reattached to their cords, which are plugged into electrical outlets for recharging.

title: Democrats and Republicans Rally on Issues
description: Under a campaign-style blue banner, President Clinton rallied today with Congressional Democrats to show party unity on a legislative agenda that would reserve more than three-quarters of Federal budget surpluses for Social Security and Medicare.

title: The Elements of Love
description: ''The Chemistry of Change'' is a cloud of vapors desperately trying to gather comedic strength. In this play by Marlene Mayer, Carlin Glynn portrays Lee, a plucky woman of a certain age who in marrying for money nine times has never hit the jackpot. Suddenly, in her liaison with an amiable carnival worker in devil's horns, played by Larry Pine, deeper feelings stir. Can this, at long last, be love?

title: More Cycling Sites
description: www.cyclingnews.com -- Commonly known as Bill's, for Bill Mitchell, the economist who founded it, this Australian site relies on more than 50 volunteers to gather race results from around the world.

title: Brought Along Slowly, Malhotra Is Maturing
description: When Manny Malhotra celebrates his 19th birthday on May 18, he probably will not be playing hockey. Even if the rebuilding Rangers qualify for the Stanley Cup playoffs, they almost certainly will be eliminated by then. And the overall statistics for 1998-99 will show Malhotra as a first-round draft choice who did not play much for most of the schedule. He probably will not get any votes for the Calder Trophy as rookie of the year. An outsider might conclude that this was a so-so debut for a young man chosen seventh over all in the National Hockey League entry draft.

title: U.S.O.C.'s Next Steps: Clean Up Mistakes
description: United States Olympic Committee officials acknowledged today that the committee's oversight of Salt Lake City's scandal-ridden bid for the 2002 Winter Games was abysmal and vowed to strictly monitor the host-city selection process in the future.

title: Ledee Says He's Ready For Work Full Time
description: Whenever Ricky Ledee tried to navigate the narrow, dusty streets around his house in Salinas, P.R., last November, the streets would usually close around him. The boys and girls would stop playing and the men and women would stop working. Everyone rushed to greet their neighbor, who was also a World Series hero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTINIQUE, ALICE BOYLE
description: BARTINIQUE-Alice Boyle. Age 86. Of Elizabeth, N.J. On March 2, 1999. Mother of Leo J. and A. Patricia Bartinique. Funeral Mass Saturday, March 6th, 10:30AM, Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Elizabeth. Viewing Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at The Leonard Home for Funerals, Elizabeth, N.J. Donations to The Alice Boyle Bartinique Scholarship Fund, c/o Saint Mary's High School, Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Something About New York Strikes at the Heart
description: People who live in New York City -- and even those who are just visiting the city -- are more likely than other Americans to die of heart attacks, according to researchers from California.

title: Always Sympathetic Ear For Dreary Commutes
description: Until recently, people who talked to their cars were generally considered to be bemused, unstable or possibly nuts. Soon they will be considered the high-tech elite.

title: Kmart Earnings Sharply Higher
description: The Kmart Corporation, the No. 2 discount retailer in the United States behind Wal-Mart, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose a greater-than-expected 32 percent as it sold more clothing and home goods under its Martha Stewart and other private brands.

title: Ability to Expel Foreigners Is Argued in Court
description: Arguing an important case on Federal refugee law, the Clinton Administration told the Supreme Court today that foreigners who have committed serious nonpolitical crimes outside the United States are ineligible for refugee status no matter how severe a risk of persecution they would face if deported to their home countries.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page obituary headline on Saturday about Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg referred imprecisely to his achievement. Plutonium was created, not found, by his team.

title: BASEBALL: Invisible Man on First; Boston Let Mo Vaughn Go, but Who Will Replace Him?
description: Mo Vaughn wasn't in the Boston Red Sox spring training camp today. Roger Clemens wasn't there, either. But then neither was Ted Williams, nor Babe Ruth for that matter.

title: Iran's Impulse for Change
description: The power of democracy is altering Iran. Unofficial results from municipal elections show that Iranians overwhelmingly supported moderate politicians associated with President Mohammad Khatami. The voting mirrored the presidential election that swept Mr. Khatami to power two years ago. Though conservative clerics remain the paramount rulers of Iran, Iranians are clearly impatient to lift religious repression and transform their country.

title: Man Claims 'Ghost' Drove Him to Push Woman to Her Death
description: A man accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a subway train told the police in a signed statement that a ''ghost or a spirit or something like that'' sparked an ''uncontrollable urge'' in him just before the attack, according to court documents released yesterday.

title: Comity in Congress May Not Be So Noble a Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: No. 2 Official At Treasury Faults G.O.P. Budget Plans
description: A top official in the Clinton Administration strongly objected today to a Republican plan that would allow some money theoretically earmarked for Social Security to be spent for other purposes over the next two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINN, OSCAR
description: ZINN-Oscar. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their former long standing member, Oscar, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Eleanor, and his family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, ALLEN
description: WARDWELL-Allen, 64. Died March 1 of a heart attack while vacationing in Colorado. He was a preeminent specialist in the art of the Northwest Coast Indian shaman, and a senior consultant in American Indian Art and Tribal Art at Christie's in New York. Educated at Groton, Yale, and New York University, Wardwell opted not to pursue a career in law-his grandfather founded the law firm of Davis, Polk and Wardwell, in which his father was a partnerchoosing instead to find work through his passion for fine art. After receiving his Master's in Art History, Wardwell served as head of the Primitive Art Dept at the Art Institute of Chicago from 1960-1973, and was director of the Asia Society Gallery, New York, from 1974-1984. From 1986 to 1990 Wardwell was director of the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in New York. He also taught university courses at various times and, among his many consulting activities was curatorial consultant for African and Oceanic Art at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. Wardwell was the author of several books and catalogues within his fields, including the recently published study of Northwest Coast shamanic Indian art, ''Tangible Visions''. Wardwell was also passionate about music and dancing, went frequently to the Rainbow Room, and could be seen dancing on his roller skates almost every weekend in Central Park. Allen leaves his wife Sally, a daughter Lelia, his sons William and Alexander, his granddaughter Sarah, two sisters Lelia Seidner and Helen DuBois, and his aunt Clarissa Pell. He was the father-in-law of Deborah Wardwell, Henriette Wardwell, and Edmund Mander. He is also survived by several cousins, nieces and nephews and many, many friends. For details about a celebration of Allen's life, please call Edmund Mander 212-665-5373.

title: CREW THREATENING TO RESIGN HIS POST AS SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: Drawing an ideological line over an emotional issue in public education, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has warned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that he will resign if the administration pushes through an experimental voucher program to spend tax dollars for children to attend private schools, a person close to the Chancellor said yesterday.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO SELL ITS STAKE IN TRASH HAULER
description: Republic Industries, the No. 1 automobile retailer, plans a public sale of its stake in the trash hauler Republic Services Inc. after it failed to get tax-free status for a distribution to shareholders. Republic Industries expects to sell 112.2 million common shares of Republic Services, the fourth-largest United States trash hauler, in the second quarter. The company said it did not distribute the stake to its own shareholders because it could not obtain a favorable ruling from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, CHARLES HENRI
description: KAHN-Charles Henri. Died on February 22, 1999 unexpectedly at his Santa Cruz, CA. home. He was 83. Mr. Kahn was an aerospace engineer with a career spanning over 65 years. His passion in life was engineering and innovation. He served in WWII in the French Foreign Legion. He is survived by his wife, Anne Marie Kahn, of Santa Cruz, his son, Philippe Kahn, of Scotts Valley, CA, and his brother, Rudy Carne, of England. He also leaves four grandchildren. A private family graveside service was held February 27 in Santa Cruz. Remembrances in his name are preferred to the Reintroduction of Wolves Program C/O Yellowstone National Park Foundation for the Reintroduction of Wolves into the Park (37 East Main Suite #

title: In Kosovo's Furtive War, a Serb Just Disappears
description: The whole village turned out, some three hundred people gathered on the hillside beside a small 12th-century Serbian Orthodox chapel. They were burying a villager, a man of 42, who was kidnapped Saturday and handed back dead a few days later.

title: Cabaret Festival With an International Flavor
description: The international success of albums by the Three Tenors and Andrea Bocelli along with the growing Latin American crossover market have created a climate in which linguistic xenophobia is finally on the wane in American pop. The receptivity to other languages even extends to the nostalgic world of cabaret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKELEY, ESTHER
description: BERKELEY-Esther, 77 on March 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph, devoted mother of Alan, Janet and Linda; loving grandmother of Joshua, Sara, Sammy, Shannon, Benji and Brett. No wife could have given more; no mother could have loved more. She was adored by her children and grandchildren. She was a blessing and an inspiration to all who knew her and her spirit. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association. Services Thursday 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: About the Tables
description: To accommodate growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is making its daily mutual funds table more concise.

title: Used-PC Bargains Add Appeal to Life in the Slow Lane
description: IN an age when you can't be too rich or too thin or have too much RAM, is there any reason to buy a secondhand computer, one of those early wood-burning Pentiums?

description: ALTER-Shelby W. On March 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Bertha. Devoted father of Bruce and Miles and father-in-law Madi and Roberta. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Services Friday 10AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Judge Refuses Separate Trials For 5 Officers in Louima Case
description: Four police officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn and a sergeant accused of trying to cover up their actions will be tried together, a Federal judge said yesterday. He rejected the motions of each to be tried separately from one or more of the others.

title: Prices Retreat A Fifth Time In Seven Days
description: The price of United States bonds fell yesterday for the fifth time in seven days as the General Motors Corporation reported stronger-than-expected February car sales, the latest sign that the economy is booming.

title: Tug-of-War Over Power Roils Senate In Alabama
description: The Alabama Legislature dissolved into chaos and paralysis this week as the state's newly elected Lieutenant Governor, a Republican, used a quick gavel on Tuesday to snatch power from the Democratic majority in the state Senate.

title: Judge Sees Good-Faith Effort To Integrate Hartford Schools
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that Connecticut had made a good-faith effort to desegregate the Hartford schools after a landmark State Supreme Court ruling two years ago, and told a group pushing for speedier progress to be more patient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ADELE EYSLER
description: HARRIS-Adele Eysler. On March 2, 1999. Formerly of Canyon Lake, TX. Beloved sister of the late A. Robert and Barbara Eysler. Adored aunt to David Eysler, M.D. and Lesley Eysler. Cherished great-aunt to Brent, Gavin and Robert. Services today 1PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpke, Woodbury, Long Island.
