description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Says New Playstation Might Even Show Movies
description: With much fanfare, Sony this week announced its plans for the next generation of Playstation, which will be released in early 2000. The company said graphics would come to life and that 3-D images would pop off the screen of the new console, which will have a 300-megahertz, 128-bit processor.

title: The Other Working Parent
description: For a lesson in what keeps us from doing a better job of meeting the needs of working mothers, take a look at the media coverage of the latest ''don't feel guilty'' study.

title: Deal Protects Maine Woods From Development
description: Great swaths of the Maine woods with a combined area larger than Rhode Island would be protected forever from development under a $28 million plan announced today and thought to encompass more territory than any other such deal.

title: Clearing the Air When the Dog Must Stay
description: WHEN I adopted a big Labrador mutt from the streets of Red Hook, Brooklyn, I never dreamed I'd be allergic to her. But every time she flopped down on the floor, little clouds of hair drifting into the air, I sneezed. My eyes itched. I developed what felt like a chronic cold. If she slept in my room, I'd wake up with that tight feeling in my chest so familiar from an asthmatic childhood.

title: A Haughty Blast From Communism's Past
description: On his first vacation as Italy's Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema took his family on a private visit to New York over Christmas. His children wanted to see the Broadway musical ''Cats'' and F. A. O. Schwarz. Mr. D'Alema, a former Communist, wanted to see what the world's leading superpower has to offer, so he also went to eat at the TriBeCa Grill, the trendy downtown restaurant.

title: Beyond 'Bus Diplomacy,' Little Hope of an Early Settlement on Kashmir
description: WASHINGTON  The "bus diplomacy" that brought the leaders of India and Pakistan together for a tension-defusing meeting last month was warmly welcomed by U.S. officials and applauded by those who follow the situation most closely in Washington.

title: Orioles-Cuba Decision Is in the Final Innings
description: While the Baltimore Orioles await word from Washington on a possible home-and-home series with the Cuban national team, Major League Baseball is nearing a decision of its own.

title: Stooped, Gray and Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: The Redwoods Deal
description: There is much to celebrate in Tuesday's historic agreement under which the Federal and California governments will pay the Pacific Lumber Company $480 million for 10,000 acres of redwood forests along the northern California coast. Saving the largest privately owned grove of ancient redwood trees in the world for future generations is a tribute to the public officials and tireless private citizens who made it happen. The deal is also a vindication of the much-maligned Endangered Species Act, without which the trees would surely have been doomed.

title: Should We Cut Social Security Loose?
description: Two conservative members of Congress -- Representative Wally Herger, a California Republican, and Representative David Minge, a Minnesota Democrat -- have introduced a bill that would separate Social Security from the rest of the Federal budget. Their rationale sounds persuasive enough on the surface: to protect future retirees by preventing Social Security's current surpluses from being absorbed into other parts of the budget.

title: Sports of The Times; Hard Work Transforms A Program
description: YOU don't see Leonard Hamilton relax that often. On the sidelines, during practices, watching film, Hamilton, the coach of the University of Miami's surging basketball team, moves with a never-ending sense of urgency. He lives in a world where the mission is never complete, the deed never done.

title: Stewing Over That Project? Laptop Stand Keeps You Cool
description: The mobile computer is a given. Now the desk is portable, too.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWE, MARY RUTH JOHNSON
description: LOWE-Mary Ruth Johnson. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 5th at 3 P.M., in the Nave of the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation be made to the Mt. Garland Baptist Church, 4000 Buckner Rd. Bumpass, VA 23024

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUTH, ARTHUR EDWARD
description: MUTH-Arthur Edward, 75, former president and co-owner of Petry Television Company, New York, NY, died March 1 at his home in Indian River Shores, FL. He was a native of Yonkers and attended Cornell and graduated from Rutgers University. He was a member of the University Club in New York, a Platform Tennis National Champion, and member of Fox Meadow Tennis Club, Scarsdale.

title: Art on the Head of a Microchip
description: WHEN Michael Davidson first started photographing silicon chips through a microscope 10 years ago, he wanted ''to promote circuitry as an art form,'' he said. Four years ago, his microscope excavated another kind of art from the microprocessor's metallic layers: a drawing of Where's Waldo. ''At first, I thought it was an example of reverse engineering,'' said Mr. Davidson, a research scientist with the Natural Magnetic High Field Laboratory in Tallahassee.

title: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
description: Rivendell Reader

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Newport News Joins in a New Venture
description: Newport News Shipbuilding Inc., the world's largest maker of nuclear submarines and aircraft carriers, and the Science Applications International Corporation formed a new company called Amsec L.L.C. to expand their fleet-services businesses. Financial terms of the deal, which was announced today, were not disclosed.

title: Marine Jury Weighs Fate Of Jet Pilot
description: A jury of eight Marine officers began deliberating this afternoon whether a pilot whose plane struck ski-lift cables in the Italian Alps 13 months ago was guilty of a crime, or whether the incident that killed all 20 people in a gondola was simply an accident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MYRON KAY (MIKE)
description: STONE-Myron Kay (Mike), died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach on March 2nd, just before his 85th birthday. Beloved husband and best friend of Natalie Gordon Stone for 58 years. Devoted father of Elizabeth and Kincaid Webb, Pamela and Robert Ancowitz, and Randall and Erin Stone. Adored grandpa of Ben, Jonno, Jenny, Jesse, Josh, Joey, Bianca and Jackie, and proud great-grandfather of Emma. Brother of Irving and Pearl Stone and Didi Stevens. Brother-in-law of Melvin and Ellin Gordon. Mourned by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Born in Brockton, Mass., son of the late Joseph and Marie Stone, graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard University 1937. Lover of art, former Chair of Boston Tributary Theater, Secretary of the Boston Chapter of American Jewish Committee, member of the Board of the Jewish Association of the Aged, Patrons' Committee of the New York Philharmonic, Board of the American Place Theater, Building Advisory Committee of Kravis Center, Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. President of Designers Originals, manufacturer of women's sweaters, and vice president of its parent company, Hampshire Design. Member of the Harvard Club and Beach Point, honorary member of the Class of 1938 of Wellesley College. The family is grateful to Tom Kirkpatrick, Gaspare Colletti, Sally Huggins, and their families for their long years of loving care. Family will receive at their summer home in Mamaroneck, New York, this Saturday, Sunday and Monday evenings, and Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at home in Palm Beach. Graveside ceremony will be private.

title: Spanish Chain to Bid For Vivendi's Hotels
description: Sol Melia S.A., a hotel chain based in Spain, said yesterday that it planned to bid for the hotel unit of Vivendi S.A., France's largest water utility, which is seeking to sell noncore assets. Sol Melia expects Vivendi to present a narrowed-down list of possible buyers by the end of the month.

title: Nassau's Democratic Chief Guilty of Bankruptcy Fraud
description: Stephen J. Sabbeth, the chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, was found guilty today of bankruptcy fraud, throwing his already splintered party into further disarray as it immediately began to talk about his departure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, DEANE F.
description: JOHNSON-Deane F. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center are deeply saddened by the death of their colleague and friend, Deane F. Johnson. Mr. Johnson was a member of Memorial Sloan-Kettering's Boards from 1982 to 1996. During his long association with the Center, he was actively supportive of the Center and its mission. We have been most grateful for Mr. Johnson's wise counsel, guidance, and generosity. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. James D. Robinson III, Honorary Co-Chairman Laurance S. Rockefeller, Honorary Co-Chairman Benno C. Schmidt, Honorary Co-Chairman Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Boards of Overseers and Managers Richard L. Gelb Vice Chairman of Boards Chairman, Board of Managers Sloan-Kettering Institute H. Virgil Sherrill Vice Chairman of Boards Chairman, Board of Managers Memorial Hospital Paul A. Marks, M.D., President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Siemens Plans U.S. Venture In Data Market
description: Siemens A.G. of Germany is about to expand into the fast-growing data networking business by forming a new American subsidiary, acquiring two private companies in the United States, investing in a third and hiring a senior executive from I.B.M., executives close to the company's planning said yesterday.

title: New Yorkers Hear First Lady and See a Candidate
description: In a speech that many Democrats viewed as a strong indication that Hillary Rodham Clinton would run for the Senate from New York, the First Lady proclaimed her commitment to government and politics yesterday before some of her most passionate supporters, New York Democratic women, in a packed and enthusiastic ballroom of the Plaza Hotel.

title: The Game Of the Name
description: The conundrum faced by many novelists, particularly mystery and romance writers, is what to do when their sales have been poor and booksellers will stock only a few copies of their new work.

title: Japan Rebuffs Requests for Information About Its Germ-Warfare Atrocities
description: More than 50 years after the Japanese Army attacked China with germ weapons and conducted gruesome experiments on thousands of human beings, Japan is resisting demands that it compensate the victims or make records of the atrocities public.

title: TALKING WITH: Adrienne Salinger; In Solitary, and Satisfied
description: THEY have nothing in common and everything in common. ''We eat over the sink and in bed, and sometimes at a table,'' said the photographer Adrienne Salinger of people like herself who live alone. ''We find things where we left them. We always know where the good scissors are.''

title: Today's Rich Don't Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Picasso's Ceramics: Seriously Casual
description: You should have fun with the exhibition of Picasso's ceramic work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Picasso certainly seems to have enjoyed carving this particular notch in his cane of art conquests. That he did so during one of the happiest periods of his life may partly account for the unclouded lightness of these charming figures, wittily decorated plates, casseroles, pitchers, masks and glazed-tile paintings. Perhaps the second-class status traditionally accorded ceramics had a relaxing effect, contributing to the air of genius on holiday, veering in and out of focus, that permeates this show.

title: Real Squabble Over Real Estate
description: Although he is 91, retirement is not in the cards for Leo Castelli. On April 17, Mr. Castelli, the art dealer, is to open a new space at 59 East 79th Street, Manhattan, just two blocks from 4 East 77th Street, where he began in 1957. The inaugural exhibition will be devoted to monotypes by Jasper Johns, one of Mr. Castelli's longtime artists.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOONE, RUTH JACKSON
description: BOONE-Ruth Jackson. Died Tuesday, February 2 in Kennett Square, PA. She will always be lovingly remembered by her children Susan, Daniel and James, her son-in-law Rick, daughters-in-law Deborah and Meredith, and as their beloved Nana, by her grandchildren Linda, Garrett, Sarah, Gage, Wilson and David. She was cherished by all of us because she brought so much to all our lives and we will miss her deeply. A memorial service will be held at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA on March 7 at 2:00 PM. Donations may be made to American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, PA.

title: Dole to Offer Definite Sign She Plans Race
description: In a clear sign that she intends to run for President, Elizabeth Dole plans to announce next week that she is starting a committee that will allow her to explore a candidacy and raise money for a campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNEN, REV. GERARD
description: DENNEN-Rev. Gerard. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former parochial vicar of Saint Joan of Arc Church, Jackson Heights, on March 1st. Reposing at Gleason's Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, on Friday, March 5, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday, March 6, at Mary's Nativity Church, 46-02 Parsons Blvd, Flushing, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMLIN, ROBERT BOND
description: HAMLIN-Robert Bond. Born October 14, 1935 in Manistee, MI. Died February 28, 1999 in New York City. Mourned by Anna Hamlin and his beloved son Matthew. Rest in Peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MYRON KAY (MIKE)
description: STONE-Myron Kay (Mike), died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach on March 2nd, just before his 85th birthday. Beloved husband and best friend of Natalie Gordon Stone for 58 years. Devoted father of Elizabeth and Kincaid Webb, Pamela and Robert Ancowitz, and Randall and Erin Stone. Adored grandpa of Ben, Jonno, Jenny, Jesse, Josh, Joey, Bianca and Jackie, and proud great-grandfather of Emma. Brother of Irving and Pearl Stone and Didi Stevens. Brother-in-law of Melvin and Ellin Gordon. Mourned by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Born in Brockton, Mass., son of the late Joseph and Marie Stone, graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard University 1937. Lover of art, former Chair of Boston Tributary Theater, Secretary of the Boston Chapter of American Jewish Committee, member of the Board of the Jewish Association of the Aged, Patrons' Committee of the New York Philharmonic, Board of the American Place Theater, Building Advisory Committee of Kravis Center, Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. President of Designers Originals, manufacturer of women's sweaters, and vice president of its parent company, Hampshire Design. Member of the Harvard Club and Beach Point, honorary member of the Class of 1938 of Wellesley College. The family is grateful to Tom Kirkpatrick, Gaspare Colletti, Sally Huggins, and their families for their long years of loving care. Family will receive at their summer home in Mamaroneck, New York, this Saturday, Sunday and Monday evenings, and Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at home in Palm Beach. Graveside ceremony will be private.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, MARJORIE KANE
description: GERRY-Marjorie Kane. Died on March 4 at the age of 89 following a short illness at Delhi, N.Y. Widow of the late Elbridge T. Gerry who died on February 26. She is survived by two sons Elbridge T. Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y. and Peter G. of Hopewell, N.J., a daughter Marjorie G. Ryland of Beverly, MA., a sister Patricia Kane Leonard of Chesiers, Switzerland, eleven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A joint memorial service for she and her husband of 67 years will be held on Wednesday, March 10, 1999 at Trinity Church, Wall St. and Broadway, NYC, at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Lake Delaware Boys Camp or The O'Connor Hospital, Delhi, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, JOYCE N.
description: NICHOLS-Joyce N. On March 3 after battling Parkinson's Disease. Retired as Director of Scarsdale Public Library (1982-1992), she lived in Nyack, NY. Survived by her husband Robert J. Trudell, Retired Greenburgh Library Director; Children, Briar DeVito, Tobin Nichols and Kyle Nichols; stepchildren Ann and Robert H. Trudell and three grandchildren. Born in Washington State, Joyce was a descendant of Robert Louis Stevenson. She was a Senior Librarian in Smithtown, L.I. and Nesconset's first library director. Her family, friends and untold readers will miss her humor, resolve and intelligence. Joan and Louis Slovinsky

title: ALCATEL AGREES TO BUY ASSURED ACCESS FOR $350 MILLION
description: Alcatel S.A., Europe's No. 2 phone-equipment maker, made another foray into the United States Internet technology market yesterday by agreeing to buy the closely held Assured Access Technology Inc. for $350 million in cash. Assured Access, based in Milpitas, Calif., makes remote access devices that let phone companies and Internet service providers sell services that allow people to dial into a computer network from remote locations, like homes and airports. Earlier this week, Alcatel agreed to buy the Xylan Corporation, which makes data-networking equipment for corporate networks, for $2 billion in cash. Shares in Alcatel, based in Paris, rose 4.8 euros, to 113.9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, LILLIAN
description: ALEXANDER-Lillian. February 22, 1999. Sorely missed by husband William, daughter Jane, granddaughter Emma & brother Dave.

title: Canal Plus Ends Talks With Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch and Canal Plus S.A. broke off talks today on a possible merger of Europe's two biggest pay-television broadcasters, marking another setback in Mr. Murdoch's efforts to gain a foothold in Continental Europe.

title: China Grimly Pledges to Push On With Reforms
description: In a businesslike speech short on party rhetoric and long on macroeconomics, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji addressed the opening session of Parliament, saying that ''despite a grim economic picture,'' China would push on with economic and social reforms and continue ''opening our country wider to the outside world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXER, DR. CONSTANCE
description: BUXER-Dr. Constance. March 3, 1999. (See Feinberg-Constance) Cherished mother, sister, grandmother, mother-in-law and friend.

title: Where's the Outrage Over Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Public Lives profile yesterday about Marty Lederhandler, The Associated Press's longest-working photographer, misstated the location of the agency's headquarters at the time he was a messenger. Before the A.P. moved to Rockefeller Center, it was at 383 Madison Avenue, near 47th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, ELIZABETH
description: WEXLER-Elizabeth. To our beloved ''Grandma Libby,'' we thank her for showing us how happy we made her. Her love will always remain in our hearts. Carol, Jack and Jenny Posen, Ken, Leslie, Michael and Zoe Abelson

title: 'Fate Had Its Own Means Of Obstructing Them'
description: MONICA'S STORY

title: A First Lady's Plea for Women's Rights
description: On the second day of her visit as a potential candidate for a New York Senate seat, Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out yesterday at the United Nations against ''the egregious and systematic trampling'' of women's rights under the Taliban in Afghanistan, and called the trafficking in women and children in Asia an international human rights violation.

title: Justice Blackmun, Author of Abortion Right, Dies
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a modest Midwestern Republican who became a passionate defender of the right to abortion in 24 years on the Supreme Court, died today at the age of 90.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Walking into this small, unattractive dining room of 16-32 Coach House does not make you instantly nostalgic for the old Coach House in Greenwich Village, now the site of Babbo. The ghost of James Beard, who loved the old restaurant, does not seem to live here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINN, RICHARD
description: SHINN-Richard. We mourn with profound sadness the death of Richard Shinn, devoted member of our Managing Board from 1979 through 1994. His distinguished years of service as a member of the Executive Committee from 1986 through 1992, including the Committee Chairmanship in the 1989-1990 season, as Treasurer of the Board from 1986 through 1989 and as Chairman of the Finance Committee from 1980 through 1989, occurred at a critical time in the history of the Metropolitan Opera. During the years of his Board tenure, he made a deeply respected and important contribution to the long-term financial sercurity of our company. We valued his counsel, his wisdom, the generosity of his time in service to the Metropolitan Opera and his friendship. He leaves an enduring legacy to the institutions he served, including the Metropolitan Opera, and to the people of New York City. His life's work in public service is an inspiring example for future generations. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Marion and his family. Metropolitan Opera Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOWSKI, MOSES
description: JANOWSKI-Moses, 87 on February 28. Beloved husband of the late Roza Janowksi, father of Aaron, Benjamin, and Batyah, grandfather to Daniel, Larry, Lisa, David, Peter, and Ephraim, brother of Berl, Rachel and Hannah. His humor, enthusiasm, respect for scholarship, integrity, dignity and caring for others will live on in the memory of all who knew him.

title: Albright Takes Some Heat For Rambouillet 'Success'
description: PARIS  Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's personal efforts staved off failure at least temporarily in the Kosovo peace talks last month at Rambouillet, France, but her intensive, often improvised, diplomacy raised concerns that her entry into the talks clouded the prospects for settling the civil war between Serbs and ethnic Albanians when the two sides reconvene on March 15, according to officials in Europe and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, MARTHA (NEE ARKAWY)
description: BARNETT-Martha (nee Arkawy) of Morristown, NJ on March 4, 1999. Wife of the late Abraham Barnett. A graveside service will be held on Friday, March 5, 1999 at 2 PM from Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, NY.

title: Computer Issues Rejuvenated, With Dow Up 191.52
description: After weeks of sour news on technology stocks, the sector received a boost yesterday when I.B.M. announced that it had won a $16 billion order from Dell Computer for parts like disk drives and displays.

title: Another Perlman, et Al.
description: When the children of great musicians decide to become performers, listeners are tempted to do some peculiar gyrations. They look for the parent's technical facility and expressive individuality in the child, and worry if they don't hear it (such a pity not to have absorbed something from a model close at hand) and if they do (similarities could indicate a lack of originality). They wonder to what degree the parent's connections ease the way for the child, or to what degree the shadow of a famous parent is inhibiting.

title: AT&T TO BUY STAKE IN METRONET OF CANADA
description: The AT&T Corporation agreed yesterday to buy about a third of the Metronet Communications Corporation, a local service provider in Canada, to better compete with Bell Canada, that nation's No. 1 phone company. AT&T will swap its 33 percent stake in the AT&T Canada long-distance business for about 21 million shares of Metronet. That will give AT&T a 31 percent stake in the combined company and the right to buy the rest if the ownership limits, now at 33 percent, are eased. The value of the deal is about $1.4 billion (Canadian), or $918 million (United States). The new entity would keep the AT&T Canada name and would offer local, long-distance, Internet and wireless services nationwide.

title: Doctors With Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit Mayor Is Step Closer to Control of Schools
description: Frustrated by the many problems of Detroit's public schools, Michigan's Governor and Republican-controlled Legislature are moving swiftly to put the system under the Mayor's control.

title: Rachel Khedoori
description: David Zwirner

title: No End to Violence in Ulster: Each Side Now Kills Its Own
description: It took death and dismemberment to bring together the families of Andrew Peden, a 35-year-old Protestant, and Andrew Kearney, a 33-year-old Catholic, but the awkward union is serving to expose one of Northern Ireland's most persistent and ruthless traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, DEANE F.
description: JOHNSON-Deane F. Members of the Board of Trustees and staff of the American Red Cross in Greater New York note with sadness the loss of Deane Johnson, loyal member of our Board of Trustees in the 1980s and the 1990s. Mr. Johnson ably led our community appeal and was a trusted advisor to Red Cross staff members and trustees alike. Under his leadership Time Warner was a generous supporter of Red Cross and Red Crescent efforts locally, nationally and internationally. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Johnson family. The American Red Cross in Greater New York Jonathan O'Herron, Chairman Robert M. Bender, Jr., Chief Executive Officer

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Strangers on a Train? Not Quite, as They Come to Understand
description: A challenge is posed to every viewer of Arlene Hutton's ''Last Train to Nibroc.'' Ms. Hutton; Michael Montel, the director of the production at the 78th Street Theater Lab, and the perfectly matched actors, Alexandra Geis and Benim Foster, seem to be daring you not to like the characters in this old-fashioned love story and not to be taken in by their almost unimaginable innocence. But don't bet against this foursome. Let your guard down for even a few seconds, and they've got you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBER, HERMAN
description: LIEBER-Herman. 99. (Furrier) Of Refada, CA, formerly of Bronx, NY on March 2, 1999. Loving husband of his late wife Clara, beloved father of Morris & Sol, grandfather of four and greatgrandfather of eight. For info. regarding graveside services-Hegarty Funeral Home, 732-679-4422.

title: The Case of the Self-Doubting Don
description: ''Analyze This'' has a funny title, an even funnier premise and inspired odd-couple casting, with Robert De Niro (above, left) in the hilarious role of a Don experiencing fits of self-doubt, and Billy Crystal (right) as his beleaguered psychiatrist.

title: REPUBLICANS' PLAN WOULD KEEP MONEY IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Republican leaders of Congress agreed today on the broad outlines of a budget plan that they said would immediately wall off Social Security funds so that they could not be used to pay for tax cuts or new Government spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPPIN, ELEANOR T.
description: LAPPIN-Eleanor T., January 13, 1935-March 4, 1999. Mrs. Lappin, a 35 year resident of Elwood, was President and founder of Patel Security, a licensed polygraph business in service to industry and the legal profession. She was a recognized expert witness in the Federal Court, a member of the American Polygraph Association, Empire State and Vermont Polygraphers, the American Society for Industrial Security and the Federal Narcotic Enforcement Officers Association. Until her recent sudden illness with lymphoma, Mrs. Lappin taught at St. Mary's Children's School for Boys in Syosset, a career which started in Elwood schools more than twenty years ago. Mrs. Lappin is survived by her husband Patrick, children Grace, Patrick and Andrew, of New York City, three surviving grandchildren, her mother Grace, brother John and sister Josephine Pellegrino of Queens, and her lifelong childhood friend John E. Rush of Queens. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to St. Mary's Children's Services or Huntington Hospital Oncology Department.

title: Police Arrest a Suspect In Robberies of Elderly
description: A Manhattan man accused of robbing and assaulting more than a dozen elderly women during the last year was arrested Wednesday night, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Up Nearly 200 Points As I.B.M. Lifts Stocks

title: Dispersing Treasures for A Good Cause
description: Giuseppe Rossi of Turin, Italy, was famous for his connoisseurship, but he will be remembered for his generosity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, JOSEPH AND ADELE
description: COOPER-Joseph and Adele. Your 92nd birthdays & 70th anniversary. Lovingly remembered and missed Betty, Dave, Andy, Suzy

title: Verdict Astounds Italians, From Prime Minister on Down
description: Italians reacted with shock and outrage tonight to the acquittal of an American pilot who, in their view, recklessly sheared the cables of an Italian ski lift, causing the death of 20 tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, BARBARA
description: PFEFFER-Barbara. On March 3, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Rose and Felix Pfeffer. Survived by sister Doris Pfeffer, a circle of loving friends and relatives in Israel, Paris and The United States. Services at ''The Riverside'' on March 7th at 11 A.M.

title: Ukraine's Ex-Premier Says He's Closer to Gaining U.S. Asylum
description: Pavlo Lazarenko, the former Ukrainian Prime Minister who asserts that his nation's leaders are using corruption charges to persecute him, said today that he had cleared the first procedural hurdle toward winning political asylum in the United States.

title: Ruling Governs Schools In Rejecting Applicants
description: A state appellate panel has ruled that school districts, in rejecting applicants because of residency requirements, must inform the applicants of the grounds on which they are rejected, and that they must also fully inform the applicants of their right to attend the district while their appeal is pending, lawyers said yesterday.

title: Telefonica in Puerto Rico
description: Telefonica S.A., the largest telecommunications company in the Spanish-speaking world, said here today that it had formed a cellular phone venture in Puerto Rico with Clearnet Communications, a United States mobile phone company. Telefonica will invest $20 million to establish the venture, and Clearnet will provide the license. The company will operate under the Telefonica Larga Distancia brand name. The partners will also invest $100 million to build a digital mobile phone network within a year.

title: Mayor Pushes Voucher Plan, Brushing Aside Crew Threat
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday intensified his campaign to push a publicly financed voucher program through the Board of Education and brushed aside Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's threat to resign over the issue.

title: Congress Acts To Alter Rules On Banking
description: Diminishing the chances that Congress will pass major banking legislation this year, House and Senate committees took action today on sharply conflicting bills to eliminate Depression-era barriers between banks, securities firms and insurance companies.

title: St. John's Gets Its Druthers: A Rematch With Miami
description: The agendas were as plentiful in St. John's Big East tournament quarterfinal game last night against Rutgers as they are in a United States Senate caucus.

title: Keeping the Thugs in Constant Motion
description: Guy Ritchie's brash, ebullient direction of his first feature, ''Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels,'' makes it very obvious that he honed his style making music videos and commercials. And for once that doesn't hurt. The punchy little flourishes that load this English gangster film with attitude are perfectly welcome, because there's no honest, substantial part of the movie they can hurt. Mr. Ritchie is skillful enough to make a fine feat of macho gamesmanship out of the way four sets of East End crooks keep outsmarting one another. And if that means having them all arm for battle while the ''Zorba the Greek'' theme music heightens the intensity of the moment, well, why not?

title: How Magical Designers Manufacture Atmosphere
description: Beginning today, a special weeklong program at the Walter Reade Theater will examine the role of costume and production design in cinema and bring together some of the most distinguished luminaries in those fields. It's a rare opportunity to hear, for instance, Dante Ferretti discuss the dazzling, evocative exotica seen in ''Kundun'' immediately after that film is screened this afternoon. And this series' ambitious, all-star lineup will not confine itself solely to films of sumptuous beauty. The emphasis is on artfully evoked atmosphere and sheer visual imagination.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Where's the Outrage Over Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMDUR, CHARLES
description: AMDUR-Charles, on March 3rd, 1999. Adoring husband of the late Helen Freedman Amdur, cherished father of Kathryn Amdur Normandy and Martin Amdur, devoted father-in-law of John Normandy and Shirley Bell Amdur, loving grandfather of Richard and Stephen Amdur and dear uncle and great-uncle. Service Friday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in his memory to the charity of your choice.

title: Allen Wardwell, 64, Authority On Asian and Primitive Art
description: Allen Wardwell, director of the Asia Society Galleries in New York from 1974-84 and a prominent authority on primitive art of many kinds, died on Monday while on vacation in Colorado. He was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: On Breaking Up Microsoft Into 'Baby Bills'
description: The nation's largest software-industry trade group has warned the Government not to impose sanctions on Microsoft that could ''fracture'' the role of the company's Windows operating system as an industry standard, if the Government wins its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the artist Hughie Lee-Smith on Monday misidentified a Washington museum that has one of his paintings in its collection. It is the National Museum of American Art, not the National Gallery of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEVILLE, ANN ADAMS
description: MANDEVILLE-Ann Adams. Buffy Mandeville died peacefully at her home in Fairfield, Connecticut on the evening of March 1, in her seventy-second year. She is mourned by her daughter Meredith Hollis and sons Christopher, Matthew, Kempton, Jonathan, & William Mandeville, her son-in-law James Hollis, and daughters-inlaw Claire, Olivia, Nancy, Anne & Maribel Mandeville, her brother Dean Adams and her former husband Hubert T. Mandeville. She will also be missed by her devoted grandchildren Erinn, Krista, Amanda, Julia, Elizabeth, Courtney, Kempton, Turner, Allison, Willie, Adelaide, Ariel, Paulina, Carlos, Miguel, Henry and Estelle. A graduate of Dana Hall & Vassar College, she will be remembered for her loyal and effective handson service to many institutions, including the Fairfield Women's Exchange, the Garden Club of America (for whom she was a widely respected judge), Trinity Parish and the Pequot Library of Southport, CT, Bridgeport Hospital, the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County, and the Dana Hall and Fairfield Country Day Schools. She was a member of the Colony Club and the Country Club of Fairfield. A person of exceptional character, probity and steadfastness, she loved and enjoyed her family, her friends and their children. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Southport, CT., on Saturday, March 6th, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to Bridgeport Hospital or the Rehabilitation Center of Fairfield County.

title: The Selling of a Cell
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Jittery Van Gundy Should Rein In Horses
description: WHEN the coach of an 8-5 basketball team ominously declares that ''the season is slipping away,'' he needs to take another look at the standings, or immediately put in a reality-check call to John Calipari.

title: A Habit Yanks Can't Seem to Shake
description: Already, the Yankees' record-setting season of 1998, when they won 125 games and a World Series title, seems like ancient images painted onto a cave wall.

title: State Constitution Poses High Hurdles for Voucher Proposal
description: Even if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gains the Board of Education's approval for an experimental school voucher program, the idea of using public money to send New York City school students to private schools will still face serious, and perhaps insurmountable, legal hurdles.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about ''The Greedy Hand: How Taxes Drive Americans Crazy and What to Do About It'' misspelled the author's surname. She is Amity Shlaes, not Schlaes.

title: Sprewell Is Ready to Play, But How Much Is Uncertain
description: Latrell Sprewell expects he will need at least 50 tickets for the Knicks' game on Friday night in Milwaukee. But just how much his hometown friends and family will get to see him play after almost four weeks on the injured list is the question.

title: Why the Movies Will Cost $10
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba's Intoxicating Mix of Spanish Song and African Beat
description: A couple of hundred people were probably seen emerging onto 57th Street on Tuesday evening with the throb of the habanera in their steps. They were the audience for ''Dance Date With Cuba,'' the New York Festival of Song's concert of music from Cuba at Weill Hall. It was the first installment of the American Composers' Orchestra's Sonidos de las Americas festival this year.

title: Lewinsky Proves to Be Popular With Both Viewers and Sponsors
description: Americans were sick and tired of Monica S. Lewinsky, and even Barbara Walters would not offer enough incentive to watch more, some people said. Others said Ms. Lewinsky's face and voice would be magnetic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAUFMAN, MICHAEL ANDREW
description: KAUFMAN - Michael Andrew. Your 39th birthday. You are forever in our hearts. Love always. Mother and Stephanie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, WARD
description: STEVENSON-Ward. Suddenly, on March 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Margot McNicol Stevenson of Bronxville, NY; dear father of Peter Stevenson of New York City, Scott Stevenson of North Carolina, and Laurie Willix of Chicago. Senior vice president and general counsel for the Church Pension Group and a former member of the law firm of Rogers and Wells. Memorial visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Saturday, March 6, 2-5 PM. Memorial service at St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50 St., Monday, March 8, at 10:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Fund for Animals, Suite 705, 200 W. 57 St, 10019.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about a study of journalists and the Internet misspelled the surname of an author and the name of his marketing and public relations firm. The author is Don Middleberg, not Middleburg; the firm is Middleberg & Associates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, REBBITZIN GUTA
description: ALPERT-Rebbitzin Guta. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Frieda Lewinter and the grandmother of our esteemed member Karen Mazurek and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: U.S. Execution of German Stirs Anger
description: A German citizen was executed in a gas chamber in Arizona on Wednesday night, leading Germans today to accuse the United States of ''barbarism'' and of flouting international law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, CLARA (NEE WOHL)
description: SCHAPIRO-Clara (nee Wohl), passed away March 3, 1999 at the age of 94 in Miami Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Sam Schapiro. Loving mother of Jules (Claudia) Schapiro of New York City and Murray (Connie) Schapiro of Hobe Sound, FL. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Roberta (Richard) Hunter, Nina Schapiro, Alan (Susan) Schapiro, Scott (Cindy) Schapiro, David Schapiro, Richard (Nobuko) Weisburd, and Stacey (Richard) Schwamb. Proud great-grandmother of Daniel, Jessica, Ian, Danielle, Holly, Michael, Tamar, Josh, Nicholas and Kimberly. Services Sunday, March 7th at 12:00 noon at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd. (corner 66th Ave.), Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Telecom Holders Grumble Over Olivetti Bid
description: Olivetti, Italy's No. 2 phone company, has yet to begin its formal $60 billion bid for the country's largest phone company, Telecom Italia, but large British and American investment funds are complaining that as the biggest shareholders in the target company they may be getting a bad deal.

title: Watchdog for H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Catalogue Sellers Thrive on Line
description: As video sales on the Internet rise, it's good to see old-line purveyors -- those with paper catalogues in the two-to-three-pound range -- holding their own, not only between covers but on the Web as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASPER, HAZEL F.
description: CASPER-Hazel F. Born 1912. Died peacefully on March 4, 1999 after nine years of suffering from Alzheimer's disease. Survived by her daughter Virginia, grandson Evan and daughter-in-law Donna Futterman of New York, and sister Esther Delcourt of Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, EDITH C.
description: WOLFSON-Edith C. On March 4, 1999, born in Budapest, extra ordinary woman of indomitable spirit. Precious wife of Cyril of NYC, cherished mother of John Varsa of Albuquerque and Susanne Moore of NYC, grandmother of Sabrina Absera of Negril and Toronto, Sali Moore of St. Paul, greatgrandmother of Ariel, Nestor and Davianna and aunt of Agnes Bakondi of NY. Service Sunday, March 7, 1PM, Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERER, DAVID M.
description: CAMERER-David M., Journalist. Of New Canaan, CT. On March 3, 1999. Funeral Mass Saturday, March 6th, 10AM, Saint Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT. Visitation Friday, 4-8PM, Hoyt Funeral Home, Main St., New Canaan. Contributions to Saint Jude's Hospital, Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101 or Pegasus Therapeutic Writing Foundaation, Box 2053, Darien, CT 06820.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Back to Their Old Tricks, but a Whole Lot Younger
description: There's something faintly ridiculous in the spectacle of Sarah Michelle Gellar and Ryan Phillippe portraying upscale Manhattan teen-age versions of the manipulative sexual predators in Choderlos de Laclos's 18th-century novel, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' Watching these fresh-faced actors go through the motions of seducing and betraying their classmates at a fancy Manhattan private school is rather like watching child actors playing gangsters in Alan Parker's Prohibition-era movie ''Bugsy Malone.'' You have the queasy sense that the whole thing is just an elaborate stunt, and in this case an exploitative one.

title: Grand Jury Gets More Time For Evidence in Diallo Case
description: In a sign that there is unlikely to be a quick decision on whether to indict the four police officers accused of shooting Amadou Diallo, a Bronx judge has extended the term of the grand jury hearing evidence in the case until March 29.

title: Congressman Rejects Race For the Senate
description: Representative Robert Menendez, a four-term Congressman who was widely seen as the leading Democrat to replace Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, announced today that he would not seek the seat in 2000, clearing the field for several people who might have been considered long shots before.

title: Unstable Autocracies in Central Asia
description: A series of car bombs recently exploded at the Government's headquarters in Uzbekistan's capital, Tashkent, killing 16 people. They narrowly missed the country's leader, Islam Karimov -- a sign that the stability provided by the dictators of Central Asia and the Caucasus can be quickly upended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAR, ROSLYN
description: ZAR-Roslyn of Rego Park (former NYC teacher). Services at Washington Cemetery. Call ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: U.S. Calls China Trade Talks 'Productive'
description: After two days of meetings, China and the United States have ''made important progress'' in defining terms for China to join the World Trade Organization, said the United States' senior trade official. But the official cautioned that there were still significant differences between the countries and ''a number of issues remained to be addressed.''

title: Half a Globe Flown, Half to Go for 2 British Balloonists
description: Two British balloonists seeking to become the first to circle the world nonstop have surpassed some of their biggest hazards, greatly improving their chances of ultimate success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, LEONARD S.
description: FIELD-Leonard S. Producer of offbeat Broadway theatrical shows, including Brendan Behan's ''The Hostage,'' stage manager for the world tour of ''Porgy and Bess'' and discoverer of numerous talents. Former member of the Board of Playwrights' Horizon. Noted habitue of Sardi's. Survived by his loving wife Virginia Clayburgh Field and two daughters, Ruth Feldberg and Katharine Field, and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Memorial service will be private.

title: A Hit Man Married to the Mob, but Nesting With Mom
description: If black comedies came any blacker than ''Six Ways to Sunday,'' you'd need the candlepower of a Government-surplus lighthouse to see them.

title: A Schroder Lieutenant Suggests Alliance With Ex-Communists
description: Already under fire from business, Germany's Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, has divided his own governing Social Democratic Party and irked Chancellor Gerhard Schroder with a suggestion that a political alliance with former East German Communists would be acceptable.

title: Schools Shift Date of Exam, Making Room For Girls' Day
description: New York City Board of Education officials scrambled yesterday to reschedule next month's citywide reading exam after learning that it conflicted with Take Our Daughters to Work Day.

title: I.B.M. Deal With Dell Put At $16 Billion
description: Signaling that its future may depend as much on computer parts as on entire machines, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it expected to sell $16 billion worth of disk drives and other components to a rival, the Dell Computer Corporation.

title: In the Magic Realm of Drawings
description: The secret life of a great art museum is often best sought out in its department of drawings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, HOWARD C., M.D.
description: BERGER-Howard C., M.D., 74, on Thursday, March 4, 1999. Retired anesthesiologist. Beloved husband of Evelyn (Schatz) for more than fifty years. Devoted father of Bradley Ian Berger and Randy Berger Sweren. Loving grandfather to Bennat and Amanda Berger, and Joshua, Becky and Evan Sweren. Brother of Raline Gershengorn. His uniqueness and spirit will live on in our hearts.

title: Big Board Switches To BBDO New York
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would shift its account to the BBDO New York unit of BBDO Worldwide, part of Omnicom Group, from the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, which had handled the account since 1996. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Hospital Recognizes Union for Doctors
description: After months of fighting a unionization effort, the management of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx announced yesterday that it would recognize the union chosen by the hospital's attending physicians and begin negotiating a contract with them.

title: After Lull to Gauge Damage, British Jets Hit Iraq
description: After a lull in fighting following the disruption of oil exports from Iraq to Turkey, air strikes against Iraq resumed today when British jets attacked a surface-to-air missile site in southern Iraq, American and British officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENS, THOMAS J.
description: STEPHENS-Thomas J., a White Plains lawyer, died on March 2, 1999 in Briarcliff Manor, New York, after a long bout with Parkinson's disease. He was 76. Mr. Stephens was born in Brooklyn, New York on September 18, 1922. He graduated from Polytechnic Preparatory School in Brooklyn and Colgate University where he attended summer sessions in order to join the U.S. Army during World War II as a private in 1942. Mr. Stephens served in the 36th infantry division of the 5th Army and eventually rose to first lieutenant in command of a rifle company with the 7th Army. He served in North Africa, Italy, France and Germany and participated in numerous campaigns, including Rapido River, Monte Cassino, the Breakthrough at Anzio, the liberation of Rome, and the invasions of Southern France and the German Rhineland. He received a battlefield commission for heroic action beyond the line of duty, the Bronze Star with a cluster, five battle stars and the combat infantryman's badge, among other decorations. After the War, Mr. Stephens earned his law degree from Syracuse University and practiced in New York City before founding the firm Stephens & Buderwitz in White Plains, New York where he practiced for nearly 40 years. Mr. Stephens ran for mayor of White Plains in 1952 and was continually active in White Plains and Westcheter County affairs. He served as President of the Bar Association of White Plains, President of the YMCA, President of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in White Plains and on the board of EM Industries and numerous other corporations. He was a member of the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk, New York. Mr. Stephens was instrumental in the planning and design of the Kingsley House residences on Barker Avenue in White Plains, restructured its sponsorship and funding and assured its completion after the initial program encountered difficulties prior to completion. Funeral services will be held at the White Plains Presbyterian Church 39 North Broadway, White Plains on Saturday, March 6, at 10:30 am. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association. Mr. Stephens is survived by wife Inge of North Salem, New York, sister Margaret Christie, son Christopher, daughters Eleanor and Merielle and granddaughter, Lara.

title: Gene Study Bolsters Hope for Treating Diseases of Aging
description: A gene that confers fountain-of-youth properties on human cells grown in laboratory glassware has been tested in mice to see if its absence will cause the opposite effect, that of premature aging. The answer -- which is partly yes -- sustains but does not yet fulfill the hope that manipulations of the gene will provide treatments for cancer, heart disease and other maladies of aging human tissues.

title: Worker on Rooftop Killed by High Wind
description: A carpenter fell 150 feet to his death today when a gust of wind blew him off the roof of an office building under construction along the Hudson River, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, VACHEL
description: BLAIR-Vachel. Beloved husband, father, relative, friend, cinematographer and righteous gentile. Died March 1. Memorial Saturday March 6, 6PM, St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREMONT, T. PAUL
description: TREMONT-T. Paul. Age 65. Of Fairfield, CT, died Thursday, March 4, 1999, of cancer. Paul was born in New York City and raised in Bridgeport, Connecticut. After graduating from Fairfield University, he received his law degree from Georgetown Law School where he served as editor of the Georgetown Law Review. After clerking for the U.S. Court of Military Appeals in Washington, DC, he returned to Bridgeport where he practiced law for over forty years. He was the founder and managing partner of Tremont and Sheldon, PC, a firm specializing in personal injury law. Throughout his professional career, Paul has served as President of the Connecticut Trial Lawyers Association, President of the Greater Bridgeport Bar Association, President of the Connecticut Chapter of the American Board of Trial Advocates, and Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. In 1984, Paul received the Fairfield University Alumni Professional Achievement Award and, most recently, was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Connecticut Trial Lawyers Association for his prominence in the legal community. He is survived by his wife Sharon, his son Geoffrey Tremont of Rehoboth, Massachusetts, his son Jason Tremont of Fairfield, CT, grandchildren Madeline and Emma, daughters-in-law Felecia and Michelle Tremont, stepdaughters Kristen and Kimberly Stram, and several aunts, uncles, and cousins. Friends are invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, March 6, 1999, at 10:30 am at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, 4070 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, Connecticut. Friends may call at 9:30 am at the church on Saturday. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the ''T. Paul Tremont Library Fund at Fairfield University'' and sent to Fairfield University, Attention: George Diffley, 1073 North Benson Road, Fairfield, CT. 06430.

title: VOLVO CHIEF SAYS HE WON'T MEET WITH NAVISTAR IN U.S.
description: Volvo A.B.'s chief executive, Leif Johansson, said his company ''is talking to almost everyone'' about alliances and other ways to compete in the truck business, but said he would not meet with Navistar International Corporation executives on a visit to the United States. Next week, Volvo shareholders will vote on the Ford Motor Company's $6.45 billion offer for Volvo's car business. Volvo wants to concentrate on its more profitable heavy-truck, bus, engine and construction equipment businesses. There has been speculation that Volvo would use part of the cash from selling its car business to buy the Chicago-based Navistar or another truck maker.

title: Good Grief! Lots of Attention For a Subversive Kid Sister
description: In a Broadway season packed with Electra, the Lomans and other gloomy characters, the true master of existential angst just may be a 5-year-old cartoon malcontent by the name of Sally Brown.

title: If This Stone Could Speak
description: To say that ''Promised Land'' is avant-garde theater is putting it mildly. The actors never show their faces (the curtain rises by degrees, but only as high as shoulder level); they speak not a single word, and, oh yes, the lead character is a rock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, ANNA. (NEE ROTHSCHILD)
description: SCHWEITZER-Anna. (nee Rothschild), 89, died on March 4, 1999. Beloved mother of Frances Turner Karten and Marvin Cohen. Adored stepmother, mother-in law, grandmother and greatgrandmother. She was a true Aishes Chayil whose giving knew no limits. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASS, DAVID A. JR.
description: NASS-David A. Jr. At age 42, on March 2, after a year-long battle with brain cancer. Beloved husband of Marcia, son of David and Henrietta, mother of Beth Ann Benjamin, Daniel and Dean. Memorial services at First Presbyterian Church, New Vernon, New Jersey, Friday, March 5, at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be made to David A. Nass Jr., Memorial Cancer Foundation, 7 Military Hill Drive, Morristown, New Jersey 07960 or Neurology Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Lisa DeAngelis, M.D., 1275 York Avenue, Box E, New York, New York 10021.

title: Yanks Deal Off, Cablevision Now Seeks Mets
description: Cablevision, which was unsuccessful in its effort to buy the Yankees, has also been engaged in discussions about purchasing the Mets from Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday for as much as $500 million, according to a major league team owner and another baseball official.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, GERARD A., M.D.
description: HOFFMAN-Gerard A., M.D. on March 3, 1999 of Forest Hills, NY. Physician, educator and healer. A kind and generous man who loved his family and friends. Member of American Psychiatric Assoc, J.F.K. Rotary and RotaCare of Long Island. Beloved husband of Hedi. Loving father of Stuart. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Inc Ascan Ave at Metropolitan Ave Forest Hills, NY 2-5 & 7-9 Friday & Saturday. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions to RotaCare-District 7250 (a volunteer group of physicians & nurses who provide free medical care for the needy) care of Mr. Mike Cavallaro 6 Harbor Lane, Glen Head NY 11545 or The Queens Federation of Churches, 86-17 105 Street, Richmond Hill, NY 11418 (which provides food to the needy) was his wish-and would be appreciated. We shall miss him.

title: ZEDILLO SUGGESTS U.S.-STYLE SYSTEM TO PICK NOMINEES
description: President Ernesto Zedillo today called on his governing party to break with 60 years of authoritarian tradition and select its presidential candidate this year through a series of state primaries that would culminate in an American-style party convention.

title: Ma Liuming
description: Jack Tilton Gallery

title: Jim Crow Past Haunts a Life Lived in Exile
description: PEGGY KING JORDE has lived and worked in New York City for the last 18 years, but a piece of her heart has stayed in her hometown of Albany.

title: Justice: A Mans Title and His Guiding Light
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Seeking More Than a Smile From Cartoons
description: THE NEW YORKER runs a controversial cover, a Hasidic man kissing a black woman or schoolchildren with guns, chances are the artist is Art Spiegelman.

title: A campaign for Miller Lite goes back to basics and beyond the appeal to younger consumers.
description: THE Miller Brewing Company is making an abrupt about-face by unceremoniously ending a campaign for the flagging Miller Lite beer brand. The campaign generated contentious debate over its unconventional content, which attempted to appeal to younger consumers with offbeat entertainment rather than product pitches.

title: Seismic Team Detects a Killer Beneath Los Angeles
description: Using information once jealously guarded by oil and gas companies, scientists have for the first time identified a major fault under downtown Los Angeles of a kind whose existence there they previously could only infer. They say it is capable of producing a devastating earthquake.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: U.S. Suit Says Queens Co-op Is Not Protecting Shorebird
description: The Government charged yesterday that a private residential community in Queens had failed to take sufficient steps to protect a breeding area for a migratory shorebird that Federal law deems a threatened species.

title: Money Went to Churches
description: To the Editor:

title: Monitor Chief Calls Kosovo Close to Flare-Up
description: The senior general in charge of international monitors in Kosovo warned today that the troubled province was perilously close to a major conflagration, as two separate incidents in the province nearly flared into violence.

title: Browns Sign Kirby, Another Ex-49er
description: The Cleveland Browns agreed to terms with the free-agent running back Terry Kirby on a two-year contract, the team said yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Budget Politics Is Delaying Relief for Central America
description: Nearly $1 billion in emergency aid to storm-stricken Central Americans ran afoul of partisan budget politics in the House and Senate today, dooming any chance that President Clinton could deliver the relief package when he visits the region next week.

title: No Surprise Here: Duke Cruises
description: The suspense in this game ended when the pairings were announced for the 46th Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: Rangers Continue Their Playoff Push
description: The Rangers are playing at their best at the most important time of the season, despite missing four key players with injuries. They are making it interesting to imagine what the fourth quarter of the schedule might be like for a team that seems to be jelling with an infusion of youth and growing in self-confidence. They increased their unbeaten streak to four games and moved within 2 points of a playoff berth tonight with a stunning 4-2 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: Retail Sales Climbed 7.6% In February
description: Retailers' sales at stores open at least a year rose 7.6 percent in February, more than expected, as shoppers snapped up basic household goods at discounters like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and new spring fashions at clothing chains like Gap Inc., according to a report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FONDILLER, ROBERT
description: FONDILLER-Robert. Memorial Service. St. Matthew and St. Timothy Church, Friday, March 5th, 26 West 84 St., NYC, 7PM

title: Incurably Ill, Hunter Is Still Hopeful
description: He's doing all right, Catfish Hunter said. ''Just my hands and arms don't work. That's the only thing.''

title: Sports of The Times; Calhoun Says Top Seeding Is Done Deed
description: HERE is something I learned from reading the wires between games of the Big East basketball tournament: all Division I teams are rated by the Collegiate Basketball News, all the way from No. 1 down to No. 310.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, MATHILDA
description: TERNER-Mathilda, 88, of Palm Beach, Fla., and Oakhurst, NJ, on the 3rd of March. Cherished and beloved wife of the late Emanuel M. Terner for 67 years. A loving mother to Nancy Behrman, Elaine Cooper and Carol Lederman. Mother-in-law to Stanley and Mark. Devoted grandmother of Peter (Josephine) Grayson, Alan (Kimberly) Mnuchin, Steven Mnuchin, Amy (Jeff) Verschleiser, and Judy Lederman. Adoring great-grandmother of Bradley Louis Grayson and Joshua Terner Verschleiser. Friends may call Thursday evening, 5-7 PM. Services 10 AM, Friday, March 5, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Burial service private. Donations in her memory to St. Mary's Hospital, 901 45th St., West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Suspects May Have Tormented Retarded Man Several Times
description: A group of Monmouth County men and women charged two weeks ago with tormenting a mildly retarded 23-year-old man had abused their victim more frequently and over a longer period of time than the authorities initially believed, the police said yesterday.

title: Watchdog for H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Montreal Journal; Orphans Who Weren't Recall Care That Wasn't
description: Down by the St. Lawrence River, in the parish hall behind the somber stone church of St. Peter the Apostle, Herve Bertrand and other French Canadian Catholics gathered recently to condemn the church that has so thoroughly shaped most aspects of life in the province of Quebec.

title: Bewildered Europeans Deplore 100% U.S. Tariff
description: Marc Ecrepont does not care about bananas. But today he became a pawn in a trade war over them between the United States and Europe.

title: Brazil Increases a Key Interest Rate to 45%
description: The Brazilian central bank raised its benchmark interest rate today to 45 percent and granted its new president expanded powers to adjust rates in an effort to head off a surge of inflation and to stabilize the country's battered currency.

title: CARAUSTAR PLANS TO BUY MILL FROM INTERNATIONAL PAPER
description: Caraustar Industries, a maker of recycled paper packaging, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a Connecticut paper mill from the International Paper Company for $108.3 million, saying the purchase would make it the largest United States maker of recycled paper for packaging. The mill, in Sprague, Conn., has the capacity to make 210,000 tons of the paper a year.

title: Crime Drops in Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHARRY, BRO
description: McSHARRY-Bro. Talbot CFX. The Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick records with profound sorrow the recent death of our Past-President and esteemed Member, Brother Talbot McSharry, CFX. Brother Joseph P. Reilly, FSC, President Edward P. Donnellan, Vice-Pres.

title: Foreign Affairs; How Bibi Got Re-elected
description: Israel's Likud Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, won re-election tonight in a landslide over the Labor party leader, Ehud Barak, pulling in 64 percent of the vote against 36 percent for Mr. Barak. Pollsters said Mr. Netanyahu's lopsided victory was due to one factor: his decision, on the eve of the voting, to unilaterally withdraw all Israeli troops from south Lebanon -- a move that has set off an earthquake in Israeli politics and throughout the Middle East.

title: Political Briefing; Qualms Aside, Iowa Is Still the Place to Be
description: Every four years, it seems, there is more talk about Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucuses being a political anachronism and a distortion of the Presidential nominating process. In today's America, the argument goes, the state is too bucolic and too homogeneously white to be considered ''typical,'' and therefore no longer qualifies as an ideal testing ground for candidates.

title: Winter and the Temperature's Down? No Matter, the Surf's Up!
description: For me, the essence of surfing is the quest for the rare summer wave: the gleam of morning sun on an August swell, the wafting scent of wild roses and cocoa butter, a water temperature of 70 degrees. Never mind that 100 surfers may have had the same idea, at the same beach. Generally, I've kept a wary distance from winter waves and those surfing zealots bundled head to toe in neoprene, poised to leap from a snow-covered beach into 38-degree water. I thought of them as a Polar Bear Club of surfing's pious, too fervid to be credible.

title: MEN'S WEARHOUSE PLANS TO PURCHASE K&G MEN'S CENTER
description: Men's Wearhouse Inc., the largest United States retailer of men's suits, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy K&G Men's Center Inc. for as much as $133 million in stock, or $13 a share, to expand its line of low-priced suits. The acquisition is the second in five months for Men's Wearhouse. In November, it agreed to buy the Moores Retail Group Inc. of Canada for as much as $127 million in stock and debt. Shares of Men's Wearhouse fell $1.5937, to $25.1562, while K&G rose $1, to $9.375.

title: From Central Asia, Exotic Textiles as Trophy Clothes
description: The most appealing exotica produced in backwater Central Asia during the 19th century -- as far from Paris as you could get, fashionwise -- were the gorgeously colored and patterned handmade silks known as ikat. Made by the complex ''resist'' method, which entails repeated binding and dying of the threads before they are woven into fabric, ikat goes back to ancient times and is known to many cultures throughout the world.

title: Chester Higgins Jr.
description: 'Landscapes of the Soul'

title: U.N. to Collect Money Its Employees Owe Their Ex-Spouses
description: Speaking on women's issues to an audience that included Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, announced a policy change yesterday that is intended to bring relief to a long-suffering group of women, the ex-wives of United Nations employees.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDROWITZ, SHIRLEY KEMPNER
description: SANDROWITZ-Shirley Kempner. March 5, 1989. Rest in peace, doll of love. For thee sweet love remembered such wealth brings. Dave

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Otumfuo Opoku Ware II, the traditional King of the Asante people in Ghana, misstated his age in some editions. He was 79, not 89.

title: Student, 16, Is Charged With Murder In Brooklyn
description: A 16-year-old high school student from Brooklyn was arrested at his school yesterday morning on charges that he fatally shot another youth when a dispute over a gold chain turned into a bloody street fight, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, ALLEN
description: WARDWELL-Allen. It is with great sadness that we mourn the sudden death of our friend. It is with smiling memories that we celebrate his remarkable life of scholarship, spirit, modesty and style. We honor his many accomplishments and express our gratefulness at having known him and shared his passion for Native American Art. To his devoted wife, Sally, and their children, we offer our condolences and love. Valerie and Charles Diker

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUNGES. Sugar fell 6 percent on expectations that Brazil, the world's top grower, will process more crops for export, adding to swollen stockpiles. In New York, sugar for May delivery fell 0.35 cent, to 5.5 cents a pound.

title: New Samplers That Give Old Pieties the Needle
description: In a series of smart, visually striking exhibitions over the past decade or so, Elaine Reichek has carved out a distinctive place for herself in New York art. She is a conceptualist who is also an ethnologist, a self-taught crafts artist, a historian, an indefatigable archivist and a shrewd cultural critic with a gift for unraveling the tangled politics of image making.

title: Threatened by Russian Mob, Journalist Pushes Back
description: He hated to be the ''bearer of bad tidings,'' the F.B.I. agent said on the telephone. Then he gave Robert I. Friedman, a freelance journalist who writes about the Russian mob, exceedingly bad news.

title: Mets Seem Set in Stone But Bring A Chisel
description: On Friday night in nearby Jupiter, the Mets open their spring exhibition schedule against the Montreal Expos. Manager Bobby Valentine's starting lineup is all but set: his pitching rotation is full, his bullpen rounded out.

title: Ups and Downs of a Delicate Partnership
description: The highs and lows of the three-and-a-half year relationship between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FROELICH, BETTY
description: FROELICH-Betty. In loving memory. Your family

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Russian Autumn In the Planning

title: Night Court Joins the Theater That Is New York
description: The hour was closing in on midnight. A detachment of ruddy-faced German tourists emerged from the metal detectors in the Criminal Courts building in lower Manhattan, took a sharp left and headed down the empty marble corridor toward the city's least likely international attraction, night court.

title: Everything The Traffic Will Allow
description: Every so often, though not close to often enough, something sharp and radiant pierces through the acrid smog that is being called ''Annie Get Your Gun.'' That something is starlight, and not surprisingly it emanates from Bernadette Peters, who has taken on the title role in the misconceived revival that opened last night at the Marquis Theater.

title: Tequila Maker Narrows Review
description: Allied Domecq Spirits USA said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for the creative portion of its Sauza tequilas brand account by eliminating one incumbent, Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Billings for the account, which includes the Sauza Conmemorativo, Hornitos, Silver and Gold brands, were estimated at $15 million.

title: Jury Awards $27 Million In Yale Malpractice Case
description: In what may be the largest medical malpractice verdict ever in Connecticut, a New Haven jury awarded $27 million yesterday to a 29-year-old resident of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., who was blinded and brain-damaged during surgery at the Yale-New Haven Hospital and Yale School of Medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBOROFF, HERBERT
description: TOBOROFF-Herbert. On March 4, 1999. Dear father of Steven. Cherished brother of Leonard Toboroff and Audrey Miller. Adored uncle. Services Sunday March 7, 10AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10018.

title: Rethinking the War on American Culture
description: A couple of years ago a British literary festival staged a public debate on the motion that ''it is the duty of every European to resist American culture.'' Along with two American journalists (one of whom was Sidney Blumenthal, now more famous as a Clinton aide and impeachment witness), I opposed the motion. I'm happy to report that we won, capturing roughly 60 percent of the audience's vote.

title: Wanted: Math Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Holds Presidential Fund-Raiser in Home State
description: At the first major fund-raiser in his bid for the Presidency, Bill Bradley raised $1.5 million tonight at a dinner in his home state.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAPLES INC., Westborough, Mass., the office supply chain, will repurchase up to 7.1 million of its common shares, or $200 million in stock. The company had about 461 million shares outstanding as of Jan. 30.

title: Campus Climate Control
description: I remember the butter pats that covered the soaring ceiling of my freshman dining hall. They were the first sign that I had entered a world utterly devoid of adults. I remember my best friend passing out from inhaling nitrous oxide. I remember someone I know falling drunkenly off a fire escape and ending up in the hospital. I remember groups of us breaking into the pool at night and swimming naked. This was not 1967. This was 1990.

title: Metro Business; Spitzer Sets Up Unit To Look Into Internet
description: The New York State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, is creating a bureau to investigate Internet matters, including on-line trading, consumer fraud, privacy issues and child pornography.

title: Turkish Government, 1,700; a U.S. Investor, 1
description: The Turkish Government got 1,700 coins yesterday. William I. Koch got one. So ended one of the most bitter disputes over antiquities in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SHERMAN-Gertrude. Age 89. Died March 4, 1999, of West Palm Beach, Fla. An extremely exceptional woman who cared for the world. Loving wife of the late Jack Sherman. Adored mother of Carol and Harvey Baron and Arthur and Nancy Sherman. Cherished grandmother of David and Nadine, Tracy and Joel, Richard and Paula, Daniel and Hope, Karen and Jeffrey. Great-grandmother of Jay, Shari, Brett, Joshua and Emily. Funeral Services on March 5th. 10AM. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad St., Mt. Vernon. The family will receive friends at 4 Spruce Drive, White Plains. Contributions may be sent to: Richmond Children's Center, Development Office, 100 Corporate Drive, Yonkers, New York 10701.

title: National News Briefs; White House Hires Aide To Guide Privacy Policy
description: The Clinton Administration has appointed a law professor from Ohio State University as the Government's new chief counselor of privacy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nine Are Arrested In School Vandalism
description: Nine people have been arrested in connection with vandalism at Orange High School, where on Feb. 7 the main office was set afire, furniture was smashed and science experiments in classrooms were destroyed, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Computer Hackers Are Stopped; Pentagon Networks Were Victim
description: Military security analysts uncovered and stopped computer hackers who had discovered a new way to attack open Pentagon networks on the Internet, Pentagon officials said today.

title: PEPSICO FORMS EASTERN BOTTLING VENTURE WITH PEPCOM
description: Pepsico Inc. signed an agreement with Pepcom Industries yesterday to form a joint venture combining bottling businesses in parts of New York and North Carolina. Pepsico said it expected the venture to account for about 3 percent of its United States beverage volume. Pepcom will be the majority shareholder in the venture, with Pepsico holding a significant minority interest. Pepsico will contribute bottling operations in Winston-Salem and Wilmington, N.C. Pepcom, a unit of the Tokyo-based Suntory Ltd., will contribute bottling operations in central and eastern North Carolina, as well as Nassau and Suffolk counties in New York.

title: Long Island Man Convicted Of Murdering 3 Prostitutes
description: A 44-year-old postal worker was found guilty today of the serial murders of three prostitutes, making him the first Long Island defendant in 21 years to face the possibility of a death sentence.

title: Lee Krasner
description: 'The Little Image to the Large Canvas'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORAN, JACK
description: MORAN-Jack. 1948-1994. Forever missed, forever loved. My Guardian Angel. Bobby

title: Langham, Ex-Scoreboard Worker, Shares Lead at Doral
description: Franklin Langham used to work at the Masters when he was a teen-ager living in Thompson, Ga., 30 miles from Augusta. As a scoreboard operator at the 16th green, Langham watched Seve Ballesteros, Jack Nicklaus and other great players, while dreaming of one day becoming a professional golfer.

title: Blackmun's Opinions Reflect His Evolution Over the 24 Court Years
description: Following are excerpts from opinions Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote in his 24 years on the Supreme Court, including his opinion for the Court in the 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade finding a constitutional right to abortion:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DECLINES. The Japanese currency fell a fourth day, to a three-month low, as the Bank of Japan pumped more money into the banking system. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.35 yen, up from 121.77 on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ISIDORE. ''TIBBY''
description: COHN-Isidore. ''Tibby'' A friend for all seasons. Close, caring and loyal. Such was Tibby to us, always there at happy times with shared excitement, and at trying times with kind words and encouragement. Always with a ''G-d Bless You.''
