His loss creates a huge void that could never be filled. Lilly & Irwin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, GILBERT
description: FEINMAN-Gilbert, 81, of Delray Beach, Florida. Dear husband of Martha, devoted father of Anita and Michael; father-in-law of Elisa. Loving grandfather of Ian, Jordan, Heath, Lauren, Jessica, Jacqueline and Alexandria; great grandfather of Hannah. Service will be held Friday, 12:15PM at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Residential Real Estate; Development to Give Dancers New Space at Their Old Address
description: An apartment building is scheduled to begin taking shape soon at 316 East 63d Street, which for nearly 50 years was the home of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance.

title: Rudy Versus Rudy
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's renewed push for a school voucher experiment illustrates what can happen when his national political ambitions conflict with the needs of New York City's public schools. A voucher program could enhance the Mayor's image in national Republican circles, but it might also lose him a fine Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew. Dr. Crew says he will resign if the Mayor forces a voucher plan that uses public funds for private or parochial schools. As the Chancellor puts it: ''Always in your life you come up to the proverbial hill to die on. This is mine.'' For the Mayor, whose aides protest that Dr. Crew is not really serious about leaving over this issue, it is apparently worth the gamble. For the city's 1.1 million schoolchildren, however, it is not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: EPSTEIN-Samuel. The family of Samuel Epstein, M.D. mourns the passing of an exceptional man, who was beloved, praised and admired by all. He was a devoted husband to Freda and, until her death, to Blanche. He was an inspiration to his children, Judy Kaufman and Robert Epstein, his son-in-law, Stephen Kaufman, his daughter-in-law Rebecca Epstein, and his grandchildren, Lisa and Alan Kava, Neal Kaufman, Daniel, Laura and Sara Epstein. He was a physician's physician, who earned the admiration and respect of his colleagues and was physician to them and their families. A man of science and letters, he was an esteemed teacher and leader in the field of cardiology. Born in New York City in 1912, he graduated from New York University in 1931 and from its Medical College in 1934. In 1943 he was Board Certified in Internal Medicine and, in 1953, in Cardiovascular Disease. He was Chief of the Cardiology Clinic at Maimonides Medical Center and on the teaching faculty of Downstate Medical Center. He had a close affiliation of over 60 years with Coney Island Hospital, as clinician, teacher, administrator and President of the Medical Board. For all his accomplishments he is best remembered by us for his deep love for and profound commitment to his family. We will always love him and miss him. Gifts in his memory may be made to: Dr. Samuel Epstein Lectureship in Cardiovascular Disease, C/O Linda Tafore, Medical Dept., Coney Island Hospital, 2601 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, New York 11235.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Wednesday, about the stock market, referred incorrectly to an earnings forecast that preceded a 6.7 percent rise in Whirlpool Corporation shares. Whirlpool predicted a double-digit increase in first-quarter and full-year operating earnings -- not in net earnings, which can be affected by one-time accounting adjustments and other extraordinary circumstances.

title: Richard Fleischner
description: 'Mazes and Squares'

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Embracing Liszt With the Mind as Well as the Hands
description: The best test of seriousness among musicians who play the piano is not necessarily Beethoven or Mozart as one would expect, but Liszt. Liszt's music invites grandiosity and self-promotion in a certain kind of artist; and when this greatest of all keyboard techniques runs amok across the printed page, the shallowness is well nigh unavoidable. Yet there is more to the music. If the ear is thoughtful, deep beauty exists beneath the glitter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLINSKY, PAUL
description: WOLINSKY-Paul. On March 2, 1999. President of National Tinsmith Distributors, Inc. Devoted husband of Selma. Beloved father of Fred, Stewart, Ronald, Jory and Martin. Loving father-in-law of Carol, Annie, Grace and Laura. Cherished grandfather of Ryan, Dustin, Benjamin, Lindsay and Dylan. Fond brother of Jack, Bernard, Barbara and the late Izzy. He was predeceased by his first wife, Esther. Always in our hearts. Family requests any donations to be made to Hospice c/o VITAS, 5420 NW 3rd Avenue, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33309. Funeral service will be held at Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Ave., B'klyn, NY, Friday, March 5 at 10:00 AM.

title: Gary Hill
description: Circular Breathing'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MERESMAN, HARRY
description: MERESMAN-Harry Embraced forever by all who were privileged to share in the life of a man for all seasons.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Shawn Mullins, a singer and songwriter who is having his first taste of fame with the hit single ''Lullaby,'' misspelled the surname of the president of his label, Columbia. He is Don Ienner, not Iennar.

title: Yeltsin Calls for Tycoon's Ouster From Diplomatic Post
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin demanded tonight that Boris A. Berezovsky be ousted from a prominent diplomatic post, capping a power struggle that has roiled the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYLES, HOPE
description: SAYLES-Hope. At her home, Laurelmead, Blackstone Boulevard, Providence, RI, February 27, at age 92. Daughter of the late Frank Arthur Sayles and Mary Dorr (Ames) Sayles. A resident of New York for much of her life, she was an assiduous world traveler. She is survived by a nephew, Paul C. Nicholson, Jr., of Providence; three nieces, Mary B. Braga of Middleburg, VA, Martha N.S. Livingston of Bristol, RI, and Lee Day Gillespie of Cambridge, MA. Burial was in Swan Point Cemetery in Providence.

title: Review/Fashion; In Italy, Alluring Ideas Are Blossoming
description: Designers, like many other people, often do their best work under stress. When the fashion world turned away from the precise tailoring Italy was known for, the country's designers floundered for a moment, toying with American-style sportswear and utility gear. But they now seem to be blossoming with ideas for more feminine, more alluring ways of dressing. When you compete in a global marketplace, you can't afford to stand still.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, ALBERT EUGENE
description: DANN-Albert Eugene. March 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Renee; loving brother of Fred Dann and Beatrice Starr; devoted stepfather of Joan Weltz. Funeral private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, LOTTIE (NEE BLADER)
description: FELDMAN-Lottie (nee Blader). On February 27. Beloved wife of the late Albert Feldman. Devoted mother of David, Barbara, Iris and Myrna. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: 2 Confess to Killing Man, Saying He Made a Sexual Advance
description: Two Alabama men told the authorities this week that they beat a man to death with an ax handle last month and then burned his body because the victim had previously made a homosexual advance to them.

title: VERIO TO PAY AMERICA ONLINE FOR WEB SERVICES DEAL
description: The Internet-service provider Verio Inc. will pay America Online Inc. at least $42.5 million to become the on-line service company's exclusive operator of Web sites for businesses. America Online will also get a share of future revenue in the deal, which includes a Verio and America Online Web site that will offer Verio Web services and Internet commerce products, the companies said yesterday. Verio will receive on-line advertising and promotion of the venture. Verio shares rose $4, to $36.50, while America Online's fell 81.25 cents, to $86.25.

title: Friends Fear Worst After Lawyer Vanishes
description: He has been a mob lawyer, an O. J. Simpson commentator, a Federal prosecutor, a Congressional candidate and a boxing promoter. Now, he has vanished.

title: Free Agent Ellsworth Gets Cold Shoulder From Giants
description: The Giants could soon lose another defensive player to free agency. Safety Percy Ellsworth, a restricted free agent, will visit the Washington Redskins today and next week plans to meet with the Chicago Bears and Cleveland Browns, according to Ellsworth's agent, Anthony Agnone.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JAY
description: COHEN-Jay. The Trustees, Faculty, Staff and Students of Mount Sinai School of Medicine are profoundly saddened by the passing of our cherished friend and esteemed colleague Jay Cohen, who retired last summer after serving Mount Sinai School of Medicine for more than three decades as Director of Admissions, Assistant Dean for Admissions and Student Affairs, Financial Aid Officer, and Bursar. A man of extraordinary integrity, he was admired for his exceptional dedication to both the School and its students, on whose behalf he worked tirelessly. Respected for his knowledge and skills, he was as warm and personable as he was talented. He will be sorely missed, but his memory will endure through the establishment of a scholarship fund in his name. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his wife, Marilyn, daughter Debbie, son Mitchell, to his grandchildren and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean

title: Metro Business; Trump Eyes Ex-G.M. Site
description: Donald Trump said yesterday that he was seriously considering a plan to turn a former General Motors Corporation assembly plant site in Tarrytown, N.Y., into a $1 billion residential, retail and hotel complex.

title: Paul Lepercq, 77, Supporter of the Arts
description: Paul Lepercq, a businessman who served as chairman of the board of the Brooklyn Academy of Music from 1971 to 1976, died on Saturday at the Hopital St. Louis in Paris. He was 77 and had homes in Paris and Bermuda.

title: Reading Scores Are Steady; a Few States Gain
description: In a nationwide test that measures the reading ability of public school students, no state lost ground last year, and a handful -- led by Connecticut -- made significant gains, according to state-by-state results released yesterday by the Department of Education.

title: Plenty of Dash in a Powerful Technique
description: The Ukrainian-born pianist Alexander Mikhailuk had garnered an impressive number of competition prizes even before he won the 1998 Young Concert Artists International Auditions in New York, which resulted in his American debut recital on Monday night at the 92nd Street Y, part of the Young Concert Artists Series. Previously, the pianist, who was trained at the Moscow Conservatory, had taken first prizes in the Franz Liszt Competition in Weimar and the Shostakovich Competition in Hanover. And that was just in just one year, 1997.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Microsoft to Sell Business Internet Software
description: Projecting a vision of a world in which most buying and selling takes place between machines, the Microsoft Corporation yesterday announced its electronic commerce strategy, a range of software products and services designed to automate business.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; A New Wave of Europeans Is Sitting Tall on the Road
description: THE sea change in the North American auto market in favor of pickups, sport utilities and minivans is being reflected in Europe, where vehicles are being designed with more spacious interiors and higher seating. At major shows like the Geneva Motor Show, which opens next week, it is clear that the European market is moving from sedans and hatchbacks to a minivan-like shape known as monospace.

title: A Young Man of Promise Who Has Lost His Way
description: The music swirls and flows in remarkable waves throughout the 75 minutes of ''Running Man,'' a new musical theater piece that is carving out a river of heartbreaking pleasure in a tiny performance space in SoHo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, CONSTANCE. (NEE BUXER)
description: FEINBERG-Constance. (nee Buxer). 75. March 3, 1999. Beloved wife of Seymour. Cherished mother of Andrew and Kenneth. Adored sister of Joseph and the late Florence. Loving grandmother of Caroline and Lance. Devoted mother-in-law of Rikki and Adele. A wonderful friend. After earning her Ph.D. in Psychotherapy in her late 40's, she treated patients for 25 years. Previously, she had been an English teacher, a political aide, an executive secretary, a lyricist and a full time mother. A very full life and a meaningful one. A loving and beautiful woman of great intelligence, she will be missed. Services Sunday, March 7th, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Keeping Secrets on Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Starts Push to Salvage Kosovo Talks
description: The Clinton Administration is unleashing what it hopes will be a speedy diplomatic offensive to salvage the Kosovo peace proposal in an effort to avoid a reprise of the last inconclusive round of talks.

title: Evan Thomas 2d Dies at 78; Published Many Best Sellers
description: Evan Welling Thomas 2d, a book editor who published dozens of books, including John F. Kennedy's ''Profiles in Courage,'' died Saturday at the Preston Health Center in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 78.

title: Why the Movies Will Cost $10
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pimpernel Is Back, and He's No Silly Weakling
description: Talk about your hardy perennials. After nearly 100 years ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' remains a tingling adventure yarn. A string of novels and stories by Baroness Emmuska Orczy that began in 1900 have spawned at least seven movies, countless spoofs and several stage adaptations, including the current Broadway musical. Betting that there's still some swash in the old boy's buckle, A&E is offering three new ''Pimpernel'' films. Judging by the first of these, to be seen on Sunday night, the bet has paid delightful dividends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HARRY
description: MERESMAN-Harry. Died on March 3, 1999 at the age of 88. Beloved husband of the late Helen Chafets Meresman, devoted father of Helaine Meresman Barnett and the late Janis Meresman Goldman, adored grandfather of Craig and Jennifer Barnett, Roger Barnett, Melissa Goldman, Lori and Brett Zbar, great-grandfather of Gabriel Barnett, father-in-law extraodinaire to Victor Barnett and Michael Goldman, loving son, brother, brother-in-law, uncle and loyal, trusted and respected friend. A man whose unquestioned integrity, ethics and morality were his hallmarks and his devotion to his family, committment to his community and his pride in his profession were his passions. The high standards by which he lead his life and his impeccable reputation will remain to all who knew him as his everlasing legacy. Funeral services Friday, March 5, 1999, 1:15pm at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Pan-Europe Talk Buoys Thomson Stock
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. has reignited investor interest in the military electronics group Thomson-CSF with comments that a possible European military alliance should include the French company. Thomson-CSF shares rose 1.58 euros, or nearly 6 percent, on the Bourse here today to 27.99 euros. British Aerospace was up 1 percent in London.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Following In the Wake

title: Isles Lack 'Killer Instinct' as Stars Win
description: For the second straight game, the Islanders played solidly against a good team, but could not finish things off. Bill Stewart, the Islanders' coach, says his team lacks ''the killer instinct.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, REBECCA RICO
description: MURPHY-Rebecca Rico. The Department of Social Work at New York Presbyterian Hospital mourns the death of their esteemed colleague, Rebecca Rico Murphy, and extends condolences to her husband Chris and her family.

title: Condoms in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Competition For Cliff Notes
description: Neither a borrower nor a lender be. . . . whateverrrrrrr!

title: Year 2000 Status Report by Visa
description: Visa International Inc. said today that 99.4 percent of credit card terminals worldwide had been updated to accept cards with expiration dates beyond Dec. 31.

title: An H.I.V.-Positive Crew Vs. 2,200 Pacific Miles
description: ''We're either stupid or brave; it depends on the moment,'' jokes a crew member of the Survivor, a racing sloop sailed by a crew of 11 H.I.V.-positive men in the grueling 1997 Trans-Pacific Yacht Race, known as TransPac.

title: INSIDE
description: Slaying Tied to Sexual Offer

title: Pilot Acquitted In Deaths of 20 On Ski Gondola
description: A Marine Corps pilot whose plane severed gondola cables in Italy last year, sending 20 people to their deaths, was acquitted of charges of involuntary homicide and manslaughter today by a court-martial jury that found no negligence, even though the plane was flying lower and faster than rules permitted.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: El Al at a Turning Point; A Mirror of Israel's Divisions Prepares to Go 49% Public
description: As airline employees cheered, the shiny Boeing 737, a blue Star of David freshly emblazoned on its tail, touched down at Ben Gurion International Airport here, the first of eight new Boeing jets that El Al, the Israeli international flag carrier, is acquiring this year.

title: The Rules of Monica's Game
description: For the past 14 months the public has had only the most fleeting, if endlessly repeated, glimpses of Monica Lewinsky. Now she is at last everywhere -- on every TV screen and on the shelves of every bookstore -- in a well-schooled, well-rehearsed version of her own voice. What makes this news is that suddenly, after many anticipatory trumpetings, one of the leading but essentially unknown characters in this national drama has walked onstage, inviting us to re-estimate her and everyone around her, including President Clinton and Kenneth Starr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKMAN, MICHAEL
description: SACKMAN-Michael. We note with great sorrow the passing in Boca Raton, Florida of the leader of our family, Michael Sackman. He was the center of the universe for all of us. He was a tower of strength, a pillar of integrity and a source of love, support, compassion and wisdom for all of us. The world is a better place today than it would have been had he not lived. He leaves behind his wife for the past fourteen years, Bernice, his son Jay and daughter Charyl, a stepdaughter Helen and seven grandchildren. A funeral will be held in Florida today, March 5, and a Memorial Service will be held on March 10, at 10:00AM at the Lake Success Jewish Center, 354 Lakeville Road, Lake Success, NY. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Michael Sackman Memorial Scholarship Fund of District 1115, SEIU, 761 Merrick Ave., Westbury, New York 11590.

title: PHILIPS TO START TENDER OFFER FOR VLSI AT $17 A SHARE
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V. said yesterday that it would start a cash tender offer for VLSI Technology Inc. at $17 a share today. The tender offer will run until April 1. VLSI is evaluating the offer of $777 million in cash and plans to respond on March 23 when its board considers a report by the investment banks Hambrecht & Quist and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. Philips ''remains hopeful that VLSI will decide to negotiate a transaction soon,'' the company said. VLSI shares rose 93.75 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $18.3125, indicating that investors expect the company to sell for more than what Amsterdam-based Philips has offered. Philips's New York-traded shares fell 87.5 cents, to $67.625.

title: Let Men Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime-Time Monica
description: Didn't Monica Lewinsky glow the other night? Didn't she look oddly happy during her interview on ABC? And no wonder. Here is a young woman who's been consuming glossy culture all her life: following the soaps, reading the women's magazines, watching Barbara Walters ask the celebrities how they feeeeel.

title: Lyrical Joins Sprightly in a Formal Pastoral Work
description: Paul Taylor's recent dance works have tended to be very funny or very nasty, sometimes both. His new and beautiful ''Fiddlers Green'' reminds us that the essential Paul Taylor is the one who hears music and choreographs to it.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We don't have anything to do with bananas, except perhaps to print them on our sheets.''

title: Justice Blackmun's Journey
description: He sometimes referred to himself as ''Old No. 3,'' recalling his unexpected ascension to the Supreme Court in 1970 as President Nixon's safe third choice following the Senate's rejection of Clement Haynsworth and G. Harrold Carswell. But Harry Blackmun, the retired Justice who died yesterday at the age of 90, evolved during a remarkable 24-year career on the Court from a bland and conservative ''Minnesota twin'' of his boyhood friend Chief Justice Warren Burger to an empathetic champion of civil rights and civil liberties.

title: Near the Courts
description: If you love restaurants, jury duty -- in Manhattan, at least -- is a dream departure from life's routine. The lunch selection in Chinatown, Little Italy and TriBeCa is wonderful. Brooklyn, too, has a couple of interesting choices, but the other three boroughs are not so fortunate. Here are 10 possibilities in Manhattan and 2 in Brooklyn. For other suggestions, you can consult the Citizens Jury Project's Web site: www.vera.org/jury/

title: Mortgage Rate Above 7%
description: The benchmark mortgage rate rose this week above 7 percent for the first time since June, Freddie Mac reported today. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 7.06 percent in the week that ends Friday from the previous week's 6.89 percent, according to a weekly survey of mortgage rates from Freddie Mac. ''Interest rates will probably be even higher in next week's survey,'' said Robert Van Order, chief economist at Freddie Mac.

title: Building Fame for $15 a Head; For the Hip-Hop Set, the Local Celebrity Is the Barber
description: His name is on the lips of the hip-hop set in Sunset Park. The teen-agers in the baggy pants and Michelin Man jackets up and down Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn know Pedro Quinones, though not as Pedro Quinones. They know him as Casper, the sultan of the shape-up, the master of the Number One Fade, the quick answer to the bad hair day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, LINDA DIANA
description: RUSSO-Linda Diana. Suddenly on March 4, 1999. Beloved wife of John. Loving sister of Joan Keane and sister-in-law of Judy and Robert Riccuiti, Lawrence and Donna Russo, and Atoinette and Craig Wessel. Devoted aunt of seven nieces and nephews and two great nephews. Linda was president of Foodcom, Inc. Reposing at Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, Visiting Friday, 7-9 PM and Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Hope Church. Cremation Fresh Pond.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Merrill Enters Trading World Of the Internet
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the country's largest brokerage house, dipped its toes into Internet stock trading last night. Now, it has to show it can swim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALBERT, WILLIAM F.
description: TALBERT-William F. The United States Tennis Association mourns the loss of a true friend and great champion. As tournament director, Bill Talbert guided the US OPEN at Forest Hills and Flushing Meadows. A four-time champion in the US Nationals doubles, Bill also led the United States to Davis Cup victories as a captain and player. We will miss Bill at the US OPEN and extend our sympathies to his sons, Peter and Pike, and the rest of his family.

title: New Video Releases
description: Slam

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mobster With Panic Attacks Meets Therapist With Problems of His Own
description: ''Analyze This'' (say that second word with feeling!) has a funny title, an even funnier premise and inspired odd-couple casting that's enough to prompt laughter just on the basis of the two-shots in its ad campaign. Think of it as an offer you can't refuse.

title: Sharing Jones Settlement
description: Paula Corbin Jones and the lawyers who represented her at various times in her sexual-misconduct suit against President Clinton have agreed on how to share the $850,000 that Mr. Clinton gave her to settle her case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENBERG, FLORENCE
description: LEVENBERG - Florence. On March 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother or Myrna, Allan and Norman. Adoring grandmother of Susan, David, Daniel, Karen and Nicole. Greatgrandmother of Jonathan and Jamie. Service Friday, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Surveys Uncover Substantial Melting of Greenland Ice Sheet
description: The southern half of the Greenland ice sheet, the second largest expanse of land-bound ice on earth, after Antarctica, has shrunk substantially in the last five years, scientists have found in airborne surveys using new and more precise techniques.

title: Treasury Prices Move Little As Investors Await Jobs Data
description: Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, as anxious investors awaited the release of the Government's monthly jobs data today.

title: How Ugly Can It Get? Don't Ask The Nets
description: The Nets are not a good team that is playing poorly. They are not a solid club experiencing difficulties because of injuries. They are a weak basketball team. It is that simple.

title: Hit or Miss for Seton Hall As Connecticut Escapes
description: The free throw bounced on the front of the rim, curled along the right side of the iron and kissed the backboard. Then the ball dropped through the net. It was the worst single point Gary Saunders had recorded at Seton Hall.

title: U.N. Bars Ethnic Tibetan's Talk, Stirring Protests
description: United Nations officials have prevented an ethnic Tibetan from addressing the organization's Commission on the Status of Women, saying this might offend the Chinese delegation and result in China's opposing the accreditation of some women's groups to the world organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, JULIUS
description: BERNSTEIN-Julius. Of Andover, MA, formerly of New York, NY. On Wednesday, March 3. Beloved husband of the late Ann (Miller) Bernstein. Loving father of Janie Fischbach of Indiana and Daniel J. Bernstein of Andover, MA. Father-in-law of Ephraim Fischbach and Doree T. Barton. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Jeremy and Michael Fischbach, Jenna and Meredith Bernstein. Dear brother of Simon Burnett of New Jersey, Regina Brooks of Boston, MA, and Ethel Morse of California. Services at Temple Emanuel, 7 Haggetts Pond Road, Andover, MA, on Friday, March 5, at 11 A.M. Memorial observance Friday until 7 P.M. and Saturday 6 to 9 P.M., at the home of Daniel Bernstein & Doree Barton. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 1 Kendall Square, Building #

title: Pataki and Giuliani Pick Hudson River Park Board Members
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed board members yesterday to govern a new park to be built along the Hudson River, ending a six-month delay that park advocates feared was jeopardizing the park's progress.

title: After Series of Disagreements, Giuliani and Pataki Talk Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met privately with Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday for the first time in months, but their aides would provide only vague details about the discussion.

title: With Its Deal for Level One, Intel Seeks New Area of Growth
description: The Intel Corporation agreed today to buy Level One Communications Inc. for $2.11 billion in stock as it pushes into the fast-growing market for chips used in networking equipment.

title: The Names Are Quirky, and the Sex Is More So
description: Not so long ago, in movieland, couples met cute. In ''Relax . . . It's Only Sex,'' they have sex cute. Two fashionable West Hollywood gay men make love while discussing a future menu (something about salmon and fresh parsley). Another gay man carries on an internal (voice-over) monologue through much of the act about the advisability of taking a particular health risk. The film's token straight couple ravage each other in the kitchen so recklessly that nearby pots and pans rattle and clatter to the floor. This is shortly after the woman, Tara (Jennifer Tilly), tries to prove just how adorably frank she is by hitting the man, Gus (Timothy Paul Perez), on the back and whining, ''But I want your sperm!''

title: Patients Got Blood That Failed Tests
description: A breach in the blood safety procedures at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center last December resulted in three patients' receiving blood that had twice tested positive for hepatitis C and should have been discarded, hospital officials said. The hospital fired two blood bank technicians on Jan. 11 and disciplined a supervisor.

title: SHARES CLIMB ON STOCK SPLIT AND BUYBACK PLAN
description: Shares of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. climbed yesterday after the retailer said it would split its stock 2 for 1, and increase its share buyback program and its quarterly dividend. After the financial markets closed on Thursday Wal-Mart said it would raise the quarterly dividend 29 percent, to 10 cents a share, pre-split, from 7.75 cents. The increased post-split dividend of 5 cents will be paid April 19 to shareholders of record March 19. The share-repurchase program was increased by about $1.2 billion, to about $2 billion. The stock split will double the number of shares to 4.4 billion, but halve their value. The company has 2.2 billion shares outstanding. Its shares closed at $92.25, up $2.875.

title: COMPUSA SHARES TUMBLE AS LOSSES ARE EXPECTED
description: CompUSA Inc. shares fell 22 percent to the lowest level in almost four years, as the largest United States personal computer retailer warned of unexpected losses for two quarters because of weak sales. CompUSA was expected to earn 21 cents a share in the fiscal third quarter and 11 cents in the fourth quarter, the average estimates of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. It has reported a loss or declining profit in each of the last four quarters. The retailer is losing PC and software sales to rival chains and direct sellers and Internet sales. And profitable corporate customers are paring their orders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, CLARA
description: SCHAPIRO-Clara. Our congregation offers deepest sympathy to Jules Schapiro and his family on the loss of his beloved mother. East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue Reuven Siegel, Rabbi Daniel Hirtenstein, President Lawrence Levine, Chairman of the Board

title: A Car We Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue of Troops in Lebanon Energizes Israeli Election
description: The Labor Party candidate for Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, succeeded this week in inserting new momentum into the volatile, personality-based election campaign by introducing an actual issue into the race, withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINN, RICHARD
description: SHINN-Richard. We mourn with profound sadness the death of Richard Shinn, devoted member of our Managing Board from 1979 through 1994. His distinguished years of service as a member of the Executive Committee from 1986 through 1992, including the Committee Chairmanship in the 1989-1990 season, as Treasurer of the Board from 1986 through 1989 and as Chairman of the Finance Committee from 1980 through 1989, occurred at a critical time in the history of the Metropolitan Opera. During the years of his Board tenure, he made a deeply respected and important contribution to the long-term financial sercurity of our company. We valued his counsel, his wisdom, the generosity of his time in service to the Metropolitan Opera and his friendship. He leaves an enduring legacy to the institutions he served, including the Metropolitan Opera, and to the people of New York City. His life's work in public service is an inspiring example for future generations. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Marion and his family. Metropolitan Opera Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, MATHILDA
description: TERNER-Mathilda. The Board of Trustees and President of Manhattan School of Music offer our deepest sympathy to devoted and valued Trustee, Nancy Terner Behrman on the passing of her beloved mother Mathilda. We extend our most sincere and heartfelt condolences to her family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH STILL AT FAST PACE AS HIRING SURGES
description: Another big burst of job growth in February showed that the United States economy was still on a roll while wage pressures remained remarkably subdued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARZMAN, ADELE
description: SWARZMAN-Adele (nee Beller). Passed away peacefully at home on March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving A. Swarzman, devoted mother of Phyllis and Harold Stock, Martin and Jan Swarzman, dearly loved ''Gram Adele'' to Sharon, Robert and Catarina, Steven, Howard and Michelle, and Laura. ''Great Gram Adele'' to Isaac, Elliot, Samantha and Danielle. Past president of Sisterhood, Temple Shaare Torah. Generous, always a lady, in speech and in demeanor. Service Sunday, March 7, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: Williams Is Not Badly Hurt; Nets Are Still in Bad Shape
description: It could have been the crushing blow in a flurry of haymakers that sent the Nets reeling like a battered prizefighter. But instead of being floored by the loss of another key starter, the Nets received good news today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, GEORGE
description: LEWIS-George, of Ft. Lee, NJ, on March 3rd, 1999. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Prince). Devoted father of Jeffrey and Jonathan. Dear brother of Roberta Lawrence and Marion Tanney. Loving grandfather of Jason, Cindy and Gina. Adoring great-grandfather of Andrew and Cameron. Friends may gather at ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, on Sunday, 11 AM. Burial will follow in Hurleville Cemetery.

title: China Reaffirms Drive to Overhaul Bloated State Industries
description: Senior Chinese officials today reaffirmed their determination to squeeze dead wood and red ink out of bloated state-owned enterprises, vowing to make nearly all of them competitive and profitable by the end of next year.

title: Clinton Wishes 'A Good Life' For Lewinsky
description: With downcast eye and bitten lip, President Clinton said today that he was sorry about all that Monica Lewinsky had been through this last year and wished her ''a good life.''

title: A Car We Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROBERT B.
description: WEINSTEIN-Robert B. On March 4, 1999. Loving son of Blanche and Herbert A. Dear brother of Laurie Besmertnik. Brother-in-law of Sid. Dear uncle of Bonnie, Todd and Sara. Service Sunday, March 7, 1999, 12 noon at the Kane St. Synagogue, 236 Kane St, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, ALLEN
description: WARDWELL-Allen. The staff of Christie's Inc. in New York expresses their profound sorrow and offers support to Allen's wife, Sally, children and grandchildren. Allen was a respected and cherished colleague whose enthusiasm and pure love of the arts were an inspiration to us all. At Christie's he was an integral part of our specialist team adding invaluable knowledge to our American Indian and Tribal Art Departments. He will forever be remembered for his zest for life and his passion for art.

title: Philips Sues To Pursue Deal
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V. sued VLSI Technology today to prevent VLSI from using a ''poison pill'' defense to block Philips from pursuing its $777 million buyout of VLSI.

title: Naked Rite of Passage Defended at Princeton
description: Princeton University officials may be planning to ban the Nude Olympics, but judging from the reaction of students Thursday night during their first public forum on the issue, the tradition will continue.

title: Cardinal Mediates Meeting on Police Role
description: Worried by the bitter aftermath of the shooting of Amadou Diallo, John Cardinal O'Connor has helped bring together black business leaders and officials of the police union to discuss just how severely the incident has frayed the relationship between black New Yorkers and the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, MARJORIE KANE
description: GERRY-Marjorie Kane. Died on March 4 at the age of 89 following a short illness at Delhi, N.Y. Widow of the late Elbridge T. Gerry who died on February 26. She is survived by two sons Elbridge T. Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y. and Peter G. of Hopewell, N.J., a daughter Marjorie G. Ryland of Beverly, MA., a sister Patricia Kane Leonard of Chesiers, Switzerland, eleven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A joint memorial service for she and her husband of 67 years will be held on Wednesday, March 10, 1999 at Trinity Church, Wall St. and Broadway, NYC, at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Lake Delaware Boys Camp or The O'Connor Hospital, Delhi, NY.

title: Lord Denning, 100, a Populist Who Enlivened British Courts
description: Lord Denning, whose bent for favoring the relaxed precepts of common sense over the starchier ones of common law earned him the nickname the People's Judge, died today at Hampshire County Hospital in Winchester. He was 100.

title: Russian Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley Names 3
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has named three people to head three new regional sales divisions as it moves to replace Robert J. Dwyer, 55, who is retiring as national sales director on April 1. The Eastern division will be run by Bruce F. Alonso, the Central by Alan A. Schroder, and the Western by Stephen R. Miller. They will report to James F. Higgins, president and chief operating officer of the individual securities group.

title: A Fusion With Funk, Thoroughly Mixed
description: In his late set on Tuesday night at Iridium, Donald Harrison and his quartet weren't playing music with terribly complicated structures; the emphasis was on the feel of the rhythm, its different tilts and pulls. Mr. Harrison, an alto saxophonist, is from New Orleans, where rhythm sections make all kinds of American music slide and roll and where even the intricacies of be-bop are danced to.

title: At Odds, Crew And the Mayor Look to Future
description: The image of the two Rudys -- Rudy Giuliani, the tough-talking, take-no-prisoners Mayor, and Rudy Crew, the canny but charming Schools Chancellor -- standing shoulder to shoulder in the Blue Room of City Hall, celebrating the latest educational achievement for New York City public schools, is a familiar one.

title: Els Decides Not to Take a Break And Finds Himself in Contention
description: Many of the world's top players took a break this week, but Ernie Els did not.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the 1999-2000 season of the Metropolitan Opera misidentified the role Placido Domingo will sing in the opening-night performance of ''Pagliacci'' on Sept. 27. It is Canio, not Tonio.

title: St. John's Gets Revenge, and a Shot at UConn
description: The St. John's basketball players had lusted for this rematch, had said all week that the only interest the Big East tournament held for them was the chance at one more meeting with Miami. They wanted, quite simply, revenge against the only team that had beaten them twice this season and surged past them in the national polls in the final week of the regular season. They owed them, Coach Mike Jarvis said.

title: Writing Well Is Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Are Sticking Together in Quest for Playoff Spot
description: On to Boston roll the Rangers, the hottest mediocre team in the Eastern Conference. By beating the Capitals, 4-2, on Thursday night at the MCI Center in Washington, the Rangers climbed within 2 points of the Bruins, who hold the eighth and final playoff berth in the East.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DWYER, MIKE
description: DWYER-Mike I remember and love. A.

title: INSIDE
description: Appeals to Kosovo Factions

title: Appeals Court Divided In Lesbian Custody Case
description: A state appeals court was split yesterday in its decision to deny a separated lesbian couple joint custody of 4-year-old twins, automatically giving the New Jersey Supreme Court a chance to decide the matter.

title: New York Puts On a More Hospitable Face
description: New York City has often had a love-hate relationship with its tourists. Sure, their money fuels the economy, but they also crowd Manhattan streets and make it even tougher to get restaurant reservations. And while locals do offer directions to out-of-towners, albeit reluctantly, the city continues to be a daunting place for visitors to master.

title: British Bank Buying Some UBS Operations
description: Standard Chartered P.L.C., the British bank that makes two-thirds of its income in Asia, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the non-Swiss global trade-finance business of UBS A.G. for 300 million Swiss francs ($204 million) in cash.

title: Beliefs; Satisfying the requirements of Rome and those of academe at Catholic colleges and universities in the United States.
description: On the phone, Bishop John Leibrecht sounded upbeat.

title: Murder Reveals Double Life Of Being Gay in Rural South
description: The closets that gay people build in small, severe towns like this one are thick and difficult to penetrate, and Billy Jack Gaither's was locked even tighter than most.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOSTER, AMOS E.
description: GLOSTER-Amos E. (of Rockville Centre, New York) Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of the late John Gloster. Loving brother of Helen and Vincent Richards, Charles and Muriel Gloster. Cherished uncle of Robert and Susan. Graveside services Sunday 11AM. at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Flushing, New York. For more information contact ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'', 718-284-1500.

title: Italian Presses Clinton on Pilot's Acquittal
description: In an unusual display of frustration between close allies, the Italian Prime Minister told President Clinton today that he was shocked at the acquittal of an American pilot in the deaths of 20 tourists in Italy and said he would not be satisfied until someone was punished.

title: Ready or Not, Reid Takes a Shot
description: Since the day he turned professional, David Reid has been saying that he is ready for a world championship fight. Al Mitchell, his trainer and manager, has been preaching patience. Finally, the time has come for the precocious junior middleweight and his cautious caretaker.

title: Markets Rally Sharply as Economic Fears Fade
description: Investors, who were braced for bad news from the February jobs report, got a pleasant surprise yesterday that helped push bond yields down sharply and stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average set a new high, rising 268.68 points, to 9,736.08 -- just 264 points from 10,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, DEANE F.
description: JOHNSON-Deane F. The Directors and Staff of The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America note with deep sorrow the passing of Deane Johnson. As a longtime friend and Trustee, Mr. Johnson was a loyal supporter of Scouting in New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Johnson family. John F. McGillicuddy, President Richard M. Ruffino, Scout Executive

title: Boeing to Provide T.W.A. Financing
description: The Boeing Company has arranged $2.36 billion in financing for Trans World Airlines Inc., which has filed for bankruptcy twice this decade and has junk-rated credit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFER, ROSE
description: HELFER-Rose (nee Prizer). Loving and loved wife of Mac. Cherished mother of Steve, Jerry, Eileen and Allen Scherl. Adored grandmother of Brett, Lindsay and Todd Mitchell, Alexis and Jason Scherl. We will all miss her love, compassion, concern and values. Funeral services Sunday, March 7th, 12:30pm at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd at 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY. Contributions may be made to the Laura Rosenberg Foundation, 73 Crystal Court, Hewlett, NY, 11557.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, BARNEY
description: LEVIN-Barney. On March 5, 1999. Age 93. Beloved husband of Alice. Devoted father to Robert, Stephen, Charles and Arthur. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Services Sunday, 12PM at Menorah Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave, Staten Island, N.Y.

title: How Big a Military?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, FRANK D.
description: LYONS-Frank D. Of Staten Island. On March 5, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lorraine Marie (nee Villella). Loving father of Dennis John Lyons and Deborah Jean Lyons. Dear father-in-law of Christine (nee Argenziano). Dear brother of John Lyons, Rosemarie Piggot and Patricia Haulk. Adored grandfather of Deanna, Cassandra, Angelica and Marissa Lyons. Funeral from Virginia Funeral Chapel, 1707 Hylan Boulevard, Staten Island, New York, on Monday, 9 A.M. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Rosary R.C. Church, 9:30 A.M. Interment Moravian Cemetery. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Wilson Is Impressive With 14 Pitches
description: After cruising through two hitless innings tonight against Montreal in the Mets' exhibition opener, Paul Wilson said it felt like a midseason start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANKEN, HAROLD IRA
description: PANKEN-Harold Ira. State Senator, trial lawyer. Beloved husband for 65 years of Sylvia. Father of Peter, Bruce and Jeffry. Father-inlaw of Beverly and Carol. Grandfather of Aaron, Melinda, Leah, Johanna and Matthew. Greatgrandfather of Eli, Max and Samantha. You have always been a presence in the lives of your family. The family will be at Peter's home on Sunday afternoon and evening and Monday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SYLVIA LAURA
description: SCHWARTZ-Sylvia Laura (nee Rubin). 79 years. Of Lauderhill, Fl. Formerly of Oceanside, NY. Died March 3, 1999. Beloved mother of Ronnie, Donald (and Helen). Cherished grandmother of Corey. Loving sister of Jeanette Gray, Gloria Ottenstein and Jerome Rubin. Services Sunday 10am at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Longbeach Rd, Rockville, Ctr, LI. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Political Notes; Next Mayor? A Democrat, Says a G.O.P Leader
description: Whether the city will elect another Republican as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's successor has been at the center of some early political sparring this week among party officials.

title: ABN to Acquire Italy Bank Stake
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V. said today that it would buy 8.75 percent of Banca di Roma S.p.A. for about 660 million euros ($715 million), a first step toward making Italy its second-largest European market outside the Netherlands.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MATTEL INC., -- the toy maker, said it planned to complete its acquisition of the children's software maker Learning Company in May instead of April because the Securities and Exchange Commission review of the deal was taking longer than expected.

title: Senator Mack, a Florida Republican, Will Retire
description: Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, will not seek a third term next year, touching off a political free-for-all in the state and another unpredictable element in the fight for control of Congress.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about a speech by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China on economic and social reforms misstated the timing. The speech was yesterday, not Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: McGUIRE-Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Happy Birthday! Forever Beautiful, Forever Remembered, Forever Loved, Forever in my Heart. Love, Sissy

title: Irabu Taking Cues From New Guru
description: David Wells was good for Hideki Irabu last year, making an effort to indoctrinate Irabu into the Yankees' clubhouse. Now it is Roger Clemens who seems to be having an effect on the pitcher from Japan, but the influence is different.

title: Sprewell Returns, and So Do Knicks' Road Woes
description: Latrell Sprewell popped off the bench and came onto the scene like a siren in the rearview mirror tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strong Job Creation Shows The Economy Is Still Robust

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We shall say we are satisfied when whoever is responsible for what happened is found guilty and punished. With so many casualties and so many deaths, you can hardly ever say you are satisfied.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERHOFF, HARRY J.
description: MEYERHOFF-Harry J. Singer, Entertainer, of Lew Beach, NY died March 3, 1999. He was 73. Beloved husband of Bonnie, devoted father of Timothy and Jonathan and loving brother of Bob. Harry was a most wonderful human being, a fabulous husband, a great father and brother. He was a God fearing man who was very spiritual. He touched many people's lives with laughter and singing. He will be dearly missed. Friends may call on Sunday, March 7, 1999 at the H.C. Bryant Funeral Home, Pearl St. Livingston Manor, NY from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral service Monday, March 8, 1999 at the Lew Beach Community Church, Lew Beach, NY at 11:00am. Interment follows at the Lew Beach Cemetery.

title: Albright, on Visit to Indonesia, Meets Detained Timor Leader
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met today with the East Timorese separatist leader, Xanana Gusmao, who was brought from house arrest in a downtown bungalow here to the Indonesian Foreign Ministry for the encounter.

title: Gebrselassie Defends 3,000-Meter Title
description: On the opening day of the seventh world indoor championships in Maebashi, Japan, Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia successfully defended the 3,000-meter title he won in Paris two years ago.

title: When Uganda Was Safe
description: I have replayed the scene in my head a hundred times: an American couple vacationing in Africa, awakened by the sound of gunfire and screams, then scrambling out the back of their tent to hide in the dense jungle. That quick thinking -- or perhaps it was pure instinct -- saved them from the band of guerrillas who slaughtered eight other tourists and a conservation warden in Uganda this week.

title: Mathilda Terner Philanthropist, 88
description: Mathilda Terner, who engaged in philanthropy with her industrialist husband, Emmanuel, died on Wednesday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 88 and also maintained a home in Oakhurst, N.J.

title: INSIGNIA FINANCIAL EXPANDS BRITISH HOLDINGS
description: Insignia Financial Group Inc. bought the British real estate services firm St. Quintin for $32 million, expanding its British subsidiary, Richard Ellis Group Ltd. The New York-based Insignia said the expansion of its London-based unit, to be renamed Richard Ellis St. Quintin, would add 3 cents a share to annual net income and 21 cents to net cash flow. Those figures do not include a $6 million charge Insignia expects to take in the first quarter for merger-related expenses. The purchase price could rise by as much as $12 million if the combined unit meets certain performance targets over the next three years. Richard Ellis St. Quintin will be one of the three largest property brokers and managers in Britain.

title: Envoys Are Pushing for Talks As Kosovo Fighting Continues
description: Western envoys flew into the Balkans today to pressure the warring sides in Kosovo to agree to a peace accord as the province suffered another day of shelling and casualties.

title: Richard Kiley, the Man of La Mancha, Is Dead at 76
description: Richard Kiley, who won a Tony Award for his compelling performance as Don Quixote in the Broadway musical ''Man of La Mancha'' and was for 40 years one of theater's most distinguished and versatile actors, died yesterday at Horton Hospital in Middletown, N.Y. He was 76 and lived in Warwick, N.Y.

title: WINSLOEW FURNITURE IN DEAL TO BE BOUGHT
description: Winsloew Furniture Inc., which makes aluminum furniture for patios and offices, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for about $223.5 million in cash by a management group led by its chairman, Earl Powell. Mr. Powell's group offered $30 a share, a 12 percent premium over Winsloew's closing price on Thursday of $26.75. The purchase is valued at about $223.5 million, based on 7.45 million shares outstanding at the end of December. Winsloew, which had 1998 sales of $141.4 million, would be bought by the Trivest Furniture Corporation, a newly formed company controlled by Mr. Powell. Trivest first offered to buy the company Jan. 18 to take it private.

title: A Deal for Tyson: No Indiana Prison
description: Mike Tyson cleared a major legal hurdle yesterday when an Indiana judge approved an agreement that would not require him to serve extra prison time in that state for violating his probation on a 1992 rape conviction.

title: Sports of The Times; An Outsider Provides the Inside Scoop
description: FOR the last 10 seasons, Dermon Player has watched March Madness from the outside. As the boys' basketball coach and athletic director of the Riverside Church Hawks, Player's real season was in the summer, when he took some of New York City's best high school players and barnstormed the country. Three years ago Player coached the Riverside team that was 67-1 in summer-league competition; that team included the St. John's players Ron Artest, Erick Barkley and Reggie Jessie. Now he's in the pressure cooker. With St. John's back as a national power, Player signed on to make sure the Red Storm stayed there.

title: UTILICORP TO ACQUIRE ST. JOSEPH LIGHT AND POWER
description: Utilicorp United Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the St. Joseph Light and Power Company for $190 million. St. Joseph stockholders will receive $23 for each of their shares, a 35.8 percent premium over the company's Thursday closing share price of $16.93. St. Joseph Light and Power, based in St. Joseph, Mo., serves 66,000 electric and gas customers in northwest Missouri. It had revenue of $124.4 million in 1998. Utilicorp, the successor company to Missouri Public Service, operates utilities that provide gas and electricity to more than three million customers in eight states and Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Britain. It had revenue of $12.6 billion in 1998. St. Joseph shares rose $3.50, to $20.375, while Utilicorp rose 62.5 cents, to $35.75.

title: If Not Strong, at Least Tricky: The Middleweight of Puctuation Politics
description: These days the semicolon, one of the least loved, least understood punctuation marks, barely ekes out a living between the period and the comma. It was not always that way.

title: Kurds Threaten Violence
description: Although the Kurdish guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan is reportedly cooperating with interrogators in prison, his guerrilla group pledged today to step up its war.

title: Devils Fall, but It's the Rangers Who Lose Ground
description: With 20 games to play in the regular season, the Boston Bruins are clinging to the eighth and last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference. Their grip hardened a bit tonight -- at the expense of the Devils and to the chagrin of the Rangers -- when Boston made three first-period goals stand up in a 4-1 victory over the Devils at Continental Arena.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS JUMPS. Natural gas rose to a six-week high as cool weather lifted demand amid falling inventories. Gas for April delivery rose 9.8 cents, or 5.7 percent, to $1.86 for a million British thermal units.

title: SEARS STOCK UP AFTER TURNAROUND SPECIALIST IS NAMED
description: Shares of Sears, Roebuck & Company rose for a second day as much as 4.3 percent yesterday after it appointed Julian C. Day, a corporate turnaround specialist, as its chief financial officer. Sears rose yesterday by 87.5 cents, to $44.625, after gaining $3.125 to close at $43.75 on Thursday. Mr. Day, 46, helped turn around Safeway Inc. during his five-year tenure as chief financial officer. Beginning on March 22, he will have responsibility for all financial operations at Sears, which has struggled with slow sales growth and as customers fell behind on their credit card payments.

title: Computer Problems Disrupt the Nasdaq
description: A computer equipment failure disrupted trading on the Nasdaq stock market for nearly 90 minutes yesterday morning, forcing market makers to their phones and leaving day traders frustrated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUILLAN, FRANCIS SEYMOUR
description: QUILLAN-Francis Seymour. Retired senior vice president of The Prudential Insurance Company of America died February 27 at his home in Palm City, FL. He was 86. Mr. Quillan was born on Block Island, RI on September 12, 1912. He was the son of Edward Thomas Quillan and the former Mabel Hayes. He graduated from Moses Brown School in 1929. In 1933 he graduated Summa cum Laude in mathematics from Brown University where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and admitted to Sigma Xi, an honorary scientific fraternity. Mr. Quillan joined the Prudential in 1933. In 1961 he was named senior vice president in charge of the General Office Administration, Claim, Debit Policy and Ordinary Policy Departments. In 1969 he also assumed responsibility for the Governmental Health Program Department. Mr. Quillan retired in 1973. For 37 years Mr. Quillan resided in Glen Ridge, NJ and was a member of the Board of Education there from 1951 until 1963. He served as president of the board from 1955 to 1963. Mr. Quillan had been vice president of the Associated Boards of Education of Essex County, treasurer and trustee of the United Community Corporation of Newark, chairman of the board of the Better Business Bureau of Greater Newark, a member of the Education Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, the national director of the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, a director of the National Urban League, and the metro director of the National Alliance of Businessmen for Newark. Mr. Quillan was married on October 7, 1939 to the former Frances Lane of Nutley, NJ who died in 1993. He is survived by four children, Marjorie Wendell of Chatham, NJ, Joanne Cotterill of Madison, NJ, Dorothy Williams of Mystic, CT and George Quillan of Morristown, NJ; three grandsons and three granddaughters; a brother, Edward Hayes Quillan of East Greenwich, RI; two nieces and one grandnephew. Services will be private. Those who wish may contribute to Hospice of Martin & St. Lucie, P.O. Box 1168, Stuart, FL 34995-1168.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, BARBARA
description: PFEFFER-Barbara. On March 3, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Rose and Felix Pfeffer. Survived by sister Doris Pfeffer, a circle of loving friends and relatives in Israel, Paris and The United States. Services at ''The Riverside'' on March 7th at 11 A.M.

title: Death Row Lessons and One Professor's Mission
description: David Protess believes his career was shaped at age 7, growing up near Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn. In that year, 1953, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed.

title: The Suharto Legacy Lives On in Indonesia
description: With riots raging in one of Indonesia's provinces and a bruising election just four months away, it's clear that nursing this economically ruined country back to health will not be easy.

title: Death Rate Decreases For Coronary Bypasses
description: The death rate for coronary artery bypass surgery in New Jersey decreased by more than 13 percent from 1994 to 1997, the State Department of Health and Senior Services said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARE, EDYTHE
description: WARE-Edythe. In our hearts you will always be remembered. Mac and our sons Lewis, Stephen and Rober

title: Teen-Ager Gets 30 Years In Murder of Girl, 16
description: A 18-year-old high school student convicted in January of murdering a classmate was sentenced yesterday to 30 years in prison without parole, county prosecutors said.

title: Bad Deal on Redwoods
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; Monica's Real Story
description: ''I saw things this past year,'' Monica Lewinsky told Barbara Walters, ''that I didn't know happened in this country.''

title: Assistant Is Expected to Replace Retiring Labor Federation Leader
description: Edward J. Cleary, the president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. since 1984, will retire on March 23 and will be succeeded by his executive assistant, Denis M. Hughes, labor leaders said yesterday.

title: Whitman Asks Delay in Case On Profiling
description: After denying for years that black and Latino drivers are targeted by state troopers searching for drugs, the Whitman administration said today that it was considering dropping its appeal of a 1996 court ruling that found troopers had a ''de facto policy of racial profiling.''

title: New York City To Face Review Of Police Role
description: The Federal Government stepped into the heated issue of the police treatment of black and Hispanic people in New York City today when the Civil Rights Commission voted to conduct a hearing into the city's police practices.

title: Hong Kong Phone Giant Seen in Microsoft Deal
description: Shares of Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. staged their biggest rally in more than six months yesterday on anticipation that the company would team up with the Microsoft Corporation. Shares of Hong Kong's dominant phone company rose 9 percent, to $14 (Hong Kong), its biggest gain since Aug. 24.

title: 3 Kidnapped Americans Killed; Colombian Rebels Are Suspected
description: Three Americans who were kidnapped last week in the Colombian rain forest were found slain Thursday just across the border in Venezuela, the authorities said yesterday.

title: The Nuclear Power Elite; A Small Circle of Companies Seeks Control of Reactors
description: FOR SALE: Five buildings on 1,600 acres of woodland. Cape Cod Bay vu. 26 years old. Original owner. Good condition.

title: Big Board Sues Amex Over Using Letter 'Q'
description: The New York Stock Exchange filed a lawsuit yesterday against the American Stock Exchange to thwart its plan to use the ticker symbol ''Q'' for a new investment product called the Nasdaq-100 Index Shares.

title: Orioles to Play in Cuba; First Such Trip Since '59
description: The Baltimore Orioles will play the Cuban national baseball team on March 28 in Havana under a deal in principle that was concluded yesterday, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said. The game will mark the first time in 40 years that a major league team will play in Cuba.

title: Partial Freedom Is Best for Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Wheels
description: The Ford Motor Company today introduced the first design change to make the rising number of huge sport utility vehicles a little safer in crashes with cars. It said its newest sport utility vehicle, a behemoth that would be the tallest and heaviest yet, would be equipped with hollow steel bars mounted below the front and rear bumpers to prevent it from riding over cars during collisions. The horizontal steel beams hang down six inches from the high-riding steel frame of the vehicle, the Ford Excursion, which is nearly seven feet tall and weighs more than three tons.

title: All Leads Are Equally Bad? No, Just the One You Chose
description: Every player has, on occasion, the following feeling: ''Whatever I do now will be wrong.'' Sometimes this is true, and any play will help the opposition. Sometimes it is not quite true, but the escape route is hard to find.

title: Elbridge T. Gerry, 90, Polo Star And Banker Who Bred Trotters
description: Elbridge T. Gerry, a banker, polo star and breeder of harness horses that twice won the Hambletonian, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Delhi, N.Y. He was 90.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: The Leap From Europe to New York
description: The German soprano Dorothea Roschmann has already won considerable attention at some prestigious European opera houses and festivals. She made an acclaimed debut at the Salzburg Festival in 1995 as Susanna in Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' has sung lyric soprano roles by Mozart, Strauss and Stravinsky in Munich and Halle and is currently a member of the Deutsche Staatsoper Berlin. So even at a young age she would seem to be a practiced professional.

title: Of Dreams and Nightmares, All East Coast
description: Gangsta rap paused for a moment to mourn when Tupac Shakur and the Notorious B.I.G. were shot. Then it went back to business: dominating the sales charts with new, more dexterous variations on its familiar tales. Two gangsta rappers who have sold millions of albums -- Jay-Z, who won the 1999 Grammy Award for best rap album, and DMX -- are headlining a tour that is selling out arenas, including the Continental Airlines Arena here on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTWEIN, HENRY
description: ALTWEIN-Henry. On March 4, 1999, beloved husband of Claire. Dear brother of Siegfried Altwein and Helena Frischer. Loving uncle and good friend. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: School Board's Reluctant Swing Voter
description: One school board member's vote on vouchers could ultimately determine whether Chancellor Rudy Crew stays in New York City long enough to preside over the opening of his fifth school year next fall.

title: A Vision of Ideal Love That Grows as It Changes
description: ''Roses,'' a 1985 work that the Paul Taylor Dance Company revived on Thursday night at City Center, features six pairs of lovers and is danced in part to Wagner's ''Siegfried Idyll.''

title: Japan Lowers Rates Again, And for Banks It's a Big Zero
description: Japan's central bank pushed overnight interest rates to the unprecedented level of effectively zero this week in one of its boldest attempts yet to invigorate the economy -- basically allowing Japanese banks to borrow free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANKEN, HAROLD
description: PANKEN-Harold. Temple Shaaray Tefila offers its heartfelt condolences to our Assistant Rabbi Melinda Panken on the passing of her grandfather. Our deepest sympathy to Rabbi Panken, her parents Beverly and Peter, and brother Aaron. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Dr. Ellen R. Saxl, President

title: The Rural Life; The Weight of Winter Rain
description: Just about now a certain winter-weariness sets in, at least for those of us who live in the country. Every morning and evening you can feel the sun pushing back the margins of night, and it's a dull soul who hasn't checked sunrise or sunset against his watch several times by now, struck by how early the light comes and how late it begins to go. But that just makes a day of heavy overcast and freezing rain feel all the worse, more of an impairment than it would have been when the sodden year was still shrinking. The rain falls as it has all winter, over ice and snow, as if to make a none-too-subtle point about the climate in this part of New York State, a point that those of us who live here start to take seriously only about now.

title: Monitoring Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Passengers Are Slashed in Separate Attacks on Subways
description: A 29-year-old Manhattan woman who refused to give money to some homeless women on the D train was cut on the face with a razor yesterday, in one of three slashing incidents on the subways, the police said.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: OSCAR MADNESS
description: The Academy Awards are only two weeks away, and the fever is high: rivalries are raging; press agents and studios are campaigning hard for votes. Sure, other awards abound, but everybody knows that Oscar is the one with magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HARRY
description: MERESMAN-Harry. Died on March 3rd, 1999 at the age of 88. Beloved husband of the late Helen Chafets Meresman, devoted father of Helaine Meresman Barnett and the late Janis Meresman Goldman, adored grandfather of Craig and Jennifer Barnett, Roger Barnett, Melissa Goldman, Lori and Brett Zbar, great-grandfather of Gabriel Barnett, father-in-law extraordinaire to Victor Barnett and Michael Goldman, loving son, brother, brother-in-law, uncle and loyal, trusted and respected friend. A man whose unquestioned integrity, ethics and morality were his hallmarks and his devotion to his family, commitment to his community and his pride in his profession were his passions. The high standards by which he lead his life and his impeccable reputation will remain to all who knew him as his everlasting legacy.

title: An Oxford Historian Whose Vox Is Populi
description: Niall Ferguson likes to joke that he became a historian by default. ''At Oxford, I discovered that I couldn't be a politician, I wouldn't make a terribly good journalist, I was a very poor double bass player and I was an absolutely appalling actor,'' he said. ''I came to realize that what made me happy was to sit in a library reading about dead people.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, LINDA DIANA
description: RUSSO-Linda Diana. Suddenly on March 4, 1999. Beloved wife of John. Loving sister of Joan Keane and sister-in-law of Judy and Robert Riccuiti, Lawrence and Donna Russo, and Atoinette and Craig Wessel. Devoted aunt of seven nieces and nephews and two great nephews. Linda was president of Foodcom, Inc. Reposing at Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, Visiting Friday, 7-9 PM and Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Hope Church. Cremation Fresh Pond.

title: Toyota to Raise Prices
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation plans to raise prices on its 1999 models sold in the United States to take advantage of strong demand. The Japan-based auto maker, the fourth largest in the United States, said it would increase the average retail price of its cars and trucks three-tenths of a percent, or $63, starting April 2. It said last month that it would also raise prices on its Lexus luxury line three-tenths of a percent. The increase comes as rival auto makers trimmed prices or held them steady on 1999 models, according to Comerica Inc.

title: Judge Refuses to Block Catholic School Closing
description: A judge yesterday refused a request by a group of parents to block the closing of Our Lady of Grace School, which church officials say they believe is the oldest Roman Catholic school in the state.

title: About New York; Confrontation Sows Doubts About Police
description: SAY hello to Sean Hawkins of Brooklyn. Do not, however, say yo.

title: Trans-Atlantic Transitions
description: The United States and Europe are quarreling over bananas, airplanes and beef, working together to secure peace in Kosovo and tangling over the future of NATO. This improbable confluence of events reflects important changes taking place in trans-Atlantic relations. Perhaps more clearly than at any time since the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, America and its European allies are confronting the economic frictions of globalization and adjusting to a world no longer shaped by the clash of ideologies.

title: How Best to Rein In Microsoft?
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Mart, One Victim Of Progress
description: After nearly four decades in the Times Square subway station, the Record Mart, the legendary Latin record store, closed this week to make way for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's renovation of the station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUN, GERTA
description: GRUN-Gerta. The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee mourn the loss of a loyal friend, fervently devoted to the enhancement of the human condition through progress in science. We express sincere condolences to Olek Schwartz, Mordecai Turi, John Grun, Jacqueline Schwartz, Doron and Eitan Schwartz, and the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUBERT, JEAN PAUL
description: GAUBERT-Jean Paul, 86, of Long Branch, NJ, died March 5, 1999, at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. During World War II, he served in the French Army and was held by the Germans as a prisoner of war in Stalag 3B. Mr. Gaubert was born in Marseilles, France, and lived in Forest Hills, Queens, before moving to Long Branch in 1995. Surviving are his wife, Lucienne C. Thauzan Gaubert; a daughter and son-in-law, Janine B. and Dr. Prescott Evarts, Jr., West Long Branch; two grandsons, Christopher J. and Geoffrey J. Evarts; and a great-granddaughter, Sylvie Duthie Evarts. Funeral Mass will be Monday, March 8, at 12 p.m. at St. Michael's R.C. Church, 800 Ocean Avenue, Long Branch. Visitation will be Monday from 10:30 a.m. until the time of the Mass, at Woolley Funeral Home, 10 Morrell Street, Long Branch, New Jersey. Interment will follow in Fairview Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, WARD
description: STEVENSON-Ward. The Board of Directors, the shareholders, the staff, Burton Wallack and Wallack Management mourn the untimely passing of Ward Stevenson, past president of Carnegie Hill 87th Street Corp.

title: Across 10 Years, Exxon Valdez Casts a Shadow
description: It was a few minutes after midnight on March 24, 1989, when the big tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef in the icy waters of Prince William Sound. ''Evidently we're leaking some oil and we're going to be here for quite a while,'' the captain radioed the Coast Guard. Even now, as the 10th anniversary of one of the nation's worst environmental disasters approaches, the Exxon Valdez is in many ways still here.

title: METAMOR WORLDWIDE PLANS TO ADD GE CAPITAL UNIT
description: Metamor Worldwide Inc., a computer staffing and services company, said yesterday that it would buy the GE Capital Corporation's GE Capital Consulting unit for $115 million in stock and cash as it expanded its electronic commerce and consulting services. Metamor shares rose $1.625, or 11 percent, to $16.75, in trading of 1.99 million shares, more than four times the three-month daily average. Metamor will issue an undisclosed number of shares to GE Capital, based on a price of $55 a share. GE Capital Consulting, with 530 consultants in 16 United States cities, is expected to generate $90 million in sales this year.

title: BERKSHIRE REALTY REBUFFS A PURCHASE OFFER
description: Berkshire Realty Company, an owner of apartment properties in the South, called a $1.15 billion buyout offer from a group of investors led by its chairman insufficient yesterday, and said it had received other offers. Berkshire's chairman, Douglas Krupp, and real estate funds managed by Blackstone Group Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Company disclosed in Securities and Exchange Commission filings on Thursday that they had offered to buy the company for $11.05 a share. The offer is a 14 percent premium to Thursday's closing price of $9.6875, but below the stock's 52-week high of $12.3125 in April. Its shares closed yesterday at $10.6875.

title: BREACH AT LOS ALAMOS: A special report.; China Stole Nuclear Secrets For Bombs, U.S. Aides Say
description: Working with nuclear secrets stolen from an American Government laboratory, China has made a leap in the development of nuclear weapons: the miniaturization of its bombs, according to Administration officials.

title: Writing Well Is Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Weighing the Vice Presidential Factor in Gore's Feeble Showing in the Polls
description: Vice President Al Gore has only one declared rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000. His party is delighting in its newfound popularity after impeachment, while President Clinton is basking in impressive job approval ratings.

title: Debt of Consumers Climbed in January
description: Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a faster pace in January as all categories of debt increased, Federal Reserve figures released today showed.

title: Turning the Tables
description: In the initial skirmishes last year over how to allocate potentially huge Federal budget surpluses, President Clinton triumphed politically by casting himself as the prudent protector of Social Security against irresponsible Republican tax cutters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOZIAN, ROSE
description: MOZIAN-Rose. On March 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Ovagem. Devoted mother of Joan M. Jensen and Bob Mozian. Dear mother-in-law of Walter Jensen and Mary Ann Mozian. Proud grandmother of Jeannine and Craig Mozian. Loving sister of Mary Ohnikian. Family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, Sun 2-4 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10AM at the Armenian Church of the Holy Martyrs. Interment Cedergrove Cemetery. Donations to the New York Armenian Home, 137-31 45 Ave., Flushing, NY 11355, and The Armenian Church of the Holy Martyers, 209-15 Horace Harding Expressway, Bayside, NY 11364, would be much appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVY, ESTHER
description: LEAVY-Esther. March 6, 1976. In loving memory. Always, Your children and grandchildren

title: How Best to Rein In Microsoft?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Best to Rein In Microsoft?
description: To the Editor:

title: Phifer Signs Three-Year Deal
description: Yesterday, on his 31st birthday, Roman Phifer, a regular with the St. Louis Rams for the last nine seasons, agreed to a three-year deal with the Jets, adding depth to the team's linebacking corps. The move was the Jets' fourth free-agent pickup of the off season.

title: Family Memories Spoken In a Ceremony of Loss
description: Dances became elegies in the two multimedia productions that Muna Tseng Dance Projects and Ping Chong and Company presented on Thursday night as attractions of the 92d Street Y Harkness Dance Project at Playhouse 91. Both featured solo dances choreographed and performed by Muna Tseng under Ping Chong's direction and with slide projections by Jan Hartley.

title: Loggers in Redwoods Deal Can't Be Trusted, Say Some
