description: For the first half of last year, the Pacific Lumber Company surprised state forestry inspectors by obeying the rules. Then, officials say, the company reverted to its old ways.

title: Writing Well Is Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Testing the Limits of Tolerance as Cultures Mix; Does Freedom Mean Accepting Rituals That Repel the West?
description: In Maine, a refugee from Afghanistan was seen kissing the penis of his baby boy, a traditional expression of love by this father. To his neighbors and the police, it was child abuse, and his son was taken away. In Seattle, a hospital tried to invent a harmless female circumcision procedure to satisfy conservative Somali parents wanting to keep an African practice alive in their community. The idea got buried in criticism from an outraged public.

title: Maryland Breezes to Victory
description: Few outstanding teams have operated in a deeper shadow than the Maryland Terrapins.

title: It's Simple: Spend Wisely
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Traders Ousted By Credit Suisse
description: The investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston said today that it had dismissed three London-based traders after an internal investigation into recent share trading in Sweden.

title: A Federal Look at Police Conduct
description: The decision by the United States Commission on Civil Rights to hold hearings in New York City on Police Department practices may provide an opportunity to heal the anger and alienation that have surfaced among many New Yorkers after the shooting of Amadou Diallo. For a long time, many minority communities in the city have felt that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the police do not care enough about building relations of trust or hearing their concerns about incidents of police brutality.

title: The Other UConn Shows Up, and Crushes Syracuse
description: Who is Souleymane Wane and why is Khalid El-Amin leaping as high as his shoes can fly to chest-bump what little chest Connecticut's backup center has? And Rashamel Jones, pumping his fist after once more knifing through the lane finishing yet another fast break -- who is he?

title: A Vote to Join CBC Strike
description: As many as 3,000 reporters and producers at the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation voted to join technical workers in what would be the largest strike ever at the state-owned broadcaster, the Canadian Media Guild said today. A two-day national vote showed 85.5 percent of the journalists, news anchors, freelancers and production staff, who are members of the Guild, voted for the action. Last month, 2,000 CBC technical and maintenance workers of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada went on strike demanding more money and better job security.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend yesterday about a film written and directed by P. J. Castellaneta misstated its name. As shown in the list of credits and in the picture caption, the title is ''Relax . . . It's Just Sex,'' not ''Relax . . . It's Only Sex.''

title: American Acquittal, Italian Outrage
description: If there were no other reason to pay attention to the acquittal of Capt. Richard Ashby, the Marine Corps pilot whose plane severed a gondola cable in the Italian Alps and sent 20 people to their deaths, the astonishingly unanimous anti-American reaction in Italy would be quite enough to give Americans and Europeans alike pause for reflection.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE REAL RISES. The real strengthened after the head of Brazil's central bank said it would continue to defend the currency against speculators. In New York, the real settled at 1.99 to the dollar, compared with 2.09 Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Poland Delays Decision On Awarding Bank Stake
description: The Government of Poland said yesterday that it would delay until April announcing the winning bidder for a 55 percent stake in Pekao S.A., the country's biggest bank by assets. The contenders are Citigroup and Unicredito Italiano S.p.A. teamed with Allianz A.G. of Germany.

title: Whistles, Rude Noises: It's the Muse of Spike Jones
description: Explorations of Paul Bowles, the early works of Leonard Bernstein and music of the 1939 World's Fair have shown Jonathan Sheffer and his Eos Orchestra to be both enterprising and serious, and having established that, the musicians let their hair down. In a program called ''Out There,'' at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Thursday evening, Mr. Sheffer offered weirdly humorous works by Ives, Gyorgy Ligeti and David del Tredici, and a sampling of Spike Jones's parodistic zaniness.

title: Drop in '98 Profits Leads to Pay Cuts for Merrill's Top Executives
description: The rising tide of executive pay did not lift all boats on Wall Street last year, with the top bosses at Merrill Lynch & Company taking a pay cut to reflect the firm's profit slump.

title: U.S. Unfairly Tying Imam to Terror Suspect, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for a Muslim clergyman in Arlington, Tex., accused Federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday of slandering his client by unfairly linking him to the suspected terrorist activities of Osama bin Laden.

title: Preserving a Buried Legacy; In Restoring Park, Digging Carefully Into Storied Past
description: A nondescript chain-link fence separates New York City's present from its past. On one side, people hustle to the subway stations and soaring office buildings of lower Manhattan. On the other, archeologists on their knees dig by hand through the historically fertile soil of City Hall Park.

title: Berlin Journal; The Reichstag Burns, This Time With Hope
description: E. Kenedy, an American soldier, was here on May 13, 1945. So, too, a couple of days later, was one Lucia Petrova of the Red Army. Both wrote their names on the walls of the Reichstag just after its capture at the end of World War II, and today their jubilant graffiti are visible once again.

title: Counterfeiters Competing For Golf Equipment Market
description: Within hours after the Taylor Made Golf Company introduced its new $300 Fire Sole driver at the recent Professional Golfers' Merchandise Show here, counterfeiters were hustling their own versions for less than half that price at the same trade show.

title: Spurning Rescue Bid, Judge Orders an H.M.O. to Close
description: A judge here today ordered the final liquidation of the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey by March 31 after rejecting a last-ditch effort by the insurer's New York-based parent company to pull it from the brink.

title: Loosening Up With a Frisky Haydn
description: The pity, as Roger Norrington roamed the peaks and valleys of high Romanticism over the last decade, having packed only a rigidly imagined Classical style of performance in his rucksack, was that behind the perverse musical polemicist lurked an excellent musician. That worthy conductor appeared at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening to lead the Orchestra of St. Luke's in the culminating concert of its seasonlong Haydn Festival.

title: Partial Freedom Is Best for Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: One Moment Stands Frozen Forever
description: Jackson Melian does not like to talk about the night. What should he say? How do you explain coming upon a terrible car accident and discovering that the two people killed in it were your parents?

title: THEATER; A Life That Was Art
description: Because theater is a collaborative art, the loss of a major figure always touches many lives. So with the death of the director Jose Quintero on Feb. 26. One of the founders, with Theodore Mann, of Circle in the Square, the theater that sparked the Off Broadway movement in the 1950's, Mr. Quintero was also revered for his productions of Eugene O'Neill's dramas, in effect reviving the playwright's reputation in his own land. As a director, he was sought after by actors who admired the clarity of his insights and his kindness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- On Language; Soonerathernlater
description: Whenever a President or other world leader uses a phrase in a highly charged situation, it echoes through the language. Sooner rather than later, it loses its referent and becomes a freestanding idiom; people use the familiar phrase out of voguish habit, forgetting the source that initially popularized it.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: The Very Clever Hatter
description: IN 1850, shortly after arriving in New York, Jenny Lind, the Swedish soprano, was given a riding hat by John N. Genin (pronounced JEN-in), a hatter. Unbeknown to Miss Lind, he called it the Jenny Lind Riding Hat and sold it, with much success, in his store at 214 Broadway, near Fulton Street (pictured at left). This stratagem was a forerunner of today's celebrity endorsement. Starting on Tuesday at the New-York Historical Society, an exhibition of Mr. Genin's hats and advertisements, among other memorabilia, will celebrate his marketing genius.

title: Hearty Risotto With Mushrooms and Herbs for a Lucky Few
description: RISOTTO is not a sensible dish for a large dinner party. It cannot be made in advance or left to simmer on the stove while the cook chats with guests. For family or even a couple of friends it is another matter, and I find it particularly appealing in the spring.

title: Legislators Propose Buying of Tract
description: Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele and a Suffolk County Legislator, George O. Guldi, have proposed state and county legislation to purchase the Bridgehampton Race Circuit rather than see it redeveloped as a golf course and housing lots.

title: The Lovelorn Learn to Lash Out
description: WHEN Suzanne Yalof was brusquely informed by her boyfriend that their romance had run its course, she did what lots of jilted women do: She shed copious tears, took to her bed and ate more Oreos than were good for her. When those time-tested remedies failed, she confided in friends.

title: Contributors
description: Photo production by Kira Pollack.

title: Winging It, With Internet Fares
description: TOP the observation deck of the 605-foot-high Space Needle, Douglas Brown pointed out Mount Rainier, the towering snow-capped peak in the distance, to his wide-eyed wife. Next he explained where the distinctive white ferryboats were probably heading as they chugged across Puget Sound. Afterward, he remarked that in this coffee-loving city, it was not unusual to find espresso machines in gas stations.

title: In America; Policing The Police
description: ''The idea,'' said Mary Frances Berry, ''is to do a responsible piece of work.''

title: A Rise in Allergies to Latex Threatens Medical Workers
description: The first signs that Dr. Barbara Zucker-Pinchoff's life was about to come apart were small and seemingly innocuous.

title: Who Is She, Anyway? Is She Her Resume?
description: THERE'S no tune like a show tune to make the world smile, but seekers of wisdom and truth look to the lyrics. For uplifting music and wise words, the score of the milestone musical ''A Chorus Line'' offers two singular samples.

title: PULSE; New Steps To Keep Pace With
description: If the Spice Girls are yesterday's flavor, tomorrow may belong to Steps. A new British music sensation, Steps is a dance-club and Top 40 phenomenon abroad whose first album, ''Step 1,'' has sold more than 2 million copies since its release last year. The group has an Abba-esque sound, and like the Spice Girls, its members have silly nicknames (Smiley, Party, Gadget, Hyperactive, Sensible). But it's not just the pre-chewed bubble gum melodies and Contempo Casual sex appeal that have helped all of Steps' five singles enter the Top 10 in Britain. The group has a gimmick: goofy dance steps. Each single comes with its own ''try this at home'' choreography, and when the songs are played, British clubgoers break into the Macarena-style routines en masse. It might be a good idea to clip and save these instructions for the line dance to the group's first hit, ''5, 6, 7, 8,'' since there are plans for an American arrival this year. ARIEL FOXMAN

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Living Single in Los Angeles; The Fine Art of Going Home Alone
description: Historically, and still, Los Angeles is a gold-rush town, and many of those who arrive in their 20's will fail to gain any purchase there, will simply slide off a surface that is as brilliant and hard as the desert light that cocoons it. But then, of course, there are those who stay, who become the future Eisners and Dillers, the masters of all they survey.

title: Handful of States Still Tax the Very Poor
description: After seven years in which surging revenues have allowed 41 states to cut taxes, 19 states continue to tax the incomes of those below the Federal poverty line, according to a study by a Washington research group. Six of those states, including New Jersey, tax people who have so little money that even if they doubled their incomes, they would still be officially classified as poor.

title: Crime
description: It takes steady nerves to infiltrate a religious cult whose charismatic leader preaches ''the cleansing nature of fire'' -- and whose members live in a wooden compound. That's the volatile situation that Anne Waverly puts herself in, in Laurie R. King's nail-biter thriller A DARKER PLACE (Bantam, $23.95), when the scholarly professor of religion agrees to take on one last undercover job for the F.B.I. Operating in the guise of ''Ana Wakefield,'' a middle-aged schoolteacher on a quest for spiritual enlightenment, Anne insinuates herself into the Arizona chapter of Change, where she eventually learns that the group mantra, ''Great heat, great hope,'' is more than a catchy phrase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBOROFF, HERBERT
description: TOBOROFF-Herbert. A sweet, generous friend, whom we will dearly miss. Doris and Bernard Weiss

title: Getting Ready for Baby With a Helping Hand; Five-Minute Doctor Visits Can Be Replaced With Midwife-Led Support Sessions
description: IT is midmorning on a Thursday and women in their teens and early 20's straggle in, one by one, to a conference room at Waterbury Hospital until there are seven of them, bound together in a common -- and obvious -- sisterhood: They're all pregnant.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: THROWIM WAY LEG

title: Audience That Wasn't
description: To the Editor:

title: OUT OF BOUNDS -- A special report.; Growth in Women's Sports Stirs Harassment Issue
description: Before the public hugs of congratulation after games escalated to private embraces in a school room, Amanda Henderson said, she found it flattering that a veteran high school football coach would take such an uncommon interest in her, a sophomore basketball player.

title: Jellyfish for Dessert Again?
description: THE COLLECTOR OF HEARTS

title: The Real World of Interiors.
description: The twilight struggle between Life and Design surely counts as one of the great long-running stories of the century now ending. This clash of terms has given us battles drenched in both tragedy and farce, on fronts as different as the Iron Curtain and the curtain wall, Soviet collective farms and Corbusian villas, American urban-renewal projects and, if I may add a somewhat less famous skirmish to the list, the redecoration of my parents' apartment in the early 1970's. It was during this episode, which took place when I was 15, that I first understood how easily our dreams of a more perfect order can founder on the shoals of everyday life.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them; More Boomer Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Yes, This Rivalry Gets Personal
description: JIM CALHOUN stood in a corridor of Madison Square Garden last night, holding court after his Connecticut team's 82-63 victory over St. John's for the Big East championship.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- The Ethicist; Stand By Your Handyman
description: 'When Freddy, the handyman in my building, lost his job recently, I felt bad -- not that he was especially handy, but he was friendly and reliable, and I believe he was forced out unjustly.

title: Taking Age in Stride and Putting It to Use
description: DANCE, like youth, may be wasted on the young. That is one of the premises of DanceGalaxy, a new ballet troupe founded by Judith Fugate and Medhi Bahiri, which makes its formal New York debut on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. The dancers, who range in age from their late 20's to their late 30's, are not old by any normal standards. In classical ballet, however, dancers start the approach to obsolescence at age 30. For modern dancers, the age is 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALBERT, WILLIAM F.
description: TALBERT-William F. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on February 28th. in New York. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, BARBARA
description: PFEFFER-Barbara. On March 3, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Rose and Felix Pfeffer. Survived by sister Doris Pfeffer, a circle of loving friends and relatives in Israel, Paris and The United States. Services at ''The Riverside'' on March 7th at 11 A.M.

title: Leopold H. Just, 95, Is Dead; Designer of New York Bridges
description: Leopold H. Just, a Latvian-born sojourner who came to New York to study medicine, took an engineering detour through Brooklyn and ended up building highways and bridges all over the world, died on Feb. 25 at a nursing home in Newport, R.I. He was 95 and as a partner in the Ammann & Whitney firm of consulting engineers had had a hand in designing virtually every major bridge in New York City from the George Washington to the Verrazano.

title: Irish Politics Enters Ring and Knocks Boxing Out
description: Plans for a boxing match between police forces from New York City and the Republic of Ireland to raise money for an injured officer set off an international furor last week, including a vehement letter to Police Commissioner Howard Safir from Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAFMAN, FAY
description: GRAFMAN-Fay. July 10, 1898February 28, 1999. We celebrate your strength of spirit and love of life. You will always be our sunshine. D, M, M, J, P, P, B

title: Once-Neglected Medium Takes On New Life
description: THE title ''Women in Wax'' conjures visions of Madame Tussaud's museum: melodramatically hyper-realistic embodiments of famous queens and notorious murderesses. In sober but more engaging fact, the Cooper Gallery is displaying ''Women in Wax,'' abstract paintings by two young artists who differ in almost everything except their use of the once rare, now fairly common medium of encaustic, in which pigments are mixed with wax and fixed by the application of heat.

title: At Discover Brokerage, An On-Line Strategy
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's Discover Brokerage Direct will be using advertising, rather than buying up Internet rivals, to try to reverse a decline in its share of the on-line brokerage business.

title: Elizabeth Nelowet, Sean Cleary
description: Elizabeth Caroline Nelowet, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nelowet of New York, was married yesterday to Sean Charles Cleary, a son of Margaret L. Cleary of San Mateo, Calif., and Dr. Gary Cleary of Los Altos Hills, Calif. The Rev. Jeremiah P. O'Neill performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Dance Music From England With a Dark Side
description: BIG beat, a boisterous hybrid of hip-hop and house music, is currently the most popular dance style in Britain. The genre's leading artist, Fatboy Slim, just scored a No. 1 single in England with ''Praise You.'' And although big beat has yet to make a breakthrough on the American pop charts, you can already hear it in countless television commercials and movies like ''She's All That.'' Big beat works well in TV ads and Hollywood films because its is good-times music, plain and simple. It's also catchy, sampling hooks and riffs from early rap, disco, raunchy arena rock and 60's frat-party sounds like garage punk and surf music.

title: The First Lady Keeps New York Guessing
description: Will she or won't she? Hillary Rodham Clinton didn't say, but she tantalized New York Democrats in her first visit to the city since announcing that she was giving ''careful thought'' to running next year for the Senate seat to be vacated by Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: Red Flags In a Co-op's Statement
description: THE economics of buying a house are fairly simple: You add up the cost of routine expenses -- mortgage, taxes, insurance, utilities and maintenance -- and then factor in how much it will cost to replace things like the roof or heating system when necessary. Then you take your checkbook, subtract the down payment, add your income and decide whether what's left over will be enough for food, clothing and other necessities, and perhaps even some non-necessities.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- Questions for Lars Eighner; A Roof of One's Own
description: Q: After being homeless for three years, you've spent the last few years in an apartment in Austin, Tex. How has the whole experience changed your idea of what home is?

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: SLACKJAW

title: Willy Loman on Ritalin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Lidz, Stephen Dreskin
description: Judith Ellen Lidz and Stephen Bruce Dreskin are to be married today at the Maplewood (N.J.) Country Club. Rabbi Daniel M. Cohen is to officiate.

title: Unforeseen, Strife Eases For Algeria
description: As the afternoon call to prayers rang through the cobbled alleyways of the Casbah, Mouloud Takdjout settled into a comfortable niche in the old city wall and watched fellow Muslims hurry past.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts & Leisure section today about the significance of the Academy Awards misstates the occasion on which Cher wore a ''bird headdress'' to the Oscar ceremony. It was in 1986, not when she won the award as best actress for the film ''Moonstruck'' two years later.

title: Stage Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Brian Moore's Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight of the (Next) Century; Converging Technologies Put Sony and Microsoft on a Collision Course
description: A BATTLE for control of the future of computing is looming between the personal computer industry and consumer electronics manufacturers.

title: New Skirmish in Motel War
description: Although construction of a two-story 42-room motel is well under way in this neighborhood, a group of residents who oppose the project has not stopped fighting it.

title: Keep Moving on the Hudson River Park
description: Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani have finally made their appointments to the new Hudson River Park Trust, eight months after the State Legislature gave the park its approval. Officials said it was not easy to find good people to serve in what is expected to be an arduous non-paying job. Whatever the reason for the delay, it is imperative that the board move swiftly to confront issues that have been left unattended.

title: Promoted, But Hardly To Cloud 9
description: Life, like footballs, takes some funny bounces. Sometimes the promises of promotion and big titles hide a reality that proves disappointing. And sometimes disappointment turns out to be the key to the door to advancement.

title: Preserving Medicare's Roots
description: WHEN Thomas C. Matzzie graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1997 with a degree in economics, he decided not to follow many of his classmates into high-paying careers on Wall Street or elsewhere. Instead, he took a lower-paying job, as a policy analyst at the Institute for America's Future, a liberal research organization in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLATT, MORRIS
description: KORNBLATT-Morris, 74. On February 28, 1999. Widower of Irene. Father of Miriam and Joshua. Retired as a Vice President of Maidenform. We fondly remember Murray's sense of humor, enjoyment of theater and fine dining, enthusiasm for the NY Giants and tennis. Contributions may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

title: Black Unlike Me
description: Who allowed this race-obsessed woman to adopt a child of color in the first place? Or any child for that matter? If she can't get past how black he is, how can she ever know him? And how can he learn to think of himself as a person first, a black person second?

title: After Getting Drubbed, the Red Storm Tries to Look Ahead
description: Perhaps Ron Artest should thank Connecticut's Khalid El-Amin for trying to cover his eyes while defending him in the first half of last night's Big East Tournament championship game.

title: Deal Is Finally Worked Out For Orioles-Cuba Exhibition
description: After two days of meetings bogged down in questions of wording, the Baltimore Orioles are set to play the Cuban national team in Havana on March 28. A second game in Baltimore remains a possibility.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistols at 20 Paces
description: PUSHKIN'S BUTTONBy Serena Vitale.Translated by Ann Goldstein and Jon Rothschild.355 pp. New York:Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: Bridgemarket Emerging, After 22 Years
description: SLOW down, you move too fast,'' Simon and Garfunkel counseled in their ''59th Street Bridge Song'' of 1966. That may have been the last time anyone thought anything was moving fast around the Queensboro Bridge. Until now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SYLVIA LAURA (NEE RUBIN)
description: SCHWARTZ-Sylvia Laura (nee Rubin). 79 years. Of Lauderhill, Fl. Formerly of Oceanside, NY. Died March 3, 1999. Beloved mother of Ronnie, Donald (and Helen). Cherished grandmother of Corey. Loving sister of Jeanette Gray, Gloria Ottenstein and Jerome Rubin. Services Sunday 10am at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Longbeach Rd, Rockville, Ctr, LI. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99; Strategies: Clutter
description: ''As you come in, on the left there's a lot of 60's fiction. Then the next is European literature. On the right is unread fiction, some recent plays, some contemporary plays. That gets you into the alleyway in the main room. There are two shelves with books about art. On the far shelves is modern literature, with British and French on the right and American on the left. But one section -- books that I'm in -- got out of hand and destroyed earlier arrangements. And new books come in all the time. It's always clear where to put them. But it's not clear, afterward, where to find them.''

title: H-P 12C, the Calculator That Lives Forever
description: Hewlett-Packard's plans for splitting in two, announced last week, shook up Silicon Valley, home of the iconic garage where the company started. But no less unsettled were legions of Wall Street M.B.A.'s who were left wondering how the spinoff would affect their beloved H-P 12C's.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: I wouldn't train a dog the way John Rosemond advocates rearing children (Susan Bolotin, Feb. 14). Unless, of course, my goal were to have the dog avoid me as Rosemond avoids his own mother.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: . . . As Foster Families Get a Big Raise
description: Last week, families that care for foster children in New Jersey received their first substantial raise in two decades. The increases, of about 33 percent, will be reflected in checks received in April. They range from $98 to $126 a child, depending on age, about 33 percent, making the totals $400 to $500 a month a child. There are about 6,500 foster children in the state, cared for by about 2,600 families.

title: Carnaval
description: To the Editor: I read the International Datebook in the Jan. 17 issue. It mentions that on Feb. 20 and 21, 27 and 28, March 6 and 7, in Gualeguaychu (Entre Rios), Argentina, there are ''Carnivalesque street parties, for no particular reason.'' I found the qualification slightly insulting and certainly erroneous. There is a reason: it is Carnaval. In Argentina, we celebrate carnaval for a few weekends after the four days of Mardi Gras, or carnaval.

title: Where Was a Rebuttal Of Psychics' Claims?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MY . . . SATCHEL: JACQUES BLONDEAU
description: He may be a top figure in the supposedly stuffy world of insurance, but Jacques Blondeau never goes anywhere without his Bugs Bunny key chain. ''I've always been a great fan of American cartoons,'' said Mr. Blondeau, chief executive of the SCOR Group, a big commercial insurance company based in Paris.

title: Giving Jerseyana A Voice
description: WHEN Nick Clemente of Oldbridge heard that Weird New Jersey magazine was seeking original songs for a CD about the state's folklore, he knew exactly what to write about: the grave of Mary Ellis. From a raised plot of land in New Brunswick surrounded by concrete walls, she has kept a lonely watch over the Raritan River since 1828.

title: Complaint Department: Consumers Are Covered
description: WHEN Dorothy Green of Bridgeport totalled her car in 1996, she decided not to replace it. She notified her insurance company but the company continued to automatically deduct car insurance premiums from her paycheck -- for more than 18 months.

title: The World: Anticipating the Unpredictable; The Dicey Game of Travel Risk
description: EIGHT tourists, including an American couple, are slashed to death deep in the Ugandan jungle, apparently by Hutu militiamen targeting Britons and Americans. They were there last week in the hope of trekking up a slope full of biting insects and stinging nettles to spend a brief hour in the company of mountain gorillas.

title: Whitman and State Police: One Answer, Many Questions
description: The political self-immolation of the State Police Superintendent, Col. Carl A. Williams, was an embarrassing moment for New Jersey race relations and law enforcement. But it also offers Governor Whitman an opportunity to seize the initiative on the charges that troopers discriminate against minorities.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Living Large in Poland; New Money is Inflating Suburban Homes . . . Into Full-fledged Mansions
description: The splendid mansions of Konstancin, a residential neighborhood a half-hour's drive from the center of Warsaw, were once home to Poland's nobility, leading intellectuals and commercial families. But after the war, the Communists seized the properties and subdivided them into apartments; the scions of Polish society suddenly found themselves sharing living space with working-class families. The grand homes rapidly fell into disrepair -- only to be rescued, years later, by nouveau-riche money from the post-Communist generation. Today you can stroll the broad, tree-lined streets of Konstancin and see the neighborhood's turbulent history: recently restored mansions with curled porticoes and columns alternate with decrepit mansions with peeling paint and drooping balconies.

title: Port Authority Sale
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has announced the $9 million sale of its remaining 20-acre property at the Yonkers Industrial Park to Hudson View Associates, a private company in Greenwich. The sale represents the public agency's continuing ''movement back to its core mission of transportation,'' the Port Authority said.

title: Bingo Night for Barbara Walters? Not Here
description: THE SETTING -- The cavernous Third Avenue Bingo parlor on 72d Street, where nearly 100 dedicated players, mostly women, gathered on Wednesday night for their game, ignoring Barbara Walters's televised interview with the First Intern.

title: Ready, Set, Renovate
description: It takes more than hammers and nails to turn a boarded-up city building into a home or office. It also takes a knowledge of the rules and a familiarity with programs that can provide aid. The state Department of Community Affairs has published a brochure called the Urban Tool Kit aimed at individuals, community groups or city officials considering urban renewal projects. For example, the brochure points out that last year New Jersey instituted what it says is the first building code in the country written just for older structures gives a phone number for more information. The brochure also includes information on getting low-interest mortgages or seed money, on tapping loans for demolishing dangerous buildings, and on programs for revitalizing downtowns and for returning vacant property to productive use. The overall idea is to encourage local people, rather than the state, to take the initiative in renewal. The Urban Tool Kit will be sent free to those who write to the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, Office of Commmunications and Policy, 101 South Broad Street, Post Office Box 800, Trenton, N.J. 08625-0800, or call (609) 292-6055.

title: Do Aliens or Humans Inspire More Fear?
description: CAMI GORDON, a children's book author who lives in Pacific Palisades, Calif., is a member of Mothers for Natural Law, an organization that recently published a book on what it believes are the dangers of unrestrained genetic science. Since her husband, Howard Gordon, is a prominent television writer, she asked him to contribute a blurb for its back cover. ''Scarier than anything on 'The X-Files'!'' wrote Mr. Gordon, a former producer of that Fox hit, encapsulating in one stroke the tone and purpose of ''Strange World,'' his latest network project.

title: A Deal to Save Privately Owned Redwoods
description: In a $480 million deal officials called as historically significant as the creation of Yosemite National Park, the Federal and California governments have bought 10,000 acres of ancient redwoods from the Pacific Lumber Company, including the largest privately owned stand of ancient redwoods in the world.

title: Free House Makes Case To Supplant Skip Away
description: The shuffling to replace the retired Skip Away as the top older horse in the United States continued today as Free House captured the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap, outdueling Event of the Year and his longtime rival Silver Charm.

title: For the Homeless, Rebirth Through Socrates
description: The students, mostly in sweat shirts and jeans, sit around a long table dotted with soda cans and cookies and consult their highlighted copies of Plato's ''Apology.'' Two professors guide their debate over whether Socrates, on the verge of execution, was arrogant or humble. Outside, the sun sets on the neogothic campus.

title: Looking Past A Single Pilot
description: Capt. Richard J. Ashby alone, and not the Marine Corps, was on trial in the court-martial that ended on Thursday with his acquittal on charges of involuntary homicide and manslaughter for flying his Prowler jet into gondola cables in the Italian Alps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, DOROTHY E.
description: CURRAN-Dorothy E. Formerly of Elmhurst, Queens. Age 91. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Elmhurst. Burial to follow in Calvary Cemetery. Contributions to the Residential Recreation Fund, Hancock Hall, 31 Staples St., Danbury, CT 06810.

title: Phillip Rhodes and Tracy Smith
description: Tracy Elizabeth Smith was married yesterday to Henry Phillip Rhodes at the First Reformed Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen performed the ceremony.

title: Dark Horse in a Bow Tie
description: P.S.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Country Living in India; A Farmhouse Isn't Always a Red Barn Affair.
description: The wind rustled through the Neem trees and the winter sunlight slanted into the courtyard, warming the backs of Lakhpat Singh, his son and his grandsons as they waited for lunch. The men sat in metal lawn chairs, trying to talk over the caws of bickering crows; the boys hunched nearby over a beeping electronic game. Inside, the women of the family squatted in the kitchen, rolling out dough for chapatis. They slapped the flat circles into a pan, then lifted them with tongs directly onto a burner on the floor, where they puffed into fragrant balloons of bread.

title: Location, Location; 'The Sopranos' Tunes In to a New Jersey Nobody Knows (Except for the Millions Who Call It Home)
description: SOMETHING unforeseen happened in January when a new television series became a hit: New Jersey became a star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINOKUR, BEATRICE S. (NEE ROSENHAUS)
description: WINOKUR - Beatrice S. (nee Rosenhaus). Wife of Harry Winokur, deceased. Born September 13, 1910, New York City. Died March 3, 1999, North Miami Beach, FL of emphysema and the smoking of 438,000 cigarettes, a conservative estimate. Executive Secretary in the Purchasing Department of Israel Zion Hospital (now called Maimonides) and Moore Electronics. She graduated from Washington Irving High School and was a recipient of the a medal from the Art School League of New York City in 1925. She is survived by her son Robert of Horsham, PA., her daughter Arline Borenkind of Greenwich, CT., and her grandchildren Lawrence & Robin Mincow and Stephan and Michael Winokur. She was a member of the Triangle Association of the Knickerbocker Lodge of the Knights of Pythias and the sponsor of Women's American ORT and the North Dade Children's Center. A loving mother and doting grandmother, a delightful and caring friend to so many people. Graveside service will take place on Monday, March 8th, at 1 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. Donations in her memory may be made to Women's American ORT or North Dade Children's Center, 16975 N.E. 35 Avenue, N. Miami Beach, FL. 33160.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, ADA (NEE HERMAN)
description: COLEMAN-Ada (nee Herman). Died on March 4th, 1999. Wife of the late Milton. Adored and cherished mother of Pat Philips-Stratta (Ettore), Jeffrey (Carole), and Richard (Karen). Beloved grandmother of Brad, Evan and Jason. Sister of Louis (Rosalie) & Morton (Arlene). Special friend to many. Past president of B'nai Brith. Pioneer of Anti-Defamation League. A beautiful lady who will be forever dearly missed.

title: Many Students Are Using School Vouchers Financed by Private Donations
description: Even as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew battle over the Mayor's proposal for a publicly financed school voucher program, thousands of New York City schoolchildren are already taking part in similar programs run with private donations.

title: 'La Grosse Pomme'
description: There's a whole lot of French going on in the city and, for anyone trying to keep track of it all, there is a Web site: New York City Francophone. An exhaustive electronic clearinghouse of things French in the five boroughs, the site invites you to ''cliquez-vous'' around an array of French-language activities in ''La Grosse Pomme.''

title: At Celebration, Some Reasons to Celebrate
description: DIANE KUPCHAK was tired of South Florida. It had grown too fast. She didn't know her neighbors. She wanted to live somewhere like Rutherford, N.J., her hometown, which she remembered as a place where neighbors were family.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, BENJAMIN
description: SEVIN-Benjamin. 4/30/15-3/6/69. Yesterday you left us. You inspired us with honesty & love. Geraldine, Ilisa, Susan & Set

title: Foreign Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: PULSE; Annie, Get Your Gear
description: While Prada and Helmut Lang are selling sleek, futuristic fanny packs, some downtown designers are taking a more fashion-backward approach to the utility craze: tool belts. ''I call it my 'Planet of the Apes' look,'' said Troy Smith, who makes a studded suede version with a cellular phone clip for $125 at Patricia Field (10 East Eighth Street). ''Basically, I took a hardware-store tool belt and streamlined it.'' Amy Chan made a tool belt for a friend who is a makeup artist, and now sells a fitted leather model for $230 at her boutique at 247 Mulberry Street (Prince Street). ''I wanted a piece that you could really put your tools in, but that was ultra-luxe,'' she said. But since these handy holsters are meant to go flat on the hips, any tools bulkier than a compact could create unsightly bulges. ''I don't want to look like I have a growth around my middle,'' said Maria Farrow, a Costume National saleswoman, who has a Troy Smith belt in hot pink. ''I've pared down what I carry to the essentials -- lip liner, note pad and pencil, bank card and cell phone.'' NANCY McDONNELL SMITH

title: Cardozo-Kennedy Final Set
description: Benjamin Cardozo High School of Queens advanced to the Public Schools Athletic League's Class A championship game with a convincing 62-54 defeat of Lincoln High School of Brooklyn last night at St. John's Alumni Hall.

title: Seeing a Forest to Save the Trees
description: WHILE environmentalists were chained to thousand-year-old redwood trees in the Headwaters forest of northern California, Thomas S. Reid was chained to his computer. He was putting those same trees, along with seabird nesting areas and salmon streams, into a simulation that proved essential to protecting the forest, the largest privately owned grove of ancient redwoods.

title: Dining Out, Not Just for the Food, in Washington
description: OVERHEARD in a New York restaurant: ''Do you think the chef will tell us where he gets his quail?''

title: Steven the Good
description: If I had any advice for Steven Spielberg, it would be to drop the hopeful endings and last-minute rescues and make a dark western or a musical.

title: The Nation; Reactors: Healthy but Dying
description: TWENTY years after the meltdown at Three Mile Island, the nuclear industry has succeeded in ways that were hard to imagine in March of 1979 as Pennsylvania cowered in fear, plants around the country lost their luster and scores of half-built reactors were abandoned. The industry is doing better now, but ironically extinction is in sight.

title: What's a Preposition? Just Ask a Dancer
description: How does dance or a visit to a museum help youngsters learn math? Such an approach makes perfect sense to Dr. David Meoli, who runs Port Washington's arts-in-education program.

title: Jane Long and Craig Gering
description: A MOTION picture agent at the William Morris Agency in New York, Craig Stephen Gering, 29, is the sort of overly organized person who always keeps Kleenex in his pocket, folded in perfect quadrants. His desk at work, colleagues say, is covered with notes that are so meticulously organized and stacked they look like origami.

title: Beautiful Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Is That Paranormal?
description: INCUBUS

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Making the Most of It in Brazil; Creating a Home . . . On the Margins
description: To climb the hillside slums, or favelas, rising between the Copacabana and Ipanema districts of Rio de Janeiro is to journey back through time, from the modern era to the preindustrial age. At the bottom stand spacious homes, with running water, electricity and glossy ceramic tiles. At the top of the hill is a neighborhood known as Vietnam. Dangerous as a war zone, it is a place where drug traffickers wage frequent gun battles for control of the lucrative markets below. In Vietnam, homes are made of mud and sticks, and light comes from candles, the moon and the stars.

title: INSIDE
description: Last Khmer Rouge Arrest

title: Cat People, and Their Owners
description: ''Not that we're coming home with a cat,'' said my wife, Kathy. ''But I've just had a brilliant idea of where to put the Kitty Litter.''

title: West Virginia Pares Welfare, but Poor Remain
description: They cannot fit many more people into the St. John's Episcopal Church auditorium, where free breakfast and lunch are available daily to the needy. In recent weeks, volunteers have set up tables on the stage to accommodate crowds now reaching 250 a meal.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: The danger in what Rosemond advocates is that some of what he says seems to make sense. It seems to make sense, but when do you teach children the skills of negotiation, of compromise, of getting along? Rosemond teaches that if you have power, you are free to use it. What a lesson to give to your children.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99; Stop the Clock
description: A new home every year: three decades in the life of John Corbett, graphic designer and ex-army brat.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANKEN, HAROLD IRA
description: PANKEN-Harold Ira. State Senator, trial lawyer. Beloved husband for 65 years of Sylvia. Father of Peter, Bruce and Jeffry. Father-inlaw of Beverly and Carol. Grandfather of Aaron, Melinda, Leah, Johanna and Matthew. Greatgrandfather of Eli, Max and Samantha. You have always been a presence in the lives of your family. The family will be at Peter's home on Sunday afternoon and evening and Monday evening.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reviewers Should Visit State's Art Galleries
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheik Isa, 65, Emir of Bahrain Who Built Non-Oil Economy
description: The Emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who collapsed and died today at 65, shaped his country into an important ally of the West during nearly four decades in power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVIOR, SHIRLEY (NEE MILLER)
description: CAVIOR-Shirley (nee Miller) on January 30 in Boston, MA. Age 96. Beloved wife of the late Joel H. Cavior. Much loved mother of Warren J. (Mariko) Cavior, Jay M. Cavior and Dr. Stephen R. Cavior. Grandmother of Mayu and Sam. She personified in a long life the old-time Yankee values of her childhood years in Portsmouth, NH. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, 141 Cambridge Street, Boston, MA 02114.

title: Sports of The Times; At 17, Taking Her Chances on Maturity
description: DOMINIQUE MOCEANU hears people talking: ''The girl is fat. She's out of shape. She'll never make it back.''

title: In the Region / New Jersey; As Caldor Fades, Retail Market Is Unfazed
description: WHEN Caldor, the discount-store chain, announced in January that it was closing its 145 stores, including 28 in New Jersey, William A. Farber was struck by a sense of deja vu.

title: A Plan to Turn Some Parking Lots Into Parks, and More
description: For six decades, an undeveloped swath of a little more than two blocks has divided downtown and brownstone Brooklyn. Now a community task force wants to see that space filled with buildings that would create an architectural buffer zone between the two areas.

title: An Allegory Unfolds, Just as It Did in Another Era
description: IT is understandable that ''John Bunyan'' is sometimes misspoken as ''Paul Bunyan'' in discussions of ''The Grand Moving Panorama of 'Pilgrim's Progress,' '' now at the Montclair Art Museum. The art in the exhibition is, in a word, gigantic.

title: Willy Loman on Ritalin?

title: In Development Battle, a Familiar War of Familiar Words
description: As a deadline edged nearer for the city to respond to the state's offer to take the lead in rehabilitating Asbury Park's oceanfront, a citizens' group picketed the City Council last week to protest the Council's refusal to consider the state proposal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRESHAN, ALLAN
description: TRESHAN-Allan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Allan Treshan, associated with The Times from 1949 until retiring in 1978.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 7 about a master's degree program in writing at Long Island University's Southampton College included one writer incorrectly among the guest lecturers. Kurt Vonnegut has not lectured for the program.

title: Bradley and Gore Compete For Donors in New Jersey
description: In the contest for votes in next year's New Jersey Presidential primary, even Vice President Al Gore's supporters agree that former Senator Bill Bradley is likely to win his home state going away.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNLIGHT, PEARL DONN
description: STERNLIGHT-Pearl Donn. Died Thursday March 4 at age 97. Widow of Morris H., she is fondly and appreciatively remembered by her children Mary Joan and Peter, her grandchildren Chris, Eric, Jean and Judy and great-grandchildren Ashleigh and Joanna. Dance and yoga teacher, artist, draftsman and 25 year school volunteer.

title: Stocks Roar In Like a March Lion
description: Hesitant investors awaiting a glimmer of good news in the battered computer sector or an excuse for the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates alone found both late last week, and responded by slamming their hands down on the ''buy'' button.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
description: The Microsoft Corporation moved to defuse a potentially explosive privacy issue today, saying it would modify a feature of its Windows 98 operating system that has been quietly used to create a vast data base of personal information about computer users.

title: Wandering With Takemitsu In His Gardens of the Mind
description: THE Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu, who died three years ago, often likened his pieces to gardens: specifically Japanese gardens, made to be admired at a strolling pace, with frequent stops to enjoy, perhaps, the foliage of a tree, or a flower, or a spider's web, or a distant view. Certainly, the analogy fits almost everything he wrote, whatever the style (and there were many), but his music's customary slow andante may have come from a deeper inkling into how we listen.

title: E-Z Passes
description: To the Editor: About the Practical Traveler, ''Electronic Tolls Pick Up Speed'' (Feb. 14). Betsy Wade's observation that ''electronic systems are demonstrably faster'' was emphasized to me two years ago when our second car was taken in for repairs. On the next E-Z Pass statement, a series of quick trips back and forth over the Throgs Neck Bridge were charged -- a total of $210! Seventy trips!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAGAN, CLAIRE
description: RAGAN-Claire. Passed away peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 5, 1999, some months after being diagnosed with ALS. Beloved wife of David. Loving mother of David Nathaniel Ragan, Sarah Sills Ragan, and Jennifer Leigh Brower. Devoted mother-inlaw of Dr. Larry K. Shore and Richard A. Brower, Jr. Proud grandmother of Madeline Claire Shore. Cherished sister of Sara Sills Harris. Former primarygrade teacher at the Dalton and Everett Schools, teacher of adult education courses at Hunter College, textbook editor at Random House, and chief fund developer for Jobs for Youth. Time and date of a private memorial service will be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Audubon Society National or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: Untangling Gridlock On the Union Pacific
description: FOR Troy Slinkard, the worst days of the Union Pacific Railroad's service crisis came in late 1997. About a year after the U.P. had merged with the Southern Pacific, the two railroads' combined train traffic was choking to a standstill in the crucial nest of tracks around and through Houston, the heart of the region that Mr. Slinkard helped direct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, EVELYN GILSON
description: BLAUNER-Evelyn Gilson. At home on March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Blauner. Mother of Marylin and Arthur Levitt Jr. and S. Richard Blauner. Grandmother of Lauri Friedland, Arthur Levitt III, Steven, Peter, Andrew, Patrick and Christopher Blauner. Great grandmother of Matthew, Sarah, Mac, William, Gabrielle, Mose and Sydney Rose. Funeral private.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Jewish Film Festival

title: Florio, the Once and Possibly Future Candidate, Says He's a New Man
description: Jim Florio is talking a lot these days about how much he has changed.

title: The Nation: Hard Time; Less Crime, More Criminals
description: LATER this month, the Government will release new figures showing how many Americans are behind bars, and the numbers will reveal that the bull market for prisons is still charging ahead. Nearly 1 of every 150 people in this country is in prison or jail, the Justice Department will announce, a figure no other democracy comes close to matching.

title: A Household Overflowing With Animals
description: IT did not take long to realize Jan Veilleux runs an unusual household; her kangaroos, Joey and Chester, greeted visitors at the front door of her yellow ranch in the Terryville section of Plymouth.

title: A Word That Could Get Too Cool for Comfort
description: WE here at Citizens for the Preservation of Linguistic Dignity are reluctant to raise a ruckus, but we feel compelled to express concern about recent goings-on in Atlantic City.

title: Voters to Decide Overhaul Of Los Angeles Government
description: To a Midwesterner, whose idea of big city governance is the Daley dynasty of Chicago, or to a New Yorker, steeped in the strong-mayor legacy of a La Guardia, Koch or Giuliani, the government of Los Angeles can sometimes seem as quaint and collective as a Quaker meeting. Here, the Mayor can't even fire his own department heads, much less make them cry.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Living Large in Texas; New Money is Inflating Suburban Homes . . . Into Full-fledged Mansions
description: Ten years ago, Mark Greenberg and Robin Muhlfeld bought a house on the north side of Austin, Tex. They had one child, and another, and another, and before long, their small house, with its spectacular view over the Texas hill country, suddenly seemed as crowded and uncomfortable as a box of Easter chicks. ''We kept on having children, and we desperately needed a bigger house, but we didn't want to give up the view,'' says Robin, who owns and operates a women's and children's clothing store in suburban Westlake. ''And we wanted a yard for the children. But everything either had the yard or the view, and we thought we'd have to give up one for the other. Our only option was to build, but where?''

title: Isles Waste 3-Goal Lead As Flyers Rally for Tie
description: Eric Lindros, the Flyers' hulking center, watched like a predator as the Islanders' defense weakened in the game's final minutes. And when the time was right, Lindros saw his chance and seized it.

title: Getting in Touch With Congress
description: Have a problem, or an opinion? Here's how to let somebody know in Washington.

title: BOXING: Still Floating, Still Building; Ali and His Wife Planning a Center to Celebrate His Life
description: An ornately dressed woman who had changed her name to Nana Yaa Asantewa rushed across the lobby of Central High School and flung herself at a large man who had changed his name to Muhammad Ali.

title: Alexander Cooper, Nicole Jacoby
description: Nicole Anne Jacoby and Alexander Matthew Cooper were married last evening in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Dr. Franklin S. Cooper, 90, Researcher in Speech
description: Dr. Franklin Seaney Cooper, a pioneer in speech research whose work was later applied to computerized speech synthesis, died on Feb. 20 in Palo Alto, Calif., where he lived. He was 90 years old.

title: Oppenheimer's Definition Of Princeton Institute
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN; From Motions to Movies
description: For several weeks last fall, the staid midtown law offices of Walter Foote & Associates were transformed into a mini-movie studio. Scruffy people with clipboards ran about, and the conference room became a wardrobe room, its bookshelves obscured by racks of clothing.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Feb. 21 about smoke alarms in New York City apartments misstated the scope of a landlord's responsibility. While a landlord is required to install the alarms, it is the tenant's responsibility, not the landlord's, to maintain them.

title: Give Vouchers a Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Not a Model Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Growth Wins Overseas, Too
description: Since 1994, United States growth funds have trounced their value-oriented brethren in performance. But it seems that foreign funds, which aren't usually divided by their growth or value orientation, have experienced a similar phenomenon.

title: POSTINGS: A Conversion to 46 Loft Condominiums in TriBeCa; Reweaving the Textile Building
description: For most of the century the Textile Building, a 12-story neo-Renaissance building at 66 Leonard Street at the southeast corner of Church Street in the TriBeCa East Historic District, housed offices and showrooms of textile concerns. Now it is being converted into a 46-unit loft condominium.

title: Those Vanishing References
description: To the Editor:

title: Domestic Partner Coverage Is Fair and Inexpensive
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Imitating Life' Plays at the Fleetwood Stage
description: ''IMITATING LIFE'' at the Fleetwood Stage is about one man's struggle to write a play. It is also an object lesson in how not to.

title: Backtalk; It's High Time for a Fair Shot
description: The N.B.A.'s second chance has begun. Not the second chance for the Bulls, the Pacers and the like with their truncated season and nail-biting anxiety over fan loyalty. The moment has arrived for the N.B.A. to take a second look and pump up its less indulged offspring. For the N.B.A., an unprecedented opportunity now exists to use its power and money to give women's professional basketball the visibility and respect it has always deserved.

title: Ms. Silverman, Mr. Goodman
description: Elizabeth Fisher Silverman, the daughter of Linda and Richard Silverman of Providence, R.I., was married last evening to Jonathan Joseph Goodman, the son of Phebe and Louis Goodman of Newtonville, Mass. Rabbi Michael Cahana officiated at the Harvard Club in Boston.

title: Reading, Writing and Rat-Tat-Tat: Noise in School
description: Last year, when students in Caryn Siegel's fourth-grade class stood in front of the room to give a presentation, she would tell them to shout.

title: That Mad Movie Season Called Oscar; Awards Abound, but The Academy Rules
description: WITH only two weeks to go until the Oscars, my local movie theater is running a promotional spot for this year's Academy Awards show. There they are, all the memories -- James Cameron crowing, David Niven fielding the streaker, Cher winning for ''Moonstruck'' in the bird headdress -- in a pitch meant to trumpet Oscar's glory. ''It's the night that brings the whole world together and sets Hollywood apart!'' the ad exclaims. Since when do we need reminding?

title: Sensitive Water Area Is Site of Development
description: THE Oyster Bay supervisor says it's an eyesore, the gaping sand pit dug into a 65-acre parcel of town-owned land in Plainview. But the pit is at the center of a zone in which vast volumes of water seep downward to replenish the underground aquifers that provide Long Islanders with their drinking water.

title: Garbage Transfer Stations Face Civil Rights Inquiry
description: The Federal Government will conduct a broad civil rights investigation into a Bronx Congressman's allegations that the concentration of dozens of garbage transfer stations in the South Bronx discriminates against minority residents, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Black Unlike Me
description: Why, in reading Jana Wolff's Lives column (Feb. 14), did I have visions of a young slave allowed to live in the main house with the masters? Maybe it's because Wolff's version of parenting is to instill in her son, Ari, a daily reminder that he is different and may not ''measure up.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Penny Greene,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, FRANK D.
description: LYONS-Frank D. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank D. Lyons, associated with The Times since 1967 until retiring in 1990.

title: Luxury Homes
description: A record 305 properties sold for more than $1 million each in 1998, 54 percent more than in 1997. And seven homes sold for more than $4 million, Houlihan/Lawrence, the area's largest real estate company, and the Westchester/Putnam County Board of Realtors reported.

title: A Museum Fitted Out With Finnish Flair
description: THROUGHOUT the galleries at Kiasma, the new Museum of Contemporary Art here, a ubiquitous black chair stands like a silent fixture that could even be mistaken for sculpture. In the cafe just off the street is another chair, one of translucent green fiberglass that appears to float above the floor.

title: Those Who Retire to Work or Volunteer
description: EVERY morning, Abraham Landau commutes from White Plains on the 8:26 train to his job as sales manager for Performing Arts magazine in the Graybar Building over Grand Central Terminal. His days are so busy, he sometimes has to rush to make the 4:47 home.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Feb. 21 with a News and Topics article about legislative efforts to lower the speed limit for buses and trucks was published in error. It showed Joseph T. Vitale, an executive vice president of St. Clare's Health Services of Denville, not state Senator Joseph F. Vitale, Democrat of Woodbridge.

title: Move Toward Adoptions
description: A 2-year-old Mount Vernon girl has been in foster care since she was 1 month old; so has her 1-year-old brother. Despite that the children's mother has a history of alcohol and drug abuse and emotional problems and previously lost her parental rights to two older children, child welfare up to now has had no authority to put the two younger children up for adoption.

title: Tick, Tick, Tick
description: APOCALYPSE PRETTY SOON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARZMAN, ADELE (NEE BELLER)
description: SWARZMAN-Adele (nee Beller). Passed away peacefully at home on March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving A. Swarzman, devoted mother of Phyllis and Harold Stock, Martin and Jan Swarzman, dearly loved ''Gram Adele'' to Sharon, Robert and Catarina, Steven, Howard and Michelle, and Laura. ''Great Gram Adele'' to Isaac, Elliot, Samantha and Danielle. Past president of Sisterhood, Temple Shaare Torah. Generous, always a lady, in speech and in demeanor. Service Sunday, March 7, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: Michael Higgins, an Innovator In Glass Design, Is Dead at 90
description: Michael Higgins, a pioneer designer of glass, died at his home in Riverside, Ill., on Feb. 13. He was 90.

title: Food; Curious Yellow
description: Like primary colors when they're mixed with one another, primary taste sensations can produce flavors that resemble none of the originals. Consider that yellow and blue equal green. Or that lemon juice and salt, the main ingredients for preserved lemons, add up to a warm, pickled flavor that has more power than its individual parts.

title: It's @786. Do You Know Where Your Computer Is?
description: WHEN Gustavo Carreno received an E-mail message at his Lisbon office last week asking for an appointment to talk about universal time, an old concept recently repackaged by the Swatch Group, the world's largest watch maker, he sent the following response:

title: The World: The C.I.A. and Guatemala; The Spies Who Never Came In From the Cold War
description: WHEN a Guatemalan truth commission implicated the United States last month in the creation of a killing machine that ravaged entire Mayan villages in the 1980's, it raised questions that are not likely to go away soon -- certainly not by the time President Clinton visits Guatemala this week:

title: In Praise of Women: A Month of Celebrations
description: March is the 13th annual Women's History Month. Here are some opportunities to join in New Jersey's observance.

title: The TV Is On, but the Show Is in the Living Room
description: IT was supposed to have been a birthday party for a fashion designer turned theatrical producer at the home of a respected Broadway choreographer. But it was the night of the Grammy Awards, so the TV was on, the sound was off and, between the pasta pomodoro and the pound cake, the well-wishers watched. Sort of. As a group, they were as vocal as the set was mute. Every time Rosie O'Donnell appeared on screen, they put down their plates, raised their wine glasses and launched into a full-throated group sing of ''When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain.''

title: ART / ARCHITECTURE; As a Life Preserver, Popularity May Not Be Enough
description: LOOMING up over the harbor, just across from the city center in the Oosterdok neighborhood, is a fantastic apparition, a wedge-shaped structure clad in green copper that could be mistaken for a giant mystery ship. Although harking back to the city's fabled seafaring past, the building is actually very much of the future: the NewMetropolis Science and Technology Center, designed by the versatile Italian architect Renzo Piano.

title: Give Vouchers a Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Recreation Areas Are Emerging From Decay Along City's Waterfront
description: Over the years, hundreds of miles of New York City's once industrial waterfront have declined to ruins -- burned-out yacht clubs, decayed piers and abandoned cement plants. Now, more and more of these narrow strips along the water are being turned into places for recreation.

title: The Psychology of Slaughter
description: Five years ago, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana lived in the Rwandan village of Mugonero, in Kibuye Province, where he was the chief pastor of the Seventh-day Adventist church. Now, he is locked away in a jail cell in Laredo, Tex.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Emptying Out in California; Making a Home a House
description: These pictures show the interiors of foreclosed properties, houses whose inhabitants have been evicted for failing to keep up with their mortgage payments. They are all in Southern California, which has been booming for nearly a century now. We are currently enjoying a time of prosperity, which may sometimes seem hard to believe as we observe continuing industrial layoffs and plant closings, but then we can also observe the regular transformation of exurban cornfields into tracts of $300,000 neo-colonial four-bedroom homes with state-of-the-art kitchens. We can also be reassured by statistics: according to Brian Carey, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a mere 1.14 percent of American homes were in a state of foreclosure in 1998.

title: Threatened by Urban Decay, Toothy Icon Finds Rescuers
description: Bruce Springsteen fans from around the world have made it their mission to save Tillie, the grinning clown face painted on the wall of an old Asbury Park arcade that officials say is in danger of collapse.

title: Giving Their Regards to Old Broadway
description: DAVID HARTMAN has been out walking the streets again. Last summer, he did a kind of crosstown video Baedeker, a public-television documentary about 42d Street from the East River to the Hudson. On Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13, he will move on a north-south axis as he makes his way up a far longer New York thoroughfare: Broadway, starting where Manhattan started 400 years ago, south of Wall Street. The program, ''A Walk Up Broadway,'' takes him 17 miles uptown, to the bridge that carries Broadway across the Harlem River and into the Bronx.

title: Stock Markets, Facing Threats, Pursue Changes
description: Threatened by competitors that are grabbing a growing share of America's booming stock-trading business, the nation's biggest stock markets are trying to transform themselves by forming alliances with their foes and adopting some of their practices.
CATHY TROCHECK, 50, an inmate at the Westchester County Correction Facility here, was clearly terrified.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Analyze Stocks, and the Professionals Learn to Listen
description: STOCKS under rocks. They're every investor's dream -- potentially lucrative companies that for one reason or another have failed to garner Wall Street's attention.

title: Cornwall, Devon Brace For Solar-Eclipse Crowds
description: WHAT could eclipse something as historic as a total solar eclipse in the closing months of a millennium? Answer: good old everyday greed.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: Personally, I think that Rosemond and his ''followers'' sound suspiciously like a cult, with their insistence on infallibility, simplistic reasoning, intolerance, calls to ignore other ''experts'' and constant references to empowerment.

title: Caught With Their Pants On
description: HALF the babies born in New York City go home from the hospital to families with incomes below the poverty level. Something like 10 million children in this country lack health insurance. And, on average, American children spend 1,500 hours a year watching television, compared with just 900 in the classroom.

title: Steven the Good
description: Spielberg's feelings about Lindbergh's bigotry are understandable. However, I wonder what would have happened if, for example, Dodi al-Fayed, an Arab, had not wanted to produce ''Chariots of Fire'' just because there was a triumphant Jewish athlete in it.

title: Squeezing Every Drop Out of Napa
description: IT'S amazing how small an oversized bottle of cabernet sauvignon can make a person feel.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Making the Most of It in Tennessee; Creating a Home . . . On the Margins
description: At 73, Rosie Cousins is content to wait for Jesus. ''I may not have much, but I will when I leave this world,'' she says. ''I will have a better place. A better home.''

title: Square Root of a Hypercube
description: THE TESSERACTBy Alex Garland.273 pp. New York:Riverhead Books. $24.95.

title: Steven the Good
description: The Spielberg I'd like to see more of is tucked away in that black-and-white photo of the young Boy Scout: the shy dreamer. The honest, obedient, cheerful, thrifty auteur.

title: New Ferries Speed Bahamas Travel
description: Fast ferries are presenting new options to Bahamas-bound travelers this year, as a company has begun service between Miami and Nassau and another is planning inter-island trips starting in July.

title: A State Police Chief Resigns After Comments About Race
description: Police departments in a wide variety of communities nationwide have been accused of routinely using racial stereotypes as a tool with which to target people for suspicion of involvement in crime.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BRIGHT ANGEL TIME

title: 'Share-Loan Payoff In a Co-op'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- Salient Facts; Disposable Outcome
description: Despite all the environmental precautions, interstate trash fights -- like the one between Virginia and New York -- are back on the front page. Here's why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIGDAL, FANNIE
description: MIGDAL-Fannie. September 22, 1899-March 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Most loved mother of Diane and the late Herb. Adored mother-in-law, grandmother and great grandmother. Funeral Services 11:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'' 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY

title: Nathaniel Samuels, 90, an Expert on the International Economy
description: Nathaniel Samuels, an investment banker who served as Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs in the Nixon Administration, died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, his family said. He was 90.

title: Q. & A.
description: Buying A Co-op for A Relative

title: Controversy in Pole Vault Hurts Hartwig
description: A controversial judges' decision cost the American pole vaulter Jeff Hartwig a landmark victory in the world indoor track and field championships today.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Power, the Glory, the 30,000-Word Week
description: The Times Of My Life And My Life With The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELLIOTT R.
description: COHEN-Elliott R. Happy birthday, Bear. You're in our hearts forever and sadly missed. Love, Kueenie (Rita) and Mr. Dog

title: The Sailors Of Winter: In the Cold, Cold Sea
description: Larchmont Yacht Club, which began its frostbiting program in 1932, has the oldest winter fleet in the Northeast, says Stanley Bell, a former racer and frostbiter who has headed the club's race committee for 19 years. Despite the many skeptics (Sailing? In the winter?) frostbiting has its accomplished devotees. It is absolutely not a place for beginners to come out and test their skills.

title: Steven the Good
description: Dubner writes that, with ''Schindler's List,'' Spielberg ''single-handedly brought the Holocaust to the attention of Middle America.'' Perhaps those of us in Middle America would be oblivious to the entire 20th century without Hollywood's movies. As a Kansas native, I must then be grateful to Spielberg for creating ''Saving Private Ryan'' and letting us Midwesterners in on the secret of World War II.

title: Sports of The Times; Posada Can Take Heart in Union's Resolve to Stand Firm
description: WHEN the Yankees renewed Jorge Posada's contract last week with unilateral frugality, there was little debate about the players' true market worth. There was no harping on fairness and faithfulness, as there was last Thanksgiving when Bernie Williams had the audacity to play the field and make a $90 million catch.

title: A Lone Star Lament
description: As Marvin S. Traub, chief executive of Bloomingdale's until 1991, is discovering, retailing in the heart of Texas has challenges never encountered in the heart of Manhattan's East Side. For one thing, floods. When the San Marcos River soaked the city of San Marcos last October, Mr. Traub had to delay his plans for opening the first store in his new Home Company-Fine Furniture Direct chain from May to July. The stores are meant to add discounted fine furniture to the Prime Retail outlet malls that now concentrate on clothing. Mr. Traub, a Prime Retail director, is chairman of the new chain; he expects it to have 10 stores in the next five years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Travel Advisory page on Feb. 28, about the Philadelphia Flower Show, misstated the show's starting date. As the accompanying report said, it opens today, not March 13.

title: Beyond The Bounce In Bond Yields
description: MAYBE it's the weather. Or the post-Christmas, pre-April 15 blues. Whatever the cause, over the last 15 years bond traders have tended to push up interest rates, in some cases quite sharply, in the first few months of the year. And in the process, they have unsettled markets.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: You report that James Dobson, ''the grandfather of punitive parenting,'' advocates ''the squeezing of the trapezius muscle between the neck and shoulder'' to cause pain as a disciplinary measure. This shows him to be a true follower of Mr. (not Dr.) Spock, who uses the maneuver on ''Star Trek'' to disable opponents. Perhaps this approach will be most comfortable for those parents who are only half human.

title: Word for Word/News of the North; How Canadians Stopped Worrying And Laughed at a Journalistic Bomb
description: IT'S not easy being in the news business in Canada. You stare at juicy American stories nearly every day while your own pages fill with curling scores and wheat quotas. Oh, for a big, page one blockbuster!

title: Dutch Designer Mixes Luxury With a Slash Technique
description: Koos Van Den Akker has returned uptown. His new Carnegie Hill shop opened on Wednesday at 1283 Madison Avenue, between 91st and 92d Streets. The designer, whose line of clothes is known simply as Koos, has sold his wares in several countries and around Manhattan; he had a spot in the Village from 1995 until last month and, for 20 years, on 68th Street and Madison Avenue from 1971 to 1991.

title: Disorientations
description: THREE-LEGGED HORSEBy Cheng Ching-wen.Edited by Pang-yuan Chi.226 pp. New York:Columbia University Press. $22.95.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hideway With Food Worthy of Notice
description: KITCHEN A BISTRO in St. James is the ultimate no-frills restaurant. Yet despite the almost total absence of amenities, its tasty, good-value, three-course, $25 prix-fixe weekend dinner and low weekday a la carte prices attract more diners than it can accommodate.

title: Even a Lowly Vagabond Can Be Love's Fool
description: LIKE Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' which preceded it on the boards of La Scala by nearly three and a half decades, Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari's ''Sly'' plays fast and loose with Shakespeare, in the process enriching the material almost past recognition. Unlike Falstaff, who marched straight from Shakespeare's quill onto the Great Stage of Archetypes, Sly is a character even his begetter promptly forgot. But Giovacchino Forzano, a man of letters and the theater active at La Scala in the first half of this century, saw in him untapped potential. A play resulted, and eventually an opera, which receives its belated American premiere on Wednesday at the Washington Opera. Jose Carreras, absent from the American operatic stage since 1987, stars.

title: F. Y. I.
description: Architectural Gem Theft

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURICELLA, JOHN
description: LAURICELLA-John August. Of East Hampton, NY; formerly of Scotch Plains, NJ on February 16, 1999 in Altamonte, FL. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of John, James and Kenneth. Adored grandfather of Katie, Michael, Daniel and Julia. A stock trader for 30 years, he was VP with Morgan Stanley for eight years before retiring in 1989. Earlier he had worked for the First Boston Corporation, Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch all in NYC. A funeral liturgy was held at 11AM at St. Helen's R.C. Church in Westfield, NJ on February 22, 1999. Entombment followed at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or to the charity of your choice.

title: Legality of Sudden Evictions at S.R.O. Hotel Is Disputed
description: Leeford C. Jones and other residents of 58 Edgecombe Avenue say they were in their rooms about 11 A.M. on Feb. 26 when they were jolted out of bed by a dozen men wielding hammers and crowbars. One man, who said he was a contractor for the landlord, knocked on every door.

title: The Everglades
description: To the Editor: Re ''Into the Wild, Wet World of the Everglades'' (Feb. 14) by Daisann McLane: The outskirts of many cities are not enticing to most of us. However, the Tamiami Trail (Route 41) in its entirety is a joy. One views the ''river of grass,'' hummocks, roosting osprey, egrets and possibly an alligator warming itself. The occasional commercialism feeds the year-round inhabitants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTZ, EVELYN P.
description: MARTZ-Evelyn P. Beloved mother of Joan Singer. Proud grandmother of Jonathan and Jacqueline. Fearless, strong and larger than life. Her courage and love nourish us. Memorial services were held on March 5th in Sunrise, Florida.
