title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLIN, MARSHALL
description: PERLIN-Marshall. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Mike Perlin, distinguished People's Lawyer, will be held Sunday, March 14th, 2PM, at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St., Manhattan. For more information, call Hank 212-663-5833.

title: A Fund Group, Alone at Last
description: It was the mutual fund group nobody seemed to want. Now senior managers of Robertson Stephens Investment Management -- which manages $3.5 billion in assets, including a stable of 10 high-profile mutual funds -- have completed their purchase of the firm from BankAmerica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHECHANOVER, SUE CAROL
description: CHECHANOVER-Sue Carol. Of Petaluma, CA, passed away on February 22, 1999. Beloved wife of Victor, mother of Robert, Paul and Michael, mother-in-law of Janine, Caryn and Vivian, grandmother of Elizabeth, Lauren, Peter and Julianne. She was very active in her community dedicating her life to helping those in need. The world was her home, and she was concerned about everyone she met, making friends everywhere. She gave everything and took nothing in return. Make a donation to your favorite charity. Goodbye Ma, we will miss your kind heart and gentle soul. Your loving sons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASO, GOLDIE
description: MASO-Goldie. On March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late James. Loving mother of Beverly Lechner-Klein and Michael Maso. Dear mother-in-law of Lisa Coady and Charles Klein. Devoted sister of Ceil Weisburd, Samuel, Harry, and the late Irving, Shirley, Jack and Roslyn Aronowitz. Adoring grandmother of Alexander and Graham Maso. Service Sunday, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 'Trenton Makes,' the Hip Buy T-Shirts
description: It takes more than talent for an artist to sell local landscapes when he's based in Trenton. It also takes fortitude.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: About the article, ''In Battle of Bags, Confusion Rules'' (Feb. 21): Though a briefcase may meet the overall length-plus-width-plus-thickness total dimension for carry-ons, it may still not pass through the template at United and other airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, ALBERT EUGENE
description: DANN-Albert Eugene. March 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Renee; loving brother of Fred Dann and Beatrice Starr; devoted stepfather of Joan Weltz. Funeral private.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them; The Oxford Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, GISELA
description: HAMBURGER-Gisela. Age 99. ''Omi.'' Beloved mother of Ruth and son-in-law David. Grandmother of Karen, Dave, Sharyl, Gregg and Laurie, and great-grandmother of Kurt, Ben and Amanda. She escaped from Nazi Germany in 1939 to Haiti and settled in Vineland, NJ, where she guided survivors in seeking restitution. She passed away March 4, at her daughter's home. She will be missed.

title: Test Soil for Planting; Keep Clearing
description: Before preparing beds for spring planting, start with a soil test from your local Cooperative Extension Service. Its report will recommend amendments to provide the best levels of nutrients and microorganisms for your soil and the plants you are growing, not just record your pH level.

title: Van Gundy Wants to Hear Some Head-Banging Music
description: Many coaches say they want their teams to set a tone in a game, but that was something Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy never really needed to worry about in the past. Knicks games had a distinct tone, set by the thumping elbows of Charles Oakley whenever an opponent strayed into the lane, usually followed by a high-pitched yelp as the player hit the floor and conducted a count of ribs or teeth.

title: On-Line Stock Advice From the Junior Set
description: Nowhere is it written that a stock guru has to be old enough to vote. But in the age of the Internet, where anyone with a modem can dispense financial wisdom and shift market tides, there are other questions raised about people like Daniel Miller, 15, who maintains a stock-advice Web site. Propelled by a CNBC appearance last month, as well as a couple of stellar picks, his following has been growing so quickly that he is soliciting advertising for his site and considering charging admission.

title: Let Them Eat Candy
description: CHOCOLAT

title: Reid Takes Boudouani's Best Shot and His Title
description: With textbook precision and masterly style, David Reid scored a 12-round unanimous decision over Laurent Boudouani tonight to win the World Boxing Association super welterweight championship. What was more impressive is that Reid put on the virtuoso performance in just his 12th professional fight.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Images From the 60's

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Hartford's Bushnell Theater Growing by a Third
description: THE BUSHNELL in downtown Hartford will break ground this spring on an 88,000-square-foot, $30 million addition that will give the 69-year-old, 2,800-seat theater a 950-seat modern auditorium for smaller productions.

title: Teacher Is Charged With Raping Student
description: A Marist brother in the South Bronx was charged Friday with raping one of his sixth-grade students in a classroom three years ago, the police said. The brother, Christopher Shannon, 57, has been charged with rape, sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child.

title: Nijinsky's Inner Choreography
description: VASLAV NIJINSKY, the world-renowned dancer and choreographer of the Ballets Russes, began a diary on the afternoon of Jan. 19, 1919. That evening he gave what would be his last public performance, a disturbing solo recital, ''Marriage With God,'' at a hotel in St. Moritz, Switzerland, where he and his family had taken up wartime residence. For the next 45 days, sometimes all night, the 29-year-old Nijinsky wrote feverishly in four leather-bound school exercise books.

title: Multinational In the East 80's
description: BALUCHI'S+

title: On the Menu Today: Health Care
description: IN a storefront soup kitchen on Front Street in Hempstead, the Interfaith Nutrition Network serves 200 meals a day, five days a week, to children and adults from the vicinity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAIN, BETTY
description: TRAIN-Betty. Dear sister of Lou Davis. Loving aunt of Bernice and Herbert Epstein, Carl Davis, Bruce and Sandi Davis, Barbara and Paul Kirwin, Burt and Rhoda Davis, Barbara and Arnold Cohen, and Robert and Linda Davis. Great aunt and great great aunt. Funeral service today, 1:30 PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Chroniclers of Wayward Souls
description: COUNTRY has long been packaged as the classical music of simple American folks. The transformation of hillbilly entertainment into an official repository of our national traditions has extended from the fancy naming of the Grand Ole Opry in 1927 to the appointment of William Ivey, the director of the Country Music Hall of Fame, to the chair of the National Endowment for the Arts in 1998. Not only Nashville's music industry, but also the ''alternative'' country made by rock- and folk-schooled rebels can be discouragingly orthodox, its vintage trappings turning cultural preservation into historical tourism.

title: An Affair to Remember
description: I'LL STAND BY YOUSelected Letters of Sylvia Townsend Warner and Valentine Ackland.With narrative by Sylvia Townsend Warner.Edited by Susanna Pinney.392 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.:Pimlico/Trafalgar Square.Paper, $24.95.

title: Another Charge Dismissed
description: The definition of ''high crimes and misdemeanors'' is subject to interpretation by the Senate. But a charge card's expiration date is etched in plastic.

title: Bred in Brooklyn For a Broadway Run
description: BROADWAY is new territory for Susan Feldman. Not that she works far away: she is the director of the well-known Arts at St. Ann's program in Brooklyn Heights. Nor is she a stranger to music theater. She has co-commissioned and produced a range of work since 1980, including ''Songs for 'Drella,'' Lou Reed and John Cale's piece about Andy Warhol.

title: Gathering Music, And Then Some
description: HANK SNOW. The Singing Ranger, as he's known. One of the top figures in country music, he recorded for RCA from 1934 to 1979 when he was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. Like so many of country's pioneers, he's pretty much ignored these days, yet the simplicity and breadth of his work still has the power to speak to true country fans.

title: On the Women's Basketball Court at Duke
description: THE athlete from Westchester County has sparked the Duke basketball team to national prominence.

title: After the Blizzard, Rochester Is Walloped by a Second Snowstorm
description: Rochester, staggered by a blizzard on Thursday that left thousands stranded on roadways, was hit with a second storm today that continued into the night.

title: New Era for Region As Clinton Sets Visit
description: When President Clinton visits El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras and Guatemala over four days this week, he will find a region forged by one tragedy or another over the last several decades, and more often than not forgotten in its intervals of renewal. The trip begins tomorrow, the day after Salvadorans vote on a new President, further cementing a remarkable democratic transformation after 12 years of civil war. Compared with the clamor of the 1980's, when the region's upheavals dominated American foreign policy, that change has occurred nearly silently.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Those of us in the grip of addiction use this process to rethink our lives. Socrates makes clear that you have to have the courage to examine yourself and to stand up for something. A lot of us have justified our weaknesses for too long a time.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, NATHANIEL
description: SAMUELS-Nathaniel. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on March 21 at 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. and 65 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to the Harvard College Fund-Maurice and Sarah Samuels Fund, c/o The Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 7, 1999
description: Weeks

title: A Certifiably Sane Guitarist
description: 'JIM HALL: A LIFE IN PROGRESS'

title: A Convict's Memoir With No Remorse
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the convicted Unabomber, has written an unrepentant memoir that tries to settle scores and correct what he says is a distorted public image. The manuscript, sent to a New York publisher from the the maximum security prison in Colorado where Mr. Kaczynski is serving a life sentence, does not admit that Mr. Kaczynski was the elusive bomber. But the book, to be published this spring, speaks of the Unabomber in admiring terms.

title: Ruth Bergida, Richard Grossman
description: Ruth Bergida and Richard S. Grossman are to be married tonight at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Scott Rosenberg officiated.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: WHERE THE RAINBOW ENDS

title: U.S. O.K. for Reactor Still a Bad Decision
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has no credibility when it says the Brookhaven Lab's High Flux Beam Reactor is safe for restart [''U.S. Sees No Problem With Nuclear Reactor,'' Feb. 28]. The N.R.C. has a long history as an apologist for the the nuclear industry. It is laughable that lab officials refer to the N.R.C. as an independent agency.

title: Poland's Grand Era Sweeps Into the U.S.
description: From 1572 through 1764, Poland was Europe's largest nation, sweeping east to include what is today Lithuania and most of Belarus and the Ukraine. It was the crossroads of trade between eastern and western Europe, the Christian bulwark against the Ottoman Empire.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: John Rosemond may believe that rearing children can be ''a no-brainer.'' And he may be right. It takes zero brains to strike -- in anger but not in rage'' -- a child who disobeys. Rosemond's boot-camp brand of parenting is based on fear and humiliation. Sure, children will obey punitive, belt-wielding parents. But they'll grow to be angry, resentful adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOKVIS, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: STOKVIS-Joseph William. 83, February 15, 1999 in Tamarac, FL. Beloved husband for 63 yrs. of Beatrice (Terry). Father of Irene Land and husband Paul; sportscaster Dick Stockton and wife, sportscaster Lesley Visser. Loving grandfather of Jonathan B. Land. Owner of Reklam Printing in NYC for 30 yrs. Commissioner of City Planning for the city of Tamarac, writer, and poet. Quatrains of his daily record of the 1977 Boston Red Sox games appeared in The New Yorker in an article by Roger Angell and later in his book, ''Late Innings.'' A Web site has been started by Jon: lateinnings.com. Tamarac will issue a Proclamation in his honor on March 10. This loving husband, father and grandfather will be forever missed, but always in our hearts.

title: Las Vegas
description: For the many people planning to visit Las Vegas since hearing that it had become family oriented, with plenty of affordable fun for the young and old, time may be running out. The place seems to be in a perpetual state of transformation, and the casino companies that built the amusement parks and Disneylike attractions in the early 1990's have now set their sights on more upscale tourists, building luxury hotels and casinos with couture shops and restaurants operated by world-renowned chefs.

title: Tempest on the River; It Was Supposed to Be an Urban Utopia. Today, Roosevelt Island Is a Battleground.
description: THEY arrived at Roosevelt Island in stages, beginning in 1975, when the first apartment building opened. Pioneers, they were lured by reasonable, and in some cases subsidized, housing, and by promises of a utopia where 20,000 people of all races and economic levels would mix, traffic would be minimal and greenery would flourish, all within sight of Manhattan's skyline.

title: The Other Melting Pot
description: SOUTH AFRICAA Narrative History.By Frank Welsh.Illustrated. 606 pp. New York:Kodansha America. $35.

title: Some Recipients Get Welfare Reduction . . .
description: Checks for reduced welfare benefits went out last week to about 2,000 families in the state, after they missed a March 1 deadline to look for work, the first deadline under new state and Federal requirements, officials said.

title: Playing Princesses, Punishers and Prudes
description: AS the title character on ''Frasier'' wound up his radio show on a recent episode, his straitlaced ex-wife, Lilith (Bebe Neuwirth), arrived. ''Someone walked into the room and just frightened me,'' announced Frasier. ''It's my ex-wife, and if you're a regular listener, you know what I'm talking about.''

title: Where the Irish Spirit Always Gets Green Light
description: ON March 17, Eamon McGahey expects to find a line of people wrapped around the block at 11 A.M. when he arrives to open up his pub, the Harp 'n' Bard in Clifton. ''The once-a-year Irish all come out then, thank goodness,'' said Mr. McGahey, who has operated this bastion of greenery on Lakeview Avenue for 15 years. ''Sometimes I wish it were once a week, but I don't think I could do it once a week.''

title: Fiddling While Antarctica Burns
description: I am glad to count myself among the handful of Washington reporters who missed the impeachment trial of the President. I was off covering a far more important story in Antarctica.

title: Kraft Sees Winner's Tent, but It Will Take Some Magic
description: Greg Kraft showed how determined he is to win. Andy Bean showed that at age 45, he can still hit terrific shots. Ernie Els showed how great players remain in contention when they are not at their best. And Glen Day showed he plans to follow a strong 1998 with an even stronger 1999.

title: Inspired Tar Heels Hold Off Terrapins
description: The junior guard Ed Cota had a few choice words for his North Carolina teammates in the days leading up to the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament. Through the media, the Brooklyn native criticized his team's sometimes sloppy, sometimes lazy play, noting that the Tar Heels all too often ran the court ''like chickens with their heads cut off.''

title: Where Films Can Rest Easy
description: IT wasn't your typical Al Pacino movie, this small film about a celebrity-obsessed thug that the box-office heavyweight had lovingly acted in and dug deep into his pockets to produce. In fact, ''The Local Stigmatic'' never enjoyed financial success, period, having landed on a dusty shelf after Mr. Pacino, who spent four years editing and re-editing the film after it was shot in 1985, failed to find a distributor.

title: For Schools, Lessons and Tests From Satanism Case
description: IN the last two weeks, a psychic, a yogi and a priest from Texas have been among the parade of witnesses testifying in a sometimes ribald White Plains court case pitting the academic freedom of the Bedford School District against the rights of parents to decide what they want their children to learn.

title: Boston Before 'The Rite of Spring'
description: WHEN the conductor Serge Koussevitzky stepped off the boat in Boston in 1924 as the new music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, one of the first questions he is said to have asked was, ''Where are your American composers?''

title: Parkland or Dump: For Now, It's a 7-Acre Compost Yard
description: To residents, the secluded corner of Canarsie Beach Park near Paerdegat Avenue was a place to fly kites in the tall grasses and pick mulberries. But to city officials, the area was little more than an overgrown dump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARMELE, RUSSELL BOGERT
description: PARMELE-Russell Bogert, 76, died at home in AZ, March 2, 1999. Son of the H.G.W. Parmeles' of Dongan Hills, SI. Russ was a Princeton graduate ('49) and Navy pilot. Surviving are wife Nancy, daughters Wendy, Randall, Patricia; son Russell Jr.; four grandchildren, two younger brothers.

title: A Dark Side Of Expansion: Housing Costs Rise Rapidly
description: A strong national economy that is rewarding many Americans through steady employment, low interest rates and rising stock prices is hurting millions of the nation's poorest people by delaying their access to affordable housing, a new report by the Federal Government says.

title: Landscapes in Pastels That Emphasize Improvisation
description: TO a nonartist, pastel seems a daunting medium even more difficult than watercolor. It would appear that a false move would be impossible to get right. Plus, there is the general pastiness of pastel: its texture often gets noticed before the subject matter, and not every subject is fit for it. But the positive side is that in the right hands pastel suits landscape perfectly. Its inherent evanescence can capture weather and fleeting effects like dappled sunlight.

title: Clinton to Begin Visit to Central America
description: When President Clinton visits Central America next week, he will witness a region forged by one tragedy or another over the last several decades and, more often than not, forgotten in its intervals of renewal.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Back From Films To Long Forgotten Photos
description: STANDING in the courtyard of Harold Becker's Hollywood Hills home is a 10-foot-tall wooden frame that bears a striking resemblance to a guillotine. Halfway down, however, rests not a murderously sharp blade but rather an old-fashioned camera, its black bellows extending nearly three feet from the lens to an 11-by-14-inch glass panel at the rear. It looks like a piece of elegant furniture, perfectly appropriate for a house belonging to the director of ''Sea of Love'' and ''City Hall.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, METHILDA
description: TERNER-Methilda. The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the death of longtime member and friend, Methilda Terner. We send our sincere condolences to her family. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: A New Tack for Republicans
description: President Clinton put Republicans on the defensive when he proposed to tap most of the budget surplus in the next 15 years to shore up Social Security and pay down the national debt, not to cut taxes as they wanted. Most voter surveys show that Americans embrace Mr. Clinton's choice. Now, in their first formal response to the President's budget, the Republicans have tried to outdo him by setting aside even more money for Social Security than Mr. Clinton proposed. They would also defer their tax cuts for at least two years. Their new approach is a step in the right direction. But it has many flaws, including unacceptable cuts in Medicare and other domestic spending.

title: Odd Twosome Takes On South Africa's Status Quo
description: The partners move through the bustle of an upscale mall in this Cape Town suburb, shaking hands and calling greetings.

title: Taking New Measurements for Jefferson's Pedestal
description: In a room just across the road from Monticello, the hilltop mansion of Thomas Jefferson, a group of scholars struggled this weekend to understand the character of the third President now that it has taken on a dimension that historians almost unanimously denied for two centuries.

title: A Rider's Plea: Don't Knock Buses
description: Shame on David Bouchier for bus-bashing [''A Bus Stop Is Where It Started,'' Out of Order, Feb. 28]. I am a longtime user of public transportation, and the public should be thankful that some people on the Island have the good sense to not own a car. Could you imagine how much worse our already crowded roads would be if we all drove?

title: It's Not Spring, but Adventure Beckons
description: THE mid-winter break is over, spring is just a hint in the afternoon sun, and Long Islanders are tackling the next big problem: Deciding what to do for outdoor fun until the beaches reopen.

title: Is There a Black Upper Class?
description: DR. CHESTER REDHEAD opens his garage, walks to his green and tan Rolls-Royce and bursts into a 1,000-watt grin. ''This is my baby,'' he says, opening the front door so a visitor can get a closer look. ''This is my toy.'' Earlier, this black dentist showed off another passion: a 1,000-bottle wine cellar in his home, which is on a leafy block in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Q&A/Kathy Grasso-Andersen; From Party Politics to Indian Rights
description: THE political activism of Kathy Grasso-Andersen began during the 1968 Presidential campaign of Senator Eugene McCarthy and a successful intraparty fight to give the Minnesota Democrat a share of Connecticut delegates to the party's tumultuous national convention that year in Chicago.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Article on Union Square Overlooked the Residents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUM, EDWARD
description: STRUM-Edward. Died January 29, 1999. Chicago born, made New York his home, theater his life, and life his art. A one-of-a-kind man, stage manager extraordinaire, proud Lithuanian-never to be forgotten. Memorial, Sunday, March 14, 3PM. Buckley Funeral Home, 445 W. 43 St, New York.

title: Our Towns; At Firehouses, Alarm Sounds Over Loyalties
description: JOSEPH B. BELLINA is the Business Administrator of Hamilton Township, and on the subject of reforming the local volunteer fire department system, he says this: ''Nobody wants to upset the volunteers.''

title: He's Rude, He Lies, He's A Lot Like Basil Fawlty
description: JOHN LARROQUETTE has found a fresh host body for his patented brand of blowhard. In the 1980's, Mr. Larroquette won four Emmys for his portrayal of the pompous, philandering assistant prosecutor Dan Fielding in ''Night Court.'' This time, in the new CBS sitcom ''Payne,'' he is an innkeeper in northern California who views his wife, his employees and his guests as impediments to his ultimate goal.

title: The Proper Sequence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, MARJORIE KANE
description: GERRY-Marjorie Kane. Died on March 4 at the age of 89 following a short illness at Delhi, N.Y. Widow of the late Elbridge T. Gerry who died on February 26. She is survived by two sons Elbridge T. Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y. and Peter G. of Hopewell, N.J., a daughter Marjorie G. Ryland of Beverly, MA., a sister Patricia Kane Leonard of Chesiers, Switzerland, eleven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A joint memorial service for she and her husband of 67 years will be held on Wednesday, March 10, 1999 at Trinity Church, Wall St. and Broadway, NYC, at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Lake Delaware Boys Camp or The O'Connor Hospital, Delhi, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, RUTH
description: METZGER-Ruth. On March 4, 1999 at the age of 89, after deteriorating health and a two month hospitalization. She will be missed by her daughter Susan, her son-inlaw Paul Gurwitz, and by her beloved grandson Joshua Gurwitz. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, March 7 at 11AM at Schwarz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Call the family for Shiva arrangements.

title: Japanese Germ Warfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Thumb Splint for Williams
description: As the Nets practiced today in preparation for Sunday's game with the Knicks, center Jayson Williams showed off the new plaster splint on his ligament-damaged left thumb. It holds his thumb at an angle; without it, he said, the thumb would bend all the way back.

title: A Blast From Past On Democratic Inroads
description: Your article, ''Nassau Democrats Primed for Inroads, but Have Own Probems,'' [Feb. 28], neglected to mention that not too long ago the Nassau Democrats were able to successfully take advantage of Republican vulnerabilities. In 1961, Eugene Nickerson, a Democrat, defeated his Republican opponent for county executive. In this upset, the Democrats were able to capitalize on the fact that the Republicans nominated a weak candidate, were weakened by internal divisions, and were easily pictured as the party of ''boss rule'' in that the longtime party chairman, J. Russell Sprague, would be running the county government from behind the scenes. Mr. Nickerson, with his Ivy League background and lack of association with a powerful political organization, appealed to the better-than-average-educated voters moving into Nassau County. The lesson would seem that if the county Democrats could overcome their internal problems and nominate appealing candidates, they could again win county offices.

title: Lara Bernstein, Douglas Goroway
description: Lara Beth Bernstein, a lawyer, and Douglas Brett Goroway, a New York City police detective, were married last evening by Rabbi Uri Goren at the East Meadow (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: BENEFITS
description: For Asian-American Theater

title: Wine Labels Mislead
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Debut, Clemens's Style Suits The Yankees
description: Roger Clemens wore a Yankees uniform in a game for the first time today, and it felt normal to him. Everything seemed as it should be, the pitcher said. Clemens was on a mound, staring down hitters, under a scorching spring sun, in a Yankees cap. ''There was nothing funny about it,'' he said.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Biggest Demolition Derby Yet
description: THE secrets of the universe may be revealed right here on Long Island. At Exit 68 of the Long Island Expressway, Brookhaven National Laboratory sits like an alien city in 5,000 acres of pine woods. Scientists are just one step away from finding the ultimate answer to the ultimate question, although nobody agrees what exactly the question is.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Improvising, From Cairo to Kansas; Beyond the Old Woman In The Shoe
description: What is it with these people? Do they wake up one day and say, ''Let's move to that abandoned missile silo'' or ''Why don't we buy an old plane and turn it into a house''? What drives people to do something this, well, bizarre? Economics, surely, isn't the only reason. Unlike Diogenes, who lived in a tub, they don't appear to be ascetics. Maybe they want to be different, to be noticed; not just to own a conversation piece but to live in one. In fact, these are some of the same sentiments that motivate the clients of high-style architecture. After all, living in a caboose is no more odd than living in a house with all-glass walls or in a house perched over a waterfall, to name but two famous architectural landmarks.

title: Early Bloom Won't Stop Wildflower Festival
description: Bluebonnets, the traditional harbingers of spring in central Texas, are in bloom again. The redbuds are budding, the daisies are dancing in the warm breezes and the sweet scent of mountain laurel fills the air. And that is not necessarily happy news for travelers who visit Austin and the Texas Hill Country to admire the spring wildflowers. Because of unusual warmth so far this year, the peak for spring wildflowers -- typically the last two weeks of March and the first two weeks of April -- is about three weeks early. ''By the second week in March, I suspect we will have peaked out,'' said Flo Oxley, botanist at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Audi A6 Avant, Mercedes-Benz E320, BMW 528i and 540i; American Icons Made in Europe
description: JUST say ''station wagon'' and any baby boomer's brain starts flipping through its memory book: driveway car washes, car pools and Dinah Shore beckoning fresh-faced families to ''See the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet.''

title: Celebrating African Traditions
description: IN ''Three African Traditions: The Art of the Dogon, Fang and Songye,'' an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through April 18, the aura created by figurative sculptures and masks is eclipsed by a compulsion to ferret out differences and commonalities.

title: Hanover's Snowy Playground
description: I WASN'T even in Hanover yet, and I already felt I had escaped New York City. A few days before leaving, I received a postcard from Pierce's Country Inn, where I had made reservations for the weekend.

title: Archives Web Site
description: The Westchester Archives Web site has been awarded the Family History Favorite Award by Ancestry Daily News. The award was recently published on its Web site: Ancestry .com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, JANE CHADBOURNE
description: SCOTT-Jane Chadbourne. Of Locust, NJ, died March 3, 1999, at the age of 85. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, George C. Scott. She is also survived by her sister, Elizabeth C. Du Bois, of Beachwood, her niece, Nancy Chadbourne Mills Crabbe, also of Beachwood, and by great-nieces Victoria S. Takacs and Kathryn I. Taylor, and a great-nephew, Thomas P. Takacs, all of Rumson. She was the daughter of the late Dean Kimball Chadbourne and Mabel Prudence Jamison Chadbourne, of Plainfield. She was a reader for the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Red Bank, and had been a founder of the Christian Scientist Church in Atlantic Highlands. Jane, as she was known to her many friends, was an expert gardener specializing in the art of bonsai, the growing and training of dwarf trees. She studied bonsai under the master, Yuji Yoshimura. ''Earth on Her Hands'', a book by Starr Ockenga (1988), profiled Jane as one of America's leading women gardeners. The chapter on Jane focused on her well-known bonsai collection. Jane has left her bonsai collection to the Monmouth County Park System, to be displayed at Deep Cut Park, Middletown. She accompanied her husband, George, who was ViceChairman of Citibank, on many trips on bank business throughout the world. She was a member of the Rumson Garden Club, the Rumson Country Club, and the Sea Bright Beach Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPS, LEE
description: PHILIPS-Lee. Television director. Passed away peacefully in his home in Brentwood, CA, from complications due to Parkinson's disease March 3, 1999. He was 72 years old. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his name to the National Parkinson Foundation, Inc., 1501 NW 9th Ave., Miami, FL 33136-1494. He is survived by his two daughters, Caitlin Philips and Julie Philips.

title: A Pack of Proposals Vie for Tobacco Money
description: With the first $100 million payment from the state's tobacco settlement arriving this year, Governor Whitman and state lawmakers are having no trouble coming up with ideas how to spend it.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Selma Blair; A Premiere That Feels Like a Prom
description: SELMA BLAIR was among the first to arrive at her movie premiere party at Henri Bendel last Wednesday night. The movie, ''Cruel Intentions,'' is a remake of ''Dangerous Liaisons,'' with students at a fictional Upper East Side private school. By showing up unfashionably early, Ms. Blair was completely in character as Cecile Caldwell, the awkward, eager freshman that she plays in the film.

title: Sports of The Times; Heavyweight Thinker Who Likes His Chess
description: IN a black tank top, black-and-blue tights, white boxing shoes and a white cap, Lennox Lewis was on display for the last time here at the Caesars Brookdale resort among the bare trees in the Poconos. Soon he would be in a limo Friday night on the way to a midtown New York hotel to await next Saturday's heavyweight title showdown with Evander Holyfield at Madison Square Garden.

title: Q&A/Renee Ickson Young; Selling the Soaps (as if They Were Real)
description: IT was no accident that Johnnie Cochran was recently called in to consult on the Annie Dutton corpse-stealing trial. It was arranged by Renee Ickson Young of New Rochelle, executive director of CBS daytime publicity. Annie Dutton is a character on the soap opera ''Guiding Light,'' and part of Ms. Young's job is to find innovative ways to get the soap opera out of the television pages and into the news. Mr. Cochran's cameo performance will be shown on Tuesday, just days after Mr. Cochran brings the cast of ''Guiding Light'' to his talk show on Court TV to discuss (as if it were real) the Annie Dutton trial.

title: Published, but Not Paid
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Lewinsky Interviews, 2 Marketing Approaches
description: Controversial television programs present a ticklish challenge for marketers. Advertising on them can turn counterproductive by striking the audience as intrusive, inappropriate, tasteless or, worst of all, an implicit taking of sides in the controversy. But oh, those ratings.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: TRAVELING MERCIESSome Thoughts on Faith.By Anne Lamott. Pantheon, $23.

title: Nights Gaudy And Regal
Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBLIN, DENIS R., M.D.
description: GIBLIN-Denis R., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the faculty and staff of The Alan and Barbara Merkin Department of Neurology in mourning the passing of Denis R. Giblin, MD, Professor of Neurology at The Albert Einstein College of Medicine (AECOM) and attending physician at BIMC. Dr. Giblin's contributions were considerable as a practitioner, mentor and teacher. He helped Beth Israel build a first rate clinical and teaching program which resulted recently in the establishment of the Denis R. Giblin Prize for Excellence in Teaching, which will be awarded annually to a graduating resident from the nurology training program at AECOM. We offer our heartfelt condolecnes to Susan Schwartz-Giblin and Dr. Giblin's entire family. Dr. Giblin's wisdom and experience will be missed by us all. Matthew E. Fink, MD, Pres & CEO Beth Israel Medical Center James S. Breslaw, MD, President of the Medical Board Susan B. Bressman, MD, Chairman, Alan and Barbara Merkin Department of Neurology

title: Clinton Aides Admit Lapses On Espionage By Chinese
description: Two of President Clinton's top advisers said today that the investigation into China's acquisition of American nuclear weapons technology showed enormous lapses in security at the Energy Department's laboratories in the 1980's, and they acknowledged that they moved too slowly to solve the problems during Mr. Clinton's first term.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Demand Rising for Attached Condominiums
description: RENEWED demand for attached houses in condominium developments that offer shared recreational facilities and maintenance-free living is bringing increasing numbers of these developments on the market.

title: After 120 Years, a General Store Serves the Community, and Pizza
description: In the 19th century, people depended on Gariss's General Store for such essentials as butter, lard and eggs. These days, it is called the Old Stillwater General store and it features a deli and a pizzeria. But it still has a porch where people can sip lemonade. The store, founded in 1871, is one of just a few general stores remaining in the state; there is no exact count, according to the state Chamber of Commerce.

title: UNITY IS ELUSIVE AS RELIGIOUS RIGHT PONDERS 2000 VOTE
description: Twenty years after the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Moral Majority Inc. propelled religious conservatives into a heavyweight force in American politics, the movement is struggling without a clear strategy, and for the first time a debate has erupted among leading figures over whether they should radically scale back their political efforts.

title: In New Haven, Flavors from South Asia
description: GUNUNG TAHAN is, as far as we know, one of just two Malaysian restaurants in Connecticut, both in New Haven. Though the dining room is medium-sized, the menu is large, with many intriguing dishes. As Malaysia is something of a melting pot, its cuisine draws on those of the many peoples who inhabit the Southeast Asian peninsula, from Indians to Chinese to Indonesians. Many dishes on the menu (such as gado-gado, satay, nasi goreng) are also found in Indonesia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROBERT B.
description: WEINSTEIN-Robert B. Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes (The Kane Street Synagogue) mourns the untimely death of its beloved member, treasurer, past president, ritual leader, teacher, and friend. Our loss of this good and gentle leader, steadfast and true to one and all, is profound. The funeral service will be held at noon on Sunday, March 7, at the Synagogue, at 236 Kane Street, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Rabbi Samuel H. Weintraub President Ellen Bowin The Officers and Board of Trustees

title: T. Norman Hurd, 88, Rockefeller's Confidant
description: T. Norman Hurd, a New York State budget director under Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller and the Governor's close confidant, died on Feb. 27 at his home in Loudonville, N.Y., a suburb of Albany. He was 88.

title: Another Man Is Slashed By Attackers in Subway
description: In the fourth such attack in less than 24 hours, a 29-year-old Brooklyn man was beaten and slashed by a group of men in a Manhattan subway car early yesterday, the police said. Detective Madelyne Colon, a police spokeswoman, said that none of the slashings appeared to be related.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Going Domestic in Ohio; Newlyweds Relish Setting Up Their First Homes . . . and Dreaming About the Next
description: Robin and Aaron Hido, newlyweds living on the first floor of a red-brick apartment building in suburban Cleveland, won't be hanging around for long: six months after getting married, they're already saving money to buy a house. Even so, the couple didn't want their first place to look like a way station, and have spent hours personalizing their $680-a-month, two-bedroom space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCHER, FRANK
description: DEUTSCHER - Frank. Beloved husband of the late Martha, loving father of Kenneth Warren, devoted brother of Sam, attorney for over fifty years. Services Sunday, 1PM at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave.

title: 3 Victims in Colombia Defended Indigenous People
description: The three Americans who were killed while on a mission to help the Uwa people of Colombia had distinguished themselves in the United States and in international organizations as passionate defenders of the environment and of the rights of indigenous people, associates said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLEDELL, JOSEPH
description: FLEDELL-Joseph. Your birthday, March 3rd has come and gone. No party, no friends, no cake, no candles, no music, no songs. Remembering you is nothing new, but somehow life goes on. The way you sang those lovely songs was truly unforgettable and so are you. You were and will forever be my happiness. The Girl That You Married, Betty

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Rich First Attempt

title: Not a Sequel to 'The Shining'
description: WHEN Tobias Perse and Craig Damraurer, first-time filmmakers, set out to make a documentary last fall, they chose their topic with a nod to the adage that authors should write about what they know. Both Mr. Perse, 28, and Mr. Damraurer, 29, are slightly bald. In their film, tentatively titled ''Bald: The Movie,'' they plan to string together interviews with 30 or 40 men and women to shed light on the complex and intense opinions and emotions that surface over the subject of hair loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKIERNAN, FRANCIS B.
description: McKIERNAN-Francis B., 77. Of Middleburgh, New York, died on Tuesday, February 23rd, 1999, at the home of his daughter, following a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn on April 15, 1921, a son of Hugh and Beatrice Gilmartin McKiernan. He was raised in Ireland. He graduated from New York University with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering. He retired in 1978 from the New York Times where he had been a security guard for thirty years. He was a United States Army veteran of W.W. II and the Korean War. He was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. He also was a member of the Newspaper Guild, Sein Fein, Clan Na Gael and the National Association for Irish Freedom. He was a communicant of St. Catherine's Church of Middleburgh. Survivors include his wife of fifty-three years, Mary Turner McKiernan, two daughters, Mary Cook of Mineola, NY and Eileen LaSpaluto of Middleburgh, two sons, Francis McKiernan of Middleburgh and Brian McKiernan of Floral Park, NY, his stepmother, Florence McKiernan of California, a sister, Marie Jennsen of California, 12 grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on Friday, February 26th, at St. Catherine's Church, Middleburgh. Father Thomas Holmes, pastor of St. Catherine's Church, and Father Sean McMahon of St. Mary's Church and Our Lady of Knock Shrine, East Durham, New York were celebrants. A Spring burial will be made in Middleburgh Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Catherine's Church, Main Street, Middleburgh, New York 12122 or Catskill Area Hospice, 1 MacArthur Avenue, Cobleskill, New York 12043.

title: Elton Brand Stands in Triple Spotlight
description: IT began with few eyes watching, a big, pudgy kid and a basketball at the Dunbar Heights Apartments in Peekskill. Dribbling, shooting, practicing on a cracked blacktop court. Actually, a half court. With a metal basket and even a metal-chain net.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, IRENE
description: KAHN-Irene. Age 95, on March 5. Beloved wife of the late Alexander L. Kahn. Mother of the late Robert E. Kahn and Marjorie Ann, and surviving daughter Joan Kaye Barrow. Grandmother of Richard Katz and Sue Ann Kates. Greatgrandmother of Benjamin Elliot Kates and Aaron Spence Katz.

title: Habitats / Fifth Avenue Near 125th Street; To Open a B & B, She Takes the A Train
description: IT'S a common enough dream. Ditch the corporate job, buy a big old house, open a bed-and-breakfast and live rent-free while you serve coffee in the morning to interesting guests who want to check out your little part of the world.

title: 'Nightingales' Sings Of Williams's Promise
description: MY next play will be simple, direct and terrible -- a picture of my own heart. There will be no artifice in it. I will speak the truth as I see it . . . It will be myself without concealment or evasion and with a fearless unashamed frontal assault upon life that will leave no room for trepidation . . . [It will be] a passionate denial of sham and a cry for beauty.''

title: The Son Also Oms
description: THE Pope wasn't the only spiritual celebrity besieged by teen-age fans during his visit to St. Louis in January.

title: Reaping Benefits Of After-School Programs
description: Martin Cantor [''We All Need More Child Care,'' Feb. 28] could not have been more correct in arguing for after-school programs, especially for young people aged 10 to 14. Young adolescence is a time when risk-taking behavior accelerates and the peer group becomes extremely important. After-school programs for children in grades five though eight are the best strategy for offering safe, supervised environments, places where students can receive homework help and participate in recreational activities.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Police Arrest 2 Brothers In Killing Outside Club
description: Two brothers from Brooklyn were arrested yesterday in connection with the beating death of a 29-year-old man they had met inside a Chelsea nightclub, the police said.

title: Your Cheatin' Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: A HOME IN THE HEART OF A CITY

title: The Millennium In Perspective, Without Hoopla
description: IT'S Dec. 31, 1999. Jesus arrives in New York with his assistant Magdalena on his arm and a vexing question on his mind: should he start the Apocalypse or not?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, MICHAEL R.
description: JOYCE-Michael R. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael R. Joyce, associated with The Times since 1952.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Devotees, and a Critic Are Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Domestic Partner Coverage Is Fair and Inexpensive
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Offers Proposal On Tainted Water
description: Tritium contaminating groundwater outside Brookhaven National Laboratory's High Flux Beam Reactor building would be allowed to diminish gradually instead of being extracted under a plan released by the Department of Energy last week.

title: The World; So Much for Grand Theories
description: IN the space of a week Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has searched for a way to use the threat of American military power to end civil war in the world's smallest would-be nation, Kosovo, and for a way to use American economic power to change the behavior of the world's largest and oldest nation, China.

title: Life Studies With a Faith In Mutability
description: THE actor David Marshall Grant knows a thing or two about plays with big messages. His Broadway debut was in ''Bent'' by Martin Sherman, a visceral look at homosexuality and identity in Nazi Germany. Then there was Tony Kushner's sweeping tale of AIDS and redemption, ''Angels in America,'' in which Mr. Grant played Joe Pitt, the sexually confused Mormon lawyer, for which he received a Tony nomination.

title: Governor Mutes His Call to Change Stringent Rockefeller-Era Drug Laws
description: In a significant policy shift, the Pataki administration has backed away from any major overhaul of the stiff Rockefeller-era drug laws that have caused New York's prison population to surge over the last two decades.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: A Cafe Blooms in a Resurgence in Pelham
description: IF further evidence of Pelham's quiet resurgence is needed, Pelham's Crossing Cafe will serve. Long considered a poor relation to the swankier villages to its north, Pelham seems poised to compete for lower Westchester's legion of discriminating diners. Walk along Wolfs Lane from the train station and note among a few antiques shops an increasingly bustling business in dining, from a coffee shop and pizza places to watering holes and full-fledged restaurants. Among the recent arrivals is this glowing little cafe.

title: A Landmark Lesson in Being Black
description: THEY had never seen anything like it. The theater critics, hurrying down the aisles under the pressure of deadline, paused at the rear of the Ethel Barrymore Theater. The date was March 11, 1959. For a few moments they stopped considering the words with which they would salute this poetically named play, ''A Raisin in the Sun.'' Instead, they watched the first-night audience deliver its own verdict: on its feet and willing to applaud, it seemed, for eternity.

title: The Art and Economics Of Teaching Creativity
description: CECIL BRIDGEWATER was insistent. ''I don't care if you don't play the right notes,'' he told the nine young musicians seated in front of him at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School. ''But you've got to get the right rhythm. Put those instruments in your lap, and let's clap.''

title: The World: Revisiting World War II Atrocities; Comparing the Unspeakable to the Unthinkable
description: AUSCHWITZ. Dachau. Ping Fan. Changchun. In the shorthand of World War II atrocities, some names are more recognizable than others.

title: The Treasure That Hung Over the Copier
description: Viewed from across the gallery in Hartford where ''Niagara Falls'' hangs, the mist and spray seem to glow, with the hint of a rainbow arching over the craggy foreground.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them; Not Like the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes / Readers' Questions; Dad's House, Stanford White Design, Swami's Visit
description: Lexington and 57th

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: STEVE MCQUEEN'S dynamic performance as a cynical American sailor gives color and authority to Robert Wise's SAND PEBBLES (1966). The workmanlike drama about an American gunboat plying Chinese waters in 1926 was filmed partly on location. Candice Bergen, as an American missionary, scores effectively, along with Richard Attenborough and Richard Crenna. The film is much too long, but it brims with back-ground color, and the suspense is well handled - Sunday at 8 P.M. on AMC.

title: Kelly Walters And Steven Feit
description: Kelly J. Walters, the daughter of Vicki Mahaffey of Russells Point, Ohio, and David Walters of Norwood, Ohio, was married yesterday to Steven M. Feit, the son of Patricia and Richard Feit of Flushing, Queens. Karen Blackburn, a lay minister of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), performed the ceremony at the Indian Lake Community Church in Russells Point.

title: Steven the Good
description: Steven Spielberg should give himself more credit for bravery (Stephen J. Dubner, Feb. 14). In 50 or 100 years, we might see that his work has the rare power to remake reality through imagination, to demonstrate that the better parts of human nature can prevail.

title: Lauren Howard, Brian Kaplow
description: Lauren Jill Howard and Brian Andrew Kaplow were married last evening by Rabbi Mitchell Romirowsky at the Colony Club in New York.

title: Before the Buds Break, Get a Jump on Pests
description: GETTING a jump on all the chores ahead means setting priorities, and high on any list should be pest control.

title: BOOKEND; Sweet Chaos, Fat Trip
description: THERE is no more disgruntled pilgrim on Grub Street than an author of a freshly published book. The labor is over but the torment has just begun, as the newborn creature is wrenched untimely from the nest. ''Mind-children,'' Mary McCarthy named the author's progeny. ''Product,'' the industry calls them, or ''stock,'' as in ''signing stock'' at a bookstore ''drop in.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99; Home Wrecked
description: When people get around to discussing Americans' obsession with their homes (and people always do), they inevitably cite the wrong evidence: housing starts up 9.6 percent last year, 66.8 percent of America owning their homes. Studying these statistics, economists try to discern important trends in national consciousness.

title: A Quartet Juggles Life and Art, Gently
description: LIFE is full of crises, to be toiled through or sailed past alone. But they usually don't involve the same four people and their careers, unless the people are members of a group as tightly knit as the Brentano String Quartet.

title: No Rent, But Not Much Of a Ceiling
description: Emily Rolla lives in a sunny five-room apartment at 360 West 47th Street, at Ninth Avenue, and hasn't paid a dime in rent for years. But three weeks ago, Ms. Rolla said, she watched in horror as workers began gutting the six-unit tenement building around her.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  QUINTERO, JOSE
description: QUINTERO-Jose. ''They're waitin' for something they feel is comin'. Something important and great. Aren't they waitin' for the eternal part in them to come out-clear?'' Alexander White

title: A Rider's Plea: Don't Knock Buses
description: I was a regular rider for many years on the Suffolk County bus system (it used to be called the Coram Bus Company), using the bus to get to work in Smithtown, and continuing to use the service when I started working at the State University at Stony Brook. There was a regular group of people who used it to get to work every day. Alas, about seven years ago the county took over the business and took Stony Brook village and St. James off the route because not enough people were using it. I had managed to exist on Long Island for almost 50 years without driving. I still don't drive -- I don't go anywhere! The bus system, as it exists, wouldn't encourage anyone to go anywhere!

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: FREIGHTER FOR LESS -- Ivaran Lines is offering a discount of $1,000 for the second person in a category C outside double cabin on the freighter Americana this spring. The saving is good on three departures -- March 19, April 9 and April 30 -- on a 21-day itinerary, which leaves from Houston and includes Veracruz, Mexico; Puerto Limon, Costa Rica; Cartagena, Colombia; La Guaira, Venezuela, and San Juan, among other ports. The fare in category C, the standard level outside cabin, is $4,914 a person, double occupancy, before the second-person discount. Air fare is extra.

title: Marine Pilot Exonerated In Italian Alps Collision
description: A jury of eight Marine officers took just over seven hours to conclude that when an Marine jet in the Italian alps hit the cables of a gondola system 13 months ago, killing all 20 aboard the skiers' transport, it was an accident, not a crime.

title: Bond Sale
description: The county has sold $75 million in tax anticipation notes at a rate of 2.83 percent. The sale provides the county with funds needed to pay for general operating expenses before the receipt of taxes that have been levied for the 1999 fiscal year. The notes will be repaid by year's end.

title: A High-Tech Purchase Brings an Arrest of 2 Chinese
description: To hear the Chinese tell it, two men arrested in the United States in recent weeks were seeking high-tech gyroscopes for a railroad project.

title: Money Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Go Tickle Elmo
description: Some parents lack the cute gene: Beanie Babies make them cringe, not coo. But even those with tougher taste seem to have a soft spot for Naughty Naughty Kiefer, Vicious French Bulldog and Bite Me Bobo, polar fleece stuffed animals made by Scary Stories. Unlike the usual friendly looking toys, these are snarling, baring their teeth or just looking mischievous. ''They're the baby gift of the moment for the downtown crowd,'' said David Shearer, an owner of Totem Design (71 Franklin Street, at Broadway), which has sold more than 200 of them. Nick Dine, a SoHo furniture designer, has a few dozen of the $24 abstract animals. ''All of our friends have some,'' said Kimbrough Kellison, an investment portfolio manager. She said one friend had her mother and three bridesmaids carry the animals like bouquets at her wedding. ''People get very attached to them,'' Mrs. Kellison said. ''I'm partial to Vicious French Bulldog myself.'' MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Q. & A.
description: Riviera by Yacht

title: Weeks of Bombing Leave Iraq's Power Structure Unshaken
description: Next week, an American diplomat named Frank Ricciardone will take on a new job. His mission is as simple as it is difficult: unify the fractured Iraqi opposition, topple Saddam Hussein and build a democratic nation from the ruins.

title: Effort to Increase Child Immunization Is Under Attack in Idaho
description: Jim Hawkins has a tough time understanding why parents would not immunize their children from preventable diseases like polio and hepatitis.

title: Without a Cause
description: THE SECRET LIVES OF CITIZENS

title: Short-Term Frustration, Long-Term Success
description: HOW now, Dow Theory? This market timing strategy -- based on the synchronism, or lack thereof, of the Dow Jones industrial and transportation averages -- turned bearish last August. Yet it stayed bearish through the 30 percent rally in stocks in the last quarter and has remained that way during this year's market gyrations.

title: Steven the Good
description: What caught my attention was Spielberg's reluctance to produce a film on the life of Charles Lindbergh. Haven't we learned over the past decades that most folk heroes have a darker side?

title: Accept the Changes, Strahan Tells Giants
description: Michael Strahan, the Pro Bowl defensive end who is the Giants' most dominant player, has a message for any teammate miffed at the $5 million signing bonus and $4 million annual salary given to Kerry Collins.

title: 'Hedwig' (Earplugs Are Optional)
description: 'HEDWIG AND THE ANGRY INCH: ORIGINAL CAST RECORDING'

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- Shop Talk; Home Is Where the Faxport Is
description: Sofield: One of the most important things is the ability of somebody to modulate or modify their own environment. Can you adjust the temperature? One thing I love about the great old European hotels is the ability to modulate the light -- you know, with shutters along with a sheer and then an overdrape.

title: Pets Feel Better, Fans Feel Feverish
description: Kevin Fitzgerald was a bouncer for the Rolling Stones when Keith Richards told him to expand his horizons. ''When Keith Richards tells you to get a grip, it's a real eye-opener,'' said Dr. Fitzgerald, who became a veterinarian. Now he's a star with fans of his own on ''Emergency Vet,'' a half-hour program on the Animal Planet cable channel (Sunday at 8:30 P.M. Eastern time, Monday through Thursday at 10 P.M.). Filmed at Alameda East Veterinary Hospital in Denver, ''Emergency Vet'' is a sort of real-life ''E.R.'' with pets for patients, complete with resident hunks who deal with challenges from kennel cough to amputation. Dr. Fitzgerald and Dr. Steven Petersen, a veterinary surgeon with George Clooney good looks (left), receive regular marriage proposals, letters and E-mail from their viewers, who total 46 million. ''They aren't afraid to be tender, and that captures your heart,'' said Monica Rizzo, who profiled Dr. Petersen for People magazine's ''Sexiest Men'' issue in November. ''Dr. Petersen's, like, a hero,'' said Roxanne Baker, 16, of Lubbock, Texas, recalling a time he saved a dog with a condition known as twisted stomach. ''He's so take-charge. He's really calm and level-headed.'' Maureen Onofrio, 40, a fan in West Haven, Conn., recently confessed her crush on Dr. Fitzgerald to her husband. ''Kevin has an emotional maturity that I find extremely sexy,'' she said. ''It's flattering,'' Dr. Fitzgerald said. ''But we're just vets. Rock stars get sexy pictures of supermodels. We get Polaroids of women with their tarantulas.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Job-Saving Plan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has started the second round of his ''Power for Jobs'' program by announcing that 615 jobs will be created and 19,697 protected under new allocations of low-cost electricity recommended by the State Economic Development Power Allocation Board.

title: Always an Antihero With a Streetwise Touch of Crass
description: WHEN asked, he would say the ''G'' stood for Goldenberg, the name under which Edward G. Robinson was born in Bucharest, Romania, on Dec. 12, 1893.

title: Iverson Learning It's Not All Ego
description: For Allen Iverson, Philadelphia freedom once meant driving the length of the court, and then using the defense and his teammates for pylons. He would score spectacularly and often. But the 76ers would invariably drop another game, after which Iverson would shrug his shoulders and exclaim, ''What more do you want me to do?''

title: Where Public Housing Meets the American Dream
description: CAROLYN BELLAMY, standing near a large bay window in the living room of her brand new two-story house in Bridgeport, is trying to decide where to put her television set when she moves in later this month.

title: Those Vanishing References
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, EDITH C.
description: WOLFSON-Edith C. On March 4, 1999, born in Budapest, extraordinary woman of indomitable spirit. Precious wife of Cyril of NYC, cherished mother of John Varsa of Albuquerque & Susanne Moore of NYC, grandmother of Sabrina Absera of Negril and Toronto, Sali Moore of St. Paul, great-grandmother of Ariel, Nestor and Davianna & aunt of Agnes Bakondi of NY. Service Sunday, March 7, at 1 P.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Inc., NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: The Mad Movie Season Called Oscar; Using the Hard Sell To Grab the Gold
description: SIX months ago, Steven Spielberg's ''Saving Private Ryan,'' was virtually anointed by Hollywood as the winner of the Academy Award. How could the 5,500 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences vote against one of the most acclaimed films of Mr. Spielberg's career, a searing and patriotic drama about World War II soldiers, a movie that unexpectedly turned into a huge box office hit for its studios, Dreamworks and Paramount?

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- Word & Image; And the Winner Should Be . . .
description: R.I.P., Monica, it's Oscar's month. Celebrity-worshipers the world over will gather at the vernal equinox to celebrate a springtime of life -- as defined by movies.

title: Maison de Sade Gets a Whipping
description: La Maison de Sade calls itself a French supper club, with a twist. Along with dinner and drinks, patrons can select from a menu of S-and-M activities, like a spanking from waiters and a humiliating seat in a high chair. But the restaurant, at 206 West 23d Street near Seventh Avenue, has come under the lash lately from the local community board, which says residents have complained about the place. The issue, the board says, is not what goes on inside, but the noise and the crowds.

title: POSTINGS: More Unbelievable Rents; Studios for $10,000 a Month
description: Mack-Cali Realty, a Cranford, N.J.-based real estate investment trust, is building its first office building in Westchester County since taking over the 4 million-square-foot office portfolio of the former Robert Martin Company in 1997.

title: Signs That Point Anew to Spring And Its Awakening
description: GEORGE MAGNUSON, a software engineer from Mount Kisco, came out with his walking stick, a pair of well-worn hiking boots and an optimism that winter would soon end. At ''50 plus and holding strong,'' as he put it, he strode con brio down the trails of Cranberry Lake Preserve here last weekend in search of signs of spring.

title: Dench Every Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCATO, FRANK M.
description: BLANCATO-Frank M., prominent attorney in Westchester County, New York, passed away at his home in Peekskill, New York, on March 3, 1999, after a long illness. He attended New York University and St. John's Law School. He served as a Company Commander in Korea at the Demilitarized Zone in 1962 and 1963. He was a retired Officer from the United States Army and received a Bronze Star. He practiced in Westchester, Rockland, and Dutchess Counties and in the Bronx, Manhattan, and Brooklyn. He had a distinguished career as a trial lawyer, with numerous criminal trials to his credit. Mr. Blancato was past-president of the Peekskill Board of Education, the Peekskill Bar Association, and the Salvation Army of Peekskill; served on the Peekskill Zoning Board, on the advisory board of HUD, and on the advisory board of the Peekskill Drug Abuse task force. Mr. Blancato was the original legal counsel for the Peekskill Police Federation and Aunt Bessie's Open Door. He also served as judge for moot court at his alma mater, St. John's Law School. In 1968, he was a Mayoral Candidate in Peekskill. He was born and raised in Peekskill, attended local schools before enrolling at New York University. He is survived by his wife, Diana, of Peekskill; a son, Philippe, of Wallingford, CT; a brother, Jerry, sister-in-law, Susanne, and two nephews, of Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: Give Vouchers a Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALIHAN, ANASTICIA
description: MALIHAN-Anasticia. Of Staten Island on March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Gaudencio. Loving mother of Adelaide, Gilbert, Minda, Joseph Malihan, Mary Schutte, Amie Malihan, Flora Laserna and Teresa Malihan. Also survived and loved by nine grandchildren. Fond sister of Ernesto Alvarez and the late Andrela. Funeral from The Handley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Staten Island, Wednesday 8:30AM. Mass Holy Family Church 9:45AM. Burial Moravian Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 P.M. Sunday.

title: A Notion, Not a Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, GERDA GERNSHEIM, PH.D.
description: MAYER - Gerda Gernsheim, Ph.D., on March 2, 1999 in her 91st year. Born Worms, Germany. Beloved wife of the late Mor Mayer. Sister of the late Hildegard Gernsheim Mayer. Cherished cousin. Long time medical researcher in New York City at Mount Sinai and Columbia Presbyterian Hospitals. Private services were held.

title: Pleasures That Await in Parks: Hikes, Wildlife and Flotsam
description: HERE is a sampling of the activities and cleanup programs that are scheduled in the next few weeks at the county's parks.

title: What Wine Goes Best With the 5:24 to Katonah?
description: Wines for the hurrying commuter may now be bought in Grand Central Terminal at Grande Harvest Wines, across the Main Concourse from Track 17. The shop's 25-foot domed ceiling and murals have been refurbished to their original splendor. The owner, Bruce Nevins, has tapped into the trend of demystifying wine buying and promises that his store will not perpetuate wine snobbery. Customers are waited on by staff who will try to match wines, with the help of daily tastings, to individual preferences. Most selections comes from lesser-known California and Italian vineyards, like Schug, Cosentino and Whitehall Lane. Also represented are France, Spain, Australia and South Africa, and there is a collection of single-malt Scotches. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Cure for Financially Ailing Medical Center Seems Elusive
description: New York Flushing Hospital Medical Center is ailing, and last week administrators from other hospitals, lawyers, union officials and a creditors committee were racing to meet a deadline and find a cure.

title: City Takes Ball Fields In Dispute On Care
description: Bulldozers were moving 15,000 cubic yards of earth last week on city-owned ball fields in College Point. But while things are moving forward, new conflicts are arising over the future of the fields, which have been embroiled in controversy for 17 months.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Cramming in New York City; What Makes People Stuff Their Most Treasured Possessions Into a Storage Locker?
description: Angela Wilson, artist, in her 50's

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Deer Park, N.Y.; A Suffolk Hamlet of Modest Homes
description: DEER PARK, a middle-income community in western Suffolk County, offers a straightforward bargain to home buyers, with nothing fancy.

title: Mets Need to Review '92 to Pass Chemistry Test
description: If the Mets have not learned from history, are they doomed to repeat it? That is a question hovering over their heads as the Mets try to meld a new group of name players into a cohesive unit and avoid the kind of meltdown that scuttled the 1992 team, which was bolstered by a series of bold moves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, HERBERT
description: AXELROD-Herbert of Fort Lee. Beloved husband of Georgine. Devoted father of Dr. Laurel Spielberg (Dr. Stephen), Sherry Greenwald, William Axelrod (Esther). Dear brother of Vivian Zaretsky and 13 grandchildren. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood, New Jersey, Sunday, 12 noon.

title: Mexico Safety
description: To the Editor: I want to discuss the Correspondent's Report ''New Questions on Safety in Mexico Are Raised'' (Jan. 31). My husband and I have been to Mexico three times, mostly to visit Maya ruins. We've driven over 2,000 miles. Last year was the first time we felt in any danger -- we were in Chiapas 10 days after the massacre of indigenous people at Acteal.

title: Bahrain Emir Dies in Palace After Meeting On U.S. Arms
description: The Emir of Bahrain, a key American ally in the Persian Gulf region, collapsed and died today at the age of 65 after a meeting with visiting Defense Secretary William S. Cohen.

title: Spring Baroque Festival at School
description: IT has probably been 50 years since the revival of interest in Baroque music took hold in the United States, and for most of those five decades the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale has led the way with a Spring Baroque Festival. The 34th celebration, which begins next Saturday at 8 P.M. in North Yonkers Community Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, expands the horizons to encompass several works by Beethoven.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 7, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The Bigger the Dream, The Harder the Fall; Costly Lessons for Modest Developer Who Bet It All on an East Side Block
description: It began as just another apartment building. Seventeen stories, 111 units. East Side of Manhattan. Big deal. This was in 1985.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them; Rules of Conformity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Voice Finds Its Style Plays on the Island
description: WHEN Norman Mailer, Dan Wolf and Ed Fancher founded The Village Voice in Greenwich Village in 1955, they hardly envisioned that their small offbeat paper, at a nickel a copy, would spawn a national industry.

title: Dole Returns From Rebels Without Assent to Kosovo Accord
description: The Clinton Administration's hope of moving the Kosovo peace plan much closer to completion was frustrated again today when its special emissary to the ethnic Albanians, former Senator Bob Dole, told Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright here that he had failed to clinch a deal with the separatists.

title: Veronica Cassidy, John Barry Jr.
description: Veronica Marie Cassidy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cassidy of Belle Harbor, Queens, was married yesterday to John Paul Barry Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Louis Trotta, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Mariners Memorial Chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, N.Y. Msgr. Hugh McManus, a cousin of the bride, took part in the service.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Methods to Bond Wood to Concrete
description: TRYING to attach furring strips or other wood members to a concrete surface might seem like a difficult, almost impossible task. There are, however, a number of fasteners available today that make the job easier. Having the right fastener is only part of the job. You also need to use the right tools. Ordinary woodworking tools are too light, and steel drill bits are too soft for concrete work.

title: Life Lessons About Blacks, Cars and the Police
description: Herman Snyder 3d, who grew up in this racially diverse community, is a 20-year-old industrial psychology student at Hampton University in Virginia whose father is a vice president of a pharmaceutical company and whose mother is a pharmaceutical broker. He has never been arrested or convicted of a crime.

title: In Language Sung Best By Its Own
description: IT should be no surprise that Americans heavily populate foreign opera companies. The soprano from Indiana University is usually better educated than a lot of her counterparts elsewhere. Her voice is healthy by virtue of what is coming to be known in the world as the American technique of singing. She can negotiate three or four languages. Most likely, she has played the piano since prepubescence. Italy, as a voice teacher from Lucca once told me, has relatively few pianos, much less people who learn music from playing them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORRANCE, DICK
description: DORRANCE-Dick. Accomplished writer, advertising executive, Dartmouth graduate '36, died February 19th at home in Goiania, Brazil. He was 85. During his long professional career, he was Director of Promotion for the CBS Radio Stations, founder of the first FM broadcasters trade organization and principal of Dorrance and Company, advertising and trade promotion specialists. He is survived by his wife Abadia, a son, daughter-in-law, daughter, and four granddaughters.

title: A Problem for H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eternal Challenge of Euclid's Geometry
description: AROUND 300 B.C., Euclid wrote the book on geometry. Twenty-three centuries later, two 14-year-old students in Westport may have rewritten a chapter; they discovered an alternate solution to one of the ancient mathematician's classic theoems. During the summer of 1995 while working for extra credit in an accelerated math course at Greens Farms Academy in Westport, David Goldenheim and Dan Litchfield stumbled on an original approach to equal partitioning, a corollary to Proposition 10 in the sixth book of ''Elements,'' the 13-volume work on mathematics that Euclid created. Given a line of any length, Euclid presents a universal geometric method for subdividing it into any number of equal parts.

title: Boy, 14, Is Killed, And 11-Year-Old Is Shot
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot and killed yesterday afternoon as he walked down the street in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Washington Talk; Fixing Social Security, Even in the Flush Times
description: Without any changes, the Social Security system will remain solvent well into the next century. So why are the politicians here, who normally put off difficult decisions as long as possible, tackling the subject now in the absence of a crisis?

title: Foes With Mud in Their Eye
description: Unless New York Harbor's shipping channels are regularly cleared of sediment and deepened to accommodate today's giant container ships, the port will clog up like a congested lung. The question is, where should all that harbor mud, some of it contaminated, be deposited after it has been dredged?

title: Club's Barge Anchored in Limbo
description: Across the Hudson, the Manhattan Yacht Club's 85-foot barge is stuck in limbo: a place known to club members as Jersey City. The commodore of the 320-member yacht club, Michael Fortenbaugh, wants the barge to be ferried to Manhattan's Pier 25 for the spring sailing season so that it can be used as a clubhouse, office and classroom.

title: Delicious, Decadent Shades of Blue for Summer
description: GARDENERS with a weakness for blue know annual lobelia well. It is a low-growing plant, rarely more than four to six inches tall with a foot-wide spread, and it's covered with clouds of exquisitely formed tiny blossoms from late spring until frost.

title: From China, Pictures And Ancient Rocks
description: FOR all the differences America has with China over political and trade issues, there's an avid interest in Chinese art and artifacts in the United States. More than a concerted craze like the King Tut mania of the early 1920's the interest is widespread. In Connecticut now are a couple of exhibitions of things Chinese that are also diverse, educational and challenging.

title: Mets' Nomo Is Experiencing A Wild Time
description: Publicly, the Mets say that Hideo Nomo's control is back to where it was a few years ago.

title: On Call With the Highway Patrol
description: THE best way to avoid becoming a traffic statistic, according to Charles F. Richmond of the Connecticut Department of Transportation, is to check your tires before a trip. All five.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITT, ELIZABETH NORTON
description: SCHMITT - Elizabeth Norton. March 4, 1999. Loving daughter of the late Philip Schmitt, Jr. and the late Mary Pearl Norton. Beloved aunt of Rosemarie S. Vietor and her husband Richard and great aunt of Abigail Vietor and Samuel Nicholls, III. Service Monday 11AM, March 8, St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street.

title: Before Titles, 'Cosi' Became 'Women Are Like That'
description: MANY Mozart experts and opera buffs will no doubt dismiss a recent release of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' from Sony Classical with a knowing huff. It is a reissue of a 1952 recording, with Fritz Stiedry conducting the orchestra and chorus of the Metropolitan Opera Association, as it was then called (Masterworks Heritage MH2K 60652; two CD's).

title: Balkan Ghosts
description: With ethnic violence in Kosovo, and politicians warning that NATO will need to occupy Bosnia for years to come, it seems to many Americans that a durable peace in the Balkans is a hopeless goal. The conflicts stem from ancient hatreds, people say. They can be buried for years or decades, but they always return.

title: Feeling a Little Creative? Just Follow Directions
description: THE avant-garde's steadfast devotion to the new has given rise to waves of inventive movements, from Cubism to Dada to Surrealism to Abstract Expressionism. Along the way, it has experimented with the making of art from instructions -- a conceit that forms the foundation of ''Do It,'' a traveling exhibition with concurrent installations at five museums throughout the state.

title: His Old Kentucky Home
description: OUT OF THE WOODSStories.By Chris Offutt.172 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMLYN, GEORGE S. JR.
description: TAMLYN-George S. Jr. Of Chatham Township, New Jersey, and Longboat Key, FL. on March 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Faye Nall Tamlyn. Devoted father of Mrs. Cynthia Snow of Malvern, PA; Mrs. Janeth Dowton of Trumbull, CT; Mrs. Patricia Greubel of Newburgh, IN., and George S. Tamlyn, III of Berwyn, PA. Brother of Bruce O. of Lakewood. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the William. A.
