Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, (Route 124), Chatham, N.J., on Monday, March 8, 1999 at 11AM. Friends may call Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Scott Gordon, Stacy Bowers
description: Stacy Meredith Bowers and Scott Benjamin Gordon were married last evening in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated at Estherwood, a historic house.

title: Melissa Steinfeld, Lawrence Galett
description: Melissa Ilene Steinfeld, a daughter of Dr. Philip Steinfeld of East Rockaway, N.Y., and the late Ruth Steinfeld, was married last evening to Lawrence Sanford Galett, the son of Rita and Martin Galett of Manhattan. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Hard Copy
description: WHO'S HOT/WHO'S NOT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, ALLAN H.
description: KUHN-Allan H. On March 4, 1999. Husband of the late Dorothy S. Kuhn and the late Elizabeth M. Kuhn. Father of Stephen D. (Ferne) Kuhn and Lawrence (Barbara Shoulson) Kuhn. Brother of Carol (James) Goldwater. Grandfather of five and great-grandfather of two. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dorothy S. Kuhn Endowment Fund, c/ o Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia, 226 South 16th St, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

title: A New Gaffe, And Mounties Put the Force Under Inquiry
description: A casino license awarded in British Columbia last December has set off two sensitive police investigations. One led to a raid on the home of the province's Premier, Glen Clark, by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The other is forcing the Mounties to look at themselves.

title: West's Bosnia Move May Hurt Kosovo Bid
description: Just before peace talks on Kosovo are due to resume, the United States and its allies are sending contradictory signals to Belgrade, making it less likely that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia will capitulate on American terms.

title: A Hint of Spring
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Young Entrepreneurs, A Step Past the Classroom
description: MOST every day after school and on weekends, Federica Bautista, 18, sells fruit, vegetables and flowers from a pushcart stationed at the entrance to Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens. When it's cold outside, she takes delivery orders by telephone at her home, a two-bedroom apartment she shares with seven relatives. Her weekly earnings of $100 to $150 on sales of $400 help support her widowed mother and her 2-year-old son, Abraham.

title: London Restaurants Show Off With Bargains
description: Having recognized that London, for some time now, has become a worthwhile destination for dining, the London Tourist Board has organized a yearlong restaurant promotion. It starts Friday with the city's first Restaurant Week, to run through March 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARZMAN, ADELE
description: SWARZMAN-Adele. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Adele Swarzman, beloved mother of our devoted members Phyllis and Harold Stock. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; Anna, of Siam Fame, Was a Staten Islander
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HARRY
description: MERESMAN-Harry. Died on March 3rd, 1999 at the age of 88. Beloved husband of the late Helen Chafets Meresman, devoted father of Helaine Meresman Barnett and the late Janis Meresman Goldman, adored grandfather of Craig and Jennifer Barnett, Roger Barnett, Melissa Goldman, Lori and Brett Zbar, great-grandfather of Gabriel Barnett, father-in-law extraordinaire to Victor Barnett and Michael Goldman, loving son, brother, brother-in-law, uncle and loyal, trusted and respected friend. A man whose unquestioned integrity, ethics and morality were his hallmarks and his devotion to his family, commitment to his community and his pride in his profession were his passions. The high standards by which he lead his life and his impeccable reputation will remain to all who knew him as his everlasting legacy.

title: WINES UNDER $20
description: New Zealand's vocation is sauvignon blanc, in a portfolio of styles. Mills Reef's 1996 edition represents a pungent strain customarily described as green, gooseberry, herbaceous or veggie. A more potent partner with asparagus, which usually doesn't like wine, and string beans is hard to imagine.

title: Bridging Goldman's Gender Gap
description: This is an iconoclastic time at Goldman, Sachs & Company. The 130-year old investment bank recently broke one long tradition when it decided to end its partnership and go public. Now it's breaking another: the male-dominated executive suite. The firm announced on Friday that two women, Robin Neustein and Leslie Tortora, would join the management committee, the top executive group.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: LILA SAYS

title: The View From/Yonkers; Priest Pushes His World Beyond One of Silence
description: IN strictly literal terms, the world is a silent place for the Rev. Thomas Coughlin, a deaf priest who lives on a tree-lined street in this city's northwest corner. But in action and spirit and determination, Father Coughlin is anything but silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, ALLEN
description: WARDWELL - Allen. Christie's pays tribute to the memory and scholarship of our esteemed colleague Allen Wardwell. We mourn his loss and extend our condolences to his family.

title: The Nation; What a Difference A Scandal Makes
description: LAST week the Clinton Administration completed a remarkable turnaround in its thinking about the independent counsel law.

title: Trump in Running For Grumman Site
description: The former Northrop-Grumman site at Calverton went from white elephant to hot property last week when Donald Trump was reported to have offered the Town of Riverhead $55 million for nearly all of the 2,900-acre site. Mr. Trump plans to build an automobile race track, a golf resort and an industrial park, according to Richard Seely, vice chairman of Grubb & Ellis New York, a real estate concern hired by the town to sell the property.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Jan. 31, about San Juan, gave an incomplete name for a hotel in the Isla Verde beach district, described as probably the liveliest hotel at night. It is the Wyndham El San Juan Hotel and Casino, not just El San Juan Hotel and Casino.

title: New EZ-Pass Problems Prompt Fears of More Delays
description: Already delayed for months, New Jersey's EZ-Pass electronic highway toll-collection system may be facing yet more setbacks that have officials questioning whether it will be running on the turnpike and parkway by the new target date of February 2000, or if it is even worth staying with the company hired to install it.

title: Full Rescue Mission For Cod Is Discussed
description: At the beginning of this century, New England's cod fishery was dominated by dorymen fishing with baited hooks. When the Bay State Fishing Company introduced the first trawler, the Spray, in 1905, the dorymen railed against it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERN, HARRIET
description: VERN-Harriet, 81. Died peacefully in Orlando, FL., after a long illness on February 26, 1999. Predeceased by her husband, magazine photographer, Ike Vern, on February 23rd, 1987, and her son, Andrew Vern, December 17, 1977. She was a passionate feminist, fighter for human rights, innovator and teacher in the field of psychiatric social work. She is survived by her loving daughter, Jane Vern, Box 602, Kent, CT. 06757, and her halfbrother Bruce Weber of Silver Springs, Maryland.

title: Commercial Property / Great River, Long Island; From Defense Technology to High Technology
description: NOT surprisingly, William Rudin sees parallels between Rudin Management Company's pioneering high-tech building at 55 Broad Street in lower Manhattan and his high-tech joint venture with Cogswell Realty Group that is about to open in an old Northrop Grumman building here on Long Island..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDLAW, CHARLES H.R. JR.
description: WARDLAW-Charles H.R. Jr. On March 4, 1999. Of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Priscilla. Loving father of Christopher and Robert. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, Christ Episcopal Church, Garden City. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Christ Episcopal Church, Garden City, are appreciated.

title: Winter's Urban Plumage
description: Could these men be signaling the first hairline crack in the wall of somber New York business coats? The coats here, in primary and pastel hues, are worlds apart from their inspiration, the colorful active sportswear that arrived in the office with dress-down Fridays. The acceptance of change in men's dress has always relied on a few Beau Brummells. Their antennae are the highest, tuned in to the wavelengths of a new idea decades before most men's, and they dare to wear it.

title: Crew Softens Threat to Quit Over Vouchers
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who last week vowed to resign if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani pushed ahead with a plan to use tax dollars to finance private-school tuition, said yesterday that he would not quit if the plan were administered by City Hall rather than by the Board of Education.

title: More on Brundage And the '36 Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Going Domestic in Taipei; Newlyweds Relish Setting Up Their First Homes . . . and Dreaming About the Next
description: When the Taiwanese couple Tseng Tzu-hsien and Liao Li-jung were married two months ago, they arranged to have a photographer document the ceremony. Rather than place an album of pictures on a coffee table in their small Taipei apartment, however, the couple covered the walls of their place with poster-size images commemorating the big day. Such outsize portraits (costing the equivalent of one month of the couple's combined $2,800-a-month income) have been faddish on the island since the late-80's economic bubble propelled Taiwanese couples to heights of extravagance -- and turned untold numbers of Taipei apartments into wedding shrines.

title: So Far, Steinbrenner Has a Silent Spring
description: At another time, in an earlier season, George Steinbrenner would have fumed.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: I have learned as a pediatrician, mother and grandmother that there are five things parents cannot make their children do: eat, poop, fall asleep, be happy and turn out the way we dream they will. I suppose the ultimate authoritarian advice would include force-feeding and using a 2-by-4 at bedtime instead of ''Goodnight Moon.''

title: Prints With All the Sweep of Their Century
description: 'Engaging Impressions: 20th-Century Prints'

title: Ideas & Trends; PBS: Clinging to a Disappearing Niche
description: UNTIL just the other day, ''contentious'' was not a word associated with ''Washington Week in Review,'' the solid or stolid weekly PBS get-together of mainstream journalists who never raised their voices in disagreement. While over at the cable stations, a gabble of strong-lunged television personalities were making reputations with passionate encounters over the latest crowd-pleaser, ''Washington Week'' kept doing what seemed in the cable commotion to come unnaturally, reporting on subjects of consequence that its panelists knew something about.

title: After Climbing So Many Mountains, a Ski Resort Giant Stumbles
description: IT was a bold strategy: Buy like mad, build like mad, pay for it with an initial stock offering and a lot of borrowed money, and pray that the snow -- and the customers -- would keep coming.

title: Cable Fares Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Comfort
description: NINE BELOW ZERO

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 21 about the awarding of the 1936 Olympic Games to Berlin referred incorrectly to the death of Edgar Fried, an Austrian Olympic official. Mr. Fried died in Austria in 1987 at the age of 92, not in a concentration camp during the war.

title: Geopolitical Animals
description: ABOUT FACEA History of America's Curious Relationship With China, From Nixon to Clinton.By James Mann.Illustrated. 433 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: When Your Rival Is Also The Referee
description: WHEN Wall Street competitors start growling and snapping at one another, the safest place for the general public is usually a good block away. As the folks down home would say, we probably don't have a dog in that fight.

title: Marla Berman, Ricardo Lewitus
description: Marla Ann Berman, an associate general counsel at Citigroup in New York, is to be married this morning to Dr. Ricardo Lewitus, a pediatrician in Marlborough, Mass. Rabbi Gerald Friedman is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Feb. 21 about the death of a 12-year-old skier at the Mountain Creek ski area in Vernon misstated the availability of protective helmets there. They are sold, but are not available for rental this season, according to Ingrid Campbell, director of marketing for Mountain Creek; she said rentals would be available next winter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FAY, VALLE WEBER
description: FAY-Valle Weber March 5, 1919-St. Louis, Missouri January 22, 1997-Norwalk, Connecticut

title: The View From/Guilford; Lessons in Restoration From a 17th-Century House
description: PICTURE a compact, attractive stone house with matching chimneys, a steeply sloping roof and leaded windows with diamond-shaped panes built in 1639 and 1640. And when the dwelling, now the Whitfield House Museum in Guilford was named a National Historic Landmark last year, it was because of its significance to the historic preservation movement in the United States.

title: What Slump? Huskies Dissect Red Storm
description: They have been called too soft, too slow and too distracted on their way to becoming the most maligned 28-2 team in college basketball. So the Connecticut Huskies last night decided to answer back swiftly, emphatically and in unison.

title: Where History Stopped By
description: ONCE a major refueling stop for ships traveling between the North and South Atlantic, the Cape Verde archipelago is little known to most tourists. Around 350 miles off the coast of Senegal in the Atlantic Ocean, the republic's nine inhabited volcanic islands vary from flat and sandy to toweringly craggy to lushly semitropical, or combine all those characteristics.

title: Blaming the Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Goldberg, Hal Samuelson
description: Jessica Robin Goldberg, the daughter of Julia Miller of Colts Neck, N.J., and Marc Goldberg of Ocean, N.J., was married last evening to Hal Richard Samuelson, the son of Adele and Harvey Samuelson of Port Washington, N.Y. Rabbi Serge Lippe performed the ceremony at the Park Savoy, a caterer in Florham Park, N.J.

title: Black Unlike Me
description: Wolff needs to lighten up about her son's wardrobe. At age 7, kids, black and white, begin to exercise a degree of autonomy through their taste in clothes. An oversize jersey with a sports hero's number is a harmless statement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTWEIN, HENRY
description: ALTWEIN-Henry. On March 4, 1999, beloved husband of Claire. Dear brother of Siegfried Altwein and Helena Frischer. Loving uncle and good friend. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Some Advice for Mr. Gates: Have Your Day in Court
description: Both sides in the Microsoft trial have retreated to their corners until mid-April, when the antitrust battle will resume in a Washington courtroom. Then, both the Government and Microsoft will have the opportunity to call a couple of rebuttal witnesses.

title: Censure Merited
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. The Senior Program Officer of the American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR), died Monday, Jan. 4, 1999. A Memorial will be held on Saturday, Mar. 13th at 4pm in the auditorium at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St. A reception in the Social Hall will follow at 5pm. RSVP to 212-806-1798

title: Laughter on the 23d Floor, Or Anywhere Else
description: In the right hands, humor can be an invaluable capitalist tool. It can break tension, restore perspective and promote creative thinking. How have you used humor to solve a problem or wriggle out of a tough situation? Or how did your attempt backfire? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Whistling Their Own Tunes; If Not a Railroad Flat, What Was It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, HERBERT E.
description: MEYER-Herbert E. Age 86. Died of cancer March 3, 1999 in New York. He was a lover of music and a passionate Chef. Following a career trading commodities, he created the food company, Gala Delicacies, and befriended Chefs from Chinatown to the Waldorf. Since the death of his wife, Marjorie in 1986, he was a flaneur in N.Y., the delight of dinner parties as host and guest. He leaves three children: John A. of Manhattan, Priscilla A. of Middletown, Ct., Christopher A. of Lexington, Ma., and two granddaughters: Rachel Trousdale and Miranda Meyer. A Musico-Epicurean celebration will be held in May.

title: Making a Connection With O'Neill
description: IT was only 50 miles away, seemingly even a shorter distance on a Saturday morning, but who wouldn't call it a pilgrimage?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILAZOLLA, ROCCO
description: FILAZOLLA-Rocco. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Rocco Filazolla, associated with The Times from 1969 until retiring in 1978.

title: To Sell a Guidebook, a Dose of Attitude
description: MATTHEW MATLACK and Daniel Greenstein, two juniors at Columbia University, knew it would take some New York hustle to get their student-written guide to the city on bookstore shelves. But ambushing the chairman of a major bookseller after a shareholders meeting was not the initial plan.

title: Who Would Wager on a Hobbled Pony?
description: WHEN you're hot in retailing, you're hot. And when you're not, you're not. But with retail stocks, it's different: When you're not hot, perhaps you really are.

title: A New Leader Is Elected in Nigeria
description: Nigeria chose a former military ruler, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, to lead its first civilian Government in 16 years, hoping to put an end to one of the darkest periods in Africa's most populous nation.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; Ninaninaninaninanina
description: Al Hirschfeld sold his first published drawing (of the French actor Sacha Guitry) to The New York Herald Tribune in 1926. The next year, his drawing of Sir Harry Lauder, the Scottish vaudeville singer, was published in The New York Times, the beginning of a relationship that has lasted ever since. As he says in HIRSCHFELD ON LINE (Applause, $49.95), he has learned to draw in the dark with a pencil stub in his pocket, in a kind of shorthand only he can decipher: hair can be Brillo, corn silk or cue ball; eyes can be fried eggs; noses can be dots; mouths can be caverns, dots, slits. Later in his studio, seated in his trademark barber chair, Hirschfeld distills the essence of a personality, be it an actor, a singer, a dancer, a musician, a conductor, a political figure, a comedian or a literary icon. ''Hirschfeld on Line'' contains more than 400 drawings, paintings and photographs, augmented by Hirschfeld's own joyous, illuminating and often droll commentary. Mel Gussow contributes an engaging biography of the artist, and there are lively essays by Arthur Miller, Kurt Vonnegut, Grace Mirabella, Whoopi Goldberg and Hirschfeld's daughter, Nina, who discusses what it's like to be a ''name'' -- her father first introduced his daughter's name in a poster (''Nina the Wonder Child'') that appeared in the background of an illustration of ''Are You With It?,'' an otherwise forgettable musical that opened the day she was born in 1945. ''This little folly was, over the decades, to turn into a monster,'' Hirschfeld writes. ''I am now incapable of discontinuing the process.'' In 1960, he began adding a numeral to his Chinese-choplike signature to disclose the number of times ''Nina'' appeared in that drawing. Finding them, by then a readers' ritual, was also considered (to Hirschfeld's astonishment) by the Pentagon as a means of testing the ability of Air Force pilot trainees to detect targets. A piece on his working methods is contributed by Louise Kerz Hirschfeld, the ''darling wife'' to whom this book is dedicated. Leila Hadley

title: Two Essences Of Granada
description: THE news from North Africa is not good. Algeria operates as a civilian slaughterhouse, Libya a university for terrorism. Morocco struggles with separatists over the Western Sahara; Ethiopia lives with endless revolution.

title: Nets Need New Heart To Save the Season
description: When the undisputed worst team in the Eastern Conference was run off its home floor by a banged-up and bad Charlotte Hornets team Thursday night, an annual rite of winter returned to the Meadowlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUBER, LUDWIG
description: KLAUBER-Ludwig. Of New York City on March 5, 1999. Loving husband of the late Alice. Dear father of Roger & Hilde. Grandfather of Gordon & Rosemary, Mark & Judy. Great-grandfather to Norbert & Sonia, Lily, Joshua and Maya. He was the founder of Klauber Bros. Inc. Services Monday, March 8, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wielding His Magic Touch With Flowers
description: FORCING plants to bloom in March instead of May is not a problem most backyard gardeners worry about. Deciding whether to plant hostas or hydrangeas or stick to hardy impatiens can usually wait until spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, JOHN A.
description: PARKER-John A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of associated with The Times from 1963 until retiring in 1981.

title: The Right Pace in San Antonio
description: TEXANS like their weekends, whether it's bobbing around in a bass boat in East Texas, promenading along the strand in Galveston or riding the trail on a Hill Country dude ranch. But San Antonio has got to be the king of the weekend.

title: Independent Listening At a Music Cooperative
description: A music emporium called Sound and Fury, with an emphasis on independent record labels, opened on Monday on the Lower East Side. At 192 Orchard Street (between Houston and Stanton Streets), it is owned by Peter Jacobson, a 26-year-old Reed College graduate who, after listing his music credentials (was a deejay on college radio, worked at Kim's Underground on Bleecker Street and plays drums), remarked, ''It feels like I've been involved with this stuff forever.''

title: Cape Cod Towns Build Fund to Control Land Development
description: A half mile east of Quaker Meeting House Road and just south of the Midcape Highway are two well-paved roads that lead to nothing, a situation that delights Sandwich town officials.

title: Political Memo; Milk Prices Put Parties in Odd Roles
description: There was a rally earlier this week to support dairy farmers, a bloc as politically influential in upstate New York as it is economically beleaguered. Gov. George E. Pataki and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, delivered stirring speeches about the need for a system to help the industry avoid market swoons -- or ''minimize the price swings,'' as Mr. Pataki artfully put it.

title: Justice Blackmun, Off the Record
description: For a long time now, because of a promise I made to a formidable old man who announced that he was speaking off the record and then gazed levelly at me and said, ''And I'm talking to you,'' I have guarded like a small secret a set of handwritten notes from two summer encounters in the Colorado Rockies.

title: The World; Why Japan Is Rooting For China
description: LAST year, Japan seemed to bite its lip as it watched China's economy continue to boom. Japan was suffering its worst slowdown in more than half a century, and its rival was the only Asian country to survive the Asian economic crisis with its reputation enhanced. Commentators made invidious comparisons between Chinese decisiveness and Japan's inability to confront its economic problems.

title: A Landmark Reopens, Restored With Love
description: THE Trenton War Memorial, lovingly renovated and restored, has emerged from years of decline followed by years of darkness. It reopened in January with Governor Whitman's annual address to a joint session of the State Legislature, but rededication events begin today.

title: The Great Outdoors Comes Inside in L.A.
description: IN Southern California, a buffet of geographic delights, there are rarely reasons to venture indoors, especially to see images of what's outside, even when what's outside isn't there any more. But right now, an exhibition at the Laguna Art Museum offers stiff competition not only to nature, but also to the van Gogh fever that has swept the town with the display of the master's work at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. And for those who never get outside anyway, an exhibit at the Orange County Museum of Arts gallery at the South Coast Plaza mall in Costa Mesa provides a small-scale memorial to the power of place.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: STOPPING FOR GREEN LIGHTSBy Alyce Miller.Doubleday, $23.95.

title: A New Plan to Sell Waste Uranium
description: For as long as the United States has been running nuclear reactors and building nuclear bombs, it has been accumulating depleted uranium, which is natural uranium with the most useful kind, uranium-235, mostly taken out. All of it is in a chemical compound that gives off toxic gas when exposed to water, and it is stored in more than 50,000 steel canisters in various stages of rusting away.

title: A Violist Who Refuses to Be Hamstrung
description: BRAHMS: CLARINET QUINTET (ARR. BASHMET); SHOSTAKOVICH: STRING QUARTET NO. 13 (ARR. A. TCHAIKOVSKY)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOSTER, AMOS E.
description: GLOSTER-Amos E. (of Rockville Centre, New York) Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of the late John Gloster. Loving brother of Helen and Vincent Richards, Charles and Muriel Gloster. Cherished uncle of Robert, Susan and David. Graveside services Sunday 11AM. at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Flushing, NY. For more information contact ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'', 718-284-1500.

title: Steven the Good
description: Spielberg is a great entertainer, but a great filmmaker he is not. He wants to please so much that he lacks the guts to be a risk taker.

title: U.N. to Use Peace Prize Money for Monument to Peacekeepers
description: Almost 11 years after winning the Nobel Peace Prize for its peacekeeping efforts in trouble spots around the world, the United Nations has finally decided to spend the money on a monument commemorating all peacekeepers who lose their lives on duty and has invited Sweden and Norway to help select a design.

title: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Sharing Space in Brooklyn; 15 People, One Loft
description: In August 1993, Beth Rollins, Morgan Meis and five friends rented part of the second floor of a former factory warehouse next to the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The 1,800-square-foot space with 14-foot ceilings, for which they paid $1,000 per month, had no dividing walls; the only source of running water was a slop sink. That fall, the seven slept on futons in the middle of the vast room. Five years and 36 roommates later, Rollins and company have expanded their empire to include the entire 5,500-square-foot floor, building a dozen sizable bedrooms (for which roommates pay $350 to $450 per month), a living room, a library, a darkroom, an exercise room, a laundry room, two kitchens and two and a half bathrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, BETTE
description: KATZ-Bette, Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of Commack, New York, on February 25, 1999. Beloved wife of Arthur, loving mother of Steven and Ellen. Devoted to her many friends and to her students and colleagues at Hauppauge High School and Forest Brook Elementary.

title: The Trail Boss Was a Rabbi
description: Other writers have related the brave stories of Jewish immigrant pioneers who made their way from tiny villages in Eastern Europe to the vast open spaces and new possibilities of the American West, but Ruhama Veltfort, in her impressive first novel, THE PROMISED LAND (Milkweed, $23.95), recasts the tale in a spiritual dimension. She delves into the religious yearnings of a group of travelers, bound together by faith and family, who flee the pogroms and poverty of 19th-century Poland. Here the inner adventure is as striking as the landscape they navigate. Yitzhak, a gentle rabbi with mystical leanings and large visions, heads the group of migrants, which includes his wife, Chana, a woman of quiet piety whose practical bent balances her husband's loftiness; his twin sister, who is able to see his dreams; her husband, whose religious conviction is tested many times over; and a fiddler whose tunes take on American rhythms as they travel. In their ecstatic prayer they find solace, singing the songs of Yitzhak's enigmatic rebbe, whose deathbed message inspired their journey. After a sojourn in St. Louis with some wealthy Jewish merchants whose ownership of slaves surprises them, they set out for Oregon, hoping for freedom and a better future in the western wilderness. Veltfort, who is the granddaughter of the psychoanalyst Otto Rank, tells this story in chapters from Chana's and Yitzhak's alternating perspectives. Their path is filled with violence and loss, but comic moments also lighten the narrative; in one memorable scene, they are introduced to the earthly pleasures of watermelon. Sandee Brawarsky

title: The Public Trough
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra Leone Is No Place to Be Young
description: As a former student at Fourah Bay College in Sierra Leone, I found it almost impossible to read Jan Goodwin's article (Feb. 14) about the forcible conscription of children in that country. My emotions at several times overcame me. I applaud your efforts in bringing news of these atrocities to the American public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMPHILL, CLIFFORD JR.
description: HEMPHIll-Clifford Jr. Of North Palm Beach, Florida formerly of Caldwell, New Jersey died March 3, 1999 at the age of 81. Attended Yale and University of Virginia. Pilot with U.S. Navy. Retired Lt. Commander. Partner of Hemphill, Noyes & Co., retired 1974 as partner in Hornblower Weeks, Hemphill, Noyes. Married to the late Lois Van Vliet Hemphill. Survived by David W. of Jacksonville, FL., Van V. of Chicago, Ill., Mary Anne of Basking Ridge, NJ. and six grandchildren. A private burial at Old Tennant, NJ., will be held at a future date. Expressions of condolence may be addressed to Howard Funeral Home, 754 U.S. Highway #

title: Marching to His Own Beat, Benjamin Goes On Winning
description: The Saintly Cup International Tournament in the Queen Victoria Building in Sydney was the strongest ever held in Australia. There were four grandmasters and six international masters in the 10-player round-robin competition, which ran from Jan. 19 to 30. Joel Benjamin, a Manhattan grandmaster, took the $1,800 first prize with 7-2, ahead of the Australian grandmaster Ian Rogers, who scored 6-3 for second place and the Chinese grandmaster Zhang Zhong, who finished third with 5 1/2-3 1/2.

title: Maids of Honor
description: A RETURN TO MODESTY

title: Executions of 3 Americans in Colombia May Prolong Civil War
description: Whether or not Colombia's main guerrilla group proves to have been responsible for the kidnapping and execution of three Americans this week, the deaths have ignited a political controversy in Colombia that is likely to inflict a major setback on efforts to negotiate an end to the country's long civil conflict.

title: Ideas & Trends; You Must Remember This. Never Mind.
description: WITH the end of the century -- nay, the millennium -- upon us, Americans are engaged in a frenzy of stockpiling canned goods, envisioning doomsday scenarios and making lists. Lots of lists. The top 100 films. The top 100 books. And last week -- courtesy of the Freedom Forum's Newseum in Arlington, Va. -- the top 100 news stories of the century.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: WINGTIPS

title: A Single Guy Looking for Love (Through a Lens)
description: FOR his first film, Myles Berkowitz set up his camera and hoped for the worst. Inspired by Ross McElwee's personal odyssey ''Sherman's March,'' a funny, rambling first-hand account of that director's fraught relationship with women, Mr. Berkowitz decided to film a series of his own dates.

title: Revealing an Inventive Southwestern Spin
description: IF restaurants were evaluated solely on food, the Elephant Room in Roslyn would be sporting a rating of excellent. David Florscher, its chef, is turning out exciting, top-drawer American fare. Mr. Florscher, who last cooked at 660 West in Garden City, was also the sous-chef under Brendan Walsh at the North Street Grill in Great Neck. Mr. Walsh's influence shows in the inventive Southwestern spin given to a number of dishes here.

title: Colleges Must Teach Students, Not Baby-Sit Them; Lure of Coed Dorms
description: To the Editor:

title: Minding Your Mentors
description: Q. I am a woman trying to get ahead in a field dominated by men. My company doesn't officially assign mentors, but upper managers often extend guidance. As a woman, I tend to get steered toward female executives, who invite me to dinner or lunch. But there are several men here whose professional interests and activities are much closer to my own. How can I make the point that the men would be the better mentors?

title: Hello. Must You Leave So Soon?
description: The Taliban, the armed religious movement that runs Afghanistan, has a problem, and his name is Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile and suspected terrorist with a $5 million bounty on his head.

title: Performances for the Young and by the Young
description: WORKS for and by young people are in abundant supply around the state this week, starting at 2 this afternoon when four members of the Norwalk Youth Symphony -- Lauren Brunswick, Alexis Elder, Jessica Kalorie and Ami Connolly -- gather as a string quartet to play Mozart and more in a free recital at the Westport Library. The group has been coached by the Lumina Quartet, which has a 7:30 P.M. Friday recital including works by Mendelssohn, Schumann and Brahms at the Congregational Church of Naugatuck; the number to call for more information is (203) 729-3037.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALMON, MARILYN F.
description: SALMON-Marilyn F. Of Glen Cove, LI, on March 5, 1999. Wife of of Daniel A. Mother of Trina (Bill Sullivan) and Patrice (Bennett Norell). Nana of Peter, Kaitlyn and Chloe. Gathering at the funeral home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, Sunday 10-11 AM. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: AT&T's Embrace of New Technology Signals Next Era
description: Amid last week's typically hectic flow of headlines about the communications industry, perhaps the most significant news of all got lost: Frank Ianna, president of the AT&T Corporation's network unit, announced that by the end of this year, the long-distance giant wanted to stop buying traditional telephone switches for the core of its network.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Princeton, Seton Hall and Hofstra Are Among the N.I.T. Selections
description: The National Invitation Tournament, the consolation prize for schools left out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, provided sufficient consolation last night for Seton Hall and Hofstra. They were selected for the 32-team field along with disappointed Princeton, which was snubbed by the N.C.A.A. for an at-large berth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBLATT, STANLEY
description: FEINBLATT-Stanley. On March 5, 1999, of Smallwood, NY. Beloved husband of Marcia. Devoted father of David and Eric. Dear fatherin-law of Debbie. Adored son of Blanche. Loving brother of Ronna Rosenthal and Jerry. Cherished grandfather of Daniel. Services were held Sunday at ''Gutterman's,'' Woodbury, NY.

title: Even Experts May Not Find The Exceptions to a Principle
description: Beginners learn, as a general principle, to prefer a major-suit game to three no-trump if an eight-card fit is available. Experts struggle to locate the exceptions, which are seldom apparent until too late: after the dummy appears. One situation that can be recognized occurs when two things are true. The partnership must have more combined points than it needs for game; and the scoring must be by imps, when the difference between scores of 430 and 450 is trivial.

title: Professors as Parents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; After the Interview: The Good and the Tawdry
description: A few final observations before the Monica Lewinsky interview fades into history:

title: Drop the Social Security Charade
description: To the Editor:

title: Bias Charges Spur Change in Pool Rules in Connecticut Town
description: After a year of discrimination complaints for its refusal to give gay couples a family discount on pool memberships, the town of West Hartford has decided to begin giving the discount only to couples with children.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; Internet retailers are attracting lots of window shoppers. Now the push is on to turn those shoppers into buyers.
description: INTERNET shoppers may be at the vanguard of a retail revolution, but as with anyone on the front lines, they are a jittery bunch.

title: David Daube, 90, an Authority On Talmudic and Roman Law
description: Prof. David Daube, an eminent authority on legal history who was best known for his writings on Talmudic law, other biblical law and Roman law, died on Feb. 24 in Oak Park Convalescent Hospital in Pleasant Hill, Calif. He was 90 and had lived in San Francisco for many years.

title: Treasury to Hold Weekly Auction of Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Cuba-Bound Owner of Orioles Wants to Win
description: Peter Angelos has spent several years trying to take his Baltimore Orioles to Cuba, and now that he has succeeded in arranging a game there, he wants to win it.

title: A New Place to Nourish One Dreamer's Legacy
description: With a short walk across Auburn Avenue, the faithful members of Ebenezer Baptist Church today left the cramped sanctuary where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preached his gospel of nonviolence and consecrated an airy new church that they dedicated to the legacy of his ministry.

title: A Voice on Capitol Hill, Filling the Silences Everywhere
description: THE House subcommittee hearing was chugging along unremarkably enough when suddenly, out of nowhere, she piped up. The Republican chairman, George W. Gekas of Pennsylvania, all but cringed.

title: Compressed Data; Pixel Aims to Exploit Fringes of the Desktop
description: In its antitrust trial, the Microsoft Corporation has repeatedly said that it has granted personal computer makers greater freedom to do as they please with the Windows desktop screen, which pops into view when a machine is turned on.

title: St. John's Gets Its Wish: No Hoopla and No Duke
description: Nothing against Boston, but you couldn't miss the relief at the St. John's University Center when the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was announced yesterday and the Red Storm wasn't in it.

title: Media Talk; Gannett Withdraws Ads From Journalism Review
description: In journalism, as in so many other endeavors, timing is everything. Editors and reporters make statements not just by printing articles but by deciding when to print them -- or not print them. Advertisers, too, can make statements, not just by buying advertisements, but by choosing when to buy them -- or withdraw them.

title: U.S. Offers Saudi Arabia New Weapons
description: As Iraq accused the United States of resorting to ''pressure and blackmail'' in the region, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen today offered Saudi Arabia new weapons and military training to help shore up its defenses against any threat from Baghdad.

title: Consumers Still Seem Resistant to Some New High-End Electronics
description: Paul Scott walked up to a display of digital cameras inside the Wiz consumer electronics store in Carle Place, N.Y., last Thursday evening with a single purpose: purchasing a gift for his wife's 50th birthday.

title: Professors as Parents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Promises to Punish Chechnya for Abduction of General
description: Russia vowed tonight to punish the separatist Chechnya region unless Chechen kidnappers quickly released a high-ranking Russian officer. The threat represented the most serious deterioration in Russian-Chechen relations since a peace settlement was concluded more than two years ago.

title: Equity in the Everglades
description: When President Clinton pledged six years ago to restore Florida's failing Everglades to good health, he committed his Administration to the most complicated and expensive ecological rescue effort ever undertaken in the United States. There has been more progress than anyone expected, given the formidable political and financial odds. But the job has barely begun, and now he and Vice President Al Gore face a major test of their commitment.

title: Music Isn't Just An I.Q. Booster
description: To the Editor:

title: Singers Tragically Deaf to a Rising Din
description: Think of ''Beatlemania'' as performed by six lesser Victor Borges, and you have some idea of the theatrical impact of ''Band in Berlin,'' the engagingly sung, dramatically inert new musical play that opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theater.

title: Without Their Swagger, Nets Fold
description: As the losses accumulate and the frustration mounts, the Nets try to exude the confidence expected of professional basketball players. They say they still believe in themselves, still step on the court with a swagger, still know they can make shots and beat their opponent.

title: Police Trailing Other Cities In Diversity
description: After a decade of record expansion, the New York Police Department remains among the least racially diverse of the forces in the nation's 10 largest cities, with the lack of black and Hispanic representation most pronounced in the higher ranks.

title: Undone by a Slump, Rutgers Is Relegated to the N.I.T.
description: The room at the Hale Center at Rutgers was crowded tonight, with players, coaches, friends and family paying rapt attention to the big-screen television that would show the post-season fate of the Scarlet Knights. When the final name of the 64-team field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was called, all that was left was for Rutgers's disappointment to be broadcast across the nation.

title: INSIDE
description: China Denies Nuclear Spying

title: P&G Consolidates All Clearasil Work
description: The Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati has consolidated the worldwide account for its Clearasil brand of skin care products at Grey Advertising in New York. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW
description: Not Shirking The Big Works

title: Bullied Isles Don't Come to the Defense of Their Goalie
description: A second-period shouting match between the Islanders' Tommy Salo and the Devils' Scott Stevens was probably not a factor in the Devils' 4-2 victory today, but it spoke volumes about the Islanders.

title: Sports of The Times; After 60 Years, There's Still Madness in That March Tournament
description: ONE of the nation's most compelling sports rituals was set in motion yesterday: 64 Division I men's basketball teams set sail for four regions where they will begin the pursuit of a national championship.

title: Tricky Credit-Card Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ERIC ROBERT
description: WOLF-Eric Robert, 76, anthropologist, of Irvington, NY, died March 6, 1999 at his home. Survivors are his wife, Sydel Silverman Wolf; two sons, J. David of Burlington, VT, and Daniel J. of Los Angeles; two stepdaughters, Eve R. Silverman of Wilton, CT and Julie Silverman Yorn of Santa Monica, CA; and three grandchildren. Services will be held Tuesday, March 9, at 12 noon at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment will follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions may be made to the Eric R. Wolf Student Research Fund, Anthropology Program, CUNY Graduate School, 33 West 42 St., New York, NY 10036.

title: Doral's Merciless 18th Has Mercy on Elkington
description: It was a dramatic victory for Steve Elkington, a disgusting loss for Ernie Els, and a cruel turn of events for Greg Kraft. And when today's final round of the Doral-Ryder Open was history, the 18th hole, one of the toughest in the world, had added to its victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENKEN, MARTIN H.
description: RENKEN-Martin H. On March 6, 1999, of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Ronnie. Brother of Marjorie R. Horstmann and Ruth E. Renken. Also survived by his nephew William Horstmann and his nieces Barbara Lauro and Jane Mangione and their families. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Prayer service at the Fairchild Chapel, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Winthrop University Hospital, The Chaplaincy Program, Mineola, NY 11501, or Variety PreSchooler's Workshop, Training and Research Fund, Syosset, NY 11791, appreciated.

title: Wary Riders Still Take Subways After Attacks
description: Rosemary Wyman believes that the four subway slashings that occurred within 24 hours on Friday and Saturday were a statistical blip.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW
description: Two Debuts In More Mahler

title: Higher Standards, Worse Schools
description: Public schools in New York State face a critical shortage of qualified teachers. It is estimated that New York City alone will need to hire 30,000 to 40,000 new teachers over the next five years. Other urban districts in the state face similar problems, though on a smaller scale. The shortage is caused by an aging teacher base and a move toward smaller classes just as the student population is increasing dramatically.

title: Gebrselassie Foils Foes' Strategy to Win the 1,500 and His Second Gold
description: Haile Gebrselassie's amazing string of performances continued today with a victory in the 1,500 meters at the world indoor championships. Coupled with his 3,000-meter victory on Friday, it gave the 25-year-old Ethiopian an unprecedented double, one duplicated today by Gabriela Szabo of Romania. It was not easy for Gebrselassie, though.

title: CABLE RATES RISING AS INDUSTRY NEARS END OF REGULATION
description: Cable television, one of the last industries to have its prices controlled by the Government, is about to become almost completely deregulated.

title: Music Isn't Just An I.Q. Booster
description: To The Editor:

title: Free Trade in Fresh Water? Canada Says No and Halts Exports
description: For just about as long as there has been a border with the United States, some Canadians have believed that Americans covet their country and the resources it contains.

title: Compressed Data; Software Turns Computers Into Desktop Lie Detectors
description: Don't fudge that expense account. Not if the people in accounts payable have been in touch with B. Francis Camis, anyway.

title: Microchips In Microcosm; Failed Partnership Is a Lens For Viewing U.S.-Intel Suit
description: At the heart of the Government's antitrust case against the Intel Corporation that goes on trial Tuesday is a meeting nearly five and a half years ago at the annual Comdex computer industry convention in Las Vegas, Nev. There, in November 1993, the chairman of Intel cut a fateful deal with his counterpart at a small but leading maker of highly specialized computer work stations, the Intergraph Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLER, BURTON
description: LIEBLER-Burton. Age 67, loving husband of Diana. Devoted father of Linda and Michele, and fatherin-law of Joseph and Tom. Caring brother of Robert. Adoring uncle to Eric and grandfather of Alyssa and Jennifer. He will be remembered for his zest for life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, SIMON (CY)
description: REISMAN-Simon (Cy). Of Miami Beach, at age 95, after a brief illness. Survived by his adoring wife of 70 years, Ethel; son, James, of New York City; and loving grandchildren, Adam and Leah. Cy will always be remembered as a pillar of strength for his family and a good friend to many who knew him since his graduation from City College in 1924, and during his long career with the New York City school system. He was a true gentleman, whose forthright personality will remain a beacon to his family and friends.

title: Mothers on Medicaid Overcharged for Pain Relief
description: Some doctors and hospitals have been forcing poor women to pay hundreds of dollars in cash for a popular procedure to relieve pain in childbirth, Federal officials say, and the Government has ordered hospitals to stop demanding such cash payments.

title: Ronald Willetts, 83, of Britain, Expert on Life in Ancient Crete
description: Prof. Ronald Willetts, a British authority on life in ancient Crete, died on Feb. 19 in Birmingham, England. He was 83.

title: Stanley Kubrick, Film Director With a Bleak Vision, Dies at 70
description: Stanley Kubrick, the famously reclusive director of such classic films as ''Dr. Strangelove,'' ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and ''A Clockwork Orange,'' died yesterday at his home in England, his family said. He was 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROSTEN, EUGENIE (GINA) S.
description: TROSTEN-Eugenie (Gina) S. 64, of Austerlitz and Manhattan died Wednesday in Hudson, NY after a brief illness. Mrs. Trosten, born December 4, 1934 in Munich, Germany emigrated to the U.S. in 1960. She was devoted to her family, friends and the welfare of animals. Survived by her husband, William S. Trosten of Austerlitz and Manhattan. Services Wednesday, 3 PM at St. James R.C. Church at the storefront Austerlitz Street Chatham, NY. Inurnment Spencertown Cemetery. Calling hours Wednesday 1-2:30 PM, Wenk Funeral Home, Payn Ave., Chatham. Memorial contributions to the Doris Day Animal League in c/o Wenk Funeral Home, Chatham, NY 12037.

title: Childs Goes From a Misfit To a Nice Fit
description: For two years, Chris Childs was a misfit. He would step onto the court as if dressed in a plaid jacket for a black-tie affair and force his racy, loud style on the conservative Knicks.

title: Serena Williams Leaves Her Mark on Davenport
description: Now that she has developed the confidence to match her muscles, Serena Williams has declared her intention of shouldering into the top five by the year's end. After all, the year's beginning has produced her first career title, collected last week in Paris, and a significant victory over the world's No. 2 player, earned this afternoon in her debut appearance in the Evert Cup's singles draw.

title: Yankees Feel Pettitte's Pain In His Elbow
description: The Yankees' starting pitching rotation, the American League's most productive and durable last season, showed its vulnerable side today.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Tips From Jimmy Carter On Living Well in Old Age
description: Jimmy Carter's latest book is ''The Virtues of Aging'' (Ballantine, 1998), and in a speech at the American Society on Aging's annual conference here, the 75-year-old former President presented his personal list of those virtues, things like time to learn new things, grandchildren and a closer relationship with his wife, Rosalynn.

title: Coast Guard Halts Search Off Florida for Lost Haitians
description: The three Haitian men whom rescuers found in cold, rough seas are apparently the only survivors of two boats that sank this weekend off the South Florida coast, leaving as many as 40 dead in what may be the worst smuggling disaster in this state's history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, RALPH
description: JAFFE-Ralph. March 6, 1999. Of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Manhasset. Loving husband of Trudy, to whom he was married fifty-three years. Adored father of Leonard and Rochelle. Cherished grandfather of five. For information, contact Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL, 1-800-992-9262.

title: Are Airline Alliances Passenger-Unfriendly?
description: IMAGINE arriving at the airport to find that instead of the familiar airline check-in desks, there is just one long row of desks displaying the logo Star Alliance. At other airports, you might have a choice of Oneworld or Atlantic Excellence. But this is Hamburg, a Star Alliance hub.

title: Finding the Perfect Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Lag in Diversity
description: The New York Police Department remains among the least racially diverse of the forces in the nation's 10 largest cities.

title: A Woman's Sermons and Searches
description: EVENSONG

title: Drop the Social Security Charade
description: To the Editor:

title: A Refugee Disaster Off Florida's Coast
description: The Coast Guard has called off the search for up to 40 Haitian refugees who are feared dead in the waters off South Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SEYMOUR HAROLD
description: BERNSTEIN - Seymour Harold. Died on March 6, 1999, at the age of 87. Beloved husband for fiftytwo years of Esther Teper Bernstein. Devoted father of Carol Weinstein, Geri Freund and Alan Bernstein. Adored grandfather of Matanya, Noa, Merav, Eliya and Benjamin. Father-in-law of Carol Bowen and Gilad Freund. Brother of the late Pearl Max, the late I. Maurice Bernstein, Ira Bernstein, Hilda Morris and Betty Bernstein. The ''Chief'' to Alex Burger. Funeral will be held at 12 noon on March 9, 1999, at The Riverside. May his strength, faith, generosity and love be a blessing to us all.

title: Yellow Pages to Get a Rival in Manhattan
description: There are no baritone endorsements from James Earl Jones, or pitches from well-known media personalities. There is no instruction to ''Let your fingers do the walking,'' either.

title: Accounts
description: * DuPont Dacron SBU, a unit of the DuPont Co., Wilmington, Del., which produces high-technology consumer fabric, bedding and insulation products, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle its account, which had been at Rowland Worldwide, New York, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. The billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANSTER, FAY (NEE NAPACH)
description: PANSTER-Fay (nee Napach). On Saturday, March 6, 1999, of Scotch Plains, NJ, formerly of Westfield, NJ. Devoted wife of the late Lawrence Panster. Beloved mother of Howard Allan Panster and the late Roberta Hoffstetter. Adored sister of Louie Napach. Loving grandmother of Randy Belfer, Elissa Berkman, Michael Hoffstetter and Michael Paige Panster. Greatgrandmother of Lauren Belfer and Jonathan Craig Belfer. Mrs. Panster was a bookkeeper for Merrill-Lynch, NYC, for 27 years. Services on Monday, March 8, 1999, at 9 AM, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: W. F. Harrington, 63, Minister At Atlanta's Peachtree Church
description: The Rev. W. Frank Harrington, senior minister of the largest Presbyterian (U.S.A.) church in North America, died on Wednesday of cardiorespiratory failure at Emory Hospital in Atlanta. He was 63.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: A Woman's Autobiography As a Study in Courage

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEGEGA, DR. CARLOS SILVERIO
description: VEGEGA-Dr. Carlos Silverio. On March 6, 1999. United Nations Vice-Chairman, International Civil Service Commission (ICSC), Chairman, Advisory Committee on Post Adjustment Questions (ACPAQ). Husband of H. Constance. Father of Dr. Marie E. Vegega, Ph.D., Lucia LaFemina, Juan S. Vegega, Alexander Vegega and Ana Maria Crofton-Sleigh. Also survived by two granddaughters. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday, 10 AM, Church of the Sacred Heart, Broadway and Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Memorial SloanKettering Hospital or American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: DIALLO LAWYERS LEVEL NEW CHARGE
description: Lawyers for the family of Amadou Diallo said yesterday that police investigators searched for damaging evidence and questioned Mr. Diallo's roommates in an effort to taint his character in the hours immediately after the fatal shooting of the West African immigrant by four police officers last month.

title: The HEALTHY Traveler : Cabin Air Hasn't Cleared
description: PARIS  The cigarette smoke has been cleared from most airline flights worldwide, but travelers are still not breathing easy. With the elimination of the most obvious pollutant, passengers and flight attendants have shifted their complaints to other unhealthy or discomforting components of cabin air  viruses from other passengers, searingly low humidity and ozone hazards.

title: Internet Concern Plans System for Small On-Line Transactions
description: Cybergold Inc., a company that pays consumers to pay attention to World Wide Web sites, now plans to let consumers make on-line purchases for as little as 25 cents.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Jets Safety Atwater: Man Who Fell to Earth
description: He is not likely to openly display selfishness or to rant, rave or pout when things go sour. No, Steve Atwater offered a convincing performance while the Denver Broncos were winning the last two Super Bowls. All the while, Atwater was slipping in stature among his coaches and was toiling in an unusual, personal mix of frustration.

title: Editorial Observer; At Last, It's Time to Bet on Japan's Recovery
description: The long national economic nightmare is finally ending in Japan. After a decade of denying reality, of bad policies being followed by worse changes, the Japanese economic pulse is starting to be heard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, MINNIE
description: EPSTEIN-Minnie, 103. Died peacefully at home on March 6. Her loss will be mourned by her loving children, Mary Jo Hamburger and William Easton, and their spouses, Robert Hamburger and Margarita Easton. Her grandchildren will miss Nana since she was important to all of them, Bobby and Peter Hamburger, their wives, Ilene and Joy; Elizabeth Traub, her husband, James; Tom Easton, his wife, Eliza. She thought her greatgrandchildren were great, Zoe and Max Hamburger, Alex Traub, David Hamburger and Isaac Easton. They in turn thought she was magic, 103 years young. Contributions in her memory may be sent to your favorite charity.

title: Gay Man Is Allowed to Be a Church Leader
description: An openly gay man may sit on the governing board of his Presbyterian church here despite his refusal to divulge whether he engages in sexual activities that would bar him from serving, ecclesiastical judges have ruled.

title: Assembly Speaker to Try to Block Money Pataki Wants for Schools Inquiry
description: The Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, will try to use the upcoming budget process to deny the $3.5 million that Governor George E. Pataki is seeking for a new commission to investigate school construction in New York City, Mr. Silver's spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: What Hath Drudge Wrought?
description: The rash of telephone calls started coming in to Doug Thompson, the publisher of Capitol Hill Blue, a four-year-old Web site, about three weeks ago. Journalists from a broadcast news organization, from U.S. News & World Report, and from several British and American newspapers, wanted his Web publication to help them reach the sources for an article he had published.

title: Cambodia Says It Plans Trial for Jailed Khmer Rouge Commander
description: Cambodian officials said yesterday that they would hold a trial in Phnom Penh for Ta Mok, the last fugitive Khmer Rouge leader, who was captured on Saturday. Their statements raised further doubts about their commitment to produce other Khmer Rouge leaders for an international tribunal.

title: Salvadoran Ruling Party Claims Victory
description: The candidate of the conservative governing party, a philosopher with a reputation for consensus building, declared victory in today's presidential elections, based on early official results and the party's own sampling showing him in the lead.

title: Its About Time!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITT, ELIZABETH NORTON
description: SCHMITT - Elizabeth Norton. March 4, 1999. Loving daughter of the late Philip Schmitt, Jr. and the late Mary Pearl Norton. Beloved aunt of Rosemarie S. Vietor and her husband Richard and great aunt of Abigail Vietor and Samuel Nicholls, III. Service Monday 11AM, March 8, St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTSKY, JENNIE
description: LUTSKY-Jennie. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Loving mother of Ira and Cheryl Lutsky, and the late Marc Lutsky. Cherished grandmother to Jordan. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIGLIANTE, RALPH A.
description: VIGLIANTE-Ralph A. Age 84. Of Elmira, NY. Died Saturday, March 6, 1999, in Elmira, NY. He was preceded in death by his sister, Regina Crea. Ralph is survived by his wife of fifty-seven years, Concetta Vigliante; three children; five grandchildren; and one sister, Theresa Shelzi. Ralph earned his undergraduate and law degrees from Fordham University. He then went to work for Prentice Hall, where he retired in 1982 after thirty-four years of service as their Vice President and Managing Editor of the Tax Division. Donations in Ralph's memory may be made to Saint Joseph's Hospital Foundation, 555 East Market St., Elmira, NY 14901.

title: New Jersey Transit May Buy 2-Deck Passenger Train Cars
description: New Jersey Transit, seeking to ease cheek-by-jowl overcrowding in the morning commute to Manhattan, is considering spending $1.3 billion to buy new railroad cars, including, for the first time, double-decker cars, officials of the agency said yesterday.

title: Musicians Want a Revolution Waged on the Internet
description: Visionaries, hopefuls, hucksters and self-described geeks mingled over the weekend at the first New York Music and Internet Expo, a convention held at the New Yorker Hotel. While Web pages flickered on monitors and cellular phones beeped, musicians and computer entrepreneurs swapped business cards and ideas about how the Internet could revolutionize the music business.

title: Bicycle Routes Span Continents : Pushing Pedals From Sea to Sea
description: IF YOU have ever dreamed of jumping on a bicycle and heading for the horizon, you might be advised to look for a signpost near you. It could well be that someone with the same idea has tried it out and already mapped a route, perhaps for thousands of miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLIN, PAUL
description: GALLIN-Paul. Beloved husband of Jeanette. Devoted father of Steven and Phyllis Gallin, and Howard and Deborah Gallin. Cherished grandfather of Richard, David, Zachary and Matthew. Loving brother of Sylvia. Services were held Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, BEA
description: CARTER-Bea. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation extends deepest sympathy upon the passing of Bea Carter, beloved mother of Judy Shatz, Founder and Trustee. Our sincere condolences to the Shatz, Max and Carter families. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation

title: Paris Journal; Deconstructing Paris, and Its Hold on Americans
description: Paris has always loomed large in the American imagination: Thomas Jefferson, Henry James, Ernest Hemingway and James Baldwin all fell under its spell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SADIE
description: RUBEN-Sadie. Beloved wife of the late Julian. Devoted mother of Dr. Robert Ruben and Cookie Slater. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Ann, Emily, A.J. and Karin, and great-grandmother of Patrick, Molly, Eliana and Zev. Gravside services Monday, 12:30 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Allied Waste Seen in Deal To Acquire Browning-Ferris
description: In what is believed to be one of the largest leveraged buyouts since Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company's hostile takeover of RJR Nabisco in 1988 for $25 billion, Allied Waste Industries and two investment firms, the Blackstone Group and Apollo Advisors, are expected to announce as early as today that they are acquiring Browning-Ferris Industries, another waste services company, for about $7.1 billion in cash, executives close to the talks said last night.

title: Executive Nominated for Times Co. Board
description: The board of The New York Times Company has nominated Henry B. Schacht, former chairman and chief executive of Lucent Technologies Inc., for election as a director at the Times Company's annual shareholder meeting on April 15.

title: Theft Report On Atom Data 'Unfounded,' China Says
description: China said today that accusations that its spies had stolen nuclear weapons designs from the United States were ''unfounded.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, HERBERT
description: AXELROD-Herbert. The Englewood Hospital and Medical Center Board of Trustees mourns the loss of a devoted member of our Medical Center Association and former member of our Board, Herbert Axelrod. His distinguished years of service and important contributions to our institution will forever be remembered. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Georgine and his family. George P. Kramer Chairman Daniel A. Kane President and CEO

title: Book Tells of 'Courtship' to Get Cuomo on High Court
description: Behind-the-scenes efforts to get Mario M. Cuomo to change his mind and accept a Supreme Court nomination came within 15 minutes of success in 1993, but just before President Clinton was to make the offer Mr. Cuomo called the White House to forestall it, George Stephanopoulos, the former Presidential adviser, says in a new book.

title: Purdue Leads the Party
description: PURDUE SHOULD FEAR ...

title: As television news enters the post-Lewinsky era, Fox pushes a 'powerful prime time' campaign.
description: WITH all the attention paid last week to a certain former White House intern, it seemed as if the 24-hour cable news television networks had changed their names to MNN, MSLNBC and MNC. But now, with the likelihood that such coverage will diminish -- and viewership could dwindle -- the time may have arrived for the cable news gatherers to consider life after Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, ALAN J.
description: HARWOOD-Alan J. On March 6, 1999. Beloved husband and best friend of Terry. Dearest father of Michael and Ann. Dear brother-inlaw of Jim Schare. Loving uncle and good friend to many. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEOBALD, DONALD, SR.
description: THEOBALD-Donald, Sr. On March 5, 1999. Devoted husband of Ida. Loving father of John, Donald, Jr., James and Stephen. Devoted grandfather of Jason, Ingrid, John, Jr., Brendan, Kathryn, Elizabeth and Sarah, and great-grandfather of Brandyn and Dylan. Private family service in West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Justice Dept. Carjacking Figures Exceed Criminologists' Estimates
description: There were an estimated 49,000 carjackings a year between 1992 and 1996, a far higher figure than criminologists had believed, the Justice Department reported yesterday in the first comprehensive study of the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, STANLEY ROY
description: ROOT-Stanley Roy. Retired attorney, passed away at home on March 6 at age 67 after a long illness. He was an outstanding human being, beloved and respected by all who knew him. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Syracuse University and Columbia Law School, where he was a member of the Alumni Board of Directors. He is survived by his wife Myrna, three children Bradford, Gregory and Kimberly, and four grandchildren. Funeral services 10:30, Tuesday, March 9, at Beth El Synagogue, Northfield Rd., corner North Ave., New Rochelle. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Donations may be sent to Multiple Myeloma Foundation.

title: Essay; American Defeat
description: Throughout the 1996 Clinton campaign for President, China's agents of influence had the run of the White House as they raised millions for the Clinton campaign. Chinese military intelligence officials were waved in without clearance. U.S. executives contributed megabucks as they lobbied for easier approval of sales of sensitive technology to Beijing.

title: When Young Performers Resemble the Characters
description: Although the spring offerings of the New York City Opera will feature some much-anticipated productions of less-known works, including Strauss's ''Intermezzo'' and a Ravel double bill of ''L'Heure Espagnole'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' the season officially began on Friday night with the most familiar of all operas, Puccini's ''Boheme.''

title: Deane F. Johnson, 80, Lawyer for Entertainers
description: Deane F. Johnson, an entertainment-industry lawyer and corporate executive prominent in nonprofit institutions, died on Feb. 28 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 80.

title: Selig Promises Realignment Soon
description: Commissioner Bud Selig, on a visit to the Yankees yesterday in Tampa, Fla., called realignment of major league teams a major priority and said he hoped to accomplish it by early this summer.

title: New York Life To Review Account
description: The New York Life Insurance Company is starting a review on its account, which has been handled for 12 years by TBWA/Chiat/Day in New York and a predecessor, Chiat/ Day. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: A New Speaker Errs on Reform
description: After two months in office, House Speaker Dennis Hastert is on his way to making the very mistake that helped destroy Newt Gingrich. Despite overwhelming bipartisan support in the House for campaign finance reform, which could lead easily to its swift passage, Mr. Hastert has bottled up the legislation in committee until later in the year or next year. This is Gingrich-style obstructionism with a more genial face. Supporters of reform need to get ready for a renewed battle, including a petition drive to force the bill to the floor by spring.

title: Deeper Look Into the Tale Of a Daughter And an Ax
description: Murder exerts a peculiar hold on the American imagination, and murder that appears to have been got away with is particularly potent. The O. J. Simpson trial and perennial interest in conspiracy theories about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy are modern manifestations of this fascination, and anyone who thinks they will fade into the pages of history books might consider the fate of Lizzie Borden, still infamous as the ax murderer of her father and stepmother more than a century after she was acquitted of the 1892 double murder.

title: Music Isn't Just An I.Q. Booster
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Harriet M. Waddy, 94, Officer In Women's Army Corps, Dies
description: Harriet M. Waddy, one of the two highest-ranking black officers in the Women's Army Corps in World War II and its wartime adviser on racial issues, died on Feb. 21 in Las Vegas, Nev. She was 94.

title: Whistle-Stops On Wall Street
description: The candidate came to the voters last week. The candidate was Ricardo Lagos, who is likely to be the next President of Chile, but virtually none of the voters he spoke with were Chilean.

title: Richard Goldberg, Contract Bridge League Executive, 76
description: Richard Goldberg, a longtime executive of the American Contract Bridge League, died yesterday at his home in Nashville, Tenn. He was 76.

title: A Topsy-Turvy Beauty In Anxious Encounters
description: Four performers from Prague who hang upside down to tell us something about the human condition might even tell us something we do not know.

title: Officers at Nassau Jail Find Job Complicated by Inquiry
description: ''Look,'' said Bruce Kusky, a burly 51-year-old, who has put in 20 years as a correction officer at the Nassau County jail, ''we don't come to work looking for somebody to beat up. We want it nice and easy, nice and safe. I want to pick up my paycheck and go home and kiss my kids.''

title: Sue Miller Discovers A Trove of Domesticity; What Lies Beneath the Family Surface And Lays Bare the Search for Another Self
description: In her fiction, from her first novel, ''The Good Mother,'' to her latest, ''While I Was Gone,'' Sue Miller is the doyenne of domesticity. Probing beneath the surface of marriages, she uncovers the disharmony as well as an individual's urge to find an alternative life.

title: Trolling for Scuttlebutt on the Internet
description: James Alexander is the bearer of bad news for hundreds of corporations. And now, Mr. Alexander's clients can take heart that he intends to bring them more negative tidings more quickly than ever.

title: People
description: * Elizabeth Shanklin, senior vice president and group account director at Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, part of the Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide unit of True North Communications, was named executive vice president and worldwide account director for the AT&T Corp. account at the agency's New York office. She assumes the account duties from Charles Taney, who had handled them temporarily; he remains chairman of the New York office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLETCHER, FLORENCE
description: FLETCHER-Florence. On March 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother to Judy and Phyllis. Mother-in-law of Seymour and Harvey. Cherished and adored grandmother to Alan, Tori, Brian and Stephanie. Services March 8, 1999, at 11:15 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Media Talk; Rush Limbaugh Brings His Show to the Internet
description: For the last few years, Rush Limbaugh, the blustery conservative radio talk show host, has resisted bringing his radio show to the Internet, even though an increasing number of syndicated radio programs were being sent on line to homes and offices throughout America.

title: Blue Devils vs. a Field of Dreamers
description: The Duke Blue Devils officially became prohibitive favorites. Their most formidable potential opponent, Connecticut, will have to win out West to get to them. And the balance of power in college basketball appears to have shifted to the East and Midwest. Or at least that appeared to be the meaning of the invitations and seedings announced yesterday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINS, LILLIAN
description: RABINS-Lillian. Devoted wife of the late Herman Rabins. She was cherished by her children, Ellen and Hubert Cohen, Elaine and Bob Adamenko, and Joan and Michael Rabins. Devoted grandmother to Andrew, Terry, Evan, Alix, Robert, Katherine and Richard. Loving sister of Sylvia Gayle and Florence and Manny Kamaiko. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Services to be held 10:45, Monday, March 8, 1999, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to one's favorite charity.

title: Caught in the Trap Of Science Run Amok
description: Here's a new television series with a mission statement. In the pilot episode of ''Strange World,'' to be seen tonight on ABC, the central character, Dr. Paul Turner, works up a righteous head of steam and declares: ''Why are people more afraid of aliens from outer space than they are of the monsters we're creating ourselves? From genetically engineered animals, viruses . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALL, MARVIN
description: BALL-Marvin. March 4, 1999. Residence: 720 Tidewater Circle, Pawleys Island, SC. A founder of Harry Ball and Sons in NY. Beloved husband of Marie (Williams) Ball. Devoted father of Marjorie Ball DiBella of East Greenwich, RI, Eileen Ball of Chicago, IL, Judy Ball of Natick, MA, and Mindy Oswald of Barrington, RI. Dear brother of Jerry Ball of Manhattan, NY, and Robert Ball of Rehobeth, MA. Loving grandfather of Gregory Doan, Samuel and Ana Lucia DiBella, and Natalie and Camille Oswald. Funeral services will be held Monday at 11 AM at the Max Sugarman Memorial Chapel, 458 Hope St., Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Ball Memorial Scholarship, c/o Kent Hester, Box 8301, NC State University-College of Textiles, Raleigh, NC 27675. Shiva will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHINGTON, AUDREY J.
description: WORTHINGTON-Audrey J. Born January 17, 1937, in Swampscott, Mass., and raised by her parents, Emerson and S. Eugenia Pierce, both deceased. She attended the Jeremiah Burke High School and graduated in 1954. She then attended Boston University School of Nursing. She stopped her schooling when she married her husband, Howard F. Worthington III on September 15, 1956. She later attended the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City earning an L.P.N. after a short work period. She attended Queensborough Community College earning an Associates degree and an R.N. She also attended C.W. Post and earned a B.S. in Nursing. Before her retirement, she worked at Long Island Jewish Medical Center for twenty-nine years. Audrey had two children from her marriage; a son, Randall Worthington, deceased, and a daughter, Sharon Rai Parker. She was blessed with two grandchildren by Sharon and Harry, Lashaunda R. Parker and Nadja R. Parker. She leaves two aunts, Ms. Portia Ellis of Framingham, Mass. and Ms. Edna Foggie of Mass. She leaves an uncle, Rev. Charles Foggie of Harrisburg, PA. Audrey leaves a host of cousins, in-laws, friends, co-workers. She was my friend, my lover, my wife for forty two and one-half years, and the mother of my children. She will be greatly missed. Audrey loved reading books, going to plays and musicals, needlepoint, knitting and travelling. Her motto was ''Education is the key to success. Be successful.'' Viewing and services will be held at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home. Viewing Tuesday, March 9, from 2-6 PM. Services Wednesday, March 10, at 10 AM.

title: Drop the Social Security Charade
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Poz Magazine Apologizes for Mailing
