description: Some magazines tell their subscribers that if they do not want their names rented out to other companies hawking merchandise, the readers can check a box on the subscription form, or call a toll-free number to protect their names and privacy.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Who Said Flamenco Had to Be Passionate?

title: How They Live Squeezed Together, Separately
description: The vibrant cafe scene in Pristina can make people forget there is a war going on in Kosovo. Through a fog of cigarette smoke and against the pounding of pop music, fashionably dressed students drink small cups of strong coffee or glasses of local cognac.

title: Giuliani's Hiring of Fund-Raiser Signals a Senate Bid, Aides Say
description: In what aides are describing as the most concrete sign yet that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is planning to run for the United States Senate next year, his main political action committee has hired a finance director with broad experience in national Republican fund-raising and a strong background in Senate campaigns.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Yes, we could have moved away. Yes, we could have gone to the suburbs. But this is the place for which Christ died.''

title: Survey Shows Viewers Want Interactive HDTV Options
description: When several hundred executives from the consumer electronics industry gathered here for a conference on digital television last week, the leaders of their trade group greeted them with a rude surprise.

title: Senate G.O.P. Takes the Lead After Impeachment Trial
description: After four years in which House Republicans dominated Congress, bringing their party its legislative energy as well as its public relations disasters and the impeachment drive, power has shifted on Capitol Hill. In the 106th Congress, Trent Lott and his Senate majority have become the ascendant Republican presence.

title: Congressman and His Colleagues Re-enact March
description: Each year on this day, this tumbledown town comes alive with the spirit of an instant in time, the beginning of the end of American apartheid, when an Alabama state trooper cracked John Lewis's skull.

title: Xerox to Expand Capabilities of Copiers
description: The Xerox Corporation, the world's biggest copier maker, will expand its lines of machines that can print, copy, fax and scan in its battle to take market share from its main competitors, the Hewlett-Packard Company and Canon Inc.

title: A Move to Limit Antibiotic Use In Animal Feed
description: Faced with mounting evidence that the routine use of antibiotics in livestock may diminish the drugs' power to cure infections in people, the Food and Drug Administration has begun a major revision of its guidelines for approving new antibiotics for animals and for monitoring the effects of old ones.

title: Outdated Maps at Heart of Satellite TV Dispute
description: Basketball fans in Denver know that to see local television broadcasts of Nuggets games, they had better stay home. A signal from a network affiliate in the city cannot be picked up in Vail, 100 miles away, even though special maps used by regulators to predict a television signal's reach say it should.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, NATHANIEL. A
description: SAMUELS-Nathaniel. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on March 21 at 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. and 65 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to the Harvard College Fund-Maurice and Sarah Samuels Fund, c/o The Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138

title: Fatherhood and Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Win Battle But Lose Samuelsson
description: With two regular defensemen already out of the lineup with injuries, the Rangers could not afford to lose any more, especially in a game with serious implications for the playoff race. But one went down, early, against the Boston Bruins today in the Fleet Center. He was Ulf Samuelsson, knocked unconscious and bleeding from the face, by Ken Belanger's vicious board check.

title: Compressed Data; New Device for Playing Music From the Internet
description: The recording industry's recognition that the Internet is changing the music business is coming none too soon.

title: Duke Runs the Table, Leaving A.C.C. in Awe
description: The details differed from game to game, but when the Duke basketball team played in the Atlantic Coast Conference this season the result was always the same.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Marriage's Vicissitudes Set to Song
description: The season of the staged song recital continues. On Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y, Hakan Hagegard and Elizabeth Futral, with Elisabeth Bostrom at the piano, presented a program of songs and duets as a day in the life of a couple living probably in Austria or Germany (to go by the dominant language) around the time of World War I (to go by the horn phonograph).

title: Coretta Leads An Irish Sweep

description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, foiled an attempt to rob her early today, and three suspects were arrested within a half-hour.

description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine has already helped broker a peace between Tommy Lasorda and Bobby Bonilla this spring. Now Lasorda would like to return the favor.

description: WEINSTEIN-Robert B. We mourn the death of our dear friend Bob, steadfast in good times and bad, expert on an amazing variety of music, marvelous traveling companion, Boatmaster, computer wizard, a man with a brilliant sense of the absurd, and generally keeper of the flame. We are all diminished by his loss. The circle of friends known as the Foon Platoon

title: The Big City; Unlikely Voice Pleads Case For Vouchers
description: SOL STERN is not losing any sleep at the prospect of Rudy Crew resigning. But if the Schools Chancellor should quit, as he has threatened to do if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani insists on a school voucher program run by the Board of Education, Mr. Stern would bear some of the responsibility. He is one of the city's more influential advocates for vouchers -- and more unlikely, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIOLI, OMER
description: CIOLI-Omer. Former Senior V.P. or Norton Lilly Shipping Company of New York, died February 22, in Melbourne, FL. Survived by his wife Jean.

title: Mexico's Opposition Party Selects a Peacemaker
description: Mexico's center-right opposition party chalked up major election gains during the early 1990's but has lost momentum as a result of recent squabbles between the party's doctrinaire conservatives and its new, more pragmatic generation.

title: Sports of The Times; Van Horn Is Caught In the Nets' Vortex
description: OUT of a useless timeout 27.1 seconds from the end of a hopeless game, the ball found Keith Van Horn, way out in the right corner where the baseline and sideline meet, and from where an offensive player has nowhere to go. Metaphorically, this is also where the Nets happen to be, about as far away from where they thought they were headed, their hopes for a turnaround in a season stuck on fast forward suddenly reduced to a wing and a prayer.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, HARRY COLE III.
description: BATES-Harry Cole III. Died March 4 in his 70th year at his home in Westbrook, CT. A graduate of the Hackley School and of Hamilton College, he earned an M.A. from Columbia in American History, and had taught that subject in independent and public schools in NY and CT. A memorial service was held March 6 in the Church of the Holy Advent, Clinton, CT. He is survived by brothers, Robert P. Turner of Weston, CT and Charles T. Bates of Irvington, NY, and by many nieces and nephews.

title: Albany Study Finds Perils in Surgery in Doctors' Offices
description: Patients who undergo surgery in a doctor's office instead of in a hospital are protected by few regulations and face dangers like outdated anesthesia equipment, according to a report by a New York Senate committee.

title: In the Plays of Fledglings, Intimations of Immortality
description: In the late 1930's a hopeful young playwright studying at a Midwestern university spent many weekends visiting a friend who was working in a nearby prison. From his observations he wrote a play about what he called ''the system's malign pressure on human brains.'' When it was turned down in a competition, he put it aside and went on to other plays. But he said he was haunted by his memories of ''those hot, humid cellblocks with tier on tier of humans'' and ''the wild, insane laughter and threatening uproars that periodically arose.''

title: Police Abuses Start to Get Attention in China
description: Villagers here say they were not entirely surprised when on the night of Aug. 7, 1997, public security officers piled four farmers deemed troublemakers into a van, drove them to an isolated rice field in front of a copse of trees and riddled them with bullets.

title: After a Season of Struggle, UConn Gets Top Seeding
description: For the Connecticut women's basketball team, which struggled through a season laden with injuries, a reward arrived yesterday. The Huskies (27-4) joined Purdue (28-1), Tennessee (28-2) and Louisiana Tech (26-2) as top-seeded teams for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament that begins on Friday.

title: Via an Aide on Russian TV, Yeltsin Warns His Prime Minister
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin has delivered a stern warning to Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, accusing him of being ''complacent'' about the nation's economic course and threatening yet another Government shake-up.

description: In a worship service that felt at turns like a rock concert and a religious revival, more than 2,000 people gathered yesterday in an old movie house in Queens to celebrate the freedom of the Rev. Frank Almonte, proclaiming it a clear sign that in times of crisis, God works.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, ANNE LOEWY
description: BASS-Anne Loewy. Died peacefully at home on March 5, 1999. Cherished mother of Rena Bass Forman and son-in-law Dr. Scott Forman. Adoring grandmother of Leila and Zaria. Anne was a survivor whose existence was challenged many times during her lifetime. She will always be remembered by her family and friends for her strength and courage. May peace, love and light be with her now and always. Graveside service at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, on March 10 at 1 PM.

title: Patents; A spiral solution for the Patent Office's wondrous excess -- long, snaking and adaptable to libraries.
description: THE number of United States patents issued last year reached a record, jumping 31.5 percent from 1997, according to statistics recently released by the Patent Office.

title: 2 Sides Seek to Avert Voucher Showdown
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was willing to consider having City Hall, rather than the Board of Education, manage his plan to use city money for vouchers to pay tuition for private and religious schools, as advisers to the Mayor and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew sought a way to avert a showdown over the issue.

title: Bush Tests Presidential Run With a Flourish
description: In a grand pageant of political might, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas introduced the 10 members of his Presidential exploratory committee today, an ethnically and ideologically diverse tableau of some of the Republican Party's biggest names and most promising stars.

title: Criteria Are Set for Applicants To Join Internet Name Registry
description: Companies wanting to compete with Network Solutions Inc. and its current monopoly in the lucrative business of registering Internet domain names can begin applying for consideration next Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, J. JOSEPH
description: CASEY-J. Joseph. Retired corporate executive. Died March 5, 1999 in Belvedere, CA, following a brief illness. He was 77. Born in Boston on July 12, 1921, Mr. Casey grew up in New York and received his Bachelor's Degree from Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service in 1942. A veteran of World War II, Mr. Casey served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in the South Pacific from 1942-1946. Mr. Casey began his forty-year career in the construction industry with Wm. Casey & Sons, Inc. From 1957-1967, Mr. Casey served as V.P. and Controller of Raymond Int'l. In July, 1967, Mr. Casey moved to Hawaii to become a V.P. for Dillingham Corp., an international construction, energy and maritime company headquartered in Honolulu. During his twenty years with Dillingham, Mr. Casey frequently served as a ''troubleshooter'' for various divisions and subsidiaries in Hawaii, Australia and California. From 1982 until his retirement in 1987, Mr. Casey was President and C.E.O. of Dillingham. He was a member of several professional organizations including the Moles, Beavers, and Financial Executives Institute. An avid sailor throughout his life, Mr. Casey was a well-known racer on the waters of Long Island Sound, Honolulu, Sidney and San Francisco Bay. At the time of his death, Mr. Casey was an active member of the San Francisco based Knarr Fleet. Mr. Casey was married to Lynn Fallon Casey from 1948-1973 and to Marlene Forde Casey from 1973-1993. He is survived by his four children, Robin Casey and husband, Lou Kimball of Austin, TX; Todd Casey and wife, Joan of Northfield, MA; Reid Casey and wife, Barbara of Fremont, CA; and Ian Joseph Casey of San Francisco; his six grandchildren, Ben, Sean, Caitlin, Dylan, Alex and Flynn; his sister and brother-inlaw, Lillian and George Bantz; and brother James Casey. Mr. Casey was pre-deceased by his parents, William and Katherine Casey; his sister, Mary Romaine; and brother Bill Casey. A memorial service for Mr. Casey will be held on March 9, 1999, at Saint Hilary's Church in Tiburon, CA, followed by a gathering of family and friends at San Francisco Yacht Club. Memorial contributions in Mr. Casey's name may be made to the United Way, 50 California, San Francisco, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOSEPH, PATRICK
description: SMITH-Joseph, Patrick, Phelan, on March 8, 1999, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Madelyn Eleanor Davis. Loving father of Kevin, Karen, Margaret and Lisa. Grandfather of Zachary and Brendan. Founding President of Cinemavue Corp. President of Pathe News Inc. Served with U.S. Army, European and Asian Theaters, in 86th Infantry Division, WW II. Member, Motion Picture Pioneers and American Film Institute. Member, Elks Lodge and Knights of Columbus. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 at Fox Funeral Home Inc., Forest Hills. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Thursday, 10:15. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. Donations to Catholic Charities.

title: Poor Indians on Rich Land Fight a U.S. Maze
description: If she could look out her window, Mary Fish Basquez would see the ground that was given to her family long ago, land now being hollowed for oil that was supposed to mean a better life for Muscogee Indians.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about assertions by Clinton Administration officials that China stole nuclear secrets from an American Government laboratory owned by the Department of Energy misspelled the given name of the Energy Secretary who served for most of 1997 and 1998. He is Federico F. Pena, not Frederico.

title: Sports of The Times; 60 Years in Public's Eye: His Privacy, Pride, Ego and Dignity
description: FOR years, Joe DiMaggio had fresh flowers placed at Marilyn Monroe's grave; now he takes her memory to his grave. During the baseball memorabilia boom, he sold himself as an icon for the millions of dollars he never made as a player, but he never sold his memories of the Hollywood goddess he was married to for 274 days.

title: Manager Given Fine In Stock Fraud Case
description: A branch manager for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has agreed to pay $10,000 to settle regulators' accusations that he failed to supervise a broker who defrauded four elderly customers of more than $300,000, regulators said today.

title: Song of the Millennium: Cool Prelude and a Fiery Coda
description: The Northern Hemisphere has been warmer in the 20th century than in any other century of the last thousand years, according to this reconstruction of the hemispheric temperature record by scientists at the University of Massachusetts and the University of Arizona.

title: Aerospace Gets Japan's Message; Without Military Largess, Industry Takes the Lean Path
description: Two years ago, the B. F. Goodrich Company's aerospace division factory here fell so far behind schedule producing parts for the new Boeing 737-700 that the Boeing Company threatened to terminate the contract.

title: Fortis to Buy U.S. Company For $2.6 Billion Plus Debt
description: Fortis, one of the biggest insurance and banking companies in Europe, said yesterday that it would buy American Bankers Insurance Group, a Miami insurer that was the object of a bidding war by two big American companies last year, for $2.6 billion plus the assumption of nearly $200 million in debt.

title: U.S. Fires Scientist Suspected Of Giving China Bomb Data
description: A Taiwan-born scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory was fired today for security breaches after the F.B.I. questioned him in connection with China's suspected theft of American nuclear secrets, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HARRY

A loyal and diligent friend of the College, Mr. Meresman served on the BCF Board since 1971. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Lois S. Cronholm Interim President Baruch College

title: Crew Puts Off Threat to Resign As Clash Over Vouchers Eases

Giuliani standing at his side, New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday withdrew his threat to resign -- at least for now -- as the Mayor said he would make no immediate effort to use city money to send public-school students to private and religious schools.

title: Newspaper Ads Up 6.3% for the Year
description: The Newspaper Association of America said yesterday that spending on newspaper advertising last year rose 6.3 percent from 1997, to $43.9 billion, in line with expectations. National advertising grew 7.7 percent, to $5.7 billion. Retail advertising, which represents the largest portion of the total spending, gained 5.7 percent, to $20.3 billion. Classified advertising climbed 6.6 percent, to $17.9 billion.

title: Siemens Buys 2 Companies To Enter Data Networking
description: Siemens A.G. of Germany became the latest European maker of traditional telephone equipment to push into the market for data communications gear when it announced yesterday that it had acquired two private United States companies and invested in a third.

title: Joe DiMaggio, Yankee Clipper, Dies at 84
description: Joe DiMaggio, the flawless center fielder for the New York Yankees who, along with Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle, symbolized the team's dynastic success across the 20th century and whose 56-game hitting streak in 1941 made him an instant and indelible American folk hero, died early today at his home here. He was 84 years old.

description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that she would accompany Cabinet members and 100 business leaders on a 10-day trade mission to Brazil, Argentina and Chile beginning this week.

title: Wohlers Coming Back After a Disastrous Year
description: An act of courage, the pitching coach called it. No, it was more, he actually said. ''When Mark Wohlers went out to pitch the other day,'' Leo Mazzone proclaimed, ''that showed me more courage than any pitcher I've ever been around.''

title: Quietly, DNA Testing Transforms Sleuth's Job; But Practice Alarms Civil Libertarians
description: It could be considered a detective's dream. When the New York City police arrested a murder suspect last month, they had no physical evidence tying him to the slaying. Only days later, they were able to link him to that homicide, plus two others and the rapes of two teen-age girls. And it all came down to a cup of coffee.

He donated 120 acres of land in South Rockdale County Georgia to be maintained as the Ramon and Marley de Castro Nature Park. He is survived by brother Robert de Castro, Brookhaven, Georgia, and nieces and nephews. For information contact Harry White Funeral Home, Conyers, GA, 770-483-7216.

title: ALBEMARLE OFFERS $655 MILLION FOR ALBRIGHT & WILSON
description: The Albemarle Corporation, a specialty-chemical maker, said yesterday that it had offered $:408 million, or $655 million, for a troubled British chemical concern, Albright & Wilson P.L.C., and Albright urged shareholders to accept the bid. Albemarle, based in Richmond, said the companies had complementary product lines in flame retardants, pharmaceuticals, consumer product ingredients, agricultural chemicals and water-treatment products. Albemarle has 2,700 workers worldwide and had sales of $820.9 million last year. Albright has 4,500 employees and had sales of $1.2 billion in 1997. Shares of Albemarle fell $1.50, to $23.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Albright rose 19.5 pence, to 129.5 pence, in London trading.

This is instead a story about how Ms. Lucci spent last weekend in a small bit of the Iditarod, the 1,000-mile dog sled race in Alaska, although she does not exactly seem the subzero, Anchorage-to-Nome type.

That's a shame, because the Administration's rather convoluted explanations seem to have obscured the essence of a rather good proposal. The substance of the policy is actually far better than the spin.

title: TransTexas Hires Adviser
description: The TransTexas Gas Corporation, which explores for oil and natural gas in Texas, said today that it had hired Jefferies & Company as its financial adviser because it was considering asset sales, strategic alliances and cost-cutting measures in an effort to raise cash. The Texas investor John Stanley owns the bulk of TransTexas. TransTexas and its parent, the TransAmerican Energy Corporation, are also seeking approval from certain bondholders to change the terms of some debt either in default or with the potential for default.

title: Joe DiMaggio Highway? The Question Is Where

description: An education bill with bipartisan support got bogged down on the Senate floor today as Republicans feuded with Democrats over President Clinton's initiative to reduce class sizes.

title: Susan McDougal Back in Arkansas for Trial
description: A still-defiant Susan H. McDougal returned to Little Rock today to stand trial on charges that she attempted to block the Whitewater investigation by refusing to tell a grand jury about the personal and political finances of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Getting Beyond the Birds and the Bees
description: Many children as young as 10 years old want to know more about sex than just where babies come from, but parents often shy away from discussing sexuality, according to a national survey conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now, a children's advocacy group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, SAMUEL
description: BLOCH-Samuel. On March 8, 1999. Graduate of Brown University ''41''. Devoted husband of Thelma, caring father of Peter and Delise. Services Tuesday at 11am, ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Cardiovasuclar Institute of Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: The Silent Superstar
description: My opinions regarding the baseball legend Joe DiMaggio would be of no particular interest to the general public were it not for the fact that 30 years ago I wrote the song ''Mrs. Robinson,'' whose lyric ''Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you'' alluded to and in turn probably enhanced DiMaggio's stature in the American iconographic landscape.

title: En Route to Spring, a Chilly Detour
description: Lillian Molina, a crossing guard at Public School 321 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, raised her arms in stiff and slow motions to urge children across the street yesterday.

title: Strumming, Singing and Gathering Emotion
description: Nearly all of Shawn Mullins's songwriting strategies show up in his hit single, ''Lullaby.'' Musically, the verses are spoken with confidential intimacy, while the chorus leaps upward to reveal Mr. Mullins's falsetto. The lyrics are a character study of a person in a specific place -- a spoiled, troubled child of Hollywood -- with a chorus, ''Everything's gonna be all right,'' that proffers a happy Hollywood movie ending.

description: Barbara Pfeffer, a photojournalist whose pictures appeared in Life, People, Town and Country and other magazines, died March 3 in her Manhattan home. She was 65.

description: ''You know what I do when I'm angry? I hit a pillow. Try that,'' suggests the psychiatrist, played by Billy Crystal, to his New York gangster client (Robert De Niro) in the Warner Brothers movie ''Analyze This.'' But it is bad advice, according to new research by social psychologists.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell on concern that Japanese exporters were taking advantage of the dollar's recent gain and bringing overseas earnings home. In New York, the dollar fell to 121.66 yen, from 122.80 on Friday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A trash hauler is buying a much bigger rival, a type of deal that makes Wall Street a bit nervous.
description: WHEN Allied Waste Industries announced yesterday that it would acquire Browning-Ferris Industries, a much bigger rival in the trash hauling business, Allied's message was simple: We can better manage those huge assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, ALAN J.
description: HARWOOD-Alan J. On March 6, 1999. Beloved husband and best friend of Terry. Dearest father of Michael and Ann. Dear brother-inlaw of Jim Schare. Loving uncle and good friend to many. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Journalist Sentenced to 18 Months in Internet Pornography Case
description: A veteran journalist who said he had been researching an article on child molesters was sentenced today to 18 months in prison for distributing child pornography over the Internet.

title: A shift in power for J. Walter Thompson as Madison Avenue's Steel Magnolia climbs aboard.
description: CHARLOTTE BEERS, often called the most powerful woman in advertising, is for the third time becoming a top leader at a giant agency.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS BUYS STAKE IN WAM NET FOR $75 MILLION
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired an 8.6 percent stake in Wam Net Inc. for $75 million in cash and real estate. The deal, which is part of an alliance between the companies, also makes Silicon Graphics the preferred provider of Wam Net's computing systems for four years. The closely held Wam Net, based in Minneapolis, develops data applications for the graphics and entertainment industries. Under the deal, Wam Net acquired Silicon Graphics' $40 million campus in Eagan, Minn., part of which Silicon Graphics will lease back. Silicon Graphics is a computer maker based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRYSTALL, HEIDI
description: KRYSTALL-Heidi. March 6, 1999. Beloved daughter of Lois and Herb. In our hearts and memories forever.

title: Little Change In Treasuries After Rally Of Last Week
description: Bond prices were little changed yesterday, after rising smartly on Friday, amid increased prospects that tame inflation will keep the Federal Reserve from increasing rates any time soon even as the economy expands.

title: Contemporaries Remember Him As the Best Baseball Had to Offer
description: They remembered Joe DiMaggio fondly and sadly yesterday and with the familiar words that had become forever linked with the player who treated center field at Yankee Stadium like his own playground. Class. Grace. Dignity. Greatness. The men who played with and against DiMaggio took deep breaths, forced their minds to rewind and spoke in reverential tones about perhaps the greatest all-round baseball player.

title: It Takes a Scientist to Tie a Necktie, 85 Different Ways
description: Scientists are constantly striving to do good for the common man. Now, two physicists in Britain have come to the aid of the well-dressed one.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about House and Senate bills for emergency aid to Central American storm victims misstated the title of Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas. He is the majority whip, not the minority whip.

title: Joltin Joe Has Left and Gone Away
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Just Ruling in Cable-Car Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ICF KAISER INTERNATIONAL INC., Fairfax, Va., an engineering and construction services company, said it planned to sell its consulting unit to the New York-based investment firm CM Equity Partners L.P., for $75 million to concentrate on its other businesses.

title: Linux Supplier to Get Equity Investment
description: Red Hat Software Inc., a start-up based in Durham, N.C., that distributes and provides technical support for the Linux operating system, plans to announce today that it has received equity investments from some of the technology industry's most influential companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHMAN, MURRAY
description: GERSHMAN-Murray. Loving husband of Lenore; children, Alice Treinis and Steven. Daughter-inlaw, Gail. Devoted sisters, Mary Pastor and Mollie Seid. Grandfather of adored Lara, Daniel, Alex and Scott. Served as air specialist in E.T.O. and over fifty-year member of B'nai Brith and PioneerMount Menorah #

title: Billy Jack Gaither's Life and Death
description: Only 40 miles from the freedom and anonymity of Birmingham, Billy Jack Gaither chose to stay in Sylacauga, Ala., population 13,000 souls, none of them openly gay. He worked in a nearby factory and lived at home with his parents, caring for them. In his bedroom Mr. Gaither hung a picture of Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable in ''Gone With the Wind'' -- the classic image for Southerners of life lost that might have been. In the living room, where he never troubled his devoutly Baptist parents with the truth about his homosexuality, he hung renderings of Jesus and the Ten Commandments. One of them seems especially his: ''Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.''

title: Foreign Affairs; KillingGoliath.com
description: I recently wrote a column about Lyle Bowlin, who, for about $150 a month, had managed to put together a Web site that could compete with Amazon.com for selling books. Mr. Bowlin was underselling Ama zon.com (and making a profit!) while running the whole operation out of a spare bedroom in his home in Cedar Falls, Iowa. Well, the column elicited the usual range of skeptical responses from experts, who argued that Mr. Bowlin's operation was just a fluke, or that he wasn't calculating his costs properly, or that Amazon.com would soon crush him and all other would-be little-guy competitors.

title: Rodgers Songs to Sate the Closet Romantic
description: ''Ladies and gentlemen: melody!'' announced Jonathan Schwartz on Friday from the stage of Alice Tully Hall where the second round of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series presented a two-evening tribute to Richard Rodgers. Even before Mr. Schwartz, the evening's host, made his declaration, it was clear that the acoustical and orchestral problems that had plagued the series's initial concerts last month had been solved.

title: A Just Ruling in Cable-Car Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Fluor Is Expected to Announce Revamping
description: The Fluor Corporation, the nation's largest engineering and construction company, is expected to announce a reorganization Tuesday that will result in $160 million in annual cost savings, according to a person close to the company.

title: Review/Fashion; In Praise of Short Memories
description: The bigger names in Italian fashion may lead impeccably civilized lives up in their art-filled palazzi, but give one of these titans of chic a rich, feel-good dish like risotto and suddenly the napkin is under the chin and he's hogging the whole platter of congealed rice for himself. Such a scene was recounted last week after a lunch for a small group of magazine editors, and while the witnesses said they didn't go hungry (the designer's cook fed them pasta), the risotto story hints at the self-centered isolation of Milan's Old Guard, who for too long have held onto the pot.

title: New I.M.F. Aid Pact Further Limits Brazil
description: The Brazilian Government and the International Monetary Fund announced a revised loan agreement today that commits Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, to more stringent conditions for receiving further aid.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: How Asteroids Jump

title: Chinese Nuclear Espionage
description: It is alarming to discover that lax security at the Los Alamos nuclear weapons laboratory in the mid-1980's may have let China steal secret designs for one of America's most compact nuclear warheads. It is also troubling to learn that the Clinton Administration did not react vigorously enough when it first heard of this possible breach of national security nearly four years ago. Some Administration officials suggest that the White House may have minimized the case to insulate its goal of improving relations with Beijing.

title: Arts Center in Newark Plans an Ailey Tribute
description: A 40th-anniversary tribute to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and two performances by the Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman are among the 1999-2000 season offerings at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. The season opens Sept. 26 with a solo performance by the singer and composer Bobby McFerrin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, RONALD
description: KING-Ronald. Died March 7, 1999, at age 72, of liver disease. Beloved husband of Lucille Gerber King for 48 years; cherished father of Larry and Peter; adored grandfather of David, and treasured father-in-law of Amy Katcher and Danny Stone. A widely respected Fairfield County (CT) real estate attorney for nearly 50 years, he will be remembered fondly by many colleagues and associates who relied on his encyclopedic knowledge and outstanding legal skills. Mourned by brother, Bert, and many cherished nephews, nieces, cousins and other members of the King, Gerber, Nyary, Levine and Folb families. He was a major presence and gained the respect and admiration of all who knew him. Services Tuesday, Noon, at Gallagher's, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Conn. (203-327-1313).

title: Turning Hip-Hop's Flash Heavenward
description: Kirk Franklin knows how to drag divinity out of culture's tackiest corners. At the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday this preacher turned pop star led the Nu Nation -- a 12-piece choir, 5-piece band and dance troupe -- through an evening marked by the casual intimacy of daytime talk shows, the flash of pop hip-hop and the overheated feeling of smooth love songs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKSTERN, REISS, HAZZAN JOSHUA
description: GLUCKSTERN - REISS - Hazzan Joshua. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a beloved colleague who fought a valiant battle with Leukemia. A 1998 graduate of the H.L. Miller Cantorial School of the J.T.S.A. He was an outstanding student and brilliant star upon the horizon of Hazzanut. He served as cantor of Congregation Gates of Prayer, Flushing, New York. His kindness, humanity and caring inspires us all. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Rabbi Karen, his parents and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, Pres. Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Exec. VP Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Exec. Administrator

title: William McGonagle, 73, Hero Of Israel Attack on the Liberty
description: William L. McGonagle, who as a Navy captain won a Medal of Honor for maintaining control of the technical research ship Liberty although wounded when the ship was attacked by Israel in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, died on Wednesday in his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENBIN, ETTA
description: DENBIN-Etta (nee) Ezersky. Beloved wife of the late Alex, adored sister of Libby Daimont and the late Louis, George, David, Harry, Rebecca and Dora, cherished Aunt, great Aunt and great, great Aunt. You were our role model. Services are today, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: LANDRY'S SEAFOOD CALLS OFF PLAN TO BUY CONSOLIDATED
description: Landry's Seafood Restaurants Inc. dropped its plan to buy the closely held Consolidated Restaurant Companies, owner of the El Chico and Spaghetti Warehouse chains, citing the disapproval of some shareholders and a fall in its stock price. The Houston-based Landry's would have paid $84 million in stock and assumed $80 million of Consolidated's debt. Landry's owns Landry's Seafood House, Joe's Crab Shack and the Crab House chains. Landry's shares, which had fallen 25 percent since the deal was announced last Tuesday, rose 62.5 cents each, yesterday, to $5.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Video Monitors Planned for Troubled Nassau Jail
description: Facing a Federal investigation of reports of abuse by guards at the county jail, the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, announced today a series of initiatives, including the installation of surveillance cameras throughout the troubled correctional center.

title: This Bout Can Carry Its Own Weight
description: The heavyweight title is the crown jewel of boxing, which is evidenced by the fact that more than 19,000 fans, some of them paying $1,500 for ringside seats, will pack Madison Square Garden on Saturday night to see Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis battle for the increasingly rare honor of becoming the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world.

title: $2.2 Billion in Bonds Offered in Malaysia
description: Renong Bhd., Malaysia's biggest industrial company, said yesterday that its cash-rich toll road unit would sell 8.4 billion ringgit ($2.2 billion) in bonds to bail out the parent company, after Renong failed to secure a state-backed rescue. The bond sale, the largest ever by a Malaysian company, will avert the collapse of the country's largest construction concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBB, BERNE J.
description: KOBB-Berne J. On 6th of March, 1999 of Melville, L.I. Loving husband of Terry. Devoted father of Andrea, Maia, and Jessica. Proud grandfather of Danny, David , Jamie and Brian. Successful entrepreneur and CEO of ACI Electronics corp, a nationwide corproration comprised of seven branch offices with corporate headquarters located in Plainview, L.I. Berne enjoyed a sportive lifestyle, which included boating, tennis and golf. He wintered in Palm Beach Gardens FL to extend his opportunity to enjoy these pleasures. Berne was deeply loved and admired by his family, friends, employees, and all that had the joy of knowing him. He will be eternally missed. Services today, 12:15PM, ''Gutterman's'' Chapel, Woodbury, L.I. Interment, Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, L.I. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in his honor be made to either The Nature Conservancy, or Cousteau Society.

title: The Thoroughly Modern Eleanor
description: Eleanor Holm Whalen had not ventured inside the White House in 66 years -- ''Sweetheart, Franklin Roosevelt was the President'' -- but the sassy former Olympic swimmer acted as if she had been a regular guest of the next 10 Presidents.

title: U.S. Says Kosovo Rebels Are Ready to Sign Peace Pact
description: The ethnic Albanian rebel army in Kosovo has told the United States that its leaders are ready to sign a peace agreement intended to end months of fighting in the troubled province and to allow for the entry of a NATO peacekeeping force, the State Department announced today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Herbal Remedies Tied to Pregnancy Risks
description: Many women trying to become pregnant are careful to avoid ingesting any substance that might impair their fertility or damage a developing embryo. According to a new study, several popular herbal remedies should be added to the list of substances that could have detrimental effects on men as well as women and could interfere with conception or a healthy pregnancy.

title: A 'Bonus' From Mars: Evidence Of Its Past; Glitch Gives a Spacecraft More Time for Photographs
description: Mars is coming into much better focus, so clearly that scientists think they now see in the towering mountains, layered canyon walls and meandering channels telling traces of the planet's early history, when volcanoes belched gases into a denser, warmer atmosphere and rivers flowed across the russet plains. It was a time, more than three billion years ago, when conditions on Mars seemed much more hospitable to life than today's cold desert environment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 22 about the workload of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission misidentified the defendant in a class action discrimination lawsuit won by the agency. The suit resulted in a settlement with the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's American subsidiary, not the Mitsubishi Corporation.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: After the 41 Shots
description: The police shooting of Amadou Diallo continues to reverberate, most recently with charges from the Diallo family lawyers that the police tried to taint or ''dirty up'' the unarmed West African immigrant after he was killed in a hail of 41 police bullets outside his Bronx apartment. In the hours after Mr. Diallo's death last month, the family lawyers contend that police investigators ransacked his apartment and questioned his roommates about his character and possible enemies without telling them that it was the police who had shot their friend and kinsman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMAGGIO, JOE
description: DiMAGGIO-Joe. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Joe DiMaggio. We are honored and proud to have been touched by this legendary athlete. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot Executive Director

title: Today's Yankees Mourn a Timeless Hero
description: They began paying tribute to Joe DiMaggio here early this morning, fans old and young visiting the pinstriped plaque erected in his name outside Legends Field, many of them wearing Yankees caps. A few brought flowers, others took pictures, some prayed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWENSTEIN, BOB
description: LOWENSTEIN-Bob. March 9, 1995 Too soon, much too soon, we will never forget. Dad and Han

title: Safir Denies Charge Police Tried to Taint Diallo's Reputation
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir acknowledged yesterday that police investigators entered the home of Amadou Diallo and questioned his roommates in the hours after officers fatally shot the unarmed man. But the Commissioner strongly denied any suggestions that they were trying to taint Mr. Diallo's character to justify the shooting.

title: Living Proof: Mammograms Are Not Always Enough
description: Ten years ago I wrote a column that might have been called ''the myth of the negative mammogram.'' In it I discussed the fact that 10 percent to 15 percent of breast cancers do not show up on a mammogram and cautioned women that any suspicious area in the breast should be biopsied even when the mammogram is negative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONHEIM, NATALIE B.
description: KONHEIM-Natalie B. Of Longboat Key, Florida. Died March 7, 1999 at the age of 81. Natalie lived in Woodmere, New York, until ten years ago when she moved to Longboat Key. She is survived by her husband, Norris Konheim, to whom she was married for 60 years. She is also survived by her daughter, Patty Goldenberg of Newton, MA., and her son-in-law, Dr. Don Goldenberg, and her grandchildren Wendy Hagen of Shelburne, VT, and Julie Goldenberg of Portland, OR. She is also survived by Kenneth Robinson and Alice Robinson of New York City, the children of Natalie and Norris' other daughter, Nancy K. Robinson, who died in 1994. Natalie was also the great-grandmother of Michael and Julia Hagen, the children of Thom and Wendy Hagen. Condolence calls can be made March 8-11 at the Konheim's apartment on Longboat Key at 4430 Exeter Drive, Apt. M107, (941) 383-0095. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota, FL 34238.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBB, BERNARD J.
description: KOBB-Bernard J. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Terry, daughters Andrea, Maia & Jessie, two sons-in-law and four grandsons. We lose a compassionate and understanding human being who helped family, friends and strangers. Goodbye dear friend. Pollan, Mauner & Wess

title: Britain Postpones the Creation of Ulster's Cabinet for 3 Weeks
description: Britain announced a three-week postponement today in the effort to create an executive cabinet that is to give the Roman Catholic minority more power and return home rule to this British province.

title: Southern Shipyard to Build 2 Large Passenger Vessels
description: A shipyard in Mississippi is planning to announce Tuesday that it will build two cruise ships, the first big passenger ships built in this country since 1958.

title: India Revokes Takeover of Poorest, Second Most Populous State
description: Bowing to certain defeat in the upper house of Parliament, the Indian Government today revoked its takeover of the government of Bihar, the poorest and second most populous state.

title: 2 Innings Later, Met Pitcher Feels Better
description: Pop went the sound of Jason Isringhausen's fastball, not his elbow. Snap went the knuckle curve, not his shoulder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, HARRY COLE III
description: BATES-Harry Cole III. Died March 4 in his 70th year at his home in Westbrook, CT. A graduate of the Hackley School and of Hamilton College, he earned an M.A. from Columbia in American History, and had taught that subject in independent and public schools in NY and CT. A memorial service was held March 6 in the Church of the Holy Advent, Clinton, CT. He is survived by brothers, Robert P. Turner of Weston, CT and Charles T. Bates of Irvington, NY, and by many nieces and nephews.

title: TV Station Sale For $46 Million
description: The Sunrise Television Corporation, an affiliate of the buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., agreed today to sell a Rochester television station to the Nexstar Broadcasting Group for $46 million as part of its long-term growth strategy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL JUMPS. Crude oil rose after Saudi Arabia and Iran said they would try to persuade the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production. In New York, crude oil rose 33 cents, to $13.63 a barrel.

title: Former Cocaine User Regains Child in Racial Custody Case
description: In a tug-of-war over a toddler that embodied issues of race, class and power in Chicago, a judge ruled today that Edward M. Burke, a powerful alderman, and his wife, Anne Burke, a state appellate judge, must return the child to the birth mother, who has overcome an addiction to drugs.

title: Ann Corio, a Burlesque Queen on Broadway, Is Dead
description: Ann Corio, the auburn-haired, green-eyed queen of burlesque whose long-running show, ''This Was Burlesque,'' kept alive the art of strippers and the comedy of baggy-pants clowns in the age of the X-rated film, died on March 1 at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. Ms. Corio, a resident of Cliffside Park, N.J., kept her age a closely guarded secret, but was believed to be in her 80's.

title: A Clemency Case Puts a Governor on the Spot
description: Little more than a month after bowing to a plea from the Pope and commuting the death sentence of a confessed triple killer, the Governor of Missouri faces the clemency petition of a condemned man who has submitted to a lie detector test to buttress his claim of innocence.

title: Help for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: HOMESTAKE MINING TO BUY A CANADIAN GOLD COMPANY
description: The Homestake Mining Company agreed yesterday to buy the Argentina Gold Corporation, a Canadian company with a majority stake in a promising gold property in South America, for $200 million in stock. Homestake will acquire each of Argentina Gold's shares outstanding for 0.545 Homestake share, or $5.14 each at Friday's closing stock price. Homestake, a San Francisco-based company, will issue 21 million additional shares. Argentina Gold, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, owns a 60 percent interest in the Veladero project in northwest Argentina. Veladero holds an estimated 4.5 million ounces of gold and 100 million ounces of silver. Shares of Homestake fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $8.875.

title: A Ritual Remembered
description: To The Editor:

title: Clinton's Total Recall
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSUEI, SR. JOSEPHINE
description: TSUEI-Sr. Josephine, M.S.C. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, the administration and staff of Cabrini Medical Center, and the medical staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of our beloved sister and esteemed colleague, Sr. Josephine Tsuei, who served as President of Cabrini Medical Center until 1990. Viewing hours Tuesday, 7pm-9pm, Wednesday, 8am-8pm at the Chapel of Cabrini Medical Center, 227 East 19 Street. Funeral mass, Thursday, March 11, 10am, Epiphany Church, Second Avenue, Manhattan. Sr. Diane Dalle Molle, M.S.C. Provincial Superior Jeffrey Frerichs, President Thomas Dunleavy, Chairman of the Board

title: Kittles Won't Let Deadline To Re-Sign Force His Hand
description: Kerry Kittles hears John Calipari praise the smoothness of his game and the calmness of his personality and wonders what is wrong. Kittles hears his coach say he will eventually be one of the league's 10 best players, a fixture on the Eastern Conference All-Star team, then asks himself why he and the Nets have not come to terms on a contract extension.

title: Court Leaves Intact Immigrants' Rights
description: The Supreme Court yesterday left intact legal protections that are available to immigrants facing deportation orders.

title: A Fighting Journalist Finds His Roots in a Fearful Child
description: After Argentina's junta freed him in 1979, Jacobo Timerman's testament of prison life, torture and anti-Semitism stirred comparisons to Dostoyevsky, Camus and Hannah Arendt. ''Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number'' brought Mr. Timerman lasting fame and fortune, and he went on to write critically acclaimed books on Chile, Cuba and Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, OSCAR
description: WARNER-Oscar. Of Boynton Beach, Florida, on March 8th, 1999 at the age of 77 after a lengthy illness and courageous struggle. Beloved husband of Ethel, devoted father of Stephen and Robert and of Peter and Lani, and devoted grandfather of Barbara, David, Elizabeth, Stephanie, and Lindsey. Brother of Jean Brooks and the late Seymour Warner. He was an inspiration to all who knew him because of his tenacity and fierce determination to live despite debilitating chronic illnesses and for his gentleness and compassion. Memorial service date to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, RALPH
description: JAFFE-Ralph. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of American ORT, deeply mourn the passing of its long-time generous supporter and friend, who served as an officer and member of our Board for many years, was a founder of our Plumbers and Real Estate Divisions, and the recipient of The American ORT William Haber Award for distinguished service in 1991. Educated at The ORT School in Kovno, Lithuania in the 1930's, Ralph was a major contributor to ORT Guttman in Netanya and ORT Syngalowski in Tel-Aviv, Israel. A founder of ORT Braude in Karmiel, Israel, his commitment to the global mission of ORT is his legacy to ORT students worldwide. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Trudy, two children, Leonard and Rochelle, and five grandchildren. Michael R. Stoler, Pres. Joe Cohen, First VP Brian J. Strum, Exec. VP Paul I. Bernick, Exec Dir Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, ROTHENBERG
description: SUMNER - ROTHENBERG - Pame la. 42. Beloved wife of Richard Rothenberg, died suddenly on Saturday, March 6, 1999. She is deeply mourned by her parents, Martha and Nolan Sumner of Dallas, Texas; by her in-laws, Marion and Jack Rothenberg of New York; by her brother, Bill and his wife, Sabrina; and by her sister-inlaw Ellen Klein, her husband, Michael and their son, Andrew. Pam, a gifted pianist and graduate of North Texas State University, played in many Broadway musicals. Her talents and skills were internationally recognized and praised. She will be affectionately remembered and greatly missed by all. Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, March 11, 1:00 pm at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street (at Central Park West).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, NATHANIEL
description: SAMUELS-Nathaniel. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on March 21 at 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. and 65 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to the Harvard College Fund-Maurice and Sarah Samuels Fund, c/o The Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: The DiMaggio Mystique
description: I has been almost half a century since Joe DiMaggio turned his center-field kingdom in Yankee Stadium over to a strapping youngster named Mickey Mantle, but even now, in death, DiMaggio still owns that green acreage. He roamed the great open spaces there with a grace and grandeur that redefined the art of fielding. Even more than the prolific hitting that earned him enduring fame, his silky, seemingly effortless motion across the outfield grass was the signature of his game.

title: ANALYSIS AND TECHNOLOGY TO BE ACQUIRED BY ANTEON
description: Analysis and Technology Inc., a provider of engineering and information-technology consulting services based in North Stonington, Conn., agreed to be acquired by the Anteon Corporation for about $104 million in cash as Anteon expands into New England. Anteon, based in Fairfax, Va., is an information-technology company. Anteon said it would pay $26 a share for Analysis and Technology's four million shares outstanding. Analysis and Technology's stock rose $2.625 a share, to $24.50, yesterday.

title: Keller To Miss Nike Cup
description: UNITED STATES MEN

title: Lexmark Divides And Chooses
description: Lexmark International, which makes and markets laser and ink jet printers, has ended a review for its account, with billings estimated at $20 million, by dividing it into creative and media portions and naming two agencies to handle those duties.

title: Lycos Board Member Quits to Protest Deal
description: Pressing his campaign to block the proposed deal between Lycos Inc. and USA Networks Inc., David S. Wetherell, who controls the largest block of Lycos stock, has resigned from the Lycos board. Mr. Wetherell is the chairman of CMGI Inc., a technology investment fund that owns 18.5 percent of Lycos.

title: A Killer Just Loaded With Charm
description: ''I'm a pretty little fellow,'' sings Matthew Broderick, alone on the stage of the Lyceum Theater, and at that moment, he certainly is. His eyes shut, his voice sweet and liquid, the open-faced Mr. Broderick has never looked or sounded so much the choirboy, as he croons a phrase from the dusty sentimental favorite ''Mighty Lak' a Rose.''

title: Health Concern Hired by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, hired a consultant today to help plan medical treatments for 60,000 salaried workers and their dependents, an effort it says will make health care more consistent and control its $4.5 billion annual tab.

title: Samford Pins Hopes on 3-Pointers
description: Here is the first clue that Samford, St. John's first-round opponent in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, is a Princeton-style team: the coach quotes Dante.

title: To Uneasy Laughter, Surreal and Creepy Sexual Innuendo
description: The dream program of the Paul Taylor Dance Company's current season turned up on Sunday night at City Center. Mr. Taylor's deliciously Gothic romance ''Nightshade'' and his hilarious ''Offenbach Overtures'' are works to take along when stranded on a desert island.

title: Mob Figure Kills Himself During His Murder Trial
description: An associate of the Genovese organized-crime family killed himself last week while on trial in a murder case, eight months after his father-in-law, another Genovese family associate, killed himself during another murder trial, officials said yesterday.

title: A Worrier's Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Property Taxes In Nassau Called Biased
description: The Justice Department says Nassau County's method of assessing property taxes discriminates against black and Hispanic homeowners, causing them to pay disproportionately high taxes, according to Government documents.

title: KODAK SAYS IT MAY SELL EASTMAN SOFTWARE DIVISION
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photography company, said yesterday that it might sell its unprofitable Eastman Software division. The unit, which Kodak acquired two years ago from Wang Laboratories Inc. for $260 million, makes software that companies use to update and track huge amounts of paperwork. Kodak told investors at a meeting last month that ''the acquisition of Eastman Software did not work out as hoped and that we're examining that piece of our portfolio,'' a company spokesman, Charles Smith, said. Mr. Smith declined to say how much money the unit was losing or to disclose its revenue. The potential sale of Eastman Software, based in Billerica, Mass., was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Seles Loses Focus and Match
description: She remembered her racquet, but Monica Seles picked the wrong day to forget her thinking cap when she headed to the Stadium Court yesterday for her third-round Evert Cup encounter with Slovakia's Henrieta Nagyova. It was not the best tactic in a sport that prides itself on being a mind game, and a dazed Seles paid for her negligence: she found herself clobbered, 6-2, 6-4, in just over an hour in Indian Wells, Calif.

title: In Search of Fairness in Patient Care
description: Q. Should patients be able to sue their health maintenance organizations? ALISHA BERGER

title: On Baseball; Amid Crumbling Records, A Streak That Will Endure
description: Tommy Henrich walked toward home plate. It was the first inning of the second game of a doubleheader in 1941, and the Yankees' right fielder was preparing to face Jack Wilson, the Boston Red Sox right-hander. Suddenly, Henrich heard a voice behind him.

title: Athletic Eligibility: Key N.C.A.A. Rule Is Voided as Biased
description: A Federal District Court in Philadelphia discarded the National Collegiate Athletic Association's minimum test score requirement for athletic scholarships yesterday, throwing into disarray the principal criterion for establishing eligibility for student-athletes.

title: Fusion Cooking for a Ming Ritual
description: The ''Peony Pavilion'' wars have been of a civil nature up to now: traditionalists arguing among themselves about how a 400-year-old Chinese opera should be put before the public. Disputes over theatrical interpretation are often loud, but this one became an international incident a year ago, much to the consternation of the Lincoln Center Festival, which found its imported centerpiece suddenly canceled by bureaucrats in Shanghai.

title: Antarctica's Frigid Waters Form Evolutionary Caldron
description: Miserably cold, dark for three months of the year and crowded with icebergs, the Antarctic seas hardly seem the sort of place to look for an overabundance of life. But in these frigid waters at the bottom of the earth, scientists are uncovering what appears to be an evolutionary explosion that has generated an impressive array of cold fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SADIE
description: RUBEN-Sadie. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Sadie Ruben, beloved mother of Robert Ruben, M.D., director of Montefiore's Robert Ruben, M.D., Communications Disorders Institute, distinguished University Professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and former Chairman of the Department of Otolaryngology at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. We extend our sincere condolences to her son and her entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President Jay B. Langner, Chairman, Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: John Lusk, 91, Dies; Built California Suburbs
description: John D. Lusk, a real-estate developer who played a major role in transforming rural Southern California into suburbs after World War II, died on Feb. 28 at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 91.

title: Moviegoers Vs. Theaters: Food Fight!
description: THE tempest of the season for many here has nothing to do with upstate snows, school vouchers, police shootings or whither Hillary. No, the big storm is over the fact that it now costs $9.50 to see a movie at Loews, Cineplex Odeon and Sony Theaters in the city. That's four bits more than two weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LARRY
description: MILLER-Larry. 58, of Marlboro Twp., died Sunday, March 7, 1999. Husband of Joan (Nee Grilihas), father of Seth and Michael, brother to Susan Sobel, and son of Ruth Miller. Services were held Monday, March 8, 1999, from the Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Ave, Manalapan, NJ. Burial followed at the Marlboro Memorial Park, Marlboro, NJ.

description: SAXE-Frederick L. Suddenly on March 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Evangeline E. Yabut. Son of Fred and Eleanore Saxe. Brother of MaryAnn, Eleanore, Annie and Dick (deceased). Visitation Tuesday 4-8 PM, Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, 1:00PM, Our Lady of Peace Church, 2nd Av. & 62 St

title: What's So Funny?; Decoding That Enigma Called Humor And Failing Gleefully
description: At one point the question before the group was whether there was any subject too dark to be claimed by humor. The Holocaust? Cross burning? AIDS? And Martin Short, the actor and sketch comedian, brought up the case of Doug Tracht, a k a the Greaseman, the radio shock jock who was fired by a Washington station after playing a song by the Grammy winner Lauryn Hill, a black singer, and dismissing the music with a reference to the racially motivated murder of a black man in Jasper, Tex.

title: New Bandage Could Avert Thousands of Deaths
description: It is a common, yet horrifying image. A traffic accident, a shooting, a fall or a stabbing. And the victim lies dead in a pool of blood, life drained away by severe hemorrhaging that could not be stopped in time.

title: Man, 72, Jumps to His Death in Midtown
description: A 72-year-old man, after telephoning a friend to say that he was going to kill himself, jumped 22 stories to the pavement from the top of his midtown Manhattan apartment building, shocking lunchtime crowds along the busy Avenue of the Americas, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Government and Intel Reach Antitrust Settlement

title: Brazilian Martial Art for Mind and Body
description: It had been over two years since my last visit to the gym, and it was beginning to show. While on a business trip last December, I was dismayed when I stepped out of the shower into a bathroom that could have doubled as a shrine to Narcissus. I noticed that the abdominal six-pack I once maintained almost effortlessly was threatening to become a keg. The shoulders that had given my body a horizon line, sagged so that they were hard to differentiate from my lower trunk. And the arms, while never pythons, were once sinewy cobras that could have belonged to a dancer. Now they were garden snakes.

title: Power Dressing on the Playing Field
description: Linda Cherny played a mean game of volleyball at the Empire State Games in Syracuse a few weeks back. A 36-year-old day care provider from Kingston, N.Y., she spiked hard and jumped high. And, she says, she owes it all to her shorts.

title: Midwest Chain Acquiring J. Peterman of 'Seinfeld' Fame
description: J. Peterman, a brand name that became known to millions of television viewers because of the long-winded, well-traveled character on ''Seinfeld,'' has been acquired by a Midwestern chain of women's clothing stores and is expected to retain its prominently positioned store at Grand Central Terminal.

Most cherished and loving grandfather of Howard and Suellen Singer, Richard & Lisa Singer, and Jonas Cooper. Loving great-grandfather of Melanie, Eric and Blake Singer. description: In a case being closely watched by lawyers and investigators, a group of seven prosecutors and sheriff's deputies will go on trial on Tuesday, charged with conspiring to frame an innocent man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIVIAN, ANNA LEVY
description: CHIVIAN-Anna Levy. A well known local singer in her youth, as well as a prize winning sculptor who studied with Chaim Gross, died in her sleep on Saturday, March 5, 1999, at her home in South Orange, NJ. She was 96. Born on February 10, 1903 in Newark, NJ, she was the daughter of Sadie and Louis Levy. From 1921 until 1945 she was chief bookkeeper for the firm of Levy and Fiorito of East Newark and Irvington, NJ. She was the widow of Dr. Jacob L. Chivian a dentist who practiced in Newark and South Orange and was affiliated with Newark Beth Israel Medical Center. Together with her late husband they were founders of the Hadassah Hebrew University Dental School in Jerusalem. She was active in Newark House, Hadassah, Miriam sisterhood and Congregation Oheb Shalom. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Simona Chivian Chazen and Jerome Chazen and her son and daughterin-law, Dr. Noah Chivian and Nancy Barrie Chivian, another daughter Naomi Chivian Parker died in 1974. She was also survived by a brother David, eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Funeral services were conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd, Union, NJ on Monday, March 8, 1999 at 1:00 PM. Contributions may be sent to: EIES of New Jersey, 59 Scotland Road, South Orange, NJ 07079.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINKHAM, MARY S.
description: PINKHAM-Mary S. (''Bunnie''). On March 8, 1999. Born in New York City December 28, 1916, the dear daughter of the late William W. and Mary G. Struthers. Adoring wife of Richard Alden Ray Pinkham, whom she married in 1941, who died in 1997. Loving and dedicated mother of Mary P. (''Penny'') Janeway of Cambridge, MA, Richard Jr. of Rye, NY, David of Barrington, RI and Elizabeth P. (''Betty'') Anderson of Billings, MT. Delighted grandmother of Sam, Daisy, Laurie, Rick, Mary, Rosie, Jamie and Tim. Sister of Nina S. Bremer, Sara S. Frothingham and the late William W. Struthers, Jr. She lived in Rye, NY until 1981 when she and her husband moved to Hobe Sound, FL and Greenwich, CT. She was a student, teacher, parent, grandparent and President of the Board of Trustees of her dear alma mater, Rye Country Day School. When the School expanded to become co-ed through 12th grade, The Mary Struthers Pinkham Building was named in her honor. She served on the Board of Managers of the United Hospital, where her four children were born, and where she died. She also served on the Advisory Board of the Foundation for Children with Learning Disabilities. An athlete all her life, she was an All-American in lacrosse and field hockey, a notable tennis player, and a golfer in her later years. Her dearest friendships lasted a lifetime, and she was widely admired and loved for her loyalty, sense of duty, selflessness, uprightness and old-fashioned grace. She has gone from the double darkness of Alzheimer's and bereavement into the Light. We grieve and we rejoice. Family visitation at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road in Rye on Wednesday, March 10 from 6:00 to 8:00 pm. Memorial service at 11:00 am, Thursday, March 11 at Christ Church, Milton Road, Rye. Contributions in her name may be made to the Rye Country Day School, Rye, New York 10580.

title: Brigantine Officials Fight Ban on Vehicles at Beach
description: City officials say their monitoring has enabled endangered piping plovers and sport utility vehicles to coexist safely on the sands of the state-run Brigantine North Natural Area.

title: Sony to Cut 17,000 Jobs And Reorganize 3 Units
description: The Sony Corporation announced a sweeping corporate overhaul today aimed at decisively changing the company's identity from a manufacturer of consumer electronics to a provider of digital network services similar to Cisco Systems or Lucent Technologies.

title: Book on Rwanda Killings Wins Award
description: ''We Wish To Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families,'' Philip Gourevitch's account of the 1994 massacres in Rwanda, yesterday was named the best nonfiction book of last year by the National Book Critics Circle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOW, ESTER RUBIN
description: PORTNOW-Ester Rubin. Age 92, on March 6, 1999 in Los Angeles, Ca. Loving aunt and friend, resident and devotee of Manhattan, avid traveller, supporter of the arts, active member of the Skating Club of New York and honored member of World Federation for Mental Health. Interment on March 7th was at Hollywood Forever Cemetery. New York City Memorial Gathering to be announced. Contributions may be made to Memorial Hospital, NYC.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION TO CUT 400 JOBS AS SALES SLOW
description: The Andrew Corporation, a communications-products maker, said yesterday that slower than expected sales would force it to cut at least 400 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force. The company said it hoped the move would save $17 million a year. The company, based in Orland Park, Ill., expects to report second-quarter earnings of 5 cents to 8 cents a share on sales of $160 million to $170 million. Analysts polled by the First Call Corporation had estimated the company would earn 22 cents a share in the quarter. Shares of Andrew fell $1 each to close at $13.375.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the death of Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa, the Emir of Bahrain, misstated his age in some copies. He was 65, not 66.

title: Dia Center To Open A Museum Upstate
description: The Dia Center for the Arts, the innovative contemporary arts institution based in Chelsea, announced yesterday that it would open a massive museum in an abandoned paperboard factory in the hard-pressed Hudson River town of Beacon.

title: L.I. Power Unit Vows to Keep Rate Cuts and Upgrade Network
description: The chairman of the Long Island Power Authority unveiled his agency's first budget today, saying that the authority's longterm fiscal health looked strong and that the eastern end of the island would receive much-needed capital improvements.

title: Accounts
description: Brause Health Inc., Tequesta, Fla., to Lotas Minard Patton McIver, New York, as the first agency to handle the account of the Lifizz Effervescent Vitamins brand. Billings were estimated at $7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSEL, SANDRA
description: CASSEL-Sandra. The Board of Governors and the members of Rock Rimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their esteemed member and extend sincere sympathy to her husband and family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, KENNETH F.
description: TUCKER-Kenneth F., M.D. Prominent phychiatrist of Sutton Place South, New York City, died March 8, 1999 at New York Hospital. A long-time resident of Scarsdale, N.Y., Dr. Tucker had suffered from kidney failure and heart disease for many years. He was born September 5, 1927 in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Isaac and Belle Cooperstein Tucker, formerly of Russia. Dr. Tucker was an early graduate of Brooklyn Tech, attended R.P.I., and served with the U.S. Army in the Phillipines in 1946-1947. He received a B.S. in Chemistry from Columbia and graduated from Cornell Medical School in 1953. From that time until his death, Dr. Tucker conducted a private practice in psychiatry in the same office on Sutton Place. Long affilated with Payne Whitney, he was an early researcher in the use of chemicals to treat mental illness. During his distinguished career, he was a valued couselor to many prominent people and a source of wisdom, comfort and joy to all who had the good fortune to know him. Dr. Tucker was also a life-long sports fan; his first job, at fourteen, was selling programs at Ebbetts Field, for which he was paid $2 a day. At sixteen, he was a member of the New York All-City Championship Handball Team. In later years, he would often return to the handball courts at Coney Island to reminisce about his year of glory. Over his life time, he grew to forgive the New York Yankees for not having been situated in Brooklyn, and his emotional health rose and fell with the fortunes of his beloved New York Giants. Dr. Tucker was proud of his Jewish heritage and raised his children in his faith. Dr Tucker was also a reader of great acuity, breadth and curiosity; he triumphed weekly over the most difficult crosswords; his sense of humor was that of a true New Yorker. He married the late Barbara Irving in 1957. They had four children: Douglas Tucker, of Berkeley, CA., a forensic psychiatrist, Duane Tucker, of New York City, a database administrator, Holly Tucker, of Berkeley, CA., a research administrator and Randolph Tucker, a lawyer, of Ojai, CA. In 1991, Dr. Tucker married Amy Ellis Tucker, of Bronxville, N.Y., who survives him. He is also loved and survived by three grandchildren, Sam, Alan and Barbara Tucker of Ojai, CA., a sister Gertrude Tucker Weker, of Bethesda, MD. (his other sister, Evelyn Tucker Feinstein, pre-deceased him); a niece, Laurie Weker Lipton, of Rockville, MD. and four nephews, Richard Feinstein of Cranston, R.I., Lester Feinstein of Littleton, CO., Jonathan Weker of Mount Pelier, VT. and Robert Weker, of Winnewood, PA. Funeral service will be on March 10th at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, N.Y. at 10AM. Contributions in Dr. Tucker's name may be made to the Cornell University Medical College, Department of Psychiatry.

description: As he enters his 19th season as a professional pitcher, David Cone says he believes his right arm has held up well beyond the norm.

description: The United States accused the European Union today of worsening a trans-Atlantic fight over banana imports by failing to provide the World Trade Organization with data vital in determining losses suffered by American fruit companies.

title: 6 Libyans Tried in Absentia In '89 Downing of French Jet
description: A French antiterrorism court in Paris put six high-ranking Libyan officials on trial in absentia today on charges of ordering the bombing of a French DC-10 airliner that killed 171 people in 1989.

title: For $32 Million, a Padre Is Highest-Paid Reliever
description: Trevor Hoffman became baseball's highest-paid reliever yesterday when he agreed to a four-year contract extension for $32 million with the San Diego Padres.

title: Court Leaves Intact Rights for Immigrants Facing Deportation
description: The Supreme Court today left intact a crazy quilt of legal protections that are available to immigrants facing deportation orders.

title: Jailers Watch Mother Held In 3 Killings
description: A 41-year-old nurse has been placed under a 24-hour suicide watch after being jailed in the deaths of her three children, who had been drugged and suffocated.

description: ROOT-Stanley Roy. On March 6, 1999. Our beloved brother, a big man both in stature and accomplishments, was a source of pride and inspiration to us, to his children, and to his ten nieces and nephews. A busy man who always had time to give advice and counsel whenever asked, and make us laugh too. We will love you and miss you forever. Your brother Martin Root, sisters Barbara Root Rubin, Sandy Root Carol and brother-in-law Herbert S. Rubin. Services, 10:30AM Tuesday March 9, Temple Beth-El, New Rochelle.

title: A 14-Year-Old Wins Top Prize In Intel Contest
description: Natalia Toro, a 14-year-old senior at Fairview High School in Boulder, Colo., was the youngest of the 40 finalists in the 1999 Intel Science Talent Search. But talent rather than age determined the outcome.

title: Russian Jews Turning Edgy as the Country's Chaos Creates an Ugly Mood
description: Like many of Russia's Jews, Anatoly Vugman would like to stay in Russia. But since the financial crisis hit last August, the 20-year-old student has begun to hedge his bets by attending evening Hebrew classes.

title: Council Panel Vote to Ease Taxi Rules Upsets City Hall
description: In the latest exchange of jibes over rules governing the taxi industry, the City Council Transportation Committee voted yesterday to soften new regulations for suspending hack licenses, provoking angry criticism from the Giuliani administration.

title: Sports of The Times; DiMaggio Left a Mark In the Sands
description: IT was a warm afternoon in early summer of '49, and all of New York was jammed into Jones Beach, blanket to blanket, shoulder to shoulder. The triumphal bellow of Mel Allen, emanating from rudimentary portable radios, drowned out the waves themselves.

title: Remark on Diallo Casts Light On a Behind-the-Scenes Player
description: It is an unusual accomplishment for a Republican member of the City Council to find himself the center of attention on the overwhelmingly Democratic political terrain of New York City. But that is precisely what Thomas V. Ognibene, the Republican leader of the Council, has managed to do in the last two weeks.

title: Pushing Limits of the Human Life Span
description: They were a small group of eminent academic scientists who had reputations to think of. They were repelled by what they saw as the hucksterism and charlatanism that had given attempts to delay human aging a bad name. And yet, at a recent meeting here, most agreed that science might be on the brink of being able to stretch the human life span, perhaps significantly.

title: CIT to Acquire Newcourt in Stock Swap
description: CIT Group Inc., the commercial finance concern based in Livingston, N.J., said yesterday that it would acquire Newcourt Credit Group Inc., a Toronto concern, in a stock swap valued at about $4.2 billion.
