title: Where Dark Enhances the Light
description: Dance, music and cultural history came together in a remarkably vivid way on Saturday night in ''Four Walls,'' a re-envisioning by the dancer and choreographer Sin Cha Hong and the pianist Aki Takahashi of a 1944 piece by Merce Cunningham and John Cage. Ms. Takahashi, for whom Cage created scores, and Ms. Hong, whose admirers include Mr. Cunningham, would seem to be the perfect choices for the project. The inspiration of the Japan Society, which commissioned the new work, the collaboration was a powerful one that proved that less can be a great deal more.

description: TAIPEI  Some patriots fly flags, others fight wars, but Stanley Yen, a Taiwan businessman, said his sacrifice for the nation is running a monumental hotel with colossal problems.

description: In a stark recognition that many commercial fishing stocks are being harvested to the verge of collapse, the world's seafaring nations have promised to make the first far-reaching cuts in their fishing fleets.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the presidential election in El Salvador misidentified the United States college attended by the winner, Francisco Flores. It was Amherst College, not the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

Jeff Van Gundy's voice would rise, then there would be the sound of sneakers rushing into position, followed by more yelling, this time from the Knicks players as they tried to work under the boards.

description: Still struggling with manufacturing difficulties, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that it would report a significant loss for the current quarter, which ends March 28, and cut 300 jobs worldwide over the next two quarters.

description: ''Right off the bat, he was my hero. He was the first player that I noticed as a kid. When I got the chance to play with him, I couldn't believe I was on the mound and he was in center field.''

title: Southern Rock Enshrined, but Still Raucous
description: When a rock band signs up to do 18 concerts in one place in one month, it had better be able to show off more than one personality. The Allman Brothers, repeating last year's residency at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan, manage that trick with ease. Here are a few things the Allmans are in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, A.
description: DANA-A. Fairfield, June 15, 1911October 25, 1999. Graveside gathering in his memory at the Hillside Cemetery, Wilton, Connecticut, Sunday, March 14, at 10:30 AM.

title: Rikers Inmate Indicted in Slaying Over Gang Membership
description: A 17-year-old Rikers Island inmate who investigators said strangled another inmate in January for claiming to be a member of his gang was indicted Friday on manslaughter charges, the authorities said yesterday.

title: SEAGATE TO TAKE $50 MILLION CHARGE FOR REVAMPING
description: Seagate Technology Inc., one of the world's largest makers of computer disk drives, said yesterday that it expected to take a third-quarter charge of $50 million to $60 million to pay for a restructuring effort. The company, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said the charge would cover the previously announced closing of its microelectronics plant in Scotland, consolidation of some customer service operations and other actions needed to increase productivity and efficiency. Seagate shares fell 75 cents each, to $29.125. Seagate has been trying adapt to sharp declines in the prices of personal computer products.

title: The Congressman Who Loved Science
description: Representative George E. Brown Jr. of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Science and the former chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, is the dean of the Congressional science buffs.

title: Helen Priest Rogers, 85, Teacher And Dance Notation Authority
description: Helen Priest Rogers, an authority on dance notation, a co-founder of the Dance Notation Bureau and a pioneer in the use of film to preserve choreography, died on Mar. 2 at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 85 and lived in West Brattleboro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, DEANE
description: JOHNSON-Deane. The Actors' Fund of America mourns the loss of our friend and Trustee, Deane Johnson. His leadership inspired us; his insight enabled us to solve problems; his enthusiasm encouraged us to accept challenges; and his vision resulted in many accomplishments. We will miss him and remember him with admiration and love. Tom Dillon, President Joseph P. Benincasa, Exec Dir. The Actors' Fund of America

description: Philippine Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it expected to raise $200 million in fresh capital within three months to meet the demands of secured creditors. The airline will submit a new rehabilitation plan to regulators on March 15.

title: Wayne Berg, 52, Architect and Professor
description: Wayne Berg, an architect who helped reinvigorate modernism in the last decade with his sleekly sensual forms, died at home in Manhattan on Feb. 25. He was 52.

title: Conceding Guidelines and Winning a Bit of Protection
description: The Government's proposed antitrust settlement with the Intel Corporation is viewed as a careful compromise that seeks to clarify the ground rules for how a powerful company can wield its intellectual property as a weapon in the marketplace.

description: CRAIG-June P. Beloved wife of Alexander. Devoted mother of Heather Olivia. Cherished daughter of Gertrude Warhaftig and the late Max. Dear sister of Ira. Services today, 10:15 A.M. at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: New York's Paragon of Class; DiMaggio Built a Legend, Then Took Care Not to Step on It
description: As Allen Johnson tells it, he was 12 years old and making his first trip to Yankee Stadium when he saw Joe DiMaggio glide silkily under a fly ball in center field. Mr. Johnson, who is black and lives in Harlem, said he could never forget DiMaggio because his father kept telling him that here was a white man who combined hustle with absolute cool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILMAN, NATALIE

title: RJR NABISCO SPLITS TOBACCO VENTURES AND FOOD BUSINESS
description: Burdened by debt and the persistent threat of fresh lawsuits over smoking, RJR Nabisco announced yesterday that it was splitting its food and tobacco businesses and selling its foreign tobacco company to a Japanese buyer.

title: A New Way With Zest
description: IT looks like a bird balancing on its belly. A black rubber handle is its body, and a curved amber plastic shaft is its outstretched neck. Nothing gives a clue to its clever function. But if you hold it in your palm, neck upward, and glide the tip backward over an orange, an amazing thing happens: a perfect strip of zest, with no pith attached, begins pulling away from the fruit. And you barely need to apply pressure.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERN, WILLIAM
description: ALPERN-William. Dear Daddy, Happy Birthday. Miss you more than ever. We have a new grandson. Love, your daughter

title: Changing Caddies Is a Major Move
description: Now that Tiger Woods has officially fired his caddie, Mike (Fluff) Cowan, 1999 becomes even more interesting for Woods.

title: About New York; Olga's Garden: A Testament To Civic Spirit
description: ALTHOUGH Olga Conway lived in a building called Grandview Towers, what she saw from her apartment was hardly thrilling in the mid 1970's. Next door to her on Broadway was the Elmhurst branch of the Queens Public Library, where the lawn had been reduced to two scraggly patches covered with litter and weeds. She could have waited for the city to clean up its financial mess before it tidied up the library. Instead, she did it herself.

title: Tobacco-Busting Lawyers On New Gold-Dusted Trails
description: Whether over grits and eggs at his favorite diner or before a jury, Wendell H. Gauthier is so self-effacing that he would be the first to admit the many malapropisms that pop out of his mouth, like the time he lamented a cattle investment because so many cows died of ''amtraks.'' Or the time he characterized another lawyer's argument as the height of ''epitome.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROST, LINDA
description: FROST-Linda. Of Great Neck, NY and Williams Island, FL. Passed away March 4, 1999 at age 58 after a long illness. Beloved wife for thirty years of Jerry Frost. She will always be remembered for her beauty, grace and compassion. Services will be held Friday, March 12, 1999 at 12:00 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, 516-487-9600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARROW, FLORENCE
description: FARROW-Florence. Died February 23, 1999. She was born on January 29, 1906 in St. Louis, MO, the daughter of a well-known radiologist Edward Skinner and his wife Florence Skinner. Her husband, John Farrow was the Chief of Breast Service at Memorial SloanKettering. Dr. and Mrs Farrow had no children. Mrs. Farrow is survived by a cousin Mrs. Betty Schroeder of Mission Viejo, CA. Burial took place at Evergreen Cemetery. A memorial service will be held Thursday. March 25, 1999 at 4PM at the Church of Heavenly Rest at 5th Ave. and 90th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Breast and Cancer Reserach Foundation, 1735 York Avenue, NY, NY 10128.

title: EDISON BROTHERS AGAIN SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Edison Brothers Stores Inc. filed for protection under Chapter 11 yesterday for the second time, listing $346.8 million in assets and $295.1 million in liabilities. The company emerged from a prior reorganization process in 1997. Edison Brothers, a national discount retail apparel and footwear chain based in St. Louis, said on Monday that it could not sustain the sales it needed in the face of heavy competition. Trading in the shares was halted, and the Nasdaq stock market said it had requested additional information from the company. The stock last traded Monday at 31.25 cents a share.

title: City Workers Accused Of Scalding a Baby
description: Two city employees were arrested yesterday and accused of severely scalding a baby while giving her a bath, the police said.

title: St. Peter's Is Playing With Nothing Up Its Sleeve
description: Lawanda Greene, a junior guard for St. Peter's College, wears shorts from her high school under her regulation shorts. She must be the first player taped before a game, and she carries around a teddy bear for luck.

title: German Unemployment Shows a Slight Drop
description: Unemployment in Germany dropped slightly in February to its lowest level since September 1996, as mild winter weather at the start of the year allowed construction companies to keep their employees working. The jobless rate dropped to 10.5 percent in February from 10.6 percent in January, Bundesbank figures released yesterday showed. That is a decline in jobless rolls of 6,000, compared with a drop of 66,000 in January, the Federal Labor Office said.

title: Senate's New Hand on the Military
description: In an institution that runs on comity and tradition, Senator John W. Warner has mastered the art of fitting in. With his impeccably tailored suits, silver-gray hair and associations with Elizabeth Taylor and Barbara Walters, the gentleman from Virginia looks, at first glance, like the senator from central casting.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about research on extending the human life span misstated the classification of the canary, whose life span of two years appears to be genetically determined. It is of the class Aves, not Mammalia.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the film director Stanley Kubrick on Monday misstated the number of times he was married and misstated the given name of his widow. His most recent marriage, which lasted from 1958 until his death on Sunday, was his third. His wife was Christiane Harlan, not Susanne. (Suzanne Harlan was her stage name during a brief acting career.)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE UP SHARPLY. Coffee futures rose amid concern about a small midseason crop in Colombia, the world's largest producer of arabica beans. In New York, coffee for May delivery rose 2.05 cents, to $1.062 a pound.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about actions taken by VLSI Technology to thwart unwelcome takeover efforts misstated the date by which the board plans to respond to a $777 million bid from Royal Philips Electronics. It is on or before March 18, not March 23.

title: N.E.A. Couldn't Tell a Book by Its Cover
description: A macaw with scarlet and violet plumes soars across the cover of a book called ''The Story of Colors,'' inviting children to read a folk tale about Mexican gods who took a gray world and filled it with brilliant hues.

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL AGREES TO SELL UNIT TO CHEMICAL LIME
description: Global Industrial Technologies, which makes industrial products for metal producers, agreed to sell its APG Lime Corporation unit to the Chemical Lime Company of Fort Worth for $130.3 million in cash and the assumption of $3.7 million in debt. The Dallas-based Global also said it planned to seek the sale of its Ameri-Forge unit, which makes heavy equipment undercarriages. Global said it planned to use the money from selling Ameri-Forge and APG Lime, which mines and processes lime, to reduce its debt and possibly buy back stock. It said it would continue to evaluate sales of assets as it focuses on the manufacturing of heat-resistant materials that are used to line furnaces for making steel, glass and other products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, PHILIP
description: OSTROW-Philip. Died March 8, 1999, in his 81st year at his home in Roslyn Hts., NY. Construction industry sales executive. He was an active member of several professional organizations including the Construction Specifications Institute and the Concrete Industry Board. Mr. Ostrow was married to Jeanne Lipkind and Helen Holowasko. He is survived by his wife, Louisette Mellen Ostrow, his son, Jon (Liz) Ostrow, his stepson, Richard (Ruth) Mellen, stepdaughter, Suzanne (Jim) Mellen, and four grandchildren, Evan, Gabriel, Alexander and Diana; predeceased by his daughter, Allyn Ostrow. Memorial service March 12th at 2PM at Unitarian Universalist Society, 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset, NY. Philip Ostrow was a wonderful man who will be remembered for his love of life and his care and concern for others. He will be dearly missed by all who knew him.

title: China Export Charges
description: A Federal grand jury in Boston today indicted Yao Yi, a Chinese scientist, and Collin Shu, a Canadian, on charges of conspiracy to violate export control laws by attempting to ship fiberoptic gyroscopes to China. Mr. Yao is being transported to Boston after his arrest two weeks ago at a scientific conference in San Diego. The Customs Service contends that the shipments, had they succeeded, could have helped China improve the accuracy of its missiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINGTON, ROBERT SR.
description: WASHINGTON-Robert Sr. Died Sunday, March 7, 1999, Bronx, NY, age 62. Devoted husband of Ethel; father to Linda, Robert Jr., Dean, Janet and Angela; grandfather of five. This teacher will be greatly missed by his extended family at Granby's Funeral Service, 4021 White Plains Road, 718-519-6047.

title: Accounts
description: * Fogdog Sports, San Jose, Calif., to Odiorne Wilde Narraway & Partners, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle the account of the on-line sporting goods store. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Enticing Flavors From the Italian Mediterranean
description: NO longer is Sami Kader a chef. Now he's a restaurateur.

title: Understanding Arithmetic
description: Learning-disabled students who appear beaten by simple arithmetic may be blocked not by mathematics but by language disorders, a professor of learning disabilities at Hunter College says.

title: Head of Porsche Opposes Possible Aid for Rover
description: The chairman of Porsche A.G., Wendelin Wiedeking, said yesterday that he planned to send a letter this week to the European Commission's cartel officer, Karel van Miert, to stop any plans by the British Government to give a subsidy to Rover, the ailing British unit of BMW A.G.

title: Crime Is Falling, but Drug War Hurts Families
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Lurching' Bolshoi Still Thinks Big; Amid a Frantic Search for a New Identity, an Audacious Building Plan but No Money
description: Nobody has ever accused the Bolshoi Theater of thinking small: after all, the word ''bolshoi'' means big, great or grand. People are trained from childhood to assume, and to assert, not only that Russia's premier opera and ballet company is bigger than its best-known rivals and performs more often, but also that it is simply the best.

title: Letting Singing Shine Above A Plot
description: Verdi wrote ''I Masnadieri'' (''The Highwaymen''), to a libretto based on Schiller's play ''The Robbers,'' for London in 1847. Queen Victoria, who was there on opening night, recorded in her diary that she found the music ''commonplace,'' and history has tended to agree with her. This is, therefore, exactly the kind of work that Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York exists to retrieve, and on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall the company produced a lusty performance. With its rollicking chorus of brigands, its ridiculously venomous villain (Francesco) and its melodramatic turns of events, the opera onstage might be hard to take seriously, but in a concert rendering one can forget the characters in favor of the singers. And since the cast on this occasion gave excellent value, the evening was thoroughly enjoyable.

title: Exploring the Backwoods of Burgundy
description: SO you love Burgundy and you know the region well. Gevrey-Chambertin, Morey-St.-Denis, Beaune, Volnay -- you're familiar with them all. O.K., ever heard of Marey-les-Fussey? Or Magny-les-Villers, or Meloisey?

title: Review/Fashion; At Saint Laurent, An Artful Remix
description: In Paris the day's runway shows are broadcast each night on television like basketball games in America. The Chambre Syndicale, French fashion's organizing body, is the N.B.A., Yves Saint Laurent is Michael Jordan, and Alber Elbaz is the upstart brought in to replace him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: RJR Nabisco to Spin Off Its Tobacco Operations

title: All Eyes for a Peek at Kubrick's Final Film
description: Stanley Kubrick's work, like his life, was shrouded in mystery and secrecy.

title: Fluor to Cut 5,000 Jobs and Reorganize Operations
description: The Fluor Corporation, suffering from the Asian economic crisis and its own bloated cost structure, said today that it would cut 5,000 employees, reorganize its operations, and narrow the range of construction projects it undertakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEFLICH, MARION
description: HOEFLICH-Marion. On March 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Loving mother of Barbara Rudd. Cherished grandmother to Richard, Fred, Mark, Leslie, Russell, Mark, Jean; and great-grandmother to Lily and Erica. Services private.

title: LaChance Gets Lost In Shuffle
description: ISLANDERS 2, FLYERS 2

title: Commercial Real Estate; Financial Software Maker Pays '97 Price for Trade Center Space
description: Eighteen years ago, Rob Patterson founded his company, Baseline Financial Services, in the basement of his home in Madison, N.J.

title: Insults All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Media That Works Changes Its Name
description: Media That Works in Cincinnati said yesterday that it would be renamed Empower Media Marketing to reflect the growing scope of the media and marketing agency as it adds services.

title: Can Things Get Any Worse? Nets Are Blown Out by Bulls
description: Rock bottom apparently has a new meaning because the Nets thought they had reached that point before tonight's game with the talent-deficient Chicago Bulls. But after Chicago played steamroller to the Nets' aluminum can, New Jersey realized the abyss it has fallen into is boundless. According to the distressed Coach John Calipari and his baffled players, what happened tonight was the worst. Worse than losing to the injury-depleted Charlotte Hornets at home. Worse than being trounced by the Terrell Brandon-less Milwaukee Bucks. Worse than the Nets ever imagined this season of doom could be.

title: A City Divided by a Judge's Desegregation Order
description: SHOW ME A HERO

title: Search Firm Executive Rejoins Field
description: Thirty years after founding what would become one of the nation's largest executive search firms, Russell S. Reynolds Jr. is at it again. Mr. Reynolds, 67, has merged his current business with a small New York search firm and plans to begin recruiting corporate directors and senior executives.

title: Millennium's Great Women
description: Those list-makers at Radcliffe College, which ranked the top 100 novels of the 20th century last year, are at it again. Get set for the 1,000 greatest women of the millennium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, STEVEN R., PH.D.
description: HOLTZMAN-Steven R., Ph.D. Critically acclaimed author, composer and technology industry executive. Died Thursday, March 4, 1999 in Woodside, CA. He was forty-three. Dr. Holtzman wrote two seminal works describing the future of digital art and content over media such as the Internet and virtual reality spaces. His pioneering research was first published in ''Digital Mantras'' and later in ''Digital Mosaics''. He held executive positions in the high-technology industry and was the founder, president and CEO of Perspecta, founder and member of the Board of Directors for Liquid Audio, founder of Optimal Networks and held executive positions with Radius, Farallon and Wyse Technologies. Born in Great Neck, N.Y. he received his Ph.D. in Music and Computer Science from the Unveristy of Edinburgh. Survived by his wife, Trudy Edelson, sisters Diane Feirman of Portola Valley and Harriet Parcells of Cabin John, MD. and a niece and three nephews. The family is establishing a scholarship fund in Dr. Holtzman's name to help aspiring students explore the world of digital expression. A memorial service will be held Thursday, March 11th at Congregation Beth Am, 26790 Arastradero Road, Los Altos Hills, CA. 94022.

title: Ms. Lewinsky's Smile
description: To the Editor:

title: Laguna San Ignacio Journal; Save the Whales? Mine the Salt? Mexican Standoff
description: At nightfall, when the winds die down and the waters become glassy, sounds like deep sighs come gliding across this lagoon. They are the echoes of the gray whales breathing, spouting and diving, carried easily to the beach on the pure, still air from hundreds of yards offshore.

title: A Fish Puts Chefs in a Quandary
description: LATELY, some New York restaurants have been offering a fish of unparalleled richness that, miraculously, is hardly fattening at all. It's called escolar, and it would be a dream come true except for one problem:

title: New Head of Pocket Books
description: Simon & Schuster, a unit of Pearson P.L.C., said yesterday that it had named Judith Curr president and publisher of its Pocket Books division, effective April 12. Ms. Curr, 43, was most recently senior vice president and publisher of Ballantine Publishing Group, a unit of the German media giant Bertelsmann A.G. Ms. Curr replaces Gina Centrello, who left the position in January. Pocket Books publishes both hardcover and paperback books.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I really didn't want to expose this -- and I'm attached to the country, the Party, the people. But we are at a critical juncture -- the medicine we have is about to run out -- and I have to think about my child.''

title: NBC Moves To Sell Goods To Its Viewers
description: Becoming the first broadcast network to own a portion of a home shopping channel, NBC announced yesterday that it would make a significant investment in the cable network Value Vision and link it with the NBC network, the cable channels CNBC and MSNBC, and the Web site MSNBC.com.

title: Where History Is Always on the Menu
description: MY mother could not resist a restaurant with history. All a place needed was a name like the Spinning Wheel or the Old Mill to make her like it. ''Just think, when this restaurant was built, they didn't even have electricity,'' she would whisper as we walked through the door. She would look around, thrilled, as if she expected to spot Abraham Lincoln at the very next table.

title: Central Asia's Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: John Atwood, Aviation Executive, Dies at 94
description: John Leland Atwood, an engineer who rose through the executive ranks at North American Aviation as it built the P-51 Mustang, the most powerful fighter plane of World War II; the F-100 Super Sabre, the first supersonic fighter, and the Apollo capsule that took men to the moon, died on March 5. He was 94 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Political Battle: What to Reveal On China Arms
description: The Administration and Congressional Republicans are wrangling over how much information to make public about official findings that China acquired some of the most sensitive American military technology.

title: Ski-Season Traffic Jams Force Colorado to Reconsider Mass Transit
description: Early-morning rays illuminated snowcapped peaks of the Continental Divide as a group of people gathered in front of a log cabin down in this village, waiting for the 7:15 and clutching plastic coffee mugs, the universal emblem of a commuter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNE, AUGUR
description: TOWNE-Augur. Of 74 East Avenue, Westerly, RI. and formerly of NYC and Stonington, Conn. died Wednesday, March 3, 1999 at his home. Born in Evanston, Ill. on May 15, 1913. Son of the late John D.C. and Jane Holabird Towne. Mr. Towne was an architect for New York Life. Survived by two nieces Diana Towne Knox of Greensboro, N.C. and Daphne Towne Witsell of Hobe Sound, Fla. Funeral services will be held at the convenience of the family. For more information The BucklerJohnston Funeral Home, 121 Main Street, Westerly, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUBRICK, STANLEY
description: KUBRICK-Stanley. He will be missed by the entire motion picture industry. It was a privilege to work with him. Martin Richards & The Producer Circle Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNOTTE, ANDRE
description: ERNOTTE-Andre. Died March 8, 1999 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in NYC. A major, talented theatre director and writer with Elliot Tiber, his longtime companion. A cherished, gentle Mensch. Distinguished, admired and much loved Board Member of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers. Burial in Belgium; NYC memorial service to be announced.

title: 20 Journalists, Including 2 Times Writers, Win Polk Awards
description: Twenty journalists whose work documented corporate deceit, political impropriety and ethnic bloodletting have been chosen as recipients of the 1998 George Polk Awards, the awards' sponsor announced yesterday.

title: Victim's Father to Run For Seat on Legislature
description: Edward Werner, whose son of the same name was sexually assaulted and killed as he went door-to-door selling candy in 1997, is running for State Assembly, he said last night.

title: P.& G. in Coffee Purchase
description: Procter & Gamble, the largest United States maker of household products, agreed today to buy the assets of Brothers Gourmet Coffees Inc., a wholesaler of roasted gourmet coffees now in bankruptcy reorganization, for $21.5 million in cash. P.& G., which makes Folgers and Millstone coffees, will also assume $1.3 million in debt. Brothers had 1998 gross sales of about $57 million. The company, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August.

title: Half of 609 Area Code To Get a New Number
description: The new area code for half of the telephones, faxes and modems now in the 609 area in southern New Jersey will be 856, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ALEX
description: COOPER-Alex. Loving and most devoted husband of Sylvia for 62 years. Loving and caring father of Ellen and Arthur Singer and Dr. Sheldon and Amy Cooper. Most cherished and loving grandfather of Howard and Suellen Singer, Richard & Lisa Singer, and Jonas Cooper. Loving great-grandfather of Melanie, Eric and Blake Singer. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 1:30 P.M., Wednesday.

title: To Reserve, Perchance to Eat
description: THE minute Evelyn Kenvin walked into Bouley Bakery for dinner on the evening of Jan. 30, something felt a little off.

title: CALENDAR
description: For Do-It-Yourself Restaurateurs

title: Secrets of a Lemon Lover In a Season of Plenty
description: IF there is one hallmark of my cooking, it is the plentiful use of lemon juice and lemon zest. As a child, I always loved unsweetened lemonade, and now, when asked what might improve a dish, my response is frequently, ''Lemon!'' Both the juice and the zest give a fresh edge to food, adding a welcome acidity to some dishes, and a tart sweetness to others.

title: Crime Is Falling, but Drug War Hurts Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USHEFF, VERA NICOLOVA
description: USHEFF-Vera Nicolova. Of Elmsford, N.Y. On March 7, 1999 in Quebec, Canada. Wife of the late Costa Dimitroff Usheff. Mother of Ana Usheff and Margaret Chang. Grandmother of Rudy Chang. Funeral service Saturday, 11 A.M., at Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Church, 46 Seymor St, Yonkers, N.Y. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: State Officials Urge Spitzer to Pursue Apollo Lawsuit More Aggressively
description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer is being urged by officials in the Pataki administration to be more aggressive in pursuing a lawsuit alleging financial mismanagement at the foundation that runs the state-owned Apollo Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, MURIEL (NEE: GOLDBERG)
description: BLOOM-Muriel (nee: Goldberg). On Monday, March 8, 1999, of Montville, NJ formerly of Bronx and Queens, NY. Loving wife of the late Ellis Bloom. Beloved mother of Joel S. Bloom and Barbara Essig. Also cherished by five grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Funeral services Wednesday, March 10, 11:00 AM at the Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Avenue, Boonton. Interment will be private. For more information call S.J. Priola, Parsippany Funeral Service 973-335-4700.

title: Educator Who Sees Both Sides of Vouchers
description: WHEN the argument over taxpayer-financed school vouchers burst noisily into public view again last week, Catherine Hickey watched the fight between the Mayor and the Schools Chancellor with a foot in each man's world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONZE, PETER H. AND ELIZABETH P.
description: CONZE-Peter H. and Elizabeth P. Peter Horst Conze and Elizabeth Powers Conze of Greenwich, Conn. died together in an auto accident in Florida on March 4. Mr. Conze was born in Brooklyn, NY June 27, 1921, son of the late Godfrey H. and Elisabeth VonRosenberg-Gruszczynski Conze. Mrs. Conze was born in NYC, January 24, 1921, the daughter of the late Walter H. and Helen Gillette Ballard Powers. Mr. and Mrs. Conze were members of Christ Church, the Belle Haven Club, Round Hill Country Club and Old Lyme Country Club. Mr. Conze graduated from Kent School, class of 1938, and was a member of the victorious Kent crew, which won the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta that year. He graduated from Princeton where he played varsity football and rugby in the class of 1942. He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during WWII. Mr. Conze retired as Vice Chairman of Celanese Corp. in 1978. Subsequently he was a President of the Greenwich Historical Society, President of the Board of Trustees of Kent School for 21 years, a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Princeton Club and the Nutmeggers. Mrs. Conze who graduated from Rye Country Day School and attended the Katherine Gibbs School in NYC was a member of the Mayflower Society, the Green Fingers Garden Club, and the Greenwich Garden Center. She served on the Greenwich RTM. Mr. and Mrs. Conze are survived by two sons, Peter Horst Conze, Jr. of Marlborough, Ma., Frederick Ballard Conze of Darien Ct., daughter Elizabeth Bradford Conze of Tucson Ar., and ten grandchildren. The Conze's were pre-deceased by a daughter, Eliza Lansing Conze Billington. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, March 16, at 2 PM at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Kent School for a fund to be established in memory of Peter Horst Conze and Elizabeth Powers Conze. Donations may be sent to Kent School, P.O. Box 2006, Kent Ct., 06757.

title: Is American Culture Unstoppable?; Rampant Consumerism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, LEONA (NEE FELDMAN)
description: BLAIR-Leona (nee Feldman). On March 8, 1999, after a valiant struggle with spinal cancer. A cherished cousin; beloved friend, and superb storyteller, ''Noni'' enriched our lives by her knowledge, humor and love. Memorial service is planned for April. The Weiss, Rosinoff, and Berkson Families

title: News Analysis; Ending a Feud On Vouchers And Finding Political Gain
description: Shortly after concluding a private, 90-minute discussion, the men known as the Two Rudys approached a bank of microphones Monday night with smiles broad enough to brighten the dim corridor of City Hall. It was as though they had just shared an inside joke that no one else would understand.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Microsoft Appears Unlikely To Settle Its Antitrust Case
description: When the Microsoft antitrust trial broke for a six-week recess on Feb. 26, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had some parting words for both sides. He called the lawyers for the Government and the Microsoft Corporation into his chambers and told them to ''use this six weeks wisely,'' according to a person close to the case.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Observatory column of Science Times yesterday about a tiny mouse that breathes through its skin after birth misstated its weight. It weighs about 6 10-thousandths of an ounce at birth, not half an ounce, and about one-hundredth of an ounce at three weeks, not 10 ounces.

title: BURNHAM PACIFIC AND CALPERS BUYING SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. and the California Public Employees' Retirement System agreed late yesterday to buy 28 shopping centers from the AMB Property Corporation for $663.4 million, allowing AMB to focus on its industrial portfolio. AMB, of San Francisco, expects to reinvest $520 million of the proceeds in industrial properties and pay down about $100 million in debt. It granted Calpers an option to buy as many as two million of its common shares for $25 a share, to be exercised on or before March 31, 2000. The shares were unchanged yesterday at $21.125. Calpers also has an option to buy as many as one million shares of Burnham Pacific at $15.37 a share, to be exercised on or before June 30, 2000. Burnham Pacific, of San Diego, closed yesterday at $10.1875, up 12.5 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDQUIST, MARGARET JOAN
description: LINDQUIST-Margaret Joan. On March 8, 1999 of New York City. Loving wife and best friend of husband, Robert F. Lindquist. Dearest sister of Mary Wiley, Patricia Hansen and John McCormack. Relatives and friends are invited to attend religious services Thursday 10:00 AM at Diffily Funeral Home, 41 Ames Avenue, Rutherford, New Jersey. Visiting on Thursday, 9:00 to 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, a donation to any animal shelter would be her most likely wish.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Kennedy Gives D'Amato a Forum

title: Wrestling Fans Wrestling Image
description: Smashing the stereotype that viewers of professional wrestling are all blue-collar, undereducated Neanderthals watching macho soap opera, students at some of the nation's most elite colleges have made a mini-cult of staging Monday night parties to watch ''WCW Monday Nitro Live'' on cable.

title: In America; A Designated Hero
description: The streak came to an end in mid-July in Cleveland beneath the blazing, bluish lights of Municipal Stadium. The crowd was enormous, 67,468, which at the time was the largest ever to have seen a night baseball game.

title: Treasuries Up As Greenspan Sees No Signs Of Inflation
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said there were ''no obvious signs'' of rising inflation, despite strong growth.

title: After The Counsel Law
description: The inherent faults in the Independent Counsel Act cannot be fixed merely by tinkering with the law's details. But it would be a mistake for Congress simply to let the act expire without replacing it with a different system. Doing so would mean that the next time serious charges of criminal misconduct are raised against a President or other top officials, much of the public will be left with suspicions that any investigation might be influenced by politics or personal interest.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEPRIN, JACK
description: WEPRIN-Jack. 1930-1996 My beloved friend is never forgotten. Marti

title: Is American Culture Unstoppable?; A Benevolent Victor
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric R. Wolf, 76, an Iconoclastic Anthropologist
description: Eric R. Wolf, an accidental anthropologist whose cultural studies of Latin American peoples and European peasants helped enrich an already eclectic field even as he challenged some established cultural assumptions, died on Sunday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 76 and had taught at Lehman College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.

title: In Black and White: Cold Blood or Hot Rage?
description: Nothing in the first few scenes of ''Everybody's Ruby'' prepares you for the moment when the actress Viola Davis takes the play and makes it hers. It happens quite stealthily, in the midst of the kind of speech that you are ready to believe you have heard a hundred times before in a hundred other dramas examining the facets of a hundred other crimes.

title: Sidney Gottlieb, 80, Dies; Took LSD to C.I.A.
description: Sidney Gottlieb, who presided over the Central Intelligence Agency's cold-war efforts to control the human mind and provided the agency poisons to kill Fidel Castro, died on Sunday in Washington, Va. He was 80 and had spent his later years caring for dying patients, trying to run a commune, folk dancing, consciousness-raising and fighting lawsuits from survivors of his secret tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDE, JOSEPH F. SGT. RETIRED CHIEF MASTER
description: GARDE-Joseph F. Sgt. Retired Chief Master. Age 81, died peacefully March 7, 1999 at home in Whiting, NJ. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Lucille and four children. Burial March 11, with full military honors at Brigadier Gen. W.C. Doyle Cemetery, Arneytown, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, HERMAN L.
description: WEISMAN-Herman L. Died March 7, in his 95th year, in West Palm Beach. A graduate of Harvard Law School in 1927, Mr. Weisman's legal career spanned over 50 years of public appointments and private practice in New York. He was a leader of the American Zionist movement during the early days of Israel and was active in Jewish community affairs. He is survived by his devoted wife of 70 years, Jeannette, his sons Edward, Robert and Matthew, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. We will remember him with love and forever cherish his gifts of wit and wisdom.

title: Principal Resigns Over Test
description: The principal of an elementary school near Syracuse has resigned after distributing a preliminary version of New York State's fourth-grade reading test to her colleagues so students could use it for practice.

title: TARRANT APPAREL TO ACQUIRE DENIM MILL IN MEXICO
description: Tarrant Apparel Group, a maker of women's casual clothing, agreed yesterday to buy a denim mill in Puebla, Mexico, for $107 million in stock and cash to improve the efficiency of its Mexican operations. Tarrant, which is based in Los Angeles and which also makes clothing for men and children, will pay two million shares of its stock and $22 million in cash for the mill. Kamel Nacif, who is selling the mill, will become president of the company's Mexican operations. Shares of Tarrant rose 50 cents yesterday, to $43.

title: International Cigarettes Unit Sold to Japan Tobacco for $8 Billion : RJR Nabisco to Split Up Company
description: NEW YORK  Bowing to investor pressure after years of mediocre returns, RJR Nabsico Holdings Corp. said Tuesday that it planned to divest its tobacco holdings, spinning off its U.S. operations to shareholders and selling its international business to Japan Tobacco Inc. for $8 billion

title: Remy Amerique And Blum Split
description: Blum Group in New York and Remy Amerique said yesterday that they had parted ways on the Mount Gay Rum account after almost five years.

title: A Heart Pumping Poetry
description: Current 93, a British Goth-folk band led by a thin, charismatic poet named David Tibet, is a perfect little cultural operation. It has a small core of fans whose devotion runs shockingly deep; the group lies so safely and cozily within a nook of the underground-rock economy that it is never exposed to attack or unrealistic sales expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIG, LESTER
description: EIG-Lester. On March 7th, 1999. Beloved husband of Doris (nee Friedman) for 44 years. Father of Robin, of San Francisco. Father of Spencer, father-in-law of Atara and grandfather of Miriam Malka and Menachem Mendel of Miami Beach. Brother of Edith Rubin of Lido Beach. Resident of Lauder Hill, FL for 12 years, he previously lived in Merrick, Forest Hills and Brooklyn, NY. A U.S. army veteran of W.W. II and a graduate of New York University, he was a retired executive of the Wearever Baby Carriage Company and other businesses. He was interred in the presence of more than one hundred friends and loved ones at Star of David Cemetery, Tamarac, FL. on March 8, 1999.

title: Why Students Need Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMMAGE, KATHERINE E.
description: GAMMAGE-Katherine E. The family of Katherine Gammage deeply mourns her passing suddenly on March 8, 1999 at the age of 87. Wife of the late Combs. Most beloved mother of Elizabeth Rankin and John. Loving and devoted grandmother of Laura Stokes, Pamela Kier, Susan Munn & John Jr., great grandmother of Amanda and Ryan Stokes. Memorial service Fri. March 12 at 11 AM, Church of Atonement, Tenafly, N.J. Memorials may be made in her honor to Church of Atonement Memorial Garden, Highwood Ave., Tenafly, N.J. 07670.

title: Royal Ahold in Deal to Acquire Pathmark Stores
description: In a deal that pushes it further into some of the toughest United States markets, Royal Ahold N.V., the scrappy Dutch food retailer, said yesterday that it would acquire Pathmark Stores Inc., the leading chain in metropolitan New York, for $250 million in cash and the assumption of $1.5 billion in debt.

title: N.C.A.A. Decision Creates Confusion
description: Now in his senior year at St. Patrick's High School in Elizabeth, N.J., Jamal Jackson has a 2.4 grade-point average in the classroom to go with his 11 points and 8 assists a game on the basketball court. He has received inquiries from Division I schools like St. Peter's and Fairfield, but in two attempts at the S.A.T, he has failed to make the National Collegiate Athletic Association minimum score of 820 required for an athletic scholarship.

title: Bill Would Help Pay For Hudson Rail Tunnel
description: A day after joining regional transportation officials in support of another commuter rail tunnel under the Hudson River, Representative Robert Franks introduced Federal legislation yesterday that would pay for up to half the cost, which is estimated now at $3.5 billion.

title: Captured Khmer Rouge Leader to Face Charges in Cambodia
description: The Khmer Rouge commander Ta Mok will be charged under a 1994 law that bans membership in the brutal Communist group and may also face charges of genocide, a Cambodian prosecutor said today.

title: Temper vs. Temperament
description: To the Editor:

title: Support Is Pledged for Republican Budget
description: Republicans pledged support today for the budget outline worked out last week by their leaders but acknowledged that turning the plan into legislation would be fraught with political risks and difficulties.

title: Playoffs to Determine Final N.C.A.A. Berths
description: Forty-four teams will be skating in men's Division I conference tournaments this weekend, from Colorado Springs to Orono, Me. By finishing first in regular-season standings, four schools have qualified for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament regardless of how they make out in conference events.

title: Republicans Call for Rise In Tax Credit For the Poor
description: Taking up one of the favorite causes of advocates for the poor, the Republicans who control the State Senate called today for an expanded tax credit for more than a million low-income workers, most of them with children.

title: Exploit and Vicar Are Set to Lead Charge This Weekend
description: The best 3-year-old horses in America were being primed today for their busiest weekend of the year, a splashy series of shakedown races on the East and West coasts and at a track in between. And they will be gunning for the prize of a lifetime when their paths cross seven weeks later at the starting gate for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Ogden-Seagram Wet 'n Wild Deal
description: The Ogden Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the water park operator Wet 'n Wild Inc. from the Universal Studios subsidiary of the Seagram Company for an undisclosed amount. The deal includes the Wet 'n Wild trademark and water parks in Las Vegas, Nev., Mexico and Brazil, Ogden said.

title: You're in Labor: Get Out Your Wallet; Doctors Break a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Poirot Popping Up
description: The fussbudget detective Hercule Poirot has been a figure of reruns for some years now, popping up regularly on the A&E cable network. The character, as embodied by the British actor David Suchet, was so popular with American audiences that A&E has persuaded Mr. Suchet to do a reprise of the role, after a five-year hiatus.

title: Pasta From the Pantry
description: YOU can never have too many pasta recipes, and finding a good new one is an event. This is especially true of fast pasta recipes, the kind in which the sauce is so easy that you have to start boiling the water before getting out the garlic.

title: RHODIA MAY JOIN BIDDING FOR ALBRIGHT & WILSON
description: The French specialty-chemical company Rhodia S.A. signaled yesterday that it might make a takeover bid for Albright & Wilson P.L.C., which on Monday agreed to be acquired by the Albemarle Corporation of Richmond. Albright, a British chemical concern, accepted Albemarle's offer of 130 pence in cash a share, valuing the company at $:408 million, or $655 million. Rhodia, one of the world's largest specialty-chemical concerns, is 70 percent owned by Rhone-Poulenc, the French pharmaceuticals and chemical company.

title: Rookie Keeps Mouth Shut And Hits Hard
description: The Mets expected they were getting a no-nonsense guy from Milwaukee last year when they obtained Mike Kinkade in exchange for Bill Pulsipher at the trading deadline.

title: Graduate Student Stabbed to Death Near Her Brooklyn Home
description: Not long after leaving the Bronx community center where she worked with battered women, a 26-year-old graduate student from Kansas who had come to New York to become a social worker was killed Monday night when she was stabbed in the back while walking home from the D train to her Brooklyn apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: N.I.T.
description: Rutgers (18-12) and Hofstra (22-9) will each have a key player slowed by injury tonight in their first-round game of the National Invitation Tournament in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Sykora and Friends Outscore Jagr by One
description: Credit Coach Robbie Ftorek for the success of the Devils this season, and credit his decision to form a line of Jason Arnott centering for the two young wings from the Czech Republic, Petr Sykora and Patrik Elias.

title: Brosius Worries as Old Glove Wears Thin
description: Scott Brosius batted .300 last year and won the most valuable player award in the World Series. But the Yankees' third baseman has determined he lacks whatever skills are required to break in a new baseball glove.

title: Business Travel; Microsoft wants the U.S. to investigate possible antitrust violations by the nation's airlines.
description: A $14.5 BILLION giant whose every thundering step shakes the software industry can be just another money-losing upstart in electronic commerce, and that makes for an interesting paradox within the Microsoft Corporation. While Microsoft the gorilla wrestles the Justice Department in a landmark antitrust suit, Microsoft the upstart is asking the same agency to investigate possible antitrust violations by the nation's airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELEY, CHARLOTTE A.
description: SELEY-Charlotte A. March 9, 1999. Loving mother of Elisabeth, John, and Carolyn, son-in-law David, daughter-in-law Liz. Cherished sister of Helen. She was a graduate of Hunter College where she worked for 34 years in the Dept. of Education. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her name to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIZEK, JOHN SCOTT
description: CIZEK-John Scott. Age 68. Died March 5, 1999 of complications following surgery. Mr. Cizek was a life-long resident of Darien and served as Vice Chairman of Aon Aviation, specializing in aviation insurance. Mr. Cizek enjoyed a 41 year career in the Commercial Aviation Insurance Industry, holding positions as President and CEO of the Aviation Division of Frank B. Hall, Inc., and Vice Chairman, Rollins, Hudig, Hall. His work encompassed associations in Mexico, Central and South America, Eastern and Western Europe, Africa and Asia. He helped pioneer the concept of re-insurance, and worked pre-Perestroika, behind the Iron Curtain, traveling to Poland, Czechoslovakia and China. Mr. Cizek graduated from Kimball Union Academy and Colgate University. While at Colgate, Mr. Cizek played varsity football and was a member of an elite men's chorale group, the Colgate Thirteen. John's voice can be heard on their recordings through his graduation in 1952. Additionally, he was an active alumnus of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity. John Cizek served in the Army's Combat Intelligence Corps during the Korean war and received an Honorable discharge. An avid golfer, John was twice required to provide liquid refreshment for his friends and opponents after achieving a hole in one at Wee Burn Country Club's seventh hole. A dedicated athlete and competitor, he also ran road races, successfully finishing the New York City Marathon with his daughter Laurie. John served on the Board of Directors as Chairman of admissions at Wee Burn Country Club and was a member of John's Island and Windsor Clubs, in Vero Beach, Florida, the Pine Valley Golf Club, and the Wings Club, Union League and Yale Clubs in Manhattan. Mr. Cizek is survived by his wife, Lucie Cizek of Darien; brother, Les Cizek of Fort Bragg, CA; son, Scott Cizek of Frederick, MD; and daughters, Laurie and Amanda Cizek of Stamford and Darien. Mr. and Mrs. Cizek have three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 13 at 2:00 p.m. at the First Congregational Church of Darien. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the John S. Cizek Memorial Fund, Colgate University, Hamilton, NY 13346-1398 or the Memorial Fund of The First Congregational Church of Darien, 14 Brookside Road, Darien, CT 06820.

title: People
description: * Monica Karo, media director/ West at TBWA/Chiat/Day, Playa del Rey, Calif., part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, was named corporate media director, succeeding Stacey Lippman, who had been based at the agency's New York office and left in June to become president for the Petersen brand and marketing at what is now the Emap Petersen unit of Emap P.L.C., New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, SHIRLEY ANN
description: WHITE-Shirley Ann. On Friday, March 5, 1999. Sister of James White, surrounded by many friends. Active in the fashion industry for many years. Founder of the Garfield County Child Advocacy Center, Enid, Okla. Services and interment in Enid. Memorial contributions may be sent to Garfield County Child Advocacy Center, POB 5204, Enid, Okla 73702. Memorial services, Marble Collegiate Church, 3 West 29 St, NYC, Thursday, March 18, at 6:30 PM.

title: Gannett's USA Today Names New Editor
description: Karen Jurgensen, editor of the editorial page of USA Today, has been named editor of the publication, the nation's largest newspaper, the paper announced yesterday.

title: Umpires Giveth and Taketh
description: Larry Parrish saw nothing different about the strike zone during the Detroit Tigers' first exhibition game against the Pittsburgh Pirates last Friday. The next day, when he went to home plate to exchange lineup cards for the game against the Cleveland Indians, the umpires delivered a message.

title: A Threat to Impoverished Schools
description: The achievement gap between affluent and disadvantaged children is a challenge to American education and a threat to national prosperity. Unfortunately, a bipartisan bill that is scheduled for debate and a vote today in Congress could widen that gap by allowing states to use Federal dollars targeted at the poorest students for other educational purposes. The so-called Ed-Flex proposal could damage the poorest districts, which have traditionally been underfinanced by the states and cities even though they bear the burden of teaching the least prepared students.

title: Man Is Found Not Guilty In Death of His Infant
description: A Brooklyn man accused in the 1995 punching death of his 4-month-old son was found not guilty yesterday on charges of murder, manslaughter and endangering a child.

title: Jury Rejects Death Penalty For Man in Two Murders
description: A businessman who built a lucrative chain of gas stations on a foundation of violence and fraud was spared the death penalty yesterday when a Federal jury in Brooklyn decided that life in prison was sufficient punishment for the two murders he orchestrated.

title: U.S. Seeks Data On Ascend Deal
description: Ascend Communications Inc. said today that Federal antitrust regulators had asked for additional information about its proposed acquisition by Lucent Technologies Inc. for stock valued at $19 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, ROTHENBERG, PAMELA
description: SUMNER - ROTHENBERG - Pamela. 42. Beloved and cherished wife of Richard Rothenberg, died suddenly on Saturday, March 6, 1999. She is deeply mourned by her parents, Martha and Nolan Sumner of Dallas, Texas; by her inlaws, Marion and Jack Rothenberg of New York; by her brother, Bill and his wife, Sabrina; and by her sister-in-law Ellen Klein, her husband, Michael and their son, Andrew. Pam, a gifted pianist who held a Master's Deg. in Piano Performance from North Texas State University, played in many Broadway musicals. Her talents and skills were internationally recognized and praised. She will be affectionately remembered and greatly missed by all. Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, March 11th, at 1:00 P.M., at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street (at Central Park West).

title: Liability Lawsuits May Continue to Pursue Both Operations
description: Despite RJR Nabisco's move to separate its food and tobacco operations, hundreds of smoking-related lawsuits will likely continue to cast a cloud over both businesses for years, legal experts said yesterday.

title: Late-Season Snowstorm From Midwest Blindsides Washington
description: After sweeping a thousand miles from the upper Midwest, a late-winter snowstorm roared into the East today, surprising many people, especially those in the Washington area, where a mild winter had lulled residents into complacency and where shoots from tulip bulbs were already five inches high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTEL, ROBERT I.
description: POSTEL-Robert I. On March 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Darren Robert. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Thursday 12:30 P.M. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND RISES. The British currency rose after the Government released a budget that included tax cuts and increased spending that could spur economic growth. In New York, the pound rose to $1.6186 from $1.6080.

title: So Tough in the Field, Such a Breeze in the Kitchen
description: IT can seem like a nasty customer, tightly closed and unyielding, more than forbidding enough to frighten off a cook or two. But those who know the artichoke know just how to slip past its defenses. That's especially true in San Francisco, where artichokes are as familiar in restaurant kitchens as potatoes. The trick, the city's chefs say, is to keep it simple and not to wear yourself out. A great artichoke doesn't need much work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORDES, LAWRENCE J., RABBI
description: HORDES-Lawrence J., Rabbi. Beloved husband of his wife of sixtyfive years, Juliet Kronovet Hordes, died on Tuesday morning after a brief illness. He is also survived by his son, Dr. Jess N. Hordes and Naomi, two grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Rabbi Hordes had a long and distinguished career as a teacher in the NY public schools in addition to ordination in the 1929 class of Yeshiva University and a law degree from NYU. He was a gifted speaker, an outstanding educator and the truest embodiment of modern Orthodox ideal of combining Torah and Mada. He was always cheerful, inclusive, thoughtful, non-judgemental and devoted to his family, his profession and his people. His generous spirit will be sorely missed. Burial Wednesday, at 2PM, in the Old Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva in Silver Spring, Maryland. Contributions to Yeshiva University are welcome.

title: Loss Widens at British American Tobacco
description: British American Tobacco P.L.C. said today that its loss in the fourth quarter had widened, reflecting costs to the company of the $206 billion settlement between cigarette makers and 46 American states, and it warned that operating profit in the current quarter was likely to be below the level a year earlier.

title: Rangers' Popovic Glad to Be Working Out
description: When Peter Popovic crumpled to the ice after being hit in the eye with a puck Feb. 14, he knew that it was trouble. But he thought if he could just ignore it, that might be enough to solve the problem.

title: Chinese Raise Interest Rates on Dollar Deposits
description: China raised interest rates today on United States dollar deposits in an effort to stem a flow of hard currency out of the country that has come as international banks cut credit lines to Chinese borrowers.

title: Celebrating Composers At Lincoln Center Series
description: A Johann Sebastian Bach marathon marking the 250th anniversary of his death, a mixed-media tribute to Shostakovich and song recitals by Dawn Upshaw, Renee Fleming and Barbara Bonney are among the highlights of the 1999-2000 season of Lincoln Center's Great Performers, announced this week.

title: Household Buyback Seen
description: Household International Inc., the second-biggest United States nonbank consumer lender, said today that it might buy up to $2 billion, or more than 10 percent, of its shares because it believes the stock is undervalued. Household plans to repurchase the shares in the open market over the next two years. Household issues credit cards and makes auto, personal, home equity and other consumer loans. Household's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $41.8125. The company announced its buyback after the close of trading.

title: 12 Arrested During Sit-In To Protest Diallo Killing
description: A dozen people protesting the killing of Amadou Diallo were arrested yesterday after staging a sit-in in front of Police Headquarters, and organizers vowed to continue with daily acts of civil disobedience until the police officers involved in the shooting are arrested.

title: Rafter Is Defeated In First Round
description: There is no tennis player more jaunty than Australia's Patrick Rafter, the two-time United States Open champion, and there is nothing less jaunty in tennis than a double fault at match point. That was Rafter's unwitting parting shot yesterday in his opening-round loss at the Newsweek Champions Cup in Indian Wells, Calif.

title: A New Sony: The Walkman Goes Digital
description: The Sony Corporation, one of Japan's truly global companies, plans to do nothing less than reinvent itself, using a combination of enduring strength in consumer electronics and emerging high technology.

title: NATIONAL ORIGINS: California's Central Coast; From Out of the Mists, the Artichoke
description: STANDING at the edge of the jagged cliffs that run along Highway 1, you can hear the violence down below, the powerful Pacific shattering itself on the rocky shoreline. But what you feel is gentleness, a light briny mist that suffuses the air.

title: Health System In China Fails As AIDS Enters
description: Song Pengfei passes his days in a spare 12-by- 12-foot room moving from the bed with the red-checked blanket, to the chair, to a donated computer. His parents, their lives crammed into the adjacent sitting room, spend their days worrying.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts to limit the use of antibiotics in animals omitted part of a quotation in some copies. The comment, by Dr. Fred Angulo, an epidemiologist with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, should have read, ''The way we will make major progress, unfortunately, is when there is continuing emergence of treatment problems, not just in humans, but when these drugs don't work in sick animals.''

title: Fishing for Solutions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTACHER, SHEILA
description: OSTACHER-Sheila. On March 9, 1999. Beloved wife of Martin. Devoted mother of Jonathan, Jackie and Andrea. Loving mother-in-law of Lauren. Cherished grandmother of Lindsay. Dear sister of Lil Mordkoff, Dottie Elias and Isabel Goodman. Service today, 1PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, N.Y. (near Ave V).

title: THE CHEF
description: FRIDAY was fish day when I was growing up, and lots of times the fish was frozen fish sticks, the sauce was tartar, and the salad was coleslaw. With seven kids and a full-time job, my mom wasn't thinking fancy when Friday rolled around. But I enjoyed the crunch of the fish sticks' crust, the moistness of the fish and the coolness of the slaw. And it didn't hurt that the tartar sauce was sweet and sharp. I had these things in mind when I created jumbo lump crab cakes with chipotle sauce. Crab cakes may be fancier, but they have the same appeal.

title: A New Image For King Cabbage
description: CABBAGE too often conjures images of rank tenements or of surviving Russian winters. But around this time of year it deserves more respect.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: When the Oscars Get Going, The Audience Gets Hungry

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SEES 'COLLISION COURSE' IN KOSOVO DISPUTE
description: As the American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke arrived here, warning that Yugoslavia and the West were on a ''collision course'' over Kosovo that could bring NATO intervention, Yugoslav authorities announced today that they had issued arrest warrants for eight Kosovo rebel leaders, including three taking part in the peace talks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLIN, MARSHALL
description: PERLIN-Marshall. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Mike Perlin, distinguished People's Lawyer, will be held Sunday, March 14th, 2PM, at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St., Manhattan. For more information, call Hank 212-663-5833.

title: BASF Profits Weaken As Chemical Prices Fall
description: BASF A.G. of Germany, Europe's largest chemical maker, indicated yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit had fallen 23 percent and predicted a difficult 1999 as chemical prices drop. Net income at BASF fell to an implied 748 million marks ($415 million) in the quarter from 972 million marks a year earlier. BASF said full-year earnings rose 2.7 percent, to 3.32 billion marks ($1.84 billion).

title: Big Board Drops Its Lawsuit Against Amex
description: The New York Stock Exchange withdrew its lawsuit against the American Stock Exchange on Monday after Amex agreed to stop using the ticker symbol ''Q'' for its Nasdaq 100 Trust shares.

title: Top French Officials Cleared Over Blood With AIDS Virus
description: A former Prime Minister and a member of his Cabinet were acquitted today on charges of criminal negligence and manslaughter in the deaths of hundreds of people who contracted AIDS in the mid-1980's from transfusions of tainted blood.

title: Thornton Stars as Brother Cheers From a Cell
description: Travis Bush hasn't found much new lately in his daily searches of the newspaper to add to the decoration on his concrete walls. He already has 10 pictures and posters -- one of them showing his brother dunking at Madison Square Garden -- taped up and dozens of articles in a photo album he takes out almost every day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, RITA
description: SACHS-Rita. Teacher, of Jamaica, New York, died on March 7, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Nathan J. Sachs, she was cherished by her children, Alma Daniel and Arthur and Sara Sachs, and her grandchildren, Peter, Anthony, Nora, Tom, Becky and Jon. She was the beloved sister of Gilda Nelson and Freda Schreider and the late Ellis Katzman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JAMES V.
description: KELLY-James V. Age 74 of Fresh Meadows, Queens, NY on Monday, March 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Irene Lee (nee Dunn) (1998). Loving father of James V. Kelly, Jr. of Manhattan, NY; Rosemary Mullen of Glen Rock, NJ and Tricia Turco of Hawthorne, NJ. Father-in-law of Susan Kelly, Charles Mullen and Lou Turco. Grandfather of Lauren and Courtney Kelly and Jacqueline Turco. Brother of the late Walter Kelly (1979). Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday 10:00 am at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. The family would welcome memorial contributions to St. Jude's Children's Hospital for Cancer Research, Memphis, TN.

title: Tourism on the Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Too Much Salt

title: Lamar Alexander Declares Run for President in 2000
description: Repeatedly invoking his cheery mantra that he would ''bring out the best in America,'' Lamar Alexander formally declared his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination today by recalling his achievements as Governor of Tennessee and vowing to restore respect for the Presidency.

title: 50 Lashes With a Wet Noodle
description: To the Editor:

title: Trusts and Estates Give to the Neediest Cases Fund
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has issued a list of trusts and estates that have contributed to its 87th annual campaign. Donations from these sources totaled $1,642,289.13, compared with $1,445,060.83 a year ago. Following are the trusts and estates that took part.

title: Editorial Observer; End of a Disaster: Dismembering RJR Nabisco
description: It's over. A decade after RJR Nabisco was bought in the largest leveraged buyout in history, the company is being sliced into three pieces. It is a sad saga for almost all involved.

title: Bellcore Is Now Telcordia
description: Bellcore, the former research division of the Bell telephone companies, changed its name today to Telcordia Technologies to mark its new focus on combined voice and data networks and independence from the Bells.

title: From Memphis to Vietnam
description: I'M usually the kind of person you can pass a platter of biscuits to and feel confident you'll get some back. So I knew something was amiss when I practically inhaled an order of smoked pork ribs ($9.95) from PRET A PORTER, a friendly takeout spot on the Upper East Side.

title: END OF AN EMPIRE: THE CAROLINA VIEW; Where the Biggest Reaction Was No Big Reaction
description: In the old days, when the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company made a big announcement, civic and business leaders here where the company started more than 100 years ago met with Reynolds officials to learn about the news. The announcement today reflected the changing times for tobacco.

title: Nissan Plans To Pay Off Unit's Debts
description: Eager to resolve a sticking point in merger negotiations with DaimlerChrysler A.G., the Nissan Motor Company plans to announce on Wednesday that it is paying off debts at a troubled subsidiary, people close to Nissan said today.

title: Amtrak Unveils Its Bullet to Boston
description: Aiming to bring high-speed rail service to Boston by the start of the new millennium, Amtrak said yesterday that it would start rolling out the first of its new 150 mile-an-hour trains by December.

title: Study Finds Little Risks From PCB's
description: The largest ever study of occupational exposure to toxic PCB chemicals has found no significant increase in cancer deaths among workers who were exposed on the job.

title: Maturity Before College
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberals Wary of Clinton's Resolve on Social Security
description: Gearing up for a major battle to preserve Social Security's guaranteed benefits, organized labor's ostensible targets are the Republicans in Congress who support reshaping the retirement system to include private accounts. But the unions, joined by an array of women's groups, civil rights organizations and other liberal advocacy groups, are just as worried about being sold out by the Clinton Administration in the name of bipartisan compromise.

title: 4 Cape Town Politicians Killed, Aggravating Pre-election Jitters
description: Four local officials of a new political party have been killed in this area in the last 48 hours, raising fears that the violence that swept the country before the 1994 elections may be repeated before the national elections scheduled for June.

title: INSIDE
description: Union Leader Is Cleared

title: Physicists Gain in Effort to Predict Disruptive Solar Eruptions
description: Analyzing X-ray images of transient S-shaped patterns on the Sun, scientists think they have found a reliable way to forecast powerful solar eruptions that can cause disruptive magnetic storms in Earth's atmosphere, knock out electrical systems and communications, and disable orbiting spacecraft.

title: Plan to Rezone a School District Is Rejected Amid Charges of Bias
description: After months of debate and charges of racial divisiveness, a plan to rezone a school district that now includes the mostly white neighborhood of Riverdale in the Bronx and largely minority Marble Hill in Manhattan was narrowly rejected by the local school board after a heated meeting on Monday night.

title: Sports of The Times; March, Insanity, Sad Facts
description: MARCH Madness is a catchy, alliterative phrase designed to draw attention -- pecuniary preferably -- to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I men's basketball tournament, which begins tomorrow at eight sites around the country. I don't recall it being called March Madness until a handful of years ago when it became a big-time attraction on television, having swelled from a dozen or so teams to 64, a tournament big enough to choke a horse.

title: You're in Labor: Get Out Your Wallet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHN, HERMAN LOUIS
description: BOHN-Herman Louis. Age 81, of Fredericksburg, VA died on March 8, 1999. Husband of Marjorie S. Bohn. Father of Jeffrey A. Bohn and Susan St. Maurice. Brother of Doris Reynolds. Grandfather of three. Memorial service 7PM Friday, March 12, 1999 at Mullins & Thompson Fredericksburg Chapel.

title: America's Obligation in Italy
description: To many Americans, and probably most Europeans, the acquittal of Capt. Richard Ashby by a military jury may seem a miscarriage of justice. Twenty innocent tourists died last year in the Italian Alps when his low-flying Marine Corps jet severed the cable of their ski gondola in the Italian mountains. But the evidence presented at his court-martial showed that many others in the Marine Corps chain of command shared the blame. That gave the jury reason not to hold Captain Ashby criminally responsible.

title: Peggy Cass, 74, an Actress; Won Tony as Agnes Gooch
description: Peggy Cass, a brassy-voiced comedian best known for her portrayal of the pregnant, unwed secretary in ''Auntie Mame,'' died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. She was 74 and had homes in Manhattan and Westhampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSUEI, SISTER JOSEPHINE, M.S.C.
description: TSUEI-Sister Josephine, M.S.C. Missionary Sister of Sacred Heart of Jesus (Cabrini Sister). In repose Cabrini Medical Center Chapel, New York, NY 8AM-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, March 11 at 10AM at Epiphany Church, New York City. Interment Cabrini Burial Grounds, West Park, NY. For information: Raccuglia & Son 718-855-7737.

title: At Whitney, The Biennial Has Turned Into a Test
description: The other shoe has dropped at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Five months after a staff shake-up, the museum recently announced that for the first time in its history its Biennial survey of American art, scheduled to open in March 2000, would be organized by a team of six curators from outside the museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUELLAU, VINCENT W.
description: SUELLAU-Vincent W. Of Manhasset, NY. Died peacefully at home March 8, 1999. Born July 14, 1903. Beloved son of August H. and Gerda W. Suellau. Loving husband of Althea F. & the late Theresa A. Devoted father of Patricia Jordan, Virginia Glynn & the late Jacquelyn McEnerney. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and 23 greatgrandchildren. Retired president, Industrial Chemical Division, Allied Chemical Corporation. Wake at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Episcopal service at Fairchild chapel Thursday 10:30. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Is American Culture Unstoppable?; Our Regional Melange
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Plans to Unveil New Regulations Today as Part of an Airline Passenger Rights Package
description: Airlines that sell tickets for travel on another carrier will have to tell passengers in advance the name of the other airline, under a new Transportation Department regulation that Vice President Al Gore plans to announce on Wednesday as part of a ''passenger rights'' package.

title: British Insurer Selling 3 Property Operations
description: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three property companies to Moorfield Estates P.L.C. for $:392 million ($631 million). The transaction involves 75 office, retail and industrial properties, primarily in London and southeastern England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAX, PHILIP
description: STRAX-Philip. A pioneer in the use of mammography and other screening techniques for the early detection of breast cancer died in his sleep on March 9, 1999. He was 90. Dr. Strax was the founder and director of the Guttman Institute in New York City and the Strax Institute in Fort Lauderdale, FL; both institutes were established as nonprofit centers for the early detection and prevention of breast cancer. In 1988, Dr. Strax received the Charles F. Kettering Prize from General Motors for his medical research which established the importance of early detection as a way to reduce death from breast cancer. He was also a published poet, an avid photographer, a 3-D movie creator, and a talented harmonica player. Dr. Strax survived his two wives, Bertha and Gertrude. Dr. Strax was loved by many, including his sister, Anne; six children, Norman, Rita, Polly, Marshall, Richard, and Gayle; eight grandchildren, Bonnie, Todd, Wayne, Jill, Daniel, Lauren, Adam, and Brandon; and one greatgrandson, Zachary, affectionately known as ''The Zak Man.'' Funeral services will be conducted at Temple Israel of Great Neck (108 Old Mill Road, 516-482-7800) on March 11, 1999 at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Dr. Philip Strax Scholarship Fund, NYU School of Medicine, Office of Alumni Relations, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

title: Clinton Visit In Honduras Dramatizes New Attitude
description: President Clinton visited American troops involved in relief efforts in Honduras today in an effort to dramatize the new security relationship between the United States and Central America.

title: No Ducking: Holyfield Says He'll KO Lewis
description: One fighter worked out for two hours in a dungeon-like gym in Lower Manhattan, the booming bass line of gospel music filling the sweat-filled air. The other didn't spar and barely worked up a sweat over 45 minutes as a reggae beat pulsated in the spacious Theater at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Sack Exchange Is Having a Reunion
description: They have not appeared on the same stage since 1983, when they all wore Jets uniforms and played at Shea Stadium. But the Sack Exchange will be reunited on Sunday, March 21, at the Crowne Plaza-Meadowlands in Secaucus, N.J., as part of a Jets and Giants reunion weekend.

title: 6 Finalists Named In Review by Lowe's
description: The Lowe's Companies in North Wilkesboro, N.C., the home-improvement retail chain, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its broadcast advertising account to six finalists. Billings for the account, which has been handled by Doner in Southfield, Mich., since 1990, were estimated at $100 million.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Smoke-Free Snacks; RJR Nabisco's Spinoff Plan Takes a 180-Degree Turn
description: For months, shareholders of RJR Nabisco Holdings have besieged the company with requests to spin off the Nabisco food operations. They urged the company to create a nontobacco entity that would be able to rise above the depressed valuation of what should be one of the world's premier consumer-product companies.

title: Financier Stays Under The Radar
description: Where's Carl C. Icahn?

title: A 2-Referee Trial
description: The technical committee of world soccer's governing body yesterday in Zurich gave support to using two referees in games.

title: The Edgy Legacy of Stanley Kubrick
