description: The adjectives that cluster around Stanley Kubrick and his work -- cool, distant, reclusive, savage, brilliant -- are words that measure discomfort. Moviegoers love nothing more than certainty, but Kubrick, who died Sunday at age 70, rarely gave them that consolation. Hollywood, which also loves certainty and is deeply distrustful of artistic independence, found Kubrick an unquantifiable sum, a man driven by perfectionism and the ideal of artistic control in an art form where collaboration, not to say compromise, is the rule.

title: Words That Guide the Weary to the Promised Land
description: When you're a reader, you take your memorable passages where you find them -- sometimes in unexpected, unheralded places. Read, for example, these words of biblical power from a commentary on Isaiah's ''shadow of a great rock in a weary land,'' spoken in Kansas in the mid-19th century by a preacher known as Brother Carper:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKSTERN, REISS, JOSHUA
description: GLUCKSTERN - REISS - Joshua. With much sorrow, we mourn the untimely passing of Hazzan Joshua Gluckstern-Reiss, a gifted and gentle soul with much talent, warmth and humor. He enthusiastically shared his talents with Hazamir: The National Jewish High School Choir and all lovers of Jewish music. Y'hi zichro baruch. Zamir Choral Foundation Matthew Lazar, Founder & Dir. Marsha Bryan Edelman, Pres.

title: French Bank Seeks to Buy 2 Big Rivals
description: Making an unexpected takeover bid that would create the largest bank in the world, Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. offered $37 billion in stock tonight to acquire two of its biggest French rivals, Societe Generale S.A.and Paribas S.A., which just last month had agreed to merge.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Judge Allows Former Teacher To Sue Principal in Bias Case
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a former public school teacher could proceed with a lawsuit that accuses the principal of a New York City middle school of systematically forcing him and the school's only other black male teacher out of their jobs and making racially derogatory comments, including describing black students as ''monkeys.''

title: Swedish Teen-Ager Leads Italian Team
description: The MetroStars' preseason tour of Italy continued to be a bumpy one as they lost to the reserve team Empoli, 1-0, yesterday with Johan Arnene, a Swedish teen-ager, scoring the goal on a free kick in the 26th minute.

title: Tobacco Money Is Considered to Pay Debt
description: Nassau County officials are considering issuing bonds -- backed by the county's portion of the state's $25 billion tobacco settlement -- to plug a hole in the budget that has grown to $300 million for 1998 and 1999.

title: Ticket Prices Rise By $5 for All Seats
description: The Giants yesterday announced a ticket price increase of $5 for all seats next season. Seats in the upper and lower tiers of Giants Stadium will be $45 and tickets for seats in the mezzanine will be $50.

title: IT GROUP IN DEAL FOR SOME ASSETS OF ICF KAISER UNIT
description: IT Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $82 million in cash to acquire some assets of an ICF Kaiser International Inc. unit. It said the acquisition should add $120 million to its annual revenue. IT Group, an environmental services company based in Monroeville, Pa., had 1998 revenues of $442.2 million. The unit, Environmental and Facilities Management Group, provides services and technical support to United States Government agencies. ICF Kaiser, of Fairfax, Va., is an engineering and construction company. On Monday, it said it would sell its consulting unit to the New York-based investment firm CM Equity Partners L.P. for $75 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, VIVIAN W.
description: LEVY-Vivian W. On March 8, 1999, of Lynbrook, NY. Beloved wife of the late Ira L.. Devoted mother of Muriel and Steven Bishop. Dear sister of David Weissberger. Cherished grandmother of Ira, Eileen and William. Graveside services Wednesday, 11:00 AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

title: This Man Is the Talk of Los Alamos
description: To his next-door neighbors of 20 years, Wen Ho Lee is a generous man who shares plums from his backyard orchard and brings over steaming plates of Peking duck on Christmas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEILL, NANCY
description: NEILL-Nancy. The Board of Trustees and staff of the South Street Seaport Museum express deepest sympathies to our fellow Board member and Museum President, Peter Neill, and his family at the passing of his mother. Nancy was an intelligent, stylish lady who combined humor with a great interest in life. We know that she will be sorely missed and extend our sincere condolences.

title: Memorial for Viola Farber
description: A memorial for the dancer and choreographer Viola Farber will be held tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea. Ms. Farber, a founding member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, died in December at 67. Among those scheduled to participate in the tribute, which is open to the public, are Mr. Cunningham and Jeff Slayton, who was Ms. Farber's husband and dance partner. There will also be performances of works by Trisha Brown, Ralph Lemon and others.

title: Mother and Daughter Sentenced In Death of a Young Foster Child
description: In a case that spotlighted the city's inability to track foster parents who repeatedly abused children, two women who admitted killing a young girl in their care in 1997 were sentenced on manslaughter charges yesterday, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said.

title: Losing Proposition
description: Many in the sports world are celebrating Monday's ruling by a Federal District Court invalidating the National Collegiate Athletic Association's requirement that athletes attain minimum test scores to receive athletic scholarships.

title: Small Liberal Arts Colleges Facing Questions on Focus
description: Endowments are up, and so are applications. At the nation's 550 small private liberal arts colleges, times have seemingly never been better. So why do many educators fear for their future?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOK FINANCIAL CORP., Tulsa, Okla., a bank holding company, plans to buy Swiss Avenue Bank, Dallas, a $223 million institution, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. The Yeshiva University family expresses profound sorrow on the passing of a longtime friend, a distinguished philanthropist and communal leader in America and Israel who was senior vice chairman of YU's Board of Trustees and a Board member for three decades, including service as acting chairman. An honorary alumnus, he was a Benefactor with his wife, Ursula, advancing a wide range of University programs. In recognition of their major gift, YU's Teachers Institute for Men was renamed Isaac Breuer College of Hebraic Studies to memorialize Mrs. Merkin's renowned father. Mr. Merkin established the Leib Merkin Distinguished Professorial Chair in Talmud and Jewish Philosophy at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary in memory of his eminent father-a chair long held by the late revered Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik. A founding member of the Boards of YU's Yeshiva College, Stern College for Women, and Sy Syms School of Business, he formerly served on the Boards of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, and Wurzweiler School of Social Work. He was an outstanding humanitarian whose benefactions covered many institutions and individuals, and he was a deeply faithful and observant Jew who was learned in the classical sources of the tradition. His life was truly a blessing. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ursula; children, Dinah (and Andrew) Mendes, Deborah (and Nathaniel) Gerber, Ezra (and Lauren) Merkin, Daphne Merkin, Solomon Nehemiah (and Sharon) Merkin, and Rabbi David Elisha (and Rebecca) Merkin; sister, Eva Bondi; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Fright Night: Ewing Hurt in Loss
description: The sight of Patrick Ewing limping off the court 29 seconds into the game with a sore Achilles' tendon opened the eyes, sharpened the minds and strengthened the resolve of his teammates. The Knicks played small and smart until a series of mistakes and one pivotal mental lapse by Latrell Sprewell undid it all.

title: VENTURE HOLDINGS TO ADD AUTO PARTS MAKER
description: The auto parts concern Venture Holdings Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Peguform G.m.b.H., Botzingen, a leading European maker of plastic auto components, from Klockner-Werke A.G., for 850 million marks, or $473 million. The combined company would have annual sales of more than $2 billion. Peguform makes such plastic components as bumpers, dashboards and door panels in 16 plants in six countries for several auto makers. Venture Holdings is a closely held company based in Fraser, Mich. Klockner-Werke, of Duisburg, Germany, is 19 percent owned by the trading company Klockner & Company, a unit of the German energy concern Viag A.G.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Monday about Gov. George W. Bush's creation of an exploratory committee for a Presidential race misspelled the surname of a Kentucky Republican who is a member. She is Representative Anne M. Northup, not Northrup.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Formerly of Sarabeth's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, RALPH
description: JAFFE-Ralph. We extend heartfelt condolences to Trudy Jaffe on the passing of her beloved husband, Ralph. He was an extraordinary and humble man whose very being radiated kindness, dignity and modesty. A Founder of the medical center together with Trudy, his leadership and exceptional commitment to tzedakah played a vital role in providing world-class and compassionate medical care to the people of Israel, rooted in the spiritual and ethical precepts of Jewish tradition to which he devoted his life. May Trudy, his son Lawrence, his daughter Rochelle Greenberg, a devoted patron and outstanding friend to the medical center, and the entire family, having loving memories of this wonderful and caring man, and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: This Company Is a Customer That Bankers Love to Help
description: Wall Street has always found creative ways to make money. But probably no other company over the years has done more to enrich the coffers of investment bankers than RJR Nabisco. Even going back to 1985, when R. J. Reynolds first acquired Nabisco Brands for $4.9 billion -- the fourth-largest deal that year -- bankers walked away with $19 million in advisory fees, including Morgan Stanley, Shearson Lehman and Dillon, Read.

title: An Early Rally Reverses and Dow Finishes Down 33.85
description: Stocks declined yesterday, led lower by concern about the performance of Intel and Walt Disney.

title: Metro Business; Pledge on Housing Loans
description: A consumer group and a Brooklyn-based bank seeking to expand into New Jersey announced an agreement yesterday that the bank would set aside $20 million over five years for low-cost mortgages and loans for small businesses and affordable housing projects in Newark and Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYNES, ALICE (NEE HANNON)
description: MYNES-Alice (nee Hannon). Of Easton, MA., Formerly of Bronx, NY on March 9, 1999. Wife of the late Laurence Mynes. Mother of Ann Orgera of Easton, MA., and Laurence Mynes of Lodi, NJ. Grandmother of two. Funeral Mass will be held on Friday at 10am in the Corpus Christi R.C. Church, Hasbrouck Heights, NJ. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting hours Thursday, 7-9PM in the Costa Memorial Home, Boulevard and Central Avenue, Hasbrouck Heights, NJ

title: Singer Sells Taiwan Plant
description: The Singer Company said yesterday that it had sold its sewing machine manufacturing operations in Taiwan to a local investment group for $10 million plus $48.6 million of assumed debt. In the deal, Singer said it would operate the business under a contract for five years while retaining current management and other personnel at the plant. Singer, which is based in Hong Kong, makes sewing machines and other consumer products.

title: Without Monica
description: Even though ABC has special access to the newswoman of the sweep month, Monica Lewinsky (though Barbara Walters could also fit that description), NBC's ''Nightly News With Tom Brokaw'' came away from the news competition for February a rather easy winner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOPP, EDITH HALPRIN
description: SCOPP-Edith Halprin. On February 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Irwin W. Scopp, loving mother of Dr. Alfred Scopp and cherished grandmother of David. Family and friends mourn the passing of Edith Scopp, former Assistant Principal, Business Studies at the Charles E. Hughes High School. Services were held in Florida and New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JOE
description: SIMONS-Joe. A valued teacher and a valued friend, Joe's ability to share his knowledge of design was instrumental in the success of the Toy Design Department at FIT. We mourn the loss of an innovative, inventive man of integrity. We have lost a rare and kind person and we will be the poorer for this loss even as we will always be to the richer for having known him. We express our deepest regrets to his family.

title: Accounting Is Questioned In Lawsuit Against iVillage
description: Just days before the planned initial public stock offering of iVillage Inc., a New York Internet service for women, a former chief financial officer of the company has filed court documents accusing iVillage of ''inappropriate'' accounting practices.

title: Television Life
description: Peter Tolan, a comedy writer whose credits include both ''The Larry Sanders Show'' and the top box office movie ''Analyze This,'' has had so much experience dealing with television executives, most of it bad, that he is writing one sitcom for HBO based on how these executives do their work (tentatively called ''The Web'') and another based on a book written by a television executive.

title: A Republican Seeks to Ban Suits Against Gun Makers
description: Opening a second front in the latest battle to protect the gun industry, Representative Bob Barr today introduced legislation that would block the lawsuits filed by cities against gun manufacturers.

title: Iran's Leader Welcomed in Italy; Main Topic Is Business
description: Seeking to break his country's isolation, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran arrived in Italy today for a three-day visit, the first Iranian leader to visit Western Europe since the Islamic Revolution toppled the Shah in 1979.

title: McCall Urges Nassau County to Overhaul Property Taxes
description: For the first time, New York's State Comptroller has called for the complete overhaul of Nassau County's archaic property tax system, which the Federal Government says discriminates against black and Hispanic homeowners.

title: Is American Culture Unstoppable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the burlesque performer Ann Corio yesterday misstated the given name of another prominent performer in her field. She was Margie Hart, not Maggie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ERIC R.
description: WOLF-Eric R. The Faculty, Staff and Students of The Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Distinguished Professor Emeritus Eric R. Wolf, member of the doctoral faculty since 1971. Recipient of a MacArthur Foundation award, he was renowned for his pioneering work in the area of peasant studies and was instrumental in redefining the anthropological concept of culture. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Graduate School Professor Emerita, Sydel Silverman, and family. Memorial contributions may be made to the Eric R. Wolf Student Research Fund, Anthropology Program, CUNY Graduate School, 33 W. 42 Street, New York, New York 10036. Frances Degen Horowitz, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, HUGO F. JR.
description: BARTH-Hugo F. Jr. March 7, 1999. Age 86, of New Vernon, NJ, and Palm Beach, FL. Husband of Margery Reeve Barth and the late Edna V. Barth, father of Hugo F., III, Bruce G. and Brent B. Barth, step-father of Margery Leiter, Susan Ippoliti & Linda Hines, brother of Ethel Morris, also survived by seven grandchildren & three step grandchildren. Funeral service at the New Vernon Presbyterian Church, Lees Hill Road, New Vernon, Friday, March 12, at 2:00p.m. Interment Fairview Cemetery, Westfield. Visitation at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Writing the Last Chapter of 'Barbarians at the Gate'
description: Yesterday's move by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to break up and spin off its tobacco business is a nonevent for consumers. Oreo cookies, Life Savers candies and Planters peanuts will continue to roll off Nabisco's production lines and Camel and Winston cigarettes will come out of the R. J. Reynolds tobacco factories.

title: Laborers' Union President Is Cleared of Links to Mob
description: An in-house hearing officer yesterday cleared Arthur A. Coia, president of the laborers' union, of associating with members of organized crime but fined him $100,000 for buying a $450,000 Ferrari with help from a supplier to the union.

title: Delay by State Police Cited in Inquiry
description: A two-year-old Federal investigation into allegations of racial discrimination by the New Jersey State Police proceeded slowly in its early stages because the police lagged in forwarding requested information to Washington, a top Justice Department official told a group of New Jersey lawmakers and black ministers today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNAUER, EMMA H.
description: ORNAUER-Emma H. 104 years. Formerly of Merrick and Floral Park. Died March 7, 1999. Wife for 70 years of the late Edwin L. Mother of Dolly Masch of Cortlandt Manor, NY and Richard L. Ornauer of Dover, DE. Also survived by six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Services will be private. Contributions may be sent to Tribute Fund, Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, 68 Hauppauge Rd., Commack, NY 11725

title: Connecticut Chiefs Assail Plan to Record Race of Drivers
description: The Connecticut State Police and police chiefs from across the state today attacked a senior legislator's plan to require officers to record the race of every motorist they pull over, saying that questioning drivers could inflame racial tensions.

title: Two New York Health Care Giants Form Joint Venture to Reduce Costs
description: Two of the largest health care providers in the New York area, the Mount Sinai N.Y.U. Medical Center and Health System and the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, have formed a joint venture intended to hold down costs and devise far-reaching quality-of-care standards.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPELMAN, MORRIS
description: KOPPELMAN-Morris. 10 years today that you left us. Dearly remembered, so sadly missed. Love, Nina

title: FIGHT OVER ORGANS SHIFTS TO STATES FROM WASHINGTON
description: The battle over the nation's scarcest medical resource, human organs, has moved from Washington to the states, where a number of legislatures have begun passing laws that would bar donated hearts, lungs, kidneys, livers and pancreases from being shipped beyond their borders to sick people elsewhere in the country.

title: CURRENTS: PORCELAIN; Fit for a Princess Or for a New Yorker
description: Manufacture de Monaco Porcelaine, founded in the principality in 1972 by Erich Rozewicz at the urging of Princess Grace, is best known for its creamy gilt-edged ashtrays, regularly stolen from the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo, and for its cobalt-blue plates, modeled on mosaics in Monaco's palace. Now, the company has produced the New York collection, handmade bowls and vases in shades of celedon.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; An Outsider Earns His Inside Access
description: THE TIMES OF MY LIFEAnd My Life With The TimesBy Max FrankelIllustrated. 546 pages. Random House. $29.95.

title: More Foreign Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Food Fight: Nabisco Is Seen As Hot Target
description: The breakup of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation that was announced on Tuesday may have satisfied a good many shareholders who had lobbied for such a change for years. But more fireworks may be in store for the separate companies that will be created by RJR's decision to abandon its 14-year effort to run food and tobacco operations under the same corporate roof.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the former swimmer Eleanor Holm Whalen, omitted the use she made of a gift she received from the Nazis at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. After receiving a silver swastika pin from Hermann Goring, she made a copy of the pin and replaced the swastika with a diamond Star of David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HELEN PRIEST
description: ROGERS-Helen Priest. Dance Notation Bureau mourns the loss of a co-founder, friend, and gracious lady. Her belief never wavered. We thank her family for naming the DNB as recipient of donations in her memory. The Dance Notation Bureau

title: A New Breed in Paris:Hyper-Realistic Designers
description: PARIS  If there is a common link to the young designers working in Paris right now  Jeremy Scott, Bless, Gaspard Yurkievich, Sharon Wauchob  it is that they all belong to a school of hyper-realism.

title: What Time Is It on the Internet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, GLADYS
description: NADLER-Gladys. Tifereth Israel/ Town & Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abby Sosland President Carol J. Green

title: Glad It Isn't A Videophone
description: It's a modern pickle. A person is lazing in the tub and watching television. Then the phone rings. What to do?

title: Pearson Reports Gain Of 12% in Profit
description: Pearson P.L.C., the world's largest educational publisher, said yesterday that its second-half profit rose 12 percent, buoyed by United States sales and its Financial Times unit. Profit from operations rose to $:185.7 million ($301 million) from $:165.6 million a year earlier.

title: 19-Year-Old's Weather Research Has the Experts Taking Note
description: Two years ago, Dr. Robert D. Cess, a climatologist at the State University of New York here, grumbled when another professor urged him to supervise a local high school student in a summer program for bright teen-agers.

title: Judge Allows Gang Leader to Talk With Other Infamous Prisoners
description: When the nation's most infamous terrorists -- the Oklahoma City bomber, the Unabomer, and the World Trade Center bomber -- are allowed out of solitary confinement so that they can have one hour of exercise in the nation's most secure Federal prison, what do they do?

title: On Beholding 'David'
description: To the Editor:

title: For Vanity And Obsession
description: Publishers are not yet madly bidding against each other for the rights to books about making movies, but quite suddenly, it seems, these and other movie-related books are popping up in numbers that no longer can be ignored. It's a genre about vanity and obsession: the conceit of the moviemakers and the infatuation of those who, to a great degree, get their culture in the flickering darkness of the picture show.

title: McGwire Tees Off On Nomo; Mets Shrug
description: After Hideo Nomo struck out Mark McGwire on a split-finger fastball in his first at-bat today, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine wanted to see what the home-run record holder would do with a conventional fastball in his next trip to the plate.

title: Sports of The Times; Joe DiMaggio's Rings, Bats and Tee Shots
description: BEFORE he was to throw out the first ball at Old-Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium last July, the silver-haired Joe DiMaggio suddenly arrived in the shadowy corridor behind the Yankee dugout. He was wearing what he often wore: a blue blazer over a white shirt with a burgundy tie, sharply creased gray slacks and shiny black shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSLOW, HENRY D.
description: WINSLOW-Henry D. Of Lexington, MA, formerly of Cambridge, MA, died March 8, 1999. Husband of Katharine (Nichols) Winslow for 64 years. Father of Henry N. Winslow and his wife, B.J. Winslow, of Newtonville, MA, Katharine W. and her husband, Dr. Alfred Herzog, of Glastonbury, CT, and the late Philip N. Winslow of New York City. Grandfather of Katharine H. Dube and Anne W. Herzog. Memorial services at First Parish Church Cambridge Unitarian Universalist on April 10 at 2:30 p.m. Donations may be made to the First Parish Church Unitarian Universalist, 3 Church Street, Cambridge, MA. 02138 or to the charity of one's choice.

title: Top Triarc Executives Halt Bid for Company
description: The Triarc Companies, the owner of Snapple and of RC Cola drinks, announced yesterday that its chairman, Nelson Peltz, and president, Peter May, had withdrawn their offer to take the company private for $18 a share, or $420 million.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HARRIET WISNIEWSKI, MD.
description: HARRIS-Harriet Wisniewski, MD. On March 9, 1999. Loving wife of the late Lewis Harris, beloved mother of Mark and David Harris both of New York City, cherished sister of Chet and Ray Wisniewski, and friend and colleague of the staff of St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. Funeral services are Friday, at Noon at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours are Thursday, 6-9PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society, The St. Francis of Assisi breadline, or the Jacob Perlow Hospice would be appreciated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: After 2d Day With Milosevic, Envoy Reports No Progress
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the American envoy, emerged today from daylong negotiations with the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, saying he had failed to win any change in the Serbian leader's opposition to the peace proposal for Kosovo.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Latest DuPont Formula Turns One Company Into Two Stocks
description: Paving the way for possible future acquisitions, the DuPont Corporation is taking a half-step to separate its giant chemical business from its pharmaceutical, agricultural chemicals and other so-called life sciences products.

title: Man of Precision Behind the Messy Microbes
description: ''PUT your foot on the gut,'' the curator says, excited.

title: Sears Settles Suit on Raising Of Its Credit Card Rates
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it would settle a class-action suit from plaintiffs who contended that the retailer had fraudulently raised the annual interest rates on their credit cards after it had promised not to. Sears agreed to pay $36 million in cash and issue store coupons worth $118 million to card holders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELDOCH, HONEY
description: BELDOCH-Honey. A Memorial Service to celebrate the life of Honey Beldoch, who died peacefully on Feb 20th in her sleep. Her Florida friends and relatives are invited 1:30pm on Saturday Mar 13th at 130 Sunrise Blvd, Palm Beach.

title: Conductor Steps In, Unrehearsed
description: It is often a matter of curiosity, for those of us who generally hear the first or second outing of a run, how well the performances might have stood up until the end, but the press of other events seldom allows time to find out. The New York Philharmonic series just ended was hardly typical, with its change of conductor for the final performance, yet that unusual aspect made it seem all the more worthwhile to check in again.

title: BRYLANE ACCEPTS $211 MILLION BID BY PINAULT-PRINTEMPS
description: Brylane Inc., a catalogue retailer based in New York, accepted a sweetened $211 million takeover offer from Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A., allowing the French company to accelerate its expansion into the United States. Pinault, owner of La Redoute catalogue in Europe, increased its offer to $24.50 a share from $20 after a Brylane shareholder complained that the first offer, made in December, was too low, said Pinault's chief executive, Serge Daniel Weinberg. Pinault owns 49.9 percent of Brylane and has been building its stake since early last year as it expands its mail-order business beyond Europe. Shares of Brylane rose $2.6875, to $24.125.

title: F.D.A. Orders Clearer Labels On Medication
description: The Food and Drug Administration is about to order the drug industry to revamp the labeling on over-the-counter medications, a move that will do away with dense fine print on medicines from aspirin to cough syrup, replacing it with simple, and bigger, text that is similar to the nutrition labels on food packages.

title: Bank and Insurer Merging in Denmark
description: Tryg-Baltica A.S., Denmark's largest insurance company not dealing in life insurance, and Unidanmark A.S., Denmark's second-largest banking company, said yesterday that they planned to merge, creating a leading Danish financial services group.

title: Europe's Right on Cows
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HENRY
description: COHEN-Henry. 91. On March 8, 1999. Loving husband of Celia, dear uncle and friend. Contributions to The Cabrini Hospice, Cabrini Medical Center, 227 E. 19 St, NYC 10003 would be appreciated.

title: New Style at St. John's: Better, Smarter, Tougher
description: St. John's last two games a grinding, methodical victory over Miami, and a blowout loss to Connecticut -- are microcosms of what may carry the Red Storm on a run through the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, or what may short-circuit it before it gets out of the first weekend.

title: Airman Is Ousted as Rebellion Against Anthrax Vaccine Grows
description: The happy military career of Jeffrey A. Bettendorf ended abruptly today. After threatening him with court-martial, the Air Force discharged Airman First Class Bettendorf under ''other than honorable conditions'' because he refused to take a vaccine that the Pentagon says could one day have saved his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ESSIE (NEE LIPPNER)
description: GREEN-Essie (nee Lippner). On March 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel H. Green. Loving mother of Larrie Majors and the late Ann Harriet Green. Service private.

title: NASA Shuttle Mission Is Moved Up to Repair Hubble Telescope
description: Seeking to avoid a ''science emergency'' with the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA officials announced today that they would launch a space shuttle to repair failing parts on the orbiting observatory in mid-October, eight months ahead of schedule.

title: House to Vote on Kosovo Force Despite White House Appeals
description: After weeks of growing unease over United States policy in Kosovo, the issue of sending American troops to enforce a peace settlement in a foreign civil war is being pushed to the House floor, despite objections by the Administration.

title: U.S. Curbs Low-Flight Training in Italy Near '98 Ski-Lift Deaths
description: American flight crews working temporarily at the base in Aviano, Italy, are now prohibited from low-level training flights like the one that hit a ski-gondola cable 13 months ago, killing 20 people, the Pentagon said today in announcing a safety review.

title: Jail Instead of Psychiatrists
description: It did not take long after the vaunted reforms of the 1970's, when warehouses for the mentally ill were shut down, for reformers to notice that the mental-health millennium had not arrived. Inmates were freed from appalling conditions behind institution walls only to reappear on city streets, wandering at risk to themselves and sometimes to others as well as to civic propriety. The community health alternatives that were supposed to replace the oversize state hospitals remained wishful thinking.

title: Amgen Gets Rights to Prostate Cancer Drug
description: Amgen Inc., the world's biggest biotechnology company, said today that it had acquired rights to a prostate cancer drug that was in the final stages of human trials. The deal was made with Praecis Pharmaceuticals Inc., a closely held company.

title: More Adult (as in Adulterated) News
description: The Monica Lewinsky jokes worked. Last week, after Ms. Lewinsky's astronomically high-rated ABC interview with Barbara Walters, Jon Stewart reported on ''The Daily Show'': ''Lewinsky said her liaison with Clinton was 'the most amazing experience of my life,' a description she had only previously given to reading 'Flowers in the Attic,' seeing 'Phantom' on stage in Baltimore and helping special-ed kids pull taffy at high school.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAX, PHILIP, M.D.
description: STRAX-Philip, M.D. The faculty, administration and alumni of the New York University School of Medicine are profoundly saddened by the passing of Dr. Philip Strax, Class of 1931, on Tuesday, March 9, 1999. Dr. Strax was a loyal member of the faculty in the Department of Environmental Medicine, and diligently served on the Board of Governors for the School of Medicine Alumni Association for over 25 years culminating in his presidency for the 198182 academic year. We will always remember his warm sense of humor and wise counsel. To his children and grandchildren we express our most heartfelt sympathy. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine Beth W. Lieberman, M.D. '73 President, NYU School of Medicine Alumni Association

title: Historic Designs, Full of Whimsy
description: Yrene Escandon, once a lady-in-waiting to Empress Carlotta of Mexico, embroidered a design in the 19th century. Now it is a Brunschwig & Fils fabric. Senorita Escandon entered a convent after serving the Empress, and from 1860 to 1869, she worked with others to embroider a silk sampler with dogs, shy goats and butterflies.

title: LESLIE FAY'S TOP HOLDER SEEKS DEBT-FOR-STOCK BUYBACK
description: The top shareholder of the Leslie Fay Company, the women's clothier, asked it to buy back 41 percent of the company's stock by exchanging 2.5 million shares for debt securities at a premium to the current share price. The holder, Dickstein & Company of New York, an investor in distressed companies, began acquiring its 41.8 percent stake in Leslie Fay, with 2.53 million shares, after the company emerged from bankruptcy in June 1997. Dickstein would participate in the buyback and also ''remain substantial stockholders,'' a filing at the Securities and Exchange Commission said. The proposal would replace a current $5 million buyback plan, which was announced last fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, BARBARA L.
description: SAMUELS-Barbara L. Died peacefully at home on March 7 at the age of 98. Widow of the late Martin Samuels, she lived a long, lively and independent life, with good health and all her marbles. Last survivor of the five Lindner sisters and their brother, she leaves, through them and through Martin, a large, loving, extended family-to all of whom she has always been, and remains, ''Aunt Barbara.''

title: Treasuries Sag As Other Debt Markets Swell
description: Treasury securities fell in price under the sheer weight of corporate and municipal supply yesterday, as big companies including Lucent Technologies and Freddie Mac sold debt to the public sector.

title: For Zaha Hadid's Buildings, the Question Is How, Not When
description: For most architects' buildings, the question is when, where and if they are ever going to be built. Zaha Hadid's startling visions of tectonic thrust make one wonder how they could be built. But after years of wowing fans of avant-garde architecture, Ms. Hadid is finding clients eager to build her designs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the movement opposing the death penalty movement misstated the affiliation of Richard Dieter. He is executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, not the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty.

title: Bank Chief Vows to Curb Brazilian Debt
description: The new president of Brazil's central bank promised ''a frontal attack'' today on the swelling public debt brought on by the financial crisis and predicted Brazil would return to the capital markets in a matter of weeks.

title: Charles J. Elia, Retired Business Writer, 72
description: Charles J. Elia, 72, a retired business reporter and columnist, died Sunday after a heart attack at his home in Brightwaters, N.Y., said his son, Ricardo Elia of Medford, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINGTON, ROBERT SR.
description: WASHINGTON-Robert Sr. Age 62, bronx, Ny died Sunday, March 7, 1999. Devoted husband of Ethel; father to Linda, Robert Jr., Dean, Janet and Angela; grandfather of five. This teacher will be greatly missed by his extended family. Services today Granby's Funeral Service, 718-519-6047.

title: Fierce Poetry From Young Turks
description: WENDELL BURNETTE'S first building, a house for himself at the edge of the Sonoran desert, has graced the covers of numerous international magazines. The British magazine Architectural Review proclaimed him ''one to watch in 1998'' and Metropolitan Home recently named him one of ''21 Rising Stars for the 21st Century.'' A 36-year-old architect from Phoenix, he has arrived.

title: Microsoft Forming Alliances in China
description: The Microsoft Corporation signed agreements today with at least nine companies operating in China, a move that may help its new operating system gain market dominance there.

title: After the Design, the Details; Digital Plans Will Make Dome a Pleasant Place to Visit
description: THE architects and engineers of the new Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan used computers to generate heat. And light.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: A Tree From Home

title: A Science Fiction Game Jumps From Video to the Big Screen
description: ''Wing Commander'' opens tomorrow in theaters around the country. If the title sounds familiar, that is because ''Wing Commander'' came to life as a science fiction video game, and in making the jump to the big screen, it is going where few video games have gone before.

title: Geeks Breathe a Sigh of Relief At the Reincarnation of Byte
description: When the venerable Byte magazine bit the dirt in July last year, it created a void for those computer users who are happiest when they are up to their pocket protectors in circuit boards and cables. For more than 20 years, spanning the PC industry's transformation from an esoteric hobby to an unavoidable part of everyday life, Byte was the guide for those who are known affectionately as computer geeks.

title: New York Police to Start Getting Hollow-Point Bullets Next Week
description: The Police Department will start equipping officers next week with hollow-point bullets, which cause greater injury than the ammunition they currently use but are less likely to pass through people and hit innocent bystanders, the police said yesterday.

title: Young Designers Shaped by Dark Gothic of '80s : Minding the (Generational) Gap
description: PARIS  Jeremy Scott, who will close the latest round of international women's ready-to-wear shows Saturday night, is just one of a number of young designers, with a median age of about 25, currently shaping fashion's future. The dark, gothic aesthetic of his contemporaries, Veronique Branquinho, Olivier Theyskens and Balenciaga's Nicholas Ghesquiere, for example, has had an enormous effect on many a runway this season.

title: Safer Web Playgrounds Are Aimed at Kids (and Paying Parents)
description: A FEW years ago, Alan Rothenberg was a frustrated parent. He was tired of buying educational CD-ROM's at $45 a pop, only to have his children become bored and abandon them after a couple of hours. Sure, the World Wide Web had plenty of sites with children's games, but he wasn't impressed with their educational content and he was reluctant to let his young children roam on the Internet, where they might end up in a seedy corner. Like many parents, he thought, ''If only there were an Internet just for them.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHAEFER, KENNETH J.
description: SCHAEFER-Kenneth J. March 11, 1969. You were with us for thirty years and, now, you are gone thirty years. You will always be loved and you will never be forgotten. The Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, PIA (NEE MARRONARO)
description: MARINO-Pia (nee Marronaro). Retired teacher Regina Pacis School. Beloved wife of Michael. Devoted mother of Dr. Phyllis Marino Domnitz and the late Anthony Marino, Esquire. Cherished mother-in-law of Dr. Steven Domnitz. Loving grandmother of Justin and Stephanie, fond sister of Elizabeth Daddiego, Joseph and Bernard Marronaro. Reposing at the Ralph Aievoli Funeral Home 1275 65 Street, corner 13th Ave., Brooklyn, on Thursday 7-9:30 P.M., on Friday 2-4:30 PM and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30AM at Regina Pacis Church.

title: Ewing Is Out Indefinitely As Pain Dictates Return
description: Patrick Ewing does not know when he will play again. The pain in his inflamed Achilles' tendon is not an ache he can conquer with grit, as he does with his battle-worn knees.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Firsthand Recall At a Book Party

title: Metro Business; Large Winemaker Near an Acquisition
description: Canandaigua Brands, the New York wine and spirits giant, is poised to buy the historic Simi Winery in California, said an employee who was briefed about the impending sale.

title: A Bevy Of Bovine Tributes
description: COWS and computers go together like, well, milk and cookies.

title: ESSAY; Shakespeare Never Lost a Manuscript to a Computer Crash
description: IS there any chance, I wonder, that we might prevail on the movie industry to change its rating for ''Shakespeare in Love'' from R to G? I'd be willing to risk whatever harm a few flashes of Gwyneth Paltrow's breasts might do to our children in exchange for the contribution the film makes to computer literacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, LAWRENCE
description: GREENSPAN-Lawrence. Worker, soldier, entrepreneur, family man, a tough human, a soft touch, he gave more than he received. Graveside service on Thursday at Sharon Gardens. Donations to Calvary Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASS, PEGGY
description: CASS-Peggy. On March 8, 1999. Beloved wife of Eugene Feeney. Reposing Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville funeral service, 1297 First Avenue, NYC, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM, at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations to Sloan-Kettering Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Essay; The Supervictim
description: In an age that celebrates victimhood, Monica Lewinsky has earned the title of Supervictim.

title: APPLIED GRAPHICS IN $92.3 MILLION BID FOR WACE GROUP
description: Applied Graphics Technologies Inc. said it had offered to acquire Wace Group P.L.C. of Britain for 72 pence a share in cash, or $92.3 million. Applied Graphics Technologies, which is based in New York, provides services ranging from combining text and graphics into page layouts before printing to digitizing information for distribution on the Internet. Wace Group operates an international network of digital imaging businesses and provides digital services.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIGITAL COURIER TECHNOLOGIES INC., Salt Lake City, a developer of electronic-commerce software, agreed to acquire Databank International SKB, a credit card transaction processing firm, in a deal valued at more than $50 million.

title: Castles, and Planetariums, in the Air
description: NO engineering degree is needed to appreciate how useful a computer would be in designing an 87-foot steel sphere capable of holding 585 people at once, apparently floating on air in the center of a giant glass cube, neither suspended from its top pole nor supported at its bottom.

title: Skepticism as a Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: ANCHOR GAMING IN $220 MILLION DEAL FOR POWERHOUSE
description: Moving to enter the on-line lottery business, Anchor Gaming agreed yesterday to acquire Powerhouse Technologies Inc. for $220 million in stock plus assumed debt of $60 million. Shares of Powerhouse jumped $3.0625, to $17.875, and Anchor Gaming rose $3.8125, to $38.375. Anchor, a gambling-machine company in Las Vegas, Nev., said the combined company would have revenue of about $450 million. Powerhouse, based in Atlanta, makes software and other equipment for on-line lotteries, video lotteries and parimutuel systems. It also operates Sunland Race Track and Casino in New Mexico.

title: Physicist-Theologian Awarded A $1.2 Million Prize in Religion
description: The world's largest monetary prize, the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, has been awarded this year to Ian G. Barbour, a physicist-theologian who has spent four decades to fostering a dialogue between science and religion.

title: Politicians of All Persuasions Rally Round Rival Bills to Protect Lands
description: Sensing widespread support for programs to preserve open spaces, lawmakers from both parties have offered competing proposals that exceed even the Clinton Administration's record $1.1 billion request to protect open land from development.

title: Skepticism as a Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is Art? That Can Mostly Depend on the Context
description: CONTEXT is what people use to make sense of new information. An unfamiliar word can make sense in a sentence. An unfamiliar place can have meaning on a map. An isolated event can be significant in the context of history. Context turns information into knowledge. It's the difference between a warehouse and a museum.

title: Exhibitions, Lectures And an Antiques Show
description: Ornate Rome

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Apology in Guatemala

title: 2 Teen-Agers Killed at Protest of Gaza Verdict
description: Palestinian security forces in the Gaza Strip shot and killed two teen-agers today in violent protests that erupted after a suspected member of the militant group Hamas was sentenced to death for killing a Palestinian police officer, witnesses said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's always a place at the table for a female candidate. But for it to become more than that, she has to have a message beyond, 'I am woman, hear me roar.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASCAL, GERMAINE L.
description: PASCAL-Germaine L. On March 9, 1999. Beloved sister of Rolande. Loving cousin of Monica and Isabella. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., NYC, Friday 2:00-5:00, 7:00-9:00 PM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Citigroup Joins Mastercard's Smaller Board
description: Citigroup joined a slimmed-down board of Mastercard International yesterday, a month after leaving Visa International's board as competition between the credit card groups intensifies.

title: Man, 37, Admits Abuse and Burglary
description: A Mullica Township man pleaded guilty Tuesday to burglary and child abuse charges for breaking into a 9-year-old girl's bedroom and kissing her several times, county prosecutors said.

title: Few in Japan See Bargain In Price of Tobacco Deal
description: Investors, analysts and business people gasped today at the $8 billion price that Japan Tobacco Inc., the former cigarette monopoly here, paid for the international tobacco business of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, HARVEY
description: HOFFMAN - Harvey. Beloved father of Jennifer. Devoted grandfather of Hannah & Grace. Loving father-in-law of Werner HoffmanBrion. Funeral Mass on Saturday, St. Mary's Church, Marlboro, NY. Donations in his memory can be sent to the Catholic Worker, 36 East 1st Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: The Land of the Rising Outlook; Public Spending May Have Reversed Japan's Downturn
description: Bulldozers and tall cranes are popping up around the country like bamboo shoots after a spring rain, and this is raising hopes that Japan may finally be close to lifting itself out of recession.

title: In a New Museum, a Blue Period
description: WHEN was the last time you loved a building and it loved you back?

title: Stay Is Sought In Testing Case
description: Lawyers for the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday filed an emergency motion to stay a Federal judge's order that threw out the use of minimum scores on standardized tests for freshman athletes in intercollegiate athletics. The lawyers said the sweeping order had created chaos in a system that typically needed two or three years to educate high school counselors and their students about any new rule.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. The Senior Program Officer of the American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR), died Monday, Jan. 4, 1999. A Memorial will be held on Saturday, Mar. 13th at 4pm in the auditorium at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St. A reception in the Social Hall will follow at 5pm. RSVP to 212-806-1798

title: New Troupe Is Familiar But Offers Surprises
description: Judith Fugate and Medhi Bahiri, once leading dancers in major ballet companies, have founded a nifty chamber ballet troupe called Dance Galaxy. It would be easy to see them as the dance world's Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney deciding suddenly ''to put on a show.'' But small touring troupes are part of a longtime ballet tradition, and careful thought was obviously behind Dance Galaxy in its official New York debut on Tuesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIDMAN, HAROLD A.
description: REIDMAN-Harold A. Of Solana Beach, Calif, formerly of Westbury, NY on March 9, 1999 at age 82. Devoted husband for 52 years to Beatrice Bellet Reidman. Beloved father of Lori Powers and Sande Weinstein. Adored grandfather of Mollie Weinstein. Loving father-inlaw and friend of Joel Weinstein and Tim Powers. Brother of the late Jean Gerber, Lee Sacharoff and Sam Reidman. He was a retired NYPD Detective and Technical Advisor to the television series ''Car 54 Where Are You?'' and the movie ''The Pawnbroker.'' His stories and humor will be greatly missed by those who had the good fortune to know him. For information contact Am Israel Mortuary, 619-583-8850, San Diego, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Manhattan records with deep sorrow the passing of our longtime devoted menber and friend Hermann Merkin. To the entire family we extend our sincerest condolences. Rabbi Allen Schwartz Murray Zucker, President

title: Full Metal Furnishing
description: THUMB through today's home furnishings catalogues or browse the design shops and decorator showrooms, and you'll see new industrial-metal furniture that looks surprisingly like the highly sought-after vintage pieces you find at Sunday morning flea markets. If you insist on the real thing, this weekend's Triple Pier Expo (Passenger Ship Terminal Piers 88-92) will be chock full of vintage metal wares; for information, (212) 255-0020. Otherwise, these items are mostly new, not that you could easily tell.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP SHARPLY. Crude oil futures soared a day before key oil producers planned to meet in Amsterdam to consider cuts in output. In New York, crude oil for April delivery rose 84 cents a barrel, to $14.69.

title: Tough and Self-Controlled, Dole Gets Ready to Be '00 Contender
description: During her husband's 1996 Presidential campaign, Elizabeth Dole showed up, right on time, to tape a commercial for him. She read the spot once off the prompter, thanked everybody and got up to leave.

title: Levi Strauss adds dashes of youth and sensuality to Dockers.
description: IN a khakis counterattack, Levi Strauss & Company is responding to inroads made by competitors by portraying its Dockers line of casual pants for men in a far more sensual and youthful manner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKER, MORRIS
description: PICKER-Morris. On March 10, 1999, at age 80. Beloved husband of Doris; loving father of Susan, Barry and David; adoring grandfather of Jason, Rori, Marshall, Craig and Jeremy. Services today 11 A.M., at Sherman's, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: The Salvador Left Applauds Clinton
description: Sitting in the front row directly across from President Clinton as he addressed the National Assembly of El Salvador today was Nidia Diaz, a former guerrilla commander who is still barred from the United States for her role in an attack that killed four American marines here in 1985, during the civil war.

title: DaimlerChrysler Abandons Talks About Buying Control of Nissan
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. abruptly broke off negotiations today to acquire a controlling stake in Nissan Motor, Japan's huge but deeply troubled auto manufacturer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JAMES V.
description: KELLY-James V. Age 74 of Fresh Meadows, Queens, NY on Monday, March 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Irene Lee (nee Dunn) (1998). Loving father of James V. Kelly, Jr. of Manhattan, NY; Rosemary Mullen of Glen Rock, NJ and Tricia Turco of Hawthorne, NJ. Father-in-law of Susan Kelly, Charles Mullen and Lou Turco. Grandfather of Lauren and Courtney Kelly and Jacqueline Turco. Brother of the late Walter Kelly (1979). Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday 10:00 am at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. The family would welcome memorial contributions to St. Jude's Children's Hospital for Cancer Research, Memphis, TN.

title: Scanners: Softening Up Hard Copies
description: SINCE the paperless office has turned out to be a fantasy, there have to be ways to get all those words and pictures on pieces of paper into a computer. Thus, the scanner.

title: District Vanquishes Snow, And With It, Bad Memories
description: After the biggest winter storm of the year dropped as much as 10 inches of snow in some parts of the District of Columbia, residents woke up this morning to find -- could it be? -- that streets had been plowed.

title: There's No Debate: These Senators Are Good
description: For the Rangers, if they are fortunate, last night's game against Ottawa at Madison Square Garden was a preview of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. The National Hockey League might be lucky if the Senators stick around until the final round. They are a young, fast, smart, disciplined, opportunistic team, and they showed it by beating the Rangers, 3-0.

title: 3Com-Microsoft Venture to Develop PC Products
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the 3Com Corporation today intend to announce an alliance to jointly develop products to connect personal computers and computer peripherals within homes, executives from the two companies said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Men With Much In Common
description: BOB WATSON was home in Houston early yesterday morning, when his phone rang. Joe Torre was on the line. Watson was pleased and surprised to hear from his old friend, his good friend. He had hired Torre to manage the Yankees in 1995 when Watson was the team's general manager and Torre was looking for a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, MAX
description: SHAW-Max. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Max Shaw, beloved father of our esteemed colleague, Susan Zimmerman. Our deepest heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Exec Dir

title: Peace and Poverty in Central America
description: The last time an American President went to Central America was 1982, when Ronald Reagan visited Honduras and Costa Rica. That year was one of the bloodiest for El Salvador and for Guatemala, where a truth commission recently labeled 1982 as a peak period for what it termed the military's ''genocide'' of Mayan Indians in the civil war. But Mr. Reagan praised the military leaders of both nations and spent billions in lethal aid to their Governments and the Nicaraguan contras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MILDRED K.
description: DAVIS-Mildred K. Died on March 7th, 1999. Graduate of Columbia University, a teacher of young children in Connecticut, St. Louis, MO., and for 22 years in Great Neck, New York. Survived by sister-in-law Frances H. Davis of Woodbury, CT, niece Diana Davis Smith of Lakewood, CO, nephew H. William Davis and his wife Kayanne of Southbury, CT, great aunt of Sam, Elizabeth, Rebecca and Emily Smith and Katie Davis, Pamela Davis Meyer, Eileen Davis Wetmore, and John Davis. All services private.

title: Killer of Student Took Pains to Conceal Clues, Police Say
description: The killer of a 26-year-old graduate student in Brooklyn on Monday night was careful to conceal clues to the fatal stabbing, apparently going so far as to wrap the murder weapon in plastic before plunging it into the woman's back, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Finding Older Usenet Postings
description: Q. Is there any way I can find a particular posting from a few months ago in a Usenet newsgroup? I know the author's name but cannot recall the exact subject line.

title: Venator Profit Fell 73% in Fourth Quarter
description: Venator Group Inc., the athletic shoe and clothing retailer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 73 percent as it cut prices to draw shoppers and reduce inventory at its Foot Locker and Champs Sports chains.

title: People
description: * Chet Halperin was named to the new position of new business development director at Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York. He had been new business development director at Dweck & Campbell, New York.

title: Six Libyans Convicted
description: A French anti-terrorism court convicted six Libyans, including a brother-in-law of the country's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, of planting a bomb on a French airliner that exploded over the African desert in 1989 and killed 171 people.

title: Foundation Will Bankroll Rebel Chief's Book N.E.A. Dropped
description: A foundation said today that it would provide the money to replace a Federal grant that was canceled when the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts learned that it was for a children's book written by a Mexican guerrilla leader.

title: From Poetry to Newspapers, MP3 Fare for the Literary Set
description: The use of the MP3 format to download audio files from the Internet has taken on a literary twist.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the rebuilding of the Reichstag in Berlin referred imprecisely to Germany's leadership at its completion. While Bismarck was instrumental in the building's construction, he was no longer Chancellor of Germany when it was completed in 1894.

title: Separate Social Security?
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M.'s Chip Sandwich: Packing In a Lot of Power
description: AS computer manufacturers scurried recently to announce their plans for the new and much-ballyhooed Pentium III chip from Intel, another technology giant, I.B.M., announced what truly seems to be a breakthrough in chip design. Some electronics experts said I.B.M.'s new design could significantly hasten the evolution of computers and personal electronics devices, allowing them to become ever smarter and ever smaller.

title: 2 Big French Banks Rebuff $37 Billion Takeover Offer
description: Michel Pebereau thought he would crash the wedding, but the happy couple told him three was a crowd.

title: Blame to Share in Africa
description: The recent massacre of eight Western tourists in Uganda was a horrible event, but the response of the Ugandan and Rwandan Governments has been just as chilling. Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, who came to power in a coup in 1986, vowed to kill the suspects on sight, even before their guilt was established.

title: Unit of Lagardere Is Selling Ad Agency
description: The French communication company Europe 1 Communication, a subsidiary of Lagardere, has signed an agreement with the Deutsche Bank affiliate Gemina Outdoor Holding S.A. to sell a 97.5 percent stake in its advertising subsidiary Giraudy, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, PEARL
description: RUBIN-Pearl. On March 9, 1999, of Hallandale, FL. Much beloved wife of Frank. Adored mother of Janice & Ian, Norma and Howard, Cynthia and Corinne. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. May she forever rest in peace. Graveside services Friday, March 12, at 10:30 A.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island. Shiva on Saturday night and on Sunday at the home of Corinne and Nicki Jaffe.

title: Are Courts Getting Too Creative?
description: Buried on the sports pages last week was a very modern tale of crime and punishment, one involving AIDS, football players and solicitation of prostitution.

title: Whitman Unveils Plan To Improve Route 30
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that the State Department of Transportation would spend up to $15 million to clean and improve Route 30, a seedy two-mile stretch of state highway in Camden.

title: $237 MILLION CHARGE IS IN PROSPECT FOR TENNECO
description: Tenneco Inc., maker of Hefty trash bags and Walker mufflers, said yesterday that it would take a first-quarter charge of as much as $237 million on the pending sale of a majority stake in its containerboard unit. Tenneco, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., agreed in January to sell Madison Dearborn Partners the stake for $2.2 billion and use the proceeds to reduce debt. The charge will range from $228 million to $237 million, or $1.36 to $1.41 a share, a Tenneco spokesman said. Tenneco is struggling to increase its share price after transforming itself in late 1996 by shedding businesses like the Case Corporation, which makes farm equipment, and the Newport News shipbuilding unit.

title: Defining Minimalism's Next Horizon
description: TRUISM No. 1: Divas make pronouncements. Truism No. 2: A diva hankering to conquer a new continent makes grander pronouncements than most.

title: Stopgap Plan Aims to Assure School Voting
description: A month after the Justice Department rejected a new system for electing school boards in New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed today to resurrect the old cumbersome voting system in time for the May school elections.

title: Telecom Italia Board Meets on Strategy to Thwart Olivetti Bid
description: Honing its weapons in the fight to fend off a $60 billion hostile bid, the board of Telecom Italia, Italy's biggest phone company, met tonight to discuss strategies intended to push the cost of a takeover beyond the reach of its pursuer, Olivetti.

title: IBP to Buy H&M Food
description: IBP Inc., the world's biggest meatpacker, said today that it had agreed to buy the H&M Food unit of the Specialty Foods Corporation as IBP expands its prepared food business to rely less on fresh meat processing. H&M Food, which has annual sales of about $200 million, makes cooked meats and other foods at two plants in Texas. IBP had 1998 sales of $12.85 billion. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Clinton Offers His Apologies To Guatemala
description: President Clinton apologized today for United States support of right-wing governments in Guatemala that killed tens of thousands of rebels and Mayan Indians in a 36-year civil war.

title: 4 to Compete For Cheese Account
description: Dairy Management Inc. in Rosemont, Ill., which conducts advertising and promotional programs for the American Dairy Association and the National Dairy Council, named four agencies yesterday to compete in a review for the creative portion of its cheese account, with billings estimated at $29 million. Those duties had been handled by the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago until the agency and Dairy Management agreed to part ways in January.

title: Cathay Pacific Posts Loss for Last Year
description: Cathay Pacific Airways reported yesterday that it had a loss of $542 million (Hong Kong), or $70 million (United States), for 1998 on revenue of $26.7 billion (Hong Kong). It was its first annual loss since 1963.

title: An Old Friend, the Family Bible, Is Dressed Up
description: THE family Bible holds a special place in the American home and imagination. In many families, it is an heirloom, passed from generation to generation. Whatever the edition (it's usually the King James) and whatever the language (it's usually English), the family Bible is considered the authentic Bible, the very word of God. The current owners might not even believe that, but they imagine that once, long ago, someone in the family did.

title: Saving Fallingwater From a Fall
description: FALLINGWATER, Frank Lloyd Wright's 1936 masterpiece, has a little less far to fall. One corner of the house, slung over a waterfall here, is more than seven inches lower than it should be, the result of structural problems that threatened to crash the building into the rocks below.

title: Laws Can't Stop Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: More Foreign Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampras and Hingis Exit in First Round
description: Absence has not made his game grow stronger. Pete Sampras, with only three tournaments and no titles in 1999, took an opening-round dive in the desert tonight at the Newsweek Champions Cup, an event he had won twice.

title: Touring Foreign Territory: Old Age
description: MARY PIPHER, the psychologist whose book about adolescent girls, ''Reviving Ophelia,'' was a phenomenal best seller, was walking on the prairie near her home at sunset, showing off the quiet beauty of winter in Nebraska. She walks here with her writers' group for women on weekends, she said, and it is where they like to celebrate New Year's Day. She walked on the prairie a lot during the 11 months her mother lay dying in a hospital in Kansas in the early 1990's.

title: Dancing in the Archives of 70's Cool
description: Like novices jiggering a Rubik's Cube, many 1990's groups are obsessively recombining styles from the 70's and early 80's, looking for the combination that will snap into place for current listeners. The process shows up most clearly in dance music, where disk jockeys and producers ransack the vinyl archives to find the most effective grooves.

title: More Foreign Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: For Cyclists, Easier Shifting
description: WHEN cyclists head out on the road, they often bring a lot of electronics along for the ride, from computers to measure speed, distance and altitude to wireless heart rate monitors.

title: New Car Stereo Packs Plenty of Road Music
description: Users of a new car stereo may opt to bring it inside every night, but not just to prevent theft. Rather, they may want to hook the stereo to a PC to load it with music.

title: Economic Scene; Despite Gains, Some Have Doubts
description: Have Japanese officials -- finally -- turned economic policy around?

title: Postnuptial Agreement Is Ruled Unfair to Wife
description: In the first decision of its kind in New Jersey, a state appeals court invalidated a postnuptial agreement signed by a Passaic County couple, ruling Tuesday that the document put unfair pressure on the wife.

title: Princeton Gains Date With the Wolfpack
description: PRINCETON 54, GEORGETOWN 47

title: Reports of a Slowdown in Arrests by Troopers Is Studied
description: The New Jersey State Police are investigating reports of a recent decline in the number of arrests and summonses by some troopers as part of a slowdown to protest ongoing state and Federal investigations of state police tactics.

title: Old Signs Revisit
description: YOU can't miss it. At the corner of Greene and West Houston Streets, a new billboard for G-Shock watches partially obscures an early 20th-century sign for the United thread company. A giant wristwatch, splayed across both advertising panels, appears to be attached to the building by trompe l'oeil nails. But is the old sign really old? Or is it new, too?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUBRICK, STANLEY
description: KUBRICK-Stanley. He will be missed by the entire motion picture industry. It was a privilege to work with him. Martin Richards & The Producer Circle Co.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a conference on Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemings, one of his slaves, omitted the name of an organizer. She was Prof. Jan E. Lewis of Rutgers University, who worked with Prof. Peter S. Onuf of the University of Virginia.

title: Tables Turn on a Filtering Site As It Is Temporarily Blocked
description: The Web site Filtering Facts advocates the use of software filters in libraries to protect children from ''objectionable'' material. One catch: last week, the site was itself temporarily blocked by Surf Watch, a leading filtering program and one that is recommended by Filtering Facts (www.filteringfacts.org).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, RUTH L.
description: EVANS-Ruth L. On March 9, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Hugh Evans. Devoted mother & mother-in-law of Margo, Marc, Mr. David Manspeiyer and Dr. Adelaide J. Evans, cherished sister and sister-in-law of Mr. & Mrs. Laurence B. Orloff. Loving daughter of the late Dr. Aaron & Sara Orloff. An educator and businesswoman, her wisdom, industriousness, self-reliance and radiant personality will be forever remembered. She will be dearly missed by all who knew her. Services private. Contributions to the Ruth L. Evans Memorial Fund, Englewood Hospital Medical Center, would be appreciated.

title: Power Fails at Hospital; No Patients Are Harmed
description: A malfunctioning backup electrical system caused a 47-minute blackout at Long Island Jewish Medical Center last night, hospital officials said, forcing doctors to operate by battery-powered light and stranding three visitors in elevators.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Yorkers' views of Joe DiMaggio misattributed a quotation. It was Richard Ben Cramer, who is writing a biography of DiMaggio -- not another author, Roger Angell -- who said: ''New York took care of him as only New York could. At the time, everybody in New York knew everybody at the top. If they had to keep it quiet, they could do that, too. DiMaggio used to ride around at night with Walter Winchell, with the police scanner going in the car. Winchell kept him out of the gossip column, unless it was something good.''

title: Drug-Abuse Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Schools From Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating the Lives and Accomplishments of Pioneering Women
description: The second sex? Not when the Women's Museum opens in Dallas next October. The museum will celebrate American women's lives as professionals and leaders. The museum held a groundbreaking ceremony on Monday for the renovation of its 70,000-square-foot brick building, constructed in 1909 as an opera house with dirt floors. ''During the day, there were cattle auctions, and at night, they'd bring in the chairs and have opera,'' said Wendy Evans Joseph, a Manhattan architect who is designing the interior of the museum.

title: Economic Growth Up In Sweden in Quarter
description: Swedish economic growth accelerated in the fourth quarter from the third, fueled by increased consumer spending. Gross domestic product grew at a 1.4 percent rate from the third quarter and expanded 3.2 percent from a year earlier, according to a report released yesterday by Statistics Sweden.

title: Citigroup Co-Chiefs Plan to Sell Stock
description: Citigroup Inc.'s co-chief executives notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that they intended to sell part of their stakes in the company but would retain a majority of their current shares.

title: TARNISHED GOLD: A special report.; From an Innocent Bid to Olympic Scandal
description: David R. Johnson and Thomas K. Welch were lionized in 1995 when they delivered the right to stage the 2002 Winter Olympic Games to a city that had tried and failed for 30 years. But after that it was a long, hard fall.

title: Dole Presents Herself as Both Nonpolitician and an Insider
description: Reprising her most famous moment in the 1996 Presidential campaign, Elizabeth Dole bounded into an audience of Iowans today to announce her Presidential exploratory committee and to present herself both as a nonpolitician and as a prepared Government insider.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: The Duke Invitational Is Under Way; To Defeat the Blue Devils, You Only Have to Be Perfect
description: They have been declared a team for the ages by many of the coaches whose teams were destroyed by them in the regular season, and they have put up the kind of numbers that inspire the untouchable status they take into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament that begins today with 16 games.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: N.I.T. ROUNDUP
description: RUTGERS 58, HOFSTRA 55

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones and S.& P. 500 Establish Record Highs

title: Three Ring, A Filly, To Face Colts
description: In the 47 years the Florida Derby has been run, no filly has ever won. But Barry Schwartz, the longtime friend and partner of Calvin Klein, put up $6,000 as an entry fee for the $750,000 Florida Derby yesterday to give his fast filly Three Ring the chance to try.

title: G3: Blue and White and Different All Over, Except the Name
description: THE official name of Apple's most powerful and most stylish Macintosh is the Power Macintosh G3. Apple Computer, which has been creative in so many other ways recently and whose current motto is ''Think Different,'' was apparently thinking undifferent that day and merely recycled the name from an earlier, uglier model also known as the Power Macintosh G3.

title: Cartel Has Cash Shortage
description: The International Natural Rubber Organization, a cartel that supports rubber prices, faces a cash shortage after some members failed to pay into a fund the group uses to buy rubber in the open market.

title: Microsoft Lawyer's Assessment of Trial: Not to Worry
description: Outsiders may think that the Microsoft Corporation is faring badly in its antitrust trial. But the case is actually going Microsoft's way, according to an internal assessment sent to the company's senior executives last week.

title: The Return of Hippie Chic  With an Italian Twist
description: MILAN  Cher's back  not only in the charts but also on the catwalk! But she has been toned down, from screaming rock siren to sophisticated earth goddess, thanks to Milan's new look of hippie chic.

title: Worse Drought Than in '98 Appears Possible in Texas
description: Still reeling from a 1998 drought that devastated the state's farming and ranching communities, Texas officials are growing increasingly alarmed about what appears to be a potentially more serious drought looming this year.

title: Victims of Relativism
description: To the Editor:

title: Succession Problems Make Them Targets for Acquisition : Can Italy Houses Stay Alive?
description: ROME  Dramatic changes are sweeping through Italy's predominantly family-owned fashion industry. Prominent ambassadors of made-in-Italy design  Giorgio Armani is the latest example  are wrestling with the dilemma of how to preserve their vast business empires when there are no heirs to carry the baton.

title: A German Baritone for the Jester
description: In a way, the German baritone Franz Grundheber is making a double debut this season at the Metropolitan Opera. On Monday night, for his official debut, he sang the title role in the season's first performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto.'' But on April 17, he will sing the title role in Berg's ''Wozzeck.'' And these two roles could not be more different.

title: Perils Amid Lure of Gentrification; Slaying Brings a Shock to a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: To understand the yin and yang of gentrification in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn, consider two very different types of recent visitors to the Park Place brownstone of William Bullock.

title: Goldman Apologizes for Thai Bank Report
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the largest United States investment-banking partnership, has apologized to Thailand for an analyst's report that drove down shares of the nation's biggest bank. A committee of the Thai Parliament is threatening to cut off business with the firm.

title: Sanur Journal; Election Fever, and Hope for Change, Sweep Bali
description: From the taut streets of Jakarta to the tense villages of East Timor, democracy is making unsteady progress in this far-flung Asian country. But here on the tropical island of Bali, democratic-style politics is bursting out with a joyful clamor.

title: When a Group's Togetherness Pays Off
description: The Pacifica Quartet, formed in Los Angeles but now based in Chicago, made an excellent showing at its Naumburg Award recital on Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall. Its sound, individually and as a group, is pure, lyrical and educated. Balance is good and clear, and the musicians' consistency in matters of tempo is remarkable. They all move on the same strong, supple band of time.

title: Laws Can't Stop Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Where Have You Gone, Major Deegan?
description: SING, O Goddess, the wrath of Major Deegan, Bronx's son.

title: Underwriter Reaffirms iVillage Offering
description: Goldman, Sachs, the lead underwriter of iVillage Inc.'s planned initial public offering, said yesterday that the deal would not be delayed by a lawsuit filed by a former employee against the company.

title: Hawaii Gas Station Deal
description: U.S. Restaurant Properties Inc. said today that it had acquired 27 service station properties in Hawaii from Equilon Enterprises, a joint venture between the Shell Oil Company, part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Texaco Inc. Terms of the purchase, which includes a former Texaco terminal property, were not disclosed. The sale was forced by Federal and state regulators concerned about the anticompetitive effects of the joint venture. U.S. Restaurant Properties, based in Dallas, is a real estate investment trust that owns and manages 894 restaurants and service station properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, LEONARD J.
description: COLLINS-Leonard J. Of Mahwah, NJ, died March 9, 1999, after a long illness. He was a United States Marine Corp. pilot in World War II.
