Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he was president of the Newman Club and a member of the Sphinx Senior Society. He was president of Park Ryan Inc., New York City, and retired from the Oppenheimer & Co. (1990). Member of NY Bond Club. Parishioner of Immaculate Conception Church in Mahwah, NJ. Survived by his wife, Dr. Margaret Jane Collins, D.D.S. (Sullivan), seven children, Joseph, Denis, Rita, Brian and wife Gina, Therese, Monica and husband James O'Reilly, Sheila and husband Tom Stanford, and three grandchildren. Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, March 13, 1999, at 11 A.M. in Immaculate Conception Church, Mahwah, NJ. Interment will be in Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. Friends will be received on Friday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. in the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, New Jersey. Donations to the Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Inc., Johns Hopkins Outpatient Center, Suite 5065, 601 N. Caroline Street, Baltimore, MD 21287 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETZLER, MAX
description: GETZLER-Max, 88, died March 1, 1999 in Florida, he was buried in LI, New York. Beloved husband of Sylvia V., father of Lynn Rosaz, father-in-law of Bernard, father of the late Herbert Getzler, grandfather of Andrew, Lawrence, Abigail Getzler, and of Valerie, Marc, Julie Rosaz, great grandfather of Jacob and Nathaniel and of Louis and Federik, uncle of Judith, Leonard and Sheila. He graduated from NYU as a CPA in 1937, retired age 78 from Security Pacific Bank, NYC. May his soul rest in peace. His Family Who Loves Him

title: Schools Balk Over Driving Penalties for Students
description: For 10 years now, the teen-age driver's li cense that sacred piece of plastic that confers mobility on the restless -- has been the bull's-eye of every state legislature in the South.

title: Pechiney's Net Rises; Unit Will Trade in U.S.
description: Pechiney S.A., the world's fourth-largest aluminum producer, indicated yesterday that its second-half earnings rose about 9 percent and said it would list its beverage can division on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, LEONA
description: BLAIR-Leona. We shall miss your spirit, intellect and friendship. Bob and Rosa

title: Riverside Bank to Be Sold
description: Associated Banc-Corp said today that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Riverside Bank of Minneapolis for $89.1 million in stock. Riverside has assets of $331 million and operates five offices in the Twin Cities area. Associated, based in Green Bay, is a bank holding company with $11.3 billion in assets. It operates 224 offices in 150 communities in Wisconsin, Illinois and Minnesota.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAIGLES, MIRIAM
description: NAIGLES-Miriam. Died on March 9, 1999 at age 91 after a brief illness. Beloved mother of Lora Goodridge and adored grandmother of Jeremy and Andrew Goodridge.

title: Taken for Granite
description: To bring that bleak industrial look indoors, Roc Inc. of Blaine, Wash., has introduced a concrete-patterned wallpaper. ''Concrete is a modern classic, but very restrictive to install,'' said Randy Bishop, Roc's president. It's not suited to, say, a nursery. Available in rolls of 100 square feet ($300) or 500 square feet ($500), including shipping; (800) 942-4902.

title: What Time Is It on the Internet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Schools From Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Schools From Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Cher Resurrected, Again, by a Hit; The Long, Hard but Serendipitous Road to 'Believe'
description: There's a saying among those who work around Cher. If there's a nuclear war, only two species will survive: the cockroaches and Cher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, BERNARD
description: JAFFE-Bernard. New York Metropolitan Region of the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism mourns the untimely passing of the beloved brother of our esteemed Vice President, Deanna Miller. Our condolences to the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Eugene D. Zinbarg, Pres. Bruce F. Greenfield, Exec. Dir.

title: Rage Against the Machine: PC's Take Brunt of Office Anger
description: If you have hard feelings toward your hard drive and malicious thoughts about your monitor, and consider drop-kicking your keyboard, take heart: you are not alone. A new survey suggests that computers are eliciting rage in the workplace, or at least taking the brunt of it.

title: More Foreign Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: If Insurers Don't Cut Auto Rates, New Jersey Will, Officials Say
description: The Whitman administration announced today that it would impose a 15 percent reduction in auto insurance rates for policyholders whose insurance companies fail to come up with the promised savings themselves.

title: SUNGARD TO BUY OSHAP TECHNOLOGIES FOR $210 MILLION
description: Sungard Data Systems Inc., a computer service and application software company in Wayne, Pa., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Oshap Technologies Ltd. of Herzlia, Israel, in a stock swap valued at about $210 million. Sungard would pay 0.3863 share for each share of Oshap, valuing the company at about $15.50 a share. Oshap shares climbed $2.875, to $13.375, while Sungard slipped 87.5 cents, to $39.0625. Oshap develops and licenses financial software and provides consulting services to large financial companies and holds equity stakes in software companies in Israel and the United States.

title: New Yorker in Peru Jail Found in Poor Health
description: Members of an American delegation who visited a New Yorker sentenced to life in prison in Peru three years ago, said today that she appeared to be in poor health but was still protesting her innocence.

title: ALBRIGHT DEFENDS POLICIES ON CHINA AS G.O.P. ATTACKS
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today defended American policy toward China in the face of concerted Republican attacks on the Administration's handling of suspicions that China stole nuclear technology from the Los Alamos laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, HERMAN L.
description: WEISMAN-Herman L. The Zionist Organization of America mourns the passing of our esteemed past National President (1970-'74). He served the cause of Israel and Zionism with distinction and he will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Jeannette, and to his bereaved family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Morton A. Klein, National Pres. Michael Orbach, Chmn. of the Bd

title: Yankees Learn Torre Has Prostate Cancer
description: Joe Girardi sat silently at the front of a Yankees team bus this morning, an island among teammates who cheerfully anticipated the return of Darryl Strawberry to baseball this afternoon in an exhibition game against the Red Sox. This was supposed to be a good day.

title: The Night People's Court
description: Two high-heeled chocolate shoes, one white, one dark brown, sat on the plaintiff's table. They were presented upon a plate of mango-raspberry coulis and adorned with fresh strawberries and star fruit.

title: What Time Is It on the Internet?
description: To the Editor:

title: More Data To Be Sought On Home Care
description: Medicare officials said tonight that they had instructed home health agencies to start collecting detailed information on the medical conditions and living arrangements of millions of elderly and disabled people who receive home health care services financed by Medicare.

title: Accounts
description: * Telecordia Technologies, Morristown, N.J., a unit of the Science Applications International Corp. that was formerly known as Bellcore, to Grey Advertising, New York, as the first agency to handle the global branding account of the telecommunications software, engineering and consulting company. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Peace Corps Invites Kids To Its Site
description: The 25th anniversary is silver. The 50th is gold. Could the 38th be the Web site anniversary?

title: Sabah Election Is Test of Economic Confidence : Malaysia Leaders Court Voters in Remote State
description: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia  They have come to this remote, northern corner of Borneo by the planeload, hundreds of briefcase-carrying government officials from Kuala Lumpur, eager to capture this often rebellious state in the first electoral test since economic crisis struck Malaysia 20 months ago.

title: Luster of New York's Trash Dims in Virginia
description: In this bucolic slice of southeastern Virginia, sturdy farmhouses command vast fields of peanuts, soybeans and cotton. Slender loblolly pines poke through the flat, wet terrain, like celery stalks wedged into a marshy bog. It seems like a Robert Penn Warren poem sprung to life.

title: Decisions Made On Accounts
description: Two big advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, ELEANOR T.
description: MOSS-Eleanor T. On March 9th, 1999, of Grand Rapids, Michigan, formerly of Manhattan. Survived by loving daughter Susan Budzynski, seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She will be greatly missed.

title: No. 1 Complaint of Chinese: All This Corruption!
description: In a typical Chinese town like this one, the local Communist Party chief rules with the authority of an old-time mobster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUKIN, ELEANORE
description: RUKIN-Eleanore. Age 82. Of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Teaneck and Saddle River, NJ, on March 10, 1999 at her daughter's home in New Jersey. Eleanore gave freely of her generous, caring spirit with dignity, humor and wisdom. An inspiration to all who knew her, Eleanore's gifts of light, beauty and love will long be rememebered by her family, friends and extended community. Devoted wife and soulmate of David Rukin, Eleanore's distinctive spirit will be carried by her surviving children Susan and Julie Eisen, Buzz and Donna Rukin, Barnie and Mark Rukin Miller, Jessica and Bruce King, Nancy and Bob Kossowsky; her grandchildren Joshua and Ellen, Andrew and Rachael, and Cara Eisen; William, Emily and Alexandra Rukin; Sarah Rukin Miller; Daniel Galen and Benjamin King; Nicole and Jacob Kossowsky; her great grandchildren Noam, Uriel, Yaniv and Luca Eisen. Funeral Service will be held at the YM-YWHA of Bergen County on Pascack Road in Washington Township, NJ, Thursday, March 11 at 10:30 AM. Shiva observed at Nancy and Bob Kossowsky's in Upper Saddle River, NJ. Donations can be made to the YM-YWHA of Bergen County, Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, Jewish Braille Institute, Ruth Rales Jewish Family Service, and Adolph Levis Jewish Community Center.

title: Mrs. Dole Leaps Into the Gap
description: A woman running for President of the United States is not a breakthrough. Victoria Woodhull was a minor-party candidate before women had the right to vote, and elected officials like Margaret Chase Smith and Shirley Chisholm have made long-shot bids for the nomination. But Elizabeth Dole is still making history as the first woman to enter the Presidential primary season as one of the front-runners. Mrs. Dole took another step toward a full-fledged candidacy for the Republican nomination yesterday when she announced she had formed an exploratory committee.

title: Dusting Off the Pages of a Bookish Vanderbilt's Passion
description: Most of the 23,000 books in George Washington Vanderbilt's collection at the 250-room mansion he built in Asheville, N.C., are marked with a bookplate he designed featuring an oil lamp and the Latin inscription ''Quaero Ex Libris Biltmore'': Inquire in the books of Biltmore.

title: Homicides in New York Up 5% This Year
description: The number of homicides reported in New York City has risen slightly this year compared with the same period last year, the police said yesterday, adding that there was no way to know whether the increase represented a temporary jump or a leveling off in the city's historic drop in crime of the last six years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ANNE
description: FISCHER-Anne. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Anne Fischer, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague Harry Fischer, M.D., Chief, Division of Rheumatology. To Harry, his family, and all of his mother's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, BIMC Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assoc

title: Crew Tells School Board Voucher Standoff Is Over
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew met privately yesterday with the Board of Education for the first time since his threat to resign over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan for school vouchers, and he assured its members that he wanted to remain in his post and that the issue was ''off the radar.''

title: Brazil Rights Group Hopes to Bar Doctors Linked to Torture
description: Brazilian medical associations have begun hearings to strip the right to practice medicine from doctors who took part in the torture of political prisoners during the military dictatorship, which ended in the 1980's.

title: No Stone-Throwing Allowed
description: When Holly Hunt, a designer and distributor of home furnishings, opens her new showroom in the Miami design district this fall, brilliant Florida sunshine will pour in from: a skylight, a double bay of windows and a soaring glass wall.

title: Some Old Advice Is Good: Doubling Slams Is Risky
description: In the early literature of the game, published more than half a century ago, there is only one book that merits a place in the library of any modern enthusiast. It is ''Why You Lose at Bridge'' by S. J. Simon, and his shrewd commentary on the weaknesses of the average player, spiced with considerable humor, is still read with pleasure and profit.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Fairness for Black College Athletes
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will need to devise new eligibility requirements for student athletes that preserve academic values without at the same time discriminating against African-Americans. That is the practical meaning of District Judge Ronald L. Buckwalter's ruling on Monday that the N.C.A.A.'s system of basing eligibility largely on standardized test scores is unfair to blacks. The ruling does not mean that colleges should abandon their worthwhile and necessary efforts to improve graduation rates among athletes. It does mean finding fairer ways to measure academic potential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEELY, JAMES SEDGWICK
description: DEELY-James Sedgwick, 77, of Palm Beach, FL, Stockbridge, MA, and Marion, MA, and formerly of New York City, died Monday, March 8, 1999, of complications following a traffic accident. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Ginn Reece Deely of Palm Beach, FL, and Marion, MA; two daughters, Catharine Burton Deely of Los Angeles, CA, and Pamela Deely Van de Loo of Albany, NY; two brothers, John Deely, Jr., of Stockbridge, MA, and Martin Deely of Lee, MA; a sister, Ann Hahn, of Fairfield, CT, and numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Deely's first wife, Patricia Johnson Deely, died in 1996. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Monday, March 15, 1999, at St. Joseph's Church of Stockbridge, MA. Additional memorial services in New York City and Palm Beach will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Williams College Museum of Art, Williamstown, MA 01267. For more information, contact Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL, at 561-832-5171.

title: Explosive Knowledge
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bias Suits Rend Morale of Town's Police
description: In the beginning, the complaints were all too familiar: three minority officers in a small-town Police Department filed civil rights lawsuits, saying they had been passed over for promotions, harassed and subjected to a hostile workplace.

title: Stringing Holes Together, 5,599,663 of Them
description: IT is one thing to design a sphere with millions of perforations, each row different from the next. But how do you inscribe this complex filigree on the metal panels themselves, especially when the factory is across the continent?

title: Passing the Ball, Failing the Class; Colleges Need Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Official of Union That Is Under Investigation Steps Down
description: The communications director for District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City municipal employees, announced her resignation yesterday, becoming the latest in a series of council officials close to the council's longtime executive director to leave.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISNIEWSKI, HARRIET M., MD.
description: WISNIEWSKI-Harriet M., MD. The Sisters of Charity, Board of Trustees, Auxiliary and Staff of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center note with sadness the death of our long-time friend and colleague, Dr. Harriet Wisniewski. Dr. Wisniewski was an ardent supporter of the values and mission of the hospital as a dedicated member of the Department of Radiology, President of the Medical Staff and long-time members of the Medical Staff Executive Committee. We will miss her wisdom, compassion, carism, and professionalism. We extend our condolences to her entire family. Thomas A. Coleman, Chairman Karl P. Adler, MD, Pres. and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, GWENDOLYN M.
description: WILLIAMS-Gwendolyn M. Lutheran Medical Center mourns the loss of Gwendolyn Williams, a dedicated member of our Board of Trustees who cared deeply about our mission to serve our patients and our community. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her husband Claude Oliver and all of her family. Her forthright advocacy, willingness to serve and gregarious personality will be missed by all of us. Dominic J. Lodato, President Howard Smith, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Novelist's Muse Lures Him to the Soul's Darkness
description: For all the exotic locales through which the reader is led in Alex Garland's two well-received novels, ''The Beach'' and ''The Tesseract,'' his personal coordinates seem comfortably local. A native North Londoner, he shares an apartment with his girlfriend in upmarket Belsize Park, just around the corner from the downmarket state primary school he attended as a boy. His mother lives across the way in one direction, and his father is equidistant in the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSWALD, FRANK GRAF III
description: OSWALD-Frank Graf III. Killed in an automobile accident on March 7 in Amado, Arizona. He is survived by his wife Laurinda Middleton Oswald; his two children Frank Graf and Julia Skye; his mother Audrey Clinton Oswald of Newport; his father Frank Graf Oswald Jr. of Port Washington; his brother David of Stamford; and his sister Diana of New York City. Memorial Services in Newport and New York City to be announced. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Newport Boys and Girls Club would be appreciated.

title: Passing the Ball, Failing the Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Snow Bike A New Toy As Slopes Diversify
description: The sticker on his helmet said, ''Speed is the spice of life.'' But looks can be deceiving. For Clark Bowling, an 8-year-old about to rent a snow-bicycle here at Loon Mountain, caution seemed kindlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFEE, NATHAN
description: JAFFEE-Nathan. We mourn the loss of N. Jay Jaffee, renowned photographer, age 78, of Huntington, New York, on March 10, 1999. Beloved father and friend, he was much loved and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his loving companion, Paula Hackeling, and his two children by his first marriage, Anna Jaffee and Cyrisse Jaffee, and two grandchildren, Ashley & Jonathan. Services will be held at the M.A. Connell Funeral Home in Huntington Station on Friday, March 12, at 1 PM, visiting hours start at 12, for immediate family and friends. A memorial service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Avenue, Suite 203, Evanston, IL 60202-1375.

title: F.A.A. Plans to Upgrade Its Tracking Computers
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has finished replacing a hulking, obsolete, trouble-prone mainframe computer at its air traffic control center in Ronkonkoma, N.Y., the first step in its nationwide modernization campaign, and plans to show off the replacement in a ceremony on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, PHYLLIS
description: FLYNN-Phyllis. 60. Of Northfield, VT, formerly of Hudson View Gardens, New York City, died March 3, 1999. She began her library career as an archivist with the Jung Foundation in NYC. Later she was employed by the American Jewish Committee, in the Blaustein Library also in NYC. Survived by a sister, Ellin Lord of Northfield, VT; a niece, Elizabeth Lord of Waterbury, VT.

title: Hamilton Puts Words, 'National Title,' to UConn's Music
description: The two magical words tumbled out of Richard Hamilton's mouth. National championship. He did not sound boastful. He sounded like he was ordering an English muffin with his bacon and eggs. National championship. Hamilton said it once, repeated it and then repeated it again. All in about three minutes.

title: Nets Lose, but Is Marbury on Way?
description: With the Nets losing for the 11th time in 12 games, the team's officials spent the day trying to inject some life into their disappointing team. In what could be the biggest trade of the season, the Nets are trying to acquire Stephon Marbury, the Minnesota Timberwolves' point guard who grew up on Coney Island.

title: Finding and Treating Prostate Cancer
description: Joe Torre joins more than 179,000 men in the United States who will be found to have prostate cancer this year, according to estimates by the American Cancer Society. New cases of prostate cancer have risen dramatically in recent years with the widespread use of a test to detect prostate-specific antigen. The test, first introduced in 1985, is recommended annually for men over 50 and measures the level of this substance in the blood and may indicate the presence of a cancer.

title: Dr. Philip Strax, 90, Is Dead; An Advocate of Mammograms
description: Dr. Philip Strax, a radiologist whose early and passionate advocacy of the mammogram helped revolutionize breast-cancer detection, died on Tuesday at a daughter's home in Bethesda, Md. He was 90.

title: Metro Business; Bank Plans to Hire 1,500
description: Commerce Bancorp said it would hire about 1,500 people this year as part of its plan to open 25 branches in New Jersey and neighboring states.

title: Hermann Merkin, 91, Benefactor Of Judaism and a Concert Hall
description: Hermann Merkin, a private investor and philanthropist for whom Merkin Concert Hall is named, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: When (Heavyweight) Words Collide
description: For the last two weeks, Evander Holyfield has kept up this steady drumbeat, saying he is going to knock out Lennox Lewis in the third round of their heavyweight unification bout at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD CONSIDERS OPTIONS FOR MEDICAL UNIT
description: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that it was considering strategic options for its medical systems unit to capitalize on the medical community's interest in its discovery of a virus that is correlated with advanced liver disease. The company also said it had formed a committee to select a successor to its chairman, president and chief executive, Emmanuel A. Kampouris, 64. Last month, the company's Diasorin Inc. unit said it had discovered a previously unidentified virus and that limited studies appeared to link the virus to advanced liver disease of an unknown cause. The medical unit had 1998 sales of $98 million. Shares of American Standard, which is based in Piscataway, N.J., rose 93.75 cents, to $32.625.

title: Wondering What It Will Take to Get Nissan a Mate
description: Once again, the future of Japan's second-largest car maker, the Nissan Motor Company, is uncertain.

title: Civil Liberties Group Sues to Stop Car Seizures
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union filed a class action lawsuit yesterday, asking a Manhattan State Supreme Court Justice to halt the Giuliani administration's new policy of seizing the cars of people arrested on drunken driving charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKSTERN, REISS, JOSHUA
description: GLUCKSTERN - REISS - Joshua. Our Temple family mourns the loss of our beloved Hazzan. In the few years that he was with us, he endeared himself to all, both young and old. We shall sorely miss his sweet voice, exuberance, his sense of humor and hearty laugh. His passionate love of Hazzanut, Jewish liturgy and music were inspirational. We mourn with his wife Rabbi Karen, his parents Martin and Toby Gluckstern, his sister Laurie Wuhrman, his friends and colleagues. Temple Gates of Prayer Albert Thaler, Rabbi Stephen Abramowitz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINAWATOK, INGRID
description: WASHINAWATOK-Ingrid. We will remember you as we continue the important work you cared so much about. MADRE

title: Maryland Routs Valparaiso
description: At the end of the game, when the coaches met to shake hands, it was difficult to tell which team had just advanced to the second round of the South Regional today.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Says Profit Rose 15%
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., Britain's second-biggest advertising and communications company, said yesterday that its second-half profit rose 15 percent as new business from existing and new clients lifted sales and earnings. Second-half net rose to $:11 million ($17.9 million) from $:9.6 million in the corresponding period in 1997. The figures a year ago were estimated by Saatchi to account for its split with Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. in December 1997.

title: On the Trail of a Beanie Burglar
description: Gigi, Jake and Jabber are still missing a month after the man in the Syracuse jacket and baseball cap snatched them and their brethren and stalked out into the cold night.

title: Why Is U.S. Foreign Policy Adrift?; These Aren't Diplomats
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Comforts of Home Can Be Clinging
description: THE homecoming Stephon Marbury fantasized about did not include a tunnel or a turnpike. Sometimes these things don't turn out exactly the way you wish them to. Marbury, a Coney Island kid who dreamed of being a Knick, leveraged his way out of Minnesota and a sure-thing playoff run, and wound up yesterday with the Nets, in New Jersey, in last place.

title: Messiaenic Ecstasy
description: In the 1970's, in concert tours and recordings, the pianist Peter Serkin, below, exhibited his mastery of the work of Messiaen. But for nearly 15 years after that, Mr. Serkin played no Messiaen, pursuing other musical interests.

title: Girl Scouts Are Accused Of Violating Girl's Rights
description: A human rights complaint has been filed against the Girl Scouts, accusing the organization of excluding an 8-year-old New York State girl from at least five troops because she has the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Microsoft to Defer $400 Million In Revenue to Its Fourth Quarter
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it expected to shift $400 million in revenue from its third quarter to its fourth quarter because of a delay in the introduction of Office 2000, the next generation of the popular group of word-processing and spreadsheet software.

title: Lynne Yamamoto
description: 'The Long Twilight'

title: Port Authority Police Press Bias Inquiry on PATH Patrols
description: Port Authority police officials are investigating allegations that a small group of its officers who patrol the PATH trains in Manhattan have been stopping and searching young black and Hispanic men without probable cause, officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Stephen Westfall
description: Lennon, Weinberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFIROFF, SELMA BERNER
description: SHAFIROFF-Selma Berner On March 10, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Charles Shafiroff. Devoted mother of Dr. Bruce and Shirley Shafiroff, Scott Shafiroff and Nina and Richard Cohan. Cherished grandmother of Annie, Michael, Charli, Adam, Alex, Charles and Rebeka. Dearest sister of Robert and Alvan Berner and Lorraine Sher. Services Friday 10am ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Taking Off Through the Trees, Beyond the Bulldozer's Reach
description: I stomp my feet for warmth on the wooden platform and lean my ski poles against a railing. It stormed all night in Jay Peak, Vt., and snow is still filtering down through the early gray light. ''How much?,'' someone behind me asks. I listen closely. ''I heard 10 inches,'' another voice replies.

title: BMW Charts a New Course Much Like the Old One
description: Few car companies have been the object of as much unwanted attention lately as BMW A.G., the Bavarian company best known for its muscular but luxurious sedans and sports cars.

title: A Mixed Verdict on Big European Mergers
description: Europe's three big hostile-takeover battles veered off into different directions today, as investors viewed a three-way French bank combination as increasingly possible, prospects for an Italian telephone acquisition seemed to dim, and signs of an amicable truce emerged between two luxury-goods giants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINOY, SUSAN K.
description: KINOY-Susan K. Died March 11, 1999 in Washington, D.C. after a short illness. Memorial services will be held at the River Road Unitarian Church, 6301 River Road, Bethesda, MD., at 2PM on March 20th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to La Clinica del Pueblo, 1470 Irving Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20010.

title: J. C. PENNEY SAYS IT WILL FOCUS ON EIGHT 'POWER BRANDS'
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it planned to focus on eight ''power brands'' to improve the profitability of its department stores and catalogues. To help the sales of the eight brands, which include Arizona Jean Company, St. John's Bay, Worthington, Stafford and Hunt Club, the company plans to open power brand shops within its stores. Penney's 34 private brands generate sales of $8 billion a year. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., operates nearly 1,150 department stores, nearly 2,900 Eckerd drugstores and a direct marketing business that focuses on insurance and credit card membership services. Penney's stock rose $1.6875 a share, to $39.50.

title: A Child Is Gone, and Then He Is Not
description: It's easy to see why ''The Deep End of the Ocean'' became Oprah Winfrey's first book club selection, the first book she thought America might read en masse. Jacquelyn Mitchard's novel about a family thrown into turmoil tells a page-turner of a story that hits a universal nerve. All Beth Cappadora need do is get caught up in the hubbub of a high school reunion and take her eyes off her 3-year-old for a couple of minutes. That's all it takes to explode Beth's picture-perfect Middle American family life. The boy is gone, perhaps forever, and all bets are off.

title: Resignation of German Official Pushes Euro Up Against the Dollar
description: The euro rose against the dollar yesterday as traders said that the resignation of the German Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, would ease the economic change that Europe needs to revive growth.

title: Awesome Vistas, Birdcalls and Rusty Colors, With Serkin as Guide
description: When Peter Serkin was told during a recent interview that in a publicity brochure for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's performance on Sunday afternoon of ''Des Canyons aux Etoiles'' (''From the Canyons to the Stars'') by Messiaen, he is described as the project's ''soloist'' and ''guiding spirit,'' the self-effacing pianist gulped, blushed and said, ''What?''

title: Gang-Busting Partners in Chinatown
description: One of the nice throwaway bits in James Foley's bracingly chilly police drama ''The Corruptor'' finds the two main characters, Chen (Chow Yun-Fat), a New York City policeman assigned to Chinatown, and his partner, Danny (Mark Wahlberg), bantering at a neighborhood fruit stand. When Danny asks for a peach, Chen insists he choose a plum instead and quotes from a Sinatra song: ''Out of the tree of life I just picked me a plum.'' Later in the film, a fragment of that Sinatra song, ''The Best Is Yet to Come,'' rises on the soundtrack at a particularly dramatic moment and lends the scene, set in the bowels of a grim freighter packed with illegal Chinese aliens, an eerie poignancy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANA, A. FAIRFIELD
description: DANA-A. Fairfield, June 15, 1911October 25, 1998. Graveside gathering in his memory at the Hillside Cemetery, Wilton, Connecticut, Sunday, March 14, at 10:30 AM.

title: Police Seeking Man for Questioning in Stabbing Death in Brooklyn
description: The police released a sketch last night of a man wanted for questioning in connection with the Monday stabbing death of a 26-year-old graduate student on a Brooklyn street.

title: Victorious in Italy
description: The MetroStars rallied to salvage the final game of their visit to Italy with a 2-1 victory over Varese yesterday.

title: On My Mind; The Diplomatic Trade
description: Falsehood, withholding critical information, distortion, cover-up. Diplomacy, a branch of government that often makes the difference between war and peace, uses these tools at least as often to deceive its own people as a potential enemy.

title: Some People Just Can't Be Taught How to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Gee, Commander, You're Cute When You Fight Green Aliens
description: ''Wing Commander'' is based on a video game and has roughly the same degree of character development. That is all most moviegoers will need to know.

title: Officials Cite Costly Hurdles to Second Avenue Subway Plan
description: Amid growing calls to renew work on the long abandoned Second Avenue subway in Manhattan, transit officials cautioned yesterday that reviving the project would require years of planning, massive engineering work and an investment running far into the billions of dollars.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The safest place in the world I always thought was a church, and now that sanctuary has been broken.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, SAMUEL M.
description: GREENFIELD-Samuel M. With love and deep sorrow, we mourn the passing of this warm and gentle man. Beloved husband of Shirley for 57 years. Adored father of Ellen, Roger, Jane, Myron, George and Robert. Devoted grandfather of Andrew, Hillary, Debra, David and Lisa. He will live on eternally in our spirit, hearts and souls.

title: A Poet, Wit and Critic Heeded by the French
description: Although his writing was more than occasionally readerproof, Stephane Mallarme (1842-98) was one of the most influential cultural figures of 19th-century France. An avant-gardist, a wit, a salon keeper, a fashion commentator, a translator of Poe's poems, a critic who supported the Impressionists and a forerunner of the Symbolist poets whose innovative ways with language had a significant impact on Modernism, he himself was nothing less than a work of art.

title: Torre May Be Out Months; Zimmer to Take His Place
description: Yankee officials remain certain that Manager Joe Torre, who was told on Tuesday that he has prostate cancer, will return to the dugout eventually. But the estimates of his absence range from three weeks to three months, and today, Torre's bench coach, Don Zimmer, said he would try to manage the team as Torre would.

title: Now You Did It. (Smash!) She's Really Mad. (Kapowie!)
description: Nobody is expecting much from the sequel to ''Carrie.'' The only star from the original 1976 film who's back for ''The Rage: Carrie 2'' is Amy Irving, but of course the other major characters died in that unfortunate conflagration at the prom. The director is new; the screenwriter is new, and Stephen King, whose early novel was the basis of the first film, is nowhere to be found. The film itself is an uninspired update with video cameras, sexual frankness, margaritas and tattoos.

title: France's Cinematic Passion
description: Having to consume the $40 million buckets of toxic popcorn Hollywood churns out month after month can throw a film critic into a state of hand-wringing despair. Why, why, why? Why has an industry with the potential to enrich our lives sunk into a soul-deadening wasteland of cartoonish violence and adolescent pranks? The answer, of course, has something to do with commercial calculation and least-common-denominator marketing.

title: Graf Survives Rubin in Semis
description: She cast aspersions about the way she got there, but the 29-year-old Steffi Graf, a two-time Evert Cup champion who has been nearly invincible at the event in Indian Wells, Calif., reached the final yesterday with a stubborn but error-strewn 2-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory over 26th-ranked Chanda Rubin.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELDOCH, HONEY
description: BELDOCH-Honey. A Memorial Service to celebrate the life of Honey Beldoch, who died peacefully on Feb 20th in her sleep. Her Florida friends and relatives are invited 1:30pm on Saturday Mar 13th at 130 Sunrise Blvd, Palm Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONZE, PETER AND ELIZABETH
description: CONZE-Peter and Elizabeth. The Board of Trustees of Kent School wish to express their profound sorrow over the deaths of Peter Horst Conze '38 and his wife Elizabeth Powers Conze. Peter served and Chancellor of Kent School following 21 years as President of the Board of Trustees. The Board, the Headmaster and Faculty, and the entire Kent School community extend their sincerest condolences to their three Kent children Peter H. Conze Jr. '61, Frederick B. Conze '62 and Elizabeth B. Conze '68 and the Conzes' ten grandchildren.

title: Reed Makes Trip to Find The Son He Couldn't Keep
description: Whether out of curiosity or simply from a desire to escape the sleep-inducing surroundings in Port St. Lucie, most of the Mets are looking forward to Friday's flight to the Dominican Republic, where they will play a two-game series against the Montreal Expos. But one Met, Rick Reed, is particularly anxious about going, and his reasons are intensely personal.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUGRUE, MARTIN R. JR.
description: SHUGRUE-Martin R. Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Martin R. Shugrue Jr., a member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, Pres. Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: UAL Said to Be Near Choice Of New Chief
description: Ending one of the most closely watched executive searches, the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, has narrowed its hunt for a new chief executive to two candidates, according to two people close to the search.

title: Another Unmarried Woman, Not by Choice
description: Two decades have passed since Jill Clayburgh showed moviegoers in ''An Unmarried Woman'' how to take it in style when your husband leaves you for a younger woman and completely disrupts your perfect if charmingly chaotic life. Now Mary McDonnell does the same in ''Replacing Dad,'' a CBS movie that rises above the brave-woman-with-troubles genre.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Thursday about the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority's award of a five-year contract to R&R Advertising misstated the billings involved and the location of the agency's headquarters. The estimated billings of $28 million is an annual figure, not the total for the five-year contract; the total billings are estimated at $140 million. R&R Advertising is based in Las Vegas, Nev., with an office in Reno; it is not based in Reno.

title: 'Deliver The Goods'
description: Perhaps the last person to see Stanley Kubrick's film ''Eyes Wide Shut'' before his death was an unlikely figure. Pat Kingsley, a top public relations executive who represents some high-profile movie stars, saw the movie last Friday afternoon at Mr. Kubrick's home in Hertfordshire, outside London. Mr. Kubrick was not at the screening but upstairs in his bedroom because he said he was coming down with the flu. But after Ms. Kingsley saw the film, she spent about 45 minutes talking to Mr. Kubrick by telephone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGZAG, MARTIN W.
description: MAGZAG-Martin W., 66, died in New Milford, CT, March 10, 1999. Retired Firefighter Yonkers No. 13. Beloved husband of Lorraine, devoted father of Martin, Michael, Maryann and Lori. Grandfather of five. Funeral 10 a.m. Saturday at St. Paul Church, Brookfield, CT. Calling Friday 5 to 9 p.m. at Brookfield Funeral Home, 786 Federal Road, Brookfield, CT.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Favoring Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Banana War's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Inner-Circle Acolyte, Then Appalled Outsider
description: ALL TOO HUMAN

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME IN $230 MILLION DEAL FOR SODAK
description: International Game Technology, the largest United States designer and manufacturer of slot machines, agreed yesterday to buy Sodak Gaming Inc., a gambling equipment distributor, for $230 million in cash. International Game, based in Reno, said it would pay $10 a share for Sodak, a 25 percent premium to its closing stock price on Wednesday. Sodak shares rose $1.125, or 14 percent, to $9.125, while International Game shares rose 62.5 cents, to $15.25. Under the terms of the deal, Sodak is expected to sell its Miss Marquette Iowa riverboat and its 50 percent interest in a gambling riverboat in Louisiana.

title: Repairman Is Crushed While Fixing Elevator
description: An elevator repairman was crushed to death by an elevator car in an office building in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Starr Spokeman Quits

title: No Calhoun, but UConn Takes Care of Business
description: Connecticut's destination may be the Final Four, but to get there, the top-seeded Huskies must take care of pesky matters like their first-round game against 16th-seeded Texas-San Antonio. Every long and magical journey starts with a first, sometimes perfunctory, step and that is what tonight's 91-66 victory was for UConn.

title: State Police Inquiries Tangle Whitman Nomination
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman decided two weeks ago that her Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, should become the next justice on the state's highest court, both Republicans and Democrats predicted that his nomination would be quickly approved with little debate.

title: Dow Surges 124.60 as It Flirts With 10,000 Mark
description: The Dow Jones industrial average pushed within 65 points of the 10,000 mark yesterday before surrendering about a quarter of its gains amid signs that the recent rally has widened to include stocks that had been left in the wake of technology shares.

title: McNown Is Cleared By the F.B.I.
description: Timothy P. McNally, the F.B.I. assistant director in Los Angeles, said yesterday that an investigation into an alleged association between a suspected mobster and several U.C.L.A. players -- including quarterback Cade McNown -- had failed to uncover evidence of wrongdoing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, RUTH L.
description: EVANS-Ruth L. The Englewood Hospital and Medical Center Board of Trustees expresses profound sorrow on the passing of our long-time benefactor and friend, Ruth Evans. She was a shining example of courage and warmth, and will be missed by the entire Medical Center family. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Hugh Evans, and her family. Daniel A. Kane President and CEO

title: BANKERS TRUST ADMITS DIVERTING UNCLAIMED MONEY
description: Bankers Trust Company pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal criminal charges that senior officers and employees had illegally diverted $19.1 million in unclaimed checks and other credits owed to customers into the bank's own books to enhance its financial performance. The bank agreed to pay a $60 million fine to the Federal Government.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Square Peg In Oval Office

title: Jaspers Hire Untested Coach
description: Manhattan College has hired Bobby Gonzalez, a former New York City high school assistant, as its men's basketball coach, the school announced yesterday.

title: Congressional Memo; New Speaker, New Style, Old Problem (but Worse)
description: J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the new Speaker of the House, may be trying to shed all comparisons with his mercurial predecessor, Newt Gingrich. But he cannot avoid one of the central problems that Mr. Gingrich faced in trying to run the House: his party appears hopelessly split, and with just a 10-vote margin, Mr. Hastert has even less room to maneuver than Mr. Gingrich had.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, NATHAN JOSEPH, D.D.S.
description: LIPKIN-Nathan Joseph, D.D.S. 75. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of New York. Passed away March 10, 1999. Beloved husband Gladys. Loving father of Harriet (Chris Sautter), Alan (Barbara) and Rebecca. Dear brother of Shirley Rosenthal. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Sam and Molly Lipkin, Josh and Stephanie Sautter. Graduate of Johns Hopkins University and the New York University School of Dentistry and its Graduate Orthodontic course. He died peacefully and painlessly. His life will be celebrated in a memorial service at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1921 Pembroke Rd., Hollywood FL. 954-921-7200, Friday, March 12, 1999 at 2PM. Graveside services will take place on Sunday, March 14, 1999 at 1PM at Beth David Cemetery on Elmont Rd in Elmont, Long Island. Shiva will be at the Lipkin residence in Hollywood, FL starting Monday, March 15, 1999.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Some People Just Can't Be Taught How to Teach; Budgets Are Starved
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Assigns New Lawyer To Gotti Case
description: In a last-minute effort to strengthen what it believes is a weakening case against John A. Gotti, the Government has brought back a veteran prosecutor from private practice to take charge of the racketeering trial of the accused Mafia leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMEL, ALBERT
description: SCHIMEL-Albert. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member David Schimel and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: MEDPARTNERS SAYS IT WILL SELL $150 MILLION OF ITS ASSETS
description: Medpartners Inc., a health care concern in the midst of a reorganization, agreed yesterday to sell assets valued at $150 million to a joint venture between St. Luke's Episcopal Health System and Methodist Heath Care System. The agreement, expected to close by April 30, includes a physician-practice management business valued at $89 million and a building and other assets valued at $61 million. The business to be sold provides services to the Kelsey-Seybold Medical Group of Houston.

title: The Modern Looks at Artists Looking at Museums
description: Of all the love-hate relationships that roil the art world, none is more fraught or more stimulating than that between artists and museums. This makes perfect sense, since the two occupy opposite ends of the art world food chain.

title: Kiner Signs A 2-Year Deal
description: Ralph Kiner has signed a new two-year deal to call a minimum of 40 total Mets games this season for Channel 11 and Fox Sports New York. Kiner, a Mets announcer since the team's inception in 1962, suffered from Bell's palsy last season, which affected his speaking and restricted his workload.

title: A Cautious Rise to a Top Name in Fashion
description: Kate Spade, the designer who built a handbag empire, was found dead in her Manhattan apartment June 5, 2018, after an apparent suicide. She was 55.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Kirby Repertory: Short and Sweet
description: With the swing revival in full force and the events of the Ellington centennial all around, it's a good moment to consider some of the swing era's side streams. The music of the John Kirby Sextet is a perfect example. Wayne Roberts, a bass player and band leader, has been working for four years on transcribing the sextet's music from the 1930's and 40's, and he has found a perfect place to show what he has learned. The Firebird Cafe, on Restaurant Row at 365 West 46th Street, Clinton, has booked him every Monday night for the last several months; its back-room cabaret, with an audience space that wraps around the bandstand, is as cozy as a living room.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Still a Contender on the Waterfront
description: On a recent March morning, I walked the windy piers of the Brooklyn waterfront, gazing out at the choppy waters of Buttermilk Channel and Upper New York Bay, looking for the shadow of my grandfather. He had fled conscription into the Czar's army in 1914, landed at Ellis Island and found work as a longshoreman on the docks of what was then one of the world's great industrial ports.

title: William Wrigley, 66, the Chief Of His Family's Gum Empire
description: William Wrigley, chief executive of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company and the heir of the chewing gum family that once owned the Chicago Cubs baseball team, died Monday after a brief bout of pneumonia. He was 66.

title: Illinois Man Is Finally Cleared in 2 Murders
description: An Illinois man who spent 16 years on death row for a double murder before college journalism students found evidence to clear him was exonerated of the killings today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the financial difficulties faced by the Nissan Motor Company misstated the amount of credit it has received from the Japan Development Bank. It is $700 million, not $7 billion.

title: True North Selects Bell as New Chief
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that David Bell, the president and chief executive of its Bozell Worldwide unit in New York, would become chairman and chief executive of True North on March 31 when Bruce Mason, the current chief executive, is scheduled to retire.

title: Malcolm Morley
description: Sperone Westwater

title: Sports of The Times; DiMaggio's Last Call: It's About Famiglia
description: ONCE this man lashed home runs in Yankee Stadium and married a glamorous actress, but yesterday Joe DiMaggio came back to the old neighborhood to be buried.

title: Cleaning Out a Sheet-Music Attic; Real-Estate Deal Closes Carl Fischer's Trove of Scores
description: Standing in a narrow aisle between dusty shelves that rise from the no-frills linoleum floor to the old-fashioned plaster ceiling, Sandy Feldstein looked down on a sales area that has not changed much since World War II. He is not, he declared, presiding over a going-out-of-business sale.

title: Oracle Reports Slower-Than-Expected Sales
description: Shares in the Oracle Corporation dropped sharply in after-hours trading today after the company reported slower-than-anticipated software sales. Oracle reported third-quarter earnings that essentially matched analysts' expectations, but revenues from both data base and applications software fell short.

title: Help for the Uninsured May Rest in Tax Code
description: Not since the demise of the Clinton Administration plan to overhaul the nation's health care system have Americans without health insurance, now more than 43 million people, received so much attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, EDWARD S. BROTHER
description: ROTH-Edward S. Brother, father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Retired New York City bridge and tunnel inspector, construction worker, founder of the Two Bridges Neighborhood Council, and labor union activist for District 65. Photographic contributor and archivist for the Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University. Services Friday, 1:30 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, MICHAEL JOSEPH
description: FINN-Michael Joseph. On March 9, 1999 at age 48 in Boston, MA. Loving son of Anna Cohen Finn and the late Michael Joseph Finn. Devoted brother of Kevin, Dennis and the late Jane Ellen McGuire and Judy Finn. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews, greatuncle of one. Friends may visit at the Andrett-Funeral Home 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Friday 2-5 & 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of the Epiphany (22nd St and Second Avenue) Saturday at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of floral tributes, please make contributions to Church of the Epiphany: New Elevator for the Disabled Fund 239 E 21st St. NY, NY 10010 ATT: Sr. Christine

title: It's Over: Clippers Stop Slide At 1-17
description: Their fans, who last saw a victory on April 18, 1998, were high-fiving long after the buzzer sounded. Their young point guard, Darrick Martin, was sinking everything he threw up. What a foreign feeling for the Los Angeles Clippers; they were winning.

title: In Paris, Paying Tribute to Jerome Robbins With Pomp and Humor
description: Barely eight months after his death, Jerome Robbins was remembered fondly tonight in a gala evening of pomp and ceremony as well as nostalgia and good humor organized by the Paris Opera Ballet, the company that the American choreographer considered his ''second family'' after the New York City Ballet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, MAX
description: SHAW-Max. Age 85. Beloved husband of Rose for 62 years. Loving father of Susan (Leonard) Zimmerman, Risa (Leroy) Doris and Deborah Shaw. Cherished grandfather of nine. Services today, 11:00 AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, LEONARD B.
description: ALPERT-Leonard B. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, on March 9, at age 68 died, as he wished, quickly and quietly in his own bed at home after a brief heart-related illness. Despite the physical limitations of quadriplegia and part time dependency on a respirator because of polio contracted in 1955, Lennie lived a life full of the realization of his goals and visions. His 26-year career at Sears Roebuck was marked by achievements in the early years of data processing and systems development. In 1980, he and his wife Marie opened Images Art Gallery in Briarcliff Manor. Both at Sears and at Images, he was mentor and friend to so many whose lives were touched by the quiet grace, dignity and incredible sense of humor with which he lived. He died just one day after his childhood hero, Joe DiMaggio, and the words which described the elegance of the athlete could well apply to Lennie. He will live on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched, but mainly in his wife Marie Pantuosco Alpert who has never known where she began and he ended and in his nephew Larry Friedman, his niece Ellen Friedman, their spouses Holly Holmes and Jeff Cowan; great nieces Rachel, Celia and Molly; great nephew Sam and sister and brother-in-law Blanche and Jack Friedman. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: Syracuse and U.C.L.A Bounced from Round 1
description: The quality of Syracuse's season was reflected in its ranking in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament: seeded No. 8, the lowest of Coach Jim Boeheim's 23-year tenure.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTH -- Stunning for Carolina; Simple for St. John's; Red Storm Exploits Jitters by Samford
description: It began with two air balls on free throws. And then things got really unsightly.

title: Stage II Apparel in Deal
description: The Stage II Apparel Corporation, a men's and boys' clothing maker, agreed yesterday to acquire the Cross Colours brand from a private group including Robert Greenberg, one of its outside directors, for an undisclosed amount of stock. The seller of casual and active-wear clothing, with 1997 sales of $16.5 million, said it would develop the Cross Colours line of young men's urban fashions and license the trademark.

title: U.N. Criticism Angers Charities Buying Sudan Slaves' Release
description: Private charities that are buying freedom for enslaved children and young women in Sudan, have reacted angrily to recent criticism of them from Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: Clinton and Latin Leaders Turn to Immigration
description: President Clinton and a group of Central American leaders declared today that they would work among themselves and with the United States to reach ''humane and permanent solutions'' to the problems of illegal immigration.

title: DiMaggio Highway Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Secretly, They Talk And Plot And Smirk
description: One way to get through ''Baby Geniuses'' is to think about whether it really is the worst movie you've ever seen. Probably not, but pretty darn close.

title: AMERICAN AXLE IS BUYING MSP INDUSTRIES FOR $60 MILLION
description: American Axle and Manufacturing Holdings Inc., the No. 2 maker of automobile drive systems, has agreed to buy the MSP Industries Corporation, a closely held parts maker, for as much as $60 million. The cash deal to buy MSP Industries, a maker of forged chassis parts with 1998 sales of $56 million, is American Axle's third purchase agreement in six months. American Axle, which also makes rear axles and suspension systems, had 1998 sales of $2.04 billion. American Axle, based in Detroit, was formed in 1994 when Richard E. Dauch, a former Chrysler executive, bought five General Motors parts plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, RALPH H. JR.
description: HUBBARD-Ralph H. Jr. Fourth generation New Yorker, lately of Conroe, Texas, and Greenwich, CT. Born April 18, 1912. Rye Country Day, Middlesex School, Princeton University 1934. U.S.N.R., O.S.S, Bronze Star. Son of Ralph H. Hubbard and Etta Fleming of Rye, NY. Survived by a son, Thomas, daughter, Hilary, and six grandchildren, all of Fairfield, CT; a brother-in-law, David Carpenter, of Sawgrass, FL, and numerous nieces and nephews. Services Saturday, March 13, at 1 p.m. at Christ Church, Rye, NY.

title: RJR Nabisco, An Epilogue
description: Like Stanley Kubrick and Joe DiMaggio, RJR Nabisco died this week. The 14-year-old company, formed in 1985 by the ill-conceived merger of the R. J. Reynolds tobacco conglomerate and the Nabisco food corporation, is to be broken up, its foreign cigarette company sold to the Japanese so that Nabisco can once more go its own way, alone.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST -- Stunning for Carolina; Simple for St. John's; Weber State Foils Tar Heels' Late Bid
description: Harold Arceneaux scored a game-high 36 points and intercepted an inbounds pass as time ran out to preserve Weber State's 76-74 upset of third-seeded North Carolina tonight in the first round of the West Regional.

title: Out of India: History and Beauty in a Colonial Context
description: Before Indian independence, some Britons seemed to think that Queen Victoria had acquired the subcontinent almost by default. After all, the East India Company had taken direct control of 60 percent of India and indirect control of most of the rest by the mid-19th century, and in 1857, the Indians finally rebelled. The Great Rebellion, also known as the Indian Mutiny, ensued; British firepower won; the company failed, and what was the Crown to do but step in?

title: First-Round Upsets
description: North Carolina was stunned by Weber State, U.C.L.A. was upset by Detroit, St. John's and UConn rolled, and Syracuse was eliminated by Oklahoma State in the closing minutes as the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament opened.

title: LUFTHANSA UNIT IS INCREASING ITS STAKE IN SKY CHEFS
description: Deutsche Lufthansa's in-flight food-service unit said yesterday that it would buy an additional 18 percent stake in Sky Chefs, the world's largest airline caterer, from the Onex Corporation for $266 million and could buy the entire company within five years. The purchase by the unit, LSG Lufthansa Service Holding, will raise its stake in Sky Chefs to 48 percent. Onex, based in Toronto, also owns about 48 percent. LSG Lufthansa said it had an option to buy Onex's stake and the remaining shares of Sky Chefs no later than Dec. 31, 2003.

title: Accessory Designers in Britain Cash In on Their Eccentricity : The Extras That Count (and the Zanier the Better)
description: LONDON  While accessory designers in London may be the unsung heroes of the city's revival as a fashion hotspot, the problem is some of them are victims of their own success.

title: Finding Flaws In the Logic Of Bias Laws
description: WHEN four subway riders were slashed within 24 hours a few days ago, no underground regular could avoid a shudder. Police assurances that subway assaults have been declining were good to hear, but they did not undo the trauma. Many passengers glanced nervously around to see who -- armed with Heaven knows what -- was entering the car.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Variable Transmission Wins New Disciples
description: WHILE driving the Honda Civic HX coupe, one immediately senses that something is missing. Step hard on the accelerator when a stoplight turns green, or press the pedal to the floor to pass on a freeway, and there is no jerk as the transmission shifts gears. Nor does the sound of the engine rise just before a shift, along with its speed, and then fall off. The tachometer's needle holds steady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ALEX
description: BERNSTEIN-Alex, 68, died March 11th. Memorial service Saturday, 2PM, Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd, Larchmont.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKEY, JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: DICKEY-Joseph Michael. We are deeply saddened and shocked by the tragic loss of our special, dearly beloved friend and associate, Joe Dickey, on March 8, 1999. He was our guide and mentor for many years. We will sorely miss him, his advice and counsel. May the family be comforted knowing that he was a gentleman of innovation and integrity. We have lost a rare and kind person and will be the poorer for this loss, although we will always be the richer for having known him. We express our deepest regrets to his family. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Joe Dickey, distinguished friend and colleague, will be held on Monday, March 15, 6:00 PM, at the Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10027. Phone 212-870-6700. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Riverside Church's Ministry for Education and Social Justice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANHEIMER, BRUCE
description: MANHEIMER-Bruce. Gone 3 years. Missing you and loving you always. Elle

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance on Tuesday by the ballet troupe Dance Galaxy at the Joyce Theater reversed the names of the partners to two dancers in the ballet ''Artifact II.'' As noted in the accompanying picture captions, Suzanne Goldman's partner was Francois Perron and Bonnie Pickard's partner was John Summers.

title: In Vote Clinton Sought to Avoid, House Backs a Force for Kosovo
description: The House voted narrowly tonight to support President Clinton's plan to send American troops to Kosovo should a peace settlement be reached, after a passionate and bitter debate on United States policy in the Balkans.

title: Fight, but No Fright
description: George Evans laughs when he hears people compare sports to combat, when a fierce game is called a war, when tournament elimination is treated like tragedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALKINS, KENNETH B.
description: CALKINS-Kenneth B. Died March 10, 1999. Kenneth was a beloved son to the late Douglas A. Calkins Jr. and the late Margo Blankarn Calkins. He is survived by his loving stepmother, Dorothy Williams Calkins. Dear partner to Vern T. Calhoun. Fond brother to Jeffrey L. Calkins, Gregory T. Calkins and Jennifer Williams Peterson. Memorial service Saturday, 12:30 PM, at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, Millwood Rd., Mount Kisco, NY (914-666-7001). In lieu of flowers, contributions in Kenneth's name may be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS (BC/ EFA), 165 W. 46 St., NY, NY 10036.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a dispute between the Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans over what to make public from a classified House committee report on China's acquisition of United States military technology misstated a concern of Representative Christopher Cox, the California Republican who is the chairman of the committee. He said he feared that some of the findings would not be disclosed in the declassification process, not that they would be disclosed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: German Finance Minister Resigns in Surprise Move

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about talks on Kosovo between the American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke and Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Yugoslavia, misstated the duration of the meeting. It was a one-day meeting, not Mr. Holbrooke's second day with Mr. Milosevic.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ASHLAND INC., -- Russell, Ky., said it would divide its wholly owned Ashland Chemical Co. into separate distribution and specialty chemicals businesses. The new divisions will be called Ashland Distribution Co. and Ashland Specialty Chemicals Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, LILLIAN
description: ELKIN-Lillian. On March 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jack M. Loving mother of Robert and Rosalind. Dear sister of Joseph and the late Nathan Moskow. Devoted aunt and good friend. Lillian was a poet, journalist, educator and active in Jewish communal service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZIA, VALENTINO D.B., M.D. AND J.D.
description: MAZZIA-Valentino D.B., M.D. and J.D. Beloved and devoted husband of Rosana. Dear brother of Alex and the late Lloret. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Monday, at 10 AM. Interment private.

title: New Party Vying to Be in Middle of Israeli Politics
description: At the gala inauguration of the Center Party tonight, before the balloons dropped from the rafters and the party jingle made its bow, Mimran Yaakov, a businessman, presented his political credentials to a reporter.

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic to File For Long Distance
description: Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local phone company, plans within six weeks to ask regulators for permission to offer long-distance service in New York State, its top officer said yesterday.

title: 3 Fragments of Soviet Realm Joining NATO's Ranks Today
description: When Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic formally join NATO on Friday, it will symbolize the return of three nations, and not merely their militaries, to the center of European civilization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSWALD, FRANK GRAF III
description: OSWALD-Frank Graf III. Killed in an automobile accident on March 7 in Amado, Arizona. He is survived by his wife Laurinda Middleton Oswald; his two children Frank Graf and Julia Skye; his mother Audrey Clinton Oswald of Newport; his father Frank Graf Oswald Jr. of Port Washington; his brother David of Stamford; and his sister Diana of New York City. Memorial Services in Newport and New York City to be announced. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Newport Boys and Girls Club would be appreciated.

title: Sergio Vega: El Paraiso en el Nuevo Mundo'
description: Basilico Fine Arts

title: A Dreamscape Of Medieval Art
description: ''Mirror of the Medieval World'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a glowing exhibition of some 300 objects brought into the Met's collection over the last 20 years. Arranged thematically, the show transforms the Met's galleries into a treasure chest thrown open, illustrating the museum's commitment to medieval art and the esthetic discernment of its curators.

title: Punctuating The Words With Action
description: A sharp satire and an amiable party enlivened ''Together Again,'' the program that James Cunningham and Jane Comfort staged on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about problems facing small private liberal arts colleges misstated the percentage of admitted applicants to Ivy League colleges and universities who ultimately enroll at Ivy League schools. The highest percentage in the Ivy League last year was 79.2 percent, at Harvard; the overall figure for the eight institutions was not ''well over 90 percent.''

title: National News Briefs; Store Owner to Leave
description: After weeks of protests by Vietnamese-Americans in Westminster, Calif., over his display of a Ho Chi Minh poster and a Vietnamese flag, a video store owner has dropped his challenge to an eviction proceeding.

title: Acrid Fumes at School Send 13 to Hospital
description: Eleven students and two teachers at a Paterson grade school were hospitalized yesterday after complaining that acrid chemical fumes had irritated their eyes, throats and noses, school and city officials said.

title: Results Due on Use of Marrow Transplants for Breast Cancer
description: Cancer researchers have announced that by mid-April they will make public the results of the first four large-scale studies comparing standard treatment for advanced breast cancer to a far more aggressive and controversial procedure involving bone-marrow transplants.

title: Favoring Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT DENIES IGNORING EVIDENCE OF NUCLEAR SPYING
description: President Clinton vigorously denied today that the Administration had minimized evidence of nuclear spying by China and defended his policy of engagement with Beijing as the only effective means of restraining Chinese behavior.

title: How They Voted on Schools
description: Following is the 330-to-90 roll-call by which the House of Representatives approved a measure to give states and schools more flexibility in how they spend $11 billion in Federal money. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 112 Democrats and 217 Republicans and one independent. Voting ''no'' were 90 Democrats. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote. X denotes the 14 representatives who did not vote. There is one vacancy.

title: Why Is U.S. Foreign Policy Adrift?; Connect the Dots
description: To the Editor:

title: Sylvia Benitez and Charles Juhasz Alvarado
description: Taller Boricua Gallery

title: A van Gogh On the Block
description: ''Do you remember among the little drawings a wooden bridge with a washing place, and a view of the town in the distance?'' Vincent van Gogh wrote his brother, Theo, on June 16, 1888. ''I have just painted that subject in a large size.''

title: DiMaggio's Funeral Respects His Privacy
description: For one last time, Joe DiMaggio tried to preserve his cherished privacy, and on this occasion he almost succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAX, PHILIP, M.D.
description: STRAX-Philip, M.D. I mourn the loss of my beloved friend and companion for ten years. Frances K. Rosen

title: Schwab Says It Settled Customers' Claims
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the biggest on-line broker, said today that it had settled claims from some customers who tried to cancel orders for shares in the fast-rising initial public offering of Theglobe.com Inc.

title: Mark Schlesinger
description: Silverstein Gallery

title: Latin American
description: Under the names Pan-Latin or nuevo latino, the cuisines of Central and South America have surged in popularity in the last year, with restaurants opening all over Manhattan to immediate popularity. Here are a dozen Latin American restaurants, both new and old. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: When Art Mocks  and Inspires  Fashion
description: PARIS  "One thing is sure. There are more fashion designers who want to be artists than the other way around," says Elein Fleiss, co-founder of Purple, fashion's artiest style review.

title: New Video Releases
description: Bulworth

title: A Dance Festival On Foot and Film
description: Performances by the Bill T. Jones and Paul Taylor troupe, Pilobolus Dance Theater, Philadanco and modern-dance companies from Argentina, China, Russia and Israel are to be presented at the American Dance Festival, June 10 to July 24, at Duke University in Durham, N.C.

title: Snoopy and the 'Peanuts' gang will no longer be Metropolitan Life's main representatives.
description: AS the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company prepares to go public, the insurance giant is starting to portray itself in a very different way, playing down cartoon faces in favor of human ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourn the passing of our esteemed friend. Hermann Merkin was truly a legendary figure at Tel Aviv University. A wise man of great compassion, his vision and generosity enabled our University to establish the Moshe Dayan Center for Middle Eastern and African Studies and the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. He was a very gentle man of infinite grace and humility. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ursula, and his family. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Alan L. Aufzien, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, Pres. Stephen Lecker, Exec. V.P.

title: Paris Boutiques Showcase Artists and Designers
description: PARIS  While fashion designers often turn to art for inspiration, increasingly the fashion crowd is turning to the art world to add another dimension to its boutiques.

title: Prudential of Britain Moves to Expand
description: Moving quickly to deliver on a pledge made just two weeks ago, the Prudential Corporation P.L.C. moved yesterday to strengthen its fund management operations by proposing to acquire M & G Group P.L.C. for $:25 a share in cash, a total of $:1.9 billion. The takeover is likely to result in minimal job losses among M & G's 1,100 employees, Prudential said.

title: Marbury, a Schoolyard Hero, Returns to Don a Nets Jersey
description: Stephon Marbury, the Brooklyn native who is one of the most electrifying basketball players to come out of New York City in the last 25 years, is returning to the metropolitan area, joining the New Jersey Nets as part of a three-team trade.

title: M. R. Shugrue, 58, Who Tried to Save Airlines
description: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., an airline executive who played a pivotal and at times controversial role in unsuccessful attempts to keep Pan American World Airways and, later, Eastern Airlines from failing, died on Sunday. He was 58 years old.

title: A Game Of Feudal Feuding
description: The revelations have not been pleasant. Plots and counterplots, all within one little family, have been exploded. A shocking sexual secret has been dragged to the surface. A father has cursed his sons, and the sons have responded in kind. War, treason, assassination all hover as serious possibilities. So what does the mother of this unwholesome clan have to say about the latest of its domestic blow-ups?

title: Chef Admits He Inflated Tips In Attempt to Steal Thousands
description: A Brooklyn-born former boxer whose talent as a chef and Barnumesque persona carried him to the pinnacle of New York culinary circles pleaded guilty yesterday to trying to steal more than $140,000 by inflating tips left by patrons of his midtown restaurant.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: 33 Hurt in Eight Alarm Fire In Upper West Side Building
description: An eight alarm fire quickly spiraled upward through a turn-of-the-century apartment building on the Upper West Side yesterday, sending 20-foot-high flames shooting from the roof and leaving 33 people injured.

title: Alcatel Now Says 12,000 Jobs Must Go
description: Alcatel S.A., the French manufacturer of phone equipment, yesterday increased by 7,000, to 12,000, the number of jobs it plans to cut. The company's chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, also said the company was holding talks with the Government about the sale of Alcatel's 44 percent stake in Framatome, the state-controlled nuclear reactor maker. The value of all of Framatome is put at $3 billion.

title: Clinton Adviser Says North Korea Is Advancing Its Nuclear Program
description: North Korea is working on its nuclear program despite Clinton Administration statements that the program is frozen, according to former Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, the President's special adviser on North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALVIN, ANDREW
description: GALVIN-Andrew. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board, and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the passing of Andrew Galvin. Sincere condolences are extended to his son, Peter A. Galvin, MD, distinguished President of the Medical Board, and to his family. Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors Robert V. Levine, President & Chief Executive Officer

title: Education Bill Clears, Providing Gain for Republicans as They Seek Policy Victories
description: The House and Senate handily approved legislation today to give states and schools more flexibility in how they spend $11 billion in Federal money, a vote that gave each party a claim to being in tune with the public's interest in education.

title: Iran's Leader and Pope Seek Better Muslim-Christian Ties
description: Seeking to improve relations between Christianity and Islam, Pope John Paul II gave a private audience to President Mohammad Khatami of Iran today. It was the first papal encounter with an Iranian head of state since the days of the Shah.

title: Editorial Observer; Monica 90210: A Small Town and Its Image
description: There are worse things than being from Beverly Hills. It was thus disconcerting to learn that Monica Lewinsky regards my hometown as the source of her anguish and our long national nightmare.
