In ''Monica's Story,'' Andrew Morton blames Beverly Hills's ''obsession'' with status, money and thinness for Ms. Lewinsky's eating compulsions and self-destructive behavior. In third grade, it seems, she was devastated not to be invited to Tori Spelling's birthday party, featuring Michael Jackson and the world's smallest pony.

title: Why Is U.S. Foreign Policy Adrift?
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Two Men Are Arrested In Thefts From Church
description: Two men knelt before the altar of a Bronx church yesterday morning and adopted prayerful poses to conceal what the police described as their real purpose: fishing money out of the church's poor boxes with a wire hanger.

title: Numbers Beat the 'Band'
description: It may not be the worst decision of the season. (Remember ''More to Love''?) But the booking of ''Band in Berlin'' in the Helen Hayes Theater on Broadway over the acclaimed drama ''Wit'' is looking more and more suspect.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Jones Apparel and Nine West plan nuptials, some investors already want an annulment.
description: JONES APPAREL GROUP INC. and Nine West Group Inc., the two fashion companies that plan to waltz down the aisle soon, have much more in common than aiming to sell chic clothing and shoes to the same high-spending career women.

title: Smoky Fire Halts Service On Four Subway Lines
description: A smoky fire in an electrical equipment room beneath the Bergen Street subway station in Brooklyn shut down subway service on parts of four lines for several hours last night and early this morning, transit officials said.

title: Amtrak's Fast Train to Boston Isn't for the Frugal
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Utility Chic An Imposter?
description: LONDON  What have international designers learned from London street style? Well, they have seen the future and it is Utility Chic. They have drawn inspiration for the spring/summer 99 collections from khaki, Velcro, hip holster bags, combat pant pockets and trophy trainers. Utility is high fashion's spin on the urban street uniform. It's high fashion in a techno-sporty-dressed-down kind of way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECRE, RICHARD
description: DECRE-Richard, age 43, died March 11 at home in Glen Rock, Pennsylvania. Beloved husband of Jacqueline; loving father of Benjamin; dearest son of Fred and Rita; also survived by a sister, Janice Boretti. Reposing at Hartenstein Funeral Home, 1-800-235-3857. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer or Hospice would be appreciated.

title: When Antarctica Slips Into the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, SALLIE, ACKLEY
description: HOLMES-Sallie, Ackley, 69 of Greenwich Village, died Sunday, March 7 at NYU Hospital. She was born in Philadelphia, PA, April 17, 1929 and resided in Jenkinstown, PA until 1950 when she moved to NY. She attended Smith College, and the Latin American Institute. She retired from Shearson Lehman and devoted much of her time during retirement to enjoying blues and jazz music. She leaves her best friend John Rodriguez, two sisters Elizabeth H. Osth of Palm Harbor, Fl and Jaquelin H. Anderson of East Granby, CT, a niece and three nephews. She will be buried at Trinity Church Cemetery and Mausoleum. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, RICHARD J., JR.
description: COTTER-Richard J., Jr. Of Duxbury, Mass, March 9. Retired attorney and horse breeder. Son of the late Richard J. and Louise (Carr) Cotter. Brother of the late Pauline L. Moran who died in 1993. Dear uncle of Cynthia L. Moran of Sutton, Mass and Diana Chabrier and her husband Wilfred of Westfield, NJ and four grandnieces. Former husband of Danielle(Cherifa Amrani). MacDonald Funeral Home, 1755 Ocean St, Marshfield, Mass, Saturday at 9AM followed by a Funeral Mass in Holy Family Church, Duxbury at 10AM. Burial Mayflower Cemetery, Duxbury. Contributions may be made to Department of Animal Control, Duxbury, New Animal Shelter Building Fund, 878 Tremont St, Duxbury, Mass 02332.

title: Unlucky in Life and Love: A Fatally Rude Awakening
description: The Washington Opera presentation on Wednesday night of Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari's ''Sly, or the Legend of the Sleeper Awakened'' seemed an odd mix of international event and family affair.

title: Judge Bars Anti-Abortion Militants Who Occupied Irish Clinic
description: A group of anti-abortion militants, including about 40 Americans, have reignited the highly emotional issue of abortion in this Roman Catholic country by forcing their way into a Dublin family-planning office and occupying it for two hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, GERY
description: HECHT-Gery. A woman of extraordinary talents, adored by her family, friends and clients. Interior designer, chef, backgammon ace, gardener and superlative mother, mother-in-law and grandmother. She is survived by her daughter, Lynn Hecht Schafran, her son-inlaw L. G. (Larry), and grandchildren David (Karen) and Brooke. Contributions to Save the Children.

title: Nike Critic Praises Gains in Air Quality at Vietnam Factory
description: A prominent critic who badly hurt Nike's image when he exposed unsafe conditions at one of its factories in Vietnam in 1997 issued a report yesterday that gave the footwear giant high marks for improving air quality at the plant, although he said some significant problems remained.

title: Wide Power Failure Strikes Southern Brazil
description: Brazil's three largest cities were plunged into darkness tonight by a power failure that the authorities said affected most of the southern third of the country.

title: Giuliani Disputes Reports That Voucher Plan Is Dead
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani denied accounts yesterday -- based on statements by schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and the Board of Education -- that he had made any concessions on school vouchers or agreed not to pursue a voucher plan in New York City.

title: Spokesman for Starr Resigns As Request Is Made on Leaks
description: The chief spokesman for Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel who has been investigating President Clinton, abruptly resigned today, as Mr. Starr asked the Justice Department to look into unauthorized disclosures of confidential material from his own office.

title: Residential Real Estate; Condominium Developers Expand Boundaries of West Village
description: An 11-story, 9-unit condominium loft building is rising on what was once a weed-choked lot at 495 West Street at the western edge of Greenwich Village. Not far away, at 359 West 11th Street, a 10-story, 25-unit condominium will soon take shape where an old garage once stood.

title: Grand Decor On the Block
description: Many people think it's news when a prominent interior designer acts to redo his space. Alberto Pinto, the veteran Paris decorator, is making news by deciding to un-do his space.

title: The D.J. Apostles Of Rock 'n' Roll
description: Documentaries often make the better shows on video. On March 23, for example, Winstar is to release ''Rock 'n' Roll Invaders,'' a Canadian film that goes past the performers to get at the AM radio disk jockeys who brought the music to the people in the 50's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKAN, ALFRED
description: ELKAN-Alfred. Tifereth IsraelTown & Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member and extends heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abby Sosland President Carol J. Green

title: Colt's Best Defense; In Difficult Times, a Gun Maker Tries to Counterattack
description: For more than 150 years, the story of Colt guns has been entwined with the history of America. Colt sidearms were the weapon of choice among frontiersmen and outlaws, Texas Rangers and Army Rangers. Colt's M-16 is known to every Vietnam veteran. The company is best known for the Colt .45 -- the ''Peacemaker'' that won the West and was later celebrated in John Wayne movies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOGULESCU, MYRA REIN ON MAR
description: MOGULESCU-Myra Rein on Mar. 9, 1999. Loving mother of Karen & Marjorie, adoring grandmother of Matthew, loving sister of Audrey, & devoted mother-in-law of David. Memorial service March 24, at 215 East 68 Street, from 4-8 PM.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Stepping off the elevator after riding to the top of 1 World Trade Center is like floating off into the sky. The intense blue glow is a wonderful new effect -- and a wonderful introduction to the newest restaurant at Windows on the World.

title: Trump and Nascar President Sign Deal to Build Speedway
description: In a bid to capture the surging popularity of motor sports, Donald J. Trump has formed a partnership with the president of Nascar to build a major speedway on up to 1,000 acres in the Catskills, northern New Jersey or Connecticut.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: German Finance Aide Quits; European Markets Jubilant
description: After losing a power struggle over economic policy that had sent tremors across Europe for months, Germany's left-wing Finance Minister abruptly resigned today, and also quit as chairman of the ruling party.

title: Oil Ministers Study Export Cuts to Aid Prices
description: Oil ministers from five major oil producing nations met in the Netherlands yesterday in an effort to cut crude oil exports of up to two million barrels a day aimed at further bolstering the recent modest recovery in crude oil prices.

title: Investigator Testifies to Louima's Signs of Fear Over Officer's Photo
description: Three days after prosecutors say he was tortured in a Brooklyn police station, a severely injured Haitian immigrant reacted with apparent fear when he was shown a photograph of the officer accused of being his main attacker, a police investigator testified yesterday.

title: Diageo Reports Decline In the First Half
description: Diageo P.L.C., the world's largest liquor maker, said yesterday that its first-half profit from operations fell 11 percent after the sale of businesses and declining demand in Asia and Latin America depressed liquor volumes. Profit in the six months that ended on Dec. 31 fell to $:733 million ($1.19 billion), from $:826 million. Pretax profit before exceptional items fell to $:1.05 billion from $:1.2 billion.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Growing Up, and Away, From a Protective Mom
description: The Other Sister

title: A Lonely Circle of Hell Is Cold, but Not All Despair
description: The Icelandic equivalents of trailer-park trash run rampant through ''Devil's Island,'' which opens today at the Angelika Film Center.

title: Foreign Affairs; Loyalty, Shmoyalty!
description: My colleague William Safire recently wrote a much-noted column that began by asking: ''What inspires the phenomenal loyalty to Bill Clinton?'' Mr. Safire wondered how everyone from the public to the Democratic Party to Presidential aides could remain so ''loyal'' to Mr. Clinton, despite all his perfidies. Mr. Safire's column got me thinking. But the more I thought about it -- particularly in the wake of George Stephanopoulos' insightful memoirs -- the more it struck me as exactly wrong.

title: TMP WORLDWIDE IS BUYING LAI IN $84 MILLION STOCK DEAL
description: TMP Worldwide Inc., a recruitment concern and the largest Yellow Pages advertising agency, agreed yesterday to acquire LAI Worldwide Inc. for about $83.9 million in stock. TMP Worldwide, which is based in New York, said it would exchange 0.1321 share for each share of LAI, a New York-based executive-search company. TMP fell $1.9375 yesterday, to $67.9375. TMP, which operates the Monster.com job-search Web site, said the acquisition would make it the fifth-largest executive search company in the world.

title: Louisiana Shooting Kills 3 at Church and One at Home
description: In the seventh row of the New St. John Fellowship Baptist Church, on the floor next to a viscous pool of blood the full width of the pew, a Bible lay face up today, opened to a chapter of John that was spattered in red.

title: Devils' Owner Offers Plan For Arena In Hoboken
description: The principal owner of the New Jersey Devils hockey team unveiled today a plan to build a new $350 million arena for the team along with an entertainment complex on Hoboken's Hudson River waterfront and atop New Jersey Transit railroad tracks.

title: Less Serbian Diplomacy and More Fighting
description: Fighting spread across southern Kosovo today and Richard C. Holbrooke, the American envoy, left for Washington empty-handed after his meetings here with the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: LONG JOHN SILVER'S SAYS IT WILL BE ACQUIRED BY A&W
description: Long John Silver's Restaurants Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in June, said yesterday that after it emerged from bankruptcy it would be acquired by A&W Restaurants Inc. Long John Silver's, a closely held company based in Lexington, Ky., operates about 1,300 fast-food seafood restaurants in 37 states, Thailand and Singapore. A&W has about 1,000 restaurants in 46 states and 17 countries. It is based in Farmington Hills, Mich. A&W, its partner Grotech Capital and Long John Silver's said they had reached agreement on the acquisition and would request a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., to seek approval from a judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HARRY
description: MERESMAN-Harry. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member, Harry Meresman. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his daughter and other members of his family. Samuel G. Weinberg, President

title: Reed Elsevier Profit Fell 11% in 2d Half
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the world's largest publisher by market value, said yesterday that its second-half profit fell by 11 percent as it spent more on electronic publishing and had slower sales in some markets. Second-half profit from operations fell to $:264 million ($429 million) from $:296 million a year earlier.

title: European Ministers Outline Reduction in Farm Subsidies
description: European farm ministers reached a broad agreement today to reduce the European Union's $45 billion program for agricultural subsidies, a potentially important breakthrough on one of Europe's most divisive political problems.

title: Amtrak's Fast Train to Boston Isn't for the Frugal; Pitifully Small?
description: To the Editor:

title: The First Steps': Emerging Artists From Japan'
description: Grey Art Gallery

title: 'The Contemporary City': Red Grooms, Yvonne Jacquette, Jacob Lawrence, Philip Pearlstein and Paul Wonner
description: D. C. Moore Gallery

title: Agents Raid Homes Of Ex-Union Officials
description: Federal agents have raided the homes of the former president of New Jersey's largest police union and one of his former aides in connection with a two-year-old investigation into about $500,000 in missing union funds, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Investment Banks Must Soothe Asian Sensibilities
description: Investment banks have always struggled to reconcile their roles as tough-minded analysts and smooth-talking salespeople. Nowhere is this truer than in Asia, where the lines between government and business can be blurry and the opportunities to offend both are legion.

title: Romping Through a Dreamscape of Medieval Art
description: I shop, therefore I am. For many seasoned New Yorkers, this neo-Cartesian maxim describes their contact sport of choice. For art museums, though, it spells out a hard fact of professional life.

title: With Heavier Heavyweights, Holyfield Is No Sure Thing
description: Even while steadfastly standing by his prediction that he will knock out Lennox Lewis in the third round at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, Evander Holyfield's ''the bigger they are, the harder they fall'' approach doesn't seem to hold much weight.

title: Science vs. National Security?
description: An inquiry into possible espionage at Los Alamos National Laboratory stirs concerns that science can sometimes function like a sieve. Page A4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, JOSEPH
description: ROSENFELD-Joseph. After a long illness. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Ilene Silberstein, Ann Mittleberg, Jeffrey Rosenfeld and Davida Rosenfeld. Cherished grandfather of Jacob, Rachel, Aaron, Brian and Sara. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Mark Francis
description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: When Antarctica Slips Into the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Marsden Hartley
description: 'The Berlin Prints'

title: Set for Life, Camby Earns His Keep
description: The Knicks turned over the couch cushions, emptied the ashtrays and found some loose change for Marcus Camby yesterday. It was not big money, not the $70 million maximums his 1996 draft peers have received over the last few weeks. But it was a contract extension nonetheless.

title: In the Heart of Your City
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Spain's Vanguard Designers Turn to Distant Cultures for Inspiration
description: MADRID  What do the American literary icon Paul Bowles, the late Spanish artist Joan Miro and an icy national park called Torre del Paine in southern Chile have in common?

title: Banks Pledge to Help Brazil
description: Banks including Chase Manhattan, Citigroup Inc. and J. P. Morgan & Company pledged yesterday to stop cutting credit lines to Brazil, offering hope the country can stem an outflow of money that has caused its currency to plunge 37 percent since January.

title: Linebacker Gordon Is Re-signed
description: The Jets' best unit, the linebackers, got stronger yesterday when they re-signed Dwayne Gordon. He had been a free agent, but after talking to such clubs as Kansas City and Jacksonville, he returned for a four-year deal.

title: Rutgers to Face Dartmouth In Opening Game Tonight
description: Rutgers may be seeded only third in its region in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament, which starts tonight and tomorrow night on 16 campus sites, but if the Scarlet Knights ever harness their vast resources, they have the potential to get to the regional final or the Final Four.

title: Harry Ford, 80, Poetry Editor With Unerring Ear, Is Dead
description: Harry Ford, whose unerring ear and impeccable taste made him one of the nation's leading poetry editors, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEITMAN, REGGIE
description: LEITMAN-Reggie. We deeply mourn the passing of Reggie Leitman, an ardent Zionist and a longtime community leader. She and her late husband, Aleck, were deeply treasured for their heartfelt generosity and philanthropic efforts. As major benefactors of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, they supported numerous causes and established Endowment Funds to aid undergraduate and graduate students. Through the donation of the Aleck and Reggie Leitman Humanities building, they were instrumental in rebuilding the Mt. Scopus Campus. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, VIRGINIA GARDNER FINCKE
description: WALL-Virginia Gardner Fincke. Born in Boston, MA. October 28, 1905. Died at home March 11, 1999. Widow of Albert Carey Wall. Resident of New York City and Fishers Island, N.Y. She is survived by two daughters, Virginia Fincke Thors, Maria Wall Patterson, and six grandchildren. Funeral services to be held Tuesday, March 16th, 11AM at Saint James' Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 72 St, NY, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Saint James' Church or the Shirley-Eustis House, 33 Shirley St, Boston, MA. 02119 would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with a fashion review of the Italian fall collections in Milan on Tuesday transposed the names of two women at the Versace runway show and misidentified a third. From the left of the picture, they were Mimi Rogers, Juliette Lewis and Marissa Ribisi. Kate Driver was not shown.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS PLUNGES. Natural gas prices tumbled on a report that inventories fell less than expected during a late-season cold spell. In New York, natural gas fell 1.21 cents, to $1.820 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: A New Start for Germany's Government
description: In his brief tenure as Germany's Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine often seemed to be running a government of his own, one that was determined to raise corporate taxes and resist pressures from international capital markets. It was a struggle he was likely to lose in any case, and it is probably best that he chose to resign yesterday, after less than five months on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRAUNSTEIN, IRVING
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Irving. March 12, 1969. 30 years since you went on ahead. Rest in peace.

title: Joseph Makes 41 Saves To Key Toronto Victory
description: MAPLE LEAFS 2, ISLANDERS 1

title: Los Alamos Case Raises Fears of Science as Sieve
description: Science has rapidly evolved from small nationalistic men's clubs into a global mix of men and women collaboratively addressing overriding questions. One result is a growing clash between the creative impulse to share information and the national security need to keep secrets -- including designs of nuclear weapons.

title: Singers Oblivious to a Sinister Backbeat
description: Wreathed in melody and suffused with the nostalgic glow of remembered romance and youthful hope, the fathomless mystery of the Holocaust and Germany's long struggle with its Nazi past weight ''The Harmonists'' with a compelling gravity.

title: Review/Fashion; Down to Earth in Paris
description: Getting into the Chloe show was difficult enough, what with the crush of television cameras, the snagging cascades of vines and one hysterical French fashion editor. But then, there she was. Not a flaming rock star. Not a bosomy actress. Not even Jerry Hall, who's in town.

title: Will East Meet West in Europe? Cost of Union Is a Big Barrier
description: Now that Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary are joining the NATO alliance, perhaps the European Union might be less afraid about letting them in too, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic observed during a recent swing through Western Europe.

title: Shares of Nissan Plunge and Its Credit Rating Follows Suit
description: Shares of Nissan plunged today and the auto maker's credit rating fell after the collapse on Wednesday of its merger talks with DaimlerChrysler A.G. The failure of the negotiations signaled serious problems not only for Nissan but also for many other auto makers.

title: Misguided Chauvinism on Organs
description: The way donated human organs are distributed to patients in this country urgently needs reform. A report released by the Department of Health and Human Services shows wide geographic disparities in waiting times for livers, kidneys and other organs needed to save lives. The median wait for patients with blood type O for a liver transplant in New York City, for example, is 511 days, while the wait a few miles away in New Jersey is 56 days. These irrational differences arise from a system that often requires that organs be used in the area where they are donated even though they might be more urgently needed elsewhere.

title: Population Grows in New York City at Faster Pace
description: New York City's population grew more last year than in any other year since 1986, fueled by a continuing heavy influx of immigrants and a decline in the number of people leaving for other regions, according to new estimates released today by the United States Census Bureau.

title: Chip Maker's Loss Is Below Expectations
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported a narrower-than-expected loss for its third fiscal quarter today, but warned of continuing uncertainty in the personal computer market. National said it expected a similar loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Suffering And Survival
description: ''Inappropriate'' may be the chief euphemism of the 1990's. (Just check how often the adjective appeared in recent Senate testimony.) Of course, it's also the word adults use to describe adolescent behavior that they condemn but would rather not discuss. It is this meaning that a group of high school students has turned on its head in a musical titled, appropriately, ''Inappropriate.''

title: Lawmakers Want I.R.S. Help on Cruise Ships and Tax Laws
description: Saying the United States could be losing billions of dollars each year, two Democratic Congressmen asked the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to estimate how much foreign-owned cruise companies are saving because of tax code provisions that exempt them from income tax and other taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVER, MELANIE JILL
description: LOVER-Melanie Jill. Age 43, on March 10, 1999 at her home in West Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of Jim Schlink, daughter of Vera and sister of Melissa. She will be deeply mourned by her family, her many friends and respected colleagues. Melanie received an undergraduate degree in Music Education from Kean College and an MBA from Adelphi University. Melanie, a Novartis Pharmaceuticals Executive, was Director of Business Development and Licensing with the Consumer Division. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to the North Shore Animal League, Lewy Street, Port Washington, NY 11050 or the West Orange Animal League. Services will be held at 11:30 AM on March 12 at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ. Interment at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J.

title: Brooklyn Man Survives Being Run Over by Train
description: A 36-year-old man was run over yesterday by a Manhattan-bound Q train in Park Slope, Brooklyn, but his only major injury was a broken leg, officials said. The incident took place in the Seventh Avenue subway stop around 7:20 A.M., disrupting morning rush service on the D and Q lines for about an hour, a spokesman for New York City Transit said.

title: Aurora-Chef's Choice Deal
description: Aurora Foods Inc., a producer of frozen and dry grocery products, plans to acquire Sea Coast Foods and its Chef's Choice line of frozen skillet meals for $50 million. Aurora, based in San Francisco, said on Wednesday that Chef's Choice would complement its other frozen-food lines, including Mrs. Paul's seafood, Aunt Jemima breakfast foods and Celeste pizza. Sales of the Chef's Choice line, which consists of 10 items, totaled $57 million in the year ended Jan. 31. The closely held Sea Coast Foods is based in Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, WILLIAM G.
description: AMBROSE-William G., 76. Of Irvington, VA., died March 10, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Priscilla Ambrose; one son, William G. Ambrose Jr., of Poland, ME..; one daughter, Catherine A. Smith, of Fredericksburg, VA.; and three grandchildren. Funeral services will be held 2 P.M., Saturday, March 13, in the Grace Episcopal Church in Kilmarnock, VA, with interment in the Historic Christ Church Cemetery in Irvington, VA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Grace Episcopal Church Memorial Fund or to the Northern Neck Free Health Clinic, Kilmarnock.

title: Jon Schueler
description: ACA Galleries ('Paintings: 1964-1975') and Katharina Rich Perlow ('Paintings: 1976-1983')

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRERAS, ANTONIO
description: CARRERAS-Antonio, age 67 of Holliswood, NY died on March 9, 1999 of a sudden illness. Beloved husband of Carmen, devoted father and father-in-law of Christine, Terri and Alan Wise, loving grandfather of Alexandra and Michael and is also survived by sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Juan Sagues and many nephews and nieces. Fairchild Funeral Home 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY, Friday 6-9pm. Service Saturday 10am at Fairchild. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association 1-800242-8721 will be appreciated.

title: Salt Lake Riddle: Who Knew What?
description: The business and political establishment of Salt Lake City has portrayed the bribe-giving involved in securing the Winter Olympic Games for 2002 as largely the handiwork of two rogue executives. Both of them, along with several board members, have resigned. Virtually everyone else involved in Salt Lake City's bid efforts was supposedly unaware. But documents obtained and interviews conducted by Times reporters strongly suggest otherwise.

title: Cerruti's Cool 'Futuristic Patchworks'
description: PARIS  How much more artsy crafty stuff can fashion take? The fall collections are filled with clothes that are either a riposte to futurism, or are intended, with their handmade effects, to take clothes to another, more artistic dimension.

title: Fighting RJR, Icahn Demands That It Spin Off Nabisco Stake
description: Two days after the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation announced that it was splitting up its food and tobacco businesses, its biggest investor, Carl C. Icahn, said yesterday that he was not happy with the plan and would wage a proxy fight to get the company to create a separate entity from its stake in Nabisco.

title: Democrats Are Ready to Pick Los Angeles for Convention
description: Ending months of speculation, the Democratic National Committee and Los Angeles civic and business leaders are scheduled to announce on Monday that the party will hold its national convention here next year, for the first time since John F. Kennedy was nominated in 1960, city and party officials said today.

title: Editorial Observer; Warming Ourselves Beside Shakespeare's Fire
description: Shakespeare seems to be everywhere. Last summer's Lincoln Center production of ''Twelfth Night,'' starring Helen Hunt, may have begun this current Shakespearean moment, but it has really been caused by the conjunction of Tom Stoppard's and Marc Norman's movie ''Shakespeare in Love'' and Harold Bloom's critical study called ''Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human.''

title: About New York; 'Who Am I?' Artist's Work Is His Answer
description: IF you examine the human face, it has infinite possibilities,'' said William Segal, an artist who has painted his share of portraits. ''With two eyes, ears, nose and a mouth, there is an infinite number of variations. Each one is different.''

title: Lawyers Oppose Racial-Profiling Case Delay
description: The Whitman administration should not be allowed to delay its appeal of a 1996 Gloucester County court ruling that found state troopers had a ''de facto policy of racial profiling,'' lawyers involved in the case argued in court papers filed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKEY, JOSEPH MICHAEL.
description: DICKEY-Joseph Michael. We are deeply saddened and shocked by the tragic loss of our special, dearly beloved friend and associate, Joe Dickey, on March 8, 1999. He was employed at the MTA NYC Transit Headquarters in the capacity of Senior Director, Medical Information Management Services. He was our guide and mentor for many years. We will sorely miss him, his advice and counsel. May the family be comforted knowing that he was a gentleman of innovation and integrity. We have lost a rare and kind person and will be the poorer for this loss, although we will always be the richer for having known him. We express our deepest regrets to his family. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Joe Dickey, distinguished friend and colleague, will be held on Monday, March 15, 6:00 PM, at the Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, New York 10027. Phone 212-870-6700. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Riverside Church's Ministry for Education and Social Justice.

title: There's but One Rule for Footwear Here:Display!: In Japan, the Allure of Feet
description: TOKYO  When the Japanese talk about female sexuality, the one thing everyone agrees on is the allure of feet. For more than a millennium, women's feet and footwear have played a major role in defining femininity. Fifteenth-century samurai warriors picked concubines by their feet, often without bothering to inspect the rest. In 19th-century Edo (old Tokyo), presenting a woman with sandals was the prelude to any sexual relationship. And until about 30 years ago, Kyoto geishas treated favored clients with the sight of their bare feet.

title: Icahn Names His Own Board In Fight for Control of RJR
description: Moving forward with his bid to gain control of RJR Nabisco, Carl C. Icahn named a nine-member board of directors yesterday that includes Mr. Icahn himself and several officials of companies he owns.

title: Oran Journal; Algeria's 'Train of Death' A Bit Safer, God Willing
description: A weak winter sun was rising over the Bay of Algiers as passengers in the capital began boarding Train 1001 for Oran, 285 miles to the west along a route through a region in the Atlas Mountains made dangerous by years of attacks by Islamic rebels.

title: UTILICORP OF KANSAS IN AUSTRALIA UTILITY DEAL
description: The Australian state of Victoria agreed yesterday to sell its Multinet Gas/Ikon Energy natural gas utility to an alliance of Utilicorp United Inc. of Kansas City, Mo., and the Australian financial services group AMP Ltd. for $1.25 billion. Utilicorp and AMP plan to combine Multinet/Ikon with their majority-owned Victoria electricity company, United Energy Ltd., under a common management team. Multinet/Ikon distributes gas to about 587,000 customers mainly in urban areas around Melbourne. The sale of Multinet/Ikon Energy brings total proceeds for Victoria's energy privatization program to $16.8 billion since the first asset sale in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Elizabeth Dole's expected campaign for President misspelled the surname of the most recent well-known woman to have sought the office. She is Shirley Chisholm, not Chisolm.

title: How Green Is Your Gridiron?; Redskins Bid Shows How Costly the Game Has Become
description: Two months ago, when Howard Milstein and Daniel Snyder agreed to buy the Washington Redskins for a stunning $800 million, it looked as if nothing could stand in the way of their dream of owning a National Football League team.

title: Japan Says Its Economy Shrank For Record 5th Straight Quarter
description: Despite a surge in public spending that was meant to help touch off a recovery, the Japanese economy was still shrinking in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government reported today. The decline, at an annual rate of 3.2 percent, was a sharp drop that extended the economic contraction to a record five straight quarters.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page headline on Wednesday about a young man in China who is infected with H.I.V. referred imprecisely to the Chinese health care system and exceeded the findings of the article. While the health system is largely unprepared to deal with the growing number of people infected with the virus that causes AIDS, the report did not characterize the system itself as failing.

title: Market for Cashmere Shawl Expands : The Lure of Pashmina
description: NEW DELHI  The Himalayan mountains are a long way from the world's fashion capitols, but this remote region at the top of the world is the source of one of this season's best-selling accessories. Brilliantly colored, featherweight pashmina shawls have become a fashion sensation, combining today's essential elements of style: comfort and luxury.

title: Oil Is Rising, but Inflation Seems to Be in Check
description: The oil price surge this year, which got another boost yesterday with a new agreement on cutting production, is beginning to sting consumers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL SERVICES INC., Houston, an electrical contractor, said it planned to acquire six electrical service companies with combined annual revenue of $43 million. The names of the companies and the purchase terms were not disclosed.

title: Only Duke Can Find The Basket
description: It was the region that couldn't shoot straight today in a brutal afternoon of substandard basketball at the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. None of the four teams competing shot better than 40 percent and one, Wisconsin, scored only 32 points. Then top-seeded Duke showed up tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Plus section of the sports pages on Thursday about a replacement on the United States basketball team that will try to qualify for the 2000 Olympics reversed two names. It is Jason Kidd who will replace Grant Hill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LOUIS
description: SCHWARTZ-Louis, orthodontist. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Ernest, Lori, Tarno, Joyce, Amy, David and the late Emily. Grandfather of eight. Brother of Rose and Michael and the late Anne and Jenny. Died March 12, 1999. Funeral Sunday March 14, 1999 at 1PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. Shiva at the Schwartz residence. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: Wistful Clinton Dedicates Boyhood Home
description: President Clinton took a sentimental journey to his first boyhood home here today, but a driving rain and a chilly wind dampened the turnout for its dedication as a historic site and cast a dispirited pall over the event.

title: Stefan A. Riesenfeld, 90, Expert on International Law
description: Stefan Albrecht Riesenfeld, an international law expert who taught at the University of California and helped frame the Constitution for West Germany after World War II, died on Feb. 17 at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Geography of Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: CNL GROUP TO MERGE 18 OF ITS PARTNERSHIPS
description: CNL Group Inc. reached an agreement yesterday to merge 18 partnerships it manages and other assets into a $1.5 billion real estate investment trust. The combined company would own or have investments in more than 1,400 fast-food and casual dining restaurant properties operated by Boston Market, Pizza Hut and Jack in the Box, among others, according to Federal filings. Under the agreement with investors in the partnerships, CNL, based in Orlando, Fla., will have its CNL American Properties Fund Inc. acquire 18 other funds, a company that is responsible for the operations of CNL American and the funds, and a concern that provides financing to restaurant operators.

title: Would Vouchers Help Poor Students?
description: To the Editor:

title: Censure of Top Delegate Raises Doubts on Reform
description: The International Olympic Committee censured the most powerful delegate implicated in the Salt Lake City bribery scandal yesterday, but stopped short of recommending his expulsion.

title: Sir Yehudi Menuhin, Violinist, Conductor and Supporter of Charities, Is Dead at 82
description: Sir Yehudi Menuhin, the legendary violinist who came to prominence in his childhood as a virtuoso in velvet knee pants and later became a respected conductor, a dedicated organizer of festivals and schools and an idealistic supporter of hundreds of charities, died yesterday at Martin Luther Hospital in Berlin. He was 82 and lived in London.

title: Giving the Audience Something to Shiver About
description: Mark Jarecke

title: At NATO Event, an Italian Call for Justice
description: Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema, in Poland to mark the expansion of NATO, warned today that Italy may someday want to make some other changes to the Atlantic alliance.

title: Abroad at Home
description: It is the year 2002, and violence has erupted again in Northern Ireland. The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service decides to target for deportation all resident aliens who have endorsed or contributed to Noraid, an American support group for the Irish Republican Army.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST -- Arizona and Washington Bitten by Upset Bug; Miami of Ohio Leader Scores 43
description: Chagrined by his losing performance in the Mid-American Conference tournament final, Miami of Ohio's Wally Szczerbiak came into the Midwest Regional looking to get the sour taste out of his mouth. He did so by keeping the basketball in his own hands.

title: Bridge; A Durable Ace Who Knows The Value of His Spot Cards
description: English cricket fans clap when a batsman reaches a total of 50 runs, a half century, and similar recognition is appropriate in other fields. Earlier this week, Alan Greenberg of Manhattan, known as Ace, completed half a century with the brokerage house of Bear, Stearns & Company, having risen from clerk to chief executive to chairman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell as traders took profits and questions arose about the impact of the resignation of the German Finance Minister on Europe. In New York, the euro was at $1.0901, down from $1.1023.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Accession to NATO is a guarantee that we will never again become powerless victims of any foreign aggression.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, LEONARD B.
description: ALPERT-Leonard B. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, on March 9, at age 68 died, as he wished, quickly and quietly in his own bed at home after a brief heart-related illness. Despite the physical limitations of quadriplegia and part time dependency on a respirator because of polio contracted in 1955, Lennie lived a life full of the realization of his goals and visions. His 26-year career at Sears Roebuck was marked by achievements in the early years of data processing and systems development. In 1980, he and his wife Marie opened Images Art Gallery in Briarcliff Manor. Both at Sears and at Images, he was mentor and friend to so many whose lives were touched by the quiet grace, dignity and incredible sense of humor with which he lived. He died just one day after his childhood hero, Joe DiMaggio, and the words which described the elegance of the athlete could well apply to Lennie. He will live on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched, but mainly in his wife Marie Pantuosco Alpert who has never known where she began and he ended and in his nephew Larry Friedman, his niece Ellen Friedman, their spouses Holly Holmes and Jeff Cowan; great nieces Rachel, Celia and Molly; great nephew Sam and sister and brother-in-law Blanche and Jack Friedman. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: Trade Body Calls Aerospace Subsidy Unfair
description: The World Trade Organization ruled today that subsidy programs in Brazil and Canada unfairly helped aerospace companies such as Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. and Bombardier Inc.

title: AMR Profit-Sharing Plan
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of the No. 2 United States carrier, American Airlines, plans to pay employees a record $341 million through its profit-sharing plan after the company's 1998 earnings climbed and fuel costs fell. The profit-sharing plan at AMR, which has more than 95,000 employees, supplements other benefits such as a 401(k) retirement plan. The airline, based in Fort Worth, started profit-sharing in 1984 and distributed $250 million last year.

title: 'A Soldier of Social Work' Is Recalled
description: About 500 people crowded an Upper East Side church yesterday morning, spilling out onto the sidewalk and street, to mourn Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old graduate student who came to live in New York less than a year ago and was stabbed to death Monday night.

title: Rules on H.I.V. Reporting And Partner Notices Set
description: After months of delay, New York State has moved one step closer to a new H.I.V. reporting and partner notification program by issuing long-awaited regulations. Those regulations appear to close loopholes in the new law, disappointing some advocates for people with H.I.V. who had hoped for a limit on those who would be identified in the state registry.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on March 5 and an article last June 30 about a dispute between the restaurateur Warner LeRoy and the chef David Bouley misstated their business relationship. They were financial partners in the Bouley Bakery in TriBeCa and in other ventures, but not in Mr. LeRoy's effort to renovate and reopen the Russian Tea Room.

title: Pulaski County Journal; A Virginia Town's Boom Is Not All It Hoped For
description: For rural Pulaski County, it was like a dream come true: Volvo, the automobile maker, decided last year to expand its truck-making plant here, a plan that would double the size of the work force to 2,500 and add an estimated 1,200 jobs in related businesses.

title: After Big Fire, Thanking Rescuers and Seeking Shelter
description: Bianca Bakija huddled yesterday with neighbors standing outside their 11-story Upper West Side building, peering up at its charred facade a day after it was damaged in an eight-alarm fire.

title: Knight Wrote the Book That Is Jarvis's Manual
description: The first basketball book St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis bought was Bobby Knight's ''Let's Play Defense.'' At $1.50, Jarvis says, it was the best basketball investment he has made, still informing his strategy more than 30 years later.

title: Chef's Mistake Is Cited in Building Fire
description: The eight alarm blaze that forced the evacuation of an Upper West Side apartment building on Thursday was caused by a careless chef who forgot he had left food cooking in a Mexican restaurant on the first floor, New York City fire officials said yesterday.

title: The Drug War Backfires
description: Almost 70 years after the failure of Prohibition, the much-trumpeted ''war on drugs,'' begun more than a decade ago, has itself hugely misfired. ''We have a failed social policy and it has to be re-evaluated,'' says Barry R. McCaffrey, the four-star general in charge of national drug control policy.

title: Connecticut Outclasses St. Francis
description: Connecticut and St. Francis had one thing in common coming into tonight's first-round game in the Mideast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Jackson Is Said to Be Intrigued by the Nets
description: The presence of Stephon Marbury on the Nets' roster apparently has not solidified the shaky ground on which the beleaguered coach John Calipari is standing. According to an Eastern Conference official, the Nets have been in contact with Phil Jackson, the former Chicago Bulls coach, since the acquisition of Marbury became a possibility earlier this week.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS 1.26 PERCENT. Crude oil rose after a group of major producers agreed to cut oil production by two million barrels a day. Crude oil for April delivery increased 18 cents, to $14.49 a barrel.

title: Title Fight Rouses The Garden's Ghosts
description: ''One thing about the Sweet Science upon which all initiates are in agreement is that it used to be better,'' wrote A. J. Liebling in The New Yorker in 1955.

title: Children and Steroids
description: To the Editor:

title: After Station Fire, Subway Lines Face Months of Turmoil
description: A control room fire on the F and G subway lines in Brooklyn on Thursday night destroyed critical switching equipment, forcing transportation officials to close five stations and disrupt service yesterday for more than 150,000 passengers in several Brooklyn neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about security concerns at Los Alamos National Laboratory misspelled the surname of the director in some copies. He is Dr. John C. Browne, not Brown.

title: Rutgers Romps; Florida Lets One Get Away
description: Rutgers did it the easy way, Arizona the hard way, as they won first-round games tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: College Athletes Should Study First, Play Later; Students in Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Longtime Steeler Is Heading West
description: The free-agent safety Darren Perry, who started 110 games through his six-year career in Pittsburgh, has signed a two-year contract to play for the San Diego Chargers.

title: Still at War, 'New Fiction' Still Has A Champion
description: William H. Gass is sitting in his living room, sipping cognac, when he makes an announcement: He will never again write a negative book review. This is the same William H. Gass who said he stopped reading Tom Wolfe in 1981 because ''From Bauhaus to Our House'' ''could have been written by Prince Charles''; the same William H. Gass who said the Pulitzer Prize for fiction ''takes dead aim at mediocrity and almost never misses.''

title: G.O.P. Picks Its Fight
description: As they seek their way after impeachment, Congressional Republicans have gone on the offensive against President Clinton on national security and foreign policy, while taking stands on Social Security and education that they hope will allow them to make some claim to these popular domestic concerns.

title: N.Y.U. Women In Region Final
description: New York University moved a step closer last night to reclaiming the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III women's basketball title it relinquished last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, LEE
description: JACOBS-Lee. Six years, 2190 days, 52,560 hours-each one missing you. Love Aimee and famil

title: Fighter Pilot Charges Discrimination by Peers
description: A lawsuit charges that two fighter pilots for the New Jersey Air National Guard were subjected to racial and sexual discrimination by their peers on the job and that their superiors did nothing about it.

title: GEOSCIENCE STOCK DOWN AS PURCHASE IS RECONSIDERED
description: Shares of the Geoscience Corporation, which makes seismic systems used to find oil and gas reserves, fell 21 percent yesterday after Core Laboratories N.V. said it was reconsidering its planned purchase of the company. The shares fell $2.125, to $7.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares have fallen steadily since reaching $16.75 on Jan. 19, the day that Core Laboratories, which specializes in tracking underground oil flows, agreed to buy Geoscience. The price at that time was put at $181 million in cash and stock. Late on Thursday, the Amsterdam-based Core Laboratories said it believed representations and warranties made by Geoscience ''are not true.'' Geoscience officials could not be reached for comment. The company is 80 percent-owned by the Tech-Sym Corporation.

title: Would Vouchers Help Poor Students?; No Hypocrisy Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZIA, VALENTINO D.B., M.D.
description: MAZZIA-Valentino D.B., M.D. and J.D. Beloved and devoted husband of Rosana. Dear brother of Alex and the late Lloret. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Monday, at 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Trip Full of Memories In Dominican Republic
description: It just felt natural, Felipe Alou said this afternoon, for him to be sitting again in the freshly painted red of the manager's office of los Leones de Escogido.

title: Three Ring, a Filly, Is Scratched
description: The filly Three Ring will be scratched from today's Florida Derby, her trainer said yesterday, and will forgo any chance of becoming the first filly to win the race, Florida's most important prep for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Missing Lawyer Declared Fugitive and Accused of Theft
description: F. Mac Buckley, the Connecticut lawyer who vanished on his way to court on March 1, is no longer simply missing. Tonight, he became a fugitive when the authorities issued a warrant charging him with embezzling money from two of his clients after forging their signatures.

title: Reading Test for 2d Graders Is Canceled After Protests
description: New York City's Board of Education has canceled a citywide reading test for second graders after a barrage of objections from parents and principals who complained that children were already being tested too much, school officials said.

title: Grotesque Bodies Sheltering Puzzled and Alienated Souls
description: A bleak but imaginatively realized landscape inhabited by alienated grotesques occupies the stage of the New Victory Theater these days.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: College Athletes Should Study First, Play Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMAGGIO, JOE
description: DiMaggio-Joe. The officers, Board of Governors and members of the Columbus Citizens Foundation deeply mourn the loss of our honorary member, Joe DiMaggio. He brought a sense of pride to the Italian American community at a time when being an Italian American was not always easy. He offered hope and joy to many. The quiet dignity and grace in which he lived his life was an inspiration to us all. We say farewell to a legendary Italian American athlete who served as Grand Marshall of the Columbus Day Parade. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family for a loss that is felt by many. Hon. Charles A. Gargano, President Columbus Citizens Foundation

title: Washington Talk; Clintons' Bond and the Beltway Buzz
description: In a court of law, the evidence would have been considered laughably circumstantial. But in a city primed for scandal and hooked on scuttlebutt, it inevitably took on the cast of something significant, or at least something worth chattering about.

title: U.S. Raid Over Tokyo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, FLORENCE (NEE LIEBERMAN).
description: BLUM-Florence (nee Lieberman). On March 11, 1999 at the age of 95. Adored wife of the late Dr. Arthur A. Blum. Beloved mother of Francine Weil and Carole Blum. Loving sister of Augusta Irving. Cherished grandmother of Amy Weil. Loving grandmotherin-law to Aravinda deSilva. Services will be held Sunday, March 14th, 12:30PM at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Serena Williams Reaches Final
description: With big sister on the singles sidelines, little sister continued to bask in the limelight yesterday as 17-year-old Serena Williams, apparently on a take-no-prisoners mission to follow Venus into the top five, bullied her way into the final of the Evert Cup with a 7-5, 6-0 victory over 12th-seeded Sandrine Testud of France.

title: On the Internet, Bigger Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Shoots 3 and Kills Self
description: A dispute in Queens ended in gunfire last night when one man shot three people and then killed himself, the police said. The shooting, which took place at 56-43 Waldron Street in the Corona section, occurred at 9:15 P.M., the police said. The dead man was identified as Sheldon Edwards, 26. The police did not provide the names of the other victims last night.

title: Cincinnati to Face Temple After Both Teams Cruise
description: Cincinnati Coach Bob Huggins finds his team as intriguing as everyone else does.

title: Setting a Modern Standard for the Lute
description: There is something endearing about the contradictions embodied in the lute. Its voice is small and personal, and listeners used to hearing it on recordings cranked up to at least harpsichord volume are surprised at its delicacy when they encounter it in the concert hall. Yet it has a body of virtuosic literature that can both dazzle and move listeners. In terms of sheer physical layout, it is an inefficient instrument for counterpoint, which demands an independence of line difficult to achieve when two fingers are required to play each note (one to stop the string on the fretboard, one to pluck it). Its most enduring repertory, though, is manifestly and demandingly contrapuntal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, VIRGINIA GARDNER FINCKE.
description: WALL-Virginia Gardner Fincke. Born in Boston, MA. October 28, 1905. Died at home March 11, 1999. Widow of Albert Carey Wall. Resident of New York City and Fishers Island, N.Y. She is survived by two daughters, Virginia Fincke Thors, Maria Wall Patterson, and six grandchildren. Funeral services to be held Tuesday, March 16th, 11AM at Saint James' Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 72 St, NY, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Saint James' Church or the Shirley-Eustis House, 33 Shirley St, Boston, MA. 02119 would be appreciated.

title: DuPont Having Discussions With Pioneer
description: Pioneer Hi-Bred International, the world's largest producer of seed corn, and the DuPont Company announced yesterday that they were discussing a possible combination, raising the prospect of a bidding war in the agriculture industry.

title: Book to Help Promote Tourist Sites for Blacks
description: State commerce officials unveiled a $500,000 plan yesterday to attract black tourists to New Jersey by publishing and promoting a guidebook that lists several historic sites of interest to black travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENUHIN, YEHUDI
description: MENUHIN-Yehudi. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of violinist Yehudi Menuhin, who performed at the Hall more than 100 times since his 1927 debut on its stage at age 11. He was a great artist who made a unique mark in the world of music, and in the world in which he lived. Yehudi Menuhin had the respect and affection of people all over the world, and we join in celebrating his life, and send his wife and his family our deepest condolences. Isaac Stern, Pres. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman

title: Holyfield Planning to Make Lewis Believe in Him, Too
description: Evander Holyfield has spent a good portion of his career making believers of those who doubt his ability. They said he would never successfully move up from cruiserweight to heavyweight. Now, people argue whether he belongs among the top 10 heavyweights in history.

title: Pregnant and Still Looking Swell : A Woman's World :From Power Dressing to Maternity Chic
description: NEW YORK  About two years ago, Liz Steinberg Lange was designing regular clothes for women when many of her friends started getting pregnant and complaining that they had nothing fashionable to wear. So Lange, herself newly married and thinking about having a baby, started looking around at the maternity market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, JAY
description: KENNY-Jay. A man respected and beloved by all those who knew him. Though his family and friends mourn that he left us so young, we know he lived life to the fullest. His love of theater and the arts and his desire to share this love with others were hallmarks of his grace and his style and his passion for life. We honor Jay's memory and give our most heartfelt condolences to his family. George K. Cooney The Screen Gems Family

title: Even Mimics Get the Blues
description: The guitarist and singer Jonny Lang sauntered onto the Hammerstein Ballroom stage on Wednesday night in a tank top that showed off the new tattoo he recently acquired on his 18th birthday. He looked like one of the many golden youths who populate Hollywood these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKUS, DAVID
description: HENKUS-David. On March 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Lorraine and Jeffrey Goldstein and Susan and Ira Henkus. Loving grandfather of Deanna, Lisa, Kevin, Gary and Scott. Dear brother of Pearl, Irving, Lillian and the late Morris. Services 10am Sunday at Gutterman Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Ads Attack Pataki's Plan On Hospitals
description: Attacking Gov. George E. Pataki directly for the first time in four years, hospitals and health care workers began a broadcast campaign today asserting that the Governor's proposed budget cuts would have dire consequences for health care, including hospital closings.

title: Ex-Police Officer Sentenced for Beatings
description: A former Elizabeth police officer was sentenced yesterday to three years of probation and 30 days in a work release program for beating an elderly brother and sister for no apparent reason other than that he was drunk, officials said.

title: Paris's Street Wear for Street Ware
description: PARIS  Smooth traffic isn't a particularly Parisian quality. The streets here function like a free zone where the only law that pedestrians and motorists respect seems to be: Cut in first or be prepared to suffer the consequences. All the while, the police manage to have their heads turned the other way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, PAAR, JUDITH
description: BRILL-PAAR-Judith. Age 63. Died March 12, 1999. Loving wife of Bill. Sister to Michael. Mother of Jason and Adam. Grandmother to Spencer, Leo and Rachel. Mother-inlaw to Gail and Susan. Aunt to Melissa and Brandon. A great lover of life, laughter, her friends and family, she will be deeply missed. Graveside service Sunday, 1PM at Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Info: 212-873-3500. Donations to Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Sports of The Times; What's With Holyfield's Prediction?
description: WHEN the bell rings, Evander Holyfield, shorter by 3 inches and outweighed by 31 pounds, is expected to try to move inside in order to smother Lennox Lewis's longer reach.

title: Microsoft to Reorganize Into 4 New Groups
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it would soon announce a reorganization, creating four groups based on customer service instead of the current three based on technology.

title: Knicks Sink Almost as Low as They Can Go
description: The Knicks had been able to hide their character flaws, their casual attitude and cardboard pride. They had been able to keep their dark secret to themselves.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Some Major Oil Producers Agree to Cut Production

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: AMAZON.WHAT
description: It takes more than the click of a mouse to navigate a $20 billion company that has never made a dime. Amazon.com urges employees to focus on the customers' needs, not on the stock price. A report by Peter de Jonge in The Times Magazine.

title: Amid Criticism From Factions, Episcopalian Bishop Resigns
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New Jersey announced his resignation yesterday, bringing to an end a four-year tenure that was marked by unprecedented turmoil.

title: A Russian Troupe Makes War Horses Look Rested
description: The Saint-Petersburg Ballet

title: Facing Shortage, Builders And Labor Court Workers
description: Reared in the poverty of a bleak housing project, Arthur Murray, 29, had kicked around for years with two boyhood pals -- ''Now one's dead and one's in prison'' -- before finding his way to the carpenter's union hall. Now an apprentice, he is headed toward a $27-an-hour job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, SHELDON
description: ROSENBLATT-Sheldon. Of Bayswater, Queens County, on March 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara Friedman Rosenblatt. Devoted father of Lois (Wayne). Adored grandfather of Jonathan and Steven. He was a lifelong resident of the Rockaway Penninsula. He was a graduate of St. John's Law School and was a practicing attorney in Rockaway for fifty years. Former N.Y.S. Deputy Secretary of State and General Council to the Department of State. He served in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He held the post of Commander in Jewish War Veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, and American Legion. He was the President of Congregation Daarchay Noam (Bayswater Jewish Center) for the past four years. Services Sunday, March 14, 11:00 AM at Bayswater Jewish Center, 2355 Healy Avenue, Bayswater, NY. Donations in his memory to Bayswater Jewish Center would be greatly appreciated.

title: Baruch College Student From Brooklyn Is Missing
description: The police are searching for a 19-year-old student at Baruch College who set off for school Monday and never returned home.

title: Ligament Sidelines Ligtenberg
description: Atlanta Braves closer Kerry Ligtenberg has a partly torn ligament in his right elbow and will be sidelined for at least one month and possibly the entire season.

title: Caterpillar Says Its Profits Will Be Below Expectations
description: Citing a sales slowdown in Latin America and stiff competition in North America, Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and earthmoving equipment, warned today that its first-quarter profits would be far below expectations. The news caused the company's stock to tumble 12.2 percent, pulling down the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: City Hall Notes; Council Holds Its Parking Perks to Be Self-Evident
description: Of the many issues facing the city today, one has few rivals in its ability to provoke passionate debate between the Giuliani administration and the City Council. But before anyone cites the battle as a reflection of democracy in action, consider the subject:

title: Ambivalence Over Voucher Concept; In Southeastern Queens, Parents Fear Impact on Public Schools
description: A little after 8 every weekday morning, Joseph R. Francisse commits an act both mundane and maddening. He sends his two sons off to Public School 136 in southeastern Queens.

title: The Void That Even the Safest College Can't Fill
description: Some unfortunate things happened during my freshman year of college. A friend of mine was date-raped by an angelic-looking preppy boy who happened to be a nasty drunk. On the night this happened, my friend had imbibed copious amounts of alcohol, smoked some pot, snorted some coke and topped off this cocktail with a hit of Ecstasy.

title: Inventors of Paper Clips and Tall Tales
description: Capping a week that illuminated whole new dimensions to the talents and accomplishments of this city's most powerful politicians, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, revealed today that he was the inventor of the modern paper clip.

title: Kosovo Rebels Act to Accept Peace Accord
description: Kosovo Liberation Army leaders decided today to accept a European-sponsored peace plan and directed the leader of the ethnic Albanian delegation to sign the accord ahead of peace talks that are planned to resume on Monday in Paris.

title: Pick a 'Seagull' to Touch The Heart or the Head
description: Konstantin, author of the play-within-the-play in Chekhov's ''Seagull,'' would probably be simpatico with an experimental Off Off Broadway theater company like Target Margin. ''We need new forms!,'' after all, is the rallying cry of his artistic Russian soul. His mother, the actress Madame Arkadina, on the other hand, would no doubt prefer the more conservative approach to the classics favored by the Pearl Theater Company. She is, of course, theater aristocracy, a practitioner from the old school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENCRANZ, MADGE
description: BLUMENCRANZ - Madge. On March 10, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Richard and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Elizabeth, Carol Shaye and Jill Glickman. title: Bankers Trust Investigation Narrows Focus
description: Federal authorities investigating corruption at the Bankers Trust Corporation are focusing on the activities of B. J. Kingdon, who formerly ran one of the bank's largest businesses and sat on its 12-member operating committee, according to lawyers and Bankers Trust employees involved in the inquiry.

title: To Reflect the City They Serve
description: The rich diversity of New York City is sadly missing in the ranks of its police force. A survey this week by The Times shows that the New York Police Department, 67 percent of whose officers are white in a city that is only 43 percent white, is far behind most large metropolitan areas in its efforts to attract, retain and promote nonwhite officers.

title: Marbury Returns Home Happier and Wealthier
description: Stephon Marbury is not your typical mama's boy. He wears the baggy jeans and shirts of the hip-hop generation, large diamond stud earrings, and, when on the basketball court, a scowl that bespeaks fearlessness.

description: The Japanese Government sent the clearest signal to date today that it would not allow the struggling Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, to collapse.

title: U.S. Maps Become Legal Issue in Alpine Cable Accident
description: More than a year after a Marine Corps jet hit an alpine gondola cable that was not on the crew's map, the Pentagon has not updated its maps.

description: When more than a hundred mathematicians from around the world gathered at the Institute for Advanced Studies here recently to discuss the work of the French-born mathematician Andre Weil, no one even mentioned his one achievement that has affected tens of thousands of people, most of whom have never heard of him.

title: The City Calls It Hazardous Housing, but the Tenants Call It Home
description: Gary R. Hyink trembles when he remembers how disoriented he felt when police officers came to his door and told him that he had 30 minutes to gather up his things because they were closing down the boardinghouse in Rockaway Park, Queens, where he lived.

Gray on May 29th at 11:00 A.M., at the Church of the Holy Spirit, Orleans, MA.

title: Robert Postel, 59, Councilman Who Ran for New York Mayor
description: Robert I. Postel, a maverick Democratic New York City Councilman in the early 1970's who conducted a brief, unsuccessful campaign for mayor, died on March 6 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

title: German Stock Market Soars As Leftist Fiscal Chief Quits
description: One day after the abrupt resignation of Germany's most powerful left-wing political boss, German financial markets soared in euphoria today while Chancellor Gerhard Schroder struggled to keep his five-month-old Government from melting down.

description: It began in 1995 as a simple racketeering and extortion indictment whose defendants included two reputed mob leaders long infamous in Irish-dominated South Boston: James Bulger and Stephen Flemmi.

title: Explorers Along Modernist Frontiers
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic, here for two weekend concerts, sent as its avant-garde, well, the avant-garde. Thursday night's forerunner was the Los Angeles Philharmonic New Music Group, a concept that for us New Yorkers must seem exotic. A resident philharmonic society that systematically explores music of its time? What will they think of next?

title: Oil Producers Agree to Trim Output to Help Bolster Prices
description: Hoping to capitalize on its modest success in stabilizing world oil prices, a coalition of major oil producers announced yesterday that it had agreed to cut production by another two million barrels a day, a move that kept crude oil prices heading upward.

description: PARIS  The absence of a designer label is only the first hint of the pleasures and polemics that come with the most controversial current fashion accessory: the shatoosh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIBACH, AARON
description: MEIBACH-Aaron. On March 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Freda (recently deceased). Loving father of Ina Lea Meibach, Doris Wallace (Martin) and Judy Meibach. A warm, gentle man, he gave joy to all with his kindness, humility, humor and sense of family. His smile lit up a room. As co-caterer of the Burnside Manor, he enhanced the simchas of many. In retirement, he relished his work as a volunteer for the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. A man of principle, he lived his Judaism in prayer and good deeds. Service Sunday, March 14th at 10AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Tenant Program Fund, 5961 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYAO, BIDU
description: SAYAO-Bidu. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of one of our greatest and most beloved artists, soprano Bidu Sayao. Her debut here in 1937 in the title role of Massenet's ''Manon'' began a love affair with the New York public which was enchanted by this small, beautiful woman with an unusually sweet voice and elegant stage demeanor. She went on to sing 236 performances of twelve roles with the Met. Her most frequent roles were her touching Mimi in Puccini's ''La Boheme,'' and her graceful Susanna in Mozart's ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' Her ability to incarnate youthful, fragile and vulnerable characters while singing with a consistently beautiful tone and great musicality was unique. As charming offstage as she was on-stage, Ms. Sayao was held in the highest esteem by her colleagues and friends in the opera house. She continued to be a strong supporter of the Met after her retirement, and in 1983 became a Member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, a position she held until her death. We offer our sincere condolences to her family and to her many devoted friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: From Wealthy Hesse, an Ally of Business
description: Germany's former Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, was a blustery bumptious political boss who managed to provoke outrage among bankers and business leaders almost daily.

title: Peace Equations in Kosovo
description: When negotiations on Kosovo resume in France on Monday, Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader, may find himself isolated in his opposition to peace. The House of Representatives voted on Thursday to support sending American peacekeeping troops to enforce a settlement in Kosovo, removing any doubt about American participation. Yesterday the commanders of the ethnic Albanian guerrillas wisely agreed to accept the peace plan proposed by Washington, its European allies and Russia. The ethnic Albanians are expected to sign the deal this weekend. If they do, Mr. Milosevic's refusal to allow international peacekeepers into Kosovo will be the only remaining obstacle. It is crucial that the countries supervising the peace talks remain united, and that NATO sustain its resolve to use force, if necessary, to get Mr. Milosevic to sign a deal.

title: Herman Weisman, 95, Leader in Zionist Groups
description: Herman L. Weisman, a lawyer who was prominent in American Zionist organizations, died on Sunday at the Hospice of Palm Beach County, Fla. He was 95 and lived in Palm Beach County.

title: For Torre, His Office Awaits
description: The door to Joe Torre's office is shut, his chair unoccupied, and Don Zimmer, the Yankees' interim manager, has no intention of changing that before Torre returns from his treatment for prostate cancer.

title: CAMBREX BUYS IROTEC LABORATORIES OF IRELAND
description: The Cambrex Corporation, based in East Rutherford, N.J., said yesterday that it had bought the drug-ingredients maker Irotec Laboratories Ltd. of Ireland for $40 million and would use the purchase to supply Germany's second-biggest generic drug company. Cambrex, which makes specialty chemicals used in pharmaceuticals, herbicides, and biotechnology applications, had 1998 sales of $441 million, while the closely held Irotec had sales of $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, DOROTHY
description: RUBY-Dorothy. Of Lakewood, New Jersey on March 5, 1999. Wife of the late William C. Ruby. Also survived by a daughter and son-inlaw Diane R. and William H. Egley of Stamford, CT. Ruby & two nephews, Richard and Walter, all of Neptune, NJ. A memorial service was conducted Friday, March 12th, 1999 at Redeemer Lutheran Church, Manchester Township, New Jersey.

title: An Earlier China Spy Case Points Up Post-Cold War Ambiguities
description: Within two weeks, Peter H. Lee, a Taiwan-born physicist who once worked at the nuclear weapons laboratory here, will complete a one-year sentence to a halfway house in California, winding up a murky case that speaks of the ambiguities surrounding resurfaced suspicions of Chinese espionage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWLON, PAUL J.
description: NEWLON-Paul J. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison express profound sorrow at the passing of Paul J. Newlon. Paul was our former partner and beloved friend, and will long be remembered for his many contributions. He was a resident of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his wife Suzanne, his daughter Joan Radner, his stepchildren Joan Alexander, Geoffrey Dodge and James Mapes Dodge III and to all the other members of his family.
