description: John MacLean sounded as if he were describing a fireworks display.

title: Religion Journal; A Professor in Nanjing Takes Up Jewish Studies
description: In a time when advances in communication and an increase in political freedom have eroded international boundaries, scholars have an ever-greater opportunity for closer attention to religions and places that might once have seemed vastly distant.

title: 5 Airlines Raise Fares; Others Hold Off
description: Five of the country's major airlines raised their fares Thursday and yesterday, though the increase could be short-lived if three other carriers do not match them.

title: HALART TO ACQUIRE TRAK AUTO FOR $53.2 MILLION
description: The Trak Auto Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired by the privately held Halart L.L.C. for $9 a share, or $53.2 million. The Michigan-based Halart, controlled by a former Exide Corporation chief executive, Arthur M. Hawkins, intends to combine Trak Auto with other auto parts companies it is seeking to acquire. Trak Auto, based in Landover, Md., operates 175 auto parts retail stores in five metropolitan areas in the East and Midwest. It had revenue of $169.6 million in the nine months ended Oct. 31. The Dart Group Corporation, a unit of Richfood Holdings Inc. and majority stockholder of Trak Auto, has agreed to vote its 67.1 percent ownership stake in favor of the proposed merger.

title: Two Prominent Law Firms Call Off a Proposed Merger
description: The prominent New York law firms of White & Case and Brown & Wood called off their proposed merger yesterday after at least four months of talks, saying the move was ''impractical.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELL, EUGENE ABRAHAM.
description: SCHNELL-Eugene Abraham. A resident of Longboat Key, FL., formerly of New York City and Tyringham, MA, died March 8 in Sarasota. He was born May 2, 1922 in New York City. Survivors include his wife Ina Spelke, and three children who reside in New York City, a son Eric, and two daughters Vicki S. Rosen and Nancy from a previous marriage; a sister Millicent Golding of Sun City, AZ; a brother Seymour Schnell, & five nieces & nephews, all of New York City. Services in Sarasota were private. Memorial donations may be made to the Robert S. Peabody Museum of Archaeology, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810, or to the Florida West Coast Symphony, 709 North Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34236.

description: Raymond L. Flynn, former Mayor of Boston and later Ambassador to the Vatican, said yesterday that he would become head of a national Roman Catholic political organization that was founded as a branch of the conservative Christian Coalition.

title: City-Run Hospitals Face Job Cuts and Lean Times
description: In a further indication that the growth of managed care among Medicaid patients will put new stress on New York City's public hospitals, the chief executive of the hospital system said yesterday that it would probably run a deficit of $60 million in the next fiscal year.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Let Administrators Off the Hook When Things Go Wrong
description: COACHES and players had finished their games Thursday and hurried back to their hotels to watch recaps of the day's upsets in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Detroit upset U.C.L.A.; Weber State upset North Carolina; Gonzaga upset Minnesota.

title: Mock Invasion Takes a Detour Above Sea Life
description: Giving in to the concerns for the safety of whales and other marine life, the Marine Corps has called off a mock assault by hovercraft on Monterey Bay.

title: Ecuador, Swept by Inflation and Unrest, Brakes the Economy
description: After a two-day strike that paralyzed commerce in Ecuador and sparked clashes between security forces and demonstrators, Ecuadoreans awoke today to find gasoline prices more than doubled, many of their bank accounts frozen and the country's politics still in turmoil.

title: El Paso Energy Is Near Deal To Buy Sonat for $3.3 Billion
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation, a natural gas pipeline operator, is expected to announce as early as Monday that it is buying a rival, Sonat Inc., people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Bidu Sayao, 94, Star Soprano of the 30's and 40's, Dies
description: Bidu Sayao, a Brazilian soprano whose gossamer voice and vivacious personality made her one of the most popular stars of the Metropolitan Opera from the late 1930's through the 40's, died yesterday at Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Rockport, Me. She was 94 and lived in Lincolnville, Me.

title: SAFESKIN SHARES RETREAT ON LOWER EARNINGS OUTLOOK
description: The shares of the Safeskin Corporation fell 41 percent after the company, the No. 1 United States maker of disposable latex examination gloves, said late on Thursday that its first-quarter earnings will be well below analysts' expectations. The shares of Safeskin fell $6.28125, to $8.96875, in Nasdaq trading of 24.7 million shares. The San Diego-based company said yesterday that it will would have earnings of 1 cent to 2 cents in the quarter ending on March 31. It had been expected to earn 27 cents, the average estimate of six analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation.

title: A Proud but Pensive Moment in Warsaw
description: In what will hardly be the last adaptation the Polish military will have to make, an honor guard performed an unusual flag-raising ceremony after dark here tonight to mark the moment that Poland became a member of NATO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, NATHAN JOSEPH, D.D.S.
description: LIPKIN-Nathan Joseph, D.D.S. 75. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of New York. Passed away March 10, 1999. Beloved husband Gladys. Loving father of Harriet (Chris Sautter), Alan (Barbara) and Rebecca. Dear brother of Shirley Rosenthal. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Sam and Molly Lipkin, Josh and Stephanie Sautter. Graduate of Johns Hopkins University and the New York University School of Dentistry and its Graduate Orthodontic course. He died peacefully and painlessly. His life will be celebrated in a memorial service at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1921 Pembroke Rd., Hollywood FL. 954-921-7200, Friday, March 12, 1999 at 2PM. Graveside services will take place on Sunday, March 14, 1999 at 1PM at Beth David Cemetery on Elmont Rd in Elmont, Long Island. Shiva will be at the Lipkin residence in Hollywood, FL starting Monday, March 15, 1999.

description: Vladimir Fedorovich Titov is not bitter. True, he was chairman of the department of Marxist-Leninist philosophy at the prestigious Moscow State University when the faculty voted in 1991, as he put it, to ''liquidate completely'' his department.

description: I was speeding north through the Chicago Loop in a television truck when the assignment editor squawked from the radio: ''Minicam Two, you've got to head back down to Area Two immediately. They're going to walk the guy in five minutes!''

Devoted brother to Joan Hersh and brothers-in-law Michael Hersh, B.B. Goldstein, Charles Goldstein, adored uncle to Tom, Jane, Buck, John, Patrick and Amy. A lover of life. All who knew him were touched by his warmth and sparkle. A light is out. We will not see another like him.

description: DENERSTEIN-Loretta B. Today on her birthday we remember with love her sweet smile, her unconditional love and her unending devotion to us, her children and grandchildren. She was a remarkable woman. We miss her so. Susan and Harris

title: Cambodia Spurns U.N. Plan For Khmer Rouge Tribunal
description: After months of wavering, Cambodia yesterday officially rejected United Nations recommendations to convene a tribunal to try surviving senior Khmer Rouge leaders, seeming to kill any chance of an international court.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST -- Arizona and Washington Bitten by Upset Bug; Oklahoma Wins by a Toe and a Tip
description: Had Michael Wright, Arizona's outstanding freshman forward, been wearing something smaller than a size 14 shoe, the Wildcats might well have advanced past the first round of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Instead, the fourth-seeded Wildcats were upset today, 61-60, by 13th-seeded Oklahoma, the last at-large team chosen for the 64-team tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, GERALDINE L.
description: JAFFE-Geraldine L. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Geraldine L. Jaffe, associated with The Times from 1966 until retiring in 1994.

title: Barbara Zeifer and Christopher Luis
description: AFTER one divorce and many broken hearts, Dr. Barbara Zeifer decided to call Denise Winston, a professional matchmaker, for help. ''I was so upset I didn't know what to do,'' said Dr. Zeifer, who is 42 and a diagnostic radiologist in New York. ''I'd exhausted all of my friends. I found myself asking strangers at work, 'Oh, do you know anyone?' People would look at me and say, 'I can't even find a good secretary, let alone someone for you to go out with.' ''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Danbury, Conn.; Bustling, but Studded With Lakes, Ponds
description: THIS 315-year-old city has a history that could well have inspired Connecticut's informal motto -- ''the land of steady habits.'' With unwavering resolve it routed a British invasion during the Revolutionary War, rebounded from the demise of its major industry -- hat-making -- and survived the death in 1981 of its beloved 112-year-old Great Danbury Fair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERCHANT, COLONEL (RET.) MARVIN HATFIELD
description: MERCHANT-Colonel (Ret.) Marvin Hatfield. Died Saturday, March 6, 1999, at the University of Virginia Medical Center. Born September 29, 1916, at Ft. Riley, KS, he was the son of the late Colonel (Ret.) Berkeley Thorne Merchant and Helen Hatfield Merchant. He was predeceased by his wife Clelia Calhoun Merchant. Colonel Merchant was a 1940 graduate of the United States Military Academy, West Point. During his 28 years of active service, Colonel Merchant served with distinction in World War II and the Vietnam conflict. He was a member of the Albemarle Historical Society and St. Paul's Church, Ivy. Survivors include a daughter, Crede Merchant Prashker of NYC; two sons Berkeley Thorne Merchant of Portland, OR, and Christopher Calhoun Hatfield Merchant of Albuquerque, NM, and one grandchild Clair Merchant of Albuquerque, NM. A memorial service will be at 1:30 PM, Saturday, March 20, 1999, at St. Paul's Church, Ivy, VA, with the Rev. Miller Hunter officiating. A graveside service will be at 1 PM, Friday, April 2, 1999, at Arlington National Cemetery. The family request that memorial donations be made to Charlottesville-Albemarle Rescue Squad, PO Box 160, Charlottesville, VA 22907. For information call Hill and Wood Funeral Service, 804-296-6148.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDDLESTON, ALMA ROBINSON
description: HUDDLESTON-Alma Robinson. On February 28, 1999 in her 90th year in Gadsden, AL; formerly of NYC. Widow of William E. Huddleston, Jr., of Clanton and Tuskegee, AL. Loving mother of twin daughters, Patricia Byrd Huddleston, wife of the Hon. James Douglas Martin, of Gadsden, AL and the late Annette Knowles Huddleston, wife of Timothy Field Beard of Roxbury, CT. Grandmother of three, great-grandmother of two.

title: Constance Cooke and John Wingate
description: Contance Blandy Cooke, a former library director and museum president, was married on Friday evening to John Barnum Wingate, the Commissioner of Social Services for Suffolk County in Ronkonkoma, N.Y. The Rev. Nancy R. Ledger, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Penn Club in Manhattan.

title: Body of Missing Student Is Discovered in Search of Shaftway
description: The body of a 19-year-old Baruch College student was discovered Friday night inside a trash-filled shaftway at the campus, four days after a fellow student had reported seeing a woman leap from an overhead window , the police said yesterday.

title: A Couple Who Play Together...
description: They're excellent musically, technically and in duo perforance. Yet saying those things first is proably jumping the gun, a practice that David Finckel and Wu Han have consistently avoided. The stable growth of their achievements is part of their steady climb over many years: his position as a cellist in the superb Emerson String Quartet, her recital career, their 14-year marriage, their joint direction of the annual Summerfest in La Jolla Calif., and their creation of a record company.

title: Ideas & Trends: Talking Heads; The Silent Celebrity and the Quotable Recluse
description: THE interview setting -- Sunday morning in a sprawling, empty movie studio outside London -- was sepulchral, as vast and quiet as Hal the computer's trans-galactic homicide scene in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' And the reclusive film director Stanley Kubrick was formidable, indeed, when he finally entered a dimly lit office to be interviewed, brandishing his wariness of celebrity before the lone questioner.

title: Putting Evolution On Fast-Forward
description: The corporate chief who has created more shareholder value ($300 billion plus) than anyone not currently accused of monopolistic practices acknowledged in a New York appearance last week that he is a ''Neanderthal'' when it comes to computers.

description: SEVRES -- BABYLONE

title: A Goodbye To the Weight Of Leveraging
description: WHEN RJR Nabisco Holdings' plan to split itself into two companies made headlines last week, a notorious chapter in the history of corporate restructuring came closer to an end. But no one waxed nostalgic for the good old 1980's.

title: A Try-at-Home Restaurant Trick for Presenting Soup in Style
description: SOUP is back in style. That staple of the home-cooked dinner has become popular enough to have inspired chains of takeout shops that serve little else. And even fine restaurants are getting into the act.

title: Dangerous or Camp, Proaganda Goes Into Reruns
description: MAJOR JAN ZEMAN was a Czech Communist Columbo, Peter Falk in immaculately pressed fatigues, a savvy television cop whose tough questions and dogged detective work unraveled the greatest mysteries of the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic and always got the party's man.

title: BACKTALK; A Chance for Cubans to See Major Leaguers
description: With the Baltimore Orioles bound for Havana to play against Cuba's best at the end of this month, I found myself thinking of two men. Both are Cuban. Both are huge baseball fans.

title: CASELOAD FORCING TWO-LEVEL SYSTEM FOR U.S. APPEALS
description: A crushing load of cases is forcing a reshaping of the Federal appeals courts, creating a two-level justice system in which tens of thousands of appeals receive limited reviews, judges and legal scholars say.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- The Ethicist; Pity for the Plagiarist
description: 'A college student called last week to say his ''friend'' had visited my Web page, lifted something I wrote and turned it in as her own work. Suspicious, her professor plans to search the Web; if he finds the paper was plagiarized, he'll recommend expulsion. The student implored me to take that paper off my site, lest her ''friend's'' academic career, and possibly her life, be ruined. What do I do?'

title: After Fire, Delays on Subway Stir Grumbling Among Riders
description: Subway riders in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn yesterday found a patchwork of shuttle trains and buses to help them bypass the Bergen Street station of the F and G lines, whose control panel was ravaged by fire Thursday night.

title: Q and A
description: Touring Lebanon

title: Jody Savin and Randall Miller
description: Jody Lynn Savin, a daughter of Marilyn Savin and Dr. Ronald C. Savin of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Randall Miller, the son of Dr. Leona Miller and Dr. Alexander Miller of New York. Rabbi Don Singer officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Huntington Hotel in Pasadena, Calif.

title: F. Y. I.
description: Boom and Busts

title: The Arts Should Pay Their Own Way; A Voice for Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Action Before Thought
description: I DIRECT an organization that teaches teen-agers how to avoid violence. Yet not long ago I was in a restaurant brawl. How could that happen?

title: A Private Audience With DiMaggio
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bombs Kill 6 in Kosovo Markets As Leaders Depart for Paris Talks
description: Three powerful bombs exploded in northern Kosovo today, tearing into people in the midst of Saturday market day, killing at least six, including two children, and wounding dozens just as the leaders of the province's ethnic Albanian majority departed for a new round of peace talks with the Serbs in Paris.

title: How to Insure That Organs Get to the Neediest; A Squeaky Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: Buses Are Essential To Many Islanders
description: The ''Out of Order'' column by David Bouchier on the meanderings of the S62 bus [March 1], while amusing, trivializes the importance of the Suffolk County bus network to thousands of Long Islanders while missing some of Suffolk County Transit's serious shortcomings.

title: Things That Go Bump
description: NO GO THE BOGEYMAN

title: Sophisticated Lady
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property /New Jersey; A 45-Acre Renewal for a Rundown Section of Lodi
description: FROM an empty site at Main Street and Union Avenue here the view northward is of a tattered landscape. Rundown factories, many vacant, press hard against the west side of Main Street while a cluster of houses and small businesses line the east side. Salvage yards, an apartment complex and a mobile-home park dot the area's northwestern fringe.

title: An Orlando Weekend Of Blooms, Birds and Tiffany
description: THE snow and sleet and ice that we were hoping to escape delayed our departure from New York for several hours, but Tom and I couldn't complain. Unlike many other flights, ours made it to Florida that Thursday.

title: Living for the Weekend
description: Bucking the trend toward longer and longer retail hours, Aisle 3, a new off-price retailer, cut the ribbon Friday on three stores that will be open just -- you guessed it -- three days a week.

title: The Drag King
description: TRUMPET

title: To Conserve Water, Sell It
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Life With Uncle Joe
description: EVERYDAY STALINISM

title: Stevens Will Offer an E-Degree In Business Technology
description: Stevens Institute of Technology will begin offering an E-business bachelor of science degree, combining computer technology and business, institute officials announced last week, saying it was the first of its kind.

title: The ABC's of Spying
description: The current furor in Washington over Chinese espionage at Los Alamos offers fresh evidence that finger-pointing and sound bites are a lousy way to protect and advance American security interests. Too many officials, at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, are trying harder to make political hay or to protect themselves than to explain the larger lessons of China's actions and our own lax security. And too many commentators would rather egg on the antagonists for another good fight than shed light on the real issues at stake.

title: From Brighton Beach to America; The Wave of Immigrants Began 25 Years Ago. Soon Russian Filled the Streets. Now, the Tide Is Ebbing.
description: AN arc of gray seagulls banked against a cold gust of wind and wheeled high above Brighton Beach toward the Atlantic Ocean. Sofia Garber followed the birds with her big blue eyes and pulled the fur collar of her coat to her cheeks. Standing on an expanse of boardwalk between a line of apartment buildings and the sand, Ms. Garber, 51, reflected on her life as a new immigrant, part of the first wave to arrive in Brooklyn from the Soviet Union in 1973.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ADELE B.
description: COHEN-Adele B. March 8, 1999 in New York City. She leaves her brother, Marshall J. of Manchester, CT. Funeral arrangements are private. For information, LaddTurkington Funeral Homes, Vernon, CT.

title: Novels Are Nice, But Oh, to Be A Rock Star
description: CHILI Palmer is up to his old tricks again in Elmore Leonard's new novel, ''Be Cool'' (Delacorte Press, 1999). In the prequel, ''Get Shorty'' (made into a hit movie starring John Travolta), Chili, a small-time loan shark from Brooklyn, becomes a Hollywood producer. ''Be Cool'' opens with Chili working on an idea for a new movie. His last film, ''Get Lost,'' was a flop, and Chili thinks he has found a character with potential. She is a young woman named Linda Moon who works for a dating service and sings with a rock band. Chili's way of developing a script is to create a real situation and then see what happens. He takes over Linda Moon's career, and along the way to making her a rock star he encounters a cast of colorful characters, from Russian mobsters to gangster rappers to record industry executives. In an interview conducted by Fletcher Roberts, the pop-music editor of Arts and Leisure, Mr. Leonard, 73, discussed his interest in pop music and its role in the novel. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Knicks Offer Apologies, But No Explanations
description: All of the coat hangers were in place, the name plaques were attached to the lockers, the chairs were upright. There was no evidence of anger, dismay or disgust Friday night when the doors were opened after the Knicks' 25-minute team meeting in Chicago, which followed their historic debacle against the Bulls.

title: Betty Dwoskin, Elliot Sternlicht
description: Betty Jane Dwoskin and Elliot F. Sternlicht are to be married this afternoon at Tifereth Israel Town and Village Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Laurence Sebert is to perform the ceremony.

title: Among Stock Funds, Small Is Beautiful
description: While bigger has certainly been better lately when it comes to stocks, that's apparently not true of mutual funds.

title: Nobody's Banning Bats
description: To the Editor:

title: Men, Women, Sex And Darwin
description: At last, a balanced account of the evidence in the new evolutionary psychology movement. It amuses me to hear hoary double standards justified in the name of science, since feminism is always being accused of politically loaded agendas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, SHELDON
description: ROSENBLATT-Sheldon. Of Bayswater, Queens County, on March 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara Friedman Rosenblatt. Devoted father of Lois (Wayne). Adored grandfather of Jonathan and Steven. He was a lifelong resident of the Rockaway Penninsula. He was a graduate of St. John's Law School and was a practicing attorney in Rockaway for fifty years. Former N.Y.S. Deputy Secretary of State and General Council to the Department of State. He served in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He held the post of Commander in Jewish War Veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, and American Legion. He was the President of Congregation Daarchay Noam (Bayswater Jewish Center) for the past four years. Services Sunday, March 14, 11:00 AM at Bayswater Jewish Center, 2355 Healy Avenue, Bayswater, NY. Donations in his memory to Bayswater Jewish Center would be greatly appreciated.

title: A Place to Make Every Day Feel Like St. Patrick's
description: It's been said that everyone claims to be Irish on St. Patrick's Day and Failte, a new Irish bar and restaurant at 531 Second Avenue (at 29th Street), is dedicated to extending that feeling for the other 364 days. Dennis Keane, a co-owner with Adrian McCarthy, grew up in Woodhaven Queens, with an early introduction to the restaurant business in his parents' place, Bridie's, on Woodhaven Boulevard. Failte (pronounced (FOAL-cha, Gaelic for ''welcome'') serves contemporary and traditional fare. To celebrate the Saint's day, Failte will serve corned beef and cabbage and lamb stew (both $13.95).

title: Appeals Court Overturns 'Post-Nuptial' Agreement
description: The state Appeals Court threw out the so-called post-nuptial agreement -- an agreement made in mid-marriage about dividing property in case of divorce -- of a West Paterson couple last week, ruling that the husband improperly coerced his wife to sign the papers by threatening to leave the marriage.

title: PARIS PULSE; Les Musts by Metro
description: REPUBLIQUE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMAGGIO, JOE
description: DiMaggio-Joe. The officers, Board of Governors and members of the Columbus Citizens Foundation deeply mourn the loss of our honorary member, Joe DiMaggio. He brought a sense of pride to the Italian American community at a time when being an Italian American was not always easy. He offered hope and joy to many. The quiet dignity and grace in which he lived his life was an inspiration to us all. We say farewell to a legendary Italian American athlete who served as Grand Marshall of the Columbus Day Parade. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family for a loss that is felt by many. Hon. Charles A. Gargano, President Columbus Citizens Foundation

title: Cantonese Food a Stripe Above the Norm
description: DYNASTY is a surprise. The new Port Washington Chinese restaurant on Inspiration Wharf, a small shopping center that runs from Main Street to Manhasset Bay, appears to be an ordinary double storefront. But inside, Dynasty is a massive, gymnasium-size spot. Its impressive vaulted ceiling, with faux skylights, is an eye-catcher, as are the huge golden dragons and phoenixes perched high on the walls. Dynasty's spacious dining room prompted one diner at our table to remark, ''I have this urge to get up and shoot hoops between courses.''

title: Auburn and Ohio State Follow the Script and Move On
description: This National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament is increasingly marked by new faces advancing to the Round of 16. But while that reflects the success of underdogs in other parts of the country, in the South Regional at the RCA Dome today it means that the two highest-seeded teams advanced.

title: Streetscapes /The Old McGraw-Hill Building; A Color-Filled Restoration of a Colorful Skyscraper
description: OVER the last year little splotches of vermilion, green and blue have been popping up on the top of the old McGraw-Hill building, at 330 West 42d Street. They seem aimless, but it turns out they are the opening strokes in a restoration campaign for one of New York's most colorful skyscrapers.

title: Young Buyers, Beware
description: It's useful to know your rights when buying goods through a catalogue, or how to avoid telemarketing fraud or price lumber. For some students at Clifton High School, it was also profitable. They were the winners of the third New Jersey High School Consumer Bowl last week. A four-member team from Clifton, along with teams from Freehold and Haddon Township High Schools, had made its way through what started as a field of 45 schools in January to meet in the finals at the Richard J. Hughes Justice Complex in Trenton. The idea behind the competition is to make teen-agers, who spend nearly $80 billion a year, aware of the regulations and the traps before they enter the 18-to-34 age range, the category most often victimized by fraud, according to the state Division of Consumer Affairs, which sponsors the Consumer Bowl. The winners received a trophy for their school, plus a medal and a $100 United States Saving Bond for each student.

title: Remembering a Move That Transformed a Neighborhood
description: The Mill Hill neighborhood near downtown Trenton consists of lovingly restored brick row houses lining brick-paved sidewalks illuminated by gas lamps. The racially mixed residents are professionals and blue-collar workers, artists, students and retirees. But in February 1964, when Betty Holland and her husband, Arthur, Trenton's mayor at the time, moved in, Mill Hill was a ghetto. The story of the white Mayor and his family moving into the neighborhood was front-page news.

title: March 7-13; This Old House: Fallingapart
description: Fallingwater, the Frank Lloyd Wright masterpiece, ''represents all the aspirations of the 20th century,'' says Lynda Waggoner, the house's director. Unfortunately, it can also serve as a tidy metaphor for a century that, for all its glories, has, well, had its problems.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Rome
description: It is now possible to get off a train in Rome, walk a few blocks, and enter the frescoed dining room of Livia Drusilla, the wife of the Emperor Augustus whose cruel conniving -- and expensive tastes -- enliven Robert Graves's novel ''I, Claudius.''

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with an article about Roosevelt Island misidentifed one site and located another incorrectly. Manhattan Park is a group of residential buildings, not a park. Island House is on the west side of the island, just north of the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, not on the east side of the island north of the bridge to Queens. The building identified as Island House was Motorgate, the island's parking garage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDMARKER, BOAZ L. COL
description: BRANDMARKER-Boaz L. Col. Formerly of New York, died Monday, March 8, 1999 in Aventura, FL at 86. Lived life to the fullest. Survived by his daughter Sue Cutler, granddaughter Amanda and his many friends who will miss him greatly.

title: Three Men, Three Cities Compete Over German Theater
description: COMPETITION can be good for business even among cultural institutions. But in Germany in the last few months, a rivalry involving three leading men of the theater has revealed the intensity with which German theaters and German cultural politicians can vie with one another.

title: Business; Is Bentley Hiding a Grin Behind Its Stiff Upper Lip?
description: FEW things in business are more delicate than the mystique of a luxury automobile brand. So one might have expected Volkswagen A.G. and its chairman, Ferdinand Piech, to handle last year's takeover of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars with kid gloves.

title: Two Approaches To Tax Resentment
description: ONE is respectable, one irreverent. But appropriately enough, this being tax season, two quite different books are asking the same question: How can we keep more of our money for ourselves?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE PYROTECHNIC INSANITARIUM

title: U.S. General Recommends Pullout From Haiti
description: The commander of United States forces in Latin America and the Caribbean has recommended the withdrawal of American troops from Haiti, saying the country's increasing political turbulence is placing them in danger.

title: Miss Frazier, Mr. Siegelbaum
description: Elizabeth Leigh Frazier, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph W. Frazier of Tampa, Fla., and the late Mr. Frazier, was married yesterday at her mother's home to Jonathan H. Siegelbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Siegelbaum of Far Hills, N.J. Judge Donald C. Evans of State Circuit Court in Tampa officiated.

title: The History of Nassau, 100 Years in the Making
description: NASSAU COUNTY turned 100 years old on Jan. 1, and to give the centennial mark its due, Hofstra University is gathering experts on the county's rich history to tell one tale after another of how the area got to where it is today. One of those people will be George F. Maher.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- Why I Prefer Miniature Cars; A Prizefighter's Playthings
description: ''Usually when I negotiate a deal for a fight, I ask for a car. It's one of the regular things I get. One time, the promoters gave me a model car -- it was a Mercedes, something they sell for maybe a hundred bucks. They thought it was a joke, like that's my car. But actually I really liked it, and I thought, 'I should collect them.' I don't buy them myself, though. I get them as gifts, and they're good that way, because it's not easy to buy presents for me. There's not much I want or need that I don't have. But model cars? I really think they're neat. I have them sitting up in my room where I can see them. It's not like I've got millions of them, and they're not something I ever thought about getting into, but they've become my favorite things.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, LEONARD B.
description: ALPERT-Leonard B. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, on March 9, at age 68 died, as he wished, quickly and quietly in his own bed at home after a brief heart-related illness. Despite the physical limitations of quadriplegia and part time dependency on a respirator because of polio contracted in 1955, Lennie lived a life full of the realization of his goals and visions. His 26-year career at Sears Roebuck was marked by achievements in the early years of data processing and systems development. In 1980, he and his wife Marie opened Images Art Gallery in Briarcliff Manor. Both at Sears and at Images, he was mentor and friend to so many whose lives were touched by the quiet grace, dignity and incredible sense of humor with which he lived. He died just one day after his childhood hero, Joe DiMaggio, and the words which described the elegance of the athlete could well apply to Lennie. He will live on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched, but mainly in his wife Marie Pantuosco Alpert who has never known where she began and he ended and in his nephew Larry Friedman, his niece Ellen Friedman, their spouses Holly Holmes and Jeff Cowan; great nieces Rachel, Celia and Molly; great nephew Sam and sister and brother-in-law Blanche and Jack Friedman. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: ART /ARCHITECTURE; Uncovering Cleopatra's Egypt Underwater
description: FEW events in history have so captured the romantic imagination as the double suicide of Cleopatra, the last of a Greek line of Ptolemies to rule Egypt, and her lover Mark Antony, following their defeat at the Battle of Actium on Sept. 2, 31 B.C. A defining moment in the classical world, the battle transformed glorious and prosperous Egypt into a province of the Roman Empire.

title: Gershon Legman, Anthologist of Erotic Humor, Is Dead at 81
description: Gershon Legman, a self-taught scholar of dirty jokes and bawdy limericks and ballads who played a pivotal role in opening up the field of erotic folklore to scholarly study in the 1960's and 70's, died on Feb. 23 at a hospital near his home in Opio, France. He was 81.

title: As an Entertainment Play, Liberty Is a Variety Show
description: HOW would you like to own a portfolio of some of the most coveted entertainment assets, run by one of the sharpest investors in the industry? It's not a mutual fund, though that may be a useful way to think of it.

title: Political Briefing
description: A Midwest Lab For Campaign Reform

title: FILM; Trim Two Scenes, and Call Me in the Morning
description: WHAT'S this on the front doorstep? The U.P.S. delivery man has left another carton, bulging with more screenplays. Once again, I've signed on as an itinerant, unpaid script doctor, and once again I'm filled with curiosity and dread. All those heroes and villains, flashbacks, conflicts and dream sequences.

title: Children's Books
description: THE OTHER SHEPARDS

title: Through a Lens, Creatively
description: IN the beginning, there was the word, treyf -- a word that two young filmmakers, Alisa Lebow and Cynthia Madansky, found so fascinating that they knew ''we had to make a film called 'Treyf' someday,'' Ms. Lebow said.

title: Suspect Bag at Airport May Be Tied to Ex-Transportation Official
description: The police at the airport in Columbus, Ohio, rushed hundreds of passengers out of a major concourse on Friday afternoon and ordered planes pushed back from their gates, causing extensive delays, after workers at America West Airlines took a suspicious bag that had been checked to a security checkpoint, and screeners saw what they suspected was a bomb.

title: Weeping Beech Will Live On in Memory, and in Art
description: The fate of New York's Weeping Beech, considered the matriarch of all such trees on the continent, will lie in the hands of a group of artists who will chisel its wood into sculptures and benches to be placed along a planned ''heritage trail'' in downtown Flushing featuring historic sites, city officials announced last week.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the robust condition of the failing nuclear power industry misstated the relationship between two technological achievements that never became commercial successes: the Three Mile Island nuclear plant and Concorde supersonic jets. The planes first flew in 1969 and began passenger service to the United States in 1976; their introduction did not come a few days before the Three Mile Island meltdown, which was in 1979.

title: MUSIC; Mendelssohn Shows The Way Back To Late Beethoven
description: SOMEWHERE in the mid-1980's, with what listeners will (according to preference) characterize as either a Big Bang or a Big Splat, the ''early-music movement,'' as it was then called, collided with Beethoven. Now, a decade and a half later, a casual observer could be forgiven for thinking that Beethoven is old news to the ''historical performance'' folks. Look at the bins in a classical-record store, and you will find mounds of Beethoven on ''period instruments'': the symphonies, of course (five or six times over), but also the concertos, the sonatas, the trios, the songs. Only after a moment of thought does it occur to you that something is missing.

title: Let's Get Serious
description: In the right hands, humor can be an invaluable capitalist tool. It can break tension, restore perspective and promote creative thinking. How have you used humor on the job to solve a problem or wriggle out of a tough situation? Or how did your attempt backfire? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The View From: White Plains; Lawyers Back to Class For a Look at Ethics Continuing Education Of the State's Lawyers
description: THERE is an old joke about lawyers: ''How can you tell when a lawyer is lying?'' Answer: ''He's moving his lips.'' At an ethics and professionalism conference last weekend at Pace Center for Continuing Legal Education here, a handful of the 300 or so participants and panelists agreed glumly that, yes, they had heard that one -- and the one that goes: ''Why don't sharks attack lawyers?'' Answer: ''Professional courtesy.''

title: SOAPBOX; 40 and Other Numbers
description: IN the Talmudic teachings of ''Ethics of Our Fathers,'' the wise rabbis of blessed memory speak of the different stages of one's life: ''And at the age of 40, one attains understanding.'' If wisdom is the seed of an idea, then understanding would be the development of that idea. To know it would be to internalize it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKIERNAN, FRANCIS B.
description: McKIERNAN-Francis B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Francis B. McKiernan, associated with The Times from 1948 until retiring in 1978.

title: New Portrait of Unabomber: Environmental Saboteur Around Montana Village for 20 Years
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski won notoriety as the Unabomber, the evil genius who mailed deadly pipe bombs to scientists and corporate targets from California to New Jersey.

title: In New Talks on Kosovo, NATO's Credibility Is at Stake
description: When peace talks on Kosovo resume here on Monday, not only the fate of the province's two million people but also the credibility of European diplomacy and the NATO military alliance will hang in the balance, European and American officials say.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HOW TO ACCOMODATE MEN

title: Moya No. 1; Serena Williams Beats Graf in Evert
description: It took a little bit of prayer and a lot of topspin, but Carlos Moya, the shaggy-haired Spaniard who announced himself as an impact player by capturing last year's French Open, today became the first man from his nation, and the 15th man ever, to attain the No. 1 ranking.

title: Lowell Fulson, 77, Who Took Texas-Style Blues to the West Coast
description: Lowell Fulson, a major figure in West Coast blues, died March 6 in Long Beach, Calif. He was 77 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, FLORENCE (NEE LIEBERMAN)
description: BLUM-Florence (nee Lieberman). On March 11, 1999 at the age of 95. Adored wife of the late Dr. Arthur A. Blum. Beloved mother of Francine Weil and Carole Blum. Loving sister of Augusta Irving. Cherished grandmother of Amy Weil. Loving grandmotherin-law to Aravinda deSilva. Services will be held Sunday, March 14th, 12:30PM at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THROWAWAY DADS The Myths and Barriers That Keep Men From Being the Fathers They Want to Be. By Ross D. Parke and Armin A. Brott. Houghton Mifflin, $24.

title: Peach Oil May Work as a Pesticide
description: Government scientists have found that the harmless natural oil that gives peaches their perfume also kills fungus and other pests in the soil and could replace methyl bromide, a widely used pesticide that is toxic to people and also damages the planet's protective ozone layer.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Secondhand, but Rosier
description: I LIVE in a secondhand house, wear secondhand clothes and eat with a secondhand fork off a secondhand table. I drive a secondhand car, read secondhand books and mix my children's milkshakes in a secondhand blender. Everywhere I look, I see what once were someone else's dressers, lamps, art, baskets and dishes. Even my husband is secondhand.

title: The Americanization of Europe: Jazz Marches On
description: The European jazz scene becomes as American as it can get this year with the observance of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Duke Ellington. So great and imaginative was his output -- nearly 2,000 compositions -- that he is not only being performed on the jazz circuit but also on the concert stage. ''Mood Indigo'' and ''Sophisticated Lady,'' for example, are scheduled at the Three Choirs Festival in Worcester, England. Other unforgettable works include ''Creole Love Call,'' ''Black, Brown and Beige'' and ''My People,'' which was commissioned for the 100th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation in 1963.

title: March 7-13; NATO Expands East to Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic
description: The cold war receded a bit farther following a ceremony in Independence, Mo., in which Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic became the first former Soviet bloc nations to formally join NATO. At the gathering at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told the foreign ministers of the three nations, ''You are truly allies, you are truly home.''

title: The Medicis' Decorator
description: THREE WORLDS OF MICHELANGELO

title: Vienna Salutes King of Waltz
description: Vienna loves to look back to its glorious musical past. This year, it's the King of the Waltz, Johann Strauss Jr., who is being memorialized with a 12-month marathon of concerts, dances and stage productions to mark the centenary of the composer's death on June 3, 1899.

title: Nets Sign Kittles and Embark on a New Start
description: Moments after the Nets squandered yet another fourth-quarter lead in losing to the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night, the team's new backcourt mates, Stephon Marbury and Kerry Kittles, stood together in the locker room. Marbury, who had not played but had watched intently from the bench, did all the talking. Kittles listened.

title: Muriel Bentley, 82, Dancer In Jerome Robbins's Ballets
description: Muriel Bentley, an early member of Ballet Theater (now American Ballet Theater) who was praised for her comic gifts and witty dancing, died on Monday at the Kaiser Permanente Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 82 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: How Much Can a Co-op Be Taxed?
description: FOR nearly 20 years, lawyers and accountants for residential co-ops across the country have been engaged in a running battle with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: All the School's a Stage; Stars Talk Shop and the Film Community Listens
description: He may be an odds-on favorite to take home another Academy Award soon, but Steven Spielberg has committed his share of gaffes along the way. For example, his memorable debut film, ''Duel,'' has a scene in which the director's reflection shows up in the glass of a phone booth -- ''a real beginner's mistake,'' Mr. Spielberg acknowledged on a recent Monday night in a college auditorium in Greenwich Village, where he sat before a couple of hundred attentive film students and one enraptured interviewer named James Lipton.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99; What They Were Thinking
description: The Rev. Jamal Bryant, N.A.A.C.P.

title: The Replacement Killer
description: TAKING LIVES

title: Danish Conquest: Legoland Comes to California
description: Junior builders of America take note.

title: Bolivian's Dark Past Starts to Catch Up With Him
description: When Hugo Banzer was democratically elected President in 1997, two decades after his military dictatorship, most Bolivians seemed more interested in economic issues than past human rights abuses.

title: A Woman, a Plan, a Canal: Gowanus Documentary
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS

title: The Way We Live Now
description: You only had to produce the new changes. We are expected to read the smaller print and decipher the tropical-fruit-colored typeface.

title: Magazine for Those Who Follow the Soaps
description: DAVID CONE, the quietly intense pitcher of the New York Yankees, shares something private and personal with Charles Barkley, the outspoken forward on the Houston Rockets. It is neither a love of sports nor of winning that specifically unites these two. It is ''All My Children,'' the soap opera.

title: Monica and Barbara and Primal Concerns
description: FROM the day the Monica Lewinsky story burst from the recesses of the Internet into the mainstream press, it has been trailed by a Greek chorus of high-minded journalists and media critics lamenting the saturation coverage of the affair. In their eyes, it has displaced the O. J. Simpson trial as the ultimate symbol of a deplorable trend: the devolution of news into entertainment. As I watched Ms. Lewinsky's interview on ''20/20,'' I could almost hear the chorus mutter: ''It's bad enough we had to pay attention to That Woman when grave questions of state were involved. But now the political crisis is over. Do we have to tolerate not only the inevitable book, but two hours of That Face on television? And can she wipe That Smile off the face, at least?''

title: Revisiting Steve Reich For the Dance Floor
description: FROM Marcel Duchamp to Robert Rauschenberg, artists have created new work out of found objects, the humble products of mass culture. In recent years, however, DJ's in the club scene have reversed the process by recycling high art for popular ends. Thanks to such appropriation (or, as some think, sacrilege), liturgical chant and Italian opera, Herbie Hancock and John Coltrane have all found a second home in dance music, where rhythm trumps everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, CHESTER M.
description: ROSS-Chester M. March 29, 1917March 11, 1999. Died peacefully in Miami after a valiant struggle with cancer and pneumonia. Services Frank Campbell, 81st and Madison Avenue, Monday, March 15, 11:30AM. Beloved hushand of Blanche, loving and loved father of Dorien and the late Arthur. Devoted brother to Joan Hersh and brothers-in-law Michael Hersh, B.B. Goldstein, Charles Goldstein, adored uncle to Tom, Jane, Buck, John, Patrick and Amy. A lover of life. All who knew him were touched by his warmth and sparkle. A light is out. We will not see another like him.

title: How to Insure That Organs Get to the Neediest; Try a Tax Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Dangers of Vaccination
description: To the Editor:

title: Bricks Falling From Building: Political Cement Is Missing
description: At the corner of Dumont Avenue and Cleveland Street, a three-story apartment building stands out sharply amid the nearby well-kept buildings. The stoop has crumbled into rubble, the roof has partly caved in and out back the body of a cat with matted yellow fur has begun to decay.

title: April Sauer, Iain Bryden
description: April Dawn Sauer and Iain Corey Bryden were married yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The bride's grandfather the Rev. Jack Sauer, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Holiday Inn Beach.

title: By Standing Pat, the Knicks Are Losing Ground
description: Jerry West, the Lakers' president and architect, entered the season with a team that might already have been championship-bound. Now, with the prompting of the Lakers' owner, Jerry Buss, West has made several major personnel moves to improve their chances. On paper, anyhow, signing Dennis Rodman and trading for Glen Rice in the last two weeks appear to give the Lakers the inside track for a title.

title: March 7-13; Curbs on Antibiotics in Feed
description: The Food and Drug Administration is revising its guidelines for approving and monitoring antibiotics for animals, fearing that the routine use of antibiotics in livestock feed to promote growth may threaten human health by fostering bacteria that no drug can kill. The agency is acting now because the nation is especially vulnerable: No new classes of antibiotics will be marketed in the near future, and doctors fear that if bacteria overwhelm existing drugs, more patients will succumb to untreatable infections. DENISE GRADY

title: Radioactive Waste
description: Radioactive nuclear waste may continue to be stored at Indian Point 2 and 3 in Buchanan and some 70 other nuclear plants throughout the United States until at least 2010, according to the latest plans of the Energy Department.

title: A McCourt Has Had It With the McCourts
description: By this time it is probably fair to say that the McCourt family of Limerick and Manhattan is as well known as any Irish family in the New World.

title: Woman Dropped Baby Out Window, Police Say
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman gave birth to a boy late Friday night, then promptly dropped it into shrubbery outside her first-floor window, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, FAYE
description: RITTER-Faye. Beloved wife of the late Louis J. Ritter, passed away on March 13, 1999, at the age of 95, in Boca Raton, FL.

title: What a Difference a Day Makes
description: Damascus By Richard Beard. 310 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $23.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Heavyweight Picture Is as Fractured as Ever
description: IT was billed as being for the undisputed world heavyweight championship, but the title is more disputed than ever.

title: Where The Screen Is King, The Stage Is Queen
description: NEAR the end of ''All About Eve,'' Hollywood's enduring, self-loathing take on the vanities of Broadway, the scheming anti-heroine accepts an award for her debut performance in New York's biggest new hit, casts her doe eyes downward and starts the inexorable process of selling out.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FLESH GUITAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSWALD, FRANK GRAF III.
description: OSWALD-Frank Graf III. Killed in an automobile accident on March 7 in Amado, Arizona. He is survived by his wife Laurinda Middleton Oswald; his two children Frank Graf and Julia Skye; his mother Audrey Clinton Oswald of Newport; his father Frank Graf Oswald Jr. of Port Washington; his brother David of Stamford; and his sister Diana of New York City. Memorial service Friday, March 19th, 2PM, Saint James Church, Madison Ave and 71 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to Zenith Center for the Arts, 330 E. 7th St, Tucson, AZ. 85706 would be appreciated.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Lecture by General Powell

title: March 7-13; RJR Nabisco, R.I.P.
description: Crumbling under the strain of debt and the specter of fresh lawsuits over smoking, RJR Nabisco said it would separate its food and tobacco businesses and sell its international tobacco division. The company's biggest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, said he would wage a proxy fight to get RJR to spin off its Nabisco holdings instead of the domestic tobacco operations, as the company proposed. CONSTANCE L. HAYS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SYDNEY
description: LEWIS-Sydney. The death of Syndey Lewis is a great loss to the contemporary art, architecture, and design communities. Sydney and his beloved wife Frances assembled one of the greatest private collections of late 19th and 20th century decorative art, which they gave to the Virginia Museum of Art, where it is on view along with their collection of post-1945 painting and sculpture. A devoted friend of contemporary artists, Sydney ignored his illness to celebrate with us at the opening of the Museum's retrospective of his dear friend Chuck Close. He will be missed by his many friends at the Museum, and we extend our deepest condolences to his wife Frances and their children and grandchildren. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael
description: There are a baseball and a bat etched onto Michael Juman's headstone. ''Cherished son and brother,'' the epitaph reads, ''Jan. 5, 1965 to Mar. 11, 1994.'' Michael's father, Martin Juman, braces against a brisk wind as he walks through the Wellwood Cemetery on Long Island to visit his son. ''He's waiting for answers,'' Martin says, looking at the grave. ''We promised him we'd find them.''

title: Adopt a Star
description: If your favorite film, television or music star has been looking a little down at the heel lately -- literally and figuratively -- here's a way to help. There are 2,128 performers who have their names on the sidewalk along Hollywood's Walk of Fame, stretching along Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street, and each of these pink marble and terrazzo stars -- honoring the likes of Bob Hope and Elvis Presley -- requires regular maintenance. For $250, an admirer can claim sponsorship of a star for a year, and receive an ''adoption'' certificate. The sponsoring group is the nonprofit Hollywood Historic Trust. For details, call (323) 468-1376 or fax (323) 469-2805. JOSEPH SIANO

title: The Technique of Skim-Coating a Plaster Wall
description: PLASTER walls frequently develop a network of hairline cracks that are too narrow to be filled with patching plaster, yet they cannot be covered with paint. The best way to restore the wall surface is by skim-coating it. Skim-coating is the technique of applying thin layers of gypsum-based joint compound over the entire surface. The layers are so thin that even after applying several coats, the total thickness of all the layers together is less than an eighth of an inch. Skim-coating can also be used to smooth a textured surface.

title: For Women in Politics, Style Isn't the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing For the Future
In the Region/Long Island; Small Firms See a Big Edge in Buying Buildings
description: ALTHOUGH Infosys International, an information-systems development and consulting company, is still renovating its 14,000-square-foot headquarters at 110 Terminal Drive in Plainview, it has already moved in.

title: In Illinois, It's the Political Life for Riley, Gilhooley Et Al.
description: THERE seems to be truth in the adage about the luck of the Irish, at least when it comes to running for political office. As sure as the Chicago River runs green for St. Patrick's Day, politicians with Irish names hold all but a few of the major offices in Illinois -- from Fitzgerald to Madigan to Devine, a pair of Ryans, and, of course, another mayor named Daley. The sons and daughters of Erin also do pretty well elsewhere in the country.

title: Money Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Brina Rausman, Elliot Ganchrow
description: Brina Rausman, the daughter of Ellen and Sam Rausman of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Elliot David Ganchrow, a son of Sheila Ganchrow and Dr. Mandell Ganchrow of Monsey, N.Y. Dr. Moses D. Tendler, a rabbi and a professor at Yeshiva University in Manhattan, officiated at the Rockleigh (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, NATHAN JOSEPH, D.D.S.
description: LIPKIN-Nathan Joseph, D.D.S. 75. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of New York. Passed away March 10, 1999. Beloved husband Gladys. Loving father of Harriet (Chris Sautter), Alan (Barbara) and Rebecca. Dear brother of Shirley Rosenthal. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Sam and Molly Lipkin, Josh and Stephanie Sautter. Graduate of Johns Hopkins University and the New York University School of Dentistry and its Graduate Orthodontic course. He died peacefully and painlessly. His life will be celebrated in a memorial service at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1921 Pembroke Rd., Hollywood FL. 954-921-7200, Friday, March 12, 1999 at 2PM. Graveside services will take place on Sunday, March 14, 1999 at 1PM at Beth David Cemetery on Elmont Rd in Elmont, Long Island. Shiva will be at the Lipkin residence in Hollywood, FL starting Monday, March 15, 1999.

title: A Folkie Plugged In to the Currents
description: AS the music industry slices itself into ever thinner market fragments, the language of music critics is dutifully following along. Performers are extolled or denounced for crossing boundaries invisible to the eye (or ear): divisions that often have little to do with how people actually create music.

title: OPINION; Putting Regents Exams to the Test
description: THE tide of rising educational standards has almost covered the entire beach by now, and before it recedes (as all educational trends inevitably do), it's time to take a look at the detritus that will be left behind on the shoreline. Some of it, I'm sure, will be quite revealing, if not embarrassing, to the most extreme of the ''raise the bar higher'' proponents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPAILLAT, MARIA
description: ESPAILLAT-Maria. On March 10, 1999. Beloved mother of Rogerio, Thelma and Juana. Cherished grandmother of Santiago, Michael and Samuel. Adored mother-inlaw to Ana, Heriberto and Lawrence. You will always be in our hearts.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade has her nomenclature reversed: Airlines that are permissive about the amount and size of carry-on luggage are not ''friendly.'' They are distinctly unfriendly to the many passengers who find no room in the overhead bin even for their coats.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: A LONG WAY FROM CHICAGO. By Richard Peck. Dial. $15.99. (Ages 8 to 12) This 1999 Newbery Honor book, a novel in seven humorous, chronological chapters, reminisces about the summer vacations Joey and his sister Mary Alice spent during the Depression in a small town in Illinois where the strangest things kept happening. A tall tale told straight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished memeber of its extended family. As Chai Founders, Mr. Merkin, together with Ursulla, his beloved partner in life and philanthrophy, provided scholarship assistance to Boys Towns' disadvantaged students, enabling them to receive a quality academic, technological and Jewish education. Mr. Merkin not only generously supported the study of Torah, but was himself an erudite Torah scholar. His committment to Am Yisroel, Eretz Yisroel and Toras Yisroel will serve as a lasting blessing and source of inspiration. Deepest sympathy to Mrs. Merkin and the entire family. May they comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Why Smoke (Still) Gets In Their Eyes
description: PURSUED by lawyers and politicians, tobacco companies have found it difficult the last few years to be proactive on behalf of what most likely is a nervous base of shareholders.

title: Wide Yield Premiums For Less-Risky Bradys
description: It's natural enough that Latin American government bonds trade at prices that translate into double-digit yields these days: With turmoil in Brazil's finances and lingering worries that it will spread, Latin bonds summon up ''risky'' in many a mind the way Tito Puente does salsa. Investors demand high yields to compensate for high currency and credit risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTLAGE, LOUISE
description: MATTLAGE-Louise. Multi-talented modern dance, artist, and poet died on March 9, 1999, in Boca Raton, FL. She was 92, and the cause was advanced Alzheimer's Disease. A sophisticated woman with a wide range of cultural interests, Ms. Mattlage's career took her from modern dance with Jose Limon, and Doris Humphrey, to director and choreographer of her own dance company, based in CT, called The Dancers of Faith. The Dance Company performed in countless churches and synagogues throughout the eastern United States. She taught modern dance at college and universities all around the world. She was the author of four books of poetry. Her numerous poems and essays were published in periodicals often concerning women's issues. Born and raised in Boston, MA, Ms. Mattlage lived for many years in Fairfield and Southport, CT. She moved to Key Biscayne, FL in 1971. She continued to spend summers in Fairfield, CT. She was a member of the Miami chapter of the Pen Women and she lectured and performed her dance and poetry well into her 80's. In 1989, she moved to Boca Raton, FL. She is survived by her son Jonathan Mattlage of Acworth, GA, her daughter Valerie Mattlage of Boca Raton, FL, and her two grandsons: Jason Ledyard, of New York, NY, and Jonathan Mattlage, Jr. of Kennesaw, GA. She was pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, W.F.H. Mattlage. Memorial contributions may be made to either the National Organization for Women, or The Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, FLORA
description: STERN-Flora. Died March 12, 1999. Survived by loving daughter, Lana, son-in-law Steve, adoring granddaughter Dana and grandson-in-law Mark.

title: Brookhaven Lab Marks New Beginning
description: One year after taking over as manager of Brookhaven National Laboratory, Brookhaven Science Associates is celebrating what John H. Marburger, the lab director, called a new beginning marked by research advances, better environmental controls and improved relations with neighbors.

title: School Budget Vote Prompts New Strategies
description: WITH a statewide vote on school budgets scheduled on May 18, most school districts are either preparing their proposals for the 1999-00 academic year or developing strategies to win over voters.

title: Black Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Found Slain at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel
description: A 56-year-old man staying at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was found dead in his room last night, the victim of a homicide, the police said.

title: For Women in Politics, Style Isn't the Story; Family Should Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: A 12-Block Glimmer of Hope for New York
description: ARCHITECTURE or real estate, what's it going to be? Does New York have room for both? These are the basic questions raised by the Canadian Center for Architecture's competition to redesign an important piece of land on the west side of midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIBACH, AARON
description: MEIBACH-Aaron. On March 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Freda (recently deceased). Loving father of Ina Lea Meibach, Doris Wallace (Martin) and Judy Meibach. A warm, gentle man, he gave joy to all with his kindness, humility, humor and sense of family. His smile lit up a room. As co-caterer of the Burnside Manor, he enhanced the simchas of many. In retirement, he relished his work as a volunteer for the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. A man of principle, he lived his Judaism in prayer and good deeds. Service Sunday, March 14th at 10AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Tenant Program Fund, 5961 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471.

title: A Baedeker for First-Time Homebuyers
description: AT times, the struggle to become a first-time homeowner seems like learning to ride a bicycle: You can't help but wonder how something that seems to have been so easy for others could be so difficult.

title: Sounds of America
description: AARON COPLAND

title: Our Towns; A Club That Nobody Wants to Join
description: ONE night five years ago, when Gabriel Swart was 21 and a senior at SUNY Buffalo, he got into a friend's car. The friend was drunk, but only Gabriel was killed in the accident.

title: Hit Parade
description: Carey Grant and Alexis Smith get top billing in Michael Curtiz's NIGHT AND DAY (1946), a thin but festive biography of Cole Porter (played by Grant, above right). But the real star in this celebratory medley of Cole Porter songs is the toothsome and tireless songbird Ginny Simms. The numbers include some ornate favorites from Broadway, and among the film's highlights are the title song. ''Night and Day,'' ''Begin the Beguine'' and an effective Mary Martin singing ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy.'' The real story of the composer's battle for survival after a crippling riding accident came much later - Saturday at 4 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

title: Russia Remains Uneasy Over NATO's Expansion
description: If NATO's diplomats get their way, next month's 50th birthday party in Washington will be replete with post-cold-war symbolism, featuring top Russian officials in its large cast to demonstrate just how well the old enemies now work side by side.

title: Housesitting
description: To the Editor: In regard to Karin Winegar's article, ''To Leave Home Find Someone to Leave Behind'' (Jan. 17): Since I moved to the mainland from San Juan, I have been housesitting for friends. The experience cannot be better. As I write this, I am taking care of two cats and a whole apartment, and watering the plants for another. Since my roommate is out of town, I also go back home to water his plants, do the recycling and collect the mail.

title: March 7-13; Arab Named Miss Israel
description: If beauty pageants are reflections of anything particularly deep, then the Miss Israel pageant broke a barrier of sorts. The woman chosen to represent Israel in the Miss World competition is, for the first time, Arab. Rana Raslan, 21, refused to read too much into her selection, saying she had been chosen in the contest as ''a beauty queen, not a political queen.''

title: Tax Reassessment Bid Lacking on Wish List
description: WHEN Westchester tax rates were set last December there seemed to be little correlation between the budget the county had adopted and what some local governments were being billed, raising a cry from County Legislators for a state law that would let the county change its system of assessment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REED, PHILLIP DUDLEY
description: REED-Phillip Dudley. January 23, 1946-March 14, 1993. With every passing year we miss you more. Loving family, Elizabeth Jackson and Philli

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 --; Here Come The Wives
description: Remember the Year of the Woman? Well, it's beginning to look as if 2000 will be the Year of the Wife. Elizabeth Dole is nearing a run for the Presidency, to the delight of many Republican strategists. And Hillary Clinton is -- famously, teasingly -- thinking about the Senate. The part of me that relishes a cinematic plot turn in real life loves the very idea. These are, after all, perfect big-screen story lines. In this President Dole story, Bob would be self-sacrificing husband, consigned to wistful observation of his wife's rising star -- because, hey, it's her turn now. In the Senator Clinton story, Hillary would be the girl scorned in high school who shows up at her reunion in splendor, humbling her old tormentors and winning a seat on the Appropriations Committee while ''I Will Survive'' crescendos on the soundtrack. You'd have to be a killjoy of the dourest hue not to see the fun in it.

title: In Their Openers, UConn Has Fun and Rutgers Warms Up
description: The women's basketball teams from Connecticut and Rutgers, both nationally ranked among the top 10, waltzed away with their first-round games Friday night in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Tonight, they get a chance to advance to next weekend's regional semifinals with perhaps only a little more difficulty.

title: Children's Books
description: MARIANTHE'S STORY

title: Terri Ambron and John Liftin
description: Mary Theresa Ambron, a daughter of Dr. Joanna Ambron and Dr. Richard Ambron of Lake Success, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Matthew Liftin, the son of Morton Liftin of Washington and the late Sylvia Liftin. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: Owners Meet This Week Amid Yearning for Replay
description: ''It was a game against Miami back in the early 70's,'' recalled Ralph Wilson, 80, for 39 years owner of the Buffalo Bills, spinning a tale with dancing, colorful wit, wisdom and inflection that few can.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- Salient Facts: Papal Indulgences; Roman Holiday
description: INDULGENCES? SOUNDS LIKE A DISTANT MEMORY FROM HISTORY CLASS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, VIRGINIA GARDNER FINCKE
description: WALL-Virginia Gardner Fincke. Born in Boston, MA. October 28, 1905. Died at home March 11, 1999. Widow of Albert Carey Wall. Resident of New York City and Fishers Island, N.Y. She is survived by two daughters, Virginia Fincke Thors, Maria Wall Patterson, and six grandchildren. Funeral services to be held Tuesday, March 16th, 11AM at Saint James' Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 72 St, NY, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Saint James' Church or the Shirley-Eustis House, 33 Shirley St, Boston, MA. 02119 would be appreciated.

title: A Dark Side of Prosperity
description: THE surging prosperity over the past three years has lifted a lot of boats, and has left the water rather choppy for many others.

title: Yale EliminatedBy Colgate
description: Colgate completed a two-game sweep of Yale, 7-2, at New Haven last night. The victory sends the team to the final-five ECAC tournament that begins at Lake Placid on Thursday.

title: Landowners Resist Nyack's Plans for a Wetland
description: For 30 years, Lucille Lapenta leased her waterfront backyard on the Hudson River in Nyack, N.Y., to a neighbor who ran a small shipyard on his own property and needed extra land. When the neighbor abandoned the shipyard more than a decade ago, the dock fell into decay. The barge that had served as a machine shop caught fire, and a charred hull was left at the water's edge. The boat sheds rotted and were bulldozed into a unsightly heap.

title: Resurgence of a Grime Fighter
description: THREE years ago, when consumers complained about the smell of its bleach, the Clorox Company cut the chlorine odor by adding floral scents -- and helped increase its share of the American bleach market to a remarkable 60 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDLOW, BENJAMIN, JR.
description: LUDLOW-Benjamin, Jr. Died on March 12 in his home in Amherst, MA. He was 88 years old. A graduate of Swarthmore College and a life-long musician, he was born in Ardmore, PA. He is survived by his wife Claire of Amherst, MA; his brothers Crozer and Alden of PA; his son John and family of El Paso, TX; five grandchildren, three great-grandchildren all of El Paso. Three step-children reside in the Boston area. A memorial service will be held at South Congregational Church in Amherst, MA on March 20, 1999 at 10:30 AM.

title: Trying To Stay True to The Street
description: WHEN Daymond John, the co-founder and chief executive of Fubu hip-hop clothing, drives through his old neighborhood in Hollis, Queens, he leaves no doubt that he has moved on -- and up.

title: Scott's 3-Point Touch Vanishes, And the Knicks Send Him Away
description: Dennis Scott never seemed to fit in with the Knicks. He arrived at training camp out of shape and was a happy-go-lucky personality on and off the court. After his 3-point shooting touch failed to materialize, the Knicks decided to waive him today and activate guard David Wingate from the injured list.

title: Water Park Is in the Works
description: When State Senator Guy J. Velella read an article in The Bronx Times Reporter last week about plans for a water park at Orchard Beach, he was stunned.

title: Stealing a Smoke, In Good Company
description: IN third grade, I wanted to be one of two things when I grew up: either a counterman at my favorite delicatessen, Feitlin's, in Passaic, N.J. -- free hot dogs and fries -- or a cigarette girl. No occupation seemed more glamorous: sexy outfits, lots of lipstick, and the men about town were always happy to see them.

title: March 7-13; Clinton Tours Central America
description: President Clinton journeyed to Central America on a mission of mercy and regret. In Nicaragua and Honduras, he viewed the damage from last fall's Hurricane Mitch and promised to do what he could to pry loose $1 billion in reconstruction aid from Congress. He also said he would try to ease the plight of thousands of Central Americans who illegally migrated to the United States.

title: The Art of the State
description: TOM MORAN is an enabler.

title: In Travels, Dodd Spreads Word About Computer Flaw
description: A Congressional staff member calls it ''the fine line between Paul Revere and Chicken Little.''

title: Jane Sullivan and Paul Beiles
description: Jane Kathryn Sullivan and Dr. Paul Russell Beiles were married yesterday by the Rev. Ned Reidy, a Roman Catholic priest, at La Quinta (Calif.) Resort and Club.

title: From a Coffin Maker, the Final Accessory
description: PATRICK J. FANT acknowledges that the designs on his coffins may not be for everyone. But for some people, they are the only way to go.

title: Michelle Simkins And Jason Rubell
description: Michelle Ann Simkins, the daughter of Leon Simkins of Miami Beach and Kathy Esformes of Malibu, Calif., was married last night to Jason Lewis Rubell, the son of Mera and Donald Rubell of Miami Beach. Rabbi Atan Yardeni officiated at the Hotel Bel-Air in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHNER, LAURA
description: KIRSHNER-Laura. Beloved sister of Ruth Becker & Rhoda Scherling. Loving aunt of Minda, Megan and Lisa, and great-aunt of Rebecca, Andrew, Jessica and Gil. Services were held on Friday, March 12, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAX, DR. PHILIP
description: STRAX-Dr. Philip. He was far more than a physician. He was far more than a medical pioneer. He was also a loving uncle always there to guide us, to inspire us, to cheer us, and to stand at our sides in moments of both happiness and sadness. He was as gentle as any, but also as strong as necessary in teaching us, his family, the blessings of life and the continuing need to do for others what they could not do for themselves. He taught us humanity and also inspired all of us with his professional dedication to his patients. He will live in our memory and in our hearts forever. He will always be with us, smiling upon us, and we shall remember him forever. We will always love you, Uncle Phil Richard, Julie & Daniel Goldstein London

title: The Nation; Please Hold for the Deputy Deputy.
description: THE Clinton Administration may have reinvented the Federal work force by cutting nearly 400,000 lower-level jobs, but it has also reinforced an already top-heavy bureaucracy with more layers of lavishly titled officials in the upper ranks of the Government, according to a new study.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BATTAGLIA, AUGUST J.
description: BATTAGLIA-August J. March 14, 1973. Remembered always with love.

title: Tracking the Decline of Fish
description: IT is the time of year when scientists who work for the Millstone Nuclear Power Plant in Waterford go out in their fishing boats looking for winter flounder. This fish used to be plentiful in the early 1980's but its numbers are way down in the state and elsewhere throughout New England.

title: Decades Later, Naming Names Still Matters
description: Four years ago, the Seattle Repertory Theater presented the world premiere of ''Jolson Sings Again,'' a play about informing during the McCarthy era in Hollywood and its toll on individual lives. Arthur Laurents, the dramatist, director and screenwriter who wrote the play, knew and worked with two major artists who informed: the choreographer and director Jerome Robbins and the stage and film director Elia Kazan. Mr. Laurents is the author of the books for the landmark Broadway musicals ''West Side Story'' and ''Gypsy'' and screenplays for a number of films, including ''The Way We Were'' and ''The Turning Point.''

title: MUSIC; O.K., Everyone in Tune, Whatever That Means
description: THE strings of a harpsichord, an old joke has it, will stay in tune for only 19 seconds. Most early-music concerts on period instruments feature a lot of tuning, sometimes to the point of making the audience squirm. Why the instruments go out of tune is no mystery. Materials like wood and gut are highly sensitive to temperature and humidity. The bigger riddle is what, exactly, it means to be in tune.

title: Hell's Angels Faulted on the Way They Park Wings
description: In their heyday in the late 60's, the Hell's Angels motorcycle club forged a reputation as a radical-chic outlaw gang, taking road trips with the writer Hunter S. Thompson and providing concert security for the Rolling Stones. These days, some neighbors of the group's clubhouse, which is on the ground floor of a brick tenement on East Third Street between First and Second Avenues, are more apt to view the Angels as quality-of-life offenders.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Henley
description: If it is not Oxford or Cambridge, there is no place in Britain more associated with rowing than Henley-on-Thames, home to the ultracompetitive and equally fashionable Henley Royal Regatta, which is held every year in early July. (The finals will be held July 4 this year.) No wonder, then, that British rowing enthusiasts chose this historic town, a mere 35 miles west of London, as the site of a striking new River and Rowing Museum, inaugurated by Queen Elizabeth last November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, LYNN H.
description: OLSON-Lynn H. Of Berkeley, CA, died on February 27, 1999, at age 82. Foreign Service officer for 25 years and Marine Midland Bank offical for four years. Husband of the late Katherine (Kay) Olson. Father of Lynn T. Olson and Nancy Olson. Grandfather of Amity and Aaron. Funeral services Monday, March 15, 3 PM, at Sunset View Cemetery, El Cerrito, CA.

title: A Tribute to Freedomland From Oe Who Missed It
description: In 1960, New York had an answer to Disneyland. It was Freedomland U.S.A., a historical theme park in the Bronx, where Co-op City now stands.
