Visitors could ride a ''correspondent's wagon'' across a Civil War battlefield or view the Rockies from an ore bucket sky ride. But Freedomland was plagued by problems and closed in 1964, dealt its final blow by competition from the World's Fair in Queens. It was forgotten by many until Rob Friedman -- who never saw it -- created a Freedomland Web site.

title: How Safe Is the Hotel Safe?
description: LAST Sept. 1, Dr. Odi Matityahu and his wife, Liat, arrived in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, to celebrate her birthday. They checked into the Renaissance Grand Beach Resort about 3 P.M. Dr. Matityahu said that the hotel staff asked if they needed a safe for their valuables, and they were given the key to a wall safe in their room. They stored their valuables, including passports and jewelry, and went swimming. When they returned at 5:20, the room safe had been removed with a beer-can opener, which was left behind. The room door had not been forced, they said.

title: Strawberry Could Figure in Any Cost Cutting
description: Darryl Strawberry is recovering his swing slowly and steadily, his timing gradually coming back. He hit a two-run double in four at-bats in an exhibition game against Detroit in Lakeland, Fla., today, and now has 2 hits in 10 rusty at-bats. But beyond getting into shape, there is a thorny issue that must be dealt with before Strawberry joins the Yankees in the regular season, an issue that may turn ugly.

title: Daring to Be Great
description: To the Editor:

title: No Place Like Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Blessings
description: WALKING ON WATER

title: New World Noise
description: To the Editor: The charming Old World spa in Interlaken (''The Grande Luxe Spa, Swiss Style,'' by Barbara Cansino, Feb. 14) looked fabulous, especially for the glorious pool.

title: Warning: Childhood Can Lead to, Gasp, Fun
description: A few weeks ago, my 6-year-old son was about to go on a play date when he asked if he could bring his Alien Attack gun. This is a goofy weapon, in the standard Nickelodeon palette of cherry red and lime green, which would look right at home in the Star Wars cantina scene. To me, it's just a noisy piece of plastic. But who knows? Other parents may draw stricter lines. I certainly didn't want to arm my son if he was going into a suburban DMZ.

title: Councilman Stands Up For Seats
description: Though a standard school bus has 66 seats, the Board of Education allows 79 students to ride if the bus route is less than 10 miles, as are all school bus routes in New York City. But City Councilman Stephen J. Fiala, a Republican whose district office is in Eltingville, Staten Island, says he is worried about the 13 students who are legally allowed to stand while a school bus is moving.

title: 13 Are Killed By Firebomb At Busy Store In Istanbul
description: Thirteen people were killed and three others were wounded today in a bomb attack on a shopping center in an outlying section of Istanbul, police officials said.

title: Bassist Who Was There Plays Ellington the Ellington Way
description: SEATED at the piano in his home here, Dr. Aaron Bell gave Duke Ellington's own interpretation to ''Sophisticated Lady.'' He knew how the Duke would have played it because Dr. Bell, now 77, regularly played bass with the Duke Ellington Orchestra from 1960 to 1962 and sporadically in later years.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Among boomers there is a new status symbol: who is going to retire first (''Live Fast, Die Old,'' by Charles McGrath, Feb.21). The ebullient stock market, along with some generous corporate buyout programs, is allowing many in their early and mid-50's to retire. Those who are in this position speak of it in close to gloating terms. Those who are not offer their two-to-five-year plans for getting there -- which will certainly be earlier than 60.

title: PARIS PULSE; Les Musts by Metro
description: GEORGE -- V

title: WINE UNDER $20; Chardonnay for the Smart and the Thrifty
description: Cult wines are scarce and overpriced. But the easily found, succulent and refreshing Cartlidge & Browne California 1997 chardonnay is adored and sought out by novice and connoisseur alike. It's where the smart, thrifty money goes.

title: Europe Is Listening
description: To the Editor:

title: The World Apart of the Side Show
description: THE poster entices: ''You won't believe your eyes! Come see the thrills!'' Viewers step onto a ramp, a rage of vivid banners hung floor to ceiling in a two-story space.

title: In America; Bush v. Blackmun
description: Both considered themselves moderate Republicans and both were faced with the tough issue of abortion. One made a stand on principle and will be remembered as a man of courage and integrity. The other has carefully gauged the direction of the wind, and may well end up as President.

title: QUICK BITE/Upper Montclair; A Fresh Cup of Coffee
description: Restless for a new coffee experience, my husband, Alan, was cheered to notice that an alternative to Starbucks had opened in our town, so we rushed right over to Bluestone. It's a bold move to open a coffee shop in a town ruled by Starbucks, but bold Harvey Shilling is, or perhaps just smart.

title: March 7-13; Uncertainty on Kosovo Plan
description: On the eve of a second round of Kosovo peace talks, scheduled to start in Paris tomorrow, progress looked as elusive as ever. The Clinton Administration tried all week to persuade the ethnic Albanians to sign on to the peace plan, which grants autonomy to Kosovo for a three-year period with 28,000 NATO-led troops as overseers. But the Kosovo Liberation Army, concerned about having to disarm, kept debating, not signing.

title: PARIS PULSE; Les Musts by Metro
description: Fashion editors in Paris last week learned that the Metro is no longer something to sniff at. In response to complaints about the smell of sulfur and body odor in the underground, the transit authority came up with Madeleine, a perfume mixed into the wax used to clean station platforms twice a month. In a poll, riders chose the floral-bouquet scent by Quest International, which has made fragrances for Givenchy and Jean-Paul Gaultier. ''The platform smells good the day they wax it,'' said a conductor passing through Invalides, ''but maybe they ought to perfume each passenger.''

title: Fidelity Opts Out Of New S.& P. Rankings
description: You might expect mutual fund managers to jump at the prospect of inclusion in Standard & Poor's new select list of top funds. S.& P., a unit of McGraw-Hill, wants to grab some of the market for fund ratings and data now dominated by Lipper Inc. and Morningstar Inc. by publishing regular lists of the top 10 percent or so of funds in more than 15 style categories.

title: Just a Soccer Star, After All
description: Way back when Jacques Chirac didn't know Zinedine Zidane from ZZ Top, before he scored the goals that won France the World Cup in 1998, before French kids voted him more popular than Michael Jordan and French women called him sexier than Brad Pitt or Antonio Banderas, before his face was painted in street murals big enough for Stalin or Mobutu, Zinedine Zidane did something brutal and dumb.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Paris
description: A century ago, the once grand Hotel de St.-Aignan in the Marais district of Paris was a crowded tenement for Jewish families fleeing Eastern Europe. The names of their businesses covered its facade, and two floors had been added to accommodate more immigrants. Today, after a $40 million restoration, the 17th-century mansion looks nothing like a tenement: Last December, it opened as the new Museum of the Art and History of Judaism.

title: The Euro's Fickle Fingers Foil Many a Plan
description: IN January, with the arrival of the new single European currency and forecasts that the American economy would slow down in 1999, European stock markets seemed as though they would be a pretty good choice for American investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, ROBERT
description: BERKLEY-Robert. Rarely are we blessed with such a combination of compassion, humor and a deep desire to care for family and friends. We will miss his laugh, his irrepressable honesty and his undying generosity. In death, as in life, he is inspiring. We continue to learn, Grandpa, and we will never forget. We love you always. Evan and Family

title: China, Without Illusions
description: For all the twists and turns in his China policy over the last six years, President Clinton has never managed to take the full measure of this complex nation as it struggles to find its place in the world order. Mr. Clinton is not alone. China's intentions are hard to divine and even its leaders and people cannot be certain what economic, political and military role they will play in the years ahead. But Mr. Clinton and his national security team can be faulted for too often gliding over acts of Chinese belligerence in their determination to improve relations and strengthen commercial ties.

title: The Arts Should Pay Their Own Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Hatreds, New Battles
description: They began arriving at dawn, desperate to escape the brutal sectarian fighting raging in the villages they had fled. Eventually, some 6,000 Muslim refugees would throng a narrow jetty in the remote Spice Islands port of Ambon, waiting for the first ferry in weeks. When it finally docked that evening, they erupted in panic, fighting their way up its narrow gangplank, as shown in the photograph at right, passing bags and babies up over their heads.

title: In Defense of Children, Cities Offer Gun Locks
description: WHEN Julio Lopez left a loaded handgun on top of a television set recently while taking a shower, the 44-year-old security guard from Bridgeport said he realized that he had to take more care in protecting his three children, 5 through 19 years old, from such carelessness.

title: The Turban Also Unwinds
description: VIKRAM CHATWAL is one of those people who uses the word ''slash'' suspiciously often when he describes what he does for a living.

title: Going Home
description: To See and See Again A Life in Iran and America. By Tara Bahrampour. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: With Neighborliness Fading, Fences Turn Inward
description: There is a good side and a bad side to everything. Especially fences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWLON, PAUL J.
description: NEWLON-Paul J. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison express profound sorrow at the passing of Paul J. Newlon. Paul was our former partner and beloved friend, and will long be remembered for his many contributions. He was a resident of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his wife Suzanne, his daughter Joan Radner, his stepchildren Joan Alexander, Geoffrey Dodge and James Mapes Dodge III and to all the other members of his family.

title: IN BRIEF; 2 Island Students In Intel Top 10
description: Two Long Island high school seniors have landed among the top 10 winners of the Intel Science Talent Search.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASNAS, MARY (HOCHBERG)
description: HASNAS-Mary (Hochberg). On March 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Judith and Bruce Gold. Dear sister of Helen Freider. Adored Nana of Emily and Jennifer. Loving aunt. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Literary Imperialism
description: THE SCANDALS

title: The Owner of Edwards To Purchase Pathmark
description: The owners of the Edwards supermarket chain, the largest on Long Island, announced last week that it would buy the No. 2 chain, Pathmark Stores, for $1.75 billion.

title: Dance's Digital Summer
description: ONE of the happiest species of tourists traveling through Europe this summer is likely to be the dance aficionado with an interest in technology and how it enhances or changes the art. Technology and dance -- an increasingly popular topic in the United States -- will be examined in festivals in Denmark and Germany.

title: Weimar Claims Its Past, Including the Horrors
description: THERE are times when Bernd Kauffmann looks a little worn down. And for good reason: How would you like to be responsible for staging a world-class cultural program in a small city whose legacy ranges from Goethe to Buchenwald?

title: Sports of The Times; A Long Road For Lewis Doesn't End
description: THERE were times, back when they were barnstorming Canadian amateurs, when Egerton Marcus had Lennox Lewis, and Lewis had Marcus, and everyone else was an opponent speaking a language they only understood as unfriendly to them.

title: Jewish Precursors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corydalis Standbys Greet Their Distant Cousins
description: THEY are a colorful group, the corydalises. Their small, trumpet-shaped flowers are tinted in yellows, blues, reds, pinks, purples or whites. Their foliage spectrum encompasses blue-greens sheathed with silver to warm greens tipped with bronze.

title: Choirs at Center Stage
description: AS Easter approaches, the number of choral programs grow apace. This morning at 10:30, at a service in United Church on the Green in New Haven, Mark Brombaugh conducts Maurice Durufle's Requiem, with choir, soloists and Martin Jean at the organ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEGMAYER, ARTHUR H.
description: STEGMAYER-Arthur H. Of Tenafly, NJ on March 11, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Alicia (nee Ward). Devoted father of Arthur W., Alan J., Paul J., William J., Joseph H., James R. and the late Peter M. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, New Jersey, on Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday 9:30AM Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y. Memorials to Regis High School, 55 East 86 Street, N.Y.C. 10028, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLD, MORRIS
description: GOLD-Morris Gone 50 years today, you are ever loved and remembered. Your family

title: Vicar Relaxes, Then Wins Florida Derby
description: Vicar, a colt who seems to specialize in winning big races by tiny margins, won the $750,000 Florida Derby by the length of his nose today, three weeks after he won the Fountain of Youth Stakes by the length of his neck. And, in the confused rush of horses headed for the Triple Crown, he solidified his ranking as perhaps the best horse to come out of Florida and aim for the May 1 Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOEPP, JOHN HERBERT
description: DOEPP-John Herbert. March 4, 1999. At home in Brooklyn, New York. Born in Buffalo, NY, April 7, 1939, the son of Ethel Haller and John Martin Doepp. Brother of Edward Frederick Doepp. Uncle of Jennifer Margaret Doepp and Edward Frederick Doepp II, all of New Orleans. Graduate of Carnegie Tech (Carnegie-Mellon) 1963. A gifted artist and multi-talented designer, his credits include architecture (The Harlequin Atlanta), restaurant design (America Las Vegas) and scenic design. In addition to assisting Jo Mielziner, his own designs were seen at The Virginia Museum Theatre, Brunswick Music Theatre, Syracuse Stage and many other venues. He was a member of United Scenic Artists. Services will be private by invitation.

title: Teaching Do's and Don't's of Housecleaning
description: IT was training day for Unity Housecleaners, a newly formed domestics' cooperative. Polishing their cleaning skills, but not the silver, a dozen maids gathered recently at Nancy Dwyer's Valley Stream home for a final practice session in the art of doing other people's dirty work.

title: Style; Up From SoHo
description: Reticence and iconoclasm have always made an alluring combination, but Rei Kawakubo has honed them to an art. Loath to make pronouncements, she lets her Comme des Gar-->ons designs do the talking -- and even though they never speak the party line, the fashion world listens. Long acknowledged as a member of that very small club, the true avant-garde, Kawakubo is consistently provocative without resorting to sensationalism. So when she shows clothes made of laser-cut synthetic fabrics attached to what looks like unfinished patterns, or unveils an ''abstract antiperfume'' made from totally inorganic materials (to evoke burned rubber rather than roses), fashion aficionados know that Kawakubo is simply following her deconstructive instincts, which always place her ahead of the curve.

title: Susan Mermelstein, Jason Klein
description: Susan Rae Mermelstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mermelstein of Potomac, Md., was married there last evening to Jason Matthew Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Klein of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Tessler performed the ceremony at Beth Shalom Congregation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZIA, VALENTINO D.B., M.D.
description: MAZZIA-Valentino D.B., M.D. and J.D. Beloved and devoted husband of Rosana. Dear brother of Alex and the late Lloret. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Monday, at 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Poets Will Converge Upon Manhattan
description: Lower Manhattan has played host to poets and their movements for more than two centuries. Edgar Allan Poe, Dylan Thomas, Allen Ginsberg and e.e. cummings all embellished their talents, and occasionally their habits, in the East Village, SoHo, the West Village, and the Lower East Side. Next month poets from around the world will visit these historic neighborhoods for the first People's Poetry Gathering.

title: Snake-Bit on Medical Care
description: Jake Bratman noticed that his pet snake, Slither, had stopped eating a few weeks back. Not too long after, the black mites appeared.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; She'd Rather Stuff Birds
description: Lois-Ann Yamanaka concludes her trilogy of novels set among the Japanese-American working class in Hilo, Hawaii, with a work that delivers a precise look at this vibrant culture yet still speaks to anyone who has experienced the joy, security and small humiliations of family life. While it lacks the exuberant tang of ''Wild Meat and the Bully Burgers'' and the wrenching pathos of ''Blu's Hanging,'' her first two novels, HEADS BY HARRY (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24) makes up for that with its own subtle charms. Again the story focuses on a young woman's coming of age ait's about how she learns to balance the sometimes conflicting obligations to family and self. The novel's spirited heroine, Toni Yagyuu, resists her parents' plans for her to go to college and escape the limitations of life in Hilo; instead, she wants to learn the art of taxidermy from her father, Harry O. (The novel is chock-full of animals, living, stuffed and at every stage between.) Toni must also contend with an occasionally adversarial tag team made up of her brother, Sheldon, whose unspoken but obvious homosexuality infuriates her father, and her more beautiful and popular sister, Bunny. On her side, usually, are Maverick, the town hunk, and Wyatt, his angry brother. Toni stumbles from disappointment to failure to heartbreak, all the while trying to convince her hardheaded but not hardhearted father that home is where she belongs. Yamanaka ends the novel, as she did her first two, with a long list of thank-yous. In doing so, she hints at the deep bonds of community and family that inspire her raw, rich stories. Michael Porter

title: A Celebration of Bach At Purchase College
description: THE Performing Arts Center at Purchase College presents dozens of events each season, but none are more ambitious than next weekend's immersion into Bach's ''Goldberg Variations.'' ''This is not only the greatest set of keyboard variations ever written,'' said Christopher Beach, the center's director and curator of the celebration that leads up to Bach's 314th birthday, ''but a prime illustration of Bach's genius.'' Performed by international artists and annotated with lectures and films, the programs offer an opportunity to experience ''the jubilant brilliance of this masterpiece,'' Mr. Beach added.

title: With Extended Stays on the Rise, Hotels Adapt
description: HOME for Jonathan Worswick is San Diego. But since last July he has been living in Manhattan, first in one hotel and now in another -- Plaza 50, at Third Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''In the Battle of the Bags, Confusion Rules'' (Feb. 21), although Betsy Wade told us of the debate over the carry-on problem, perhaps she would have performed a greater service had she provided advice on packing to meet the various restrictions -- particularly for international flights, where the one-bag rule is standard.

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: JIM TRECKER
description: AS president of International Soccer Consultants and a special adviser to the Japanese organizing committee for the 2002 World Cup of soccer, Jim Trecker is on the road more than half the year. He recently returned to his home in Oradell, N.J., from a nine-day trip to Tokyo.

title: The Lullabies Of West Broadway
description: BAROLO**

title: March 7-13; Dr. Seuss He's Not
description: It took only hours for William J. Ivey, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, to decide about a $15,000 grant the agency had authorized for a small Texas publisher to translate an unusual children's book.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPONE, THERESA BREADEN
description: CAPONE-Theresa Breaden. Dearest Tess, I carry you always in my heart and know that we shall find each other again. Nothing will ever part us then and the love we shared God will rebuild better than before. I love you. Dino

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BENJAMIN
description: ROSEN-Benjamin. Deceased February 21, 1999. He was 104 years old. His survivors are a brother, Stanley B. Rosen, a sister, Claire Flohr, a niece, a grandnephew, a daughter, Claire Weiss, three grandsons and six great-grandchildren. He was a violinist, music teacher, a poet, and operated a music store until his 100th birthday. He was noted for the rarity of the music he sold. He was honored by Jascha Heifetz for his contribution to music. He was a good friend and loved by many.

title: The View From/Hampton; A Writer's World and the Legacy at Trail Wood
description: FORTY years ago, Edwin Way Teale and his wife, Nellie, stood in the doorway of their snug Cape Cod-style house and watched yellow lights in the field opposite them wink on and off in the soft air of a summer evening. That was how Firefly Meadow was christened.

title: On the Sears Style Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: New Directions, Literally, To Healthful Living
description: It doesn't show all the usual tourist attractions, but Healthy Map is a guide to all types of health-oriented businesses in Manhattan, including acupuncturists, natural food markets and juice bars.

title: A Reprieve for Day Care Center?
description: For 24 years, the Unidad Day Care Center on West 97th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, has looked after the children of working parents and people on welfare. Lately, though, the staff of the city-financed center have been worrying about losing their 5,000-square-foot ground-floor space.

title: Art by Mail, Web and Ono
description: INTERACTIVITY is at the heart of the art exhibition titled ''Transmit,'' on view at the Queens Library Gallery through March 28.

title: Beacon for Others
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nassau's Taxes: The Fed's Case
description: Nassau County taxes residential property in black and Hispanic communities at a considerably higher percentage of value than in other areas, according to an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, which threatened last week to sue the county for racial discrimination unless it ends the practice. The Goernment based its study on an analysis of assessed property value and market value for more than 11,000 residential properties sold in Nassau between August 1, 1995, and July 31, 1996. It then compared the results with the latest demographic data available from the Census Bureau. The analysis, broken down by census tract in two maps accompanying the study, showed a strong correlation between race and the property assessment rate, according to Zachary W. Carter, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. On avaerage, he said, the assessment rate in predominantly minority tracts was 27 percent higher than the average rate for all property in Nassau. JOHN T. MCQUISTON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALKINS, KENNETH B.
description: CALKINS-Kenneth B. Washington Square Partners want to express their sadness upon the loss of a warm and gracious friend and associate. We extend our condolences to his family and his friends upon their tragic early loss. Paul Travis, Managing Partner

title: A Million Enemies
description: BLACK HAWK DOWN

title: Florio? Oh, He's the Obstacle Standing in Pallone's Way.
description: The un-Florio.

title: Reed Almost Misses Reunion
description: Mets pitcher Rick Reed drove today to the inland town of Santiago, about a two-hour trip, to find the young Dominican he and his wife tried unsuccessfully to adopt in 1988.

title: Law School Looking to Buy a Beloved Church Building
description: For the last three years, members of the Judson Memorial Church have agonized over whether to sell or renovate their cherished but deteriorating Judson House. But now the church is in negotiations with the New York University School of Law for the sale of the property, and Peter Lahrman, the pastor, is optimistic.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Oporto
description: The era when no rule was left unbroken, no icon undefiled -- the unbridled 1960's -- is the point of departure for an audacious newcomer to Portugal's art scene, the Serralves Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: Proposal for Huge Mall in Meadowlands Is Mired in Debate
description: The Meadowlands has been viewed as many things: a shelter for wildlife, a water filtration system and a dump. And it has also been seen, because of its location a half-dozen miles from Manhattan, as a prime location for development.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Doing More With Less
description: ''Works of art, unlike pieces of literature or music, are structured by the manipulation of material properties,'' Jonathan Brown and Carmen Garrido write in VELZQUEZ: The Technique of Genius (Yale University, $50). ''By engaging with their physicality, we partake of their essence.'' The central issue of Velzquez's career was how to reconcile his artistic genius with his desire to attain social status. Brown, a professor of fine arts at New York University, explains in his brief, cogent essay how Velzquez (1599-1660) conquered the royal court of Philip IV of Spain, eventually being appointed curator of the royal collection. Garrido, the head of technical services at the Prado in Madrid, uses techniques like X-ray and infrared images (examples of which generously pepper the text) to show that Velzquez rarely started with a fixed idea, preferring to work by trial and error and invent new techniques as he went along. Eventually, he ''devised a succinct way to reach the desired effect,'' Garrido writes. ''As time went on, he was able to do more with less.'' Accompanying these essays are commentaries on 30 individual works. Robin Lippincott

title: Hampton Jitneys Also Wintering in Florida
description: LINED up along with the palm trees here the other day was a convoy of green buses with New York license plates, waiting to take 150 students from a local middle school to a medieval fair in Sarasota. A few miles away, two more green buses idled near a supermarket. Their mission -- to transport tourists to Busch Gardens in Tampa and a strawberry festival in Plant City.

title: Not-So-Light German Fare in Yorktown Hts.
description: GERMAN food has never had a reputation for being light or delicate. It is the fuel of cold regions, generous, rib-sticking fare to climb mountains with. Although it might contradict current culinary trends, food of this sort has never entirely lost its appeal, in great part because of seasonings. Forthright spices and herbs like clove, bay leaf, caraway, thyme, nutmeg, mustard, cinnamon, mace and paprika are employed without apology.

title: F's to A's in the Bronx
description: IN her first free period of the school day, Bisrat Yohannes can be found helping her guidance counselor in the offices of Ms. Yohannes's house at DeWitt Clinton High in the Bronx. She is not alone. Most days, as many as eight students at a time can be found in each of Clinton's 10 house offices, doing homework or administrative tasks or chatting with classmates, a guidance counselor or a house coordinator.

title: No One Hurt in Blast Near Abortion Clinic
description: A bomb exploded this morning near an abortion clinic in the western North Carolina city of Asheville, Federal authorities said.

title: March 7-13; Medicaid and Pain Relief
description: Medicaid officials have reminded doctors and hospitals that they must not demand cash payments for anesthesia services from poor women in labor.

title: The One Let Go
description: To the Editor:

title: From Nigeria to a Queens Classroom
description: NEW YORK still amazes Christian Ugbode. The cold weather. The graffiti. The freedom of expression. ''A student called a teacher a 'bitch,' and nothing happened to him,'' he said. ''There is too much freedom. There should be limits.''

title: Garson Kanin, a Writer and Director of Classic Movies and Plays, Is Dead at 86
description: Garson Kanin, who broke into show business as a saxophone-playing high school dropout and went on to write ''Born Yesterday,'' direct ''The Diary of Anne Frank'' and become the co-writer of two classic Tracy-Hepburn movies, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: N.F.L. Plans to Make Decision On Its 32d Team This Week
description: Bob McNair wants to own the National Football League's 32d team, and wants it in Houston. Eli Broad and Michael Ovitz, who are leading competing expansion groups in Los Angeles, want the team in their city.

title: Tiny Gonzaga Comes Up Big In Stanford's Land of the Giants
description: Tiny Gonzaga joined the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's tradition of giant-killers today by shocking second-seeded Stanford, 82-74, in the second round of the West Region at Key Arena.

title: Cultural Perversions
description: Sex and Social Justice

title: Lasting Attributes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Nation: Pondering a White House Shrink; Every First Family Is Unhappy in Its Own Way
description: IN the aftermath of the Monica S. Lewinsky scandal, people are wondering what can be done to prevent such a mess from ever occurring again. For one thing, both major parties are poised to eliminate, or at least eviscerate, the Office of the Independent Counsel.

title: A Composer At Last Comes Into Her Own
description: Amy Cheney Beach was born in 1867, but it has taken until now -- next month, actually -- for her to be inducted into American music's Hall of Fame. Plenty of people have never heard of her, but ''it's all starting to happen now,'' said Joanne Polk, who is recording ''everything she wrote that's remotely for piano.''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: A Hero's Homecoming; Nets' Marbury Lives Out Dreams of His Old Neighborhood

title: Sports of The Times; Jarvis's Rebuilding Passes a Huge Test
description: SUDDENLY, the sky is looking to be the limit for St. John's. A team that was picked to finish fourth in its own league, a team with a freshman point guard, a first-year coach and a volatile sophomore star, is headed to the Round of 16 for the first time since 1991.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- Body Check Coffee; To Drink or Not to Drink
description: No substance has been the subject of more urgent health bulletins -- all mutually contradictory -- than coffee. Over the years, countless teams of undercaffeinated researchers have declared that it's bad for just about every bit of human flesh -- and they published reports that Americans eagerly consumed along with their morning coffee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISHER, DOROTHY
description: ENGLISHER-Dorothy. The Board of the YM/YWHA of Washington Heights and Inwood mark with great sadness the death of Dorothy Englisher, a longterm Washington Heights resident and early supporter of the Y. She introduced her son Martin to this agency and encouraged him throughout his successful leadership of the center. Her caring and compassion will be missed. Our deepest sympathy to her husband Elihu and her sons Martin and Larry. Dr. Ruth Westheimer, President

title: Women in Jail Find Voice in Writing
description: CATHY TROCHECK, 50, an inmate at the Westchester County Correction Facility here, was clearly terrified. She had written a poem and now it was time to read it aloud.

title: Polluted Runoff
description: The most common source of water pollution is runoff -- from city streets, parking lots, marinas, construction sites, logging sites and roadways -- and it threatens the public health and the economy of coastal communities. That is the conclusion of a report released by 20 organizations, including Save the Sound, an environmental group in Glen Cove and Stamford.

description: BIR -- HAKEIM

title: INSIDE
description: Istanbul Firebombs Kill 13

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You know, in my country, every time I walk the street, I was with one of my friends. Here, when I get out of school, I walk by myself. Nobody talks to me. I don't talk to nobody. I feel, 'Where I am? Where I am?''

title: Editorial Observer; Hail to the Chief and Pass the Word Processor
description: George Stephanopoulos seems to feel bad, in retrospect, that he did not press Bill Clinton harder about what went on with Gennifer Flowers before jumping to his candidate's defense. ''I needed Clinton to see me as his defender, not his interrogator, which made me, of course, an enabler,'' he writes in his new memoir, ''All Too Human.'' Ambivalence and regret are the two main emotional chords in the book, but in this case Mr. Stephanopoulos seems to be beating himself up unnecessarily. Throughout American history, when a bimbo eruption has hit an American Presidential campaign, the last thing a candidates' aides have considered doing is asking the Big Guy for the real story. When Grover Cleveland was accused of having an illegitimate child, he ordered his advisers to ''tell the truth'' and went off to sulk for the rest of the campaign. Nobody ran after him to ask exactly what the truth was supposed to be.

title: Vatican Seeks Mercy For Pope's Assailant
description: The Vatican has let the Italian Government know that it would favor clemency for Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who tried to assassinate the Pope in 1981.

title: Of Top Khmer Rouge, Only One Awaits Judgment
description: In the end he was alone, the last fighter left in the brutal three-decade-long Khmer Rouge insurgency. As his colleagues surrendered and were embraced by the Government, the peasant general Ta Mok remained in the jungle, searching in vain for a place to hide.

title: Jeanne Tedeschi, Patrick Dwyer
description: Jeanne Marie Tedeschi, a daughter of Kathleen M. Tedeschi of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Richard F. Tedeschi of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Dwyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Dwyer of Wall, N.J. The Rev. William Reynolds performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Security Council Relegated to Sidelines
description: In a world with conflicts raging from Angola to Kosovo, the United Nations Security Council, the heart of the world body, finds itself increasingly marginalized.

title: 609 Divided by 2 Will Equal Area Code 856
description: The new area code for residents of southwestern New Jersey, now part of 609, will be 856. The change takes effect June 12, although area 609, both codes will work until Nov. 13. The change will not affect rates, and cellular phones with area 609 will keep it. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Crime Wave

title: Dinner, Dancing and, Oh Yes, Art
description: AS New York's social establishment took their seats at the annual winter gala for the Whitney Museum of American Art, Andre Harrell was perplexed. Sitting beneath a giant orb of white carnations, Mr. Harrell, a rap producer, gazed upon guests like Ronald O. Perelman, John F. Kennedy Jr. and Martha Stewart, and asked: ''What is this about? And what does this have to do with hip-hop?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSH, JACK
description: KARSH-Jack. Of Riverdale, New York, died of heart failure on March 4th, 1999 at Montefiore Hospital's Cardiac Unit. He was 83 years old. Beloved husband and best friend of Frieda. Adored father of Babette Wasserman and Rowena Karsh-Hymson, sons-inlaw Steven Wasserman and Michael Hymson. Cherished and devoted grandfather of Dr. Eric J. Wasserman and wife Deborah, Brooke Wasserman and Brian & Lara, Rowena's children. He was born and lived in New York City all his life. He was graduated from City College at age 19 and received a Master's Degree in English six months later. Professionally, he was completely devoted to the field of education. He taught English in high school, and became Principal of P.S. 94, Bronx. He was Confidential Secretary to the Bronx Commissioner of Education and a faculty member of Bronx Community College and Hunter College Graduate School.He retired in 1977 from his professional activi ties. Mr. Karsh was a longtime member of the Riverdale Jewish Center and Vice President of its men's club. He loved the outdoors, was an avid tennis player, and had a country home at Lake Louise Marie at Rock Hill, NY where he was also an active member of the Crescent Hill Synagogue. Funeral Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York, and burial took place at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, New York. Memorial remembrances may be made to the charity of choice.

title: Solo in the Big City: Women's Tales From the Front
description: THE SETTING -- The downstairs lounge of the Astor Bar on the Bowery, where 200 people turned out Wednesday night for a party celebrating the publication ''On the Loose: Big City Days and Nights of Three Single Women'' (William Morrow) by Melissa Roth, a 31-year-old single woman. Most of the guests were women, many appeared to be single, and some were talking about the amusing, disconcerting and sometimes bizarre experiences they had while dating.

title: Andre Ernotte, 55, A Versatile Director
description: Andre Gilbert Ernotte, a playwright, filmmaker and director of stage, television and opera productions in New York and Europe, died on March 8 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

title: My Bonus Is Smaller Than Yours
description: Q. I am a manager at a company that regularly uses cash rewards and other recognition to single out employees for outstanding work. The program was a big morale builder in my group, until word got around that the winners in the marketing department received much more money than those in other departments, including ours. (It was news to me, too.) Short of getting the president to balance the awards, which he has so far refused to consider, how can I relieve my staff's resentment and restore the incentives' effectiveness?

title: A New 'Annie,' The Same Old Berlin Magic
description: IRVING BERLIN, born Israel Baline, was 5 when his family emigrated from Byelorussia to the United States in 1893 and settled on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. By 1910 he was an established Tin Pan Alley songwriter. The following year, with his first great success, ''Alexander's Ragtime Band,'' his career as America's premier composer and lyricist took off and never seriously faltered for much of the rest of the century.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: I , too, intend to burn out rather than rust, albeit with a little less chrome. But I don't need to retire to have a romantic date and share a glass of chardonnay with my wife.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 14, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The Dow Soars. The Market Snores.
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average threatening to top 10,000, stock market investors may want to break out a bit of the bubbly and celebrate their good fortune. If so, better to uncork some of the cheap stuff and leave the Dom Perignon on ice.

title: Charges Against Prospect Dropped
description: The case against Ruddi De La Cruz, one of five Mets minor leaguers accused of raping a 17-year-old woman last April in Port St. Lucie, Fla., has been dismissed.

title: Teaching the Teachers, a Group Effort
description: TEACHERS operate in a group setting, but still may feel removed from other teachers. They may interact with colleagues at their school, but rarely does that connection extend to other teachers in their district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SHYKA
description: COHEN-Shyka. Beloved son, brother, uncle, gallery owner and real estate developer died on Wednesday, March 10, in New York City. He was 47 years old. Born and raised in Tel Aviv, Israel, he immigrated to the United States in 1973 after serving in the Israeli army. He studied fine art, his love, at the Maryland Institute College of Art and moved to New York in 1977 to study architecture and design. He designed and renovated many residential and commercial spaces in Manhattan and eventually formed his own company to develop and restore city properties. Fine art remained his first love. In 1996, after a long fight with cancer during which he received a kidney from his mother, he opened the Ice Gallery, dedicated to promoting non-conceptual 20th Century art. He sponsored several artists whose work represented what he considered to be traditional values, and he worked with the Maryland Institute College of Art to begin an exchange program for art students in the United States and Israel. His mother, Elizabeth Dagani-Cohen, and a brother, Eitan Cohen, survive him. Both reside in Tel Aviv. Mr. Cohen will be interred at the Mount of Olives Cemetery in Israel. Friends may pay their last respects at a memorial service to be held at the Ice Gallery on Monday, March 15 at 7:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to the Kidney Foundation of New York would be appreciated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Bits and Pieces of an Alter Ego
description: WITH everything you lost on this vacation, you could build a whole other person!'' said my husband.

title: The Many Faces Of Hunger; Even in an Affluent County, Many Have Little To Spend on Food After Paying the Rent
description: IN this well-to-do county where the median price of a single-family house is $340,000 and the median income $61,861, the problem of hunger is often difficult to see.

title: March 7-13; Crayola Changes Stripes
description: Sometimes a few simple strokes can hint at the sweep of history -- strokes of a crayon, say. Only twice in 96 years had Crayola changed a color's name, rechristening ''Prussian blue'' as ''midnight blue'' in 1958 because people had lost track of exactly what Prussia was, and changing ''flesh'' to ''peach'' in 1962, recognizing that flesh is a many-colored thing. Now it will relabel ''indian red'' to wipe out any associations with Native Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELY, ALICE ELEANOR (NEE VANCE)
description: SEELY - Alice Eleanor (nee Vance). Age 89, died March 10. Adored wife of the late Leonard Seely for 43 years. Beloved aunt of Jeanne Pape and Harry Schneider, Jr. Honored sister-in-law of Harry Schneider, Sr. For 35 years a gifted and devoted teacher of young children in the NYC school system. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, on Sunday, March 21, at the Union Church of Bay Ridge, 80th St. and Ridge Blvd.

title: Whether Hip or Not Clubs Can Be Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column last Sunday gave an outdated address for Paola's. The restaurant moved last May to 245 East 84th Street from 343 East 85th Street.

title: Of the Plight of Workers, Portraits With Evanescence
description: TWO unrelated, one-person photography exhibitions at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven are nevertheless tied together in their overriding sensibility. Both shows communicate a strong sense of loss. Both photographers convey this poignancy through visual elegance.

title: It's All-American Favorites That Please
description: HAMBURGERS, roast chicken, meat balls, macaroni and cheese, bread pudding and chocolate layer cake are America's soul food. At Gonzalo and Joe's American Cafe in Glen Cove, dishes like these cost less and taste better than most comparable fare elsewhere on the Island. It is a restaurant your stomach and pocket book will welcome. This storefront bistro, at 5 School Street (656-0003), serves no-nonsense meals that fill, warm and satisfy chilled diners on wintery nights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, BRENDA
description: GOLDFRANK-Brenda. Of Manhasset, NY, died on March 11, 1999. She was predeceased by her loving husband Richard and son Bruce. She is survived by her daughter Diane Richards and her grandson David Goldfrank. Mrs. Goldfrank was born in 1915 in Northampton, MA, and attended Colby-Sawyer College. During her life she and her husband divided their time between their homes in Manhasset and Tangiers, Morocco. Donations may be made to the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS).

title: Editor's Note
description: A photo essay in The Times Magazine on Feb. 7 depicted the chic night life on the French Caribbean island of St. Barts. The essay included a picture of the rapper Sean (Puffy) Combs at a party he gave; he was pointing to a woman wearing a low-cut dress. In fact the photograph had been retouched to reveal less of the woman's breast.

title: Lemieux Is Trying to Save the Bankrupt Penguins
description: Once again, Mario Lemieux was the center, moving forward with purpose and with teammates on each wing. But this was not a comeback for the retired hockey star who left the game too soon because of injuries and illness. Instead of wearing Pittsburgh Penguins uniforms and carrying hockey sticks, these men wore business suits and carried briefcases. Instead of crossing ice, they moved over the sidewalks of midtown Manhattan.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Your ethical solution to the parents who let their 4-year-old boy play naked when they visit is to chatter hopefully and misleadingly about everything but the reason the hosts are upset (The Ethicist, Feb. 21). Most of us would be inclined to say flatly, if not totally truthfully, ''We think it's great that you let your kid play in the nude, but this is not O.K. in our house, and it's making our 9-year-old uncomfortable.''

title: Not a Pretty Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Spend, Spend, Spend
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, KENNETH J.
description: LYONS-Kenneth J. On March 11, 1999. Adored husband of Roslyn. Beloved father of David Lyons and Judy Gomby. Loving and devoted Grandpa of Jonathan and Samantha Lyons, Joshua, Rebecca and Daniel Gomby. Cherished father in-law and friend of Margaret Lyons and Gary Gomby. We will all miss his great warmth and affection. Donations in his memory to American Cancer Society.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Prague
description: Alfons Mucha was the Andy Warhol of his era, a decorative artist who defined a style -- Art Nouveau -- and became a media star.

title: Rappers Who Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/A Studio in the East 80's for $1,175 a Month; SqueezingInto250Sq.Feet
description: ALEXANDER BLAKE is probably not living in the smallest studio apartment in New York. It has room for a queen-size bed, a combination bureau and night table, a very small couch and a television. On a recent evening, he apologized for the dim light shed by his sole lamp. He plans to buy more lamps, but their placement will have to be considered carefully. End tables could prove hazardous.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: All in the Family

title: Signature Not Required (But the Tax Is Still Due)
description: THE signing of income tax returns, an American ritual in its 86th year, is being swept into the dustbin of history.

title: Lost Youth In Ireland: Suicide Rate Is Climbing
description: Though long stereotyped as a happy land of pious churchgoers and bibulous dancers of jigs, Ireland is suffering a sharply rising increase in suicides, particularly among young men.

title: The World; Wherever That Town Is, Someone Will Die for It
description: IT would seem like the simplest of questions, one that could be settled with a few good maps and maybe a cheap global positioning device: Where on Earth, quite literally, is the town of Badme?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYRICH, MARION S.
description: MEYRICH-Marion S. 92, of Sarasota, FL, died March 11, 1999. Born on June 20, 1906 in NYC where she taught for 30 years. Survivors include son, Victor, grandson, Hart, niece Mona. No services planned. Donations may be made to American Civil Liberties Union. Remains will be placed next to her husband, Herman at Ferncliff Cemetery in Westchester.

title: The Sensuous Duo
description: Life With Swan

title: There Will Always Be an England
description: Andrew Sullivan reports the changes that are rapidly taking place in England's economy, politics and culture, but to epitomize those changes by asserting they imply an ''end'' is too simplistic to define British reality. History records the ''end'' of the dinosaur, but Britain is no dinosaur.

title: The Nation; Running With (and From) a Famous Name
description: ANNOUNCING her Presidential exploratory committee here last week, Elizabeth Dole invoked the last Republican hero, Ronald Reagan. Three days earlier, presenting his own committee in Austin, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas mentioned the first Republican hero, Abraham Lincoln.

title: Greening the Silver Screen
description: ''I'm 30 years old,'' Terry Mulligan said, ''and after I put this thing together, I will have aged another 30 years.'' Mr. Mulligan, a second-generation Irish-American from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the man behind a four-day Irish film festival called the Film Fleadh (fleadh, pronounced flah, is Gaelic for festival) at the Directors Guild of America Theater at 110 West 57th Street. He created it from scratch, he said, and he needed a sense of humor to keep him going.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 14, 1999
description: Weeks

title: N.Y.U., '97 Champ, Is Eliminated
description: New York University was knocked out of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament in the Mid-Atlantic Regional championship game last night with an 81-60 loss to the University of Scranton at Scranton, Pa.

title: A Costly Noble Idea
description: SHOW ME A HERO A Tale of Murder, Suicide, Race, and Redemption. By Lisa Belkin. 331 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $25.

title: Baring the Intricacies of Desire and Shame
description: ''IF you can't dazzle them, shock them!'' the adolescent heroine of Catherine Breillat's 1989 film ''36 Fillette'' declares, with a glance at her own daring decollete. Could that be the French director's motto? Ms. Breillat, who is 50, is no stranger to scandal. From her first novel, written when she was 17, to her most recent film, ''Romance,'' her candid dissections of human sexuality have ignited debate at home and abroad.

title: UConn Welcomes Calhoun With Fast Start and a Romp
description: No shocks, no surprises, no problems. There was not even a hint of them for Connecticut today. The Huskies swaggered onto the court fully focused on continuing their march toward a national championship, and they did it in an emphatic manner. New Mexico was dazed before intermission.

title: POSTINGS: The City's Rules Are on the Web; Zoning Code In Cyberspace
description: What's to stop a sign from being erected on a rooftop in a commercial district? Section 32-657 of the Zoning Resolution. What's to say that pedestrian circulation areas along the waterfront are to be open to the public from dawn to dusk? Section 62-624.

title: The Coleridge Scholar Who Took On Marlowe
description: ROSS MACDONALD

title: Private Sector; Warburg's Big Wager
description: A collective gasp was heard on Wall Street last week. Who, traders and bankers asked, could really be worth $70 million? To Warburg Dillon Read, the investment banking business of UBS A.G. of Switzerland, which was struggling to bolster its presence in the United States, the answer was Benjamin Lorello, a Salomon Smith Barney health care banker. Mr. Lorello left for Warburg after being offered more than $50 million in salary and bonuses over three years and about $25 million in deferred stock benefits.

title: Ms. Berman, Mr. Rosenberg
description: Lauren Shelby Berman and Andrew I. Rosenberg, associates at law firms in Miami, were married last evening in Aventura, Fla. Rabbi Edward Maline performed the ceremony at the Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Bolzano
description: Soon after it was discovered melting out of an Alpine glacier in 1991, the 5,300-year-old corpse known as the Iceman was heralded as the world's oldest naturally preserved body. For the next six years, Austrian scientists shielded the Iceman from the public, bundling him in layers of sterile sheets, pack ice and plastic in a walk-in freezer in Innsbruck. Most said the risk of light and microbiological damage would prevent the delicate remains from ever being displayed.

title: The New Order in the Court; Long Considered the Nation's Best, the State Supreme Court May Be Losing Its Edge
description: WHATEVER the rest of the country says about New Jersey, it accepts that the state has the legal equivalent of the New York Yankees. It has the New Jersey Supreme Court. The words that consistently come up are ''pre-eminent,'' ''path-breaking,'' even ''brilliant.'' For years, law professors have told their classes to pay attention to this court's decisions.

title: Wolf Ulrich von Hassell, 85, German Ambassador
description: Wolf Ulrich von Hassell, a former West German ambassador to the United Nations who helped the German resistance to Hitler during World War II and oversaw his country's post-war transition to full membership in international organizations, died at his home in Southampton, N.Y., on March 3.

title: Celebrity Undermines Conscience
description: IT must amuse Arthur Laurents to discover that his 7-year-old play ''Jolson Sings Again,'' which was prompted by outtakes from the 26-year-old screenplay ''The Way We Were'' and deals with an ignominious time 50 years ago -- blacklisting in Hollywood -- is suddenly a prelude to the presentation of an honorary Academy Award to Elia Kazan. Mr. Kazan is at once a celebrated director and, to many minds, the unforgivable informer nonpareil.

title: Steps, Turns and Leaps in a Time of Transition for Two Companies
description: ONE choreographer's return to New Jersey intersects, by chance, with another's departure, bringing out important issues in the dance world. Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company is back after Ms. Dorfman's yearlong sabbatical, while Septime Webre is leaving American Repertory Ballet to become artistic director of the Washington Ballet, which performs at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The parallels are skewed, perhaps, but they uncover the state's healthy profusion of possibilities.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Kicking Off The Blankets
description: On days without bright sun, begin removing evergreen boughs protecting shrubs and perennials. Keep them handy so they can be replaced quickly if an ice storm threatens. Nudge aside (but don't remove for several weeks) other mulches from around the crowns of perennials. Firmly push down any plants that are frost-heaved.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: My wife and I travel with rolling bags. While I believe some restrictions are necessary, I would like to point out that the space between seats has gotten tighter as some airlines have jammed in more rows. I have spent five minutes or more trying to get the bags under the seats in front of us, pushing up the cushion of my seat to maneuver them in. On one occasion, I had to put the suitcase in the overhead compartment.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Edinburgh
description: Edinburgh, Scotland's stateliest city, is already known as a center for some of Britain's finest collections of art. Among its most distinguished museums are the three National Galleries of Scotland -- the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art and the National Gallery of Scotland. Starting on March 27, there is to be a fourth, the Dean Gallery, set on landscaped parkland across the street from the Gallery of Modern Art and designed to be a new home for Scottish and European modern art.

title: Ideas & Trends: Talking Heads; The Silent Celebrity and the Quotable Recluse
description: IN Joe DiMaggio's day, athletes were expected to play, not talk. Still, the shy Yankee legend, who died last week at 84, did thousands of interviews over six decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, LOUIS
description: BERKLEY-Louis. On March 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of David, Richard and Robert. Dear brother of Sara Greenwood. Cherished grandfather of Amy, Andrew, Rachael and Margaret. A wonderful man who touched everyone with his kindness and who will be truly missed.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Change is only good if it is an improvement. Yours, in my view, is not.

title: Nihilsm Gets a Butcher's Face, France a Jolt of Realism
description: AFTER seeing ''I Stand Alone,'' after meeting its 35-year-old director, Gaspar Noe, one couldn't help but ask: How could a pleasant young man with a positive view of life make a film as dark and desperate as this one?

title: Lower Interest Rates
description: The state's Mortgage Agency has dropped its interest rate, under a low-interest-rate program, to 5.5 percent. To expand the number of families eligible for its programs, effective March 1, the program, commonly known as Sonyma, also increased the household income limits for house buyers.

title: Timber Rattlesnake Puts Development on Endangered List
description: A sleeping snake has awakened environmentalists and bitten a developer, who has been forced to stop work on homes in the Pinelands.

title: Candid Cameras
description: To the Editor: The article ''Statue of Liberty, Central Park and Me'' by Ted Botha (Feb. 21) brought to mind two of my snapshots. One, taken in a park in Rio de Janeiro, revealed a rear view of a male tourist in shorts, shirtless, which was reflected in a mirrored cube. My camera was aimed at some musicians who were performing above the cube.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSON, SALLY
description: MICHELSON-Sally. Beloved wife of Judge Harry Michelson. Devoted sister and sister-in-law. Loving aunt. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on Feb. 21, about East Berlin, referred incorrectly to the mushrooms known in German as Steinpilze. They are cepes, not chanterelles, and are also known as boletus.

title: Geneva
description: As Easter approaches, it's the time of year that Geneva shakes off its winter doldrums, stops being a way station for skiers and comes into its own as a lovely flower-filled city on western Europe's largest lake.

title: Cruise Extras
description: To the Editor: To add to what Betsy Wade wrote about the extra costs on a luxury cruise ship (''At Sea, Extras Can Add Up Fast,'' Jan. 31), let me say that Crystal Cruises' ships have tried to address this situation by giving passengers a shipboard credit of $200 or more.

title: State Pressures Insurers To Reduce Auto Rates
description: If automobile insurance companies do not reduce rates by 15 percent, or close to it, by March 22, the state will do it for them, the Banking and Insurance Commissioner, Jaynee LaVecchia, warned last week.

title: Who's Really in Charge Here Anyway?
description: IS the local wildlife in some kind of revolt? Is it trying to take back the territory that it once had?

title: FAR FROM HOME, ALONE -- A special report.; Young Immigrants Find a Hard New Land
description: Monir was hardly among the huddled, hungry masses of Bangladesh when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport three years ago. His father was an engineer; everyone expected Monir would go to college and study accounting.

title: Discovering the Modern Ties In a Corsetted Ibsen Creation
description: EVER since Henrik Ibsen wrote ''Hedda Gabler'' in 1890, the role has tantalized and lured actresses. The tragedy, about a bored, vengeful wife on the edge of madness, has been interpreted, with various degrees of Freudian and feminist shadings, by Eva Le Gallienne, Geraldine Page, Maggie Smith, Glenda Jackson, Jane Alexander and Dianne Wiest, among others. ''What Hamlet is to men, Hedda is, in some ways, to women,'' said Annette Bening, the latest Hedda, who has found the role the most complex and haunting of her career.

title: Cheap Air Fares: Bidding on the Web
description: A New York tour operator and airline-ticket consolidator has opened a Web site to accept bids on domestic and overseas tickets, and the owner says that no bid -- not even $1 -- is too small to start. Many of the fares have limited windows of availability; others, particularly for students, offer a round trip to anywhere in the United States to be used in a wide period of time.

title: Loft Pioneers' New Frontiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SUSPICION

title: SWF, 56, Seeks . . .
description: PICKING UP

title: Lives; The Fiber-Optic Confessional
description: I am a customer service representative. Along with 140 other C.S.R.'s here at the corporate home office, I answer the phone for a major company. Specifically, I field questions from customers about their present insurance policies. In a very real way, like my counterparts at General Motors, General Electric or AT&T;, I am the Voice -- and the Ears -- of Corporate America.

title: Men, Women, Sex And Darwin
description: Natalie Angier plays the gender card in order to portray evolutionary psychology as a sexist science. She selectively quotes male defenders and female critics, ignoring the many women who shaped the field (Feb. 21). She fabricates a preposterous claim -- that women want a man who can ''maybe dominate them just a little'' -- to inflame her readers, but the claim contradicts the central tenet of evolutionary psychology, that women's and men's emotions serve their partly competing interests. Angier garbles the claim that women's sexual desire is different from men's into the claim that it is puny, warps my explanation of Clinton's behavior into an ''apologia'' and repeatedly takes credit for arguments that her targets have been making for decades.

title: Cinema Dispute's Sequel: The Ins and Outs of a New Ramp
description: Last week, Forest City Ratner, which is developing a 14-screen multiplex, yielded to residents' demands and offered to build a second ramp to the theater's rooftop parking lot. But instead of ending a yearlong conflict, the proposal has created another, this one among neighbors.

title: Art and a Racial Murder Meet on a London Stage
description: WHICH new play has provoked the most attention in the British theater so far this year? Which has garnered the most column inches in the press, the most hours on television, and by far the most enthusiastic reviews? No, the answer is not some striking drama at the National or a searing satire at the Royal Court. It has been a defiantly undemonstrative, unpretentiously devastating piece called ''The Color of Justice'' that opened in January in the little Tricycle Theater in the unfashionable North London area of Kilburn and went on to replace a revival of ''Annie'' at a 1,500-seat theater in the West End, where it ended its run yesterday.

title: Freshman Sets Record in Pole Vault
description: Samantha Shepard, a high school freshman from Weston, Mass., set a national indoor record yesterday in the girls' pole vault when she cleared 12 feet 7 inches. Shepard set the mark at the National Interscholastic Indoor Championships at the Reggie Lewis Center in Boston. The national best was 12-6i by Michelle Kercado of Monroe, N.Y., who finished third in yesterday's event at 11-11.

title: Another Hoedown at Saturn Ranch
description: NO plans for a summer vacation? If you own a Saturn automobile -- or are just a Saturn groupie -- the General Motors Corporation's import-fighting subsidiary wants to show you a good time.

title: Innocent or Not So? The Shifting Visions of Childhood
description: THE exact dates are debated, but many historians agree that the idea of childhood innocence developed in the 18th century. Before then, they argue, children were generally viewed as little adults who would benefit from discipline.

title: As Tough As, Well, Netting a Butterfly
description: LIKE Muhammad Ali in his boxing prime, financial wagers on the Year 2000 problem can float like a butterfly, sting like a bee. Just ask futures traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Like Cures Like
description: The Law

title: Theft From Disabled
description: Thelma Moore, 46, an employee of the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities, has been arrested and charged with fourth-degree grand larceny, a class E felony, in connection with the reported theft of $1,186.23 in cash from disabled residents of a group home in the village of Sleepy Hollow, where she worked as a house manager.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGULIES, ESTELLE
description: MARGULIES - Estelle. Happy Birthday to my beautiful, adored sister, grandmother, great-grandmother. Love you and miss you more each day. Eternal Love. Diane, Robert, Michael, Denise and Demi.

title: In the Region /Westchester; A Mix for a Tuckahoe Site Vacant for a Decade
description: IN this smallest Westchester municipality, an ambitious village-like development, featuring mixed-use housing, a restaurant and an assisted-living facility will rise on a prime commercial site near the center of downtown and a short walk from the Metro-North train station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, MALCIA
description: GELLER-Malcia. Died on March 1st, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Israel Geller, cherished mother of Martin J. Geller and Ellen H. Kamaras, loving grandmother of Joshua, Jackie, Sarah, Harrison and Logan. A true eshet chayel, a woman of valor, far beyond pearls was her value. She devoted her whole life to family and friends. We will miss her love and kindness everyday. She touched us all and her light brightened our world. Contributions may be made to the Abraham Joshua Heschel School, 314 West 91 Street, New York, NY 10024, Att: Ms. Tracy Port.

title: Game Serves as an Elixir for Dominicans' Suffering
description: Omar Minaya stared out the window of the Mets' team bus, taking in the devastation Hurricane Georges had wrought.

title: Experts Concerned About Return Of Deadly Bacteria in Cold Cuts
description: Contamination of hot dogs and cold cuts by a sometimes deadly bacterium -- one that is little known by the public -- has led to an extraordinary series of recalls in recent months, as well as increased Government action to detect the problem sooner and prevent it.

title: To Revive a Sick Economy, Japan Hands Out Coupons
description: With all the strength of her 90 years, Chizuko Miyata clutched her crisp, cream-colored coupons and began dreaming of what she would buy with them.

title: An Advocate for Oppressed Scientists
description: Joel L. Lebowitz, a professor of mathematics and physics at Rutgers University, is an advocate for scientists in oppressed countries. Through his work with the Committee of Concerned Scientists and several other international organizations, Dr. Lebowitz, 68, of Princeton, has helped to gain freedom for the Russian scientist Andrei Sakharov and the astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, who supported dissident students during the Tianenmen Square massacre.

title: Lisa Margolin, Andrew Merkatz
description: Lisa Ann Margolin, a behavioral therapist, and Andrew Phillip Merkatz, an advertising executive, were married last evening by Rabbi Judith S. Lewis at Temple Israel in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINOY, SUSAN
description: KINOY-Susan. The Block Island (RI) community of Susan's friends mourns her passing after so many years at her joyous summer home. She takes with her a portion of the beautiful island landscape that is so dear to all of us & to which she contributed so much. She made us see afresh each season the special quality of the sea, the light that graces the cliffs and the beaches that held, for her, a multitude of family and friends. No toddler with her first sandpail was unnoticed by Susan; no longabsent Islander was hailed with more pleasure by anyone more than Susan. For her, the island was yet another site in which she could express her special quality of love for people, for the land on which she picked wild blackberries and for the sun and ocean so nourishing to her soul. Summer will not be the same without Susan, but her warm laughter and dear, loving spirit will echo among the bayberry and the gardens always. Susan's Block Island Friends

title: Hair, Nails, Facial, Massage, And Hold All Calls
description: ''A relaxing world with no telephones'' is the way Joan Murray describes her six-week-old day spa in Brooklyn Heights named Tapestry. The communications ban on the service floor -- the office phone is (718) 522-1202 -- is an attempt, she says, to insure a complete focus on the customer during hair, manicure, facials or massage. The site is 107 Montague Street (between Hicks and Henry Streets). Ms. Murray previously helped run a marketing business, and raised her family. At her new spa, patrons can sip coffee or tea on heated reclining chairs as they luxuriate in Tapestry's services, like facials for $65 and massages, $75.

title: Ms. Bissu, Mr. Dansinger
description: Rem Bissu, a daughter of Nadine and Alfred Bissu of Brooklyn, is to be married there this evening to Dr. Michael Lee Dansinger, a son of Sheila and Stuart Dansinger of Minneapolis. Dr. Milton Kroopnich, the senior rabbi at Temple Hillel in Brooklyn, is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zion.

title: In a Tribute to a Tactician, The Play Evokes His Esprit
description: The Second Stage of the Russian Cup, a 129-entrant Swiss-system Tournament in Moscow in late February, was dedicated this year as a memorial to Yefim Geller, a frequent candidate for the world championship who died in November. Two young Russian grandmasters, 20-year-old Mikhail Kobalija and 25-year-old Aleksandr Rustemov, shared first place with 7 1/2 points in 9 rounds.

title: Clinton Initiatives to Promote Trust in Police
description: President Clinton said today that recent reports of police misconduct had shaken the public's faith in the police, and he proposed several measures that he said would help restore that trust.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on Feb. 14 about a ghostly apparition in a firehouse on West Third Street in Greenwich Village misstated the site at which Edgar Allan Poe wrote his poem ''The Raven.'' It was a farmhouse on West 84th Street, not a house on West Third Street.

title: 13 Different Approaches Toward Architecture
description: CLAIRE FISHMAN, the exhibition's curator, has brought together 13 artists, including herself, with an eye toward architecture, with the intention of revealing a variety of unusual approaches that are both intellectually and emotionally rewarding. This is a tall order for any curator, as is all too apparent in the current exhibition at the Paramount Center for the Arts tilted ''Architectonics.''

title: Private Sector; Restoring the Junk Bond King
description: THERE, on one stage at a conference, sat some of the best economic minds in the nation -- Gary Becker, Nobel laureate; Merton H. Miller, Nobel laureate; Douglass North, Nobel laureate; Myron S. Scholes, Nobel laureate, and Michael R. Milken, fallen financier.

title: Still a Mover and Shaker With Harlem on His Mind
description: FROM his office window, Arthur Mitchell, artistic director of Dance Theater of Harlem, was looking out on an undistinguished block of West 152d Street near Amsterdam Avenue, not far from where he spent his childhood. Across the street, next to an overgrown lot, are a couple of abandoned buildings. ''We'll be putting dorms in there soon so our out-of-town students won't have to stay with local families,'' he said, standing up behind his desk for a better view. ''They're being made landmarks. Look at the details.'' The bright winter sun cast stark shadows on the elaborate cornices.

title: Food; The Pot Luck of the Irish
description: Many different Irelands came to dinner the other night. They came from here and there. There was the Anglo-Irish and the American-Irish. The self-loathing and the self-congratulatory Irish. The young, recently arrived Irish and the Irish who have lived here longer than they've lived there. But no matter where they were from, and what they had done in life, all 16 people shared a singular antipathy for St. Patrick's Day.

title: March 7-13; Intel Settles Antitrust Suit
description: The Intel Corporation settled an antitrust case brought by the Government just before the trial was to begin, agreeing not to force computer manufacturers that need crucial technical information about the company's microprocessor chips to surrender rival technology.

title: Director Calls Again
description: FIVE years ago, Stephen Daldry made his Broadway directing debut with a highly charged revival of ''An Inspector Calls'' by J. B. Priestley, and the production's fiercely expressionistic take on a 1945 English warhorse left no doubt as to the director's intentions. Rain lashed down, an air raid siren blared and, at the finale, the set itself seemed to rise up, as if in revolt at the morals of an insular English elite whose smugness collapses just as the contents of their jewel-box house come crashing down.

title: Montale in English
description: To the Editor:

title: In Love With Shakespeare
description: EMBLAZONED on the National Theater's latest brochure is the face of a wise-looking playwright with a seriously retreating hairline. But, no, it isn't William Shakespeare. It's Noel Coward, the centenary of whose birth we British are celebrating this year. A statue of the Master, as his acolytes called him, was recently unveiled. His two best plays, ''Private Lives'' and ''Hay Fever,'' are about to get revivals in the city through whose streets he sauntered with hat, cane and debonair air. Other Coward work is likely to follow. But more of the Master, David Hare and assorted moderns in a moment.

title: Sea Scouts Seeking Another Success
description: It is with understandable optimism that a bunch of teen-age sailors are preparing these cold, wintry days for Block Island Race Week in June. The team of Sea Scouts slipped into the event through the back door two years ago, and an unexpected victory made them defending champions in the biennial rendition of the regatta.

title: Only the Living Know Brooklyn: Where the Community Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; second Tuesday of the month; next meeting is April 13, 6:30 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg; Community board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENICHEL, NATHAN, M.D.
description: FENICHEL-Nathan, M.D., age 93 of Allentown, PA., formerly of New York City, on March 10, 1999. Husband of the late Pearl Fenichel, father to Judith Morrison, and Dr. Samuel Fenichel. Services were held in Allentown.

title: Children's Books
description: LOVE'S A SWEET By Clyde Watson. Illustrated by Wendy Watson. Viking, $15.99. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: PARIS PULSE; Les Musts by Metro
description: TEMPLE

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Flavorful Cabernet

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazone.com
description: I have seen the future, and it's a little exaggerated. It's the Frederick's of Hollywood padded panty No. 50404, which promises to add a dollop of bump to any behind. I stumbled upon this fetchingly inflated undergarment the same way -- if you believe what you hear -- I will find almost everything in the glorious, not-too-distant future. I found it on Amazon.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHOROROS, LAURENCE
description: CHOROROS-Laurence. 2/9/56-3/14/94. His promise, grace & courage are remembered with pride & love.

title: Five Points Of Light For Games
description: Although bitter and hurt at not having been chosen independent counsel for the Olympic investigation, I have decided to share my recommendations with the International Olympic Committee, which meets this week to whitewash itself.

title: Back by Popular Demand
description: THE UNDISCOVERED CHEKHOV

title: There Will Always Be an England
description: I am distressed by the blatant anti-Marmitism displayed by, of all things, an Englishman, referring to Marmite as ''the odious brown sauce made out of vegetable extract.'' This stuff is nectar! It is the very taste of home! When, in these days of political correctness, can we Brits expect to see an end to this cultural abuse?

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Jan. 31, about San Juan, gave an incomplete name for a hotel in the Isla Verde beach district, described as probably the liveliest hotel at night. It is the Wyndham El San Juan Hotel and Casino, not just the El San Juan.

title: Two Big Milestones And a Biennale
description: IN Europe, 1999 is a special year for some celebrated names in art. Two revered old masters, Anthony van Dyck and Diego Velazquez, are birthday boys (both born in 1599) and the marvelous textile designer Anni Albers (1899-1994) is a birthday girl. Major parties are being thrown for all three.

title: Drug Law
description: Now that the State Senate has passed legislation to increase penalties for those who involve minors in the sale of drugs, the State Assembly has taken up the measure.

title: When Downsizing Moves Up the Ladder
description: The lowest jobless rate since the Nixon Administration isn't translating into job security in American executive suites. Corporate cost-cutters are increasingly aiming at the well-compensated.

title: El Greco's Legacy To Three Countries
