description: An exhibition of El Greco paintings, which opened in Madrid on Feb. 4 and is due later this year in Rome and Athens, covers three main stylistic periods, starting in Crete, where the artist was born in 1541, to his introduction to the Renaissance in Italy in 1567 and finally to his many years in Spain, where he died in 1614 in Toledo. ''El Greco, Identity and Transformation'' features 70 of his works, including 11 paintings that have never before been part of an El Greco exhibition.

title: Debate Rekindled as Boston Moves Beyond Busing
description: Nearly 25 years ago Jacqueline Johnson boarded a school bus every school day to travel from her black neighborhood, Roxbury, to a predominantly white school in another part of the city, Jamaica Plain. Today, with three children of her own in Boston public schools she eagerly hopes the city will end busing.

title: Taking Up Choreography as a Path Out of Mourning
description: IT'S not often that someone starts making dances after turning 60. Lucia Dlugoszewski, who makes her choreographic debut on March 23 at Playhouse 91, is not a total neophyte, though. A seasoned composer and musician, she carried on a creative partnership, and marriage, with the choreographer Erick Hawkins for more than 40 years.

title: Crystalline Poetry Cracks a Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Alou Hopes Expos Stay Put
description: The Montreal Expos are apparently on the verge of moving to Charlotte, N.C., or Northern Virginia, but Manager Felipe Alou is still hoping it doesn't happen.

title: Why Buy More Time?
description: The news, lately reported, that the life span of humans might be doubled in the next century is cause for sober and deliberate contemplation. Like so much that is baffling and wondrous, the word comes from a conference in Southern California.

title: Tempers Rising in Feud Between Suffolk District Attorney and Sheriff
description: The blood is bad between the Suffolk County sheriff and the District Attorney.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISNER, ROSLYN
description: EISNER-Roslyn. Roz, You'll always be loved and never forgotten. Your brother, Mel Mond

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, KENNETH F., M.D.
description: TUCKER-Kenneth F., M.D. Prominent psychiatrist of Sutton Place South, New York City, died March 8, 1999 at New York Hospital. A long-time resident of Scarsdale, NY, Dr. Tucker had suffered from kidney failure and heart disease for many years. He was born September 5, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, to Isaac and Belle Cooperstein Tucker, formerly of Russia. Dr. Tucker was an early graduate of Brooklyn Tech, attended R.P.I., and served with the U.S. Army in the Philippines in 1946-1947. He received a B.S. in Chemistry from Columbia and graduated from Cornell Medical School in 1953. From that time until his death, Dr. Tucker conducted a private practice in psychiatry in the same office on Sutton Place. Long affilated with Payne Whitney, he was an early researcher in the use of chemicals to treat mental illness. During his distinguished career, he was a valued counselor to many prominent people and a source of wisdom, comfort and joy to all who had the good fortune to know him. Dr. Tucker was also a life-long sports fan; his first job, at fourteen, was selling programs at Ebbetts Field, for which he was paid $2 a day. At sixteen, he was a member of the New York All-City Championship Handball Team. In later years, he would often return to the handball courts at Coney Island to reminisce about his year of glory. Over his life time, he grew to forgive the New York Yankees for not having been situated in Brooklyn, and his emotional health rose and fell with the fortunes of his beloved New York Giants. Dr. Tucker was proud of his Jewish heritage and raised his children in his faith. Dr Tucker was also a reader of great acuity, breadth and curiosity; he triumphed weekly over the most difficult crosswords; his sense of humor was that of a true New Yorker. He married the late Barbara Irving in 1957. They had four children: Douglas Tucker, of Berkeley, CA, a forensic psychiatrist, Duane Tucker, of New York City, a database administrator, Holly Tucker, of Berkeley, CA, a research administrator and Randolph Tucker, a lawyer, of Ojai, CA. In 1991, Dr. Tucker married Amy Ellis Tucker, of Bronxville, NY, who survives him. He is also loved and survived by three grandchildren, Sam, Alan and Barbara Tucker of Ojai, CA, a sister Gertrude Tucker Weker, of Bethesda, MD; (his other sister, Evelyn Tucker Feinstein, pre-deceased him); a niece, Laurie Weker Lipton, of Rockville, MD, and four nephews, Richard Feinstein of Cranston, RI, Lester Feinstein of Littleton, CO, Jonathan Weker of Montpelier, VT and Robert Weker, of Wynnewood, PA. Contributions in Dr. Tucker's name may be made to the Cornell University Medical College, Department of Psychiatry.

title: Braves and Yankees Are Now Role Models
description: When the Houston Astros gathered for the first full-squad workout of spring training, their manager told them he wanted to be just like the Atlanta Braves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PHEBE U.
description: SMITH-Phebe U. Of Muttontown, LI, on March 13, 1999, age 92. Wife of the late Dr. Morley L. Mother of Morley L., Jr., and Phebe S. Apgar. Sister of Alice U. Mitchell. Grandmother of six, great-grandmother of two. Aunt of Samuel U. Mitchell. Service Jericho Friends Meeting House, Saturday, April 3, at 2 PM. Donations to Jericho Monthly Meeting or Friends Academy.

title: Germany, in the Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Born to Be Blue
description: RAY CHARLES Man and Music. By Michael Lydon. Illustrated. 433 pp. New York: Riverhead Books. $27.95.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- On Language; Gam(bl)ing
description: The Committee to Restore American Values, reports Richard L. Berke in The New York Times, has been asking Presidential candidates to take a kind of litmus test. Every Bronx High School of Science graduate knows that litmus is a paper covered with the coloring matter from lichens that stays blue when dipped in an alkaline solution and turns pink when dipped in an acid solution. (Or is it the other way around? I did poorly in chemistry, but got through because the kid next to me, who ultimately won a Nobel Prize, let me crib. Some may call that cheating; we called it ''helping a flunking friend,'' a Value that needs Restoring.)

title: 'Angels' in L.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Naugatuck Safe for Living Things Again
description: THE Naugatuck River of Francis M. McDonald's youth was an aquatic menace. He grew up in the 1930's and 40's, and though he loved trout and the intricacies of fly fishing, at that time he avoided the poisonous currents that ran through his hometown of Waterbury.

title: Schnyder's Links To Guru Cause Alarm
description: The tennis star and her guru chose a table in the sun, spread out a late lunch repast of beans, greens and guava chips, and spoke with a mix of defensiveness and delight about the controversial alliance that has the entire WTA Tour buzzing in alarm.

title: Considering Parole, Releasing Nightmares; For Victims, Hearings Dredge Up Memories of an Infamous Crime Spree
description: THERE have been bloodier episodes. But in a couple of ways the events of May 28 and 29, 1982, were a barbarity on a scale never experienced on Long Island before.

title: Local Officials Criticize School-Aid Formula
description: If a student made as many mistakes on a math test, he would flunk. But when the state Department of Education admitted last month that it had bungled state school aid figures for the second consecutive year, superintendents could do little but complain to lawmakers.

title: Water Everywhere, Finally, Aquariums
description: LONG ISLAND would seem to be a logical place for a major aquarium -- it is even shaped like a fish. The island's existence is defined by watery boundaries. It is surrounded by the ocean, sound and bays and is dotted with ponds, lakes, streams and rivers. Boating and fishing loom large in its heritage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, JAY. A
description: KENNY-Jay. A man respected and beloved by all those who knew him. Though his family and friends mourn that he left us so young, we know he lived life to the fullest. His love of theater and the arts and his desire to share this love with others were hallmarks of his grace and his style and his passion for life. We honor Jay's memory and give our most heartfelt condolences to his family. George K. Cooney The Screen Gems Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, ISABEL (BETTY)
description: EGAN-Isabel (Betty). Of Scarsdale, New York, on March 10, 1999. Beloved sister of Charles Egan. Fond aunt of Sherry Schrade, Charles A. Egan, Jean E. Smith, Meg Dworkin and the late Jerome (Jay) Egan. Dear great-aunt of twelve. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral mass will be held Tuesday 11 AM at Our Lady of Rosary Chapel, Brewster, NY.

title: BOXING: Let the Disputes Begin; Lewis Dominates Holyfield, but the Judges See It Differently and Call Unification Bout a Draw
description: Lennox Lewis, fighting a strategically sound fight and dispelling misconceptions about his grit and his heart, and Evander Holyfield, looking like an aging warrior who could no longer summon the spirit and the fortitude to win convincingly, fought to a draw last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mexican Mob In California Is the Target Of Prosecutors
description: As guilty verdicts were read, over and over, in the racketeering prosecution two years ago of the prison gang known as la Eme, a pattern emerged: one defendant, Victor Murillo, was being acquitted of all counts. His co-defendants cheered and ultimately, he was the only one of 13 men on trial to be set free.

title: Bronx Is Joining Controversy Over St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: The first St. Patrick's Day parade in the Bronx in 70 years has, in the last few days, become embroiled in the same political turmoil over gay marchers that has troubled the St. Patrick's Day parade in Manhattan since 1991.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Even though things about the way we live now were trying to compete for my attention, the magazine won. This new section is much more in keeping with the journalistic excellence you continue to bring to a world that sorely needs better writers and thinkers.

title: Of a New Home, Same Chef, Bigger Menu
description: CAFE CHRISTINA was such a fixture in the former Westport library building, it came as a surprise to learn that it has moved to new digs in the Westport Inn. Fortunately, chef and ownership at Christina's remain the same as before.

title: Transfixing Motion and Emotion in a Shutter's Blink
description: PHOTOGRAPHY does some things poorly and others too well. For a long time it could not stop motion, and then, when it could, the results were too good to believe: people were uncomfortable with Eadweard Muybridge's pictures of galloping horses because no one had ever seen a horse look exactly like that.

title: Christ the King to Play Rice
description: Christ the King, of Queens, and Rice, of Manhattan, notched convincing victories yesterday in the Catholic High School Athletic Association's Class A basketball semifinals at St. John's, setting up their third championship confrontation in four years. Rice won the last two meetings.

title: The Billboard Question: Should We Allow Them?
description: To the Editor:

title: Run It Up the Flagpole
description: CREATING THE

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Neon; Hi, Again: That Congenial Compact Grows Up
description: THE Chrysler Corporation broke the rules when it brought out the first-generation Neon in January 1994.

title: Private Sector; A Journalist's Juicy Reward
description: It's the rare journalist who figures so large in a company's business that his compensation becomes public as part of routine financial disclosures. Add to the short list James J. Cramer -- hedge fund manager, columnist and part owner of TheStreet.Com, the popular on-line financial news service.

title: The Nation; Finding Out How Much The Boss Really Makes
description: FOR all the railing of unions about income inequality, some labor leaders don't seem to take the issue too seriously when it hits close to home. Take Gus Bevona, the longtime president of a New York City janitors' local who made $531,529 in 1997. That's 17 times what his union's members earned on average. Or take Frank Wsol, head of a teamsters local in Chicago, who was paid $473,069.

title: Road Rage, But in a Parked Car
description: I THINK I just had my first experience of road rage, but I wasn't driving at the time. Someone rapped angrily on the window of my car as I was sitting outside the supermarket, neatly parked between the lines and making a rather urgent call on the cellular phone. This happens all the time in New York City, but not in Wading River. I reached in my pocket for a quarter and rolled down the window. A large lady thrust a furious face at me.

title: Defrocking the Artist
description: Recently I happened to be reading, around the same time, Anthony Heilbut's ''Thomas Mann: Eros and Literature'' (1996) and James Anderson Winn's ''John Dryden and His World'' (1987). I was in for a surprise. When I was in college, Mann meant far more to me than neo-classical poets. Today, Mann and his concern, in his early work, with the relationship of the artist to society and of morbidity to genius seem more remote -- even alien -- than Dryden and Pope and their world of clubbable poets and scribbling polemicists. According to an unscientific survey of friends and acquaintances, I'm not alone.

title: An Enraged Lampley Lands the Most Devasting Blows
description: Before last night's Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight unification fight, the TVKO announcer Jim Lampley said he had changed his mind from just a week ago and decided that Lewis would beat Holyfield. He called Holyfield's vow to knock Lewis out in three rounds ''wacky,'' a sign he had ceded the psychological edge.

title: Germany Tries to Adjust as All Its Neighbors Become Friends
description: Throughout its modern history, Germany has wrestled with the trauma of being ''das Land der Mitte'' -- ''the country in the middle.'' From Bismarck to former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, leaders sought to anchor and secure the state in its uneasy geographical position between East and West.

title: Q & A/Dr. Richard L. Schwab; What It Takes to Produce Good Teachers
description: THE dean of the School of Education at the University of Connecticut, Dr. Richard L. Schwab, is a happy man. Recently a philanthropist and alumnus, Raymond Neag, donated $21 million to the school. Dr. Schwab has lots of plans for that money: scholarships and graduate assistantships, endowed chairs, outreach activities and professional development activities were among the areas he mentioned.

title: Audrey Samers, David Glicksman
description: Audrey Meryl Samers and David Seth Glicksman are to be married today in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Golub is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club.

title: Arnold Machin, 87, Creator Of Ubiquitous Royal Portrait
description: Sir Arnold Machin, a master British sculptor who upstaged his distinguished career with a single bas-relief bust that became one of the world's most reproduced images, died on Monday at his home in Staffordshire, England. He was 87 and had designed the portrait of Queen Elizabeth II that has appeared on every British postage stamp since 1967.

title: Statehouse Journal; A Road-Kill Proposal Is Food for Jokesters
description: If only the bill had contained the word ''deer,'' then perhaps the possum jokes could have been stopped flat. If the bill had just made it clear that someone who hits a deer on the highway can take home the carcass and eat it, then maybe Tennessee would have been spared all the raccoon cookbooks, the dead-skunk songs, the bumper stickers, the sniggering headlines, the laughter that has lighted up the Legislature for the last few weeks.

title: Man Kills Wife and Son And Is Slain by Police
description: A Chatham Township man who authorities say was estranged from his wife broke into her home last night and stabbed her and their 8-year-old son to death before he was shot and killed by the police, officials said.

title: Teri Goldberg, John Horowitz
description: Teri Goldberg, a daughter of Bernard Goldberg of Manhattan and the late Monica D. Goldberg, was married last evening to John Horowitz, the son of Janet Zusi and Ronald J. Horowitz, both of Summit, N.J. Rabbi Miriam Berkowitz officiated at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLAN, BERTRAM
description: COWLAN-Bertram. On March 10, 1999, loving father of Maggi and Janet. Dear brother of Richard. Father-in-law of Sam. Grandfather of Joshua. Service Sunday, 11AM. at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: Ideas & Trends; Wanna See a Real Live Martian? Try the Mirror.
description: GOOD science often starts with flights of imagination that are all but unknown publicly. That's because the creative process ends in scientific reports cast to seem as dry and objective as possible. All the same, history shows scientists driven by visions not only wild in their own day, but sometimes still audacious.

title: With Cars at Risk, a Boomlet in Alcohol Testing
description: In neighborhoods like Ridgewood, Queens, at bars like the Glenlo Tavern, patrons often get behind the wheel to go home. That's why the city's new policy of seizing the cars of those arrested for drunken driving has sent chills up the wrists of many pint sippers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MARK JAY, M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Mark Jay, M.D. On March 13, 1999, of lymphoma. He was a beloved father of Robyn and Matthew, husband of Ellen, son of Eleanor and Arthur, brother of Bruce and Lainie. Loving sonin-law, brother-in-law and uncle to several nieces and nephews. A graduate of SUNY at Stony Brook and SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Mark was a respected and compassionate cardiologist, who served his patients with dignity, kindness and respect. He will be dearly missed. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Mark Jay Friedman Foundation, c/o Long Island Cardiovascular Consultants, 1129 Northern Blvd., Suite 408, Manhasset, NY 11030.

title: Can a Star of Walk Be a Star Who Talks?
description: IT'S not quite right to say that Carolyn Murphy's face is unfamiliar to filmgoers. She is widely seen on popcorn bags sold in movie theaters, advertising Calvin Klein khakis and other clothes.

title: Global Fashion? It's a Wrap
description: Global fashion is the talk of the fashion world, but the poncho anticipated the concept by thousands of years. Nothing more than a length of material with a hole in the center to slip the head through, the poncho dates from ancient civilizations and was worn by the farmers of Asia, the shepherds of Europe and the hunters of the pre-Columbian Americas. In its current revival, the poncho is most popular when knitted or crocheted as outerwear. There are also rainproof varieties, versions in woven fabrics and, this winter, a knitted poncho with sleeves (bottom, third from right).

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-14-99 -- Gray Zone; Dangerous Crossing
description: As the sun breaks over the green-brown cliff that forms the western border of Hoboken, N.J., the armies of the dawn descend from the ridge onto the town, picking their way down uneven stone staircases, scrambling along a steeply twisting path through trash-strewn woods, marching down a long viaduct as cars whiz by.

title: Children's Books
description: The Disappearing Alphabet By Richard Wilbur. Illustrated by David Diaz. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace & Company. $16. (All ages)

title: There Will Always Be an England
description: Great Britain, under the dominance of England, has time and again this century taken steps that almost seemed designed to reduce the immense influence the United Kingdom had in the 19th century. Between the supercilious blindness of the Tories and the bitter envy of Labor, a dominant force in Western culture has been allowed to wither (Andrew Sullivan, Feb. 21).

title: A First Floor, 200 Feet Above the Ground
description: Construction workers have been busy building a foundation for a 455-room Doubletree Hotel in Times Square, but unlike most foundation work, this is going on almost 200 feet in the air.

title: Political Animals; Growling Over Dogs' Rights
description: IN cities and towns across the nation, a chorus of politically influential voices cries out in unison: Woof!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARB, ETHEL
description: GARB-Ethel. On March 12, 1999. At Hallandale, Florida. Adored and loving mother of Carolyn and Bernard Lippert, Phyllis and Bernard Putter, Sharron and Paul Weiner. Cherished grandmother of Sari and Doug, Hildy and Donald, Joseph and Sonia, Lauren and Andrew, Kenneth and Nanci, Vicki and Steven, and great-grandmother of Frank, Corey, Julie, Ben, Sydney, Marcus, Evan and Adam. Dear sister of Anita Siegel, Marvin and Phyllis Levy, and Anna Levy. She will be missed by her caring cousins Sylvia and Naomi, and her devoted companion Madge Chang. With sincere appreciation to her great-nephew and physician, Dr. Jack Turken. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M., Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELL, EUGENE ABRAHAM
description: SCHNELL-Eugene Abraham. A resident of Longboat Key, FL., formerly of New York City and Tyringham, MA, died March 8 in Sarasota. He was born May 2, 1922 in New York City. Survivors include his wife Ina Spelke, and three children who reside in New York City, a son Eric, and two daughters Vicki S. Rosen and Nancy from a previous marriage; a sister Millicent Golding of Sun City, AZ; a brother Seymour Schnell, & five nieces & nephews, all of New York City. Services in Sarasota were private. Memorial donations may be made to the Robert S. Peabody Museum of Archaeology, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810, or to the Florida West Coast Symphony, 709 North Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34236.

title: Democrats Resurgent, but Nyman Steps Back
description: AS Nassau County's Republican leadership grapples with a health insurance scandal, a monumental budget shortfall and now a Federal challenge to the county's taxation system, local Democrats' political prospects seem brighter than they have been in decades. So why is Bruce Nyman standing at the plane door with a parachute strapped to his chest?

title: March 7-13; N.C.A.A. Rule Is Voided
description: A Federal court in Philadelphia discarded the National Collegiate Athletic Association's minimum test score requirement for athletic scholarships. The court found that the requirement ''has an unjustified disparate impact against African-Americans.'' It was a significant comment on the debate over cultural bias in standardized test. For the moment, the N.C.A.A. has no clear standard for scholarship eligibility, and has asked for a stay of the ruling. JOE DRAPE

title: Hospital Is Haunted by History of Deals With Board Members
description: In the early 1990's, a small nonprofit hospital just outside Peekskill embarked on an expansion that would transform it from a homespun but antiquated local landmark into a region-wide medical center rated among the top 4 percent of the nation's hospitals.

title: Franchise Learning Centers Offer Mastery
description: IN the world of franchising, the name Kumon is to learning what McDonald's is to hamburgers. Over the last five years, after-school learning programs have proliferated, which is good news for companies like Kumon Educational Institute in Japan and for the owners of its seven franchises in Westchester.

title: How to Insure That Organs Get to the Neediest; Regional Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Return of A Security Deposit
description: Q. I recently broke my lease and moved out of a rent-stabilized apartment I lived in for eight years. When I told my landlord I was moving out, he asked me to write him a letter informing him of the date that I would be vacating the apartment. According to the doorman, the apartment was rented on the day I moved out. My former landlord claims, however, that he was unable to rent the place for a month, and that my security deposit was used to pay that month's rent. I don't believe the landlord. Do I have any legal recourse to get back my security deposit or at least the eight years' worth of interest? . . . Nadia Zonis, Manhattan.

title: Fresh Perspectives On Past and Present; Berlin
description: For many German Jews, what Hitler said was quite literally beyond belief. Established members of society -- doctors, lawyers and World War I military heroes -- they could not conceive of themselves as outcasts, let alone as targets for mass murder. Their first feeling, then, was one of profound disorientation.

title: Sports of The Times; College Coaches Feeling Each Other's Pain
description: FOR the poor beleaguered basketball coach, it's always something.

title: Affordable Hockney, Playing the Promoter
description: IF you have ever dreamed of owning a David Hockney but haven't had $20,000 (or considerably more) to spend on a drawing, oil painting or lithograph, Christie's South Kensington has come along with the largest-ever sale of Hockney posters, to be held here on March 25. And although one might argue that posters are not in the same league as paintings and lithographs, the collection testifies to precisely that dazzling breadth and wit that have made Mr. Hockney, now 61, one of the most popular and admired of contemporary artists.

title: Private Sector; What Was That Take On the RJR Cycle?
description: Another turn in the history of RJR Nabisco changes participants into revisionists, rehearsing what might have been. J. Tylee Wilson, the former R. J. Reynolds chief executive who merged the tobacco company with Nabisco in 1985, still thinks that building a broad-based consumer products company makes sense. But Mr. Wilson, now 68 and retired, is not about to second-guess the intention of RJR Nabisco Holdings, t announced last week, to split up the businesses and sell foreign tobacco operations.

title: Style
description: A curved black wall, enclosing the dressing room, brings to mind a Richard Serra sculpture.

title: Swiss Dip
description: THE history of fondue is truly epic: the dish can be traced to Homer's ''Iliad'' (Song XI) as a mixture of Pramnos wine, grated goat cheese and white flour. Swiss fondue originated in Zurich at a time when food was scarce during interminably long, cold winters. Villagers had to turn to their home-produced foods -- cheese, wine and homemade bread -- to survive.

title: How to Insure That Organs Get to the Neediest
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Persichilli, Michael Keogh
description: Karen Mary Elizabeth Persichilli and Michael P. Keogh were married yesterday in Brooklyn. Msgr. Joseph Nagle performed the ceremony at St. Saviour Roman Catholic Church.

title: Buying Railroad Cars, Selling Out the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Public School Ice Hockey Expands With Persuasion and Parents' Aid
description: AT 16, Josh Cherney of Chappaqua has played hundreds of ice hockey games with club teams and collected more than a dozen trophies from tournaments played from Boston to Canada. But there was one experience on ice that he had not enjoyed until this year -- slipping on a school jersey over his pads and skating for his high school.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTTER, HAROLD (HAL)
description: POTTER-Harold (Hal). January 23, 1932-March 17, 1992. Without you nothing is the same. Love, Joyce, Seth, Robert and Warren

title: A Half Century in Baseball, And Zimmer Still Breathes It
description: The Christmas card list of Don and Jean Carol Zimmer holds steady at about 300 and requires more than a month to satisfy, for there has always been news to report in their 51 years in baseball, and she can't help but write long notes.

title: POSTINGS: 12-Level, $70 Million Complex to Be Built; New Student Center for N.Y.U.
description: Within weeks of its opening in 1959, the Loeb Student Center on Washington Square South was aptly described as the 10-story ''living room'' of New York University. It still feels that way: Trotskyites hand out literature at the front door, a calypso band plays exuberantly in the cafe, students pick up E-mail at nearby terminals.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THIS week's film run the gamut from a deluxe murder mystery and a top vehicle for Hollywood's favorite dance team to a comedy gem and a tale of young summer love.

title: Princeton Institute's Patron Deserves More Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: New Status For Berlin, Everywhere But the Air
description: Early this year, Mayor Eberhard Diepgen of Berlin slipped off to Chicago to try to resolve an increasingly desperate problem: the city presenting itself as ''the new capital of Europe'' does not have a single direct flight to or from the United States.

title: Side Effects
description: SONNY LISTON WAS

title: INVESTING WITH: William V. Fries; Thornburg Value Fund
description: THE idea, as always, is to buy low and sell high -- but that doesn't mean that William V. Fries looks only at stocks with tiny price-to-earnings ratios.

title: Fairy Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Well, Just 124 Points Shy of 10,000
description: Delay the celebrations. Many analysts say it is only a matter of time before the Dow Jones industrial average crosses 10,000. But it didn't quite happen last week. After climbing steadily, the Dow fell back to 9,876.35 on Friday, although it was still up 1.4 percent for the week.

title: Giving in North Carolina
description: Having succeeded in business, particularly in high technology, entrepreneurs have been teaming up to form ''giving circles,'' supporting local charities by pooling dollars and expertise. Such groups are already operating in Seattle and Silicon Valley, but a new one is starting in the Research Triangle of North Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ABBEY, EDWARD PAUL
description: ABBEY-Edward Paul. O Nedward, Edward, Eddie ten years gone. Miss. -Ingoo.

title: Madrid Dining
description: To the Editor: Your inclusion of Posada de la Villa among recommended restaurants (''What's Doing in Madrid,'' Penelope Casas, Feb. 21) gives me mixed feelings. I'm glad my tastes are vindicated -- I've been saying it's the best place to eat in Madrid for years. But now all the Americans who were safely stowed in Botin down the street are going to plague Posada, and I won't be able to get a table.

title: Consider Homing Pigeons Instead of Telephoning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGLOIN, KATHERINE
description: McGLOIN-Katherine. On March 12, 1999 of Forest Hills Gardens, NY. Retired elementary school teacher for over 25 years (PS 101). Beloved wife of the late John Pilgrim. Survived by many loving nieces, nephews and friends. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave. at Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills, NY, Sunday 2-6 PM. Services Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, NY, Monday March 15, 1999 at 10:30 AM. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, MEG
description: MERRILL-Meg. Beloved wife of Si Merrill, dear mother of Michael Kiddon, loving grandmother of Chloe and Olivia Kiddon and daughter-in-law Joan Kiddon. Her only other survivor is her brother, Joseph Hartman, of Memphis, Tenn. She was the author of two successful Simon & Schuster books on needlepoint and two Pet Library volumes on ocelots and margays-a vibrant, exciting woman, deeply committed to social justice. She died on March 11th, 1999, at NYU Medical Center from complications of lung cancer. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LETTERS IN CAPTIVITY, 1945-1946

title: Batons At the Ready
description: FOR those seeking summer musical delight across the Atlantic, there is always the danger that the musicians you heard all winter will be on the plane with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, JAMES B.
description: KENNY-James B. Died suddenly on March 11, 1999. Beloved son of William and Bette Kenny of Syosset, NY. Dearest brother of Carol Ann, Marilee and Christine. Also survived by nephew Jake, niece Caitlin, brothers-in-law Andrew and Michael. He will be most deeply missed and will remain in our hearts forever. Services Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 PM at Barrett Funeral Home, NYC. Funeral Mass St. Malachy's RC Church, 239 West 49th St., NYC, 10:00 AM Monday. In lieu of flowers contributions to Broadway Cares Equities Fights Aids, 212840-0770 or American Foundation for Aids Research, 212-806-1600, would be appreciated.

title: Stamps to Give Way to Sofas
description: Restoration Hardware, a national chain of 68 housewares shops, plans to open a second Manhattan store, in the post office building at 103 Prince Street.

title: They Right The Songs
description: ALI GROSSMAN, a senior studying film at New York University, recently learned a painful lesson.

title: Foes Vow to Keep Eyes on Developer and Movie House
description: After pleading guilty to environmental crimes at the RKO Keith Theater, Tommy Huang, a Flushing developer, is determined to renovate the shuttered movie palace, one of his lawyers said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAFKA, TOBY
description: KAFKA-Toby. Died March 12 in Brooklyn, age 94, after a brief illness. At Toby's request, services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Hospice of Greater New York, 6323 7th Ave., Brooklyn, New York 11220.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; From Texas, With Love and Peanuts
description: CAN a yee-haw! airline from Texas find happiness in or even near New York City? Southwest Airlines commences its famously zany but low-cost, high-frequency service today out of Islip, on Long Island. Texans generally consider Southwest their finest export since barbecued brisket and the betting here is that Yankees will like it, too.

title: Where the Shows, Concerts and Dance Are
description: Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBACH, FRIEDERIKE, M.D.
description: STEINBACH - Friederike, M.D. Born December 26, 1912 in Vienna. Graduated Vienna Medical School. Practiced OBGYN at 310 East 12 St., NYC. Affiliated NY Infirmary. Died March 6, 1999, 170 Cherry Lane, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

title: The Nation: Hold Onto Your Cap; Taking the Caddy for a Spin
description: MENTION Cadillac and the images that spring to mind are pretty sedate: Midwestern grandfathers tooling down suburban roads, perhaps, or chauffeurs in caps holding rear doors open for wealthy widows carrying sculpted poodles out of Fifth Avenue co-ops.

title: Resources For Taxpayers
description: There is an abundance of help available both for preparing returns and for pursuing tax-saving strategies. Among the best are these:

title: N.Y.U. Hospital Plans a High-Rise, to Neighbors' Dismay
description: For years, the vacant lot in the block bordered by Beekman, Spruce, Nassau and Gold Streets has been used as a hospital parking lot. But last week, the president of New York University Downtown Hospital told a Community Board 1 committee meeting that financial pressures are forcing the hospital to put up a building, perhaps as tall as 45 stories, on the site. Many neighbors reacted warily to the plan.

title: Children's Books; Clipping the Devil's Hairs
description: Here's an odd book indeed -- and not just because it looks as if the printer forgot to put the title on the cover. Two of the greats in children's bookdom, the esteemed author Natalie Babbitt and the gifted illustrator Fred Marcellino, come together for OUCH! (Michael di Capua/ HarperCollins, $14.95; all ages), which the publisher says is ''a brisk retelling'' of a little-known tale from Grimm.

title: The Disciples of Discipline
description: The ultimate goal of John Rosemond's child-rearing advice (Susan Bolotin, Feb. 14) seems to be loyal, obedient, more easily controlled children, words that also could be used to describe the forcibly conscripted children of Sierra Leone who now kill without question (Jan Goodwin, Feb. 14). The young, unwilling soldiers are reared in the ideal Rosemond setting: male authority figures who administer frequent corporal punishment without regard to the development of a child's self-esteem.

title: A Visionary, a Mind-Blower, Kubrick Never Failed to Stun
description: WHEN Stanley Kubrick died a week ago, he left behind the monolith from ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' as the single most salient image of his career. This (who could forget?) was the dark, austere object that arrived in the midst of primitive ape-men. It drove them into a state of high anxiety as they rallied around the thing, touched it, recoiled, tried to fathom it, sensed its intense power without quite grasping what that power might mean. The arrival of each new mind-blowing Kubrick film was much the same.

title: Mr. Bruno's Excellent Idea
description: It is not often that the major social welfare agencies in New York line up to support a proposal advanced by Joseph Bruno, the upstate Republican who is majority leader of the State Senate. It happened last week when Mr. Bruno, previously an advocate of cutbacks in welfare and health care for the poor, proposed a tax break for low-income workers. It would be paid for by savings that have resulted from the drop in welfare rolls. The idea makes particular sense because it would reward, among others, precisely those people who managed to get low-paying jobs after being on welfare.

title: Q&A/Joel A. Martin; Jazzical: When Classical and Jazz Entwine
description: HIS father plays 36 instruments, his mother, 12. It is no wonder that Joel A. Martin became a musician.

title: China Syndrome; Seeing Beyond Spies Is the Hard Part
description: A SPY worms his way into a delicate niche of American military intelligence. He steals its secrets and sells them to another government. His treachery inflicts the gravest damage to American national security.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: St. John's Dazes Indiana With Awe-Inspiring Zone
description: They barely raised their arms above their heads, and their smiles were only a bit broader. Their small contingent of fans was outscreaming the enormous gathering of red-clad Hoosier rooters, but the St. John's players' reaction to their stunningly easy 86-61 victory over Indiana in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament today was as methodical and cool as their dismantling of Indiana.

title: One Big Anniversary Party
description: EUROPE'S musical menus this season are filled with anniversary tributes and provide abundant choices from the world's rich heritage. The festivals offer a chance to experience some works for the first time and others in different settings performed, perhaps, by a future star.

title: In a Tabloid Comedy, the Serial Killer Is Sensitive
description: ON a recent Sunday, as the subscriber audience at Playwrights Horizons filed into the venerable 140-seat house on Theater Row, Christopher Durang poked his head out from behind a door for a moment and then retreated. ''Looking at them,'' he said of the mostly older crowd known to be armed with opinions as sharp as their umbrella tips, ''we could be in for some trouble today.''

title: Microsoft's Counterattack To Focus on Rivals' Linkup
description: The Microsoft Corporation, portrayed by the Government as an entrenched monopolist, will counterattack when its antitrust trial resumes next month by presenting evidence that suggests America Online Inc. plans to become a head-on challenger, according to people close to the software company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABRE, RICHARD E.
description: FABRE-Richard E. A member of the piano faculty at the Juilliard School of Music, Pre-College Division since 1961, died March 6, 1999. He was 68. Born in Washington, D.C. on December 22, 1930 to Velmont J. Fabre and Lucy D. Fabre, he began his music education in Sarasota, Florida at the age of 15. He graduated with honors from the University of Miami in Coral Gables, then studied under a two year Fulbright Grant at the Conservatoire Nationale de Paris. As a scholarship student at the Juilliard School, he was a student of Rosina Lhevinne. He has appeared in recitals, as soloist with orchestra, and in chamber concerts in this country and Europe. His students have been prize winners in virtually every national competition open to pre-college age. Mr. Fabre is survived by a sister, Mary Alice Noel of Nooksack, Washington, and three nephews and one neice of Juneau, Alaska. Interment will be in Sarasota, Florida. Contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Moya's New Crown Is Knocked Askew by Philippoussis
description: It seemed like only yesterday that Carlos Moya, the newest No. 1 in men's tennis, was brandishing a champagne bottle in one hand and a crystal trophy in the other as he jumped in a Jacuzzi to celebrate his installation as ''king of the world.''

title: Dismissal Report Puts Knick Coach on Alert
description: The teaser worked. Jeff Van Gundy stayed tuned when he heard his name mentioned just before a commercial during an NBC broadcast yesterday. About 60 seconds later, NBC reported that Van Gundy could be fired last night if the Knicks did not beat Charlotte.

title: Rutgers Has an Easy Time With Arizona From the Start
description: The seedings, the national rankings and a little insight said Rutgers should have beaten Arizona tonight in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament. But this easily? By a runaway score of 90-47?

title: Corrections
description: A photograph yesterday with an article about tensions between Suffolk County's District Attorney and Sheriff was published in error. The picture on the right was of the Nassau County Sheriff, Joseph P. Jablonsky, not the Suffolk County Sheriff, Patrick A. Mahoney.

title: Villagers Hope Kosovo Peace Arrives Before the War
description: On a tranquil Sunday morning, the residents of this village were chatting in the sun outside their local shop, or working among the chickens in the walled courtyards of their houses.

title: Torre Likely to Talk to Players Today
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre is expected to meet with his players Monday afternoon, the first time he will speak to the team collectively since he was found to have prostate cancer last week. Others in the organization believe he will give the players the details of his treatment, and an estimate of how long he will be away from the team.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warren Buffett Attacks Manipulation of Earnings

title: Weak Drug Law Reforms
description: Far from reforming New York's rigid drug laws, Gov. George Pataki now says he is willing only to consider very modest changes. Shortly after taking office, Mr. Pataki let it be known that he thought the laws enacted under Gov. Nelson Rockefeller in 1973 were filling up costly prison space with nonviolent drug offenders who might be handled better by drug treatment. But his new stance indicates that he is not willing to lead on this issue. Instead, his position seems a calculated effort to head off demands for a complete overhaul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SYDNEY
description: LEWIS-Sydney. The death of Syndey Lewis is a great loss to the contemporary art, architecture, and design communities. Sydney and his beloved wife Frances assembled one of the greatest private collections of late 19th and 20th century decorative art, which they gave to the Virginia Museum of Art, where it is on view along with their collection of post-1945 painting and sculpture. A devoted friend of contemporary artists, Sydney ignored his illness to celebrate with us at the opening of the Museum's retrospective of his dear friend Chuck Close. He will be missed by his many friends at the Museum, and we extend our deepest condolences to his wife Frances and their children and grandchildren. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: One Precinct, 2 Very Different Murder Cases
description: The two names almost rhyme, Watkins and Watson, like an old-time song-and-dance team. They did not know each other, but Amy Watkins and Marvin Watson were both young, both archetypes of the New York newcomer. She was the Midwestern idealist come to the big city, a graduate student hoping to become a social worker. He was the striver from Jamaica, an immigrant who became an electrician and was saving money for the birth of his child.

title: 6 Gay Marchers Arrested at St. Patrick's Parade in Bronx
description: Until the moment the whistle blew, Brendan Fay said yesterday with tears rolling down his face, he held out hope that a showdown would be averted, that his exclusion would not be made palpable.

title: Cleaves Rouses Spartans; Oklahoma Wins in Upset
description: When it came time for Mateen Cleaves to wake up, and wake his team up, he did so -- in the nick of time. For much of this afternoon's second-round National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game in the Midwest Regional, Cleaves, the all-America guard for top-seeded Michigan State, played in desultory fashion against ninth-seeded Mississippi. Cleaves had been racking up nearly as many turnovers as points at the Bradley Center.

title: No Clear Front-Runner for Derby
description: So, who is No. 1 on the road to the Kentucky Derby now that Exploit came to the end of his five-race winning streak, now that his stablemate Prime Timber outran him in the San Felipe Stakes, now that Vicar won the Florida Derby for his second straight score in a Grade I stakes in three weeks and now that the filly Silverbulletday won in the mud for her eighth victory in nine starts?

title: Independent Booksellers Plan to Open On-Line Store
description: Facing intensifying competition, the nation's trade association for independent booksellers is creating its own national on-line store, Book Sense, to stave off fierce competition from Amazon.com and Barnesandnoble.com.

title: This Time, Miami's Szczerbiak Shares the Wealth
description: Wally Szczerbiak sat on a table in Miami of Ohio's locker room when it was over, his right knee wrapped in ice as he leaned against a wall. The 43-point man of Friday had a sweet encore today, and he clearly wants more.

title: William E. Warwick, Commodore of QE2, Dies at 86
description: Commodore William E. Warwick, a grizzled Cunard mariner who became first master of the last great ocean liner, died in England on Feb. 27. He was 86 and had commanded the Queen Elizabeth 2 on her maiden voyage 30 years ago.

title: Trash-Talking Tulsa Learns a Lesson in Humility at the Hands of Duke
description: Tulsa's players had talked about a monumental upset, about how they matched up with the top-seeded Duke Blue Devils, about how they knew they could play with them. But 40 minutes and a 41-point loss later, the Golden Hurricane admitted it was foolish to think this Duke team could be beaten in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: The Big City; A Hand Signal To Counteract Road Rage
description: WHAT we have here is a failure to communicate. New York's streets and sidewalks are clogged with more people from more places than ever before, and often the only way they can talk to one another is through sign language. But there is only one clearly understood gesture.

title: Nissan in Talks With Renault About Stake
description: Negotiations concerning the sale of a stake in the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car maker, continued this weekend in Europe.

title: Will Beijing's Nuclear Arsenal Stay Small or Will It Mushroom?
description: Buried deep in the mountains 150 miles east of Xian, where the Chinese built a terra cotta army to protect the remains of the emperors, lies a far smaller but lethal force: a half dozen or so intercontinental ballistic missiles that could reach the United States.

title: 'No Question,' U.S. Says, Leak Helped China
description: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, acknowledged today that ''there's no question'' that China benefited from important information leaked from the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

title: Cardozo's City Title Ends An 18-Year Wait for Coach
description: Benjamin N. Cardozo High School had locked up the Public Schools Athletic League boys' basketball championship with 14 seconds left yesterday when its coach, Ron Naclerio, walked by four subs who were waiting to enter the game. ''One year, one year, one year, two years,'' he said as he tapped each player. ''It took me 18 years, baby.''

title: Capitalists to Be Granted Official Status in Communist China
description: Sitting under stirring photographs of the young Chairman Mao, Chen Jinfei relaxed recently in the plush 35th-floor offices of his billion-dollar corporation and reflected on the love-hate relationship between China's Communist Government and private businessmen like himself, who have helped push the country's economy forward.

title: Buffett Deplores Trend of Manipulated Earnings
description: The executives who run companies for Warren E. Buffett know that few things are as sure to anger the legendary investor as dishonesty about how their businesses are performing. So, too, has Mr. Buffett always promised the people he works for -- the shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. -- nothing less than total candor.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an offer by the Banque Nationale de Paris to purchase two other French banks referred incorrectly to a comment by Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, on opposition to the merger. Mr. Steinberg said that because of the banks' resistance to settling issues involving accounts of Holocaust victims or their survivors, a great deal of opposition to the merger existed in the leadership of the World Jewish Congress -- not in the United States Congress.

title: Fleet Financial Is Expected to Buy BankBoston for $16 Billion
description: Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire the BankBoston Corporation for $16 billion in a deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in the country and the pre-eminent bank in New England, the companies said yesterday.

title: Tories Scoreless; Is Their Coach in Hot Water?
description: The big issue of the day was a Labor-Conservative dispute over reform of the House of Lords, and Baroness Jay, leader of the peers, was scheduled to appear on a Sunday morning talk show.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Wednesday about Catherine Hickey, superintendent of schools for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, misstated the affiliation of the Catholic school system in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was educated. It was the Diocese of Brooklyn , not the New York Archdiocese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, MILDRED T. (JUDY)
description: CARROLL-Mildred T. (Judy). On March 12, 1999. Beloved sister of Mary E. Shevlin and predeceased by John J. Carroll, Julia Carey, Rita O'Rourke and Eleanor Nacy. Loving aunt of Rita Shevlin Murphy. Graduate of Hunter College and retired executive, New York Telephone Company. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor, Inc., 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Thomas More Church, Tuesday, at 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-10, Monday. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Caffrey-Conroy Learning Center at Saint Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, would be appreciated.

title: Contest for Memorial At Black Burial Ground
description: When the Federal Building at 290 Broadway was completed in 1994, one thing was missing: the memorial the Government promised to build marking the 18th-century African Burial Ground unearthed during the excavation for the building.

title: The Court and Disabled Students
description: In an important recent decision, the Supreme Court has interpreted Federal law to require public schools to pay for special care for students with disabilities as long as the services can be provided by someone other than a doctor.

title: Accounts
description: Toysmart.com, Waltham, Mass., to Arnold Communications, Boston, a unit of Snyder Communications, as the first agency to handle the account of the Internet-based educational toy retailer. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: The Weather Channel's High-Profit Center
description: He may not know it, but Elmer Gruber is a ''weather weenie.''

title: High Noon for the I.O.C.
description: In the wake of the Salt Lake City Olympic bribery scandal, corporate sponsors of the Games like John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance have wisely decided to think about how else they might spend their money. The International Olympic Committee ought to keep that in mind as its members gather this week in Switzerland to determine how much to reform their discredited organization. The answer is a lot.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph yesterday with an article about tensions between Suffolk County's District Attorney and Sheriff was published in error. The picture on the right was of the Nassau County Sheriff, Joseph P. Jablonsky, not the Suffolk County Sheriff, Patrick A. Mahoney.

title: High Expectations for Gas and Power Market Growth
description: WILL Latin America continue to provide significant opportunities for energy investors in light of the current economic troubles?

title: Former Official in Bankers Trust Fraud Case Claims a Set-Up
description: B. J. Kingdon, a once high-powered executive at the Bankers Trust Corporation, is being unfairly singled out as the mastermind of a fraud at the bank by his former employer and the Federal Government, his lawyer contends.

title: Editorial Observer; A Wild Market Ride: From Fearful to Fearless
description: There has never been a bull market quite like the one that America is now enjoying. And while there is logically no more significance to approaching 10,000 on the Dow Jones industrial average than there was to approaching 9,500 or any other number, it is worth noting just how far -- and fast -- we have come.

title: Irate Boston Media Fault '60 Minutes' For Nanny Report
description: The so-called Nanny murder stirred widespread debate in 1997, especially after Louise Woodward, the young British woman accused of killing an infant in her charge, was freed by a judge after being convicted of second-degree murder.

title: A Basketball Upset That Made a Lasting Impact
description: AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN

title: A Poker-Faced Shareholder Is Behind the Showdown Over Lycos
description: For nearly a decade, almost without fail, David S. Wetherell played poker with friends on the first Thursday night of each month. Two years ago, as his Internet investments started taking more of his time, he had to give up poker. But the 44-year-old chairman and chief executive of the investment firm CMGI Inc. is holding his cards close to his vest once again -- this time in a gamble that could become the first hostile takeover battle in the short history of Internet commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGRID, BIRD
description: SIGRID-Bird. On March 12, 1999. Longtime fundraiser for Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Beloved daughter of the late Sigmund and Rebecca Hoffstein. Dear sister of the late Alice Bassin. Loving aunt of Rebecca Bassin Schneider. Cherished greataunt to Allison and Mitchell. Friend of Alan and Desi Koslin. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made to the U.J.A. Federation.

title: Providence College And R.P.I. Advance
description: Rensselaer defeated Harvard, 4-2, yesterday to send the Engineers to Lake Placid, N.Y., for the final five of the conference tournament, which resumes on Thursday.

title: The Next Tobacco Giant: Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Szczerbiak Shares Wealth As Miami Knocks Off Utah
description: Wally Szczerbiak sat on a table in Miami of Ohio's locker room when it was over, his right knee wrapped in ice as he leaned against a wall. The 43-point man of Friday had a sweet encore today, and he clearly wants more.

title: Suspect Bag Part of TV Report, Ex-Transportation Official Says
description: A former Transportation Department official acknowledged today that she was the person who checked a suitcase at the airport on Friday in Columbus, Ohio, that security officials said they suspected contained a bomb. The former official, Mary Schiavo, said her aim was to help a local television station prepare a story about security, not to disrupt operations at the airport.

title: More women gain credit as inventors, and some move well beyond household problem-solving.
description: IN the stacks at the Patent and Trademark Office archives, researchers often have to turn sideways to pass one another in the narrow walkways between towering shelves that hold paper copies of every patent issued since the 1790's.

title: A Modern Caspian Model for U.S. War Games
description: In its search to remain prepared in today's ever unsettled, rapidly changing world, the Army has a notion at least of the type of messy international mission its forces may well have to face in the years ahead: protecting Caspian Sea oil.

title: Junior Defends Mile Title
description: Andy Powell of North Easton, Mass., easily defended his boys one-mile title yesterday when he won the event in 4 minutes 9.98 seconds, the fastest time in the country this season, at the National Interscholastic Indoor Championships at the Reggie Lewis Center in Boston.

title: Number of Inmates Reaches Record 1.8 Million
description: The number of inmates in the nation's jails and prisons rose again last year, to a record 1.8 million, though crime rates have dropped for seven consecutive years, the Justice Department reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of its generous benefactor, Hermann Merkin, prominent leader of the American Jewish community, who, together with his wife, Ursula, has played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Mr. Merkin's sons Ezra and David have also been deeply involved in NJOP's outreach efforts, demonstrating the values and heritage he transmitted to them and all his children. Sincere condolences to the family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Gucci and LVMH to Meet About Dispute
description: Gucci Group N.V., one of Italy's biggest fashion houses, and LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's largest maker of luxury goods, are moving closer to ending a monthlong battle about LVMH's influence over Gucci.

title: Defiance And Gloom As I.O.C. Convenes
description: In a palatial hotel lobby with crystal chandeliers, members of the International Olympic Committee began gathering today with a sense of both resignation and defiance about the future of the Olympic movement.

title: Clinton Wants to Strengthen U.S. Whistle-Blower Shield
description: After finding that workers who complain of health and safety hazards are often dismissed from their jobs, the Clinton Administration will soon propose sweeping new protections for such whistle-blowers, Federal officials say.

title: Why Not Let Judges Use Their Heads?
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Not Let Judges Use Their Heads?; An Inherent Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Group's Study Finds Military Harassment Rising
description: Five years after the Clinton Administration adopted its ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy for gay members of the military, incidents of anti-homosexual harassment have increased in each of the armed services, according to a legal group that represents gay men and lesbians.

title: Parking by the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warren Buffett Attacks Manipulation of Earnings

title: 4 Irish Legislators Accuse Dublin of Negligence on Abortion Policy
description: The dispute over Ireland's virtual ban on abortion accelerated today as all four women who represent the country in the European Parliament accused the Government of negligence in delaying a statement of its policy on the issue.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: From Celebrity Doctor, Medical Advice on Line
description: Consider it the ultimate play in celebrity marketing. A new Web site bearing the name of Dr. C. Everett Koop, who as United States Surgeon General during the Reagan Administration became America's doctor, is about to join the ranks of Internet initial public offerings.

title: The uproar over the USA Networks-Lycos deal may start a rethinking of the portal concept.
description: WHETHER or not shareholders ultimately bless or curse the proposed merger of Lycos with Barry Diller's television shopping company, USA Networks, the deal may well have catalyzed a long-overdue rethinking of the business of Internet portals, those launching pads from which millions of Web surfers rocket onto the Internet each day.

title: Theft Report Is a 'Farce,' China Says
description: China's state news agency today rejected assertions that its spies stole nuclear-weapon designs from the United States as a ''farce'' and a ''fabrication'' by forces out to sabotage Chinese-American relations.

title: Training for a Presidential Race
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Kubrick and Beethoven, a Marriage Made in Hell
description: As appreciations of the director Stanley Kubrick continue after his death, with paeans to his icy brilliance and his meticulous artistry, one of his major characters is being neglected, and I don't mean Dr. Strangelove or HAL or Lolita. I mean music.

title: The Great Campus Goof-Off Machine
description: Conventional wisdom says that computers are a necessary tool for higher education. Many colleges and universities these days require students to have personal computers, and some factor the cost of one into tuition. A number of colleges have put high-speed Internet connections in every dorm room. But there are good reasons to question the wisdom of this preoccupation with computers and the Internet.

title: MacManus Consolidates P.& G.'s Account
description: MacManus Group in New York is consolidating its large Procter & Gamble Company accounts by shifting brands from its smaller agency, N. W. Ayer & Partners, to its larger one, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications.

title: Delirium and Other Intensities From Cuba
description: Aramis Galindo's eyes rolled into the back of his head, and he kneeled at the edge of the stage, leering into the camera's lens. When he sang, his voice jumped into a higher register, the way an automatic transmission might, unexpectedly. Mr. Galindo was singing at Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture in the Bronx on Saturday night, and everything he did suggested that the ecstatic moment was rippling away under a surface that already wasn't particularly tranquil.

title: Mired at 3-17, Calipari Probably Sees the End
description: Nets Coach John Calipari called a player into his office for a routine meeting last season. He assured the player that he was doing all the right things, but told him that some of his teammates didn't quite get it; he used the conversation to criticize other players.

title: 2 Marketers Select New Agencies
description: Two advertisers have named agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBLER, IDA (AIDA)
description: OBLER-Ida (Aida). On March 14, 1999. Former resident at 400 East 52nd Street in the city she loved, New York, and recently at Senior Quarters in East Northport, NY. Mother of Marcia Fisher, three grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and an extended family of hundreds. She lived the fairy tale life reserved for those who went to the ''Big City'' and found fame, fortune and happiness. In lieu of flowers, donations to your choice. Funeral services Tuesday, 12:45 PM, at the I.J. Morris Dix Hills Chapel, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLMAN, LOUIS J., M.D.
description: MILLMAN-Louis J., M.D. 89, of Riverdale, NY, died on March 11, of congestive heart failure. A graduate of CCNY, he went on to study medicine in Munich and Basel, graduating with honors. He served for three years in the Army Medical Corps as a pathologist with the rank of Major, receiving two Presidential Citations. Dr. Millman was Director of Pathology at Fordham Hospital for 20 years and on the teaching faculty of Albert Einstein. He is survived by his wife Beverly, his sons Dr. Jonathan Millman of Mobile, AL, Paul Millman of Palo Alto, CA, and daughter Amy Millman Faxon of Manhattan. He has six grandchildren.

title: Basketball Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Expresses Regret Over Police Shooting of Immigrant
description: At the invitation of a coalition of African immigrant groups, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir attended a religious service in Brooklyn yesterday that was described by its organizers as an ''interfaith prayer and community healing'' event after the shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: Whispering Pines Whispers Of Its Origins
description: It says everything about John Laroquette's new sitcom that he plays a cranky innkeeper whose last name is Payne and whose first name is, no kidding, Royal. Outside the hotel is a sign that reads: ''Whispering Pines -- a Payne Inn,'' and though that line virtually dares critics to trash the show with more bad puns, why descend to its level? It's enough to say that this remake of John Cleese's hilarious, farcical ''Fawlty Towers'' has been given a hackneyed Hollywood treatment.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the appointment of Karen Jurgensen as editor of USA Today misstated the newspaper's circulation rank. According to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, which does not credit third-party bulk sales to institutions like airlines and hotels, USA Today is the second-best-selling newspaper in the nation, with an average daily circulation of 1,653,428. The circulation of The Wall Street Journal is 1,740,450.

title: 2 Big Boston Banks In $16 Billion Union
description: Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire BankBoston for $16 billion in a stock deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in the country and the pre-eminent bank in New England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, LEONARD I.
description: SCHREIBER-Leonard I. Of Westport, CT, on March 13, 1999, at age 84 at home. Lee was a graduate of Columbia College, Columbia Law School, and was active in alumni affairs. He practiced law in New York until recently as Senior Partner of Schreiber and McBride. He served as Director and General Counsel to Atari Corp. and Commodore International. He is survived by his two daughters, Ellen W. McBride and Laurie L. Baker, five grandchildren, Seth McBride, Justine Fellows, Jonah Fernald, Jason Fernald, Mallory Baker, and great-granddaughter, Kallie Fellows. Services Tueday, at 12 noon, at the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd, Fairfield, CT.

title: Massacres of Low-Born Touch Off a Crisis in India
description: This hamlet on the edge of a lush, palm-fringed field lay quiet on the moonlit night of Jan. 25. But as the villagers slept, more than 50 upper-caste men, members of an outlawed landowners' army, crept toward them through rustling spears of wheat.

title: A Rematch For Holyfield And Lewis Is Ordered
description: The presidents of the three sanctioning bodies for the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight unification bout have ordered a rematch within six months. The bout Saturday night at Madison Square Garden ended in a controversial draw, even though it appeared that Lewis had clearly controlled the entire fight.

title: Turkey's Political Turmoil Deepens as National Election Nears
description: With a national election approaching, Parliament in open rebellion against the political establishment, murderous terror attacks being mounted against civilians and the trial of a hated Kurdish guerrilla leader approaching, Turkey suddenly finds itself facing deep uncertainties.

title: 3 More Airlines Raise Fares In 2d Industry Move This Year
description: Northwest Airlines, U S Airways and Trans World Airlines raised ticket prices over the weekend, matching fare increases made late last week by the nation's other major carriers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZER, ABE
description: MINTZER-Abe. Of Queens, New York. Died Saturday, March 13, 1999, at the age of 86. Married fifty-two years to devoted wife, Esther. Loving father of Yvette Mintzer. Father-in-law of Michael Bender. Grandfather of Ariel and Gabriel Bender. Services Monday, March 15, 1 PM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Canada Proceeds With Law To Protect Magazine Industry
description: The Canadian House of Commons is expected to pass legislation on Monday that would protect its magazine industry from American competition, a move that could lead Washington to retaliate.

title: Quick Cuts: The Novel Follows Film Into a World of Fewer Words
description: The effect of a hundred years of filmmaking on the practice of literature has been considerable.

title: Swindles Start to Flourish on Worries Over Year 2000 Problems
description: While many consumers have worried that Year 2000 computer problems will cripple the banking system, bankers and law enforcement officials have been warning that the bigger financial risks may come from scam artists and thieves playing on such fears.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Wednesday about the appointment of a president at the Pocket Books unit of Simon & Schuster misstated the company's ownership. It is a unit of Viacom. Pearson purchased some of Simon & Schuster's publishing operations last year, but not Pocket Books.

title: In Angler's Freezer Since '62, Fish May Refute 'Extinction'
description: Call it nostalgia. Or sentimentality. Or call it an uncanny prescience.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Sports of The Times; Lewis Has Himself To Blame for the Draw
description: IT'S being denounced as the biggest robbery since Willie Sutton was the heavyweight champion of bank heists. But for all the complaints about Lennox Lewis's 12-round draw with Evander Holyfield, he robbed himself.

title: Dragon Systems Delays Initial Public Offering
description: The stock market debut of Dragon Systems, a voice-recognition software company in Newton, Mass., has been postponed until at least next month, following Dragon's report of unexpectedly anemic sales revenue in the fourth quarter of 1998.

title: How the U.S. Can Do Right by Central America; Forgive All Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: How the U.S. Can Do Right by Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODFRIEND, DANIEL
description: GOODFRIEND - Daniel. Died March 13, 1999. Beloved husband and lifelong soulmate of Norma Goodfriend. Devoted and adoring father of Ronnie and father-in-law of Philip Feldman. Doting grandfather of Candace. Caring brotherin-law, uncle and good friend to all who knew him. A gentleman's gentleman, honest, kind, thoughtful, sincere, unassuming and giving without expecting returns. A charitable man, retired accountant/controller who will be missed by all. Funeral Monday, March 15, 1999, noon, Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Mixing the Glass Half Empty With One Full of Punch
description: Lou Barlow kept apologizing when his band, Sebadoh, performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night. ''I wish I wasn't sick,'' he said. He was coughing between songs, and by the end of the 90-minute set his voice was giving out. ''Maybe I just don't have what it takes.''

title: Sharp Analysis Wins a Bet, If Not a High-Stakes Game
description: Most aspects of the game involve some degree of luck. Duplicate competition seems to eliminate it but does not. If a small slam is a 50-50 proposition, somebody is sure to be lucky and somebody else unlucky. One exception is the par competition in which players must cope with prepared deals. Another is the post-mortem, in which quick analysis is required.

title: Huddled Masses Still Yearning to Breathe Free
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELTZER, DR. MORTON B.
description: GELTZER-Dr. Morton B. Beloved husband of Caryl. Devoted father of Mindy and Gregory White. Dear brother of Dr. Arthur Geltzer. Loving grandfather of Andrew and Jessica. Services today, 10 AM, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Haunted by 'Lost Decade,' Reformists Push Ahead
description: IT IS "second thoughts" time again in Latin America. After more than a decade of reform that has modernized and transformed the economies of the region, Latin America is gripped by a downturn that is still spreading and that portends at least a year of slow growth and recession. Led by Brazil, the overall regional economy could decline by 1.5 percent to as much as 3 percent. Yet, the very extent of reform means that the region is in much better shape

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, ALEXANDER
description: POLLACK-Alexander. On March 13, 1999, at the age of 75. Beloved husband to Violet. Devoted father to Nancy, Michael and Anne. Caring father-in-law to Bob and Barbara. Adored grandfather of Leslie, Eric, Lucy and Ava. Loving son of Frank and the late Lillian. Loyal brother, brother-in-law, uncle, granduncle, great-granduncle and friend to all who knew him. A kind, wonderful man, he brought joy and love to his family and friends with his friendly face and bright smile. The songs he sang will echo in our hearts. His passion and charm will be greatly missed. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Training for Next War, Army Slow to Change
description: Out in the rough ochre hills of California's high desert, Staff Sgt. Joseph W. Burris of the 4th Infantry Division clambered from his M1-A1 tank, dusty and tired, and explained how the enemy had knocked him out of the day's war game.

title: Mother's Work Is Never Done, Never Done, Never Done . . .
description: She begins her day in a chenille bathrobe and envies her husband the luxury of taking an uninterrupted shower. Her day is an endless medley of dressing children, undressing them, taking one to school, picking him up, mediating their arguments, sprinting when they try to run into the street and generally responding to the call ''Mommy!''

title: Why Not Let Judges Use Their Heads?; Not a Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a roll-call listing in some editions on Friday for the House vote on giving states and schools more flexibility in spending $11 billion in Federal money included a group of names erroneously under the heading for West Virginia. That state's Representatives were Mollohan, Rahall and Wise; all others shown were duplicates of Washington State entries.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Glorious, Yes, But Resisting Today's World; The Vienna Philharmonic Returns, Virtually a Male Bastion
description: As usual there were sold-out houses at Carnegie Hall for the series of three concerts by the Vienna Philharmonic, under the conductor Riccardo Muti, on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. And as usual the playing of this esteemed orchestra, with its distinctively warm sound and its palpable connection to a renowned musical heritage, was remarkable.

title: Muckler Has Rangers Majoring in Positives
description: After the mob of happy Rangers congratulated Adam Graves for his overtime game-winner yesterday, they skated in a loose procession to the opposite corner of the rink in Nassau Coliseum. There, in front of the open exit, stood Coach John Muckler, like the doorman at the China Club, his big grin bright enough to be seen from the top row.

title: Seaver's Vote on Wilson: Still More Seasoning
description: On his final day with the Mets before the regular season starts, Tom Seaver was asked today which young pitchers had impressed him most in his nearly two weeks around the team.

title: Keeping Politicians True to Their Inner Selves
description: AS a Libertarian with attitude, Paul Jacob is simply not going to let House members forget their ballyhooed term-limit promises of the Contract With America class of 1994.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Set
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Wednesday about the appointment of a president at the Pocket Books unit of Simon & Schuster misstated the company's ownership. It is a unit of Viacom. Pearson purchased some of Simon & Schuster's publishing operations last year, but not Pocket Books.

title: INSIDE
description: Calipari Era Nears End

title: Tainted Animal Feed
description: To the Editor:

title: An imaginary pitchwoman steps out from her home territory, the pages of Reader's Digest.
description: AS imaginary advertising characters go, Carolyn Davis is no Betty Crocker. The prosaic Davis, who pitches products in the pages of Reader's Digest magazine, is more akin to Carol Wright, the fictitious queen of cents-off coupons, than to a widely familiar, even popular creation like Crocker.

title: Today's Bill Sale Is Sole Auction Set by Treasury This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Albany Faces A New Reality: A Late Budget Means Late Pay
description: One of the most emotionally charged questions before the State Legislature these days has nothing to do with welfare, taxes, crime or any other major policy matter. It centers on a far more personal concern: whether lawmakers will be paid.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Essay; Of Nukes & Spooks
description: ''Absolutely no truth to it it's an outrageous statement,'' fumed Samuel Berger, the first national security adviser to regularly attend political campaign meetings in the White House. ''It's wrong . . . not based on any facts whatsoever.''

title: How the U.S. Can Do Right by Central America; Stability in Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: Southwest Flights at MacArthur Take Off to Mixed Reactions
