description: Bumped off an overbooked flight home hours earlier, Jim Mihnovich stood at the end of a long line at Long Island MacArthur Airport this morning a grateful man. Grateful mostly for Southwest Airlines, which started operations at MacArthur today.

title: Talk Media Names A Financial Officer
description: Talk Media -- the multimedia company founded by Tina Brown, the former editor of The New Yorker, and Ron Galotti, the former publisher of Vogue -- has hired Gerard A. Fragetti, a longtime executive of the News Corporation, as its chief financial officer.

title: Earlier Work With Children Steers Them From Crime
description: Programs that seek to reduce violence, drug abuse, pregnancy and other dangerous or unhealthy activities among adolescents are notorious for doing too little too late and at too great a cost.

title: Missing Lesson in Computer Class: Avoiding Injury
description: Toddlers practice coloring inside the lines on computer workstations at a Queens public library, their feet dangling because the chairs are too high. Fourth graders in Westchester County check stock quotations on the Internet, arching their necks at mom or dad's computer, to complete a homework assignment about investing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the appointment of Karen Jurgensen as editor of USA Today misstated the newspaper's circulation rank. According to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, which does not credit third-party bulk sales to institutions like airlines and hotels, USA Today is the second-best-selling newspaper in the nation, with an average daily circulation of 1,653,428. The circulation of The Wall Street Journal is 1,740,450.

title: Snowstorm Picks Its Way Along the Northeast Coast
description: A huge storm that dumped more than a foot of snow on parts of the Plains states over the weekend reached the East today and threatened to bring snow to a 75-mile-wide band from Washington to Boston.

title: Aide Who Resigned Tosses a Barb at Schroder
description: Oskar Lafontaine, who threw Germany's Government into turmoil on Thursday by quitting as both Finance Minister and as chairman of the ruling political party, ended three days of silence today with a thinly veiled attack on Chancellor Gerhard Schroder.

title: Rangers Stay in Playoff Picture With Victory Over Isles
description: Adam Graves was dragging after 64 minutes of up-and-down hockey when the puck found his stick. Desperate, like his Rangers, he fired a long shot from just inside the Islanders' blue line.

title: Connecticut Edges Upset-Minded Xavier With Late Rally
description: Before tonight's game against Connecticut, Xavier Coach Melanie Balcomb told her players that the key to an upset was being able to handle the Huskies' vaunted pressure. Balcomb also told them, ''UConn is like any other team and can be beaten.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANIN, GARSON
description: KANIN-Garson. We mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed member, past Vice President and Lifetime Director. A recipient of the Booth Award, his life and career in the theater were exemplary. His wit and charm were legendary. We will miss him greatly. Our heartfelt sympathies to our fellow Player, Marian, to whom we are devoted. The Players

title: Just a Couple Of Old Pals Wrestling For an Oscar
description: It's Harvey versus Jeffrey!

title: No Longer Yanks' New Face, Knoblauch Finds His Niche
description: Chuck Knoblauch's locker in the clubhouse is a few feet from that of Derek Jeter, and the banter between the Yankees infielders is as steady as the trains running to and from Grand Central Terminal. Jeter likes to adjust his pronunciation of Knoblauch's name -- ''Knob-a-lockah,'' Jeter will say -- and they play catch together before each workout, their friendship growing.

title: The Next Tobacco Giant: Japan; An Empire Crumbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Art on the Hudson: New Use for an Old Factory Lifts a City's Hopes
description: From the Depression through the booming 1980's, crowds of men and women wearing blue coveralls thronged each day to the sprawling factory on the riverfront here. Around the clock, they printed, cut and folded colorful cartons for Ritz crackers, Milk-Bone dog biscuits, Oreo cookies and other products of what once was the National Biscuit Company.

title: Man Suspected of Killing His Wife and Son Is Shot to Death by Police
description: A man in Chatham, N.J., who the authorities said had killed his estranged wife and their 8-year-old son was shot dead by a police officer Saturday night after he refused to drop a large kitchen knife, the police said yesterday.

title: Taking the Fish Market Into Cyberspace
description: As a third-generation ''fish guy'' in New York City, Stratis Morfogen practically grew up at the Fulton Fish Market, watching men dicker over seafood.

title: The Celebrity Author Who Sat and Wrote
description: It's become common to assume that celebrity authors rarely write more than the autograph in their books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEREFF, ROSE (KLEIN)
description: SHEREFF-Rose (Klein). On March 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Abraham I. Loving mother of Judith Harte and Richard Shereff. Cherished grandmother of Douglas Harte, Jonathan Harte and Helaine Harte. Services 2:15 graveside today, at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, New York. For information, contact Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Credit Lyonnais Stakes Limited
description: France said today that large investors would not be able to buy more than 10 percent of Credit Lyonnais S.A. when its sale starts as soon as next month, quashing speculation that Credit Agricole would buy most of France's fourth-largest bank.

title: Purdue and Temple Prevail In Upsets as They Advance
description: Duke's waltz through college basketball's big dance seemingly got that much easier today. Miami and Cincinnati, the No. 2- and No. 3-seeded teams, respectively, in the East Regional of the National College Athletic Association tournament -- where Duke is seeded No. 1 -- were eliminated at the Fleet Center.

title: Unraveling, Not Relaxing, At This Beach House
description: In the name of sanity, can someone please stop that noise? All those chuckles, titters, giggles, guffaws: they're so much scarier than the usual shrieks, groans and clanking chains. Such are the diabolical, synthetic sounds of amusement that plague the sunny but definitely haunted beach house of ''Betty's Summer Vacation,'' an ecstatically angry new comedy by Christopher Durang that suggests that Western civilization is ending not with a bang but with a laugh track.

title: Placing the Blame in an Infant's Death; Mother Faces Trial After Baby Dies From Lack of Breast Milk
description: When Tabitha Walrond, a 19-year-old welfare recipient, gave birth to her first child on June 27, 1997, she did what new mothers rich and poor are urged to do these days: she breast-fed her baby. But on Aug. 27, seven weeks after leaving the hospital, the son she had named Tyler Isaac Walrond died in her arms of malnutrition.

title: Muriel Bentley, 82, Dancer In Jerome Robbins's Ballets
description: Muriel Bentley, an early member of Ballet Theater (now American Ballet Theater) who was praised for her comic gifts and witty dancing, died on March 8 at the Kaiser Permanente Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 82 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Needed: a G.O.P. Environmental Identity
description: At the turn of the century, President Theodore Roosevelt derided political leaders who talked a good game on the environment but did little else as ''nature fakers.'' Roosevelt would probably apply that same label to many of today's politicians -- including some members of his own Republican Party.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an offer by the Banque Nationale de Paris to purchase two other French banks referred incorrectly to a comment by Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, on opposition to the merger. Mr. Steinberg said that because of the banks' resistance to settling issues involving accounts of Holocaust victims or their survivors, a great deal of opposition to the merger existed in the leadership of the World Jewish Congress -- not in the United States Congress.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Wednesday about Catherine Hickey, superintendent of schools for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, misstated the affiliation of the Catholic school system in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was educated. It was the Diocese of Brooklyn , not the New York Archdiocese.

title: Game 2 of Series Set for May 3
description: The Cuban national baseball team will play the Orioles in Baltimore on May 3 in the second game of the two-game series between the teams, baseball officials said yesterday. The Orioles will play in Havana on March 28, making them the first major league team to play in Cuba since 1959.

title: G.E. Chief Received $56.6 Million in '98
description: The chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company, John Welch Jr., took home $56.6 million in 1998, including $10.1 million in salary and bonus, during a year when G.E. stock rose 39 percent.

title: U.S. HOPE IS SLIM AS TALKS RESTART ON KOSOVO CRISIS
description: Few in the Clinton Administration were prepared to predict success today on the eve of the second round of Kosovo peace talks in Paris.

title: New-Media Shops Share Honors
description: Three agencies shared top honors for new-media advertising, winning the most awards, at a ceremony in New York sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRANUM, VERNE
description: TRANUM-Verne. March 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Charles B. Tranum. Loving mother of John Budlong, Sherry Kock and Kyle Weinig. Grandmother of Christobel Langan, Kimberly Norris, Caroline Kock, Marshall Kock and Alexander Weinig. Sister of Dorothy Fay Somers and Peggy Constance Stone. Interment private.

title: Man Ingested 92 Bags of Heroin, Police Say
description: A 44-year-old man who fainted and went into convulsions at La Guardia Airport early yesterday had 92 thumb-size packets of heroin in his digestive tract, an officer with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Criminals Who Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Flying With Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanity Fair's Star Quality; Editor Celebrates Hollywood and Advertisers Applaud
description: At Vanity Fair's Oscar party last year, Morton's restaurant became so choked with people -- balding billionaires, actresses with plunging necklines and silicone-enhanced poitrines, studio heads and their entourages, gawking advertisers trying to look nonchalant and the ephemeral characters who circumnavigate Hollywood society -- that at midnight the Los Angeles fire marshals stormed in and took action.

title: Pocket Paperbacks Are Losing Readers To Hardcover Sales
description: There was a time when the lowly and cheap paperback tucked on a drugstore rack was lavished with high praise, ranked in the revolutionary stratosphere with the advent of the Pill, or at the very least, air-conditioning or color television.

title: Investing Success Breeds Unlikely Troubles
description: Is CMGI an Internet company or a mutual fund?

title: Fleet Financial to Buy BankBoston in $16 Billion Stock Deal
description: Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire the BankBoston Corporation for $16 billion in a deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in the country and the pre-eminent bank in New England, the companies said yesterday.

title: Brazilian Economist Killed In Waldorf-Astoria Attack
description: The man killed Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria was identified yesterday as a well-to-do Brazilian economist who ran agricultural projects in the Amazon rain forest, owned a popular antiques store and traveled the world several times a year, the police and his relatives said.

title: Calipari's Number Is Up as Nets' Coach
description: The beginning of one Nets era apparently coincided with the end of another today at Miami Arena. After the team's uninspired performance in Stephon Marbury's debut with the Nets, the club's owners met with John Calipari and discussed relieving him of his coaching duties, according to a person close to the team who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: Los Alamos Spies, Then and Now
description: ''This is going to be just as bad as the Rosenbergs,'' Paul Redmond, formerly the chief spy hunter for the Central Intelligence Agency, recalls saying when he was briefed in 1996 on the evidence that China had stolen nuclear secrets from the Los Alamos National Laboratory. The current scandal inevitably conjures up memories of Soviet atomic espionage. There are similarities between the two cases, but differences between them are more significant.

title: A Writer With a Past Turns to Advertising
description: Ruth Shalit, a former associate editor at The New Republic whose quick rise to prominence as a political reporter was halted by accusations of plagiarism, has found a new calling: advertising.

title: Firefighters Get Help In Fighting Terrorism
description: Dissatisfied with the pace of efforts to prepare the nation for a germ or chemical weapons attack, President Clinton has decided to provide an additional $11 million to train firefighters and other emergency service personnel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The heart isn't traded on the stock market yet, but it has a home. And it beats to the left.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, BRENDA
description: GOLDFRANK-Brenda. Of Manhasset, NY, died on March 11, 1999. She was predeceased by her loving husband Richard and son Bruce. She is survived by her daughter Diane Richards and her grandson David Goldfrank. Mrs. Goldfrank was born in 1915 in Northampton, MA, and attended Colby-Sawyer College. During her life she and her husband divided their time between their homes in Manhasset and Tangiers, Morocco. Donations may be made to the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS).

title: Motorola Invests In Home-Network Studies
description: The Motorola Corporation plans to announce today that it will donate $5 million to create a new research center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory to explore ''think and link'' technologies that connect everyday appliances.

title: Talk Radio Copes With Life After Lewinsky
description: President Clinton's romantic travails and legal entanglements proved both a boon and bane to talk radio over the last year.

title: Garson Kanin, a Writer and Director of Classic Movies and Plays, Is Dead at 86
description: Garson Kanin, who broke into show business as a saxophone-playing high school dropout and went on to write ''Born Yesterday,'' direct ''The Diary of Anne Frank'' and become the co-writer of two classic Tracy-Hepburn movies, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DEAN FOODS CO., Franklin Park, Ill., said it would buy Alta Dena Certified Dairy, City of Industry, Calif., from Bongrain S.A. for undisclosed terms. Alta Dena has annual sales of about $200 million.

title: A Bat's Swift Bite, Unfelt, That Could Bring Rabies
description: Last Dec. 15, when a 29-year-old man serving time at the Nottoway Correctional Center in Virginia became ill with muscle pains, vomiting and abdominal cramps, he was simply given an aspirin substitute. But over the next few days his symptoms worsened: pain and tremors developed in his right arm, and he had trouble walking.

title: El Paso Energy to Buy Sonat, Creating Gas Pipeline Giant
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation agreed today to buy a rival, Sonat Inc., for $3.9 billion in stock and $1.9 billion in assumed debt, creating the largest interstate natural gas pipeline company in the United States.

title: Mind Games of the Baroque And Minimalist Shock
description: Three concerts by the Los Angeles Philharmonic formed a kind of arrow aimed squarely at Sunday afternoon's final event: John Adams's ''Naive and Sentimental Music'' in its New York premiere. A meandering arrow to be sure: first new and mostly American chamber music on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, and then orchestra concerts of the old and the recent on Friday and Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall next door.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDLER, JAY
description: SANDLER-Jay. Died March 15, 1996. Then, now and forever is our love for you. Estelle and Dale

title: Middle Class Climbs, but Elite Hangs On
description: Long before anyone discovered that Gonzaga was a small Catholic school in Spokane, Wash., before anyone was welcomed to Wally's World by a sweet-shooting 6-foot-8-inch forward, before Southwest Missouri State got a ticket to a regional semifinal in New Jersey, a coach from down on Tobacco Road offered up a couple of predictions about how the 1998-99 college basketball season would play out.

title: Now Playing in Seattle: Plenty; A City Where Theaters Grow Quickly and Compete Amiably
description: ''The Sisters Matsumoto,'' a play by Philip Kan Gotanda about Japanese-Americans emerging from internment camps after World War II, was ending its well-received world premiere run at the Seattle Repertory Theater's new 286-seat house when the theater opened a new show on its main stage: the Northwest premiere of Martin McDonagh's Broadway hit, ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane.'' For several nights in a row the lobby of the theater at the Seattle Center, this city's sprawling arts campus was thick with the hushed fervor of engaged playgoers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, EVA
description: HORNSTEIN-Eva. Born November 2nd, 1911. Died March 14, 1999 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Devoted wife of Hyman Hornstein. Cherished mother of Barbara Kass and Richard Hornstein, son-in-law & daughter-in-law, Herbert Kass & Marie Hornstein. Survived by dear sister & brother, Gertrude Hornstein & Louis Shapiro, loving grandchildren, Jennifer Kass, Deborah Halperin and Emily and Joseph Hornstein. Her loss is deeply mourned by all. Services Tuesday, March 16th, at 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: If Microsoft Loses Suit, 19 States Plan to Seek a Radical Overhaul
description: Flush with optimism about the way their case is progressing, the 19 state attorneys general who joined the Federal Government in the landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation say they will not be satisfied, should they win the case, with any remedy that does not revamp the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, FANNIE FRIEDENBERG
description: SIMON-Fannie Friedenberg. Died in Chicago on March 15th, 1999. Loyal partner of the late Rabbi Abraham Simon. Beloved mother of Ruth Ritterband, Israel Simon and Judith Simon. Sweet grandmother of Oren Ritterband, Sherry Simon & David Simon. Dear aunt of Enid Brecker, Carol Lerner, Rick Simon and Dr. Ben Finder. Alumna of Hunter College, B.A., M.A., Teacher's Institute JTSA, B.R.E. Life Member of Hadassah. Board member of Central Region and National Board of Women's League for Conservative Judaism. Contributions to Torah Fund are appreciated.

title: Ethnic Albanians Move to Accept Kosovo Pact
description: Ethnic Albanians announced today that they were ready to sign the Kosovo peace accord. But the signing was delayed while mediators consulted the Serbs to see whether they would accept the agreement with some minor changes, French officials said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER PLUNGES. Silver fell after Warren E. Buffett declined in an annual report to disclose his holdings, which last year equaled a quarter of annual mine production. In New York, silver fell 21.2 cents, to $5.098 an ounce.

title: Amtrack Train Derails in Crash Near Chicago, Injuring Dozens
description: The Amtrak passenger train City of New Orleans derailed last night in a heap of rail cars after striking a truck loaded with steel beams near Kankakee, Ill., Amtrak officials said.

title: Waiting List Grows as Seders for Women Increase in Popularity
description: No invitations were sent, no advertisements printed, yet Ma'yan, an organization that promotes religious equality for Jewish women, could not meet the demand for places at the women's seders it began holding last weekend.

title: For Nets, It's Like Starting Over
description: Less than two months ago, John Calipari had every reason to believe he was on the verge of leading the Nets to their best season in the National Basketball Association and that, in doing so, he would solidify his image as a program builder.

title: UAL Says Earnings Exceed Expectations of Analysts
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that strong domestic sales and the spillover from last month's sickout by pilots at rival American Airlines would help lift its earnings above Wall Street estimates.

title: On Central America, No Apology Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SYDNEY
description: LEWIS-Sydney. The death of Sydney Lewis is a great loss to the contemporary art, architecture, and design communities. Sydney and his beloved wife Frances assembled one of the greatest private collections of late 19th and 20th century decorative art, which they gave to the Virginia Museum of Art, where it is on view along with their collection of post-1945 painting and sculpture. A devoted friend of contemporary artists, Sydney ignored his illness to celebrate with us at the opening of the Museum's retrospective of his dear friend Chuck Close. He will be missed by his many friends at the Museum, and we extend our deepest condolences to his wife Frances and their children and grandchildren. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, SHARON (PESIN BLANK)
description: DALE-Sharon (Pesin Blank). Beloved wife of Floyd P. Blank. Devoted mother of Lisa Dale Goldberg. Cherished daughter of Molly (nee Singer) and the late Harry Pesin. Dear sister of Stuart Pesin and a friend to all who knew her. Services at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam Ave, N.Y., N.Y. Thursday, 11AM. Visiting at the chapel Wednesday 7-9 PM.

title: Banks in Ecuador Reopen After Week's Closing, but Taxi Strike Aggravates Tensions
description: Banks here opened today for the first time in more than a week, during which the Government had kept them closed because of a worsening financial crisis. But a strike by taxi drivers blocked roads and brought commerce and transport to a near halt, and tensions remain high.

title: Doing Things the Wright Way
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Therapist in the White House?
description: To the Editor:

title: One of 2 Teams in Genome-Map Race Sets an Earlier Deadline
description: The date for completing the first draft of the human genome, the three billion units of DNA held in every human cell, has been moved up to the spring of 2000, the publicly financed consortium sponsoring the work announced yesterday.

title: Vulcan Ventures Is Buying A Major Stake in Go2net
description: Vulcan Ventures Inc., the investment company controlled by Paul Allen, the co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, agreed to buy a major stake in Go2net Inc. for as much as $750 million to link his cable television holdings with a growing Internet search directory.

title: YAHOO TO OFFER CREDIT CARD SERVICES THROUGH BANK ONE
description: Yahoo Inc., the No. 1 Internet directory, signed an agreement with the Bank One Corporation and the First Data Corporation to offer credit card processing services to on-line stores featured on Yahoo's Web site. Yahoo said it was working with Banc One Payment Services, a joint venture of First Data and Bank One. Terms were not disclosed. Yahoo began its store service last year, allowing retailers to design and set up Web sites that let people buy and sell goods on the Internet. The credit card service will help Yahoo merchants establish and process credit cards within 48 hours of setting up shop on the Web, instead of the usual wait of as long as six weeks. Yahoo rose $3.4375 a share, to $179.4375.

title: Yields at 3-Week Lows, With Favorable Inflation News Seen
description: Treasury bond prices rose for a second day, pushing yields to the lowest in almost three weeks, as investors bet that economic reports this week will point to subdued inflation and slowing growth.

title: College Web Surfers Need the Library, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a review of ''Re-Orientations: Photography From South Asia, 1845-1920'' at Sepia International Inc. and the Alkazi Collection of Photography in Chelsea, misstated the location of Srirangam, India, site of Ranganatha Temple, the subject of a photograph by Samuel Bourne. The town is in southern India, not northwestern India.

title: Swimming Miles Without Moving an Inch
description: Barbara Stevens swims 40 minutes every day in a flume, a pool no bigger than a sport utility vehicle that functions as a kind of aquatic treadmill. A lifelong swimmer with artificial hip and knee joints, Mrs. Stevens, 67, bought her flume in 1992 and installed the 7-by-15-foot pool in the side garden of her home in San Francisco.

title: Canadian Stock Exchanges to Reorganize
description: In a bid to reduce costs and compete more effectively for domestic and international trading business, leaders of the four largest stock exchanges in Canada announced yesterday that they had agreed to a sweeping reorganization.

title: Reeve Urges Surcharge For Spinal Research
description: After viewing videotaped testimony from Christopher Reeve, the Senate Health Committee approved a $1 surcharge on motor vehicle fines to pay for spinal cord research yesterday.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Mayoral Absence From a Table for 5

title: Moya Takes Over Top Spot From Sampras
description: Spain's Carlos Moya became the 15th player to reach the top of the weekly ATP tennis rankings even though he finished as the runner-up to Mark Philippoussis in the Champions Cup in Indian Wells, Calif., over the weekend.

title: Fair Has Location, Location, Location . . . and Art
description: Thirty-three private planes flew into the tiny airport here during the first 24 hours of the opening of the European Fine Art Fair over the weekend, with others rerouted to nearby Liege, Belgium. Hotel rooms were sold out nearly a year in advance. On Friday afternoon and all day Saturday, cars were backed up for miles on local roads, and the best restaurants within 50 miles were fully booked all weekend. These are the trappings of art buying on a scale never seen in the United States.

title: St. John's Aims to Knock Maryland Off Its Beat
description: Duke's Shane Battier knows what it will take for St. John's to beat Maryland in Knoxville, Tenn., on Thursday in the South Regional semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYES, DR. HARRY CLARK
description: NOYES-Dr. Harry Clark. Of Dobbs Ferry on March 15, 1999. Devoted companion of Scott Shoureck, dear friend & business partner of Jeffrey Halvorsen. Funeral service Friday 10AM, South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Visiting on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to South Presbyterian Church or Westchester Humane Society appreciated.

title: Patterns
description: Photographers Protest

title: Prevent Domestic Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANIN, GARSON
description: KANIN-Garson. The Producers, Cast and Crew of ''Three Tall Women'' mourn the passing of Garson Kanin whose lifetime devotion to the theatre will be sorely missed by his family, friends and theatre-goers. He contributed to the lives of many with his unique talent and humor. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marian Seldes, our dear friend and colleague.

title: Watching as Species Fall Into Extinction
description: In the life of every species that goes extinct, there comes a moment when things take a final turn for the worse, when a species that has been teetering on the brink begins its irreversible descent into the abyss.

title: Debate on Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Chief Wants Salary From Sunbeam
description: Albert J. Dunlap, the former chairman and chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation, has filed a claim seeking to force the company to pay him about $5.25 million in unpaid salary, according to his attorney.

title: Chance Encounters in Alphaville
description: For many Americans, Polish dance means folk dancing. But the Silesian Dance Theater, which performed on Friday night at Kaye Playhouse, is something different.

title: Cancer Regimen Found Safe in Pregnancy
description: Pregnant women diagnosed with breast cancer once felt they had to choose either the toxic doses of chemotherapy or a healthy baby, but never both.

title: Review/Fashion; Lagerfeld's Lesson for Younger Designers: Stay Relevant
description: He's been in fashion long enough for his thick black hair to gleam white -- with some artful help from powder dusting. He's seen bell-bottoms come and go and come back. He's lost his label, been abandoned by Chloe for a younger woman, and that outre business of posing with a fan has gone on a little too long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYETT, DR. BENJAMIN I.
description: DYETT-Dr. Benjamin I. On March 13, 1999. Dr. Dyett leaves to celebrate his life, his loving wife, Betty; four children, Laura Hamilton of White Plains, N.Y.; Deborah Desir of Woodbridge, CT; Sharyn Dyett of Huber Heights, OH; & Benjamin Dyett, Jr., of New York, N.Y.; a son-in-law, Dr. Gary Desir; a daughter-in-law, Rosemarie Ryan; seven grandchildren; a sister, Gloria Lawrence of Teaneck, N.J.; a niece, Sherry Latney of Teaneck, N.J.; a sister and brother-inlaw, Rev. and Mrs. David Pharr of White Plains, N.Y., & many loving relatives & friends. Wake 7-9 P.M., Wednesday at Grace Episcopal Church, 33 Church Street, White Plains, N.Y. Services 11 A.M., Thursday at the Church. Entombment, Rose Hills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, N.Y. Contributions may be made to the Senior Choir of Grace Church.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, MELVIN N., D.D.S.
description: BLAKE-Melvin N., D.D.S. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health deeply mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague Melvin N. Blake, D.D.S., Associate Clinical Professor of Dentistry who was associated with Mount Sinai for forty three years. A noted Oral and Maxillo-Facial Surgeon, Dr. Blake earned his dental degree from New York University and joined Mount Sinai in 1956 as Clinical Instructor. He rose to the ranks of Associate Clinical Professor in 1991 and served as director of the Division of Oral and Maxillo-Facial Surgery for five years. Dr. Blake also served as the Chairman of the Department of Dentistry at Lenox Hill Hospital until his retirement from clinical practice in 1991. Dr. Blake will be remembered warmly and he will be sorely missed. We extend sincere condolences to his family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President Alan L. Schiller, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, ALICE MACK
description: GEFFEN-Alice Mack. Of Sea Cliff, New York. On March 15th, 1999. Beloved friend of Carole Berglie. Devoted sister of Joy Hornick and Jacqueline Schlesinger. Nature and travel writer, author of three books and many articles. Private memorial.

title: Torre Is Reassuring In Visit With Yanks
description: Joe Torre moved from one end of the 80-foot clubhouse to the other while he talked to the Yankee players today, speaking confidently, mixing in jokes -- like an entertainer working the room, one player said. In this manner, the manager educated them about his prostate cancer and his impending treatment.

title: Sprewell Helps The Knicks Cure Their Road Blues
description: Latrell Sprewell is the new guy. He doesn't have enough history with Jeff Van Gundy to pour out his soul for his coach nor enough time with his teammates to understand their bond with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNEIL, DOROTHY (NEE STRYKER)
description: MacNEIL-Dorothy (nee Stryker). Of Brookside, N.J. On Friday, March 12, 1999. Mother of David and his wife Gail of Chatham, New Jersey, and Jane of Oldwick, New Jersey. Grandmother of Jocelyn of New York City and Karen Nordmeyer of Boone, North Carolina. Also survived by a great grandchild. A memorial service will be held Monday, March 22nd, 11 AM at the Hilltop Presbyterian Church, Mendham, New Jersey. Interment is private. Memorial gifts may be made to Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, New Jersey 07960.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Trading on E*Trade's Success; Chief Has Aggressive Plans to Expand Internet Broker
description: If a computer glitch kept thousands of customers unsatisfied, wouldn't any company be embarrassed?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTIAGO, FUNDADOR
description: SANTIAGO-Fundador. On March 15th, 1999. Beloved husband of Francisca. Loving father of Nilsa, Nelson, Roberto and Gilberto. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday and Wednesday 49PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Cecilia Church, 120 E. 106 St., NYC, Thursday 10 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SIDNEY, PH.D.
description: WEINER-Sidney, Ph.D. Saturday, March 13, 1999. Dr. Sidney Weiner of Silver Spring, MD., was the devoted brother of Leo Weiner, of Cape Coral, FL. Dr. Weiner is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be held Wednesday March 17, 1999, at Judean Memorial Gardens at 1 P.M. Expressions of sympathy in his name may be made to the charity of your choice. For further information please contact the Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapels, Inc., Rockville, Maryland: phone: 301-340-1400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. The Officers and Directors of Mesivtha Tifereth Jerusalem express deep sorrow on the passing of Mr. Hermann Merkin, of blessed memory, a devoted friend and supporter of our Yeshiva for many years. Together with his dear wife, Ursula, he was a great benefactor of Torah, and many other worthy causes. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his dear wife, children, and grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the Mourners of Zion and Israel. Rabbi David Feinstein Rosh Hayeshiva Rabbi Yisrael H. Eidelman Executive Vice President

title: Police Kill Holdup Suspect in Brooklyn Shootout
description: A man who had just robbed a bodega in Brooklyn was shot dead by the police in a gunfight involving three armed suspects and at least as many officers just outside the door of the store, the police said.

title: Lincoln Center to Revive Opera Thwarted by China
description: Lincoln Center announced yesterday that it would present a complete 20-hour production of the classic Chinese opera '' The Peony Pavilion'' similar to the one that was canceled last summer after cultural officials in Shanghai refused to allow the performers to leave China.

title: Those Rising Cable Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tools Yield Clues to Disasters at Sea
description: There were no distress calls or survivors. The sea that brutal night claimed the lives of 42 men and two women. Six weeks later, one lifeboat was found afloat, empty and broken, torn from its davits.

title: Springsteen, Joel and Others Enter Ranks of Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
description: After years as a participant at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremonies -- praising his idols, jamming with the band -- Bruce Springsteen joined the club himself last night. At the 14th annual induction, held at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Springsteen said, ''I stood on this stage and inducted Roy Orbison, Bob Dylan and Creedence Clearwater Revival,'' he said. ''I hope my music served my audience half as well.''

title: Rangers Settle for a Tie And Now Take a Break
description: All things considered, the Rangers probably got about what they deserved last night at Madison Square Garden when they tied the Washington Capitals, 1-1. Weary from a busy schedule, the Rangers failed to hold a lead, but survived to gain 1 point in the standings in the race for the final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference.

title: Two Agencies In Acquisitions
description: Two agencies are expanding through acquisitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINE, VERA (NEE NEWMARK)
description: RUBINE-Vera (nee Newmark). Of Westfield, N.J. Beloved wife of George Rubine. Devoted mother of Allen Rubine & Marcia Masten. Adored grandmother of five grandchildren. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El, 756 East Broad St., Westfield, N.J. on Wednesday, March 17, at 10:30AM. For information contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, N.J. Donations in her memory can be sent to Alzheimer's Assoc., 299 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, N.J. 07054.

title: The Day After a Night of Happiness
description: DAMASCUS

title: No Passion, No Effort and Still No Victory for Islanders
description: Since Bill Stewart took over behind the Islanders' bench nearly two months ago, an uninspiring performance by his team had become so rare that it was difficult to remember a time when it did not work hard in a game.

title: Los Alamos Scientist Admits Contacts With Chinese, U.S. Says
description: A Taiwan-born scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory questioned in a nuclear espionage investigation admitted to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he had had unauthorized contacts with Chinese scientists, senior intelligence and law enforcement officials said today.

title: Enron Files to Offer Unit
description: The Enron Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission to make an initial public stock offering of its Azurix Corporation unit. The company said it planned to raise up to $750 million, or $863 million if the overallotment option was exercised. Azurix, which has headquarters in Houston and London, owns water and waste-water utilities in Britain and Latin America. Enron, based in Houston, supplies electricity and natural gas. It had revenue of $31.26 billion in 1998.

title: College Web Surfers Need the Library, Too; Live and Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Go Forth With 'Pied Piper'
description: Though Humperdinck's ''Hansel und Gretel'' is beloved by children, it is a fully adult opera with a score of near-Wagnerian richness. A true children's opera is one that can be performed by, as well as for, children. It is those works that the Cynthia Auerbach Children's Opera Theater, named after the program's former director, has always championed.

title: When Politics Meant More Than an Oscar
description: MAYBE the seismic politics that rocked 1950's America, left and right, will be put behind us some day. But it won't be this week.

title: Bank Deal Unlikely to Spur Other Mergers
description: Once again, two large banks have merged. Once again, speculation is rampant about which banks will rush to the altar next.

title: A Dubious Verdict at the Garden
description: Somebody once called boxing the sweet science, but there was nothing sweet about last Saturday night's Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight title bout or scientific about the collective wisdom of the three judges who called it a draw. Lewis was clearly the superior fighter for most of a dreary evening, and one judge actually awarded him the fight. A second judge called it a draw while a third, astonishingly, gave it to Holyfield. Holyfield and Lewis will continue to share the title. The only clear winners were the promoters, who will stage a rematch in six months.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO SELL BRANCHES TO CITIGROUP
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation said it had agreed to sell 128 consumer-finance branches to Commercial Credit Inc., a unit of Citigroup Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Associates First, based in Dallas with assets of $64.5 billion, acquired the branches in January as part of its $3.9 billion purchase of Avco Financial Services Inc., a subsidiary of Textron Inc. Commercial Credit offers individual loans and has more than 1,000 offices nationwide. It is a unit of Travelers, which combined with Citicorp last year to form Citigroup.

title: LEADING SENATORS DEMAND U.S. LIMIT HELP FOR BEIJING
description: Influential Senators threatened today to block the Clinton Administration's leading diplomatic effort to improve fast-deteriorating relations with China, and they urged the suspension of some scientific exchange programs.

title: DuPont Buying Top Supplier of Farm Seed
description: The DuPont Company, seeking to create an agricultural powerhouse to match its giant chemical business, said yesterday that it would pay more than $7.7 billion in cash and stock to buy the remaining 80 percent of Pioneer Hi-Bred International, the world's largest producer of seed corn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDEMAN, PATRICIA M. ''TRISHA''
description: LUDEMAN-Patricia M. ''Trisha''. On March 14, 1999. Wife of the late Louis. Beloved and dedicated mother of Christopher, Louis, Gerard and Sue Ann Haesloop. Cherished daughter of the late Elizabeth and Harry Hickey, former Treasurer of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Dear sister of Betty and Dr. Herbert Fett and the late Virginia and John Garvin. Devoted and endearing grandmother of Bryan and Owen, whom she adored. Fond mother-in-law of E. Gordon Haesloop. Trisha leaves many family members and dear friends who will remember and love her always. Visiting on Tuesday and Wednesday, from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, on Thursday, 10 A.M., St. Anselms Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBLER, IDA (AIDA)
description: OBLER-Ida (Aida) On March 14, 1999. Former Vice President of M D Publications, Inc., and Executive Administrative Assistant to the President and Publisher of M D, the international Medico-Cultural Magazine. Your friends and associates in the publishing world remember you with boundless love and will be ever grateful for the privilege and joy of having known you.

title: No Link Seen Between Explosion At Clinic and Bombing Fugitive
description: Federal officials said today that there was no evidence linking Eric Robert Rudolph, the North Carolina fugitive charged in four Southern bombings, to an explosion outside an abortion clinic in Asheville, N.C., on Saturday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHMAN, FRANK
description: GERSHMAN-Frank. Died March 15th, 1999 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Devoted father of Marvin Gershman, Helen Meade and Albert Gershman. Dear grandfather of Paul and Steven Meade, Amy, Daniel and Andrew Gershman. Lifelong and dedicated member of the Jewish Community Center of Bensonhurst. Over 50-year member of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows. Funeral services on Wednesday, March 17th, 1999, at 12 Noon, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue Brooklyn, NY. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMENWAY, CATHERINE MACKAY CASEY
description: HEMENWAY-Catherine MacKay Casey. Died after a long illness at home in Manhattan on March 14, 1999. Beloved mother of Anne, wife of Russell, sister of Jody Martin and Mary Ellen Turner, Catherine is much loved and will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at 10:00 am on Saturday, March 20th at The Madison Ave Presbyterian Church at 73rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions should be sent to Planned Parenthood or The Democratic National Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSTER, FLORENCE
description: JACOBSTER-Florence Minsk Of Delray Beach, Fla. Passed away March 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Leon for 51 years. Cherished mother of Harriet and Michael. Services 1pm Wednesday, March 17, 1999 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. For further info ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 718-284-1500.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the celebration in Poland on joining NATO misstated the date of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising, an event commemorated on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw, where the NATO ceremony was held. It was April 1943, not October 1944.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCKENNA, FLORENCE
description: MCKENNA-Florence. In loving memory of Florence McKenna, who died suddenly on January 31, 1999, there will be a Memorial Mass held on Thursday, March 25, 1999, at 11 A.M. at Saint Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, 84th Street and Park Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Washington's Mayor Urges Moving Its Public University, Creating Furor
description: Taking on an issue today that has always exposed the gulf between haves and have-nots in the nation's capital, Mayor Anthony A. Williams proposed moving the University of the District of Columbia from its current campus in northwest Washington near embassies and expensive homes, to Anacostia, the poorest section of the city.

title: Floodlight Of Divers May Blind Shrimp
description: In spots, the depths of the sea teem with shrimp whose eyes are exquisitely adapted for life in a world of eternal darkness. Extraordinarily sensitive, the eyes can apparently see a diffuse light given off by hot volcanic springs, around which the creatures feed by the millions.

title: $3.5 Million Bonus for Chief of Philip Morris
description: Geoffrey C. Bible, the chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, received a $3.5 million bonus from his company's compensation committee for his participation in talks that led to the $206 billion settlement between cigarette makers and 46 states, according to a proxy statement released yesterday.

title: ESSAY; Nurses, Patients and Managed Care
description: When hospitals and other health care agencies started worrying about pressures from managed care organizations, they brought in highly paid consultants to help them restructure. Though they recommended cutbacks in a number of areas, the quick, cookie-cutter solution for which many firms earned millions was to cut direct-care nursing staff. Patients, families and nurses are alarmed about what these cuts have meant to quality of care.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE REAL RISES. The Brazilian currency rose as banks sold dollars amid growing optimism about the outlook for Latin America's biggest economy. In New York, the real settled at 1.8600 to the dollar, up from 1.9000 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MINNA (HERSHFIELD)
description: LEVINE-Minna (Hershfield). On Monday, March 15, of North Andover, MA. Beloved wife of the late Samuel A. Levine. Loving mother of Charlotte J. Lynch and her late husband Kalman of Andover, MA., and the late Edward Levine. Dear aunt of Janet Horwood of Chicago, IL. Cherished grandmother of Susan (Lynch) and Peter Infantine, Rachel (Lynch) DiFeliciantonio, Daniel and Elizabeth Lynch, Steven and Mary Levine, Sheryl Perez, Jill Levine and adored great-grandmother (G.G.) of Katie and Joshua Infantine, Emily and Samantha DiFeliciantonio, Allison and Zachary Lynch, Jennifer and Katelyn Levine and Jonathan Perez. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Temple Emanuel, 7 Haggetts Pond Road, Andover, MA 01810. For further information please call the Levine Chapel at 617-277-8300.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the Brazilian soprano Bidu Sayao on Saturday misstated her age. She was 96, not 94. The obituary also omitted Ms. Sayao's most celebrated recording. The piece, ''Bachiana Brasileira No. 5,'' is a vocalise -- an aria without words -- transcribed for her by the Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos.

title: When Dumbbells and Antibiotics Clash
description: Many drugs carry consumer warnings: Avoid overexposure to the sun; do not drink alcohol, or take caution when operating machinery. But doctors may soon be offering a very different caveat when prescribing fluoroquinolone antibiotics, commonly used to treat urinary tract, bronchopulmonary or intestinal infections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEREIRA, DR. BENJAMIN
description: PEREIRA-Dr. Benjamin. Age 61, of Leonia, N.J. Beloved husband of Florence, father of Leslie, Jeffrey, Mia, and Gabriella. Brother of Sheila Charmak. Donations would be appreciated to Educational Jewish Center, 805 Astor Ave, Bronx, N.Y. 10467. Services are 1 P.M. Wednesday, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Democrats Pick '00 Site: Los Angeles
description: Evoking the glories and the ghost of John F. Kennedy, the Democratic National Committee announced today that it would hold its national convention here in the summer of 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAISDELL, PHILIP E. (''TEX'')
description: BLAISDELL-Philip E. (''Tex''), 3/30/20-3/14/99. Survived by his wife of 57 years, Elaine French, daughter Barbara of Rochester, NY, son Bruce of Boston, MA, grandson Nicholas in college in Washington, DC, brother and sister-in-law ''Bud'' and Anne of Isle Au Haut, ME, and many other loving relatives and friends. Cartoon artist, editor and teacher for over 60 years. Memorial service on April 18, 2-6PM, sharing memories at 3PM, at the Illustrator's Club, 128 E. 63 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Milt Gross Fund, the charitable arm of the National Cartoonist's Society, 443 Hillside Ave., Mountainside, NJ 07092.

title: In a Late-Winter Blast, Snow Sweeps New York Region
description: Even when the winter storm warnings were broadcast Sunday night, Toni McCloskey, like many residents of southern New York, Connecticut, and New Jersey, refused to take the bait.

title: Tribes Weigh Tradition Against Growth of Casino Resorts
description: With muscular yet elegant curves, the Rio Grande winds its way through the Santa Ana Pueblo reservation. Stand along its yucca- and cactus-sprinkled banks and face north from the sacred Indian grounds where the Spanish explorer Coronado once trekked, and the Sandia Mountains seem to hang like gods in the sky to the east.

title: Panel Says Smallpox Stocks May Be Useful
description: An independent scientific panel has found that preserving the last known samples of deadly smallpox virus in Russia and the United States may provide important scientific and medical opportunities that would be lost if the virus is destroyed this year, as planned.

title: POLL IN NEW YORK FINDS MANY THINK POLICE ARE BIASED
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: When Symptoms Are Obvious, but Cause Is Not
description: More than a century ago, physicians encountered a syndrome they called neurasthenia, characterized by a wide variety of symptoms that variously included fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint pain, headache, memory and concentration difficulties, runny nose, disturbed sleep and palpitations. Researchers expected that a cause would soon be identified -- a virus, bacterium or toxic agent -- that would account for these complaints. It never happened.

title: Q & A
description: Trees' Partners

title: COLD PURSUIT: A special report; Mexican General Off-Limits To U.S. Agents in Drug Sting
description: Early last year, as undercover United States Customs agents neared the end of the biggest investigation ever conducted into the illegal movement of drug money, bankers working with Mexico's most powerful cocaine cartel approached them with a stunning offer.

title: 7 Democratic Chiefs Back Florio for Senate
description: The Democratic chairmen of the state's seven southern counties announced their support yesterday for former Gov. Jim Florio in next year's race for the United States Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, MORRIS, MD.
description: BLOCK-Morris, MD. Age 96. Beloved husband of Helen M. Block. Survived by brother Sidney (Martha), nephews Jospeh (Sue), Lewis Buchman, grand nephews Mark, Seth, Andrew and Michael Buchman. Comm. USNR 1942-1946 Dr. of Medicine N.Y.U., 1927, Attending Physician Bellevue Hospital 1931, Associate Physician at Bellevue, Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine N.Y.U. College of Medicine, Associate Visiting Physician N.Y.U. Hospital, Consultant U.S. Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Attending Physician V.A. Hospital, certified by Board of Internal Medicine, Fellow of N.Y. Academy of Medicine, Fellow of the American College of Physicians, Fellow of the American Trudeau Society and Fellow of the N.Y. Trudeau Society, Alpha Omega Alpha, coauthor of five published papers on Pneumococcal Pneumonia. Funeral Services at Bayside Cemetery, 80-35 Pitkin Ave., Ozone Park, NY, Thursday, March 18, 1999 at 1:30 P.M. Contributions may be made in his memory to the N.Y.U. School of Medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTTITA, NANCY M. (NEE DIMARCO)
description: CUTTITA-Nancy M. (nee DiMarco). Suddenly, on March 15, at 84 years of age. Loving wife of the late Frank, beloved mother of Ignatius, Peter, Vincent and Constance, grandmother of thirteen, great-grandmother of one. Visiting hours Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Ave, NYC Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10 AM Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, NYC. Entombment St. Michaels Cemetery.

title: 2 Yarn Plants to Be Closed
description: Unifi Inc. said today that it planned to close its covered- yarn plants in Raeford and Sanford, N.C., on May 15 and eliminate 257 jobs. The Greensboro-based textile maker said it would consolidate operations in its plants in Rockingham County, N.C., to improve efficiency and lower operating costs. The displaced workers will be offered job counseling and placement assistance, Unifi said.

title: Study Alters Time Line for the Splitting of Human Populations
description: The ancestors of Africans and non-Africans split apart almost 200,000 years ago, much earlier than previously thought, a study of DNA in living populations has found.

title: PUMP MAKER AGREES TO BE BOUGHT FOR $72.8 MILLION
description: Haskel International Inc., a high-pressure pump maker, agreed yesterday to be bought by the closely held Tinicum Capital Partners L.P. for $12.90 a share in cash, a total of $72.8 million. Tinicum is an investment fund in New York. Haskel, in Burbank, Calif., had 1998 revenue of $53.7 million and has struggled in recent years to increase shareholder returns. Its shares rose $3 yesterday, to $12.0625. Under Tinicum, Haskel will have more access to capital for expansion, said Malcolm Greaves, Haskel's president and chief executive.

title: More Trouble Seen on Defaulted Russian Debt
description: A group of 19 Western banks holding $15 billion in defaulted short-term Russian Government debt headed for deeper division today after the largest creditor, Credit Suisse First Boston, broke the group's already fractured ranks to announce a new ruble-based investment fund aimed at recovering the bad debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, JUDITH (NEE MUSLINER)
description: NEWMAN-Judith (nee Musliner), of Ft. Lee, NJ, on March 14th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Marjorie Tversky and Jo Anne Abraskin. Dear sister of Annette Blau. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, Tuesday, 11 AM. The memorial period will be observed at the Newman residence Tuesday, 6-9 PM.

title: Croatia Puts Itself on Trial
description: Like France during the recent Maurice Papon case, Croatia now faces its own trial of a Nazi collaborator -- one whose alleged crimes implicate the entire nation. Unlike France, however, Croatia has to prove that it is capable of dealing not just with its shameful past, but also with its shameful present.

title: On Central America, No Apology Due; Freedom for Berenson
description: To the Editor:

title: Del Close, 64, a Comedian With a Flair for Improvisation
description: Del Close, an actor, improvisational comic and mentor to such comedians as John Belushi, John Candy and Bill Murray, died on March 4 at Illinois Masonic Hospital in Chicago. He was 64 and lived in Chicago.

title: Japan Money Supply Rises
description: Japan's most-watched measure of money supply rose at a faster than expected pace in February. Cash in circulation, regular and time deposits and certificates of deposit expanded at an annualized rate of 4.8 percent in February, compared with January, to 607 trillion yen ($5.1 trillion), the Bank of Japan said today. The Bank of Japan is injecting a significant amount of money into the financial system, bringing the overnight call rate effectively down to zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, LUCY P.
description: GRAVES-Lucy P. Beloved and greatly missed, turned home again March 13, 1999. Visitation Tuesday, 4-9PM at Walter B. Cooke, 117 W. 72 St, NYC. Service and interment private.

title: Be It Ever So Humble: Hudson Park Has New Office
description: What may become the longest, grandest, costliest waterfront park in the nation -- the Hudson River Park to be built between Battery Park City and 59th Street -- has a new home: a 50-foot trailer.

title: Nissan Shares, And Hopes, Rise Sharply
description: Shares of the ailing Nissan Motor Company rose 13 percent in heavy trading today as investors increased their bets that Renault S.A. would seek to preserve its future in the rapidly consolidating global auto industry by taking a stake in Japan's second-largest car maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGNEW, DONALD
description: AGNEW-Donald. At age 92. Died at his home on Jupiter Island in Hobe Sound, Florida. He was the beloved husband of Rebecca Tenney Agnew. They were married for 52 years. Mr. Agnew was a brother of Cornelius Rea Agnew Jr., and of Alice Agnew Morris and of Sanford Agnew. Mr. Agnew graduated in 1928 from Princeton University and from the Harvard Law School in 1931. Thereafter, Mr. Agnew was a partner in the law firm of Wickes Riddell in New York City until his retirement. Subsequently, he became a limited partner of Fahnestock and Company until he moved to Florida in 1967. Mr. Agnew enlisted in the U.S. Navy in 1941 and retired as a Lt. Commander in 1945. Mr. Agnew was a member of the Union Club of New York City and the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, New York. In addition to his wife, Mr. Agnew is survived by eight nieces and nephews.

title: Rooney Retiring From Front Office
description: Tim Rooney, the Giants' director of pro personnel since 1985, will announce his retirement, perhaps as soon as today. A club official confirmed last night that Rooney would leave the football team in May after the college draft and the process of signing undrafted free agents is complete.

title: Truck Drivers for Daily News Win a Big Raise in Arbitration
description: An arbitration ruling last week awarded a sizeable wage increase to truck drivers at The Daily News and could also apply to other union workers, causing concern about the tabloid's finances, management and labor sources said yesterday.

title: Spending by Insurers Pushes Albany Lobbying to Record
description: An unsuccessful bid by life insurance companies to loosen regulations on their industry helped to push spending on lobbying in the Statehouse to another record last year, according to a report issued today.

title: Classicism, Sweetly And Authoritatively
description: A great deal of faith has been placed in Christopher Wheeldon as the bearer of the dimming torch of ballet choreography into a new era. Mr. Wheeldon, who trained in England and dances with the New York City Ballet, does seem drawn to the rich resources of pure ballet classicism. His quietly authoritative new ''Corybantic Ecstasies,'' created for the Boston Ballet and performed by the company at the Shubert Theater here this afternoon, follows the suite structure beloved of young modern-dance choreographers these days. But there is not a Graham contraction or Limon fall and recovery in sight in this ballet idyll.

title: U.S. Magazine Curbs Advance in Canada
description: The Canadian House of Commons passed legislation today intended to protect this country's magazine industry from American competition for advertising revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, LEE
description: FALK-Lee. Died March 13, 1999. Adored by wife Elizabeth, brother Leslie, his children, Conley, Diane, Valerie, her children, Tony, Rondi, Marie Louise and her Gwendolyn. A Player, a Centurion, he will be missed in the worlds of theatre and comic art and wherever elegance abounds. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Thursday March 18th from 4-6 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Provincetown Academy of the Living Arts, Hampden-Booth Theatre Library at The Players or Klanwatch.

title: Many Seniors Face Failure In New Test
description: With just a year to go before high school students must pass a tough new English Regents test to graduate, New York State education officials released test results yesterday showing that more than a quarter of all seniors -- and more than a third of those in New York City -- would have failed if the requirement had been in place last year.

title: China's Premier Stresses Cooperation for U.S. Visit
description: Less than a month before he leaves for a state visit to the United States, the blunt-speaking Prime Minister of China, Zhu Rongji, laid out his agenda today for what promises to be a turbulent trip, saying the two nations would continue to cooperate despite renewed friction on issues ranging from human rights to charges that China stole nuclear secrets.

title: A Therapist in the White House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERZOF, SYLVIA (NEE EVANS)
description: GERZOF-Sylvia (nee Evans). Beloved wife of the late Julius M. Devoted mother of Stephen and Gail, Richard and Donna. Loving grandmother. Dear sister of Sheldon and Harold Evans. Former owner of the Evans Kiamesha Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, NY. Graveside services Wednesday at 1 PM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. For further information contact ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 516-764-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARONSON, HOWARD O.
description: AARONSON-Howard O. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother. Retired partner from Jaros, Baum and Bolles. Volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum. Died peacefully March 14, 1999, at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, MD. He will be remembered by all for his kindness and gentleness. Services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue, Thursday, March 18th at 12:30PM.

title: Dow Climbs 82.42 Closer To 10,000 as Nasdaq Rises
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, swept higher by a couple of big merger announcements, enthusiastic buying of technology shares and an optimistic earnings forecast from UAL, the nation's biggest commercial airline company.

title: ALLTRISTA TO BUY TRIANGLE PLASTICS FOR $148 MILLION
description: The Alltrista Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Triangle Plastics Inc. for $148 million. The seller is retaining an undisclosed amount of debt, Alltrista said. Alltrista, based in Indianapolis, makes plastic and metal products, with sales of $244 million in 1998. Triangle Plastics, in Independence, Iowa, had sales of $114 million. It makes pallets and parts for the heavy-truck, agricultural and construction markets through thermoforming, which softens a rigid plastic sheet under heat and molds it into a finished part. Alltrista shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $23.75.

title: 17 Colleges Join Against Sweatshops
description: Seventeen colleges and universities, including Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Duke and Notre Dame, announced yesterday that they would be the first to join a new factory monitoring association that the White House supports in an effort to insure that apparel carrying their names is not made in sweatshops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLER, DR. LILLY
description: ENGLER-Dr. Lilly. On March 15, 1999. In loving memory of a great woman. Services on Tuesday, 12:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Clinton to Offer Debt Relief Plan for Poor Nations
description: President Clinton will propose extensive debt forgiveness on Tuesday for some of the poorest nations, agreeing to relieve repayment obligations of some countries in Africa and other regions if they enact broad reforms, Administration officials said today.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: From Fries to Fuel

title: Nets' Casey To Rescue
description: With Don Casey at the helm, there will be no more screaming on the sideline, no more unusual motivational moves, such as sending players to the scorer's table just to get a rise out of the guys in the game. When it comes to coaching demeanor, Casey will be something of an anti-Calipari.

title: Gore Offers a More 'Livable World' With Some Tinkering
description: Vice President Al Gore began laying out a platform today for his all-but-announced Presidential candidacy, appealing to harried suburbanites and promising to create a more ''livable world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANSTOREN, ADELE
description: KANSTOREN-Adele. Adored wife of the late David W. Kanstoren, loving mother of Joan and Sylvan Schefler, dear grandmother of Dawn and Dr. Robert Spiera, Hope and Glenn Taitz, Nicole and Brad Silver. Proud great grandmother to Amanda, David, Julia, Emily, Zachary, Jeremy, and Harrison. Services Tuesday 12 noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Cancer as Top Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Date Sought for Rematch
description: With the I.B.F., W.B.C. and W.B.A. mandating a rematch between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis, Seth Abraham, the president of Time Warner Sports, TVKO's parent company, said yesterday that he was looking at dates in July or August.

title: Debate on Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXTRON PRESIDENT TO SUCCEED INGERSOLL-RAND CHIEF
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, the construction equipment maker based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said yesterday that it had named a Textron Inc. executive, Herbert L. Henkel, as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Henkel, who was named president of Textron in February and had served as chief operating officer since July 1998, was also named a director of Ingersoll-Rand and was designated to succeed the chief executive, James E. Perrella, in October. Mr. Perrella will continue as chairman. Textron, which is based in Providence, R.I., named John A. Janitz to succeed Mr. Henkel. Mr. Janitz had been chairman, president and chief executive of Textron's automotive unit.

title: College Web Surfers Need the Library, Too; World at Our Fingers
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency to List Pacific Salmon As Threatened
description: Federal officials will formally declare on Tuesday that nine wild salmon species in the Pacific Northwest are threatened with extinction, the first listing under the 26-year-old Endangered Species Act that affects an entire urban region, a Government official said.

title: Sports of The Times; The Guru Is Waiting For a Call
description: GREETINGS, basketball fans, from Woodstock, my sabbatical retreat, where the snow is fresh and the air is clean, and on a clear day, you can just about pick up the NBC signal coming out of New York.

title: Los Angeles Likely to Get 32d Franchise
description: National Football League owners appear ready to select Los Angeles as the site for the league's 32d club, which would be expected to begin play in 2002. But in a twist, the owners would hold open bidding for new groups in Los Angeles to toss in their hats for team ownership.

title: Renegade Protestants Kill Lawyer in Ulster
description: A well-known human rights lawyer who had received death threats for her work representing Catholics in one of Northern Ireland's most volatile communities was killed today when a bomb blew up her car as she drove from her home.

title: African Expelled From I.O.C. Lobbies for His Reinstatement
description: The clubbiness of the International Olympic Committee was evident today when the delegate accused of receiving the most illicit favors from Salt Lake City Olympic organizers checked into the same hotel as the members who will vote on his expulsion and sauntered through the lobby, shaking their hands and kissing them on the cheek.

title: What's a Dog to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: E. Lynn Turgeon, Economics Professor, 78
description: E. Lynn Turgeon, a longtime professor of economics at Hofstra University, died last Wednesday at University Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 78.

title: By Design; Ponchos Can't Be Far Behind
description: Winter coat weather persists in many parts of the country, but thoughts of spring have already stirred fashion-conscious shoppers to snap up the coming season's cover-up of choice, the poncho. Stores report that many styles have already sold out, but some are still in stock.

title: Panel Is Proposed to Fight Corruption in Trash Industry
description: For decades, the Westchester County government knew that organized crime had controlled many of the county's trash hauling companies, including the Suburban Carting Corporation, the very company that operates the county's recycling plant and three garbage collection stations.

title: Man Acquitted of Murder Is Wanted in Texas
description: A Brooklyn man who was acquitted of all charges last month in the slaying of a Bronx teacher has been in jail since Thursday night, when he was arrested in South Jamaica, Queens, for driving with a suspended license, law enforcement officials said yesterday. And a routine computer background check revealed that the man, Montoun T. Hart, was wanted in Texas for a probation violation.

title: Bill Is Introduced To Give Tax Rebates
description: Legislation was introduced yesterday that would carry out a $1 billion property-tax rebate outlined by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, MARION DIACK
description: REEVES-Marion Diack. Of Solomons, MD., formerly of Warren, CT, on March 13, 1999. Beloved wife of Robert B. Reeves Jr., devoted mother of Robert T. Reeves of Annapolis, MD., Barbara Reeves Worthington of Baltimore, MD., and Carolyn Reeves Dunn of Ligonier, PA. She is also survived by 8 grandchildren and 2 greatgrandchildren. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Warren, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Warren Congregational Church, Warren, CT. 06754. For information contact Rausch Funeral Home, P.A., Port Republic, MD. (410-586-0520).

title: Enthusiasts Try to Learn How Wright Brothers Did It
description: It looks eerily out of place. In a giant NASA wind tunnel used to test components of advanced airplanes and spacecraft sits a fragile looking biplane of wood and cloth: a replica of the Wright brothers' aircraft that began the age of powered flight.

title: Group Running European Union Quits en Masse
description: The entire executive leadership of the European Union in Brussels, 20 highly paid members of a powerful bureaucracy appointed by the 15 member countries, resigned early this morning after an independent panel accused the group of chronic cronyism and corruption.

title: Sydney Lewis, 79, Art Collector and Patron
description: Sydney Lewis, a leading collector of contemporary art, Art Nouveau and Art Deco, and a major benefactor of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, died on Friday at Medical College of Virginia Hospitals in Richmond. He was 79 and had been ill for some time, his family said.

title: When the Main Event is Metaphor, It's Easy to Get Lost
description: ''I love you with my skin and teeth,'' sang Joe Henry in a song from his exquisite new album, ''Fuse'' (Mammoth), at Shine on Thursday night. He winced and growled, cupping the microphone with his hands to produce a hollow tone, as his masterly band rolled out a carpet of rhythms behind him. ''Skin and teeth,'' Mr. Henry repeated, the music as smooth and relaxing as a back rub.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Screening Method for Cervical Cancer
description: Cervical cancer, curable if detected early, kills more women in the developing world than any other cancer for the lack of a simple, inexpensive and effective screening method. But researchers in Zimbabwe believe they have found just that, in vinegar, a trained eye and a flashlight.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted on Sunday for the picture with Garson Kanin's obituary in some editions, showing him with Ruth Gordon. The photographer was Yousef Karsh of Ottawa.

title: A Therapist in the White House?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Project 30 Years in the Making; Durst Tries to Revive Father's Dream, Decades Later
description: More than 30 years ago, Seymour B. Durst set his sights on a dingy block at the eastern edge of Times Square.

title: Revealing the Poetry Behind Bartok's Fangs
description: At the start of the New York Philharmonic's concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening, the violinist Gil Shaham, who was on hand to play Bartok's Violin Concerto No. 2, announced that the concert was dedicated to the memory of Yehudi Menuhin, who died on Friday. Other musical organizations with concerts this week will probably follow suit, but what made Mr. Shaham's dedication particularly apt was Menuhin's close association with Bartok. Menuhin gave the premiere of the Sonata for Solo Violin in 1944, and he was an early champion of the work Mr. Shaham was about to play.

title: Don't Go Sleepless Without This Advice
description: Researchers studying sleep-deprived soldiers and doctors suggest that the best way to make it through the night with a clear head is to take an afternoon nap, drink two cups of coffee around midnight and then tough it out, with no catnapping.

title: Dinkins Among 14 Arrested in Protest of Police Shooting
description: Former Mayor David N. Dinkins, Representative Charles B. Rangel and 12 others were arrested yesterday as they staged a protest at Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan over the police killing of Amadou Diallo.

title: Life on the Far Side of 150
description: The prospect of hyper-elongated life spans is tantalizing, not least to one's curiosity. If Thomas Jefferson, who was born in 1743, had lived to 200, he would have been spared by half a century the DNA analysis of Sally Hemings's descendants, but he would have witnessed automobiles and airplanes, not to mention two world wars. What might a 200-year-old born today eventually see?

title: Nomo Controls the Scoreboard, but Not His Location
description: Hideo Nomo's every pitch in training camp has been under scrutiny by the Mets' staff.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: In today's in-your-face world, the people of rural western Maryland are apparently just too nice.

title: Mammograms Plus Self-Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Fat-Gobbling Pill: Too Good to Be True?
description: Q. The new supplement Cellasene claims to reduce cellulite, the fatty deposits that make the hips, thighs and buttocks look lumpy. Can this work? ALISHA BERGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIENER, SANDER
description: LIENER-Sander. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Nattalie and brother of Doris Kukin, board member of our Stern College for Women. The entire Kukin family are cherished friends of the University. Doris and Dr. Ira Kukin are YU Benefactors and Founders of Sy Syms School of Business. Dr. Kukin is Vice Chairman of the YU Board of Trustees; he and their children serve on several constituent boards. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Liener/ Kukin family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the violinist and conductor Yehudi Menuhin on Saturday omitted an honor he received from the British throne and thus misstated his title. In addition to granting him a knighthood in 1966, Queen Elizabeth II made him a life peer in 1993. So he was Lord Menuhin, not Sir Yehudi.

title: CIENA IN TWO ACQUISITIONS FOR $980 MILLION
description: The Ciena Corporation, which makes equipment that increases the capacity of phone networks, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Lightera Networks Inc. and Omnia Communications Inc. for about $980 million in stock to broaden its product line. Ciena, in Linthicum, Md., will issue 20.6 million shares, valued at $552 million, for Lightera and 16 million shares, or $429 million, for Omnia. Lightera makes equipment that directs traffic on networks; Omnia's products make it easier to carry both voice and data calls. Ciena has lost contracts in the last year to rivals that offer phone companies more products. Yesterday, Ciena shares fell $2.0625, to $24.75.

title: Daily News to Feature Ex-Boston Columnist
description: Mike Barnicle, the columnist who resigned from The Boston Globe last summer amid charges of plagiarism and slipshod reporting, will begin writing a column for the opinion pages of The Daily News's Sunday paper at the end of the month, according to senior news executives at the New York paper.

title: U.S. Judge Voids Charges 2 Tried to Sell Organs of Chinese Prisoners
description: Federal charges against two men accused of conspiring to sell human organs taken from Chinese prisoners were dismissed yesterday by a judge who sharply criticized the Government for building its case around an informant she denounced as ''a fraudulent opportunist.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Approaches 10,000 As Stocks Set Records

title: Traveling Companion Is Sought In Killing at the Waldorf-Astoria
description: Investigators are seeking the traveling companion of a Brazilian economist who was found murdered Saturday in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria, a police official said yesterday.

title: America's Secret Past in Chile
description: One of the lingering mysteries about Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile is whether Washington aided in the 1973 military coup that brought him to power and how much it knew of the murders and forced disappearances committed by his Government. Beginning with an investigation by a Senate committee in 1975, tantalizing bits of information have emerged about failed Central Intelligence Agency efforts to keep the Socialist Salvador Allende from becoming president of Chile in 1970, and the C.I.A.'s ties to Mr. Pinochet's intelligence organizations. Now, if the Clinton Administration carries out a well-designed plan to declassify its information on Chile, the details of America's role may be known.

title: INSIDE
description: Marines Drop Charges

title: A Guide for Perplexed Parents Weighing Circumcision
