description: Circumcision of infant boys has alternately been called ''the unkindest cut'' and the key to good penile health and hygiene. Which is correct, and how does a parent with a newborn son make the decision?

title: Schwab Says Profit Will Beat Forecasts
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings would exceed analyst estimates by as much as 30 percent, doubling income in the period a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDROWITZ, SHIRLEY KEMPNER
description: SANDROWITZ-Shirley Kempner. March 5, 1989. Rest in peace, doll of love. For thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings. Dave

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRANUM, VERNE
description: TRANUM-Verne. March 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Charles B. Tranum. Loving mother of John Budlong, Sherry Kock and Kyle Weinig. Grandmother of Christobel Langan, Kimberly Norris, Caroline Kock, Marshall Kock and Alexander Weinig. Sister of Dorothy Fay Somers and Peggy Constance Stone. Interment private.

title: BOEING TO SPEED UP JOB CUTS IN COMMERCIAL PLANE UNIT
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would accelerate job cuts in its commercial airplane division because it was making more progress in cutting factory costs. The 111,400-worker division is expected to have 93,700 employees by the end of the year, fewer than an earlier target of 96,500, a spokesman, Larry McCracken, said. He said the cuts, to be made through layoffs and attrition, were still within Boeing's overall plan to cut 48,000 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, by the end of 2000. Boeing has been steadily cutting overtime pay and reducing assembly-line snarls that crippled its factories in late 1997 and early 1998. The company's business has also been declining.

title: Senator Chafee Plans to Leave At End of Term
description: Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the courtly Republican who is one of his party's dwindling band of Senate moderates, announced today that he would not seek a fifth term in 2000.

title: Review/Fashion; Gaultier and a Missourian Are Over the Top
description: The question of why people come here for fashion, rather than mere clothes, was answered this weekend by two starkly different shows, one by Jean Paul Gaultier, who sent his audience screaming ''Ooh-la-la'' toward the new millennium, and the other by Jeremy Scott, whose all-pink revue literally sent his howling into the night, but wondering, What if he is right? What if this funny-looking youngster from Missouri is talented after all?

title: Wendy's founder wasn't a hit, except with customers.
description: PAUL BASILE and Jim McKennan thought their advertising careers were over.

title: Medicare Panel Chief Doubts He'll Find Votes for Change
description: The chairman of a bipartisan commission studying the future of Medicare made a last-ditch effort tonight to salvage his proposal for radical changes in the health insurance program for the elderly, but he said he did not know if he could round up the necessary votes in time for the panel's final meeting on Tuesday.

title: Robert Q. Marston, 76, Dies; Directed Institutes of Health
description: Robert Quarles Marston, a leading medical educator and researcher who fought for the separation of science and politics while he directed the National Institutes of Health in the Nixon Administration, died on Sunday at a hospice in Gainesville, Fla. He was 76 and had lived on a farm in nearby Alachua.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some copies on Sunday with an article about the men's national tournament basketball game between St. John's and Indiana misidentified an Indiana player. He was Lynn Washington, not Luke Recker.

title: New Zealanders Press Plan for Apes' Rights
description: A group of scientists and conservationists here is pushing a plan that could make this the first nation to grant basic ''human'' rights to apes.

title: Filmmakers on the Verge of a Civility Breakdown
description: When ''The Grandfather'' won an Oscar nomination last month as best foreign-language film, there was a sense of vindication for its director, Jose Luis Garci, who has been locked in a nasty credibility battle with Spain's film establishment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELL, NORMAN
description: TELL-Norman. Died peacefully at home March 15, 1999, at almost 80 years old. Survived by his wife of 54 years, Jeanne, sons Peter (Meah), Richard, and daughter Constance (Jeffrey); also grandchildren David, Shoshana and Anya. Services Wednesday March 17, 10:00 AM at Congregation Beth Am, 510 Claremont Ave., Teaneck, New Jersey. Contributions may be made to Congregation Beth Am or the charity of your choice.

title: Radio Giant Cancels Deal For Lin TV
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation, the big radio and outdoor-advertising company in Dallas, called off its $900 million deal to buy the Lin Television Corporation yesterday and said that its chief executive had resigned.

title: NBC Names a New President For Its Entertainment Division
description: NBC named Garth Ancier, the former president for entertainment at the WB network, as its president for entertainment yesterday. The appointment, which had been expected, completes NBC's plans to reshape its entertainment division under Scott Sassa, as president of NBC's West Coast division, and Mr. Ancier.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's like a leisure virus. We're trading our souls for money. Some tribe members say 'Hey, it's O.K. It's glamorous.' But that's not what we are supposed to be. We are supposed to be stewards of this land.''

title: In Congress or in Cuffs, He Loves the Battle
description: CHARLES B. RANGEL had an excellent day yesterday. The Democratic Representative from Harlem got to talk up Hillary Rodham Clinton, yet again, for the United States Senate, then managed to get himself arrested with former Mayor David N. Dinkins for disorderly conduct at a demonstration at Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan. And all before lunch.

title: For One School, Scores Affirm Strategy
description: Danny Dries was elated but not surprised yesterday when he learned that reading scores at Public School 234 in TriBeCa had leaped 6 percentage points last year over 1997. The smile that crept across his face was that of a proud father. His daughters attend the school.

title: Progress Reported in Attacking Tumor Blood Supply
description: Researchers are reporting new insights into understanding angiogenesis, the body's process of forming new blood vessels, and how it might be blocked as a therapy against cancer.

title: For Villages Of Kosovo, War Is Part Of Daily Life
description: It was mid-morning on the main road north out of Kosovo. The police had blocked off the road and automatic gunfire rattled beyond the village. Over the brow of the hill, three Yugoslav Army tanks pulled into position beside the road, training their guns on the houses opposite.

title: Loyalty, in All Its Shadings
description: One day in mid-1974, Richard Nixon and I sat together in the Lincoln Sitting Room, the most private place in the White House. It is a small room with a fireplace and huge windows. That day I was looking out and looking in, thinking, ''Should the weak side of this man be exposed or not?''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about Dr. Philip Strax, a radiologist whose early advocacy of the mammogram helped revolutionize breast cancer detection, misstated the date of an interview in which he explained that a good physical examination of the breast included instruction in self-examination. It was in 1986, not 1966.

title: Charge in Gondola Accident Is Reduced
description: The Marine Corps today dropped manslaughter and homicide charges against the navigator of the EA-6b Prowler that sliced a gondola cable in the Italian Alps last year, saying it would be ''unreasonable'' to proceed after the pilot was acquitted of the same charges.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Chemists Create Foam To Fight Nerve Gases
description: By combining ingredients of hair-conditioning creams and toothpaste, Government chemists have created a foam that they say could neutralize many of the chemical poisons and disease-causing microbes that might be spread by terrorists in confined spaces.

title: The Most Local of Fishes
description: When the blue pike began to disappear from Lake Erie in the 1950's, it took with it a major regional fishery and a cornerstone of the Friday fish fry, a thriving culinary institution in the heavily Catholic towns and cities that line the lake shore in Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York. Other fish filled in once the blue pike was gone -- it was declared extinct in 1975, when the Great Lakes themselves seemed moribund -- but nothing really replaced it. It is odd to think that no one under the age of 45 is likely to remember tasting blue pike, though it was a staple of their parents' diet and a vital element in their parents' religious observance.

title: Metro Business; Plans at Garden Reported
description: Vornado Realty Trust is in talks to hire Mills Corporation to help it redevelop much of the area it owns near Madison Square Garden into an entertainment district like Times Square, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: M-G-M to Regain Film Distribution Rights
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., the movie studio, said today that it would pay Time Warner Inc.'s Warner Brothers $225 million to regain video distribution rights to M-G-M's film library.

title: Nets Dismiss Calipari With a 3-17 Record
description: John Calipari, the Nets' head coach and executive vice president for basketball operations, was fired yesterday after the team's disastrous 3-17 start. Calipari, who was hired from the University of Massachusetts in 1996 to rebuild the franchise, had an overall record of 72-112.

title: Arena Takes Loss In Stride
description: The euphoria after victories over Germany and Chile this year came to an end for the United States team in its 2-1 loss to Mexico in San Diego on Saturday. The victory gave the Mexicans their third consecutive title in the Nike U.S. Cup.

title: NATO Still Divides
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINN, JOAN
description: WINN-Joan. Died at home on March 15, 1999. She was 89. A graduate of Charles University in Prague (Doctor of Laws 1933), she emigrated to the US with her husband and children in 1939 and became a citizen in 1944. She worked for many years on the Czech Desk of the Voice of America and as a volunteer for Amnesty International in NY. She is survived by her daughters, Janet Malcolm and Marie Winn both of NY, her grandchildren Michael W. Miller of NY, Anne Malcolm of Cambridge, MA, and Steven Miller of San Francisco, CA, and three great grandchildren. Contributons may be made to Amnesty. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, NATHANIEL. THE RABBI
description: LEE-Nathaniel. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Amex Chairman Named Chief of Thermo Electron
description: Richard F. Syron, who spent four years buffing up the image of the often-beleaguered American Stock Exchange before executing a surprising merger with the rival Nasdaq stock market last year, will leave his job as chairman of the exchange on June 1 to become chief executive of Thermo Electron.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: In the Hands Of India Star, A Spike Heel Could Hurt
description: Jayalalitha Jayaram, the former movie star who is one of India's most politically powerful and dependably outlandish figures, faced charges today that she had thrashed her former accountant with high-heel shoes, beating him black and blue during an hourlong ordeal and leaving him bedridden with a bandaged right eye.

title: Insight on UConn: Inexperience, Inconsistency, Injuries
description: The Connecticut captain, Amy Duran, put it best before the start of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament. ''We've really been immature at a time when you need to be most mature, and our inexperience is starting to show,'' said Duran, who should know since she is the only front-line senior on a Huskies team that meets Iowa State in the Mideast Regional semifinals on Saturday in Cincinnati.

title: Judge Defends Decision for Holyfield
description: Eugenia Williams has attended fights for as long as she can recall and trained to box as a teen-ager before women were accepted in the sport. A referee introduced her to judging amateur fights, and by 1989 she was licensed by New Jersey and sanctioned by the International Boxing Federation.

title: Some Oil Nations Detail Cutbacks
description: Oil producers disclosed details today about a plan to cut world oil supply an additional 2.7 percent, the latest attempt by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to raise oil prices.

title: At the Bar In a Nation's Great Cases
description: The last time I saw Laurence Luckinbill, he was wearing Lyndon B. Johnson's facial features in a one-man Off Broadway show, ''Lyndon.'' But that was eight years ago, and Mr. Luckinbill, now in his 60's, appears to be turning himself into the title character of ''Clarence Darrow Tonight'' without benefit of makeup. This one-man show, which Mr. Luckinbill also wrote and staged, is uneven but at times vivid and engrossing.

title: Group Dismisses Saatchi & Saatchi
description: The Auckland and Wellington, New Zealand, offices of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., have been dismissed by the New Zealand Tourism Board in Wellington in the wake of a political scandal in that country that led to calls for the resignation of Prime Minister Jenny Shipley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, SARA
description: SCHECHTER-Sara, of Roslyn, NY, on March 14th, 1999. Beloved mother of Jan, Marvin and his wife, Sharon. Devoted sister of Fay Sydelman. Cherished grandmother of Pamela, Michael, Elizabeth, Diann and Tracy. Greatgrandmother of Gabriel. Funeral service Tuesday, 10 AM, I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY.

title: METAMOR WORLDWIDE AND SPR CALL OFF PLANS TO MERGE
description: Metamor Worldwide Inc. called off plans yesterday to acquire a rival computer-staffing services company, SPR Inc., after both decided that the deal was not in shareholders' best interest. SPR shares lost half their value, falling to $4.75, and Metamor surged $2.8125, to $16.9375. Neither party will owe the other a breakup fee. In January, Metamor, which is based in Houston, said it would acquire SPR, of Oak Brook, Ill., for $22.80 a share, or about $285 million. At the time, Michael T. Willis, Metamor chairman and chief executive, said SPR's profitable outsourcing and computer maintenance business would enable his company to compete for larger contracts.

title: Subway Cable Fails, Closing a Brooklyn Hub
description: In the latest annoyance for Brooklyn subway riders, the two busiest lines between lower Manhattan and Brooklyn's largest subway hub -- the station at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues -- were shut down for 49 minutes during the morning rush yesterday after snow shorted out an electrical cable.

title: On Central America, No Apology Due; Stop the Arms Flow
description: To the Editor:

title: What's a Dog to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Still Divides
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton to Get More From Tobacco Settlement
description: The State Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, announced yesterday that New Jersey would receive $216 million more from a nationwide settlement with the tobacco industry, in addition to the $7.6 billion already announced.

title: Giuliani Names Career Police Administrator as Sanitation Chief
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tapped a high-ranking police official yesterday to be the city's next Sanitation Commissioner, saying the official, Kevin Farrell, was ''perfectly suited'' to the challenge of closing the giant Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.

title: Breast-Feeding as Manslaughter
description: The death of two-month-old Tyler Walrond from malnutrition in 1997 has been made more tragic by the prosecution of his mother, Tabitha Walrond, who goes on trial in the Bronx for manslaughter tomorrow. If convicted, she could face up to 15 years in prison. Ms. Walrond, who breast-fed her son, is charged with recklessly causing her baby's death by failing to feed him sufficiently and to seek medical care when he became sickly. No other signs of abuse were found.

title: When Irish Eyes Are Smiling and Not
description: Sure, with St. Patrick's Day tomorrow you may be yearning to make some wee connection, searching the closet for that Kelly green necktie or trying to remember the lyrics to ''Did Your Mother Come From Ireland?'' But even if your mother did come from Ireland, your authenticity credentials may pale beside those of the McCourt brothers, New York's reigning jacks of heartstrings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHER, HELYNE
description: WASHER-Helyne. The Jewish Center of Teaneck, and its constituent organizations, offer heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Rabbi Emeritus, Dr. Judah Washer, on the passing of his devoted wife, Helyne. She was Rebbitzen and leader for many decades, beloved, admired, highly respected by all. Dr. David M. Feldman, Rabbi David Waldman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MARK JAY, M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Mark Jay, M.D. We note with sorrow the death of a highly respected physician known for his commitment to medical excellence and devotion to patient care. Professionalism and dedication were the hallmarks of Mark Jay Friedman's practice in cardiology and internal medicine. He will be remembered by his colleagues at North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center, his family, and his many friends as a man who took an active role in serving others. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Lawrence Scherr, M.D., MACP Chief Medical Officer North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Foreign Affairs; The Doomsday A-List
description: I don't know about you, but I slept particularly well last Friday night, knowing that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic had just joined NATO. What? You say you were too disturbed by the reports of the Clinton team's lackadaisical response to potential Chinese pilfering of U.S. nuclear secrets to sleep well? You say you had insomnia over the fact that our nuclear arms control regime with Russia is crumbling?

title: As Analyst, Frazier's Rhymes Have Little Reason
description: To misuse English as a professional vocation, one had best be entertaining. Dizzy Dean did it on baseball telecasts. The comedian Norm Crosby does it. Casey Stengel's Stengelese was simultaneously stream-of-consciousness and strategic obfuscation. And Cousin Itt Addams appears to chatter away in speedy nonsense, but slow down the videotape and he's a bard.

title: Citizens and the Police
description: The civic muscle that holds New York City together suddenly feels taut, strained by the danger of communities fracturing along racial lines. The shooting of an unarmed West African last month by four white policemen has focused these tensions among New Yorkers, not only in the ordinary street and subway encounters but also in official settings like One Police Plaza, where former Mayor David Dinkins, Representative Charles Rangel and others invited ceremonial arrests on Monday.

title: Knicks Go 3 for 3 As Sprewell Scores 31
description: By the fourth quarter last night, with fans emptying out of the stands at about the same rate the coaches were emptying their benches, the Knicks showed in one glittering play all that they could be. A steal, Chris Dudley throwing an unlikely over-the-shoulder outlet pass, Chris Childs making an unselfish assist and Kurt Thomas swooping to the basket for an uncontested dunk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DOREN, A
description: VAN DOREN-A. Reading, age 94, of Stamford, CT, died March 12, 1999. Calling hours will be held at the Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT on Thursday, March 18th, from 4-8 PM. Burial will be in Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ on Friday, March 19th at 12 Noon.

title: Internet Goof-Offs
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Ads to Trumpet Whitman's Tax Plan
description: With a possible Senate run in store for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Republican State Committee yesterday announced a $153,000 television and radio campaign in support of the Governor's property tax relief proposal.

title: Letting Little Go to Waste; An Enterprise Evolves From the Byproducts of Industry
description: Over a decade ago, Michael R. Daley was touring a plant that burned old tires for energy when he learned that it paid haulers to cart away gypsum, one of its byproducts. Mr. Daley was astounded: Gypsum, he knew, is used in plaster, toothpaste, paints, even molds for false teeth. So Mr. Daley set up shop near the plant to collect and resell the gypsum.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCEVOY, BRIAN
description: McEVOY-Brian. March 17th, 1967June 20th, 1970. Remembered and missed today and always. Love, Meema

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, CHARLES F. JR.
description: LYNCH-Charles F. Jr. The Board of Trustees of the Long Beach Medical Center records with profound sorrow the passing of our former colleague, Charles F. Lynch Jr. From 1961 to 1989, he served as a members and officer of the Board and helped the Medical Center grow and prosper. We will miss his wise counsel and sound guidance. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Maryanne and his entire family. Alfred Osterland, Chairman Martin F. Nester, Jr., CEO

title: Commercial Real Estate; Purchase of One New York Plaza Reflects Toronto Company's Role
description: The decade of the 1980's looms in the history of Manhattan real estate as the era of the Japanese. Their money poured in through acquisitions of such trophy office properties as Rockefeller Center, the Exxon Building at 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, and Tower 49, at 12 East 49th Street.

title: Invisible Invaders
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Amresco in a Loan Deal
description: Amresco Inc. agreed today to acquire three commercial mortgage-loan portfolios totaling about $7 billion from Nomura Holding America Inc. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Amresco said the agreement involved 1,029 loans. Amresco, a Dallas-based financial services company, has assets of about $2.63 billion. Nomura Holding is a unit of the Nomura Securities Company, the Japanese securities company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, SARAH
description: HAMMERMAN-Sarah. Died on March 16th, 1999 at the age of 88. Wife of Murray. Loving mother of Drs. Ira and Ellen, Mr. Daniel and Charlotte, and Rabbi Richard and Sharon. Adored grandmother of Ariel, Tova and Yossi, Shifra and Chaim, Yossi, Adam and Alicia, Noah & Shira, Eytan, Leah, Yael, and seven great-grandchildren. Member of Washington Heights Congregation. Funeral Services Wednesday, March 17, 1:30PM, at Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., Bronx, at 167th Street and Edward L. Grant Highway. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: The Arrogant Ascent to 10,000
description: With the Dow Jones industrial average on the verge of closing over 10,000, I can't get my mind off a strange stock picker known as Tokyo Joe.

title: A General Will Admit To Adultery
description: A retired two-star general who briefly served as the Army's deputy inspector general has agreed to plead guilty to eight counts of misconduct stemming from adulterous relationships he had with the wives of four subordinate officers, his lawyer said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOICHER, ROSE
description: SOICHER-Rose. Wife of Leslie Molnar and the late R. Irving Soicher. Loving and beloved mother of Larry, and Harvey and Linda. Adored grandmother of Barry and Lisa Slote, and cherished great grandmother of Lindsay and Erica. Service Thursday, 10:45 A.M, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel 212-769-4400. In lieu of flowers contributions to NYU Medical Center or Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: iVillage Offering Is Priced Higher
description: The price range for an initial public offering by iVillage Inc., the operator of a Web site for women, is being increased -- a move that could raise the proceeds by as much as 58 percent.

title: Fairness in Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: Inflation Optimism Helps to Push 30-Year Treasuries' Yield Lower
description: Bond yields dropped to their lowest point in three weeks yesterday, aided by optimism that inflation will not accelerate and, to a lesser extent, by comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggesting that the central bank will not raise short-term interest rates.

title: Trademark Traits Bring Cresson's Career to Close
description: PARIS  Taking up a sought-after appointment on the European Commission in Brussels four years ago, Edith Cresson seemed to put a safe distance between herself and her image from early in the decade as a headstrong politician with a knack for insulting remarks, including slurs against Britain and Japan when she was France's first female prime minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINE, VERA (NEE NEWMARK)
description: RUBINE-Vera (nee Newmark). Of Westfield, N.J. Died March 15, 1999 after a long illness. Wife of George Rubine. Mother of Marcia Rubine Masten of New York and Allen Rubine of Providence, R.I. Motherin-law of John Masten and Barbara Rubine. Grandmother of Benjamin and Andrew Masten, Daniel, Michael and Jessica Rubine. Funeral service today, March 17th, 10:30AM at Temple Emanu El, 756 E. Broad St, Westfield, N.J. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimers Disease Association, N.Y.C. Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10017.

title: $1.2 Billion Bill at Coke Raises Eyebrows
description: In 1998, a grim year for the Coca-Cola Company, one bright spot was the United States, where case volume sales rose a healthy 6 percent. But that appears to have come at a high price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, S. EMIL
description: HOLLAND-S. Emil. Beloved husband of Anne and the late Mildred, loving brother of the late Sadie Zatt, Jack and Louis Holland, and Sylvia Orkin. Devoted father of Cora and Ted Ginsberg, Dede and Michael Thea. Adored stepfather of Greg Meidel. Cherished grandfather of Amy and Steven, Debbie and John, Peter and Katie, Wendy and David, Gaby and Rob, Jennifer and George, Deena and Mark. Cherished great-grandfather of 16 great-grandchildren. Loving uncle and grand uncle. Funeral service Thursday, March 18, 1999, 11:15 AM at The ''Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: CROWN CASTLE AGREES TO BUY 650 TOWERS FROM POWERTEL
description: The Crown Castle International Corporation agreed yesterday to buy 650 communications towers from the digital cell-phone company Powertel Inc. for about $275 million. Crown Castle will provide Powertel with a 10-year lease on the sites, with three five-year renewal terms. In return, Powertel will pay Crown Castle a monthly fee of $1,800 a tower. Powertel, based in West Point, Ga., provides wireless communications services in the Southeast. Crown Castle, based in Houston, specializes in tower management. The transaction, the latest in a string of tower-management deals, gives Crown 6,000 tower sites.

title: Mouse That Roared: European Parliament Stands Up
description: Long preoccupied with establishing a single market, introducing a common currency, even talking bananas with the United States, the European Union discovered today that its lack of attention to the theme of democracy could have devastating consequences.

title: N.F.L. Picks Los Angeles With Conditions
description: Los Angeles was awarded the National Football League's 32d franchise by an overwhelming margin today at the team owners' annual meeting. There were, however, several conditions.

title: Government Says Crash Site Had a Computerized Warning System
description: The Federal Government says it has been working hard since 1991 to reduce the chance of train-vehicle collisions like the one on Monday in Bourbonnais, Ill., but the railroad crossing there was one the Government said had already been fixed.

title: A Longer Life Can Be a Deeper Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientific Leaning
description: PBS plans a new ''Science at Its Best'' block on Tuesday nights starting this summer, Kathy Quattrone, PBS's programming chief, said in a speech yesterday before the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOELSON, GEORGE J., C.L.U.
description: JOELSON-George J., C.L.U. Age 75. President and Co-Founder of Prestige Planning Corporation of 90 John Street, New York City died suddenly Monday, March 15, 1999 at his home in Ocean, New Jersey. He also resided in New York City. An Agent of Equitable Life Assurance for over fifty years, he was also a Lifetime Member of the Million Dollar Round Table. Born in Paterson, New Jersey, to Dr. Morris S. Joelson & Rae Aronsohn Joelson, he attended Blair Academy and was a graduate of Brown University. During WWII, he served with distinction in the U.S. Navy on the USS Whiteside in the Pacific Theater. He is a member and former Trustee of Hollywood Golf Club, Deal, N.J. & a member of the Board of Camp Oakhurst. Survived by his sister Norma J. Hayman of Rumson, N.J. and nine nieces and nephews and nine great nieces & nephews and two sisters-in-law. He is predeceased by two brothers, Robert and Benjamin. Funeral services will be held at Schoem Menorah Chapel, Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey on Thursday, March 18 at 11:00 A.M.

title: Unexpected Profits for Credit Suisse
description: Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland's No. 2 bank, reported higher-than-expected second-half profits today, helped by growth in money management and private banking that more than compensated for investment banking losses in Russia.

title: Toys 'R' Us Names Review Participants
description: Toys ''R'' Us has named the agencies that are taking part in reviews for the creative and media parts of its account, with billings estimated at $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARONSON, HOWARD
description: AARONSON - Howard. Central Synagogue and its Sisterhood record with profound sorrow the passing of their long time member, Howard Aaronson. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President Shirley Steinhauser, Sisterhood President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLAT, LINCOLN K.
description: WILLAT-Lincoln K. In Greenbrae, CA, March 10, 1999, at 90 years of age. Survived by sister-in-law, Jean Mae Lyons of San Rafael, CA; her children, Victoria Gordon of Denver, CO, and Anna LyonsRoost of Eugene, OR; nephew, Gerald M. Mayer, Jr., of Newbury, NH; and his children, Cathey Kennedy of Sand Lake, NY, Deborah O'Brien and Cynthia Benfield, both of Mystic, CT, and Tad Mayer of Sudbury, MA. Preceded in death by his wife, Florence Emanuel Willat, in 1991. Born in Moscow, ID, he served in the U.S. Navy during World War II as a pharmacist's mate in the Pacific; he worked for many years as a commercial artist for A&S Department Store in Brooklyn, NY; after retiring in 1973 he mooved to San Rafael, CA, where he lived until his death. He was a member of Marin Jewish Comunity Center. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date; inurnment Sunset Mausoleum, Kensington, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Guide Dogs for the Blind, Inc., PO Box 3950, San Rafael, CA. 94912, or Hospice of Marin, 150 Nellen Ave., Corte Madera, CA 94925. For information, call Sunset View Mortuary, El Cerrito, CA, 510-525-5111.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This bill recognizes the threat is real and that the world has changed.''

title: Guard Is Among 9 Charged With Fraud
description: A Monmouth County corrections officer, his father and seven others were charged in Federal District Court yesterday with conspiracy to commit mail and wire fraud in a scheme to create a company they planned to let go bankrupt after pocketing cash from the sale of inventory bought on credit, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, CHESTER
description: ROSS-Chester. The Board of Directors and Staff of the New York Association for New Americans, Inc. (NYANA) note with sadness the passing of Chester Ross, beloved husband of Blanche Ross, esteemed Honorary Board Member of NYANA, and past-President of the Agency. On behalf of the NYANA family, we extend our heartfelt condolences to Blanche and to her daughter, Dorie. Laura G. Ross, President Mark Handelman, Exec. V.P.

title: Notebook; Can We at Least Agree On the Lunch Menu?
description: It is common wisdom that parents need to be actively involved in their children's schools. But just how involved, and in what ways?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, SHARON (PESIN BLANK)
description: DALE-Sharon (Pesin Blank). Services at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, New York, Thursday, at 11 A.M.

title: Demotion Has Wilson Feeling Ambushed
description: Paul Wilson's comeback dream took a painful detour today when the pitcher selected by the Mets as the No. 1 overall pick in the 1994 draft was optioned to the club's Class AAA team in Norfolk, Va.

title: AIDS, the war that isn't over, gains some new marketing generals and unpaid foot soldiers.
description: A GIANT agency company is enlisting in the fight against AIDS to battle not fear or ignorance but a perception that the fight is finished.

title: Books From The Times
description: More than 200 recipes for Passover dishes, from the food pages of this newspaper and from cookbooks by Craig Claiborne, Mimi Sheraton and Molly O'Neill, have been compiled in ''The New York Times Passover Cookbook'' (William Morrow & Company, $25).

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Instant Decision By Don King

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Deal Cleared by New York
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's largest local phone company, said its planned purchase of the GTE Corporation for $79.9 billion was approved by the New York State Public Service Commission, the 24th state regulator to either approve or decline jurisdiction over the transaction.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, which starts at 11 A.M. today, a number of Manhattan streets will be closed from 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., including Fifth Avenue from 42d to 90th Streets; 44th to 46th Streets from Avenue of the Americas to Vanderbilt Avenue; 47th and 48th Streets from Avenue of the Americas to Park Avenue; 86th Street from Third to Fifth Avenues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEIGER, DOROTHY
description: SCHWEIGER-Dorothy. March 17, 1998. CON AMOR. E.

title: Accounts
description: * The food and beverage businesses at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and Waldorf Towers, New York, owned by Hilton Hotels Corp., to Pedone & Partners, New York, to handle the account, which had been at Warren/ Kremer/CMP Advertising, New York. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANSTOREN, ADELE
description: KANSTOREN-Adele. The Simon Wiesenthal Center extends its sincerest condolences to our Trustees, Sylvan and Joan Schefler and the entire Schefler family on the death of Adele Kanstoren, beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know of no further sorrow for a long time. Simon Wiesenthal Center Rabbi Marvin Hier, Dean & Founder Samuel Belzberg, Chairman Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman Marc Utay, Chair, NY Executive Board Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

title: About New York; For Students, The Work Is in Albany
description: THE mushy mounds of slush and snow outside Hunter College on Monday morning were enough to prompt any self-respecting student to look forward to the rituals of spring break. Enticingly, a chartered bus awaited them on Lexington Avenue. A few students groggily went on board and settled into the seats in anticipation of their trip.

title: The Year China Policy Went Awry
description: Untangling the various strands of the Clinton Administration's China policy will not be easy in the politically charged atmosphere that prevails in Congress on this issue. But it is essential that the multiple investigations now under way yield a dispassionate assessment of whether the White House was lackadaisical about protecting American security interests, and whether 1996 Clinton campaign fund-raising distorted policy making.

title: Daniel Rejects A Takeover Bid
description: Daniel Industries, an oilfield-equipment company, said today that its board had rejected an unsolicited bid of about $267 million and hired an investment-banking firm to help it review its options.

title: A Longer Life Can Be a Deeper Life
description: To the Editor:

title: An Architect Of Diplomacy Seeks Detente With History
description: YEARS OF RENEWAL

title: Tax Cuts and Painful Reductions Proposed in G.O.P Budget
description: Republicans laid out a budget proposal today that makes good on their promises to cut taxes and increase spending on the military and education, but at the cost of deep cuts elsewhere.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the novelist William Gass omitted the final sentence. The article said Mr. Gass thought the best outcome for his books would be to have them taught and collected in academic anthologies. Asked what the worst fate would be, he replied, ''They fall into oblivion.''

title: 14-Year-Old May Sue Over Locked Pro Courts
description: When Monique Viele was 6, she vowed to become a veterinarian once she grew up, but that was before she discovered tennis, and before the mechanism that packages tennis prodigies with flavor-of-the-month precision discovered her.

title: Breast-Feeding Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Protesting Police Behavior
description: On Monday morning I asked former Mayor David Dinkins if he was going downtown just to demonstrate, or to commit an act of civil disobedience.

title: Jordan Can Envision A Return by Jackson
description: Michael Jordan said he would not be surprised if Phil Jackson returned to coaching next season, either with the Nets or the Knicks, if either job were available.

title: LOTUS PACIFIC TO BUY STAKE IN TURBONET COMMUNICATIONS
description: Lotus Pacific Inc., which offers on-line trading services and Internet access through television sets, agreed to buy 81 percent of the cable modem maker Turbonet Communications for $80 million in restricted stock as it seeks to broaden its customer base. Turbonet will not be able to sell the stock until it has annual revenue in excess of $30 million and pretax annual profit of $6 million. Turbonet, based in San Diego and partly owned by the Toshiba Corporation, currently has annual revenue of about $2 million. Lotus Pacific, based in Piscataway, N.J., offers Internet access though TV set-top boxes in hotel rooms.

title: From Gravy to Jus, Now 'Amish' Is Trendy
description: FOR centuries, the word ''Amish'' has been associated with devout religious belief, barn raisings and Kelly McGillis churning butter for Harrison Ford. Now it has a new connotation.

title: For Mexico, An Economy With Gusto
description: The menu was eggs with hot chili sauce, and the mood had a certain zing as well. Top executives from foreign companies had breakfast today with President Ernesto Zedillo and told him that they planned to spend $10 billion this year on factories and other projects in Mexico, matching last year's direct foreign investment despite continuing uncertainties about Latin America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Love After 60 Could Lead to an Oscar at 32
description: They talked about wanting love and sex and the need just to have someone to hold them. They talked about what the world looks like for someone who is 75 or 80 and alone. When a group of elderly members of a Lower East Side theater group shared the most intimate details of their lives, their stories were powerful enough to persuade a student filmmaker, Keiko Ibi, to turn her senior thesis into a documentary, and it has been nominated for an Oscar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, DAVID
description: BERG-David. Attorney and philanthropist, died at age 94, loving father of Betsy Berg. Service on Friday 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Pataki Agrees to DiMaggio Highway as Aides Talk of Rift
description: Gov. George E. Pataki agreed tonight to rename the West Side Highway after Joe DiMaggio, but his announcement was partly overshadowed by new tensions with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, suggesting that relations between the two men are so strained that they have trouble concurring on whether to put up a few street signs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELY, ALICE ELEANOR (NEE VANCE)
description: SEELY - Alice Eleanor (nee Vance). Age 89, died March 10. Adored wife of the late Leonard Seely for 43 years. Beloved aunt of Jeanne Pape and Harry Schneider, Jr. Honored sister-in-law of Harry Schneider, Sr. For 35 years a gifted and devoted teacher of young children in the NYC school system. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, on Sunday, March 21, at the Union Church of Bay Ridge, 80th St. and Ridge Blvd.

title: Even a Tiny Slice of a Big Pie Tastes Rich
description: A secretary plans to buy a summer home. A 36-year-old banker is already pondering retirement.

title: Amid Clamor for Computer in Every Classroom, Some Dissenting Voices
description: Zenobia Barlow remembers when the frenzy over computers in the classroom came to California. As director of the Center for Ecoliteracy, a nonprofit foundation in San Francisco, she had long shepherded money to elementary schools seeking to involve students in hands-on science projects like local creek-bed restoration and organic gardening.

title: Big Hoechst Holder Said To Favor Rhone Merger
description: Contrary to speculation, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation is not opposed to a merger of equals between Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France and Hoechst A.G. of Germany, the president of Rhone-Poulenc, Igor Landau, said yesterday. Reports that Kuwait Petroleum -- the leading shareholder in Hoechst, with 24 percent -- was opposed to the merger and might try to block the deal emerged almost as soon as the merger was announced on Dec. 1.

title: CSX WILL DIVIDE ITS SEA-LAND UNIT INTO THREE COMPANIES
description: The CSX Corporation said yesterday that it would split its Sea-Land Service Inc. business, the biggest United States ocean-shipping company, into three units in a move that might make it easier to sell. CSX, which also owns the third-largest railroad in the United States, will separate its Sea-Land unit into a terminal company that handles port business, a domestic shipping company and an international shipper. The three units will begin operating separately in mid-1999. The move could make it easier for CSX to sell its ocean-shipping business as it shifts to concentrate on its railroad. CSX, based in Richmond, has focused on absorbing its purchase of part of Conrail Inc., which it bought with the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $10.2 billion.

title: School for Violent Students Faces Objections in Queens
description: The Board of Education hopes to place 100 of the city's most violent students in a new school inside the former Swingline factory in Long Island City, Queens, but residents and local officials worry that such a school would hamper the neighborhood's budding resurgence.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about high school students' performance on the Regents examination in English referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of students who took the test in New York City in January. It was 53,000; 27,000 is the number of 11th graders who were tested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SYDNEY
description: LEWIS-Sydney. Dear Frances, the death of Sydney caused me deep pain. In this difficult life I thought of him as a second father. I will always remember him as I do remember Cesare Cassina was for me and for a long time more than a friend. Also as Venetian I would like to express here a Venetian's grief for the death of Sydney Lewis, its noble admirer. Gaetano Pesce

title: Reduced Pay Increase Reported at Toyota
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation has agreed with its union to raise salaries by an average of 7,600 yen ($64) a month starting in April, the financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported yesterday.

title: Arkansas Truck Tire Deal
description: The Arkansas Best Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay $9 a share, a total of $45.9 million, for the 51 percent of Treadco Inc. it did not already own. Arkansas Best, a trucking company, and Treadco, a retreader and seller of commercial truck tires, are both based in Fort Smith. In Nasdaq trading, the shares of Treadco closed at $8.875, up 18.75 cents, and Arkansas Best was unchanged at $7.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKIN, HERMANN
description: MERKIN-Hermann. The American Friends of Assaf Harofeh Medical Center mourn the passing of our true friend, great philanthropist and member of our Board of Directors, Hermann Merkin. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ulla, and his family. Kenneth Kronen, Chairman Bronka Weintraub, Vice Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, LILLIAN
description: SILVERBERG-Lillian. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, N.J. mourns the passing of our esteemed member and long time employee who served many years as Executive Secretary to our synagogue. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: A Bit of Rock History From Five Young Guys Doomed to Repeat It
description: Just as one of its songs says, 'N Sync is a group for the girls who have everything. Thousands of those young women, from teen-agers to tiny grade schoolers, flocked with parents in tow to Nassau Coliseum on Friday night to scream at the hard-working pop quintet.

title: On Campus; Should Harvard make sure its students go out and play? Students and deans are divided.
description: For the first time anyone here can remember, Harvard College is wondering whether it should find a way to get students out of their rooms and away from their books to -- gasp -- relax and socialize.

title: Nuclear Lapses Known in '96, Aides Now Say
description: In late 1996, months earlier than previously acknowledged, a senior Clinton Administration official ordered that security measures at the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories be quickly strengthened, but his orders were largely ignored or delayed, Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about security concerns at Los Alamos National Laboratory referred incorrectly to the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed in 1953 for espionage. They were convicted of having conspired with David Greenglass, an engineer at Los Alamos, not of having acted as couriers for two other workers at Los Alamos -- Klaus Fuchs and Ted Hall -- who spied for the Soviet Union.

title: Union Leader Is Expelled In Misuse of Money
description: District Council 37, the umbrella union representing 120,000 New York City municipal workers, announced yesterday that Francine Autovino, president of a local representing City University administrative assistants, had been expelled after being found to have misappropriated union money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, VIRGINIA J.
description: COHEN-Virginia J. Peacefully and stoically on March 15th, 1999 in her 95th year. She will be remembered lovingly. Her Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNICK, ABBY, DR.
description: ZELNICK-Abby, Dr. Our warmest thoughts and sympathy are with our dear friend, Marilyn, and her family. So many of our shared experiences were enriched by Abby's love of life, energy and enthusiasm. He played an irreplaceable role in our lives. Fran and Marty Harris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYAO, BIDU
description: SAYAO-Bidu, March 12, 1999. Sony Classical mourns the passing of this great artist. She will be missed by all who experienced her in the opera house or heard her in concert and on recordings.

title: When Irish Eyes Are Smiling Maliciously
description: ONE of the dangers with interviewing Sean Kelly is that you might find out what your name means, if it happens to be Irish. (From the Gaelic, Kelly translates as something like ''sacred prostitute.'' Kennedy means ''ugly head.'')

title: Study Finds Singular South Korean Rebound
description: South Korea is the only sizable Asian economy that appears to be pulling out of economic crisis, although its unemployment rate has risen and shows no immediate sign of declining, the International Labor Organization said in a study released here today.

title: Metal, Yes, but Not All Heavy; Music That Goes Aargh! in the Night
description: ''What's up, Jersaay!'' screamed Matthew Barlow, the long-haired singer for the heavy-metal band Iced Earth, at the dark throng before him under the vast ceiling of the Convention Hall here. It was the first night of the first annual March Metal Meltdown' and the crowd of mostly white working-class teen-agers, dressed almost to a one in black, collectively shuddered in response; the insulation in the hulking old building was not working very well.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: 'Careless Collisions' By Careful People

title: Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited
description: Novartis A.G., the world's No. 3 drug maker, indicated yesterday that its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent on improved profit margins and on cost savings resulting from the merger that formed the company. The implied second-half profit at the company, which makes the hypertension drug Diovan and the Alzheimer's drug Exelon, rose to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion a year earlier.

title: Big-Game Hunter's Gift Roils the Smithsonian
description: Officials at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington could hardly contain their delight 16 months ago when a wealthy California real estate developer, Kenneth E. Behring, pledged $20 million in cash to the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History.

title: Nine West Plans To Shut a Chain
description: Nine West Group Inc., the maker and seller of women's shoes, said it would take an $11.2 million fourth-quarter charge to close the 63-store 9 & Co. chain and try to relocate most of its 600 employees.

title: Graves Special Not Just for Goals
description: Thirty-three goals and a multimillion-dollar contract tell much about how this season is going for Adam Graves of the Rangers. But his total value can't be quantified by mere numbers on paper. You have to see him play as he did Monday night, when the Rangers tied the Washington Capitals, 1-1, at Madison Square Garden to move 1 point behind the Boston Bruins in the chase for the eighth and final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference of the National Hockey League.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an obituary about Commodore William E. Warwick, the former first master of the Queen Elizabeth 2, misidentified the ship he was standing on. It was the Queen Elizabeth, on which he also served, not the QE2.

title: MEDICARE PANEL, SHARPLY DIVIDED, SUBMITS NO PLAN
description: A Federal advisory commission searching for ways to preserve Medicare disbanded tonight in disagreement, just three hours after President Clinton denounced its proposed report and said he would devise a plan of his own as an alternative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERZOF, SYLVIA
description: GERZOF-Sylvia. Delaire Country Club announces with deep regret the passing of Sylvia Gerzof and extends their sincerest sympathy to her family. Robert Goldberg, President

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Business Travel; It's no accident that many of the faces in airport departure lounges are looking younger these days.
description: RUTH STANAT talks fast, but this probably comes naturally for someone who has visited more than 100 countries on business in the last couple of years.

title: The Big Cellar in the Desert
description: ''WOULD you care for some wine, sir?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, SHARON (NEE PESIN)
description: BLANK-Sharon (nee Pesin). Like a singular star, her brilliant radiance shone on all who knew her. We forever celebrate her love, her spirit and her friendship. She will never be forgotten. A friend

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, ALFRED F., ESQUIRE
description: WACHTEL-Alfred F., Esquire. Devoted son of the late Elsie (nee Bender) and Samuel. He is survived by his beloved and devoted children Eric David and Marjorie Wachtel, Esqs. and Nancy Lynne Wolff and by his adored grandchildren Molly Elizabeth and Andrew Georges Wolff and Harrison Samuel Wachtel. He was predeceased by his only brother Howard and his beloved son-in-law Charles Henry Wolff, M.D. He proudly served his country in World War II and was awarded a Purple Heart. For over forty years he engaged in the private practice of law.

title: THE CHEF; For an Ocean of Fish, Just One Sauce
description: IF I had to choose my one ''desert island'' sauce, the only sauce I would be allowed to take to a place where I'd have lots of fish of different varieties, this vinaigrette would be it. It's an ideal companion to fish firm or soft, big-flavored or mild. It is easy to make, but it required the usual balancing act to develop.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Former Times Building Is Named a Landmark
description: A craggy, Romanesque tower in lower Manhattan where all the news became fit to print was designated a New York City landmark yesterday.

title: A Longer Life Can Be a Deeper Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairness in Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: Diallo Case Tests Bronx Prosecutor; Inquiry Into Police Conduct Is Highlight of a 10-Year Tenure
description: For Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney, 1996 was a trying year. In March, a police officer, Kevin Gillespie, was shot and killed, and a former convict was arrested in his murder. Convinced that Mr. Johnson, who previously stated that he would not seek the death sentence, would not pursue it in this case, Gov. George E. Pataki removed him from it.

title: Taft to Hoover to Dole
description: If Elizabeth Dole formally enters the race for the Presidency, she will join a very small group: women who have run for the highest office in the land. If she wins the election, she will join a different but almost equally exclusive group: Presidents who had never before held any important elective office.

title: Between Upsets, Alford Squeezes In Fun
description: He was Indiana's Mr. Basketball in 1983, a gold medal Olympian in 1984 and an all-American on the Hoosier's national championship team in 1987.

title: Holocaust Inspires New Work
description: The New York Chamber Symphony returned to Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening in decent if not top form after its strike last month.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Both Healing and Rejoicing, But Without Specifics

title: INSIDE
description: Orders to Heighten Security At Nuclear Lab Were Ignored

title: Clerk Is Wounded in Shootout During Holdup
description: A clerk in a Brooklyn grocery was beaten and briefly held hostage Monday night, then wounded in a gunfight between the police and three men who robbed the store, the authorities said yesterday. One suspect died, and another was wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, MELVIN N., DDS.
description: BLAKE-Melvin N., DDS. The Board of Trustees and Medical Staff of Lennox Hill Hospital express sorrow at the passing of our colleague, Melvin N. Blake, DDS, Honorary Attending Physician. Dr. Blake, who joined the Department of Surgery in 1977, served as Chief of Dentistry and Oral Surgery from 1977 until 1989. A highly accomplished oral surgeon, he was renowned throughout his career for his knowledge of oral pathology and diseases and his outstanding diagnostic and surgical skills. He was a dedicated and gifted teacher to those many dentists and oral surgeons fortunate to have trained with him. The Lennox Hill Hospital family honors the memory of this kind and compassionate man who leaves a legacy of impressive achievements in his field. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Stephen A. Obstbaum, M.D., President, Medical Board Valavanur A. Subramanian, M.D., Director, Surgery

title: Stefan Schnabel, 87, Actor on Stage and TV
description: Stefan Schnabel, an actor known for his portrayal of Middle European characters onstage, in films and on television, died last Thursday at his home in Rogaro, Italy. He was 87.

title: Appeals Court Tells Museum To Hold Austrian Paintings
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that the Museum of Modern Art cannot return two Egon Schiele paintings to Austria until a criminal investigation into their ownership is concluded.

title: To Africa, Through Its Food
description: JESSICA B. HARRIS'S first trip to Africa, when she was 24, was a ''going home,'' to the West Africa of her roots. It was her introduction to a continent of vast geographic and ethnic diversity, which she has revisited many times since that first trip in 1972. Those trips, and the foods she sampled in her travels, are recounted in her new book, ''The Africa Cookbook: Tastes of a Continent'' (Simon & Schuster, $25).

title: Why We Shouldn't Write Off Russia
description: When the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, visits Washington next week, he and President Clinton will have to confront this incongruity: The International Monetary Fund needs to renew lending to Russia not so Russia can finally reform itself, but mainly so that it can repay the I.M.F. It's an absurd situation, but international finance is like that.

title: Mitteleuropa Loses a Voice As Soros Shuts His Magazine
description: The post-Communist world's sole magazine devoted to analyzing the region's own transformations is dead, a victim of the Russian financial crisis, bad management and the shifting priorities of its main supporter, the financier George Soros.

title: Metro Business; Office Building Sale
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation agreed to sell for $85 million four older New York office buildings it is buying from Tower Realty Trust, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Gold Plunges After Clinton Suggests Sales by the I.M.F.
description: The price of gold plunged yesterday after President Clinton suggested that the International Monetary Fund should sell some of its gold reserves to help reduce the debt burdens on the world's poorest nations.

title: LEAR TO BUY PARTS UNIT OF UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's largest maker of car seats and interiors, agreed yesterday to buy the United Technologies Corporation's auto-parts unit for $2.3 billion. United Technologies wants to concentrate on its more profitable Pratt & Whitney jet engines, Sikorsky helicopters, Carrier heating and air-conditioning products, Otis elevators and Hamilton Standard flight and space systems. United Technologies, based in Hartford, said it would gain $600 million from the sale and would use the money to buy back shares and help pay for the Sundstrand Corporation, which it agreed last month to buy. UT Automotive last year sold about $3 billion worth of dashboards, electrical distribution systems, motors and air-flow parts, interior door panels and switches. Lear is based in Southfield, Mich.

title: Three Ring Turns Plan B Into a Grade A Success
description: Nobody knows what the filly Three Ring might have done against colts Saturday if she hadn't been scratched from the Florida Derby because she drew an outside post position in the starting gate. But everybody knows what she did today when she started from a middle slot against four other fillies in the Bonnie Miss Stakes on Gulfstream Park's closing day.

title: C. Clyde Atkins, Federal Judge In Refugees' Case, Dies at 84
description: C. Clyde Atkins, a former chief judge of the Federal District Court in Miami, died last Thursday at Mercy Hospital in Miami. A resident of Miami, he was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDWIG, ALICE B.
description: LUDWIG-Alice B. Of Bronxville, N.Y., on March 16th, 1999. Wife of the late George S. Ludwig. Loving sister of Helen Weir and Frances Berner Diehl. Aunt of John F. Berner and Ellen Svenningsen. Service at The Reformed Church, Bronxville, on Friday, March 19th, at 11 A.M.

title: Top-Level Executive Shift Made As T.W.A. Continues to Struggle
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that William F. Compton, the carrier's president, will take over as chief executive in May, succeeding Gerald L. Gitner, who will remain as chairman.

title: Referee Says Lewis Clearly Was Winner
description: Arthur Mercante Jr., the referee in Saturday's controversial draw between Lennox Lewis and Evander Holyfield, said yesterday that he felt Lewis was the clear victor.

title: CALENDAR
description: Passover the Sephardic Way

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Farewell to the Chef

title: CENTRAL PARKING SELLING 74 LOTS TO ADVANCE A PURCHASE
description: The Central Parking Corporation, the nation's largest operator of parking lots, agreed to sell 74 lots in 18 cities to settle a Justice Department suit challenging its proposed $585 million purchase of Allright Holdings Inc. Central Parking, based in Nashville, agreed to the divestitures in a consent decree that settles the Justice Department's complaint, which had said the combination of the nation's two largest parking-lot companies would hurt competition. The properties to be sold include about 18,000 parking spaces out of more than a million in 2,400 facilities operated by Central Parking. The closely held Allright has 2,300 parking facilities with nearly 600,000 spaces.

title: The Night to Be Funny
description: Al Franken knows he has one last shot at making his comedy series ''Lateline'' a candidate for survival on NBC. As of last night, the show, a satire of both television news and politics, had six episodes left in which to find a following sufficient for NBC to bring it back for new episodes next fall.

title: Fewer Fall Behind on Mortgage Payments
description: The number of American borrowers who fell behind on their mortgage payments declined in the fourth quarter, according to a survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

title: No Encore: Cubs' Wood Is Out for Season
description: In what his manager saw as an inevitable development, Kerry Wood, the Chicago Cubs' electrifying young pitcher, has a damaged right elbow and will miss the 1999 season.

title: Nothing but Brutality For an Ill-Starred Butcher
description: ''I Stand Alone'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Film Forum, 209 Houston Street, South Village.

title: Mischief From Mr. Gramm
description: Cities that were in drastic decline 20 years ago are experiencing rebirth, thanks to new homeowners who are transforming neighborhoods of transients into places where families have a stake in what happens. The renaissance is due in part to the Federal Community Reinvestment Act, which requires banks to reinvest actively in depressed and minority areas that were historically written off. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas now wants to weaken the Reinvestment Act, encouraging a return to the bad old days, when banks took everyone's deposits but lent them only to the affluent. Sensible members of Congress need to keep the measure intact.

title: The Dow Briefly Breaks 10,000 Before Retreating
description: The Dow Jones industrial average continued flirting with the 10,000-point mark yesterday, and even crossed it for a short time. But it reversed its early climb and ended the session lower.

title: Rutgers Comes Up Just Short
description: CLEMSON 78, RUTGERS 68

title: New Sports and Retail Complex Is Proposed for the Meadowlands
description: Even as the Nets and Devils develop plans for new arenas elsewhere in the state, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority today proposed building a new $212 million home for the teams in the Meadowlands and replacing the existing arena with a giant entertainment complex.

title: People
description: * Mylene Pollock was named chief creative officer at Long Haymes Carr, Winston-Salem, N.C., part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., assuming duties from James P. White, vice chairman and chief creative officer, now chief creative officer at another Interpublic agency, Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis. Ms. Pollack had been senior partner and group creative director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: Lyons Steps Down From Presidency of Black Baptist Group
description: The Rev. Henry J. Lyons, the nationally prominent black minister from Florida who was convicted this month on charges of racketeering and grand theft, stepped down today as president of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A.

title: Notebook; Rallying for Literacy
description: Few skills are as important to an adult as reading and writing, yet a fifth of all Americans over 16 are barely literate; that is, they would have trouble writing a letter explaining an error in a credit-card bill.

title: Brazil Stocks Defy Recession's Damage
description: After spending much of 1999 so far straddling the line between pessimism and panic, Brazilian markets are staging a cautious rally that may be the first sign the economy, Latin America's largest, is starting to creep its way out of recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, DR. MORRIS
description: BLOCK-Dr. Morris. Manhattan Guild sorrowfully records the passing of Dr. Block, beloved brother of our esteemed member, Sidney Block. Our deepest sympathies to the family.

title: The Gleaming Gold of Bali
description: All seemed golden when the Dancers and Musicians of Bali performed on Friday night at Town Hall. Jennifer Stamps's lighting bathed the stage with a golden glow. Many costumes gleamed with gold. Even more importantly, the music and dancing gave the impression of springing from a sunny artistic tradition. This was a radiant occasion.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: New Age Takeout, Ever So Subtle

title: S.E.C. Considers Tightening Company Disclosure Rules
description: Concerned that some investors may be getting key stock information before the rest of the market, Federal securities regulators are considering tightening disclosure rules so that companies will be forced to announce news to all investors at the same time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DR. MARK JAY
description: FRIEDMAN - Dr. Mark Jay. Temple Beth Torah in Westbury, L.I., mourns the loss of an esteemed member of our congregation, Dr. Mark Jay Friedman, on March 13, 1999. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Ellen, children Robyn and Matt, parents Eleanor and Arthur, sister Lainie and brother Bruce. May God comfort all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Diane Wohl, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, A. ELLIOTT
description: BERNSTEIN-A. Elliott. Beloved husband of Naomi. Devoted father of Resa Scalone, Jennifer Murphy, Leslie, Dana Kuznetzkoff, Michael and Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather. P.D.D.G.M. Free & Accepted Masons. More than an avid New York Jet fan and a true friend. Services at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, NYC today at 11:30 A.M.

title: TCI's Cable Revenue Fell by 7% in 1998
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that cable television revenue at the recently acquired Tele-Communications Inc. fell 7 percent last year as it bought and sold cable systems to get better geographical clusters of customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAFT, EDWARD O.
description: CRAFT-Edward O. Age 82, former Legislative Counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives and resident of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Died March 10, 1999 in Bloomington, Indiana. For more information call Day Mortuary, 812-336-6331

title: Corrections
description: An article in the New Jersey section on Sunday about a concert of piano music by the early-20th-century composer Amy Cheney Beach at Caldwell College in Caldwell, N.J., misstated the timing. It is at 8 P.M. Friday, not tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTENSTEIN, NANCY SHIRLEY NEE GILMAN
description: OTTENSTEIN-Nancy Shirley nee Gilman. Of New Milford, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Nathan, devoted mother of Bernice Leibowitz & Arthur Ottenstein. Dear sister of Julius Gilman. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner of Passaic and Park St, Hackensack, New Jersey on Thursday at Noon.

title: Sterkfontein Journal; Solving a 3.5-Million-Year-Old, 3-D Jigsaw Puzzle
description: Deep in the dark, dank caverns here, Dr. Ronald J. Clarke, a man with a long list of academic credentials, is at work, sprawled against a rock face, lying on an old camping mattress, his tools scattered on a ledge: a few sharpened nail punches, some dental picks, Super Glue, a jam jar full of lacquer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a scandal in Spain's film industry misidentified the party in a dispute who apologized. A producer, Andres Vicente Gomez, called a director, Jose Luis Garci, a coward for not attending the Spanish film academy's annual awards ceremony in January, and Mr. Vicente Gomez apologized the next day. It was not Mr. Garci who apologized.

title: Service Merchandise Forced to Reorganize
description: The Service Merchandise Company, a troubled specialty retailer, said today that five vendors had forced it into court-supervised reorganization by filing an involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition.

title: Curbs on Managed Care Still Divide Two Parties
description: Of the issues likely to draw serious attention from Congress this year, managed health care would seem to be particularly ripe for action. Republicans and Democrats agree that Americans need guarantees of better treatment from health plans and that most voters would applaud steps in that direction.

title: Mendoza's Quiet Mien Is Somewhat Misleading
description: Ramiro Mendoza hung his head shyly today, avoided eye contact and smiled slightly when a reporter asked a question in English. He has always preferred using an interpreter in interviews, but Mariano Rivera, a fellow Panamanian and his best friend on the Yankees, was having none of it.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS PLANS TO BUY BRITISH OPERATIONS
description: The Morgan Crucible Company, a British engineering company, said yesterday that it would sell its maintenance, repair and overhaul businesses to Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $:174.3 million, or about $283.3 million. Morgan Crucible said it was selling the business to focus on its core ceramics and carbon operations. Illinois Tool, based in Glenview, Ill., makes industrial components and had 1997 revenues of $5.22 billion.

title: His Lawyer Says Diallo Lied on Request for Political Asylum
description: Amadou Diallo, the Guinean immigrant who was killed in a fusillade of police bullets last month, had applied for and received political asylum under false pretenses, one of his family's lawyers said last night.

title: A Rival Gains On 'Felicity'
description: ''Felicity,'' the WB drama about a young woman in her first year in college, began last fall with a heliumlike burst of publicity, a campaign that helped put its star, Keri Russell, on the covers of Seventeen magazine and Entertainment Weekly and had the theme song (sung by Madonna) playing in movie theaters everywhere.

title: Internet Goof-Offs
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Denies Gotti Request To Bar Tapes From Wiretap
description: In a victory for the prosecutors, a Federal judge ruled today that all of the wiretapping evidence gathered during years of eavesdropping on John A. Gotti and his associates was obtained legally and could be presented when Mr. Gotti goes to trial next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, BERNARD
description: MILLS-Bernard. Age 78, of Coconut Creek, FL., and formerly of Long Island, NY, passed away on March 16, 1999. Mr. Mills was a graduate of Queens College in New York and enjoyed a 22 year career as a court administrator before moving to Florida in 1991. Mr. Mills was the beloved husband of Hannah; loving father of Ileene (Joseph) Yashpeh, Susan (Elliot) Richmond and Nancy (Charles) Fishman; dear brother of Marvin (Laura) Mills and Marilyn (Alfred) Young; cherished grandfather of Alexa, Logan, Kimberly, Matthew and Jillian. Funeral Services will be held on Friday, March 19, 1999 at 9:45 am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY, 718-896-9000.

title: Bids Still to Be Decided
description: Conference tournaments concluding this weekend will not decide very much as to the makeup of the 12-team field that is to compete for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's championship beginning March 25. Automatic bids and a selection system based on a rigid rating formula have largely defined the qualifiers, said Joe Marsh, chairman of the hockey committee and also the St. Lawrence head coach.

title: The Tortilla As Omelet
description: THE Spanish tortilla has nothing in common with the Mexican tortilla except its shape and its name. One is just a bread. The other can be an appetizer, a snack, or even a light meal.

title: Nets' Coaching Change Brings More of Same
description: The smiles worn by John Calipari's enemies in the Nets' organization turned to grimaces and frowns tonight. In a display that was as shocking as their 3-18 record, the Nets were run out of Air Canada Center by the Toronto Raptors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHILCOTT, RUTH HACKNEY
description: CHILCOTT-Ruth Hackney. Of New Vernon, New Jersey, at her residence on Monday, March 15, 1999. Wife of the late James Clemens Chilcott. Stepmother of Barbara C. Esten, Joan C. McKenna and Diane C. Carson; and aunt of Mary Goodrich Johnson and Lorraine G. Simonton. A memorial service will be held in the First Presbyterian Church, New Vernon, New Jersey on Thursday, March 18, 1999 at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Morristown Memorial Hospital, Morristown, NJ; First Presbyterian Church, New Vernon, NJ; The Dartmouth Medical School, Hanover, NH or The Seeing Eye, Morristown, NJ.

title: N. KOREA CONSENTS TO U.S. INSPECTION OF A SUSPECT SITE
description: After months of negotiations, North Korea agreed today to allow the United States to inspect a huge underground site that Washington suspects is the beginning of a renewed North Korean effort to build atomic weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAFFER, MENDELSON, RHODA
description: FAFFER - MENDELSON - Rhoda. Age 87, on March 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Faffer of Perth Amboy, N.J., and the late Cantor Nathan Mendelson of Montreal, Canada. Devoted mother of Lillian Faffer of New York City and Bertha James of Baltimore, MD, mother-in-law of Solis James. Cherished sister of Meyer Chazin of Jamesburg, N.J., and Rabbi Pinchos Chazin of Philadelphia, PA., the late Mae Mendelson, Theodore Chazin and Abraham Chazin. Loving grandmother of Barry James and Stephanie and Richard Bolnick, great-grandmother of Jared, Aaron and Seth Bolnick. Daughter of the late Dora and Cantor Hirsch L. Chazin. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Active in many Jewish organizations. Funeral services 2PM Wednesday, March 17th at Flynn and Son, 424 East Avenue, Perth Amboy, New Jersey. The family would appreciate donations to the Hazzan Nathan Mendelson Music Foundation, C/O Congregation Shaare Hashomayim, 450 Kensington Avenue, Westmount, Quebec, Canada H3Y 3AZ.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILLIAMS, CRAIG MILLER
description: WILLIAMS-Craig Miller. Born in Mobile, AL, died in New York City on March 17, 1998. His laughter which rang like wind chimes and his smile as bright as the Noonday sun will live forever in our hearts. He is missed by wife Jacqueline, sister Martha, son Craig, Jr., mom Roberta, brother Mack, aunt Mary, co-workers of The New York Times, many relatives and friends in New York and Alabama

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, BENJAMIN
description: DUBIN-Benjamin. On March 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of James and Harriet. Grandfather of Jacob, David, Alexander and Elizabeth. Brother of Florence Rubin and the late Ann Leventhal. Services today 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: From Kings County, First Black Grandmaster
description: Twenty years ago, when Maurice Ashley was 14 and living in Brownsville, Brooklyn, he was soundly defeated in an offhand game of chess. Embarrassed and angry, he dug up a paperback on the game, intending to brush up, to learn a trick or two. Instead, he fell deeply in love.

title: Research Efforts Win Recognition
description: The Steel Alliance in Washington, a trade organization that promotes the use of steel, took top honors last night at the Advertising Research Foundation's fifth annual David Ogilvy Award ceremony for excellence in research. Sharing the award, for research that best supported a successful campaign, were GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of Omnicom Group, and the Orem, Utah, office of Wirthlin Worldwide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Crosses 10,000 Mark But Retreats for the Day

title: Pursuing an Aim to Startle
description: Great performances like the one the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center gave of Messiaen's ''Des Canyons aux Etoiles . . .'' at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday can make a work immediate, can put it right inside you. But they can also render it strange. The two things are allied: being placed in sudden close contact with a piece, one is made particularly aware of its peculiarities. And in the case of this Messiaen work, there are a lot of them.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Bossa Nova, Oiled and Spiced
description: Following the Algonquin Hotel's cabaret mini-festival of international voices, Garrick Gaieties, a tiny midtown club, has gone non-English-speaking with a two-week engagement of Kleber Jorge, a singer, songwriter and guitarist from Rio de Janeiro.

title: Endangered: The Beloved American Layer Cake
description: THE layer cake, an American icon, is in dire straits.
