title: Can't Wait Till Summer to Barbecue? Read On
description: THERE are many charms to late winter, but right about now, they are definitely fading. For one thing, it seems like years, rather than months, since we enjoyed the foods of summer. And for us, that means barbecue.

title: Insomnia in Aged Found Treatable
description: If ''the sleep of a labouring man is sweet,'' as the Old Testament insists, the slumber of a retired man, or woman, should be even sweeter. But for 25 percent to 35 percent of older Americans, sleep is not something that comes all that easily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, SHIRLEY
description: SCHARF-Shirley. On March 15, 1999. Beloved wife of Irwin, devoted mother of Royce and Jay Marks, dear sister of Anita Coopersmith and Rhoda Hellman, cherished grandmother of Elyse Merman. Services Wednesday, 10:30 AM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Ctr, L.I.

title: McDougal Trial Sees Mrs. Clinton's Videotape
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, appearing on videotape today in the trial of a woman who once was her business partner in the Whitewater real estate deal, testified that she had little knowledge of the development company's financial transactions.

title: An Agency Clears the Way For 3-Bank Deal in France
description: French regulators approved today the $38 billion unsolicited offer made by Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. for Societe Generale S.A. and Paribas S.A., opening the way for the creation of the world's biggest bank.

title: Between the Tastes of Greece and the Middle East
description: TURKEY has never been on the main tourist route that has been well trampled by Americans herding through Provence, Italy or the Greek isles. As a result, Turkish cooking has never really achieved the vogue of other Mediterranean cuisines.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Some Potent Revelations On Icarus and Victoriana

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: How Jews Turn Houses Into Homes on West Bank
description: From this entrenched Jewish settlement on a bluff above the Palestinian territories, the vista is dotted for miles around with what the Israelis call ''facts on the ground.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREYHOUND LINES INC., Dallas, the bus operator, said its shareholders had approved a $650 million takeover by Laidlaw, Burlington, Ontario, which is North America's largest school bus and ambulance operator.

title: Russia to Offer U.S. Deal To End Iran Nuclear Aid
description: Russia has offered to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran if Washington ends sanctions against two leading Russian nuclear research centers, Russia's Atomic Energy Minister says.

title: New N.C.A.A. Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Democrats Urge 4.6% Budget Increase
description: The Democrats who control the Assembly called today for a 4.6 percent rise in state spending, more than double the increase Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed, setting the boundaries for another fierce budget fight.

title: Bayer Hints It's Willing To Make Acquisitions
description: Bayer A.G., the second-largest drug and chemical company in Germany, indicated yesterday that it might make big acquisitions this year to expand its drug and agribusiness units as falling chemical prices hurt earnings. Saying it had a disappointing start to 1999, Bayer said it was ready to increase significantly the 12 billion marks ($6.7 billion) it invested last year, if it found the right acquisition opportunities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEARY, DONALD D.
description: GEARY-Donald D. Attorney and Copper Executive, died March 16th, at his home in Larchmont following a year long battle with lung cancer. He was 74. A graduate of Deerfield Academy, Yale University and Yale Law School, Mr. Geary spent the first seven years of his career as a practicing attorney with the NYC law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside, Wolff, and Brophy. In 1958 he joined the Anaconda Company and became the General Counsel and Senior Vice President; in 1971 he was appointed to Anaconda's Board of Directors. After Anaconda merged with ARCO, he joined the Kennecott Corporation as Corporate Secretary and Senior Vice President. He finished his career with ten years as President of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, retiring in 1991. Mr. Geary was born May 13, 1924 in NYC to Pauline Stevens and Donald D. Geary. A veteran, he served with the Military Intelligence in Europe from 1943 to 1946. Mr. Geary had been a Commissioner of the town of Mamaroneck Police Dept., a member of the town zoning board, Commodore of the Larchmont Yacht Club, a vestryman at St. John's Episcopal Church and President of the Larchmont University Club as well as a Director and Secretary of the University Glee Club of the City of New York. His wife Ann Tuttle Geary of Larchmont, three daughters and four grandchildren survive him. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Larchmont on Friday, March 19 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to St. John's Church, Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY 10538 or the Waterford School Fine Arts Campaign, 1480 East 9400 South, Sandy, Utah 84093.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, MAUD (CABOT)
description: MORGAN-Maud (Cabot). In Cambridge, MA, March 14, 1999. Mother of Victoria M. Benedict and Alexis Morgan both of Cambridge. Also survived by two nieces, her nephew and several grand nieces and grand nephews. Memorial services in the First Parish in Cambridge, 3 Church St., Harvard Square, Cambridge, MA Thursday, March 18 at 3P.M. In lieu of flowers gifts in her memory may be sent to the Maud Morgan Prize Museum of Fine Arts, 465 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. On March 15, 1999 at the age of 94. A distinguished attorney in practice for more than 70 years, he is survived by many devoted friends. Service and interment private. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Transracial Adoptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODGOLD, MURRAY
description: GOODGOLD-Murray. Beloved-adored. Sally, Iris, Jay

title: Forbes Declares Candidacy On Internet and the Stump
description: Renouncing the traditional brass bands and patriotic bunting, Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher, today became the first Presidential contender to formally announce his candidacy on the Internet.

title: China's Spying Poses Special Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Surprise, Factory Output Had a Slight Gain in February
description: Industrial production unexpectedly rose in February, led by a fifth consecutive monthly gain in factory output, and construction of new homes stayed near a 12-year high, the latest signs the economy is surging as it heads into its ninth year of expansion.

title: China's Spying Poses Special Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Boxing's Beautiful Black Eye
description: THE fuel of boxing is controversy -- after all, what are matches, not to speak of rematches, made of, anyway? It goes back to at least Pindar, who composed soaring odes to the boxing brawls in the ancient Greek Olympiad, some of which were surely, as the saying goes, manipulated. The peculiar fascination continued through the centuries, to Saturday night, when, by the estimation of a thick majority of spectators, Lennox Lewis clearly won the unified heavyweight championship of this planet, but the three judges awarded him a measly draw with Evander Holyfield. Ah, but such is the essential charm of boxing -- the sleaziness of it all. And thus the fuel for controversy. There is simply no fuel like an old fuel.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about threats to Pacific salmon misstated the planned classification of the fish. Federal officials proposed to declare that eight of nine wild salmon types in the Pacific Northwest would be listed as threatened species. Only one type, not all, would be listed as endangered. The Endangered Species Act allows officials more time to develop protections for species listed as threatened than it does for those with the more serious classification of endangered.

title: Death Penalty For Killing Of Mistress
description: Addressing the defendant as an ''angry, sinister, controlling and malignant force,'' a state judge today ordered that Thomas J. Capano, a once-prominent and wealthy Delaware lawyer, be executed for the murder of a former mistress three years ago.

title: I.O.C. Expulsion Vote Is Key for Samaranch
description: A vote to ratify the expulsion of six delegates of the International Olympic Committee on Wednesday will essentially be a referendum on Juan Antonio Samaranch.

title: Saks Reports Earnings Gain
description: Saks Inc., the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and other department stores, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 26 percent and warned that this year's profit might be less than expected as it integrates acquired chains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, JOAN. (NEE AISENSTAT)
description: KINGSLEY-Joan. (nee Aisenstat) Suddenly on March 15, 1999. Devoted mother of David. Loving sister of Marjorie Lieberman. Dedicated employee for the Israeli Consulate for many years. Service Wednesday 1:00 PM at Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Ave., B'klyn. ''She loved to laugh.''

title: 13 Are Killed as Amtrak Train Collides With Truck in Illinois
description: They were just settling in for the night, comfortably ensconced in the first-class double-decker sleeper car of a train with a famous name, The City of New Orleans. They had boarded in Chicago, just two hours before, and their train, its legend celebrated in a popular American folk song, was due to pull into New Orleans in the late afternoon of the next day.

title: Apple Adopts 'Open Source' Code Strategy
description: The ''open source'' software movement won a vote of confidence today from yet another major computer maker as Apple Computer released an open source operating system for the server computers that connect desktop and laptop machines across a business or to the Internet.

title: British Food Company Rejects Bid From Dairy
description: Terranova Foods P.L.C., a maker of chilled food that was spun off from Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C. in October, rejected an offer of $:228.5 million ($370.2 million) yesterday from Unigate P.L.C., Britain's second-largest milk producer. Terranova said the offer was inadequate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIBACH, AARON
description: MEIBACH-Aaron. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the death of Aaron Meibach, for more than 23 years, a dedicated, compassionate volunteer who gave generously of his time and energies in support of the residents and the work of The Hebrew Home. As recent tenants of River House West, Aaron and his late, dear wife Freda widened even further their circle of friendships here. Our deepest sympathies go to Aaron's beloved daughters Ina Meibach, Judy Meibach and Doris Wallace. He will be missed, and his memory cherished by all. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Giuliani Says Diallo Shooting Coverage Skewed Poll
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani blamed partisan politics and an ''obsessive media concern'' yesterday for the results of a New York Times poll released this week that showed a sharp drop in his job-approval rating and a widespread belief among the city's black and Hispanic residents that the police routinely use excessive force against them.

title: China's Spying Poses Special Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Is an Island in Midtown
description: AS we are leaving, the hostess hands us the chef's business card. Then, very ceremoniously, she bows. We bow back. She bows again. And so we exit slowly, bowing ourselves out the door.

title: Serbs Reinforce Kosovo Forces, Clouding Talks
description: The Kosovo peace effort was on the verge of collapse today as Serbia moved heavy tanks and thousands more troops into the province at the same time that Serbian negotiators here insisted on extensive changes to a draft peace agreement.

title: Trucker Fined for Taking A Ride on the Boardwalk
description: A month after she drove a tractor-trailer onto the Boardwalk, leaving nearly a mile of splintered planks in her wake, a trucker from Tennessee was fined $1,150 after pleading guilty yesterday in Atlantic City Municipal Court, her lawyer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, DANIELLE
description: RUBINSTEIN-Danielle. Daughter of the late Isaac and Tauba, of Melbourne, Australia. Sister of Maya Solow. Service Thursday, 2 PM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Layer Cake, as Translated by the French
description: SOME desserts are so perfectly balanced that they are simultaneously light and intense, crunchy and velvety, bitter, sweet and salty. One slice, no matter what size, is never enough. Just such a dessert -- worlds away from a layer cake -- has made its triumphant return to Madison Avenue at 89th Street, at Cafe Guy Pascal.

title: City Law to Require Apartment Sprinklers
description: The City Council unanimously approved legislation yesterday that will require sprinkler systems in new residential buildings with four or more units. The measure, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign into law, would require sprinklers in every unit and every common hallway in new buildings, and would mandate installation of sprinklers in existing residential properties that undergo renovations costing 50 percent or more of the building's value.

title: No Whistle, But Sirens And Flames
description: The passenger train had just swept across the snowy farm fields, passing a tall white grain elevator, and was headed, a bit late, for its stop in Kankakee, an old railroad town where the whistle echoes like a lullaby every night.

title: Why Buy Paperbacks?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The single currency was higher on hope that the resignation of the entire European Commission might bring changes that could help spur growth. The euro settled in New York at $1.0985, up from $1.0935 Monday.

title: Metro Business; Unemployment Milestone
description: New Jersey's preliminary unemployment rate for February was 4.1 percent, its lowest level in a decade and the first time it has dipped below the national rate since 1991, the State Labor Department announced yesterday.

title: Reno to Urge Senate to Abandon Statute on Independent Counsels
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has decided to announce at a Senate hearing on Wednesday that the independent counsel statute is ''structurally flawed'' and should be abandoned, a striking reversal from her past embrace of the 21-year-old Watergate-era reform law, Government officials said today.

title: An Expensive Fish
description: In a sense, what is most remarkable about the Federal Government's announcement today that it would list nine types of salmon under the Endangered Species Act, a move that will force new building restrictions and raise taxes across the Seattle area and elsewhere in the Northwest, is how little controversy it has stirred -- so far, anyway.

title: Bill Is Passed Requiring Sprinklers in Most New Residences
description: The City Council approved legislation yesterday requiring sprinkler systems in most new residential buildings in the city, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was expected to sign the measure into law.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Using Masa Harina

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 1999 Is Already the Year of the Flip-Flop Forecast
description: The unexpectedly strong performance of the economy so far this year has pushed the earnings forecasts of many strategists higher. For example, Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, turned his earnings growth prediction on its head, flipping to an increase of 3.5 percent from a decline of 5 percent.

title: Clinton Abandons His Threat to Veto Missile Defense Bill
description: The White House and Senate Democrats today abandoned their longstanding opposition to a politically popular bill that calls for a national defense against limited long-range missile attacks.

title: Britain and F.B.I. To Look Into Slaying Of Lawyer in Ulster
description: The Northern Ireland police chief said today that an independent police official from the British mainland and agents from the F.B.I. would investigate whether there was police collusion in the killing on Monday of a prominent Roman Catholic human rights lawyer.

title: Court Won't Permit Delay In Racial Profiling Case
description: A New Jersey appeals court refused tonight to give the Whitman administration more time to appeal a judge's ruling in 1996 that the State Police tolerated a ''de facto policy of racial profiling'' on the southern half of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Brokaw in Moscow
description: A lot has changed in Moscow since Tom Brokaw scored one of the biggest coups of his career in 1987 with his exclusive interview with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then the President of the Soviet Union.

title: An Orchestra Out on a Limb, Touting the 20th Century
description: The directors of the Philadelphia Orchestra were not pleased to read the headline over a recent article in The Philadelphia Inquirer about plans for the orchestra's 1999-2000 centennial season.

title: O.K., You Love the House. Now Meet the Neighbors.
description: A little, smart, friendly subversion by Beatriz Cordoba, the director, and the cast of Repertorio Espanol's production of Dolores Prida's ''Casa Propia'' (''A House of Her Own'') makes the performance a more high-spirited comedy than the script might suggest. The company does not mute Ms. Prida's occasional excursions into gloomy comments on the abuse some women suffer from male partners, but the actors focus with so much gleeful invention on developing a handful of memorably funny characters that they preserve the comedy from the intrusions of the playwright's social conscience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHER, HELYNE
description: WASHER-Helyne. The New York Board of Rabbis mourns the passing of the beloved wife of its distinguished Past President, Rabbi Judah Washer. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, President Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal, Executive Vice President

title: Irish Leader Who Grew Into Eloquence
description: When he was campaigning for election as Prime Minister in 1997, Bertie Ahern was disdained by many voters and politicians as a lightweight who had risen from the working class of Dublin and still spoke with a distinct North Side accent, which turned ''th'' sounds into D's.

description: BRECKIR-Albert. Happy 99th, Bill Bailey. Your Family

description: In one of the biggest gambles that a European car company has ever taken, Renault S.A. of France today offered to buy 35 percent of Nissan Motor Company, Japan's huge but deeply troubled producer of cars and trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, MELVIN N.
description: BLAKE-Melvin N. The Department of Dentistry of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center deeply mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Melvin N. Blake, DDS. Dr. Blake was a member of our staff for 43 years, beginning with his Chief Resident position in 1956 and culminating as Associate Clinical Professor in the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. His career was marked by many professional accomplishments. Beside maintaining an active private oral and maxillofacial surgical practice, he was a superb teacher and the Chief of Oral Surgery for five years. He then became Director of the Department of Dentistry at Lenox Hill Hospital unitl his retirement. In addition, he was a renowned oral pathologist and Clinical Professor of Pathology and Director of Oral Pathology at Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Dr. Blake was a respected mentor and teacher to the many students fortunate enough to have trained with him and well loved by countless patients. He was a most compassionate practitioner. Our sincere condolences to his family. Jack Klatell, DDS, Professor and Chairman

title: Politics and Pop Mix in Film Piracy Protest in Hong Kong
description: The stars were on glittering display in Hong Kong today, though not on the silver screen.

title: Of Secrets, Service and Both at the Waldorf
description: BY becoming a murder victim last weekend, a guest at the Waldorf-Astoria created the ultimate crisis for his hosts. And if you think Chief Concierge Michael L. Romei is going to talk about it, it has been a while since you stayed in a nice hotel.

title: It Tastes Like Dinner, but It Sure Looks Like a Circus
description: The tent in the vacant lot on the outskirts of downtown is conspicuous but not particularly distinguished. It's just a big white tent. Anything might be inside it; a farmer's market, maybe, or a petting zoo or a traveling antique show. But what goes on there four nights a week, a vaudevillian dinner cabaret known as Teatro ZinZanni that has become this city's hottest ticket, isn't even the biggest surprise.

title: Holbrooke on Hold
description: We might be more effective in stopping the fighting in Kosovo if we had a credibly tough diplomat like Richard Holbrooke on the job.

description: Having floated some 20,000 miles over Europe, Africa, Asia, the Pacific Ocean and Central America, the Breitling Orbiter 3 headed into the home stretch over the Atlantic Ocean yesterday in its bid to become the first balloon to circle the world nonstop.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICA ONLINE INC., -- Dulles, Va., the largest provider of on-line services, completed its acquisition of the Internet software maker Netscape Communications Corp., Mountain View, Calif., for $9.8 billion.

title: DOMINGUEZ SERVICES RECEIVES UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER BID
description: The Dominguez Services Corporation received an unsolicited takeover offer yesterday from the American States Water Company, which it considers superior to an earlier bid from California Water Service Group. In November, Dominguez, a water utility holding company in Long Beach, Calif., agreed to be acquired for 1.778 million California Water shares, then valued at $47.6 million. The price of California Water's stock has since fallen, reducing the value of the deal to $43.3 million. The American States offer, valued at $49.2 million, calls for Dominguez stockholders to swap each share for American States shares worth $32.50. Both buyers would assume $10.5 million in Dominguez debt. Shares of Dominguez rose $1.50, nearly 6 percent, to $28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, ABRAHAM
description: PRESS-Abraham. Of Irvington, NY. October 15, 1909-March 16, 1999. Deeply missed husband of Helane; brother of Solomon, Anita, & Bessie; father of Nancy Miriam, David, and Janet; grandfather of Joshua, Gina, Noah, Esau, Elizabeth, Joanna, and Gregory, and great-grandfather of Callie. Service at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York, at noon, on Saturday, March 20, 1999.

title: Ketchum's challenge is how to remake the Zippo as something other than a cigarette lighter.
description: THE assignment was not exactly straightforward: create an advertising campaign that recasts the famous Zippo lighter as something -- anything -- other than a cigarette lighter. And, most importantly, aim the campaign at young people, but not too young.

description: Moving to gain a foothold in the United States, Global Crossing Ltd. of Bermuda, a new international communications carrier, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Frontier Corporation for $10.8 billion in stock.

description: Exploit, compared favorably by the trainer Bob Baffert to the last two Kentucky Derby winners and unbeaten until finishing second in Saturday's San Felipe Stakes at Santa Anita, was retired to stud after suffering a knee fracture in the race, Baffert said yesterday in Arcadia, Calif.

title: Ericsson Stake in Juniper
description: As part of a push into the United States market for computer-networking equipment, Ericsson A.B. of Sweden, the world's No. 3 maker of mobile phones, has raised its stake in the closely held Juniper Networks Inc. and taken a seat on Juniper's board. The stake, of an undisclosed size, makes Ericsson the largest corporate investor in Juniper, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Juniper makes a switch that routes data over computer networks at high speeds.

title: Israeli Politician Convicted of Corruption
description: A powerful, charismatic Israeli politician was convicted today on corruption charges in a verdict that outraged the ultra-Orthodox Sephardic Jews who consider him the champion of their underclass community.

title: Wood Must Cope With Lost Season
description: At the age of 21, Kerry Wood has a torn ligament in his pitching elbow. He learned the potential dangers of pitching at an even younger age. ''I've thought about this,'' the Chicago Cubs' right-hander said yesterday in Mesa, Ariz., ''from the first time I saw the video of the guy -- I don't remember his name now -- who threw one pitch and his arm broke. The first time I saw that video, it was in my mind that any pitch, any given day it could happen.''

title: Who Leads, and by How Much, Varies From Survey to Survey
description: Although the election is 20 months away, and neither candidate has formally declared an intention to run for United States Senate, several polling organizations have asked voters in New York State about their preference if Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani were paired in the contest. Their results have varied.

title: Survey Suggests A Fierce Battle For U.S. Senate
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani test the waters for Senate campaigns next year, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows that New York State voters hold strongly partisan opinions, but also nagging reservations, about both politicians, indicating that a contest between them would be highly competitive.

description: Everything but the cloudless sky was green yesterday, as record numbers packed St. Patrick's Cathedral, marched up Fifth Avenue in the 238th annual St. Patrick's Day parade and lined the 2 1/2-mile route to hoot and holler in support.

description: In what will inevitably be seen as competing memorials, the families and allies of Yitzhak Rabin and Menachem Begin are raising millions of dollars to build museum-scale centers to honor the late Prime Ministers.

title: LILLY SHARES DROP ON CONCERN ABOUT PROZAC
description: The shares of Eli Lilly & Company fell 5.65 percent yesterday after an analyst for the securities firm SG Cowen & Company lowered his estimate for sales this year of Prozac, the drug maker's top seller. Prozac, which made up about 30 percent of Lilly's 1998 sales, is the world's biggest antidepression drug, with $2.8 billion in sales last year. Prozac now faces more competition from Celexa, a drug sold by Forest Laboratories Inc. and the Warner-Lambert Company. That puts more pressure on Lilly to market new drugs. Lilly's shares fell $5.3125, to $88.75. Stephen Scala, a SG Cowen analyst, said Prozac sales could be $2.93 billion in 1999, below its estimate of $3.05 billion.

title: House Panel Passes Blueprint For Tax Cuts and Spending
description: The House Budget Committee passed a Republican tax and spending blueprint tonight, sweeping aside objections from Democrats who said the plan promised too much in tax cuts and did too little to deal with the looming problems in Social Security and Medicare.

description: FEINBLATT-Allen S., age 68. Died on March 16th, 1999, after a long illness. A lifelong resident of New York City, he was a graduate of New York University and worked as a stockbroker. Allen was a scholar with a deep appreciation of history, music and art. He is survived by several cousins and close friends. Service Thursday, 10:30AM, at ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: The nine artists who have lived at 12, 14 and 16 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village for almost 30 years always thought of themselves as pushing the envelope.

title: Fed Sees Continuing Strong Growth With Low Inflation
description: The economy's run of strong growth and low inflation shows few signs of changing, the Federal Reserve's latest regional survey showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTNER, HAROLD
description: GARTNER-Harold. We mourn the passing of our beloved and longtime friend. Shers, Blazers & Rappaports

description: Private Treasures

title: Rare Expose in China Warns Of Unrest Over Dam Project
description: In an unusual critique of Government policy, a mainstream journal here has published a searing expose of social problems caused by construction of the giant Three Gorges Dam.

title: Pretty Petals All in a Row
description: No watering can is needed to keep the blooms on the simple silk daisies (above), sunflowers and roses made by Optimer International of Bellevue, Wash. Perched atop slender copper rods on steel plates, they wave slightly in a breeze. At $7.95 to $11 each, they are available in Santa Monica and Los Angeles at the MOCA Stores, (310) 396-9833, and in Manhattan at Medici, 24 West 23d Street, (212) 604-0888. Information on other stores: (425) 455-4388.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SYDNEY
description: LEWIS-Sydney. Dear Frances, the death of Sydney caused me deep pain. In this difficult life I thought of him as a second father. I will always remember him as I do remember Cesare Cassina who was for me and for a long time more than a friend. Also as Venetian I would like to express here a Venetian's grief for the death of Sydney Lewis, its noble admirer. Gaetano Pesce

title: Children With Lives Predetermined by War
description: Mayra Nguyen Donohoe/In Mixed Company

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Attorney General Janet Reno's changed view of the independent counsel law misspelled the surname of the Interior Secretary in some copies. He is Bruce Babbitt, not Babbit. The article also misstated the background of Labor Secretary Alexis Herman. She was formerly head of the White House Public Liaison Office, not Energy Secretary.

title: Indonesia to Reduce Oil Production 4%
description: Indonesia, the only Asian member of OPEC, is ready to cut crude oil production by 4 percent, or 34,000 barrels a day, in line with an agreement among OPEC members, a Government official said. OPEC members and other oil exporters said last week that they planned to reduce oil output by 2 million barrels a day to reverse a slump in world crude oil prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, RAE GOLDIN
description: RAFF-Rae Goldin. Sweet, unassuming lady who graciously gave of herself. We extend our sympathy to her family and especially to our treasured Judi Cohen. May her mother's memory be for a blessing. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNICK, DR. ABBY
description: ZELNICK-Dr. Abby. He traveled with us, played with us, laughed and cried with us. He will be with us always. Fran and Al Newman

title: The Pop Life; D.J.'s and Cults Make Heads Spin
description: ''When are we supposed to sleep?'' That was one of the most perplexing and frequently asked questions here as the annual Winter Music Conference brought 4,000 D.J.'s, producers, record executives, party promoters and miscellaneous revelers to Miami Beach. The occasion was five days, from Saturday until yesterday, of networking with and dancing to the sounds of some of the most esteemed electronic dance-music D.J.'s and musicians from the United States and Europe, including Fatboy Slim, Roni Size, Danny Tenaglia, Juan Atkins, Armand Van Helden, Derrick Carter, Carl Cox and Kruder and Dorfmeister.

title: Eritrea Says It Killed Hundreds In Routing Ethiopians on Border
description: Eritrea said today that it had repulsed Ethiopian troops after a three-day battle along their disputed border, in fighting that cost the lives of at least several hundred soldiers and perhaps many more.

title: The Sculptor In Frank Gehry
description: The architect Frank Gehry had always resisted doing anything for a gallery. But now, with ''A Study'' -- his sculpture made of wood clad in lead -- Mr. Gehry moves into the realm of pure art. The work (model above) is a variation on one of his architectural projects, being built in Berlin. Big enough to walk in, it almost fills the minimalist pace at the Gagosian Gallery (by Richard Meier), in Beverly Hills, where it opens today and will be on view through May 1; (310) 271-9400.

title: Signing On With Your Fingerprints
description: WHILE people continue to repeat the New Yorker cartoon tag line that no one knows you're a dog on the Internet, the computer industry is working diligently to sort out the sheep from the goats. Anonymity may offer a bit of excitement to chat rooms and keep us safe from stalkers we meet on line, but careful industries like banks and investment houses continue to look for better technology for identifying people. Some of the latest solutions on the horizon are devices for reading people's fingerprints.

title: Florida's Tobacco Suit
description: To the Editor:

title: Student's Mother Fined In Assault on Official
description: An Elizabeth school vice principal who threatened to kill an unruly student has been acquitted of assault and harassment charges, and the student's mother, who later struck the vice principal, has been convicted of assault, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, ROSE
description: MARKMAN-Rose. There is never a good time for a life to end. Even though expected, the shock can be to hard to bear. Although Rose Markman was long in years, her mind was functioning as a young adult up until the last second of her life. To say we should celebrate her life and thank God for having her many, many years, does not diminish the ache her family now feels. She cherished each new life and did a poor job of trying to hide her intense love. Her sharp mind and quick response was astonishing. After the sixth great grandchild, we thought we were going to be lucky-we were going to have Nanny forever! Yesterday our luck ran out. What we'll always remember is her fiery and competitive spirit. Being good just isn't good enough. Love, The Markman Family

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about allergic reactions to latex gloves among medical workers described gloves manufactured by Regent Medical incorrectly. None of the company's gloves are sprinkled with a powder to make them easier to put on (the powder can cause an allergic reaction). The five percent figure used in the article referred to the percentage of the company's gloves that are non-latex, not the percentage that are powder-free.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Fell 35.4% in February
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell 35.4 percent in February from January as exports declined while imports rose.

title: Ad Logo on Editorial Insert Kills Award for a Magazine
description: For the first time in its 33-year history, the American Society of Magazine Editors has stripped a magazine of nominations for the society's National Magazine awards for not complying with guidelines regarding the separation of advertising and editorial content.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLO, MARY (NEE DERRICO)
description: GALLO-Mary (nee Derrico). March 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Cherished mother of Jean Arena and Josephine Pisterzi. Loving grandmother of Al, Katharine, Gianfranco, Christine, Joseph and Anne Marie. Great grandmother of Nicholas, Nicole and Gabrielle. She was a dedicated teacher in the Archdioceses of New York. Graduated from NYU in 1927. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, March 19th, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 20th, 10AM, Saint John the Evangelist Church, 1st Ave and 55 St.

title: Kosovo Brinkmanship
description: By balking at a reasonable peace plan and sending more combat forces into Kosovo, Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader, is pushing the United States and its NATO allies to the brink of military conflict in the Balkans. Unless Mr. Milosevic retreats at the last minute, which he has done before, American missiles and NATO warplanes could be attacking Serbian targets within a matter of days.

title: Siemens to Spin Off Semiconductor Division
description: The German manufacturing company Siemens A.G. said yesterday that it would spin off its semiconductor division on April 1 under a new name in a move to prepare it for a public offering on the stock market by the end of 1999.

title: Wright's Sagging Balcony
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Schools Of Cuba, Forgotten No More
description: In 1961, Fidel Castro and Che Guevara played golf at Havana's most exclusive country club. Too decadent, they thought. Instead, they decided, the land should be used for an arts institution to develop a ''new culture'' for the ''new man,'' said John A. Loomis, an author and architect. So, Ricardo Porro, Vittorio Garatti and Roberto Gottardi, architects, designed five schools -- for plastic arts (top far right, as photographed in 1965), modern dance (bottom far right, 1965), music, theater and ballet. These brick and tile buildings, with Catalan vaults (right, 1992), fused Afro-Cuban culture with Hispanic-American and modernist ideas. Mr. Porro's School of Plastic Arts was inspired by the fertility goddesses of Afro-Cuban animist beliefs. It was, he said ecstatically last week, ''a city of breasts.'' But in 1965, construction was suspended, and the schools were opened unfinished. Castro had aligned himself with the Soviet model of standardized buildings. Mr. Porro left for Paris, and the schools fell into disrepair.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEVENS, RICK
description: STEVENS-Rick. March 18, 1945April 18, 1997. Remembered with love every day and especially today

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOELSON, GEORGE
description: JOELSON-George. From around the world tears will fall, for a man in life who stood so tall, George, your stories we will always miss, and seeing you with a big hug and kiss. On behalf of all of George's friends, we extend our deepest condolences to Norma and his entire family. Fran and Herb Wilson

title: Sports of The Times; Just Thank Testaverde For Replay
description: VINNY TESTAVERDE's numbers as the Jets quarterback last season show only one rushing touchdown. One for the books, the history books.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOSEPH, RUTH V., M.D.
description: JOSEPH-Ruth V., M.D. March 18, 1998. Always loved, always cherished, all ways missed. Your Loving Fan Club

title: No Father of Computing, But Maybe He's an Uncle
description: When Vice President Al Gore said in an interview on CNN last week that he ''took the initiative in creating the Internet,'' Republicans wasted no time ridiculing the assertion. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, announced that he himself invented the paper clip, and Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, laid claim to the Interstate highway system.

title: If Partner Gives a Signal, Ignoring It May Be Costly
description: Thousands of players from around North America and a handful from other countries are converging on Vancouver, British Columbia, today for the 11 days of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. Many will recall the only previous such occasion there, or anywhere else in Western Canada, a quarter-century ago.

title: All the World's a Stage, Ruled by Guess Who; Why Shakespeare Resonates With the Modern Age
description: Only two years ago, a report that two-thirds of leading American universities had dropped the Shakespeare requirement for English majors in favor of courses on popular culture and gender studies prompted worries that the playwright -- regarded by many left-wing ideologues as the quintessential Dead White Male -- was becoming a has-been, a victim of the commissars of political correctness and willfully watered-down curriculums.

title: Worldwide Chip Sales Up 1.2% in January
description: Worldwide semiconductor sales rose 1.2 percent in January from a year earlier, as rising demand in Europe and much of Asia offset lower sales in the Americas.

title: Our China Policy Is Based on Wishful Thinking; Spies and Gossips
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Appeals Courts Flout Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, SIMON (SOL)
description: DRUCKER-Simon (Sol), died March 16th, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Joel and Terry and daughter-in-law, Debbie. Adored grandfather. Services will be held Thursday, 1 PM, at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Avenue, Manalapan, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, DANIELLE
description: RUBINSTEIN-Danielle. The AntiDefamation League mourns the untimely passing of Danielle Rubinstein, a longtime member of ADL's International Affairs Committee. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, VIRGINIA L. (NEE DUFFY)
description: McNAMARA-Virginia L. (nee Duffy). On March 16, 1999. Loving daughter of the late Louise Ryan and Edward Duffy. Beloved wife of the late James J. McNamara & sister of the late Anne Andrechak. Survived by her brother Edward Duffy and son Paul and family. Retired parochial school teacher and active College of Mt. St. Vincent Alumni, class of 1936. A dear friend to many. Reposing on Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Jazzy Form Reinvented as Meditative Balm
description: Danny Buraczeski is at his considerable best in the program of new works presented by Jazzdance by Danny Buraczeski, which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Everything comes together in two of Mr. Buraczeski's three pieces, in imaginative and humane choreography that proves unarguably that there is rich life for jazz dance after Bob Fosse. A fourth piece, by Cathy Young, reiterates that message, though in more familiar jazz-dance terms.

title: Sometimes One Man's Wart Is Another's Fancy
description: If Prince Charles were to visit Culver City, Calif., he might pronounce a building addition there as yet another ''wart on the face of an old friend'' (as he once called the winning design for an extension on the National Gallery in London). Other people, however, are amused at this whimsy, by the architect Eric Owen Moss. The ''little bump on the wall,'' as Mr. Moss calls it, is a flamboyant gesture in an otherwise restrained renovation of an office building at 3524 Hayden Avenue. Made of 1,000 concrete blocks, the bump, which houses a software company's executive office and conference room, was an effort to create something ''very free and malleable'' out of standard, hard materials, Mr. Moss said.

title: At the End of the Yellow Brick Road: Maryland
description: It was during the long, lonely rides across Texas that Steve Francis had his doubts.

title: JACOR TO BUY 2 PHOENIX RADIO STATIONS FOR $142 MILLION
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two Phoenix radio stations from Owens Broadcasting and Owens MAC Radio for $142 million. The acquisitions will give Jacor four radio stations in Phoenix. Under the agreement, Owens Broadcasting will sell KNIX-FM. Owens Mac Radio, a venture between Owens Broadcasting and MAC America Communication Inc., will sell KESZ-FM. The closely held Owens Broadcasting is managed by Michael Owens, the son of the country music star Buck Owens. Jacor, a radio broadcaster, is based in Covington, Ky. The company's stock fell $2.625, to $70.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Rising Tide: Sites Born of Hate
description: AT first glance, Nole's Page looks like any one of the thousands of personal home pages digitally dashed upon the Internet by adolescents with a modicum of computer skills and a hankering to be noticed. The page, which claims to be all about Santa Barbara, Calif., displays the name of the city, framed by American flags, above torches that burn with animated fire. Along the left side of the page are buttons directing viewers to some of Nole's favorite things, including ''the beer of champions.''

title: Amid Rangers' Surge, Gretzky Is Not the Forgotten One
description: The Rangers have played themselves back into the playoff race, and they have somehow managed to pull that off without Wayne Gretzky, their top scorer.

title: Q & A /Stephen Nachtsheim, Intel Vice President : Venture Capital Investments:The Reasons for Global Push
description: Stephen P. Nachtsheim, an Intel Corp. vice president, helps direct the chipmaker's investments in other technology companies. Intel usually takes small, minority stakes  generally worth less than $10 million  in private or sometimes public companies. During a recent trip to Paris, Mr. Nachtsheim discussed Intel's plans to expand its venture capital investing outside of the United States this year with Victoria Shannon of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Where Fans Of Kubrick Can Grieve
description: How does a community cope with loss? That was the question that members of the Stanley Kubrick newsgroup, alt.movies.kubrick, were asking themselves after the director of such films as ''A Clockwork Orange,'' ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and ''Dr. Strangelove,'' died last week. For on-line devotees of the cerebral director, who was often described as having a cold, unemotional vision, it was a rare occasion to unload.

title: Clinton Urges Sides to Pursue Peace in Ulster
description: With the nearly year-old Northern Ireland peace agreement facing a critical turning point, President Clinton today used the confidence he enjoys with both sides to urge them to move ahead in forming a joint Protestant-Catholic government.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Just the Right Note For Social Register

title: AMR Profit Drop Deepens Over Pilot Sickout
description: The parent of American Airlines, the AMR Corporation, said yesterday that the financial pain caused by the crippling 10-day sickout by its pilots last month had been worse than expected and that its first-quarter profit would be about half of Wall Street's current estimate.

title: JOY OF COOKING
description: (Simon & Schuster Interactive/Compuworks; $19.99; Windows 95 and 98.)

title: Without Ewing, Other Scorers Can Run in the Fast Lane
description: It was almost effortless, the way that Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston, and Larry Johnson raced up and down the floor on Tuesday night, dropping in one open jump shot after another. If it seemed at times that there was no defense against it, that was because there wasn't, with the opposition being the Los Angeles Clippers, a team that only the 50-game season can stop from setting records for futility.

title: G.O.P. Still Places Environment Last
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONIS, HENRY
description: BONIS-Henry. Of Lakehurst, NJ on March 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Julia, loving father of Leonard, Fred and Ilene, dear brother of Herb and Eleanor, adoring grandfather of Jessica, Brian, Geoffrey, Chelsea, Emma, Cassie and Eric, devoted uncle. Service Thursday, 12 noon, at the ''Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue

title: Lois to Reorganize Chicago Operations
description: Lois/USA in New York said yesterday that it would reorganize its operations in Chicago by spinning off part of an office there.

title: Big Board May Add Membership Seats
description: The New York Stock Exchange may create memberships, as it prepares to open a new floor for trading foreign shares and expand trading hours next year, the Big Board's president, William R. Johnston, said yesterday.

title: Street Searches By City's Police Lead to Inquiry
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said yesterday that his office would investigate allegations that New York City police officers stop people on the streets and frisk them without justification.

title: They Built Los Angeles
description: WITH the revival of interest in post-World War II Los Angeles architecture, coupled with a fascination for today's West Coast architects, book publishers have been working furiously to meet the demand. New books on Los Angeles design include Monacelli Press's splendid ''Frank O. Gehry: The Complete Works,'' so heavy you would need a few workouts to lift it, and two, yes, two volumes from the Spanish company Editorial Gustavo Gili on R. M. Schindler, who was among the first immigrants to plant the seeds of European modernism in Los Angeles in the 1920's.

title: Lame-Duck Coach Gives Iowa an 'Edge' Against UConn
description: If they stop to think about it, the Iowa players are already feeling deprived over the pending departure of their coach, Dr. Tom Davis, whose contract is running out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOICHER, ROSE
description: SOICHER-Rose. Wife of Leslie Molnar and the late R. Irving Soicher. Loving and beloved mother of Larry, and Harvey and Linda. Adored grandmother of Barry and Lisa Slote, and cherished great grandmother of Lindsay and Erica. Service Thursday, 10:45 A.M, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel 212-769-4400. In lieu of flowers contributions to NYU Medical Center or Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Post-PC Era Dream:Linking Up All Electronic Devices
description: WASHINGTON  Racing against a deadline, a group of executives meets in a hotel room to create a contract presentation. Between them, they have the usual toys of on-the-road professional life: laptop computer, a pager, a cell phone. The room has a TV set and fax machine; down the hall is a color printer.

title: Airbus Won't Be Transformed This Year, Finance Chief Says
description: Airbus Industrie, the passenger jet consortium jointly owned by four European companies, will not transform itself into a single corporation this year, its chief financial officer said yesterday.

title: Harry Callahan, Cool Master of the Commonplace, Dies at 86
description: Harry Callahan, a photographer whose pictures married the elegant precision of American modernists like Ansel Adams with the restless experimental spirit of European modernists like Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, died on Monday at his home in Atlanta. He was 86.

title: Freedom of Hate Speech?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Saudi Plan to Cut Production Pushes Crude Oil Prices Higher
description: Crude oil futures surged yesterday, with prices nearing a five-month high, after Saudi Aramco, the state-owned oil company in Saudi Arabia, said it would cut sales of crude oil to all its major clients by 12 percent April 1.

title: The Big City; Call to Resist Easy Promises Of Milk Cartel
description: IT'S not surprising that dairy farmers would like New Yorkers to pay more for milk, or that politicians want to oblige the farmers. But why are environmental groups supporting this cause when it may end up harming the environment even more than consumers?

title: Census Bills Gain Despite the Bureau's Protest
description: After engaging in heated and partisan debate on how best to manage the 2000 census, a House committee approved several Republican-sponsored bills today over objections by the Census Bureau's director that they would be ''just short of disastrous'' and could even delay the beginning of the count.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Such Rib-Sticking Meat Pies!
description: If she doesn't erase memories of Angela Lansbury, radiating dotty, malicious charm in the original Broadway production of ''Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street,'' Christine Baranski certainly supplies wondrous new ones.

title: Artest Suffers A Strange Injury
description: Ron Artest was limping noticeably during yesterday's practice in Knoxville, Tenn., raising the question of whether the St. John's star would be healthy for tonight's Southeast Regional semifinal game with Maryland.

title: Ruling Blocks Trenton Order On Insurance
description: A state appeals court temporarily blocked today a Whitman administration order that required insurance companies to reduce automobile policy rates by 13 percent to 15 percent for each of their customers.

title: Do Appeals Courts Flout Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Renault Offer To Nissan Is Questioned
description: Having failed in previous international mergers in the United States and elsewhere, Renault S.A. is encountering considerable skepticism in financial markets following the French auto maker's offer for a large stake in heavily indebted Nissan Motor Company of Japan.

title: Independent Counsel Law Is Too Flawed to Renew, Reno Tells Senate Panel
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said at a Senate hearing today that she was prepared to abandon the independent counsel statute because it had failed to remove politics from cases involving top administration officials, was fatally flawed by procedural ambiguities and seriously distorted critical prosecution decisions.

title: A Well-Blazed Trail for the Police
description: In confronting racial bias, most police departments lag so far behind America's other institutions, from corporations to the military, that critics' periodic calls for change often seem like futile rhetoric. So if you're black and used to being hassled by cops for no good reason, you can be excused for feeling a touch cynical now that politicians -- including, most recently, President Clinton -- are again making high-sounding pledges of police reform.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, WALTER E.
description: BRETT-Walter E. Of Point Lookout, L.I. on March 17, 1999. A 38 year member NYFD. Battalion Commander of the 11th Battalion of the NYFD. Beloved husband of Ginger (nee Caruso), loving father of Audrey Thiel, Andrew and Christian. Fond father-in-law of Robert Thiel and Ann Brett. Adored grandfather of Alexandra, Taylor, Michael & Ryan. Reposing after 2PM Thursday, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave (Exit 28N Southern State Pkwy) Wantagh, L.I. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout, L.I. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York Fire Fighters Burn Center, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475. 718-379-1900 would be appreciated. Family will receive friends Thursday and Friday, 2-5, 7-10PM.

title: The I.O.C. Ousts Six Members, but Stands by Samaranch
description: Under tremendous pressure to reform, the International Olympic Committee formally expelled six members today for corruption related to the Salt Lake City bribery scandal.

title: Holyfield-Lennox Hearing Is Deferred
description: New York State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer yesterday canceled a hearing set for tomorrow into the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis fight to avoid interfering with a criminal inquiry by Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau.

title: In Justifying Indiscretion, A Spin Doctor Does a Tango
description: In just a few days, George Stephanopoulos's book has replaced Monica Lewinsky's as No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list (for March 28), outselling her book in some places by nearly four to one. To many people, not necessarily those in book publishing, this is perhaps surprising because one has the feeling she must be known to everyone in the world. Even her persona has been reduced to one word, Monica, like Madonna.

title: Investigation Suggests Envoy Lied to House
description: A senior State Department officer, now the head of the American delegation to the Kosovo peace talks, may have lied when he testified before Congress three years ago about death squads in Haiti, according to an investigation by the State Department's inspector general.

title: Scandal Over Top Russian Prosecutor Deepens New Crisis
description: Six weeks ago, Russia's top prosecutor, Yuri I. Skuratov, handed in his resignation and disappeared from sight, causing a scandal.

title: N.F.L. Backs Limited Replay After Complaints of Bad Calls
description: After a seven-year absence, instant replay will return this fall to the National Football League for a one-year trial.

title: Serbs' Killing of 40 Albanians Ruled a Crime Against Humanity
description: The 40 ethnic Albanians killed in the village of Racak in January were all unarmed civilians, and their slaying amounted to a crime against humanity, the head of a Finnish forensic team that examined the bodies said today.

title: CMGI to Split Shares
description: CMGI Inc., an Internet venture fund company, said today that it would split its shares 2 for 1. CMGI will split its shares May 27 to shareholders of record May 13, pending shareholder approval. It is the second split since December by the company, which has seen its shares more than triple in value since the start of the year. CMGI, which is the largest shareholder of the No. 3 Internet search service Lycos Inc., drew a spotlight last month when its chief executive said he would not support Lycos's pending acquisition by USA Networks Inc. Shares of CGMI fell $5.375 each, to $175.375.

title: Bonn Ministry Sees No Signs of Pickup
description: The German Finance Ministry said yesterday that it saw no immediate signs of a pickup in the economy. But the ministry also said the outlook for the second half of 1999 was positive primarily because of an expected increase in private consumption.

title: And the Partyers Go to . . .
description: On Sunday night, one of the busiest intersections will be Melrose Avenue and Robertson Boulevard, where two post-Academy Award parties will be given. Elton John's gala, planned by Merv Griffin Productions, will be held at Pagani (right and inset), a striking restaurant designed by Hagy Belzberg, with dynamic wood columns. Across the street, Sweeny Walter Architects is adding a tent to Morton's restaurant for the expected overflow from the Vanity Fair party. (Last year, fire marshals were called because of overcrowding at Morton's.) With a hole above the bar for cigarette smoke, the tent (drawing far right) promises to be open and airy. Invitation only.

title: Marbury's 29 Invigorate Nets and Fans
description: The Nets definitely overreacted tonight, but can you blame them?

title: Retired General Is Penalized, Not Jailed, in Adultery Case
description: A retired two-star Army general who admitted to committing adultery with the wives of four subordinates was ordered today to pay $22,000 in penalties but was spared a prison sentence after his lawyer argued that his client's valor in Vietnam outweighed his misconduct.

title: On 2067 Battleground, 1999 Political Passions
description: THE year is 2067, and the United Nations Starship Unity hurtles through space. Behind it: Earth, ravaged by war, famine and disease. Ahead: a planet orbiting Alpha Centauri, where humankind can make a new start. Aboard: thousands of cryogenically frozen men and women with the skills to create a new society.

title: On-Line Book Clubs: Everything but Food
description: CAN a book club be a book club without muffins?

title: Tokyo to Continue Buying Its Bonds a While Longer
description: The Japanese Government said today that it would continue to buy its bonds into the next fiscal year, maintaining demand for at least a while longer and discouraging a quick drop in bond prices from the prospect of oversupply.

title: Politically and Technically Complex, Medicare Defies a Sweeping Redesign
description: Ira C. Magaziner, the politically tone-deaf architect of President Clinton's ill-fated health plan, and Senator John B. Breaux, the deal-making chairman of a commission that failed to find a solution to Medicare's financial woes, share what might be called the hubris of health care reformers: the belief that they could devise an all-encompassing scheme to redesign a huge swath of America's health care system.

title: Beethoven First, Last and Nearly Always
description: Seymour Lipkin, pianist

title: E-Z Pass May Be Installed A Few Booths at a Time
description: In order to get E-Z Pass up and running sooner on the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway, the electronic toll collection technology may be installed at a few booths at a time rather than all at once, the Turnpike's top official said yesterday.

title: Junk Your Old Computer? You Can Give It Away
description: WHEN Lisa Castagliuolo, a teacher, sent a wish list of items for her kindergarten classroom to parents, she asked for books, a new rug and computers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, a passage was omitted yesterday from an article about the Philadelphia Orchestra's plans to focus on 20th-century works in its 1999-2000 season. The affected section should have read: ''In the 19th century, all orchestras were essentially contemporary music ensembles, playing mostly new or recent works. Occasionally, something like Mozart's Symphony in G minor would turn up, as a special revival. For complex and much-debated reasons, orchestras this century have increasingly put far more energy and money into maintaining old works than into fostering new ones. It is not surprising, then, that the orchestra's plan is being greeted in some circles as a 'gutsy and timely move,' to quote The Philadelphia Daily News.''

title: In 'Tosca,' a Pavarotti Renewed
description: Infirmities of various kinds have made Luciano Pavarotti's appearances at the Metropolitan Opera fairly rare over the last couple of years, but he did turn up for his 30th-anniversary gala early this season -- the performance is to be broadcast by PBS on March 31 -- and soon after it, the Met announced that he would sing three performances as Cavaradossi in the company's production of ''Tosca.'' The first was on Tuesday evening, when Carol Vaness also joined the cast in the title role, and James Morris took over the role of Scarpia. The new cast is to sing the Saturday afternoon performance, which is one of the Met's international radio broadcasts, and again next Thursday.

title: Mister September Unsettled For April
description: Shane Spencer, the Yankees' Mr. September of last season, says he loves playing winter baseball in Venezuela because it's so similar to performing in New York.

title: Multiple Listings Come to Manhattan. Sort of.
description: THIRTY-THREE of New York City's real estate companies have adopted a new coordinated computer system for selling apartments -- a system that, even before it is operating, is the subject of a debate about the city's selective way of selling real estate.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Signs of Healing in Emerging Markets
description: It is like the tree falling in the forest when no one is around. But quietly, some emerging stock markets have turned around after a year in which their sector dropped 25 percent as a whole and some individual markets plunged more than 40 percent.

title: PLEXUS AGREES TO BUY SEAMED FOR $67.4 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Plexus Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Seamed Corporation, a medical-instrument maker, for $67.4 million in stock. Seamed also warned that its second-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates. Plexus, which provides design, manufacturing and testing services to computer, medical and telecommunications companies, will exchange four-tenths of a share, valued at $11.90, for each share of Seamed. Plexus's shares fell $3.4375 each, to $29.75, and Seamed jumped $2.5625, to $10.25. For Plexus, the acquisition would expand its engineering staff by 50 percent and strengthen its niche in the medical market. It also enhances Plexus's ability to design more complex products.

title: Blair Uses EU Crisis to Push Reform
description: LONDON  By acting swiftly to demand wholesale changes at the European Union's executive commission, Prime Minister Tony Blair appears determined to use the corruption crisis to push for fundamental EU reform and demonstrate the value of his positive engagement with Britain's European partners, officials and analysts said.

title: Chinese Concerns Drop Share Plans
description: Three Chinese companies have dropped plans to issue class B shares, citing weak investor sentiment and Government regulations.

title: Chronic Heartburn Can Increase Risk of Esophagus Cancer, Study Shows
description: Chronic heartburn can greatly increase a person's risk of developing one of the deadliest of cancers, adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, a major new study has shown.

title: Hypocrisy in a Memoir
description: To the Editor:

title: Salesman Dies After Falling Out a Window
description: A sales representative for a software company died last night after falling through a 13th-floor plate-glass window of the General Motors building at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUITTMAN, HERMAN Z.
description: QUITTMAN-Herman Z. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father and father-in-law of Stephen & Linda, Michael & Lorraine. Uncle of Sue & Saul Zucker, Judith & Robert Steinberg, &Eli Jacobson. Adored grandfather of Kenneth & Louisa, Daniel, Tara and Marissa. Services Friday, 9:30 AM at ''B'nai Zion House'' 136 East 39 Street, Manhattan. For further information call Gutterman's Funeral Home at 212-873-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, EDITH
description: ADELSON-Edith. On March 15, 1999. Beloved wife of Bernard. Cherished mother of Joan Dwyer and grandmother of John Dwyer. Dear sister of Marvin Margolies. Service Friday, 12:30PM at Plaza Memorial, 91 St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Contributions in her memory to: International Fund For Animal Welfare, P.O. Box 193, Yarmouth Port, MA. 02675. She will be missed.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA GUIDE TO GOOD COOKING
description: (Broderbund; $39.95; Windows 95 and 98, Power Macintosh.)

title: Hempstead Democrats Perk Up, Winning 2 Trustee Races
description: Democrats have long outnumbered Republicans here in the state's most populous village, where two-thirds of the 47,000 residents are black. But until Tuesday, a Democrat had not won a municipal race in 21 years.

title: Bates Gets Account From Allied Domecq
description: Allied Domecq Spirits USA said yesterday that it had awarded Bates New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., creative duties for its Sauza tequilas brand account, with billings estimated at $15 million. The account had been divided between Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., and Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York.

title: Velvet That Lets in the Summer Breezes
description: SPRING cleaning once augured the hauling out of slipcovers. Time to camouflage the velvet sofa! Velvet, with its deep, dark colors, practically defined the wintry look. But today it comes in high-impact hues and has a cool image that's making it a fabric for all seasons.

title: Still Apropros, Songs of the 30's
description: Betty Comden and Adolph Green

title: New York City Is Planning 'Tobacco Bonds,' but Experts Are Wary
description: New York City is likely to become the first government in the country to raise money based on future payments it will receive from the $206 billion tobacco settlement.

title: In Pelham Contest, Another Nail-Biter
description: After tabulating most of the absentee ballots from Tuesday's election for Pelham mayor, election officials determined this morning that the incumbent, Joseph E. Durnin Jr., had tripled his lead over his upstart challenger, Arthur L. Scinta.

title: An Electric Charge in Rattles and Gongs
description: The Percussionists of the Met Orchestra set aside their Verdi and Puccini scores on Sunday evening to give a free concert of contemporary works at the Great Hall at Cooper Union. The performance was part of a series offered by the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, which normally presents such programs at its own Bruno Walter Auditorium but is currently in exile while its Lincoln Center home is being renovated.

title: Telling Details in Report That Felled European Group
description: As a retired dentist from the French provincial town of Chatellerault, Rene Berthelot had no obvious qualifications to work as a scientific adviser to the 15-nation European Union.

title: Instant Postcards And Fast Food
description: Say cheeeese -- burger!

title: Russia to Disclose Terms for Reinvesting
description: Russia said yesterday that it would announce plans on Monday to allow investors to reinvest ruble proceeds from its swap of defaulted Treasury debt for new bonds and cash.

title: Decision on Sale of Redskins Tabled Until April
description: The Washington Redskins sale for $800 million to the real estate developer Howard Milstein, who is also a co-owner of the Islanders, and to the businessman Daniel M. Snyder was tabled today for three weeks so the league and the purchasing group could study the bid, its financial packaging and each other. The owners will meet again at an undetermined site the week of April 4-10 to decide on the bid.

title: Long Island Youths, Irish or Not, Head to Parade in Rite of Spring
description: A throng of youths lined the platform at the Massapequa Park railroad station yesterday morning, waiting for the 9:22 to Manhattan. Truants, community college students, baby-faced objectors to the 9 to 5 work world, mall rats. Some were Irish, others were not, but already their faces were aflame with beer and smoke.

title: Ah! The Sounds of (Almost) Silence
description: THEY can put a man on the moon -- but they can't silence the teeth-rattling sputter of your neighbor's lawn mower on a Sunday morning.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rebounded slightly from a one-month low against the yen after Japanese Finance Ministry officials said the yen was rising too fast. In New York, the dollar rose to 118.01 yen, from 117.79 on Tuesday.

title: Woman Found in Park Dies of Gunshot Wound
description: A woman who had been shot in the face was found in a Queens park Tuesday morning and later died, the police said yesterday.

title: For a Safe-Needles Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Downsizing Sound Files
description: Q. How can I convert a sound file in the WAV format used in the Windows Sound Recorder to the smaller MIDI format so I can send the file by E-mail?

title: Tighter Security at Energy Dept.'s Nuclear Labs
description: The Energy Department has begun an internal investigation into accusations that its chief of intelligence was improperly barred from briefing Congress last year about allegations that China stole data from a nuclear weapons laboratory, Secretary Bill Richardson announced today.

title: Newark to Join Lawsuits Against Gun Makers
description: The City Council voted unanimously last night to become the sixth urban area across the country to sue handgun manufacturers to recoup public costs associated with gun violence. Naomi Paiss, a spokeswoman for the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence in Washington D.C., which assisted Newark in planning its lawsuit, called Newark ''a very viable plaintiff.''.

title: Pinochet to Hear His Fate
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet will learn next week whether he is free to return to Chile or must remain in England to face possible extradition to Spain on charges of crimes against humanity.

title: NEPTUNE ORIENT TO SELL NORTH AMERICAN TRAIN NETWORK
description: Neptune Orient Lines Ltd. of Singapore said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the North American train network of its United States container-shipping unit to a group headed by an executive who created the network in the 1980's, for $315 million. The buyer group includes Pacer International, led by Donald C. Orris, and the New York investment firm Apollo Management L.P. The network extends to 58 cities in the United States, Mexico and Canada.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Building Up Bulbs and Bulblets

title: Reading Exam Postponed For Annual Day for Girls
description: New York City Board of Education officials announced yesterday that next month's citywide reading exam will be held on April 21. The date was changed after officials learned that the original test date -- April 22 -- conflicted with Take Our Daughters to Work Day, said Karen A. Crowe, a spokeswoman.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Thomas J. Capano, a wealthy Delaware lawyer who was sentenced to death for the murder of a former mistress, misstated his lawyers' plan for an appeal. They said they would appeal his charge of first-degree murder, not his death sentence. Appeal of a death sentence is automatic in Delaware.

title: NBC and 24/7 In Marketing Deal
description: The NBC unit of the General Electric Company and 24/7 Media Inc. in New York, a Web advertising company, have signed a three-year agreement to collaborate on television and Internet marketing plans for local advertisers.

title: Mexican Military Arrests Dissident Army Officer
description: A fugitive dissident army officer who has publicly accused the armed forces of justice abuses was arrested today by military police, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: General Avoids Jail In an Adultery Case
description: After admitting he committed adultery with the wives of four subordinates, a retired two-star general was spared a prison sentence in a court-martial but was ordered to pay $22,000 in penalties for conduct unbecoming an officer and making false statements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSLER, EMANUEL
description: WEISSLER-Emanuel. Artist and sculptor. Beloved husband of Hannah. Cherished brother of Irving & Frances Lilienfeld. Services today 10 A.M., Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Avenue and 10th Street, NYC.

title: Seeking Solace in Deep Faith and Prayer
description: No one here ever truly understood how June Bonnin managed to stay alive, holding cancer at bay, refusing all treatment and relying on prayer to consume her tumors and growths. But she did survive, building a splendid white inn here with the extra years granted to her, and the delight she took in beating the odds magnified the impact for her friends of her apparent death on Monday on the Amtrak train that crashed in Illinois.

title: Death Camps As Kitsch
description: In St. Petersburg, Fla., the powers that be have graciously prepared a list of ''40 Fun Things to Do'' in their city. No. 11 on the list is ''Remember the Holocaust.'' Those out for an enjoyable afternoon are invited to visit the local Holocaust museum, where for $39.95 they can purchase a scale-model replica of a Polish boxcar once used by the Nazis to transport Jews and others to the concentration camps. (If that's not enough, they can donate $5,000 or more to the museum and receive a genuine railway spike from Treblinka preserved in Lucite.)

title: AN IOMEGA HAZARD
description: Iomega is recalling about 60,000 external Jaz disk drives because of a potential electrical hazard. The problem, the company said in a release issued along with the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, is that the housing for the drives' power supply units can split, exposing the electronics inside. The faulty units were sold with Jaz two-gigabyte drives and remanufactured Jaz one-gigabyte drives and as replacement power supply units. Consumers can exchange their units by calling Iomega at (800) 781-3296 or going to www .iomega.com, the company's Web site.

title: Discovering and Rediscovering Cuba
description: The American Composers Orchestra began its Sonidos de las Americas project five years ago with a glimpse of Mexican music that was thrilling, leaving aside the embarrassment one felt at having so much to discover and be thrilled by. Mexico was revealed to have at least one classic composer of major importance in Silvestre Revueltas, of whom Esa-Pekka Salonen coincidentally provided a reminder last week when he and his Los Angeles Philharmonic New Music Group played the tiny, ebulliently cross-rhythmed ''Ocho por Radio'' (also available on a wonderfully lively new all-Revueltas CD, Sony SK 60676, from the same source).

title: Report on Baby's Death Prompts Delay in Trial
description: A judge yesterday postponed the trial of Tabitha Walrond, a Bronx woman charged with manslaughter in the death of the baby son she had breast-fed, after prosecutors asked for time to consider a new medical report by a defense pathologist. The pathologist said the baby's death was due not only to malnutrition, but to a birth defect that the medical examiner had overlooked.

title: A Cubicle of One's Own
description: Did you hear about the new ''Jobs Rated Almanac'' that ranks 250 jobs, from best to worst? The author, Les Krantz, ranked them according to income, stress, physical demands, potential growth, job security and work environment. Being President of the United States rated No. 229 (low job security, no room for growth). Technology-related jobs came out on top.

title: At Least One Oscar Nominee Is Comfortable in Cyberspace
description: Movie fans who don't want to line up to see this year's Oscar nominees can turn to a smaller screen. ''Bunny,'' one of the five films nominated in the animated short film category, will be broadcast over the Internet through Wednesday.

title: GOVERNMENT STUDY OF MARIJUANA SEES MEDICAL BENEFITS
description: The active ingredients in marijuana appear to be useful for treating pain, nausea and the severe weight loss associated with AIDS, according to a new study commissioned by the Government that is inflaming the contentious debate over whether doctors should be permitted to prescribe the drug.

title: Needed: Minority Clerks at the Court
description: A Congressional hearing on the Supreme Court's annual budget last week took a valuable detour as Justices Clarence Thomas and David Souter engaged in a lengthy colloquy with lawmakers about the Court's dismal record in recruiting and hiring minority law clerks.

title: A Landlord-Tenant Dispute Blocks an Acclaimed Play
description: The show was ready to go on, but a landlord-tenant dispute kept the Kit Kat Klub dark last night. And an acclaimed musical revue about the black vaudeville circuit, scheduled to open yesterday at the theater off Times Square, was canceled.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Dozens of Criminal Cases Stalled by Investigation of Troopers
description: Twenty-five black and Hispanic criminal defendants are in legal limbo after the New Jersey Attorney General's office postponed their prosecutions because all were arrested or stopped by two troopers involved in a controversial shooting on the New Jersey Turnpike last April.

title: Auditioning A New Mall For Oscar
description: HOW do you create a mall that gives tangible form to an illusion? How do you make it an attraction that draws both the tourists that celebrities wish to avoid and the celebrities that tourists yearn to see? How do you create a theater there that can be queen for one day (for the Academy Awards) and a working girl for the rest of the year?
