title: GROUP 1 AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 12 DEALERS FOR $45 MILLION
description: Group 1 Automotive Inc., a fast-growing operator and consolidator of vehicle dealerships, plans to acquire 12 dealers in Florida, Oklahoma and Texas for $45 million in cash and stock. In the first three months of this year, Group 1, based in Houston, has announced agreements to acquire 28 dealership franchises with revenue of $720 million. Upon completing all announced acquisitions, Group 1 will own 83 dealership franchises representing 24 different brands, in six Southern and Southwestern states. Under the latest agreement, Group 1 will pay $32 million in cash and 595,000 shares, worth about $13 million, for the 12 dealerships, which have total revenue of more than $275 million. The acquisition will give Group 1 annual revenue of more than $2.4 billion.

title: Momentum Wanes as the Dow Falls Again, to 9,879.41
description: Stocks fell yesterday, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average briefly topped 10,000 for the first time. Eli Lilly & Company led the drop after an analyst warned sales of its top drug, Prozac, would be disappointing.

title: The Tulip, From Stew Pot to Cachepot
description: ''YOU never know why a love affair starts,'' said Anna Pavord, a British garden writer who has had quite an affair with the tulip. Moreover, she said, ''an affair can't be sustained over a long period unless that object of your affection is mysterious and endlessly fascinating, revealing things you didn't know -- it's such an incredibly complicated flower.''

title: A Gift of Winter: Snowboarding for City Youth
description: You might say that it takes a snowboarder to know one. When Jake Burton Carpenter was growing up, he was a rebellious teen-ager who was kicked out of high school when he was 15.

title: Olivetti Improves Bid for Telecom Italia
description: Olivetti sweetened its $60 billion takeover offer for Telecom Italia today by proposing to buy back 30 percent of the huge phone company's savings shares if its hostile bid succeeded.

title: Prodi the Front-Runner For EU Commission Job
description: BRUSSELS  Former Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy emerged late Wednesday as the front-runner for the post of president of the European Commission, following the resignation of all 20 members of the European executive in the face of a scathing anti-corruption report.

title: 'Band in Berlin' to Close
description: ''Band in Berlin,'' a musical by Susan Feldman, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Patricia Birch and Ms. Feldman, will have run for 16 regular performances and 19 previews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, DAVID
description: BERG-David. Attorney and philanthropist, died at age 94, loving father of Betsy Berg. Service on Friday 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Mobile Phone Roaming:Easier but Not Cheaper
description: PARIS  When digital mobile phone networks were first introduced in the early 1990s, one of the most exciting aspects of the new technology was the ability to roam, to make and receive calls using the same phone in different countries.

title: Group Sues to Halt Kaiser Permanente Ads
description: In the latest legal attack on managed health care, a consumer advocacy group asked a California court this week to halt advertising by Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, contending that the company's advertising recruited members by fraudulently portraying Kaiser's 10,000 doctors as not subject to financial constraints on patient care.

title: Do Appeals Courts Flout Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAYBURN, SAMUEL T.
description: GRAYBURN-Samuel T. Age 84 died March 16; devoted father of Susan T. Grayburn and Leslie (and Roland) Charbonnel; loving grandfather of Elisa, Benji, Leo & Abby; beloved brother of Ruth. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Love Is Like an Unhealthy Obsession
description: SUCH A PRETTY, PRETTY GIRL

title: They've Got Mail, and Game; Chess Fans Make Their Move
description: WHILE slick on-line games like Baldur's Gate and Half-Life are attracting plenty of players with their intense action and glorious graphics, there is another group of gamers on the Internet that is just as passionate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. On March 15, 1999 at the age of 94. A distinguished attorney in practice for more than 70 years, he is survived by many devoted friends. Service and interment private. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Our China Policy Is Based on Wishful Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDER, ETHELETTE
description: RIDDER-Ethelette French Tucker. Of New York City and Southampton on Tuesday, March 16 at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. Mother of Susan Lane Ridder and Eric Ridder, Jr. of Bedminster, NJ and grandmother of Catherine Tucker Ridder and Eric Ridder, III. Longtime companion and special friend of Nelson Montgomery Loud. Member of the Board of Trustees and former Chairman of the Womens Committee of Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Friday March 19 from 11AM to 5PM. Services will be held at St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., New York City, Monday, March 22 at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club, 1930 Randall Avenue, Bronx, New York 10473.

title: Riyadh Journal; The Internet's 'Open Sesame' Is Answered Warily
description: Ever so gingerly, the Internet is being allowed across some final frontiers, into restrictive parts of the Islamic world, under the wary eye of governments used to playing Big Brother.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST -- Player and Town Live a Dream; Szczerbiak Takes Miami of Ohio to New Territory: Round of 16
description: Wally Szczerbiak carefully slid out of the Chevrolet Lumina on High Street, a bounce pass off Miami University's campus, and the traffic soon stopped. The cars and the pedestrians. Horns honked and people pointed. Some of the admittedly apathetic students, who might have yawned if Bill Clinton had cruised by in a convertible, acted like 3-year-olds who had just seen Barney.

title: Arnott Scores 2 Goals As Devils Win Again
description: DEVILS 4, OILERS 1

title: INSURANCE AUTO REJECTS COPART BID AND ITS SHARES RISE
description: The shares of Insurance Auto Auctions Inc.'s rose almost 12 percent yesterday after the company, which sells salvaged cars for the insurance industry, rejected a $152 million takeover bid from a rival, Copart Inc. Insurance Auto shares rose $1.3125, to $12.5625, while Copart fell $1.25, to $17.25. Copart said it had offered to buy Insurance Auto for stock worth about $13.27 a share. Insurance Auto, which is 15 percent-owned by the Allstate Corporation, said it had rejected the offer because it was not in the best interest of shareholders.

title: Russia's Patchwork Economy; Korean Companies, Chinese Workers and U.S. Entree
description: It is well after dark on a recent evening, but the red brick garment factory on a bluff overlooking the Sea of Japan is ablaze with light. From inside the building comes a haunting song, unfamiliar in this overwhelmingly Russian city: the seamstresses are singing in Chinese.

title: Walls a Bikini Could Love
description: Liza Bruce, a London-based swimwear designer, has enjoyed an international following among fashion cognoscenti since the early 1980's. Now, she has brought her experimental bathing suits and clothing to the West Coast. Her new store, designed by her husband, Nicholas Alvis Vega, complements her bold, minimalist designs with Pop Art-style walls (left) painted like Pantone color charts. Lilac-tinted windows suffuse the showroom with roseate light. Liza Bruce, 7977 Melrose Avenue; (323) 655-5012.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHT, MADELINE SHAPIRO
description: WACHT-Madeline Shapiro. On March 17, 1999. Loving mother of Rita Hirsch and the late Elinor Gardner. Adored grandmother of Bruce and Donald Hirsch, Peter and Kenneth Gardner. Cherished grandmother to Katie, Tommy, Jimmy, Allison, Stephen, Eric, Zachary, Jacob Harry, and Jacob Henry. Services Friday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Reed Scatters 5 Hits Against Astros
description: Rick Reed scattered five hits and one run over five innings yesterday as the Mets defeated the Houston Astros, 2-1, at Kissimmee, Fla.

title: For Patrons of Prostitutes, Remedial Instruction
description: The 60 men were slumped in their chairs, weary with the weight of the former prostitute's insults.

title: Donaldson, Lufkin Makes A Move Up Merger Charts
description: Business has been so good for the investment bankers at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette lately, even they can hardly believe it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about two Marine aviators charged with obstruction of justice included an erroneous report from the Marine Corps about the potential penalties for the officers' handling of a videotape made from the cockpit of their plane, which sliced a gondola cable in the Italian Alps last year.

title: The Carnage at Bourbonnais
description: Tragedies like Monday night's collision of an Amtrak passenger train and a truck in Bourbonnais, Ill., south of Chicago, often appear to be freak accidents that would be difficult to prevent. But adopting that attitude toward the collision that took at least 11 lives and injured more than 100 people would be shortsighted. Even if human error -- possible reckless driving around warning gates by a truck driver with a problematic driving record -- turns out to be a cause of the collision, there are steps that can be taken to lessen the risks at the nation's more than 260,000 grade-level rail crossings. Curbing fatalities is going to require local, state and Federal officials to accelerate the use of engineering solutions, law enforcement and public education.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 14 of the House & Home section today about a computer system that will be used to share listings among some real estate agents in New York City misstates the eligibility rule for participants. They must be licensed real estate brokers; they need not be members of the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: Saving a Regional Icon
description: The Federal Government's decision on Tuesday to order new protections for nine threatened salmon populations in the Pacific Northwest is just the beginning of what could be the biggest and most expensive rescue effort in the 26-year history of the Endangered Species Act. It is an effort worth making. The decline of the once-great salmon runs of the Pacific Northwest ranks high among the ecological blunders committed in the name of economic growth. The time has surely come to correct that mistake.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was a prostitute for 20 years, and a heroin addict. I planned on sticking a knife in a john, any john, and thank God for you and me that I got out before that happened.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINETSKY, DR. JOSEPH
description: KAMINETSKY-Dr. Joseph. The Yeshiva University family expresses profound sorrow on the passing of a visionary leader in Jewish education for over half a century who-as founding president of Torah Umesorah-pioneered the development of the Hebrew Day School movement in North America. A member of Yeshiva College's first graduating class-the Class of '32-he was an honored authority on Jewish education and lectured widely in this field. He served with distinction as associate professor and chairman of the Jewish education department at our former Graduate School of Education. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Selma; children; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Do Appeals Courts Flout Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Rockland Ends Tax On Some Clothing
description: In a move to lure back Rockland County residents who typically shop for clothing in tax-free New Jersey, the County Legislature voted 19-2 on Tuesday night to eliminate its 3 percent sales tax on clothing items costing $110 or less, effective Dec. 1.

title: Boy, 4, Is Shot on the Street
description: A 4-year-old boy standing with his father on a street corner in Brooklyn was shot last night, apparently by a stray bullet, the police said.

title: BY A WIDE MARGIN, THE HOUSE VOTES STEEL IMPORT CURB
description: The House voted decisively today to limit steel imports, ignoring opposition from the Republican leadership and a White House warning that the measure would violate world trade agreements.

title: Do Appeals Courts Flout Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: By Wide Margin, Senate Approves Missile Defense System
description: Embracing a new national policy, the Senate today overwhelmingly approved legislation to field a system to defend the country against limited long-range missile attacks.

title: 'Silicon Valleys' Take Root in Europe
description: PARIS  Call them high-tech clusters. Call them centers for innovation. Draw a curve linking Scotland's "Silicon Glen" between Edinburgh and Glasgow, down through Cambridge, across the Channel to Belgium's Leuven area, to the Amsterdam-Rotterdam complex, then on to Lyon, then to Silicon Bavaria, with its "Medical Valley," back around to Grenoble, then toward Nice and on to Milan. Continue south to Bari and hook around through the Mediterranean to Barcelona  and it forms a configuration something like a croissant.

title: No One Knows the Way, So Marbury Shows It
description: Before the game against Dallas last night, Stephon Marbury talked about the help his new, staggering Nets needed. It was, he believed, lodged in the person of Phil Jackson, the retired pedagogue of the Chicago Bulls, now presumed to be ensconced in upstate New York. Marbury may have been excused his star-gazing, since he had played two games for the Nets since being traded from Minnesota and what he saw was about as attractive as a building implosion.

title: THE COMPLETE MASTERCOOK SUITE
description: (Sierra; $49.95; Windows 3.1 or higher, Macintosh.)

title: U.S. Approves Accord in Case Against Intel
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved a settlement today of its antitrust case against the Intel Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIREICH, SUSAN ELLEN
description: FREIREICH-Susan Ellen. Born in South Bend, Indiana on October 30, 1944, died March 16, 1999. Beloved mother, companion, sister, daughter and friend. Service will be held on Thursday, 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial, 91 St. at Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to: B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West 89 Street, NYC.

title: Vitamin O Product Is Just Water, Agency Says, Charging Fraud
description: The Federal Trade Commission has accused two companies of bottling salt water, labeling it ''Vitamin O'' and selling it as a dietary supplement for $10 an ounce. The agency said the companies claimed that the product would treat cancer, high blood pressure, lung disease, headaches, infections, colds, flu and other ailments.

title: Geocities Encourages Members To Make Their Web Pages Pay
description: Geocities is now offering a program that turns personal Web sites into something like virtual Tupperware parties where hosts earn commissions on purchases made through their pages. The program, called Pages That Pay (www

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ARTHUR R. JR.
description: LEWIS-Arthur R. Jr. Of Brewster, New York. On March 17, 1999. Age 51 years. Son of Arthur R. Lewis Sr., Of White Plains, NY and the late Muriel Z. Lewis. Brother of Joan Anders. Brother-in-law of Howard Anders. Uncle of David and James Anders. Funeral service Friday, 11AM at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY. Entombment Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Search For Change, Hamiltion Ave, White Plains, New York 10601 would be appreciated.

title: Sons and Daughters of HAL Go on Line
description: PEOPLE find Alice easy to talk to. She listens more than she speaks. She says she likes dining by candlelight. She reads newspapers and news magazines, so she is up on popular culture. She says the best book she has read recently is ''Mason & Dixon,'' by Thomas Pynchon. She even likes bad jokes. (''Did you hear the one about the mountain goats in the Andes? It was Baaaaad.'') But Alice's favorite topic of conversation is robots. That's because she is one.

title: Architecture and CAD
description: To the Editor:

title: John Paul on CD, for Easter and the Millennium
description: First came the book, then the show, and now the major-label compact disk.

title: Anti-Apartheid Cleric Is Guilty of Stealing Money From Charity
description: The former anti-apartheid activist Allan Boesak was found guilty today of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars donated to his foundation. The money was supposed to help needy children and to educate black voters before South Africa's first all-race election in 1994.

title: False War Tales Lead Jays to Drop Johnson
description: Two weeks ago, Tim Johnson proclaimed his Vietnam problem was behind him. He obviously did not know what lay ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIENER, SANDER
description: LIENER-Sander. Died March 13, 1999. Devoted husband of Nattalie Liener. Cherished father of Rochelle Liener. Survived by sisters, Hilda Waitzman of West Hartford, Evelyn Nadler of Rehoveth, Israel, Doris Kukin of West Orange, Jane Stein of Lawrenceville, NJ, Carol Deutsch of Pittsburgh. He was a pious, synagogue-oriented, and extremely kind humanitarian. Shiva observed through Friday at 6723 213th St., Bayside (718-423-0204).

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday, summarizing the approaches of Internet stock trading companies, showed an erroneous screen to illustrate E*Trade. The screen belonged to a different company, known as e-trade. That section of the chart, corrected, appears today on page C2.

title: Sympathy for the 'Perp'
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Protecting a patient's rights without inviting lawsuits.
description: WHO should control patient care -- doctors at the patient's bedside or doctors working for the patient's insurance company? The Senate Labor Committee appears poised to answer ''neither'' when it votes this week on patient protections.

title: Kosovo Talks Near End as Serbs Build Up
description: As the Serbs continued to pour troops and tanks into Kosovo, European and American intermediaries in peace talks here prepared today to shut down the negotiations without any agreement, probably on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBB, PETER B.
description: ROBB-Peter B. Of London, England, formerly of Riverside, CT, died suddenly on March 13, 1999. He was 59. A graduate of Phillips Academy, Andover, MA, and MIT, with a M.S. from Northeastern University. He served in the U.S. Marine Corp and was employed by M & T Chemical Co, and Olin Corp before heading up Glencore Int'l AG's MIS in Stamford, CT, Zug, Switzerland, and London. He retired in 1997. He is survived by his wife, Ann Salmon Robb, of London, three children, Elizabeth Robb Malone, of Pelham, NY, Peter Taylor Robb, of Maun, Botswana, and Christopher Bradley Robb, of Zug, his mother, Lillimor T. Robb, of Loudenville, NY, three sisters and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 20th at 11 A.M., First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made to Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 10810, or Perrot Memorial Library, Old Greenwich, CT 06870.

title: Prosecutor Sues Defense Lawyers, Citing Threat
description: An assistant district attorney in the Bronx filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing three defense lawyers of threatening her while she was prosecuting one of their clients on murder charges.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Backs Missile Plan As Clinton Joins Bandwagon

title: People
description: * Scott Murray, director for client services at TFA/Leo Burnett Technology Group, Chicago, a unit of the Leo Burnett Co., was named to head a new Austin, Tex., office of TFA/ Burnett as president.

title: I.B.M. Conventional Monitor Will Challenge Flat Models
description: For desktop computers, the trade-off for bigger monitors comes down to a choice between less desk space and a lot less money. The designers at I.B.M. say they may have a solution: a new 19-inch monitor that is moderately priced and uses conventional cathode-ray-tube technology but takes up little more desktop real estate than a 15-inch monitor.

title: City Reverses Itself On Effort to Protect Land at Reservoirs
description: After repeated efforts to persuade the Federal Government to strictly limit building on marshes around New York City's upstate reservoirs, the Giuliani administration reversed itself this week, saying the wetlands needed no special protections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, DANIEL G.
description: FORBES-Daniel G. Age 81, in Southport, CT, executive owner of Jaftex Corp of NYC on March 17, 1999. A WWII Navy pilot, corporate attorney, and author of several books, and girls sports writer for community news in Fairfield and Westport, CT. A former Justice of the Peace, former member of the zoning board of appeals, a former board member of The Westport Nature Center, and member of Birchwood Country Club. Loving husband of Cynthia Rockwell Forbes of Southport, CT. Devoted father of Jan & John Auleta of Point Lookout, L.I., Glenn & Jamie Forbes of Fairfield, CT, Danette Muller-Forbes & Bram Muller of Dordrecht, Holland, Peter & Ann Forbes of Canaan, NH, Courtney Rockwell of Southport, CT, cherished brother of Everett Fortunoff of NYC, Gilbert Fortune of FL, adoring grandfather of Ferrian Shapiro, Allison Forbes, Avery Forbes, Leendert Muller, Lars Muller and Willoughby Forbes. Memorial service Sunday 12:00 Noon from Abraham L. Green & Son 88 Beach Rd Fairfield, CT. Friends may call at 11:00 A.M. Memorial contributions to The Westport Nature Center.

title: Where Good Yarns are Both Sold and Told
description: DEBBIE BOYLAN is a dinosaur and proud of it, the owner of an independent bookstore in Westchester County who is not persuaded that she wants to go head-to-head with Barnes & Noble and Amazon.com.

title: NTL TO BUY AUSTRALIAN TV NETWORK FOR $407 MILLION
description: NTL Inc., a New York-based company that is the No. 3 cable-television company in Britain, agreed yesterday to buy Australia's only national radio and TV network for $407 million. The purchase of the Australian National Transmission Network, which includes 560 TV towers, would make NTL the exclusive carrier of television signals in Australia. The company's customers in Australia would include the Telstra Corporation, Vodafone Group P.L.C., WIN Television and Prime Television. NTL's shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $79.

title: British Cable Maker Rebuffed by a Rival
description: Wassall P.L.C., a British cable maker, said yesterday that it had made a takeover bid for a rival, BICC P.L.C., but had been rejected by BICC's board. The bid, which was made on March 12, valued BICC's common shares at 90 pence each.

title: Keith Cottingham
description: Ronald Feldman Gallery

title: Northrop Grumman to Restate Results for a Write-Off Loss
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said today that it would restate its results for the fourth quarter of 1998, taking a loss because of a write-off associated with an investment in a start-up rocket company.

title: Doubts on NATO Air Raids As the Talks on Kosovo End
description: With the Kosovo talks at a dead end, and the Yugoslav leader more recalcitrant than ever, the Clinton Administration was publicly pushing the threat of air strikes today, but officials said they had no option but diplomacy, at least for another week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAICH, MARGARET BRADY
description: SAICH-Margaret Brady. Of Sparkill, NY, formerly of Yonkers and Rye, died on Wednesday, March 17 at the age of 85. She is survived by one son, William of Hartsdale, NY; two daughters, Helen Senko of Brewster and Sister Margo Saich, O.P., a member of the Sparkill Dominican Order. For funeral information call Moritz Funeral Home, 914-359-0890.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Saudis Release Iraqi Plane in Sanctions Dispute
description: Saudi Arabia today released an Iraqi plane it seized on Wednesday after the United Nations sanctions committee failed to agree on whether such flights of religious pilgrims violate United Nations sanctions.

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt
description: Here are some favorite Liszt recordings of the classical music critics of The Times. Compact disks range from $9.99 to $16.99 for one CD, to $18 to $24 for a three-CD set, to $53.64 for a package of seven. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, WALTER H.
description: GOTTLIEB-Walter H., of Pompano, Florida. Died at home on March 15 at the age of 93. Married to the late Edith Gottlieb for 65 years. Son of Marion and Israel Gottlieb, survived by son, Gerald, and daughter-in-law, Janet, grandson, Benjamin, and granddaughter, Rachael, brother, Bertram, nieces, Beverly Reich, Susan Rosenstiel. Dear brother of the late Goldie Samilson, Minnie Reich, Lillian Lissman, Helen Lachman, Selma Fund, Jerome and Alfred Gottlieb. Walter Gottlieb graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School in New York, The Wharton School, class of 1927, and Columbia Law School, class of 1930. He was a former President of the Hungarian Mutual Benevolent Society of New York. Service and interment in Miami, FL.

title: Donald Baechler
description: Tony Shafrazi Gallery

title: Treasuries Gain on Sign Inflation Still Is No Threat
description: Treasury bond prices rose for the second time in three sessions yesterday after a Government report pointed to tame inflation, even amid strong economic growth.

title: Police Cite Play Fighting In Fatal Plunge
description: A software salesman who plunged to his death from the 13th floor of his Fifth Avenue office Wednesday night was pushed by a colleague during a rowdy evening of horseplay and crashed through a plate glass window, according to the police and the software company's chief executive.

title: Vivian Hallinan, 88, Doyenne Of Colorful West Coast Family
description: Vivian Hallinan, the striking matriarch of one of San Francisco's best-known and most colorful political families, died on Tuesday at a granddaughter's home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 88.

title: Clinton Asks Panel to Analyze and Solve Security Threats to Nuclear Labs
description: President Clinton asked an advisory panel today to analyze security threats at the Energy Department's nuclear laboratories, after suspicions surfaced that China stole nuclear-weapons designs from the United States.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Monday about the prospect of a Presidential campaign by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas described a series of tutorials aimed at helping him study issues he would face. As published, the article included an opinionated sentence casting doubt on his mastery of those issues.

title: Minority Law Clerks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARROW, FLORENCE
description: FARROW-Florence. Died February 23, 1999. She was born on January 29, 1906 in St. Louis, MO, the daughter of a well-known radiologist Edward Skinner and his wife Florence Skinner. Her husband, Joseph Farrow was the Chief of Breast Service at Memorial SloanKettering. Dr. and Mrs. Farrow had no children. Mrs. Farrow is survived by a cousin Mrs. Betty Schroeder of Mission Viejo, CA. Burial took place at Evergreen Cemetery. A memorial service will be held Thursday. March 25, 1999 at 4PM at the Church of Heavenly Rest at 5th Ave. and 90th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Breast and Cancer Reserach Foundation, 1735 York Avenue, NY, NY 10128.

title: New and Old Depression Drugs Are Found Equal
description: A new Government report on antidepressants offers some conclusions that may surprise Prozac Nation, even if they are no surprise to researchers: Prozac and other drugs of its generation are not any better -- or any worse -- than older compounds in treating major depression.

title: Suiza Challenged on Broughton Foods Bid
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation's proposed $123 million purchase of the Broughton Foods Company has been challenged by United States antitrust enforcers, who said in court papers that the transaction would lead to schools paying more for milk.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAPLAN, JOAN PLATOFF
description: CHAPLAN-Joan Platoff. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 21, 1999, 11 AM, Mt. Moriah Cemetery Chapel, Fairview, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINIGSBERG, LEO
description: KINIGSBERG-Leo. Age 90, died on March 17. Beloved husband of the late Billie Isabelle and devoted father of Renee Sacks and Frederick Kinigsberg. Loving grandfather of Justin, Allison, Mark, Lara, Eric and Cory. Father-in-law to Jerry Greenberg and Wendy Kinigsberg. Good friend and companion to Nettie Lostfogel. Funeral services today at 12:30pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, New York. Born in Lodz, Poland in 1908, he retired from a successful leather manufacturing business at the age of 84. With his family, he shared the lessons of his lifes' challenges with great dignity. He will always be remembered for his courage and his love.

title: New Video Releases
description: Pleasantville

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUFFENBART, WALTER
description: RAUFFENBART - Walter. We mourn the passing of a great legal scholar and publisher and the father of Suzanne Santry of our Board. We extend our love and sympathy to Suzanne and her mother, and all of their family. The Board of Overseers and Staff, the BCOA/HC

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the cost of the pilots' sickout for the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, misstated the effect on the company's first-quarter financial results. AMR estimated that the action would cut $200 million to $225 million from its pretax earnings, not from its sales.

title: Gillette Honored For Mach 3 Razor
description: The Gillette Company took top honors last night at the 13th annual presentation of the Edison Best New Product Awards, sponsored by the American Marketing Association.

title: A. Doak Barnett Dies; China Scholar, 77
description: Arthur Doak Barnett, a leading scholar and government adviser on China, died on Monday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 77. The cause was respiratory failure, the family said, and friends said he also had lung cancer.

title: Long Lives for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Stock Fundamentals Passe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Playing Out Presidency In Reveries and a Long Twilight
description: The lights had dimmed, the band was packing up, the crowd of more than 2,000 in the cavernous convention hall had dwindled to less than two dozen.

title: The Tell-Tale Hearts of Writers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Deutsche Bank Discusses Bankers Trust Financing
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Bank A.G. said yesterday that the company, Germany's largest lender, would raise 6 billion marks ($3.38 billion) in new equity to finance its acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation. The capital increase is scheduled for April, the executive, Rolf Breuer, said yesterday as Deutsche released its annual report.

title: Verdict Backs Cigarette Makers In Suit by Union Health Funds
description: In a major legal victory for tobacco companies, a Federal jury in Akron, Ohio, ruled yesterday that the companies did not have to repay dozens of union health and benefit plans in that state the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses.

title: Mahler, All From Memory, By a Stand-In Conductor
description: The symphonies of Mahler have not been helped by the cult of conductors, audiences and record collectors who extol these works above all others and argue ceaselessly about the ''true'' way to perform them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDI, ARLEEN J.
description: CARDI-Arleen J. Wonderful wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Died peacefully surrounded by her loving family on March 15, 1999. She is survived by her husband, John, four daughters, Dawn, Donna, Christine, and Lorraine, and eight grandchildren. Friends may call Thursday 7 to 9:30 P.M. and Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9:30 P.M. at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, NY (at City Line). Funeral mass 9:30 A.M. Saturday, St. Mary's Gate of Heaven Church, Ozone Park, NY. Entombment to follow at St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania Lung Transplant Program, 3400 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104.

title: RCN RAISING $1.25 BILLION FROM STOCK SALE AND LOAN
description: The RCN Corporation, a telecommunications-service provider in Princeton, N.J., said yesterday that it would raise $1.25 billion for long-term growth through a loan agreement and a stock sale to Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. The company, which offers cable television, telephone and Internet services to residential customers, said it would sell $250 million of senior convertible preferred stock due 2014 to a Hicks, Muse fund. RCN also has a $1 billion loan commitment through Chase Securities Inc. When those transactions close, RCN, which had sales of $210 million last year, will have about $2.25 billion in cash and capital to finance construction of a fiber optic network to serve its new California customers.

title: Judges Turn Back Challenge To a Federal Inquiry of Starr
description: A Federal appeals court today dismissed an effort by a private legal group to halt the Justice Department's inquiry into possible misconduct by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr.

title: For a Very Few Patients, U.S. Provides Free Marijuana
description: Every weekday morning around 11 o'clock, a middle-aged stockbroker named Irvin Rosenfeld gets up from his desk and walks to a breezeway outside his office in Boca Raton, Fla. There, alongside the potted palms and smokers taking their breaks, he lights up a cigarette of his own -- not tobacco, but marijuana, sent to him by the Federal Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELSON, DAVID
description: BELSON-David. Died peacefully in his sleep Sunday, March 14, 1999 in Laguna Hills, CA. Former New York Assistant Attorney General, former General Counsel to Hebrew Butcher Workers Union Local 234. Engaged in the practice of law in New York City from 1938 to 1988. Authored and co-authored books with his wife Ruth Belson ''How to Write Letters for all Occasions'', ''What to Say and How to Say It'', ''Tributes and Forms for Public Occasions'', ''The Chairman and Speakers Role Made Easy''. A noted wit and brilliant raconteur. Devoted to his wife of fifty-two years. Survived by sister Ida Selzer, brothers Bernard and Sidney and a flock of nephews and nieces, too numerous to mention. He was a gentle, kind and generous man who will be missed by those who knew and loved him. Maxine and Jerome Belson I. Victor and Arlene Belson

title: Buckeyes Surprise Auburn, Await Red Storm in Final
description: The only team standing between St. John's and the Final Four is one that finished 8-22 last season and was dead last in the Big Ten with just one victory in the conference.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Smoke and Heat
description: The long-awaited Government-commissioned report on marijuana that was issued on Wednesday may have concerned the drug's medicinal uses, but it has also opened a debate on marijuana's longstanding role as linchpin of a national policy of zero tolerance toward illicit drugs.

title: Getting in Touch With His Inner Good Guy
description: In ''True Crime,'' Clint Eastwood makes his entrance perched on a barstool, putting his codgerly moves on a 23-year-old blonde. Flashing a silly grin, he looks worn and more than a little ludicrous. And that's the point, since Steve Everett, the veteran newspaper reporter whom he plays, has a knack for the embarrassing fiasco.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DELIA'S INC., New York, said yesterday that it had promoted Evan Guillemin, the chief financial officer at the teen-age apparel retailer, to president, succeeding Stephen I. Kahn, one of the company's founders, who remains chief executive and chairman.

title: It's NATO Peacekeepers, Not Bombs, Irking Serbs
description: ''So, is NATO going to bomb us?'' As Serbian soldiers and police officers drank coffee and cognac in the shabby Cafi Marko on the main street, the same question kept cropping up.

title: American Interests: Not a Bad Concept; Back Up the Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Yanks Await Manager, Friend and Buffer
description: The Yankees' veteran players have united like a neighborhood watch since Joe Torre left the team last week, a few of them even using the manager's office to meet privately over some issue the other day.

title: St. John's, Gonzaga, UConn, O.S.U. Win
description: St. John's reached the final of the South Regional of the men's national basketball tournament last night with a convincing 76-62 victory over Maryland. The Red Storm can get to the Final Four for the first time since 1985 by beating Ohio State tomorrow. Ohio State beat Auburn, 72-64.

title: The Art of the Machine, The Machine as an Art
description: Sculptors often dream of being more down to earth. David Smith, for example, fancied himself a blacksmith. Another favorite fantasy is that of the nutty mechanic, a guy who invents odd things with screwdrivers, pipes and electric motors down in the basement. Three notable examples of this type -- Tim Hawkinson, Steven Brower and John Kalymnios -- are currently exhibiting their works at different downtown galleries. For each of these artists, eccentric tinkering with everyday hardware gives rise to eye- and mind-opening images, ideas and metaphors.

title: Georges Braque
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a heavy-metal music festival in Asbury Park, N.J., misstated the nationality of the black-metal group Dimmu Borgir. The band is from Norway, not Sweden.

title: American Interests: Not a Bad Concept; U.N. Isn't Slighted
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Daily Protesters in Handcuffs Keep Focus on Diallo Killing
description: It went according to plan.

title: $6 Million Held for Cuba Must Go to U.S. Families, Judge Rules
description: A Federal judge ruled today that more than $6.2 million owed to Cuba by telephone companies in the United States must now be paid to the families of three Cuban-Americans who were killed in 1996 when their planes were shot down over international waters by Cuban fighter jets.

title: Knock Out Boxing
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For an Orphan (and Fleas), A School of Hard Knocks
description: By the time Kit sings ''The Company of Fleas'' (''Oh a flea, yessiree, can surely be a good friend''), her life is pretty much out of control. It started when she ran away from the orphanage, dressed as a boy. Then she met Professor Malefetta, who offered her a glamorous job with his theatrical company. But his troupe turned out to be a flea circus and Malefetta (Don Mayo) is not the greatest boss. Where can she turn next? And, oh my gosh, what if Malefetta finds out she's a girl?

title: Neilson Punished For Throwing Stick
description: Philadelphia Flyers Coach Roger Neilson was suspended for two games and fined $10,000 yesterday for throwing a stick onto the ice in Tuesday's loss in St. Louis.

title: Meeting Saturday Is Expected to Cement Their Reconciliation : South Korea and Japan Find a Way
description: SEOUL  Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea hope to resolve most of their differences over North Korea when they meet Saturday to form a "unified policy" of reconciliation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JEFFREY R.
description: SHAPIRO-Jeffrey R., Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a revered colleague of more than two and a half decades. A graduate of the former Cantors Institute, now the H.L. Miller Cantorial School of the J.T.S.A., he served as Cantor in New Bedford, Ma., Syosset, N.Y. and in Cherry Hill, N.J. His kindness, his humanity and his caring inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his wife Theodora, children and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice Pres Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESLER, BERTHA
description: TESLER-Bertha, on March 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late James. Devoted mother of Ruth and the late Max. Dear sister and sister-in-law of Rita and Bernard Tolnick. Loving Grandma ''B'' and Nanna Bertha of Shari, David, Kenneth, Robert, Douglas, and great-grandmother of Hayley, Kevin, and Noah.

title: IOC Reforms Olympic City Selection Rules
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  In an effort to curb the corruption that has tarnished the selection process for Olympic host cities and sparked a winter of widespread discontent, the International Olympic Committee formally adopted a new system Thursday that curtails the direct contact its members will have with the six cities bidding for the 2006 Winter Games.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McCORMICK & CO., Sparks, Md., the spice and flavorings company, said it planned to buy back up to $250 million of its stock, or about 12 percent of its 71.9 milllion shares outstanding.

title: IBERDROLA OF SPAIN PLANS TO BUY ENERGYWORKS
description: Iberdrola S.A., Spain's No. 2 power company, plans to buy a power plant development company from Bechtel Group Inc. and Pacificorp for $50 million. The acquisition of the power company, Energyworks Ltd., based in Landover, Md., would be Iberdrola's first purchase of a United States company. Energyworks has most of its projects in Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela. Pacificorp, based in Portland, Ore., said it was selling its 50 percent interest in Energyworks because it was refocusing its efforts on the sale of electricity in the Pacific Northwest. Pacificorp formed the Energyworks joint venture in October 1995 with Bechtel Group Inc., the giant engineering and construction company.

title: Frisking Policy Of the Police Faces Scrutiny
description: An investigation by Federal prosecutors into the tactics of the New York Police Department will be expanded to focus increased scrutiny on the Street Crime Unit, the elite police squad that includes four officers who fatally shot Amadou Diallo, the Justice Department announced yesterday.

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt
description: Here are some favorite Liszt recordings of the classical music critics of The Times. Compact disks range from $9.99 to $16.99 for one CD, to $18 to $24 for a three-CD set, to $53.64 for a package of seven. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Surrendering on Missile Defense
description: The Clinton Administration this week capitulated to Republican pressure to begin building a missile defense system at the earliest technologically feasible date. It was a political decision, designed to shield the White House from accusations in next year's campaign that it was complacent about protecting American security. Though the need to develop such a system is real, the rush to put one in place invites wasteful spending and could undermine critical arms reduction treaties with Russia that are no less important to America's defense. To avoid those mistakes, the White House must now manage this program with great care.

title: Fame, and High Price Tags, Cling to Stars' Oscar Gowns
description: First there was the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis auction with the $574,500 humidor and the $442,500 rocking chair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACHTER, LEO
description: ZACHTER-Leo. The Officers, Members of the Board and Administration of OHEL, Bais Ezra and the Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved father of Mel Zachter, devoted Chairman of OHEL's Executive Committee and Treasurer, and selfless and giving friend to the children and families who turn to us in their greatest times of distress and need. Leo was the patriarch of a family renowned for its generosity and concern for the welfare of the Jewish community around the world. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman, OHEL Pres. David Jacobson, Bais Ezra Pres. Ronny Hersh, Lifetime Care Pres. Moshe Zakheim, Chairman of the Board David Mandel, CEO

title: Another Meteorite May Show Life on Mars, Scientists Report
description: The same scientists who caused a sensation by asserting that a meteorite from Mars appeared to contain fossil and chemical traces of microbial life announced yesterday that they had found another meteorite with similar intriguing characteristics.

title: Boeing Bets Faith and Money on Jetliner Executive
description: Many aerospace-industry analysts believe that the Boeing Company is banking its future on Alan R. Mulally, the newly appointed head of its troubled commercial airplane division. And indeed it appears that Boeing is willing to back up its faith with dollars.

title: Call by Call, Hillary Clinton Queries New York Leaders
description: In the month since announcing her interest in a United States Senate seat from New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton has discussed her potential candidacy with more than 50 influential Democrats in the state, most often in lengthy telephone calls she placed from the private quarters of the White House.

title: Owner of Plant Won't Yield On Stadium Site Demands
description: The company that owns a steam plant on the site of a proposed stadium for the New England Patriots said today that it would not yield on its $100 million demand for vacating the land, and it accused state leaders of negligence for failing to allot money for the move.

title: I.O.C. Makes Changes, But Trust Becomes Issue
description: Even as it offered a framework for reform today, the International Olympic Committee continued to raise questions about just how vigorously it is determined to root out corruption that has gravely damaged the Olympic movement.

title: A Prince Among Men
description: The title character in ''The Happy Prince'' is not your usual, bland, fairy-tale royalty. Although oblivious and self-absorbed in life, he becomes a kind of messianic figure in death, sacrificing his immortality for the sake of the poor. Even more intriguing, though, is the fact that he was created by Oscar Wilde, whose literature for children has a tenderness and a spirituality that are surprising, coming from its famously dissolute, sharp-witted author.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISBECK, MARCELLE ELLINGER
description: RAISBECK - Marcelle Ellinger. Died peacefully in her home in San Francisco at the age of 100 on March 1, 1999. She was married to the distinguished cardiologist Dr. Milton J. Raisbeck, who died in 1988, with whom she lived most of her life in New York. She is survived by a son, Gordon Raisbeck, of Portland, Maine; seven grandchildren; 15 great-grandchildren; and two great-great-grandchildren. At her request, there will be no services. Donations may be made in her name to the St. Anthony Foundation, 121 Golden Gate Avenue, San Francisco, California 94101.

title: Sunny Stretch Around a Bay
description: Once upon a time, when there were more orange groves than golf courses in Florida, Tampa Bay was surrounded by a series of distinct communities: industrial, ethnically mixed Tampa, white-bread St. Petersburg and its retirees from the Midwest, laid-back Bradenton and Clearwater and, down the coast a bit, artsy, cosmopolitan Sarasota, where the circus spent the winter.

title: His Favorite Dessert? Ladyfingers, of Course!
description: If there's anything worse than a cannibal movie, it's an undead-cannibal movie with pretensions about Manifest Destiny in the American West. And the problems with Antonia Bird's ''Ravenous'' don't end there. Buried beneath laughable fake facial hair and frequently awash in gurgling blood, a potentially strong cast makes its way in deadly earnest through material that's often better suited to a Monty Python skit. The result is better appreciated as a 110-minute diet aid than as a film.

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt; Attuned to Liszt: Concerts and Lectures
description: Here is a sampling of music by Franz Liszt that is to be performed in Manhattan through April:

title: A Caldron of Ambition Boils Over With Trouble
description: Ron Daniels, the director, and an energetic cast bring cogent ideas about ''Macbeth'' and its characters to the Theater for a New Audience's production at the American Place Theater. But then Mr. Daniels allows the performance to stumble over its own supporting apparatus in ways that simply leave one puzzled.

title: Sports of The Times; A Story Of Success: St. John's
description: FINALLY there is an honest-to-goodness basketball story in New York. Not cascades of trade rumors, not professional teams using smoke and mirrors in an attempt to bury mountains of errors, not firings or talk of firings. None of that.

title: Jim Shaw
description: Metro Pictures

title: Are Stock Fundamentals Passe?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt
description: Here are some favorite Liszt recordings of the classical music critics of The Times. Compact disks range from $9.99 to $16.99 for one CD, to $18 to $24 for a three-CD set, to $53.64 for a package of seven. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Talks on Kosovo Wind Up As Only the Albanians Sign
description: Peace talks on Kosovo concluded tonight with representatives of the ethnic Albanian majority in the province signing an agreement on autonomy that was worked out by international mediators, while the Serbian authorities still refused to accept it.

title: Some Charges Against Former Sports Unit Head Are Dismissed
description: A state judge today dismissed most of the charges against Michael Francis that accused him of using his role as head of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to benefit his private business.

title: School Official Dismissed Over Handling of Gun Incident
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, dismissed a Queens school superintendent yesterday, charging that she deliberately misled parents last year by saying a gun confiscated from a third grader resembled a toy.

title: Michael Byron
description: 'Portraits of Objects'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWIN, FLORENCE
description: LOWIN-Florence. We are saddened by the loss of our beautiful, sensitive and creative friend who died last Monday. Our sincere condolences are extended to her son Eric and her sisters Charlotte and Roslyn. The Briloffs

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: You probably know that celadon is a tender shade of green. You may not know that it is also French for ''a sentimental swain'' and the name of a character in Ovid's ''Metamorphoses.''

title: From the Park To the Final 4
description: Horace Jenkins is not the first Division III basketball player to be plucked from a playground, but his impact is remarkable. Before he joined William Paterson University's team in midseason, the Pioneers had a 3-5 record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, DR. IRWIN HERBERT
description: KAISER-Dr. Irwin Herbert, 81, died March 17th in New Rochelle, after a prolonged illness. Dr. Kaiser was professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York. He is survived by wife Barbara Lieberman Kaiser; and children Susan, with her children Chad and Guy Currier; Peter, with his wife Luce and children Mireille and Ariel; Richard, with his wife Anne Farber and children Rachel, Emily, Deborah, and Samuel Farber-Kaiser; Peg, with her husband Roger Schatzlein and children Sarah, Alice, and Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein; Steven, with his wife Carol Nyman and children Michael and Christopher Kaiser-Nyman; and James, with his wife Kathryn Jones and children David and Amy Kaiser-Jones. A family gathering will be held on Saturday, March 20th, from 2-5 at the family's residence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, BENJAMIN F.
description: ABRAHAM-Benjamin F. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Devoted father of Marian Saltzman (Edward). Cherished grandfather of Carol Andrykowski, Steven Saltzman and Lisa Solomon. Adored great-grandfather of Jett, Silvie, Matthew, Jordan, Charlotte and Abigail. Services Friday, 12 noon, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Pataki Tests National Appeal With New Hampshire Visit
description: Looking more than ever like a candidate for the Republican national ticket next year, Gov. George E. Pataki made his first political trip to New Hampshire today, and leveled his most direct attacks yet on President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.

title: Riches for a Saint Who Scorned Them
description: The curving road from the Umbrian plains up to the Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi has been a pilgrim's path for more than 700 years. In spring the air is pasture sweet; in winter the cold can be stinging. Francis himself, native son and a man inclined to joyousness, took pleasure in both seasons.

title: A Tell-Tale Exhibition
description: Dredging up the actual man from the turbulent sea that has been Edgar Allan Poe's mixture of life and legend is no easy challenge, but it is one that the Morgan Library has accepted with ''Poe: The Ardent Imagination,'' an exhibition of manuscripts and memorabilia. It includes the engraved portrait below, by an unidentified artist from a daguerreotype of Poe taken shortly before his death.

title: Marketers expect the high price of Oscar time to be worth it.
description: NEVER mind Shakespeare. It's Madison Avenue that's in love -- with Oscar.

title: INSIDE
description: On Russia's Wayward Cash

title: Her Psychic's No Friend And Neither Is Her Man
description: Melba May (Park Overall), the sarcastically nicknamed title character of Darren Stein's confused, overwrought comedy ''Sparkler,'' is a not-so-dumb blond naif who lives in a trailer park in the California desert somewhere between Los Angeles and Las Vegas. The film's opening scenes ridicule Melba's world of dime store dreams (she fantasizes about winning a publishing house sweepstakes jackpot) and trashy taste (her trailer and the area around it are littered with toy animals and hideous tchotchkes). And at first the movie appears to be nothing more than a cheap satirical shot at the rural Western pool of potential guests on ''The Jerry Springer Show.''

title: A Community Garden in Brooklyn Wins Reprieve
description: A once-vacant lot in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that is now a tranquil garden popular with elderly residents and schoolchildren has been removed from a list of more than 100 city-owned lots scheduled to be auctioned in May. The move was the first sign that the Giuliani administration may be willing to spare some of the community gardens from development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENAWALT, MARTHA SLOAN
description: GREENAWALT-Martha Sloan. Died March 17, 1999 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth and mother of William, Kent and Kim Greenawalt, and Ann Abernethy, with 16 grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Outstanding civic and community leader throughout her life. Service will be held at 3PM on Sunday, March 21, and reception will follow, at the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road (at White Plains Post Road), Scarsdale, NY.

title: National Gallery Fills Its Garden
description: Nearly two years ago the National Gallery of Art in Washington broke ground on a $12 million sculpture garden, on six acres adjacent to its West Building on the Mall. At the time, there were about 12 outdoor sculptures in the permanent collection, and museum officials said that they were planning to double that number. This week, Earl A. Powell 3d, director of the Gallery, said it had acquired 10 major sculptures in time for the garden's opening on May 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINETSKY, JOSEPH
description: KAMINETSKY-Joseph. With profound sorrow, Torah Umesorah, the National Society for Hebrew Day Schools, mourns the passing of its Founding National Director, Rabbi Dr. Joseph Kaminetsky, Z'L. Rabbi Dr. Kaminetsky, working in concert with Torah Umesorah's founder Reb. Shraga Feivel Mendlowitz and the Rabbinical leadership of his time, dedicted his life to the furtherance of Jewish education and authentic Jewish values. He single-handedly took it upon himself to gain support for and create Jewish day schools across the United States-from the centers of Jewish living, to the most remote communities, with little or no Jewish infrastructure. Rabbi Kaminetsky was the embodiment of Torah values and ideals. Through a combination of his extraordinary warmth, his burning desire to spread Torah and his enduring love for the Jewish people, Rabbi Kaminetsky, or ''JK'' as he was affectionately called, succeeded in crashing through the barriers of ignorance, indifference and resistance. His memory will be forever etched in the annals of Jewish history where, as a direct result of his-life work, the Torah Umesorah Day School movement is today 160,000 children strong. Y'hi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Elya Svei, Chairman, Rabbinic Administrative Board Rabbi Yakov Rajchenbach, Pres. Rabbi Joshua Fishman, Exec V.P. Mr. David Singer, Chair. of Board Dr. Shmuel Zentman, Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, EMIL
description: HOLLAND-Emil. The Partners and staff of Spector, Rothenberg & Co. mourn the passing of Emil Holland. We extend our condolences to Anne Holland and the entire Holland family.

title: Bernd and Hilla Becher
description: Sonnabend Gallery

title: Development Approval Nears For the Hackensack Wetlands
description: Federal and state officials are near agreement on a plan that would allow development on the vast stretch of marsh and former landfill known as the Hackensack Meadowlands and streamline the approval process, in exchange for substantial reductions in the amount of wetlands that could be filled.

title: SIEMENS BUYS REDSTONE, A U.S. INTERNET SWITCH COMPANY
description: The German electronics giant Siemens A.G. said yesterday that it had bought Redstone Communications Inc., a developer of high-speed switches for Internet transmission, for an undisclosed amount. Redstone, a privately held start-up based in Westford, Mass., will be folded into the Siemens Unisphere Solutions Inc., a new subsidiary formed in Burlington, Mass., to oversee integration of electronic, voice and video data into networks. The purchase is the latest in a string of acquisitions by Siemens in the data networking. Siemens also said it would spin off its smart-card operations into a separate company later this year. Smart cards are plastic cards used for high-security applications, such as entry to networks or buildings.

title: Wehabilitating Bugs, Boop et al.
description: It still makes one of the better cartoon standoffs. The year is 1936, and in Tom Palmer's animated short, Cupid is doing his best to bury arrows into the obstinate W. C. Fields and an equally irascible woman with whom, or so Cupid supposes, Fields might make a match.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, ROSE
description: MARKMAN-Rose. Dear Nanny, your spirit will continue to inspire us all. You will always be a part of us. Love forever-The children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren of Rose Markman. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., NYC, 12:15pm today. In lieu of gifts, donations may be made to Johns Hopkins Oncology Center c/o Dr. Richard Ambinder, 418 North Bond St., Baltimore, MD 21231

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMANN, PETER
description: LAMANN-Peter, 89. Beloved husband, father, brother, friend. Trustee Sinai Temple, President Men's Club, Volunteer at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. A true gentleman, a beautiful soul; he will be remembered. Services today, 12 noon, Hirsch and Sons Chapel, Jerome Ave. at 167th. St. Bronx.

title: Ndur Is Adding Toughness
description: It is not up yet, but the puck that Rumun Ndur fired past Washington Capitals goalie Olaf Kolzig on Monday night will soon be mounted to hang on his wall.

title: A G.O.P. Bill On the Rights Of Patients Advances
description: A Senate committee approved legislation tonight to create a wide range of new rights for patients, but Democrats said the protections fell far short of what was needed to help people deal with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Few Words From the Mime

title: MetroStars Have 'No Excuses' Now
description: Major League Soccer is calling its fourth season, which will get under way tomorrow, the ''Year of No Excuses.'' In truth, the term applies more to the MetroStars' progress than it does to the league's 11 other teams.

title: Unfit Highway Tribute
description: To the Editor:

title: Rugged UConn Eliminates Iowa
description: Connecticut and Iowa decided from the start that their Round of 16 matchup in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament would boil down to this: One team was going down. Literally. On the deck. With a push and a shove. No gentle nudge.

title: Debris Strikes 3 as Gusts Hit Times Square
description: Fierce winds yesterday peeled a mammoth vinyl advertisement off the Times Square building famous for the New Year's Eve ball drop, injuring three women with falling debris and prompting the police to close a wide swath of midtown Manhattan.

title: Underestimate Poe's Legacy? Nevermore
description: Reviewing the life and career of Edgar Allan Poe can be a hall-of-mirrors-like experience. There are as many Poes, it seems, as there are people to make, calumniate and rehabilitate his reputation, with some observers doing double duty as both foe and friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUITTMAN, HERMAN Z.
description: QUITTMAN-Herman Z. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father and father-in-law of Stephen & Linda, Michael & Lorraine. Uncle of Sue & Saul Zucker, Judith & Robert Steinberg, &Eli Jacobson. Dear brother of Serene Werner. Adored grandfather of Kenneth & Louisa, Daniel, Tara and Marissa. Services Friday, 9:30 AM at ''B'nai Zion House'' 136 East 39 Street, Manhattan. For further information call Gutterman's Funeral Home at 212-873-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSAFT, HARRY
description: WEINSAFT-Harry. After a long illness on March 16 at age 76 in Detroit. Served in W.W. II, US Army 10th Mountain Division. Member of Crew of Exodus 1947. Survived by his wife Madeline and family in Detroit, Israel, New York, Alaska. Burial in Kibbuz Afikim, Israel. Next to his parents and sister Noemi who passed away six weeks ago. He will be greatly missed. Sofie and Nathan Holz and Family

title: The Guggenheim Sounds the Alarm: It Ain't Necessarily So
description: ''The Giant,'' a black-and-white photomontage that Cindy Sherman made in 1976, is the unsung center of the Guggenheim Museum's exhibition of its new photography collection.

title: A Long-Shot House Vote to Limit Steel Imports
description: With surprising force and fury, the House's vote to limit steel imports reflects a strong sense of frustration within the domestic steel industry over low-price steel that landed on American shores during economic crises in Asia and Russia last year.

title: Millennium May End With a Bang Or Whimper
description: ''The Book of Life'' and ''Life on Earth'' were shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10. The films open today in separate double-feature programs as part of the ''2000 Seen By'' series at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Late Goal Gives Princeton the Game
description: A late third-period goal by Princeton's Benoit Morin gave the Tigers a 3-2 victory over Colgate last night at the Olympic Arena in Lake Placid, N.Y., in the opening game of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference men's hockey tourna ment.

title: Ecuadorean Concessions Win Support for Austerity Measures
description: Eager to avoid prolonging the strikes and economic turmoil that have paralyzed this country since the beginning of the month, President Jamil Mahuad today lifted the state of emergency he imposed last week and rolled back drastic increases in gasoline prices.

title: A Murder Investigation in a Past Future
description: In the first scene of ''The Rook,'' Martin Donovan, dressed like a character from a Henry James novel (one of his best looks), rides into town in a mule-driven carriage. Then he photographs a dead body with what looks like a very modern mini-camera. The police chief he has come to see wears something resembling 20th-century Chinese fashion and a coat with a bulky fur collar. He offers his guest ''Tea? Water? Lemon soda?'' Telephones ring like old alarm clocks, and offices have electric desks.

title: BMW's Income Fell Last Year
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said here today that its profit fell nearly 28 percent in 1998 as losses at the British unit Rover dragged down corporate earnings.

title: North Korea Wins Again
description: Hold the champagne! Tuesday's agreement between the United States and North Korea doesn't validate the success of the Clinton Administration's North Korea policy. Indeed, since the agreement calls only for the right of American investigators to visit one suspect nuclear site, one that the North Koreans have had a year to sanitize, it probably doesn't even get our policy ''back on track.''

title: The Knicks Disappear In 4th Quarter
description: Once it ended, the Knicks began to hand out tired excuses like pamphlets on a street corner. To many of them, particularly Coach Jeff Van Gundy, the Knicks screeched to a halt against the Orlando Magic with an 86-78 loss because of sluggish pulses and blank looks on their faces.

title: TSI SOFTWARE PLANS TO BUY BRAID GROUP FOR $91 MILLION
description: The TSI International Software Corporation, which makes computer programs that link unrelated business software, said yesterday that it would buy Braid Group Ltd. of Britain for about $91 million in cash and stock. TSI will pay $30 million cash and stock valued at $61 million for the closely held Braid, which makes financial-transaction software used by banks and securities firms. Braid handles 40 percent of all equity trades on the London Stock Exchange. It will add about $23 million to TSI's revenue for the remainder of this year. TSI, which is based in Wilton, Conn., had revenue of about $45 million last year. Shares of TSI rose $3.8125 each, to $59.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: America West and Union Continue Contract Talks
description: America West Airlines and its flight attendants met in Washington for a second day of federally mediated talks yesterday in an attempt to reach an agreement before a strike deadline at midnight tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSDORF, BERNARD
description: NUSSDORF-Bernard. Patti Kantor and Fred Paliani, together with their colleagues at Edwards & Angell, LLP, mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our friend and client, Bernie. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Motorist Asserts Trucker Tried To Pass Gates Before Crash
description: A possible witness has come forward in the deadly crash of an Amtrak train and a truck on Monday night in Bourbonnais, Ill., and a Federal official said tonight that the man said he saw the truck driver try to snake through the lowered crossing gates.

title: AXA Says Profit Rose 8% in Half
description: AXA S.A., Europe's biggest insurer by sales, indicated yesterday that its second-half profit rose 8 percent, in line with expectations, as it was helped by earnings at its French and United States life insurance businesses. Implied net income rose to 3.997 billion French francs ($672 million), from 3.7 billion francs a year earlier period.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS AS IMPORTS INCREASE SHARPLY
description: As American exports continued to fall, the United States trade deficit jumped to a monthly record of nearly $17 billion in January, fueled by a flood of imports from China that could stir further protectionist sentiments in Congress.

title: St. John's Turns Maryland Upside Down
description: The bitter defeats during the regular season to Stanford and Duke and Connecticut would prepare them, St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis told his team, for post-season moments like this. Those losses seemed like quaint memories tonight as the Red Storm delivered a staggering 20-0 run to end the first half and went on to a 76-62 destruction of second-seeded Maryland in the South Regional semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NATHAN
description: GOODMAN-Nathan. Loving husband of Phyllis, devoted and best father of Iris and Shelley, extraordinarily proud grandfather of Sacha and devoted brother of Alfred. A generous and kind human being, he cared so deeply about everyone in his life and prayed everyday for sick family, friends and strangers. We will miss him very much. Services at Wien & Wien, Englewood, NJ at 12:30PM Sunday, March 21, 1999.

title: Breast-Feeding Is Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday about a Russian effort to end United States sanctions on two Russian nuclear research centers, imposed because of concerns about aid to Iran, misstated the Russian offer. Russia offered to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran, not to end it.

title: Marbury Shoots Like a Net, Hitting Only 7 of 24 Attempts
description: Stephon Marbury, who shot 47 percent in his first three games with the Nets, could not find the rim in his fourth. Missing 17 of 24 shots tonight, Marbury fell into that dark shooting hole that has engulfed the Nets all season. The result was another embarrassing loss, 104-95, to the no-name Chicago Bulls.

title: An Officer and a Judge Trade Charges After a Fender Bender
description: A fender bender between a judge and an off-duty police officer on the Upper East Side yesterday morning escalated into allegations of racism and official misconduct.

title: No Starring Role For Agents
description: Once a year on Oscar night, and only then, toute Hollywood turns out to celebrate the industry's accomplishments, to share a bit of movie glamour at an event in which everyone is included. Well, almost everyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDER, ETHELETTE FRENCH TUCKER
description: RIDDER-Ethelette French Tucker. Of New York City and Southampton on Tuesday, March 16 at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. Mother of Susan Lane Ridder and Eric Ridder, Jr. of Bedminster, NJ and grandmother of Catherine Tucker Ridder and Eric Ridder, III. Longtime companion and special friend of Nelson Montgomery Loud. Member of the Board of Trustees and former Chairman of the Womens Committee of Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Friday March 19 from 11AM to 5PM. Services will be held at St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., New York City, Monday, March 22 at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club, 1930 Randall Avenue, Bronx, New York 10473.

title: At Duke, the Course Is Coaching 101
description: The coach almost did not hear the whistle because it was blown far from a basketball court by someone who had never called a foul on him before: his wife. It was January 1995 and Mickie Krzyzewski felt like a failure. Her husband, Mike, was a superstar basketball coach and she was afraid it was killing him.

title: Tough-Guy Coaches Patrolling the Sidelines
description: Here's how Rasheed Brokenborough describes Temple basketball: ''You don't have fun playing for Temple. It's all business. Coach said that we're here to do a job -- win. Wherever we went this season, we didn't go out. Hotel, practice and game. We didn't even go out to eat. We ordered room service.''

title: Training Better Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Devastated by a Fire, Lowery Bounces Back
description: As Steve Lowery walked down the fourth fairway today, he passed by the charred remains of his home.

title: VLSI REJECTS PHILIPS'S $17-A-SHARE OFFER
description: VLSI Technology Inc. yesterday formally rejected a $777 million bid from Royal Philips Electronics N.V. as inadequate. It said it would pursue other options, including merging with another company or entering into more negotiations with Philips, Europe's biggest semiconductor maker. Philips began an unsolicited $17-a-share tender offer on March 5, after VLSI did not respond to a Philips offer in late February. VLSI did not name any potential new partners. Shares in VLSI, a chip maker based in San Jose, Calif., rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $18.9375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Car of 3 Missing Women Is Found Burned
description: Investigators said today that a rental car used by three women who disappeared more than four weeks ago had been found burned in a remote area near Yosemite National Park.

title: Worker Is Killed In Fall From Building
description: A construction worker fell 65 feet to his death at a building site at Broadway and 47th Street yesterday, the police said.

title: Late Tip-In Keeps Gonzaga on Its Thrilling Ride
description: To make the final eight of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, a team's origin and name matters little.

title: Miami Worries About Kentucky
description: There is one thing that Miami University's Wally Szczerbiak admits frightens him about Kentucky -- but, actually, it is more than one thing, because it is the entire team.

title: Senate Committee Passes G.O.P. Budget, With Medicare Still a Sticking Point
description: The Senate Budget Committee approved the Republican tax and spending plan today as the Clinton Administration and Congressional Democrats stepped up their attacks on the measure and labeled it irresponsible.

title: Spice Girls: Salt-n-Pepa, Still Talking About Sex
description: It doesn't seem fair that Salt-n-Pepa, the most successful female rap group in history, should be out of the limelight just as ''women in hip-hop'' becomes the big story that ''women in rock'' has been for a decade. A little crown reclamation is in order. That's why Cheryl (Salt) James, Sandra (Pepa) Denton, and Deirdra (Spinderella) Roper appeared at Life on Bleecker Street on Tuesday night, pumping out a high-energy club show that highlighted the hits they don't want forgotten.

title: An Early Start on the Census; Bureau Focuses on Those Least Likely to Be Counted
description: Eun Joo Kim, diminutive and demure in a black jacket and white blouse, surveyed the audience of elderly Korean immigrants who beamed up at her like indulgent grandparents and then, grabbing her microphone and turning to her marker board, got down to business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ANNE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Anne. Beloved aunt of Ruth Zeligs, of Cincinnati, Jules Ginsberg, of Florida, Sylvia Schlessinger, and Gilbert Graham of New York. Great aunt of Joseph Zeligs, Betsy Goldberg, Cary Browse, Nina Graham, Andrew Graham, Dan Graham, Deborah Graham, Robert Baker and Marilyn Fierro. Died peacefully at the age of 96 in New York City on March 16, 1999. Services will be held at Zion Memorial Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., 2PM, Friday, March 19th. Donations may be made to Hadassah, in her name.

title: Olympic Minimalists
description: Perhaps the Olympic movement should create an event for those who excel at just getting by. If it did, Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, surely would have won a gold medal this week. Despite his declaration of victory over bribery and corruption at the close of the organization's meeting yesterday, the actions and reforms ratified were quite meager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILL, MARGARET ALICE NEE TULLER
description: DILL-Margaret Alice nee Tuller, 84, of Rumson, N.J. on Saturday, March 13, 1999. Wife of John H. Dill, Mother of John Colby and James Tuller Dill, Grandmother of Donald D. and Lucas Alexander Dill. Services and interment are private at the convenience of the family. For information contact John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave, Red Bank, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STILLMAN, NED
description: STILLMAN-Ned Miss you very much. Rest in peace. Your Be

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Unseen Risks For a Buyer Of Nissan
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. has been painting a grim picture of the Nissan Motor Company's balance sheet -- or rather, what is absent from it.

title: Minority Law Clerks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZADRA, ROSE
description: ZADRA-Rose, 84 years. Died on March 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Marlene and Gerald Posner, and Robert and Phyllis Zadra. Cherished grandmother of Heather, Garwin, Gabrielle and Jaime. Dearest sister of Jerry and Lou Akawie. Graveside services on Friday, 11:30 A.M. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Service for Sadie Delany
description: A memorial service for Sarah (Sadie) Delany, whose long, active life with her sister Dr. A. Elizabeth (Bessie) Delany in the South and Harlem became the subject of a best-selling book, will be held at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow. Miss Delany died on Jan. 25 at age 109.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FLORA DAVIS
description: BERNSTEIN-Flora Davis, loved by all who knew her. Mother of Karen and Lucille. Grandmother of Katharine, Barbara, Michael and Melissa. Beloved by Larry Goldberg, her son-in-law. A dedicated teacher and devoted friend. Memorial services at Plaza Memorial, Amsterdam & 91 St Friday,

title: Are Stock Fundamentals Passe?
