description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Spitzer's Inquiry
description: The police shooting last month of the West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is provoking ever-larger protests. Well-televised arrests at One Police Plaza trumpet the message that many New Yorkers believe the steep drop in crime has been accompanied by an increase in police harassment of minorities. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says the demonstrations are being conducted ''for a highly partisan political purpose.'' But it is also true that nonviolent sit-ins have become an established form of dissent when communities confront polarizing issues, and orderly protests can challenge elected officials to respond to civic concerns they might otherwise ignore. The fact that the American Jewish Committee has joined with black officials in questioning police conduct shows that worries about New York's policing practices cross racial lines.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Collecting; And Your Neighbors Better Be Nice
description: COLLECTORS of vintage military vehicles can drive around with all the bravado of Gen. George S. Patton, confident that the objects of their affection were built to last. After all, going to war is the ultimate in endurance testing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, DAVID
description: BERG-David. YAD VASHEM, The Remembrance Authority in Jerusalem, its board and the officers of the International and American Society for Yad Vashem are saddened by the death of David Berg. We mourn the passing of our esteemed Honorary Vice President and Benefactor of Yad Vashem. David Berg was a a man of high principles and great wisdom who strongly believed that the legacy of the Shoah must be carried forward for future generations. We extend our condolences to his daughter Betsy and all the family. Eli Zborowski, Chairman, American and International Societies for Yad Vashem Dr. Josef Burg and Avner Shalev, Chairmen Yad Vashem, Jerusalem

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With Liszt
description: ALL right, so the Music of the Future that Franz Liszt cooked up with his cronies speaks less powerfully to the present than, say, Brahms's supposed music of the past. Still, Liszt's dynamic personality, by turns voluptuary and ascetic, retains its hold on the contemporary imagination as the veritable embodiment of Romantic genius. And his flamboyant musical style, with its juxtapositions of giddy virtuosity and solemnity, unabashed bombast and sobriety, to say nothing of its omnivorous use of folk sources and reuse of other composers' best tunes, paved the way for musical post-modernism as surely as Mahler's did.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Residential Real Estate; Jersey City Towers Broaden Lure of Living West of the Hudson
description: A 12-acre site at the southeastern corner of the giant Newport mixed-use development in Jersey City will soon be filled by the third of four rental buildings in the Towers of America complex, which is to have 1,640 units.

title: Foreign Affairs
description: I last visited Thailand 15 months ago as the country's economy was in a tailspin, on its way into the history books as the first domino of the 1997-98 global economic crisis. After revisiting Thailand for a couple of days, all I can say is: What a difference a year makes!

title: Joyce Kozloff
description: D. C. Moore Gallery

title: Drivers Are at Fault in Most Pedestrian Deaths, Study Reports
description: Despite the reputation of New Yorkers as reckless jaywalkers who routinely court death, a study released yesterday by a pedestrian-rights group found that drivers are responsible for the vast majority of accidents in which pedestrians are killed.

title: Stylish Fakes That Attract Connoisseurs
description: What is more valuable in the long run, style or authenticity? That question is increasingly redefining the rules of connoisseurship, especially in an era when a small folding table worth around $100 can bring more than $12,000 simply because Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis owned it.

title: Deal Said to Be in Works That Would Free Hacker
description: Kevin D. Mitnick, perhaps the nation's most notorious computer hacker, has reached a plea agreement with Federal prosecutors that could pave the way for his release from prison, people involved in the situation said.

title: Silicon Valley's Awesome Look at New Sony Toy
description: On a giant video screen, a lifelike rubber duck splashed about in a bathtub fleeing from a pursuing submarine. Suddenly the drain opened and both were swept into the resulting whirlpool.

title: Drama but no Gladiators in a Triple Concerto
description: How could one not love Richard Wilson? He starts out his program notes for his Triple Concerto, which had its first performance at the American Symphony Orchestra's concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday, by saying he had always hated the Beethoven work in the same genre. But now, as a fully fledged triple concerto composer himself, he has listened to Beethoven's work again and changed his mind. However: ''The improvement in my opinion of his piece is counter-balanced by a deterioration in confidence in my own effort.''

title: In State Dept. View, Envoy Did Not Lie to House
description: The State Department released internal documents this evening showing that it had concluded that a senior diplomat, who is the new special envoy to the Balkans, did not lie to Congress about death squads in Haiti. But the agency admonished him for not giving complete testimony.

title: New Profits in Old Bottles; Companies Find Bonus in Drugs That Cure Several Ills
description: Executives of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the pharmaceutical giant, said they were delighted to learn earlier this month that an independent study had found that one of their drugs was more effective for people trying to quit smoking than was the nicotine patch.

title: Tayeglu Journal; Again, Shunned Somalia Is Staring at Starvation
description: It took three days and one gun battle -- for the ratty caravan of trucks, piled with sacks of corn, to arrive here from a port near Mogadishu. When there is little rain, food is like money, and this caravan was guarded by no fewer than 132 young toughs with machine guns.

title: American Interests: Not a Bad Concept
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar slipped as a record United States trade deficit left more dollars with foreigners to convert into their home currencies. In New York, the dollar fell to 117.45 yen, from 118.01 on Wednesday.

title: Dow Again Tops 10,000, Then Slips
description: They huffed and they puffed, but United States stock traders still couldn't push the Dow Jones industrial average to close above 10,000 points yesterday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Aliens Ahead: Not Cute Or Cuddly Like E.T.
description: There are so many things to learn about the coming alien invasion. First, stay away from exclusive, secret downtown clubs in New York: everybody there is a space alien inhabiting a genetic duplicate of a human body. If you find yourself there anyway, do not let anyone nuzzle your ear, especially someone who might be hiding a worm in his or her mouth. This is how they infect you, downloading your DNA and your memories to make a duplicate of you. The only known solution is to drink blue agave tequila, which makes the worm leave your body.

title: The Adulterous General
description: By any standard, Maj. Gen. David Hale's adulterous conduct with the wives of four subordinates was a disgrace. Under military law, it was also a crime. On the eve of his court-martial, the retired general, after adamantly insisting on his innocence for months, agreed to plead guilty to eight counts of misconduct for committing adultery and lying to the Pentagon's deputy inspector general about it. He could have been punished with up to 11 years in prison. The sentence imposed by the judge at the court-martial -- a reprimand and an order to pay $22,000 in penalties -- is surprisingly light given the devastating effect his betrayals had on officers directly under his command.

title: On My Mind; A Return to India
description: When I was young in India, for four years I reported a story I wrote of as ''the great adventure'' and believed was one of the most important of our century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTS, CATHERINE HILLERY
description: WATTS-Catherine Hillery. Died March 12, 1999. She attended Wilberforce University and NYU. Her lifetime career in social work was with the NYC Dept. of Social Services in projects such as Womens Shelters, Home Care Operations and the Social Service Welfare Center. Catherine was a valued participant in the Wiltwyck School for Boys, Symphony of the New World, the Alpha Kappa Alpha's National Reading Project and the Queens Botanical Gardens. She leaves behind her devoted husband Joesph, sister-in-law Virginia, brother-in-law Frederick and eight nephews and nieces. Services were held on March 18 and she was interred at the Maple Grove Cemetery in Kew Gardens, NY.

title: Boxing's Breakdown
description: Many are still asking how the heavyweight fight held in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night could possibly have been declared a draw when Lennox Lewis clearly outboxed Evander Holyfield. Watching the bout on closed-circuit television, I scored nine rounds for Lewis and two for Holyfield, with one very close. When the decision was announced, my first reaction was, ''They are killing boxing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIJUR, HERBERT I.
description: BIJUR-Herbert I. Passed away peacefully on March 17, 1999 at age 88. A Haverford graduate with a successful career in retailing and publishing culminating in the position of President, McCalls Pattern Company. Avid orchid grower, active at the New York Botanical Garden and Bartlett Arboretum, Stamford, CT, flutist, fisherman & Mark Twain collector. Enriched the lives of family, friends and community. Survived by his wife, Marion, children Peter, Pricilla and Polly, and eight grandchildren. Services will be held privately. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Official Shock About Boxing Is Fishy, Too
description: POLITICIANS up and down the state have been venting their outrage over the heavyweight championship fight at Madison Square Garden last weekend, the one that the judges called a draw even though most spectators thought that Lennox Lewis had cleaned Evander Holyfield's clock.

title: British Mad Cow Disease Toll Rises, but the Cause Is Unclear
description: The number of people who have died in Britain from a human form of mad cow disease increased at an ''alarming rate'' at the end of last year, according to a scientific report being published in tomorrow's issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal.

title: Slimmer Version of Browser Is Rolled Out by Microsoft
description: The pitch was given on a stage designed to resemble a homey living room, but when Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, introduced a new version of his company's Web browser today, the most surprising new feature was all business.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC NAMES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Shares of the Boston Scientific Corporation rose more than 13 percent yesterday after the company, a medical device maker, said it had named James R. Tobin as its president and chief executive. Mr. Tobin had held those posts at Biogen Inc., until he resigned suddenly in December. Mr. Tobin, 54, replaces Pete Nicholas as chief executive. Mr. Nicholas, a founder of Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., will remain as chairman. At Biogen, Mr. Tobin was credited with introducing Avonex, now the best-selling multiple-sclerosis drug in the country. Boston Scientific stock closed up $4.50 a share, at $38.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Seahawks Close to Trading Draft Choice for Jets' Foley
description: Glenn Foley's career as a Jets quarterback is days, if not hours, from ending, but Foley may get in a trade what he could no longer get with the Jets -- the chance to compete for a starting assignment.

title: Shadowy Half-Lives Cavort With the Ghosts of Swing
description: Ghosts from several worlds and times inhabit Dean Moss's new ''Spooky Action at a Distance,'' performed on Wednesday night at the Kitchen. Most immediate are the ghosts embodied by Mr. Moss and his dancers, Kacie Chang and Marcelo Coutinho. Fred Astaire is seen as clearly, on a television monitor, putting on blackface for his ''shadow'' dance with Bill (Bojangles) Robinson in ''Swing Time,'' an inspiration for the piece.

title: Omnicom Names Chairman at TBWA
description: Omnicom Group in New York said yesterday that as expected it would name Lee Clow as chairman of its TBWA Worldwide unit, in addition to his title as chief creative officer. As chairman, Mr. Clow, who is 55, succeeds Bill Tragos, who retired.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a Finnish forensic team's report on the killings of 40 ethnic Albanians in Kosovo in January summarized remarks by the team leader, Dr. Helena Ranta, imprecisely. While she called the killings a crime against humanity and the report contradicts Serbian officials' accounts of the incident, she did not say the killings were committed by Serbs.

title: Long Lives for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Will Miss 6 to 12 Weeks Following Successful Surgery
description: The doctor who performed prostate cancer surgery today on Joe Torre deemed the two-and-a-half-hour procedure successful, said that he did not believe the cancer had spread and speculated that Torre would not be able to return and manage the Yankees for at least another 6 to 12 weeks.

title: Russian Panel to Review Prosecutor's Scandal
description: As the focus of Russia's latest political scandal shifted from corruption to sex, President Boris N. Yeltsin appointed a commission today to investigate the making and distribution of a videotape that showed the Prosecutor General in bed naked with two young women.

title: Mets Pitcher Dreaming Of Coaching Basketball
description: It is not unusual for a baseball player to want to go into coaching when his career is over. It is unusual, however, when the sport he wants to coach is basketball.

title: True Love as Windy, Leaky Shelter
description: Does Sandra Bullock's loopy girl-next-door charm really make audiences want to follow her anywhere? If so, they'd better be prepared for the amusement-park ride with senior citizens, the gay-bar strip scene and the antic hourslong romp through a K-mart that ''Forces of Nature'' so desperately offers.

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt
description: Here are some favorite Liszt recordings of the classical music critics of The Times. Compact disks range from $9.99 to $16.99 for one CD, to $18 to $24 for a three-CD set, to $53.64 for a package of seven. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: 157 Homes Burned in Religious Clash in India
description: Less than two months after a Hindu mob killed a Christian missionary from Australia and his two young sons here in the eastern state of Orissa, Hindus and Christians clashed in a village this week, and 157 of the 250 Christian homes were burned down, state officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the potential costs of a proposed Second Avenue subway line misstated the year the Second Avenue elevated line was demolished. It was 1942, not 1956.

title: Gucci Reports 11% Increase in Earnings
description: Gucci Group N.V. reported an 11 percent increase in fiscal year 1999 earnings today and said the strong results showed that the Italian fashion house needed no help from LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods maker that is trying to take it over.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Soars To Almost $17 Billion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMEISTER, RALPH F.
description: HOFFMEISTER-Ralph F. On March 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Kovach). Devoted father of Patricia Toney and Noreen. Loving grandfather of Kevin Toney. Father-in-law Gene Toney. Reposing at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10AM at Most Holy Redeemer Church, 173 East 3rd Street. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Breast-Feeding Is Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson Is Seeking An Early Release
description: Under a proposal his lawyers have been discussing with the fighter's judge and prosecutor, Mike Tyson could be released from jail as early as next Friday.

title: John Bock
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Outsider in a Passionate Land
description: There he is, unmistakably, the Englishman abroad: stiff, self-conscious, bewildered, amused, always polite and always a bit embarrassed. His hands are locked tensely over his midriff; his smile is eager and uneasy. You've seen his kind before, probably, furrowing their brows over unpronounceable items on menus, making jokes over not knowing the word for water closet.

title: In Keyboard Rhapsody With a Flamboyant Liszt
description: Here are some favorite Liszt recordings of the classical music critics of The Times. Compact disks range from $9.99 to $16.99 for one CD, to $18 to $24 for a three-CD set, to $53.64 for a package of seven. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I honestly think for her to be taking the next broad step of calling folks like me, that's more than sticking your toe in the water.''

title: The Sorrows of Goethe: A Creepy East German Tale
description: ''My peace is gone,'' Gretchen sighs as she contemplates her woes in Goethe's ''Faust.'' So too, it seems, is that of the great poet who created her.

title: A Dialogue Between East and West
description: THE MONK AND THE PHILOSOPHER

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Wood Fires
description: Wood is the primal cooking fuel. No matter how far kitchen technology has advanced since the first meat was cooked, through coal, charcoal, gas and electricity, chefs have never turned their backs on the simple wood fire. Here are a dozen restaurants that still use this most old-fashioned of methods. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Walter D. Scott, 84, Ex-Chief Who Spread NBC's Use of Color
description: Walter Decker Scott, who stepped down as chairman of NBC in 1974 after a 36-year career that spanned the heyday of network radio and TV's golden age, died on March 12 at Carmel Valley Manor, a retirement home in Carmel, Calif. He was 84.

title: If Rodgers and Hammerstein Had Written for Looney Tunes
description: In the middle of a storm at sea, Anna, her son and several sailors sing and march around to ''I Whistle a Happy Tune.'' This completely freaks out the fire-breathing sea monster who was attacking them, and it goes away.

title: Popular Intellectual Magazine Is Shut in Crackdown by Beijing
description: The authorities have shut down a popular intellectual magazine here for ''reorganization,'' the latest move in an uneven tightening of controls over liberal publications.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUNGES. Coffee prices fell after truck drivers in Colombia ended a strike that had disrupted shipments from the world's second-largest grower. In New York, coffee for May delivery fell 4.55 cents a pound, to $1.0265.

title: Judge Says Her View Was Obstructed in Title Bout
description: The judge who scored Saturday night's heavyweight unification bout in Evander Holyfield's favor sat in a witness chair yesterday and watched a videotape of the fight's fifth round. Eugenia Williams scored the round for Holyfield despite Lennox Lewis's decisive edge in punches landed. Of the other two judges, one voted for Lewis and the other called it a draw, and the fight resulted in a draw.

title: House Joins Senate in Voting for System to Defend Against Missiles
description: Following the Senate's lead, the House today decisively approved a bill to field a system to defend the country against a limited long-range missile attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JACK
description: KAYE-Jack. Of Coconut Creek, Florida, died on March 17, 1999. Formerly of Sunnyside, Queens. He was a former labor arbitrator with ILGWU. Survived by his wife Minna, daughter Letitia Ciolkowski, two grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.

title: Contract Is Awarded as Part of Effort to Upgrade Channels for Supertankers
description: In the first phase of a long-awaited project to make New York Harbor accessible to huge ships, the Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a $23.6 million contract to an Illinois company to begin dredging a 1.5-mile section of Kill van Kull, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Frantic Rush For 'Jeeves'
description: The closing of ''Band in Berlin'' at the Helen Hayes this weekend has set off rampant speculation about the next tenant at the theater, Broadway's smallest.

title: Consumer Prices Held Almost Steady in February
description: Consumer prices barely budged in February as reductions in apparel, automobile and fuel oil costs almost canceled out small increases in food and medical care expenses, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Budget Committees Pass Property-Tax Relief Plan
description: Budget committees of the State Senate and Assembly approved Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's property-tax relief plan yesterday over objections by some Democrats and taxpayer advocates.

title: Credit Lyonnais Reports Tripling of Profit
description: The French bank Credit Lyonnais said yesterday that its profit more than tripled in 1998, rising to 165 million euros ($181.6 million) from 54 million euros a year earlier. But net banking income was down 4.7 percent, at 6.69 billion euros, due mainly to divestments of European subsidiaries. Credit Lyonnais said it expects profitability to rise in all business areas in 1999.

title: Gun Producers' Use of a Safety Device Is Called Erratic
description: It is an accident that safety experts say does not have to happen: A person picks up a semiautomatic pistol, takes out the magazine containing the cartridges and, thinking the weapon is empty, squeezes the trigger and shoots himself or someone else.

title: South Korea's Jobless Rate Rises to 8.7%
description: South Korea's jobless rate rose to a record 8.7 percent in February, in line with expectations, as manufacturers and contractors scaled back hiring.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WOMEN; Rutgers Is Peaking on Time And Has a Vision of a Title
description: As Rutgers prepared to leave this week for Normal, Ill., the site of the Midwest Regional, not one player or coach appeared excited. Clearly, the expectation had surpassed the elation of making it to the Round of 16 for the second consecutive year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. On March 15, 1999 at the age of 94. A distinguished attorney in practice for more than 70 years, he is survived by many devoted friends. Service and interment private. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Court Told of Draft Indictment That Included the First Lady
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was named in an indictment drafted by a top aide to Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, but the document was never presented to a grand jury and no charges were brought against the First Lady, the aide testified in Federal District Court here today.

title: Are Stock Fundamentals Passe?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Official Questions How Russia Used Loan
description: The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, told a Congressional panel today that he suspected that much of the $4.8 billion in loans sent to Russia last summer by the International Monetary Fund ''may have been siphoned off improperly.''

title: With One Injury Too Many, Foley Becomes a Seahawk
description: Glenn Foley acknowledged yesterday that his chance to be the Jets' starting quarterback under Coach Bill Parcells ended when another injury sidelined him after the team's second game last season.

title: INSIDE
description: Lethal Bombing in Russia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALATUCCI, ELEANOR (NEE CUNNION)
description: PALATUCCI-Eleanor (nee Cunnion). On March 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Armond L. Loving father of A. Theodore, Richard L., Jeanne Crosson, Joseph M., John F.X. and the late Christine Palatucci Smith. Adored grandmother of 12. Devoted sister of the Reverend Theodore Cunnion, S.J. Reposing Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10 AM St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bronxville. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUITTMAN, HERMAN Z.
description: QUITTMAN-Herman Z. The World Confederation of United Zionists extend their deepest condolences to the family of Herman Z. Quittman, a great Zionist leader, member of the Zionist Executive and Honorary Fellow appointed by the Confederation. Kalman Sultanik, Co-President Marlene Post, Co-President

title: Taking Jokes By Duchamp To Another Level of Art
description: In 1913, a decade before Marcel Duchamp gave up art for chess, he took a bicycle wheel into his studio and mounted it on a stool. He liked to watch it spin. The next year he took home a bottle rack. In a letter to his sister, Suzanne, he said it was a sculpture ''already made.'' For the next few years he collected common, mass-produced objects, treated them as art and called them readymades: a snow shovel (which he named ''In Advance of the Broken Arm''), a urinal (''Fountain''), a hat rack, a comb and a dozen or so more.

title: Monitors and Embassy Staff Told to Leave Yugoslavia
description: International monitors were ordered today to pull out of Kosovo, and Western embassies ordered their nonessential staff to leave Yugoslavia after peace talks here collapsed. NATO has renewed threats to bomb unless President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia accepts a peace plan for Kosovo.

title: One Consolation for Clinton: Democratic Donations Surge
description: President Clinton's impeachment appears to have a silver lining, or at least a green one.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday for a performance by the Desoff Choirs tonight at 8 at Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan misstated the name of the John Corigliano piece on the program. It is ''Fern Hill,'' not ''Farm Hill.''

title: VENATOR GROUP GIVEN $400 MILLION CREDIT LINE
description: Venator Group Inc., the top United States retailer of athletic shoes and clothing, said yesterday that it had received a $400 million revolving line of credit in an amended agreement with its banks. The company, the former Woolworth Corporation, which operates the Foot Locker and Champs Sports chains, said the agreement modified some financial covenants and included restrictions on its dividends, stock buybacks and capital expenditures. Venator had to amend its credit agreement before a waiver expired yesterday, because of a wider-than-expected third-quarter loss and costs related to store sales and closings. The retailer, which has about 5,900 stores, was hurt by weak sales and price markdowns much of the last year, in part because of heightened competition.

title: Uniforms Are Same, but St. John's Game Is Different
description: Who is this team in the St. John's uniforms that is on the verge of going to the Final Four, and where has it hidden the group that stumbled through the end of the regular season just two weeks ago?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Make no mistake. If we and our allies do not have the will to act, there will be more massacres. In dealing with aggressors in the Balkans, hesitation is a license to kill. But action and resolve can stop armies and save lives.''

title: Marian Searchinger Theatrical Agent, 81
description: Marian Searchinger, a New York theatrical agent, died on Monday at a convalescent home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 81.

title: The Cabala and Messianism, A Match Made in Heaven; From Celebrities to Zionists, an Endless Source of Solace
description: For centuries the study of the cabala, the Jewish mystical tradition, could be undertaken only by married men over 40 who had mastered other aspects of Jewish law and learning. If anybody else delved into this esoteric lore with its arcane symbols and doctrines, the promised result was insanity.

title: 2 Bodies Found in Trunk of Women's Burned Car in California
description: There was still hope on Thursday when the rental car of three missing tourists to Yosemite National Park was found after a month of searching. But today, just hours after relatives appeared on news programs to say they remained optimistic that the women would turn up, the authorities announced here that two bodies, burned beyond recognition, were found in the car's trunk.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Abroad at Home; In Credibility Gulch
description: Over the last year the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have repeatedly warned and threatened Slobodan Milosevic. Stop your assaults on the people of Kosovo, we have told the Yugoslav President, or we will carry out air attacks on Serbian forces there and elsewhere in Serbia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, IRWIN H.
description: KAISER-Irwin H. The Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine records with pride the long life and distinguished career of its colleague Professor Emeritus Irwin H. Kaiser, MD. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara and to their children and grandchildren. Dr. Kaiser's career was noteworthy because of his probing intellect and productive scholarship. He was a stimulating and challenging educator, a patient advocate, and an outstanding physician. He defended the rights of women in their access to health care. Dr. Kaiser will be especially remembered for his integrity. Irwin R. Merkatz, MD Professor and Chairman Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: After Attacking a Sprinkler, Love Ties for Bay Hill Lead
description: It was a successful day for Davis Love 3d, but an embarrassing one as well.

title: 2 Passers-By Help Families To Escape Building Fire
description: Residents of a five-story walk-up on the West Side of Manhattan fled their building yesterday after two passers-by climbed the fire escape, banging on windows to alert them to a fire that had broken out on the top floor.

title: New-Generation, but Noisy, Australian Submarines Under Attack
description: SYDNEY  It was touted as the most advanced nonnuclear submarine in the world  a silent, potent leviathan capable of staying submerged for 70 days and patrolling over long distances.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's preparations for a possible Senate campaign referred incorrectly to the accommodations for a group of New Yorkers who recently stayed overnight at the White House. Two guests -- State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and his wife, Dr. Joyce Brown -- indeed slept in the Lincoln Bedroom.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the House's passage of a bill to create a missile defense system misstated the final vote. It was 317 to 105, not 371 to 105.

title: Middle Age Crazy, and Ready to Show It
description: Watching Susan Sarandon loosen up is always fun. Her classic transformation was, of course, eight years ago in ''Thelma and Louise.'' On the road, she traded hair spray, high-collared blouses and ladylike repression for jeans, a ponytail and a spree of feminist retaliation and almost justifiable crime, her windburned but glowing-with-freedom face to the sun. Ms. Sarandon's metamorphosis tonight on the HBO film ''Earthly Possessions'' isn't nearly so satisfying, but it has its own charm. Don't let the fact that she seems to be playing her early scenes as Edith Bunker throw you; the movie gets much better.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENBERG, LARRY
description: EISENBERG-Larry. 1952-1993. Not a day goes by when you're not part of our life. Mother and Arlene

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Saturday with articles about the entry of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into NATO misspelled the given name of Poland's Foreign Minister. He is Bronislaw Geremek, not Bronislav.

title: '400 Years' in Irish Jail Lasts Just 16 Months
description: Four Irish Republican Army guerrillas convicted of terrorist crimes were sentenced today to a total of 400 years in prison by a judge in Belfast, Northern Ireland. But under the terms of the Northern Ireland peace agreement approved last year, they will be freed by July 2000.

title: And Now, The Salmon War
description: Unlike other environmental crises here in the Pacific Northwest, the salmon crisis is one none of us can escape.

title: G.M. and VW to Increase Output in Brazil
description: The General Motors Corporation and Volkswagen A.G. plan to increase production in Brazilian factories, providing signs of life in the country's struggling auto industry.

title: Jean Pierre-Bloch, 93, Is Dead; Resistance Fighter for France
description: Jean Pierre-Bloch, a French Resistance figure, high-ranking member of de Gaulle's Free French movement during World War II and spokesman for human rights causes, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Paris. He was 93.

title: Maybe Colleges Don't Want to Play Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NATHAN
description: GOODMAN-Nathan. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Phyllis and the entire family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 1.6% on New York Exchange
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange increased 1.6 percent last month to 3.68 billion shares, the exchange said yesterday.

title: Adventures In Retailing; A Successful Outfitter Ranges Beyond Its Territory
description: On their way to a fishing tournament in Oklahoma last June, the 12 members of Zimbabwe's national fishing team stopped at this city of 150,000 on the edge of the Ozarks. The reason? To visit Bass Pro Shops Outdoor World, a sportsman's paradise whose inventory of fishing and hunting equipment is as wide as all outdoors.

title: Clinton Says Force Is Needed to Halt Kosovo Bloodshed
description: Preparing the American public for military action in the Balkans, President Clinton said today that the Serbs had crossed the threshold of acceptable behavior and that force was the answer to prevent further bloodshed in Kosovo.

title: BELIEFS
description: ''To draw, paint or sculpt the crucifixion is a terrifying experience,'' Charles McCollough says, ''for the artist must feel some bit of the horrible pain and humiliation of being hung up to die.''

title: Balloonists Close In on Goal: Around the World Nonstop
description: The Breit ling Orbiter 3 balloon was less than one day's flying time tonight from achieving what had thwarted balloonists for two centuries: a nonstop voyage around the world.

title: Mayor Can't Ignore Police Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICATTO, MARY
description: RICATTO-Mary. On March 18, 1999. Devoted wife of Michael Sr. Loving mother of Mike Jr. and daughter-in-law Julia. Beloved grandmother of Michael III, John, Patricia Fernandez, Vincenzo Ricatto and Santino Ricatto. Cherished sister of Frances Laporta. Reposing at the Fredericks Funeral Home, Saturday and Sunday, 25pm & 7-10pm. Northern Blvd & 193rd St, Flushing, NY. Mass Monday, Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 9:30am. Entombment Saint Johns Cemetery.

title: Preventing Railroad Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FRACMASTER LTD., -- Calgary, Alberta, an oilfield services company, sought court protection from creditors, as it rebuilds after an unsuccessful search for a buyer.

title: Man Gets Life Terms In Killing and Assault
description: A Burlington Township man who was convicted of killing his girlfriend with a hatchet and then sexually assaulting her 14-year-old daughter was sentenced yesterday to two consecutive life terms in prison, county prosecutors said.

title: Drunken Driving Charge for Firefighter in Fatality
description: An off-duty New York City firefighter was charged with drunken driving after striking another car on Staten Island early yesterday morning and fatally injuring a woman on her way home from work, the police said.

title: After Sign Falls in Wind, City Orders Others Moved
description: The city's Department of Buildings ordered the owner and manager of 1 Times Square yesterday to remove four mammoth advertisements that are similar to the one that tore loose in high winds on Thursday, injuring three women and creating traffic chaos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, MORRIS, M.D.
description: BLOCK-Morris, M.D. The faculty and staff of the NYU Medical Center and NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of Morris Block, Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine. Dr. Block was a longtime member of the faculty and a 1927 graduate of the School of Medicine. An expert on pneumococcal pneumonia, he was a member of various medical societies and a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa Bischoff, President, NYU Hospitals Center

title: Lilly to Stop Developing Migraine Drug
description: Eli Lilly & Company announced yesterday that it would end development of an experimental migraine drug that had been billed as a promising new method to treat the monster headaches.

title: A Russian Among Russians
description: Yuri Temirkanov, the Russian conductor who is to take over as music director of the Baltimore Symphony next season, devoted his New York Philharmonic program on Thursday evening to works by two of his countrymen, Rodion Shchedrin and Igor Stravinsky, composers whose works both draw on Russian musical traditions and stretch toward a more cosmopolitan ideal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, A. DOAK
description: BARNETT-A. Doak. The Board of Directors, Members, and Staff of the National Committee on United States-China Relations mourn the passing of A. Doak Barnett, esteemed colleague, distinguished scholar, and dear friend. A founding member of the National Committee, Professor Barnett helped guide us over the past 33 years, serving as Chairman 1968-1969, Director, and most recently Vice Chairman. His wisdom, knowledge, spirit, and friendship will be profoundly missed.

title: Strawberry's Treatment Causes Confusion
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, ordered General Manager Brian Cashman to return to the team's complex in Tampa today after hearing that Darryl Strawberry was upset and feeling left out of the club's plans.

title: Met's 'Queen of Spades' With a Domingo Trump
description: When a new production at the Metropolitan Opera returns a few seasons after its premiere, the company understandably cannot commit the same amount of rehearsal to it as when it was new. This probably explains why the performance of Tchaikovsky's ''Queen of Spades'' on Thursday night, the first of the season, lacked some of the dramatic flow and vivid detail that characterized this Elijah Moshinsky production when it was unveiled in 1995.

title: Court is Still Studying Auto Insurance Reform
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday failed to reach a decision on challenges to key components of New Jersey's auto insurance reform law, which was scheduled to take effect on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENAWALT, MARTHA S.
description: GREENAWALT-Martha S. The Members of the League of Women Voters mourn the passing of our leader, mentor and dear friend. Martha was President of the Greenburgh, Westchester, N Y State, and Tri-State leagues, a LWVUS Board Member and a life Member of the Scarsdale LWV. We extend deepest sympathies to her family and friends and to all those who lives she touched. Evelyn Stock, Pres., LWVNYS Jo Brill, Pres., LWVWestchester Marcia Kusnetz, Pres., LWV Scars.

title: Injured Bonilla Might Miss Opener
description: A magnetic resonance imaging test of Bobby Bonilla's right knee today revealed that his posterior cruciate ligament has a 15 percent tear, an injury that will keep the Mets' starting right fielder out of the lineup for the next 10 days to 2 weeks.

title: Lehman Results Are Better Than Expected
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., one of Wall Street's largest bond traders, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose a better-than-expected 13 percent as rallies in the bond and stock markets swelled income from trades and commissions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, MYRA
description: FEIN-Myra. Beloved wife of Skippy (Franklin). Loving mother of Mindy and Alan Delman, Jayne and Neil Kirby and Lisa and Keith Lipstein. Cherished grandmother of Erica, Jonathan and Andy Delman, Michael and Peter Kirby and Emily and Sophie Lipstein. Dear sister of Jay and Marty Goldberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 P.M. Sunday.

title: Mayor Can't Ignore Police Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge's Ruling Clears Way for Hoffa to Be Sworn In as Teamsters President
description: A Federal judge cleared the way yesterday for James P. Hoffa to be sworn in as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, 42 years after his famous father took the helm of the powerful truckers' union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LEONORA
description: GORDON-Leonora. Devoted wife of the late Nash. Most dearly beloved mother of Marjorie Pacheco and Louis Gordon, mother-in-law to Joe and Amy. Loving grandmother of Jennifer and Michael, loving aunt and friend. Family was everything to her and she was everything to her family.

title: Experimental School Is in Jeopardy
description: The West Side Community School, a tiny experimental program on the fifth floor of an old school building on West 93d Street, is like no other public school in New York City.

title: Judge Rules L.I. Utility Is Not Entitled to Rebates
description: A State Supreme Court judge ruled today that the Long Island Power Authority was not entitled to collect nearly $800 million plus interest in property tax rebates that was owed to its predecessor, the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Europe Pay-TV Provider Expects Profit This Year
description: The shares of Canal Plus S.A. rose 6 percent yesterday after the company, Europe's biggest pay-television concern, forecast it would return to profit in 1999 as its satellite TV service breaks even. The stock rose 5.05 euros, to 90.15 euros ($98.54). Canal Plus made the forecast Thursday night when it confirmed it lost 185 million francs in 1998.

title: Progress in Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL TO BUY PINNACLE BANC
description: The Old Kent Financial Corporation, a financial services group, agreed yesterday to buy Pinnacle Banc Group in a $243 million deal it said would further strengthen its Chicago-area franchise. Pinnacle, based in Oak Brook, Ill., has 13 branches. The deal accompanies Old Kent's pending acquisition of CFSB Bancorp, which is based in Lansing, Mich. Under the transaction Pinnacle shareholders will receive 0.717 Old Ken share for each Pinnacle share. Old Kent, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich., operates 235 banking offices in Michigan, Illinois and Indiana. In Nasdaq trading, Pinnacle Banc Group shares jumped $2.3125, to $29.50, while Old Kent Financial was down $1.5625 a share, at $43.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRENADIER, GEORGE
description: GRENADIER-George, 83. Of Westport, CT, on March 18, 1999. Founder and president of Grenadier Corp of New York City. Predeceased by his wife, Hindel (''Del'') Kronick Grenadier in 1998. Loving father of Lisa Grenadier and Tom Connor of Southport, CT, Michael Grenadier of New York City, James Grenadier of Austin, TX; cherished brother of Simon Grenadier of New Rochelle, NY, and adoring grandfather of three. Services Monday, 11 a.m., at Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd, Fairfield, CT. Interment will follow at Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT.

title: Enron and Qatar Cancel a Gas Project
description: The Enron Corporation, one of the world's largest energy companies, and the Qatar Government have canceled plans to build a $4 billion liquefied natural-gas plant after three years of talks.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Gerhard Herzberg, 94, Nobel Winner for Molecular Research
description: Dr. Gerhard Herzberg, winner of the 1971 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for research into the structure of molecules, died on March 3 at his home in Ottawa. He was 94.

title: Looking for a Quick $500 Million From Governors Island
description: The Federal budget is chock-full of them every year: sources of revenue based more on wishful thinking than hard-headed analysis. They help balance the budget on paper, though they may not produce a dime. One of them happens to be a historic island in New York Harbor.

title: Albany Notes; Unusual Enemies Arise In Budget Skirmishing
description: The Democrats who control the State Assembly have long been staunch allies of the health care industry, but this week the two groups turned on each other in an unexpected row over the state budget.

title: Clinton Voices Anger and Compassion at Serbian Intransigence on Kosovo
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today at the White House, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Happiness Without Pills
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK BOTTOM RESTAURANTS IN BUYOUT AGREEMENT
description: Rock Bottom Restaurants Inc. agreed yesterday to a management-led buyout of $10 a share, or $58.3 million in cash. RB Capital Inc., an investor group led by Frank B. Day, who is Rock Bottom's chairman, president and chief executive, agreed to buy the 72 percent of the company it does not already own. Rock Bottom, based on Louisville, Colo., owns and operates 62 restaurants that feature microbrews and specialty beers. It had revenue of $160.1 million in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, EDITH
description: STERNBERG-Edith, 75. Of Bronx, New York. Devoted wife of the late David. Cherished and beloved mother of Elizabeth & Ernest and Jeanie & Andrew. Loving grandmother of David, Josh and Eric. Caring sister & aunt. A Holocaust survivor-the source of strength to all her family. Services Sunday 10:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mayor Can't Ignore Police Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Ewing Puts Fear Factor On Knicks' Side Again
description: Patrick Ewing did not break his long, loping stride as he pushed through the practice facility door like a gunslinger leaving a saloon. He departed as the strong and almost silent type.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMONT, STEPHEN
description: ELMONT-Stephen of Boston, International Food Consultant, on March 18. Husband of Linda J. Schwabe and son of Maxine Elmont and the late Stanley. Services at Temple Israel, Boston on Sunday, March 21 at 3:00PM.

title: SYNOVUS FINANCIAL TO PURCHASE MERIT HOLDING
description: The Synovus Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Merit Holding Corporation for $109 million in stock, expanding its banking business around Atlanta. Synovus, based in Columbus, Ga., agreed to pay 1.0529 shares for each share of Merit, which is in Tucker, Ga. That values Merit at $23.29 a share based on yesterday's closing price for Synovus. Merit rose $3.8125, or 20 percent, to $23. Merit owns Mountain National Bank, based in Tucker, and the Charter Bank and Trust Company in Marietta, Ga., The two banks together have $306 million in assets and six offices. Synovus has $10.5 billion in assets and owns 36 banks in Georgia, Alabama, Florida and South Carolina. Synovus shares fell 81.25 cents, to $22.125.

title: Treasuries Are Sharply Lower In Advance of AT&T Offering
description: Treasury bond prices posted their biggest loss in two weeks on speculation the AT&T Corporation would increase its bond sale from the $6 billion or more already planned.

title: Springsteen Infuses Asbury Park; He Helps Some Recall Youth or Resort's Faded Glory
description: When Ed Gubitosa and his wife, Grace, learned that Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band would be giving a sneak preview of their first concert tour in more than a decade, they dropped everything.

title: VIACOM AGREES TO BUY REST OF SPELLING ENTERTAINMENT
description: Viacom Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the 20 percent of Spelling Entertainment Group Inc. that it did not already own for $9 a share in cash. With about 93 million shares outstanding, the remaining stake in Spelling Entertainment, the producer of such hit TV shows as ''Melrose Place'' and ''Beverly Hills 90210'' is worth about $167 million. Spelling Entertainment shares climbed by $2.25 each, or 33 percent, to $9. Viacom, which owns MTV Networks, Nickelodeon and Showtime Networks, said it intended to consolidate Spelling Entertainment with Paramount Television Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, DANIEL G.
description: FORBES-Daniel G. Fortunoff. It is with great sadness that we mark the sudden loss of our dear brother Dan at age 81. He lived an interesting, exciting and fulfilling life, and will be long remembered for his kind and generous nature. May he rest in peace. Everett and Isabel Fortunoff Gilbert and Isabel Fortune

title: Realistic School Standards
description: The school standards movement is being undermined by a failure of political will. In state after state, politicians pander to the public with tough new standards and tests -- while failing to provide qualified teachers or the rudimentary labs necessary to prepare students adequately. When students fail the new tests, parents explode in outrage and the standards are eased, feeding the impression that public schooling is worthless and that some children can never learn.

title: A New Arena For Islanders Hits a Snag
description: With Nassau County worrying about growing debt and the owner of the New York Islanders thinking about football, plans for a new Nassau Coliseum for the hockey team are in doubt.

title: Free of Mob Taint, Union Swears In Leader
description: Marking an end to 13 years of Federal overview of what was once one of the nation's most corrupt union locals, Peter Brown was sworn in today as president of Local 560 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLADE, WERNER, M.D.
description: BLADE-Werner, M.D. On March 16 at age 87. Beloved husband of Erna Schwab Blade. Loving father of Linda Blade Diesso. Captain in the US Air Force during the 2nd World War. Services private.

title: New Yorkers Riveted by Dow's Dance With 10,000
description: As the soaring stock market approached a new milestone early this week, Richard K. Anderson Jr. decided exactly what he would say when the widely watched Dow Jones industrial average ended the day above 10,000. Because that moment would be both important and ''cool,'' he said, he planned to shout, ''Yes!'' -- which sounds like what he says when he reaches a new level in Donkey Kong.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Washington Journal; Old-Fashioned Cafeteria Edging Toward Oblivion
description: How about the liver and onions for $2.25? Or fried whiting, the most expensive entree on the menu, for $3.95? For dessert, the pudding will set a diner back only 65 cents, or he can splurge, with homemade rhubarb pie for $1.65.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WOMEN; Again on the Threshold of 30 Victories, the Huskies Aim for a Higher Goal
description: Geno Auriemma has had a lot of success during his 14 years as the women's basketball coach at Connecticut. He has a .793 winning percentage and a 6-0 record in the Round of 16. His 1995 national championship team finished at 35-0.

title: Help Children Early
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: NO AGE LIMITS
description: Longer life expectancy and a growing older population are changing the meaning of retirement. Whether it's going back to college, discovering a talent for art or keeping one foot in the working world, there are almost as many ways to retire these days as there are retirees. Retirement: A special section.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOKES, MARGUERITE FARRINGTON
description: STOKES-Marguerite Farrington. On March 18, 1999 at age 100 years. First woman in the United States to have six Caesarean Sections between 1929-1939. Beloved wife of the late Christopher. Devoted mother of John, Christopher, Patricia Carroll, Jacqueline Schmidt, Audrey Parker and Marguerite Montuori. Loving grandmother of 25. Great-grandmother of 58. Great-great-grandmother of one. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 9:30 A.M. at Saint Thomas More Church, Breezy Point. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Sunday, 2-5 pm and 7-10 pm.

title: Mayor Can't Ignore Police Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Who Informed And Those Who Didn't
description: Sunday night, if all goes according to schedule, the legendary, brilliant director Elia Kazan will appear on the stage of the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. On Saturday afternoon, another legendary, brilliant director of Greek heritage, whose name is Andreas, will appear here on the stage of the George Street Playhouse, where he has been spending much time recently.

title: After Routing Purdue, Temple Faces Duke
description: The Temple Owls turned two Purdue technical fouls into a 10-point swing and had one of their best shooting performances of the year to drub the Boilermakers, 77-55, and reach the East Regional final.

title: Weehawken's Panoramic Skyline View Wins Protection
description: To thousands of New Jersey motorists and countless tourists bound for New York City, there is a magical panorama of the Hudson River and the Manhattan skyline from the helix ramps leading to the Lincoln Tunnel. It is only a brief, breathtaking glimpse (unless the traffic is stalled).

title: Ailing Farrakhan to Rest for Four Months
description: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, will take a four-month sabbatical to rest from treatment for prostate cancer and two severe bouts of the flu, his doctor said today.

title: Kentucky Against Szczerbiak Is No Contest
description: Wally Szczerbiak could not rescue Miami of Ohio one more time. He could not keep his and Miami's magical journey through March alive, not by himself. That is really what it amounted to tonight as Szczerbiak and four sometimes-invisible teammates fought Kentucky and lost, 58-43. The matchup was a mismatch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, LEWIS J.
description: SCHER-Lewis J. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Fresh Meadows, New York. Died on March 13, 1999. A memorial service was held in Florida. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Palm Beach County Florida Library System. Beloved husband of Marion; devoted father of Vicki and Seth; loving grandfather of Hilary; much loved brother of Jack & Belle; and treasured uncle of Paul. ''His life was gentle, and the elements so mixed in him, that nature might stand up and say to all the world, 'This was a man.'''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about A. Doak Barnett, the scholar and government adviser on China, misstated the day of his death. It was Wednesday, not Monday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones Industrials Fail To Close Above 10,000

title: Swisscom Withdrawing From Asian Operations
description: Swisscom A.G., the Swiss telecommunications company, conceded defeat yesterday in Asia, saying it would pull out of its costly investments in Malaysia and India, where in 1998 alone it lost 519 million Swiss francs. Swisscom is in talks with international and local companies interested in buying the units.

title: Judge Rules Guilty Plea Can't Be Withdrawn
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a man who had already admitted taking part in a fatal armed robbery attempt in 1996 cannot withdraw his guilty plea in order to pursue an insanity defense, Federal prosecutors said.

title: AT&T, British Telecom Said To Be Moving Into Japan
description: The AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. are close to buying a stake in the Japan Telecom Company, adding a third partner to their $10 billion alliance and speeding their entry in the Japanese market, a senior official at the Japanese company said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the News Watch column in Circuits on Thursday referred incorrectly to a recall by the Iomega Corporation. It affects the power supply units of some external Jaz disk drives, not the drives themselves.

title: Editorial Observer; Searching for Graves -- and Justice -- in Tulsa
description: The mention of mass graves brings to mind the genocidal wars that have bloodied Bosnia, Rwanda and Central America. But at its meeting yesterday, a state commission in Oklahoma discussed its search for mass burials along the Arkansas River in downtown Tulsa and elsewhere in the city. The panel, the Tulsa Race Riot Commission, was created by the state legislature in 1997 to investigate violence that swept the city in 1921. In less than one day, rioting whites killed perhaps as many as 200 to 300 black citizens, burned more than 1,000 residences and razed one of the most prosperous business districts in the Southwest.

title: The Merrill Steamroller Encounters Potholes
description: Juggernaut. Steamroller. Mother Merrill. Those are the nicknames most commonly associated with Merrill Lynch & Company, a brokerage firm that long ago decided that it wanted to be No. 1, or very close to it, in everything Wall Street does.

title: Paris Journal; The Teacher in Charge Is Taught a Thing or Two
description: Trying to change the education system in a country that fears any change is a thankless job, Claude Allegre, the feisty French Minister of Education, says with some exasperation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, REV. WALTER J.
description: SULLIVAN-Rev. Walter J., C.S.P. On March 18, 1999 at age 92, was born in East Pepperell, MA. Ordained a Paulist priest on June 15, 1935. During his sixty-four priesthood years he served: 19 years in mission work; eight years as Chaplain with the Army Air Corps & USAF; six years with the administrative and governing body of the Paulist Community; and 30 years in service to the people of Boston, MA. He was awarded the Bronze Star, a Presidential Citation with two clusters, and commendations from the 379th Bomb Group. Recalled during the Korean War he was attached to the 66th Recon, 38th Bomb Group. An accomplished author, Fr. Sullivan retained the rank of Lt. Col. in the Air Force Reserve. A wake will be held on Saturday and Sunday March 20-21 from 3 until 4:30 PM in the Paulist residence chapel, Park Street, Boston. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, March 22, 10am at the Paulist Park Street Center, Boston. Interment will be in East Pepperell, MA.

title: 2 European Media Giants to Form Network
description: Mediaset S.p.A., Italy's No. 1 commercial television company, and Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, said today that they had agreed to pool one billion euros ($1.1 billion) in assets to create the first pan-European television network.

title: Libya Sets Date for Turning Over 2 Suspects in Lockerbie Bombing
description: Libya told the United Nations today that it would hand over the two suspects in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing for trial in the Netherlands by April 6.

title: Preventing Railroad Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Says He Was Not Aware of Any Nuclear Spying During His Presidency
description: President Clinton said today that he was unaware of any espionage cases at the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories during his time in office, and defended his Administration's response to suspicions that China stole American nuclear secrets from one of the labs in the 1980s.

title: Bob Cato, 75, Designer of Covers for Albums
description: Bob Cato, a ground-breaking graphic designer who helped turn the record album cover into an important form of contemporary art, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giving a Holiday a Bad Reputation
description: The scrap-wood and two-by-four fires will start burning in the back streets and alleyways before dark, the acrid smoke attracting eager participants to the ancient rite long before the piles have been reduced to embers and the first man (or boy) leaps over, taking the jump between winter and spring.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the columnist Mike Barnicle's new job at The Daily News rendered a comment by a News columnist, Jim Dwyer, incorrectly. He said, ''Whatever about Mike Barnicle, the voice that really belongs in a daily newspaper in New York City is Pete Hamill,'' the newspaper's former editor. He did not say ''the voice that really belongs in The Daily News in New York City.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAPLAN, JOAN PLATOFF
description: CHAPLAN-Joan Platoff. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 21, 1999, 11 AM, Mt. Moriah Cemetery Chapel, Fairview, NJ.

title: Maybe Colleges Don't Want to Play Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: No Upset This Time As Duke Rolls Again
description: Southwest Missouri State's surprising journey through the men's college basketball tournament came to an end last night. The Bears, seeded 12th in the East Regional, hit a roadblock hard by the New Jersey Turnpike when they ran into top-rated Duke and lost by 78-61 at the Meadowlands.

title: Less Oversight Of Derivatives Is Supported By Greenspan
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the success of derivatives traded outside of exchanges suggested that United States futures markets could operate with less Government oversight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PINCUS, JOAN
description: PINCUS-Joan. You will always be loved and never forgotten. It's not the same without you. Barbara and Marty

title: Saudis Subsidize Iraqis' Pilgrimage, Defusing Feud With U.N.
description: A dispute between Iraq and the United Nations that threatened to prevent Iraqis from making the annual pilgrimage to Mecca was resolved today when Saudi Arabia said it would pay the Iraqis' expenses.

title: New Floods of Refugees Are on the Move
description: His house is only half built, and there is only one room that is habitable and warm, but Afrim Vojvoda, a young farmer, and his wife, Shyhrete, put up 49 people when refugees swarmed down the hill from neighboring villages two nights ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIJUR, HERBERT I.
description: BIJUR-Herbert I. The Board of The New York Botanical Garden is saddened by the loss of former colleague Herb Bijur. As Director of Special Projects, he was a fulltime volunteer for a full decade. We extend our condolences to his wife, son Peter Bijur, a Garden Board member, and his entire family. Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Gregory Long, President

title: OTHER ISSUES
description: NATO READIES ASSAULT -- Swift and intense strikes could lead to a more ambitious attack on Yugoslavia's tanks and heavy weapons. Page A6.

title: British Investment Trust Gets Unwelcome Bid
description: Electra Investment Trust P.L.C., a British venture capital company, rejected a takeover bid yesterday by 3i Group P.L.C. and advised its shareholders against selling their shares. Electra said the $:1.25 billion ($2.04 billion) offer made by 3i earlier in the day was inadequate.

title: Illuminating a Vast Realm of the Invisible
description: The great French mime, Marcel Marceau, returned triumphantly to New York on Thursday night and taught us again that the best of art is never literal.

title: Hong Kong Says Economy Shrank 5.7% in 4th Quarter
description: Confirming a dismal earlier prognosis, Hong Kong said today that its economy shrank an estimated 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 1998 and 5.1 percent over the whole year.

title: Spartans Beat Sooners in Brutal Battle
description: Michigan State survived tonight, barely and brutally.

title: Harlem Minister Urges Boycott to Protest Racism
description: A prominent Harlem minister called on African-Americans yesterday to boycott two shopping districts in New York City to demonstrate their economic strength and to protest racism that included ''the murderous behavior by police officers who kill unarmed blacks.''

title: The Urchin: No Chicken of the Sea but Surely Deserving of Praise
description: To Martin Wells, the grandson of H. G. Wells and a retired zoologist, dolphins are overrated and whales are not quite as smart as they are cracked up to be. Mr. Wells, you see, champions cephalods, those marine mollusks with varying numbers of arms, suckers and fin-bearing mantle. Here are excerpts from his book ''Civilization and the Limpet'' (Perseus Books, 1998).

title: Rejecting Lawyers' Advice, Teen-Ager Pleads Guilty to Killing a Boy
description: Over the objections of his parents and lawyers, 17-year-old Samuel Manzie pleaded guilty today to murdering a sixth grader in 1997 as the boy made door-to-door sales of candy and gift wrap for a school fund-raiser.

title: Smallpox Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Plan Calls for Widening Strikes on Air Defenses and Heavy Weapons
description: NATO's plans for attacking Yugoslavia include missile and air strikes that would begin with attacks against air defenses and would widen to more sustained strikes on tanks and other heavy weapons, NATO and Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTT, PETER GEORGE
description: MOTT-Peter George. 6/13/47 - 3/20/97 Together on this earth, 1260 days. But we are forever one. W.

title: CORNERSTONE REALTY REJECTS BID FROM INVESTOR
description: Cornerstone Realty Income Trust, an owner of apartment properties, has received and rejected an $11.50-a-share buyout offer from the investor Irwin Jacobs, Mr. Jacobs said yesterday. The stock of Cornerstone, a real estate investment trust based in Richmond, rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $10.0625. At that price the company's common stock has a total market value of more than $393 million. Cornerstone owns 58 properties in the South and Texas with 13,462 apartments. It manages another 27 properties with 7,034 apartments for an affiliate. Officials at Cornerstone did not return phone calls seeking comment.

title: Sports of The Times; A Chatty El-Amin Backing It Up
description: JIM CALHOUN is built like one of those enforcers who used to protect Bob Cousy in the old days. His speech is unadulterated Boston corner boy. But he looks at Khalid El-Amin, an Orthodox Muslim point guard from Minneapolis, with body by Teletubbies, and he sees a kindred soul.

title: A President Re-emerges
description: At his first full-dress news conference in 11 turbulent months, President Clinton showed yesterday what normalcy could be like. It was not especially newsworthy, which may have been a White House objective. Extremely cautious when discussing China and animated in outlining his economic program, the President referred many times to his 22 months left in office. But he also hinted that he had begun thinking about the more distant future, which could include living in New York. There was almost no talk of confrontation with the Republicans and no real moral or intellectual engagement with the conduct that brought about his impeachment. All told, from Mr. Clinton's point of view things went smoothly, leaving no reason for him not to return to a normal schedule of press conferences in the future.

title: Witness's Story Shifts With Language, Crash Investigators Say
description: As they wound down their investigation at the scene of Monday's deadly crash of an Amtrak train and a truck loaded with steel, Federal investigators said today that a language barrier might have caused them to misunderstand the description of the accident by their first witness. They now understand the witness to have said that he did not see the truck drive around a crossing gate before it was struck by the train.

title: Aon in 3-for-2 Stock Split
description: The Aon Corporation declared a 3-for-2 stock split today and increased its quarterly dividend to 31 cents on a presplit basis from 28 cents. Aon, a Chicago-based insurance holding company, said it would pay the split and the dividend on May 17 to stockholders of record on May 4. The company will pay the cash dividend on a presplit basis. The company also said it would repurchase up to 21 million shares on a post-split basis after April 1. Shares of Aon closed down 31.25 cents today, at $65.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: In Hong Kong, a Growing Sense That Tycoons Skew Competition
description: HONG KONG  On any morning, a typical resident here may wake up in an apartment developed by one of a handful of billionaire Hong Kong property owners, take a bus to work owned by one of the same tycoons, and make a mobile phone call along the way over a tycoon-owned network.

title: Hertz Workers Strike At Newark Airport
description: About 100 Teamsters employed by Hertz car rentals at Newark International Airport went on strike yesterday after the union's rank and file rejected an initial agreement last month and the company repeated the same offer on Wednesday, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCKE, JOHN
description: MENCKE-John. The directors, officers, and employees of the Berkshire Bank mourn the loss of our friend, an original incorporator of the bank, and a director for ten years. Your efforts, insight, devotion, and friendship will be missed, but never forgotten. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. The Berkshire Bank

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANN
description: MILLER-Ann. Dear wife of the late Robert Miller, died Friday, March 19th, 1999. Services at 10 AM, Sunday, March 21st, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam. Interment in Boston.

title: Maybe Colleges Don't Want to Play Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: Record's Pluses Outweigh Lie, President Says
description: President Clinton said today that when the final word was written on his legacy, he would have one strike against him -- for lying -- but ''hundreds and hundreds and hundreds'' of pluses for the times that he was truthful and had not abused his office.

title: About New York; Visit to Reef For Seafood Signals Spring
description: LIKE the namesake hibernators in her neck of the woods, Annie Ciabattoni spent the winter in her home near Bear Mountain dreaming of spring. So what if she was almost buried by a blizzard this week? Something told her that it was time to go to the Bronx and luxuriate in the sights and sounds of the impending season.

title: 4,000 Players Ring In Spring With Eyes on the Vanderbilt
description: Some 4,000 players are here at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, and more contestants are to come. The focus will be on the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, to begin Sunday. Most of the top teams include a player-sponsor, but there is a major exception from the New York area: Bob Blanchard, Jim Krekorian and Mark Feldman of Manhattan; Ron Gerard of White Plains, and Bill Pollack of Warren, N.J., with Drew Casen of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOBEL, HAROLD
description: SOBEL-Harold. November 24, 1922-March 20, 1981. There will never be another you. Bernice, Peter and Jonatha

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSDORF, BERNARD
description: NUSSDORF-Bernard. Died March 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth. Father of Stephen, Glen and Arlene. Adored father-in-law of Alicia, Claudine and Steve. Grandfather of Marni, Zachary, Jacob, Aaron, Julia, Ethan and Madeline. Brother of Matilda, Natalie and Herbert. Everyone's special friend. He touched the hearts of all of us and made the world a better place to be. We are thankful for the love and wisdom he gave and the memories we will cherish forever. Contributions may be made to the Brooklyn College Foundation, The Bernard Nussdorf Entrepreneur Scholarship, Brooklyn College, 2900 Bedford Ave, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11210. Service Sunday, 11:30AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, ANNE
description: RUBINSTEIN-Anne. 86. Family and friends wish to announce her death on Wednesday, March 17. Funeral Sunday, 11:00 AM, Weinstein Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: Suspect Found, but Not the Beanie Babies
description: The Beanie Baby Bandit is safely behind bars, the Suffolk County police said today. But the litter that was stolen from a Centerport stationery shop last month -- 200 floppy creatures with names like Gigi, Jake and Jabber -- appears to have been lost forever.

title: Show Goes On Despite Landlord-Tenant Feud
description: An acclaimed musical revue had its first performance at the Kit Kat Klub last night, hours after a judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan lifted an order that had delayed the performance for two days.

title: After Sex-Tape Attack on Prosecutor, Yeltsin Fires a 2d Aide
description: Less than two days after his Government's television network shocked pretty much everyone by broadcasting a videotape of Russia's chief prosecutor in bed with two women, President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed his chief of staff tonight.

title: Beukeboom Is Out for Season
description: Jeff Beukeboom, the big veteran defenseman of the Rangers, announced last night that he would take off the rest of the season to recover from post-concussion syndrome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, MELVIN N., DDS
description: BLAKE-Melvin N., DDS On behalf of the Faculty, we are saddened to learn of the loss of Melvin N. Blake, DDS, Clinical Professor of Pathology at Columbia University, on March 14, 1999. Dr. Blake was an esteemed member of the Columbia University Faculty for over 30 years & he was deeply devoted to the profession of dentistry and to the education of our dental students. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his brothers, Arnold & Ernest, to his sister Rhoda, and to his nieces and nephews. Memorial service April 11, 1999, 3PM Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. New York, New York. Dean Allan J. Formicola, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR DROPS 3.15 PERCENT. Sugar fell after a report that Brazil, the world's largest grower, increased exports while supplies are ample and demand is weak. Sugar for May delivery slid 0.18 cent a pound, to 5.54 cents.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO. The euro declined on concerns that the European Central Bank's failure to raise interest rates was hindering economic recovery in the 11-nation currency union. The euro slipped to $1.0892, from $1.097 Thursday.

title: For Kevorkian, a Fifth, but Very Different, Trial
description: Four times, prosecutors have tried to prove that Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the man who says he has presided over more than 130 suicides, committed a crime when he helped seriously ill people die.

title: No. 1 Duke Rolls Over a Bump in the Road
description: No. 1-ranked Duke came into the East Regional like a bullet train in a stagecoach race, beating its last 11 opponents by an average of 31 points.

title: Battle Erupts To Control Gucci Group
description: A battle for the famed Italian fashion house Gucci Group N.V. erupted today when a wealthy French takeover investor agreed to pay $3 billion for a 40 percent stake to rescue it from a hostile bid for control by the French luxury goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A.

title: Corrections
description: The $25 and Under column in the Dining section on Wednesday misstated the cross street for the Sultan restaurant, at 1435 Second Avenue. It is near 74th Street, not 34th.

title: Rangers Lose Lead and Game After Getting Caught Short
description: Earlier this decade, John Muckler helped build the Buffalo Sabres as their general manager. Now he is trying to help mold the Rangers as their coach. Muckler's former team met his current team last night at Madison Square Garden in an entertaining and edgy match. The Sabres, a Stanley Cup contender, won, 3-2, in overtime, and the result further wounded the Rangers' chances of qualifying for the playoffs.

title: By Any Name, Gonzaga Is a Winner
description: First, they want you to get the name right. It is not Gon-ZAH-ga. It is Gon-ZAY-ga. Got it?

title: California Guaranteeing Some a Place In Universities
description: The University of California's Board of Regents decided today to guarantee a place in the prestigious public university system for the top 4 percent of the students in each of the state's high schools.

title: Midday Bomb in Caucasus Market Kills 62 and Hurts 100
description: In a devastating act of violence in the volatile North Caucasus region, a powerful bomb ripped through the center of a market in Vladikavkaz today, killing 62 people and wounding 100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, BLOSSOM
description: GREENBLATT-Blossom. Loving wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Alan and Cindi and Mark and Lisa. Cherished grandmother of Staci, Jarod, Bari and Jena. Loving sister of Eugene. Funeral services Sunday, 10:30 AM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Why They Dream Big In Indiana
description: THE coach's son discovered at a tender age that the country was a vast playground of wondrous talent beyond the scope of even an Indiana boy who could really play. In New Castle, Ind., Brandon Miller had learned from his father that basketball was like religion, something in the blood. But from his boyhood idol came the message that fame and fortune are not necessarily part of the same basketball equation.

title: A 'Bad Writer' Bites Back
description: In the last few years, a small, culturally conservative academic journal has gained public attention by showcasing difficult sentences written by intellectuals in the academy. The journal, Philosophy and Literature, has offered itself as the arbiter of good prose and accused some of us of bad writing by awarding us ''prizes.'' (I'm still waiting for my check!)
