title: Sports of The Times; They're Letting Bygones Be Bygones
description: LAST week Lou Carnesecca, Brian Mahoney and Ron Rutledge sat together in Orlando, Fla., and watched St. John's whip Samford and tear apart Indiana. On Thursday, they watched St. John's play a near-perfect first half on the way to a romp over Maryland.

title: For Ordinary Saudis, Days Of Oil and Roses Are Over
description: Not long ago, most Saudis scorned greasy spoons like Abu Zeid's.

title: Mexico Opposition Parties Weigh Joint Strategy for Election in '00
description: A call by the Mayor of Mexico City for an opposition alliance to defeat President Ernesto Zedillo's party in the Presidential election next year has prompted a major debate. Supporters of the plan argue that it may be the only way to unseat the world's longest-governing party.

title: Black Officer Gets No. 2 Post On Crime Unit
description: Facing criticism of the Police Department's treatment of blacks and Hispanics both in the community and in its ranks, Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday appointed an African-American officer to the No. 2 post in the elite Street Crime Unit.

title: Manufacturing the Next Extreme Sport
description: In the 1990's, sports went rock-and-roll. So-called extreme sports, specifically, have become a youth-culture touchstone, a wellspring of new, ready-made hipness for mainstream marketers. Just as bands scramble for the recognition of record-company talent scouts, fresh-faced entrepreneurs now jockey to create the Next Big Sport.

title: Lawyer's Role In Abortion Protest Case
description: The article on the Rev. John Murphy [''Anti-Abortion Activist Wins a Round,'' Feb. 28] included an account of an effort to remove Judge Samuel Levine of Criminal District Court in Hempstead, who had twice exonerated Father Murphy of trespassing during protests at the site of an abortion clinic. The article failed to mention that Edward Land, the lawyer who is seeking to have Judge Levine removed from the bench, has also represented several pro-abortion groups in various lawsuits.

title: No Wariness This Ides Week
description: Partygoers were out in force, celebrating everything from Oscar gowns to Peter Rabbit.

title: Style; Mature Subject Matter
description: There has always been something fishy about the whole youth movement in couture. Couturiers could never quite look you in the eye when they talked about their ''new young clients.'' And those Marlboro-puffing, Diet Coke-guzzling waifs always looked slightly ridiculous loping down the runway under the weight of $10,000 worth of beads.

title: Habitats / Tribeca Pointe in Battery Park City; Choosing an Apartment From the Office Window
description: WHEN Scotty King's company asked her last year to move from West Hartford to New York, she assumed she would buy an apartment. She started looking, but in August the stock market ''tanked,'' as she puts it, and forcefully reminded her of the risks of ownership. ''It was an epiphany,'' she says. ''I realized I didn't want to own.''

title: Analyze This
description: Darkest Desire

title: Strawberry Hits Three-Run Homer
description: Darryl Strawberry hammered a monstrous three-run home run yesterday, his first homer of the spring, about 24 hours after his most recent chemotherapy for colon cancer. Strawberry also had a single and two strikeouts in five at-bats in a 10-9 loss to the Cleveland Indians in Winter Haven, Fla.

title: Up in the 'Real Maine,' One Man Picks Up Where He Left Off
description: YOU can go home again. Not everyone wants to, of course, and not everyone has left. But it is a given in this restless land that a lot of us will leave our roots to chase some dream. Of those, more than a few will share the fantasy that when they retire they will return to the place where they grew up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMPLE, MURIEL
description: SEMPLE-Muriel. Of Huntington, LI. (nee Campion). Widow of Robert. Devoted mother of Edmund, Susan, Michael and the late Robert Jr. Visitation Sunday 2-5 & 7-9, Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington. Mass Monday, 11 AM Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JARMEL, TODD MICHAEL
description: JARMEL-Todd Michael. March 21, 1982 FOREVER IN OUR HEARTS Mom, Dad and Ellin

title: Take My Revised Dances. Please.
description: TALK about a tough crowd. Last fall, the choreographer Danial Shapiro invited some friends and colleagues to a preview of his new solo, ''Shtick,'' at the Southern Theater in Minneapolis. Set to klezmer music and Henny Youngman jokes, the dance was conceived as an upbeat sequel to his 1996 elegy about Jewish ghettos and concentration camps, called ''What Dark/Falling Into Light.'' With the first public performance just two nights away, Mr. Shapiro was looking for a pat on the back, and maybe a little constructive criticism. Instead he learned what a lonely place the stage can be.

title: March 14-20; Replay the Replay
description: Often, the most intense sports dramas in this sports-mad nation involve heated disputes among mature adults about whether some ball or body part landed a smidgen this or that side of the line. Who can forget the touchdown-that-wasn't in the December Jets-Seahawks game?

title: Home Improvement
description: THE HANDYMAN

title: March 14-20; Bombing Threatened
description: President Clinton said NATO must be ready to carry out air strikes against the Serbs, who have acted in a manner that provoked a military response. Calling his first full news conference in almost a year, Mr. Clinton said, ''Hesitation is a license to kill.''

title: The Hitchcock Movie, With Seeds
description: THE sunbirds are back. No, not those annoying elderly people with condos in Florida: the real birds, with feathers and insatiable beaks. This is the season when bird lovers begin to have second thoughts. All through the winter, our feeders have been hosts to a well-behaved regular clientele of woodpeckers, cardinals, blue jays, juncos and other year-round residents. Suddenly it's like an Alfred Hitchcock movie out there: thousands of grackles all over the lawn, robins digging in the flower beds and red-winged blackbirds and European starlings facing off like prize fighters over the suet cake.

title: Long Island Voice Is Boastful Newcomer
description: I believe it is very presumptuous for The Long Island Voice to present itself as the great avant-garde vehicle that will save Nassau and Suffolk from the doldrums of suburban babbitry [''The Voice Finds Its Style Plays on the Island,'' March 7]. Long Island has traditionally been the home of many free and low-cost weeklies featuring the music scene and community-based reporting. Too often, The Voice's iconoclasm is the juvenile tendency to proclaim that ''everyone is stupid but us.'' Most adults outgrow this sometime after the freshman year in college.

title: Unfair to Small Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Theo Saal and Larry Gurwitch
description: GROWING up on Central Park West in the 1960's and 70's, Theodora Mathilda Saal was the child of ''Upper West Side creative book people,'' as she puts it. Her father, the late Hubert Saal, was the chief music and dance critic for Newsweek, and her mother, Rollene W. Saal, now a writer, was a Doubleday executive and later the editor in chief of Bantam Books.

title: Them I.R.S. Blues
description: THE GREEDY HAND How Taxes Drive Americans Crazy and What to Do About It. By Amity Shlaes. 255 pp. New York: Random House. $22.95.

title: A Fan Saves an Art-Movie House in Baltimore
description: FIVE years ago James Cusack, a fan of offbeat films, knew little about the movie-theater business. That changed when his nephew, John Standiford, told him that the Charles Theater, one of the city's two first-run art movie houses, was about to close.

title: Barkley Misses Destination, but the Journey of St. John's Isn't Over
description: EVERYBODY wants to know why that mountain is so hard to climb, why the top is so hard to reach. Now St. John's knows. Erick Barkley, St. John's freshman point guard, knows with excruciating exactness. For 20 minutes after the Red Storm's 77-74 season-ending loss, Barkley sat in a crowded, stuffy locker room, surrounded by microphones and camera crews and reporters waiting for some explanation, some perspective, some emotion to describe the worst five seconds of his career.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Regents Examinations Are Fair and Needed
description: In ''Putting Regents Exams to the Test'' [Opinion, March 14] Fredric Cohen argues that the new Regents standards cannot measure work ethic and other crucial factors in workplace performance. While work ethic is necessary for future success, it is not sufficient. The ability to learn and put that learning to use is required, even granting that academic achievement is not a guarantee of success, nor the lack thereof an implication of failure. Examinations are the only methods to characterize abilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERGA, GLENN H.
description: ALBERGA-Glenn H.., 96. Accomplished industrial engineer, died on February 19 in Venice, Florida. Born Brooklyn, 1902, he graduated Erasmus High School and Cornell University (E.E., 1926). He helped develop first telephone dialing system in NYC (with Western Electric) and first wireless European connection (with Bell Labs). His professional accomplishments are recorded in Who's Who in America, Who's Who in New England, Who's Who in Engineering. Member of Mensa, AIIE, ASME, Cornell and Ivy League Clubs, and Lambda Chi Alpha. Surviving are his daughter, Sandra (Maine), his son, Robert (Florida, and his niece, Virginia (Florida). Donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: March 14-20; North Korean Assent
description: Last year American spy satellites found a giant hole in the ground in North Korea, dug by thousands of military troops. Problem was, it looked a lot like a future home for a nuclear reprocessing plant, a place for the North Koreans to revive their frozen nuclear weapons program. After months of negotiations, the North Koreans have finally agreed to allow American inspectors to visit the site regularly. In return they got what they need the most: a promise of continuing food aid, and an agreement to help teach the country how to plant potatoes. It may be the first ever spuds-for-nukes deal. DAVID E. SANGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELDON, SOLOMON
description: MELDON-Solomon. Age 74, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Died on March 17, 1999, in Boynton Beach, FL. Mr. Meldon was in the field of education for over 25 years. He was a principal and the former Director of the Gifted Child Program for the city of New York. Beloved husband of the late Bernice J. Meldon (1926-1999). Loving father of Lance Meldon and Jill Meldon. Cherished grandfather of Sara Elizabeth, and devoted brother of George (Helen) Meldon and Martha (Morris) Weissman. Funeral services will be held today, Sunday, in Boynton Beach, FL. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Leukemia Foundation.

title: A Man Stabs His Wife and Son to Death, and Breaks Chatham's Heart
description: Chatham Township awoke to an eerily beautiful Tuesday morning. The late winter snowstorm that had forced schools to close on Monday quietly blanketed the spaces between the trees with a brightness that made the sun even more brilliant and the sky impossibly blue.

title: Sloan Satenstein And Robert Klein
description: Sloan Andrea Satenstein and Robert Scott Klein were married last evening by Evelyn Langlieb Greer, a justice of the peace, at the Fisher Island Club on Fisher Island in Miami.

title: Intruder Pushes In Door And Sets Woman on Fire
description: A Queens woman looking for money pushed her way into a neighbor's home yesterday morning, then tried to strangle the 82-year-old Greek immigrant with a phone cord before setting her ablaze, the police said.

title: Las Vegas Meets Disney in Atlantic City's Boardwalk Plan
description: A new and improved Boardwalk is coming to Atlantic City -- but don't hold your breath.

title: Road Sweep Is Elusive For Devils
description: With less than a month left in the regular season, the Devils have their sights set on several targets. They want to finish first in the Eastern Conference to have the home ice advantage in the playoffs and pocket the gate receipts that come with it, but they also want to capture their third consecutive divisional title and break the league record for most road victories.

title: Kentucky and Padgett Ready to Run With Spartans
description: Scott Padgett had just made a critical 3-pointer to push Kentucky closer to defeating Miami of Ohio on Friday night and meeting Michigan State on Sunday afternoon. So he shouted, he shook his head back and forth and he patted his fist against his heart. Look at me, Padgett's actions seemed to be bellowing.

title: School Board Race Gets Attention
description: From the start, Anthony Amato's tenure as superintendent of Community School District 6 was tinged with controversy. Appointed to the post in 1987 by Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones, who had suspended the local school board amid charges of mismanagement and poor performance, Mr. Amato got both accolades and criticism during the next 12 years. Now he plans to leave, and the school board that will be elected in May will pick his successor. So many are carefully watching the race.

title: INVESTING WITH: Bruce E. Behrens and Liam D. Burke; Flag Investors Communications Trust
description: BRUCE E. BEHRENS assumed command of a sleepy-sounding mutual fund, Flag Investors Telephone Income Trust, at its inception in January 1984. At the time, its shareholders probably had no inkling of the breathtaking voyage ahead.

title: On the Grass, Alas
description: To the Editor:

title: Should the West Save Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Design for Living; That's Not a Skim Latte. It's a Way of Life.
description: THE last time you pulled a shirt out of a drawer, it is possible you were not simply getting dressed. You were actually living out a small moment of a life style, one shared with thousands of others, and one you probably didn't know you were leading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, MELVIN, D.D.S.
description: BLAKE-Melvin, D.D.S.. On March 14, 1999, at the age of 71, after a wonderful life that enriched all those who knew him. Mel was a superbly skilled specialist in both oral surgery and oral pathology and was an avid collector of fine art. A bright light has gone out. The family will miss his warmth and gentle manner. Memorial service Sunday, April 11, 3 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- Product; Broken Windows Theory
description: Forget about Y2K. This is serious. Microsoft now acknowledges the existence of a bug in tens of millions of copies of Windows 95 and Windows 98 that will cause your computer to ''stop responding (hang)'' -- you know, what you call crash -- after exactly 49 days, 17 hours, 2 minutes and 47.296 seconds of continuous operation.

title: Where Oversize Entrees Are the Magnet
description: CAFE BELLA VITA was immediately likable, with its complementary color scheme and vibrant original art on the sponge-painted walls. It was so attractive, in an understated way, that we began rooting for it immediately. Even the recitation of nightly specials didn't irritate us as much as usual because they were few in number.

title: Placebo Nation
description: Over the past decade, psychiatrists and the news media have proclaimed the wonders of Prozac and the rest of a new generation of antidepressant drugs, known collectively as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. Now a report from the United States Department of Health and Human Services has confirmed what has long been an open secret among mental-illness researchers: the S.S.R.I.'s are no more effective at treating depression than older classes of drugs, like tricyclics.

title: Waiting for Small Caps? Bring a Good Book
description: CONTEMPORARY investors seem to have condemned to the mists of time the lessons of ''Small is Beautiful,'' the 1973 book by the late E. F. Schumacher that extolled the benefits of all things micro. Based on recent history, big is best is now the philosophy of choice.

title: Balancing Act
description: Last October, I met with troops from the former Yugoslavia in a small Hungarian town near the Croatian border. It was a damp, muddy day, and I wore a pair of heavy, well-made, comfortable boots, camouflage-printed, which I had bought from John Bartlett's autumn collection. I was deep in conversation with a soldier when a senior officer interrupted us. ''I need such boots for our troops,'' he said. ''They are U.S. standard issue or from a private supplier?'' I gave him the name of the very private SoHo boutique where my footwear was at that time available, and warned him that he might encounter financial obstacles to the bulk orders he had in mind.

title: Rabbi Pleads Not Guilty In Cherry Hill Murder
description: Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, the former leader of a 900-family synagogue in Cherry Hill, last week pleaded not guilty to arranging the bludgeoning death of his 52-year-old wife in November 1994.

title: Chamber Ensembles, From Brahms to Modern
description: CHAMBER music enlivens the week's list of concert opportunities. At 2 o'clock this afternoon, for instance, there is a choice of free recitals by the Prism Saxophone Quartet at the Yale Center for British Art in New Havena and the Classic Brass Quintet at the Westport Public Library. The Prisms focus on English music by Holst, Vaughan Williams and David Bedford while the Classic Brass promises ''a variety of music from Renaissance pieces to contemporary jazz.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: When Dreams Came True

title: INSIDE
description: UConn and Ohio State Reach the Final Four

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERBER, SAMUEL
description: SPERBER-Samuel. Of Fort Lauderdale. Beloved husband of the late Emily. Devoted father of Irwin Sperber and Karen Terach. Loving grandfather of Janette, Claudia, Julie and Michael. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, Sunday, at 2:30 P.M., 1-800-378-1892.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, SIGMUND
description: GOLDBLATT - Sigmund. Died March 9, 1999, Boca Raton, FL. Born in New York City, July 16th, 1913. Attended Stuyvesant High School, City College of New York, and Brooklyn Law School. He lived in Washington, D.C., during his adult life, worked at the Department of State, then as land developer in northern VA. Husband of the late Mona Steinman Goldblatt for 47 years. Survived by wife A. Lorraine; by daughters Emily Goldblatt Patterson, of Boston, Susan Goldblatt, of MD, and Joan Jordan Goldblatt of NC; grandchildren Nicholas Jacob Patterson of Boston, Jacob Goldblatt and Stacy Flynn of Maryland; sistersin-law Evelyn Neyman and Adele Goodman; also by stepdaughters Brenda Cipriano and Seena Clark, and stepgrandson Adam Cipriano. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund for Goldblatt Family Forest in Israel, or Cleveland Clinic, FL.

title: Uptown Block Opts Out of Intensive Police Program
description: By many accounts, the New York City Police Department's model block program has been a resounding success, with officers and residents in nearly two dozen areas where it has been applied noticing a sharp drop in crime.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99; Me, With the Stars in My Eyes
description: By nature, movie stars refuse to observe the laws of time and space. They wear size 4 dresses, but their faces, at will, expand to fill a Cineplex screen. Come the 8 P.M. screening, they appear simultaneously at 2,000 far-flung theaters.

title: Ashley Rawls, Matthew Gelber
description: Ashley Elizabeth Rawls, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas S. Rawls of Summerville, S.C., was married yesterday to Matthew Charles Gelber, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Rene L. Gelber of Highland, Md. The Rev. Needham R. Williamson performed the ceremony at the John Wesley United Methodist Church in Charleston, S.C.

title: The Nation: The Perpetual-Motion Economy; The Stronger It Gets, the Sweatier the Palms
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average floats near 10,000. Jobs are plentiful. Wages are rising. Spending is everywhere. The economy booms, month after month. And nothing seems to shake the public sense of prosperity. So why are the oracles of the economy talking like Nervous Nellies?

title: Janet Cohen, Daniel Kramarsky
description: Janet Cohen, a daughter of Suzanne F. Cohen of Baltimore and the late Nathan L. Cohen, was married last evening to Daniel Jacob Kramarsky, a son of Sarah-Ann and Werner H. Kramarsky of Manhattan. Rabbi Joel H. Zaiman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
description: SAN RAFAEL , Calif.  LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.

title: One-Party Rule Broken in Scarsdale
description: WHEN he began his effort to overturn the decades-old one-party rule in Scarsdale, Robert H. Harrison expected to be part of the revolution when it occurred. But like Moses, who never got to the Promised Land, Mr. Harrison will not be a village Trustee in Scarsdale next year.

title: Testing, Testing: How the City's Third Graders Performed in 1998
description: The Board of Education released New York City's annual school report cards last week, and they held some discouraging news: not only do the city's elementary schools continue to lag far behind the rest of the state on the closely watched third-grade reading and math tests, but the gap widened from the previous year. (Performance on citywide tests, not given in the rest of the state, generally improved from the year before.)

title: The World: Latin America's Contagion; Where Taxes Aren't So Certain
description: AS the year began, the Ecuadorean Government was nearing bankruptcy, unable to pay teachers, doctors and other public employees or to repair $2.6 billion in damage inflicted by El Nino. Another example of global economic contagion? Not directly. It reflected a much older, if related, problem in Latin America, tax evasion. Here it had become so bad that the Ecuadorean Congress took a truly unorthodox step: It abolished the income tax altogether in favor of a one percent tax on financial transactions.

title: Oscars Journal; Academy Bells Summon Moguls and Mavens
description: For the creme de la few in this company town, the day of the Academy Awards has long been the unofficial holiday of Hollywood, that moment each year when the movie business stops worshiping the golden calf just long enough to bow down before a 13-and-a-half-inch gold-plated idol named Oscar.

title: What if Day Traders Had to Pass a Test?
description: THE era of wide-open day trading in stocks, when any investor with money and moxie can sit down in an office and lose both, may be ending as suddenly as it dawned. Regulators, rightly worried that many day traders don't understand the risks of the practice, are starting to rein in the day-trading firms.

title: New Pressure To Help Insure Child Support
description: Even the staunchest critics of Gov. George E. Pataki's welfare policies have praised his campaign to collect child support from delinquent parents, most of them men, so their families do not wind up on public assistance.

title: Fashions of The Times
description: The wit and humor of your latest special fashion issue were quite refreshing (Feb. 21). However, I can find no humor in the disturbing images of the model on pages 100-107. Will someone please feed that creature?

title: Aiming for the Next Level, He Shoots, She Scores; A Clear Lane to College And Perhaps Beyond
description: THIS is not the level of enthusiasm you'd expect for the game of basketball as played by high school girls. But even given the rising interest in women's basketball, Nicole Kaczmarski generates a rare level of excitement.

title: The Sleepy Suburb That Is the Upper West Side
description: SANDWICHED between friends in a booth at Lot 61 on West 21st Street, dressed in leather pants and Manolo Blahnik heels, Tait Chatmon took a moment to appreciate the view. ''In one glance you have dreads, then you have lawyer types, then you have city kids, then you have bridge and tunnel,'' she said, dragging her finger across the room as if swiping icing off a cake. ''I love it!''

title: George Lucas: 'I'm a Cynic Who Has Hope for the Human Race'
description: Following are excerpts from several wide-ranging conversations between the director George Lucas and the writer Orville Schell that took place recently at Mr. Lucas's house in San Rafael, Calif., and nearby at his Skywalker Ranch.

title: A Galaxy Of Myth, Money And Kids
description: LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.

title: The Making of a Fugitive
description: Doris Grady's rambling victorian house in Pittsburgh has seen more than its share of would-be saints. And of all those who have passed through, she says, crowding into her wood-trimmed living room and sleeping on the tufted couches and bare wood floors, none was more gentle and devout, more sincerely devoted to nonviolence, than James Charles Kopp. A shy, red-haired man in his 40's, with a quiet sense of humor, she recalls, he traveled the country with other activists opposed to abortion, rescuing babies before they could be ripped from their mothers' wombs, torn apart and flushed into sewers. He loved classical music, books and old movies. His favorite time to visit was the fall.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Along Came a Spider . . .
description: ONCE the mere proximity of a dragonfly would send me into paroxysms of panic. Last summer, though, I noticed one trapped in my kitchen and carefully escorted it outside, perched on my hand. The season also saw me cooing to spiders I used to cringe at and, rather than running for the Raid, shrugging when I discovered an army of ants under the family room carpet.

title: The Holocaust, In Today's Terms; Memory's Custodians
description: To the Editor:

title: Firing of a School Leader Prompts a Power Struggle
description: The dismissal of a school Superintendent in Queens for her handling of a school gun incident has set the stage for a fresh legal and political fight over the power of the New York City Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, to impose his will on elected community school boards, school and community officials said yesterday.

title: Judging the Tuition Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Golomb, Jeffrey Michael
description: Lisa Michele Golomb, a daughter of Judith and Robert Golomb of Dunwoody, Ga., was married last evening to Dr. Jeffrey Jay Michael, the son of Joyce and David Michael of Bellmore, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Franklin officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: BENEFITS
description: Blues Memorial

title: New Pension Plans Are Cash and Carry
description: FOR years, a pension has meant just one thing: a reward for sticking with one company for a long, long time. Now a new kind of pension program, called a ''cash balance'' plan, is growing in popularity with large corporations trying to cope with an increasingly mobile work force.

title: Horowitz Gift
description: Wanda Toscanini Horowitz -- daughter of the conductor Arturo Toscanini and widow of the pianist Vladimir Horowitz -- has left a five-story Manhattan town house on the Upper East Side to Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights.

title: The North Korean Threat
description: The Clinton Administration has defused a dangerous crisis by persuading North Korea to permit unlimited American inspections of a suspicious construction site. Washington feared the area was being readied for secret nuclear weapons work. But the inspection agreement leaves many problems unresolved, including the future of North Korea's provocative long-range missile program.

title: A Tasty Melange In the East 60's
description: AUREOLE ***

title: Seller of Asian Antiques Caters to Demand
description: EVER since the time of Marco Polo Chinese art has captured the hearts and pocketbooks of collectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEITMAN, EDWARD W.
description: KLEITMAN-Edward W.. Of Camarillo, CA passed away March 9 at age 87. Loving husband of fifty years to the late Sadie Lipson Kleitman, he is survived by his beloved Alice Schweitzer of Camarillo, loving daughter Jean Kleitman Lesavoy of Brentwood, California, loving son Kenneth Kleitman of Atlanta, Georgia, & grandchildren Brian, Jordan & Nicole Lesavoy & Jonathan and Emily Kleitman. Born in New York on September 25, 1911, his alma mater was the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, and he remained a devoted Tar Heel fan all his life. He was a Certified Public Accountant in New York and worked for Columbia Pictures, Leitesdorf, Levinson Brothers and New York Merchandise. He believed in social justice long before it became a catchphrase and lived his beliefs his entire life. Services were held on March 12 at Conejo Mt. Memorial Park, Camarillo, California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMMER, ALICE
description: WIMMER-Alice. Died March 17, aged 95, in her Berkeley, CA home. Born in Vienna, she lived in New York from 1940 to 1977. Widow of Hugo, Alice is survived by her daughter Gertrude Weil of Berkeley, son Harry Wimmer and his wife Shirley Givens of NYC, four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. WYOGE-Irving/d. Retired pharmacist. Died on March 19, 1999 at the age of 95. Beloved husband of 61 years of Esther. Devoted father of Dr. Norman and Felice Wyloge, Madi and Bruce Alter, Diane and Gregg Borak. Adored grandfather of Jonathan and Marci, Daniel, Nicole and Jonathan, Ilana, Jarrod, Shane, Cody and great grandfather of Jordan and Zachary. A quiet, gentle, scholarly man who was loved by all. Services today, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, THOMAS POULTNEY
description: COOK-Thomas Poultney. On March 18, 1999. Age 88. Country lawyer, public servant, devoted husband of Mildred Benedict Cook and father of Charlotte Cook Rakela, Thomas P., Jr. and Louisa Cook Moats. Relatives and friends are invited to his memorial service at Princeton University Chapel on Friday, April 16, 1999 at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Friends of Princeton Open Space, P.O. Box 374, Princeton, N.J. 08540. For information, contact Jos. A. Fluehr III Funeral Home, Richboro, PA.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 21, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- Word & Image; What's Happened to The Media?
description: I am a marked man these days, contemptuously branded a ''member of the media'' wherever I go. We members are treated with the fascinated revulsion normally reserved for prostitutes. We are considered peddlers of filth and disease, preying on humanity's basest appetites.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The first thing I'll do is phone my wife, and then, like the good Englishman I am, I'll have a cup of tea.''

title: Q. & A.
description: Taxes Paid at A Closing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, MYRA
description: FEIN-Myra. Beloved wife of Skippy (Franklin). Loving mother of Mindy and Alan Delman, Jayne and Neil Kirby and Lisa and Keith Lipstein. Cherished grandmother of Erica, Jonathan and Andy Delman, Michael and Peter Kirby and Emily and Sophie Lipstein. Dear sister of Jay and Marty Goldberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 P.M. Sunday.

title: The Holocaust, In Today's Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about the Bridgemarket project under the Manhattan approach to the Queensboro Bridge referred imprecisely to the role of Lynden B. Miller, the designer of the gardens adjacent to the market, in two earlier projects. She designed the gardens at Bryant Park and Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City. The landscape architect for both projects was Hanna/Olin, now the Olin Partnership.

title: Balloon History, and in Only 20 Days
description: Dr. Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones sailed into history on Saturday when their Breitling Orbiter 3 completed the first nonstop balloon trip around the world -- a goal many had sought but never achieved.

title: Partnership With Film Society To Help in Restoring a Theater
description: PEOPLE have come to me with tears in their eyes when talking about the Rome Theater,'' recalled Steve Apkon, owner since last July of the theater here.

title: White Lightning
description: Men in white will be everywhere this season, as a crisp, fresh look dominates everything from sportswear to suits.

title: School Swap Of Disabled Is Faulted
description: Ever since school officials moved Emmanuel Rosario, 9, from Public School 380 to Intermediate School 71 last month, his shy grin has given way to outbursts of anger, said his father, Reinaldo Rosario.

title: Under a Casino's Lights, No One Looks Too Old to Play
description: WHEN it comes to crooning, Jim Walsh is no Frank Sinatra. And when it comes to gambling, he is no James Bond, leaning over the baccarat tables of Monte Carlo, sipping martinis while dressed in a tuxedo. But on Tuesday nights at Prairie Meadows Racetrack and Casino outside Des Moines, Mr. Walsh, a 77-year-old retired ballroom dance instructor, gets to revel in the fantasy of acting a little like both men.

title: Italian Food With a Hearty Welcome
description: ''HOW ya doin' ''is the standard greeting at New York New York Ristorante, An Italian Eatery in a modest middle-class area of Cedarhurst. Patrons, all of whom seem to know one another, say it to other diners as do waitresses to guests. The 15-month-old New York New York itself is doin' just fine. Call it an unapologetic throwback, serving robust, rather than refined, Italian soul food, a warm family-owned neighborhood spot of a sort that used to dot the five boroughs, on a corner at 331 Washington Avenue (239-6885).

title: A Seldom-Heard Voice on Broadway
description: IT was a cold Thursday afternoon and the world of Thulani Davis was a spare, softly lighted stage at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. Ms. Davis's play ''Everybody's Ruby'' was in rehearsals, with Phylicia Rashad as the writer Zora Neale Hurston and Viola Davis as Ruby McCollum, a black woman in a small Florida town who killed a prominent white doctor in the early 1950's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBUD, JULE. M.D.
description: EISENBUD-Jule. M.D.. 90. Died on March 10th, 1999. A native New Yorker, Dr. Eisenbud attended Columbia University and The New York Psychoanalytic Institute. He moved to Denver in 1950, became its first psychoanalyist, and taught at the University of Colorado Medical Center. His wife Molly died in 1995. He is survived by three children, five grandchildren, and a great-grandson.

title: What Was That Name Again?; Betting on Behind-the-Scenes Nominees
description: In this age of 24-hour entertainment news channels, it's becoming easier for moviegoers to predict who's going to win an Academy Award. Even if film fans haven't got around to seeing ''Saving Private Ryan'' or ''Shakespeare in Love,'' it's difficult to avoid the seemingly endless supply of critical 10-best lists, made-for-television awards shows and lavish, unsubtle Oscar campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIDERMAN, ANNA (NEE PLOTKIN)
description: LEIDERMAN-Anna (nee Plotkin). On Thursday, March 18, in her 100th year. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Adored mother of Al (Lillian), Ralph (Doris), and Bernice (the late Dr. Marvin) Fein. Loving grandmother to Michael (Hermine), the late Robert, Dr. Beth (Martin) Statfeld, Dr. Richard, Robin (Michael) Goldstein, Jaynie Segal, Dr. David (Dr. Leslie) Fein and Carrie (David) Harmon. Cherished by her 14 great grandchildren. She was kind of heart, considerate of others and clear of mind to the very end. Services today, 11:15 AM, Sinai Chapels, 16205 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: I Like It Here. The House Is Paid For. I Think I'll Stay!
description: AS a checkered grid of modest-sized homes, schools and strip malls that sprang from the post-World War II housing and baby boom, this Long Island town is typical of where middle-class America grew up. Now, it is typical of where middle-class America grows old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, LEONARD
description: DRISCOLL-Leonard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Leonard Driscoll, associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1978.

title: Coach-and-Star Talk Turns Magic Around
description: Barely eight days ago, the luster had worn off Orlando's quick start. The Magic had lost embarrassingly to Dallas, Penny Hardaway was pouting and all the old liabilities -- fragile egos, poor shooting and bad chemistry -- had begun to resurface.

title: Ruling Says Chirac Can't Be Prosecuted on Corruption Charge
description: A French prosecutor has ruled that President Jacques Chirac cannot be prosecuted while in office on political corruption charges stemming from his years as Mayor of Paris and leader of his conservative Gaullist party.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Sex and Social Justice,'' by Martha C. Nussbaum, in the Book Review last Sunday misidentified the state whose power to prosecute private homosexual acts under a law forbidding oral or anal sex was upheld by the Supreme Court in the case of Bowers v. Hardwick in 1986. It was Georgia, not Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, MORRIS
description: BLOCK-Morris. The faculty of the Department of Medicine, many of them former students, and all the alumni of the NYU School of Medicine are sorrowed by the demise of Dr. Morris Block, an alumnus and professor of clinical medicine who died at the age of 96. He was a much beloved teacher who established for us high standards for the knowledge and practice of clinical medicine. He taught us to be independent thinkers and compassionate physicians. His legacy is always with us. Saul J. Farber, M.D. Frederick King, Professor of Medicine Chairman, Dept of Medicine, NYU

title: The Way We Live Now
description: The high tax burden on a pack of cigarettes is easily avoided -- just don't smoke (''The Economics of Cigarettes,'' Andy Newman, Feb. 28).

title: Who Is Buried in Virgil's Tomb?
description: VIRGIL

title: The Persistence Of Polygamy
description: Regarding the Mormon Mayor Dan Barlow's comment ''They think what goes on here is all about sex'': it's never about sex. It's always about power.

title: On a Once Forlorn Avenue, Tax Preparers Now Flourish
description: It slopes up from the old Schlitz Brewery, past empty lots, storefront churches, Victory over Violence Park, and the Black Holocaust Museum. It burned in two days of racial violence in 1967. Since then, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, once a proud retailers row, has mostly been known as an asphalt emblem of urban distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUSSOW, CHARLOTTE STEARNS SMITH
description: GUSSOW - Charlotte Stearns Smith. On March 11, 1999, of Broadmead Community, Cockeysville, MD. Wife of the late James Kinnear Gussow, Sr., and mother of Priscilla T. Spahn and James K. Gussow, Jr. Services and inurnment private. Lemmon Funeral Home, 410-252-6000.

title: Fears Deepens as Monitors Quit Kosovo
description: Thousands of panicked refugees fled on foot, by tractor or by horse and cart today, carrying young children and clutching a few possessions, as Serbian forces pressed an offensive against the ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo.

title: Internet Generation Isn't Just Wasting Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Men, Women, Sex and Darwin
description: Natalie Angier wields her trademark self-righteous mockery to suggest that Darwinian approaches to human sexuality are feather-frail and little more than camouflage for antediluvian efforts to maintain sexual inequality (Feb. 21). She correctly notes that there is tremendous variation in how men and women live their lives but at the same time fails to suggest from what real central patterns the variation flows. The implication that there is no human sexual nature at all, which follows hazily if finally from her argument, is a bizarre cousin of post-modern intellectual nihilism. One would be hard put from her article to suspect that Darwinian theory remains one of the sturdiest in modern science and that its very success provides Angier the platform of data and theory on which she is able to stand.

title: State's Insurance Industry Reinvents Itself
description: THE darkest clouds have finally parted over Connecticut's insurance industry. Mergers are smaller; layoffs are a sprinkle of what they were earlier in the 90's, and many companies have begun hiring again.

title: Reinventing Al Gore
description: Al Gore has been one of the most active Vice Presidents in American history, a central player in an Administration that continues to get high approval ratings. Yet those same polls show that the public is ambivalent about a Gore Presidency. That may be unsettling to Mr. Gore, but he is hardly the first Vice President to face the problem of stepping out of the shadows. Indeed, his problem is less formidable than that faced by George Bush. In 1988, he had to offer himself as a substitute for the American family's revered, if somewhat dotty father figure. Mr. Gore has only to supplant the overindulged naughty brother. Even so, Mr. Gore will have to offer more than an exaggerated rural boyhood, a resume and an aura of entitlement if he is to win in his own right.

title: Stealth Status for the Few, the Proud
description: WHAT do Arnold Schwarzenegger, Bill Cosby, Liam Neeson, Christie Brinkley, Boris Becker and Tommy Hilfiger have in common? Obviously, they all have incomes that make it unnecessary to do much heavy lifting. But they also belong to an exclusive, well, cult: the cult of the Gelaendewagen.

title: A New Web Site for Buffett Followers
description: Almost everyonewho follows the doings of Warren E. Buffett, the acclaimed value investor and the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, is familiar with his enduring bets on companies like Coca-Cola, American Express and Gillette. These and other big holdings are disclosed in Berkshire's annual reports.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Beetle Battles

title: Pedicure Junction
description: The fashion-forward guy falls for the girl in L.L. Bean. The wordsmith goes gaga for the malaprop. Mr. Manana is smitten by Ms. Martinet. No sooner is the knot tied, however, than he starts pushing her toward Helmut Lang. She corrects him each time he opens his mouth. He urges her to chill out, for God's sake. Do we hook up with our opposites just so we can spend our lives trying to change them?

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- Voir Dire; Can You Get Busted for Gambling on the Internet?
description: As it stands now, it's a real long shot. And that isn't likely to change -- despite the Senate's pending legislation to clamp down on on-line gambling. An early draft of the Internet gambling prohibition bill contained specific penalties for players: six months in jail or a $2,500 fine. But the final version will target gambling Web sites, and probably leave users in the clear.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / The Turtle Bay Neighborhood; In U.N.'s Shadow, Elegance, Convenience
description: FOR 30 years, Sherrill K. de Gonzaga and her family have lived in Embassy House at 301 East 47th Street in the Turtle Bay neighborhood. It is a short walk from the United Nations headquarters on First Avenue where she represents two nongovernmental organizations concerned with environmental and health issues that are accredited to the world organization.

title: What Audiences Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirsten Davis and David Camp
description: Kirsten Madeleine Davis, the daughter of Madeleine D. Burns of Manhattan and Laurence Laird Davis Jr. of Morristown, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to David Camp, the son of Lois and Mitchell Camp of Harrington, Park, N.J. The Rev. Betty Zimmer, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the St. Regis in Manhattan.

title: Bill to Offer More Options To Students In the Capital
description: Legislation has been introduced in Congress that would expand academic options for high school graduates from the District of Columbia by substantially reducing their tuition fees at state colleges nationwide and by providing about $2 million for the local public university.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, CONSTANCE
description: COLLINS-Constance. March 12, 1999 in NY. We'll treasure the happy memories. We love you Connie. Love Bridie and Family

title: Jamaica Takes Steps To Protect Tourists
description: Jamaica is putting soldiers in tourist areas to prevent thefts and harassment of visitors. The new policy of using members of the country's military, mostly in plainclothes and some armed with pistols, to augment police protection was announced in January by Francis Tulloch, the Minister of Tourism, with the strong support of the island's hotel association.

title: Treacherous Days Recalled
description: IT was a golden time when a group of theater artists had a communal cause and the cause was theater art. How fitting that they would create a company and call it the Group Theater.

title: Debra Bayer, Anthony Wolk
description: Debra Joy Bayer, a daughter of Cheryl and Michael Bayer of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to Anthony Lesser Wolk, a son of Dr. Nancy Wolk and Elliot Wolk of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: No More Hair Dryers: Steam Duck Before Roasting
description: PEKING or Long Island ducks are difficult to roast well because they have an enormous amount of fat, which does not break down easily. I have tried everything, from boiling a duck before roasting it, to opening up its pores with a hand-held hair dryer. But recently I found the answer, which does not involve my previous methods or air-drying the duck for a week and deep-frying it as they do in Chinese restaurants. I got the idea from a recipe by Chef Paul Bertolli in ''Chez Panisse Cooking'' (Random House).

title: An Orchestra Builder Who Won't Just Walk Away
description: FOR an American conductor like Leonard Slatkin, it would seem to be a seller's market. The major American orchestras are exhorted these days to get in tune with the times and in touch with the nation, and in those regards, Mr. Slatkin could be a quick fix: a champion of many current composers and a century's worth of American music as well as a respected interpreter of standard repertory. Conductors are being courted to replace the lame-duck German music directors of the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia and Cleveland Orchestras, to name just the most prominent ensembles with vacancies looming, and Mr. Slatkin, with an established reputation as an orchestra builder at the St. Louis Symphony and a growing one here at the National Symphony, should be a contender.

title: Some Head South, And Some Head Back
description: FOR Patricia DiFiore, the moment of truth came when none of her new neighbors could identify Donald Trump or the QE2. ''Talk about culture shock,'' said Mrs. DiFiore, who with her husband, Joe, had retired to the Tampa Bay area of Florida after a lifetime in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Congrats! You're a Big Number On Campus!
description: COMPUTER glitches are a pain, but they can be especially embarrassing when they strike an American institution of higher learning. Consider the following form letter from Arizona State University, in which a prospective student's Social Security number was inadvertently substituted for his name.

title: The Beautiful People
description: Survival of the Prettiest

title: March 14-20; The Minutiae of Wealth
description: The first time Goldman, Sachs & Company prepared to go public, it honored a tradition that dates from its founding as a private partnership 130 years ago: obsessive secrecy.

title: Exploring Limbo
description: 'SAM SHEPARD:

title: Ray Forrest Is Dead at 83; Nation's First TV Personality
description: Ray Forrest, who worked for many years at his family's jewelry store in Paterson, N.J., died on March 11 at a hospital near his home in Kinnelon, N.J. He was 83 and all but forgotten as the man who became a hero to hundreds in 1939 as the nation's first television personality.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE DANGEROUS AGE

title: Caterpillars Turn Pinelands Into Potential Tinderbox
description: Two types of tiny caterpillars are eating their way through the Pine Barrens, leaving in their wake dead pine needles that are increasing the danger of forest fires at a time of year when fires already are a major hazard, a state forestry expert said last week.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: WOMEN'S HISTORY MONTH

title: Ali's True Legacy; DiMaggio's Grace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Is New Hampshire Ripe for Governor Whosit?
description: Let me summarize George Pataki's problem this way. In Manchester, N.H., for Mr. Pataki's big debut as a potential Republican Presidential candidate at a Lincoln Day dinner, I got into an argument with a cab driver who insisted that the Governor of New York is Rudy Giuliani.

title: Men, Women, Sex and Darwin
description: Bravo to Natalie Angier for her intelligent and sensible article on evolutionary psychology. With government funds going almost exclusively to biological and genetic research on human behavior (nature) as opposed to research on social and environmental effects (nurture), we see too many studies claiming that all our behavior is in the genes. That nature and nurture interact is forgotten as people flock eagerly to simplistic biological explanations of their behavior.

title: Those New Teen-Age Movies Fogged My Glasses
description: THE trailers and buzz have begun for ''American Pie,'' a fantastically puerile summer movie that could be the next ''Porky's.'' Despite its leering, sophomoric crudeness, the most shocking thing about ''American Pie'' is how tame it looks next to the other teen-age movies out there. The worst thing that happens is that a confused teen-age boy sexually abuses his dessert, the titular ''pie.'' Philip Roth's Alexander Portnoy did worse with a piece of liver -- and they called it literature.

title: Another Way to Win With Amazon.com Stock
description: Soaring Internet stocks may be hard to puncture in the marketplace. But that doesn't mean they can't be deflated on the Web. Global Investor Bookshop, a British on-line bookstore specializing in financial publications, is trying to do just that with a new Internet competition tilting at its much bigger rival, Amazon.com.

title: Prune Roses and Sow Vegetables
description: When forsythia and glory-of-the-snow bloom and the coldest weather seems past, prune roses while still dormant. Make cuts at a 45-degree angle just above healthy, outward-facing buds, remove dead and diseased canes, old, nonproductive wood, and crossing stems or any that grow into the center of the plant. Hybrid teas and grandifloras should be cut back to 10 to 12 inches for best flower production. Lightly prune modern shrub roses -- rugosas and the floribunda types like Carefree Wonder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLOGE, IRVING
description: WYLOGE-Irving. We mourn the loss of our Recording Secretary, a tireless and devoted member for over 50 years. Our condolences to his dear wife, Esther, his children and their families. He was a gentle and kind man and ''A True Melamed.'' Services Sunday, 12:00, Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY. Gerald Gersten, President Congregation Nusach Sfard

title: Ewing Comes Back, but It's the Sprewell Show
description: Latrell Sprewell was blinking, buzzing and glowing like a neon sign on a desert highway yesterday. For miles and miles of the game, Sprewell was the only visible sight on the floor.

title: Stacey Mayesh, Stanley Sandberg
description: Stacey Janet Mayesh, a daughter of Leslie and Jay Mayesh of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Stanley Mark Sandberg, the son of Francoise and Herbert Sandberg of Merrimack, N.H. Rabbi Barry Friedman officiated at the New York Palace.

title: Russian With Many Faces May Get Lift in U.S. Visit
description: In his long and somewhat mysterious political career, Yevgeny M. Primakov has dealt with the United States in many guises: reform Communist, intelligence chief and an occasionally quarrelsome Foreign Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSON, MORRIS
description: EDELSON-Morris. Loving husband to Shirley. Beloved father to Susan (Jeffrey) Spiro, David (Rosalie), Michal (Dave) Porath. Doting grandfather to Adam, Samantha, Seth, Leigh, Jack, Ben and Jonathan. Caring uncle to Barry, Sara, Cheryl, Sandra and Craig. Devoted brother to Sam and the late Anna. He will be missed by family and friends and remembered for his devotion to his family, his generosity and his sense of humor. Service Sunday at noon at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre. Shiva will be at Rosalie and David's home in Merrick, LI, on Monday and Tuesday. Donations may be made in Morris' memory to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OELBAUM, HELEN FAUST
description: OELBAUM-Helen Faust. Gone 20 years. In ever loving memory. Hugs & Kisses

title: Building a Nest Egg: An Exercise in Constant Guesswork
description: HERE is a secret about the perfect retirement plan: It doesn't exist.

title: Jets' Moves Driven By Desire to Win Now
description: And then there was one -- maybe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWAN, SANFORD R.
description: COWAN-Sanford R. Of Great Neck and Miami, FL. On March 19, 1999, in his 92nd year. Founder of Cowan Publishing Corporation, past Commander of the Great Neck Power Squadron and past Commodore of the Sands Point Yacht Club. Founder and 32nd Degree Grandmaster of the Steppingstone Masonic Lodge. Past member of Mariners Lodge in NYC. Devoted husband to the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Richard and Cary Cowan and Amy Blane. Grandfather of 11 and greatgrandfather of five. Masonic services Monday, 12 noon, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park. Family will be sitting Monday afternoon and evening at the Port Washington home of Amy Blane. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to St. Jude's or the charity of your choice.

title: Joining the Club, and Profiting
description: NOT all investment clubs are exclusively for small-town Midwestern women or for people whose income includes, or will soon include, Social Security checks.

title: An Inhuman Way to Tell Which Way Wind Blows
description: A HAILSTORM of denunciation is pelting the National Weather Service office here after it switched from humans to a computer-generated synthesized voice to deliver forecasts on its radio network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, RITA
description: BARRY-Rita. On March 19, 1999. She will be missed by her loving family. Sister Frieda Osias, daughter and son-in-law Gloria Cherry and Jules Lazar, grandson Ben Lazar, adored granddaughters and their husbands or partners, Sabrina Cherry and Marc Gourevitch, Dana and Paul Greci, Pamela and Michael Fischer, and Cara Cherry, and Jonathan Lisco and great-grandchildren Rebecca and Ruth Gourevitch, Sarah and William Fischer. Services Monday, March 22, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Auto Insurance Crash Course; Getting the Best Premiums Is More Complex Than Ever
description: WHEN Amy Salvatore looked over her auto insurance bill last month, she figured that she could save about $300 a year by eliminating coverage for theft and collision on her 10-year-old Chevy Astro minivan.

title: Lost in Transition
description: Walt Frazier was indisputably one of the best and most popular New York professional athletes, but his transition to the broadcast booth has been embarrassing. His commentary adds nothing to the game, and his insistence on wordplay is baffling. Step aside, Clyde. You were King of the Court, but you are the Bane of the Booth.

title: Tennessee Overpowers Virginia Tech
description: Pat Summitt figures her dominating Tennessee team is good for at least two offensive explosions a game. This afternoon at the Greensboro Coliseum, it took a single burst by the top-seeded Lady Vols to subdue Virginia Tech, 68-52, in the East Regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: March 14-20; A Bookish Trend
description: The pocket book revolution that trumpeted itself as bringing ''good reading for the millions'' is losing its revolutionary zeal. Since 1995, the number of mass market paperbacks sold declined by almost 9 percent, falling to 484 million copies last year. Discounted hard covers are eroding the market, but other entertainment forms like video rentals may also be diverting readers. Publishers suspect that their most dependable customers -- affluent, aging baby boomers -- are shifting away from paperbacks because they can afford hard covers and the larger print is easier on fading eyesight. DOREEN CARVAJAL

title: March 14-20; A Stitch in Time
description: How to reduce adolescent violence and other risky behavior while fostering an interest in learning? Starting in first grade, researchers in Seattle say, treat children with respect, encourage them to cooperate with one another and their teachers, reward their accomplishments, give them a quiet place to do their homework and teach them how to say no without losing friends and status.

title: The Nation: Guests, Fish and Politicians; When the Candidate Can't Take a Hint
description: IN New Jersey, former Gov. Jim Florio wants to run for the Senate. In California, former Representative Robert K. Dornan is threatening to challenge a fellow Republican Congressman. And in New York, former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato keeps floating his name as a candidate for his old job.

title: Introduction
description: Dog lovers ferociously took us to task for the cover illustration for ''The Anatomy of Fear,'' by Stephen S. Hall. But we used a composite; no dog was included. Equally heated, still, is the debate provoked by Natalie Angier's article on evolutionary psychology.

title: How Can You Tell?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Seeks to Strike Police Exam Questions
description: Autobiographical questions would be stricken from police hiring exams in Suffolk County under a bill narrowly approved last week by the County Legislature but opposed by the police commissioner.

title: 'Cool' Is Still Cool For Atlantic City
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on March 7, about Las Vegas, misstated the hours at the shopping mall at the Venetian, a resort that is to open April 14. They will be 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. Sunday to Thursday. (It is also to be open 10 A.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday.)

title: Ideas & Trends; Hawking the Hustler Sensibility
description: IT'S 11 o'clock on Friday night in a brightly lit store on the Sunset Strip. Men and women with expressions ranging from nonchalance to embarrassment are perusing the merchandise: saucy lingerie, edible body powders and, behind a translucent partition bearing the words, ''Relax, It's Just Sex,'' hardcore videos and sex toys. Elsewhere, customers are sipping lattes and looking over shelves of best-selling books, newspapers and sexually explicit magazines.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about a documentary on baldness misspelled the surname of one filmmaker. He is Craig Damrauer, not Damraurer. Because of an editing error, a picture caption misstated the surname of the other filmmaker. He is Tobias Perse, not Russ.

title: March 14-20; Not Quite Becoming
description: A retired two-star general who served as the Army's deputy inspector general pleaded guilty to eight counts of misconduct stemming from affairs he had with the wives of his subordinates. The Army hopes the court martial of Maj. Gen. David R. E. Hale will put to rest criticism that senior officers are treated more leniently than junior personnel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HAROLD
description: SCHWARTZ-Harold. Age 84, of Pine Island Ridge, Fort Lauderdale, FL, passed away March 15, 1999. Devoted and beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Mara and Gerry Pasternack of Ashville, NC, Michael and Bernadette Murphy of Princeton, NJ, Judith and Harry Katz of Manhattan, Eileen and Anthony Montalbano of Piermont, NY, and Toby Ozure of Port Washington, NY. Loving grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of one. Survived by his brother Arnold Schwartz of Boynton Beach, FL, and Sally Feldman of Queens. Cofounder of Schwartz Liebman Textiles in 1941 and later President of the company, a division of Cranston Printworks, Cranston, RI, until his retirement in 1984. Widely renowned, highly respected and well loved by all in the textile industry. Boy Scout leader 1943-1945, Master Franklin Lodge #

title: Seeds of Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Generation Isn't Just Wasting Time
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST AND WEST SIDES -- BUZZ; After Dinner, Keeping Kosher In the Bedroom
description: THE SETTING, TAKE ONE -- Congregation B'nai Jeshurun on West 88th Street, where about 400 people gathered Tuesday night to hear Rabbi Shmuley Boteach, 32, ex-Lubavitch father of six and author of ''Kosher Sex'' (Doubleday), spell out his recipe for keeping passion aflame. A native of Miami and currently the resident rabbi at Oxford University, Rabbi Boteach says his formula is inspired by and in keeping with the Talmud.

title: Gangsta
description: STREET KINGDOM

title: Ms. Ehret, Mr. Newhouse
description: Michelle Maxine Ehret, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Ehret of Fort Lee, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Howard Newhouse, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Newhouse of Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Arnold Marans is to officiate at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Should the West Save Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: They're King-Size Issues, Whatever You Call Him
description: Is the symbol to the left so hallowed that only the person it represents should determine its use? Can anyone wield such control over how the print and electronic media refer to him? Such are the issues raised by the Artist Formerly Known as Prince in a suit filed in late February in New York against Uptown magazine, a fanzine devoted to him.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Dangerous Selectivity About Rules of Global Trade
description: IN peacetime, Washington starts trade wars. First there was the Battle of the Bananas, still being slugged out across the Atlantic. Then came the gleaming edge of steel, a fight that pits the workers of Weirton, W. Va., against their counterparts in Brazil, Russia, Japan, Korea and China. For this week, the White House has scheduled a beef over hormone-treated meat.

title: Schools Seek New Ways Of Making Renovations
description: PRESSURED to house a rapidly increasing elementary school population in outdated buildings that often need extensive repairs, many districts on Long Island are investigating new ways to expand and renovate their schools.

title: Suffolk's High-Stakes Police Test
description: Lyndon Santiago almost didn't sign up for this year's Suffolk County police test. He sat for the last exam in 1996, dug down for the $50 fee and got his hopes up, and then the whole test was thrown out because of a cheating scandal.

title: Hewing to Both Musical and Racial Roots in Brazil
description: IN Salvador, the capital of Brazil's state of Bahia, which has one of the richest carnival traditions in the new world, all the connoisseurs of Bahia's Carnaval have the same thing jotted down in their agendas: to attend the start of the Ile Aiye parade.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of costs on March 7 for three weekend excursions misstated a meal price for San Antonio. As the article said, a Riverwalk barge dinner for four at Boudro's cost $171.33, not $71.33. (The total cost of the weekend was given correctly.)

title: Amy Ship, Robert Cohen
description: Dr. Amy Nisana Ship, an internist at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, and Dr. Robert Alan Cohen, a nephrologist at the center, were married last evening by Rabbi Balfour Brickner at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: Labels After the Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Rainy Days in Mesquite, There's Always Politics
description: STEELY-EYED Mormon pioneers look down from yellowing portraits on the wall as Verde Hughes thumbs through a 40-year-old album of baby pictures, delivery room photographs from the days when the rock bungalow that is now the Desert Valley Museum was a one-room hospital.

title: Musical Memories
description: To the Editor: Reading Barbara Comins's article, ''The Melody Lingers On'' (Feb. 28) reminded us of Assisi in October 1982, the 800th anniversary of the death of St. Francis. We scandalized our waiter by taking only one hour for dinner so that we could get to the Basilica for the Bach Mass in B Minor we had seen on posters.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Black and Blue

title: Corrections
description: The New York On Line column last Sunday gave an incorrect address for a Web site about Freedomland, an amusement park from the early 1960's on the site of what is now Co-op City in the Bronx. The correct address is:

title: Willy Eberlein, Ayano Ichida
description: Ayano Ichida, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Koji Ichida of New York and Tokyo, was married yesterday to John Andrew Eberlein, a son of Jean Nicholls of Cleveland, and the late Otto Peter Eberlein. Judge Paul Metzler of the Van Nuys (Calif.) Municipal Court, officiated at the Riviera Country Club in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about the rapid expansion of the American Skiing Company and its later financial problems referred incompletely to its dealings with Fleet Bank. Fleet was a lender to American Skiing before the company went public in November 1997, but the bank severed the relationship around the time of the public offering and was not one of the banks with which the company recently renegotiated loans.

title: Playing in Draw's Opposite Sides Benefits the Williamses and the Game
description: The most ambitious sister act ever to declare itself a sure bet for a total takeover of women's tennis has developed complications consistent with a head-on collision: fifth-ranked Venus Williams and 16th-ranked Serena Williams are gaining on an identical destination, the No. 1 ranking. Will one have to mow down the other to get there? Their parents suspect so.

title: Caroline Fox and David Shechter
description: Caroline Leah Fox, a daughter of Jane Perry of Manhattan and the late Gerald Fox, is to be married this afternoon to David Michael Shechter, a son of Cynthia and Ira Shechter of Syosset, N.Y. Rabbi Lester Bronstein is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Ansche Chesed in Manhattan.

title: Ms. Houghton And Mr. Barden
description: Elizabeth Clark Houghton, the daughter of Margot Dooling Houghton and Francis J. Houghton Jr., both of New York, was married last evening to Dan Barden, a son of Dr. Lillian Barden of San Mateo, Calif., and the late Frank M. Barden. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Allergy Warning
description: To the Editor: I have allergic bronchitis (a mild asthma) and four years ago had a very debilitating attack when I went to Snowmass, Colo., in July.

title: Forget Development, Protect Groundwater
description: I was outraged and alarmed to read in ''Sensitive Water Area Is Site of Development'' [March 7] that a massive building project might be built in an area designated by the state as a special groundwater protection area. I am even more astonished because this land is town-owned. The government ought to be working to preserve exactly these type of areas. On Long Island, our aquifer system is our sole source of drinking water.

title: Echoes of Tobacco Battle in Gun Suits
description: The battle lines look familiar. On one side are public officials who are frustrated because they have been unable to get laws passed regulating an industry that makes a dangerous product. Egged on by trial lawyers, the officials have sued the industry to try to win in court what they cannot win in the political arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLVERD, MARTIN
description: COLVERD-Martin. Of Ojai, Calif., September 22 1928-March 16, 1999. Born in London and educated at Balliol College (Oxford), Columbia University and California State University-Northridge, he Worked as a librarian or records manager for American Electric Power, Columbia University, Louis Dreyfus and the N.Y. Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Cremation private. Contributions in his memory would be appreciated to a charity of your choice. We shall always recall with affection his English accent and how wondrously it withstood 44 years of American assault, his insights and wit, his passions for movies and beaches and views. Fans of Martin

title: Q&A/The Rev. John Thompson; Battling for Children's Lives Amid a War
description: IT could have been Germany in the 1940's, but it is Sierra Leone today. Soldiers arrive at the door searching for people to conscript or shoot. Upstairs people silently huddle together, hearts racing.

title: The Persistence Of Polygamy
description: It was divine intervention, not political expediency, that led the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) to ban the practice of polygamy more than 100 years ago. Indeed, any church member who engages in polygamy is excommunicated, whether the native country allows the practice or not.

title: Out Of The Jungle
description: ''Gods and Monsters'' is more than one of the most critically acclaimed movies of the year; it is the way that Hollywood works. Here, the gods are producers and studio executives, the monsters are the talent. Or, rather, the gods turn the talent into monsters -- overgrown boys who trash their hotel rooms or refuse to work without a personal chef.

title: Following the Dots Inspired by Nature to Create Abstractions
description: THOSE looking for an example of how abstraction, or good Abstract Art, can be distilled from life should visit the exhibition of paintings and watercolors by Caren Raphael at Kenise Barnes Fine Art here. Ms. Raphael's paintings are inspired by her fascination with the shapes and patterns of nature, whereby common sights are broken down, digested, then re-introduced in highly resolved abstractions.

title: March 14-20; Prison Nation
description: Despite seven straight years of falling crime, the number of inmates in the nation's jails and prisons climbed again last year, to a record 1.8 million, the Justice Department reported. The rise in the prison population is not the result of more effective police department policies. It is but largely the outcome of the get-tough-on-crime movement in this country: politicians legislating mandatory sentences, prosecutors pushing to make sure more offenders are locked up, judges giving longer sentences and parole boards less willing to let convicts out early. FOX BUTTERFIELD

title: 'Official Secrets'
description: To the Editor:

title: Batteries Not Included
description: The Technology of Orgasm

title: Upstate New York May Get Air Fare Relief
description: FLYING between New York City and upstate New York, which can cost more than flying across the Atlantic, may get cheaper this fall, because investors in a proposed discount airline are working with a variety of elected officials to bring fares down. But there are formidable obstacles to the plan, and leisure travelers may not benefit nearly so much as last-minute travelers paying full coach fare.

title: Castro's Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Needy Nets Hoping Seikaly Can Put His Ice Pack Aside
description: Rony Seikaly slipped around a pick at practice today, rose toward the basket, received a pass and in the same motion slammed it in with one hand. But as with most Nets plays, the good sign was accompanied by a bad sign: Seikaly gingerly landed on one foot.

title: 'Bunny' From Harrison Competes for Oscar
description: A LONELY old rabbit, hopping around her kitchen with the aid of a walker, begins to prepare a carrot cake when she is visited by memories of her dear, departed mate -- and a troublesome moth. After an exhausting battle with the winged intruder, which leads to its inclusion in the cake batter, the rabbit wakes from a fretful nap to investigate a strange occurrence emanating from inside her kitchen oven. Suddenly, she finds herself embarking on a journey into a new realm.

title: Andrea Cohen, David Meyer
description: Andrea Lynn Cohen, a daughter of Margery S. Cohen of New York and Albert A. Cohen of Aventura, Fla., was married last evening to Dr. David Benjamin Meyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Meyer of Kingston, Pa. Rabbi David H. Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: 3 Veterans Are Traded As Rebuilding Begins
description: Again without hope of making the playoffs, the Islanders began preparing for the future yesterday by trading three veterans to playoff-contending teams in exchange for youth and draft picks.

title: Please Enter Your 4-Digit Dining PIN
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter wants to keep employees from practicing arbitrage in the over-the-deli-counter market at its Two World Trade Center cafeteria in Manhattan. It seems that some workers would ask for extra sandwich fillings but not always mention them to the cashier.

title: COUNT ST. JOHN'S OUT; Red Storm Fumbles Last Chance Away
description: St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis looked back at the end to see what he was missing. Erick Barkley already knew. The St. John's point guard pulled his white jersey up over his eyes and weaved blindly through the celebrating Ohio State players tumbling around him, never raising his head, inconsolable over the result.

title: In French Wine Country, Good Eating, Too
description: VINEYARDS command the horizon along the Rhone River from Avignon to Lyons and, farther north, in Burgundy. In winter, of course, there are no grapes, or even vines. They've been pruned back, leaving only thick, gnarled stalks, rising a twisted foot or so above the ground.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about people who help writers, filmmakers and others get permission to use copyrighted materials misstated the length of one woman's experience in the field. Barbara Zimmerman, the president of BZ/Rights and Permissions, has been doing such work for 20 years, not 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, ELEANOR
description: KURTZ-Eleanor. Cherished sister of Arthur and Ann. Loving aunt of Wendy Shlomo, Jeffrey and Lori; and great-aunt. Service private.

title: From a Newark Principal, Lessons in Accountability
description: Vanessa McNeil was a freshman at West Side High School here when the state took over the Newark schools because of low academic achievement and corruption at the central office.

title: Taking On The War Between The Coasts
description: IN the ceaseless civic sniping between New York and this redoubt of surface charm and deep faults, everybody always talks about the weather, but nobody ever does anything about it. Until now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN, GEORGE J.
description: CHRISTENSEN-George J.. On March 20, 1999. Devoted husband of Ruth Korn Christensen, beloved father of Faith Maricic, and of George, Gerard, and Marylou, adored grandfather of Alexa, Brett, Eric and Gabriel-a noble, loving, dedicated giant of a man in all three roles. Founding President and CEO of Cristex Corporation of NY and NC. A true renaissance man interested and involved in a wide range of pursuits. With his passion for golf, boating, swimming, reading, gardening, world affairs, and with his zest for life, he enjoyed the love and esteem of all whose paths he crossed. Contributions in Mr. Christensen's memory may be made to The Center for Hope Hospice, 176 Hussa Street, Linden, NJ 07036; St. Agnes Church, 332 Madison Hill Rd., Clark, NJ 07066; or the Make A Wish Foundation.

title: For Sipping At the Seder
description: The modern Passover seder will jump-start with a semidry spiritual ancestor of Manischewitz, Gan Eden's '97 black muscat ($8), a piquant, near-sweet California light red, best served lightly chilled, or the '97 Yarden muscat white table wine, a semisweet, tangy, high-octane Israeli treat (500 milliliters, $11).

title: Chamber Music, Traditional Arts, Virtual Sante Fe
description: WHAT began as a New York appearance by performers of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival has evolved into a virtual weekend in the historic capital of New Mexico: a three-day musical and cultural holiday, beginning on Thursday, mostly within the confines of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And as befits Santa Fe, where controversy flows back through history to the city's founding in 1610, the music is likely to be accompanied by a note of political discord.

title: At War
description: To the Editor:

title: Theft in Spain
description: To the Editor: On Oct. 31, I stopped for coffee on the Barcelona-Tarragona Expressway. My wife stayed in the car and was soon approached by a young man who engaged her in banal conversation. We resumed driving, and very soon the rear tire on the passenger side went flat, forcing me to enter a nearby rest area. Shortly after, a car entered the area and the same young man offered his help.

title: A Quiet Leader Who Is No Pushover
