description: THERE is a mountain view from the large glass windows in the living room of the gray farmhouse. The house has been expanded, updated, and decorated with artifacts brought back from travel to Asia. A bright red barn sits in the backyard. The property, bordered on one side by a stonewall, has a meadow and brook across the road. In 1951, when the Eads family bought it, the house fit all the requirements of M. Adela and Vern Eads because it has a rural setting, a barn and water. The couple reared their two sons there and Mr. Eads runs a business from there. Storing parts in the barn, he buys and sells large machinery used to make such things as propellors and anchors, and he liquidates manufacturing plants.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 21 about the current show of photographs by Abelardo Morell at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston included an erroneous reference from the exhibition's organizers to his history of solo shows. His first was at the National Arts Club in New York in 1993; it is not this show.

title: D'Amato's Legacy to Island Park May Include a Huge Federal Fine
description: ISLAND PARK'S claim to fame has long been its favorite son. For years the welcoming sign on the main road into the village boasted: ''Entering Island Park, N.Y., U.S.A., home of Al D'Amato, U.S. Senator.''

title: Rebecca Grossman and Ari Berman
description: Rebecca Lynne Grossman, a daughter of Arlene Grossman and Dr. Harry Grossman of North Brunswick, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Ari Michael Berman, a son of Susan and Joel Berman of Hewlett Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Mandelbaum is to officiate at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Should the West Save Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear Itself
description: Ruth Lippin's first panic attack in -- ''of all places'' -- the middle of a vast farm field in Holland reminded me of a quote attributed to Kierkegaard: ''Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom.'' Perhaps some of our general anxieties are a result of those brief and infrequent episodes of consciousness, the ''weird thing, the unusual thing'' mentioned by Joseph LeDoux.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 21, 1999
description: Weeks

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: An Unfinished Merlot

title: What Does Joy Schott Want? Wall Street Is Listening
description: THINKING of starting or investing in a business to serve retired people? The monthly luncheon of the Desert Newcomers, a club for retired women who recently moved to Las Vegas, might be a good place to do market research, except for one hitch. The ladies do not like to talk business. Desert Newcomers is strictly a social club.

title: Finding a Slice of Heaven In the Delis of Hoboken
description: THERE was a bitter, if forlorn yet stubborn beauty everywhere you looked in Hoboken.'' So wrote Edward Abbey, the naturalist and writer, who lived in the Mile Square City for a single year in the 60's, or maybe the 70's (he was not clear on the point).

title: Transcendent Music
description: To the Editor:

title: March 14-20; A Truck, a Train And a Fatal Encounter
description: An Amtrak train heading from Chicago to New Orleans crashed into a truck at a crossing in Bourbonnais, Ill., 50 miles south of Chicago, raising fresh questions about the safety of the country's track crossings. Eleven people were killed and more than 100 were injured.

title: Rocky Mountain Low
description: PERFECT MURDER, PERFECT TOWN

title: SOAPBOX; When Life Was a Dream
description: TO the viewing public, Roberto Benigni's Oscar-nominated film, ''Life is Beautiful,'' is about the Holocaust. To savvy film critics, it's about a father-son relationship within the context of war. But to the children of Holocaust survivors, the movie's underlying premise is as obvious as it is familiar. It's about rewriting our family's stories.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the evolution of software-based robots, known as bots, misstated the given name of the inventor of what is now called the Turing test, which judges the sophistication of artificial intelligence programs. He was Alan M. Turing, not Joseph.

title: Honoring A Passion For State's History
description: A MAN whose lifelong career was devoted to Connecticut's artistic and historical heritage will be remembered in a series of lectures sponsored by the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society, a statewide museum-based preservation organization. William Warren, who died last year at the age of 86, joined the society shortly after its founding, became a trustee, contributed to its scholarly journal and played a major role in developing two of its finest properties as museums.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARIAS, HERNANDO
description: ARIAS-Hernando. March 21, 1994. It's been five years, but it seems more like an eternity. Love, Cuca

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Foreign Bodies

title: DATABANK: March 15-19; Asian Markets Gain, as the Dow Teases Teases
description: There are momentous thresholds, like the Dow 10,000, and then there is momentum.

title: Rediscovering Joy in a Box in the Basement
description: SALT MARSH along the Connecticut River in Old Lyme heaves with the tide like the pelt of a lazy lion stretching under a pre-spring sun. Old stone walls lace the landscape. On the back lawn, a deer gently grazes.

title: Rooms and Tickets For Sydney Olympics
description: The next Olympic Summer Games, to be held in Sydney, are a little less than 18 months away, but it's not too early to order hotel accommodations and tickets. Cartan Tours, the company chosen by the organizers of the Sydney games as the official United States sales agent for Olympics tickets and tours, began taking orders last week for the Games, scheduled for Sept. 15 to Oct. 1, 2000.

title: When Not to Mix Deals With Gemutlichkeit
description: Headed for Europe to break bread and make deals? Make them over lunch in most countries, but over breakfast or dinner in Italy. But in Germany, don't even think about a business breakfast; in fact, you might want to skip mixing food and business altogether.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Not a Photograph but . . .

title: Canada Faces New Pressure To Safeguard Rare Wildlife
description: In just one day, a North American grizzly bear can lumber across the border from Montana, where it is protected by law, to the Canadian province of Alberta, where it can be legally hunted and shot.

title: The Tie That Binds Two Rangers: Concussions
description: Backstage at Madison Square Garden last week, two very different hockey players discussed their very similar injuries and their unpleasant consequences. In a large banquet room stood Pat LaFontaine, small for a professional athlete, eloquently thanking guests who came to honor him for a brilliant career that prematurely ended at age 33 because of multiple concussions.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on March 7 with an artist's rendering of the Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville omitted a credit. It was provided by Lee H. Skolnick Architecture and Design Partnership, the designer of the center.

title: High Rents Squeeze Lawmakers
description: When Eric Schneiderman began representing the West Side of Manhattan in the State Senate last January, his first task was a doozy: finding office space in the city for $20,000 in annual rent, the maximum the Senate allots its members.

title: Forget Golf, There Are Masterpieces to Make
description: DAVID BIALOBRODA, 80, was in the studio, working on his latest sculpture, which will portray the American Revolution, and the wars and revolutions that followed it. He had finished carving a resolute George Washington, with clenched fists, surrounded by the faces of 170 soldiers.

description: Following are excerpts from several wide-ranging conversations between the director George Lucas and the writer Orville Schell that took place recently at Mr. Lucas's house in San Rafael, Calif., and nearby at his Skywalker Ranch.

description: AND THE WALLS CAME

title: Coming of Age At Bloomberg L.P.
description: SETH RUSKIN, a global equities trader in Florida who is about to change jobs, made it a point to insist on one thing from his new employer, Wanger Asset Management of Chicago. The firm had only a few computer terminals providing the Bloomberg financial data service, and he wanted to be sure he had one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNICK, DR. ABBY
description: ZELNICK-Dr. Abby. You were a joyful part of our lives. We will always remember and always miss you. Shirley and Ely Krellenstein

title: In Spain, Americans on the Trail of the Exotic, the Dynamic
description: THE ready assumption about late 19th- and early 20th-century American painting influenced by Spain and Spanish art is that the Americans borrowed from the distinguished tradition to give their work an exotic twist. In part this is true, but it must be remembered that Spain did not simply represent the romantic past. It was an extremely vital country: in the years just preceding the beginning of the 20th century, a time Spain was America's major rival on the world stage.

title: Reining In the Hedge Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheel Men
description: Streetwise skateboarders put their best foot forward in new styles for spring.

title: Playground For Fish And Man
description: ON board the stern-wheeler Columbia Gorge, we are headed toward a precipice where the river plunges 70 feet through Bonneville Dam. Technically, our triple decker boat -- a modernized replica of the big stern-wheelers that plied the Columbia River at the turn of the century -- is paddling its way along a lake, the body of water that was formed 61 years ago when the dam was built on the Columbia River. But the water here in Lake Bonneville moves along swiftly, over the dam and on to the Pacific Ocean.

title: March 14-20; South African Found Guilty
description: The courtroom was packed as the former anti-apartheid activist Allan Boesak was found guilty of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars earmarked for helping children and educating black voters before South Africa's 1994 elections.

description: THE JEWISH LOVER By Edward Topol. St. Martin's, $25.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Jule Eisenbud, 90, Parapsychology Researcher
description: Dr. Jule Eisenbud, a psychiatrist, author and researcher best known for his interest in parapsychology, died on March 10 in Denver. He was 90.

title: They'll Take Manhattan, and the Subway, Too
description: ASK Ruth Weiss what she likes about her chosen retirement community and she will rattle off a host of conveniences, including the short walk to the local concert hall and the shorter walks to nearby markets. Mrs. Weiss's building provides daily meals and laundry service, and she can always find a game of Rummy Q in one of the public lounges.

title: Mets Enjoy Watching The Progress Of Escobar
description: Watching players, some of them barely out of high school, on Friday afternoon, it was hard to imagine that anyone on the remote field at Dodgertown in nearby Vero Beach was anywhere close to a year and half away from the major leagues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, MURRY C.
description: BECKER-Murry C.. Dear Father, we miss you and honor your memory with love and reverence. Your Children, Grandchildren, and Great-Granddaughter

title: Thar She Blows!
description: A blowup in Paris: The old metro vents are playing havoc with the newly revived full skirts and are catching a new generation off guard, as their pleats inflate like parachutes and winter coats go horizontal. Parisian women old enough to remember Marilyn Monroe's famous encounter -- and the full-skirted New Look of the 1950's -- know to avoid the updrafts. Which is harder to do in Paris than in New York, because the vents (from which the air blows continually, not just when trains pass) can cover virtually the entire sidewalk. Beware especially the Rue de Rivoli, outside the Louvre.

title: Hale (and Some Not-So-Hale) Fellows, All of Them Well Met
description: IN the steam of the shower room, a full hour before dawn, the rumor sounded with a certain echoing gravity. ''Al Lucero,'' said Vic, soaping the Hula dancer tattooed on his biceps back in his Navy days, during World War II. ''Al Lucero has bought a swim suit.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE NARROWBACK

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ANNETTE ROSE (NEE GOLDBERG)
description: COHEN-Annette Rose (nee Goldberg). 3/24/59. In cherished and loving memory of our dearly beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Still loved and very much missed. Always in our hearts. Lucille Richard Jay and Daughters Lindsey Heather & Ashley Brooke

title: Teacher Sentenced
description: Martin O'Keefe, 53, a former teacher in the Yonkers School District, was sentenced this month to three to six years in state prison. After a nonjury trial, he was convicted on Nov. 23, 1998, of nine counts of sexual abuse and three counts of endangering the welfare of a child.

title: Chaney Has His Owls In a Zone of Their Own
description: He said his match-up zone defense is about time and distance. It is simple really, Temple Coach John Chaney insisted today. Temple's Rasheed Brokenborough backed him up. The senior guard explained that the defense is not a 2-3 or a 1-3-1; it is called Rover, and he claimed the Owls only practice it the first two weeks of the season.

title: Queens College Dorm Critics Fear 'Berkeley by the L.I.E.'
description: As Queens College administrators begin looking into whether to build dormitories nearby, some residents and local officials have a message for them: Don't even think about it.

title: Police Shoot Two Teen-Agers After Car Chase in Brooklyn
description: Police officers investigating a car theft in Brooklyn yesterday morning shot and wounded two teen-age suspects when they tried to run over the officers, the police said.

title: Not an Age, but an Expanding State of Mind
description: FOR three years now, ever since abandoning a full-time job at age 66, I've been keeping track of the responses from friends and acquaintances to the statement, ''I'm retired.'' In general, younger people have congratulated me on my new-found freedom: ''You're a lucky guy!'' The reaction from older people has been more reserved, even concerned: ''What are you going to do with yourself? How will you manage?''

title: Hotel Tenants Worry and City Sues Owner
description: Alexa Benoit has lived in a residential hotel at 350 West 88th Street, near Riverside Drive, for 12 years, and has seen it transformed from a low-income women's residence called the Simmons House to the Hotel Riverside, a tourist hotel charging $110 a night.

title: The Holocaust, In Today's Terms; Don't Blame Academics
description: To the Editor:

title: Obsessed by Place, and Finding One on a Frontier
description: ONE evening in 1966, drifting through the streets of midtown Manhattan, Ernie Gehr came in out of the rain. Not knowing what to do with his life, he had been aimlessly traveling around the country after his release from the Army -- 99 days for $99 on Greyhound -- and hadn't been in New York for long. He took shelter in the doorway of a building that, as it happened, housed a theater in the basement where a screening of experimental cinema was being held. It was work by Stan Brakhage, a fierce pioneer of the one-man film who was renowned in avant-garde circles. Making films had never occurred to this young wanderer, but the screening that kept him from a downpour was a revelation. Here was a guy making films in a way he, too, could make them. Ernie Gehr had come in out of the rain and found his vocation.

title: Rose's Turn
description: There are three reasons Charlie Rose doesn't think this article should have been written. ''No. 1, I'm boring,'' he says over his usual lunch, Cobb salad, at his usual table, front and center, at his usual restaurant, Michael's, the kind of place where water costs $6 a bottle and the man in the pinstripe suit at the next table is likely to be the C.E.O. of a media conglomerate. ''No. 2,'' he goes on, ''I don't want to be out front on this '60 Minutes' thing.'' This ''60 Minutes' thing'' is ''60 Minutes II'' or, as they say in the business, ''62,'' the clone of the original television newsmagazine that had its premiere in January.

title: All-You-Can-Eat Buffet With an Emphasis on Curry
description: Dakshin, an Indian restaurant that opened three weeks ago in Clinton, at 741 Ninth Avenue, at 50th Street, is owned by Sanjay Bahatnajar (formerly general manager of Bay Leaf on West 56th Street), and Gurubex Bhatia (who also owns Besara at 50th Street and First Avenue). Northern and southern Indian cuisine is featured, and there is a $7 all-you-can-eat lunch buffet, from noon to 3 P.M. daily, with chicken, lamb, rice, six salads and three vegetable dishes. Among a la carte appetizers are juinga jaltoori, shrimp with mustard and curry leaves ($5). Entrees include mangalorean fry, spicy stir-fry chicken with green chilies ($8).

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Amber Hunter,

title: Restoring An Aging Bathtub
description: WHEN a car gets old and rusty you replace it. When a shirt gets stained and yellow you retire it. And when a carpet gets worn and shabby, you toss it out and get a new one.

title: Up in the 'Real Maine,' One Man Picks Up Where He Left Off
description: YOU can go home again. Not everyone wants to, of course, and not everyone has left. But it is a given in this restless land that a lot of us will leave our roots to chase some dream. Of those, more than a few will share the fantasy that when they retire they will return to the place where they grew up.

title: Tuning In to N.Y. Kids
description: http://www.nykids.org

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- On Language; Mother Wit
description: 'No, it had nothing to do with ethics,'' said President Clinton's friend Vernon Jordan, originally from Georgia, explaining to Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas why he would have no hand in the destruction of evidence, ''as much as it's just good common sense, mother wit -- you remember that in the South.''

title: East Harlem Provocateur on the City Payroll
description: ''YOU come back in six months,'' Philip Reed said to me 13 months ago. He was just starting his first year as a member of the City Council. ''I might have answers. I will surely have a carpet on the floor.''

title: Bright Young Things
description: WHEN WE WERE THREE

title: Making Late-Course Adjustments to the Rest of Their Lives
description: HERB ELLIOTT is more excited than perhaps one man should be as he shows off a small pile of Native American arrowheads and stone tools, which he found among the bulldozers and overturned dirt on the eighth fairway near his new home.

title: THE NATION: Taking Off; Missile Defenses Leave Fantasy Behind
description: IT'S a far cry from the space-based, rocket-zapping shield that President Ronald Reagan envisioned more than a decade and a half ago in the depths of the cold war. But the country is suddenly jettisoning its qualms about forging a national missile defense and is moving fast toward building one.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST; Rutgers to Meet Purdue In the Midwest Final
description: It was one of those precious moments known to bring a tear, a smile and even a moment of reflection. After all, Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer had made it known that she wasn't exceptionally joyous just to get her team to the Round of 16 of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: SOAPBOX; Movie Manners: The End?
description: WHEN I sit down tonight to watch the Oscars, there is one thing for which I'll be grateful, the solitude of my own home. I've spent a lot of time in movie theaters lately, as an escape from the fast-paced, stress-filled days that define my life. But lately this pastime has become a source of annoyance, right up there with dental appointments and gynecological exams. The old sense of moviegoing etiquette, where you paid your $4.50 and remained silently absorbed in the film, has deteriorated, if not vanished.

title: America's Cup Challengers Closely Guard Their Secrets
description: It would seem that security at a boat yard would not be much of a concern. But America's Cup fever has been known to force competitors to search each other's garbage for clues on boat design. So with the start of the next cup races less than seven months away, no one is taking chances.

title: March 14-20; Sleep and Aging
description: Mary Gordon, the novelist, once described her erotic fantasy: Getting a good night's sleep. Aging boomers will understand soon enough. Sleep grows lighter with age, and almost a third will suffer from chronic insomnia. Sleeping pills can treat symptoms, but side effects in the elderly are linked to falls and car accidents. A more durable solution, researchers reported, is behavioral therapy to instill better sleep habits. ERICA GOODE

title: Done With Work, Volunteers Move On to Giving Back
description: EIGHT adults crowd around a conference table in the library of the Taylor Elementary School to discuss their work with the youngest students. They refer to ''my child'' and ''my children'' as if they are talking about members of their families, even though they are not. The school is in an area that is called either North Philly or the Badlands depending on whether the geography or the sociology is being described.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: TRACKING DOWN THE ARTS

title: New Jersey Finds No Simple Solutions in School Takeovers
description: Ten years ago, New Jersey officials decided they were tired of watching from the sidelines as Jersey City school and city officials seemed more concerned with providing jobs for friends than with falling student test scores. So state officials took charge of the system, kicking out the Superintendent and the locally elected Board of Education members.

title: Red Carpet Runway
description: Diamond-studded sandals. Body glitter. Three-piece tuxedos. A scouting report reveals some of the trends the stars are applauding as they get ready for the big show tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, MAURICE JR
description: ADELMAN-Maurice Jr. Funeral mass in Savannah, Georgia. Interment at Old Bohemia Church Yard, Warwick, Maryland. Memorial service, Sunday, May 2, 1999 at Church of the Virgin Mary, Eighth Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn, New York at 11 A.M. Refreshments after the service at the Montauk Club, 25 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Brooklyn Public Library, Main Branch would be appreciated.

title: ART / ARCHITECTURE; A Colorful Desert Gets a Splash of Magical Realism
description: ONE of Santa Fe's legends recounts the martyrdom of a missionary whose prayers that his death not be in vain suddenly caused the surrounding mountain range to glow crimson. As if to commemorate the event that christened it Sangre de Cristo (or Blood of Christ), the range continues to turn brilliant hues of rust red and pink with each dawn and sunset. By day, the mountains' connection with their picturesque name is no less striking: viewed through the clear, dry desert air, the Sangre de Cristo displays the richest shades of blue and purple. To such an enchanted landscape now comes the sensibility of a magical realist. Not in the form of a Latino writer, a Gabriel Garcia Marquez or a Laura Esquivel, for example, but that of an architect, the Mexican designer Ricardo Legorreta.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- The Ethicist; A Slap in the Face
description: 'I was on the subway when I saw a frustrated mother slap her child for crying. She didn't hit him hard enough to endanger his life, but the scene suggested something equally scary: an eternity of whacks, verbal abuse and humiliation. I was afraid to say something lest I make the mother even angrier -- at the child. Should I have?'

title: Article 1999032100000832707 -- No Title
description: Lynn Marie Roland and Donald Francis Steele 3d were married last evening at Studio Z805, a photography studio in New York. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester County, performed the ceremony.

title: America West Averts Strike As Attendants Reach Accord
description: Averting a strike minutes after a deadline had passed, America West Airlines and the union representing its 2,300 flight attendants reached tentative agreement on a contract early yesterday.

title: In Scarsdale, Skiing Runs in the Family
description: GENERATIONS of Scarsdale residents have put family members on the high school downhill ski teams here that have known little else than success. In the last dozen years, for example, the Lawrence Matlick family has had 5 members on the teams, Susan Cohen has put 4 of her children on teams, and 20 other families have had 2 siblings each on the teams -- frequently simultaneously -- and occasionally, both are captains.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Danbury, Conn., misidentified the affiliation of a broker, Ellen Boyle. She is with William Pitt Real Estate, not Prudential Connecticut Realty.

title: Saturday Night Moves
description: IT was a concert that could have made mummies dance. The Wha? Band was playing amply amplified funk, the revelers were jammed so close they seemed vacuum-packed, and about 200 people stood in the rain outside, waiting to be funneled in.

title: Word for Word / A Sex Manual, Then and Now; Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Changing With the Times*
description: IN 1969, the California psychiatrist Dr. David Reuben published a groundbreaking book with the improbable title ''Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* *But Were Afraid to Ask.'' Answering hundreds of blush-inducing questions about the most basic of human relations (''What does impotence mean?'' ''What happens during orgasm?''), it was a blockbuster primer for those confronted by the polymorphous excesses of the Age of Aquarius. Dr. Reuben was touted as ''the new apostle of sanity in sex'' and his carnal Baedeker became a No. 1 best-seller in 51 countries.

title: Billionaire Boy Scouts
description: GOLDMAN SACHS

title: KOSOVO SITUATION WORSENS AS SERBS PRESS OFFENSIVE
description: As hundreds of foreign monitors left Kosovo and President Clinton met his national security advisers to discuss the worsening situation there, Serbian forces took advantage of the vacuum today to press a heavy offensive against the separatist Kosovo Liberation Army.

title: Reason in Rhymes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, IRWIN H.
description: KAISER-Irwin H.., M.D. Mentor, teacher and dear friend. A great man for whom prejudice was unknown and condemned. His memory will live long in generations of residents and medical students for his keen intellect, iconoclastic views which challenged them to better themselves. He was a pioneer in championing women's rights, causes and health care. An early advocate of patient's rights. To his wife Judge Barabara (of whom he was very proud) and his family our heartfelt sympathy and sadness. Kay and Mamdouh Anderson-Moukhtar, M.D.'s

title: Children's Barber With a Secret Weapon: Candy
description: Decorated with Winnie the Pooh murals and gaily colored floor mats, Kidz World, a barber shop for children, opened in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, at 1891 Fulton Street between Ralph and Howard Avenues. The owner, Stephen Usenbor, 22, came to New York from Nigeria when he was 3. After working as a barber at adult salons, he opened Kidz World. ''I love kids, so I'd rather do kids' hair,'' Mr. Usenbor said. ''There aren't many places like this in the area.'' How does he keep fidgety children tranquil? Candy. ''And I let them hold the clippers, so they realize that it won't hurt. So far, they've all left with a haircut.''

title: Flamboyant Lawyer Had a Darker Side; He Disappears as Claims of Theft And Ignoring Clients' Cases Multiply
description: A hard rain was tailing off about noon on March 1 when F. Mac Buckley, a burly cigar smoker who was one of Connecticut's best-known criminal-defense lawyers, pulled out of the driveway of his 258-year-old Colonial here in the countryside southeast of Hartford. He grabbed his cellular phone and called his Hartford office to say he was headed for Federal court in New Haven, where he was due at a 2 P.M. hearing for a client charged with selling cocaine.

title: The World; Two Different Tyrants, Very Much the Same
description: BACK in the West's halcyon days, spring 1991, when Saddam Hussein had just been vanquished in the gulf war and Eastern Europe had apparently jettisoned Communism for good, few Americans had even heard of the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Bamberger Is Remembered In His Hometoown
description: To the Editor:

title: A Curse on The House
description: When a party leader states that he has no clue as to why the majority of Americans feel so strongly about the nation's top issue (impeachment), maybe it's time to start looking at the whole picture (James Traub, Feb. 28). Frank Luntz's admission ''How the rest of the country can not feel good about it is truly beyond me'' says a lot. If Dennis Hastert and Luntz want to find out what's wrong with the party, they could start by examining the connection between the close-mindedness of the far right and the blindness exhibited by the Luntz statement.

title: Bookend; You May Already Be a Winner
description: Just going to sit there while huge conglomerates pay millions for memoirs and autobiographies by folks even duller and less accomplished than you? If you're a windbag, egomaniac, faded star -- or simply like the sound of your own droning voice -- here's your chance to cash in on the hottest trend in book publishing today: smash celebrity megaflops!

title: Where Were the Spitballs In Caesar's Gallic Wars?
description: I'M sure you are as alarmed as I am about the deterioration of basic skills among New Jersey's high school population.

title: Just One Maniac Per Point
description: When 10,000 Maniacs played its first show in September 1981, the Dow Jones industrial average was in the 800's. . Before a concert in Ithaca last week, just a day after the Dow first inched over 10,000, the band talked about what its members called ''the other 10,000.''

title: Escape From Paradise
description: DEVIL'S VALLEY By Andre Brink. 401 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $24.

title: Pinstriped for Greatness
description: It is a testament to Derek Jeter that his peers will project his future greatness, estimate how big a star he will become, or try to guess what his place in history will be. Baseball veterans typically frown on such conjecture, for their game is relentlessly demanding and challenging and they know almost all young players will wilt.

title: Jump Start
description: Leap on it! Spring, there are clothes for pros from all walks of life, even acrobats

title: . . . And a Live-Wire Climber From Australia
description: EVEN before she made her first movie, Rachel Griffiths's face was famous. She first realized this back home in Australia while sitting in a Melbourne movie house watching Martin Scorsese's 1991 remake of the thriller ''Cape Fear.'' In it, Robert De Niro's oily convict stalks a teen-ager played by Juliette Lewis, who has the same high forehead as Ms. Griffiths, as well as the same full mouth, large eyes and short dark hair. Being presented with so many similarities writ so very large was almost too much for Ms. Griffiths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERHEYDEN, JAIME
description: VANDERHEYDEN-Jaime. Beloved and feisty daughter of Gail LeVine Vanderheyden and John W. Vanderheyden, Falls Church, VA. Granddaughter of Robert and Marge LeVine of Roslyn, NY, and Frank and Marion Vanderheyden of Falls Church, VA. Succumbed to brain and spinal cancer after a 5-1/2 year battle at age 11-1/2 on 3/17/99. Adored by aunts and uncles, Robin and Bob Ballin, Lon and Jan LeVine, Lore and Mel Mallin, Alice Schild, Sonya Goldman and Dale Vanderheyden. Donations may be sent to Eagle Mount of Bozeman, Mont.-Special Love of Winchester VA-and Make A Wish Foundations

title: New Local Law
description: The Board of Legislators has passed a local law prohibiting the sale of spray paint, box cutters and laser-pointing devices to customers younger than 18.

title: The History of Retirement, From Early Man to A.A.R.P.
description: IN THE BEGINNING

title: Lives; In the Dark
description: If you're like most folks with good eyes, you've probably examined the Braille in hotel elevators. You may even have touched the raised dots signifying your floor and marveled at the capacity of the blind to travel and read in the dark. Who would imagine that Braille would be supplanted by machines? Who would guess that Braille is even now nearly extinct?

title: Planning, by the Numbers
description: A number of organizations maintain Web sites with work sheets that consumers can use and valuable information for planning. Among them are the following:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENSON, MILTON
description: LEBENSON-Milton. Beloved husband of the late Gladys. Dearest father of Richard. Loving brother of Leonard. Services Monday, 12 noon, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Singing in Tongues (the Original Ones, That Is)
description: When English-speaking choruses prepare a work by Bach or Brahms, they try to place their vocal tone and speaking mechanism to produce a ''German sound'' -- hard to describe but easy to recognize. Similarly, Russian sound in a Russian work is worth striving for, even if total capture is not achieved.

title: To a Photographer, Objects of Affection But Also Inspiration
description: MOST people view the things they collect as a diversion from what they do for a living. But for the Japanese photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto, the traditional Japanese art he collects is absolutely essential to the art he creates: compelling images of seascapes, waxworks, life-size Buddhas and the gilded interiors of motion picture palaces.

title: Q&A/Donald W. Downes; Regulating Utilities in Turbulent Times
description: WHEN utility bills rise, angry Connecticut consumers call the Department of Public Utility Control. When utility companies want their rates raised, they call the Department. The chairman who balances these competing forces is Donald W. Downes, a lawyer and former deputy in Gov. John G. Rowland's budget office.

title: Dutch Court to Hear Case of Frenchman Trying to Control Gucci
description: The high-stakes, high-drama struggle for control of Italy's fabled Gucci fashion house goes back to a Dutch court on Monday, after the French luxury goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. said it would seek to invalidate a deal Gucci struck on Friday to sell 40 percent of its shares to one of France's wealthiest takeover investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSSMAN, LORRAINE V.
description: HAUSSMAN-Lorraine V.. Film producer passed away quietly on March 14, 1999 in Acapulco, Mexico. Devoted daughter of Philippe Haussmann and the late Fay Haussman. Beloved sister of Claude Haussmann. She will be missed. Condolences can be sent to Claude Haussmann, 1619 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10128. HAUSSMAN-Lorraine V. With our deepest sympathies to Claude and Philippe Haussmann. Our thoughts are with you. Pauline J. Perahia and family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTNER, HAROLD
description: GARTNER-Harold. It is with great sadness that we mourn the sudden loss of our dear brother-in-law and uncle who will live within our hearts forever. The Gordon & Schindler Families

title: Let's Ban Boxing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A New Stage Where There's Always a Doctor in the House
description: WHEN Gabor Barabas, 19 years old and newly married, was a pre-med student at the University of Cincinnati in 1968, his 18-year-old wife, SuzAnne, who had taken acting classes with Lee Strasberg, had to do something to ''maintain my sanity,'' as she put it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENBACH, L.
description: KATZENBACH-L.. Emery, 83. Of Waccabuc, N.Y. and Westport, MA.. An investment banker and former Chairman of White Weld & Company of N.Y. On March 18, 1999 at home. Beloved husband of Marley (nee Marseilles). Loving father to Mrs. Nicholas Niles, Jr. of Southport, CT., Mrs. William A. Barker of Dublin, N.H., and Christian D. Katzenbach of Irasburg, VT. Six grandchildren also survive. He was predeceased by a son, L. Emery Katzenbach, Jr. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, March 24 at 11 A.M. in the chapel of the United Congregational Church of New Canaan, 23 Park Street, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Atlantic Salmon Federation (U.S.) PO Box 429, St. Andrew's New Brunswick, Canada EOG-2XO or St. Johnsbury Athenaeum, 30 Main St., St. Johnsbury, VT 05819.

title: Older Students Bring New Life to Campuses
description: AFTER teaching high school Latin for 38 years in Binghamton, N.Y., Nancy L. Hanover retired last fall to the mountains of western North Carolina with a hunger to learn all of those things she could never find time to learn as a working mother of three.

title: A Growing Market in Hot Technology
description: CRIMINALS following the Willie Sutton rule -- go where the money is -- are not knocking over banks, as Sutton did. They are raiding shipments of computers, microchips and cell phones.

title: A Balloonist's Adventurous Lineage
description: By profession, Bertrand Piccard is a Swiss psychiatrist. By avocation, he is a pioneer, from a family of noted scientific adventurers.

title: Corrections
description: The hardcover Business Best Sellers list last Sunday misidentified the publisher of ''Goldman Sachs: The Culture of Success,'' the No. 11 book. It is Alfred A. Knopf, not Cliff Street/HarperCollins.

title: Studs Terkel's 'Working': Singing the Unsung Heroic
description: IT is no surprise that the most resounding way the musical ''Working'' strikes a fanfare for the common man is, clearly and simply, through the words of Studs Terkel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JOSEPH R.
description: GROSS-Joseph R.. Age 64, lifelong resident of NYC. Died on March 19, 1999, in Greensburg, PA, after a short illness. He was preceded in death by his parents, Elsie Woehl Gross and Joseph G. Gross. He is survived by cousins Lourdes Woehl Nowalk and her husband Thomas, and Dr. Joseph J. Woehl of Greensburg. He was a graduate of Regis Academy and Fordham University. Mr. Gross was a retired social worker for the city of New York. He was a gentle man of Christian spirit and luminous intellect. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd St, on Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Gregory the Great R.C. Church. Interment Old St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: An Activist Shareholder Takes On The World
description: ROBERT A. G. MONKS, money manager and shareholder rights proponent, has long been a sort of Lone Ranger of American investing, charging in to exhort companies to change their ways in the name of helping shareholders.

title: National News Briefs; Autopsies on 2 Bodies Conducted in California
description: Autopsies were expected to be completed today on the two bodies found on Friday in the trunk of a car that had been rented by three sightseers who disappeared near Yosemite National Park more than a month ago, but the authorities said they had not identified the bodies or determined the cause of death.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; First Accord Seen Near on Cleanup Reimbursement
description: TODD L. NORMANE calls the more flexible way the state works with developers to recycle polluted industrial sites ''more like a handshake than a hammer.'' For the process includes a new financial incentive -- reimbursement for up to 75 percent of the cleanup cost.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERT, CECIL
description: LAMBERT-Cecil. Dear father, on this your 90th birthday you are remembered with love always. Steven, Barbara, Corey & Joseph.

title: An Artist Responds To a Critic's Assumption
description: It was a pleasure to be included in ''Three Whose Works Transcend the Genre'' [Jan. 17], the review of the exhibition ''A Silvermine Arrangement'' at the Hammond Museum in North Salem and very satisfying to see my painted fan, ''Sun Flowers,'' reproduced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDER, ETHELETTE TUCKER
description: RIDDER-Ethelette Tucker. Of NYC, on Tuesday, March 16 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Sister of James G. Black. Mother of Susan and Eric Ridder, Jr. Longtime companion of Nelson Loud. Services will be held at St. James Church, Madison and 71 Street, Monday at 12 noon.

title: Should the West Save Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Working Under the Spirit of Aaron Copland
description: THE composer Mark Kilstofte recently completed an enviable, if daunting, experience. Ensconced in solitude on a wooded hilltop here, he found that his only responsibilities were music. Food was delivered, a donated car awaited his every whim and a housekeeper arrived punctually to whisk away the dust.

title: At Two Sites, Comfort Food That Spans the Globe
description: Walk along Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, and you can now find two Harvest restaurants. David Schneider, who has owned Harvest at 218 Court Street, between Warren and Baltic Streets, for the last two years, recently opened Harvest East, at No. 242 (between Baltic and Kane Streets). Harvest serves southern American comfort food, and Harvest East serves a blend of Asian and American cooking and has a sake bar. Appetizers include fried lobster wontons and smoked shrimp spring rolls (both $6). Green chili roast chicken and braised beef soup are each $12.

title: When Do Artists Pack It In? Never
description: I travel widely in the village of Sargentville, Me., and its environs, an area of 5 square miles with a full-time population of about 75. I do not have to go very far to find examples of retired people who continue to lead creative lives long after they have reached old age. They are, or have been, all around me.

title: Winning Is Less Important on the Other Side of the Street
description: ''Where I come from,'' growled Jennifer Llaneras, a 14-year-old artist and shortstop from East Harlem, ''girls are supposed to be china dolls and stay on shelves. Not me. I'm here to play, not be displayed.''

title: Bonnie Benedek, Howard Hornstein
description: Bonnie Berken Benedek, an interior designer, and Howard B. Hornstein, a lawyer, were married in New York on Thursday. Rabbi Henry Michaelman officiated at the home of Ellen Carter Wiesenthal, a friend of the bride.

title: Accord in Ecuador Can't Hide Woes
description: For the moment, the streets are quiet again and no one except an exiled former President is demanding that the current head of state, Jamil Mahuad, step down. But even after cobbling together an accord that ended two weeks of strikes and political turmoil, Ecuador remains as divided and economically vulnerable as ever.

title: The Problem Solver
description: INSISTING ON THE IMPOSSIBLE The Life of Edwin Land. By Victor K. McElheny. Illustrated. 510 pp. Reading, Mass.: A Merloyd Lawrence Book/Perseus Books. $30.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: In the Land of God and Man

title: Four Brothers Walking on Air
description: If everything goes according to the Amazing Vitas' plan, once you have read this, you can head to the nearest record store and buy their rap album, tentatively titled ''Soul Patrol.'' And they hope you'll run to your local multiplex a year from now to see a movie with the same name.

title: For Openers, MetroStars Win Dramatic Shootout
description: It wasn't Jets-Dolphins, Knicks-Heat or even Mets-Marlins. But the MetroStars and Fusion tonight added another rivalry to the New York-Miami sports scene.

title: Food; Bait and Switch
description: Even before Florida had the razzle-dazzle of Disney, the Sunshine State was no stranger to flimflam. Florida's most prized fish, pompano and red snapper, have long been maligned by cheeky impostors.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. If only authenticity were the reason the musicians are wearing their own shoes. And socks. And belts. The real explanation is that the van carrying the shoot's clothes and accessories was late the first day. Day two, the driver simply didn't show. Fortunately, the clothes had already been unloaded. The van company eventually reported that the driver had taken ill and driven himself and the accessories to the hospital. 2. James Intveld can now add fashion model to his roster of credits as singer, songwriter, actor and producer. Intveld, who has played with Willie Nelson, Bruce Springsteen and Bob Dylan, and acted with Sean Penn and Willem Dafoe, refers to his own blend of rockabilly and swing as ''roots rock.'' (a) Charlie Overbey's band, Custom Made Scare, has a little more fire -- he calls it ''cow punk'' -- than its rockabilly counterparts. Its first CD is ''The Greatest Show on Dirt.'' 3. Eddie Nichols started Royal Crown Revue in 1989. The swing band's big-screen debut was ''The Mask'' in 1994, when it played while Jim Carrey and Cameron Diaz danced. ''The Contender'' is its latest release. 4. The rockabilly look isn't complete without a black leather jacket. After all, Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One'' would hardly have embodied cool in a corduroy blazer with elbow patches. Vintage leathers from the 40's and 50's can be found at Reminiscence, 50 West 23d Street. 5. ''I've tried everything in my hair, from axle grease to Crisco, and I tend to like Murray's the best,'' says Buster Kretin of Mr. Badwrench, a rockabilly band. Daniel Howell, the hair stylist for this shoot, recommends a similar pomade, Dax Wave and Groom. 6. It's got to be a classy joint if Harry Belafonte stayed there. In fact, the Beverly Laurel Motor Hotel in Los Angeles has been host to several musicians, entertainers, writers, models and photographers. And it's a Lindy hop, skip and a twirl from Swingers, the diner in the same building that offers breakfast until 4 A.M. 7. Pinup girls, daggers through roses, cards, guitars and cars are all typical rockabilly-style tattoos, says Eric Maaske, a tattooer at Classic Tattoo in Fullerton, Calif. ''I do a lot of traditional American tattooing from the 1940's and 50's,'' says Maaske, ''simple designs that are easy to look at.'' But not so easy to get. The process ''feels like a constant bee sting,'' he says. This original design by Maaske, a 90-minute bee sting, costs about $200. 8. On location at Bar Deluxe, where Janice Desoto, the owner, pictured here in her fake fur with Charlie Overbey, was recruited to scout likely models. ''All rockabilly guys are into style big time,'' she says. 9. The photographer Ben Watts, here with Buster Kretin, left, and Chopper Von Franklinstein, right, isn't even into rockabilly music. He picked the style because he admires both musicians and their look. He collects books on fashion cults, and was once a mod in his native England. Odd, then, that he chose rockabilly, which could be considered the archenemy of mod. Watts says, ''I don't care if the music stinks, just as long as you look good.''

title: COUNT ST. JOHN'S OUT; Huskies Topple Feisty Gonzaga
description: When Connecticut's Kevin Freeman grabbed the bounding ball and flung it high toward the America West Arena rafters, frustration and the burdens of high expectation went with it. Connecticut can dance. And smile. And proudly wear the look of a team that just reached the other side.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 21 with an article about living in Wilton, Conn., misidentified the building at the right in the Cannon Crossing shopping area. It is the Olde Schoolhouse Grill, not the Cannon Grange Hall.

title: March 14-20; Marijuana Finds Its Niche
description: It has been smoked for centuries, lionized in poetry and song (''Everybody must get stoned!''), vilified in film (''Reefer Madness''). Now marijuana, which can bring both euphoria and a Federal prison term, has secured its place in the medical literature, with a comprehensive Government-financed report that finds its active components help patients with pain, nausea and the severe weight loss associated with AIDS.

title: Sports of The Times; The Draw Could Turn Into a Knockout After All
description: LIKE any title fight, it was supposed to be over after 12 rounds, but with all the commotion over the debatable draw between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis, it's as if it were now scheduled for 12 weeks, if not 12 months or more. That might be how long its implications will be examined in Washington and in the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Internet Generation Isn't Just Wasting Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk Looks West For Open-Space Picks
description: The Suffolk County Legislature chose properties almost exclusively in the county's more densely developed western towns last week when it agreed on the first land purchases under a $62 million program to preserve open space, farmland and parks that voters approved in November.

title: SOAPBOX; Ditchdigger's Daughter
description: Students from third through eighth grade in all 21 counties in the state took part in an essay contest this month as part of the International Women's Day Celebration, a project of the Y.W.C.A. of the U.S.A. This year's topic focused on women distinguished for their contributions as health workers. Here are excerpts from one of the winning essays, edited for space.

title: Making Late-Course Adjustments to the Rest of Their Lives
description: HERB ELLIOTT is more excited than perhaps one man should be as he shows off a small pile of Native American arrowheads and stone tools, which he found among the bulldozers and overturned dirt on the eighth fairway near his new home.

title: Storm Watching, in Style
description: YOU'RE interested in storm watching?'' Richard Cutler, the managing agent of Oregon's Inn at Otter Crest, asked me with a twinkle in his eye. ''Well, I was here when the roof blew off. It was Dec. 12, 1995, and the staff was meeting right in this dining room. We could see -- and hear -- the waves below us, and then this gust hit and it took a chunk off the roof. Fifty trees went down around the property.'' Mr. Cutler and I were standing under the restaurant's repaired roof, looking up at the plunging bluff of Oregon's aptly named Cape Foulweather, and hoping -- at least I was hoping -- for some spectacularly awful weather.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: What Lies Ahead In White Plains?; As a $175 Million Project Appears to Weaken, Many Merchants' Plans May Be Dashed
description: FOR struggling merchants in this city's downtown, hope for an economic recovery in what was once known as the City of 1,000 Stores is dimming again.

title: Steeler
description: Singing the City

title: Ministries Flourishing In a World Of Tattooing
description: Late one evening in his tattoo shop, Sid Stankovits bent over the outstretched leg of Jeff Houston, who had his shoe off and sock turned down. To the buzz of his electric needle, Mr. Stankovits drew a picture on Mr. Houston's calf: a kneeling angel, followed by a cross and Easter lilies.

title: POSTINGS: 110-  by 76-Foot Work on Ceiling Was Installed in 1930; Chrysler Building Mural Awakens
description: It will come as news to most New Yorkers that the ceiling mural in the Chrysler Building lobby has been restored. Actually, it will come as news to most New Yorkers that there is a ceiling mural in the Chrysler Building lobby.

title: Berlin, Young Again
description: YOU can spot one from a mile away, ambling erratically through these streets, head flipped back like the top of a Pez dispenser, eyes scanning the building facades, searching: Have the windows been cleaned in the last six months? Are there curtains? Is light burning inside? Is the apartment free?

title: MUSIC; A 'Child' of Miles Honors Her Spiritual Father
description: CASSANDRA WILSON'S new release, ''Traveling Miles,'' pays tribute to Miles Davis, the jazz trumpet innovator she mentions whenever asked to name her most potent artistic influence. ''I'm a Miles Davis child,'' she once said, first having heard Davis at home in Jackson, Miss., where her father, the baritone saxophonist Henry Fowlkes, played his records on the hi-fi. ''I remember listening to Miles Davis's 'Sketches of Spain' at 7 or 8. It knocked me out. It was so different from the rest of Daddy's jazz collection, so expansive, so wide.''

title: A Much-Analyzed Gambit Only the Boldest Will Try
description: There is no adventure that has got as bad a press as the venerable King's Gambit. One of its greatest protagonists, the Austrian Rudolph Spielmann, a genius of attack, wrote about his disillusionment in the 1920's piece, ''From the Sickbed of the King's Gambit.'' In the 1960's, Bobby Fischer wrote an article entitled, ''A Bust to the King's Gambit.''

title: American Voodoo
description: The Immaculate Invasion

title: Rainy City, Sunny Mood
description: ONE snowstorm after another had pummeled my high-desert home east of the Cascades in this winter of La Nina (who looked suspiciously like her brother, El Nino). Green leaves, soft air, early spring and a laid-back university town were temptation enough to bolt. The city of Eugene, on Oregon's mild side, was calling.

title: For Acting Troupe, Students Learn on Cue
description: THE Trumbull High School juniors had been loud and raucous, even yelling out jokes during some of the skits performed about the potential dangers of drinking and using drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NATHAN
description: GOODMAN-Nathan. The Officers and Members of the Boards of Governors of the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center and the Jewish Home at Rockleigh note with profound sorrow the passing of our Board Member Emeritus, dear friend and longtime supporter, Nathan Goodman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Phyllis, and his entire family. May his name be for a blessing. Carl Epstein, President Charles P. Berkowitz, Executive Vice President

title: Longing for Love, Finding Only Sex and Solitude
description: THE American sex industry as theatrical muse? Well, why not? In 1996, the British dramatist Patrick Marber brought his first play to America, ''Dealer's Choice,'' a black comedy in which six men play poker around a table while competing in a savage survival of the slickest.

title: Company Plans to Fight Ruling Against Two Waterfront Towers
description: Hartz Mountain Industries said yesterday that it planned to fight a New Jersey judge's ruling to block its plans for two 160-foot towers on the Weehawken waterfront. The judge said the towers would obscure views of the Hudson River and the Manhattan skyline that motorists glimpse from the ramps of the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Family Secrets
description: AFTER LONG SILENCE

title: Whitman's Road Rage Of a Different Kind
description: Sean Russell never saw Governor Whitman's motorcade drive down Admiral Wilson Boulevard on March 10.

title: Personal-Size Pizza in Briarcliff Manor
description: THE name conjures up images of cliffside dwellings dripping with bougainvillea, overlooking vast sunny expanses of blue. But Briarcliff Manor's Amalfi displays little to evoke its namesake. A couple of tinkling wall fountains and a divider of palms failed to enliven a somewhat cheerless and shabby dining room. Window treatment, once so spiffy, has been relegated to the lower part of the soaring glass, and the dusty curtains needed a wash; the bare upper areas could have used the attention of a window cleaner.

title: Christina Cunneff And James Kapp
description: Christina Isabel Cunneff, the daughter of Donna Campagna of Columbia, Md., and Raymond Cunneff of Palmdale, Calif., was married yesterday to James Matthew Kapp, a son of Anita and John Kapp of Upper Montclair, N.J. Msgr. J. Christopher Maloney performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYROUTY, RAYMOND , M.D.
description: BEYROUTY-Raymond , M.D.. The Central Brooklyn Medical Group, P.C. notes with sadness the death of Raymond Beyrouty, M.D. Ray was a dedicated member of the Group for many years and he just loved to practice Medicine. He will be missed by his patients and colleagues. Byron Toyloy, M.D. Regional Medical Director

title: Whether Spring or Just a Hint of, Organize!
description: THIS is an exciting time of year. Spring is here. Each day there will be signs of the new season. The snow drops and early crocus have already made their statement. So has the witch hazel bloomed in full glory.

title: Art in Barbados
description: To the Editor: Everything Frances Frank Marcus wrote about the Casuarina Beach Club in Barbados (Feb. 14) is true, but for anyone interested in art, the resort is much more. The public rooms and foyers are also filled with the works of contemporary Barbadian painters. The manager, Sonia Cole-Wilson, has been collecting major works by Caribbean artists and craftspeople for many years, and most are placed or hung where guests can enjoy them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITRELLI, ANTHONY
description: PITRELLI-Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony Pitrelli, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1983.

title: OPINION; Chilling Facts of Charter Schools
description: IT is a peculiarity of the human mind that it is able to hold two entirely contradictory ideas simultaneously. For example, the introduction of market forces into medicine is generally held responsible for deterioration in the quality of health care. How many people, other than H.M.O. executives, believe that health care has improved under managed care?

title: Clarkson Edges St. Lawrence
description: Clarkson won the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament last night, defeating St. Lawrence, 3-2. Ben Maidment scored the winning goal at 11 minutes 25 seconds of the third period before a capacity crowd of 8,459 in the Olympic Arena at Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Levi's Blues
description: In a dimly lighted, windowless conference room on the fifth floor of the global headquarters of Levi Strauss & Company in San Francisco, we are contemplating the life and death of cool. Posted on walls around us are crowded ranks of illustrations of clothing lines the company is poised to unveil in coming months, and samples of jeans, khakis, jackets, shirts, pullovers and T-shirts are stacked on shelves at the back of the room. Leaning against one wall, like campaign posters ready for a convention, are jumbo photographs of New York street kids from Levi's latest ad campaign.

title: Getting Specific On Co-op Finances
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Chameleon Of Modernism, Years of Groping
description: FOR a moment, picture the Mexican muralist Diego Rivera as he was in 1907: obscure, a shy, virginal art student boarding a Spanish steamer, the Alfonso XIII, and heading for the port of La Coruna in Spain.

title: Amenities
description: To the Editor: Jan D. Baumgartner's article, ''Deep in Africa, a Most Civilized Discovery'' (Jan. 3), reminded me of an experience on my honeymoon three years ago.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PINK SLIP By Rita Ciresi. Delacorte, $22.95.

title: An Island Institution Takes the Babel Route
description: IF she wanted to, Joey Alcarese could program her computer, push a few buttons and literally operate her radio station from her desk. It would be oh-so-easy to run a packaged program, digitalize a baritone voice and spin out homogenized, formulized happy talk that sounds local but really isn't, like so many other channels on the AM dial.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MASLANSKY, MICHAEL
description: MASLANSKY-Michael. Beloved son, brother, husband, father, uncle and friend. Michael, we miss you. ''For he who lives more lives than one, more deaths than one must die.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOBLOCH, ARON
description: KNOBLOCH-Aron. Founder of Aron Knoblock, Inc. Beloved husband of Rene. Loving father of Fred and Rochelle. Cherished grandfather of Marc, Michael and Carley, and Andrew. You will be forever in our hearts. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 10:15 A.M., Sunday.

title: Another Voice Sings Out in a Musical Clan
description: SHE shares the family's famous last name and impressive vocal cords, but Sloan Wainwright is otherwise a distinctive member of one of the country's most prolific singer-songwriter clans.

title: Jewish Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Paintoonist' Collects Memories
description: THE garbage collector, the buffalo head and bowling alleys all have significance in Jerry Moriarty's life and in his art, which reveals the overlooked value of everyday events. His somewhat autobiographical exhibition, ''Jerry Moriarty: Paintoonist,'' contains some 50 paintings and cartoons, is at the Visual Arts Museum through April 1.

title: The Nation; I'm the Fiscal Purist. No, I Am.
description: THE Federal budget deficit is history, and the strong economy is generating surpluses that could last for decades. But in Washington, pledges of budgetary austerity are emanating from both parties in a way they never did when the outlook was bleak.

title: The Keyboard Stars in Programs
description: THE keyboard in solo, chamber and concerto form is especially prominent this week, starting today at 2 P.M. at the Fox Lane School in Bedford, where Anthony Newman takes to the harpsichord for an all-Bach recital encompassing the ''Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue,'' the ''Italian'' Concerto and the ''Goldberg Variations.''

title: Protecting Your Estate From Uncle Sam's Savings Account
description: YOU have a Social Security check once a month, maybe another check from a pension plan, a house that is paid up and perhaps a big, fat, individual retirement account brimming with stock market gains. But just when you start enjoying retirement, a big headache arises called estate planning.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: A Global Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAC NEARY, JOHN D.
description: MAC NEARY-John D.. Beloved husband of Doris F. and father of Brian and John P. Passed away February 13, 1999 at the age of 85. Mr. Mac Neary spent a long successful career with the Irving Trust Company, New York. A memorial service will be held at 1 PM on Saturday, March 27, at the Mac Neary home at 1 Harrison Ave, West Caldwell, NJ. Parking will be next door at the Caldwell Nursery on Passaic Avenue.

title: Offbeat or Basic: 10 N.Y.C. Guides
description: THE only thing spinning faster than the machines turning out New York guidebooks is the city itself. Publishers cannot possibly keep up with the construction crews and busy chefs, but they sure try. I have been accumulating paperbacks, and in just a few weeks gathered a stack of 23, not counting ones for people who live in the city, like ''Short Bicycle Rides.'' For this column, I've winnowed the list to those that appear of widest use to Americans who are going to visit New York, and three guides for specialized audiences: parents with young children and nature lovers.

title: Crime
description: It's nice to know that after 25 years of playing it smart in Robert B. Parker's novels, Spenser doesn't have all the answers. In HUSH MONEY (Putnam, $22.95), the Boston private eye is thrown by the lethal combination of sex (straight, gay, kinky) and politics (racial, sexual, academic) that erupts at a certain university in Cambridge when an African-American professor is implicated in the suicide of a militantly gay graduate student. In a situation that adds to his discomposure, Spenser finds himself being sexually hounded by a woman whom he has just rescued from the similarly unhealthy attentions of a former boyfriend.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BALANCING ACT

title: Q & A
description: Visiting Carnac

title: China Tries To Fend Off U.N. Censure Over Rights
description: Even before the start of this year's meetings of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which begins a six-week session on Monday, China has begun a vigorous campaign to head off possible censure of its human rights record.

title: Hospital Expansion
description: This month, about the time that Mount Vernon Hospital closed its maternity center, the White Plains Hospital Center announced it would expand its neonatal and maternity wing. The $4 million renovation, which will triple the size of the existing center, will begin this year and be completed next year, the hospital said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOFF, NATASHA
description: JACOFF-Natasha. Beloved wife and lifelong companion for 64 years to Richard. Devoted mother of Rachel Jacoff and the late Leonard. She gave of herself to everyone and was surrounded by love. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBLATT, ALLEN S.
description: FEINBLATT-Allen S.., 68, died on March 16, 1999 after a long illness. A lifelong resident of New York City, he was a graduate o f New York University and worked as a stockbroker. Allen was a scholar with a deep appreciation of history, music and art. He is survived by several cousins and close friends.

title: The Nation; Following Baby-Size Issues Into Voters' Hearts
description: FIRST he decried the evils of traffic congestion. Then he vowed to do something about cow manure that pollutes streams. Then he called for larger print on over-the-counter drug labels.

title: Lawmakers Get Away From Capital for Lesson in Being Nice
description: During fights on the House floor, they have plenty of opportunity to snipe. During committee hearings, they have ample occasion to seethe.

title: Valentino Mazzia, 77, Student Of Deaths Under Anesthesia
description: Valentino D. B. Mazzia, who was a pioneer in the investigation of operating room deaths in New York and who also served as chairman of the department of anesthesiology at the New York University School of Medicine, died on March 10 at Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Mazzia, who held degrees in medicine and law, was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Textures of Black

title: Where Coffee, Cigarettes and Pooches Are Passions
description: The chalkboard sign outside the Grey Dog's Coffee on Carmine Street reads ''Next Latte, 10 miles.'' This tiny, rumpled cafe is an oasis of sorts for its dog-loving, cigarette-smoking, Rollerblade-wearing, trend-weary Greenwich Village clientele. In the midst of a mayoralty that some in the city see as obsessed with civil obedience, the Grey Dog's merrily tolerates a sometimes disobedient crowd.

title: In the Region / Long Island; As Caldor Leaves, Others Rush to Take Up Leases
description: A SIGN over the customer-service desk inside the 91,800-square-foot Caldor store on Hempstead Turnpike in Levittown read, ''Committed to making you a satisfied repeat customer.''

title: Punching and Kicking All the Way to the Bank
description: I'M not going to say that I never saw the tapes,'' said Rique Uresti, a former male cheerleader wearing a Jim Carrey-ish smile and slightly flared brown tights. ''But Tae-Bo is Tae-Bo and this is Gotham Box.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLE, EUGENE, M.D.
description: SOLE-Eugene, M.D.. Age 94. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia and Sessi. Loving father of Michael and Gary. Dear grandfather of Andrew, Allison, Steven, Marc and Jay. Brother of Phillip, Regina, Malvina, Henry, Armin, Elizabeth, Louis, Alex and Lillian. Major in the US Army during WW II. Esteemed physician to his many patients for 50 years.

title: March 14-20; Candidacy on the Net
description: The multimillionaire publisher Steve Forbes formally announced his candidacy for the Presidency, becoming the first contender to announce on the Internet. In his second campaign for the Republican nomination, Mr. Forbes cast himself as the unconventional choice, telling visitors to his Web site, ''You and I are entering the information age -- and the Washington politicians are stuck in the Stone Age.''

title: Nyman to Leave For City Manager Post
description: Bruce Nyman, the Nassau County Legislature's minority leader, announced last week that he was resigning from the Legislature to accept the $105,000-a-year position of Long Beach city manager.

title: Fusion Cuisine in a Bistro in Northport
description: DESPITE its name, Soup du Jour Bistro is about more than soup. It is not one of those soup-only spots springing up all over the Island, which offer a half-dozen or more choices with diners lined up for speedy takeout. The emphasis at this Northport newcomer is on bistro.

title: The Persistence Of Polygamy
description: As an ex-Mormon woman who spent the first 35 years of her life wedged in the Mormon culture, I think it should be noted that although the Salt Lake City ''Temple Square'' brand of Mormonism does not practice polygamy, it certainly preaches it loudly from the pulpit for ''worthy male church members'' in the afterlife. Mormon men are taught that part of the reward that awaits them in the afterlife, if they lead a ''pious'' Mormon earth life, is the opportunity to take on more than one wife after death so that they may become head of their own expansive patriarchies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNS, KATHRYN, PH.D.
description: TOWNS-Kathryn, Ph.D.., Emerita Professor, The Pennsylvania State University. On February 22, 1999 in Harrisburg, PA. A memorial service was held on February 26, 1999, at the Penn State Capitol Campus where she had been instrumental in founding both the Community Psychology and Women's Studies programs. An internationally known advocate for women and children, Towns also founded PROBE, a non-profit career counseling service for single parents, homemakers, and pregnant teens; it was the model for a network of programs in Pennsylvania. She was the Executive Director for 22 years until her death. A woman of ''fierce decency'' and a consummate educator, Towns was a brilliant effective force for equality in development of the human potential without regard to race, gender, ethnicity, or sexual orientation. Her stellar career spanned over half a century. After earning a B.S. from Miami University, in 1944, she was a mathematician on the Manhattan Project and then a meterologist in the WAVES. She spent the next 12 years teaching in high schools in Ohio and Pennsylvania. She then earned an M.Ed. and Ph.D. in Educational Psychology from Penn State in 1970. In 27 years at Penn State, she taught a wide range of graduate subjects from multivariate analysis to child development. She authored 121 papers. Among the many awards honoring her dedication and inspiration, she particularly cherished the Penn State Jordan Memorial Award for Teaching Excellence, the Artist of Life, from the International Women's Writing Guild, the first Service to Women award given in Pennsylvania and being designated Pennsylvania Woman of the Year by then Governor Thornburgh. She will be remembered by the thousands of people she empowered including students, colleagues, counselors, friends, and family. She changed lives. Her great spirit and ''yes, do it!'' will live on in heads beyond counting and across many cultures. Kathryn Towns is survived by a son, Michael Starkey in North Carolina, three daughters, Kristin Dukay in Washington state, Rhonda and Ann Starkey, both in Massachusetts, and two grandchildren. She is deeply missed by all. She asked that contributions in her name go to PROBE, 815 Cumberland St, Lebanon, PA 17042.

title: Third Time Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Not Your Average Beach
description: There is nothing usual about the guests staying at the Almayer Inn, a seaside hotel ''perched on the last narrow ledge of the world'' and the main setting for Alessandro Baricco's euphoric new novel, OCEAN SEA (Knopf, $23), splendidly translated by Alastair McEwen. In Room 3 resides Professor Bartleboom, who is compiling an encyclopedia of limits, including an entry for where the sea ends. Almost every evening he writes a letter to the as yet imaginary woman he hopes to meet and marry. Ann Deveria has been sent to the hotel by her husband so that the sea air might calm her and induce her to forget her lover. The artist Plasson, a renowned portrait painter, is devoting the rest of his career to painting a portrait of the sea. Elisewin, an extremely delicate girl fading from life, comes to the inn as a last hope, accompanied by a priest who unintentionally says precisely what he thinks. A man known only as Adams, who has ''the look of an animal stalking its prey,'' waits at the inn to commit a murder. And, of course, there is the ocean sea lurking just beyond the threshold of the inn, holding the guests' intertwining fates in its mysterious and musical embrace. As in his previous novel, ''Silk,'' Baricco hypnotizes us with exotic language and erotic entanglements. Only occasionally does his prose seem pretentious. More often, ''Ocean Sea'' is highly romantic and breathtakingly lyrical. Jenny McPhee

title: Math Book Salted With Brand Names Raises New Alarm
description: When his 11-year-old son asked Joe Stein for help with his homework last fall, Mr. Stein got a big surprise. There on the page of his son's sixth-grade math textbook was ''what looked like an ad for a chain electronics store,'' he said. Going through the rest of the book, Mr. Stein discovered references to a wide array of brand-name consumer products, from Nike and Gatorade to Disneyland and Topps baseball cards, many of which appeared in illustrations as well. And that made him angry.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. They may not soar as high as Osei Vita, pictured here, but fashion houses are also flipping for bright colors this season, especially pink. Washed silk shirt, $570, and cotton twill pants, $350. Both at Gucci, 685 Fifth Avenue and selected stores. 2. Babatu, the eldest brother and the Amazing Vitas' spokesman, was not the first to meet the photographer Dewey Nicks, flanked here by the Vitas. Nicks learned of the brothers when he met Osei Vita on a photo shoot. As their self-described ''biggest fan,'' Nicks jumped at the opportunity to work with them. For many of the preceding photographs, he was perched high on a giant ladder to capture the brothers leaping on a trampoline. Reaching heights of 20 to 30 feet, ''they were moving really fast,'' Nicks says, ''but their technical beauty was so smooth, it felt like I had a lot of time to get the shots.'' The Vitas brought rap music to perform to, and every time ''Ruff Ryders' Anthem'' by DMX played, they'd stop whatever they were doing and burst into a routine. ''These guys really are amazing,'' raves Nicks. ''They're a dream come true in terms of subject matter.'' 3. Originally designed for America's Cup athletes, Prada's first sneakers, made of leather and silver mesh, will give all types of athletes (and fashionable couch potatoes) sleek feet. The pair here, $260, at Prada, 116 Wooster Street. The sailors on the three Prada-sponsored America's Cup boats stand by -- and in -- them. 4. While arms and legs flailed, the Vitas' hair stayed nicely put, thanks to the hair stylists Johnny Villanueva and Jennifer Davis. Davis used, and recommends for braided hair, Dirt from Jonathan Product. Massaged into the scalp, this pomade helps keep flyaways at bay and gives hair a deep shine. For the Vitas without braids, Davis used Kiehl's Silk Groom, which, when worked into dry hair, gives it luster. Davis also recommends that people with braids ''sleep with a silk cap.'' She adds, ''It preserves the braids and keeps the ends from splitting.'' 5. What better to blast what Omari Vita calls the ''hip-hop culture'' sounds of the Vitas' CD, tentatively titled ''Soul Patrol''? JVC's Kaboom Box RV-B99, $330. For stores, call (800) 252-5722. Two of the CD's tracks are ''Chosen 4'' and ''Soul Patrol,'' which, according to Omari, is ''what we do. We patrol the soul.'' 6. If you're in California and want to watch the Vitas practice, head to the Los Angeles Valley College gymnasium, where the guys train for three hours, twice a week. The rest of their 25-hour training week takes place at home and in local parks. Then it's off to their recording studio, Divine Dynasty, where the brothers spend another five hours a day, Monday through Friday. Time is on their side with Tag Heuer's chronograph watch, $895, at Kenjo, 40 West 57th Street, and Tourneau Time Machine, 12 East 57th Street. 7. In sunny California, you are what you wear -- especially on your eyes. So go ahead and see the world through rose-tinted -- or green, yellow or blue -- glasses. (a) Lunor sunglasses, $385. At Robert Marc Opticians, 575 Madison Avenue. (b) Accuflex sunglasses, from Flexon by Marchon, $269. At Cohen's Fashion Optical, 767 Lexington Avenue. (c) Aero sunglasses from Oliver Peoples, $275. At Bergdorf Goodman. Oliver Peoples, 366 West Broadway.
