title: For Winter and Summer, Tips on Adequate Attic Ventilation
description: GOOD attic ventilation is important because it helps to dissipate excess heat in the summer, making it easier to cool the house and lowering energy costs. In the winter, a well-ventilated attic expels water vapor that would otherwise condense in the insulation. Proper ventilation also maintains a cold roof in the winter and prevents the formation of troublesome ice dams.

title: Shelton or Huntington, What's in a Name?
description: WHEN it came to naming towns, settlers in Connecticut played it pretty safe. They simply named most of them for the communities they had left behind in England (Greenwich, Manchester, Oxford), some for biblical places (Bethlehem, Goshen), and a few for heroes of the new world (Washington, Madison). Most likely, the theory was that if a place got a nice name, it would last forever. And then there is Shelton.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Sublime Science
description: Physics makes the world more beautiful. But convincing people with little scientific background of that has been difficult. Now it may become a little easier. The American Physical Society and the American Institute of Physics have co-sponsored a book by Curt Suplee, a writer for The Washington Post, that is the most comprehensible authoritative survey of all of physics for unscientific readers. In 217 pages PHYSICS IN THE 20TH CENTURY (Abrams, $49.50) gives state-of-the-art accounts of developments in physics in the last 100 years, a time when we have learned more about the universe than all human beings before us were able to discover. The thrill of intellectual adventure is palpable in the book, and Suplee makes it fairly easy for anyone to see the vast range of this science by showing how its theoretical and experimental discoveries fit together. In seven short chapters he leads us through the structure and function of atoms, the astonishing intimacy of light and matter, the often amusing improbabilities of quantum mechanics, the architecture of exotic materials, the elusive lives of subatomic particles that are the stuff of all creation, and chaos and order in nature -- until we arrive at a vision of the entire universe. He does it without equations or misleading analogies, and often with humor (yes, the idea for bubble chambers did occur to a physicist looking at a glass of beer). Many of the 220 illustrations speak eloquently about the subtlety of matter, like a photograph of 48 atoms in a circle that clearly reveals particles that act like waves, and others display scientific machines so gorgeous they are almost erotic. Unfortunately, pictures from the Hubble Space Telescope here lack the brilliance and depth of those at the Hubble site on the Internet. And the typography can annoy: the design of some pages is distracting and the type is so lightweight it tires the eye. That said, take a look. The world is more beautiful than you suspected. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: For a Super, Pressing Issues
description: The first thing the co-founder, editor and director of marketing for Soft Skull Press, Sander Hicks, wants a visitor to his basement office at 98 Suffolk Street to see is the makeshift bathroom he installed by running a split hose to the main-water line.

The Rev. Victor Kim, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

description: What do guys need for a day at the lake? Swim trunks for starters, from trim, square cuts to knee-length versions, in bold color blocks or graphic prints, like camouflage and photo montage. To ward off the sun, there are sleeveless knit shirts, silvery sunglasses in modified aviator models and bucket-style hats. Sandals with Velcro and single-strap ''mailbags'' complete the look, while chunky sport watches signal when it's time to call it a day.

description: THE breeding grounds for the international avant-garde: first Paris, later New York, then -- New Brunswick?

description: William Perkins, a City Councilman from Harlem, was among those arrested at police headquarters with David Dinkins and Charles Rangel last week. It was not his idea of a good time. Even if you have chosen to offer yourself up for arrest, being in the custody of the police with your hands cuffed behind your back is not fun.

description: WHEN Sara M. Dunham regularly drives the seven hours from her home in Baton Rouge, La., to work on spending about $200,000 a year at the flagship Neiman Marcus store here, her rewards go beyond the clothing, jewelry and furs she buys. As a member of In Circle, the Neiman Marcus frequent-shopper club, she will be treated this year to a free week in Milan with her husband, with first-class flights and hotels. Last year, it was Paris.

description: DRAMATIC variations, from ancient legends and Nazi prisoners to World War II espionage and contemporary psychodrama, lend excitement to the week's lineup of movies.

title: Anything Goes
description: Agreed, pink pants are not for everyone. So maybe you could wear a pink shirt under a denim suit. O.K., under a navy wool suit. Well, how do you feel about a hood? Only at the gym? It's a start. A boat-neck sweater is kind of nice. Or something sleeveless. You can wear a jacket over it. A short jacket. (Relax. It's sporty.) You've been craving clamdiggers, haven't you? (Of course, you haven't.) But trust me. (You're not trusting me.) At least try a floral print to liven things up. You won't wear flowers? Fine. And head-to-toe white is out of the question? You know what? Suit yourself. But you'd look better if you listened to me.

title: The Things You Learn
description: Newark's schools, taken over by the state in 1995, may be best known for their troubles. But there are models of educational excellence to be found in the city, say the makers of a television documentary called ''Brick City Lessons: Reinventing Newark Schools.'' The producers and writers, Amber Edwards and Dave Davidson, discovered that many notable programs incorporate the arts. For example, the hourlong program highlights a school for talented students called Arts High as well as West Kenney Alternative High School, where teachers use poetry to reach teen-agers on the verge of expulsion. The documentary, narrated by the actor John Amos, who once lived in Newark, will be broadcast on NJN Friday at 10 P.M. and again on April 10 at 6 P.M. It is the second part in what will be a trilogy focusing on education. The first installment, broadcast last year, was a look at the year in the life of two elementary-school principals in New Jersey, and the third is to focus on programs for exceptional students.

title: The Belgian Conquest; Suddenly, Tiny Nation Is A New York Trendsetter
description: BELGIAN chic. Even some Belgians call it a breathtaking oxymoron, given how stubbornly self-deprecating people from that tiny nation by the North Sea can be. Yet New Yorkers seem to be mesmerized by the Belgian thing: The beer. The frites. The chocolates. The cheeses. The fashion. But it is the surge of new restaurants that has given this improbable phenomenon such unexpected visibility and critical mass.

title: UP AND COMING: Teresita Fernandez; From an Architect of Desire, Many-Layered Constructions
description: HAREMS, tile work and parterre garden plans are just some of the lush references that the installation artist Teresita Fernandez embeds in her elegantly spare architectural constructions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNICK, ABBY, D.D.S.

Grandfather of Danielle and Jonathan. Dear brother of Renee and Nelson Salzman. Uncle of Joan Grant and Lori Kleppe. (Instructor extraordinaire.) A wonderful man who touched everyone with his kindness and generosity.

He will be even more practiced soon because he will be campaigning for a seat in the New Jersey Assembly.

Indeed, for twerpy adolescent boys lacking the patience to become Nobel Prize-winning diplomats, the last best hope to win the girl has always been to alchemize into rock stars.

It is not George Marshall, the ''Man of Crisis'' on a 1950 U.S. News & World Report, or Caspar W. Weinberger, who wonders ''How to Spend a Trillion'' on a 1981 Time cover.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- Salient Facts: Imported Food; The Global Grocery War
description: Bananas were in the headlines again this month when President Clinton retaliated for the harsh limits Europe has imposed on the quantity that American companies sell there. The Administration's countermeasures included a whopping 100 percent tariff on European luxury goods like Louis Vuitton purses and Scottish cashmere sweaters. (You thought they were expensive before?) In the United States, where bananas are the single-most popular fruit, they remain as cheap and plentiful as ever, but in Paris, Chiquitas have become tres chere. As for imported goods available in American supermarkets, the battles over prices, tariffs and quotas never end. Peter Keating

In any case, it will take a lot of time to arrange for our children, establish separate households, confer with lawyers and attend to all the details. What should I tell my bosses and colleagues? And how, more generally, do I keep a personal disaster from becoming a professional one as well?

description: NO CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHT TO BE LADIES Women and the Obligations of Citizenship. By Linda K. Kerber. Illustrated. 405 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $25.

title: Eyes on Oscar: Brazil's 'National Treasure' . . .
description: THE first time it occurred to Fernanda Montenegro that she could win an Academy Award for best actress was at the Berlin Film Festival early last year, before she and the film ''Central Station'' had won the festival's top prizes. At breakfast one morning, the movie's producer, Arthur Cohn, turned to her and said: ''You know, you're going to get an Oscar nomination out of this.''

title: Hospital System Strengthens Cancer Care
description: AS regional competition for cancer patients increases and cancer care rapidly evolves, North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is taking steps to solidify its position as Long Island's largest health organization and a center for cancer treatment.

title: Patronizing Bach
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption today on page 90 of Men's Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about the actor Brendan Fraser, omits a credit. The grooming is by Robert Hallowell for Kitchen Beautiful.

title: Out of the Blue, Quiet Briton Wins Fame
description: Brian Jones, the co-pilot on the Breitling mission, would have remained a quiet but crucial part of his team's ballooning effort if it had not been for a series of lucky breaks.

title: Sports Arena Plans Put Some on Edge
description: Amid the cheering of city officials hungry for a new downtown sports arena Soraida Cruz has one thing to say: ''Over my dead body.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBURT, SAMUEL G.
description: GILBURT-Samuel G.., 88 years of age, died at home in West Palm Beach, FL, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Lillian, daughter Judy, two brothers, Jack and David. Mr. Gilburt was a retired Junior High School principal from NYC. He was active in, and an officer of, a number of professional organizations. He was also involved in community education affairs. He was especially interested in the study and writing of poetry. He was known as the ''Poet Laureate of Brooklyn.'' Mr. Gilburt wrote the poem entitled ''I am Brooklyn'' which is recorded in the Congressional Record.

title: Our Towns; Taking Sides When Teacher Stands Trial
description: UNTIL the police came, the worst thing anyone at Briarwood Elementary School said about David Ford was that he should, perhaps, push his third- and fourth-grade math students a little harder and cut back on the birthday parties. Other teachers hold one party for several children, but Mr. Ford brought in cupcakes for each birthday boy and girl, and eventually Jack Wootton, the principal, had to speak to him about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, SOL
description: SLOAN-Sol. On March 19, 1999. Of Albertson, LI. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of Ronni Stern and Barbara Sloan. Loving grandfather of Craig Lapp, Dr. Mark Lapp, Jodi Lapp and Mitchell Stern. Dear brother of Vivian Zemel and brother-in-law of Betty and Seymour Halpern. Cherished father-in-law of Sheldon Stern. He found balance throughout his life on the ski slopes and in his 70's he was still on the National Ski Patrol. Services today, 11 AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Mental Muscle
description: When Jonathan Watt meets with his clients at Crunch Fitness in Los Angeles to run laps, lift weights and do all those other calorie-wasting, sweat-inducing things that personal trainers do, he spends the majority of his time listening closely as well. So closely that he often feels more like a shrink than a fitness instructor.

title: Streetscapes /2 Landmark Blocks on East 61st and 62d Streets; A 2d Transformation for 1870's Brownstones
description: THE two blocks of modest brownstones on East 61st and 62d Streets between Third and Second Avenues had taken on a more contemporary look by the 1920's, as a new generation of owners erased the brownstone fronts in favor of lighter colors and styles.

title: Miami Attractions
description: To the Editor: My husband and I have just returned from a week in South Florida where we followed many of Mireya Navarro's suggestions from ''What's Doing in Miami'' (Jan. 3), including visits to the Parrot Jungle, Vizcaya Gardens and the Homestead Rodeo.

title: A Growing Gap Between the Savers and the Save-Nots
description: IN two years, when the first of the baby boomers turn 55 and become eligible for early retirement, a new trend should begin to emerge that will separate the ants from the grasshoppers.

title: Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Market
description: DEEP within our psyches, many of us believe that good is inevitably followed by bad. Maybe we've been influenced by predictions like Joseph's in the Book of Genesis, that seven good years in Egypt would be followed by seven so severe that ''all the plenty shall be forgotten.''

title: A Rush to Index Funds
description: It's no secret that over the last few years, mutual funds that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have been on a roll, outperforming their actively managed peers by wide margins. This year, however, investors are really taking notice.

title: A Danse Macabre In the Art World
description: EVERYONE who's ever met Jack has thought about killing him,'' says Vincent Cummings, an art dealer. He is talking about the no-talent, manic, unctuous and abusive painter, Jack Brooks.

title: 8 Years After the Bones, More Battles
description: In 1991, a construction crew digging the foundation for a Federal office building at 290 Broadway unearthed the African Burial Ground, containing the graves of more than 400 people of African descent. Now, eight years and $15 million later, disputes continue over the study of the 18th-century remains and the creation of a memorial.

title: March 14-20; Grandmaster First
description: Amassing the necessary number of points in the necessary number of games, Maurice Ashley of Brooklyn became a grandmaster of chess, the loftiest level of the game, and a status conferred by the International Chess Federation. The 33-year-old Jamaican immigrant not only attained his own lifelong dream but also became the first black ever admitted to the elite group of 470 of the world's most brilliant players. ''It's not significant to be the best black chess player in the world,'' Mr. Ashley said. ''But it is sweet to be the first.'' BARBARA STEWART

title: Banner Year for Golf?
description: Hoping for another record year, the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will open its five golf courses -- Dunwoodie and Sprain Lake in Yonkers, Maple Moor in White Plains, Mohansic in Yorktown Heights and Saxon Woods in Scarsdale -- next Saturday.

title: Two Images Of Polaroid, But Which Is Sharper?
description: TALKING with outside observers and then with management about the Polaroid Corporation's travails is like living a corporate version of ''Rashomon,'' full of wildly different perspectives.

title: War Crimes Panel Finds Croat Troops 'Cleansed' the Serbs
description: Investigators at the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague have concluded that the Croatian Army carried out summary executions, indiscriminate shelling of civilian populations and ''ethnic cleansing'' during a 1995 assault that was a turning point in the Balkan wars, according to tribunal documents.

title: Let's Get Serious
description: In the right hands, humor can be an invaluable capitalist tool. It can break tension, restore perspective and promote creative thinking. How have you used humor on the job to solve a problem or wriggle out of a tough situation? Or how did your attempt backfire? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, the Market Insight column last Sunday about the legal and financial outlook for the tobacco industry rendered the designation of a court incorrectly in a comment from Calvert D. Crary, a lawyer and securities analyst, about its ruling last year that the Food and Drug Administration had no authority to regulate tobacco. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, not the Fourth U.S. District Court of Appeals.

title: Following Muslim Charity and Dietary Laws, Food for the Needy
description: Down the street from a train yard in Paterson, a small sign marks the offices of the Holy Land Foundation, a charitable organization that recently opened a pantry for the needy, offering food that follows Muslim dietary restrictions. Although its primary focus is helping Palestinians here and abroad, the foundation provides social services to all.

title: An Outsider Determined Not to Be Someone He's Not
description: HE is wry and witty, the very picture of a promising young playwright, with his blue jeans, his black leather jacket and his California cool. But in his mind's eye, he is still clumsy and awkward, a gawky crow craving acceptance from a tribe of graceful sparrows. And it is this metaphor, he says, that best reflects his existence as a gay Chinese-American writer struggling to succeed in a white world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, JOSEPHINE B.
description: McNAMARA-Josephine B.. On March 19, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Nicholas and Marie Bisulka. Dear friend of Michael R. McGarvey. Funeral services at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 122 E. 88 St. at Lexington Ave., Tuesday, March 23, 11 AM. Interment to follow at Trinity Church Mausoleum. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the National Kidney Foundation Inc., 30 E. 33 St., NY NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, BLOSSOM
description: GREENBLATT - Blossom. The partners and staff of Rochlin, Greenblatt, Gallo, LLP, mourn the passing of Blossom Greenblatt, mother of our esteemed senior partner Alan Greenblatt. Blossom was a devoted wife to the late Paul Greenblatt, mother and grandmother, a woman of high principles, courage and great wisdom. We will always remember her kindness, and her warm personality. Our sincerest condolences to her children Alan and Cindy, Mark and Lisa; to her grandchildren Jarad, Stacey, Jena and Bari.

title: Win One, Lose One: Michelin Unveils 3-Stars
description: The 90th edition of the Michelin Red Guide to France was released March 3, bestowing one new three-star rating, on the chef Michel Bras, for the restaurant that bears his name in Laguiole (pronounced Lie-OLE) in the Auvergne region of south-central France. One restaurant, Marc Meneau's Esperance in the Burgundian village of Vezelay, was demoted from three stars to two. Thus the number of three-star restaurants remains unchanged at 21, with 6 in Paris and 15 in the provinces.

title: Fear Itself
description: Stephen S. Hall asserts that ''irrational fear equals irrational behavior'' is the ''disabling equation of anxiety disorders'' (Feb. 28). This may be true of panic disorder, but it is an inaccurate description of post-traumatic stress disorder. Those who have survived traumatic events know something that the rest of us don't (yet) know: the world is a dangerously unpredictable place. It is the belief in a safe, predictable world that is irrational -- a belief necessary for daily functioning, but an illusion nonetheless. Regaining this sustaining illusion is the task of the trauma survivor.

title: Family Football Saga: Saint, Sinner and Son
description: Kelly Sullivan was 6 years old when his mother, Gail, drove him and his 10-year-old brother, Ramsey, to Clinton Prison in Dannemora, N.Y., for their first family visit with their father.

title: Ruffling Fuzzy Conservatism Is Goal of Liberal Watchdog
description: Liberals in other parts of the country have been rescued time and again from the consequences of their own silliness by the scary behavior of conservatives, but liberals in New Jersey have not had this advantage.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: 1. Paris couture is fashion's most decadent spectacle, and designers always offer the same reason that these clothes are so expensive: labor. Among the most extravagant -- and labor-intensive -- dresses of the season were: (a) Valentino's hand-embroidered top and dress, which took 30 days to make and costs around $81,000; (b) Alexander McQueen's $20,000-plus ''schoolmistress'' dress for Givenchy, which logged in at 530 hours of embroidery; (c) Chanel's shimmery jacket and dress, which took 1,110 hours for 565,000 sequins to be sewn on; (d) John Galliano's mermaid sheath for Dior, a steal at $150,000 for 800 hours of labor; (e) Christian Lacroix's silk-and-wool gown, with 25 different types of hand-weaving; (f) Emanuel Ungaro's tiered ensemble, with four kinds of lace; and (g) Donatella Versace's caviar-beaded gown, which took 500 hours to make and starts at $100,000. (Where prices are available, they're approximate, depending on things like time spent for fittings -- designers not being above charging for gossip by the hour.)

title: Internet Generation Isn't Just Wasting Time
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Larchmont; With Facial Comes Renewal, Maybe
description: THE effect at first is vaguely reminiscent of something in the realm of science fiction. You walk through a hallway lined with closed doors as New Age music plays softly. Behind each door, a different treatment is under way; visitors are asked to speak in hushed tones to avoid disturbing the beneficiaries of the ministrations. An aura of mystery prevails.

title: American Actors' Woe
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Mall Developers Battle for Regional Dominance
description: DEVELOPERS who have long contended with local detractors trying to block construction of malls in their communities now find themselves involved in another battle.

title: Behind the Labor Peace at Ford
description: When the General Motors Corporation was paralyzed by a 54-day strike last summer, several Wall Street analysts offered the same solution: G.M.'s leaders should go to the home of Peter J. Pestillo, the longtime labor czar of the Ford Motor Company, and offer him any sum of money, no matter how large, to fix their problems.

title: Pulsipher, Having Recovered From Similar Surgery, Feels for Wood
description: The road to the Brewers' rotation was filled with detours and potholes. The most severe obstacle was the torn ligament Pulsipher sustained in his left elbow in 1996 in a scenario that strikingly resembled the injury that knocked out Wood, the Chicago Cubs' young phenom, for at least this season. But Pulsipher suffered a jarring ride through New York as well.

title: Going to Bat With a Dream And a Patent
description: ''I THOUGHT I was a boy until I turned 12,'' recalls Pamela Ryan, 42, an inventor and a mother of three girls. ''I'd wanted to be a quarterback.''

title: 'Golden Handcuffs' That Turn To Dross
description: JAMES MOORE figured that his career was in great shape. In 1988, after five years as manager of the Acme Corrugated Box Company plant in Philadelphia, he had broken the union while keeping production humming. Revenues were soaring, as were profits, even as half the local competitors went out of business.

title: With Balloon's Work Done, Its Builder Reveals a Secret
description: The mission headquarters at the Geneva airport for the Breitling Orbiter balloon flown by Dr. Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones calculated today that they had covered a record-smashing 29,054.6 miles since they took off from Chateau-d'Oex in the Swiss Alps three weeks ago.

title: Finding Little Justice in Appeals Courts; Require Referrals
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Premier Sees Progress On Arms Issue In the North
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland said today that there would be a settlement of the dispute over Irish Republican Army disarmament in time for the Northern Ireland peace effort to advance by an Easter deadline.

title: Saunders Makes UConn More of a Force
description: Connecticut, a 32-2 team, trucks to the Final Four with this deployment:

title: MILOSEVIC TO GET ONE 'LAST CHANCE' TO AVOID BOMBING
description: The Clinton Administration today dispatched a special envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, to meet with Slobodan Milosevic in what senior officials described as a ''last chance'' to persuade the Yugoslav leader to accept a peace agreement for Kosovo and avoid bombing by NATO.

title: Soul-Searchers in Print
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: ROUND OF 8 -- WOMEN; Coaches Speak Softly Entering Midwest Final
description: Just the mere thought of losing has both coaches Rutgers's C. Vivian Stringer and Purdue's Carolyn Peck -- a little secretive about what to expect from each other's very tenacious basketball teams Monday night in the Midwest Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; To cut costs of finding consumers on the Internet, on-line merchants pay other Web sites for customer referrals.
description: IF 1998 was the Year of the Portal in electronic commerce, 1999 may be the Year of the Affiliate, as Web merchants realize that one way to balance the books is to recruit other sites to help sell their goods.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC Plans Production Cut

title: Computer Error Brings Early Food Stamp Credits and Shopping Spree
description: Shoppers packed grocery stores throughout New Jersey yesterday after food stamp accounts were accidentally credited 11 days early because of an error resulting from an effort to fix year 2000 computer problems.

title: Day Traders: A Democratic Breed
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Admit Restricting U.S. Warplanes in Iraq
description: Nearly three months of American bombings against Iraq are proving an irritant to ties between the United States and Saudi Arabia, as senior Saudi officials acknowledge that the kingdom refuses to allow American warplanes based here to take part in what it regards as punitive raids.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: MacManus Creating New Marketing Unit
description: MacManus Group is creating a relationship marketing division in New York, Dialogue Works, by consolidating Ayer/Deare & Partners in New York, the relationship marketing division of N. W. Ayer & Partners, with two accounts and 25 employees of Clarion Direct in New Greenwich, Conn., part of Clarion Marketing and Communications.

title: Clarkson Wins ECAC Title
description: Clarkson won the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament last night, defeating St. Lawrence, 3-2. Ben Maidment scored the winning goal at 11 minutes 25 seconds of the third period before a capacity crowd of 8,459 in the Olympic Arena at Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: ROUND OF 8 -- WOMEN; Lacking at Point Guard, Huskies Missed Final Four
description: Although top-seeded Connecticut was favored to win the Mideast Regional and advance to the Final Four, Iowa State had one thing that the talent-rich Huskies did not -- a point guard.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the director Stanley Kubrick on March 8 misidentified the writer of his 1953 film ''Fear and Desire.'' The writer was Howard O. Sackler, not Mr. Kubrick.

title: Computer Expert's Sleuthing Locates a Bug and a Victory
description: An expert from Texas, Jim Griffin of Austin, earns his living as a computer consultant, working on the year 2000 problem. He recently found a bug in the complex Toad Club system that he plays with Ken Schutze, a lawyer, also of Austin.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday, summarizing the approaches used by Internet stock trading companies to attract customers, referred incorrectly to Waterhouse Securities Inc. It is a large nationwide discount brokerage firm, not a regional brokerage firm.

title: Finding Little Justice in Appeals Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEVINE, CHARLES
description: DEVINE-Charles. November 7, 1953 to March 22, 1997. Dear Uncle Charlie, I miss you a lot and I have a dog, Missy, and a new sister, Sierrah. I wish you could take me on the farm again to ride a horse. Love, Sypriah, Sierrah, Balto and Auntie Tye

title: The Wiggle Of a Finger Says a Lot
description: Marcel Marceau presented another program of solo sketches on Saturday night as part of his season at the Kaye Playhouse. The works of this great French mime can be whimsical, farcical, bitter, sweet and bittersweet. But most of them are gentle in tone.

title: Digital Polish for Factory Floors; Software Simulations Lead to Better Assembly Lines
description: Without question, this has been the decade in which software moved irrevocably into the industrial designer's world. In corporate offices across the country, engineers have been booting up programs that let them tinker, in three dimensions, with every permutation and combination of a product's design. Be the item as lowly as a dinner plate or as complex as a Boeing 777 jet, the goal has always been the same: save time and money in getting products to market.

title: Serbs Burn the Birthplace Of the Albanians' Revolt
description: This village, birthplace a year ago of the armed Albanian revolt against Serbia's rule of Kosovo, was empty and burning today, a symbol of the Serbs' sudden punch into the guerrilla heartland, an assault born in vengeance and intended to spread fear.

title: Wilson Could Face Surgery Yet Again
description: There was only one thing Paul Wilson could think about when he learned he would have to fly to New York on Monday morning for a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right elbow, his pitching elbow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, TIMOTHY P.
description: McCARTHY-Timothy P. Born on January 26, 1964, died March 20, 1999. Graduate of Georgetown University, Masters of Theology of Catholic University. Of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Garden City, NY. Assistant Vice President Metro Tech Conference Center of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Beloved son of Maureen and the late Timothy McCarthy of Albany and formerly of Garden City. Dearest brother of Christopher of Delmar, NY, Mariallanna of West Cork, Ireland, Caitlin of Albany, NY. Brother-in-law of Katherine O'Leary and Michael Larabee. Dearest grandson of Irene and the late Patrick Farrell, and the late Mary and Timothy McCarthy. Much loved uncle of Christopher and Cormac McCarthy of Delmar, NY. Also many other aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at R.R. Plaza), Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church in Floral Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 11 about the outlook for the Nissan Motor Company referred incorrectly to the financial condition of Renault S.A. of France, which has offered to buy a stake in Nissan. Renault has a net cash position worth about $2.1 billion, which means that if the company paid all debts it would have about $2.1 billion left. Renault does not have a high level of debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HAROLD
description: SCHWARTZ-Harold. Age 84, of Pine Island Ridge, Fort Lauderdale, FL, passed away March 15, 1999. Devoted and beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Mara and Gerry Pasternack of Ashville, NC, Michael and Bernadette Murphy of Princeton, NJ, Judith Schwartz of Manhattan, Eileen and Anthony Montalbano of Piermont, NY, and Toby Ozure of Port Washington, NY, Harry Katz, of Manhattan. Loving grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of one. Survived by his brother Arnold Schwartz of Boynton Beach, FL, and Sally Feldman of Queens. Co-founder of Schwartz Liebman Textiles in 1941 and later President of the company, a division of Cranston Printworks, Cranston, RI, until his retirement in 1984. Widely renowned, highly respected and well loved by all in the textile industry. Boy Scout leader 1943-1945, Master Franklin Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBEL, ABRAHAM
description: GIBEL-Abraham. Devoted father of Linda and Peter Nelson. Loving grandfather of Eric. Dear brotherin-law of Pearl Gibel. Services 12 noon, today, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Credit Offerings Expected During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and the sale of a two-year note on Wednesday. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.50 percent and on a six-month bill, 4.62 percent.

title: Holocaust, Trivialized
description: To the Editor:

title: Day Traders: A Democratic Breed
description: To the Editor:

title: George E. Reedy, 81, Writer And Aide to President Johnson
description: George E. Reedy, a thoughtful reporter who served both as Lyndon B. Johnson's press secretary and as one of his private whipping boys, died today at the St. John's Tower nursing home in Milwaukee. He was 81 and had lived for many years in Milwaukee, where he was on the faculty of Marquette University.

title: Productivity Gains Help Keep Economy on a Roll
description: At the Maytag Corporation factory in nearby Newton, four young people stand around a large lazy susan, as if it were a coffee bar, assembling washing-machine doors. As the plastic door molds circle slowly by, each worker adds one metal part, and every 37 seconds a finished door comes off the revolving table.

title: The Big City; Ideas for Dates Inch Closer To Reality
description: EVEN hardened veterans of the Manhattan singles scene were depressed by Michael Russo's performance in ''Unmade Beds,'' the quasi-documentary film by Nicholas Barker that came out last year. Mr. Russo was one of the four people who played themselves in re-enacting the worst moments of their dating careers in New York.

title: Disabled Find Housing Fails On Access Test
description: Eight years after a Federal law went into effect requiring new multifamily dwellings to be accessible to people with disabilities, the measure has been widely ignored, say the Justice Department and advocates for the disabled.

title: St. John's Trying to Put Pain of Its Loss Behind
description: Tyrone Grant had finally poked his head out of the tent of towels he had constructed in his despair Saturday night after St. John's lost the South Regional final to Ohio State, 77-74.

title: Sports of The Times; Chaney Gets Beat 'by the Right Guys'
description: BEHIND the blue curtains where the coaches cross paths on their way in and out of the interview room, John Chaney embraced Mike Krzyzewski without a tear, with a smile.

title: With the Best Research and Intentions, a Game Maker Fails
description: Paper dolls still cling to the walls of the deserted loft where Purple Moon L.L.C. sought and failed to make a viable business out of computer games for girls -- titles that in contrast to current top-sellers, were not about eyeshadow selection, nail-polish tricks or adventures around the pressing question, ''Where's Ken?''

title: Ice Road Journal; Big Rigs Out on the Ice, Holding Their Breath
description: He wants to hear what the ice says, so no matter how low the temperature gets, Peter Paul leaves his truck window open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, IRA
description: ROSENFELD-Ira (Buddy). We mourn the tragic loss of our very dear friend, Buddy. We will always remember his kindness, thoughtfulness and humility. Our thoughts are with Evelyn and the family. We loved him and will miss him forever. Shelby and Bill Modell

title: Mr. Primakov Comes Calling
description: In the seven months that he has been Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny Primakov has restored a measure of stability to his shaken nation. Under his cautious leadership, Russia has avoided the civil unrest and collapse of central authority that seemed possible in the chaotic days after the ruble was devalued last summer. But as Mr. Primakov heads to Washington this week, he remains a caretaker figure with a socialist tint who is mostly marking time until a new president, possibly Mr. Primakov himself, is elected next year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTLEMAN, IRWIN
description: GITTLEMAN-Irwin. March 22, 1997. You in live my heart of hearts forever. Kid sister, Phyllis

title: German Reds and Greens Get the Blues
description: At Germany's most recent Cabinet meeting, Jurgen Trittin, the Environment Minister, pointedly took out a newspaper and began reading while important Government business was discussed.

title: The Defender of a Jail Under Attack
description: The second-floor windows through which Sheriff Joseph P. Jablonsky looks out over the Nassau County jail might as well be tinted rose.

title: David Longaberger, Basket Maker, Dies at 64
description: Dave Longaberger, a born basket weaver and business visionary who figured out that the way to make basket weaving pay was to get a lot of other people to do the weaving and a lot more to do the selling, died on Wednesday at his home outside Newark, Ohio. He was 64 and had turned a small basket-weaving venture into a $700 million-a-year business even as he transformed a slice of central Ohio into a sprawling theme park based on Longaberger baskets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRIGAN, REV. JAMES J.
description: CORRIGAN-Rev. James J. Retired Colonel, US Army, of Cardinal Spellman High School, on March 19, 1999. Son of the late Denis and Margaret Corrigan. Brother of Rosemary Campion and the late Jack, Ann Dougherty and Peg Campion. Also surviving are ten nieces and nephews, 11 grandnieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Sunday, 2-4 PM, Monday. Mass of the High Priest on Monday, March 22, at 7:30 PM, at Sts. Peter and Paul Church, Fleetwood. Mass of Christian Burial Sts. Peter and Paul Church, on Tuesday, March 23, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Father Corrigan Scholarship fund, c/o Cardinal Spellman High School.

title: Criticized as Elitist, Poets' Organization Revamps Its Structure
description: The Academy of American Poets, a 65-year-old organization that is at the symbolic heart of the American poetry establishment, is making what it calls significant changes in its structure in response to criticism that it is an elitist group, dominated by white male poets.

title: OPEC Is Prepared to Reduce Oil Production to Raise Prices
description: As they slipped out of their black limousines into luxury hotels dotting the contours of Vienna's graceful Stadtpark tonight, officials of OPEC, the nearly moribund oil cartel, were stirring with new life, ready to jolt oil prices back up.

title: Market Place; Novell to Offer Data-Privacy Technology For Internet
description: Seeking new markets beyond its mainstay corporate data network software, the Novell Corporation plans today to announce an Internet technology intended to give Web surfers greater control over their identities as they travel through cyberspace.

title: Leader of Chechnya Survives Car-Bomb Assassination Attempt
description: The leader of the breakaway region of Chechnya survived an assassination attempt today when a bomb exploded near his motorcade in Grozny, the regional capital.

title: Blue Devils Are Back in Familiar Place
description: One is a self-described money player who got that way on the glass-strewn, double-rimmed playgrounds of East St. Louis, Ill. The other is a long-range sharpshooter who honed his eye on the polished hardwood in Alaskan gyms. Before Chris Carrawell and Trajan Langdon could share a triumphant hug today in the final minute of a tussle with a determined Temple team at Continental Arena, they first had to share the ball.

title: Breaking the Waves in a Sea of Opinion
description: When does an 85-year-old need a face lift?

title: May the Force Be With(in) You
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ANDRE
description: FRANK-Andre. Age 75, of Sunrise, FL. Passed away Friday, March 19, 1999. He was born in Romania. Emigrated to NY with his family in 1955. After retirement has lived in Sunrise for the last five years. He was a member of Local 3 of the IBEW. He is survived by Rose Frank, his wife of 53 years, daughter Dr. Hettie B. Frank, son-in-law Dr. Frederick E. Kahn, grandson Nicholas Max Kahn, of NYC, and his brother Imre Frankovits of Denver, CO.

title: Cardinal Urges a Dialogue To Rebuild Trust in Police
description: In a Mass dedicated to officers of the New York City Police Department, John Cardinal O'Connor plunged yesterday into the emotional and political storm around the police shooting of Amadou Diallo by expressing his gratitude for the officers' service and urging an end to the hostile rhetoric between city officials and leaders of the daily protests against the police.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Compressed Data; Survey Suggests Consumers Are Taking to E-Commerce
description: New evidence that the rise of electronic commerce is a wave, not a bubble, comes from Odyssey, a market research firm. In survey results to be released today, Odyssey found that half of the American households on line are now making purchases over the Internet, and that the total number of on-line purchases in the last six months jumped fourfold from the comparable period a year earlier, to 56 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, DONALD
description: BRAVERMAN-Donald P. On March 20, 1999. Loving and devoted husband of Meryl. Loving son of Edna and the late Theodore. Nephew of Lillian Berkal and Dr. Lawrence Ames. Brother of Arline and Irwin. Beloved father of Peter, Jill and Andrew, Rhonda and Arnie, and Mark and Barbara. Loving and proud grandfather of Sandy, Felice, Melissa and Marc. He was the Vice President of Salomon Smith Barney. He served proudly in the Korean War and was Lieutenant J.G., serving on the North Wind. He will be missed by all who loved him. Funeral service 12:00, Monday, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Giuliani in Phoenix: a Speech, Some Politics, and a Little Golf
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spent the weekend here meeting with Arizona Republicans to discuss national politics, and taking a rare break to play golf and relax before giving a speech this evening to an American Medical Association conference.

title: Europe Gives Democracy a Try
description: The mass resignation of all 20 members of the European Commission is probably the most dramatic crisis the European Union has faced. The story behind the story, however, may be of even greater consequence. The driving force in the resignations was the European Parliament -- an institution long dismissed by Europeans as toothless and ignored by Americans as irrelevant. Now it has emerged as an important new political actor in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, RHODA
description: WEISS-Rhoda. Of Weston, Mass. Formerly of Cranbury, NJ. Died on March 21, 1999. Beloved mother of Mickey (Brian) Strum, Stanley (Judi) Weiss; and Phyllis (Ed) Koban. Loving grandmother of Anna, Matthew, Elizabeth, Michael, Beth, Howie and Ira. Devoted sister of Bernard (Claire) Wasserman. Funeral services will beheld at Robert Schoem's in Paramus, NJ, (201) 843-9090 on Tuesday, March 23. Donations in her name may be made to American ORT, 817 Broadway, New York City, 10003.

title: New Portal To 'Rich Media' To Make Debut
description: Snap, an Internet company partly owned by NBC, will introduce a service today that is intended for users of the Internet who can connect at high speeds.

title: Similar Tasks, Different Methods, for 2 Lawyers for Police Officers
description: One is ebullient and outspoken, a lawyer who has a pugnacious courtroom style and relishes the limelight. The other is reserved and often seems somber, a lawyer quietly tenacious in court and with the mien of someone who accepts the spotlight as an occasional part of the job.

title: Ambulance Office in Queens Is Sinking, but Is to Stay Open
description: An ambulance dispatching office in Maspeth, Queens, has developed cracks and begun to sink, but the authorities said yesterday that the building was safe and would not be closed.

title: Torre's Cancer Was Contained
description: Joe Torre's cancer was confined to his prostate, according to the results of pathology reports, the Yankees announced today.

title: MORE TOLERANCE NEEDED BY MAYOR, PATAKI SUGGESTS
description: With the grand jury investigation of the Amadou Diallo case wrapping up and the daily protests over Mr. Diallo's slaying in a hail of police gunfire gathering momentum, Gov. George E. Pataki described the case yesterday as horrific and suggested that the Giuliani administration was not ''responding appropriately to criticism'' over the matter.

title: Kemp Saw It Coming: Nets Fail At Finish
description: Anyone who has watched a couple of Nets games knew that Keith Van Horn was going to fake right, spin and shoot. That is the heralded forward's go-to move, and tonight, when the Nets needed a basket, he went to it.

title: Saving Salmon to Save Ourselves; Fry the Right Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Deciphering Hitler and the Nation That Nurtured Him
description: Ian Kershaw was hard to miss. He was the one walking around the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan with a picture of Hitler. O.K., it was an early photograph and it was on the cover of his new book, ''Hitler, 1889-1936: Hubris'' (W. W. Norton), but anyway, he stood out.

description: MALINA-William. Devoted husband of Jean and father of Michael (Anita) and Robert (Fran). title: Essay; The Lagrangian Codes
description: Though dead for nearly two centuries, Joseph Louis Lagrange, the greatest French mathematician, is about to make news in the developing Chinese espionage scandal.

title: An Entertainment Weekly series aims to give marketers an association with popular culture.
description: WHEN the Beatles came to America, they were dubbed the Fab Four. Thirty-five years later, an elaborate marketing and promotional program centered on popular culture is being called the Fab 400.

title: Gates Book Offers a Study in Contrasts
description: Which is the real Bill Gates?

title: Trans-Atlantic Drawing Power for U.S. Scandal
description: Lindsey Calderbank, a sales clerk at the Stencil Store, did not really know how she felt about Monica S. Lewinsky, or what inexorable force had propelled her across one of Britain's biggest malls to catch a glimpse of the woman herself.

title: 'Shakespeare' Best Picture But Spielberg Best Director
description: In an upset, ''Shakespeare in Love'' was selected best picture tonight at the 71st annual Academy Awards, defeating Steven Spielberg's ''Saving Private Ryan,'' the favorite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ROSE
description: BERNSTEIN-Rose. Of White Plains, NY. Mother of Richard and James Bernstein. Mother-in-law of Janice Abbott and Jean Bernstein. Loving grandmother of Mallory, Alyssa, Lauren, Maxwell and Alana. Funeral service Monday, March 22, 1 PM, at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Memorial contributions to White Plains Hospital Center would be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Great alliances and great countries don't remain great if they issue threats and don't keep them.''

title: Remote Control
description: Recently I needed to call a friend and colleague to find out the deadline for proposals for a comparative-literature conference that we both planned to attend. A moment before calling, I hesitated: isn't a telephone call an intrusion? An imposition? Isn't it more appropriate to send her an E-mail, so that she can answer when it's convenient?

title: Comcast-Mediaone Merger Talks Reported
description: The Comcast Corporation and Mediaone Group Inc., two of the nation's largest cable operators, were in intense talks late last week about a possible merger, a person familiar with the discussions said last night.

title: Angst of Working Stiffs From Mason to Waitress
description: ''Working'' is a musical about people who are never in musicals. The hard hats, cleaning women, parking lot attendants and bricklayers portrayed in this sweet-tempered revue are propelled from the chorus line of life into unlikely leading roles. The trucker on a long haul, the operator on a short break, the waitress on a circuit of the dining room: all get the chance in this show to exercise their inalienable American right to life, liberty and the pursuit of a boffo production number.

title: Three Packed Libraries Seek Storage Space in New Jersey
description: Columbia University is double-stacking library books, stashing them in every nook and cranny. Princeton is stowing books out of sequence that could no longer be crammed in where they belonged. And the New York Public Library is projecting that it will run out of space for its research collections by 2003.

title: Oakley Teaches the Knicks What's Missing: Him
description: Charles Oakley was surrounded by a bunch of dancing and whirling kids bouncing on the purple-trimmed court as if it was a box-spring mattress.

title: The Whirlwind Life of (Not Just) a Political Wife
description: OF the many reasons members of Congress gave for attending a bipartisan civility retreat in Hershey, Pa., over the weekend, Representative John D. Dingell's was simplest: his wife made him do it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTE, THOMAS
description: CHRISTE-Thomas, 45. Of North Salem, New York. Died on March 19, 1999. Thomas was the beloved son of Clarence and Marguerite Christe. Dear brother of James, Peter, Andrew, Philip, Margaret and the late John Christe. Brotherin-law to Atsuko, Regina and Wayne. Cherished nephew, uncle, cousin and friend. Friends may call Tuesday, 2-9 PM, at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, Inc., 262 Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York. Funeral Mass, Wednesday, 10 AM, Saint Francis of Assisi, Mount Kisco, NY. Interment private. Suggested contributions may be made to the Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center at 1249 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10029, in the memory of Thomas and John Christe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFFMAN, JOSEPH
description: OFFMAN-Joseph. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Mayer Offman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi David Yagoda, Chairman Dr. William Schwartz, President

description: FISCHER-Ruth S. Mommie, I long to hold your hand. Your Linda

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUEGER, HAROLD ERNEST
description: KRUEGER-Harold Ernest. It is with the greatest sadness that his family announces the death of Harold Ernest Krueger on March 18, 1999 after a brief fight with cancer. Born November 16, 1912 in Tomahawk, Wisconsin, Mr. Krueger graduated from high school in 1930 in Wausau, Wisconsin, and went on to work as an insurance adjuster. Following service in the United States Army as a pilot, 1941-1945, he embarked on a successful career as a lumber broker, a director of the Newberry State Bank, and owner of the Falls Building Supply in Newberry, Michigan, until his retirement in 1980. He was a member of the order of the Elks and a 32nd degree Mason. He was a devoted husband and father, a raconteur and humorist extraordinaire, a musician, an avid fisherman, an outdoorsman, and, in his later years, a golfer, and possessed of a personality loved by all. He was preceded in death by his parents, August and Adele Krueger, of Wausau, Wisconsin, and a brother, Louis Krueger, of Eau Claire, Wisconsin. He was married to Marvel Bohn Krueger of Newberry, Michigan, until her death in 1985. He is survived by and will be sorely missed by his wife, Aloha Krueger, of Gulf Stream, Florida; his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Richard Krueger and Dr. Meg Kaplan, of New York City; his daughter, Marilyn Krueger, of Los Angeles; his stepdaughter, Sharon Osmolofsky, of Kensington, Maryland; his granddaughter, Tena Gilbreath, of Los Angeles; his granddaughter, Molly Krueger, of New York City; his brother, Norman Krueger, of Wausau, Wisconsin; and his sister, Marge Erickson, of Medford, Wisconsin, as well as his many nieces and nephews. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be sent to the Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Florida or to the RP Hicks Memorial Hospice in Newberry, Michigan. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 25, 1999 at 1:00 P.M., at Our Redeemer Lutheran Church in Newberry, Michigan, with a reception to celebrate his life to follow at his home in Newberry.

title: Herron Wins Pressure-Packed Bay Hill
description: It was the most difficult victory of Tim Herron's career, and by far the most impressive. It took two playoff holes for him to prevail. He outplayed two former major winners, Tom Lehman and Davis Love 3d, who battled with Herron today in a pressure-packed, final-round showdown at the Bay Hill Invitational.

title: Service Campaign Will Feature Hanks
description: The actor Tom Hanks, featured in the World War II film ''Saving Private Ryan,'' has agreed to appear in his first public service campaign, to raise funds for a World War II memorial to be built in Washington.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unicredito Makes Offer For Banca Commerciale

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILMAR, HOWARD
description: PILMAR-Howard. It is three years since you have been taken from us. We miss you and think about you every day. We know that your murderers will soon be found. Dad, Carol and Heather

title: NATO Said to Move Toward Approving Bomb Attacks on Elite Serbian Units
description: NATO appeared today to be moving toward agreement on an American plan that would authorize heavy bombing directly against elite Serbian units carrying out attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

title: HORSE RACING: Road to the Derby; Dream Takes Pounding As Menifee Finishes 2d
description: A Kentucky Derby dream did not exactly shatter here today on a neat little track about a thousand miles from Churchill Downs. But the dream, the design and the investment being made by two old friends took a bit of a pounding when their undefeated 3-year-old colt, Menifee, ran second to Pineaff by the length of a horse in the Tampa Bay Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KITSON, THOMAS M.
description: KITSON-Thomas M. Eighth Anniversary You were some piece of material. Your friends and family will always love and miss you.

title: Holbrooke: Last Chip?
description: By preference and habit, Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, has always waited until the last moment before revealing his real bottom line.

title: New Labor Leaders Are Turning Aggressive
description: After a wave of corruption investigations swept away many of New York City's longtime labor leaders, a new cast of union leaders is starting to make the city's labor movement more vigorous -- and more combative -- than it has been in decades, labor experts and union officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, JOHN F.
description: HARVEY-John F. On March 20, 1999. (Ret. NYFD). Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Weichel). Dear father of Mary Santos, Anne Marks, John, Andrew, and Margaret Legg. title: Mexican Rebels, Showing Flair for Politics, Hold a Referendum
description: Mexico's Zapatista rebels, in a characteristically imaginative but one-sided attempt to put their isolated movement back in the limelight, held a nationwide referendum today on their proposals for peace with the Government.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: A Drug War Against the Sick
description: A Government-commissioned panel of experts reported last week that there had been ''an explosion of new scientific knowledge'' on the medical uses of marijuana. The chemicals in marijuana, they concluded, can fight the nausea induced by chemotherapy, boost the appetites of AIDS patients and ameliorate some symptoms of multiple sclerosis. The report was no news to me. I had reached the same conclusions as a cancer patient, seven years ago.

title: Media Talk; From the New Media Back to the Old
description: The world of work -- not to mention, publishing -- is vastly different from the days when the oral historian Studs Terkel set about chronicling it in his book ''Working'' 25 years ago. Which is why the staff at the on-line magazine Word (http:// www.word.com) was inspired to conduct a series of interviews about how peope make their livings in a regular column published on the site.

title: And the Oscar Winners Are . . .
description: Best Actress: Gwyneth Paltrow -- ''Shakespeare in Love''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Magic and Dominance: Michigan State and Duke Advance
description: Magic Johnson stood on a chair about 10 rows from the crowded court, smiling and behaving like a proud father while he watched Michigan State celebrate after halting Kentucky, 73-66, in the championship game of the Midwest Regional today. The scene brought back so many memories for Johnson, from as long as 20 years ago, when he was the point guard, and as recently as 10 months ago, when he was an imposing practice player against these Spartans.

title: Chaos Aside, the Yanks Are Finding Their Stride
description: The Yankees' training camp has generally been chaos, in the word of the interim manager Don Zimmer. He is right: from the first-day trade of David Wells for Roger Clemens, the merger with the Nets and Manager Joe Torre's cancer diagnosis and surgery, the Yankees have had a crazy spring.

description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Joins Dugan Valva
description: Keith McCracken, who in 1986 helped found the promotional marketing shop McCracken Brooks in Minneapolis, is leaving to join Dugan Valva Contess as executive vice president and general manager for the Midwest and West.

title: Jaime Sabines Gutierrez, Popular Mexican Poet, Dies at 72
description: Jaime Sabines Gutierrez, the poet whose lyrical hymns about desire and loss were embraced and recited by generations of Mexicans, died at his home here on Friday at 72.

Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery.

title: September Rematch of Holyfield And Lewis
description: A week after the controversial draw between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis at Madison Square Garden rocked the boxing world, the stage has been set for a rematch of their heavyweight unification bout sometime in September. But a date and site for the fight have not been been selected.

title: Soul-Searchers in Print
description: To the Editor:

title: A Calm Voice for a Combative Mayor; Lhota Provides a Steadying Influence as a Deputy to Giuliani
description: Even by City Hall standards, the battle was exceptionally fierce: the City Council had defied Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani by overhauling the rules on homeless shelters, and he had vowed to retaliate by opening a shelter in the Brooklyn district of Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, who had sponsored the legislation. Mayoral aides were leveling threats, Council members were staging protests and a solution seemed all but impossible.

title: Patents; A new software program takes aim at personal long-distance phone calls made by employees.
description: BAD news for workers everywhere who surreptitiously award themselves an unofficial perk: a Canadian inventor has patented software that can identify personal long-distance calls made from telephones in the workplace.

title: After Scandals, New Union Leaders Turn More Aggressive
description: After a wave of corruption investigations swept away many of New York City's longtime labor leaders, a new cast of union leaders is starting to make the city's labor movement more vigorous -- and more combative -- than it has been in decades, labor experts and union officials say.

title: Saving Salmon to Save Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Protesters Arrested at Brooklyn Parade
description: For the second time in a week, a group of gay Irish-Americans yesterday was denied permission to march in a St. Patrick's Day parade. Eight protesters were arrested for trying to block the parade, but after the arrests, a few of the demonstrators managed to march anyway, under a different group's banner.

title: A Love Of Glitter In Works By Ravel
description: Ravel at home was small, fastidious, obsessively elegant in dress and well satisfied that visitors walking through his rooms could find no trace, other than a piano, that he was connected to music. Ravel also collected figurines and porcelain ranging, his friends said, from the discreet to the ''quite bad.'' ''L'Heure Espagnole'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' which played at the New York City Opera on Friday night, would have fit nicely on his shelves.

title: The New Abortion Rhetoric
description: Pragmatists within the Republican Party have come to regard the abortion issue as an albatross that could ruin their chances of maintaining control of Congress and winning the Presidency in 2000. While all of the party's declared Presidential candidates describe themselves as pro-life, the real issues debate among them has not been over how to outlaw abortion, but how to keep it from playing a central part in the upcoming campaign.

title: On Defining Race, When Only Thinking Makes It So
description: One is not born, one becomes a white person, to adapt Simone de Beauvoir's famous dictum about becoming a woman. To become a woman or a black means to become part of a system (a system of beliefs, habits or laws) that generally rates you somewhere between mildly sub-par and thoroughly inferior. To become successfully male or white means that you should accept as right and natural a system that, subtly or blatantly, declares you the most intelligent, handsome and gifted of all people.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the improvisational comic Del Close on Tuesday misstated the year he appeared as Polonius in a production of ''Hamlet'' at the Wisdom Bridge Theater in Chicago. It was 1985, not 1975.

title: Amid Protests, Elia Kazan Receives His Oscar
description: Elia Kazan said ''thank you'' tonight at the Academy Awards, and then walked off stage slowly to sustained applause.

title: Queens Subway Station Is Site of Fatal Stabbing
description: A 22-year-old man was fatally stabbed in the stairwell of a Queens subway station Saturday, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, HYMAN W.
description: WEINBERG-Hyman W. Of Massapequa Park, died March 20, 1999, after a long battle with brain cancer. Beloved father of Robert, Andrew and David, and grandfather of Joshua, Elena and Sara. After a brief tour with the Medic Corps in the Army in WW II, he studied at Brooklyn College and PCOM, and became an osteopathic family practice physician. He practiced medicine for 22 years in Massapequa, and then spent nine years as instructor at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine. In the early 1980's, he served as President of the L.I. Society of Osteopathic Physicians. Services will be held Tuesday, March 23, at 10 AM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY; 516-921-5757.

title: Finding Little Justice in Appeals Courts; Luck of the Draw
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review of Paris fashion shows on Tuesday misidentified the actor who played a character obsessed with the color pink in the film ''What a Way to Go!'' It was Gene Kelly, not Shirley MacLaine.

title: Clinton 'Singed but Not Burned' at Gridiron Dinner
description: After the long and harrowing struggle to defeat impeachment, President Clinton finally joined in the general laughter at his plight on Saturday night, when he sat through a satirical dinner and had the last word with the announcement of his White House memoir: ''My Story and I'm Sticking to It.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Dec. 28, 1996, described a Democratic National Committee report about that year's election campaign financing. The report, written in April 1996 and later turned over to a Congressional committee investigating campaign finance, referred to the role of Doris Matsui, then a White House aide. Ms. Matsui served as chairwoman of a private group that drafted a plan to enlist Asian-Americans in supporting President Clinton's re-election.

title: Lindros Scores to End Philadelphia's Long Skid
description: FLYERS 5, RED WINGS 4

title: Living With a Grief That Will Never Die, After the Murders of 2 Loved Ones
description: Jim Larson is accustomed to the stares.

title: Editorial Observer; Starting a Trade War When Times Are Good
description: The consumer-confidence polls report that Americans have never felt better about the country's economy. But a vote in Washington last week indicates that politicians suspect the confidence is not very deep.

title: Roller-Coaster Odyssey Through a Calamitous Era
description: FREDY NEPTUNE

description: A Connecticut legislator revealed that he was gay at a rally at the Capitol today, then said later that he had not planned to do so and had felt pushed into it by organizers of the event.

title: Temple Finds Its Best Just Isn't Good Enough
description: There were two and a half minutes left in today's National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional final, and Rasheed Brokenborough, Temple's shooting guard, peeked at the scoreboard. Duke was leading by 18 points and was heading toward the Final Four.

title: Feints and Parries Aplenty in the Battle for Gucci
description: Earlier this month, over a lunch of baked fish at the Paris town house of Francois Pinault, Domenico de Sole began thinking he might be home safe.

title: Media Talk; Keeping Watch Over One of Their Own
description: When Eric M. Breindel, the conservative talk-show moderator and former editor of The New York Post opinion page, died last year at the age of 42, his funeral drew hundreds of mourners, including Henry A. Kissinger, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan; there were so many eulogies that the ceremony lasted four hours.

title: Top Coaches See Rice Capture Catholic Title
description: To understand the magnitude of the Catholic High School Athletic Association final between Rice and Christ the King yesterday at Fordham, one needed only to look in the stands.

title: Cable Television Ups the Ante on the Outrageous
description: In the next few months, as the broadcast network channels grow more and more congested with repeats, you may find yourself channel surfing and running into some unusual sights and sounds on cable television.

title: Republicans Looking Right and Left for the Best Tax Cut Plan
description: John R. Kasich, the irrepressible Ohio Congressman who is running for President on a theme of grass-roots empowerment, wants a 10 percent across-the-board cut in Federal income tax rates. ''The more money people have in their pocket,'' he says, ''the more they control their destiny.''

title: Media Talk; Jailhouse Interview for '60 Minutes' Fizzles
description: ''60 Minutes,'' it seemed, had finally won. After battling off the competition, the CBS news program had landed one of the biggest Manhattan crime-story interviews of the year.

title: Bank One Selects Deutsch
description: The Bank One Corporation in Chicago and Columbus, Ohio, has named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle advertising, which had been handled by the Martin Agency in Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: Long-Shot Badge Trounces Favorites in Gotham Stakes
description: With his 7 1/2-length, come-from-behind victory over favored Apremont in the Gotham Stakes yesterday, Badge proved he could do more than handle six furlongs on the inner track at Aqueduct.

title: Italian Bank Bids Set to Challenge Mediobanca
description: ROME  Italy's banking sector was rocked Sunday two separate multibillion-dollar bids that challenged the power of Mediobanca SpA, the secretive Milan-based bank that until now has wielded enormous influence over Italian finance and industry.

title: Delaying the Inevitable: Ranger Lead Slips Away
description: When the machine that resurfaces the ice accidentally delays a game for 35 minutes by gouging long gashes into the playing surface, the witnesses seek meaning in such an omen. Does it suggest that winter is over and it is time for the ice to go away? Or could it be that the Rangers' playoff hopes, already on thin ice, are about to be ripped to shreds?

title: Russell Ross, 69, Pioneer in Artery Research
description: Dr. Russell Ross, a medical researcher whose theories radically changed the understanding of why arteries harden, died on Thursday at the University of Washington Medical Center in Seattle. He was 69 and lived in Seattle.

title: Vaughn Brings Bat and Leadership
description: Before the Boston Red Sox, before the Anaheim Angels, there was Haimish Fletcher.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Wilson, Facing Surgery, May Lose Season Again
description: A magnetic resonance imaging test in New York this evening revealed that the Mets' Paul Wilson had a significant partial tear of the medial collateral ligament in his pitching elbow.

title: Knockout Incentive
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, GERTRUDE
description: SCHWARTZ-Gertrude (Lefkowitz). A resident of South River died Sunday at the St. Peter's Medical Center, New Brunswick, New Jersey. Mrs. Schwartz was born in Jersey City and was 90 years of age. She is survived by her husband Abe Schwartz, a son Gary Schwartz of East Brunswick, four grandchildren Robert of New York City, Michael of Jersey City, Lynn of New York City and David of Elizabeth. She was predeceased by a son Peter, who died in 1992. Mrs. Schwartz graduated from Jersey City State Teachers College in 1930, taught Jersey City, East Brunswick and Spotswood School Systems, was a member of the Congregation Anshe Emeth in South River, a member of the Hadasha, was active in the sisterhood, taught Sunday school at the Temple, was active in the South River and Middlesex County P.T.A. and was a Grey Lady during W.W. II at Camp Kilmer. A private graveside service was conducted. Shiva will be observed at the home of her son Gary Schwartz, 56 North Drive, East Brunswick, NJ.

title: BASEBALL: SPRING TRAINING
description: ST. LOUIS

title: When a Saxophone Can Offer a Prayer
description: A few years ago Manfred Eicher of the record company ECM decided to bring together his most successful artists: the Hilliard Ensemble, whose specialties were medieval music and Arvo Part, and the improvising saxophonist Jan Garbarek. It seemed a crazy idea but in a way it worked, and the resulting CD, ''Officium,'' became one of Mr. Eicher's biggest sellers.

title: Sports of The Times; In Old Cuba With Dihigo And Lasorda
description: BEFORE the Baltimore Orioles play Cuba's national team in Havana on Sunday, somebody should take the time in the pre-game ceremonies to remember a baseball player not many current fans are aware of: Martin Dihigo, the only Cuban with a bronze plaque in Cooperstown.

title: U.S. ISSUES APPEAL TO SERBS TO HALT ATTACK IN KOSOVO
description: Under orders not to let Serbia delay NATO action while Kosovo burns, an American diplomat struggled today to negotiate at least a cease-fire.

title: A New Campaign On Animal Rights
description: The animal-rights advocates at People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, always adept at turning the conventions of advertising against marketers they deem objectionable, are ''introducing'' a beverage they don't expect anyone to drink.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SURGES. Copper futures prices jumped as supplies poured out of Singapore warehouses, raising hope that demand is rising from Japanese electronics companies. May copper rose 2.75 cents, to 64.50 cents a pound.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Technology As the Dow's Party Pooper
description: Put away the party hats, the bunting and the punch bowl. For the moment, Dow 10,000 seems to be receding into the mists of what might have been.

title: Moya Falls From No. 1 After a Loss at Lipton
description: Carlos Moya, the world's No. 1 player, wore an invisible bounty on his head along with his signature white headband as he shuffled out to the grandstand court today for his fourth-round assignation with the scruffy Sebastien Grosjean of France at the Lipton Championships.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Deferring to a Virtuoso's Formidable Powers
description: Pianists who accompany singers have long been used to getting second billing. This may not be entirely fair, since the musical impact even of a simple song by Schubert depends on a pianist's sensitive handling of the accompaniment. But such piano parts are, after all, accompaniments.

title: Safir Faces Criticism After Oscar Trip
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir returned yesterday from his black-tie weekend at the Academy Awards ceremony to criticism that the trip showed he did not understand the depth of anger over the police killing of Amadou Diallo.

title: A Flamenco Account of a Gypsy's Three Lives
description: Carlota Santana opted for the didactic and the creative rather than the traditional when her Spanish dance company, Flamenco Vivo/ Carlota Santana, performed as part of the children's programming at the New Victory Theater on Friday night. The indisputable hit was ''Bailaor,'' in which Antonio Hidalgo's choreography offered a quick abbreviated survey of men's flamenco dances. The work's pop flavor, current in today's flamenco experiments, brought down the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COFFINO, IRVING
description: COFFINO-Irving. 73. Of the Bronx, March 22, 1999. Devoted husband of Nancy and the late Adeline, father of Michael, Tommy, Dianne, Theresa, John and Joan, stepfather to Steven, Michael and Joseph, and grandfather to Torin, Aidan, Alex, Gabriel, Natasha, Michael and Brandon. Irv was the ultimate giver, devoting himself to family, friends and strangers with uncommon and unconditional selflessness. Those who knew him can never forget him. Services to be held Wednesday evening, March 24th, and Thursday afternoon and evening, March 25th, at Balsamo's Funeral Home, 3188 Westchester Avenue, Bronx, New York 10461, 718-597-8380. Funeral Friday, March 26th, at Woodlawn Chapel, Bronx, New York.

title: Police Head Defends His Force As Protests in Diallo Case Go On
description: As Police Commissioner Howard Safir came under mounting criticism, 141 people, including State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, were arrested yesterday in the largest act of civil disobedience yet protesting the police shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: Cartoon-Star Duo: Tobacco and Alcohol
description: Parental concerns about the messages small children receive in G-rated animated feature films have resulted in a review showing that two-thirds of such movies produced over the last 60 years include the use of tobacco and alcohol by villains and heroes alike.

title: ISLANDERS-DEVILS TRADE
description: The Devils added depth to their forward line last night by acquiring Sergei Nemchinov from the Islanders for a 1999 fourth-round draft choice. He will take part in this morning's skate and play tonight against visiting Buffalo.

title: TI GROUP BUYS TRI-MANUFACTURING FROM UNIT OF G.E.
description: TI Group P.L.C. said yesterday it had bought Tri-Manufacturing from GE Aircraft Engines for $58 million. TI, based in Abingdon, England, is an engineering company with interests in seals and sealing systems, fluid carrying systems for refrigeration and aerospace systems and equipment. It had revenue of $:2.17 billion, or $3.5 billion, in 1998. Tri-Manufacturing, with headquarters in Terre Haute, Ind., makes components for jet engine manufacturers, including G.E. and Pratt & Whitney. GE Aircraft Engines, based in Evandale, Ohio, is a unit of General Electric Company, based in Fairfield, Conn.

title: In the Family Business, 3d Man in the Ring
description: MANY boxing heavies were weighing in with their opinions at State Senator Roy M. Goodman's inquiry last week regarding the much disputed match between Lennox Lewis and Evander Holyfield: the promoter Don King, accompanied by five lawyers; the former light-heavyweight champ Jose Torres; the HBO boxing executive Lou DiBella.

title: Hazy Memories of Chats With Children
description: Parents, therapists and police officers who give hearsay testimony in court about young children's statements may not be reliable witnesses, according to a new study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORCHARD, MARIE, LOUISE
description: ORCHARD - Marie - Louise (nee Valentin). Beloved wife of William I. Devoted mother of William Paul, Michael Thomas, Anne-Marie, Christiane and Laurence Bryan. Cherished grandmother of eight. Reposing Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison St., NYC until Wednesday 9AM, Mass of Ressurection, St. James Church, 9:30AM

title: Cable TV and the Internet, Too; Battling the Bells, but With Some High-Speed Whistles
description: Is cable television passe? One could have thought so from the way executives of the Comcast Corporation and Mediaone Group Inc., two of the nation's biggest cable companies, trumpeted their $53 billion deal yesterday.

title: In Thin Air, Drossin Pushes Herself Higher
description: Two and a half years ago, Deena Drossin settled in Alamosa, Colo., to renew her passion for running amid the 14,000-foot peaks of the Sangre de Cristo range, live off the beauty of the San Luis Valley and train with a group of men who would draw out her talent for Olympic contention.

title: Gay Couples Split by Immigration Law; Under 1996 Act, Personal Commitments Are Not Recognized
