description: A dozen roses in hand and butterflies in his stomach, Kent McCoy stood in the arrivals area at Kennedy International Airport last summer waiting for his companion, Samer Yahya, to return from a monthlong visit with relatives in Italy.

title: Rising Oil Prices
description: Oil prices are heading up, as Saudi Arabia and other oil producers seek to restrain the supply. Those higher prices will dampen the economic boom in the United States but will not cause severe problems for this country. The rise should serve as a reminder to Americans that energy conservation, largely forgotten as oil prices have fallen to their lowest level in years, remains an important goal.

title: ROHN INDUSTRIES POSTPONES PURCHASE OF PIROD HOLDINGS
description: Rohn Industries Inc., which builds telecommunications towers and makes telecommunications cabinets and poles, said yesterday that it was postponing the purchase of closely held Pirod Holdings Inc. because an expected slowdown in the wireless telecommunications industry had made financing terms for the transaction less favorable. Rohn, based in Peoria, Ill., said in December that it would buy Pirod for about $79 million in stock and assumed debt.

title: Journalist Held Hostage in Lebanon Sues Iran
description: Terry Anderson, the journalist who was held hostage for more than six years in Lebanon, sued the Iranian Government yesterday for what he says is its role in his imprisonment.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TRAVEL UNIT FOR SMALLER COMPANIES
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had created a division to handle travel arrangements for small to midsize companies. Called American Express One, the new unit combines two of the company's customer service units with Travel One, a travel agency based in Mount Laurel, N.J., that American Express, based in New York, bought last fall. American Express One will have 3,500 employees and handle about $3 billion in travel sales, largely from companies with less than $10 million in annual travel expenses, the company said.

title: Arab Web Censorship; Pakistan Is Wired
description: To the Editor:

title: Whittenburg To Get Top Job
description: Dereck Whittenburg, an assistant coach at Georgia Tech for the last five years, is expected to be named the Wagner College head coach at a news conference today, according to a person close to the athletic department at the Staten Island school.

title: Solid CO2 Has Effect On Light
description: Carbon dioxide, a ubiquitous chemical exhaled by all animals and incorporated into plants as their main building block, has assumed a new and astonishing form: a solid that resembles quartz, is nearly as hard as diamond, and transforms light in intriguing (and potentially very useful) ways.

title: On Circumcision, From a Male
description: To the Editor:

title: Rap Group Founder Arrested On Drug Charge in Brooklyn
description: A rap performer who has had frequent confrontations with the police was arrested early yesterday on a charge of possession of crack cocaine, the police said.

title: North Korea Pact Is a Starting Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOTZER, PHILIP
description: GLOTZER-Philip, M.D. It is with deep sadness that Montefiore Medical Center notes the death of Dr. Philip Glotzer, a respected surgeon and member of our medical staff for more than forty years. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his dear wife, Joan; daughter, Taya; son, David; and his entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Looking Beyond the Symptoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Muscle Machine for Great Gym in the Sky
description: To get into space, astronauts have to fight gravity. To stay strong and healthy in space, they have to make up for gravity's absence, because muscles atrophy and bones lose calcium without the earth's steady pull to struggle against. As a January 2000 launching date for the first resident mission to the new International Space Station approaches, NASA is making its most serious effort ever to break the muscle barrier to extended stays in zero gravity.

title: Lakers Improve to 11-0 With Rodman in Lineup
description: LAKERS 96, MAVERICKS 93

title: Doctor Marries Doctor: Good Medicine
description: Some years ago, well before I got engaged, I had a conversation with a young gastroenterologist about marriage. I was readying myself for medical school and concerned I would not meet anyone outside of medicine. I was certain I did not want to marry a doctor. ''No, marry a doctor,'' the fellow advised. ''When you get paged away during your anniversary dinner, only another doctor will understand.''

title: Dr. Aubre de Lambert Maynard, 97, a Surgeon
description: Dr. Aubre de Lambert Maynard, an authority on surgery to treat heart, chest and abdominal wounds who was credited with saving the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. after he was stabbed in 1958, died Saturday at his home on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. He was 97.

title: North Korea Pact Is a Starting Point; Nuclear Blackmail
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Your Home Hazardous to Your Health?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Wrong Way To Punish Beijing
description: As the rage over China's alleged theft of American nuclear secrets continues to seethe in Washington, Congress will be looking for ways to punish Beijing. The obvious move would be to deny China something it wants -- entry into the World Trade Organization, which would give Beijing both the prestige of membership and a voice in the development of a powerful international institution.

title: Jack Tarver, 82, Atlanta Publisher in Civil Rights Era, Dies
description: Jack Tarver, who used his influence as publisher of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution in the 1960's and early 1970's to protect Ralph McGill, The Constitution's Pulitzer Prize-winning editor, from bitter complaints about his support for the civil rights movement, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in Atlanta, his daughter, Margaret Tarver Jason, said. He was 82.

title: Debating Affirmative Action but Keeping it Cordial
description: The debate over affirmative action has been going on so long that it has become a ritual. Both sides fall into incantations, formulas and slogans to stand for worn arguments. Fresh ideas are in short supply as the debaters concentrate on phrases with enough emotional punch to move voters in the referendums that have become the focus of national attention.

title: AMR TO SPEND $80 MILLION ON CHICAGO O'HARE EXPANSION
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it would spend $80 million to improve its terminal and gates at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. The airport plans alterations to accommodate more overseas flights. AMR, based in Fort Worth, plans to add concession and retail space, expand restrooms and improve lighting, heating and air-conditioning. The project is expected to be completed in the fall of 2001. Shares of AMR fell $3.3125, to $57.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Registered Nurses in Short Supply at Hospitals Nationwide
description: The nation's hospitals are experiencing a shortage of registered nurses, especially the specialized, highly trained nurses who staff operating rooms, emergency rooms, intensive care units and pediatric wards for high-risk babies.

title: Allied Signal Says It Has Plans for Internet
description: Allied Signal Inc., the aerospace company, plans to tap the Internet to better serve customers and increase revenue.

title: 2 Huge Cable TV Companies To Unite in $53 Billion Deal
description: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Mediaone in a $53 billion takeover that would create the third-largest cable television company in the nation but would have little to do with television.

title: Oscar Aftermath: And the Winner Is Not...
description: Geena Davis, the host of ABC's first-ever Oscar pre-show, asked Helen Hunt about having won an Academy Award. ''Did you have the same experience I did, that when they called your name you went, like, out of body?'' she asked, sounding out of her body at that very moment, not to mention out of her mind. What possessed her to take this inane job, in which she stood on a set inside the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion looking at a huge monitor that showed the red carpet arrivals outside? Reading robotically from a teleprompter, she said, ''It's so much fun to catch our first glimpse of the stars as they arrive.''

title: Is Microsoft Moving to Settle? U.S. Says No
description: The way the Justice Department sees it, if the Microsoft Corporation and the Government are to begin talks to settle the antitrust suit now at issue in Federal court here, Microsoft will have to make the first move. So far, that has not happened.

title: Teletubbies Take On the Bubbly Chubbies as Cute Winds Up in Federal Court
description: ''Teletubbies'' -- those four cuddly, cooing, antenna-topped dolls that arrived on American television from Britain last year and have generated $800 million in sales from spinoff toys and other kiddie products -- have distinctive features: human but ''extraplanetary,'' their makers and marketers say.

title: Senators Clash Over U.S. Role In a NATO Bombing Campaign
description: A handful of Senators clashed today over the American role in a NATO air campaign if Belgrade refuses to sign the peace accord.

title: Exploiting the Holocaust; Remembrance Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: DUPONT TO SELL OFF REST OF CONOCO TO SHAREHOLDERS
description: The DuPont Company plans to sell off its 70 percent stake in Conoco Inc., the oil company, to DuPont shareholders by the end of the third quarter of 1999. DuPont sold a 30 percent Conoco stake to investors in October, raising $4.4 billion in the largest initial public offering in the United States. The remaining stake is valued at more than $10 billion. Under a plan disclosed in a Conoco filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, DuPont shareholders would be able to exchange their common stock for Conoco Class B common stock held by DuPont. The announcement came after the close of trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, MILTON S.
description: GOULD-Milton S. Cornell University mourns the loss of a devoted son and friend, Milton S. Gould. A member of the Class of '30 and the Cornell Law School Class of '33, Presidential Councillor and life member of the Cornell University Council, he was a man whose vision and commitment had a profound impact on the Law School, the Department of Classics and, indeed, the University as a whole. Co-founder of the New York City law firm of Shea and Gould, author, and legendary trial lawyer whose courtroom feats were legion, he was honored, with his late wife of 61 years, Eleanor Greenburg Gould, as Foremost Benefactors of Cornell. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children, Patricia Booth, Jonathan Gould and Judson Gould, their spouses, Francis Booth and Gay Leonhardt, and grandchildren, Eliza and Olivia Booth. He had boundless enthusiasm for Cornell, and we share his and Eleanor's pride in counting two of his children and his granddaughters among the graduates of the University. He will be missed. Harold Tanner Chairman, Cornell University Board of Trustees Hunter R. Rawlings III President, Cornell University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JACK
description: ALTMAN-Jack. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of our dear member, Trustee and devoted Chairman of our Kiddush Committee. Heartfelt condolences to the family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLER, LYNNE C.
description: ENGLER-Lynne C. Died on March 18, 1999, at home in New York. She was 85. Much beloved, adored and loving mother of Carla Leigh Engler, grandmother of James Wylie Deitch and motherin-law of Edward G. Deitch. Lynne was a talented fashion designer of sophisticated loungewear and robes, women's sportswear and children's wear. She was a top fashion model in the 1940's and 50's, appearing in such magazines as Harper's Bazaar, Life, Fashions of The Times and Look. She was also an actress, appearing most notably in Moss Hart's Broadway production of ''Winged Victory'' in 1945. Her beloved husband, James J. Engler, predeceased her. Lynne was a lovely lady and wonderful mother, always full of smiles, grace, optimism and love. No one will ever replace her in our hearts. Friends may call on Wednesday, March 24, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street; a funeral Mass will be held Thursday, March 25, at 11 A.M., at The Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWEY, FREDERICK
description: LOWEY-Frederick. On March 21, 1999. Owner of Frederick Lowey Watch Repair for over 45 years. Beloved husband of the late Olga. Loving father of Henry and Curtis and daughters-in-law Elaine and Bette. Cherished grandfather of Denise, Stephanie, Diane, Melissa, David , Alison, four great grandchildren and companion Elsa Lowy. Services Wednesday 9AM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76 Road Forest Hills

title: Melvin Blake, 71, Collector of Figurative Art
description: Melvin Blake, an oral surgeon whose collection of figurative art formed the opening exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, died on March 14 at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: An American Century (With Swiss)
description: The program that the Dessoff Choirs sang on Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall was called ''Music of the American Century,'' a title vague enough to be more inclusive than it seems at a glance. Four of the five composers were Americans; the fifth, Hindemith, moved to the United States in 1940, but his ''Six Chansons,'' performed here, were written in Switzerland in 1939 and show little American influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EVELYN KAY
description: MILLER-Evelyn Kay, in Atlanta, Georgia, on March 19, 1999, in her 90th year. Beloved wife of the late Max Miller and Irving Adler Kay. Devoted mother of Michael and Ann Kay, and Jeffrey Kay. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan and Jennifer Kay and Alison and Todd Lubin. Services private. Contributions may be made to Jewish Family Services, 4549 Chamblee Dunwoody Road, Dunwoody, GA.

title: Mindless Creatures Acting 'Mindfully'
description: Oblivious to its fellows, the single-celled creature called the cellular slime mold slithers amoeba-like along the ground, lapping up the nutrients in its path. But when the food supply runs out, it has a biochemical panic attack, frantically sending out molecular signals to other nearby slime molds, which in turn are sending out signals of their own. Guided by these primitive conversations, the individual cells come together to form a multicelled organism, sprouting a stalk and a head of spores that become the seeds of the next generation. When these fall to the ground, the cycle begins anew.

title: Vacant Building Collapses, Forcing Evacuation Nearby
description: An abandoned four-story building in the East Village, whose roof neighbors say caved in weeks ago, collapsed even further last night, prompting the evacuation of an adjacent apartment building. No one was injured, the authorities said.

title: Savory Diet That's Good For Heart? Let's Eat
description: A generation ago, Dr. Ancel Keys and colleagues at the University of Minnesota published findings that, if heeded then, would have extended millions of American lives during the last 30 years and millions more in the years to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFFMAN, JOSEF
description: OFFMAN-Josef. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Josef Offman, beloved father of our devoted member, Mayer Offman. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Their Paths Were Different, Their Goal Is the Same
description: Some of the coaches have cried. Their players have slapped high-fives, fashioned necklaces from the nets snipped after winning regional championships and, as Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun joked today, are nursing sore shoulders from congratulatory backslapping.

title: Nurses at Bronx Hospital Vote to Join 1199 Union
description: More than 400 registered nurses at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx have decided to become union members after a hard-fought eight-month organizing drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, BEATRICE VENETEK
description: BERMAN-Beatrice Venetek. January 7, 1925 to March 21, 1999. Will be missed by her children, grandchildren, sisters and extended family. In lieu of flowers donations to American Cancer Society. She will be laid to rest at Mount Sinai Mortuary, Los Angeles, CA.

title: U.N. Warns U.S. to Pay Bill or Lose Assembly Vote
description: The United States will need to pay at least $250 million to the United Nations this year if it is to avoid losing its vote in the General Assembly, the senior financial officer of the United Nations has warned.

title: Reports of Abuse of Elderly Are Ignored, Panel Is Told
description: Complaints about the abusive treatment of elderly people in nursing homes are often ignored for many months by state and Federal officials, Congressional investigators said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYSTON, ANN M.
description: LYSTON-Ann M. On March 21, 1999. Beloved aunt of James K. and Timothy M., and great aunt of James Charles. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St), New York City, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10 A.M. at Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, IRA
description: ROSENFELD-Ira. Our family mourns Buddy's death while fondly remembering his life. A gentle man, his legacy to all who knew and loved him is one of courage, intelligence, warmth and kindness. Our condolences to Evelyn, Mary and Jonathan Sanders; Jackie, Andy, Adam and Charlie Schuyler; Meryl and Bruce Freedman. Sybil Sanders; Ellen and Jeffrey, Joy and Ross Nirenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUERTAS, THOMAS C.
description: HUERTAS-Thomas C. March 20, 1999, of Somers, NY. Former archivist for the United Nations. Survived by five children, two sisters, and nine grandchildren. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, NY, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST; No. 1 Purdue Pulls Rank On Game Rutgers Team
description: It was one of those times when all the right things had been done. Great defense, clutch shooting. Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer could not have asked her team for more.

title: The Road to Florida, Maine and Syphilis
description: Interstate 95 runs along the Eastern Seaboard linking rural Maine to Florida, enabling people and commerce to travel north to south. But in one area, epidemiologists believe the highway may also be a pipeline for syphilis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHACTER, CHARLES BANKS
description: SHACTER-Charles Banks. March 23rd Happy birthday, dearest Papa. You are with us always

title: A Kosovo Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWOPE, SARAH PORTER
description: SWOPE-Sarah Porter. On Friday, March 19th of Ossining, New York. Mother of Dorothea H. Swope of Manhattan and David Swope, Jr. of Ossining, NY. Sister of Jerome C. Hunsaker of Lincoln, MA., and Alice Bird of Henley-on-Thames, England. A Memorial Service will be held at Clearview School, Route 9, Scarborough, NY on Saturday, April 10th at 11AM. Contributions may be made to the Westchester Community College Foundation, Teatown Lake Reservation, Inc, or Ossining Children's Center.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Weigh Race Barrier in Hawaiian Voting
description: In a case that mixes history, race and evolving constitutional doctrine, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Hawaii may continue to deny anyone who is not descended from the original Hawaiians the right to vote for the leadership of an agency that administers tens of millions of dollars in public money.

title: Hub Group in Acquisitions
description: Hub Group Inc., which arranges rail and trucking transportation services for companies, said today that it planned to buy the remaining minority interest in 17 of its operating companies for $110 million. When the purchase is complete, Hub Group will own all of its operations in North America and Europe with the exception of Hub Group Distribution Services. The acquisition, financed through unsecured debt, is expected to close in April.

title: Nine Recalcitrant Notes, But Reliable Arpeggios
description: On Thursday evening at Merkin Hall the pianist Joseph Kubera dealt in his sober, plain fashion with a variety of odd musical situations thrown up by composers within the American experimental tradition. There was one classic: Christian Wolff's ''For Piano I'' of 1952, a crackling display of what can be done with just nine notes, from right across the keyboard, that refuse to gel into any settled pattern. Otherwise the pieces were all from the last 11 years.

title: Obesity-Cancer Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Filmmakers Study a Man Who Studied the Apes
description: One cannot help imagining the younger members of the Coolidge family whining, of a boring rainy afternoon, ''Oh, no, Uncle Hal! Not the expedition movies again!''

title: Jeff Beck, Speaking Through His Guitar
description: Jeff Beck didn't have much use for the microphone onstage at Roseland on Friday night. After two approaches, he told the sold-out crowd he had forgotten what he was going to say; later, he named band members and offered thank yous. But his guitar was his true voice, and still every bit as brazen and subtle, wayward and exalted as it has been since he sliced through British blues in the 1960's.

title: Rules for Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Ethnic Albanian Rebel Asks NATO to Start Strikes
description: The general commander of the Kosovo Liberation Army called on NATO today to carry out air strikes on Serbia to put an end to the violence, as Yugoslav Army and police forces continued their ransacking and burning of villages.

title: Renault Executive Seen in Nissan Post
description: Carlos Ghosn, an executive vice president of Renault S.A. who is known in France as ''le cost-killer,'' is the most likely candidate to become the chief operating officer of the Nissan Motor Company, French union officials said yesterday in Paris. Renault, the French car maker, has offered an estimated 32 billion francs, or $5.3 billion, for a 35 percent stake in Nissan.

title: Borneo Death March /Of 2,700 Prisoners, 6 Survived : An Old Soldier Remembers a Wartime Atrocity
description: SANDAKAN, Malaysia  Owen Campbell returned to Borneo last week, back to the jungles where half a century ago his best mates were marched to their deaths.

title: Fighting to Force a Giant to Share Its Vital Lines
description: As two giant cable television companies were justifying their merger as key to competing in the high-speed Internet access business, executives of Internet companies attending a computer conference here were sparring over how open to competition cable modem services and other so-called broadband products should be.

title: Watered-Down Racism Resolution
description: By killing a resolution condemning ''the racism and bigotry espoused by'' a white supremacist group called the Council of Conservative Citizens, Republican Congressional leaders have set back their party's effort to be viewed as inclusive.

title: $30 Million Error May Be a Precursor of Year 2000 Flaws
description: In what some are calling the most widespread damage yet from an attempt to fix a year 2000 flaw, New Jersey officials scrambled yesterday to correct a computer error that gave $30 million in unexpected credits to food stamp recipients, who crowded grocery stores for the second day of a statewide shopping spree.

title: Spanish Order to Airbus
description: The Spanish airline Spanair said today that it had ordered as many as 45 Airbus planes worth as much as $2.2 billion as it prepared to expand service in Spain and the rest of Europe. Spanair said it had placed a firm order for 21 planes and taken another 21 subject to reconfirmation and 12 more on option. The airline said it wanted to take delivery of the short- to medium-range single-aisle aircraft starting in September 2000. The new planes would triple the size of Spanair's fleet.

title: Disappointed Checketts Still Hopeful
description: Having approved major personnel changes during the off season, Dave Checketts had hoped the Knicks would contend for the Eastern Conference finals. Halfway through the season, however, the Madison Square Garden president is dismayed at the team's progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKHAM, JANET G.
description: PECKHAM-Janet G., Chairman and C.E.O. of Peckham Industries of White Plains, N.Y., died on Sunday, March 21, 1999 at her home in Chappaqua, N.Y. An active civil leader in the community for over thirty years, a life-long resident of Westchester County, Mrs. Peckkam was the widow of John S. Peckham. She is survived by her three children, daughter Katherine Moreau and sons John and Douglas Peckham, a sister Joan MacArthur and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco at 4:00 pm on Wednesday, March 24th. The family has requested that donations be made to The Sloane Kettering Memorial Cancer Research Fund or the Westchester Council for the Arts in lieu of flowers.

title: Colgate's Appeal on Tax Shelter Is Rejected
description: The Supreme Court rejected without comment today a bid by the Colgate-Palmolive Company to gain tens of millions of dollars in tax benefits through an offshore shelter devised by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROHN, DAVID
description: CROHN-David. Died in Israel, his home, March 19, age 77. Survived by his wife of 50 years, the former Annette Lash, three daughters Ariella Yosefi of Herzlia, Yael Duhl of Jerusalem, Aviva Plaut, of Magnolia, KY, and eight grandchildren. Our beloved husband, father and grandfather has left us forever. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends.

title: By Design; Spring Training
description: The baseball shirt -- sans team logo -- is shaping up as the preferred T-shirt for spring. Stella McCartney put airbrushed designs of birds, palm trees and sunsets on her shirts for Chloe, but most have solid-color bodies and contrasting sleeves.

title: M.I.T. Admits Discrimination Against Female Professors
description: In an extraordinary admission, top officials at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the most prestigious science and engineering university in the country, have issued a report acknowledging that female professors here suffer from pervasive, if unintentional, discrimination.

title: Former Officer Gets a Life Term For 10 Murders in a Drug Gang
description: A former housing police officer in the Bronx avoided the death penalty yesterday by pleading guilty to Federal charges that he had killed 10 people while he was a member of a violent drug gang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLALLY, DR. JOSEPH PATRICK MICHAEL
description: MULLALLY-Dr. Joseph Patrick Michael. On March 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Agnes (nee Galligan). Devoted father of Mary Ann Rose, Joan Scales, Noreen McGuire, Kathleen Mullally and Virginia Hallinan. Dearest brother of Sr. Marie Annunciata of the Sisters of St. Joseph of Brentwood. Loving grandfather of ten grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. He was born in Kilross, County Tipperary, Ireland on March 17, 1913. He received his Doctorate in Philosophy from Columbia University in 1944. As a lover of all things Irish, he taught at the University of Notre Dame from 1944 to 1950. He then taught at Queens College until his retirement in the late 1970's. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9PM and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9PM at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10AM. St. Mary's R.C. Church, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORGREN, LYNDON M.
description: NORGREN-Lyndon M. Age 93, on March 21, 1999. Married to the late Martha Sandstrom Norgren for fifty-six years. Brother of Irving, father of Johanna, Peter, and Connie, grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Amy, Benjamin, Luke, great grandfather of Nathaniel. We love you Dad, and will miss you. For information please contact CareyHand Funeral Home, Orlando, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, DR. NORMAN
description: FREUND-Dr. Norman. Of New York and Florida passed away March 22nd, 1999. Loving husband of Sylvia and the late Mildred (nee Weitzman), devoted father, grandfather and great grandfather.

title: Oscar Broadcast Lost at Least Nine Million Viewers
description: Sunday night's Academy Awards broadcast on ABC suffered a significant ratings drop from the 1998 version, drawing at least 10 percent fewer viewers, preliminary figures showed yesterday.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Developing a Glow

title: Accounts
description: * The Children's Place, West Caldwell, N.J., to Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle the account for the children's apparel retailer. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $10 million.

title: Racial Hype: Nasty Days Here Again
description: EVERY New Yorker of good will wished Edward I. Koch a speedy recovery yesterday after he suddenly fell ill. But any New Yorker with even a threadbare sense of humor had to be disappointed when wooziness kept the former Mayor from joining the Rev. Al Sharpton's cavalcade of political stars outside police headquarters.

title: Democratic Leader Urges Pataki to Fire Port Authority Director
description: Judith Hope, the chairwoman of the State Democratic Committee, has called on Gov. George E. Pataki to fire Robert E. Boyle as executive director of the Port Authority after published reports described costly agency parties and raised questions about Mr. Boyle's private real estate dealings as chairman of a nonprofit Westchester hospital.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the first nonstop round-the-world flight by balloonists incorrectly described the end of an attempt last year by the ICO Global Challenge balloon. It ditched in the Pacific Ocean near Hawaii because a low-pressure trough was stalling its progress and it was running low on fuel. It did not run out of fuel.

title: Vatican to Review Taiwan Ties
description: A top Vatican official said today that the Holy See would reconsider its ties with Taiwan in order to secure better relations with China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEEHAN, DENNIS W.
description: SHEEHAN-Dennis W. Age 65, of Tappahannock, Virginia, and Lake Forest, Illinois died on Sunday, March 21, 1999. He was a member of St. Timothy's Catholic Church, Tappahannock. He was former Chairman & CEO of Axia, Inc and former Chairman of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Sheehan served on the Board of Directors of Axia, Inc., Allied Healthcare, National Council on Crime & Delinquency and Greenfield Corp. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club, Tastevin, Commonwealth Club, St. Louis Club, Downtown Club and Chicago Club. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Hellyer Sheehan; three children, Dennis W. Sheehan, Jr., (Kathleen C. Mahoney), Catherine E. Sheehan and John E. Sheehan (Maureen M.); two sisters, Janet B. Helm and Helyn S. Harris; four brothers, Greg A. Sheehan, Brian C. Sheehan, Theodore D. Sheehan and Edward F. Sheehan; five grandchildren, Tara E. Sheehan, Kelsey K. Sheehan, Claire M. Sheehan, Haley M. Sheehan and John E. Sheehan, Jr. The family will receive friends from 6:00-8:00 p.m. Wednesday at St. Timothy's Catholic Church where the Funeral Mass will be held 11:00 a.m. Thursday. Interment will be private. A reception will be held at the residence from 3:00-5:00 p.m. Thursday afternoon. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Sheehan Family Foundation P.O. Box 2032, Tappahannock, VA 22560. Marks-Bristow Funeral Home, Tappahannock, VA.

title: Looking Beyond the Symptoms
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Chairman Seeks Mutual Fund Changes
description: Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed strengthening oversight of mutual funds by independent directors yesterday but stopped short of offering the more sweeping changes that he had considered.

title: Q & A
description: Long-Lasting Immunity

title: Prison Term Imposed for Helping Man Get Gun to Kill Officer
description: After relatives of a slain New York City police officer spoke emotionally of their loss, a Brooklyn woman was sentenced yesterday to 15 years to life in prison for helping her boyfriend get hold of the gun that he used to kill the officer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Comcast Buying Mediaone In a Deal Worth $53 Billion

title: Navy Admiral Removed From Post Over an Affair
description: The two-star admiral in charge of the Navy's air forces in the Mediterranean was formally relieved of his duties today after an investigation found that he had had an adulterous affair with a civilian and then lied about it to investigators.

title: China Says Los Alamos Scientist Gave It No Secrets on Warheads
description: Chinese officials say that Wen Ho Lee, the Taiwan-born American scientist suspected of leaking nuclear secrets, attended two scientific meetings in China in the 1980's.

title: NATO Allows Chief to Order Air Strikes Against Serbs
description: The NATO allies stepped up their threats today, giving their top civilian leader the authority to mount air strikes directly against Serbian forces who are attacking ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo province. The expanded authority is subject to consultation with Western leaders.

title: Vivendi of France Acquiring U.S. Filter
description: Vivendi S.A. of France is to acquire the United States Filter Corporation for $6.2 billion in cash, or $31.50 a share. The deal, announced yesterday, would create a $12 billion behemoth that would be ''the largest company in one of the world's fastest-growing industries,'' said Rod Lache, an analyst with Deutsche Bank Securities.

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, DR. IRWIN H.
description: KAISER-Dr. Irwin H. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the death of their Life Fellow, Dr. Irwin H. Kaiser on March 18, 1999. Howard L. Minkoff, M.D. President Richard U. Levine, M.D. Secretary

title: In Cairo, the First Lady Parries Questions About a Senate Bid
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton deflected questions today about whether she plans to run for the Senate from New York, but said she was looking for a way to advance the issues involving children and women ''I've spent more than 25 years working on.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVALLARO, JOSEPH J.
description: CAVALLARO-Joseph J. Unexpectedly passed on March 20th, 1999. Beloved father of Paul and daughter-in-law, Lorraine. Dear grandfather of Jennifer, Cristina and Paul, Jr. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, W. 71st St. Mr. Cavallaro was restaurateur of Jennifer's Restaurant.

title: Ailing Depleted Nets Roll To Victory
description: Before tonight's game, Jayson Williams sat at his locker, his sore left hand encased in padding to protect a sore left thumb. After the Nets' 106-87 pasting of the Toronto Raptors, his right elbow was wrapped in ice. Even a rare victory is painful for Williams.

title: Designers Had Oscar Jitters, Too
description: It's Sunday, about 1:30 P.M. in Los Angeles, and the designer Randolph Duke, relaxed and triumphant, is having a pedicure.

title: When a Loss Remains Unresolved
description: Jenny and and her husband had enjoyed 15 years of an emotionally and intellectually fulfilling marriage when he suffered a stroke and Jenny's whole life suddenly screeched to a halt. Instead of gradually recovering, over the next five years her husband got progressively worse. The stroke had unmasked or hastened the onset of Alzheimer's disease, and Jenny became his permanent de facto caretaker.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Education page on Wednesday with an article about social life at Harvard misspelled the name of a residential house. It is Pforzheimer, not Pfozheimer.

title: Metro Business; Hong Kong Stock Sale
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, ING Barings and Jardine Fleming Holdings were picked for Asia's most lucrative investment banking job: helping the Hong Kong government arrange to sell its $23 billion stock portfolio, said people involved in the negotiations.

title: Early Eating Habits Tied to Adult Ills
description: Two new studies lend support to the view that by the time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in the problems they may suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes.

title: Should Serbia Be Scared?
description: NATO's threat to conduct air strikes against Serbian military forces is not a sufficient strategy for ending the conflict in Kosovo. The United States and its allies need a backup plan in case this instinctive response does not work -- and they need one fast.

title: Benigni's Oscar Gives a Lift to a Town and an Industry
description: It was 4 A.M. when the news hit the Casa del Popolo, a social center in Vergaio, Roberto Benigni's hometown in Tuscany. As a giant screen, set up for the evening, showed the Italian filmmaker joyously bounding up onto the backs of seats at the Academy Awards ceremony, thousands of local supporters outside the Casa del Popolo jumped up and down and screamed ''Ha vinto!'' (''He won!'') in a perfect synchrony of excitement.

title: Looking Beyond the Symptoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Beloved Country Repays Mandela in Kind
description: The pink light of dawn was on the runway at Waterkloof Air Force Base near here when Nelson Mandela settled into a specially padded seat aboard his presidential jet. The flight attendant knelt to remove his shoes and, in what seemed like a well-worn routine, helped him lift his swollen legs high onto two pillows.

title: Board to Give Likely Cause For Jet Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will try on Tuesday to end the longest investigation in its history, planning to identify the reason for two crashes and several harrowing incidents involving the world's most popular jetliner, the Boeing 737. But after four and a half years of intensive investigation, there are no simple answers in sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVARESE, CATHERINE N.
description: SAVARESE-Catherine N. On March 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis B. Devoted mother of Catherine S. Johnston, Margaret R. Savarese and Louis V. Also survived by seven loving grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45 AM, at Resurrection Ascension Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULDER, JAMES
description: GOULDER-James. Of Scarsdale, NY, on March 21. Husband of Alice Goulder. Father of John, Alison and James Goulder, Jr. Grandfather of Debra and David Steingesser. Funeral service Tuesday, 2:00 PM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY, where the family will receive friends from 1:302:00 PM. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery. Memorial contributions to Harvard Choral Society or the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: A Big Challenge to Skilled Doctors
description: Doctors and health officials have long been eager to determine which doctors are most likely to be sued for malpractice. Some studies have suggested that bedside manner is the most effective tool for preventing litigation; other experts have found that lawsuits do not seem to be linked to actual incompetence.

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Miscellany
description: * MDC Communications Corp., Toronto, agreed to acquire an 80 percent stake in Colle & McVoy, Minneapolis, for an estimated $19 million in cash. Colle & McVoy has billings estimated at $130 million from clients like Caterpillar and Pfizer.

title: Mogul in Love . . . With Winning; Monday Morning Quarterbacking After Miramax's Big Night
description: The post-Oscar King of Hollywood lives in New York, behaves like an old-time studio mogul and has plenty of enemies. Especially this morning.

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Student Is Found Stabbed to Death in Bronx
description: A 19-year-old nursing student was found stabbed to death in her bedroom in her family's apartment in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: FIRST DATA TO BUY 45% OF PAYMENTECH FOR $400 MILLION
description: The First Data Corporation, the nation's largest processor of consumer payments to merchants, agreed to buy 45 percent of its rival Paymentech Inc. and combine it with a unit of the Bank One Corporation, which owns the other 55 percent. First Data, based in Atlanta, will pay $25.50 a share for about 16 million shares of Paymentech, the third-largest processor of credit card transactions in the United States, making the acquisition worth about $400 million. Paymentech, based in Dallas, will be merged into Banc One Payment Services, a payment-processing alliance between Bank One and First Data that they will now jointly own. Pamela Patsley, chief executive of Paymentech, will run the combined unit.

title: Court Ruling May Intensify Fight to Control Gucci
description: The takeover struggle for the Gucci Group seemed to intensify tonight when a Dutch arbitration court handed down a mixed ruling that was described as a victory both by the famous fashion house and its unwanted suitor.

title: EDISON UNIT TO BUY 40 PERCENT OF NEW ZEALAND UTILITY
description: Edison International Inc. said its Edison Mission Energy unit had submitted the winning bid of $1.21 billion (New Zealand), or $640 million, for a 40 percent stake in the New Zealand Government-owned electric utility Contact Energy Ltd. Edison International, based in Rosemead, Calif., is a utility holding company whose principal subsidiary is Southern California Edison. Contact has 27.4 percent of New Zealand's installed electricity generation capacity. Edison has also emerged as the leading bidder for a group of power plants being sold by the Chicago-based Unicom Corporation, offering more than $5 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Cendant Chief Earned $61.1 Million in '98
description: Henry Silverman, chairman and chief executive of the Cendant Corporation, earned profits of $61.1 million last year by exercising stock options, more than offsetting a cut in his annual bonus.

title: Worldwide Drug Sales Up 7% in '98
description: World sales of pharmaceuticals grew 7 percent last year, to $251.3 billion, thanks to the popularity of several new drugs and their simultaneous introductions in many countries, according to an annual industry survey scheduled to be released today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIROUX, CARMEN DE ARANGO
description: GIROUX-Carmen de Arango. Of Greenwich, CT, on March 19th, 1999. Former advisor to the Holy See Missions Delegation to the United Nations, reporting directly to the Vatican in Rome. Calling hours will be today, 4-8 pm, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, St. Mary's Church, 10 am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITCHARD, WILBUR L.
description: PRITCHARD-Wilbur L. The Directors and members of the Townsend Harris Alumni Association, Inc., wish to express their sympathy to the family of Wilbur L. Pritchard '39 on his passing. In 1991, Mr. Pritchard was inducted into the Townsend Harris Hall of Fame in recognition of his achievements as an aerospace engineering executive. His gentle smile and warm manner will be missed. Saul Grossman, Ph.D.-Chairman Lester Friesner-President Charles Puglisi-Secretary

title: Teotihuacan Journal; An Ancient Sun Melts Mexico's Modern Stresses
description: The crowds, half a million people dressed in white with red headbands, clambered over a towering ancient pyramid and packed the broad ceremonial avenue below it. When the sun reached its noon zenith they closed their eyes and turned to it, stretching their palms upward to absorb the invigorating rays.

title: U.S. Options: Unpalatable
description: Of all the times that Richard C. Holbrooke, the Clinton Administration's envoy, has negotiated with the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the room for maneuvering has probably never been so restricted and the options so unpalatable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAY, DAVID
description: DUNAY-David. Passed away March 20, 1999. Educated at the George Washington High School in New York City, he served in the U.S. Army during World War II. His career began as Visual Presentation Manager at Lord and Taylor in New York. He proceeded to Neiman Marcus, Rich's, and the Hecht Co. He was President of Creative Services at the May Company in Los Angeles. He is survived by his wife Patricia Hunter Dunay of Los Angeles, two daughters, Alexia Dunay of New York and Nicole Dunay Calloway of Trumbull, CT, and two grandsons Max Dunay Calloway and Lucas Dunay Calloway. Memorial services will be held at Temple Kol Tikvah, 20400 Ventura Boulevard, Woodland Hills, CA at 3:00 pm on March 23, 1999. Donations may be sent to the Children of Parkinsonians, 73-700 El Paseo, Suite 2, Palm Desert, CA 92260.

title: Intel Introduces a Faster Computer Chip
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer chips, introduced a faster version of its Celeron processors for low-cost personal computers. The company is trying to regain market share lost to Advanced Micro Devices Inc.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have always believed that contemporary gender discrimination within universities is part reality and part perception. True, but I now understand that reality is by far the greater part of the balance.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 11 about the outlook for the Nissan Motor Company referred incorrectly to the financial condition of Renault S.A. of France, which has offered to buy a stake in Nissan. Renault has a net cash position worth about $2.1 billion, which means that if the company paid all debts it would have about $2.1 billion left. Renault does not have a high level of debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE COTTON WRENN, DOROTHY
description: WHYTE COTTON WRENN-Dorothy. Died on March 18, 1999 in Portland, Oregon, born in Auburn, NY, she attended The University Michigan and Columbia University. In a professional career devoted to journalism and public health education in the broadest sense, her special concern was with the rights and well-being of mothers and children. She lived and worked in New York City for many years, serving as Editor-InChief of Parents Magazine until 1970 when she moved to Oregon. She is survived by her son, Michael Whyte, daughter-in-law, Susan, and grandsons, Timothy and Zachary. At her request, there will not be a service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood.

title: Who'll Sequence Human Genome First? It's Up to Phred
description: Last week the public consortium working to sequence the human genome said it would complete a ''first draft'' of the human DNA sequence next spring, well ahead of the target date announced by its commercial rival, the Celera Corporation. Each side has committed $250 million to the project, but the outcome of this battle of titans seems to lie to some extent in the hands of an esoteric computer program named Phred.

title: Tennessee Women Are Upset by Duke
description: Tennessee's quest for a fourth straight N.C.A.A. women's basketball championship ended when the Vols were defeated by Duke, 69-63, in the East Regional final. No. 1-ranked Purdue (32-1) defeated Rutgers and Georgia also advanced. SportsTuesday, pages D1 and D3.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Court Cuts Gallery's Ties To Francis Bacon Estate
description: Marlborough Fine Art, the gallery that handled the artistic management of the British painter Francis Bacon for virtually his entire career, has had all association with his estate ended by England's High Court.

title: Oil Executives Work the Room at OPEC Meeting
description: The Libyan oil minister's senior bodyguard kept a stern vigil outside his boss's 12th- floor suite at the Hotel Intercontinental today, but not to protect him from terrorists.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Auctioned Gown In the Spotlight

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCKENNA, FLORENCE
description: MCKENNA-Florence. In loving memory of Florence McKenna, who died suddenly on January 31, 1999, there will be a Memorial Mass held on Thursday, March 25, 1999, at 11 A.M. at Saint Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, 84th Street and Park Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Rangers Gain Gretzky But Still Lose Ground
description: Wayne Gretzky is back in the lineup. The Rangers are falling further back in the playoff race. It will be interesting to see which of Gretzky's teammates are back for the next game, after Tuesday's trading deadline has passed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Friday about an increase in the printing run of a children's book written by a Mexican rebel leader misspelled the name of the foundation that is supporting the book with a grant to replace one withdrawn by the National Endowment for the Arts. It is the Lannan Foundation, not the Lennan Foundation.

title: Cal Is Back in the Spotlight After Paying a Stiff Price
description: The college coaches who gathered in Manhattan yesterday to discuss their teams' berths in the National Invitation Tournament's semifinals were predictably excited, so much so that you could almost forget that there was another tournament going on. But when California's Ben Braun spoke of his excitement to be here, it seemed easy to believe.

title: People
description: * Ed McCarrick was named publisher at Time magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., succeeding Jack Haire, who was recently named president at a sibling, Fortune Group, New York, overseeing Fortune and Your Company magazines. Mr. McCarrick had been publisher at another sibling, Life magazine, New York.

title: Hilfiger and Nintendo Get Marketing Honors
description: A promotion marketing campaign for Tommy Hilfiger Inc. in New York and Nintendo America in Redmond, Wash., a unit of the Nintendo Company, took top honors at the 16th annual Reggie Awards competition sponsored by the Promotion Marketing Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLES, ROY, E.
description: TILLES-Roy, E. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Roy E. Tilles, whose many years of friendship and devotion to the Club will always be remembered. We extend deepest sympathy to the family. Richard M. Feldman, President Edward J. Landau, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKALINSKI, WALLY
description: BAKALINSKI-Wally. Died on March 21 after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Mary Blake and father of Ruth and grandfather of Tiffany. Cherished nephew, brother-in-law, uncle and greatuncle to Rachel. Services Tuesday 12Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Around-the-World Balloon Pilots Cheered on Return to Switzerland
description: As Dr. Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones stepped from a plane from Cairo today after becoming the first balloonists to circle the world nonstop, a trumpeter played the ''Triumphal March'' from ''Aida'' and a thunderous cheer rose from the dignitaries and well-wishers who had gathered at Geneva International Airport.

title: A New Threat to Irish Peace
description: Northern Ireland's peace agreement is facing the most serious crisis of its 11 months of life. David Trimble, the Protestant Unionist who is First Minister of Northern Ireland's new assembly, is set to appoint a cabinet of 10 ministers, 2 of them from the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein. But he will do so only if the I.R.A. starts to turn over its buried weapons and explosives. Such disarmament, while not required now under the peace agreement, is clearly reasonable. The I.R.A.'s refusal to begin even token disarmament could destroy the peace.

title: There's No Bright Side for the Knicks
description: Fourth-quarter scenes from a debacle: Marcus Camby launching an eight-foot jump shot that travels 12 feet; an unguarded Chris Childs, lofting an air ball from behind the 3-point line; a nonchalant Allan Houston throwing an entry pass into the post that gets stolen.

title: An Evening Of Baroque Discoveries
description: With the New York Collegium instantly acclaimed as a new force on the early-music scene in the city this season, hard-working older ensembles have to be asking whether they, after all, have been merely chopped liver. Artek, for one, has afforded many pleasures in its 14 seasons, as it did on Wednesday evening in a mostly fascinating program of French Baroque music at the Church of the Resurrection on East 74th Street in Manhattan.

title: Senators May Demand Court Nominee's Records
description: Senate Democratic leaders said yesterday that they would take the unusual move of seeking to subpoena the records of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero as part of hearings into his nomination to the State Supreme Court.

title: Arab Web Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat's Tightrope: Palestinian Statehood
description: Yasir Arafat, who is to meet with President Clinton on Tuesday, has always been a master of the tightrope, and once more his acrobatic skills are being tested.

title: Looking Beyond the Symptoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENBACH, L. EMERY
description: KATZENBACH-L. Emery. The Mount Sinai NYU Medical Center & Health System Board of Trustees and Administration mourns the loss of L. Emery Katzenbach. Mr. Katzenbach was elected a member of The NYU Medical Center Board in 1972 and became a Life Member of The Board in 1991. He served on its Education and Research Financial and Budget and Trustees Committees. An investment banker, he joined the firm of White Weld & Company in 1941, and later became Chairman and CEO of the company. To his wife, Marley, and his children, and grandchildren, we offer our heartfelt sympathy. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman, Board of Trustees Mount Sinai NYU Medical Center and Health System John W. Rowe, M.D. President and Chief Exec Officer Mount Sinai NYU Medical Center and Health System Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTNIK, ALEX
description: KUTNIK-Alex. Of Margate, Fl. Jewelry store owner and manager in New York and California. Survived by son, Dr. Leonard, daughter-in-law, Marti, grandchildren, Jacqueline, Deborah, Marc, Shawn; brother, Nat. Services at 10 A.M. Levayah Garlick Home, 1091 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: The Economics of Cancer
description: Jane Brody's story of her own breast cancer (''Living Proof: Mammograms Are Not Always Enough,'' March 8) omits a critical health problem. She says that ''money should not be a concern that deters women from having regular mammograms.'' But for the millions without health insurance, if the result is positive, what happens next? Who pays for the biopsy, pathology report, radiation, surgery and five years of expensive tamoxifen? What are the ethics of encouraging breast cancer detection when many women have no access to care. We need a tax-based universal access health system. Otherwise, we find the cancer, we tell the woman and we leave her to die.

title: Difficult Works, Indirectly Reflecting A Worshiper's Mind
description: Music can no more be religious than it can hairy or triangular. No moral stands emanate from major or minor triads; the diminished seventh chord expresses an unsettled state, but evil? I don't think so. But music can, as Robert Spano and the Brooklyn Philharmonic showed us on Saturday night, give us an indirect reflection of what is on the worshiper's mind. For what we can measure and record is the extravagance or reticence of the declamation contained in any ''religious'' piece.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated the numbers for the New Jersey Pick 3 game in some copies. The winning number for March 21 was 944, not 691.

title: Moscow Opposes Air Raids, but Is Miffed at Serbs
description: Serbia's latest offensive in Kosovo is leading some of Russia's top foreign policy specialists to question Moscow's longstanding support for Belgrade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MURIEL
description: SIMON-Muriel. We mourn the tragic loss of our beloved Muriel. We will always remember her thoughtfulness, kindness and caring. Our thoughts are with Sherman and the family. We loved her and will miss her forever. Til Lee, Bert, Carol, Gene and Rita Rothkopf

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, BUDDY
description: ROSENFELD-Buddy. A warm, gentle person. You will surely be missed, but never forgotten. Terry & Arty

title: Cement Company Banned From City Hall Park Renovation
description: Since January, the Empire Transit Mix Company of Brooklyn has supplied $200,000 worth of cement for one of the Giuliani administration's pet projects, the renovation of City Hall Park. Empire also had orders to deliver an additional $400,000 worth of cement in coming months.

title: China's Choices
description: When viewed from here, there is something incredibly off-base about the debate on China going on in the United States today. The best parallel I can think of is the debate in America about Japan a decade ago.

title: Pope Reported To Plan Visit To Jerusalem Next March
description: Israel's Tourism Minister announced today that Pope John Paul II intended to visit Jerusalem in March next year to celebrate the millennium. It would be the first papal trip to the Holy Land since Paul VI visited Jerusalem in 1964.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, IRVING
description: BRANDT-Irving. Age 85. Of West Palm Beach, FL. Passed away March 22, 1999. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Rhoda and by his devoted and loving children Francine (Stanley Goldstein), Fort Lee, N.J., Warren (Barbara Brandt), Stamford, CT. and by the love of his life grandson Jeffrey L. Brandt. Also survived by devoted sisters Florence Brodish and Gertrude Brand of Forest Hills, N.Y. He was associated with the New York City School System for 33 years. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 12N Wednesday, March 24th. Contributions to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Bch, FL. 33407.

title: On-Line Privacy Group Decides Not to Pursue Microsoft Case
description: A nonprofit watchdog group founded to monitor on-line privacy policies scolded but declined to pursue an audit yesterday of one of its biggest donors, the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Irabu's Bag Of Pitches Includes Some Junk
description: Hideki Irabu has a good fastball and forkball, and on some days, when his fastball is 95 miles an hour and the forkball is diving, that's good enough. But relying on two pitches is like painting in black and white: eventually, you need more. You've got to have more.

title: A Big Blue Stop Sign On Spartans' Title Road
description: The news conference featuring Michigan State's Tom Izzo had frittered down to its final question on Sunday night. Izzo was almost out of his chair, eager to return to the Spartans' delirious locker room at the Trans World Dome in St. Louis. But then that daunting four-letter word was uttered. Duke. Coach, what about playing Duke?

title: Duke Stops 3-Time Champion Vols and Holdsclaw
description: For the first time in four years, Tennessee will not be the national champion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINA, WILLIAM
description: MALINA-William. Yeshivas Bais Yisroel, Jerusalem, Israel expresses its profound sorrow on the death of William Malina, one of our earliest supporters. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Jean, his children, Michael and Anita, Robert and Fran, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Doniel Lehrfield Rosh Yeshiva

title: British Developer Rejects Soros Bid
description: Greycoat P.L.C., a developer of office properties in London, rejected an offer yesterday to be acquired by Delancey Estates P.L.C., a British property group controlled by the investor George Soros, for $:197 million, or $320 million. Greycoat's board said the offer undervalued the company's assets and prospects.

title: Drifter Sheds His and Others' Skins
description: TAKING LIVES

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Summing Up an Art in Segments
description: Four composers divvied up the century for ''Jazz: The 20th-Century Musical Miracle,'' the concert by the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. The group commissioned Manny Albam, Slide Hampton, Jim McNeely and Muhal Richard Abrams to contemplate jazz from its New Orleans beginnings to its free-jazz extrapolations. The composers all drew on the strengths of the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band: its precise, brassy attack, its nimble articulation, its sweeping dynamics and its central allegiance to be-bop. The concert telescoped jazz's early years, lingered in the band's beloved 1940's and 50's, then recognized the rule-shattering 1960's avant-garde.

title: Shiva vs. Jesus: Hindus Burn Homes of Christians
description: The Christian settlement here until this month a thriving community of 1,200 Baptists -- is now a smoldering ruin. Women stumble through jagged remains of mud walls and step over charred beams, beating their chests, sifting the ashes through their fingers and crying out in sorrow for the homes they have lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULOVAS, REV. MSGR. FRANK JOHN
description: BULOVAS-Rev. Msgr. Frank John. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Transfiguration Church, 64-14 Clinton Avenue, Maspeth, on March 19. Reposing at Kodis Funeral Home, 63-03 Flushing Avenue, Flushing, Tuesday, March 23, from 2 to 5 PM. Mass of Transferral Tuesday, March 23, at 7:30 PM in Transfiguration Church. Funeral Mass Wednesday, March 24, at Transfiguration Church, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MORTON
description: GREEN-Morton. Beloved husband of Rose Alice. Devoted father of Jeff and Beth, and Andy. Dear brother of Fradel. Adored grandfather of Emily Teyo and Sophie. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Association for the Cure of Cancer of the Prostate (CAPCURE), 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, JANET EATON
description: GLOVER-Janet Eaton. 74. Died Saturday at her home in Hanover, NH. Beloved wife to Paul W. Glover Jr., Hanover, NH; loving mother to daughters, Margaret MacPherson Gardiner, Cornville, AZ., and Susan Gardiner Trespalacios, Morristown, NJ and sons, Peter Eaton Gardiner, Chestnut Hill, MA and Thomas Buchanan Gardiner, Morristown, NJ; stepdaughter, Gwendolyn G. Thompson, Norwich, VT; stepsons, Paul W. Glover, III, Sacramento, CA, John B. Glover, Franconia, NH and Andrew H. Glover, Pittsburgh, PA; two grandchildren and twelve step grandchildren. Memorial service Wednesday, 2:00 pm, St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Hanover, NH. Memorial donations to Norris Cotton Cancer Center, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756-0001.

title: Animated Antics: A Pair of Cartoon Characters Spring (Boinnng!) to Life
description: If they did not appear at the Westbeth Theater Center in three dimensions, you might mistake David Collins and Shane Dundas for figments of an animator's imagination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIRICO, DOMINICK F.
description: CHIRICO-Dominick F., M.D. Passed away Sunday March 21, 1999 in East Troy, WI. Age 87 years. Formerly of Long Island. Survived by relatives and friends. Funeral services were held. Dr. Chirico was a psychoanalyst in the Long Island area for many years. For information contact Heritage Funeral Home, East Troy, WI: 414642-5057.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL IMAGING INC., Tampa, Fla., an office equipment services company, agreed to acquire closely held Lewan & Associates Inc., of Denver, which services and sells copiers and maintains network systems, for an undisclosed price.

title: Cruise Line Pleads Guilty In Dumping
description: In a surprise move, Royal Caribbean Cruises pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges of making false statements to Coast Guard inspectors in an effort to conceal discharges of oily waste water from one of its ships on three occasions in 1994.

title: 2 Organizations That Handle Stock Paperwork Plan to Merge
description: Two critical pieces of Wall Street's behind-the-scenes machinery, the Depository Trust Company and the National Securities Clearing Corporation, announced yesterday that their boards have approved a plan to combine the two institutions.

title: Primakov Says Russia Will Fight Anti-Semitism
description: Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov promised a group of American Jews today that the Russian Government will combat a rising tide of anti-Semitism.

title: Changes come to Campbell Soup, Toys 'R' Us, Progressive Insurance and American Media.
description: SPRING has sprung and the change in seasons has brought a change in the status of several accounts and assignments, with billings estimated at $375 million.

title: A Tempest in a Test Tube, 10 Years Later
description: B. Stanley Pons and Martin Fleischmann are still true believers, as are other scientists and enthusiasts scattered around the globe who still see a glimmer of hope. Even the Federal Government keeps a few researchers investigating the topic, though inconspicuously.

title: Apax Partners Buying Computer Concern
description: Apax Partners & Company, a venture capital group, said yesterday that it was leading a group of investors buying the computer-services company CCMX S.A. for 1 billion French francs ($170 million) from the French Government. Apax is buying 68 percent of CCMX; Financiere et Industrielle Gaz & Eaux S.A., a Lazard Freres holding company, is buying 29 percent, and CCMX managers are buying 3 percent.

title: Romance and Folk Tales In a Troupe From Taiwan
description: Unlike modern dance, ballet has apparently not thrived in Taiwan, where its popularity and training have waxed and waned. Capital Ballet-Tapei, a small 10-year-old troupe that performed at the Taipei Theater in Manhattan on Sunday afternoon, suggests a promising path taken, with work still to be done.

title: If We Want Schools to Improve . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Patrick Heron, 79, Art Critic And British Abstract Painter
description: Patrick Heron, prominent in Britain since the 1940's as an abstract painter and as a vigorous critic and advocate in the international art world, died on Saturday at his home near St. Ives in Cornwall, England. He was 79.

title: Kevorkian Says His Role in Death Was 'Duty'
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian today told a jury here considering murder charges against him that he was no more a criminal for giving a seriously ill Michigan man a lethal injection of chemicals last year than is an executioner.

title: U.S. Designates 6 Power Plants To Burn Stockpiled Plutonium
description: The Energy Department chose six commercial nuclear power plants today, in the Carolinas and Virginia, to burn plutonium from nuclear weapons stockpiles, and selected a consortium involving the Duke Power Company, Stone & Webster and Cogema Inc., a French nuclear company, to make the fuel.

title: Portugal's Last Days in Macao Marred by Chinese Troop Issue
description: In less than nine months, this postage-stamp Portuguese colony will be absorbed into China. And its 502,000 residents, most of whom are Chinese, have few illusions about which side is calling the shots in the twilight of the transition to Chinese rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYER, MORTON S.
description: BRYER-Morton S., M.D. On March 20, 1999, Loving and devoted husband of Rella, loving father of Nicole and Lanning, loving grandfather of Jaime, Ian, Benjamin, Jayne and Josephine.

title: The Governor's Message
description: Whatever his motivation, Gov. George Pataki made sensible suggestions on Sunday about how New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, should respond to the civic turmoil over the shooting of Amadou Diallo by police officers. Part of political leadership, Mr. Pataki said, is ''listening to criticism and responding appropriately to criticism.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAZAR, ROD JOSEPH
description: SALAZAR-Rod Joseph. On March 19, 1999. Adored and adoring husband of Hibren. Cherished son of Carmen and the late Adolphe. Devoted father of Adam. Beloved brother of Adolfo Kenneth. Retired NYC public school principal and friend to hundreds. His strong convictions and passionate spirit were an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. Funeral Mass today, 10AM at Holy Trinity R.C. Church, 213 West 82 St, NYC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAITCH, ALFRED ALAN
description: DAITCH-Alfred Alan. On March 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Mickie (Minerva). Loving father of Randi and Jill. Father-in-law of Robert Wolchok and James Rosenberg. Grandfather (Poppy) of Sydney, Marc and Marni. Services at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY, Tuesday, March 23, at noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to Westchester Reform Temple or American Diabetes Association.

title: INSIDE
description: Court Takes Hawaii Case

title: Exploiting the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Audit of Apollo Management Is Expected This Week
description: A long-awaited audit of the nonprofit foundation that runs the Apollo Theater is expected to be delivered to the state by the end of the week, Pataki administration officials said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIPS. The dollar rose to 118.11 Japanese yen, from 117.28, as traders speculated about how high Japanese officials wanted the American currency. But the euro rose to $1.0908, from $1.0892, in quiet trading.

title: Young Americans Stand Out
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: Koch Hospitalized, Then Goes Home
description: Just hours before he had planned to get arrested to protest Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's response to the shooting of Amadou Diallo, former Mayor Edward I. Koch was taken to the hospital early yesterday morning after saying that he felt weak and lightheaded.

title: CASE TO EXPAND RUSSIAN SALES AND JOINT PRODUCTION
description: The Case Corporation, the second-largest American maker of farm equipment, will expand its presence in Russia with agreements to increase sales and service operations and start joint-manufacturing projects. Case said it would work with Russia to develop an entrepreneurial-style agricultural sector that could increase production by using modern equipment. In 1998 the Russian Federation harvested crops at a level significantly less than what was needed to feed its population.

title: 2 Proposed Italian Bank Combinations Win Favor of Market
description: Share prices of two big Italian banks sought by domestic rivals increased in value today, reflecting investors' delight with the premiums that buyers will pay to gain greater size in Italy's fragmented banking industry.

title: Antidote for Pretty Poison Is Found, but at Big Price
description: They are pretty poisons. Sweet, pretty with their yellow-green glow and all around us, as common as cars, in homes and garages everywhere.

title: Police May Have Understated Street Searches, Spitzer Says
description: An elite police unit that includes the four officers who shot Amadou Diallo may have vastly underreported the number of people it has stopped and searched on the streets in the last two years, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said in a radio interview broadcast yesterday.

title: Imports Face Higher Tariffs On Beef Issue
description: The United States prepared to open a new front in its trans-Atlantic trade disputes today, publishing a list of $900 million in European goods like truffles and foie gras that could be subjected to 100 percent tariffs if American farmers are not permitted to export hormone-treated beef to Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEMETH, GALE S.
description: NEMETH-Gale S. Beloved mother of Marc. Dear daughter of Helen and Al Neuman. Loving sister of Cherie. Funeral services Tuesday, March 23, 11:45 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, DONALD
description: BRAVERMAN-Donald. Dearest, you will always be a part of me and you will always have a part of me with you. I am so grateful for the beautiful times we shared together and I was always proud to be your wife. With all my love, Meryl

title: Liberties; Saving Private Gore
description: Al Gore could do worse than to take a lesson from the Oscars.

title: SERVICEMASTER TO BUY TEXAS COMPANY FOR $92 MILLION
description: The Servicemaster Company, best known for its Rescue Rooter plumbing business, said that it planned to acquire American Residential Services Inc. for $92 million plus $180 million in assumed debt. American Residential Services, based in Houston, provides commercial and residential plumbing, electrical, heating and air-conditioning services. Servicemaster, in Downers Grove, Ill., has interests in maintenance, cleaning, pest control, lawn care and other services. In trading yesterday, shares of American Residential rose $1.0625, to $5.4375, and those of Servicemaster fell 43.75 cents, to $19.125.

title: Yeltsin's Inner Circle Under Investigation for Corruption
description: The evidence is still flimsy, and the political motives are obvious, but Russia's chief prosecutor's office confirmed today that it was investigating corruption inside the Kremlin itself, aimed at members of President Boris N. Yeltsin's inner circle.

title: Sir Michael Caine, 71, Muse Behind Britain's Booker Prize
description: Sir Michael Caine, a corporate chief with a love of books who was the driving force behind the Booker Prize for Fiction, Britain's most prestigious literary award, died of cancer on Saturday in London. He was 71.

title: Union Says Evidence Shows 4 Leaders Misused Funds
description: Union investigators presented evidence yesterday that Albert Diop, one of the most powerful figures in New York City's largest union of municipal employees, misused funds by double billing for limousine service, by charging $162,000 in New York City hotel expenses and by spending more than $800,000 in union money without providing documentation.

title: Rangers Face Questions As Samuelsson Departs
description: Ulf Samuelsson, the veteran defenseman, is no longer a Ranger, but he has strong opinions about his former team. Three days before his 35th birthday, he was traded today for two draft choices to the Detroit Red Wings, who are trying to win the Stanley Cup for the third consecutive season.

title: With Sampras at No. 1, Krajicek Rises to the Occasion
description: The shoulders were sunken, the head was bowed, the racquet spewed sour notes like an out-of-tune piano. Though Pete Sampras is again back in his accustomed perch as the No. 1 men's player in the world, he and his game have not yet caught up to his numeral. The bludgeoned backhand volley that missed the court and set up his adversary's second match point today was visible proof of his current shortcomings.

title: Love and Fate in a Land That Breathes Desperation
description: NINE BELOW ZERO

title: Pictures of Arrests Are Prevented
description: There was something different yesterday in what have become daily acts of civil disobedience at Police Headquarters to protest the Diallo case: the police made it almost impossible for the crowd of photographers to take pictures of the protesters in handcuffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAINER, DANIEL S.
description: RAINER-Daniel S. On March 23, 1999, of Port Washington, NY. A retired U.S. Customs Department examiner & import specialist, also an international trade consultant to Hasbro Toys. He is survived by his wife Anne Tarasoff Rainer; children and (grandchildren) Jill and Michael Rainer (Kyle), Nancy and Kenny Tarasoff (Melissa & David), Karyn and Dr. Henry Pek (Mandi, Matthew, Zachary and Jessie), Elana & Michael Tarasoff (Matthew, Craig and Ryan), and Gail Sutton (Brittany and Jordon); brothers Robert and Beverly and Gilbert Rainer; and niece Laurie Rainer. Services today, 10AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Arts section on Monday about ''James Baldwin: Collected Essays,'' a reading that night at the Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, misidentified the publisher of a collection of Baldwin's work, edited by Toni Morrison. It is The Library of America, not the Library of Congress.

title: Russian Leads After Sloppy Short Program
description: The temptations are greater now for Olympic-eligible figure skaters: the compensation is better and the competitions are more numerous, leaving the legs and psyches wearier in late March than perhaps ever before.

title: Anti-Missile System: Same Old Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bankers Trust Officials to Get $122 Million
description: The top three executives of the Bankers Trust Corporation are to receive $122 million over three years after the bank is purchased by Deutsche Bank A.G., Bankers Trust said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: U.S. Negotiators Depart, Frustrated by Milosevic's Hard Line
description: Through six hours of negotiations over two days with the American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia refused ''every opportunity'' to avoid an onslaught of NATO air power, a senior American official said today.
