title: High Court Expands Authority Of Judges on Expert Testimony
description: In a substantial victory for defendants in product liability suits, the Supreme Court gave Federal judges new authority today to keep expert testimony of questionable reliability out of the courtroom and away from the jury.

title: Mitchell, Ex-Jaguar Tight End, Signs
description: The Giants' decadelong search for a tight end with downfield pass-catching abilities -- something they have not had since Mark Bavaro left the team -- continued yesterday when the Giants signed the free agent Pete Mitchell, the Jacksonville Jaguars' starting tight end for the last two seasons.

title: Brazil's Trade Surplus Lower Than Expected
description: Brazil reported a lower-than-expected trade surplus yesterday for the first 21 days of March. A credit squeeze reined in exports, offsetting the expected lift from a currency devaluation, and imports fell as demand crumbled. The trade surplus during the period was $46 million, compared with a surplus of $219 million for the month of February.

title: A Wary Senate Gives Support For Air Strikes
description: Badly divided, the Senate voted tonight to support NATO air strikes against Serbian military targets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERMAIN, LAWRENCE
description: GERMAIN - Lawrence, who passed away March 24th, 1991. A husband is a special gift. One you think will stay. You never think the day will come When he is called away. God looked around his garden And saw an empty space. He then looked down from heaven And saw your kindly face. He put his arms around you And whispered, ''Come and rest.'' His garden must be beautiful. He only takes the best. Have you ever lost a husband Who meant the world to you The one you loved so dearly And miss him like I do. If you have never had that feeling Then I pray you never do For when God takes your husband He takes a part of you. A shadow walks beside me Forever by my side Always there to guide me Ever since you died. And now it's your anniversary, Lawrence It's up to God above To tell you how much I miss you And give you all my love. Sadly missed by your loving wife, Sheila

title: Vote on Bias Resolution Tests Bipartisan Civility in Congress
description: ''The people watching this debate must be scratching their heads,'' Representative Michael P. Forbes, Republican of New York, said as he took his turn on the House floor today to argue over whether Congress should pass a resolution that condemned all bigotry and racist groups.

title: Hard Road to Recovery, But Wilson Knows Way
description: When Jason Isringhausen spotted Paul Wilson entering the Mets' clubhouse today, Isringhausen quickly walked over and put his arm around his fellow pitcher.

title: Israel Can't Be Owned
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining a la Garbo: Alone, Not Lonely
description: WE were four strangers. Each of us had happened upon a narrow, smoky Alsatian restaurant in an unfashionable part of Paris and taken a seat around the right-angled end of the bar. Before long, we found ourselves in a lively conversation about the rise of the supermarket in France and the decline of the small bakeries and food shops. We debated whether golf was a bore and argued over the Frenchman's insistence that Alsatian pinot noir was the only wine to drink with sauerkraut.

title: In School; To improve learning and attendance, schools are drumming up interest in after-school programs.
description: The springlike breeze pushing through the tattered orange curtains hardly distracted the nearly 1,000 students from the task at hand: shouting their heads off, clapping their hands red and testing the structural integrity of the seats at Theodore Roosevelt High School's auditorium.

title: Notebook; A Problem in Special Ed
description: Despite increased attention to the needs of disabled students, the nation faces a chronic and persistent shortage of certified special education teachers, according to the Federal Department of Education's annual report on educating the disabled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATZ, LEONARD W.
description: KATZ-Leonard W. Died March 24, 1998. Mildred, Laurie, John, Polly, Tony, and grandchildren all miss you so very much.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONLAN, REV. THOMAS C.
description: DONLAN-Rev. Thomas C., O.P. Who spent the eight year period from 1989 to 1997 with us at Saint Agnes Church, 143 East 43rd St, NYC, died February 25th. We invite his friends in New York to join our parishioners at a Month's Mind Memorial Mass for him this Thursday evening, March 25th at 6:30 P.M. Bishop Edwin Broderick will be the principal celebrant and homilist. Music of Gregorian Chant and Movements from The Durufle Requiem.

title: Malaysian Trial Over Sex and Graft Ends Abruptly; Verdict to Come Later
description: With one last judicial twist and one last cry of outrage from the defense, the politically charged sex-and-corruption trial of Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, came to a sudden end today.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Once a Bridesmaid, Now a Bride in Full

title: NATO AUTHORIZES BOMB STRIKES; PRIMAKOV, IN AIR, SKIPS U.S. VISIT
description: NATO today authorized air strikes against Serbia as President Clinton declared that force was necessary to halt the aggression by Serbs against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If President Milosevic is not willing to make peace, we are willing to limit his ability to make war on the Kosovars.''

title: Metro Business; Grants on Home Care
description: Seven hospitals in New York City were given a total of $1.15 million in grants yesterday to develop programs to help people who care for relatives in their homes. The grants were awarded by the United Hospital Fund, a Manhattan-based research and philanthropic organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEFERT, DENNIS H.
description: SEFERT-Dennis H., 56. Died on Monday, March 22, 1999 after a long fought battle with cancer. He spent thirteen years in the Bond Department of Solomon Bros. in New York and Cleveland. In 1981, Mr. Sefert left Solomon to become involved in the commodity futures business in Chicago. Mr. Sefert died peacefully surrounded by family. He is survived by his wife Olivia, his sister Beth and his children Geoffrey, Wendy, Ashley and Jennifer. Memorial service Friday, March 26th, 1 PM, at Saint Chrysostom's Episcopal Church, 1424 N. Dearborn, Chicago. IL.

title: S.E.C. Accord on Auditors' Investments
description: Partners and other key figures at the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche must sell all their direct holdings in Fidelity Investments before the company begins auditing some Fidelity funds, according to an agreement reached today between the firm and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Arafat Says Little on Clinton Meeting
description: After meeting with President Clinton today, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, remained tight-lipped about whether he would unilaterally declare a Palestinian state on May 4, as he has indicated he might, and Administration officials said they gleaned no clue about which way he might be leaning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, ARTHUR
description: CHAPLIN-Arthur. Temple Israel Lawrence, NY, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to his family. Services 11:30AM, Friday at Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: 'Bad Writing' Has No Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: A Phone Call From Gore and a U-Turn to Moscow
description: Just after 1 P.M. today, an angry Russian Prime Minister, en route to Washington for some of the most important talks of his short tenure, ordered his pilot to turn his Ilyushin airliner around and return to Moscow.

title: Magic Johnson to Resurrect a Movie Palace
description: Magic Johnson, the former Los Angeles Lakers star whose post-basketball ventures include developing movie theaters, has reached an agreement with New York City to refurbish the historic Loews Kings Theate2 on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, officials announced yesterday.

title: A Premiere And a Title Coincide
description: When it came time to print the program for the Sunday afternoon performance by the Creative Outlet Dance Theater of Brooklyn at Aaron Davis Hall, Jamel Gaines had not settled upon a title for his premiere. It was simply listed as ''Section II.''

title: Granada Group Buying Scottish Media Stake
description: Granada Group P.L.C., Britain's independent television network, agreed yesterday to buy Mirror P.L.C.'s 18.6 percent stake in Scottish Media Group P.L.C., a commercial television broadcaster, for $:110.3 million, or $179.4 million, in cash. Granada will pay 915 pence a share for Mirror's more than 12 million shares in Scottish Media, about an 8.5 percent premium to Scottish Media's closing share price of 843.5 pence on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MURRAY
description: BERGER-Murray. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father of Albert and Ralph and father-in-law of Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Beth and Brian. Fighter in the Jewish Resistance during W.W. II. Retired printer. Honored member, Jewish Communal Center and East Midwood Jewish Center. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the East Midwood Jewish Center, 1625 Ocean Avenue, Bklyn, NY 11230 or the charity of your choice.

title: In Albany, G.O.P. in Senate Makes 3d Version of Budget
description: All three of the Capitol's power players have now staked out their positions on the state budget, as the Republicans who control the Senate announced their package today, but with eight days left in the fiscal year, the Legislature appears little closer to a budget accord than it was a month ago.

title: RUNNING: Once a Gold Medalist, Now a Prisoner; Mamo Wolde, Winner of the 1968 Olympic Marathon, Is on Trial for Murder in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia -- On a hot morning in late November, the dry season in Ethiopia, women lined up outside the Federal High Court building carrying umbrellas or wearing cotton scarves over their head to block the sun. Men stood on the opposite side of a small dirt road by a row of trees. Under the watchful eye of soldiers carrying Kalashnikov rifles, they submitted to frisking, then filed up several steps into the one-story courthouse.

title: Albanians And Serbs, All Sinking Into Fear
description: The suburb was deserted. Washing flapped on clotheslines, cars were parked outside the houses, but there were no people. Four figures, two women and two children carrying bundles and bags, were hurrying up the hill away from the houses.

title: Editorial Observer; It's What a Mayor Says and How He Says It
description: The Mayor could not understand why he had such a problem with black and Latino New Yorkers. He had met with a group of minority officials and explained how he believed in a level playing field, not playing favorites. The officials twitched restlessly, and left unimpressed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a possible visit to Jersualem next March by Pope John Paul II misstated the location of one of the other cities he may visit. Nazareth is in Israel, not the Palestinian territories.

title: Energy Company In Bankruptcy
description: Forcenergy Inc., an energy concern burdened by heavy debt, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COFFINO, IRVING
description: COFFINO-Irving. 73. Of the Bronx, March 22, 1999. Devoted husband of Nancy and the late Adeline, father of Michael, Tommy, Dianne, Theresa, John and Joan, stepfather to Steven, Michael and Joseph, and grandfather to Torin, Aidan, Alex, Gabriel, Natasha, Michael and Brandon. Irv was the ultimate giver, devoting himself to family, friends and strangers with uncommon and unconditional selflessness. Those who knew him can never forget him. Services to be held Wednesday evening, March 24th, and Thursday afternoon and evening, March 25th, at Balsamo's Funeral Home, 3188 Westchester Avenue, Bronx, New York 10461, 718-597-8380. Funeral Friday, March 26th, at Woodlawn Chapel, Bronx, New York.

title: CNET BUYS KILLERAPP FOR $46.7 MILLION IN STOCK
description: CNET Inc. said that it had acquired the Killerapp Corporation, a closely held Internet media company based in Fremont, Calif., for about $46.7 million in stock. CNET, a producer of Internet network and television programming based in San Francisco, said it had exchanged 500,000 of its shares for the company. Killerapp, which operates a network of comparison shopping services for computer and consumer electronics products, will become part of CNET's on-line shopping service, CNET said. CNET shares rose $1.25, to $94.50.

title: Teen-Ager Accused of Killing Ex-Girlfriend
description: An 18-year-old was arrested yesterday and charged with stabbing his former girlfriend to death in her bedroom in the Bronx on Monday, the police said.

title: Milton S. Gould, 89, Legal Giant in a City of Lawyers, Dies
description: Milton S. Gould, a classicist turned storied courtroom litigator who for years played the scholarly Mr. Inside to William A. Shea's gregarious Mr. Outside as a managing partner of one of New York City's most politically connected and ethnically balanced law firms, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 and since the disbanding of Shea & Gould in 1994 had continued his 65-year legal career with the firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae.

title: The Rationale for Air Strikes
description: As Slobodan Milosevic's army continues to shell and murder its way through Kosovo, the United States and its NATO allies appear ready to bomb Serbian military targets, perhaps today. Mr. Milosevic has been given every chance to end his aggression, and every warning of what would happen if he did not. He has ignored them, and the bombing must begin quickly before his rampage takes more lives.

title: Management by 2 Cultures May Be a Growing Source of Strain for DaimlerChrysler
description: The merger in November of Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation, presented at the time as a merger of equals, is producing considerable unhappiness among some American managers at DaimlerChrysler A.G. who contend privately that the combined company has come to be dominated by Germans.

title: Carr, a Throw-In in Marbury Trade, Finds Niche on Nets
description: It has become a ritual after Nets practice: Chris Carr pops jump shot after jump shot off a running dribble while the assistant coach, Jim Lynam, stresses the importance of Carr's creating for himself in the half-court-oriented Eastern Conference.

title: Opponents Say Tower Will Spoil River Site
description: Tucked away in the northwest corner of the city is the largest piece of privately owned land in Philadelphia, more than 600 acres high above the Schuylkill River that were once Indian sites and farms. On one parcel, a scruffy plateau of reeds and underbrush, only gusting winds break the silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, EDWARD I.
description: FARLEY-Edward I. Of Locust Valley, Long Island, N.Y. on March 23, 1999, age 83. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Minton). Father of Jane F. Simonds, Edward I. Jr., Alexander T., Christopher M. Peterkin. Brother of Philip W., Elise F. Higgins and the late John C. Grandfather of William, Alexander, Caroline, Maggie, Edward III, Lyles, Lacey, and Alexander. Memorial Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Friday, March 26th at 2:30PM. Donations to Waldoboro Library, Waldoboro, ME, 04572.

title: THE CHEF; In Salmon, Smoky Meets Sharp and Sweet
description: OFTEN, the most successful meals evoke a childhood memory. This dish was inspired by a long-ago trip to a ballpark, where I had a smoky grilled hot dog that was slathered with sharp mustard and topped with crunchy, slightly sweet relish. When I became a chef, I decided to create a dish with the same trio of flavors: smoky, sharp and sweet.

title: 'Bad Writing' Has No Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: VLSI ASKS TO TALK TO PHILIPS, THE REJECTED SUITOR
description: VLSI Technology Inc., a semiconductor maker based in San Jose, Calif., wants to talk further with Royal Philips Electronics N.V., even though it rejected a hostile $777 million takeover bid by Philips last week. In a letter sent late Monday to Philips, the Dutch consumer electronics giant, VLSI asked that Philips's investment bankers and lawyers call on its own representatives to discuss a possible takeover. On March 5, Philips offered $17 a share for VLSI. In its response last Thursday, VLSI termed the price ''inadequate'' and said its board had determined that VLSI should explore alternatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTNER, FANNIE (KITTY)
description: KITTNER-Fannie (Kitty). March 21. Survived by nieces, Ruth Wauters, Alice Bratter, nephews, Charles Bratter, David Chalmers, cousin, Pauline Pritzker, and the Weisman family.

title: Biggest Financial Groups In Norway Plan Merger
description: Norway's state-owned Postbanken agreed yesterday to be purchased by Den Norske Bank A.S. for 4.5 billion Norwegian kroner, or $579.9 million, in stock and cash. The merger joins Norske Bank, Norway's largest financial services group, with the nation's leading retail bank. With assets of $41 billion, the combined group will control 21 percent of Norway's retail banking market and 15 percent of the corporate market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUERTAS, THOMAS C.
description: HUERTAS-Thomas C. March 20, 1999, of Somers, NY. Former archivist for the United Nations. Survived by five children, two sisters, and nine grandchildren. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, NY, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: With the population explosion at the cheese counter these days, a guide that fits into a pocketbook could come in handy. ''The Cheese Companion'' (Running Press, $24.95), Judy Ridgway's slim guide, is filled with tempting color photographs and evocative descriptions of about 50 varieties. Commonplace cheeses, like Edam, alternate with esoteric examples, including Spanish tetilla, a mild cow's-milk cheese in a distinctive, pointy pyramid shape; picodon, a nutty-tasting French goat's-milk cheese, and Cornish yarg, a nettle-wrapped cow's-milk cheese made from an old recipe (its name is that of the cheese maker spelled backward). Suggestions of appropriate wines for cheeses are also given, as is an overview of cheese-making and history.

title: Kosovo and the Echoes of Isolationism
description: The conflict in Kosovo has exposed a multiple-personality disorder among Republicans. The party's Presidential candidates and its leaders in Congress insist they want more robust American leadership in the world, invoking the internationalist legacy of Ronald Reagan. But in the current crisis, candidates and legislators alike have flirted with another Republican tradition, the isolationism of William Borah, Robert Taft and Patrick Buchanan.

title: Appeals Court Upholds End to Jail Oversight
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a lower court decision to end outside oversight of New York City's jails.

title: $25 Million for Music School
description: The University of Southern California announced today that its music school had received a $25 million gift from the philanthropist Flora L. Thornton.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PANETTA, AMEDEO
description: PANETTA-Amedeo. July 31, 1918March 24, 1994. Dear Amedeo, time goes by, we miss you more and more. Di and Laur

title: McDougal Testifies In Her Own Defense And in President's
description: Susan H. McDougal, whose steadfast refusal to answer prosecutors' questions about President Clinton put her in jail for 18 months, crisply and directly answered those very same questions today in a Federal court, testifying that she had no knowledge of any wrongdoing by Mr. Clinton.

title: Cal Cruises and Clemson Wins in Struggle
description: For California, without a player who had played in a post-season game before this season, the National Invitation Tournament presented a precious opportunity, one the Golden Bears used to reach the semifinals at Madison Square Garden last night. But for the opening 20 minutes of their game against Oregon, Michael Gill mostly just watched and wondered if this moment had passed him by.

title: Muscles on the Half Shell on the Menu?
description: Shunned by landlords on newly scrubbed 42d Street, the World Wrestling Federation may have finally found a home in the middle of Times Square for a theme restaurant with the company's own bizarre blend of athletics and theatrics.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa rebounded from a five-year low as processors took advantage of low prices to secure supplies for making chocolate. In New York, cocoa for May delivery rose $11, to $1,187 a metric ton.

title: Can Things Get Worse For Isles? It's a Cinch
description: The Islanders are hopelessly out of the playoff race for a fifth consecutive season, the co-owner wants to buy the Washington Redskins, the president hasn't been seen inside Nassau Coliseum in months and General Manager Mike Milbury has been slashing the payroll for the last two weeks. Could the situation for this franchise be any more worse?

title: California Utility Buying 16 Illinois Plants
description: Edison International, California's second-biggest utility, agreed today to buy 16 power plants in Illinois from the Unicom Corporation for $4.8 billion in cash to expand into the Midwest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SHIRLEY
description: SCHWARTZ-Shirley. The bravest, most beautiful person. Adored by daughter Elizabeth Dellureficio, beloved by her sister Phyllis Fisher and cherished by her granddaughter Nika. Services Thursday 12:45PM at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOM, HENRY
description: TOM-Henry. Died on March 22, 1999. Veteran of W.W. II, received a Purple Heart. Served in African and Italian invasions. Graduated from Long Island University. Dear brother of Ann Fong, Jane, Alfred, Arthur, Elizabeth Yee and Jack Yee and the late Gertrude Chin and Helen Seetoo, as well as many nieces and nephews. ''Ginny'' (Hank) will be missed by all who loved him. Friends may call on Friday, March 26, from 3-8PM at Chinese Cheung Sang Funeral Home, 22 Mulberry Street, New York, New York.

title: Anti-Missile System: Same Old Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: The Cuisine of Santa Fe

title: Anti-Missile System: Same Old Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Managed Care Squeezes Research Funds and Charity Health Aid, Studies Find
description: In the wake of the managed care revolution, health policy analysts have long suspected that financial pressures would threaten care for the poor and prevent academic health centers from financing their own biomedical research. Now, two new studies provide the first evidence that those suspicions are correct.

title: TEMPTATION
description: FANCIFULLY stylized marzipan blossoms in pretty-as-spring pastel colors cover the cakes for Easter by Black Hound bakery. Though to some these cakes may resemble old-fashioned bathing caps more than Easter bonnets, they nevertheless are a pleasant change of pace from cakes adorned with commonplace sprays of vivid buttercream flowers. But what true cake lover will quibble with a piece of cake in one hand and a fork in the other?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Friday about Robert Matza misidentified the investment firm that hired him to run its record-keeping business. It is Neuberger Berman, not Neuberger & Berman L.L.C.

title: Notebook; Brooklyn Poly's Angels
description: Polytechnic University in Brooklyn is having a very good year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a Connecticut legislator who revealed that he is gay misidentified the legislator. He is Representative Patrick J. Flaherty, a Democrat who represents Coventry, not Representative Brian G. Flaherty, a Republican who represents Watertown.

title: About New York; 2d Thoughts After a Brush With the Law
description: MICHAEL MAZZARIELLO says it's hard work to live in New Lots, the Brooklyn neighborhood where he was born and where he has his home and law office.

title: Striking Out At the Serbs
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Divisive Steel-Quota Debate Moves To the Senate
description: Facing a wave of protectionist sentiment, two top trade officials argued today that a House measure to impose quotas on steel imports would hurt the American economy, lead to raw material shortages and rising prices and could set off a trade war.

title: Metro Business; Prada Store to Take SoHo Museum Space
description: SoHo is about to get its third Prada shop. Prada, the Italian retailer, has just signed a 15-year lease for 24,500 square feet at 575 Broadway, on the northwest corner of Prince Street and Broadway. For six and a half years the space had been used as the visitors' entrance and bookshop of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum's SoHo branch.

title: People
description: * Claudio Pella, executive vice president for Latin America at Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of True North Communications, was named to the new post of president for the Latin American region.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Two Goaltenders, Two Goals and 1 Point
description: Every time there is a confrontation between the Devils and the Sabres, Martin Brodeur and Dominik Hasek are the focus of attention.

title: Sports of The Times; A Double For Duke?
description: The way it was for Seth Creger, a senior majoring in public policy at Duke University, was typical of the cool, sophisticated, blase approach common to the undergraduates at this august temple of higher learning. ''We're beating Tennessee! We're beating Tennessee!'' he shrieked as he watched the game on television Monday night in his campus apartment. ''I can't believe it!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RUTH
description: EPSTEIN-Ruth. Devoted wife of the late Edwin. Beloved mother of Louis Epstein & Nancy Saminsky. Dear mother-in-law of Marilyn and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Robert, David, Heath, Steven, Jackie & Jessica. Services today 1PM at Wellwood cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, MILTON S.
description: GOULD-Milton S. Age 89, born in Manhattan, October 8, 1909, died March 22, 1999. Husband of the late Eleanor. Father of Patricia Booth, Judson and Jonathan. Grandfather of Eliza, Alexander, Olivia, Eleanor and Oliver. Brother of Hinda Rosenthal and the late Walter. Memorial service to be announced. A great judge once said to Milton, ''Mr. Gould, you have not wasted one moment of this court's time.'' Contributions in his memory may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 823 UN Plaza, New York, NY 10017, or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th St., New York, NY 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSMAN, FLORENCE
description: GLICKSMAN-Florence. On March 22, 1999, beloved wife of Jerome, devoted mother of Mitchell and Charles (Chuck). Dear sister of Edna Schonwetter, and Sam Morgenstern. Services on Wednesday, at 12 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: 'Bad Writing' Has No Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Leadership Void Hobbles CUNY as It Faces Severe Problems
description: Two years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki gave the trustees of the chronically troubled City University of New York a new chairwoman with a mandate to steer the university in a new direction. Less than five months later, the trustees got the chance to shape their own management team when they forced the resignation of Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT'S DANISH UNIT MAKES OFFER TO MERGE
description: WM Miljoe Service A.S., a Danish subsidiary of Waste Management Inc., said yesterday that it had offered to buy the traded B shares of Marius Pedersen A.S. in a move to merge the two environmental service companies. The offer is for 180 kroner a share, or a total of 484 million kroner ($71 million). The company's A shares, which have more voting power, are owned by the Entreprenoer Marius Pedersens Fond foundation, which is backing the offer. USA Waste Services assumed the Waste Management name last year when it bought the company for $24.9 billion in stock and assumed debt.

title: Lee revives an old pal, and sprinkles in some quirks, in an effort to entice the young.
description: WHEN the Lee Company was looking for a new way to appeal to young consumers, it simply dusted off an old icon.

title: A Nike Raise in Indonesia
description: Nike Inc. said today that it would increase the monthly wages it pays entry-level workers in Indonesia, a move that coincides with an increase in that country's minimum wage. Nike said it would increase wages to 265,000 rupiah, or $31.44, a month, from 250,000 rupiah, or $29.66. The higher wages are part of a new monthly package for workers including bonuses, housing, health care, transportation and meal allowances. The new wage package is effective on April 1. Indonesia's minimum wage is expected to increase to 231,000 rupiah, or $27.41, a month.

title: After the Oscars, The Complaints
description: ABC and the Academy Awards broadcast took a pounding from critics after Sunday's show, the main targets being its extreme length and Whoopi Goldberg's performance as host.

title: Britain's Truckers Feel New Pressures
description: When European nations hang out their shingles to attract foreign investors, Britain's appeal runs something like this: come to Britain for low labor costs, low taxes, low overhead.

title: Safir Flew to Oscar Ceremony in Revlon's Jet
description: A trip to the Academy Awards ceremony that Police Commissioner Howard Safir and his wife took last weekend was paid for by a cosmetics company executive, spokesmen for the company and the Police Department said last night.

title: Classrooms for Sale
description: The recent news that McGraw-Hill Inc. had published an elementary-school math textbook full of brand names shocked some parents, but it didn't shock anyone who has been keeping a close eye on American education. The math book -- with its references to Nike, Gatorade and Sony Play Stations -- is hardly the most egregious example of commercialism infiltrating schools.

title: Glitzing Up The West Side
description: SWINGING his coat off his shoulders, the man by the door knocks the young woman behind him off her feet. ''I'm so sorry,'' he apologizes, ''there is just no room.'' Turning to help her up, he finds himself staring down at a little girl who is crawling through the legs of the crowd to reach the exit. A waiter looks despairingly at the impenetrable mass of people, hoists his heavily laden tray above his head and gingerly picks his way to the tables by the window. ''I hope you don't drop that,'' says one woman he passes. ''This is a new suit.'' She turns to the harried hostess and wails, ''Can you tell me when we'll be seated?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELIX, LORNA RENEE SILVERMAN
description: FELIX-Lorna Renee Silverman.. Today is your 75th birthday. Thinking of you. Love, Steve, Jay, Gregg, Manney and Claudette

title: Where Strawberries Thrive Till Summer Comes; Fresh Berries With a Flourish for Dessert
description: UNLESS strawberries are perfect, they may need a little help to be called dessert. All but one of these treatments take 15 minutes or less, using hulled berries.

title: Kiwi Bankruptcy Sets Stage for Link With Pan Am
description: Kiwi International Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, stipulating that it had a commitment from Pan American Airlines Inc. of $3 million in new financing to pay off Kiwi's debts.

title: Tom Waits's Night on Earth
description: ''I must sound like George Burns!'' Tom Waits commented midway through his performance on Saturday night as part of the South by Southwest festival at the Paramount Theater here. He could have been talking about his gravelly, nicotine-stained voice or the steady stream of jokes he kept making between songs. It was Mr. Waits's first concert in nine years (not counting benefit performances), and by the end of the two-hour, 19-song show, it was hard not to wonder why he doesn't perform more often.

title: Jesse Jackson Will Skip 2000 Race, Advisers Say
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson will announce on Wednesday that he does not intend to run a third time for the Democratic Presidential nomination, advisers close to him said today.

title: Japan Intercepts Two Boats That May Be North Korean
description: Japanese patrol boats, warships and aircraft intercepted two suspicious boats with false markings on Tuesday and later fired warning shots in an attempt to force them to stop.

title: Strawberry Is Contrite After a Show of Anger
description: Darryl Strawberry has played in just 5 of the Yankees' 22 exhibition games, but he is prompting more meetings, more conference calls, more discussion than anyone in camp.

title: Tough Times: Rock's Incubator Turns Down the Heat
description: In the past at the South by Southwest convention, for years the rock business's most important cavalcade of performances and panel discussions, talent scouts came looking for tomorrow's rock stars. Acts like Fastball, Lisa Loeb, the Presidents of the United States of America, Cake and even Hanson set deals in motion here. But something was different this year.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Officials Warn Of Danger of Steel Quotas

title: Three Trooper Unions Disavow Racial Profiling
description: Amid accusations that the state police stop drivers based on their race, three unions representing troopers have issued a statement disavowing the practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMETRIOU, ATHOS
description: DEMETRIOU-Athos. On March 20th at St. Vincent's Hospital, died after a long and valiant struggle. He will be sorely missed by family, companions, friends and former colleagues, here, in England and in Cyprus, his homeland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVARESE, CATHERINE N.
description: SAVARESE-Catherine N. On March 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis B. Devoted mother of Catherine S. Johnston, Margaret R. Savarese and Louis V. Also survived by seven loving grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45 AM, at Resurrection Ascension Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Shouting for Mussels and Beer in the East Village
description: AT Belgo Nieuw York, an unusual new restaurant in the East Village, Belgium has been thoroughly transformed from country to concept. The smooth, arced ceiling of the cavernous two-level dining room is intended to suggest the barrel vaulting of a medieval cellar, and waiters and waitresses are tricked out in monks' robes, outfits inspired perhaps by the outstanding beers and ales produced in Belgian abbeys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLES, ROY E. JR.
description: TILLES-Roy E. Jr., 82, of Rye, New York, passed away March 22, 1999, after a short illness. Devoted and beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Roy E. III, of Rye, NY, and Thomas N., of Bethel, CT, and daughters-in-law, Barbara and Cynthia. Loving grandfather of Amy, Scott, Bradley, and Kerrie. Survived by his sister Carol T. Shore, of Palm Beach, FL. Born May 18, 1916, in St. Louis, MO, and raised in New Rochelle, NY. Graduated from The Peddie School in Heightstown, NJ, in 1933, and Amherst College in 1937. Attended Harvard Business School, where he was an Assistant Coach for The Harvard College Freshman Football Team. Following service in The United States Navy as a Lieutenant J.G. (1943-1946), he embarked on a business career with Gotham Hosiery. This was followed by a long and successful career as a respected stockbroker with Merrill Lynch in New York City and until recently with Tucker Anthony in Stamford, CT. Avid golfer and member for over 60 years of The Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, NY. 25 year member of The New York State Seniors and The Westchester Seniors Golf Association. Friends may call Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY. Funeral services and interment private. Memorial contributions may be made to Amherst College, Amherst, MA 01002.

title: Man Charged in Murder Linked to Separatist Cult
description: A man who pleaded guilty to four murders linked to a black separatist cult in Florida has been named the second defendant in a 1984 killing in Newark that has been linked to the same cult, officials said yesterday.

title: Inhibitions of a Gay Man In Pursuit of a Paragon
description: The most striking messages in Jean-Claude van Itallie's ''War, Sex and Dreams'' are that being gay isn't easy and that in the experience of the playwright through almost 50 years, love and sex are frequently separated. With good humor but evident exasperation, he says the energy he pours into adoration often leaves him intimidated by the thought of profaning the paragon he worships. That is not the only inhibition revealed in this often amusing and often sad confession of a man in his 60's whose heart is lonely and who teases one into wondering what, despite his remarkable candor, he is leaving out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLALLY, DR. JOSEPH PATRICK MICHAEL
description: MULLALLY-Dr. Joseph Patrick Michael. On March 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Agnes (nee Galligan). Devoted father of Mary Ann Rose, Joan Scales, Noreen McGuire, Kathleen Mullally and Virginia Hallinan. Dearest brother of Sr. Marie Annunciata of the Sisters of St. Joseph of Brentwood. Loving grandfather of ten grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. He was born in Kilross, County Tipperary, Ireland on March 17, 1913. He received his Doctorate in Philosophy from Columbia University in 1944. As a lover of all things Irish, he taught at the University of Notre Dame from 1944 to 1950. He then taught at Queens College until his retirement in the late 1970's. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9PM and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9PM at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10AM. St. Mary's R.C. Church, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: They're Like, You Know . . . Seinfeld
description: The ''Seinfeld'' DNA is unmistakable and the title entirely off-putting, but those are misleading first impressions of ''It's Like, You Know . . .,'' a witty, charming, acerbic comedy in which a cynical New Yorker parachutes into the midst of a group of Los Angeles friends. Experiencing severe culture shock, he is stunned by the models, the road rules, the pretty masseuse who moonlights as a subpoena server.

title: Giuliani Softens His Tone But Still Defends the Police
description: While protesters chanted outside Police Headquarters a few hundred yards away, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered a measured defense yesterday of his administration's response to the Amadou Diallo shooting, praising the overall efforts of the Police Department but avoiding the caustic tone he has often turned on his critics.

title: Judge Says He May Extend Deadline for New Jersey HIP Policyholders
description: The judge overseeing the liquidation of the HIP Health Plans of New Jersey said today that nearly 25 percent of the bankrupt plan's members had yet to find new coverage and that as a result he would consider ''a limited extension'' of the enrollment period.

title: Stocks Plunge Over Concern On Earnings
description: A broad selloff sent stock prices sharply lower yesterday as worries about high valuations and anxiety about corporate profits led investors to pare their holdings. Chances that the United States might soon be involved in air strikes over Kosovo only added to the anxiety.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Sprucing Up Brings Turnaround for Office Tower
description: It is no easy thing for an office building with 3.6 million square feet of space to turn a corner.

title: Azerbaijan Detains Russian MIG Shipment
description: Azerbaijan has detained a Russian transport plane that was ferrying arms to Yugoslavia in violation of an international embargo, a senior Azerbaijani official said today.

title: ARTS ABROAD
description: Jacques and Natasha Gelman were art collectors in the most beneficent sense of the word. ''Jacques liked to say that he was not the owner, merely the link that carried the art from the studio to the museum,'' recalled Pierre Schneider, a French curator and longtime friend of the couple. ''But they were always discussing where the paintings should end up. Their greatest anxiety was to keep the collection intact. They considered it a work of art in its own right.''

title: Jazz Festival to Open With Swing
description: The 27th annual JVC Jazz Festival on June 14 to 27 will present some of the leading names in jazz, rhythm-and-blues and Latin music, with performers appearing in 36 places around New York. The festival will open with a series of concerts at the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse featuring mostly swing-era shows, including ''Revisiting the Kingdom of Swing,'' produced by the clarinetist Ken Peplowski.

title: 'Bad Writing' Has No Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITCHARD, DR. WILBUR L.
description: PRITCHARD-Dr. Wilbur L. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Wilbur L. Pritchard, a distinguished alumnus of the School of Engineering, Class of 1943. Dr. Pritchard, a pioneer in satellite engineering and an early advocate of satellite broadcasting, was the president of W.L. Pritchard & Co., Inc., a consulting engineering firm doing technical and economic studies in telecommunications for private firms and governments. Dr. Pritchard was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree from CCNY in 1993. He was a firm friend of his Alma Mater and a strong supporter of public higher education. On behalf of the City College community I wish to extend my deepest sympathy to his family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: 10 Years After the Big Spill
description: With the Administration's backing, a bill will be introduced in Congress today to give permanent wilderness protection to one of America's great natural treasures, the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The timing could not be more apt. Today is also the 10th anniversary of the day the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound, spreading 11 million gallons of crude oil over 3,000 square miles and causing horrendous damage to one of the nation's most sensitive ecosystems. Placing 1.6 million acres of Alaskan wilderness permanently beyond the reach of the oil companies would provide a measure of expiation for a major calamity.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Gets Discover Card Work
description: Discover Financial Services said yesterday that it had awarded Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of Omnicom Group, the creative and media planning portions of the Discover Card account, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million. Those duties had been handled for 10 years by DDB Needham Chicago, part of the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom.

title: CITIGROUP TO BUY PITTSBURGH BANK'S CREDIT CARDS
description: Citigroup Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the credit card business of the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh at an undisclosed price. The business includes 800,000 accounts and $1.9 billion in loans. The deal, which is expected to close in the third quarter, will increase the number of Citigroup cards in circulation to 70 million in the United States and 96 million worldwide. As part of the deal, Citigroup's Citibank unit will market cards under the Mellon and Dreyfus mutual fund names. Mellon said in January that it would leave the credit card and mortgage businesses to focus on others with higher revenue and profit.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO EDGES UP. The dollar was little changed against major currencies, held back by a three-session slump in United States stock markets. In New York, the euro settled at $1.09110, up from $1.09080.

title: For the Well-Dressed Roast, A Coat That's Not Too Sweet
description: COOKING a roast with a sugary coating serves a dual purpose. The sweetness of something like apricot jam adds an element of flavor not often found in savory dishes, and the sugar encourages browning. It makes a dish, essentially of just two ingredients, that is almost no work and has great flavor -- but the result is often too sweet, at least for my taste.

title: A Study Finds Link Between Birth Defects And Solvents
description: Canadian scientists report today in a study that women who were exposed to organic solvents like phenol, xylene and acetone during pregnancy had a greatly increased chance of having a baby with a birth defect.

title: Nissan Is Set To Combine Parts Units
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that two parts-supplier subsidiaries would merge, furthering an effort by the troubled company to simplify its sprawling operations even while considering Renault S.A.'s offer to buy a 35 percent stake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDSTEIN, ESTHER G.
description: FELDSTEIN-Esther G. age 89. On March 21, 1999 at the Newton & Wellesley Alzheimer Center. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted and cherished mother of Martin and Helen. Dear mother-inlaw of Kate. Adoring grandmother of Margaret and Janet. Loving sister of Mary Rhodes and Hilda Sklar.

title: Heroin Use Is Unabated, Report Says
description: Heroin use in New York City remains high, with more young people trying heroin and more users now snorting the drug than injecting it, often under the misconception that snorting will not lead to addiction, according to a new report on drug trends released yesterday.

title: Though Suspected as China Spy, Scientist Got Sensitive Job at Lab
description: In spring 1997, Los Alamos National Laboratory chose a scientist who was already under investigation as a suspected spy for China to run a sensitive new nuclear weapons program, several senior Government officials say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OCEAN ENERGY INC., Houston, a petroleum exploration company that is merging with Seagull Energy Corp., agreed to sell United States oil and natural gas properties for more than $42 million, to be used to reduce debt.

title: Blues Clueless
description: The rumors sound like the Beatles hoax of the late 1960's, when word spread that Paul McCartney had died and that the proof was that he was barefoot on the ''Abbey Road'' album cover and that you could hear ''Paul is dead'' if you played the song ''Revolution No. 9'' backward.

title: It's Spring, and New Science Centers Are Abloom on Campuses
description: The last great science building boom on American campuses came in the late 1950's and early 60's, when the nation was desperate to catch up with the Soviet Union in the race into space. (Remember Sputnik?)

title: 'Bad Writing' Has No Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Countries Approve World Cutback of 3%
description: With remarkable speed and unity, OPEC clinched a far-reaching agreement with four independent oil-producing nations today to cut world output by 2.1 million barrels a day. The move, if carried out, would significantly reduce the supply of crude oil and drive up the price of gasoline and other fuel.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
description: When John T. Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems Inc., walks into his windowless, cubicle-like office here each morning, he sees a dinosaur on his desk that he is intent on driving to extinction.

title: Protesters Arrested At Home Depot Store
description: A group of environmentalists was arrested yesterday after hanging a 100-foot-wide banner outside a Home Depot store accusing the chain of selling wood from endangered rain forests.

title: Op-Art; Circumnavigation: The Balloon Community Responds
New Idea For Fish Echoes Seders Past
description: THE menu for a Passover seder, the dinner that starts the eight-day observance of the holiday, is largely determined by ritual and tradition. Certain ceremonial foods, like matzohs, bitter herbs and wine, must be served. The rest of the meal is often dictated by family expectations, which can often seem just as immutable.

title: Business Travel; Slowly, the airlines' pocket timetables are becoming the victims of the electronic age.
description: THE airline pocket timetable is not yet a relic, but the handy guide is becoming harder to come by. American Airlines no longer publishes one. American, a unit of AMR, said the information -- flight numbers, departure and arrival times, stops and connections -- was widely available on the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about software robots misspelled the given name of the Czech dramatist who wrote the play ''R.U.R.'' and misstated the year in which it was first produced. The playwright was Karel Capek, not Karl, and the production was in 1921, not 1917.

title: PAXSON IN $70 MILLION DEALS TO BUY TV STATION AND SELL 3
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation, a broadcaster of family-oriented programming, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a television station in Pittsburgh and sell three others in the Midwest as it concentrates on bigger markets. Paxson, which is based in West Palm Beach, Fla., said it had agreed to buy the Pittsburgh station from the closely held Cornerstone Television Inc. for more than $30 million. Paxson said the closely held Acme Television Inc. had agreed to buy Paxson stations serving Dayton, Ohio; Green Bay, Wis., and Champaign and Decatur, Ill., for $40 million. Paxson said the deals would give it stations in each of the nation's 20 biggest media markets.

title: Milosevic-Holbrooke: Never a Smooth Mix
description: When Slobodan Milosevic and Richard C. Holbrooke first met in August 1995, an onlooker remarked of their prolonged and animated exchange, ''The two egos danced all night.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, ALBERT B.
description: RICHARDSON-Albert B. Of Chatham, MA, age 82, in Harwich, MA March 10, 1999. Husband of the late Joan (Thompson), father of Sarah Whitehouse, Peter, David, Michael, Mark Richardson, brother of Margaret Woolverton, also survived by nine grandchildren, one great grandchild, many nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be held in St. Christophers Church, Chatham, MA., Saturday March 27 at 11AM. Burial will be private. Donations may be made to St. Christophers Church Main St. Chatham, MA. 02633 or Cape Cod Hospital Foundation 4 Bayview St. Hyannis, MA. 02601. Nickerson Funeral Home Chatham MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKER, THERESA J. (TERRY)
description: STOCKER-Theresa J. (Terry). Age 75, of Port Washington, Long Island, on March 22, 1999. Adored wife of William M. Jr., Devoted mother of William M., III and Susan Page Sturman. Beloved grandmother of Sarah Helene Sturman. Also survived by a sister, Mimi Javello; a brother, Francis Zinghini; as well as many nieces and nephews. Mrs. Stocker was the President of New York State Federation of Music Clubs, a Past President and Life Member of the Port Singers and a past President of the Port Washington Music Study Club. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Saturday, 3 P.M., St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Port Washington. Interment, Monday, Locust Valley Cemetery. Memorial Contributions may be made to the Make a Wish Foundation, 382 Main Street, Port Washington, NY 11050 or to St. Stephen's Church Memorial Fund, 9 Carlton Avenue, Port Washington, New York 11050.

title: Smokers: Plain or Fancy?
description: PAULA KATZ, who lives on the Upper West Side, wanted to buy a stove-top smoker for her mother-in-law. She went to Zabar's, fully intending to make the purchase. But after one look she came home empty-handed. ''What is it?'' she said, ''A roasting pan, a rack and a lid?'' Her mother-in-law already had all that, she said, and besides, it would be just something else to be crammed into a closet.

title: BID IS RAISED TO $63.5 MILLION IN CALIFORNIA WATER FIGHT
description: California Water Service Group, the big publicly traded water utility, said that it had raised its offer for the Dominguez Services Corporation to about $63.5 million in stock and assumed debt to top a rival bid by the American States Water Company. The offer, of $33.75 a share, comes a week after American States, in San Dimas, Calif., made an unsolicited bid of $32.50 a share. California Water, based in San Jose, agreed in November to buy Dominguez for about $58.1 million to expand its water business and cut costs by consolidating two systems in the Los Angeles area. Dominguez is in Long Beach.

title: NATIONAL ORIGINS: Plant City, Florida; Where Strawberries Thrive Till Summer Comes
description: CONSIDER the strawberry.

title: Annan Asks Security Council For Inquiry on Rwanda Horrors
description: Five years after the worst massacre in recent African history, Secretary General Kofi Annan today proposed an independent inquiry into the United Nations role in the killing frenzy in Rwanda in 1994.

title: Taking the Ordinary and Finding the Beautiful; Paper Napkins Turn Into Flowers as a Career Unfolds in Accessible Art
description: Inspiration, like opportunity, often comes cloaked in strange guises. For Jim Hodges, a Brooklyn artist, it came in a life-changing way because a cashier at a Korean deli did what cashiers do hundreds of thousands of times every day in New York.

title: Man in Jersey City Accused of Murder
description: A Jersey City man was charged yesterday in the murder of a California woman whom he said he had met over the Internet, after he led investigators to her body, lying in the weeds in Liberty State Park, the police said.

title: Our Virtual Jeeves; Universal Intrusion
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO's Plan: A Barrage, Not a Pinprick
description: Initial NATO bombings of Serbia will be broader and more punishing than originally envisioned, going after 60 targets instead of delivering short, sharp strikes, European and American officials said tonight.

title: Rail Service Disrupted By Water Line Break
description: About 8,000 commuters were delayed up to an hour and a half yesterday morning when a 20-foot geyser from a water line break showered a train trestle on the Hoboken-Jersey City border, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, JEAN STEADMAN
description: BARR-Jean Steadman. On March 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David P. Barr, M.D. She is survived by her brother E. THomas Steadman, M.D. Services will be held at 3PM on March 29, at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave at 74 St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the David Barr Scholarship Fund, Weil Medical College of Cornell University, 1300 York Ave, Box 61, New York, NY 10021.

title: Rudder Flaw Cited in Boeing 737 Crashes
description: The Boeing 737 is vulnerable to extremely rare rudder malfunctions that come and go and leave no trace, but have caused two crashes and several other close calls, the staff of the National Transportation Safety Board said today. The staff said that the airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration and the Boeing Company had not learned what they should from those accidents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLER, RUTH
description: HILLER-Ruth. Passed away March 21, 1999. 97 years of age, died at Tietz Nursing Home. Beloved wife of the late Gary, dear aunt of Rita and Frank Shewer, Karin, Kenny, and their families as well as her beloved caretaker, Lillian Chavez. Funeral was private.

title: Manager Commits Hara-Kiri to Fight Corporate Restructuring
description: Moments before he slashed his stomach with a 14-inch fish-slicing knife today, a 58-year-old manager in a business suit was in heated talks over corporate restructuring with the president of one of the world's largest tire makers and said he would commit ritual suicide.

title: Europe Power-Plant Venture to Overtake G.E.
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the world's leading electrical-engineering company, and Alstom S.A. of France have agreed to combine their power-plant manufacturing units as recessions in Asia cut profits.

title: Profit Rose 26% Last Year for Audi
description: Volkswagen A.G.'s Audi unit said yesterday that its 1998 profit rose 26 percent and forecast that profit would be ''slightly below'' that level in 1999. Profit was 463 million marks, or $258 million; sales grew 22 percent, to 27.2 billion marks.

title: Saving Social Security: Comparing Three Plans
description: With more than three workers paying taxes today for every retiree, the Social Security system is running a surplus. But by the third decade of the next century, when most baby boomers will have retired, there will be only about two workers for every person drawing benefits. Without some change, Social Security will eventually be unable to pay all promised benefits.

title: Fighting Urban Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: Plot of New Sitcom: Adventures in Social Work
description: ''You can't take my dog,'' insists a man who had left his dachshund at the pound but has now changed his mind.

title: Forget Taiwan Missile Shield, China Warns
description: China's chief negotiator on Taiwan today strongly attacked a proposal under consideration in the United States to deploy a missile defense system, warning that if it was used to protect Taiwan, it would provoke an arms race.

title: INSIDE
description: Social Security: A Road Map

title: David Strickland, 29, Actor; Had Role in Television Sitcom
description: David Strickland, an actor who regularly appeared on the television comedy ''Suddenly Susan'' and had a supporting role in the recently released film ''Forces of Nature'' was found dead on Monday in a Las Vegas motel room. He was 29.

title: Frites, Frites And Frites
description: NEW YORKERS' interest in Belgian foods centers on three things: beer, mussels and fried potatoes. The beer, though, is ultimately too esoteric and expensive for most Americans, who may enjoy the wonderful variety of fruit-infused ales and Trappist brews as only an occasional splurge. Mussels have clearly gained favor, though the truth is that the Belgian preparation is not that different from what you might find in a French bistro. But fried potatoes! Here is a Belgian food that is relatively cheap, already adored by Americans, and yet distinctive.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: The Kitchen Goes On

title: For Ohio State Coach, A Familiar Roadblock
description: Ohio State Coach Jim O'Brien, clutching the net from the South Regional, had barely descended the ladder last Saturday night when a question about the Buckeyes' opponent in the Final Four brought a wistful grin to his face.

title: Bank of New York Adding Scottish Trust Bank
description: The Bank of New York Company agreed yesterday to buy the trust bank of the Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C. for an undisclosed sum, making the Bank of New York the world's largest custodian of investor assets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York City's decision to bar the Empire Transit Mix Company of Brooklyn from involvement in the renovation of City Hall Park referred incorrectly to the product that the company was supplying for the project. It was concrete, not cement (which is a component of concrete).

title: Treasuries Up As Investors Focus on Issue From AT&T
description: Prices of Government securities rose modestly yesterday as investors focused primarily on the AT&T Corporation's record-setting global bond offering priced earlier in the day.

title: Alsatians, a Match for Any Dish
description: ON a scale of 1 to 10, I would rate most wine dinners that showcase only white wines at about 4, ranking in excitement somewhere between arm wrestling and the novels of Judith Krantz. But that didn't prevent me from hustling over to La Caravelle in Manhattan recently to a dinner devoted to the wines, all of them white, of the Domaine Trimbach, one of the best-known producers in Alsace.

title: Our Virtual Jeeves
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Foe of Bunny Sculptures and Weasel Words
description: IT is exceedingly rare to hear public figures say what they really think about one another. Accusations of dishonesty become accusations of disingenuousness. Misdeeds become lapses in judgment.

title: Mellow Beer Emboldened By Hops
description: THE newest beer of Rogue Ales sounds more aggressive than it is. Brutal Bitter is actually a full-bodied, deeply flavored, intensely hoppy brew. There is nothing brutal about the rich, deep, mellow taste. It's crackling but not sharp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATAMIAN, INES LOCATELLI
description: ATAMIAN-Ines Locatelli. March 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Georges Atamian. Beloved mother of Christopher and Jean-Marie. Cherished grandmother of Narine and Stepan. Loving sister of Maxime Locatelli and the late Lena Locatelli. Service Saturday, March 27, 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: Johannesburg Journal; These Streets Belong to the Pre-Millennium Bug
description: Insect of the Year for the year 2000 may be the millennium bug. But here in the shady gardens (and sometimes the quiet bedrooms) of the northern suburbs, 1999 belongs to the real chitinous-skeletoned thing, the tiny scourge of Johannesburg known as the Parktown prawn.

title: Kevorkian Stumbles in His Self-Defense
description: Insisting upon acting as his own lawyer in his trial for first-degree murder, Dr. Jack Kevorkian stumbled conspicuously today through the first day of testimony, asking witnesses legally inappropriate questions and raising impermissible legal arguments as he tried to persuade a jury to acquit him for his role in ending the life of a seriously ill man.

title: Food Stamp Error Not Tied To Year 2000, Officials Say
description: A multimillion-dollar error in distributing food-stamp benefits throughout New Jersey was not rooted in reprogramming computers to fix a year 2000 flaw, as was first believed, but stemmed from an overburdened computer memory, state officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADAMI, NICK F.
description: BADAMI-Nick F. Of New City, New York. Died on March 23, 1999 at Westchester Medical Center. Mr. Badami was born in the Bronx June 27, 1930 to Bernard & Alfina Tornatore Badami. He was a Rockland resident for thirty-eight years, residing in West Nyack and New City. Mr. Badami was the President and CEO of Ritangela Construction Corp., Bardonia, NY for thirty-nine years. He was also president of the Association of General Contractors for New York State, Director of the Construction Industry Council, Past President of the N.Y.S. Asphalt Association and Paving Association, Director of the National Association of General Contractors, President and CEO of Maybrook Materials, Maybrook, NY, and was a member of the Board of Directors of Dominican College. He was the recipient of the Governors Award and also a recipient of the Bronze Star during the Korean War. He was a member of St. Anthony's Church, Nanuet, NY. Nick married Rita Cincotti at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, New York City, in 1954. He is survived by his wife Rita; daughters Angela Mancino, Carla Whittle and Patrice Flannery; brothers Richard and Ben; grandchildren Julia, Charlie, Gabriella and Nicholas. He was predeceased by his son Nicholas in 1991. Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday at 10 AM at St. Anthony's Church, Nanuet, NY. Burial to follow in St. Anthony's Cemetery. Visiting at Higgins Funeral Home, New City, on Wednesday from 7-9 PM and Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations to American Cancer Society, Rockland County Unit.

title: In Louisville, Now the Car Is a Stage (Phone Is Too)
description: In a scene with a strange sense of deja vu, two Federal agents corner a man in a SoHo warehouse and besiege him with questions and accusations while saying, unconvincingly, that he is free to leave at will. The man, an erudite editor at Random House, cynically passes off the interrogation as mere harassment until he realizes the earnestness of the agents' inquiry and the extent of their knowledge about him.

title: Man Stabbed In Building That Houses State Court
description: A 31-year-old man was stabbed yesterday in a restroom at the Bronx County Building, which houses the State Supreme Court, and his attacker eluded the authorities, the police said.

title: Judge Rejects Most of Law On Commuter Van Licenses
description: Backers of the private commuter vans, often called ''dollar vans,'' that serve poor and working-class neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens, won a legal victory last week. If it stands, the decision is certain to sharply increase the number of licensed vans in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKHAM, JANET G.
description: PECKHAM-Janet G. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Westchester Arts Council mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague Janet G. Peckham. Cherished friend and wise leader, she shared her talents cheerfully. Her quiet accomplishments during more than 10 years as a trustee leave an indelible mark on the Westchester Arts Council and the entire arts community. She will be profoundly missed. We extend condolences to her family and to those whose lives she touched. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Westchester Arts Council

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, WILLIAM B.
description: CAMERON-William B. On March 22, age 49 in Southampton, Long Island, of lung cancer. Loving son of Jane B. Cameron and devoted brother of Laurie C. Carson. Friends may call on Thursday, March 25, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at the J.M. O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton. A funeral service will be held on Friday, March 26 at 1 PM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Southampton. His battle against his disease was a source of inspiration to all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Society of Memorial SloanKettering at 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978-7048.

title: A Filly, Three Ring, To Enter Race
description: In a year in which the top 3-year-old fillies have looked as strong as the top 3-year-old colts there has been considerable speculation that one or more fillies would eventually be pointed toward the Kentucky Derby.

title: Youth Offers To Testify He Agreed to Sex With Man, 45
description: In a seemingly misguided effort to help a 45-year-old man accused of sodomizing him, Samuel Manzie, 17, has offered to testify that he willingly engaged in sex with the man, lawyers said today.

title: Officers in Diallo Shooting Won't Testify for Grand Jury
description: All four police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo have decided not to testify before the Bronx grand jury investigating the case, their lawyers said yesterday.

title: Queens Anger Prompts Board To Cancel Vote On New Schools
description: The New York City Board of Education has canceled a vote scheduled for today on an $11 billion, five-year school construction proposal after angry complaints from Queens officials that the plan would leave the borough with cramped classroom space for tens of thousands of students.

title: Tainted Game Trophy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREID, MAX
description: FREID-Max. Born in Brooklyn in 1915, a C.P.A., lived in Concordia, Cranbury, NJ. He was a loving husband and caring father. He is survived by wife, Sally, daughter, Anne, and son, Harvey. Funeral services today, 11AM, at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, E. Brunswick, NJ. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.Donations can be made to Concordia Deborah Hospital

title: It's Scary at the Top: Vertigo as Restaurant Trend
description: YOU have just had a long meal at Tabla -- three courses and plenty of wine. When it's time to leave, you are feeling fine.

title: Havas Plans a Merger For Its Media Services
description: Havas Advertising S.A. in Paris said yesterday that it would merge its media services agencies, which operate under names like SFM Media and Mediapolis, with Media Planning S.A. in Madrid and Barcelona, Spain. The merged agency, to operate under the Media Planning name, will have 1,200 employees at offices in Europe, Latin America and the United States, handling media accounts with combined billings estimated at $5 billion.

title: Social Security: Divergent Paths
description: When the Clinton Administration put shoring up Social Security at the top of the national agenda early last year, White House officials said the first order of business was to make it politically safe to have a frank debate about the options.

title: On Pro Basketball; Knicks Picked Wrong Season For a Remake
description: Never mind Patrick Ewing missing from the free-throw line, Allan Houston missing from the perimeter and Marcus Camby missing, well, everything. The main problem with the Knicks? It's a franchise that became so consumed with moving beyond its hard-nosed past and toward its young, athletic future, that it somehow forgot the present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELASHMET, G. BART, SR.
description: DELASHMET-G. Bart, Sr. Age 70, a retired newsprint executive from Southeast Paper Manufacturing Company and Abitibi-Price, died of cancer on Monday at Hospice Atlanta. A prisoner of war captured by the Chinese in Korea in 1950 and held until 1953, he retired from the U.S. Army as a Captain in 1954. He was awarded the Bronze Star, Purple Heart, American Defense Medal, Army of Occupation Medal, the Korean Campaign Medal with ten battle stars, Combat Infantryman's Badge, POW Medal, and the Presidential Unit Citation of both Korea and the United States. He was later inducted into the ROTC Hall of Fame at his Alma Mater, the University of Mississippi. Survivors include: His wife, Lois Ross DeLashmet; sons, Dr. G. Bart DeLashmet of Jackson, MS and W. Pemble DeLashmet of Mobile, AL; daughter, Kathrine Casey DeLashmet of Providence, RI; brother, Thomas L. DeLashmet, Jr. of Moss Point, MS; and six grandchildren. Visitation is Wednesday, March 24, 6:00 PM to 8:00 PM at H.M. Patterson and Sons Funeral Home, Spring Hill, Atlanta, GA. Services are Thursday, March 25, 2:00 PM at All Saints Episcopal Church, 634 West Peachtree Street, Atlanta. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: The G. Bart DeLashmet, Sr. Liberal Arts Scholarship Fund, The University of Mississippi Foundation, P.O. Box 249, University, MS 38677 or Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Drive, Atlanta, Georgia 30319.

title: Brooklyn Academy Plans Gala for Its Chief
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will pay tribute to its outgoing president and executive producer, Harvey Lichtenstein, with an evening of performances on June 3 by contemporary artists long associated with the organization. Mr. Lichtenstein, who has led the academy since 1967, will step down from his posts on June 30.

title: Notebook; Astronomers in the Vatican
description: The Meteoritical Society, a major international association devoted to what is out there and what is incoming, will hold its annual meeting in 2001 at Gregorian University in the Vatican. Astronomers, astrophysicists, geologists and planetary scientists will attend the September 2001 meeting.

title: ARCO to Test a Cleaner Diesel Fuel on the Road in California
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company says it has developed a cleaner diesel fuel for trucks and other large vehicles that will soon be tested on the road in California, the state that has led the nation in pushing oil companies to develop cleaner-burning fuels.

title: America Online Plans Layoffs Of Up to 1,000
description: In an effort to pare redundant operations resulting from its acquisition of the Netscape Communications Corporation, America Online Inc. today announced plans to lay off between 700 and 1,000 employees at the newly combined company.

title: British Bookseller Plans Internet Service
description: W. H. Smith Group P.L.C., Britain's largest book retailer, said yesterday that it would set up a free Internet access service through a venture with the Microsoft Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. Users will be able to buy books, music and videos. The move counters a free service begun by Dixons Group P.L.C. last September.

title: Mayor, Under Fire, Opens Door Wider To Black Officials
description: After an hourlong meeting with C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan Borough President, whom he had shunned for more than a year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that he would meet again with her and with other leading black officials at a time when the aftershocks of the Amadou Diallo shooting continue to rumble through the city.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about ''Nine Below Zero,'' a novel by Kevin Canty, misstated the title of a William Faulkner novel in comparing some passages in Mr. Canty's book to Faulkner's. The Faulkner novel is ''As I Lay Dying,'' not ''While I Lay Dying.''

title: Phone Can Boss Around Household Appliances
description: In an advance that will allow people to program their VCR's while also speeding down the freeway -- not that this is necessarily a good thing -- a German company has come up with a way to turn telephones into remote controls for household appliances.

title: Perches for the Armchair Gardener
description: IT'S not too soon to think about outfitting the garden or terrace. And this spring, with Martha Stewart's new garden collection for Kmart and Michael Graves's for Target, the incentives to refurnish are plentiful.

title: Frames Are Worth at Least 500 Words
description: A PICTURE frame, usually the final fillip, the last deft gesture, is many things to many people.

title: Clemson Is Ready For California
description: In the moments following Clemson's 79-76 victory over Xavier on Tuesday night in the semifinals of the National Invitational Tournament, while the players streamed into the locker room at Madison Square Garden and celebrated, Coach Larry Shyatt was stopped by one of his assistants.

title: International Sprint Venture Is Said to Be Near Collapse
description: The Global One telecommunications consortium of Sprint, France Telecom and Germany's Deutsche Telekom is close to collapse, and an agreement to dissolve the venture could come within six weeks, executives close to Global One said yesterday.

title: Danish Modern, A Loving Portrait
description: How has Danish design remained so dependably original over the last century? A new book, ''Danish Chairs'' (Chronicle Books, $29.95) by Noritsugu Oda, shows how the simplest things can bare the soul of a whole culture. The book's preface explains how Danish designers have worked to simplify life by building comfortable, useful, beautiful and affordable items.

title: At 3 giant agency companies, there are signs of the growing importance of interactive operations.
description: IN a sign of the growing importance of operations outside the realm of traditional advertising, three giant agency companies are expanding in interactive marketing and media services.

title: Parts Maker Is Sold
description: Johnstown America Industries, a maker of seats for heavy trucks, has agreed to buy Imperial Group Inc., a closely held maker of truck parts, for an undisclosed price. The purchase of Imperial Group, which is expected to have revenue this year of more than $100 million, gives Johnstown America, based in Chicago, new products like bumpers, fenders and fuel tanks for heavy trucks. Johnstown America, which also makes railroad freight cars, had revenue of $966.1 million last year, while Imperial Group, based in Portland, Tenn., had more than $80 million.

title: Queens Girl, 5, Killed by Her School Bus
description: A 5-year-old girl was struck and killed yesterday by a school bus that had just dropped her off in front of her Queens home, where her mother stood waiting for her, the police said.

title: In Yugoslavia, Economy Is Already Limp
description: With the Yugoslav economy already battered and trade limited since international economic sanctions were first imposed in 1992, air strikes by the United States and its NATO allies against Serbia are unlikely to cause great economic harm.

title: Women at M.I.T.: 'Slights' Count
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Music Companies Press for Prosecution
description: Three music companies asked the Norwegian police today to start a copyright prosecution of Fast Search and Transfer, which provides Lycos Inc. with a directory of MP3 audio files for its Internet search service, the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about the expeditions of the naturalist Harold Jefferson Coolidge misidentified the pair of animals hanging from Mr. Coolidge's arms. The animals were gibbons, not macaques.

title: An Islander Prospect Gets A Chance to Impress Coach
description: Positives are scarce around the Islanders these days. But if there is one good thing about being out of the playoff race, it is that minor league prospects will get some National Hockey League exposure, and a chance to impress the coach.

title: UNITED AMERICAN ENERGY PLANS TO BUY 2 POWER PROJECTS
description: The United American Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two electrical power projects for $181 million in separate transactions. United, a privately held owner and operator of independent power generating sites, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., did not identify the projects or their sellers. It said equity financing for the acquisitions was being provided by investment funds managed by Fox Paine & Company, a San Francisco-based investment firm. Fox Paine will pay $75 million for a 44 percent stake in United American. The Duke Energy Power Services unit of the Duke Energy Corporation has also agreed to increase its stake in United American to 25 percent by investing $25 million, United American said.

title: NEWS WATCH; Coupon Clippers Go on Line More and More, Report Says
description: The use of coupons delivered via the Web is starting to take off, according to a study by the NPD Group, a marketing research company based in Port Washington, N.Y.
