The survey, which was based on a questionnaire answered by 2,673 individuals who are on line, found that nearly a third of them get Web coupons for shopping in an average month.

title: U.S. Sues New York City Over Disposal of Freon Appliances
description: A lawsuit filed yesterday by the Federal Government seeks to impose heavy fines on New York City for disposing refrigerators and other appliances in ways that cause ozone-depleting refrigerants to be released into the atmosphere.

title: The Complete Hamilton: Fast Feet, Deep Thoughts
description: Edward Hamilton was a steel worker who knew how to handle a pool stick. His grandson Richard knew how to handle a basketball. Neither would talk about his gifts much, especially last summer when the two would sit together in front of the television wondering what the fall would bring.

title: Undoing Urban Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Dresdner Bank In Settlement
description: Dresdner Bank A.G. said today that it would pay a fine of 37 million marks, or $21 million, to settle a six-year investigation into tax evasion.

title: Sports of The Times; Strawberry Should Take Longer View
description: THE Yankees were so catatonic, they could barely muster enough energy to toss a ball. Rarely will you ever witness a more demoralized group of athletes, as well as a very ashen young general manager named Brian Cashman.

title: S.E.C. Investigating Trading-places.net
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into trading activity at a stock chat room called Trading-places.net, according to the owner of the site.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: E-Mail Pen Pal Sites Give Prisoners a Link to the World Outside
description: USING E-mail is not the easiest way to start a relationship. Just ask Diane, a psychotherapist from Colorado. In 1995, she began exchanging letters with a man whom she had met through a notice posted on a Web site. Through their correspondence, the pair fell in love and plan to marry next year. That is the earliest her fiance is expected to be released from prison.

title: Two Stole $140,000 From Woman, Police Say
description: A man and woman were arrested yesterday on charges of swindling an elderly Manhattan woman out of $140,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, HAVEN ROLLER.
description: BLOOM-Haven Roller. Suddenly on March 24th, 1999, beloved daughter of Barry and Frances Bloom, cherished granddaughter of Betty Roller, the late James J. Roller, the late Murray Bloom and the late Fay Bloom. Dear niece of Jessica Roller and Carol Bloom Furman. She was a Class 9 student at The Chapin School, New York City. Service Friday, March 26, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Chapin School.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a Government report that outlined risks and benefits of the medical use of marijuana misstated the location of the office of Unimed Pharmaceuticals Inc., the manufacturer of the drug Marinol, which delivers the active components of marijuana. The company is in Buffalo Grove, Ill., not Somerville, N.J.

title: Mayor Reserves Judgment on Safir Trip
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he expected Police Commissioner Howard Safir to keep his job, but that he would await the outcome of an ethics investigation into Mr. Safir's trip last weekend to the Academy Awards ceremony, as a guest of a Revlon executive, before passing judgment on it.

title: Corrections
description: A picture layout yesterday with an Artist at Work article about Jim Hodges merged two separate pictures taken at his studio in Brooklyn. The picture showing Mr. Hodges in front of a flowered wall ended at the dark bar on the right; the flowers to the right of that bar were part of a second picture of the studio wall.

title: Text-to-Speech Programs With Touchy-Feely Voices
description: LIKE everyone else these days, computers are getting in touch with their feelings. Or at least learning to fake it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUKOWSKI, ELEANOR P (DOEBELE).
description: BUKOWSKI-Eleanor P (Doebele). Of Pelham Manor, beloved wife of Richard L. Bukowski. Services to be held at Galloway and Crane Funeral Home, Basking Ridge, New Jersey, Saturday, March 27th at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: Booksellers Group Selects Bozell
description: The American Booksellers Association in Tarrytown, N.Y., an organization of independent book retailers, has named Bozell Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications, as the first agency to create a branding and integrated marketing program to help independent bookstores compete against big chains. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: On the Horizon: A Way to Write In Thin Air
description: British Telecommunications is developing a computerized pen that writes and acts as both an electronic organizer and a text-recording device.

title: For Serious Lincoln Scholars, Chances for New Discoveries
description: IT is reassuring to know, 190 years after Lincoln's birth in 1809, that in 2000 and beyond, new studies will continue to seek clues to the 16th President's life and language -- electronically. Even though the shelves hold more books about Lincoln than about any other President, modern technology will soon enable historians to scour his ideas and actions even more closely than in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYER, MORTON S., M.D.
description: BRYER-Morton S., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. A member of Mount Sinai's staff for over forty years, Dr. Bryer distinguished himself not only in the practice of medicine, but in service to his country. The recipient of both the Bronze and Silver Star, he was the Alumni's most highly decorated serviceman during W.W. II. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbash, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, Treasurer

title: Contest Essays Find Heroes Near Home
description: It used to anger Po Lin Ho that her mother had to sit hunched over a sewing machine 12 hours a day, 6 days a week, in a dimly lighted factory in Chinatown. As Po Lin, 16, a junior at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side, put it, the family had an easier time in Hong Kong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNON, LILLIAN MALLEY.
description: VERNON-Lillian Malley. Of Remsenburg, formerly of Hartford, CT, and New York City, on March 23, 1999. Survived by sister-in-law, Mrs. Paul Malley, nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Reposing Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, NY. Funeral services 11 A.M. Friday at Remsenburg Presbyterian Church, Remsenburg, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, EDWARD I.
description: FARLEY-Edward I. Of Locust Valley, Long Island, N.Y. on March 23, 1999, age 83. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Minton). Father of Jane F. Simonds, Edward I. Jr., Alexander T., Christopher M. Peterkin. Brother of Philip W., Elise F. Higgins and the late John C. Grandfather of William, Alexander, Caroline, Maggie, Edward III, Lyles, Lacey, and Alexander. Memorial Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Friday, March 26th at 2:30PM. Donations to Waldoboro Library, Waldoboro, ME, 04572.

title: In the Golf Bag: Gear to Mask Most Sins
description: AS golfers count the days until they can launch balls down lush green fairways, they start to look doubtfully at their equipment: Will that dinged-up putter really do this year? Has some new club come along to prompt the golfer to put last year's flashy titanium driver out to pasture? Is the next guy's ball giving him a huge advantage over everybody else?

title: In Abrupt Reversal, F.A.A. Grounds Kiwi Airlines
description: A day after Kiwi International Airlines thought it had won a reprieve from a Government-imposed death sentence, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday grounded the struggling carrier, saying that it was unsafe to fly.

title: Anti-Apartheid Cleric Sentenced to 6 Years for Embezzlement
description: A judge sentenced the former anti-apartheid activist Allan Boesak today to six years in prison for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars donated to help needy children and educate black voters.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE ON THE BOMBINGS
description: Clinton Explains Decision

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VIACOM INC., New York, the entertainment company, said it would repurchase as much as $500 million of its stock from time to time, effective immediately. The company also said that it would split its stock 2 for 1 on March 31 and that it had completed a $2 billion stock repurchase begun in August.

title: George Benson, 91, A College Founder And Nixon Official
description: George C. S. Benson, an author of books on American politics and government who in 1946 was the founding president of what is now Claremont McKenna College, died on Monday at the Pilgrim Place nursing home in Claremont, Calif. He was 91 and lived in Claremont.

title: COLLEGES: HOCKEY
description: MEN'S DIVISION I

title: After the Years of Mourning, a Time for Joy
description: All morning yesterday, Albanian men crowded into their Bronx clubhouse, chain-smoking and grimly focusing on CNN. When President Clinton appeared on television to announce that the NATO bombing of Serbia had begun, they were utterly silent, seemingly too tense to allow themselves to exhale.

title: Music of the Spheres, Squiggles and Snips
description: REMEMBER Silly Putty? An amorphous blob of industrial goo marketed to children, its chief virtue was flexibility, and its many uses were encyclopedically demonstrated in Saturday morning television commercials: You can stretch Silly Putty into any shape! It can be rolled into a ball and bounced! And if you flatten it over a comic book, the image transfers, turning the featureless, gray-beige lump into a temporary storage medium for colorful drawings. Would wonders never cease.

title: A Rare OPEC Blend of Oil and Politics
description: The key to raising the price of oil, OPEC has decided, is found more in politics than economics.

title: Rating of Doctors Now a Business Unto Itself
description: When Richard D. Topp was putting together his new guide to New York's ''most talked-about doctors,'' he approached women sunbathing in Central Park and asked them about their gynecologists -- who was great, who was imperious, who made patients wait and who made them comfortable.

title: Ameritech to Buy 20% Stake In Unit of Canadian Carrier
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the local phone company set to be acquired by SBC Communications Inc., said today that it would buy a 20 percent stake in Bell Canada for $5.1 billion (Canadian), or $3.4 billion (United States), to take advantage of deregulation.

title: WARBURG PINCUS LEADS A $424 MILLION OFFER FOR KNOLL
description: Knoll Inc., the office-furniture maker, received a bid of about $424 million yesterday from its management and Warburg Pincus Ventures L.P., the New York investment firm, to acquire the 40 percent of the company that Warburg does not already own. The bid, at $25 a share, represents a 61 percent premium to Knoll's closing price on Tuesday. After the company warned of weaker first-quarter sales, Kroll shares had fallen 62 percent as of Tuesday's closing, from a high of $40.625 a year ago. Yesterday, shares rose $9, to $24.25. Knoll said it was unlikely to dismiss any of its 4,400 employees.

title: Serena Williams Will Put Streak on Line Against Hingis
description: Unstoppable, unbeatable and, at least for now, unapologetic about treating her superiors in the pecking order like stepping stones toward her sudden success at 17, Serena Williams extended her tour-best unbeaten streak to 15 matches with a 6-4, 6-0 demolition of ninth-seeded Amanda Coetzer of South Africa tonight at the Lipton Championships.

title: Chase Manhattan Names a New Chief Executive
description: In an unexpected move that is likely to dampen merger speculation surrounding the nation's third-largest bank, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said that William B. Harrison Jr. would succeed Walter V. Shipley as chief executive on June 1.

title: INSIDE
description: 737 Rudder Action Advised

title: V.A. Hospital Is Told to Halt All Research
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs has for the first time suspended all research in one of its health care centers, saying the center has failed to meet ethical guidelines in human experiments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FANEUIL
description: ADAMS-Faneuil. The Officers and Trustees of Chess-In-TheSchools mourn the loss of our esteemed President. We will be forever grateful for his leadership in creating our program and bringing the organization to its present level. We extend our deepest condolences to his dear wife Emiko and daughters Rebecca and Susannah. A memorial service will be held at the United Nations Chapel, 1st Ave & 44th St on Thursday, April 1st at 12 noon. Lewis B. Cullman, Chairman

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: War Minus Pictures Puts Crimp In Reports
description: The first video images of the destruction done by NATO missiles didn't arrive until late afternoon, and they came prefaced with a warning that they were from Serbian State Television. American commentators on cable who picked up those scenes could not verify or identify the sites shown in the dramatic pictures of fiery buildings and rubble-strewn streets.

title: Daring Flights of Fancy From a Master's Notes
description: When Erick Hawkins died in 1994, he left behind his choreographic notes for two unproduced pieces, ''Why Does a Man Dance?'' and ''Last Love Duet.'' Lucia Dlugoszewski, the composer who is Hawkins's widow, has now brought them to the stage. They received their premieres on Tuesday night when the Erick Hawkins Dance Company opened a week's engagement as part of the 92d Street Y Harkness Dance Project at Playhouse 91.

title: Patient's Right to Sue
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Get Reality Check Courtesy of the Pistons
description: The Nets thought they had momentum. They had won two straight home games, routed a hot Toronto club and, in getting way ahead of themselves, begun thinking playoffs. But the Detroit Pistons -- a mediocre, slumping team that had lost its last four road games -- came into Continental Arena tonight and proved that nothing had changed for the Nets. Appearing unstoppable on offense and impenetrable on defense, Detroit drilled the Nets by 84-71 before a crowd of 16,896.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Drop of 5% Is Reported In Orders for Durable Goods
description: Factory orders for big-ticket goods posted the largest decline in more than seven years in February, a sign that an expected recovery in manufacturing could be a few months away, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Economic Scene; New York blazes a trail on how to handle local-phone access.
description: THIS is a story of triumph by a government regulator, a triumph so unusual that every side praises the agency -- the New York State Public Service Commission -- and points to its procedures as an enviable model for states nationwide.

title: Saner Debate on Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life-Saving Device For Avalanche Victims
description: The warm sunshine that comes with spring skiing means groomed trails and corn snow at many resorts. But for the increasing number of skiers and snowboarders who venture into the backcountry, spring also means avalanche danger.

title: Shea Is Cautious In Spring Practice
description: Coach Terry Shea's optimism through his first two lean years at Rutgers was difficult to believe. But as the Scarlet Knights heralded the arrival of spring practice yesterday at Rutgers Stadium, Shea's cautious yet upbeat forecast for next season carried the ring of truth.

title: Essay; Against Internal Aggression
description: Never will so many nations inflict so much destruction with so little relish.

title: Most Top Seeds Find Victory In Team Play at Tournament
description: Nearly all the top seeds survived in Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here on Tuesday at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. The only exception was the 10th-seeded team of Bart Bramley, Sidney Lazard, Howard Weinstein and Steve Garner, all of whom won bronze medals in the 1998 world championships and played here with Hugh Ross and Peter Nagy. They lost by 36 imps to Mitch Dunitz, Jill Meyers, Steve Beatty, Allan Falk, Dick Bruno and Jeff Schuett.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article yesterday about the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., referred ambiguously to one play. The sentence should have read, ''Naomi Iizuka's 'Aloha, Say the Pretty Girls' had the outward appearance but not the substance of a Robert Altman movie, tracking a group of tiresome young people who repeatedly cross paths on a journey that takes them from New York to Hawaii and Alaska.''

title: Contract to Apollo Metals
description: Apollo Metals P.L.C., Europe's largest aerospace metals supplier, said today that it had won a 10-year contract worth about $:500 million, or $813 million, to provide metal for British Aerospace P.L.C.'s military aircraft. Apollo, which is based in Birmingham, England, said the cost of buying metal stock to meet the 10-year contract would push 1999 earnings below last year's before earnings improve substantially in 2000. The agreement will be worth as much as $:50 million in annual sales when fully operational, Apollo said.

title: House Passes Disaster Bill Despite Threat Of a Veto
description: Against the backdrop of a veto threat by President Clinton, members of the House tonight approved a $1.3 billion emergency spending bill that included nearly $1 billion in relief to Central American countries ravaged by a hurricane and scaled back an array of Government programs to pay for the expenditures.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are Up Nearly 1% on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose nearly 1 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, said yesterday. The rise of 0.93 percent came after five consecutive months of declines in short-interest positions.

title: Knicks Blow Lead And Bow To Kings
description: The Knicks took another blow to their self-esteem and mental stability tonight. They took another crushing loss in a tight finish.

title: The Mets Give Up: Nomo Is Outrighted
description: Disappointed with the progress of Hideo Nomo, the once-celebrated Japanese right-hander, the Mets demoted him to Class AAA Norfolk today.

title: SHARES OF GEOSCIENCE PLUMMET AFTER BUYER PULLS OUT
description: Shares of the Geoscience Corporation, a maker of seismic systems used to find oil and gas, fell as much as 32 percent yesterday after Core Laboratories N.V. canceled a $214 million deal to buy it. The shares fell $1.5625, to $6.1250, after touching $5.25, a 52-week low. The stock has slid steadily since reaching a 52-week high of $16.75 on Jan. 19, the day Core agreed to buy the company for $17.90 a share. Shares of Core, which is based in Amsterdam, fell $1.625, to $23.1875, yesterday. The Houston-based Geoscience is 80 percent-owned by the Tech-Sym Corporation. Core, which analyzes underground oil reservoirs, said two weeks ago that it was reconsidering the purchase.

title: Roy Johnson, 93, Admiral in Tonkin Gulf Attacks, Dies
description: Roy Lee Johnson, the Navy admiral who oversaw what the Government said were defensive attacks against North Vietnamese torpedo boats in the Gulf of Tonkin in 1964, died on Saturday in Virginia Beach, Va. He was 93.

title: Safety Board Recommends Rudder Changes in 737's
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that changes should be made in thousands of Boeing 737's to assure that no more crashes occur because of a single mechanical failure in the plane's rudder control mechanism.

title: In 2001, I'll See You on the Phone
description: EXISTING mobile phones have not allowed users to make calls in the United States, Europe and Asia using the same phone. But the next generation of mobile networks will allow them to do so and will provide better services to boot.

title: Firm Pays Fund $1.6 Million After Investment Turns Sour
description: The investment firm headed by Ronald Baron has paid $1.6 million to Baron Asset Fund to compensate for unrealized losses on 650,000 shares of AMF Bowling Inc., which the fund bought in October from one of the firm's private clients.

title: Russian Anger at U.S. Tempered by Need for Cash
description: Stung by NATO's decision to carry out air strikes against Yugoslavia, Russia tonight suspended cooperation with the Western alliance and denounced the attack as an act of brazen aggression.

title: Back to Budget Root Canal
description: The new era of Federal surpluses was supposed to change the tired dynamics of budget battles in Washington. That was because there really is enough money to enact some tax cuts, some new spending and some help for Social Security and Medicare. For now, however, the Republican Congressional leadership appears to prefer radical tax and spending cuts to reasoned accommodation on the budget.

title: Treasures of the American Experience
description: The Library of Congress: Eyes of the Nation. ($39.95 for CD-ROM, Windows 95 and 98, Power Macintosh. DVD-ROM, $44.95.)

title: In the President's Words: 'We Act to Prevent a Wider War'
description: Following is a transcript of the speech by President Clinton last night on Kosovo, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Intruders Turn Tail, and Japan Thrills to Echoes of Its Own Roar
description: Japan called on North Korea today to seize and hand over two ships that set off a crisis on Tuesday in the Sea of Japan, and the Government here seemed to exult in its relatively firm response to the ships' infiltration.

title: Aide to Starr Tries to Refute Testimony By McDougal
description: A prosecutor for Kenneth W. Starr sought today to undermine Susan H. McDougal's testimony about President Clinton's knowledge of decades-old financial dealings in Arkansas, portraying her as someone who has never accepted the reality of her own criminal conviction and who tailors her accounts to fit the drama of the moment.

title: In Love With Technology, as Long as It's Dusty
description: IN 1863, nearly 15 years before Thomas Alva Edison created the first phonograph, an inventor named Leon Scott is said to have visited the White House. If historical anecdotes are accurate, he made a tracing of President Lincoln's voice with his newly invented ''phonautograph,'' a machine that scratched sound patterns onto a soot-blackened sheet of paper wrapped around a drum.

title: Ameritech Shifts Work to Ammirati
description: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that it had consolidated its general-market creative advertising assignments at the Chicago and New York offices of Ammirati Puris Lintas by awarding the agency those duties for its cellular telephone and paging businesses, which had been at Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., since January 1997. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS. Sugar prices eased to a 12 1/2-year low as oversupply worries outweighed signs of increased buying by importers taking advantage of low prices. May sugar contracts fell 0.13 cent in New York, to 5.47 cents a pound.

title: Trouble in Paradise: The Changing of the Guard
description: AS the Florida sun beats relentlessly on the perfect palms and spotless thoroughfares, the residents of this Mediterranean-style mecca are losing their cool over big houses.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Scaling the Draft Day Mountain; Oregon's Akili Smith (Who?) Has Become the Potential No. 1 Pick
description: Last December, National Football League scouts believed that Akili Smith of Oregon would be selected near the bottom of the second round, perhaps 60th, in the April 17 draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, HARRY K. JR.
description: TUCKER-Harry K. Jr. March 23, age 77, of Vero Beach, Florida. Husband of Sheila Bullock Tucker, father of Alice Tooke, Peter, Bryan and the late Harry III. Stepfather of Marian Payson, her companion Helen Wiley, Parker Payson and his wife Marian Macpherson. Brother of Thomas Tucker and June Jeter; survived by six grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, March 27, 11 AM, Trinity Episcopal Church, Vero Beach. Contributions may be made to Geffen Cancer Foundation, 981 37th Place, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYEROWITZ, ALBERT
description: MEYEROWITZ-Albert. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Ellen Greenberg and Laurie Kopp. Loving father-in-law of Stephen and the late Bruce. Dear brother of Joseph. Cherished grandfather of Emily and Brett, Abigale, Glen and Alexis. Services today 1:30pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Microsoft Offers Settlement Script, in Rough Draft
description: The Microsoft Corporation made an opening step toward trying to settle its antitrust battle with the Government in a four-page proposal sent to the Justice Department on Monday, lawyers close to the case said yesterday.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE IS IN $64 MILLION DEAL FOR INTERLINK
description: Sterling Software Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Interlink Computer Sciences Inc. for about $64 million in cash. The Dallas-based Sterling will pay $7 a share for all outstanding Interlink shares. Interlink shares jumped 84.38 cents, to $6.5938, on news of the deal. Interlink, based in Fremont, Calif., had 1998 profits of $7.4 million on sales of $29 million. Sterling Software is one of the 20 largest independent software companies in the world. It had a 1998 net income of $76 million on revenues of $720 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, BEVERLY
description: HAAS-Beverly. On March 23, 1999. Beloved and devoted wife of Henry. Loving mother of Rosalyn and Laurence, Lawrence and Marjorie, Nancy and Rick, and Jeffrey and Elyse. Adoring grandmother of Jason, Michael, Lisa, Jake, Sarah, Jenny and Ethan. Cherished sister of Seymour Glasser. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Congregation Ohr Torah, 410 Hungry Harbor Road, North Woodmere, NY 11581.

title: Tests Doomed to Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Chasing Winter Blues With Pinks and Reds Of an Orchid Jungle
description: The World Financial Center is known for its suits, yachts, shops and palms, as well as for its Winter Garden, a public space with a staircase worthy of Florenz Ziegfeld. But until the center's arts and events program started housing the New York International Orchid Show there nine years ago, the place never seemed that lush.

title: Quill vs. Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: What Bombs Can't Do
description: The decision to begin the NATO air campaign against Yugoslavia was inevitable. The longstanding worry that allowing President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia a free hand was undermining NATO's credibility, combined with renewed revulsion at Serb atrocities and deepening anxiety over thousands of refugees, eventually stiffened the resolve of Western leaders.

title: Ex-Official Urges Beijing to End Tiananmen 'Cover-Up'
description: Two months before the 10th anniversary of the crackdown on student protesters in Tiananmen Square, a former top Chinese official has sent an impassioned letter to China's leaders urging them to end a decade-long ''cover-up'' and to renounce the order that sent soldiers to disperse the demonstrators, killing hundreds.

title: New Japan and Wako Will Merge Next Year
description: The New Japan Securities Company and the Wako Securities Company said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in April 2000 in a deal that would create Japan's fourth-largest securities company. The new company, which will keep the New Japan name, will have assets of 9.4 trillion yen ($80 billion), ranking it behind the Nomura Securities Company, the Daiwa Securities Company and the Nikko Securities Company in size.

title: Gem-Like Glow Put in Place By the Experts
description: When it comes to luxury tableware, certain standards reign. The silver must be glittery. The crystal crystalline. The porcelain impossibly light. And the prices weighty.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Screen: Not 'Death,' But Annoying
description: Q. What is a ''blue screen of death'' error?

title: The Big City; No One Wants To See Crime In a Tradeoff
description: WHEN the Rev. Al Sharpton leads a protest for racial justice, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake generally makes it a point not to be there. He has always told his predominantly black congregation in Queens to concentrate on building instead of demonstrating. But he is planning to make an exception at Police Headquarters today.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, WILLIAM B.
description: CAMERON-William B. On March 22, age 49 in Southampton, Long Island, of lung cancer. Loving son of Jane B. Cameron and devoted brother of Laurie C. Carson. Friends may call on Thursday, March 25, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at the J.M. O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton. A funeral service will be held on Friday, March 26 at 1 PM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Southampton. His battle against his disease was a source of inspiration to all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Society of Memorial SloanKettering at 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978-7048.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMITAI, HANNAH
description: AMITAI-Hannah. On March 23, 1999. Daughter of Edna and the late Edward McCann. Sister of Edward McCann and Susan Legg. Beloved niece of Edward and Barbara Capone. Treasured friend of many. Contributions to American Cancer Society. Services Thursday, 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Weeklong Bask in Asia's Beauty
description: Ming. Bohdissattva. Celadon. In the world of antiques, these Asian buzz words may someday be as common as Victoriana, Sun King and ormolu. This is Asia Week, when many of the city's museums, galleries and auction houses concentrate on works from East and Southeast Asia.

title: Quill vs. Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Pair Defend World Title
description: If the crowd in the Hartwell arena had been scoring the pairs competition at the world figure skating championships tonight, there is no doubt who would have had the highest marks: Shen Xue and Zhao Hongbo of China.

title: Sports of The Times; Palmer Has One Word For Torre: Patience
description: IN the Yankees' dugout last season, Joe Torre was talking about his daughter, Andrea Rae, then 2 1/2 years old, who earlier that day had been acting like, well, a 2 1/2-year-old.

title: Politically Correct Mergers; Europe's Deal Frenzy Tends to Stop at National Borders
description: It looks, some say, like a European replay of the 1980's on Wall Street: hostile takeovers, poison pills, white knights and an endless stream of high-priced investment bankers pitching new deals.

title: U.S. Kith and Kin Feel the Attack Themselves
description: William Rupich, a Serbian-American World War II veteran who earned a Bronze Star, fought back the tears today. The land of his forebears had been made the enemy.

title: Honor Compels Opposition to Rally Around Belgrade
description: Because he hates what Slobodan Milosevic has done to Serbia, Milanko Zablacanski, a prominent actor here, quit his well-paid job with state-controlled television three years ago.

title: Televised Defiance Lost Amid Sirens, Blasts and Fireballs
description: As NATO bombs and cruise missiles brought the Balkan wars he initiated to his doorstep tonight, the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, called on his people to defend their country ''by all possible means.''

title: G.O.P. Fund-Raisers Take a Lesson From Clinton
description: Even as Congressional Republicans work publicly to shed their image as the party of impeachment, party officials behind the scenes are using the trial of President Clinton as a fund-raising tool with conservatives to help Republicans keep control of the House of Representatives next year.

title: From Graham Dancer To Choreographic Icon
description: Choreography is not about talking, Bessie Schonberg says often in ''Bessie: A Portrait of Bessie Schonberg,'' a 1998 documentary by Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker that will be broadcast tonight at 10 on Channel 13.

title: Turkish Mayor's Jailing a Sign of Bolder Moves on Opposition
description: When the former Mayor of Istanbul enters jail on Friday to begin serving a sentence for subversion, he will be the most visible victim to date of an intensifying campaign against what military commanders and their civilian allies say is Islamic fundamentalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, FINI S.
description: KENT-FINI S. Age 91 of Great Neck. Died March 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Lester Kent. Devoted mother of Robert and Peter. Beloved grandmother of Adam, Jennifer, Steven, Lauren and Andrew. Memorial services at 4:30 PM on Friday, April 2, 1999 at The Unitarian Universalist Congregation at 48 Shelter Rock Road in Manhasset.

title: With a Song In Her Heart, A Woman Of the People
description: Lauryn Hill staked out her high-minded aspirations as she began her set on Tuesday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. From a darkened stage came Bob Marley's ''Redemption Song,'' about music's promise of freedom and consolation; then she sang ''His Eye Is on the Sparrow,'' about the certainty of faith. Reggae and gospel are touchstones for Ms. Hill, who's determined to pass on positive messages along with a groove. But she doesn't stop there. She also wants to update the sensuality and confessional intimacy of smooth 1970's soul and to harness the streetwise bluntness of hip-hop. For long stretches of her show at the Theater she managed to do it all.

title: Before Explosions, a Rush for Safety and Supplies
description: Two enormous flashes filled the sky shortly after 8 P.M. Seconds later came the sound of the explosions as the first NATO missiles struck somewhere south of the city, possibly the airport, or one of the military bases.

title: Campaigns Aimed At Readers and Voters
description: There have been two developments involving advertising and marketing efforts aimed at members of minority groups.

title: A Fresh Set Of U.S. Goals
description: For half a century, the United States and other countries have pursued political goals through air power, bombing their adversaries in an effort to persuade them -- force them, if possible -- to change their policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, SOL
description: SLOAN-Sol. The Officers and Members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the passing of Sol Sloan, founding member of our congregation. Husband of Anita, father of Barbara and Ronnie, grandfather of Craig Lapp, Mark Lapp M.D., Jodie Lapp and Mitchell Stern, brother of Vivian Zemel. We extend our deepest condolences to all who cherish his memory. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Daniel S. Reich, President

title: Monumental Mysteries
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: CARLYLE GROUP TO ACQUIRE HONSEL-WERKE FOR $66 MILLION
description: The Carlyle Group, a buyout fund based in Washington, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Honsel-Werke A.G., a German aluminum company, for about 60.4 million euros ($66 million), joining other United States buyout funds in acquiring European companies. Carlyle bought a 72 percent stake in Honsel from the controlling family and will offer 117.6 euros a share for the remaining Honsel shares. That is an 8.9 percent premium over Tuesday's prices. Honsel's shares, having fallen as low as 42.2 euros in 1996, are at about the same level as in 1994. Yesterday, the shares rose 9.8 euros, to 117.80 euros.

title: Pinochet Arrest Upheld, but Most Charges Are Discarded
description: The Law Lords ruled today that Gen. Augusto Pinochet must remain in England and face possible extradition to Spain, but they significantly narrowed the charges on which the case will turn.

title: Notes From the Land of the E-Less
description: MY dear Aunt Mildred, a 98-year-old Roman Catholic nun who lives in a convent, stopped me at a recent family gathering to broach the topic of the newfangled ways of modern society.

title: A Web Surfer's Guide to Ancient British Past
description: IN the beginning, when the glaciers had retreated and the land was young, when warrior kings and their priests had learned how to use awe and fear, and even before they had learned to use an alphabet, there was Stonehenge.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lawyer Is Solitary Killer's Reluctant Pen Pal
description: THE letters arrive every couple of days, written in loopy script on lined yellow paper, postmarked from the Federal penitentiary in Florence, Colo. ''How you doing, friend?'' one begins. ''Hi, Larry, man,'' says another. The rambling communications are signed, ''Always, Luis,'' and often include tortured artwork of old men in chains and clocks that long ago stopped ticking.

title: Defense Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Refusing to Testify About a Client
description: A defense lawyer who throughout her career has represented an array of radical and unpopular defendants pleaded guilty last night to an eight-year-old charge of refusing to testify about a client.

title: Former Top Aide Admits Altering Vote at District Council 37
description: A former top official in New York City's largest union of municipal workers yesterday became the first person to plead guilty to fixing a 1996 contract ratification vote and implicated three other union leaders in the fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIAMPI, GIOTTO
description: CIAMPI-Giotto. On March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Bennie Calder Ciampi, step-father of Bruce Calder of Dallas, Texas. For funeral information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500. Donations may be sent to Alimondo Ciampi Foundation, C/O Remo Ciampi Lucarelli in Chianti, Siena, Italy 53017.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: THE FINAL FOUR -- WOMEN; Players At Purdue As Focused As Coach
description: Off the court, the Purdue players and coaches had been guarded and almost bland whenever they spoke during the Midwest Regional last weekend.

title: Personal Weather Stations Evolve
description: LAST July when a vicious storm descended on the unnamed mountain peak that Michael Coyne was climbing in Alaska, he pulled out a palm-size gadget with a tiny fan protruding from the top. As the air currents starting spinning the fan, an L.C.D. display told him that the winds were gusting up to 72 miles per hour. The device then calculated that the wind chill was a numbing minus 21.1 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANOF, ABRAM
description: KANOF-Abram. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum mourn the loss of Dr. Abram Kanof, past Board President and longtime friend, colleague and supporter of The Museum. An acknowledged leader in the field of Jewish Cermonial Art, Dr. Kanof's collecting and patronage combined his love of Judaism and art. His enthusiasm, scholarship and vision influenced the creation of The Tobe Pascher Workshop devoted to the creation of contemporary cermonial art. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his entire family. Robert Hurst, Chairman Philip Laskawy, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: EL PASO ENERGY BUYS ENCAP INVESTMENTS FOR $52 MILLION
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation, one of the largest United States operators of natural gas pipelines, bought Encap Investments L.C. yesterday for $52 million in cash and stock, allowing El Paso to offer financing to oil and gas explorers. Both companies are based in Houston. Encap, founded in 1988, lends money to drilling companies and manages about $600 million invested by institutions. El Paso agreed this month to buy a rival, Sonat Inc., in a deal now valued at about $5.6 billion in stock and assumed debt.

title: With Words and Spirit, Conjuring Up the Dead
description: You never know what you will get with Shapiro and Smith Dance, the modern dance troupe headed by the husband-and-wife team of Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith. Or rather, you know what you will not get. At the opening of the company's run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night it was obvious again that pure movement and form for its own sake are never its concern. ''Shtick,'' a new solo for Mr. Shapiro, takes on the angst behind a comedian's grinning exterior, while ''Notes From a Seance,'' a mock Gothic romance, zeroes in on fake spiritualists.

title: CELANESE CANADA IN TALKS TO SELL ITS POLYESTER BUSINESS
description: Celanese Canada Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its polyester business for undisclosed terms to Kosa, a Houston-based group of companies, as the first step in a planned corporate revamping at Celanese. Celanese's polyester business contributed $245 million (Canadian), or $162 million (United States), to Celanese's $696.5 million (Canadian) in sales last year, the company said. Kosa is a venture between Koch Industries of Wichita, Kansas, and IMASAB S.A. of Mexico. The Montreal-based chemical and fiber maker also said it was discussing a number of strategic alternatives with its 56 percent majority shareholder, Hoechst A.G. of Germany, aimed at reshuffling its businesses and increasing share value.

title: Kremlinophilia to Kremlinophobia
description: A COVERT LIFE

title: Disney's Studio Chief Says Competitors May Quit Animation Business
description: Peter Schneider, president of Walt Disney Studios, said yesterday that he expected some movie studios that had recently entered the field of animation to leave it within the next few years because of rising costs.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Revlon shares jump on rumors of a possible takeover, and analysts give Unilever a wink.
description: SHARES of Revlon Inc. rose sharply for the second straight day yesterday on speculation that a buyer may soon step in to rescue the cosmetics giant from its huge debt and weak performance lately in the powder and perfume business.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES. The dollar slipped against the Japanese currency and the euro, unable to continue a move upward that began with the air attacks on Serbian forces. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.89 yen, down from 118 Tuesday.

title: Quill vs. Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: California Republican Tries Altering Campaign Finance
description: Ron K. Unz, the Silicon Valley millionaire who sponsored the ballot proposition that effectively ended bilingual education in California last year, is proposing a sweeping new measure that would overhaul the state's campaign finance and disclosure laws and take reapportionment out of the hands of the Legislature and turn it over to an independent commission.

title: Geek Elite: Gadgets They Use
description: The 800 people who are attending the PC Forum 99 conference here, an annual gathering of some of the world's technological elite, are the people who envision, finance and make the products and services used by the ''early adopters,'' people who buy new technologies for technology's sake.

title: In America; After the Protests
description: James Farmer told me a few years ago that the civil rights leaders of the 1950's and 1960's made a grave error when they failed to develop plans to build upon their stunning successes.

title: Bias Crimes Against Jews Increase by 16 Percent
description: The state chapter of the Anti-Defamation League said yesterday that bias crimes against Jews were up 16 percent in New Jersey last year, a much sharper increase than the 2 percent rise nationally. The number of reported bias incidents, from desecrated gravestones to beatings, rose to 229 incidents in 1998 from 197 the year before, said Shai Goldstein, the organization's regional director for New Jersey.

title: General Strike Across Israel Fails to Snarl Most Services
description: Israel shrugged off a general strike today as 400,000 unionized workers walked off state jobs but failed to halt most essential public services or to force the Government to accept their wage proposals.

title: Ledee Back on His Feet After a Big Afternoon
description: Starting jobs are not won or lost on a single day in spring training, but Ricky Ledee needed the big performance he generated today in the Yankees' 8-6 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: The Secretary General Offers Implicit Endorsement of Raids
description: With an important reservation, Secretary General Kofi Annan effectively endorsed the NATO air strikes against Serbia today, blaming Yugoslavia's persistent rejection of a political settlement for the resort to force.

title: A Cable Show Networks Truly Watch
description: ''The Sopranos'' is such a white-hot favorite in the television industry that network executives are trying to figure out how they can copy the breakthrough style of the HBO miniseries and perhaps make up for the mistake several of them made in passing up the show in the first place.

title: EMC SIGNS A $3 BILLION, 5-YEAR DEAL WITH I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation won a $3 billion parts order yesterday from a rival, the EMC Corporation, expanding a plan to profit from sales of its technology. EMC, a maker of computer storage systems for corporate networks, already buys disk drives from I.B.M. The new five-year agreement is likely to include custom computer chips as well as cross-licensing of storage technology. I.B.M. has been moving away from its slowing computer business. Last year, its personal computer business lost $992 million as it cut prices. The pretax loss widened from $161 million in 1997, according to I.B.M.'s annual report. Its shares rose $4.125 yesterday, to $169.50.

title: Collapsed Tank Dumps Corrosive Into River
description: A cleanup crew used vinegar to neutralize a chemical spill into the Hackensack River yesterday, after a storage tank collapsed on Tuesday, officials said.

title: Albany to Pass Bill to Benefit Prison Guards
description: The State Legislature plans to pass a bill giving 25,000 state correction and security officers the coveted and controversial right to retire with a tax-free disability pension of three-quarters pay if they suffer any kind of heart ailment.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Is Still Tops In Auto Insurance Rates
description: For the fifth straight year, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners has found that New Jersey had the highest auto insurance premiums in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the redevelopment of the Loews Kings Theater in Brooklyn by Magic Johnson Theaters referred imprecisely to the company's partner in the project. It is Loews Cineplex Entertainment, not the Sony Corporation. (Sony is the largest shareholder of Loews Cineplex Entertainment.)

title: French Banks Raise Merger Profit Estimate
description: Societe Generale S.A. and Paribas S.A., trying to avoid a takeover of both by Banque Nationale de Paris S.A., said their proposed merger would increase profit more than first estimated. The two banks said that by 2001 profit would rise 650 million euros ($711 million) because of their merger, up from an initial estimate of 500 million euros, which would bolster return on equity to 18 percent.

title: Flower Show, Lectures, Book Sale
description: Blooms on Broadway

title: Nassau Democratic Leader Is Expected to Step Down
description: Stephen J. Sabbeth, who was convicted of Federal bankruptcy fraud earlier this month, is preparing to step down as chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, officials here and in Albany said today.

title: Giuliani Signs Bill on Apartment-House Sprinklers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed a measure into law yesterday requiring sprinkler systems to be installed in most new residential buildings in the city.

title: Addicted to a Mob Family Potion
description: Everyone in therapy talks about mom, but Tony Soprano has a unique family problem. ''What do you think?'' he asks, outraged at his psychiatrist's suggestion. ''My mother tried to have me whacked 'cause I put her in a nursing home?'' Well, maybe. In ''The Sopranos,'' HBO's brilliantly nuanced series about a suburban New Jersey mob boss in emotional crisis, the psychiatrist is helping Tony cope with this breakthrough: in the Sopranos' world you truly can't trust your own mother.

title: Europeans Pick Italian To Head Commission
description: Leaders of the European Union today appointed Romano Prodi, a former Italian Prime Minister, to take over as president of the European Union Commission, the powerful Brussels-based executive body whose top officials resigned in a corruption scandal last week.

title: SYSTEMSOFT TO SELL ASSETS IN BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Systemsoft Corporation filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code yesterday and said that it would try to sell its technology assets to pay off creditors and shareholders. The software company, which is based in Natick, Mass., said it would operate with a reduced staff to fill existing contracts until all the assets were sold. Systemsoft, whose stock was delisted by Nasdaq on March 11, posted a loss for the nine months ended Oct. 31, 1998, of $27.2 million, or $1.02 a share, on revenue of $7.5 million.

title: Crime in Nassau County Declines Again
description: Nassau County's steadily dwindling crime rate plummeted by another 18 percent last year, officials said today, though they were unable to pin down precise reasons for the good news.

title: NATO OPENS BROAD BARRAGE AGAINST SERBS AS CLINTON DENOUNCES YUGOSLAV PRESIDENT
description: The forces of NATO opened an assault on Serbia with cruise missiles and bombs today as President Clinton denounced the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, for feeding the ''flames of ethnic and religious division'' in Kosovo and endangering neighboring countries.

title: Serbs Hold Foreign Reporters
description: Serbian military authorities have begun to to crack down on foreign journalists who were reporting news of the NATO air strikes from Yugoslavia.

title: Dow Fails to Join In as Nasdaq Rises From Tuesday Losses
description: Technology stocks caught fire in the last 90 minutes of trading yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a 1.83 percent gain, a recovery of more than half of what it lost in the broad market selloff Tuesday.

title: Board Rejects Expansion Of Roosevelt Field Mall
description: In a move to cap the growth of Roosevelt Field, one of the nation's oldest and biggest shopping malls, Hempstead Town officials yesterday rejected a proposed expansion that would have added a Saks Fifth Avenue and several other shops.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Growing Gooseberries

title: Tests Doomed to Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Georgia Setting Up Tough Anti-Sprawl Agency
description: In January, it seemed a radical proposal for a conservative state: a transportation superagency with broad powers to impose transit systems and highways on local governments, restrict development, and even put pressure on cities and counties to raise taxes. Many supporters predicted that Gov. Roy E. Barnes would have a hard time getting his plan through a skeptical Georgia Legislature.

title: An On-Line Delivery Service Wants to Be a 'Food Portal'
description: On Monday, Cybermeals.com, the site that let users order food for delivery from thousands of restaurants across the country, was reborn as Food.com. Robert Frank, the entrepreneur behind the original site, hopes that food lovers will have even less reason to leave the house.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: U.S. Official Says Politics Didn't Halt Mexico Case
description: A senior Customs official said today that a major inquiry into money laundering by Mexican banks was stopped only after undercover agents had been unable to proceed in talks with corrupt bankers to move more than $1 billion that was said to belong to the Mexican Defense Minister and other officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOSEPHINE P.
description: SMITH-Josephine P. The Board of Regents, Administration and Staff of Long Island College Hospital joins with the Board of Trustees of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in mourning the passing of Josephine P. Smith, beloved mother of our esteemed friend and highly respected colleague, the Reverend Dr. Paul Smith. To Reverend Smith, the entire Smith family, and all of Ms. Smith's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Continuum John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents, LICH Peter Kelly, Interim President, LICH Sandra Phillips, Ph.D., Chief Operating Officer, LICH

title: Hollywood's Shocked and Appalled by Miramax? Oh, Please!
description: There's still nothing quite as exhilarating as the spectacle of some of Hollywood's toughest wheeler-dealers, each of whom has an average income exceeding the G.N.P. of many countries, as they take umbrage at the shabby behavior of an upstart not yet in their club.

title: AT&T to Sell Language Interpretation Unit
description: The AT&T Corporation agreed on Tuesday to sell its over-the-phone language interpretation service to an affiliate of Providence Equity Partners Inc., a private investment firm.

title: Latest Israeli Candidate Has One Handicap
description: In the ever-shifting chess game of the Israeli election campaign, Azmi Bishara has put a new piece on the board.

title: COMDISCO PLANS TO QUIT MAINFRAME COMPUTER BUSINESS
description: Comdisco Inc., an asset management and equipment leasing company, said yesterday that it planned to sell its mainframe computer leasing and vendor leasing businesses to focus on its more profitable technology services operations. Comdisco, which had $3.24 billion in sales for the year ended Sept. 30, also said it had acquired the closely held Prism Communications Services Inc., a New York-based provider of high-speed communications services, for an undisclosed price. The company said it would take pretax charges related to the revamping of $150 million, or about 60 cents a share after taxes, in the fiscal second quarter ending March 31.

title: From Athens by Way of Las Vegas
description: Anna Vissi brought all the trappings of a No. 1 hit maker with her when she performed at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. She had the shimmery form-fitting dresses, the posse of dancers in black, the stick-twirling drummer and a music-video-ready set of shiny, dangling diagonals. She also had some torchy, big-build ballads about suffering for love, in the multinational mode of Celine Dion.

title: All the Luxury . . . Of Plastic and Tin
description: For those who want to downscale their luncheons (or upscale their picnics), there is good news. William-Wayne & Company sells trompe l'oeil plates that look like Sevres porcelain but are made of painted tin. Unbreakable and surprisingly lightweight, they are $7.50 each. William-Wayne & Company is at 850 Lexington Avenue, near 64th Street; (212) 288-9243.

title: Dr. Kevorkian's Client
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian is learning the hard way that a court of law is not always a congenial forum for airing a political or moral position. His blundering attempts to present his own case at his murder trial are looking more pathetic than crusading. The doctor is charged with deliberately killing a man by lethal injection in a macabre case where the key piece of evidence is his own videotape of the death, broadcast on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' last November.

title: Loan Delinquencies Rose in 4th Quarter
description: Delinquencies among credit card, home equity and auto loan borrowers rose slightly in the fourth quarter, yet the number remains well below record levels, the American Bankers Association reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEBSTER, JOHN BANCROFT.
description: WEBSTER-John Bancroft. September 22, 1916 - March 25, 1997. Forever in my heart. All my love, Sul

title: Why 'Shakespeare' Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilbur Pritchard, 75, Executive And Engineer of Satellite Systems
description: Wilbur Louis Pritchard, a telecommunications engineer who became the founding director of the Communications Satellite Corporation's Comsat research laboratories in 1967, died on March 18 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. Mr. Pritchard, who lived in Bethesda, was 75.

title: Riding to Rescue in the Last Scene: Saving Movies
description: WHILE we were waiting for a man to land on the moon in the 1960's, the nation's space program rewarded us with useful byproducts like Teflon and Tang. Today, while many Americans wait for the price of high-definition televisions to drop from the completely absurd to the merely ridiculous, they have already reaped largely unseen benefits from this new broadcast standard. Thanks to the technology involved in HDTV, many classic motion pictures that have been damaged over time may soon be restored to a nearly pristine state.

title: Wall St. Executive Considers Running for Senate From New Jersey
description: Jon S. Corzine, who is retiring as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has told friends that he is strongly considering running for the Senate from New Jersey next year and is preparing to meet with Democratic leaders and contributors to explore whether there would be support for his candidacy.

title: Cubans in Majors Opposing Orioles' Trip to Homeland
description: Major League Baseball's presence in Castro's Cuba could have become a regular event had world political and military events not intervened nearly a quarter of a century ago.

title: Howell T. Conant Sr., 83, Photographer
description: Howell T. Conant Sr., a photographer best known for his pictures of Princess Grace of Monaco, died on March 11 at his home in Carefree, Ariz. He was 83 and also had a home on Block Island, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MURRAY
description: BERGER-Murray. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father of Albert and Ralph and father-in-law of Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Beth and Brian. Fighter in the Jewish Resistance during W.W. II. Retired printer. Honored member, Jewish Communal Center and East Midwood Jewish Center. Services today, 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the East Midwood Jewish Center, 1625 Ocean Avenue, Bklyn, NY 11230 or the charity of your choice.

title: A Master With New Curves Up His Sleeve
description: The furniture designer Vladimir Kagan has seen curves come full circle -- from the 50's, when he pioneered radically swervy shapes, to the 90's, when youngsters have begun aping his oeuvre. Mr. Kagan's Bilbao sofa, introduced last fall by Preview Furniture at the High Point (N.C.) furniture fair and just reaching stores, looks daring, even a bit defiant. Choose guests carefully: they'll be on rigorous display.

title: Elizabeth Huckaby, 93, Official Who Helped Ease '57 Integration
description: Elizabeth Huckaby, who as a vice principal shepherded nine black students through the tumultuous integration of Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957, died on March 18 in Little Rock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, BETTINA
description: KESSLER-Bettina. On March 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving Kenneth Kessler. Devoted mother of Doctors Jeffrey and Jack Kessler. Cherished grandmother. Dearest sister of Toby and Clare. Memorial service will be announced.

title: Rangers Overtake Panthers; Trade Talk Engulfs Gretzky
description: As they say up the coast in Cape Canaveral, you can start the countdown: 10, 9, 8 . . . .

title: Methodist Pastor Faces Trial for Uniting 2 Men
description: For the second time in a year, a United Methodist Church minister will face an ecclesiastical trial on a charge that he violated a church law against ministers' officiating at same-sex unions.

title: Campaign-Finance Game
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Inaction in the face of brutality simply invites more brutality, but firmness can stop armies and save lives.''

title: CLOSE TO HOME; It's Guys Only in the Basement
description: THE ambiance might charitably be described as early 20th-century American dungeon: the cobwebbed walls are made of thick slabs of Manhattan schist set in brown mortar, which over the last century has shed enough sand and lime to form an inch-high berm at their base. A network of rusty pipes -- steam, gas, drain, sprinkler and water -- crisscrosses the floor and ceiling. The air is moist and pungent, redolent of No. 2 heating oil and steam-boiler exhaust, and it shimmers in rude blue fluorescent light. This is a basement, my basement, and I love it.

title: Top Players Ready For Top Challenge
description: The $5 million purse equals the largest on the PGA Tour. The field includes 49 of the top 50 players in the world ranking. And the course, the T.P.C. at Sawgrass in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., is among the tour's most challenging, featuring the famous island green at No. 17, where many hopes and many balls have plunged into the water.

title: Mobile Phone Group to Sell British Venture
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and the Mediaone Group want to sell One 2 One Ltd., a British mobile-phone venture worth an estimated $:8 billion ($13.1 billion), an investment banker advising on the sale said today.

title: Early Attacks Focus on Web Of Air Defense
description: Waves of NATO strikes today opened what officials said would be a protracted assault on the Yugoslav military, but one that would do little immediately to end the deadly crackdown in Kosovo.

title: Faneuil Adams Jr., 75, a Patron Of Chess for Inner-City Students
description: Faneuil Adams Jr., one of America's premier patrons and aficionados of chess and its top players, died Monday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Antidepressants Change Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Campaign Against Yugoslavia
description: With the start of NATO air and missile attacks on Yugoslavia yesterday, the long-running crisis over Kosovo has entered a new, uncertain and decidedly more dangerous phase. More broadly, the attacks mark an important watershed for the Atlantic alliance. While NATO planes attacked Serbian militias in Bosnia a few years ago, the alliance had never before unleashed its military power against a sovereign state.

title: NATO Assures 5 Neighbors That Fear Serbian Attack
description: NATO gave unusual written assurances today to five countries neighboring Serbia that the alliance would consider any military strikes against them by Belgrade ''unacceptable.''

title: In Chile, Opponents and Supporters View Ruling as a Victory
description: Both supporters of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and family members of the ''disappeared'' expressed mostly muted enthusiasm for the British legal ruling that upheld the detention of the former dictator while throwing out all but three of the 30 charges against him.

title: I.M.F. Expected to Offer More Aid to Indonesia
description: A senior official of the International Monetary Fund said here today that he expected the fund to approve more financial aid to Indonesia in a board meeting in Washington on Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Revlon Shares Soaring On Takeover Speculation

title: President's Reasons: Moral Revulsion and Weight of U.S. Interests
description: President Clinton said tonight that his decision to authorize military strikes against Serbia was derived from moral revulsion at the killing in Kosovo and a calculated assessment of American interests in the Balkans.

title: Keychain Pager Is Aimed At the Playground Crowd
description: It's bad enough that pagers and cellular phones ring during the opera. Now they might go off during nap time. Playmates Toys has just released a just-for-children pager that is called Friend.link. The $20 keychain toy can send E-mail-style messages via radio waves to other Friends.links within 25 feet. The messages are entered with a small data wheel and can be up to 48 characters long. Children can also enter personal information like their sex, age and hobbies. When that device comes within range of another unit programmed with similar interests, the pagers will ring, alerting the owners, much like last year's Japanese toy matchmaker, the Love Getty.

title: New Computer for Just $299? Well, Most of One, Anyway
description: Will computers join the likes of gum, batteries and magazines as impulse buys in the checkout aisle? That's not implausible, given the phenomenon loosely known as the Incredibly Falling Price of PC's. The latest sign of that trend is a $299 computer from a Seattle company called Microworkz Computer.

title: Just In Time For June Weddings
description: THINK of the Waring Blendor, which was introduced in 1937, with its sexy Art Deco silhouette and its two-speed motor, as the Platonic ideal. Blenders still perform much like the original Waring but have been endlessly restyled. From the 16-button models of the 60's -- back when buttons represented space-age convenience -- to the cordless models that came out a couple of years ago to the most up-to-date versions with soft illuminated keypads, the blender changes to mirror our passing technological obsessions.

title: Justices Question the Presence of News Crews at Police Searches and Arrests
description: Supreme Court Justices across the ideological spectrum were sharply critical today of police officers who allow reporters and photographers to accompany them as they search homes for evidence and suspects.

title: Zestful Variations on 'Goldberg'
description: It was some party. You half expected old Bach himself to show up. After all, Christopher Beach, the director of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York here, was summoning ghosts: that of Roger Norrington's ''Experience'' weekends on the campus a decade ago and the hoarier one of the Pepsico Summerfares directed here by his mentor, Christopher Hunt.

title: A Handwritten Bible With a New Perspective
description: In the early eighth century, the Benedictine monks of Wearmouth and Jarrow in Northumberland copied a monumental Bible, which they presented to the Pope in 716. In 1168, the Benedictines of San Vito in Pisa created another, paid for by 60 laborers whose meager donations were dutifully recorded. Yesterday at the New York Public Library, an order of Benedictine monks from Collegeville, Minn., unveiled the first page of what they call the only handwritten and illuminated Bible to be commissioned since the advent of the printing press 500 years ago.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Diamonds Are Forever

title: Tomorrow Is Another Deal
description: To recap the battle over the sequel to the sequel of ''Gone With the Wind'': when last visited in November, negotiations involving the best-selling novelist Pat Conroy, his agents, two book publishers and the executors who control the rights to the saga were concluding after nearly two and a half years of complexity and fury, the literary equivalent of Sherman's siege of Atlanta.

title: Expert on Biological Chemistry Is Picked to Lead Hughes Institute
description: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute has chosen as its next president Thomas R. Cech, an expert on the chemistry of biological systems.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Help for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, DANNY
description: KIRSCH-Danny, 75. Of New York City, died on March 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Susan Brink and Ken Kirsch, and grandfather of Becky and Sarah Brink, and Molly and David Kirsch. He will be deeply missed. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Protests in Police Killing of Diallo Grow Larger, and More Diverse
description: The last time Sidney Socolar, 75, a retired biophysics professor, got himself arrested was in the mid-1980's, when he sat outside Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's office to protest America's involvement in El Salvador's civil war.

title: Parable Set in a Reign of Terror
description: The serene visage of Chairman Mao stares out at the audience at the Manhattan Theater Club, and of course, the face on the outsize painting is deceiving. Obscured by the placid exterior is any hint of the dark side of the man who went to such paranoid lengths as to foment the Cultural Revolution, the ideological reign of terror that from 1966 to 1976 purged and punished many of China's leading artists and intellectuals.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: ALWAYS IN TOUCH -- A new program for the ICQ instant message system means users can run, but they cannot hide. The Signaler, from the Israeli company NECS, works by sending something like an electronic knock on the door to a designated computer's modem. Even if the recipient is not on line, a window will open on the screen, signaling that someone is trying to get in touch.

title: For an Artist in the Family
description: Paige Rense, the editor in chief of Architectural Digest, sent her husband, Kenneth Noland, an extraordinary valentine in February. His 1960 painting ''Fair'' is featured on her March cover, left. An editor's page disclosure was made at the suggestion of S. I. Newhouse Jr., Ms. Rense's employer.

title: Metro Business; Two Companies Ally For Office Projects
description: Two of New Jersey's largest real estate companies, one a publicly traded real estate investment trust and the other privately owned, have announced a joint venture to develop two office projects in the state.

title: When Clashing Political Ideas Really Stirred Passions
description: No doubt somewhere passions still rage over political ideas as distinguished from practical politics, but their celebration in a two-hour television documentary through the careers of four New York academics is not the usual stuff of prime time. Yet political ideas are what ''Arguing the World,'' being shown on PBS this week after a brief run in theaters last year, is all about. It can be seen at midnight tonight on Channel 13 and tomorrow night at 9 on other PBS stations.

title: State Senate Again Passes Ban on a Type Of Abortion
description: For the third time, the State Senate passed a bill today outlawing a form of abortion, continuing a national debate over the procedure, which opponents call partial-birth abortion.

title: Ericsson Stock Falls On Profit Warning
description: Shares of Ericsson A.B. slid as much as 7.1 percent yesterday after the company said its profit would fall in the first quarter on revamping costs and slowing sales growth. The company had warned in January that first-half profit would fall. The stock lost 14.5 kronor, to 175.5.

title: Special Courtrooms to Hear Suits Against New York City
description: With lawsuits against New York City clogging the civil courts, state officials said yesterday that they planned to establish special courtrooms just to handle cases filed against the city.

title: Women at M.I.T.: 'Slights' Count
description: To the Editor:

title: President Will Succeed Chief At Parent of United Airlines
description: Completing a suddenly meteoric rise after 32 years at United Airlines, James E. Goodwin was appointed chairman and chief executive yesterday of the UAL Corporation, United's parent. He will take over in July, succeeding Gerald Greenwald, who is retiring.

title: Eve Fowler
description: Julie Saul Gallery

title: Is NATO Right To Bomb Serbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Outgrowing the Salmon
description: To the Editor:

title: VW Predicts Slowing Of Sales in 1999
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that sales would rise less than 10 percent this year for the first time in five years as weak economies in Latin America and Asia limit gains. Sales have fallen ''significantly'' in Britain and Italy, although first-quarter sales rose worldwide by 7.1 percent, to 1.2 million cars, VW said.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The King and I

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINTON, JOAN MARIE
description: BRINTON-Joan Marie. Age 56. Born in Seattle, Wa. Died at her longtime home in Brooklyn. Loving mother of Adam, Anthony and Matthew. She was an original who will be missed by many. Devoted to family, friends and community. Her kindness, selflessness, knowledge and gentle nature touched our hearts. Her positive outlook, strength of spirit and determination continued to give us comfort in this difficult time. She will always be a part of us and we have been blessed by the joy she spread. Service to be announced.

title: SHARES OF DURAMED RISE 77% AFTER NEW DRUG IS APPROVED
description: Shares of Duramed Pharmaceuticals Inc. nearly doubled yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration said late Wednesday that it had approved the marketing of the company's Cenestin tablets for treating the symptoms of menopause. The shares closed at $12.375, up $5.375, or 77 percent. Cenestin, an estrogen synthetic, is expected to be the first major competitor for Premarin, the estrogen-replacement product made by the American Home Products Corporation of Madison, N.J. Duramed, which is based in Cincinnati, said it expected Cenestin, which will be available by prescription within three months, to bring in more than $100 million in annual sales.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Mayor Reaches Out
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has finally begun to reach out to African-American leaders concerned over his administration's handling of the Amadou Diallo killing. The Mayor met this week with Manhattan Borough President C. Virginia Fields, announced plans to talk with State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and expressed through his spokeswoman a desire to begin ''building bridges.'' This is something of a breakthrough for an administration that insisted for a long time that there were bridges aplenty, and only a lack of politically objective black leaders willing to march across them.

title: A Host of Alleluias to Celebrate the Easter Season
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) This selection, compiled by Paul Griffiths, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations; unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.

title: The Squad That Was Mod Is Reshod
description: When P. T. Barnum said, ''There's a sucker born every minute,'' he might have been anticipating the moviegoers who will pay as much as $9.50 to see the torturously boring ''The Mod Squad.''

title: Shortcomings of Art In the Realm of Tragedy
description: There are many sides to the art of Thomas Schutte, and two of the better ones can be seen in exhibitions at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea and at the Marian Goodman Gallery uptown, where Schutte, who is German, has shown his work since 1989.

title: February Pace of Home Resales Remained Near January Record
description: Home resales hovered close to a record level in February, topping an annual rate of five million sales for the third consecutive month as affordable mortgages and plentiful jobs stoked demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARON, WILLIAM
description: KARON-William. Cherished husband of Pearl; father of Laurie, Vicki, and David. Services will be held Friday, March 26, 1999, at Hillside Mortuary in Los Angeles.

title: First Turn This Spring For Strawberry in Left
description: Darryl Strawberry has probably caught hundreds of thousands of fly balls in his lifetime, from his days at Crenshaw High School in Los Angeles to his nights at Shea Stadium and Yankee Stadium.

title: Canary Wharf Offering Raises $:551 Million
description: Canary Wharf Group P.L.C., the property company, raised $:551 million ($904 million) yesterday in its initial share sale, at the high end of expectations, as demand soared for an office project that was once responsible for one of the world's biggest bankruptcies.

title: Loud Knocks In the Night, And Orders To Get Out
description: Within hours of secretly transmitting fluorescent green ''nightscope'' camera images of the first NATO air strikes on Kosovo on Wednesday night, Brent Sadler, a CNN correspondent, and his three crew members heard their hotel room door being broken down at 3 A.M. In came a man brandishing a rifle and a flashlight.

title: In Kosovo, War Is Peace
description: I also know that this may change the behavior of the Balkan people toward war. The inhabitants of southeastern Europe will have to face the fact that NATO has created a security umbrella over them and that the warfare of the last years -- indeed, of the past centuries throughout Europe -- will not be allowed to continue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, ELIZABETH A
description: PEARSON-Elizabeth A.. (Betty). On March 22, 1999 of Port Washington, New York. Beloved wife of the late Paul Sr. Mother of Paul, David, John, and Andrew. Grandmother of Jamie, Megan, Alison, Caitlin, and Elisabeth. Greatgrandmother of Tyler. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Saturday and Sunday 3-5 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, 9:30 A.M., St. Peter of Alcantara RC Church, Port Washington, with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care of Long Island.

title: Riders' Group, In a Report, Gives Buses Low Marks
description: Amid a huge increase in demand for public transportation, the buses in New York City Transit's overtaxed fleet are bunching up, slowing down and providing more erratic service, according to a report released yesterday by a transit advocacy group.

title: Russia Takes Protest to the U.N. Council
description: Russia introduced a Security Council resolution today demanding an immediate end to NATO's air strikes against Yugoslavia, denouncing them as a ''threat to international peace'' and a ''flagrant violation'' of both the United Nations Charter and Yugoslav sovereignty.

title: Metro Business; Successful Stock Offering
