description: OneMain.com Inc., an Internet service provider for rural and less populous markets, soared in its first day of trading after an initial public stock offering.

title: Is NATO Right To Bomb Serbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can't rub it out with an eraser and pretend it's some nation without culture, without reason, without civilization, that we are all savages, because of a Milosevic.''

title: Venus Williams Gains; And Yes, So Does Serena
description: It's not nice to jerk the defending champion of the Lipton Championships around the court like a wayward puppy on a leash, but that's precisely what Jana Novotna, the 30-year-old defending Wimbledon champion, did today to 18-year-old Venus Williams in the opening set of their titanic 2-hour-20-minute Lipton quarterfinal.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT SOARS. Wheat prices surged on speculation that the United States would clear the way for a $500 million sale of crops to Iran. In Chicago, wheat for May delivery rose 12.5 cents, to $2.8225 a bushel.

title: SHAW AGREES TO BUY TWO CABLE SYSTEMS IN NOVA SCOTIA
description: Shaw Communications Inc. of Calgary, Alberta, agreed yesterday to pay $167 million (Canadian), or $111 million (United States), for a 75 percent stake in Access Communications Inc. of Nova Scotia, and all of Access Television Bedford/Sackville Ltd., to expand in eastern Canada. Under terms of the transaction, Shaw would issue two million class B non-voting shares valued at $82.5 million (Canadian), pay $44.5 million (Canadian) in cash and assume $40 million (Canadian) in debt. Shaw is buying the cable systems from one of its directors, Charles V. Keating of Nova Scotia.

title: Solar Eclipse of the Heart: Love in a Suburb of the 50's
description: Much of ''Judy Berlin,'' Eric Mendelsohn's evocatively eerie meditation on modern suburbia, takes place during what may be the longest solar eclipse known to movies. That solar event in the middle of a sleepy late September afternoon draws the lonely, withdrawn inhabitants of a middle-class Long Island town out of their immaculate houses to wander through the deserted streets like zombies stirring to life after a long, silent sleep. As they encounter one another in an apocalyptic gloom, in which the street lights seem to cast a nuclear glow, they tentatively reach out to reconnect with one another in ways they haven't done in years.

title: Lack of Rules Cited in Death Of Schoolgirl; Bus That She Rode On Faced Less Regulation
description: A school bus that struck and killed a 5-year-old just moments after dropping her off in front of her Queens home on Wednesday is owned and operated by a private bus company that, like many others in the state, is not subject to the stringent safety regulations for public school bus services.

title: Suddenly, Women's Field Is Full of Intrigue
description: Tennessee is gone, its Final Four challenge having become a frantic quest to pawn $50,000 worth of hotel rooms and tickets to the Final Four games that the school and its boosters no longer need.

title: Turkish and Greek
description: Turkey and Greece have been at odds politically and historically, but the two cuisines make beautiful harmony. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: I.B.M. AND TELEFONICA OF SPAIN FORM A PARTNERSHIP
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Telefonica S.A. formed a multibillion-dollar partnership yesterday to sell more services to Spanish-speaking telecommunications customers. The companies will offer data transmission, video and other enhanced services in Spain and Latin America through the network of Telefonica, Spain's biggest phone company. I.B.M. will help develop the services and will also take over the operation of Telefonica's internal computer system for 10 years. Last year, Telefonica joined with MCI Worldcom Inc. to develop services in Latin America.

title: Mixing Algebra and Advertising; Free Texts at a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Gleaning Inspiration From a Student's Death
description: EMOTION comes easily to Michael Fabricant, a professor at the Hunter College Graduate School of Social Work. So he makes no effort to blink back tears when he speaks of Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old student with a radiant smile and a boundless future who was killed early this month just blocks from her home in Brooklyn.

title: Woman Is Arrested In Death of Grandfather
description: A 27-year-old woman was arrested yesterday and charged with the stabbing death of her grandfather, county prosecutors said.

title: Popular Drug For Diabetes Is Scrutinized
description: The market for oral diabetes drugs will soon become more competitive -- but just how competitive may depend in large part on what action regulators take on a popular diabetes pill that has been linked to 28 deaths and liver problems that resulted in seven transplants.

title: Milutinovic Gets Players' Attention
description: Coach Bora Milutinovic and his MetroStars endured questions great and small yesterday at the team's news media day. The MetroStars, coming off last Saturday's opening-day shootout victory over the Fusion in Miami, play host to the Columbus Crew tomorrow afternoon on the temporary natural grass field in Giants Stadium in their home opener.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHERIDAN HEALTHCARE Inc., Hollywood, Fla., a physician-practice management company, said that it had agreed to be taken private by an investor group led by Vestar Capital Partners, New York, and Sheridan Healthcare senior management for $9.25 a share, or about $75 million.

title: Mortgage Rates Decline
description: The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage declined to 6.98 percent from 7.01 percent last week, the lowest since 6.89 percent in the week ended Feb. 26, according to a weekly survey of mortgage rates from Freddie Mac. The report also showed that the average rate on an adjustable mortgage fell to 5.69 percent from 5.75 percent the previous week; 15-year mortgage rates declined to 6.61 percent from 6.64 percent.

title: Strauss Offers an Opportunity for Heroism
description: If you were conducting ''Ein Heldenleben'' and had before you an enormous orchestra, it might be hard to keep remembering that the hero of this ''hero's life'' is Richard Strauss, the composer, not you. It might be hard to disappear. Yet Jesus Lopez-Cobos managed just that, managed to keep himself quiet amid the great volume of sound he was getting from the Cincinnati Symphony during the remarkable performance he and his players gave at Carnegie Hall on Monday night.

title: Swallowed Up By an Exhibition
description: Most parents avoid taking their children to shows that are filled with blood and gore. So why expose them to entertainment that includes graphic views of internal organs, not to mention naked skin?

title: Nassau Jail to Provide Shelter for Visitors
description: Workers at the Nassau County jail are installing benches inside an old trailer that will be used to shelter relatives and friends of inmates while they wait for a seat in the jail's visiting room, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALINGER, JAMES J.
description: SALINGER-James J.. On March 25th, 1999. Devoted husband of Marie (Harris) Salinger. Beloved father of Peter and Jane Salinger. Cherished by friends and family. Contributions in lieu of flowers to The Alzheimer's Association, 7910 Woodmont Avenue, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORR, CHARLES D.
description: SHORR-Charles D.. Age 77. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Forbes). Brother of Dr. Joseph Shorr. Father of Stephen, Kenneth and Linette. Grandfather of Reuven, Ezra and Justin. Favorite father-in-law of Connie and Alisa. Passed away in the early hours of March 25, 1999. Services 12 Noon, Friday, March 26th, at Beth Israel Cemetery, Phoenix, AZ.

title: White House Pushing Deal With Beijing
description: In a series of closed-door negotiations and back-channel messages, the United States and China are racing to reach a broad accord in the next two weeks that could pave the way for Beijing to enter the World Trade Organization, even as the White House fears the effort could be torpedoed by Congress.

title: Residential Real Estate; Impending Tax Stirring Hamptons Home Sales
description: A 2 percent real estate transfer tax on expensive homes and vacant land set to take effect in the Hamptons on April 1 is creating something of a boomlet in an already booming local real estate market.

title: Foreign Affairs; While We Were Sleeping
description: Visiting Shanghai is always a useful reminder of how frozen perceptions of China are in America today, and how far reality has moved here. To listen to some of the talk in Congress, one would think that nothing has changed in China since Tiananmen Square. To talk to Chinese is to understand that a ''New Deal'' has been forged in the past decade between the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese people. It is a messy, cynical, pragmatic deal, but it is the central political reality of China today, and it explains why America is winning here, not losing.

title: Decades in the Making, John Corigliano's 'Dylan Thomas' Gets Its Premiere
description: After four decades as a composer of works that have become increasingly complex and stylistically wide-ranging, yet also increasingly popular for their lyricism and accessibility, John Corigliano thought he had figured out how to keep his workload from becoming overwhelming. Trim and young-looking at 61, Mr. Corigliano insists that he won't accept a commission until he has asked himself a few crucial questions.

title: China Mounts All-Out Verbal Assault on Air Raids
description: China pressed an all-out verbal assault on the NATO air strikes against Serbian forces today, issuing multiple demands that the attack be halted, while the flagship state newspaper called the operation a ''dangerous precedent of naked aggression.''

title: The NATO General Who Is Intimately Familiar With His Adversary
description: Wesley K. Clark, the four-star American general who as Supreme Allied Commander Europe is in charge of the powerful NATO air offensive against Serbia for its attacks against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, knows his adversary well.

title: Fight Over Fish Poaching Stirs Up Icy Southern Sea
description: MELBOURNE  Bitterly cold, terrifyingly remote and frequently lashed by gale force winds and mountainous waves, the Southern Ocean seems an unlikely Eldorado for poachers.

title: H. V. Graham, 82, Dies; Led Guard in Crises
description: Henry V. Graham, the National Guard general who told Gov. George C. Wallace to step aside and allow the first black students to enter a University of Alabama building in 1963, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Birmingham, Ala. He was 82.

title: When Welfare Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Offer to Settle Receives a Cool Reception

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: For Jane and Joe Public, Wariness and Ignorance
description: In Londonderry, N.H.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, NATHAN
description: SHAPIRO-Nathan. Of Teaneck, NJ, March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Ellen Shapiro, Dr. Mark Lipkovitz, Dr. Robyn Susser, Leslie Weiss and Harriet Zonderman. Loving grandfather of Chad Pilatsky, Heather Susser, Erin Hopp Weiss and Rachel Zonderman. Services Gutterman-Musicant, corner of Passaic and Park Sts., Hackensack, NJ today at 1:00 PM. Contributions to B'nai Brith A.D.L. or Hadassah would be appreciated.

title: South Bronx Incinerator Will Be Torn Down
description: A medical-waste incinerator in the South Bronx, temporarily closed in 1997 after community opposition, will be torn down, according to an agreement announced yesterday.

title: Mixing Algebra and Advertising; Three More R's
description: To the Editor:

title: Ebay to Pay $75 Million for Spots On Several America Online Sites
description: In one of the largest partnership deals in the short history of the World Wide Web, the on-line auction site Ebay announced today that it would pay $75 million for prominent placement on several services owned by America Online Inc.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Bill Condon successfully tackled a provocative subject when he adapted and directed ''Gods and Monsters,'' a fictionalized account of the last days of the filmmaker James Whale, creator of the Frankenstein movies. On Sunday Mr. Condon won an Academy Award for best adapted screenplay. But his first studio film, which he hopes to begin shooting later this year, may be even more provocative, especially for New Yorkers. He is undertaking the life story of Bess Myerson (above). The movie is tentatively called ''Queen of the Jews.''

title: Matching a Baroque Work to the Site and the Forces
description: Handel's 1739 oratorio ''Israel in Egypt'' was first performed in London in the well-appointed King's Theater, the site of the composer's earlier triumphs in Italian opera, which for a good 25 years the London public could not get enough of. There are certainly operatic trappings about the work, which loosely tells the story of the Israelites' plight in Egypt and the punishments that God rained upon the Egyptian oppressors to protect his chosen people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, RALPH, M.D.
description: GOLDIN-Ralph, M.D., On March 24, 1999. Professor of Radiology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Survived by son Jude and brothers Albert and Ned. Interment in Lima, Ohio. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Alzheimers Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: Control of Detroit Schools Is Transferred to Mayor and Governor
description: Michigan's House and Senate voted today to transfer control of Detroit's schools from the city's elected school board to the Mayor and the Governor, the latest in a series of efforts by state legislatures to improve test scores by taking authority away from school boards.

title: On My Mind; On Killing Serbs
description: For awhile, some days or weeks, many Americans will put aside their puzzlement about President Clinton's decision to go to war against Yugoslavia because of Kosovo. They will support the war because ''our troops are out there'' and because only a person whose soul has died can stand the pictures of refugees and bodies without wanting to stop the carnage.

title: At UConn, Obsession Rewarded; Trip to Basketball's Final Four Sends State Into Frenzy
description: Faced with dark-tinted windows on the charter bus packed with University of Connecticut basketball players, Steve Rowe stood on tiptoes, pried open a vent, then stuck his video camera in to catch some blurry players jostling in the aisles.

title: Accounts
description: Optiva Corp., Bellevue, Wash., to Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of Omnicom Group, to handle brand strategy, creative and media planning duties for the Sonicare toothbrush, which had been handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, majority-owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. CPM Media Management, Chicago, handles media buying.

title: During the Lunar Walk, a Giant Leap for a New York Housewife in the Catskills
description: ''A Walk on the Moon'' is as seductive as the handsome, itinerant hippie who turns its heroine's life upside down. In this nostalgic, beautifully acted tale of romance and responsibility, that heroine is a housewife who could not be at a more dangerous time and place for maintaining the status quo. As she has every summer, Pearl Kantrowitz (Diane Lane) totes her ironing board, dish drainer, children and mother-in-law to a Jewish holiday camp in the Catskills to vacation all summer while her husband Marty (Liev Schreiber) stays in New York City repairing television sets. It's a peaceful but dull existence, and that's the way it is supposed to stay.

title: One of Time's Strays, but Cool and Chic
description: Not every time traveler is a wide-eyed innocent (Michael J. Fox in ''Back to the Future,'' Kathleen Turner in ''Peggy Sue Got Married,'' Malcolm McDowell in ''Time After Time''), mouth agape at the wonders on every corner. Some, like Tucker Harding in ''The Sticky Fingers of Time,'' take the experience in stride.

title: Warhol 'Supper' For Openers
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim's SoHo branch, whose closing in January was rumored to be permanent, will reopen -- 7,000 square feet smaller -- on May 12. Most of the ground floor occupied by the museum at 575 Broadway, at the corner of Prince Street, will soon become a Prada store, the Italian retailer's third in SoHo.

title: As Record Indicates, This Club Can't Shoot
description: Among the Nets' problems in their 5-21 season is the team's awful shooting, which has mushroomed from a slump to a trend to a life style. Excuses about the short training period no longer apply. Every other team in the National Basketball Association has faced the same condition, and not one has a worse shooting percentage than New Jersey's 38 percent heading into tonight's game against Indiana at Continental Arena.

title: Birthday in a Shelter, With 'Fireworks'
description: Even after the air raid sirens wailed, Sara, nearly 5, refused to go down to the basement shelter until the ''Ninja Turtles'' program was over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROSS, CHARLES M.
description: MOROSS-Charles M.. of White Plains, NY, died on March 25, 1999 at the age of 77. Born on July 1, 1921 in NYC. Survived by his beloved wife Lila (Kravis) of 49 years. He is also survived by his daughter Barbara Moross and her husband, Renaud Da, and his loving grandchildren, Melissa, Jeremy and Frederic Da, and his beloved nieces Susanna, Sonya and Gladys. He was a theatrical payroll manager for Handley-Walker, Inc., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Pl., White Plains, NY 10601. For further information, please call the McMahon, Lyon and Harnett Funeral Home, 914-949-7777

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE /Film; But First There Was 'Heaven'
description: In 1978 Terrence Malick, who had once worked as a wheat harvester, made a rapturously beautiful film well remembered for its golden fields and sublime magic-hour light. But ''Days of Heaven,'' now opening for a two-week revival at the Film Forum, looks different today. Its thematic and stylistic resemblances to ''The Thin Red Line'' are striking, and hindsight casts much of it in a nostalgic glow. This film is nominally about a pastoral idyll in an all-too-fragile paradise, but now it brings to mind another kind of heaven: the era when films this eccentric, daring and original were not unexpected, and not the flukes they would be today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Jack Tarver, the former publisher of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution, misstated their publishing schedules. The Constitution is the morning paper and The Journal is the evening paper; they are published as one on weekends.

title: Congress Passes G.O.P.'s Budget, Voting Largely Along Party Lines
description: Congress passed the Republican budget tonight, driving toward a big tax cut and a showdown with the Clinton Administration over the nation's priorities in an emerging era of fiscal plenty.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When you walk into the new Amaranth, it is hard to believe that it was once Arcadia. ''Was the room this small?'' you find yourself wondering. ''Was it this crowded?'' You might also want to ask if it was this noisy, but there's no point: you probably wouldn't hear the answer.

title: As Brazil Devalued, Some Got Rich
description: While many Brazilians are fretting over the effects of currency devaluation, Roberto Ruhman is celebrating.

title: Out of Breath, but Not Choices
description: Franka Potente, above, sets a furiously kinetic pace in the title role of Tom Tykwer's ''Run Lola Run,'' which tonight opens the New Directors/New Films series sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. The young German director fuses lightning-fast visual tricks and interactive storytelling into the best-case scenario for a cinematic video game. His vigor and pizazz offset the essentially empty nature of the exercise.

title: All Life, All the Time, No Matter How Loony
description: In his good-humored, deceptively easygoing satire ''EdTV,'' Ron Howard holds up a fun-house mirror to a world ruled by voyeurism and specious fame. It's a world where a simple ''He's cute!'' can lead to overnight stardom and where a book can be written by someone who has never read one. It's a world where tabloids and television truly snoop to conquer, and where the distinction between nobody's business and everybody's business is unclear. And it's all too well-trod territory. Mr. Howard can't really say much about it that's new.

title: Indictment Was Possible, Clinton Grand Juror Says
description: The grand jury forewoman in the Monica Lewinsky scandal said tonight that she would have indicted President Clinton on a perjury charge if she had been asked to.

title: Police Headquarters Rallies Won't End, Protesters Vow
description: As the Bronx grand jury considering last month's police shooting of Amadou Diallo finished its work yesterday, 219 people protesting the incident were arrested on disorderly conduct charges in front of Police Headquarters and a high-profile group of black and Hispanic leaders began to plot strategy for meetings with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Birdie Tebbetts, Plain Speaker With 53-Year Baseball Career
description: George (Birdie) Tebbetts, a bright, pragmatic baseball man whose major league career encompassed 14 years as a catcher, 11 as a manager and 28 as a scout, died Wednesday in Sunrise Rehabilitation Center in Bradenton, Fla. He was 86.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday illustrating a recent increase in gasoline prices misstated the latest national average price for a gallon of regular gasoline, as calculated on Monday by the Energy Information Administration. It is $1.017, not $1.0869.

title: Marijuana as Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixing Algebra and Advertising; Future Consumers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Grim Waltz Of Desire
description: What is this thing called love? Cole Porter's famous question resonates throughout ''Closer,'' Patrick Marber's bleak, chic study of the laws of attraction in contemporary London. But the answers, such as they are, aren't anything you would set to a lilting melody.

title: Treasuries Off In Advance of Next Week's Fed Meeting
description: Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday as market participants awaited next week's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee.

title: The Devils Tighten Their Grip On First
description: Although Jaromir Jagr was having a quiet game, the Penguins were having their way with the Devils. Pittsburgh was leading by 3-2 at the start of the third period tonight, in a game that would decide the Atlantic Division leader.

title: New Directors/New Films Festival: When and Where the Movies Will Be Shown
description: The 28th New Directors/New Films series, sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film and video at the Museum of Modern Art, opens today and runs through April 11. Screenings are in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the museum, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan. Tickets are $10; a pass for the entire series (23 films) is $200 ($165 for museum and film society members). Unless otherwise noted, the films are 1998 releases. All foreign-language films are subtitled in English. Information: (212) 708-9500. Here is a series schedule.

title: Ericsson and Qualcomm Settle Dispute
description: Ericsson A.B., the world's No. 3 mobile telephone maker, and Qualcomm Inc., a United States rival, agreed today to share access to each other's technology in a market that is expected to add 700 million cellular phone users over the next five years.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Assignment Whets Calligrapher's Quill

title: A City With Its Heart in the Sea
description: When the whalemen of New Bedford, Mass., built their city, they built it sturdy and massive, setting columns and pediments and granite boxes squarely upon the land. But to this day the colors in the historic district, of the Custom House and Seaman's Bethel, even of the cobblestones that line the streets, reflect where the founding fathers' hearts really lay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSSERMAN, RICHARD A.
description: OSSERMAN-Richard A.., Esq. Of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of New York City and Stamford, CT. Died peacefully at home on March 24, 1999, in his 68th year after 2-1/2 years of heroic battle with cancer. He was deeply loved by his family, friends and colleagues. A lawyer for over 40 years, Richard loved his profession and was devoted to his clients. He was a gentleman and mensch in the truest sense, and believed he was a very lucky man, as he lived all his dreams, traveled the world and experienced life to the fullest. He was a brilliant man with an open mind and heart who constantly reinvented himself and adapted to life's changes and challenges. He will be very much missed by his loving wife Malka, and his devoted sons Eric, Joel, Justin and Jordan, and his two stepsons Steve and Robert Chait. He will also be missed by his daughter-in-law Linda and four grandchildren, Harris, Amy, Matthew and Gwen, as well as his brother George and wife Zan D. Gallaway, and his nephews and nieces. He will be missed and remembered fondly by everyone who was touched by him. The family asks that gifts in memory of Richard A. Osserman be made out to the Richard Osserman Memorial Fund and sent to Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, New York 14456. Services will be Sunday, March 28, 1999, at 3:30 PM, at the Star of David Cemetery and Funeral Home, 7701 Bailey Road, North Lauderdale, Florida 33068, phone 954-722-9000.

title: Protect Gay Couples
description: To the Editor:

title: Bard College Backs Plans For an Arts Center
description: Trustees of Bard College approved plans yesterday to build a $40 million performing arts center at the northern end of the Dutchess County campus -- about three-quarters of a mile away from an earlier site that had drawn opposition from preservationists and environmentalists.

title: Dizzying Realm Of Asian Art
description: ''Asia'' doesn't exist and it never has. It isn't a place or culture; it's a geopolitical fiction, a patchwork of people, climates and languages stitched together lightly, and only here and there, by the bright thread of Buddhism.

title: Fiona Banner
description: Murray Guy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIDALGO, ARTHUR J.
description: HIDALGO-Arthur J.. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of Arthur J. Hidalgo, Vice President of Student Affairs and Administration. In our hearts, he can not be replaced. Through his wit, his intelligence, and his commitment to education, he made our time with him an enriching experience. Arthur's dedication to excellence, wealth of ideas and tireless hard work was, and is, an inspiration to all of us. He was the keystone and anchor for all of our efforts and he touched the lives of all of the students, staff, faculty and administration of our school. In the words of school President Alex Shchegol, ''he built this school.'' Arthur, as a friend and colleague, you will always be missed but never forgotten. The administration, faculty, staff and students of ASA Institute of Business & Computer Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWEN, LESTER G.
description: COWEN-Lester G.. Of Armonk, NY, March 23. Adoring husband of the late Helen. Loving father of Nancy (Steve) Patchen, Margie (Robert) Cohen, and Mark (Paddi) Cowen. Beloved grandfather of David, Michael, Jennifer, Daniel, Jonathan, and Elyse. Dearest brother of Sander (Dolores). Devoted brother-in-law of Alice Rosenfeld. In his lifetime he wore many hats: U.S. Navy veteran; principal of Garfield-Wolar; chicken, duck, and sheep farmer; carpenter extraordinaire; mechanical maven; and producer of delicious smoked salmon. We'll always miss you, Daddy/Poppi. Funeral private. Family receiving Saturday 7 to 9 P.M., and Sunday and Monday 1 to 9 P.M. at the Cowen residence, 21 Penny Lane, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: American Diabetes Association or Food Patch.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE  Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.   Opera   ''AIDA,'' Metropolitan Opera. This is the 18th performance that Verdi's Egyptian opera has had since the opening of the season, so the horses must know their way across the stage by now. The cast includes several who return from the fall: Maria Guleghina, who was sweet and sure in the title role, Nina Terentieva as Amneris, and Robert Lloyd, a formidable Ramfis. Placido Domingo is also back, conducting, while his role of Radames is sung by Dennis O'Neill. Jeffrey Wells is the King and Alexandru Agache, new to the company, Amonasro. Tomorrow night at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $25 to $210; sold out, but returns may be available  (Paul Griffiths).
description: ''LA BOHEME,'' New York City Opera. Those relatively new to Puccini's ''Boheme'' and those confirmed Puccini fans who want a break from the Zeffirellian opulence of the Met's version will not go wrong with City Opera's current production. It's intimate, refreshingly spare, colorful and effectively directed by Graziella Sciutti. Best of all, the singers (two casts alternate in the lead roles) are young, ardent and look like the characters they are supposed to be. Tomorrow night at 8, New York State Theater, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $20 to $90 (Anthony Tommasini).

title: Painfully, European Union Agrees on Budget Reform
description: Leaders of the European Union today reached a last-ditch accord on a reform of the 15-nation bloc's $92-billion-dollar annual budget that would eventually make it possible for Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary to join.

title: Is NATO Right To Bomb Serbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Historians Note Flaws In President's Speech
description: About a dozen historians and Balkan specialists consulted yesterday said that President Clinton's use of history in justifying the decision to bomb Serbia to the American people was imprecise and misleading.

title: Four Who Were on the Fast Track
description: Following are sketches of the four police officers reportedly indicted yesterday in the Amadou Diallo shooting:

title: Sex With a Subordinate Costs Israel Army General a Promotion
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that an army general disciplined for having sex with a female subordinate three years ago could not be promoted.

title: For Jane and Joe Public, Wariness and Ignorance
description: In Florida

title: In Which Herman Melville, A Blue Monster, Wears a Wig
description: Children who go to see ''Doug's First Movie'' will come home knowing the name Herman Melville. Of course they will know it only as the name of the gentle, soulful-eyed blue monster from Lucky Duck Lake, but that's better than nothing. (The monster gets the name because while visiting a human family's house it tries to eat ''Moby-Dick.'' In hardcover.)

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Suit! Anger! Agreement!

title: Debt Markets Reopening to Brazil Banks
description: Testing an international aversion to Brazilian debtors after the mid-January devaluation of the nation's currency, a handful of Brazilian companies have resumed borrowing in dollars on global debt markets.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Zeneca-Astra Deal Is Cleared by F.T.C.
description: Zeneca Group of Britain said today that it had received approval from the United States Federal Trade Commission to buy Astra of Sweden for about $35 billion in stock.

title: Embassies Are Stoned As Tensions Begin to Rise
description: Giving vent to their rage over NATO bombings of their neighboring country, thousands of sympathizers with Serbia marched on the American Embassy here today, throwing rocks, setting embassy cars on fire and seeking to burn down the compound with firebombs.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Rally Sharply

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, JEANETTE
description: RAUCH-Jeanette. (nee Breslau). In her 100th year, beloved wife of the late Sol Rauch. Loving mother of Lloyd & Midge, Dick and Joan. Adored grandmother of Nancy & Nasanal Yachnes, Debby Rauch, Bob and Linda Rauch, Steve and Carol Rauch, Linda & Brian Sokol. Proud great-grandmother of eight. Graveside service. Shiva at Lloyd and Midge, 384 Francis Court, Oradell, New Jersey, on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Joan and Dick, 90 Eagle Chase, Woodbury, New York, on Saturday night, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday. RAUCH-Jeanette. Of Hallandale, FL, died March 25 in her 100th year. Beloved mother of Lloyd and Richard. Cherished Grandma & ''G.G.'' Friend of Melzeta and Jenny. We will miss her deeply.

title: B-2's Debut: 4 Warplanes Join Strikes
description: The B-2 stealth bomber, the most expensive and intricate aircraft ever built, has finally made its combat debut.

title: Reports on Most-Violent Events in Universe
description: Thousands of times more energetic than ordinary exploding stars, their visible light as bright as a million galaxies, gamma-ray bursts are the most violent events in the universe, and radiation from one of these events reaches the vicinity of Earth at a rate of about one a day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENSOHN, ICEK
description: BLUMENSOHN-Icek. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Eva Zellner and family on the loss of her beloved father. May the families be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: A Feeling We're Not in Springfield . . .
description: Lisa Simpson would be charmed by ''Futurama,'' but her brother Bart might reach for the clicker to see what else was on. That's just a guess. For a better bead on Bart's preferences, you'd have to ask a certified expert, like Matt Groening. He, of course, invented Bart, Lisa and their ubiquitous family. Now, nine years (several generations in television terms) after ''The Simpsons'' became a national institution, Mr. Groening has put his imprimatur on a second animated Fox series, ''Futurama,'' a look at life in the year 3000.

title: MORE  ON  THE  BOMBINGS
description: History as Clinton Sees It

title: Andes Battle: Right vs. Left vs. Civilians vs. Troops
description: A leftist member of Congress here is assassinated just a few yards from the Capitol building, and Colombians with ties to that country's right-wing death squads are arrested for the crime. A wealthy Venezuelan businessman is kidnapped in Caracas and ends up in the hands a left-wing Colombian guerrillas.

title: Henry James's Eerie Crew, In Search of the Willies
description: Rocco Sisto is not the first man to play a female English housekeeper on a New York stage this season. That honor can be claimed by Stephen DeRosa, he of the voluminous aprons and devastating sidelong glances in the hilarious ''Mystery of Irma Vep.'' Watching Mr. Sisto slip into a similar role -- one of several he plays in a lugubrious new adaptation of Henry James's ''Turn of the Screw'' at Primary Stages -- one cannot help but think back wistfully on that other more enjoyable evening of theater.

title: Productivity Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Hustle on 3-Point Play Lifts California to Title
description: Geno Carlisle did not know whether it was the rigors of the extended run into the post-season or simply the struggles of an untimely slump, but throughout last night's game at Madison Square Garden, he seemed a step slow, a bit sluggish. Nor did he know why in the final seconds of the National Invitation Tournament's championship game everything around him suddenly seemed in slow motion.

title: More 737 Homework for Boeing
description: Despite significant modifications made after the 1994 crash of a Boeing 737 jetliner near Pittsburgh, the National Transportation Safety Board has rightly decided to withhold its approval from the current design of 737 rudders. In a unanimous decision, the Federal safety panel found that the design ''is not reliably redundant'' -- meaning, essentially, that it does not have sufficient capacity to compensate for its own failure.

title: A Surprise Defeat in Bridge
description: The top-seeded squad in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship went down to a surprising defeat at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Wednesday night. Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Eric Rodwell, Jeff Meckstroth, Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff led by 7 imps going into the final set of 16 deals but could not hold on. Malcolm Brachman, Eddie Wold, Curtis Cheek, Billy Miller, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson gained 20 to win by 13.

title: Mets Plug Hershiser Into Their Jumbled Rotation
description: One day after officially evicting Hideo Nomo from their starting rotation, the Mets acquired another former Los Angeles Dodger ace today, signing Orel Hershiser to a guaranteed one-year, $2 million contract.

title: Yellowstone-Biotechnology Deal Is Suspended by a Federal Judge
description: A Federal judge has ordered a temporary halt to a precedent-setting arrangement under which a biotechnology company is paying Yellowstone National Park for the rights to search its geysers and hot springs for commercially valuable microbes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FALCO, LOUIS
description: FALCO-Louis. 3/26/93. Dearest Louis, thank you for your love, inspiration and contributions to dance, art and theater, your family and friends. We miss you. God bless you.

title: Reactions Mix Worry About 'Leap Backward' and Support for Lesser of Evils
description: Europeans reacted today with a mixture of dread at the return of large-scale combat to the continent where two world wars were fought, apprehension that the conflict could spread and widespread if sometimes grudging support for the allied decision to take military action.

title: Half a Century After Hitler, German Jets Join the Attack
description: For the first time since the end of World War II, German fighter jets have gone to war, taking part in the attack on Yugoslavia as part of a NATO force and marking this country's definitive emancipation from post-war pacifism.

title: Fight Over Autonomy Splits Sierra Club
description: The Sierra Club's New York State chapter is threatening to suspend its New York City group in a dispute over the local group's political and financial independence, according to leaders of the environmental organization.

title: An Opportunity on Civil Rights
description: President Clinton is renewing the fight to get Bill Lann Lee confirmed as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, a position Mr. Lee has filled admirably on an acting basis for nearly two years -- since Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee first blocked his nomination.

title: NATO Strikes Go On as Serbs Step Up Campaign
description: Serbia withstood a second round of NATO air assaults today, and the White House vowed prolonged and severe attacks while President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was reported to be defiantly stepping up his military campaign in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEPNER, DORIS BRIAN
description: HEPNER-Doris Brian. Age 88. Died peacefully in her sleep on March 24, 1999.

title: Court Allows Lawsuit Against H.M.O. Doctor
description: In a decision that could make it easier for patients to bring malpractice suits against doctors in managed-care programs, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that the widow of a man who died of a heart attack could sue her husband's primary-care doctor for failing to refer him quickly enough to a heart specialist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFEL, SADIE
description: GRIFEL-Sadie. On March 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted father of Matilda and Martin Fink, Marcia and Jimmy O'Toole, and Fran and Aaron Hirschhorn. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Service 12 noon, Friday at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Clash of Cultures, Pride and Passion
description: The 16-year-old boy in a New York Yankees cap lingered outside the field at the Provincial Academy of Baseball here, watching quietly with intense eyes as older players went through batting practice.

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Russian Keeps His Title By Beating Countryman
description: He still had a combination spin and a flying spin remaining, but as soon as Aleksei Yagudin landed his last triple jump cleanly tonight, he was already pumping his fists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, RITA
description: EISNER-Rita. On March 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Drs. Cathey and Kenneth Falvo. Adoring grandmother of Jessica. A graveside service Sunday 12:30 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. Contributions in her memory to Physicians for Social Responsibility/NYC, 475 Riverside Drive, Room 551, New York City 10115.

description: LENTAKIS-Cynthia Joyce. On March 24, 1999. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Michael, Tom and Diane. Devoted sister of Mary Hatton and Denise Adeane. Funeral service on Saturday, 10 AM at All Souls Church, 55 Parkway Dr., Portchester, NY. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, ARTHUR
description: CHAPLIN-Arthur. You will surely be missed for the rest of our lives. We love you, Arthur. Evelyn & Irving, Ruth & Harold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMAN, BERNARD, D.D.S.
description: TUCHMAN-Bernard, D.D.S.. On March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Joan Hesse Tuchman. Loving father of Marlene, Drs. Judith and Ira, Adam, and Stacy and Michael. Cherished brother of Murray and Caryl and Stephan, uncle and great-uncle. All who knew and loved him will miss him. Funeral Services private. TUCHMAN-Bernard, D.D.S. We'll miss you, old friend. Peace at last. Emily & Irwin Rosen

title: KPMG's Canadian Unit Is Preparing to Bolt
description: Concerned that their giant accounting firm is not staying competitive at a time many companies have global operations, the 5,000 accountants and consultants working at KPMG in Canada are planning to move to the firm of Arthur Andersen, top partners at both firms in Canada said yesterday.

Funeral services at I.J. Morris, 2:15 Friday, March 26 at 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, Long Island.

description: Security was high and the bars and restaurants normally frequented by NATO troops were virtually empty tonight around this northern Italian air base that is the launching pad for many of the NATO aircraft striking Yugoslavia.

title: Ruth Root
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIAL, ALLEN
description: FIAL-Allen. Died peacefully. Devoted husband of Anita. Loving father of Alison & Michael, and Barrie & Jonathan. Adored 'Papa' of Jordan, Andrew, Dana, Darren and Alex. Truly a man of all seasons who touched so many in his own unique way. Rest peacefully. Services at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY at 12 Noon, Friday, March 26.

title: Blunt Appraisal of City Schools From No. 2 Official
description: The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that New York City's public schools, with their large classes, antiquated computers, scarce library books, dilapidated buildings and poorly trained teachers, lagged far behind the rest of the state on almost every measure of school quality.

title: Copacabana Journal; Auto Insurance for All Comers, Yours for a Prayer
description: They drive from all over Bolivia, Peru and even northern Argentina to this remote town on the shore of Lake Titicaca -- taxi drivers, truck drivers and other motorists seeking a priest's blessings for protection against drunken drivers, landslides, bad brakes and broken axles.

description: In percent

title: The Buckeyes' Biggest Booster
description: They knew this point guard was coming to Ohio State, hard on the heels of the new coach, and they knew fast that he would be a shot of adrenaline for a dying team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, JOSEPH
description: MORSE-Joseph. on March 25, 1999. Loving husband of the late Cynthia. survived by his boys Billy, Michael and daughter-in-law Jo. He will be deeply missed and remembered as a great father andwonderful friend. Services private.

title: LASON AGREES TO BUY M-R GROUP FOR $145 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Lason Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire M-R Group P.L.C. of Britain for about $145 million in stock, a move that would make it the world's leading manager of computer records for other companies. Lason, based in Troy, Mich., said M-R Group shareholders would receive 4.877 new Lason shares for every 100 M-R Group shares. M-R Group, which has about $90 million in annual revenue, handles laser printing, digital imagery and microfilming. Lason had 1998 revenue of $279.8 million. Its shares rose $1.50, to $55.375.

title: Ethnic Albanians Now Fear Wrath of Serbs
description: After a night of heavy explosions and fires, this city was strangely calm early today. Serbs seemed at ease, if angry over the NATO bombing; ethnic Albanians were anxious, even terrified of what was to come.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE  Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.   DAN BERN, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. Could Dan Bern be more obnoxious? He wails about the colossal size of his private anatomy, suggests that humanity originated with a sex act between aliens and monkeys, praises his female peers as ''chick singers'' and brings up uncomfortable subjects like racial separatism and the still mythical cure for AIDS. He earns the right to cause this trouble by being genuinely witty, often touching and just a heck of a fun guy to be around. His albums haven't yet totally captured the daring of his live performances, in which Mr. Bern lives up to the legacy of his idol, Lenny Bruce, by pushing himself and his audience in directions even he never expected. Tomorrow night at 7:30 and 10:30; tickets are $15 (Ann Powers).
description: DAMON AND NAOMI, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Damon and Naomi, partners in life and music, were once the rhythm section in Galaxie 500, the cult band that turned underground rock into mood music, and they've been pursuing nuanced reveries ever since. Tonight they share a night of soothing sounds with Retsin, a project that turns the interplay between two female friends, Tara Jane O'Neil and Cynthia Nelson, into dulcet balladry. Tomorrow night at 10; tickets are $8. (Powers)

title: In Russia, No Gloves But Also No Fists
description: As Yugoslavia's Ambassador to Russia, the elder brother of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic has done his best to drum up support for Yugoslavia in Moscow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSIN, CLAUS F.
description: ROSSIN-Claus F.., 61. Of 19 Shore Road Watch Hill, Rhode Island. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Moore Rossin. Died suddenly March 24, 1999. Mr. Rossin born in Austria, October 18, 1937. He was extremely proud to have become an American Citizen. Mr. Rossin had been employed by Bertelsman Publishing Company in both Germany and New York City. He was also employed as Vice President of Marketing at both Doubleday Publishing and Meredith Burda Publishing Companies in NYC. Upon moving to RI he and his wife purchased Charles C. Buffum Realty, Inc., in Westerly, RI. As President of Buffum & Rossin Realty he expanded their offices to include those in Avondale and Watch Hill, RI, and Stonington & Mystic, CT. In addition to his wife he leaves two sons Christopher J. Keeler, of Coeur'alene, Idaho and Joakim Rossin of Frankfurt, Germany. One daughter Heidi M. Keeler of Salt Lake CIty, Utah, one brother Ulrich C. Romberg of Germany. Three grandchildren Kenneth, Jessica and Kevin Rossin. Funeral service will be held in Watch Hill Chapel, Saturday, March 27, at 1 PM. Visiting hours are omitted. For further information Gaffney - Dolan Funeral Home, 59 Spruce Street, Westerly, RI. In lieu of flowers family request contributions be made to: ''The Claus F. Rossin Memorial Sailing Trust'' to benefit sailors striving for world class status, C/O The Watch Hill Yatch Club, PO Box 2933, Westerly, Rhode Island 02891, in his memory.

title: Seeking to Be Tokyo Governor, Politician Attacks U.S. Presence
description: Until now, the calls for Yankees to go home have usually focused on the American military bases in Okinawa, in southern Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITZEL, IRVING
description: WITZEL-Irving. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Sisterhood and Couples Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Dr. Phyllis Speiser, and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Asst Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Case Hinges On Question: When Is Error A Crime?
description: In the end, the prosecution of the four police officers reportedly indicted yesterday in the shooting of Amadou Diallo will rest on a deceptively simple question: when does a mistake become a crime?

title: The Mystery Now Puzzling NATO: Yugoslavia's Silent SAM's
description: Call it the mystery of the missing missiles.

title: Kevorkian Appeals to Emotions of Jurors As They Begin Weighing Murder Charges
description: It has been a strikingly short murder trial, one in which the defense called no witnesses and presented no evidence.

title: Four Officers Indicted For Murder in Killing Of Diallo, Lawyer Says
description: A Bronx grand jury yesterday indicted four white street crime officers in the killing of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed African immigrant cut down last month in a fusillade of 41 shots at his Bronx apartment building, a lawyer and a law enforcement official said.

title: Bill Protecting Medicaid Patients Is Signed
description: President Clinton today signed legislation that prohibits nursing homes from evicting people on Medicaid, as some have done in recent years as part of an effort to recruit more affluent patients.

title: New Federal Food Guide for Young Children Has Soft-Drink Makers in a Fizz
description: The Department of Agriculture yesterday issued its first guidelines on how to feed young children a nutritious diet, emphasizing the value of grains, fruits and vegetables. A soft drink can that illustrates the recommendation that children should ''eat less'' sugar in their diets has outraged the soda companies, which annually sell an average of 56.1 gallons of soda per person in the United States.

title: DELTA SAYS IT WILL SELL 119 PLANES TO PRATT & WHITNEY
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it would sell 119 Boeing 727's and 39 spare jet engines to Pratt & Whitney in what Delta called the biggest-ever sale of used aircraft. Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, will market the planes through a partnership with the closely held Republic Financial Corporation of Denver, which will convert them to cargo carriers. Terms were not disclosed, but recent resale prices indicate the planes could fetch more than $700 million. Delta plans to retire its Boeing 727-200's by June 2005 and replace them with Boeing 737's, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: BASF Planning U.S. Plant
description: BASF of Germany, the No. 1 European producer of chemicals, said today that it would build a plant at an existing site in Geismar, La., for butanediol, an intermediary for polyurethane, which is used in foam cushioning and condoms. It did not disclose financial details. A rival, BP Amoco, is building a butanediol plant in Ohio that will start up in the second quarter of this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Stephen J. Sabbeth's plan to step down as chairman of the Democratic Party in Nassau County misstated the background of Lewis J. Yevoli, who intends to run for party leader. Mr. Yevoli is a former Supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay, not a former Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, HERBERT
description: KLAPPER-Herbert. Beloved husband of Adele. Treasured father of Bonnie (Lonny) and Wendie. Adored Poppy of Brandon and Ryan Schwartz. Founder and President of Superior Sewing Machine & Supply Corp. An enthusiastic art collector. Services today, 11:30 A.M., ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. KLAPPER-Herbert. The staff of Superior Sewing Machine mourns the loss of our Founder and President. He was an inspiration, and we will miss his kindness and guidance. Our condolences to his dear wife Adele, his daughter Wendy, his daughter Bonnie and her husband Lonnie and his grandchildren Brandon and Ryan. KLAPPER-Herbert. We mourn the passing of a wonderful, spirited and generous man. It was a honor and a privilege to have known him. We extend our condolences to his loving wife, Adele, daughters Bonnie, Wendi and family. Jeffrey and Nancy Haber KLAPPER-Herbert. The Director and Board of Trustees of The Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, NY would like to express their deepest sorrow for the recent passing of their fellow Board Member, Mr. Herbert Klapper of Hewlett Harbor, NY.

title: Daily Diversions of a Gay Serial Killer
description: ''Hard,'' a strident, grisly thriller about a gay serial killer in Los Angeles who plays fiendish cat-and-mouse games with a closeted gay cop assigned to his case, isn't exactly the Jeffrey Dahmer story, although there are some obvious similarities.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Clinton's speech to the nation Wednesday night on Kosovo referred incorrectly in some copies to the year Yugoslavia began to break apart. It was 1991, not 1989.

title: Caucus Plans Meetings On Racial Profiling
description: The Black and Latino Caucus of the State Legislature announced yesterday that it would hold public meetings in April to look into allegations that the New Jersey State Police stop drivers based on their race.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELKINS, MICHAEL J.
description: ELKINS-Michael J.. March 26th, 1962. Happy birthday Mike. I miss you so much. Your Futaba.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, IDA
description: DOUGLAS-Ida, 83. devoted wife of Eugene, adored mother of Jeffrey and fiancee Linda, devoted sister of Karl and Shirley Lens. Services are 11AM, today at Weinstein West End Funeral Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar eked out gains against the euro on concern that air raids against Serbian forces could sour investors on European assets. In New York, the euro fell to $1.0826 from $1.0932 on Wednesday.

title: Levitz Furniture To Review Account
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., has begun a review on the creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $20 million. Those duties had been handled since December 1997 by Bozell Retail in New York, part of the Bozell Worldwide unit of True North Communications.

title: Samm Kunce
description: John Gibson Gallery

title: New Video Releases
description: Everest

title: The Unexpected Charms Of a Craggy Kind of Guy
description: The free-spirited daredevils who cavort through ''Among Giants'' are about as close to American cowboys as you are likely to find in a British film set in contemporary England. Rugged rock climbers from the working class, they earn their living taking risky free-lance work painting the electrical towers connecting power lines over hundreds of miles of English landscape. In their spare time, these paint-smeared wretches hang out in pubs where the musical fare is American country. While working as a team at dizzying elevations, smacking paint against the girders of power stations looming over the moors around Sheffield, they join voices to sing American pop songs like ''Stand by Me.''

title: Beatrice Wood: 'Drawing for Life'
description: Achim Moeller Fine Art

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the popularity of ''The Sopranos,'' an HBO television series about a New Jersey mob boss, omitted the given name and title of an HBO executive who talked about the show. He is Chris Albrecht, HBO's president for original programming.

title: Handy Made the Blues Live, And the Tributes Go On
description: American popular music depends on entrepreneurs as well as musicians, and William Christopher Handy was a savvy combination of both. The W. C. Handy Foundation marked his 125th birthday -- he was born on Nov. 11, 1873 -- with a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, bringing together singers and musicians who will tour cities associated with Handy from May until November.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: A Dangerous Game With Several Endings
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series, sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, blasts off tonight with the jolting, futuristic energy of the hit German film ''Run Lola Run.'' It's a furiously kinetic display of pyrotechnics from the director Tom Tykwer, who fuses lightning-fast visual tricks, tirelessly shifting styles and the arbitrary possibilities of interactive storytelling into the best-case scenario for a cinematic video game.

title: Step by Step: How the U.S. Decided to Attack, and Why the Move Came So Fast
description: In the last week, before the decision was made that force would be used against Yugoslavia, the impending visit of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia became a focal point that helped push the Administration to act sooner than it had planned, according to officials.

title: The Too-Secret Police
description: Even though the New York City police are bathed in the light of publicity right now, much of their work remains obscure -- and that is the problem confronting the Police Department and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as they try to quiet the furor over the shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: Cabdriver, 40, Is Stabbed to Death in Brooklyn During an Attempted Robbery
description: A self-employed livery-cab driver was stabbed to death yesterday morning in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn by three men who were trying to rob him, the police said.

title: Stocks Across the Board March Vigorously Upward
description: Stocks posted sharp gains across the board yesterday as investors reacted to a profit surge at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, a deal solidifying ties between America Online and Ebay, and an analyst's favorable report on Procter & Gamble. Even long-depressed stocks of smaller companies gained.

title: Doctor Fired After Dispute Over L.I. Jail
description: The doctor who oversaw medical care at the Nassau County Jail has been fired after dozens of inmates complained of long delays in treatment, poor care and withheld medications, officials at the Nassau County Medical Center said today.

title: Morgan Stanley Had Big Gains In First Quarter
description: Most Wall Street firms are enjoying the robust profits that come hand-in-hand with a strong stock market, but Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is enjoying the ride more than most.

title: High-Voltage Benefits Of Improved Batteries
description: ONE of the most primitive and troublesome components under a car's hood, the battery, is due for an update, auto company executives say. As a result, there could be a cascade of new technologies that would make cars more fuel-efficient and less likely to turn up dead on cold winter mornings.

title: Louis Mueller: 'Rolling Papers'
description: Franklin Parrasch Gallery

title: It's Jade Time At the Galleries And the Fair
description: To the Chinese, jade is more than a gemstone.

title: A Jaded Culture
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Schumer Says Racial Tensions Could Undermine War on Crime
description: In his first speech on the floor of the Senate, Senator Charles E. Schumer warned today that tensions between New York City's police force and minority groups threaten to undermine the city's war on crime, and he called on the department to make major policy changes to help close the widening racial rift.

title: Watts and Estes Share Lead At Players Championship
description: After his first three holes today, Brian Watts was already four over par.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: I.M.F. Approves $460 Million Loan Installment for Indonesia
description: The International Monetary Fund approved a $460 million loan installment for Indonesia today and increased its credit line to the Southeast Asian country by $1 billion as the recession there deepened and private creditors refused to invest in the country.

title: People
description: Vivian Lines, senior vice president at the Hong Kong office of Hill & Knowlton, New York, part of WPP Group, was named chief operating officer for the Asia-Pacific region, succeeding Cliff Kagawa, who left to become president for the Asia-Pacific region at the Hong Kong office of Burson-Marsteller, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Forks In the Road Of Final Four
description: THE lessons of the old school are not so easily dismissed. Leon Barmore never looked at the sport of women's basketball as the land of opportunity, and for most of his two decades-plus at Louisiana Tech, there was never a reason to.

title: Cal Ripken Sr., 63, Veteran Baseball Coach
description: Cal Ripken Sr., a gruff, single-minded baseball person and the only one to manage two sons on the same major league team, died yesterday at Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FANEUIL
description: ADAMS-Faneuil. The Officers and Trustees of Chess-In-TheSchools mourn the loss of our esteemed President. We will be forever grateful for his leadership in creating our program and bringing the organization to its present level. We extend our deepest condolences to his dear wife Emiko and daughters Rebecca and Susannah. A memorial service will be held at the United Nations Chapel, 1st Ave & 44th St on Thursday, April 1st at 12 noon. Lewis B. Cullman, Chairman

title: Troupe Irks San Francisco Catholics
description: The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence, an irreverent and largely gay street theater group whose members dress like nuns and use elements of Roman Catholic ritual in their performances, have angered Catholics here with plans for an Easter street party to celebrate the troupe's 20th anniversary.

title: INTERIM SERVICES IN $438 MILLION DEAL FOR NORRELL
description: Interim Services Inc., the provider of staffing services, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, the Norrell Corporation, for about $438 million in stock. Interim said it would exchange 0.9 of a share for each Norrell share. A spokeswoman said the company would also assume about $115 million in Norrell debt. Interim, which had revenue of $1.89 billion for the year ended Dec. 25, expects that the combined company will be able to increase revenue to $4 billion this year. Norrell had revenue of $1.4 billion for the year ended Nov. 1. Interim, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., acquired seven staffing-related companies in the last year, and expects Norrell, based in Atlanta, to be its last major purchase in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, BEATRICE SOBEL
description: MELTZER-Beatrice Sobel. At age 95, on March 25th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman Meltzer. Devoted sister of Gladys Sobel Blair and the late Annette Sobel Barnet. Cherished aunt and greataunt. Always in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLLIN, ALBERT E.
description: GOLLIN-Albert E.. Died peacefully among family on March 24, 1999. Beloved father of Mark and Karin Gollin, cherished husband of Ann K. Gollin, loving stepfather of Michael, Maria and Kaia. His compassionate wisdom, incisive wit, and discerning intellect will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at 2PM, Friday April 2, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by a reception at his home. In his memory, a fund for the advancement of public opinion research has been established at Columbia University. Contributions may be sent to Albert E. Gollin Memorial Gift, c/o Mark A. Gollin, 2409 East Helen St, Seattle WA 98112, checks to be made out to School of General Studies, Columbia University.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Lycos, an Eager Bride, Accepted a Tough Proposal
description: Not every deal maker could finagle a merger agreement that forbids his proposed partner from negotiating with other interested parties. And if his betrothed does get an unsolicited offer, requires it to sell him nearly 20 percent of the company.

title: Mayor Wears Kinder Face, For Now
description: YESTERDAY brought another day of the new feel-your-pain Mayor, the man who prefers to accent his sensitivity to troublesome aspects of police behavior.

title: Minority Private-School Students Claim Police Harassment
description: Lorenzo Laboy was still in his school uniform -- tan pants, neat white shirt, black tie, the gold script of Rice High School bold against his green V-neck sweater -- as he headed one afternoon two weeks ago to his job at Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Washington Heights.

title: EATON TO SELL 2 UNITS TO HELP PAY FOR AEROQUIP PURCHASE
description: The Eaton Corporation of Cleveland, which makes products ranging from engine parts to golf club grips, is selling two units to help pay for its $1.7 billion cash acquisition of Aeroquip-Vickers Inc. One unit, in Brunswick, Ohio, makes fastening devices for automotive and other applications and has 650 employees. The other, which is based in Marshall, Mich., makes engine-cooling fan drives for cars and trucks. It has 1,050 employees. The purchase of Aeroquip-Vickers, based in Maumee, Ohio, was announced in February.

title: Aims of an Air War in Kosovo
description: As NATO air raids on Yugoslavia moved into a second night, both sides seemed to be settling in for a long campaign. President Clinton and other NATO leaders say they are prepared to continue the attacks until President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia accepts the international peace plan for Kosovo. Mr. Milosevic says he will do no such thing.

title: A Hint in Texas About the Fate of the Missing Atheist Leader Madalyn O'Hair
description: In what may be a breakthrough in the disappearance of the atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair, an Austin lawyer representing a former office manager for the missing woman said Federal officials told him that his client is suspected of being part of a plot to rob and murder Ms. O'Hair.

title: ABC Sports President Named
description: Howard Katz, who was named president of ABC Sports yesterday, said his first reaction upon being asked to take the job was, ''Why would I want to do that?''

title: Erwin Pfrang
description: Nolan/Eckman Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGER, CAROL
description: BRAGER-Carol. On March 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Elizabeth Brager and Marilyn Kress. Adoring grandmother of Marielle Kress. Service Friday, 1:30PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Innovative campaigns by Procter & Gamble? Wonders never cease.
description: ONE of the hoariest of advertising devices, the man-on-the-street interview, is being overhauled for a new generation of consumers by one of the most traditional of advertisers, the Procter & Gamble Company.

title: The Stepchildren of Banking; Efforts to Serve Low-Income Areas Appear to Sputter
description: Marilyn Vasquez quickly dismisses the notion that she would be better off using a bank. Local check cashers ''don't ask for so much ID,'' said Ms. Vasquez, 20, a resident of the Bronx. ''Banks are too much hassle.''

title: Deep Desert Grave Awaits First Load of Nuclear Waste
description: Putting a coda on the cold war, a flatbed truck rumbled out tonight from this ''atomic city,'' the birthplace of nuclear weapons, carrying an inaugural shipment for the world's first deep underground nuclear waste depository.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, HAVEN
description: BLOOM-Haven. The Chapin School is deeply saddened by the loss of its student, Haven Bloom, beloved daughter of Fran Bloom, Director of Studies and Assistant to the Head of The Chapin School, and her husband, Barry. The Chapin community extends heartfelt sympathy to the family. Sandra J. Theunick Head of School Cera B. Robbins, President, Board of Trustees BLOOM-Haven. Her sudden death is a tragedy that we will all have to endure. Condolences to Fran and Barry. The Heffner Family BLOOM-Haven. We will miss our fond friend and classmate. With love, Missye Brickell The Chapin School-Class Nine BLOOM-Haven. You will always remain in our hearts. Chapin School Grade 9

title: DVD Showing Its Strength
description: Late last year signs in store windows summed it up: DVD is here. After a sputtering start in 1997, more than 2,500 films were available on the compact digital video disk and more than one million players had been sold. Where do things stand?

title: Agency Approves a Railroad Acquisition
description: The Canadian National Railway Company's $3 billion purchase of the Illinois Central Corporation cleared a big hurdle today with the unanimous approval of the Federal Surface Transportation Board.

title: Is NATO Right To Bomb Serbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOMBLER, BERTHA
description: STOMBLER-Bertha. The officers, staff and leadership of the Jewish Labor Committee share in the sorrow at the death of Bertha Stombler, mother of our dear friend and colleague, Natalie Cimbol. A devoted and loving mother to Natalie and her brothers, Eugene and Milton Stombler, she leaves a loving family of ten grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren with warm memories of happier times. We extend our deepest condolences to her relatives and all who knew and loved her. May her memory be a blessing. Morton Bahr President Avram B. Lyon Executive Director

title: Is NATO Right To Bomb Serbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Penetrating the Mystery of a Mother's Silence
description: TERRA INFIRMA

title: Reaction to Offer From Microsoft Is Cool
description: State and Federal officials were dismissive today of Microsoft's proposal to settle its antitrust suit, but they added that the two sides would meet for settlement talks, probably beginning on Tuesday.

title: A Promising Young Man Kills Himself, and a Small Town Is Shaken
description: To most people in this small, affluent town, Sam Hingston was just about the finest young man they had ever seen: a courteous A student at Wilton High School, a captain on the football and wrestling teams, and as handsome as any 17-year-old kid on television.

title: Elegant Angles Warmed By a Gentle Humanity
description: Like many of his contemporaries of the late 1920's and early 30's the photographer Wendell MacRae saw a hushed beauty in machinery and lovely geometries in sunlight and shadow on Manhattan skyscraper facades. Unlike such artists as Margaret Bourke-White or Ralph Steiner, MacRae didn't seem as intent on showing the majestically or coldly beautiful. Instead, in his elegant photographs, whether they're of hand tools or factories or cityscapes, he seldom lost sight of a gentle human component.

title: This Time, Houston Gets to Watch Knicks Fold
description: Allan Houston could lie back, stretch out his legs and let his perspiration dry. He could be himself on the bench, where there was no one to tell him to stand up straight, puff out his chest or snap to attention.

title: Nasdaq Approves Rule on Trading Halts
description: As the ''anything.com'' stocks continue to gyrate on the Nasdaq stock market, the market's governing board approved a rule yesterday that would allow officials to halt trading in a stock in response to market news or rumors, even if the officials cannot immediately reach the company's executives.

title: Wild Life: Return of the Seals to Long Island
description: We're sitting on top of a sand dune on Montauk Point two days after a northeaster dumped 11 inches of snow on the East End of Long Island. It's the tail end of winter and there's not a soul on the beach, just some sea gulls and a few hardy ducks bobbing in the surf. Our eyes are trained on the sea, the tide is going out and the conditions -- except for a gnawing wind from the west -- are near perfect for seal spotting.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a guilty plea by Mark Shaplo, a former municipal union official, incorrectly described the involvement of another official in the corruption scandal at District Council 37. As the article stated, the other official, Bessie Jamison, pleaded guilty to receiving kickbacks when her local provided holiday turkeys to its members; she was not implicated in the vote-rigging charges to which Mr. Shaplo pleaded guilty.

title: Mixing Algebra and Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, JERRY
description: GREENBERG-Jerry. Remembered with love. Your sister, Arlene

title: Impasse on Budget Worsens As Pataki Threatens Vetoes
description: The state's budget impasse worsened today as Gov. George E. Pataki declared the Assembly and Senate proposals unacceptable, threatening a repeat of last year's sweeping vetoes unless the Legislature drastically scales back its spending plans.

title: Matthew Cusick: 'Diamonds Are Forever'
description: Kent Gallery

title: New Wrinkle in Questions About Safir's Trip
description: The company that controls Revlon Inc. hires off-duty New York City police officers, in uniform, to guard its offices at night under a city-sponsored arrangement that may complicate the ethics inquiry into Police Commissioner Howard Safir's free trip to the Academy Awards with the president of Revlon.

title: 'Views From the Edge of the World'
description: Marlborough Chelsea

title: NEW CENTURY AND NORTHERN STATES PLAN MERGER
description: New Century Energies Inc. and the Northern States Power Company agreed yesterday to a $4.9 billion merger, creating a company that would sell electricity and natural gas to 4.5 million customers in 12 states. Investors reacted negatively, sending New Century shares down $2.1875, to $36.50. Northern States fell $1.0625, to $26.1875. New Century shareholders would own 54 percent of the new company and receive 1.55 shares for each current share, at a value of $42.24. Northern States shareholders would get one new share. New Century, based in Denver, and Northern States, based in Minneapolis, expect the merger to save $1.1 billion in the first 10 years.

title: Two Men Are Shot at Restaurant
description: One man was shot dead and another critically wounded last night by a fellow diner at a bar and grill in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Trooper Suing State Says Vandals Hit His Home
description: County prosecutors are investigating whether someone vandalized the home of a New Jersey state trooper who filed a lawsuit last month against the state police, claiming he was forced by his superiors to stop drivers based on their race.

title: Milosevic Might Win From the Loss of Kosovo
description: Whispers about a face-saving Serbian loss to the world's most powerful military alliance began here long before NATO bombs started to fall on Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, HARRY S.
description: GARBER-Harry S. At the age of 94 on March 25, 1999 in Israel. Beloved father of Judy and Kenny, Ephraim and Shirley, Laurence and Sherry. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Beloved husband of the late Sadie Garber and Estelle Zweibel. Shiva will be observed all day Tuesday and Wednesday morning at 5 Iris Street, Cedarhurst, New York.

title: Religion Journal; Acknowledging Discord Over NATO Air Strikes
description: Polls show Americans are divided over the decision this week by the United States and other NATO members to bomb military targets in Yugoslavia. It is a division that also extends to religious organizations, even as many of those organizations echo the concern voiced by the NATO Governments over the Yugoslav military's attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo province, the situation that led to the conflict.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPAR AEROSPACE LTD., Toronto, set a shareholder vote for May 13 after a group including its two biggest holders -- Crescendo Partners L.P., New York, and I.M.P. Group Ltd., Halifax, Nova Scotia -- proposed ousting most of the board and distributing at least $66 million in cash to shareholders.

title: Officers Hope Cloud Over Force Will Lift
description: For almost two months, New York City police officers have found themselves the target of constant criticism: protesters calling them murderers, suspects mumbling caustic remarks and headlines raising questions about both their aggressiveness and training.

title: Russia Cancels Lewinsky Visit
description: Russia's rage over NATO air strikes in Yugoslavia boiled over tonight when it canceled the upcoming visit by Monica Lewinsky.

title: Only Days to Shutdown, 50,000 Patients Are Still Clinging to HIP
description: For the employees and the estimated 50,000 remaining policyholders who are the forlorn rear guard in the last days of the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, these are hectic days of rage and anxiety.

title: Yesteryear's Erotica, Today's Quaint
