description: A sustained off-color joke directed with high visual style, Aleksei Balabanov's film ''Of Freaks and Men,'' is extremely close in mood and attitude to the work of Guy Maddin, the eccentric Canadian director whose oddball period fantasies have earned him an enthusiastic cult following. ''Of Freaks and Men'' is also a striking change of direction by this Russian director, whose film ''Brother,'' a brutally powerful gangster movie set in contemporary St. Petersburg, was respectfully received when it opened last year.

title: White House Tells of Reports Of a Forced March in Kosovo
description: The Clinton Administration and a European security group said today that they had received reports from refugees fleeing Kosovo and others that an estimated 15,000 to 20,000 ethnic Albanian civilians were put on a forced march in central Kosovo by Serbian forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLEK, FANNY
description: DALLEK-Fanny. She enriched us with her wisdom, values, smiles and optimism. Survived by her daughter Shirley Cohen (Joe), son Godfrey, brother Jerry Rothman (Anita), brother-in-law Abner Jaffe, Godfrey's children, Dr. Nancy (Jeff Pearlstein), Steven, Shirley's children, Neil, Fred (Audrey), Sandra, Marc (Diane), greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews. Graveside services 11 AM, Sunday, Wellwood, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERLICHT, BRIAN H.
description: FEUERLICHT-Brian H., 39. Of Edison, NJ on March 26, 1999. Services will be Sunday 1 PM at the East Brunswick Jewish Center, Ryders Lane, East Brunswick. Contributions to the American Heart Association. For information contact Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, New Brunswick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EDWIN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Edwin R. On March 25, 1999. Beloved brother of Elliott and the late David. Devoted uncle of George, Ellen, Joseph, Lawrence and Daniel. Service at New York Society of Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, Manhattan, 3 P.M. on Sunday, March 28th.

title: Reports of Reprisals Rely on Refugee Accounts and Scratchy Phone Calls
description: On a rocky hill that overlooks the village in Kosovo 20 yards across the border that he fled last week, Agim, 27, squinted through binoculars today at two Serbian armored vehicles parked in the middle of his town.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Russia's Move To End Strikes Loses; Margin Is a Surprise
description: The United States and the NATO alliance won a victory today when the Security Council rejected, 12 to 3, a Russian resolution demanding an immediate end to NATO's air attacks on Yugoslavia.

title: Rice and Cardozo Advance to Class A Final
description: Rice, the nation's second-ranked team, overcame an 8-point halftime deficit last night to defeat Long Island Lutheran, 75-65, in a New York State Federation Class A semifinal game at the Glens Falls Civic Center.

title: Russia and the I.M.F.
description: When Russia's Prime Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, hastily canceled his trip to Washington this week in protest against the air war on Yugoslavia, it was understood that his planned discussion with the International Monetary Fund could not be long delayed. Russia's financial situation is desperate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, FRANCES L.
description: ORKIN-Frances L., of Manhattan. Born July 11, 1916, died Thursday March 25, 1999 after a long illness. A former Information Officer for The United Nations and a longtime successful entreprenuer. Ms. Orkin loved people, loved life and loved New York City. She is survived by family members and dear friends who mourn the passing of our caring, elegant, eloquent and witty friend. Ms. Orkin is the daughter of the late Louis and Fanny Orkin. There will be no funeral although a memorial gathering will be held at her request in her memory. Contributions may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice or to Saint Vincent Cancer Center.

title: CORT BUSINESS SERVICES TO CHANGE HANDS
description: The Cort Business Services Corporation, a furniture rental concern based in Fairfax, Va., said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by its management and the investment firm Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherill & Company of New York for $363 million in stock plus $90 million in debt. Under the agreement, expected to close this spring, the group will acquire Cort for $24 a share in cash and $2.50 a share in preferred stock, an offer that represents a 58 percent premium above Thursday's closing price of $16.75 for Cort's common shares. Cort's shares rose $6 yesterday, to $22.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. will retain part of its 44 percent stake in Cort and provide equity financing to the new company, Cort said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCENTHAL, MILTON
description: PRINCENTHAL - Milton. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife Frances, and family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Editorial Notebook; It's Great Beisbol, but Diplomacy Lite
description: Fans of the Baltimore Orioles (79-83 last season) have learned not to expect too much, and that is good advice for those looking for political fallout from the Orioles' baseball game tomorrow against a Cuban all-star team in Havana. The Orioles are the latest American athletes to be pressed into service as diplomats. But the game, part of a modest package of measures to expand American contact with ordinary Cubans, is likely to give only a slight boost to relations between Washington and Havana. Sports diplomacy has produced dramatic breakthroughs only when the governments using it were looking for one.

title: Talented Backcourts Will Go Head to Head
description: Khalid El-Amin was sitting behind the microphone, his head bobbing, his legs jiggling, all the energy he infuses into the Connecticut offense seeping out with nowhere to go. An hour later, his Ohio State counterpart, Scoonie Penn, sat in the same spot, leaning his head so low over the table his shoulders practically disappeared, his voice low, no movement wasted.

title: Nighttime Training and Awacs Capitalize on MIG's Weak Spots
description: The Yugoslav MIG-29's are among the world's top fighter jets. But NATO has Awacs radar planes to track their every move, long-range air-to-air missiles to shoot at them and better trained pilots who anticipate the Yugoslav pilots' antiquated Soviet-style tactics.

title: Asthma Drug Is Approved, But Sepracor Shares Tumble
description: Sepracor Inc., a biotechnology company based in Marlborough, Mass., said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing a new inhalable drug named Xopenex for the treatment of asthma.

title: Jean Guitton, 97, Philosopher, Author and Friend of Popes
description: Jean Guitton, a French Catholic philosopher and author and a friend of popes and French presidents, died on Sunday in Val-de-Grace Hospital in Paris. He was 97 and had homes in Paris and in Bellegarde-en-Marche, France.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They are fighting for their core constituency of right-wing fundamentalists who say, 'Let's stay home and take care of our own, deal with our issues first.' The other Republicans are guarding their bets.''

title: About New York; An Outpost Where Hope Can Thrive
description: TEEN-AGERS climbed up three flights of stairs in an old house in Brooklyn, steadying themselves on the banister and pausing for breath. This little bit of exercise was just a warm-up, since the real after-school workout was yet to begin. In each room of the Bushwick Center of El Puente, young people huddled with tutors as they sweated it out over math problems and chemistry formulas.

title: Doubts Persist, Despite Reports of Indictments
description: For the residents of Wheeler Avenue, a modest stretch of two-story apartment buildings in the Soundview section of the Bronx, reports that four police officers had been indicted on charges of second-degree murder in the killing of their neighbor, Amadou Diallo, did little yesterday to allay their suspicion of the justice system.

title: On Race Relations, Look to Boston; Offensive Discourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRCHILD, JOHN ARTHUR
description: FAIRCHILD-John Arthur, of Bronxville, NY, on March 25, 1999. Father of Diane Fairchild Doyle, Joann Fairchild-Ludington (Ivan), and John ''Bobby'' Arthur Fairchild Jr. Also surviving are five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1-4 PM Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, March 29, at 11 AM.

title: Lavishing Attention On Life's Longings
description: Lucia Dlugoszewski is known in the dance world primarily as an avant-garde composer and the wife of Erick Hawkins, who died in 1994, and now the director of his troupe. With the premiere of ''Radical Ardent'' this season, Ms. Dlugoszewski may now be considered a modern-dance choreographer of exceptional promise. The new work, performed by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Thursday night at Playhouse 91, is fascinating.

title: Elderly Find a Champion on Drug Cutbacks
description: William F. Galvin, the low-profile Massachusetts Secretary of State, is normally more even-tempered. But he just got too outraged, he says, by the hundreds of phone calls his office was getting from elderly people suddenly struggling to afford their prescription medicine.

title: CONVERGYS TO BECOME SOLE OWNER OF WIZTEC
description: The Convergys Corporation, a management services company based in Cincinnati, yesterday offered to buy the 30 percent of Wiztec Solutions Ltd. it does not already own for about $54.9 million, to strengthen its software line and give it access to clients in Europe and Asia. Wiztec, based in Herzliya, Israel, makes billing software for cable television companies. Convergys is paying $18.30 a share, a 10 percent premium over Wiztec's closing price of $16.625 on Thursday. Yesterday, Convergys shares fell 25 cents, to $17.8125. Wiztec gained $1.1875, to $17.8125.

title: Misfiring Nets Lose Van Horn And Game
description: The Nets executed fairly well, beat a larger opponent on the backboards, played with fire and showed some heart tonight. But their failure to correct a problem that has dogged them this season was too much to overcome against the polished Indiana Pacers.

title: What's in the Beef?
description: To the Editor:

title: E-mail: Friendly or Alienating?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foie Gras and Chips, Anyone?; Internet Shopping Is (Sort of) Catching On in Europe
description: Maria Paola Sassella is often amused by her customers, who are experimenting with what for Europeans is still an unfamiliar practice: shopping on the World Wide Web.

title: Statesmanlike Schroder Pulls Harmony From Europe's Hat
description: Showing a statesmanship that had seemed to elude him, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder guided the European Union early today to a landmark agreement to hold down its spending enough to enable three Central European countries to join.

title: Heavy Selling of Corporate Debt Saps Demand for Treasuries
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, as Citigroup and other companies sold $3.8 billion of debt, sapping demand for Government securities.

title: SCHAWK ABANDONS ATTEMPT TO ACQUIRE WACE GROUP
description: Schawk Inc., North America's No. 1 supplier of digital imaging for the packaging and advertising industries, said yesterday that it was abandoning its battle for the British digital imaging services company Wace Group P.L.C., paving the way for the New York-based Applied Graphics Technologies Inc. to acquire Wace for $180.1 million. Schawk, based in Des Plaines, Ill., said it would not top Applied Graphics' cash bid of 90 pence for each share of Wace, a total of $:71.4 million and a 12.5 percent premium on the bid of 80 pence a share made by Schawk on March 17. Applied Graphics will also allow Wace preferred stockholders to convert their shares into common stock, a total of about $:39.2 million. The battle for control of Wace erupted after a $:41.7 million offer by Photobition Group P.L.C., Europe's biggest media support services company, was rejected in December.

title: Nonfighters In NATO Give Help For Raids
description: Iceland has no military. Luxembourg has no air force. Greece does not want to bomb a neighbor. And three other nations not contributing forces to the NATO air war against Serbia have been alliance members for only two weeks.

title: NATO's Attack On a Sovereign Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Clear Writing Can Challenge Status Quo; Food for Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, HERBERT
description: KLAPPER-Herbert. Goodbye to an old friend. Solace to the family. Sandy and Skip

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISTROFF, JANET
description: MISTROFF-Janet. March 25, 1999. Beloved lifetime companion of Thomas Epstein. She will be deeply missed by all of her family who loved her dearly. Memorial service Sunday, March 28, 1pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Dr. Kevorkian Is a Murderer, The Jury Finds
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who claims he has helped more than 130 people commit suicide, was convicted today of murder for giving a fatal injection to a man with a terminal illness.

title: U.S. Media Policy: Justify Air Assault But Skimp on Detail
description: In the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the military allies gave detailed briefings twice a day, in Washington and in Saudi Arabia, announcing the number of combat flights, targets hit and Iraqi troop movements.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE IN DEMAND. Coffee prices surged as roasters, expecting a smaller crop in Brazil, snapped up beans at prices near a three-year low. In New York, coffee for May delivery rose 5 cents, or 4.8 percent, to $1.092 a pound.

title: Defeat From Jaws of Victory
description: The semifinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here today at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals had an international flavor. Three of the four participating squads include European players who have won international titles.

title: Investigators Dig, But Fail to Find Body of a Boxer
description: With shovels, rakes and long metal probes, about two dozen investigators dug for several hours yesterday in the backyard of a house here after receiving a tip that the body of a Russian boxer who vanished from Brooklyn in 1995 was buried there.

title: Swiss Life Says Big Bank Has Sold Its 25% Stake
description: Swiss Life, the insurer, said yesterday that the 25 percent stake in the company held by the big Swiss bank UBS A.G., had been sold to more than 10 institutions, including Zuercher Kantonalbank, a regional bank that had reached a cooperative agreement with Swiss Life.

title: In the Presidential Race, Hopefuls Split Over Attacks
description: Republican Presidential hopefuls are deeply divided over whether the United States should play any role in Serbia, and most accused President Clinton of a misguided foreign policy that led to this country's entanglement there.

title: Rapper Is Arrested For 2d Time in a Week
description: The rap performer Russell Jones was arrested last night for at least the fourth time this year and the second time this week after a traffic stop in Harlem, the police said.

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Helping Robber Flee
description: A Princeton man pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to helping a bank robber flee the scene of his crime in exchange for $500, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, HAVEN
description: BLOOM-Haven. A friend and classmate for the past 9-1/2 years. You will always remain in our thoughts and hearts. Mariel Poole The Chapin School, Class 9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, ARTHUR
description: CHAPLIN-Arthur. Forget about it! You'll always be missed and loved. Sue and Bernie

title: Sharing Just Isn't Sprewell's Style
description: Latrell Sprewell was talking hoops last night, how it feels to dribble down the court and launch a jumper on a whim. This is called ''ballin'' on the playground, and the term is best reserved for those players who move at warp speed and have no conscience when they miss two, three, four shots in a row.

title: A Mess in Russia: 2 Views of Why; 'Transition' Is a Notion Rooted in U.S. Ego
description: With the Russian economy in disarray, people are trying to figure out what went wrong. Indeed, Russia's reaction this week to NATO's bombing of Serbia -- one hand raised in anger, the other out appealing for Western aid -- underscores how this onetime superpower's fortunes have changed.

title: Australia Approves Flu Medication for Sale
description: Biota Holdings Ltd., an Australian pharmaceuticals company, and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. said today that they had won approval to sell a new flu drug in Australia.

title: Setbacks in Drug Issues Send the Dow 14 Points Lower
description: Stocks fell yesterday as Merck & Company and the Warner-Lambert Company suffered setbacks on profitable drugs. The Oracle Corporation and other software companies limited the decline, gaining on speculation that investors had overreacted to concern about slowing sales of personal computers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Wen Ho Lee, a scientist who has been dismissed from Los Alamos National Laboratory for security breaches, misspelled the surname of the senior Democrat on the House committee investigating unauthorized transfers of military technology to China. He is Representative Norm Dicks of Washington, not Norm Dix.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAIO, PAUL (AKA PAUL MAYO)
description: DEMAIO-Paul (aka Paul Mayo) 93, born February 18, 1906 in New York City passed away on March 26, 1999. Paul was a resident of Freeport, NY and Dania, FL and is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Charlotte, Dania Beach, FL; son Charles, Carmel, IN; daughter Carlotta DeMaio Dillon, Chadds Fords, PA; sisters Catherine Campanale, Mary Magluilo, Josephine Salamone, all of NY; and brother Nicholas DeMaio, CA. Mr. DeMaio was founder and President of The Paul Mayo Riding Shop Inc. The Riding Shop located in Cold Spring Harbor, NY, enjoyed a worldwide reputation for providing the finest in equestrian riding products and services. In retirement, Mr. DeMaio put his energies into the Dania Library. Serving as President of the Friends of the Dania Library, he dedicated his later years to the campaign for ''Read a Book.'' ''Read a Book'' became the slogan of choice within the library community and is widely recognized within southern FL. He was instrumental in the development & expansion of the Dania Library, culminating in 1995 with the dedication of the new library. Visitation Sunday, March 28, 1999, 59PM, with a Funeral Service at 8PM at Panciera Memorial Home, in Hollywood, FL. Inurnment at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. In lieu of flowers family request donations can be made to Friends of the Dania Beach Library, 485 South Federal Highway, Dania Beach, Florida 33004.

title: President of Toys 'R' Us Quits Abruptly
description: Just a year after arriving at Toys ''R'' Us as second in command, Bruce W. Krysiak has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the beleaguered retailer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, ALFRED
description: WEIL-Alfred. A World War II Veteran and a member of the Masonic Lodge, died at his home in Riverdale, New York on March 24, 1999. Mr. Weil was born December 8, 1916 in Germany, and was predeceased by his wife Ruth Orlikoff Weil in 1981. He is survived by his sisters-in-law Mrs. Eva Dobrofsky, Mrs. Esther Keil, and Mrs. Doris Orlikoff; his Brother-in-law Horace Greenberg; his Nieces Lynne Arkin, Helene Christianson, Harriet Harris and Nephews Neal Dobrofsky, Gary Greenberg, Michael Orlikoff of California, Michael S. Orlikoff of Phoenix, AZ, and Steven Orlikoff of New York City. A graveside service will be at 2 PM Sunday, March 28 at Salem Fields Cemetery at the Kaufman-Rothschild Mausoleum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, S.
description: SCHILLER-S. Gary, 82, of Little Neck, NY, died 25 March, after a brief illness. Battle of Normandy survivor, awarded Purple Heart, active American Legion, Jewish War Veterans, Boy Scouts of America. In loving memory. Survived by wife, Teddi of Little Neck; son, Justin G. of Kingston, NY, and sister, Ethel Barasch of Las Vegas. Services 12 Noon on Sunday, 28 March, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY. (516) 921-5757; interment, Linden Hill Cemetery.

title: A Mess in Russia: 2 Views of Why; Communist Legacy Foreclosed Choices
description: With the Russian economy in disarray, people are trying to figure out what went wrong. Indeed, Russia's reaction this week to NATO's bombing of Serbia -- one hand raised in anger, the other out appealing for Western aid -- underscores how this onetime superpower's fortunes have changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, MIRIAM H., MD.
description: FIELD-Miriam H., MD. On March 25, 1999, of Walnut Creek, Ca. Born in 1904 in Suwalki, then Russia now Poland. The youngest child of Hirsch Lewinsohn, she was educated in Hamburg, Germany, immigrated in November 1938 to the U.S. Widow of John Hirschfeldt Field, she leaves a loving and devoted family: son Michael Field, MD, grandsons John, Ezra and Benjamin, daughter-in-law Linda Seidel (Field), two nieces Dr. Viera Gawze of Tel Aviv and Renee (Mrs. Gerhart) Neuhaus of San Francisco, along with numerous grand nieces and nephews in California and Israel. Service Sunday 12:15pm at the ''Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Av.

title: Abroad at Home; Mr. Milosevic's Campaign of Terror
description: For three days now, on Slobodan Milosevic's orders, Serbian policemen, soldiers and paramilitary thugs have been spreading terror across Kosovo. They have burned and shelled villages, driven thousands of ethnic Albanians from their homes and carried out dozens of assassinations.

title: Nissan Looms Large for Renault's 'Cost Killer'
description: Here is the question confronting Carlos Ghosn: Can his team of 40 French executives rescue a loss-plagued Japanese car company with 40,000 employees?

title: Aid to Environment, Or Threat to Lake?; Cornell Pursues Pumping Plan, But Critics Fear Fouled Water
description: It seems an environmentalist's dream: a system that can cool 10 million square feet of Cornell University dormitories, laboratories and computer rooms simply by pumping frigid water from the depths of a nearby lake. No more chlorofluorocarbons, the refrigerants that can destroy protective ozone in the atmosphere. An electric bill 80 percent smaller than for conventional air conditioners. To top it off, nothing goes back into the lake, except water that came from the lake in the first place.

title: Stricter Rules Are Urged On Use of a Diabetes Drug
description: Amid reports of deaths and serious liver damage caused by the diabetes drug Rezulin, a panel of scientific experts today recommended that the Government place stricter limits on the use of the drug, and urged that patients take it only when other therapies have failed.

title: NATO's Attack On a Sovereign Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: To Increase Their Chances, Spartans Plan to Go Slow
description: Michigan State has a plan. Reduce the 94-foot court to an 8-foot battle zone. Crowd the foul lanes at both ends of the floor with elbows spread. Contain the Duke sharpshooters and slow down the pace of the Final Four semifinal game at Tropicana Field.

title: Famed Computer Intruder Gets Prison Term
description: Kevin D. Mitnick pleaded guilty today to computer fraud and wire fraud in a plea agreement that will result in a sentence of 46 months.

title: ENRON AGREES TO BUY PHILIP SERVICES WATER UNIT
description: The Enron Corporation of Houston agreed yesterday to buy a water and sewer treatment business controlled by the Philip Services Corporation for $107 million in cash and $13 million in assumed debt to expand its Azurix water unit in North America. The business, Philip Utilities Management, operates water and sewer treatment systems in 18 cities in the United States and Canada, including Hamilton, Ontario, where Philip Services is based. Enron, an energy company, is evaluating about 20 water companies and municipal water systems to invest in or buy as it bids to become one of the largest water companies in the world.

title: ELITE POLICE UNIT IN DIALLO SLAYING GETS AN OVERHAUL
description: After weeks of protests over the combative police policies of the Giuliani administration, Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday unveiled major changes in the Street Crime Unit aimed at averting confrontations like that in which four white officers gunned down Amadou Diallo, an unarmed black man, last month.

title: Viacom Gives 3 Top Officers $104 Million in Stock Options
description: The media company Viacom Inc. gave its top three executives stock options together valued at about $104 million last year.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Duke Double' Stays Alive On 2 Coasts
description: A TEAM of women who barely get off the floor sent its athletic director and company flying high to the men's Final Four last night. The ''Duke Double'' is alive, and Joe Alleva will be back here for tomorrow's women's championship game against Purdue, whether his bladder can take it or not.

title: How a War Pulls Apart Every Life
description: With an eye for affectingly quotidian detail, Ziad Doueiri makes ''West Beirut'' a largely autobiographical account of war brewing in his native Lebanon, circa 1975. ''During the first years of the civil war, despite the anxiety that I could sense in my parents, I was incapable of feeling it myself,'' he has said about the events described here. ''I wasn't born with fear; I acquired it.'' His film described how that happened, step by step.

title: Legal Scholars Support Case for Using Force
description: The NATO attack on Yugoslavia skirts the edge of international law, legal experts say. But there are few meaningful sanctions that could be imposed under international law, and legal principles are vague enough to provide justification for the bombing as a humanitarian act.

title: Nassau Democratic Leader, Expected to Resign, Doesn't
description: Stephen J. Sabbeth, who was convicted of bankruptcy fraud earlier this month, has delayed his plans to step down as chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, frustrating efforts by both his supporters and opponents to reorganize in preparation for this fall's elections.

title: E-mail: Friendly or Alienating?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Race Relations, Look to Boston; Not Love but Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlikely Protesters: Diallo Case Draws Diverse Group
description: The plan was simple, an old-fashioned civil disobedience campaign to protest the Feb. 4 shooting death of Amadou Diallo. But when the Rev. Al Sharpton counted his troops early this month, he had only about 80 people willing to get arrested for the cause. They were mostly professional protesters, fist shakers, tried-and-true community advocates. Not exactly the stuff of front-page headlines.

title: Few Clear Lessons From Nation's First School-Choice Program
description: Nine years into the nation's first school-voucher program here, there is no question that the concept has taken hold. More than 6,000 poor children, 6 percent of the city's students, receive publicly financed vouchers of nearly $5,000 a year to attend private or parochial schools.

title: Clear Writing Can Challenge Status Quo; Whose Common Sense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Wholesaler May Close Many Units
description: The Nissho Iwai Corporation of Japan, an international wholesaler of everything from lumber to aircraft, said yesterday that it might cut the number of its subsidiaries almost in half, to 130, by shutting unprofitable units and combining others as it seeks to shore up its earnings.

title: Body of Third Missing Woman Is Found Along a Highway Leading to Yosemite
description: The sorrowful mystery of what happened to three tourists who disappeared from Yosemite National Park was in large part answered today when the authorities announced that a body found along a highway leading to the park was that of the last missing person.

title: A 1911 Inferno With a Lesson for Today
description: At first, passers-by thought they were seeing bundles of cloth being tossed into the street. It took them a few minutes to realize they were seeing women, their voluminous skirts billowing out as they leaped from eighth- and ninth-story windows, desperately trying to escape the fire behind them.

title: Ozaki Has Been Leader After 2 Rounds Before
description: Joe Ozaki is facing a familiar situation, but he is hoping for a different outcome.

title: Brazilian Police Question Man in Waldorf Killing
description: A man wanted for questioning in the death of a Brazilian economist killed in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria earlier this month has turned himself in to the police in Brazil, officials said yesterday.

title: Steinbrenner in Love: the Lost Manuscript
description: Excerpts from ''King George III,'' the newly discovered play penned by William Shakespeare.

title: Mexico Faulted on Drugs
description: Differing sharply with President Clinton, Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the Republican Speaker, said he did not think Mexico should be certified as a fully cooperative ally in fighting drugs. In an on-line chat with high school students, Mr. Hastert cited wide corruption and said, ''They haven't done their part as far as helping us stop drug trafficking.''

title: Corrections
description: Brief profiles in some editions yesterday of the four officers involved in the police shooting of Amadou Diallo included incorrect information from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office about the status of an investigation into an earlier shooting by one of the officers, Kenneth Boss. The case, involving the fatal shooting of Patrick Bailey on Oct. 31, 1997, remains open. Officer Boss has not been cleared.

title: It's Williams, and Then Williams Completes the Billing for the Final
description: Like twin juggernauts, the Williams siblings went for the jugular today in the women's semifinals at the Lipton Championships. Their mission was to create the sport's first sister versus sister finale in 115 years.

title: No Room for Nomo, but Mets May Not Be Done Maneuvering
description: The Mets' weeklong chess match with Hideo Nomo apparently reached its endgame today. Nomo accepted an assignment to the minor leagues, but then the Mets turned around and placed him on irrevocable waivers.

title: Duke and Purdue Make Their Way to Title Game
description: Duke's players and its coach seem bemused by the fuss and the abject surprise that have enveloped the team's captivating charge through the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: South Korea Sells Stake In State Power Company
description: South Korea sold a 4.3 percent stake in Korea Electric Power Corporation yesterday, raising at least $655 million in a crucial test of investor confidence in the nation's battered economy. The Government sold 54.61 million global depository receipts, which trade in the United States and Britain, for $12 each.

title: Nestle Earnings Rise 2.6%, Beating Analysts' Forecasts
description: Nestle S.A., the world's No. 1 foods maker, reported today that its profit rose 2.6 percent in 1998, beating most forecasts, as demand for products from Perrier mineral water to Alcon contact lens solution in the United States and Western Europe outweighed slumping income in Asia and Russia.

title: Officer Is Accused Of Drunken Driving And Van Is Seized
description: An off-duty police officer backed his Chevrolet van into a Queens liquor store, knocking down part of a wall and prompting the first confiscation of a vehicle from an officer accused of drunken driving, the police said yesterday.

title: Show Us the Money
description: Among the possible casualties of the furious budget bargaining in Albany is Gov. George Pataki's request for $28 million in new money to begin construction of the Hudson River Park in New York City. The Republican-controlled Senate knocked the appropriation out of its budget bill, in part because Mr. Pataki has spent only $4 million of $20 million approved last year, leaving a $16 million carryover. The Democrats in the Assembly approved $21 million of the $28 million request. When the Governor and the legislative leaders sit down to discuss differences, Mr. Pataki must insist, at the very least, on the Assembly's more generous figure.

title: Caroming Between Extremes, Social Scientists Can Overlook Reality
description: Are children harmed by divorce? So far the public debate has done more to confuse than enlighten, says Andrew Cherlin, the president of the Population Association of America. Here are excerpts from the presidential address he delivered yesterday at the group's annual meeting in New York City.

title: Sports of The Times; For 4 Teams, Reality Is Starting to Sink In: This Is the Weekend
description: SCOONIE PENN walked out on the court for practice yesterday afternoon and looked up at 27,662 fans who showed up for a midday workout session. Finally it all sunk in: this really was it.

title: Dr. Kevorkian's Luck Runs Out
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian sought to have a court of law determine whether euthanasia, or ''mercy killing,'' is a crime. He got an answer yesterday when a jury convicted him of second-degree murder and of delivering a controlled substance in the killing of Thomas Youk, a man suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease. There was no dispute on the facts. Dr. Kevorkian videotaped himself giving Mr. Youk a lethal injection of drugs, and then had the tape broadcast on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' last November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, JOHN L., M.D.
description: MADDEN-John L., M.D. March 25, 1999. Master surgeon, teacher, writer. Beloved husband of the late Bertie. Loving father of Pam, John, Brian, Michael, Tom, Kathy and grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, March 29, 4-8 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Tuesday, March 30, 10 a.m. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Daytop Village Foundation, 54 W. 40 St., New York, N.Y. 10108.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rallied against the euro as the air attacks by NATO against Serbian forces continued for a third day. The euro dropped to $1.0769 from $1.0826 on Thursday.

title: Methodist Minister Is Convicted of Breaking Church Law With Gay Rite
description: A United Methodist Church minister in Chicago was suspended after being found guilty yesterday of breaking church law by having blessed the union of two gay men, in an ecclesiastical trial that drew national attention to an increasingly controversial issue among many Protestants.

title: CHUBB BUYS STAKE IN BRITISH INSURANCE COMPANY
description: The Chubb Corporation said yesterday that its Federal Insurance Company unit had acquired 28 percent of Hiscox P.L.C., a British specialty insurance group, for $:89.9 million ($146 million). Chubb, an insurance holding company based in Warren, N.J., with assets of more than $20 billion, said it bought the shares from Trident Partnership L.P., a Bermuda insurance investment fund.

title: Market Grows For U.S. Cars From Canada
description: American entrepreneurs have been buying tens of thousands of vehicles cheaply at Canadian dealerships and reselling them in the United States, making substantial profits and in the process sidestepping American fuel-economy rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MARJORIE H. (NEE MARJORIE SYLVIA HILLSON)
description: ROSENBERG-Marjorie H. (nee Marjorie Sylvia Hillson), on March 15, 1999, age 82 years. Early years in Boston area, 55 years Larchmont, NY, relocated to Columbus, Ohio, November 1998. Predeceased last month by her husband of 57 years, internationally renowned scientist, Paul Rosenberg, Ph.D. Predeceased by younger brother, Raymond Hillson. Survived by Columbus residents, daughter, Gale R. Gross; son-inlaw, William F. Gross; grandson, Joshua Samuel Gross. Boston University librarian/administrator, husband's firm 50 years. Prolific reader, eclectic interests in literature, arts, music, politics. Volunteer, extensive professional/social contacts. Funeral service Sunday, 1 PM, at the Ballard Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Family requests donations only to Smith College, Development Office, c/o Jan, Northampton, MA 01063, or Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY 10538.

title: Adm. William Floyd Bringle, 85, Naval Air Commander in 2 Wars
description: Adm. William Floyd Bringle, a highly decorated aviator who commanded naval air forces in Europe and the Pacific in World War II, died on March 19 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in San Diego. He was 85 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: On Race Relations, Look to Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: How Fooling Around Turned Unfunny
description: As Monica Lewinsky's self-justifying confessional gets knocked from the No. 1 spot on the best-seller list, more than a scandal is winding down. Along with the loss of Presidential dignity and personal privacy, the Lewinsky affair may spell the end of a noble genre: the adultery comedy.

title: Who Will Crack First?
description: The allied military strategy for stopping Serbian attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo rests largely on the hope that Serbian military commanders will seek an end to the intense NATO bombing before it destroys their army and air defenses.

title: Clear Writing Can Challenge Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, JOHN ''JACK'' PAUL WATSON
description: WATSON-John ''Jack'' Paul Watson, 54, of Avon, CT., husband of Valerie (Dawson) Watson, died Wednesday, March 24, 1999, at his home. He was the Corporate VicePresident and Group Executive of the Danaher Corp. in Simsbury, CT. Besides his wife he is survived by his daughter Laura, son Timothy and brother Tom of Wayne, PA. Memorial Service will be Saturday, April 17, at 3:00 p.m., in Christ Church, 35 Harris Rd, Avon. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Liver Foundation, PO Box 4062, Woodbridge, CT, 06525

title: Michigan Rallies to Beat Denver
description: Michigan overcame a dreadful first period last night against Denver to avoid elimination from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Worcester, Mass.

title: A Tumble Puts Kwan In Fourth At Worlds
description: The day after Aleksei Yagudin leaned over and kissed the ice after flirting with perfection, Michelle Kwan skidded across the ice after falling during her double axel.

title: F.A.A. Creates Airline No-Flight Zone Around the Fighting
description: Shortly before 3 P.M. on Wednesday, the same afternoon that NATO warplanes and missiles attacked Yugoslavia, the Federal Aviation Administration barred United States airlines from flying over the fighting zone.

title: A Child's Nightmare Reality
description: The French director Sandrine Veysset has a special gift for envisioning the world through the eyes of a child. Her first film, ''Will It Snow for Christmas?,'' an examination of the Spartan life of a French farming family, found everyday magic in children's outdoor games and in the mystique of snow and holiday preparations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, BEVERLY
description: HAAS-Beverly. Congregation Ohr Torah and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of its beloved member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Mordekai Shapiro, Rabbi Jerald C. Newman, President Leonard S. Epstein, Exec VP

title: NATO LAUNCHES DAYTIME STRIKE; MILOSEVIC RESISTING FIERCELY; TWO SERB JETS ARE SHOT DOWN
description: NATO forces stepped up their air and missile assault into the daylight hours as President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia maintained fierce resistance today both on the ground and in the air. Two of his MIG-29 fighters were shot down while on what NATO claimed was a foray into neighboring Bosnia. The status of the pilots was unknown.

title: COSMETIC CENTER TO CLOSE 116 STORES
description: Cosmetic Center Inc. said yesterday that to reduce operating costs it would close 116 of its perfume and cosmetics stores, almost half of the total number, and dismiss 875 workers. The company, based in Columbia, Md., plans to get out of the Chicago and North Carolina markets and to close all but one store in Philadelphia. In December, Revlon Inc., the biggest maker of mass market cosmetics in the United States, sold its 85 percent stake in Cosmetic Center, taking a loss of $32.7 million on the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELEANOR
description: SCHWARTZ-Eleanor. Age 78. Of Pearl River, New York. Died peacefully on Thursday, March 25, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Nathaniel. Devoted mother of Harriett and Jay Glassman and Susan and Kenneth White. Adoring grandmother of Miriam and David Rukeyser, Juliane Glassman and Max White. Loving great grandmother of Emily and Sara Rukeyser. Other survivors include Dr. Abraham and Beatrice Gitlow, Yvette and Louis Tekel and Lawrence Gitlow. Services to be held Sunday, March 28th, 1PM at Hellman's Memorial Chapel, Spring Valley, N.Y. Donations may be made to the Rockland County Jewish Home for the Aged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, RALPH., MD.
description: GOLDIN-Ralph., MD. On March 24, 1999. Jacobi Medical Center mourns the passing of one of our esteemed attending physicians and one of the founding members of the Jacobi Dept. of Radiology. He was responsible for training a generation of doctors who will remember him as an excellent physician, teacher and mentor. He will be fondly remembered by his colleagues for his calm, professional demeanor as well as his superior clinical skills and diagnostic expertise. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. North Bronx Healthcare Network Jacobi Medical Center North Central Bronx Hospital

title: U.S. to Back The Censure Of Beijing Over Rights
description: The Administration announced today that it would sponsor a United Nations resolution next month condemning Beijing for what the resolution calls the wholesale violation of human rights.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Circling the Globe
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Thursday about a diamond necklace that the producer Bruce Paltrow bought for his daugther, the actress Gwyneth Paltrow, misstated the weight of its 40 diamonds. It is about a quarter of an ounce, not 43.88615 ounces (or almost one-third the weight of an Oscar).

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Serbia's expulsion of some foreign reporters misstated the nationality of Peter Finn, a correspondent for The Washington Post who was detained by the police and then expelled. While he is expected to have United States citizenship by next week, he is an Irish citizen, not an American.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the News Watch column in Circuits on Thursday misstated the given name of the chief executive of Food.com and described his history at the company incorrectly. He is Rich Frank, not Robert. He joined the company in 1998, when it was called Cybermeals.com; he was not a founder of it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column of the House & Home section on Thursday about art on display during Asia Week misspelled the Buddhist term for a person who has attained enlightenment. It is bodhisattva, not bohdissattva.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Seeks Censure of China

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIEL, HARRY AHARON
description: ARIEL-Harry Aharon, on 9th of Nisan, 5759. Beloved father, devoted husband, cherished uncle and brother, and sharing friend. A gifted engineer and modest individual, he was admired by all who knew him. As a former soldier who fought in the battle for Israel's independence, he remained a steadfast supporter of Eretz Yisroel, Torat Yisroel and Am Yisroel. Kevurah on Har Hazeitim. Upon return from Israel, shiva to be observed at family residence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOW, CLAIRE SONDHEIM
description: DAVIDOW-Claire Sondheim. A native of Reading, PA., where she was born March 4, 1908, passed away peacefully at her residence in San Mateo, CA March 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leonard S. Davidow whom she married November 12, 1931. Loving mother of Ann Hayes of Boulder, CO. and William Davidow of Woodside, CA. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Goodman and Carolyn Putney of Menlo Park, CA., Thomas Goodman of Foster City, CA and Rebecca Logan of Woodside, CA. Daughter of the late Edith and Leo Sondheim of Reading, PA. Dear sister of Rita Blumstein of Philadelphia, PA. Also survived by Margaret & Henry Rodkin of Chicago, Il. Mrs Davidow served on the National Board of the Girl Scouts of the USA for 16 years. Served as president of OUR CABANA, an International Friendship Center for Girl Guides and Girl Scouts in Cuernavaca, Mexico for nine years. Member of the Olave Baden-Powell Society and the Women's Board of the University of Chicago. Memorial Services will be private. Memorials to the Girl Scouts of the USA, 420 5th Ave, New York, New York 10018, Chicago Botanic Garden, 1000 Lake Cooke Rd, Glencoe, Il 60022.

title: No-Frills 'Follies' Still Has Songs and Legs
description: A warm laugh rises from the audience when, in the finale of ''Ziegfeld Follies of 1936,'' Howard McGillin steps forward and sings: ''We're not explaining the plot/You cannot explain what's not.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKLER, MORTIMER
description: STECKLER-Mortimer, the most gentle of men. Devoted husband of Selda, loving father of son Steven and daughter Amy Fox, caring father-in-law of Sharon Steckler and Daniel Fox, adoring grandfather of Adam, Leigh and Noah. Funeral services Sunday, March 28th, at 2 PM at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY.

title: For Cubans, Wood Bats Mean More Sting (and Less Ping)
description: When the Cuban hitters face Scott Erickson on Sunday, it could seem like New York on an April night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROSS, CHARLIE M.
description: MOROSS-Charlie M. We will sorely miss you, just as will all your friends in the theater. Cheryl and Bill Harriette and Mel

title: U.S. and Russia Sign Uranium Sales Deal
description: Russia and the United States have quietly signed an agreement that salvages a $12 billion deal aimed at helping Russia convert uranium from its nuclear weapons into fuel for American nuclear reactors, Administration officials said today.

title: An Assertive Start for New Labor Chief
description: He has been the head of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. for less than a week, but Denis M. Hughes is already planning an offensive against Gov. George E. Pataki's budget.

title: Defense Disputes Cause of Louima's Injuries
description: The lawyer for a New York City police officer charged with torturing Abner Louima in a Brooklyn police station says that medical experts will testify for the defense that Mr. Louima's injuries could not have been inflicted in the way the prosecution has charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORPER, HAZEL PRIEST
description: KORPER-Hazel Priest, 87, wife of the late George W. Korper, Jr., died peacefully at home on Wednesday, March 24. She was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Priest of Providence and Narragansett, Rhode Island. Mrs. Korper was graduated from Lincoln School, Providence, and National Seminary, Washington, D.C. Hazel Priest Korper, along with others, was instrumental in founding the American Society of Interior Designers in 1975, where she remained a board member for many years. She was active in Hospice in Connecticut and in promoting barrier-free design for the handicapped. She is survived by her sons, Samuel Priest Korper, Ph.D., and George W. Korper III, four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Nantucket, Massachusetts papers, please copy.

title: Republicans' Resolve in Rallying Around Budget Sets Up Tougher Tests
description: Republican leaders in Congress took care of the easy part of this year's budget battle in passing their tax and spending plan on Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Concern About Drug Issues Sends Stock Market Lower

title: Duke, Purdue Reach Women's Title Game
description: There was no letdown for the Duke women's basketball team last night, just four days after its exhilarating victory over the three-time defending champion, Tennessee. Rather, the Blue Devils maintained their emotional pitch and strong play and reached college basketball's title game with an 81-69 victory over Georgia in San Jose, Calif.

title: Arthur Raymond, DC-3 Maker, Dies at 99
description: Arthur E. Raymond, whose career spanned the years between biplanes and the first lunar landing but who was best known for leading the team that designed the DC-3, one of commercial aviation's most durable workhorses, died on Monday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was two days short of his 100th birthday.

title: Yugoslavia Selling to Iraq Under a U.N. Aid Program
description: At the time when the Clinton Administration has been searching for ways to squeeze the President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, it has given up an economic weapon, allowing him to do business with Saddam Hussein, according to United Nations documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORTON, CLIFFORD (BOBBY)
description: HORTON-Clifford (Bobby). 48. Died at home of congestive heart failure on February 14. Bobby was known for his ''joie de vivre''. He loved making people smile and could always be found at Christmas playing Santa Claus for needy children. For the past ten years, he organized and funded a profuse gift giving campaign at Christmas for New York's underprivileged children. Bobby was the head of the patternmaking department at Tyme Design. Bobby is survived by his wife, Patricia, and son, Kenny. His family, many friends and colleagues will all miss him dearly. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Art That Reached Out and Tweaked History
description: Art, it has been said, ''remains the one way possible of speaking truth'' (Robert Browning); ''has as much reason for being as the earth and the sun'' (Ralph Waldo Emerson); ''hath an enemy named Ignorance'' (Ben Jonson); ''makes life, makes interest, makes importance'' (Henry James); ''comes to you proposing frankly to give nothing but the highest quality to your moments'' (Walter Pater).

title: Holocaust Remembrance
description: Oral history and therapy, chamber music and rock mingle in ''The Past Is Present,'' by Jeffrey Schanzer, a self-described ''multimedia cantata'' that had its premiere at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street in Chelsea) on Thursday night and is to be performed there through tonight. It is a Holocaust remembrance based on the accounts of Mr. Schanzer's mother and cousin, Jews in Poland who survived World War II, and on his own memories and reactions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUSTEIN, HAROLD J.
description: HEUSTEIN-Harold J. March 26, 1999, of New York, Nantucket & Palm Beach. Cherished husband and partner in adventure of Judi, devoted son-in-law of Lucille Baumgarten, cherished brother of Barbara Leibowits, admired uncle, dear cousin of Judith Kotkin, best buddy of Petruchio. Founder and President of Woodworks Construction Company, Inc. Services on Nantucket, Monday March 29. Memorial service in N.Y. to be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANEY, PETER PAUL
description: YANEY-Peter Paul. After a short illness. Beloved husband of Marion Vincent Yaney and father of Dr. Gordon Yaney and Paula Yaney Gambill. Grandfather of Jane Vincent Gambill and Abigail Katharine Yaney. An honorable and committed man. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Saturday, 2-5 PM. Funeral service on Sunday at 12 noon at Christ Episcopal Church, Manhasset, with interment to follow in the churchyard

title: Schools Turn Kosovo Into Civics Lesson
description: In schools around the country, a complicated lesson in geopolitics has suddenly sprung from the textbook onto the television screen. And like many of their parents, students are struggling to make sense of it.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: FAST WORLD: A MANIFESTO
description: For the new globalism to work, America can't be afraid to act like the almighty superpower that it is. A report by Thomas L. Friedman, in The Times Magazine.

title: MILLER FREEMAN ANNOUNCES AN ACQUISITION
description: Miller Freeman Inc., a producer of trade shows and publisher of technical and industry-specific magazines, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Continuing Medical Education Inc., the publisher of the trade magazines Psychiatric Times and Medicine & Behavior, for $111 million in cash. Miller Freeman, a New York-based unit of United News and Media P.L.C. of London, said it would integrate the company into its San Francisco-based Healthcare Communications Group, but that it would retain its headquarters in Irvine, Calif.

title: E-mail: Friendly or Alienating?
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Chance Seen That Fed Will Lift Rates
description: The Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday, but the central bank remains wary of resurgent inflation because of the economy's continued strength, analysts say.

title: CBS-King World Talks Are Reported
description: CBS has been in preliminary discussions to acquire King World Productions, the syndicator of such hit shows as ''Oprah'' and ''Wheel of Fortune,'' executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, JUDGE IRVING
description: TENENBAUM-Judge Irving. At the age of 90. Often sighted as Dean of Magistrates and confidant to judges and lawyers. Passed away peacefully at home after a long illness. Beloved husband of Hannah, devoted father of Kenneth, loving brother of Samuel. Services Sunday 12:30pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plz, Great Neck.

title: It's No Mirage as Knicks End Losing Streak
description: A player was singing a rap song behind a wall of showers, a tune that filtered into the locker room. Chris Childs was playfully flipping an aerosol can across the room to a teammate, and Patrick Ewing was pulling his T-shirt over his head as he joked with someone walking by.

title: Social Security Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Interviews Chinese Man in Spy Case
description: The F.B.I. has found and questioned a Chinese researcher in connection with the inquiry into China's suspected theft of American nuclear secrets from the Los Alamos National Laboratory, Government officials said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Torre Visits Clubhouse 8 Days After Cancer Surgery
description: Just eight days after undergoing surgery to remove his cancerous prostate, Manager Joe Torre showed up in the Yankees' clubhouse today, assuring his players in a closed-door meeting that he is on the way to a full recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDEN, DEANNA
description: JORDEN-Deanna. It was with great sadness that our office learned of the passing of one of the most compassionate people. Deanna was a woman who never questioned the work her boards and owners requested of her and did it with great pride and joy. It is a rare pleasure when an employer can count on such dedication from an employee. Deanna planned to be with our family for the long haul, giving 110% of herself to the job, the people she worked for and mostly the people she worked with. A listing of names of the persons who will miss this sweet soul would span this entire paper, from her tenants to her superintendents to her contractors...from Norman Buchbinder & Eugene Warren to all of her co-workers and their families. An empty desk sits looking out at Union Square today. A desk that has been filled with thirteen years of wonderful memories from a wonderful person. We love you and we'll miss you forever. All of us at Buchbinder & Warren

title: In Parables, a Harsh Beauty
description: Mojtaba Raei's mystical meditation, ''Birth of a Butterfly,'' was filmed in the mountains of northwestern Iran, where the people's elemental relationship with nature is colored by an intense spiritual faith. Consisting of three parables in which that faith is tested, the movie suggests that Christianity and Western culture have no monopoly on turning out religious kitsch. Although ''Birth of a Butterfly'' is comparatively restrained and tasteful as these things go, it imitates the Hollywood technique of using gushy music to underscore moments of revelation.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Web Problems At Trading Firm
description: Waterhouse Investor Services Inc. shut off its Web trading service for almost two hours at the start of trading yesterday because of a data-processing disruption.

title: Barclays Is Selling Unit
description: The British bank Barclays P.L.C. said on Thursday that it would sell Merck Finck & Company, a private German bank, to Kredietbank S.A. Luxembourgeoise for 500 million marks ($278 million) as of April 1 because it no longer fits its strategy. Barclays said it would take a charge of $:140 million pounds ($230 million).

title: Toll Rises to 35 in Mont Blanc Tunnel Fire
description: French and Italian officials said today that at least 35 people had died in a fire that erupted Wednesday deep inside the Mont Blanc tunnel in the Alps. The blaze, which began in a heavy truck and quickly engulfed some 30 other vehicles, was finally brought under control this afternoon.

title: RENT-A-CENTER WARNS OF POSSIBLE DEBT PROBLEMS
description: Rent-a-Center Inc., which rents appliances, furniture and electronics with an option to buy, said in its annual report that it may have trouble meeting debt obligations after its acquisition of Thorn P.L.C.'s United States rental business. The company, which is based in Plano, Tex., said that as of the end of 1998 it owed about $805.7 million under debt agreements. The news was first reported in The Wall Street Journal. Yesterday, Rent-a-Center shares fell 81.25 cents, to $28.625. Rent-a-Center acquired the Thorn unit last August for about $900 million in cash, including the repayment of certain Thorn debt.

title: Apathy About Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Only the Few Benefit From Charter Schools
description: Re: ''Chilling Facts About Charter Schools'' [Opinion, March 21]: New York State's charter school law means yet another victory for freedom and personal self-interest and another loss for equality and commitment to public good. It comes as no surprise. After all, it's a lot easier to pull one's own child from a low-performing school than it is to use the democratic process to improve that school for all children. It's easier still to blame bureacracy and red tape than it is to face up to the fact that one never really cared about educating the other children anyway. Make no mistake, the charter school rationale is not to improve educational opportunity. It's a politically motivated ploy to make some people feel as if they have freedom.

title: Dishes That Brighten Passover and Easter
description: PASSOVER and Easter fall close together this year -- and when it comes to appropriate dishes for those holidays, there can also be a certain degree of overlap.

title: Trolling 'Low' Culture For High-Flying Ideas: A Sport of Intellectuals
description: IN the mid-1950's, the literary critic Roland Barthes described some of the quirky French wrestlers who were then attracting attention: one had ''an obese and sagging body'' and an ''asexual hideousness''; another was ''short and arrogant like a cock''; a third possessed an ''arrogant and ridiculous character.'' But Barthes was not interested in just describing these bizarrely costumed musclemen. When he looked at wrestlers throwing each other out of the ring or torturing each other in excruciating holds that inspired grotesque grimaces, he saw figures out of Racine and Moliere. He saw the gods of Greek drama. He compared wrestling to a ''triumphant classical art'' offering an ''ideal understanding of things.''

title: Duval, a Stroke Ahead, Survives a Torture Test
description: Nothing came easy today at the Players Championship. Not for David Duval, who lost a four-stroke lead, before he regrouped to lead by just one. Not for the 14 players who shot 80 or worse. Not for Joe Ozaki, who started the day with a one-stroke lead, but who shot an 81 and finished the day six strokes behind Duval.

title: But Enough About You . . .
description: INTIMACY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, MIRIAM H., MD.
description: FIELD-Miriam H., MD. On March 25, 1999, of Walnut Creek, Ca. Born in 1904 in Suwalki, then Russia now Poland. The youngest child of Hirsch Lewinsohn, she was educated in Hamburg, Germany, immigrated in November 1938 to the U.S. Widow of John Hirschfeldt Field, she leaves a loving and devoted family: son Michael Field, MD, grandsons John, Ezra and Benjamin, daughter-in-law Linda Seidel (Field), two nieces Dr. Viera Gawze of Tel Aviv and Renee (Mrs. Gerhart) Neuhaus of San Francisco, along with numerous grand nieces and nephews in California and Israel. Service Sunday 12:15pm at the ''Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Av.

title: It's No Fun Being Normal
description: SURVIVAL RATES

title: March 21-27; For Detained Pinochet, A Partial Victory
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet's desire to end his house arrest in England and return home to Chile got a boost when England's highest court threw out the bulk of the charges that could be used in the Spanish effort to extradite him to Madrid to stand trial for crimes against humanity.

title: All Should Be Tested For a Popular Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton's Hard Lesson On Picking School Chief
description: Given the rich literary heritage here, just say the long day's journey into night is over -- for now.

title: Japanese Stocks Look Better From Afar
description: NEVER mind that unemployment is rising, consumer spending and capital investment continue to decline and only Government officials are willing to express confidence that the economy here will show growth in the fiscal year that begins this week.

title: Elizabeth Sims, Michael Steinberg
description: Elizabeth Sarah Sims, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sims of East Rockaway, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Saren Steinberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice D. Steinberg of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Stuart Geller officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNBACK, LEWIS
description: BROWNBACK-Lewis. 35. His death on March 26, 1999 at Cabrini Hospital has left us all bereft. Known for his unerring taste, determination and loyalty as well as his kindness, playfulness and loving nature. Lewis was insistent in his individuality and in his certainty of purpose. Associated with the Emporium Antique Shop, Ltd., his talent and individuality have given us all inspiration. We love you, will always love you, and you will be missed. Until we meet again.

title: On the Road 2000
description: Here is the latest crop of packages and tours planned to mark Jan. 1, 2000. Prices are per person, double occupancy, unless otherwise noted; prospective travelers should inquire carefully about deposit and refund policies.

title: What Rock Could Learn From the W.W.F.
description: ONE of the most telling moments in modern professional wrestling came during Wrestlemania XIV, last year's World Wrestling Federation event that featured not only Mike Tyson in the ring but also Gennifer Flowers. (''Everyone likes Gennifer Flowers,'' commented the announcer on her role as a timekeeper.)

title: The Cost of Educating a Pupil Varies Widely Among School Districts
description: What does $14,000 per student buy in New Jersey's public schools?

title: Butyrskaya Dethrones Kwan at World Championships
description: Michelle Kwan will soon reassume control of her own destiny as she sorts through what many an 18-year-old American sorts through when winter turns to spring: university acceptance letters.

title: Paper Mill Playhouse Needs New Director
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Beth Walsh And Jon Morales
description: Mary Elizabeth Walsh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Walsh of Key Colony Beach, Fla., was married on Friday to Jon Donald Morales, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Morales of Fairport, N.Y. The Rev. Randolph Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Monitor of the Olympic Mettle
description: DAVID D'ALESSANDRO is not a typical insurance executive. Known for his jazzy ties, he once startled his sales force with a videotape of himself and top aides pirouetting in ballet tights. ''We wanted to get their attention,'' he said.

title: Who Holds The Deed to Stock Data?
description: AT 24 seconds after 12:16 P.M. last Thursday, 75,000 shares of Lucent Technologies sold on the New York Stock Exchange for $101 apiece.

title: Having Invoked The Power of Fate, An Opera Feels It
description: LAST month, after an absence of 20 years, ''La Forza del Destino'' returned to La Scala, where in 1869 Verdi introduced the opera in its significantly revised, definitive form. For much of this century -- from the late 20's to the mid-60's -- audiences in Milan could count on two revivals per decade; in the 40's alone, there were four. But even as the consensus of informed opinion has been advancing the reputation of the composer's lesser as well as his greatest works, the challenge of realizing some of them in performance has grown all but insurmountable.

title: SOAPBOX; All Aboard
description: IT was the conductors who dubbed us the Gang of Five. I know this because someone got on ahead of me at the Edison train platform and tried to sit in our cluster of facing seats. I heard the conductor tell her, ''Sorry, Ma'am, those are reserved for the Gang of Five.'' When I saw the mixture of fear and consternation on her face, I knew the name would stick.

title: Out With It!
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Rankings
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF CLASS IN BRITAIN

title: How Mega Can a Mall Be?; Roosevelt Field, 3.3 Million Square Feet, Wants to Expand. Some Think It's Too Big Already.
description: THE shopping center that began in the 1950's with a few freestanding stores on a nearly vacant suburban plain and mushroomed into Long Island's largest mall has hit a wall of protest on its way to the 21st century.

title: The Human Habitat
description: I read Pollan's article with interest. As an interior designer, I find that people come to me for all sorts of reasons -- some for the art, some for the snobbery, some out of sheer desperation. Whatever the reason, I have one credo: bring me your tired tchotchkes yearning to be free. It is these mementos that make each project a statement for the individual: I do want my art ''haunted'' by my client's past. That's the point.

title: After the Avalanches, Europe Skis Into Spring
description: BOTH skiers and ski resort operators in the Alps live for snow, but some of the heaviest snowfalls this century turned deadly this winter, setting off a series of avalanches in February.

title: New Fast-Spreading Virus Takes the Internet by Storm
description: A rapidly spreading computer virus forced several large corporations to shut down their E-mail servers on Friday night as it rode the Internet on a global rampage, several leading network security companies reported today.

title: Lucienne Bloch, Muralist, Is Dead at 90
description: Lucienne Bloch, an acclaimed muralist whose most significant contribution to art may have been a series of surreptitious photographs she took in 1933, died on March 13 at her home in Gualala, Calif. She was 90.

title: The Human Habitat
description: 'The Human Habitat'' (March 7) was one of your best issues, and Michael Pollan's article, ''The Real World of Interiors,'' struck a particular chord in me, one of several thousand people who lost everything in the 1991 Oakland firestorm. Over the three years it took me to rebuild, I visited a number of houses that looked as if a decorator had just walked out the door. Like Michael Pollan, I, too, felt that living ''under (or up to)'' such designs ''was not going to be easy.''

title: A Rock in a Hard Place?
description: Barbara Waite and several of her neighbors on Daniel Low Terrace and on Belmont Place say they are worried about the construction of 24 new homes nearby. The reason? Something called serpentine rock, a kind of rock that contains asbestos and lies within a 17-square-mile oval area from St. George in northern Staten Island to New Springville in the middle of the borough. The fear is that the construction may release asbestos into the air.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: IN PLATO'S CAVE

title: The Human Habitat
description: Now that was a home-design issue! The myriad ways of creating one's own sense of place illustrated a beautiful Moroccan proverb: ''The first thing one should own is a home; and it is the last thing one should sell, for a home is one's tomb this side of heaven.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, JOHN L., M.D.
description: MADDEN-John L., M.D. March 25, 1999. Master surgeon, teacher, writer. Beloved husband of the late Bertie. Loving father of Pam, John, Brian, Michael, Tom, Kathy and grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, March 29, 4-8 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Tuesday, March 30, 10 a.m. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Daytop Village Foundation, 54 W. 40 St., New York, N.Y. 10108.

title: Orchids, Wine And Asian Art
All About France On a Telephone Line
description: If you are planning a trip to France and have a question about a historic site, an art exhibition, a music festival, transportation, or a place to eat or stay, there will be a new number to call starting Thursday: (410) 286-8310.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 28, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Liberties; Broken Bones
description: My father shot a man to death once.

title: Kathleen Bartlett, C. J. Schneider
description: Kathleen Kerry Bartlett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bartlett of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday at Christ Church to Lieut. Christopher James Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Schneider of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Charles Rush performed the United Church of Christ ceremony. The Rev. Peter Sella, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Can't Get There From Here Without These
description: Prince Henry the Navigator may not have needed to buy one, but most voyagers must. A map, that is. Now, an array of the indispensable travel companions can be found in lower Manhattan's week-old Hagstrom Map and Travel Center at 125 Maiden Lane (at Water Street).

title: Depression Drugs Outperform Placebos; Why Refuse Help?
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Authorities Grow More Aggressive in Examining Police Nationwide
description: The widening Federal investigation of the New York Police Department is one of at least 10 examinations of police and sheriff's departments across the country by Government prosecutors looking for patterns of brutality, civil rights violations and other misconduct.

title: Market Makeover
description: KAPITALIZM

title: Tuberculosis Cases Drop To a Low in the 90's
description: The number of people with active tuberculosis in New Jersey dropped to 640 last year, the lowest number this decade, after a peak of 984 active cases in 1992, said Dennis McGowan, spokesman for the state Department of Health and Senior Services. There were 718 cases in 1997.

title: Master of Her Cub Den at 82
description: Forty years of Brooklyn boyhood are captured where you would hardly expect them: in an 82-year-old golden-haired great-grandmother. On a recent Saturday morning, Ann Mannix, the Cubmaster of Cub Scout Pack 22, bustled around what she called the lyceum -- she quickly corrected herself to ''youth center'' -- and its adjoining office at St. Francis Xavier Church on Sixth Avenue.

title: Strawberry Is Pushing To Get in Playing Shape
description: From the moment Darryl Strawberry stepped onto the field at Jack Russell Stadium today, he clearly attracted the most fan attention among the Yankees. Never mind that Bernie Williams made this trip, as did Derek Jeter and Paul O'Neill.

title: A Zoo in Peril Stirs a Debate About Navajo Traditions
description: A spring sandstorm whipping into the Navajo Nation's zoo does not ruffle Yogi, a 475-pound bear sedated and sprawled on the ground for his annual checkup. Scott Bender, a veterinarian, stoops to listen to the animal's heart, using a stethoscope with tubes wrapped in delicate Navajo beadwork. A dozen zoo workers and visiting children, most of them Navajos, watch intently from outside the bear's enclosure, and Dr. Bender improvises a bear anatomy lesson.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHACTER, CHARLES BANKS
description: SHACTER-Charles Banks Remembering precious husband and Dad at birthday time with love. Jean-Carol-Family

title: Device That Can Aid Cardiac Arrest Victims
description: ADELE LANGER of Rye had no history of heart problems when she collapsed after getting off her boat in June 1997. She was in luck. There was a defibrillator in the police car that responded from Port Chester, one of the first communities to equip police cars with the device. Within 90 seconds, she was getting cardiopulmonary resuscitation and defibrillation.

title: Orioles Will Be Taking a Look At the Best Cuba Has to Offer
description: Omar Linares is the best-known member of the Cuban national team that will play the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday, and deservedly so. But Yobal Duenas may be the one player the Orioles want to watch and remember.

title: Bookend; Is Franz Bibfeldt for Real? Yes and No
description: It is 1999, and time to reconsider the work of Franz Bibfeldt. Bibfeldt slouched into my life in the summer of 1997. I had just published a long, tedious, yet superficial essay for The Atlantic Monthly on the Year Zero, or rather the lack of same, in the mathematically challenged Christian calendar. This anomaly makes it difficult to reckon years from B.C. to A.D., and impossible to determine whether the new millennium begins in 2000 or 2001. In July a letter arrived, smelling faintly of petits fours and scrod -- it having been forwarded from The Atlantic's Boston offices -- from a Colleen Cullinan, a student at the University of Chicago Divinity School, who expressed her disappointment that I had neglected to mention the contributions of Bibfeldt, the eminent neosyllogistic existential theologian.

title: Joanne Street, Kenneth Orce Jr.
description: Joanne Elizabeth Street, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Street of Melbourne, Australia, was married on Friday to Kenneth William Orce Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Orce Sr. of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. I. R. Carter officiated at Trinity Uniting Episcopal Church in Melbourne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DOUGLASS G.
description: WILLIAMS-Douglass G. Died March 19, 1999 at his home in Neptune Beach, FL. He is survived by his wife Joyce, two children and five grandchildren. His burial will be at a National Cemetery in New York State. He graduated from Indiana University with a degree in fine arts and worked for American Federation of Arts in New York City and the William Cook Advertising agency in Florida.

title: A Career Explaining Dead to the Living
description: FOR the Nassau County Medical Examiner, Dr. Leslie Lukash, working with the dead is just as important as working with the living.

title: Ideas & Trends: Uncle Sam in Televisionland; Lessons Not Quite Ready for Prime Time
description: IF some adults doubt how difficult it is to deliver educational messages to children through television, they should have attended a recent conference here on creating positive programming. Some children, ages 11 to 14, were asked if they watched Jerry Springer. They all said yes. Asked if the show was staged, these young viewers, wise to the ways of manipulation, said yes again, with several adding that the staging increased the thrills.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: VITTORIO, THE VAMPIRE

title: Upper West Side Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/West End Avenue; A Baritone's Rental Solo
description: IF you're the Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard, who spends more than six months a year traveling around the world, performing and teaching, even the best hotels begin to lose their charm. ''I don't like to sing in a hotel,'' he says. ''I feel limited, closed in.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; No Irish Need Return
description: In MORE BREAD OR I'LL APPEAR (Houghton Mifflin, $23), her sharp-witted novel about an Irish family struggling to stay connected despite geographical and emotional distance, Emer Martin traces a young woman's globe-trotting quest to find her long-lost older sister. Fourteen years earlier, Aisling, the favored eldest daughter, fled her clinging mother, her institutionalized father (a man stricken with ''the doubting disease,'' obsessive-compulsive disorder) and the four siblings she virtually raised to travel the world, never to return home. The mother, now ailing, asks Keelin, her youngest and most dutiful child, to leave a promising teaching job and search for Aisling. So Keelin flies to Japan, Aisling's last known residence, and follows her sister's circuitous trail through Hiroshima's transvestite subculture, Tokyo hostess bars and finally to Central America, all the while grappling with acquaintances' tales of Aisling as an idealistic hippie, a lesbian obsessed with an African artist, a call girl. Keelin occasionally travels with her likable but troubled siblings -- Orla, an earthy Bronx baker who mourns the son she gave up for adoption; Siobhan, a London fashion maven who battles anorexia; and Patrick, whose compulsive habits have shaped his aimless existence -- and with her uncle, a wealthy, rather debauched Jesuit priest with secrets of his own. While the peripatetic narrative sometimes wanders astray, Martin's wry, trenchant prose keeps things animated. What is more impressive, Aisling becomes a nuanced symbol for the family's lost ideal -- one startlingly refuted by her actual appearance. Keelin's odyssey movingly reveals the harm of clinging to the past, even in the name of family. Megan Harlan
