title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GODNICK, AUDREY
description: GODNICK-Audrey. On March 31, 1996. Three years ago. There will never be another like you.

title: A Bit of Nerve, and Plenty of Pleases
description: ABOUT five weeks into my evening class in Russian, I came to a hard truth. I knew, abruptly and positively, that I was never going to speak this language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, HARRY S.
description: GARBER-Harry S. At the age of 94 on March 25, 1999 in Israel. Beloved father of Judy and Kenny, Ephraim and Shirley, Laurence and Sherry. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Beloved husband of the late Sadie Garber and Estelle Zweibel. Shiva will be observed all day Tuesday and Wednesday morning at 5 Iris Street, Cedarhurst, New York.

title: Do Brand Names Help Children Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sakura, Shrines and Obento in Kyoto
description: IN Kyoto, buds typically appear on bare cherry tree branches the last week in March. Unfurling to full splendor by early April, sakura last for only a few days before their fragile petals are scattered. It is the very fleeting nature of cherry blossoms -- the national flower -- that so appeals to the Japanese.

title: March 21-27; One Crisis, Hold the Anchovies
description: How can you possibly rank national crises? Who's to say, ''Yep, that one's an 8, but this has got to be a 10''? Do you measure headline size, count talk-show references, or just throw up your hands and await history's ruling?

title: From Spain, a $5 Red
description: Comfort foods want to be washed down by casual tonics like the '97 Protocolo, a hearty Spanish red from an obscure producer, Dominio de Eguren, and the '96 Domaine John Kaltsis, a charming Greek red from Nemea on the Peloponnesus. Protocolo is a best buy at $5 ($4.50 a bottle if a $54 case is bought) at SoHo Wines and Spirits, 461 West Broadway (Houston Street).

title: The New Pop Hero: A Mirage Of Muscle And Mean
description: NOW that the Presidential impeachment trial is over and its ennobling lessons in constitutional responsibility and high-minded judicial oratory have left an impression on our American aonscience no less indelible than a Dean Martin celebrity roast featuring Professor Irwin Corey, many of you are no doubt wondering what will become of your favorite media analysts. What will the pan-pundit class have to write about now? What will the talking heads say? How will they eke out a living? How feed, clothe and school the young punditae? Whither our windbag elite now that Ms. Lewinsky has spilled the beans to Ms. Walters and recedes hereafter into the shadows at the Fawn Hall of Fame?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, JOSEPH J.
description: SHERR-Joseph J. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Rose Lynn and Brian. Cherished father-in-law of Jack Pollock and Janet Eaton. Dear brother of Simon, Irving and Ruth (Cohn). Loving grandfather of Alexa, Elise and Mallerie. Dear uncle. Funeral Congregation Torah Ohr, Boca Raton, FL, Sunday 2 PM. Burial Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ Monday 1 PM. His valor, loyalty and brilliance will be cherished forever. For information call ''Wien & Wien'' 800322-0533.

title: Race Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMAN, BERNARD, D.D.S.
description: TUCHMAN-Bernard, D.D.S. On March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Joan Hesse Tuchman. Loving father of Marlene, Drs. Judith and Ira, Adam, and Stacy and Michael. Cherished brother of Murray and Caryl and Stephan, uncle and great-uncle. All who knew and loved him will miss him. Funeral Services private.

title: The Superpower That Couldn't Say No
description: A hundred years ago the leading superpower of the day, Great Britain, sent troops into the Sudan. Its statesmen explained their decision thus: Britain's global position rested on its empire in India. Access to India required a secure Suez Canal, which required that Egypt be safeguarded, which required that the upper Nile valley be controlled. So the Sudan was vital, you see.

title: Q&A/Selma Miriam; Mixing Feminist Politics and Business
description: IN Selma Miriam's first incarnation, the Bridgeport native did what women were expected to do; she went to college, got married and raised a family. In her second life, at age 40, she said she began to do what she wanted to do.

title: Maine Advances
description: Steve Kariya scored three goals and had three assists as Maine routed Clarkson, 7-2, at Worcester, Mass., last night in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's hockey tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNO, CYNTHIA RAE (NEE SINGER).
description: BRUNO-Cynthia Rae (nee Singer). Age 46. Our beloved Cindy died March 19, 1999 at home, after a fierce battle with breast cancer. Among many who will miss her, are her children Douglas, Matthew and Ethan, husband Vince, mother Susi Singer, father Arthur Singer, Gloria Singer and Grace Bruno. We cherish her bravery and love.

title: Buffett of Arabia? Well, Maybe
description: HE calls them his 100 wives and honors each with a flag tacked to his office wall. Citigroup. Saks Fifth Avenue. Four Seasons Hotels. Apple Computer. Movenpick. Saatchi & Saatchi. Daewoo. Donna Karan International. Trans World Airlines. The News Corporation. Planet Hollywood. Hyundai Motor. Teledesic.

title: The Drug-Test Tightrope
description: Q. My company is instituting random drug testing, and my fellow managers and I are trying to decide how strict to be. For safety reasons, we figure that a factory worker who tests positive should be severely penalized or dismissed, but that such punishment seems extreme for secretaries and midlevel managers. How can we be both fair and effective? And what is the best way to present the new rules to employees?

title: Curtain Up on a London Weekend
description: HERE are some things I love about London theater: The curtain is often at 7:30, so you can eat afterward at a sane hour. Tickets cost less, on the whole, than in New York. You can take your drink (or your ice cream) back to your seat without fear of reprisal. Some bathrooms are right next door to the auditorium, not through winding corridors and down dangerously steep stairs. The theater names are grand (the Royal Court, the Prince of Wales, the Duchess, Her Majesty's). And later you get to toss your head and say, ''Oh, I saw it in London.''

title: Variety of Programs Offered at Caramoor
description: NO longer just a summer festival, Caramoor in Katonah has announced a diverse set of enticements for its spring season, including recitals, opera, lectures, cabaret, jazz, teas, garden tours, plant sales and art courses.

title: Tight Quarters, But, Oh, the View
description: JACLYN RYAN is the Olive Oyl of Popeye's dreams. For the past two years she has lived on her sailboat ''Last Mango'' with her dog, Tugboat, and her own iron will.

title: From the Bumptious to the Gentle
description: 'NEW WORLD JAZZ'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, JULIUS
description: FISHMAN-Julius. March 26, 1980. So many years have gone by. Your family has grown, yet there is no one to fill the void we feel when we think of all the years without you. We continue to miss you each day. We will love you forever. Anna Mae, Children, Grandchildren, and Great-Grandchildren

title: Van Horn Sits Out Another Nets Loss
description: With their best front-court player cheering from the sideline in a slick three-button suit, the Nets turned in one of their most inspiring performances of the season tonight at Continental Arena. Keith Van Horn, his sprained right ankle too tender to play, watched from the bench as a Nets lineup that included his new and unheralded teammates, Jamie Feick and Mark Hendrickson, pushed the Cleveland Cavaliers to the brink before losing by 109-99.

title: Drug Companies Getting F.D.A. Reprimands for False or Misleading Advertising
description: The Federal Government has repeatedly reprimanded drug companies in recent months after finding that they have made false or misleading claims in television commercials and magazine advertisements for a wide range of prescription drugs.

title: Out of the Attic for the 21st Century
description: NINE months and three days to go, and nobody on Long Island seems to be taking the millennium seriously. In places like California and Montana, survivalists are heading for the hills with supplies of canned health food and bottled water. But a quick check of Long Island's mountain region -- the heights of Bald Hill, a dizzy 295 feet above sea level -- reveals no doomsday cultists living in tents with lifetime supplies of beer and pizza. They may be waiting for warmer weather.

title: Old Garbage Seen as Precious
description: When a 19th-century house on West 11th Street was demolished about a month ago, neighbors noticed a round brick structure in the ground and identified it as an old cistern. Now preservationists want to excavate it, but they say they have been denied access to the site, which may be filled with historically significant junk.

title: The Arts Of the Game, Martial and Delicate
description: ON the surface, board games seem intended to amuse and entertain, but on closer look they have much in common with military campaigns or religious rituals. According to a Chinese legend from the Qin Dynasty, to avoid further bloodshed, a war between an uncle and nephew was settled by a game of weiqi, a kind of chess. This and many other stories are charmingly related through the nearly 100 objects exhibited in ''Games People Play: Ancient Pastimes of Asia'' at the E. & J. Frankel gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan until May 1.

title: High Price Of Isolation Giuliani's Embrace Leaves Some Cold
description: Time and again, the Giuliani administration has demonstrated the ability to make the routine seem unusual and the bizarre seem mundane. How else could a meeting between the Mayor and the city's highest-elected black official take on the significance of a Botha-Mandela sitdown? How else could a mayor have refused to meet that leader for more than a year?

title: Show Features Work With Marks Of a Masterpiece
description: IF a work of art speaks for the time in which it was created by capturing an important realization, concept, event or state of mind, then it may be considered a great piece. But what makes a great work of art a masterpiece?

title: And Our Next Sports Car Will Be Called the Blue Devil
description: Originally, G. Richard Wagoner Jr., president of General Motors, was going to be the host of a reception tomorrow night at Cipriani 42d Street, in advance of the New York Auto Show. But G.M. had a change of heart after a restaurant workers' union ran a newspaper ad urging a boycott of the Rainbow Room, another establishment run by the Cipriani family, and saying, ''a lot of people think the Ciprianis have hearts of stone.'' The car maker promptly switched the site to Vanderbilt Hall of Grand Central Terminal, but the change it highlighted in large letters in its letter to the media was something else altogether.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Echoes of a Native Land:

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Personal Business Diary column last Sunday about a computerized system for ordering sandwiches misspelled the surname of an assistant vice president at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which is using the system at its cafeteria at Two World Trade Center in Manhattan. He is Keith Worters, not Waters.

title: Influx of Elder Centers Worries Dix Hills
description: FELICIA B. SCHWARTZ said she and her family moved from a condominium in Long Beach to Dix Hills in October 1997 because it was ''less congested and the character of the neighborhood -- it's beautiful, serene and calming -- was just what we wanted for our family.''

title: High Court Faces Moment of Truth in Federalism Cases
description: Beginning with an argument next week in an obscure case about overtime pay for state probation officers in Maine, the Supreme Court is setting out on an extended foray along the border that separates Federal authority from state prerogatives.

title: Red Leather Days
description: Lipstick-red leather jackets are the accessory that signifies the ready-to-be-bad look in two new movies. In ''Go,'' opening on April 9, Sarah Polley (top) plays a supermarket clerk who wears a retro one during a lame attempt to become a drug dealer. ''It's not a nice red leather coat,'' said the costume designer for ''Go,'' Genevieve Tyrrell, who made it for Ms. Polley. ''She could have got it in a vintage store for 20, 30 bucks.'' In the opening sequences of ''The Mod Squad,'' Claire Danes (inset) is introduced as a thief, a former drug addict but still stylish in a custom-made red leather patchwork jacket. ''It has that vintage 70's feel, something she could have found at a thrift store,'' said Arianne Phillips, the movie's costume designer. A version inspired by her design is being marketed by Levi's for the unthrifty price of $230. But the trend may have passed its peak. In January, Redbook, that bible of young moms, gave its readers 99 ways to jump-start their lives. No. 56 was buying a red leather jacket. No. 1 was sewing on missing buttons. LINDA LEE

title: The Hidden Track: Already a Worn Trick
description: THE music of Whitney Houston, the Offspring, Robert Earl Keen, Sheryl Crow, Korn, Beck and Jewel has little in common, but the musicians do share one thing: they all included hidden tracks on their most recent CD's.

title: Report Cards Point to Struggles for Middle and High Schools
description: The annual report cards for New York City's public school, released this month, suggest that large numbers of students will face a struggle to meet new state graduation requirements being introduced during the next few years.

title: Sherri Putterman and Drew Caplin
description: Dr. Sherri Putterman, the daughter of Helen and Burton Putterman of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married last evening to Dr. Drew Caplin, the son of Cheryl and Richard Caplin of East Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Gerald Weider performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Unfair Comparison I
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Mother-In-Law Diaries

title: Fishing for Meaning And for a Good Time
description: ARTIST and environmentalist, Connie Jost lived and worked in South Jersey. In a career that spanned only about 15 years, she attained a reputation for her realistic images of marine life. ''Fish Tales,'' at the Noyes Museum of Art here, is a retrospective exhibition of 32 works by Ms. Jost dating from 1981 to 1995, the last year she was healthy enough to create major pieces.

title: Deliver Us From Evil
description: FOR THE TIME BEING

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- Shop Talk; Getting to Yes
description: Shell: One of the big differences between what you and I do is what happens if we don't use negotiation. In a business deal, typically, either there's just no deal and everybody keeps going on, or there's something like litigation. In your business the alternative to negotiation, at the worst end, is war.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The Attractions of Asian Art
description: The rich and famous came out in force on Wednesday at the International Asian Art Fair in Manhattan, but they were mostly just looking. Veronica Hearst, wearing part of a diamond stomacher with a big pearl drop, said her husband, Randolph Hearst, chairman of the Hearst Corporation, ''likes jade, and if I see something I like, I'll surprise him.''

title: U.N. to Create Own Satellite Program to Find Illegal Drug Crops
description: The United Nations program charged with reducing illicit drugs is creating its own satellite monitoring system to identify the cultivation of narcotics in the major source countries.

title: Fraschilla, Former St. John's Coach, Is Headed to New Mexico
description: Fran Fraschilla, who was fired by St. John's 10 months ago, just weeks after leading it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, was hired yesterday as the head basketball coach at New Mexico.

title: The Human Habitat
description: For years I've daydreamed about coming into a large sum of money and being able to redecorate my home from top to bottom. After reading Pollan's funny and perceptive article, I have newfound respect for the eclectic furniture (some from my husband's first marriage), clearance-sale mistakes and ''stuff'' that clutters the walls, bookshelves and table tops of our home. Tacky though some of it may be, it tells our story. My thanks to Michael Pollan for freeing me from magazine-cover dreams of perfection.

title: Albany Memo; Democrats Keep Eye on Veto Knife
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki used his veto power over New York's budget last year for the first time, boldly slicing more than $1 billion in spending, it so startled Democratic lawmakers that it has left them with a kind of political post-traumatic stress. Worried, even panicked, that the Governor will again wipe away their programs, the Democrats have all but brought this year's talks to a standstill as they hunt for a way to fend him off.

title: March 21-27; White House Offers China Plan
description: The White House thought it had a plan to improve relations with China: Get Beijing into the World Trade Organization, something the Chinese have sought for more than a decade. But the Chinese never wanted to pay the price -- lower tariffs on imports, an end to huge trade barriers and protection for state-owned industries.

title: Easter Chase: Bring Your Own Basket
description: During the Easter season, children visiting New England have a choice of historical sites for egg hunting.

title: Looting India
description: To the Editor:

title: Oahu, Beyond Pearl Harbor and Waikiki
description: AS visitors from even the nearest cities on the mainland United States know, any trip to Oahu takes at least six hours of air travel. From the East Coast, the trip can be twice that, or more. Such is the price of getting to the island that is home to Honolulu, and of seeing the sights and enjoying all that makes Oahu the favorite island of those who know Hawaii well.

title: Ms. Jones, Mr. Holtzman
description: Cynthia Catron Jones, a daughter of Carol and Abbott Jones of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married today to Abraham Eli Holtzman, the son of Zipora and Jacob Holtzman of Mahwah, N.J. Rabbi David Fass is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Science Fiction
description: The hero of John Barnes's 1995 novel ''Kaleidoscope Century'' was a coldhearted hit man with one redeeming quality: he was marginally less nasty than a sadistic comrade in arms who took pleasure in ''serbing'' his female victims before dispatching them. Since Barnes has an undeniable knack for getting under the skin of his characters, it was perhaps inevitable that some readers had trouble distinguishing the author from his disturbing creations. My grudgingly positive review of ''Kaleidoscope Century'' ended with the hope that there would be no sequels. I am happy to report that FINITY (Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95) is an altogether different kind of book.

title: Hold the Sin
description: JEFFREY FAVIA knew he was taking a chance seven years ago when he opened Favia Lite on Washington Street in Hoboken. Having majored in fitness studies at Springfield College in Massachusetts, Mr. Favia always recommended that his fitness clients eat healthy foods like pasta, but suggested they avoid the cream sauces that render them high in fat. In continually exhorting such changes in diet, he came up with an idea for a restaurant that celebrates straightforward, flavorful, low-fatcooking.

title: The Pit Bull on the Subway
description: HE was standing immobile in the center of the Grand Concourse at Grand Central Terminal, an arresting figure in the near-deserted hub late on a rain-drenched January night.

title: A Manifesto for the Fast World
description: In the winter of 1996, I accompanied Madeleine K. Albright, then the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, on a trip to the war zones of Africa. During the last stop, in Rwanda, she asked her staff to pose for a picture outside her Air Force 737. The group included a Greek-American, a Czech-American, Jewish Americans, black Americans and white Americans. There were Air Force crewmen from small towns and diplomats from Ivy League colleges, and they were all standing there shoulder to shoulder.

title: The World; Old, Slow and Indispensable
description: THE most expensive warplane ever built, the $2 billion B-2 stealth bomber, made its combat debut against Yugoslavia last week after more than a decade of controversy over its costs and abilities. But the truly remarkable aircraft taking part in NATO's strikes was not the newest but the oldest: the B-52.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS to COURTLAND COX; Strength In Diversity, And in Unity
description: IT is not unusual for businesspeople with a common background to join together to promote economic development and entrepreneurship in their community, forming groups like the Asian American Business Development Center in New York.

title: Kerith Aronow And Saul Shapiro
description: Kerith Jane Aronow, a television producer, and Saul Benjamin Shapiro, a lawyer, were married last evening in Philadelphia. Rabbi Philip Bentley, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Society Hill Synagogue.

title: Protect Wilderness From Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Profits Are Tasty, But Artificially Flavored
description: THE winter quarter ends on Wednesday, and as the crocuses emerge, public attention turns to profits. The stock market in the coming weeks will ride -- up or down -- on the quarterly profit reports that will spew forth soon from corporate America. Will those reports signal continuing economic strength? If so, is corporate America reporting its profits truthfully?

title: Where Music and the Ministry Merge
description: WHEN it comes to percussion, Norman Freeman has done it all: played in wedding bands and R & B acts as well as in the orchestra pit of ''A Chorus Line.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, MABEL
description: REID-Mabel. Died February 24, 1999. Born 1906, Jamaica, NY. Graduated from Vassar College and Columbia University. Resident of Garden City, NY for 27 years, Bridgeport, CT final five years. Retired as Director of Statistics and Studies, Visiting Nurse Service of NY, in 1966 after 30-year career. Evaluated rural nursing programs in Indian and Thailand at request of Indian and Thai governments under auspices of World Health Organization of United Nations. She is survived by four nieces, one nephew. Interment at Mountain Grove Cemetery, Bridgeport, CT. Contributions to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: Generational Myopia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSSMANN, PHILIPPE
description: HAUSSMANN-Philippe. Passed away quietly on March 21, 1999 in Acapulco, Mexico. Father of the late Lorraine V. Haussmann. He is survived by his sister Mary Claude (Jean) Bernard of Paris, France; son Claude Haussmann (Joann Perahia) and grandsons Philippe and Alexandre. His loving memory will be carried on. Condolences can be sent to Claude Haussmann, 1619 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10128.

title: Daimler's Tiny Smart Car Falters After a Fast Start
description: SMART cars are struggling to live up to their name. DaimlerChrysler's Micro Compact Car Smart subsidiary has reduced 1999 sales goals to 100,000, from 130,000, and plans to close its factory in Strasbourg, France, for two weeks next month. And in an effort to reach its new goal, Smart has cut prices, added equipment and planned a three-month ad campaign.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Melissa Barkan, Shawn Wallach
description: Melissa Carrie Barkan, the daughter of Francine and Jay Barkan of Melville, N.Y., is to be married this evening in Lawrence, N.Y., to Shawn Jared Wallach, a son of Caryl and Bruce Wallach of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Bruce Goldwasser is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SARETSKY, STAN
description: SARETSKY-Stan. Beloved principal and great runner. We miss you and think of you in your afterlife. Bullet and the Boys

title: Footnotes; Shell Shocked
description: *If the Garden of Eden had beachfront footage, Adam and Eve probably had a shell collection. These humble but architecturally extravagant bits of nature have been linked with the mystic, the erotic and the esthetic since ancient times. Aphrodite, Venus, St. James and two King Louises were into shells. So were Max Ernst, Diego Giacometti, Jean Cocteau -- and me.

title: 'Turtles' Rush In When Anger Flares in Jail
description: WHEN the phone rang at 12:35 one recent afternoon in what was formerly the central booking area of the County Jail here, seven men in green Army fatigues snapped to attention and raced into a hallway where they stopped briefly before seven chairs lined against the wall. Each man grabbed a heavy green flak jacket and black visored helmet from a chair and put it on. The first man in line strapped a plexiglass shield to his arm.

title: In Renault-Nissan Deal, Big Risks and Big Opportunities
description: In taking a stake in the troubled Nissan Motor Company, Renault, the stodgy French car company that has tried to become a formidable force in Europe, has embarked on a risky business gamble to strengthen the global competitiveness of both companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLKY, MIRIAM C.

Bolster of New York. The Rev. William L. George performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

description: AFTER a decade-long drought in new construction, downtown Chicago is suddenly awash in new luxury apartment towers. About half a dozen towers are currently rising on the Near North and South Sides, several in neighborhoods not previously known as high-end residential enclaves.

description: THE phrase ''film festival'' conjures glamorous images: the beaches of Cannes, the slopes of Park City, Utah, and a crush of photographers aiming at the latest starlet.

title: Alison Berkley, David Wagonfeld
description: Alison Joan Berkley, the daughter of Peter and Nancy Berkley of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to David Seth Wagonfeld, a son of Dr. Samuel Wagonfeld of Denver and the late Barbara Wagonfeld. Cantor Roslyn Barak performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco.

title: March 21-27; At Last, a Balloon Makes It
description: Dr. Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones became the first balloonists to circle the world nonstop. They were greeted in Geneva by a thunderous cheer and a trumpeter playing the ''Triumphal March'' from ''Aida.'' Dr. Piccard, 41, a Swiss psychiatrist, and his British co-pilot, Mr. Jones, 52, completed a 19-day trip around the world in their Breitling Orbiter 3 balloon when they flew over an invisible finish line at 9 degrees 27 minutes west longitude in Mauritania, then touched down in the soft sands of southern Egypt.

title: Court Ruling Allows Trips To the Titanic
description: The company salvaging the wreckage of the Titanic has exclusive rights to the ship's artifacts but it cannot keep others from visiting and photographing the wreckage, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WESTCARR, MILDRED
description: WESTCARR-Mildred. April 12, 1981. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Daughters, Shirley and Lorraine; Brother, Archibal

title: Aquariums Do Exist For Islanders' Enjoyment
description: Contrary to the assertions in your article on projected aquariums in Riverhead and Bay Shore [''Water Everywhere, Finally Aquariums,'' Mar. 14], Long Island has been home to two such in institutions for many decades.

title: Taxi Arrests
description: The White Plains police have arrested 23 taxi drivers for falsifying health information on applications for license renewals.

title: Good Friends Join Enemies To Criticize U.S. on Rights
description: The United States, which regards itself as a bastion of human rights, found itself under attack from friend and foe alike during the first week of the United Nations annual meeting on global democratic rights.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Assembly campaign of Edward G. Werner misstated the status of the case against the man accused of murdering his son. Samuel Manzie pleaded guilty to the crime on March 19 and is to be sentenced on April 14. He will not go to trial as scheduled on April 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, BESSIE
description: GOLDMAN-Bessie. Age 94. Died peacefully with her family at her side on March 26, 1999. A school teacher for 48 years and a life-long world traveler, she was admired by all who knew her. To her last days she retained her loving nature, wisdom, humor and independence of spirit with which she lived her full life. She will be deeply missed and always remembered. ''Nana'' is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Claire of New York City; her grandson Michael, grand - daughter - in - law Cora and great-grandson Irvin of Jerusalem, Israel; grandson Ethan, grandson Neal and granddaughter-in-law Lora, also from New York City.

title: Lively Precursors
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Web Site For Conference Calls
description: Individual investors have been shut out of companies' conference calls with analysts for just about as long as corporations have been conducting such chats. Now, a new company is using its Web site to keep individuals abreast of when such conference calls are scheduled, providing dates, times and phone numbers.

title: Honoring Ragtime, Jazz Classics
description: SCOTT JOPLIN'S ''Maple Leaf Rag,'' published 100 years ago, is the featured attraction this afternoon at 3 P.M. at a ''Ragtime Centennial'' concert at Crowell Hall, Wesleyan University, in Middletown. Performing are the five members of Elite Syncopations, an ensemble that recreates early Americana with period arrangements.

title: No State Title For Basketball Phenom
description: It was a bittersweet ending to a record-breaking career for Nicole Kaczmarski, the Sachem High School senior hailed as the best girls' basketball player ever on Long Island. Sachem was eliminated in the semifinal round of the New York State basketball tournament by Shenendehowa, 61-54, though Miss Kaczmarski scored a game-high 27 points in defeat.

title: Jury Selection to Begin In Louima Beating Case
description: More than a year and a half after a Haitian immigrant named Abner Louima was reportedly brutalized by police officers in Brooklyn, jury selection is to begin tomorrow for the trial of four officers charged with attacking him and of a sergeant accused of joining them in an attempted cover-up.

title: Tracing the Origins Of 'Empire State'
description: To the Editor:

title: Counterpoint to World War II Celebrations
description: In an unusual display of baby boomer wistfulness, World War II is being celebrated these days as a model of heroism, righteous motives and duty fulfilled. By contrast, of course, the postwar generation is seen as somehow undeserving, or at least as having not completed such an ambitious journey.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Faces Without Lives
description: Garry Winogrand prowled the public spaces of the United States with his camera from 1959 to 1976 and stole glimpses of the transitory lives around him. THE MAN IN THE CROWD: The Uneasy Streets of Garry Winogrand (Fraenkel Gallery/

title: Will Lakers Blow Away All Foes Or Blow Up?
description: There's another peroxide blond turning heads at the Great Western Forum, and this one may completely discombobulate the Lakers.

title: House of Cards
description: Frederick Barthelme has published 11 works of fiction. Among them are the story collection ''Moon Deluxe'' and, most recently, the novel ''Bob the Gambler.'' The chances of your having read any of them are slight, because, as Barthelme told me, everything he writes sells to ''the usual 5,000 suspects.'' I think that this is a shame, that his is a talent deserving celebration. (Writers from Margaret Atwood to John Barth have expressed the same feeling.) When I was on my way to see him in southern Mississippi, where he has taught and lived since the late 70's, I got off the plane, looked at the sky and felt immediately as if I'd been there before. Then I realized I'd only read about this clear, thin light in the pages of Barthelme's books.

title: The Ascending Senators Crush the Descending Islanders
description: Ted Donato's stay on Long Island was brief just five months -- but that was enough time for him to form strong opinions on the Islanders' sad situation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Last night, for the first time, everyone in Belgrade felt the real impact of the war. Everyone could see the big explosions in the central city and the suburbs.''

Jackson 3d, both of Coral Gables, Fla., was married there yesterday at the Granada Presbyterian Church to Leonor Fresnel Loree 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Loree 3d of Richmond. The Rev. David Miller, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Danny Levi, a Presbyterian minister, took part.

title: Myanmar Opposition Leader's Husband Dies, Denied a Last Visit
description: Michael Aris, the British husband of the Burmese opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, died of cancer today in London after being denied permission by Burmese authorities to pay a last visit to her.

description: Two days after an important home victory against Pittsburgh, the Devils struggled to salvage a 4-4 tie today with the Chicago Blackhawks, the worst team in the Western Conference.

title: A New Battle for D-Day Veterans: Raising Funds for Memorial
description: Bob Slaughter hasn't bought a movie ticket since his wife dragged him to see ''The Sound of Music'' way back in 1965. ''I have no interest whatsoever in that stuff,'' Mr. Slaughter, a 74-year-old retiree, said.

title: Jill Wilkins, Jonathan Kaplan
description: Jill Wilkins, a public affairs counselor at the World Bank in Washington, and Jonathan Albert Kaplan, the chief of staff of the National Economic Council at the White House, were married last evening. Rabbi Allen Smith officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

description: DISTRICT 1 -- Port Morris, Melrose, Mott Haven; last Thursday of the month; next meeting April 29, 6:30 P.M., Lincoln Hospital, 234 East 149th Street; (718) 585-7117. Chairman: George Rodriguez; District Manager: Cedric Loftin.

title: Firefighters' Backs Up Over Backups
description: New Jersey firefighters say they appreciate that the new regulations requiring additional backup outside burning buildings are meant to protect them. But, many say, the rules, which went into effect last Sunday, may make it harder to respond to fires and may result in the destruction of more property.

title: A Sculptor's Virtual Studio
description: The Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum, in a converted factory with an encircling garden in Long Island City, Queens, may be one of the most comprehensive collections of the sculptor's work in the world. But when the museum's officials decided to set up a Web site in 1997, introducing visitors to its exhibits, they knew they had to go further.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTROVE, BERTRAM
description: ASTROVE-Bertram. Age 78, of Wellington, passed away March 25, 1999. He moved to South Florida from White Plains, NY, and was a retired decorated World War II pilot. He is predeceased by his loving wife, Anita. Mr. Astrove is survived by his sons, Dr. Andrew Astrove of Boca Raton and Skip Astrove of Banks, Oregon; two brothers, Alan and Edgar, and six grandchildren. The family will have services in New York at a later date.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 28, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Credit Agency Cuts Nassau's Rating
description: As Nassau County officials reworked a poorly received plan to close a cumulative budget deficit that is approaching $300 million, the county's bonds were downgraded last week by one Wall Street rating agency, and two others repeated earlier warnings that they were watching to see if Nassau was moving too slowly in closing the gap.

title: Pepper, Shore Leader, Has A Chance to End Her Skid
description: Dottie Pepper has been the best women's golfer not to win a tournament over the last two and a half years, and she is in position to end that victory drought Sunday in the final round of the $1 million Nabisco Dinah Shore.

title: Tokyo
description: The sakura ''front'' is already moving up the Japanese archipelago, working its magic on a country emerging from winter, if not from its economic slump.

title: Inventing NATO's New Role
description: The air campaign against Yugoslavia is doing what years of abstract debate could not. It is beginning to define the role for the NATO alliance to play in post-cold-war Europe. Four days of bombing is not enough to resolve this issue fully. But the early indications are that the members of the expanded alliance are capable of a unified response to threats to Continental security and stability.

title: March 21-27; Possible Clue On Missing Atheist
description: With a former employee of the missing atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair in custody, charged with weapons violations, investigators were hoping for a long-awaited breakthrough in the perplexing 1995 disappearance of the 77-year-old woman, her son, her granddaughter and $500,000 in gold coins.

title: Word for Word / Designer Babble; In Architecture, Mortar Isn't The Stuff You Lay On Really Thick
description: YOU know about the Tower of Babel, the ambitious architectural project that the Lord foiled in Genesis by rendering its overreaching builders unable to communicate with one another. Now consider its modern heir: the babble about towers spouted by architects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, HAROLD
description: STEINBERG-Harold. On March 26, 1999. Publisher, innovator, optimist. Devoted husband of Mary McCarthy Steinberg, adored father of Katharine Steinberg Golick, Anthony Burgess Steinberg and the late Jeffrey Steinberg, fatherin-law of Dee Dibble Steinberg and Jeffrey Golick, beloved brother of Bernard and Herbert Steinberg, Joy Schwartz, and the late Clarice Brown, cherished grandfather of Jordan and Nicholas Steinberg, son of the late Paul and Edna Steinberg, many nieces and nephews, and many friends. Funeral Monday, March 29, 1 PM, Independent Jewish Cemetery, Route 114, Sag Harbor, NY. For further information, call Yardley Pino Funeral Home: 516-725-0251.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- Test Run; Net Gain
description: Sometimes science, indeed, marches on; at other times its movement might be more accurately described as a sashay. Case in point: Nokia's 9000 model mobile phone, which does what other cell phones have only promised -- it provides relatively easy access to the Internet. Not only does the Communicator, which costs about $1,000, double as a palmtop organizer with Internet, fax, alphanumeric paging and calculator functions, but its hands-free speakerphone and comically minuscule keyboard allow you simultaneously to ride in an elevator, talk on the phone and calculate your divorce settlement.

title: Hildegard Elizabeth Peplau, 89, Developer of Psychiatric Nursing
description: Dr. Hildegard Elizabeth Peplau, a nursing educator who played a major role in developing the theory and practice of psychiatric and mental health nursing, died on March 17 at her home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. She was 89.

description: Call it the Janus effect.

description: THE Village of Lynbrook, an older suburb with a venerable rail link to Brooklyn that lured early commuters, has aged gracefully, like an old shoe of high quality.

title: Sign, Which Sign? Oh, That Sign. Are You Sure?; The City Has 564,000 Parking Signs. Drivers Moan That Few Are Perfectly Clear.
description: ALLEN DUDLEY studied the two-tiered parking sign on West 47th Street with the same attention he devotes to Federal statutes. A third-year law student at George Mason University in Virginia, he soon deduced what he thought was the only logical interpretation of the sign: it was safe to park his Ford Taurus near the sign on a Sunday.

title: Rushing In as Insiders Rush Out
description: Back in early February, an investing site on the World Wide Web called Trading-places.net generated a flurry of excitement among investors who followed the advice of its guru and owner, Chris Rea. Known on the web as Merlin, Mr. Rea puts his picks out to members, who then tend to pile into the stocks.

title: Down on the Farm
description: LORD OF THE BARNYARD

title: A Night for Spirits, Both Dark and Light
description: THE SETTING -- The first-ever Spirits Expo New York on Wednesday night in the Irving Berlin room at the Crowne Plaza Hotel, where a few hundred thirsty souls, mostly liquor industry types and fans of their products, showed up for a two-hour tasting of famous and not-so-famous whiskies, vodkas, tequilas and aperitifs. Guests, who paid $75 each, were handed a glass at the door before entering a mundane meeting room transformed into a veritable boozapalooza.

title: Memo to Hollywood, Re TV: It's Not That Bad
description: You people sit there day after day, night after night, all ages, colors, creeds. We're all you know. You're beginning to believe the illusions we're spinning here. You're beginning to think that the tube is reality and that your own lives are unreal. You do whatever the tube tells you. You dress like the tube, you eat like the tube, you raise your children like the tube, you even think like the tube. This is mass madness, you maniacs!

title: Old Enmities Puncture Baseball Detente in Cuba
description: Despite the excitement over the Baltimore Orioles' exhibition game here and the veneer of openness it conveys, American baseball comes to Cuba in a climate of heightened political repression. A law passed this year tightens the reins on both dissent and press freedom and specifically makes it a crime to engage in conduct that supports American policy toward Cuba.

title: Ms. Washington And Mr. Ebanks
description: Michelle Marie Washington, a publishing executive, and Gordon Anthony Ebanks, a computer software executive, were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick Brunson, an Episcopal priest, at the TriBeCa Rooftop, a loft space in New York.

title: A Little League's Biggest Problem Is Parents
description: The worst part of Little League baseball, as any center fielder with a runny nose and a skinned knee can tell you, is an angry and argumentative parent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSE, ROBERT GARDNER,
description: PEARSE-Robert Gardner, 86. Of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Rumson, N.J., and St. Croix, USVI, died Monday, March 22nd, 1999 in Delray Beach. Mr. Pearse's wife of 58 years, Virginia Rogers Pearse, died in 1997. He is survived by three daughters, Penelope P. Houghton of Rumson and Delray Beach, Stephanie P. Hurtt of Navesink, and Roberta Pearse-Drance of Pennington, NJ, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. George's-by-the-River, Rumson, on Thursday, April 1, at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to the Oncological Nursing Continuing Education Scholarship Fund at Riverview Medical Center, which was established in memory of Mrs. Pearse, at Riverview Foundation, One Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, New Jersey 07701.

title: Decades of Work From the Elusive Will Barnet
description: WILL BARNET is one of those artists whose work is much better known than he is. It was not that long ago that every other dorm room or young person's apartment was decorated with a poster of one of his familiar images: a languid woman boldly drawn, often paired with a sinuous cat. Perhaps the appeal of these images is that they are presented with great clarity, but still remain enigmatic, and thus endure. Much of Mr. Barnet's elusiveness is dispelled by a satisfyingly full survey of his prints from the 30's to the 90's at the Thomas J. Walsh Art Gallery at Fairfield University in Fairfield; Mr. Barnet turns 88 this year. He was born in Beverly, Mass., and studied, as did so many figurative artists of the era, at the Art Students League in New York. Early on he turned out typical New York social realist works with titles like ''Subway'' and ''Central Park Siesta.''

title: Secluded Molokai
description: AS I tried to take in the sheer size of Papohaku Beach, its sunlit golden sand made me blink. Famous as the largest beach on Molokai, and, some claim, anywhere in Hawaii, Papohaku extends for more than two and a half miles. So after unpacking, I had hurried to its edge, only a 10-minute walk from our town house door. I was happily imagining a week of brisk early-morning walks from one end of the beach to another. But when I scrambled down to the soft, deep sand, I immediately sank in to my ankles. Walking on Papohaku, I realized, would be very slow. If I were going to enjoy it, I would have to abandon my usual high-speed pace. That, it turned out, was the best way to approach our week on Molokai.

title: Hollywood Haggadah
description: In America, promotional tie-ins to the Haggadah, the text recited at a Passover seder, are almost as much a tradition as gefilte fish. Maxwell House coffee sponsored a standard version used in Jewish homes for decades -- and now there's ''The Prince of Egypt Passover Haggadah'' by Dreamworks and the Orthodox Union ($12.99 at West Side Judaica, 2412 Broadway, near 88th Street). What makes this Haggadah different from all others? Oscar-winning song lyrics for starters (''River, O River, flow gently for me'') and animated stills including a glossy centerfold of the Hebrews trekking between the Red Sea's parted waters. In the margins there are questions to generate discussion of Passover themes (''Was Moses a mover or an agent?''). Critics of the edition liken it to stuffed Torah scrolls and other religious artifacts that are turned into toys or kitsch for the sake of mass appeal. Some rabbis don't see any problem. ''I remember when I was a kid there was a comic book of Bible stories, and I loved it,'' said Rabbi David H. Lincoln of the Park Avenue Synagogue. ''Anything that attracts people to a greater interest in the seder is to be encouraged.'' SARA IVRY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALINGER, JAMES J.
description: SALINGER-James J. On March 25th, 1999. Devoted husband of Marie (Harris) Salinger. Beloved father of Peter and Jane Salinger. Cherished by friends and family. Contributions in lieu of flowers to The Alzheimer's Association, 7910 Woodmont Avenue, #

title: The Human Habitat
description: It was wonderful to see the experiment in communal living. Cohousing communities have been springing up in recent years, where residents own their own homes but share additional land and a common house for communal meals and activities. Like those in your article, people all across the country are discovering that truly living among other people is so much more satisfying than living beside them -- and not even knowing their names.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/John C. Marbach; Law Career That Began With Nuremberg
description: AS a lawyer, John C. Marbach, now 83, helped research and write the legal opinions that were used at the Nuremberg war crimes trials, and later as a State Supreme Court justice in White Plains, he presided in one of Westchester's most complex civil cases. A father, grandfather and great-grandfather, he has long lent a helping hand to children at St. Agnes hospital. And he and his wife, Margaret, have been married for almost 58 years. Justice Marbach said his life would really be complete if he could just play better gin rummy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBIN MILLER.
description: FELDMAN-Robin Miller. 59, passed away March 27, 1999, surrounded by her family, after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Allen. Devoted and loving daughter of Anne Miller and the late Sidney J. Miller. Most beloved mother of Douglas, Todd and Gregg Feldman, sister of Gary J. Miller and the late Carol Miller Hershaft, adored mother-inlaw of Alissa Feldman, sister-inlaw of Patty Miller, Dr. Bernard (Bob), Clare Feldman, and Arthur Hershaft, grandmother of Alexander Nathan Feldman and aunt of Sloane, Max, David and Janet. Upon receiving her MBA with high honors, she went on to become internationally respected in the antique jewelry industry. She was a truly special and unique person who touched the lives of all who were blessed to have known her. Service Sunday 1:45 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times; Duke's Top Players And Team Leaders

The Blue Devils had defeated pesky but overmatched Michigan State, 68-62, to earn a spot in the championship game for the first time in five seasons. Brand, the national player of the year, sat down with four fouls late in the game, his team up by 3 points.

title: F-117 Stealth Fighter Has an Almost-Mythic Reputation but Also a Checkered Past
description: For 43 nights in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, radar-evading F-117 stealth fighters swooped in and out of downtown Baghdad, dropping their bombs and escaping a fusillade of ground fire unscathed.

title: Get Thee to a Nunnery With a New Italy Guide
description: ''Bed and Blessings, Italy,'' a new paperback ($16.95, Paulist Press) describes 131 convents and monasteries that take overnight guests for around $50 a person in Rome, $30 elsewhere. The authors, June and Anne Walsh, say that most places are welcoming, but that they are basic and generally do not take credit cards. The book can be ordered from (800) 218-1903.

title: Author and Expert on Serial Killers Who Relishes His Work
description: THERE is little in Dr. Harold Schechter's demeanor to suggest someone immersed in the subjects of murder and gore, but his office decorations -- which include several skeletons, a small corpse on a stretcher, a rubber version of a dismembered foot and his complete collection of serial killer trading cards -- might provide a hint.

title: Three for Dinner
description: Three new North Fork wines need food to complement or bring out their varying characters.

title: Cash for Nissan; Couture, Too?
description: NISSAN can certainly use Renault's help to straighten out its bleak and tangled finances. But it could also stand a nudge at the drawing board, some auto industry analysts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACCACI, HOPE NORTON.
description: IACCACI-Hope Norton. Passed away on March 20, 1999 at her home in Santa Barbara, California. She was 95 years old and died of natural causes. Mrs. Iaccaci, fondly known as ''Tita,'' was born in Greenwich, CT on October 27, 1903. As a young girl, she attended Miss Porters School, Farmington, CT. She lived a major part of her life in Darien and New Canaan, CT and maintained a summer residence in Hebron, NH. In the early 1980's, she moved to Belvedere, CA and later relocated to Montecito, CA. At the time of her death she was living with her daughter, Thayer I. Lambrecht in Santa Barbara where she had purchased a home. Mrs. Iaccaci was the daughter of Evermont Hope Norton and Lilly Morrison Carr. Mr. Norton had been instrumental in the economic development of Ecuador, South America. She was the widow of Paul Thayer Iaccaci. Her first marriage was to George E. Stevens. Tita is survived by two sons, Don Edward Stevens of La Jolla, CA, Peter Norton Stevens of Carlsbad, CA and her daughter, Thayer Iaccaci Lambrecht, of Santa Barbara. She leaves nine grandchildren and twelve greatgrandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held in Hebron, NH this summer. For more information contact McDermott-Crockett Mortuary, Santa Barbara, CA.

title: Harlem After Dark Is Cooking Again
description: ONCE, clusters of dapper night owls would zigzag down the broad, limestone-lined avenues of Harlem, from jazz joint to rent party to cabaret. In 1929, during the Harlem Renaissance, Variety reported: ''When it comes to pep, pulchritude, punch and presentation, the Harlem places have Broadway's nightclubs distanced. Celebrities in all walks of life 'make' the Harlem joints every night. You'll likely see a Lady Mountbatten on the ringside of the Cotton Club, a David Belasco at another and a diplomat in the next.''

title: DLJ Direct Takes On Japan
description: If Japan's still fledgling Internet trading business ever takes off, at least one American brokerage firm will be there to claim a piece of the pie. DLJ Direct, the discount subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and one of the top on-line firms in the United States, will begin a Japanese Internet securities firm with Sumitomo Bank, Japan's second-largest lender.

title: When Words Become A Means of Reaching A Different Plane
description: 'Wordsmiths'

title: POSTINGS: $10 Million Restoration of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church; Under Plywood, an 1899 Legacy
description: Thank goodness, the ceiling fell.

title: Dancing Through the Fragments of Memory
description: IF unquenchable curiosity is an artist's most fundamental attribute, the dancer-choreographer Margaret Jenkins need not worry. Her creativity is not about to dry up. A need to inquire is the 'irthright of this fifth-generation San Franciscan, who grew up in a politically progressive family -- her grandmother studied with Isadora Duncan, her father was a union organizer, her mother a poet -- in which passionately argued opinions were as much a part of dinner as the food. Over the last 25 years, fueled by a fierce commitment to the life of the mind, Ms. Jenkins has created a sensuous body of work in which ideas rub against one another much as her dancers do. In the process she has learled to live with ambiguity. So have her audiences.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Human Habitat
description: Thanks for the excellent series of vignettes on homes around the world. But one category not covered was the growing number of us who, in retirement, have given up a permanent home to realize our dreams of living in faraway places. Many are doing it in R.V.'s. Others are taking advantage of retirement's gift of time to return to their favorite foreign cities to find out what it is like to live there.

title: When Flying Tourist Meant Going in Style
description: SOME people made fun of Sean Penn for his widely leaked letter to 20th Century Fox complaining that the studio wouldn't give him a private jet for a publicity trip.

title: Making Philadelphia More Friendly For Its Orchestra
description: ASK a Philadelphian to name the most beloved building in the city, and chances are, the answer will be the Academy of Music. An elegant brick edifice on Broad Street, the Academy opened in 1857 and is the oldest continuously operating music hall in the United States. It has a passionate following among music lovers, many of whom regard it as virtually synonymous with its oldest resident company and landlord, the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: For Italian Dinners at a Languorous Pace
description: CHEZ PETER sounds French but is Italian. A glance at its menu reveals that it is loaded with rollatinis, saltimbocca, osso buco, rigatoni Napolitana and parmigianas. The new Atlantic Beach spot is named for its chef and co-owner, Peter Schaeperkoetter. Kenneth Ciampa, the other owner, can be heard playing laid-back standards on the piano. (There is live music every night.)

title: Madeline Singer, Michael Brisman Madline
description: Lori Singer, a daughter of Cynthia Singer and Dr. Joel B. Singer of Westport, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Michael Harold Brisman, a son of Joan Brisman and Dr. Ronald Brisman of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Jonathan Wong and Juliana Chan
description: Juliana Chan, a daughter of Agnes and Bing Chan of Stony Brook, N.Y., and Dr. Jonathan Wane Wong, the son of Anna and Henry Wong of Roslyn, N.Y., are to be married today in Dix Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Bonaventure Thekkezeetil is to perform the ceremony at St. Matthew Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FANEUIL
description: ADAMS-Faneuil. The Officers and Trustees of Chess-In-TheSchools mourn the loss of our esteemed President. We will be forever grateful for his leadership in creating our program and bringing the organization to its present level. We extend our deepest condolences to his dear wife Emiko and daughters Rebecca and Susannah. A memorial service will be held at the United Nations Chapel, 1st Ave & 44th St on Thursday, April 1st at 12 noon. Lewis B. Cullman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUSTEIN, HAROLD J.
description: HEUSTEIN-Harold J. March 26, 1999, of New York, Nantucket & Palm Beach. Treasured husband and partner in adventure of Judi, devoted son-in-law of Lucille Baumgarten, cherished brother of Barbara Leibowits, admired uncle, dear cousin of Judith Kotkin, best buddy of Petruchio. Founder and President of Woodworks Construction Company, Inc. Services on Nantucket, Monday March 29. Memorial service in N.Y. to be announced at a later date.

title: INSIDE
description: Computer Virus Erupts

title: Streetscapes/7 West 66th Street; From a Ring for Horses to a Studio for Anchors
description: ABC'S low building at 7 West 66th Street has long been a mysterious oddity, its peculiar shape slathered in scored pink stucco lamely masquerading as brick. But last year the network took off the stucco on one section and revealed the warm orange Roman brick of the original 1901 Durland's Riding Academy. This year ABC will finish a limited restoration of the facade.

title: Redecorating on a Screen
description: Even when they have enough money to buy designer furniture, shoppers can face a different squeeze: The item doesn't fit the room and has to be returned. The Web site of the Herman Miller Store (www.hmstore.com) has a room-planning feature that reduces the hazard by letting users move chairs and tables around on a floor plan before a truck arrives with the real thing.

title: Yonkers Deadline
description: In his latest order, Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan has given Yonkers a May 1 deadline to give the city's schools $32.5 million in construction money for the second year of a court-ordered desegregation plan, Lawrence W. Thomas, the school district's lawyer, said.

title: Clash Struggle: Debaters Go Toe to Toe
description: WHEN the moment of clash finally arrives, when two minds go one-on-one at the line of scrimmage, it is easy to imagine debate as a contact sport.

title: Model Program
description: Terming Westchester's Department of Probation a model program, Gov. George E. Pataki presented the county with a proclamation at a recent Governor's Forum on Criminal Justice in Albany. It was the first time such an award has been presented.

title: Praise for Arts, but a Cold Shoulder for Artists
description: IT wasn't long ago that artists were welcomed and embraced in the nation's capital as well as in the mainstream news media. I vividly recall a reception called by John Brademas, then majority whip of the House, in a majestic room on the Hill in the late 1970's. The artists were lined up on one side -- they included Robert Rauschenberg, George Segal, James Rosenquist and a younger, post-Pop Art tribe that included video-performance-conceptualists like me. The whip introduced us to the other side, an assembled throng of Senators and Representatives. One of them was Edward I. Koch, then a New York Congressman. I shook his hand and expressed my sorrow that SoHo, where I live, was excluded from his district. ''If you live in SoHo,'' he told me, eyes gleaming, ''I am your Congressman in spirit.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LETTERS OF INTENT

title: Jordan Seeks Share in Hornets
description: Michael Jordan is negotiating to buy a share of the Charlotte Hornets, National Basketball Association officials confirmed yesterday.

title: March 21-27; Jackson Says, 'No Thanks'
description: Campaign after campaign, supporters of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson greeted the civil rights leader with the rallying cry, ''Run Jesse Run!'' This time, he could not be enticed. Mr. Jackson, who has run twice for President, announced he would sit out the 2000 contest, saying he would rather concentrate on persuading corporations to invest in minority businesses. ''The time spent running for President is time that cannot be spent doing something else,'' he said. ''I've got so many issues I want to raise. I've got so many battles left to fight.''

title: Orioles Try to Rally From a Down Season
description: Chris Hoiles succinctly summed up the Baltimore Orioles' 1998 season. ''It pretty much goes to show you can't buy a World Series,'' Hoiles, the team's erstwhile catcher, said. Not even for $72 million.

title: Scott Gold and Diana Olick
description: Diana Meredith Olick, the daughter of Alice and Philip S. Olick of New York, was married last evening to Scott Wagner Gold, the son of Paula Gold of Boston and Herbert Gold of Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: OPINION; Misleading Fallout From Radiation
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY has appropriated $300,000 to appease a number of East End pressure groups that are dedicated to closing Brookhaven National Laboratory. The money will be taken from the county's health and environment programs to allow these groups to conduct independent sampling and reporting in the search for plutonium that may have been released by the lab and leached into the Peconic River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, DR. MORTIMER A.
description: ROSENFELD-Dr. Mortimer A. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Raleigh, N.C. Beloved father of Amelia and the late Mark. Dear grandfather of Lillian and Miriam. Devoted sonin-law of Rose Fishel. Cherished husband of the late Babette. He will be greatly missed by members of the Rosenfeld and Albert families.

title: Florio Is Pinning His Hopes On South Jersey Rising Again
description: While former Gov. Jim Florio quietly lined up two more Democratic county chairmen last week to support his possible run for the Senate, some of the state's Democratic leaders continued their scramble to line up more candidates to try to block his political comeback.

title: Women of Which Cloth? Tweed? Cashmere?
description: BEFORE leading services at Central Synagogue in Manhattan, Rabbi Jill Kreitman, 35, performs a few rituals: she splashes on Spring Flower perfume by Creed, applies Stila lipstick and slips on flats by Prada or Gucci. ''When you have to get up to take out the Torah from the Holy Ark during services, you don't want to be wobbly,'' Rabbi Kreitman said. She also irons her hair, because, she adds, the light on the pulpit ''tends to accentuate the frizzies.''

title: The Human Habitat
description: It's a shame that your broad-ranging survey of ''The Human Habitat'' was introduced by the narrow views of Michael Pollan. In other issues of the magazine, your design features show how architects and designers not only create visual delight but also provide comfort and solve functional problems. Pollan seems to regard these professionals as meddlers in the ''real world.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOYAR, JANE
description: BOYAR-Jane. March 28, 1997. You are always with me. Burt

title: Tracing the Origins Of 'Empire State'
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Newman And Alex Brown
description: Jennifer Robinson Newman, the daughter of Stephen and Judith Newman of McLean, Va., was married last evening to Alexander Lev Brown, the son of Rona and Ralph Brown of Chicago. Cantor Deborah Bard officiated at the Hotel Inter-Continental in Chicago.

title: The Preparation and Installation of Attic Vents
description: LAST week this column discussed the need for proper attic ventilation with vents. Vents rely on natural temperature differences within the attic to move the air. They use no electricity, so they are economical. In most cases, a few well-positioned vents may be all you need to keep the air recycling in your attic.

title: Classics of the Middle American Variety
description: GRACIE'S Hearty Foods and Spirits is a humble, homespun, new restaurant in downtown Rocky Point serving large portions of American classic dishes at penny-wise prices. Named after Gracie Sutphen, a local short-order cook and a grandmother of John and Jim Barchi, who bought Harry's, a 1939 vintage bar and turned it into a restaurant and bar about three months ago, Gracie's is in a modest neighborhood, at the corner of Broadway and Prince Road (744-9179). But this little landmark cottage, with the look of a middle-American roadhouse, could just as easily be in Iowa or Indiana (like them, it's a cash-only operation). Deviled eggs, meatloaf, pot roast, chicken pot pie, apple pie a la mode, bread pudding and old-fashioned strawberry shortcake on weekends are on the menu. Warm corn muffins and raisin bread greet diners, and the early-eating weekday dinnertime crowd has, for the most part, cleared out by 8 P.M.

title: Giving Women a Fitness Place of Their Own
description: A CLUB only for women? Is that sexist? A return to the 50's?

title: A Family Tradition Inspires a Boutique
description: Clothing design began as a family exercise for Michael Sin, the owner of a self-named boutique in the East Village. ''My grandmother and mother sewed and crocheted,'' he said, ''so I learned early.'' Mr. Sin's three-week-old shop, at 21 Avenue B, near Third Street, is the culmination of years in the fashion industry, designing in Paris, London and the South Beach section of Miami Beach, and also a change of heart: ''I was studying to be a psychologist until I made the switch to fashion in 1986.''

title: Business Ventures
description: The Women's Enterprise Project, which helps female welfare recipients begin businesses of their own, recently received two grants: $57,000 from the Westchester Industrial Development Agency and $57,000 from the County Department of Social Services.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: THE FINAL FOUR -- Only Connecticut Stands in Duke's Way Now; Blue Devils Survive a Scare
description: He was 2 for 8 up to this point, and his shooting stroke was as icy as the playgrounds in his native Alaska. But Trajan Langdon wanted the ball. Michigan State had just closed to within 3 points, 51-48, and Langdon's teammate and Duke's inside dominator, Elton Brand, was on the bench with four fouls.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Another Italian Deli, Up the Hill From Hoboken
description: To the Editor:

title: They Sure Were Nonprofit Musicals
description: FOR musicals with big bold intentions, they certainly didn't make much noise. The first to come and go quietly was ''Parade,'' the funereal $5.5 million Lincoln Center Theater show about the lynching of Leo Frank. Next was ''Bright Lights Big City,'' the $500,000 musical adaptation of the Jay McInerney novel that opened and closed at New York Theater Workshop in what seemed like the span of a single yawn. The last to depart, ''Captains Courageous,'' a $1 million musical that opened in mid-February to the equivalent of a citywide shrug, is to vacate the Manhattan Theater Club next Sunday.

title: March 21-27; Bright Lights, Wrong City
description: Two buildings, a continent apart, with crowds peppered with celebrities. But there the similarities ended. At the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, film stars stepped smilingly in for the Academy Awards ceremony. And at Police Headquarters in Manhattan, former mayors, other politicians, union leaders, even a few actors, gathered day after day to protest the shooting of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed man who died in a hail of 41 police bullets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINGLE, WILLIAM F.
description: BRINGLE-William F. March 19, 1999. Survived by wife Donnie and son Donald Bringle. A memorial service will be held at U.S.N.A. Chapel, Annapolis, MD, Tuesday, April 6, 2:00 PM.

title: Depression Drugs Outperform Placebos; A Chronic Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, SAMUEL J.
description: WALD-Samuel J. At age 90 of Hallandale, FL, died March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Sara for 63 years, cherished father of Dr. Stewart (Beth) and Marcia; adored grandfather of Erica (Bill) Britton, Jonathan (Stacey), Douglas (Alex); and loving greatgrandfather of three. Former President of Lincoln Engraving & Printing Corp. and Executive Vice President of Bowne & Co. of New York City. Services were held in Florida.

title: March 21-27; In Japan, a Ritual Suicide Strikes a Chord
description: A Japanese manager shocked the nation when he committed hara-kiri in a protest of the corporate restructuring that is starting to take place across the country. Moments before he slashed his stomach with a 14-inch fish-slicing knife, Masaharu Nonaka had been in heated talks with the president of the Bridgestone Corporation, one of the world's largest tire makers.

title: Krajicek Wins Final as the Backup Act
description: Before Richard Krajicek and Sebastien Grosjean, the pair of marquee also-rans who toiled today in the final of what had become an anticlimactic men's event at the Lipton Championships, marched out to battle on the sun-blasted stadium court this afternoon, they nearly had to ask permission to use it.

title: March 21-27; A Windfall in the Budget
description: Deficits have given way to surpluses, but budget politics in Washington go on. Both the House and the Senate adopted Republican tax-and-spending plans, putting Congress on a collision course with the Clinton Administration over how to divide the huge fiscal windfall.

title: Derby Candidate Finishes Fourth
description: New Kentucky Derby candidates surfaced and old candidates faded from contention yesterday when Stephen Got Even won the $750,000 Gallery Furniture Stakes at Turfway Park in northern Kentucky while the favorite from the West Coast, Straight Man, finished fourth.

title: A Contemporary Island In a Sea of Antiques
description: Foundation, a contemporary furniture spot amid a sea of antiques shops, is set to open next week. Jayme Sklar, a Red Hook resident and Fashion Institute of Technology graduate, is opening the shop at 329 Atlantic Avenue (between Smith and Hoyt Streets) in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Unfair Comparison II
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Awaited At Cuban Airport
description: Several hundred Cubans crowded around the entrance to the terminal at Jose Marti Airport in Havana yesterday, eagerly awaiting the arrival of the advance contingent of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: The Many Messages Of the Lei
description: I BUY at least 50 leis a year. If I had the materials and the time I would make them myself, but I don't, so I buy them -- for birthdays, weddings, retirements, funerals, graduations, Lei Day (May 1), friends and their friends arriving in Hawaii from out of town, and sometimes, for no reason at all, just to place on my own shoulders.

title: A New Grandmaster Gives A Demonstration of Cool
description: Maurice Ashley, America's most recent grandmaster and the world's first black player to achieve that top rank, is, over the chessboard, a man for all seasons. In the Manhattan Chess Club's March International Tournament, which ended on March 15, he took second place behind only the Ukrainian grandmaster Georgy Timoshenko in the course of earning the grandmaster title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLONDMAN, JACK
description: BLONDMAN-Jack. Beloved husband of Madeline. Devoted father of Alan and Randi Blondman and Mark Blondman. Adoring and loving grandfather of Max, Evan, Marissa, Spencer and Henry. Services Sunday at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Amy Zuckerman And Morris Brown
description: Amy Beth Zuckerman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Zuckerman of Tucson, Ariz., was married last evening to Morris David Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Brown of Kingston, Pa. Rabbi Arthur Oleisky officiated at the Westin La Paloma hotel in Tucson.

title: Another Transplant to the Suburbs: Rats
description: THEY are the mascots of urban decay, at home in a tenement, the subways or the sewers of a Victor Hugo novel. But now rats are popping up in the suburbs of Long Island, in record numbers.

title: An Inmate's Family of Strangers; Bonds Sustain 12-Year Quest for a New Murder Trial
description: On a snowy afternoon in March 1986, someone fatally stabbed an inmate named Tyrone Julius at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora. Sixteen months later, David Wong, an illegal Chinese immigrant who was serving time for armed robbery, was convicted of second-degree murder in Mr. Julius's death and sentenced to 25 years to life in prison.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Growing Prospects Of Room at the Top
description: Frustrated middle managers wondering if they will ever have a chance to move up could be in for a pleasant surprise: Some demographics of the workplace are turning in their favor.

title: Western Canada Is Up in Arms Over Gun Control
description: When it comes to guns, people on Canada's frontier see things differently than the rest of the country does, and nothing shows that better than the shooting range that was in the basement of a local school for more than 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDENTHAL, RENEE
description: FRIEDENTHAL-Renee. Beloved wife of Walter. Dear daughter of Anna and the late Louis Sheinberg. Cherished mother of Eric and Felicity, and Alan and Laura. Loving sister of Myrna Goodman. Adoring grandmother of Lanie and Meryl. Funeral services today, 1 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: The World: Fog of War -- Coping With the Truth About Friend and Foe; Victims Not Quite Innocent
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S argument, enticing in its simplicity, packages the bombing of Yugoslavia's armed forces as a humanitarian mission: It is meant, he says, to halt a murderous campaign against innocent ethnic Albanians who make up 90 percent of the 2 million people living in the Serbian province of Kosovo.

title: Japan Weighs Formal Status For Its Flag And Anthem
description: The Japanese Government is trying to rehabilitate the flag of the rising sun and the national song of praise for the Emperor, giving them legal status despite criticism that in World War II they were emblematic of Japanese militarism.

title: Ideas & Trends; Slavery's Truths (and Tales) Come Flocking Home
description: Emancipation was declared in 1863, but it is in this last decade of the 20th century that historians and writers are writing freely about the brutality and violence of slavery -- taboo topics that have silenced families, black and white, for centuries.

title: Can't I.D. a Plant? Check Bud Arrangement
description: THE woody plants are still dormant. There is no better time to observe and learn the age-old method of identifying plants.

title: For Serbs, Apparatchik Appeals to Nationalist Pride to Become a Hero
description: For Slobodan Milosevic things have come full circle, returning to Kosovo, where almost 12 years ago, with one short phrase, he transformed himself from a colorless Communist hack into a firebrand of Serbian nationalism and set Yugoslavia on a course of conflict, fragmentation and violence.

title: A City Shaken By the Intensity Of Latest Raids
description: Residents of Belgrade, the Serbian capital, said today that for the first time since the NATO bombing started, large explosions had occurred in the city before air raid sirens sounded, giving credence to NATO assertions that Yugoslavia's integrated air defense system has been damaged, even around the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BICKERMAN, MILTON
description: BICKERMAN-Milton. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Milton Bickerman, associated with The Times from 1934 until retiring in 1985.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOODGOOD, GEORGE J.
description: BLOODGOOD-George J. On March 25, 1999, of congestive heart failure. Of Rockville Centre, NY. Loving husband of Patricia (nee Dolan). Beloved father of William, Maura, Patricia, Eileen, Regina and Deirdre. Dear fatherin-law of of Christopher Cleveland, Kevin Maler, and Sidice Mutandwa. Cherished grandfather of Henry Maler and Lillian Ryan. Devoted friend of Bill W. Retired substance abuse counselor after twenty-five year career with Time, Inc. He worked his way up from the mail room of Life Magazine to become Picture Editor of Sports Illustrated. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, St. Anthony's RC Church, Oceanside, NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: A South Florida Strongman Pushes for Secession From Miami-Dade County
description: This city's heart and soul are apparent along Okeechobee Road, which forms one of its borders with Miami: auto repair shops with names like Torres Tires; travel agencies where one can book a fare or send money to a relative in Cuba; accountants' and lawyers' offices where speaking in Spanish is taken for granted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, BERNARD
description: UNGER-Bernard. On March 23, 1999, in Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Mary. Dear brother of Dr. Allen and Beth. Devoted uncle of Allison and Eric, David and Bradley. A retired U.S. Environmental Protection Agency personnel classifier, Bernie was a distinguished authority on personnel management and lectured widely in this field. He was a brilliant and kind man and will be sorely missed. Inurnment at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- The Ethicist; The Company You Keep
description: 'I've been offered a job at a questionable law firm. I'd only be working on civic-minded pro bono cases, not the dicier corporate accounts that pay the firm's bills. Should I take the job?' -- L.A., New York

title: On Line, Few Kick Tires, but Many Look
description: WHEN two of the leading on-line car-buying services, Autoweb.com and Autobytel.com, took their stocks public last week, investors found themselves scrambling to map out the differences between two companies with eerily similar business plans.

title: Officer Injured by a Rock
description: A New York City police sergeant driving on Southern State Parkway in Suffolk County was seriously injured Friday night when a rock went through his windshield and hit him in the head, causing him to crash his car into a tree, the police said.

title: Labor Dispute At Restaurant Keeps Sizzling
description: The dispute between Angelo & Maxie's Steakhouse and several former employees who said they were fired for trying to organize immigrant workers is unabated, nearly 10 months after an employee who began the unionizing effort was dismissed.

title: Rangers Left Bleeding, Dazed and Fading Fast
description: Every now and then, a single image seems to sum up an entire game, maybe even a whole season.
