One of those images could be seen here today, late in Philadelphia's 3-1 victory that helped reduce the Rangers' dwindling playoff hopes to rapidly dying dreams. In the picture was Petr Nedved, the Rangers' first-line center, on his hands and knees, dazed, with blood pouring from three cuts around his right eye.

title: Like an Italian
description: To the Editor:

title: The Outsider
description: After 32 years in the israeli Army, Yitzhak Mordechai could not help himself. When a graveside military salute began with rifles cocking, the former Minister of Defense snapped back his shoulders and lifted his chin. As he stood at attention, his craggy face was impassive but his eyes were misty. Another of his men was being lowered into the ground, and this one, Brig. Gen. Erez Gerstein, he had known well; it was Mordechai who had promoted him into his post in Lebanon, where he was killed.

title: The Human Habitat
description: 'Fifteen People, One Loft'' sent me back to my own postcollege days. We were recent graduates who rented a rambling house in Brookline, Mass., dubbed the ''House of Nine'' by our friends.

title: Editorial Observer; Is It Time for Ron Perelman to Sell Off Revlon?
description: Sometimes a company gets attention it would just as soon pass up. Last week Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company controlled by Ronald Perelman, got a double dose. Rumors of an impending takeover put the company at the top of the business section just as the generosity of its president, George Fellows, put it on the front page.

title: Schools, and Parents, Struggle With Redistricting Proposals
description: CAROL A. STUPORE of Dix Hills leaned forward in her seat in the auditorium of Half Hollow Hills High School East for a better look at the numbers being projected on the stage.

title: Mary Beaudet, Thomas Portzline
description: Mary Beaudet, a social worker, was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas Portzline, a psychiatrist. Judge Arlene H. Hahn of New York City Housing Court officiated at Bouterin, a restaurant in New York.

title: Mistreated Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Sherri Golden and Wayne Heller
description: Sherri Arlene Golden, a daughter of Elaine Golden Bressler of West Orange, N.J., and the late Norman S. Golden, is to be married this afternoon to Wayne Evan Heller, a son of Phyllis and George Heller of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Perspective; At Spring Training, a Sunny Disposition
description: David Cone plunked sprightly into his chair in the Yankees' clubhouse last week, only one coat of sweat glistening on his neck.

title: NATO's Claim of a New Focus Is Challenged
description: By moving to widen the attack against Yugoslavia's military targets, NATO is still trying to cut off the head of Belgrade's war machine rather than dismember it piece by piece.

title: The World; Kosovo's Brutal Game of See-Saw
description: ANTAGONISMS between Serbs and Albanians have marked Kosovo's history since the disintegration of the Ottoman Empire. Christian Serb forces seized the province in October 1912 during the first Balkan War. Massive recriminations against local Muslim Albanians followed, including the burning of villages and forced conversions, which were described by reporters, including the Vienna correspondent of the Ukrainian newspaper Kievskaia Mysl, Lev Bronshtein, later known as Leon Trotsky. At the time, Serbs made up about 25 percent of a population of about 300,000; most of the rest were Muslims who identified themselves as either Turks or Albanians. An estimated 20,000 Albanians were killed.

title: Vladimir Petrov Is Dead at 83; Soviet Prisoner
description: Vladimir Petrov, who survived six years in a Soviet prison camp and later became a professor of international affairs at George Washington University, died on March 17 in his home in Kensington, Md., a suburb of Washington. He was 83.

title: Look Who's Joining The Internet Parade
description: The Internet seems to have an odd catnip quality for political heavyweights, and vice versa. Vice President Al Gore hardly had time to live down his widely ridiculed recent remarks seeming to claim partial credit for inventing cyberspace, when along came word that a hot Internet stock has added none other than Bob Dole to its board of directors.

title: Our Towns; When to Fire? For the Police, It's No Game
description: TERRY HOWARD, normally a power-plant operator but playing a state trooper for now, pulled over the woman in the red convertible for running a stop sign, and when she aimed a gun at him, he killed her with a shot to the head.

title: The Metamorphosis
description: KAFKA'S CURSE By Achmat Dangor. 225 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.

title: In Freewayland Without a Car
description: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA has for so long been the land of the freeway that the idea of negotiating it carless seems daunting, even revolutionary. But as traffic has thickened so that many highways become eight-lane parking lots during increasingly extended rush hours, residents and visitors are turning to public transportation to get around, and municipalities are extending mass transit systems.

title: Bud Arrangment Clue To Plant Identification
description: THE woody plants are still dormant. There is no better time to observe and learn the age-old method of identifying plants.

title: IN MY... FIBERGLASS CASE: JAMES MARTIN
description: A lot of executives carry laptop computers. But James Martin, 65, the founder of several technology companies and now an independent, globe-trotting consultant, carries two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALNITSKY, GEORGE
description: KALNITSKY-George. Age 81, of Longboat Key, FL, and Iowa City, Iowa, died March 23, 1999. He was a biochemistry professor at the University of Iowa School of Medicine.

title: Dishes That Can Brighten Both Passover and Easter
description: PASSOVER and Easter converge closely this year -- and when it comes to appropriate dishes for those holidays, there can also be a certain degree of overlap.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, JOEL A.
description: HALPERN-Joel A. 18 years since your tragic accident. We think of you every day with pride and unending love. You are in our hearts forever. Mother and Dad

title: The Classics: Italian Fare, Solicitous Service
description: PERUSING the short menu in the spacious dining room at La Fontanella in Stamford reminded us how much Italian restaurants in Connecticut have changed over the past 20 years. The former occupant of the premises was Armando's, whose Southern Italian menu was typical of its time, as is La Fontanella's, which touches on several regional Italian cuisines.

title: A Maestro Of Esoteric Invention Becomes Accessible
description: IN 1937 John Cage inaugurated a musical revolution in three sentences of typically Zenlike simplicity: ''Wherever we are, what we hear is mostly noise. When we ignore it, it disturbs us. When we listen to it, we find it fascinating.'' In the future, he declared, music would be replaced by a broader field of creativity, which he called ''the organization of sound.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, ALFRED
description: WEIL-Alfred. A World War II Veteran and a member of the Masonic Lodge, died at his home in Riverdale, New York on March 24, 1999. Mr. Weil was born December 8, 1916 in Germany, and was predeceased by his wife Ruth Orlikoff Weil in 1981. He is survived by his sisters-in-law Mrs. Eva Dobrofsky, Mrs. Esther Keil, and Mrs. Doris Orlikoff; his Brother-in-law Horace Greenberg; his Nieces Lynne Arkin, Helene Christianson, Harriet Harris and Nephews Neal Dobrofsky, Gary Greenberg, Michael Orlikoff of California, Michael S. Orlikoff of Phoenix, AZ, and Steven Orlikoff of New York City. A graveside service will be at 2 PM Sunday, March 28 at Salem Fields Cemetery at the Kaufman-Rothschild Mausoleum.

title: Ms. Biggar, Mr. Kaniewski
description: Lynne Michelle Biggar, a marketing executive, and Thomas Edward Kaniewski, a television producer, were married yesterday at First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony.

title: Lonesome Glory Rallies to Win
description: After trailing the field for the first mile and three-quarters of the race, the four-time steeplechaser of the year, Lonesome Glory, caught the front-running Assurance at the 14th and final jump and then galloped out to post a 6-length lead in the 67th running of the Carolina Cup Steeplechase yesterday in Camden, S.C.

title: Do Brand Names Help Children Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Time-Killing 1040
description: IF there is any time of year that most of us would love to skip, this is it. Taxes are due in less than three weeks, and only two weekends remain for us to lock ourselves away and get the chore done. The pressure is on.

title: When Hats Were Fun (and Fashionable, Too)
description: JUDY GARLAND strutted her flowered picture hat in the movie ''Easter Parade.'' Maurice Chevalier, always debonair, tipped his boater in ''Gigi.'' Hats were the crowning touch.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOUMBAKIS, ANNE CHRISTINA,
description: TOUMBAKIS - Anne Christina, Tuesday, March 30th, 1999, 7 PM. St. Vladimir's Orthodox Seminary, 575 Scarsdale Rd., Crestwood, NY.

title: March 21-27; Conviction for Kevorkian
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian was convicted of second-degree murder for giving a lethal injection to a 52-year-old man with Lou Gehrig's disease. Dr. Kevorkian, who defended himself at the trial in Pontiac, Mich., faces a minimum sentence of 10 to 25 years in prison. It was the 70-year-old doctor's first murder trial. In the past, he has been charged only with assisted suicide. He was acquitted three times and a fourth case resulted in a mistrial.

title: March 21-27; A Call for Changes in the 737
description: The rudder system of the Boeing 737 should be changed, the National Transportation Safety Board said, to meet one of the simplest principles of aviation: that every crucial part have a back-up. The recommendation for the world's most popular airliner was based on investigations of two crashes and several smaller mishaps, and could be among the most far-reaching the board has ever made.

title: A Cape May Estate
description: Reserve chardonnay, 1997, and reserve cabernet sauvignon, 1996. (Each $15 at the winery.)

title: New Home For a Lost Generation Of Innovators
description: LIKE a growing number of young Asian entrepreneurs, Nobuhiro Michishita saw a future for himself in cyberspace but felt that he had to go to the United States to pursue it.

title: A Secretive Army Grows to Maintain Order in China
description: In late 1997, President Jiang Zemin announced that China would cut the People's Liberation Army, then three million strong, by half a million troops as part of China's drive for a leaner, more advanced military that could both defend the homeland and reinforce China's image as a power in Asia.

title: U.S. STEALTH FIGHTER IS DOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA AS NATO ORDERS ATTACK ON SERB ARMY UNITS
description: An American F-117 stealth fighter went down in Yugoslavia tonight, the first allied loss in the four-day Balkan conflict, even as NATO officials announced a broad new phase of the air assault on Serbian targets.

title: Of Shards of History, Love, Hate and Family
description: THEY enter laughing, a happy family for all the world to see. But everyone who knows what the fates ordained for the Tyrones is hearing the most chilling laughter in contemporary theater.

title: Artist Sees Hope in Mastectomy Ruling
description: When a doctor removed one of her breasts eight years ago, telling her the mastectomy could save her life, JoAnne Motichka transformed her scarred chest into political art.

title: 70 Minutes on an Emotional Roller-Coaster: A Solo Journey From Ohio to Auschwitz
description: ''BIZARRE MURDER!!! A Lesbian Forces Blind Holocaust Victim on Roller Coaster!''

title: Style; Malibu Xanadu
description: Not long ago, a French television crew came to Los Angeles to do a segment on contemporary local designers and architects. They found a bunch of of midcentury modern types, who practiced a stark minimalism, and they found Tony Duquette, who practiced whatever it is that's on the opposite pole of the planet from that. Or, as Duquette put it when told who else was in the segment, ''the other side of the forest.''

title: An Improved Ligeti Masterpiece
description: PROBABLY no opera of the last quarter-century has been seen by more people than Gyorgy Ligeti's ''Grand Macabre.'' Since its premiere in Stockholm in 1978, the work has had several different stagings in Europe, though none so far in this country.

title: The Invisible Children of Illegal Aliens
description: SPURNED by caseworkers at the County Department of Social Services and threatened with deportation, Luisa L., an illegal Mexican immigrant, worries where to turn next. Eleven years after arriving in the United States with the hope of work and a promising future, she spends her days performing odd jobs and struggling to feed and clothe her three American-born children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, BELLE
description: TANNENBAUM-Belle. Beloved wife of Larry. Devoted mother of Stephen and Peter. Four adoring grandsons. She is also survived by her sister Laura Soberman. Services will held Monday 1 PM, at I. J. Morris, Inc., 21 E. Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY.

title: He Won't Have Manhattan
description: Little brown birds tapped on the window of Daniel Hauben's studio in a garden apartment on 247th Street, just west of the Henry Hudson Parkway, as they visited a feeder that Mr. Hauben had attached to the pane. The view from his window, a tree-lined block, was almost suburban.

title: Protect Wilderness From Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: Black History On Campus
description: A 1907 campus scene, ''Portia Playing Basketball'' (shown at right), is one in a series of photos that were considered irrefutable evidence that the educational system of the historically black Hampton Institute (now Hampton University) in Hampton, Va., improved its students' lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLVERT, RONALD S.
description: CALLVERT-Ronald S. Of New York City, died Thursday March 25, aged 86. Beloved husband of Lidia Sava Callvert and devoted stepfather to Lumi Sava. Grew up in Portland, Oregon, where he was born. Graduate of Stamford University Class of 1933. His first wife was Isabel Errington Callvert who died in 1977. His whole career was with the Bell System and AT&T Company. When he retired in 1976, he was Vice President of Public Relations at AT&T's Headquarters in New York. He was life member of Explorers Club. For over 50 years, he explored, discovered and photographed Mayan ruins in Central America. He wrote, narrated and produced four TV shows entitled ''The Mystery of the Ancient Mayas'', shown repeatedly on PBS. Services will be held at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, (between 69th and 70th Street) Monday, March 29, 11 AM.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, JOSEPH J.
description: DAVIS-Joseph J. June 13, 1950March 28, 1993. Thank you for your beautiful life, love and music. Mary, Family and Friends

title: BENEFITS
description: Seen Here First

title: West Meets East
description: A global audience convened this month in Paris for the fashion collections by top international designers. Many of the guests wore the less-extreme designs of the most avant-garde talents, whose shows rivaled art happenings. Chief among them were four Japanese designers, whose work is shown here: Rei Kawakubo (1), Junya Watanabe (2, 4), Yohji Yamamoto (3, 5, 7, 8, 9) and Issey Miyake (6). The four are known for innovative fabrics, somber colors and the reintroduction of architectural silhouettes, as in Mr. Watanabe's inventive use of aluminum tubing to shape designs. Their deconstruction of Western clothes is the dominant influence on fashion today.

title: To Some, Cinema Complex Is Not a Coming Attraction
description: Some residents of Bensonhurst are voicing fear that a proposed theater complex with up to 16 screens, 3,500 seats, 700 parking spaces and retail stores will snarl traffic and increase pollution in the neighborhood. And people who live in apartment buildings on Cropsey Avenue are expressing worry that congestion from the Bayside Cinema, at 25th Avenue and Shore Parkway, would trap them inside or outside their homes on Friday and Saturday nights.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: THE FINAL FOUR -- Only Connecticut Stands in Duke's Way Now; Huskies Step Over Ohio State
description: Jim Calhoun pumped his fists twice and then, one by one, embraced the players who had carried him to the brink of a national championship. There was Khalid El-Amin, the rotund point guard, and Richard Hamilton, the silky shooter. Ricky Moore, the defensive whiz, was next.

title: A Quarrelsome Product Of a Handshake Deal
description: BILL MARVIN can remember when a handshake and a promise were good enough to do business with his company. That was the way he built a small-town lumber company into the largest custom window manufacturer in the world. Now a handshake deal gone bad may prove to be the company's undoing.

title: Places of the Heart; Historic Houses of Worship, From Soaring Spires to Simple Quaker Meeting Houses
description: BERNARD A. FLANAGAN fell in love with the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart when he was a child.

title: For 'Bunny,' Oscar Caps Much Work
description: THE seven-minute film ''Bunny'' from Blue Sky Studios, the Harrison-based computer animation company, won an Oscar at the 71st Academy Awards last Sunday, topping four other competitors in the Best Animated Short Film category.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 40 of The Times Magazine today, about the responsibility of the United States as the world's remaining superpower, contains several outdated references to the conflict in Kosovo and what role the United States should have in ending it. The NATO bombing raids now under way in Yugoslavia began after the magazine was printed.

title: Ancient Thracian Art On View in Boston
description: They had no alphabet and left no documents about their culture. Most of what is known about the Thracians, who, from the earliest historical times, occupied land that is now part of Bulgaria, northern Greece, western Turkey and Romania, came from the writings of their neighbors, especially the Greeks and the Romans.

title: The Young Woman Most Invited
description: AT age 4, Aerin Lauder liked to play dress-up. In a photograph from that period snapped at the Palm Beach, Fla., house of her grandmother, the cosmetics empress Estee Lauder, Aerin vogues in Mrs. Lauder's straw hat and gold sandals. One arm, saucily perched on her hip, is sheathed to the elbow in a white satin glove.

title: Alleluias, Glorias and Simpler Songs, Too
description: FOR the past few years, amid the works by Handel, Bach, Dupre and Brahms, a simpler form of song has crept into the Easter repertory. It is called Taize and it originated in the early 1940's in a French village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, PAULINE WASHBURN,
description: ROGERS-Pauline Washburn, 79 of Niantic, CT formerly of New York City, died on Friday, March 19, 1999. She is the widow of Francis Day Rogers. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM on Friday, April 2, 1999 at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Lyme St, Old Lyme, CT. Donations may be made in her memory to the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme or a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Drug Marketing Starts Legal Battle
description: Two drug companies seeking to tap the vast market of postmenopausal women at risk for breast cancer, heart disease and bone loss have clashed with each other and run afoul of the Food and Drug Administration over their marketing practices, prompting a flurry of lawsuits, Government warning letters and accusations that inaccurate assertions could endanger women's health.

title: Let's Get Serious
description: In the right hands, humor can be an invaluable capitalist tool. It can break tension, restore perspective and promote creative thinking. How have you used humor on the job to solve a problem or wriggle out of a tough situation? Or how did your attempt backfire? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: March 21-27; Cruise Line Takes a Plea
description: Royal Caribbean Cruises pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Los Angeles to three counts of making false statements to Coast Guard inspectors in an attempt to conceal the illegal dumping of oily waste water into the Pacific Ocean in 1994. Prosecutors believe the unexpected admission reinforces United States jurisdiction over foreign cruise ships. Royal Caribbean, the world's second-largest cruise company, still faces potential dumping charges in New York and Alaska. The industry is under Congressional scrutiny on several fronts, including whether to alter the tax-free status that saves foreign ships plying American waters billions of dollars a year. DOUGLAS FRANTZ

title: In This School Tournament The Final Four Were Robots
description: THE scene inside the Hartford Meadows Music Theater was hot, intense, surreal. A half-dozen teen-agers wearing face paint and jungle camouflage wheeled a cylindrical metal object up a ramp to a stage alive with smoke, lights, and the banshee-like wail of thousands of screaming spectators.

title: Varied Group Lists Demands For the Police
description: An uncommon assembly of politicians, labor leaders, clergy members and business executives, representing the broad array of protesters in the weeks after the killing of Amadou Diallo, announced 10 demands yesterday to create ''a safer and more just New York,'' including hiring more black and Hispanic police officers and creating a permanent special prosecutor for police brutality and corruption in New York.

title: A Goldwyn on the Way Up in the Family Business
description: ABOUT five years ago, the actor Tony Goldwyn started getting restless. ''I'd gotten to the point in my career where I knew I would get work -- I knew the mortgage would get paid,'' he says. His performance in the 1990 off-Broadway play ''The Sum of Us'' had put him on the New York theater map. The same year, his portrayal of the yuppie villain in ''Ghost'' had done the same in Hollywood. But he wanted more.

title: The Sperminator
description: In July 1995, a young man died suddenly in a California hospital. Within hours, his wife's family was on the phone to Cappy Rothman, a urologist at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. They asked him to meet her at the morgue to collect sperm from her late husband's corpse. Thirty hours after his death, the man produced the sperm that now, four years later, has resulted in his wife's pregnancy. She is due to deliver the baby this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLEK, FANNY
description: DALLEK-Fanny. We mourn the loss of a wonderful matriarch. Along with her loving husband, the late Nathan Dallek, she established the office furniture business that continues to flourish in its third generation. Heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Shirley Cohen, son Godfrey Dallek, brother Jerry Rothman, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, sister-in-law, brothers-in-law, son-in-law, nieces, nephews and extended family. Dallek Inc

title: The Premise Is, Poking Fun Can Be a Poke in the Eye
description: HOLLYWOOD is roiling in violence and infighting. Never have so many famous people committed such bizarre and savage acts against one another. Witness some of the star-studded mayhem:

title: Alliance Fights a Plan to Develop a Florida Getaway Born of Racism
description: For years in Dade County, until 1945, the Atlantic Ocean was emerald green and deep blue, the beach was black-specked gray, and the people who swam and sunbathed and built castles in the sand were, by law, white. Jim Crow laws banned black people from Miami Beach, from Key Biscayne, from a picture-postcard ocean that gave South Florida a reason for being.

title: Whose English?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; Tropical Heat
description: In the beginning there was bumbu. Such was the epiphany that Heinz von Holzen experienced shortly after he arrived in Bali 10 years ago. The exacting Swiss-trained chef had gone to the island to create a world-class dining room in one of the island's most exclusive hotels. His mission was to produce Balinese cuisine incorporating traditional European techniques and concepts. But in less than a month, he was convinced that for a neophyte the assignment was impossible.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELKIN, DAVID B.
description: ELKIN-David B. March 28, 1998. Miss you always, dear brother. Love you. Ethel

title: March 21-27; Oscar's Hangover
description: As a four-hour endurance contest, the 71st annual Academy Awards seemed even longer than usual. By the time it was over, the question of the night was, what were former Senator John Glenn and Colin L. Powell doing on stage? No one knew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKIN, RUTH BACHARACH.
description: ASKIN-Ruth Bacharach. March 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Seymour R. Askin. Stepmother of Seymour R. Askin, Jr. and Susan A. Wolman. Step-grandmother of Peter and Nancy Askin, Paul, Peter, and Margot Wolman. Step great-grandmother of Julia Askin. Loving aunt of James Goldsmith, Ann Harris and Peggy Goldstein. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Pinochet Faces 33 New Counts In Extradition
description: The Spanish judge whose extradition request has kept Gen. Augusto Pinochet under house arrest in London for the past five months today sent British prosecutors 33 new charges of human rights abuses against the former Chilean dictator.

title: For Individual Artists, Museums All Their Own
description: I DON'T know what it says about America that we have a Yogi Berra Museum but not an Alexander Calder Museum. Maybe Calder didn't play on the right team. Or maybe the art world needs better managers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-24

title: It Beats Hanging Out at the Cooler
description: Who says the workplace has to be about carpel tunnel syndrome? ''There are a lot of demented minds out there ready to have fun,'' said Matt Weinstein, the mastermind behind the fourth annual International Fun at Work Day on April 1. Mr. Weinstein, founder of Playfair Inc., a San Francisco consulting firm, has signed up hundreds of companies, including Federal Express and AT&T, for the event.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUNDIN, BERTHA
description: LUNDIN-Bertha. 1891-1983. Happy Birthday, Darling Mother. We're so lucky to have had you. Phyllis, Bob, Dick & Carole Anne

title: Deborah Streicher, David Rosen
description: Deborah Beth Streicher, the daughter of Carolyn and Richard Streicher of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to David Mark Rosen, the son of Helen and Arnold Rosen of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Using Dummies to Speak Out Against Advertising
description: While many people have come to accept the huge painted advertisements on buildings along Houston Street, between Lafayette Street and West Broadway, as part of the urban landscape, members of a neighborhood group called Public Works say they are dismayed by the commercial use of such highly visible public space. On Monday night, they demonstrated their opposition to the advertisements by suspending mannequins from scaffolding at a building at Broadway and Houston Street.

title: Serial Muse
description: Diaries 1898-1902

title: An N.Y.U. Plan Casts a Shadow
description: When Jane Gaddis moved to the neighborhood in 1950, she thought of Washington Square Park as a sort of an island within an island, a refuge from vertical Manhattan. Then, in the early 1970's, New York University opened the 150-foot-high Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, which takes up an entire block at 70 Washington Square South. Now the university has unveiled a plan to build an equally tall $70 million student center next to the library to replace the deteriorating Loeb Student Center on Washington Square South, and Ms. Gaddis isn't taking the news well.

title: The Human Habitat
description: Your issue on ''The Human Habitat'' was engrossing and visually strong -- worthy of bravos.

title: From Unemployed To Interview-Ready
description: THEY were 19 men down on their luck, and they came to the penthouse of the Times Square Hotel in New York at 1 P.M. on a rainy January day to get a big boost in their search for work.

title: PLUS: ROWING -- SAN DIEGO CREW CLASSIC; Cal Dominates Qualifying Heats
description: California dominated yesterday's qualifying heats at the 26th annual San Diego Crew Classic.

title: Elizabeth Scanlon, John Paskowski
description: Elizabeth Diane Scanlon, a daughter of Dorothy and John T. Scanlon of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. John Richard Paskowski, a son of Dr. Catherine Paskowski and Dr. Richard Paskowski of New City, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, SAM
description: MEYERSON-Sam. Three Arrows Co-op Society mourns the loss of our longtime member and active participant. Deepest sympathy to children Lucy Isaacs, Jon (Beverly), Tina Louie (Ming), grandchildren, brother Max (Edythe). Alice Appenzeller, President

title: A Hoboken Album
description: Though much of the architecture in Hoboken has been around for a long time, a display of photographs of the city in the 1950's and 60's shows that much of the atmosphere has changed. The photographs, by a skilled amateur named Anita Heimbruch, show yards crisscrossed by clotheslines, corner peddlers and stately old ferries traveling to Manhattan. Miss Heimbruch worked for much of her life at the old Keuffel & Esser instruments company (now the Clock Tower apartment building), at one point raising spiders whose web filaments were used to make gun and surveying sights. She died a few years ago, and her nursing home informed the Hoboken Historical Museum that she had left it her slides, most of Europe, but some of her hometown. The local pictures, made into prints, are on show through May 1 at the Truckstop Cafe, 723 Jefferson Street, Hoboken, (201) 217-9616. Some prints are for sale, framed, for $125.

title: Lives; The Medium Has a Message
description: I'm at a party talking with people about art, politics, books. One person is an architect, the other a microbiologist, the next an English professor. I usually don't tell people what I do for a living, but this group seems open-minded, so I am lulled into saying, ''I'm a psychic.'' The conversation stops. They roll their eyes, smirk. Suddenly, my I.Q. has dropped 50 points.

title: 'Quality Time' on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Monica Ever Get Her Blue Dress Back?
description: Regarding Thomas Mallon's article (Feb. 28), we would like your readers to know that in our Watergate gallery -- the largest room in the museum devoted to a single subject -- we prominently display four pieces of White House tape-recording equipment, all on extended loan from the National Archives and Records Administration.

title: Getting Cancer Care On the Island
description: I am a breast cancer survivor. Five years ago I was told I had the disease by physicians and facilities on Long Island. At the insistence of my family to get a second opinion, still sore from the biopsy, I took the Long Island Rail Road into the city, schlepped across town and went to Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Bridging Boundaries in Israel
description: With ethnic conflict rampant in the world, reconciliation is suddenly big news in Israel. This month, Rana Raslan became the first Arab Miss Israel, Abdel Rahman Zu'bi became the first Arab appointed to the Israeli Supreme Court and an Arab member of Parliament said he would run for Prime Minister. It was the sort of ethnic intermingling that a couple of New York money managers, one Jewish, the other Arab-American, have promoted for years.

title: Long Island Beachhead For Southwest Airlines
description: Southwest Airlines began flying to Long Island this month, providing service to MacArthur Airport in Islip, N.Y., from Baltimore-Washington, Chicago, Nashville and Tampa. And US Airways began a new service, hourly flights between La Guardia and Dulles International Airport outside Washington.

title: Vaise Lawhorne, Louis Gerstner 3d
description: Mary Gervaise Lawhorne, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lawhorne Jr. of Columbus, Ga., was married yesterday to Louis Vincent Gerstner 3d, the son of Mr. Gerstner Jr., the chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., and Mrs. Gerstner of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Douglas McBane Renegar, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church, Frederica on St. Simons Island, off the Georgia coast.

title: In the Region/Long Island; New Developments Returning to Main Street
description: THE attraction of living within walking distance of restaurants and cultural activities persuaded Eli Egozi and his wife, Kathleen, to settle for a 2,500-square-foot semi-attached town house in a development called Harborview at Port Jefferson, even though their previous home in the Chicago suburb of Naperville had given them more than 4,000 square feet.

title: Vacation Getaway
description: TEETH OF THE DOG By Jill Ciment. 216 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $22.

title: Sailor Calls 1,000-Day Voyage an Adventure
description: Seldom does the allure of sailing come with a more outlandish vision than the trip planned by Reid Stowe, an artist and boat-builder living aboard a schooner off 23d Street in New York City. He and his bride-to-be want to go sailing for 1,000 days -- nonstop. But first comes a shake-down cruise this June, a whirlwind trip scheduled to last a mere 180 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETTAN, ANNE (NEE LIEBOWITZ).
description: WETTAN-Anne (nee Liebowitz). Loving wife of the late Nathan. Loving and devoted mother of Helene and Irwin Zuckerman. Loving sister of the late Jean Kessler, Abe Liebowitz and Sara Wettan. Loving aunt.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DOG EAT DOG By Jerry Jay Carroll. Ace, paper, $12.

title: The View From/Norwich; Jail Hill's Rich History Is Reborn in Research
description: CITIES with imperial pretensions often claim to have been built, like Rome, on seven hills. Norwich is one of those cities. In 1865 it had more millionaires per capita than any other city in the United States, said Dale Plummer, the city historian. Many of the tallest hills are named for the families that built the most prominent homes on those hills. But the seventh hill, the hill with the most sweeping views of the harbor at the confluence of the Shetucket, the Yantic and the Thames rivers, the hill that should have been the city's acropolis, is still known as Jail Hill, although the county jail was demolished in the 1950's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLLIN, ALBERT E.
description: GOLLIN-Albert E. Died peacefully among family on March 24, 1999. Beloved father of Mark and Karin Gollin, cherished husband of Ann K. Gollin, loving stepfather of Michael, Maria and Kaia. His compassionate wisdom, incisive wit, and discerning intellect will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at 2PM, Friday April 2, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by a reception at his home. In his memory, a fund for the advancement of public opinion research has been established at Columbia University. Contributions may be sent to Albert E. Gollin Memorial Gift, c/o Mark A. Gollin, 2409 East Helen St, Seattle WA 98112, checks to be made out to School of General Studies, Columbia University.

title: In Verdi's Words
description: To the Editor:

title: The Numbers May Change, But Not the Optimism
description: ONE of these years Abby Joseph Cohen, a managing director and chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, is going to change her tune about the stock market. But it's not going to be this year. Indeed, barring unforeseen developments, it seems that her largely positive view on equities will be in place in Y2K, too.

title: A Modest Proposal For Chopin
description: ANOTHER anniversary is upon us, yet the music business is strangely muted. Frederic Chopin died 150 years ago, and the relative silence has less to do with our forgetfulness than with our despair. For what are we to give the man who has everything?

title: Returning Life to an Urban Neighborhood
description: WASHINGTON PARK, nestled in a low-income neighborhood on Bridgeport's East Side, embodies much of what the city's cognoscenti say is its metropolitan character. Once the crown jewel of neighborhood parks in the Park City, its faded glory speaks of lost wealth, sophistication, industrial might and fashionable style, and the inimitable P. T. Barnum, perhaps the city's most famous personage.

title: The World; Cheap Oil Focuses Minds
description: WHEN Arabs united in 1973 to slap an oil embargo on the United States because it had supported Israel, the international oil cartel known as OPEC fell into line and shock waves reached every continent. In 1979, Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini launched a second oil shock when he telegraphed his consuming wrath at the ''Great Satan'' by slashing oil production in half. Again, the political passion behind the action drew OPEC's cooperation. Oil prices quadrupled in months.

title: The Evolution of a President: From a Protesting Dove to a Hesitant Hawk
description: Bill Clinton is a politician to his core, a man of persuasion, not intimidation. He has always been ambivalent about the use of force to accomplish his purposes, an ambivalence that mirrors his still uneasy relationship with the American military.

title: In America; Going to Extremes
description: There was nothing symbolic about the arrest of Rebecca Scanlon last week.

title: Andreina Rojas, Alfredo Sergio
description: Andreina Rojas Tovar and Alfredo Maria Sergio were married yesterday in Erwinna, Pa. Judge Nitza Quinones Alejandro of the Court of Common Pleas in Philadelphia officiated at the Golden Pheasant Inn.

title: A Mystical Tradition Brought Close to Home
description: YOU enter the cabala seminar half expecting to be enveloped by candlelight and the smell of incense, or met by bearded men in robes. That is still a popular view of this Jewish mystical tradition: magic shrouded in the occult, wrapped in superstition. But the weekday evening meeting at the Greenwich Village Synagogue on Charles Street is like a book discussion group, the 200-year-old synagogue well lighted by two rows of chandeliers.

title: Opening the World of Business to Children
description: IT started with a quarter. Karen Tenenbaum's daughter, Allison, put the coin in a vending machine. Out dropped a plastic egg with a fake quarter inside. Allison, then 6, was thrilled. But Mrs. Tenenbaum, 39, is a tax lawyer and an accountant. She was ''horrified,'' she said.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CONTROVERSIES AND COMMANDERS

title: In the Region/Westchester; Caldor Closings Bring Newcomers, Including Kmart
description: KMART, the country's second-largest discount retailer after Wal-Mart, will make its debut in Westchester County when it takes over three stores that had been leased to Caldor, the discount chain that recently announced it was going out of business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEGLAN, FRANCES C.
description: BEGLAN-Frances C. At age 95, formerly of Yonkers, New York, in California. Beloved mother of John Beglan, Margaret Murphy, Joseph F. Beglan, David Beglan, Eugene Beglan & Kathleen Pielli. Also survived by 20 grandchildren, 32 great grandchildren and two great great grandchildren. Mass 10AM Tuesday, March 30, 1999, St. Matthews RC Church, Warburton Avenue, Hastings on Hudson, NY. Interment Mt. Hope Cemetery.

title: At Last, a Ride Scarier Than the Turnpike
description: THE people at Six Flags Great Adventure, the voracious amusement park in Jackson, have it all wrong. A few months ago they declared ''an all-out assault on ride lines,'' as Bill Muirhead, the park's vice president, put it. But this . . . this . . . this thing they've now built at one edge of the park is only going to bring even more screamers out of the woodwork.

title: Ideas & Trends; Enough About Feminism. Should I Wear Lipstick?
description: WHEN the January issue of Glamour magazine reached its 2.2 million readers, some may have been surprised to find this line blaring from the cover: ''New for '99: You asked for it! Horoscopes. Psychic details you need for your love, lust and work life. Big Decisions!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUNGBLUTH, HENRY
description: JUNGBLUTH-Henry, 86. Passed away March 17, 1999. Of Franklin Square, Long Island. Henry Jungbluth was a World War II Veteran. He was employed by The New York Times in 1936 and retired 1974. He was member of The International Typographical Union, AFL-CIO for at least forty years. Survivors are his wife Evelyn of 63 years, his daughter Laura Denton and two grandchildren.

title: Tantantara!
description: THE SOUND OF TRUMPETS By John Mortimer. 273 pp. New York: Viking. $23.95.

title: The Human Habitat
description: I can't decide whether I am envious of Mark Greenberg and Robin Muhlfeld for their beautiful home, individual bedrooms and everyone having his ''own space,'' or overly disturbed by the fact that they have four vehicles parked in the drive (''New Money Is Inflating Suburban Homes''). Is it really necessary to have that many vehicles for one family? I hope that after they peruse the magazine, they read about global warming and the environment. A giant leap? I don't think so.

title: Fluent Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Attracting Industries From Manhattan to Jersey City
description: THE PATH trains run literally in the back yard of the old industrial building at 190 Baldwin Street, and the owners of the now-empty structure hope to use that proximity to transportation to attract printers and other graphic arts companies that are being squeezed out of lower Manhattan.

title: 'The Good Doctor' in Croton Falls
description: A WRITER must write, incessantly, day by day, hour after hour. He has no choice. In everyone he meets, he sees a character for a story or a play. When his train of thought goes to alternative pathways of life, he gets back on track with a new story idea. Sometimes the spinning wheels of his mind come to a standstill. That is called writer's block. Or they go nowhere. Then it is just a bad story. But a writer's course is never derailed.

title: Talking Your Way To Career Failure
description: Perhaps you were thinking it was the crucial assignment you flubbed, or the glaring gap in your resume, or petty politics in your office, or even illegal discrimination that was holding you back from the rapid career advancement you crave. No, no, no, according to one of the latest secrets-of-success books: It's how fast you talk.

title: A Family of Some Cultivation
description: JUST up the Garden State Parkway and across the Hudson River from here, the Channel Gardens of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan are traditionally awash in a sea of fragrant lilies at Easter.

title: PULSE; Auricular Illusion
description: ''Strangers are always asking, 'How did you stick that through your ear?' or 'Did that hurt?' '' said Brenda Brunson-Bey, left, a clothing designer, who wears jarringly large earrings, called ear spears. ''It's definitely a conversation piece,'' she added. ''But more important, it's a cultural piece.''

title: Into the Attic Of the History Of Flight
description: MY first glimpse of the Enola Gay was haunting. She seemed shrunken. Her forward fuselage, without wings and tail section, was propped on stands in a gloomy storage hangar. Still, she loomed in the dim, eerie light as the specter of an immense historic event.

title: Van Gundy and Sprewell on Different Pages
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy supported the risk the Knicks took in acquiring Latrell Sprewell after his league suspension for choking his previous coach, Golden State's P. J. Carlesimo. But now a slight fissure is starting to show in the relationship between Van Gundy and the three-time All-Star guard.

title: No, Not That Governor of Minnesota
description: Me

title: Mary Jane Conlon And Robert Reilly
description: Mary Jane Conlon, the dean of students at the Lincoln Center campus of Fordham University, and Robert J. Reilly, an assistant dean at the Fordham School of Law in Manhattan, were married on Friday. The Rev. James E. Hentges performed the ceremony at the Fordham University Church on the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.

title: First Master of the Universe
description: MORGAN

title: Two Who Transferred From Purdue Give Duke Extra Incentive in Final
description: Michele VanGorp and Nicole Erickson came to Purdue in 1995 hoping to lead the school to its first national championship in women's basketball.

title: Mild Winter Augurs Well for Trout Season
description: Even if you have made no preparations for the April 1 opening of the trout fishing season in New York State, there is still time to get some of your gear in order, an endeavor that should heighten your anticipation of the pleasures that lie ahead.

title: Sports of The Times; Connecticut Sails Happily In New Waters
description: THEY meant well, the people who told Jim Calhoun to have a great time at the Final Four. So he refrained from biting their heads off.

title: Underdog Mora Bids For a Spot On Mets
description: Melvin Mora wanted a shot at top-level play somewhere so badly he went halfway around the world before last season and ended up in Taiwan.

title: The Central Figures in a Long-Awaited Courtroom Battle
description: A veteran judge is to begin working with prosecutors and defense lawyers tomorrow in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on jury selection for the trial of four police officers from the 70th Precinct charged with attacking Abner Louima and of a sergeant accused of trying to cover up part of the assault.

title: The Newark Archdiocese Grows, and Sprouts Palm Trees
description: The Turks and Caicos, with their white sandy beaches, palm trees and coral reefs, are about as physically different from Newark as they can be, not to mention being a British colony that is 1,000 miles away. But in one sense the islands are a part of Newark. On Jan. 3, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark began overseeing the 6,000 Roman Catholic island residents, adding them to about 1.5 million in Essex, Hudson, Bergen and Union Counties. On that date Joseph Cardinal Tomko, Prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelization of People, turned over canonical possession of the string of 12 islands 90 miles north of Haiti to Theodore E. McCarrick, the Archbishop of Newark. Archbishop McCarrick talked recently about the archdiocese's new assignment.

title: Meredith Artley, Naka Nathaniel
description: Meredith Lynn Artley and Nakana'ela Scott Nathaniel were married on Thursday by Paula Pagan, a marriage clerk, at the Municipal Building in New York.

title: The Nation: Flame Throwers and Radio Transmitters; For Car Thieves, a Technological Arms Race
description: THE end of the cold war has had many unexpected effects, but few are as unusual as the arms race that has developed between the people who make cars and the people who steal them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KREIDMAN, RICHARD
description: KREIDMAN-Richard. March 28, 1945-April 30, 1993. We miss you so much. Always in our hearts, now and forever. Sister Tina, Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROUD, EDWIN T.
description: STROUD-Edwin T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edwin T. Stroud, associated with The Times since 1960 until retiring in 1987.

title: The Envelope, Please
description: After the Oscars last Sunday, awards fever continued with the fifth annual Cosmetic Executive Women Beauty Awards, the beauty industry's less dressy but no less self-important version of the Academy Awards. About 1,100 industry insiders voted, from scientists to beauty editors, and the top-secret results were delivered to the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria in sealed envelopes by the accounting firm Ernst & Young.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNNEWELL, ELEANOR MCCLURG.
description: HUNNEWELL-Eleanor McClurg. Of Westwood, Massachusetts and Prouts Neck, Maine on March 19, 1999. Wife of James F. Hunnewell. Mother of James F. Hunnewell Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Ogden McC. Hunnewell of Brookline and Robert C. Hunnewell of Wenham. Sister of Barbara McClurg Potter of Chicago, Illinois. Also survived by five grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held in the Trinity Church Copley Square Boston, on Wednesday, April 21 at 10:30 A.M. Relatives and friends are invited. In lieu of flowers remembrances may be sent to the Vincent Memorial Hospital in Boston, The Gore Place Society in Waltham or the Prouts Neck Association in Prouts Neck, Maine. J.S. Waterman and Sons-Eastman-Waring Funeral Service Kenmore Square, Boston.

title: Q and A
description: Cranberry Bogs

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Under House Arrest

title: The Human Habitat
description: Rejoice! ''The Human Habitat'' apparently is still a place for reading. Almost all the pictures, even the ads, show newspapers, magazines and books -- sometimes shelves of them. Richard Kostelanetz, the artist and writer, has books jammed to the ceiling; a homeless man saves his in a storage locker. The few rooms without books seem curiously vacant. It is a quiet sign of hope.

title: Bombs Fall, Goal Unmet?
description: Reports of multiplying atrocities filtering out of Kosovo, bad enough news on purely humanitarian grounds, convey a still bleaker message for allied policy makers trying to stem the bloodshed.

title: A Giant Who Didn't Run and Didn't Block, but Always Knew Who Could
description: Tim Rooney is leaving professional football after almost 30 years. His retirement announcement was made quietly by the Giants last week, amid the din of college basketball. But not even March Madness can obscure what has been one of the truly great football careers.

title: The View From/Scarsdale; Illness to Shut Haven For Famous and Others
description: YOU don't even have to go inside to know that Alex & Henry's in the Vernon Hills Shopping Center here is different -- very different -- from the trendy, nouvelle, tiny-portions-on-the-plate restaurants. For starters, there is the name, Alex & Henry's Roman Gardens. Then there are the burgundy awning emblazoned with A & H in white letters in a crest and the white columns lining the entrance.

title: Psychics Need Debunking, Not Cover Article
description: To the Editor:

title: After Meetings, Mayor Vows 'Major Changes' For Police
description: After meetings with black politicians, ministers and teen-agers yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that he would announce unspecified ''major changes''in the Police Department next week to respond to concerns raised since the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: Doctors Tackle Scars of Nairobi Blast
description: ''You know, when you have the scars,'' Rebecca Gicuku said, ''everybody is staring at you. They tell you, 'Sorry.' I don't feel comfortable. It reminds me of the horrible day.''

title: New Rule On Lead Draws Fire
description: BEGINNING June 1, the Federal Government will require contractors and others involved with renovation of painted surfaces in pre-1978 residential buildings to notify both occupants and owners of the hazards of lead-based paint.

title: Care for Tools and Hemlocks
description: If your tool handles are rough or splintering, rub with steel wool until smooth, and then treat with linseed oil. Make sure blades of hand tools and mowers are sharp.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- Why I Prefer Spring Break; Where the Birds Are
description: My ideal spring break would be with my wife in the Tari valley in Papua New Guinea, at a place called the Ambua Lodge. Eight species of birds of paradise have been seen around the lodge, so every bird-watcher in the world wants to go there.

title: He's a Team Player. Just Ask His Neighbors.
description: Build it and they will come. But build it too big and, even in a woodsy corner of Monmouth County, they will come with complaints.

title: Lori Taylor and John Moukad
description: Lori Lyn Taylor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Taylor of Gettysburg, Pa., was married on Friday to John Connorton Moukad, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Moukad of New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas D. Wintle performed the ceremony at the First Parish Unitarian Church in Weston, Mass.

title: March 21-27; M.I.T. Admits It's Tough on Women
description: From Harvard to Stanford, top American universities are often accused of discriminating against their female professors, and usually respond with defensive denials. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology took a different, more scientific approach: It gathered the data, quantified the problem and verified its existence.

title: Under the Beds of the Reds
description: A COVERT LIFE

title: Fathoming the Cherry Tomato, a Seed at a Time
description: I HAVE seen gardens which were all experiment, given over to every new thing, and which produced little or nothing to the owners, except the pleasure of expectation.'' With those century-old words of wisdom from the essayist and editor Charles Dudley Warner (''My Summer in a Garden,'' 1888) looming over me, I still went ahead two years ago to devote 120 square feet of my property to cherry tomatoes, almost two dozen varieties. I wanted to see how different one variety was from the next in plant size and health, and in fruit size, color and -- most important -- flavor.

title: The World: Fog of War -- Coping With the Truth About Friend and Foe; The Guesses That Turned Out Wrong
description: If anyone has ever wondered how wars begin, they begin like this: Two sides, starting from different principles and world views, back one another into a trap of their own rhetoric and mythologies.

title: Ethics Suspensions
description: Two members of the Westchester County Taxi and Limousine Commission and a member of the County Parks, Recreation and Conservation Board have been suspended pending a hearing after the Westchester Board of Ethics recommended their dismissal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENLOWE, SAMUEL
description: MENLOWE-Samuel. A retired civil engineer formerly of New York died Sunday, March 21, 1999 in Richmond, VA. He is survived by his beloved wife, Myra; loving daughter and son-in-law, Shari and Michael Barck; and adored grandchildren, Alexis Nicole and Jordan Benjamin. He was a devoted brother, brother-in-law, uncle, and great-uncle.

title: Minister Is Suspended for Officiating in Gay Ceremony
description: A United Methodist Church minister in Chicago, convicted of breaking church law by officiating at the union of two gay men, has been suspended from his duties.

title: Music That Lifts the Spirit at Easter
description: FOR the last few years, amid works by Handel, Bach, Dupre, Billings, Rutter, Brahms and down the long list of composers whose sacred music elevates the holiday spirit, a simpler form of song, or psalm, has become part of the repertory.

title: Disabled Return to Old School but Segregation Is Charged
description: Responding to protests from parents, school officials last week pledged to move children with multiple handicaps back to Public School 380, the elementary school they were moved from last month. The parents are happy with the move, but they are now concerned that their children are being segregated from disabled Hasidic children.

title: Corrections
description: The article on page 55 of the Television section today, about the film ''Mutiny,'' misstates the number of men convicted in a 1944 mutiny, and mistates their discharge circumstances, because of misinformation supplied by NBC.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York

title: In All 5 Boroughs, A Robust Market
description: FROM the heights of Manhattan's luxury towers to the wood-framed and aluminum-sided homes of its more proletarian neighborhoods, New York City's residential real estate market saw prices continue to rise last year -- riding the crest of the nation's record-breaking housing expansion and the region's ongoing rebound from the moribund days of the early 1990's.

title: Ideas & Trends: Civil Disobedience, Negotiated; Arresting Choreography
description: FOR the last two weeks, Police Headquarters in New York City has provided an austere backdrop for a recurring drama: the daily noontime engagement between police officers in protective gear and protesters decrying police misconduct and brutality. Each session ends with the arrests of dozens of people for participating in the time-honored act of civil disobedience.

title: 'ETHNIC CLEANSING'
description: The brutality against ethnic Albanian civilians by Serbian forces represents a ''broad-based ethnic cleansing campaign across Kosovo'' that is far swifter and more sweeping than similar efforts by Serbian forces during the war in Bosnia, a senior Administration official said today.

title: A Director Whose Goal Is to Vanish
description: IAN RICKSON says he admires auteur stage directors like Robert Wilson and Anne Bogart, who leave their emphatic imprint on a production. But he prefers to burrow out from the inside of a play. And if people don't notice what he has done, that may be the highest compliment.

title: Sports of The Times; A Teacher Firm and Strong: The Father Behind Ripken's Streak
description: WHEN his father was in his early years as a manager in the Baltimore Orioles farm system, Cal Ripken Jr. was too young to wonder how baseball should be played.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BEDFORD PARK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZBERG, JACK
description: SCHWARTZBERG - Jack. Of Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn, New York, died on Sunday, March 7th, 1999 at the age of 95. He is survived by his son Stanley (Mary Lou), grandchildren Mark (Sasha), Laury (Andrew), David, and Sarah (Kenneth); five great-grandchildren, many relatives and friends. A generous man who enriched the lives of all those who knew him. He will be greatly missed.

title: Lowering the Skyline in Jersey City
description: FOR months, a small army of demolition workers hammered away at the top of a high-rise building, a remnant of 1950's housing-project design. By last week, only six floors remained as machinery moved in to complete the work, so the foundations for town houses could be laid. Fear of damaging nearby utility mains had prevented the use of explosives.

title: Hunters Warned About Radioactive Deer
description: The Bureau of Environmental Radiation Protection of the New York State Health Department recommended in a report released last week that hunters and members of the public be advised of elevated levels of radioactive cesium-137 in deer near Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: NATO Bombing Brings Market Unease
description: In the end, it was difficult to ignore the NATO air assaults in Yugoslavia. For the first two days, the market seemed to take the strikes in stride. But on the third day - with the weekend looming - the situation in the Balkans gave investors pause.

title: Karen Harrison and Richard Schiffer
description: TO picture Karen Tina Harrison, think of how Madonna looked in the movie ''Desperately Seeking Susan'': zany, theatrical and in love with accessories. Ms. Harrison, 42, is a freelance fashion journalist who has begun writing television screenplays and lives in a Manhattan studio filled with flea market finds, black clothes, costume jewelry and lipsticks of every color.

title: 'The Devil's Arithmetic': Memories Count
description: CAN you get from the mall to the death camps?

title: THE GUIDE
description: Rocks as Art

title: A Director Advances the Vision of a Lost Creator
description: WHEN theatergoers signed up for the McCarter Theater season, they expected Moliere, translated by Richard Wilbur and directed by Andre Ernotte -- a winning triple play.

title: Disclosing A Broker's Past Crime
description: IN 1971, a 17-year-old New Orleans high school student made the mistake of his life. A young man he met asked to be introduced to a drug dealer, and he complied. The acquaintance, who bought a single orange mescaline pill, turned out to be a narcotics agent, and in 1973, the student, by then in college, was convicted of felony drug possession in connection with the incident.

title: Court Ruling Deepens Feud Over LIPA Rates
description: WHEN a Suffolk County judge ruled on March 19 that the Long Island Power Authority could not collect a tax judgment of nearly $800 million for overassessment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, county legislators claimed a huge victory.

title: Can't I.D. a Plant? Check Bud Arrangement
description: THE woody plants are still dormant. There is no better time to observe and learn the age-old method of identifying plants.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: JOHN FARROW'S WAKE ISLAND (1942) is a superbly realistic depiction of Marine pluck and heroism on a Pacific island where a contingent of American troops is enveloped by the Japanese enemy. A fine cast is headed by Robert Preston, Brian Donlevy, Macdonald Carey and Albert Dekker. Typical of the unsentimental portrayal is the fadeout, a casual, clear-eyed exchange by Donlevy and Dekker - Sunday at 6 P.M. on AMC.

title: Guerrillas Said to Find 60 Bodies Near Village
description: Ethnic Albanian rebels from the Kosovo Liberation Army today found the bodies of 60 men, women and children in several places around a village in southwestern Kosovo, a foreign observer said after speaking with the ethnic Albanian commander whose men made the find.

title: It's All in the Narrative
description: To the Editor:

title: From Book to Stage, A Heathcliff Notes Version of 'Wuthering Heights'
description: CREATING literary epics for the stage is nothing new. In the 1960's and through the 1980's, the APA-Phoenix Repertory Company, under the artistic direction of Ellis Rabb, morphed Tolstoy's ''War and Peace'' into what was called a ''vest pocket spectacular . . . on a tiny stage, a feat of imagination to match Shakespeare's Battle of Agincourt at the Old Globe.'' The tiny stage was on Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIZARES, ENRIQUE O.
description: LIZARES-Enrique O. On March 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Cecilia Navas Lizares. Loving father of sons Rick and Roland, stepson Ray and stepdaughter Robin. He will be deeply missed. Services will be held Wednesday, March 31, 1999, 7 PM, at Dimiceli & Sons, Inc., 182 Lexington Ave. (between 31st and 32nd), 212-683-1798.

title: A New Age Of Reform Is Upon Us
description: You can hold your breath. Sports is entering an Age of Reform. Which will be over soon.

title: Rice and Christ the King: State's Best
description: The Rice boys and Christ the King girls repeated as New York State Federation Class A champions tonight, but their reactions were as different as the journeys they took to get to the top.

title: In Five Towns, Buses Supply Trips to the Train
description: Commuters in five municipalities along the Morris and Essex rail lines will be able to ride a jitney to the train station, and avoid parking hassles. A program financed by New Jersey Transit handed keys to buses to three towns last week.

title: The Allure of the Everyday
description: Freedom Song Three Novels. By Amit Chaudhuri. 434 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCENTHAL, MILTON
description: PRINCENTHAL - Milton. Died March 26 at 82. Beloved husband of Frances for 62 years. Father of Roger and Edward. Grandfather of Adam, Jodi, Jordan. Great grandfather of Ethan. Services Sunday, 2:00 PM, Gutterman Memorial Chapel, Woodbury, NY.

title: U.N. Panel Urges New Inspections in Iraq
description: The 20-member panel reviewing Iraq's disarmament record has concluded that because of Iraq's unwillingness to reveal information, the United Nations needs to continue to monitor, inspect and investigate Iraq's weapons programs, diplomats said today.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- On Language; Crater
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sent a message to Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic via Charles Gibson on ABC's revitalized ''Good Morning America'': ''Whichever side cratered the talks would be held responsible.'' The use of that verb was surely planned and tested: the same night, the Queen of Foggy Bottom repeated that high-impact figure of speech on Jim Lehrer's ''News Hour'' on PBS.

title: Dr. Milling And Dr. Jacobs
description: Dr. Cassandra Jean Milling and Dr. Bradley Scott Jacobs, neurologists, were married last evening at Congregation Shearith Israel in Manhattan. Rabbi Marc D. Angel performed the ceremony.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Basketball Clinic

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: AY CUBA!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANS, DAVID
description: GANS-David. On March 13, 1999. Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at New York University. Beloved husband and friend of Charlotte. Dear brother-in-law, uncle and great uncle. His courage, gentleness, wisdom and wit gave us comfort and strength.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, A. DOAK.
description: BARNETT-A. Doak. Of McLean, Virginia. Died Wednesday, March 17th. A memorial service wil be held Saturday, April 10th, 11AM, Rock Spring Congregational Church, 5010 Little Falls Road, Arlington, Virginia 22207. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the A. Doak Barnett Memorial Fund, established at the National Committee on US-China Relations, 71 West 23 St., #

title: Exploring Love in the Arctic, Finding Success in Spain
description: JULIO MEDEM makes sophisticated, elegantly constructed films whose characters seem to wander blindly through a maze of experience. The 40-year-old director has earned a reputation as Spain's most promising auteur; but as an artist, he prefers not knowing where he's going.

title: Elizabeth Osha And Ashbel Green
description: Elizabeth Allnutt Osha, a segment producer in New York for ''Dateline NBC,'' the television news magazine, was married yesterday to Ashbel Green, a vice president and senior editor at Alfred A. Knopf, the book publisher in New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a chart last Sunday about third-grade reading test scores omitted a shaded key to a map of the city's community school districts. The map used five shadings: the lightest indicated the highest student performance, compared with a benchmark based on students' family income and English proficiency; the darkest indicated the lowest performance. The map also omitted the label designating District 21, in southwestern Brooklyn.

title: Will of 'Yuppie Guru' Inspires an Un-Zenlike Battle
description: When Frederick P. Lenz 3d swallowed 150 tablets of Valium and stepped off a dock into the bay behind his Long Island home last year, he left behind a collection of mansions, private jets and luxury cars valued at $18 million, and a will that practically invited a lawsuit.

title: For Wine Lovers, A Palace in Portugal
description: There is a new addition to the network of government-run inns, called pousadas, in Portugal: the 31-room Pousada Solar da Rede in a 17th-century Baroque palace built by the Italian architect Niccolo Nazzoni. The decor is 17th century, with reproductions of furniture of the period. The palace is set in a 100-acre vineyard and olive and orange grove near Mesao Frio in northern Portugal. Among the amenities is a wharf for cruises along the Douro River between Porto and Spain. The location in the Douro Valley, where grapes for port are grown, offers visitors a chance to investigate the region's wine production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORPER, HAZEL PRIEST
description: KORPER-Hazel Priest, 87, wife of the late George W. Korper, Jr., died peacefully at home on Wednesday, March 24. She was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Priest of Providence and Narragansett, Rhode Island. Mrs. Korper was graduated from Lincoln School, Providence, and National Seminary, Washington, D.C. Hazel Priest Korper, along with others, was instrumental in founding the American Society of Interior Designers in 1975, where she remained a board member for many years. She was active in Hospice in Connecticut and in promoting barrier-free design for the handicapped. She is survived by her sons, Samuel Priest Korper, Ph.D., and George W. Korper III, four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Nantucket, Massachusetts papers, please copy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTIE, WALTER E.
description: BEATTIE-Walter E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter E. Beattie, associated with The Times from 1954 until retiring in 1990.

title: Property Tax Rebate Easily Passes in Senate
description: The Senate last week passed a bill that would return about $120 in property taxes to the average homeowner beginning this fall. The vote was 34-5.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99 -- Questions for Tim McCarver; Fair Ball
description: Q: The Mets fired you because management thought you were too critical of the team. Did it make you think you should've done your job differently?

title: Extra Witty! They've Gone Over-Bard!
description: How have the media been recycling Shakespeare lately in the midst of the playwright's pop-culture renaissance? Let us only begin to count the ways with the following headlines, starting with last week's Oscar awards, at which ''Shakespeare in Love'' won Best Picture. TOM KUNTZ

title: Gender Bias on the Campus
description: The American Association of University Professors last month reported that the gap in salaries between male and female faculty members of the same rank actually worsened from 1975 to 1998, even though the proportion of women teaching at universities and colleges grew over that period. Women are moving into academia in greater numbers, but they seem to be less valued and more likely to be relegated to lesser-paying jobs in lower-ranking institutions.

title: Gore Shifts to Grass-Roots Part of Campaign
description: Al Gore quacked like a duck to amuse a baby. He empathized with a woman about caring for her ailing elderly mother. He hammed it up in a home video. He donned a pullover sweater and slacks, strolled into several living rooms and stopped by a front porch, where he hugged a woman with lung cancer.

title: Ghost Town
description: THE BOOK OF BLAM

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEIT, ROSE BROOKS,
description: VEIT-Rose Brooks, 78. Of Bradenton, FL, died March 24, 1999. Born in New York City, she moved to Bradenton in 1986 from there. She is a retired Administrator & Director of alumni affairs at Columbia University. She attended New York University. She is survived by her husband Ivan; a son, Larry Brooks of Los Angeles, CA., and two grandchildren. Brown & Sons Funeral Homes of Bradenton, Florida for information.

title: 'Quality Time' on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Showdown Between Teams at Bridge Final
description: Teams headed by George Jacobs of Hinsdale, Ill., and Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., clashed here today in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: F.Y.I.
description: White Fright

title: The Human Habitat
description: Robert Sullivan may not be totally proficient at renovating homes, but he certainly is effective at helping homeless youth (''Home Wrecked''). When I was one of the directors at Covenant House in New York, I enlisted him to teach one young man how to read. That young man reads today because of Robert Sullivan. I call that home improvement!

title: Hidden Costs in On-Line Trading
description: MILLIONS of Americans have rushed into the brave new world of electronic stock trading. Armed with fast computers and sophisticated software, they see themselves not only at the market's epicenter but also on the same plain as professional traders. For extra enticement, there are low commissions, sometimes less than $10 a trade.

title: Tapas and Other Dishes of Spain in Irvington
description: UNLIKE other waterfront eating spots that are destinations because of the scenery, Solera on Hudson, like the previous occupant Bridge Street, has no view. The dramatic riverside surround -- between two bridges -- is spectacular nonetheless, as a short after-dinner stroll to the river's edge will reveal. The meager proximity is hardly a plus, however, as Solera would succeed in the middle of a desert.

title: 10-Point Plan on Misconduct and Brutality
description: Following are the proposals issued yesterday by a broad coalition of political leaders and community organizers in response to the shooting of Amadou Diallo:

title: Errata
description: To the Editor:

title: Aquariums Do Exist For Islanders' Enjoyment
description: ''Does the Island need two aquariums?'' is the question posed in ''Water Everywhere, Finally Aquariums'' [March 14]. My answer is it doesn't need any. What the Island needs are more natural areas where community residents can walk free of charge to enjoy making discoveries of nature. Both aquariums will offer exhibits that will undoubtedly wow viewers. But contrived aquarium exhibits are simply gimmicks to draw dollar bills.

title: DANCE; New Insights for a Distinctive Modernist Vision
description: REHASH or celebration? As a work in progress, the New York City Ballet's 50th anniversary year looks like both. The celebration is, in effect, a retrospective: Now halfway through the 100 ballets it plans to present through June, the company leaned toward the familiar in its recent winter season. Yet the packaging was often different, and new contexts made for new insights.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-28-99; Complainers of The World, Unite!
description: At last, the immense power of the Federal Government is being mobilized to confront one of America's most tenacious social evils. How often have you arrived at the departure gate, shoulder aching from the strain of schlepping two just-over-the-maximum-size carry-on bags across vast stretches of gleaming airport tundra, only to hear that boarding will be delayed 20 minutes? And how often, at these moments, have you turned to the ticket holder next to you -- a man, it may be, apparently hoping to pass a carton containing a new espresso maker off as an item that can be safely stowed under the seat in front of him -- and said, in a tone of admirably restrained indignation, ''At least they could tell us why there's a delay.'' Not that many times? How about one time? Wouldn't that be a lot? Well, soon, when this happens, they will tell you why there's a delay or risk paying a nice stiff penalty. The requirement that airline travelers be provided with full explanations for delays may shortly become the law of the land.

title: What's the Exit Out of Kosovo?; Misplaced Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Terra Cotta On West 42d Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking Barriers of Alzheimer's
description: ''LET'S wave,'' Patricia Wong said. ''Come on, Rita, wave. Everybody waves.''
