description: PAUL WESTERBERG: 'SUICAINE GRATIFACTION'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIAMPI, GIOTTO
description: CIAMPI-Giotto. On March 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Bennie Calder Ciampi, step-father of Bruce Calder of Dallas, Texas. Service Wednesday, April 7, 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC. Donations may be sent to Alimondo Ciampi Foundation, C/O Remo Ciampi Lucarelli in Chianti, Siena, Italy 53017.

title: Pension Fund Agency Is Being Scrutinized
description: A quarter-century ago, Congress created the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to make sure that the 42 million workers with traditional pensions would get paid even if their employer went bankrupt. The legislation was hailed at the time as second only to Social Security in its significance to working Americans.

title: How Are the Rangers Failing? Count the Ways
description: The Rangers are without many victories lately, but they won one small battle off the ice yesterday when the National Hockey League suspended Eric Lindros for two games for cutting Petr Nedved with a high stick on Saturday. Nedved bled from three places around his right eye when Lindros injured him late in the Flyers' 3-1 victory in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAND, ANNE
description: GRAND-Anne. After a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother, sister, sisterin-law, grandmother and aunt. Memorial service at NY Congregational Nursing Center Chapel at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to NY Congregational Nursing Center.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN ALBANIA -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops; Long Lines of Refugees Hounded Into Albania
description: Their Kosovo villages in flames behind them, tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians are being hounded into Albania by Serbian forces, threatening to overwhelm the scant resources of this desperately poor country and the hasty efforts of Western aid workers.

title: Computer Games Venture Into the World of Gun, Bow and Big Game
description: The business mastermind behind one of the hot trends in computing today is not Bill Gates or Michael Dell, and not some Internet whiz kid from Silicon Valley or Seattle, but an anonymous middle manager from Bentonville, Ark.

title: Cairo Journal; When Sheep Are Invited, Much to Their Dismay
description: It was a bad time to be a sheep here. All last week, it seemed, they were everywhere you looked -- being herded down crowded streets, peering from taxi windows, even munching clover on urban balconies. But this was no sheep's holiday. They were on their way to the slaughter.

title: Mayor Hobbles CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * John Hoyle, president of Ogilvy & Mather Mexico, Mexico City, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C., was named to the new post of chief operating officer and multinational client director for the Latin American region of Ogilvy Worldwide, based in the Sao Paulo, Brazil, office. Leopoldo Garza, president and managing director at Nazca Saatchi & Saatchi, Los Morales Polanco, Mexico, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., was named to succeed Mr. Hoyle in Mexico City.

title: Sports of The Times; Duke Has Become a Team You Can Root For
description: WHO would have guessed at the beginning of the decade that by the end of it Duke, an elite private university in North Carolina, would have a basketball team that could be heralded as the People's Team? Just goes to show how time can alter images and perceptions.

title: Makeover: The Postal Service Goes Hollywood
description: The United States Postal Service knew it had an image problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBERHART, DORATHEA C.
description: EBERHART-Dorathea C. On March 26, 1999 at the age of 96. Survived by a niece Nancy Rothe, nephews Frank and David Eberhart, and the late Walter M. Eberhart, a sister-in-law Elizabeth Eberhart, cousin Paul Eberhart, and many other devoted cousins, great-nieces and nephews. Services at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 315 E. 88th St., Monday April 5, at 10 AM.

title: Media Talk; TV Reporter Gets a Jump on His Beat
description: How much is a good Rolodex worth?

title: Arrests Drop and Shootings Rise as the Police, Giuliani Says, Are Distracted
description: With police statistics showing the rate of violent crime creeping up again in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested yesterday that the trend might be the result of a less active police force distracted by the uproar over the killing of Amadou Diallo seven weeks ago.

title: Looking for That Good Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place: Technology; For Silicon Alley, a Time to Rise and Shine
description: Out of symbolic modesty -- or maybe impatience -- Candice Carpenter took the subway rather than a limousine back to her office from the Wall Street headquarters of Goldman, Sachs earlier this month.

title: Too-Young Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 2, Survives Four-Story Fall From an Apartment in Queens
description: A 2-year-old boy fell four stories from an apartment window in Queens yesterday but suffered only a broken jaw and cuts and scratches, his family said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACEL, PAUL
description: ACEL-Paul. On March 27, 1999. Of New York City. Beloved husband of Antonia. Loving father of Peter. Cherished grandfather of Marissa and Monika. Dear brother-in-law to Franciska Pauker. Services were held privately.

title: The Players in the Printer-Copier Game Change Again
description: So, shuffle the deck again and deal out the logo cards. The list of who is battling whom in the printer-copier market just changed one more time.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN BELGRADE -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops; Support for Homeland Up as Sirens Wail and News Is Censored
description: Slobodan Milosevic, defiant as ever and proud of his nation's resistance to NATO's air attacks, staged an eerie celebration today -- a rock concert in the center of Belgrade to show solidarity with the soldiers facing down the allied assaults.

title: The 20th Century and What It Brought
description: It's not as if the year 2000 comes with Big Ideas already attached; it's a number, not a philosophy. No wonder we're facing a glut of retrospectives that seem driven more by public relations than public sentiment: millennial fever as a commercial ploy or a knee-jerk response to some imagined obligation. So the Whitney Museum of American Art presents an exhibition (coming next month) called ''The American Century: Art and Culture,'' not to be confused with Harold Evans's best-selling book called, simply, ''The American Century.'' The pattern is bound to go on well into 2001. It's as if publishers and producers everywhere were thinking, ''It's the end of the century, got to do something.''

title: Maker of Inexpensive PC's Reports a Flood of Orders
description: Richard Latman believes there is no such thing as a free lunch -- or a free PC.

title: Activism Surges at Campuses Nationwide, and Labor Is at Issue
description: In the biggest surge in campus activism in nearly two decades, student protests have burst onto the scene with rallies, teach-ins and sit-ins protesting sweatshops and other labor issues.

title: Memories That Everyone Can Relate To
description: Janis Brenner and Dancers packed the ground floor of a building opposite Grand Central Terminal on Thursday night: the performers in casual attire looked both like the pedestrians who peered at them through windows and the spectators seated inside on folding chairs.

title: Heard From Beyond the Beltway: New Music
description: When an orchestra presents a particularly noteworthy program, it is typically punished for its good deed with a mere glancing mention by critics of its own contribution, added almost as an afterthought, all that limited space allows. So let it be said at the outset that the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, in its concerts of New York premieres on Thursday and Friday evenings at Carnegie Hall, played superbly.

title: Balkan Rarity: A Peaceful Mixture of Ethnic Groups, All Looking to the West
description: As a mullah sang out the call to prayer at a mosque here, local volunteers today distributed sheep, ritually slaughtered for the Muslim holiday that began Saturday, to Albanian refugees from Kosovo.

title: Fans in Cuba Walking Tall Despite Loss
description: It was a sunny event laced with nationalism and patriotic feeling, but in the end, the game played here today between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national team was about baseball, and the 50,000 Cubans who attended walked out with their heads high.

title: Tactics Were Barrier To Top Serb's Indictment
description: President Clinton in recent days has described President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia as the ''leader who started the wars in Bosnia and Croatia,'' and a senior British official accused him of being a ''serial ethnic cleanser.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERL, BESSIE
description: SCHERL-Bessie. Of Miami Beach, FL. Former partner at the Park Terrace Caterers of the Bronx, and the Fountainhead of New Rochelle. Beloved wife of the late Ted. Devoted mother of Allen and Eileen Scherl, Stanley and Marge Lewin. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother of Jason and Alexis Scherl, Bruce Lewin, Jamie and Mark Meadow, Brett, Lindsay and Todd Mitchell, Stacey and Matt Meadow. She will be deeply missed. Services Monday, 1:30 PM, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. Contributions may be made to the Laura Rosenberg Foundation, 73 Crystal Court, Hewlett, NY 11557, or Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For First Time in War, E-Mail Plays a Vital Role
description: The E-mail messages from Yugoslavia spill forth by the thousands, each freighted with a miniature etching of life under the bombs.

title: Ties Prolong Jury Selection In Pizza Workers' Slaying
description: Jury selection for a trial in the ambush killings of two pizza deliverymen in 1997 has stretched into a fifth week, reflecting, in part, how the case has intersected with the lives of so many people here at the rural northern tip of New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, DIONNE R.
description: SLATER-Dionne R. Of Locust Valley, LI, on March 27, 1999. Beloved wife of Alexander B. Mother of Henry L. Murray, Jr., Margaret M. Sullivan, John M. Murray, Catherine W. Murray, and her stepchildren Kathy S. Hart, Alexander B., Jr., and Serena S. Wilson. Sister of Mary Louise Smith. Grandmother of Linda, Michael, Catherine, Audrey, J. Morgan, Henry, Ryan, Kathleen and Alexis. Aunt of Bruce and Richard Smith. Service St. John's of Lattingtown on Wednesday, March 31, at 11 AM. Donations to Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx, NY, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Beyond Lawrence Welk: Contest Aims to Bring Accordions Into the 90's
description: Until her first year of high school, Terri Conti lived a secret life. During the week, she was a typical New Jersey teen-ager. But on weekends, Ms. Conti strapped on her accordion and sneaked out to musical competitions.

title: Team of Seasoned Champions Earns Knockout Team Title
description: After a week of competition a group led by George Jacobs of Hinsdale, Ill., emerged as winners of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here on Saturday night. Jacobs's partner was Ralph Katz, also of Hinsdale, and their squad included two pairs that have won world team titles: Peter Weichsel of Los Gatos, Calif., and Alan Sontag of Manhattan, Bermuda Bowl winners in 1983; and the reigning world champions, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace of Italy.

title: 2 Makers Plan Introductions of Digital VCR
description: Two Silicon Valley makers of digital VCR's plan to make announcements on Monday about their services and products, which enable television viewers to filter, store and retrieve programs as digitized video.

title: North Dakota Fails To Reach Semifinals
description: Boston College upset North Dakota, 3-1, at Madison, Wis., last night in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Western Regional final. The Fighting Sioux of the Western Association had won 32 of 39 games and had been ranked first in the polls through most of the season.

title: Mets Look To Settle For Help In Rotation
description: In one breath, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips said today that yes, he would still like to upgrade his team's starting rotation. In another breath, Phillips quickly added, ''I'm not all that hopeful for a trade before the end of spring training.''

title: Kosovo Rebels Hold Off A Strong Serb Offensive
description: The separatist rebels in Kosovo are holding out surprisingly well against an apparent major Serbian offensive in Kosovo, despite losses and a shortage of ammunition, foreign military observers here say.

title: Castro Proves a Perfect Host
description: He wined and dined them, then he sat in the middle of them at a baseball game today. Fidel Castro was the perfect host.

title: Making Math Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for That Good Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDLENER, JASON CRAIG
description: REDLENER-Jason Craig. Of Bend, OR. Died March 27, 1999, at the age of 28. Jason was born May 15, 1970, in Riverdale, NY. Jason is survived by his wife, Sheareen Bahrami Redlener of Bend, OR. He is survived by his loving parents, Irwin and Karen Redlener, and Arlene and Mark Goldberg. Jason is also survived by his brothers and sisters, David, Michael, Stephanie; and Lara and Amy. Also survived by his caring grandparents, Helen and Jack Berman, and Charlotte Weinblatt. Jason was extremely close to his many aunts, uncles, and cousins and will be missed by all. Jason's love of life and vibrance touched many people and he will be irreplaceable to those who loved him. Funeral service will be held, 10:30 AM, Tuesday, March 30, 1999, at the Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment will follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery. Contributions in his memory to Children's Health Fund, 317 E. 64 St., New York, NY 10021.

title: 2 Gunmen Attack U.S. Site And Flee
description: A masked gunman tried to fire a grenade launcher at the United States Embassy today, igniting a gun battle that left the building pockmarked with bullet holes.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about Patrick Marber's Broadway play ''Closer,'' cited a quotation erroneously. The quotation, ''Everything our parents told us was good for us will kill us -- sun, milk, meat -- love,'' was in an earlier script of Mr. Marber's play but is not in the Broadway production.

title: Trade Deal Close, Aide Is Off to China
description: The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, flew to Beijing today after American negotiators told her they were close to a deal under which Washington could support China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Questioning Three Gorges Dam
description: In China, where even a slight relaxation in suppression of debate can indicate a softening of official policy, it is encouraging that some publications have cast an increasingly critical eye on the Three Gorges Dam being built on the Yangtze River. The official line is that there is no turning back on a project that will destroy one of the world's great scenic areas, inundate hundreds of archeological sites and force 1.3 million people to resettle elsewhere when the dam's 400-mile reservoir floods towns and farmlands. But the insoluble social, environmental and technical problems that have plagued the project cannot be wished away, and they may now be getting some consideration.

title: Hoops Heaven Is Getting Crowded
description: Duke has been in this position before, sailing through March and landing safely on a Monday night with the chance to be crowned the premier squad in college basketball. Connecticut will walk into foreign territory, tiptoeing a bit as it tries to defeat a team many experts consider impenetrable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOENIG, CAROL
description: SHOENIG-Carol. Park East Synagogue sadly mourns the passing of Carol Shoenig, beloved sister of our devoted member and Sisterhood Trustee, Barbara Kasell. To her, her husband David, and the entire family, our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Knicks Lose Control Against Lakers
description: The Knicks allowed agitation and Dennis Rodman perhaps one and the same -- to ruin the strategy they had in mind for concluding their West Coast trip.

title: Philosophy Illuminates Minds Darkened by Misfortune
description: During an unusual course in philosophy and literature that Earl Shorris was teaching specifically for the poor and homeless, a student who had a history of violent behavior telephoned Mr. Shorris. The student had become so angry at a colleague, he reported, that he wanted ''to smack her up against the wall.'' Mr. Shorris feared the worst. Was this a call from jail? No, because instead of striking outward, the student had reflected inward and asked himself, ''What would Socrates do?''

title: California Takes West Coast Finale
description: The heavyweight men's varsity crew of California won the final of the 26th annual San Diego Crew Classic, taking the featured Copley Cup in 5 minutes 51.10 seconds. Cal finished 10.5 seconds, or more than two boat-lengths, ahead of second-place Washington, winner of the cup for the last four years.

title: Access for the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLEK, FANNY
description: DALLEK-Fanny. We mourn the loss of a wonderful matriarch. Along with her loving husband, the late Nathan Dallek, she established the office furniture business that continues to flourish in its third generation. Heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Shirley Cohen, son Godfrey Dallek, brother Jerry Rothman, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, sister-in-law, brothers-in-law, son-in-law, nieces, nephews and extended family. Dallek Inc

title: Neighbors Travel From Playground To the Final
description: A time will come in Monday's National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game when Duke's point guard, William Avery, will try to penetrate Connecticut's defense and the polished floor at Tropicana Field will feel like torn-up blacktop; when Avery will find the Huskies' premier defender, Ricky Moore, closing in on his personal space. Then, they will replay the childhood showdowns from Oak Park in Augusta, Ga.

title: Member of Lost Boyz Hip-Hop Group Slain
description: A member of the Lost Boyz, a popular hip-hop group, was shot to death early yesterday as he left a party at a Queens hotel, the police said.

title: Latin America Safer for Journalists
description: As dictatorships disappear from the map of Latin America, leaving Cuba as a holdout, violence against reporters has dropped correspondingly, to 23 journalists killed last year from 41 in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREGEAU, THOMAS A., SR.
description: FREGEAU-Thomas A., Sr. Age 73. Of Madison, CT. Owner and President of the Bigelow Co. Funeral Liturgy at St. Margaret Church in Madison, CT, Wednesday, 10 AM. Calling hours at the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Road, Madison, CT, Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Heroes vs. Intruders (NATO) and Terrorists (Albanians)
description: For Serbs watching Government-controlled Serbian television, the world of the Balkans is not complex and conflicted, but crystal clear. NATO attacked Serbia because of a longstanding criminal conspiracy by the West. Ethnic Albanians in Kosovo are terrorists. And Serbia, above all, will fight to the last man. The only thing in doubt, as the somber-suited men and women of the Serbian evening news say repeatedly, is the eventual ''international recognition of our just cause.''

title: Serbia Forfeited Sovereignty Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUB, SUSAN
description: STAUB-Susan. 54, a New City resident of 27 years, died on Wednesday, March 24, 1999 in Nyack Hospital. Beloved wife of Michael and devoted mother of Amy and Craig. Susan was the middle school science teacher and lower school science coordinator at Reuben Gittelman Hebrew Day School for the past 18 years. She was a member of the Coordination Committee for the Rockland County Science, Inventions and Technical Exhibition, a member of N.O.W., where she was involved in the Women's Health Task Force and a founding member of the Mother's Center of Rockland County. Susan was actively involved in health and environmental awareness education. We shall cherish the memory of a great woman and an inspirational teacher forever

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the actor David Strickland described his role in the new film ''Forces of Nature'' incorrectly. He plays the former boyfriend of a character played by Maura Tierney, not by Sandra Bullock.

title: Duval Is Supreme, and His Dad's a Winner Too
description: On a scale of 1 to 10, David Duval would rate his weekend a 20.

title: Suspense Offstage for the Roundabout
description: It's moving time again at the Roundabout Theater Company. (Is that why they call it the Roundabout?)

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Compressed Data; The Stars Are Right For Web Site Move
description: The timing has nothing to do with April Fool's Day, but this Thursday is a particularly propitious date for the Astrology Zone Web site to make its debut on the Walt Disney Company's Go Network (www.astrologyzone.go.com).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, BESSIE
description: GOLDMAN-Bessie. Age 94. Died peacefully with her family at her side on March 26, 1999. A school teacher for 48 years and a life-long world traveler, she was admired by all who knew her. To her last days she retained her loving nature, wisdom, humor and independence of spirit with which she lived her full life. She will be deeply missed and always remembered. ''Nana'' is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Claire of New York City; her grandson Michael, grand - daughter - in - law Cora and great-grandson Irvin of Jerusalem, Israel; grandson Ethan, grandson Neal and granddaughter-in-law Lora, also from New York City.

title: Arafat Is Israel's Best Hope
description: In the 1970's, when I was a senior operative in the Mossad, Israel's foreign intelligence service, Yasir Arafat was my blood enemy. My colleagues and I hounded him and his terrorist P.L.O. henchmen, trying to stop them from murdering innocent Jews, certain that his demise would be a great victory for Israel.

title: Chief of Algroup Quits Over Deal
description: Algroup, the world's biggest maker of pharmaceutical packaging, said today that its chairman, Theodor Tschopp, had resigned over a planned $8.7 billion merger with Viag A.G., Germany's No. 3 utility.

title: BP Amoco and ARCO Are Reported to Be Holding Talks on a Merger
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., the giant oil company, has been in serious discussions to buy the Atlantic Richfield Company, the oil and gas exploration and refining concern, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Makeshift Pharmacies Are Dispensing Death
description: No one knows for sure how many there are. A police officer who is trying to track and close them before any more babies die says it is almost impossible to say.

title: Strawberry Likely to Be Demoted
description: Darryl Strawberry met with Yankees officials today to discuss their plans for him, in what was most likely the first step toward assigning him to the minor leagues -- perhaps as soon as Monday.

title: Behind Enemy Lines, a Race to Save Fighter Pilot
description: Shortly after 8:45 P.M. on Saturday in the Balkans, a secretive search-and-rescue team based with American forces in Bosnia received an urgent phone call: An F-117A stealth fighter, the premier attack plane in America's arsenal, was down in Yugoslavia. The fate of the Air Force pilot was unknown.

title: Keeping Magazines All in the Family; Spinoffs Seek Readers And the Advertisers Who Love Them
description: Your newsstand is overflowing.

title: China's Natural Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, JOHN L., M.D.
description: MADDEN-John L., M.D. March 25, 1999. Master surgeon, teacher, writer. Beloved husband of the late Bertie. Loving father of Pam, John, Brian, Michael, Tom, Kathy and grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, March 29, 4-8 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Tuesday, March 30, 10 a.m. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Daytop Village Foundation, 54 W. 40 St., New York, N.Y. 10108.

title: Williams Showdown: Venus Beats Sister Serena
description: Their father likened it to a bullfight, this Lipton Championships finale between his teen-age prodigies Venus and Serena Williams, the first sisters to lock horns in a final since Maud Watson ambushed her older sister Lilian and hoisted the trophy at Wimbledon in 1884.

title: A New Broom for Boxing
description: The people who organized the farcical heavyweight title bout between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis are busily arranging a rematch, perhaps hoping -- in the words of the promoter Don King -- that the prospect of another fight will act as a ''curative,'' erasing the memories of one of the worst decisions in the history of an already-tarnished sport. Mr. King and his confederates may also be banking on the boxing public's notorious cynicism and the fact that boxing's historical landscape is littered with well-intentioned investigations that have gone nowhere.

title: In 2 Minority Neighborhoods, Residents See a Pattern of Hostile Street Searches
description: Jason Perry is a 17-year-old Brooklyn high school student who takes it for granted that he will be hassled by the police if he goes out after dark in his Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood. He estimates that in the past year, he has been stopped, frisked and interrogated at least 10 times. Once, he said, he was issued a summons for not carrying an identification card.

title: Serbia Forfeited Sovereignty Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFEL, SADIE
description: GRIFEL-Sadie. On March 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Matilda and Martin Fink, Marcia and Jimmy O'Toole, and Fran and Aaron Hirschhorn. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Cuban Players Scorn Those Who Defected
description: They wouldn't be expected to say anything else or have a different view, but to a man today, members of the Cuban national team that played the Baltimore Orioles were critical of the Cuban players who have defected to the United States and the major leagues.

title: Too-Young Police; Whose Responsibility?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubans Match Big Leaguers Pitch for Pitch, But Lose in 11
description: The team that compiled a losing record last year despite having the highest payroll in baseball history nearly topped itself today. Embarrassing themselves but avoiding humiliation, the Baltimore Orioles outlasted the Cuban national team, 3-2, in 11 innings.

title: Political Memo; Diallo Protest Buffs Image For Sharpton
description: Barely a year ago, the Rev. Al Sharpton was viewed in many quarters as a fading presence, permanently compromised by his association with Tawana Brawley's discredited story of abduction and rape. He was on the verge of becoming a caricature of the disaffected New York protester, shunned by establishment politicians both white and black.

title: When Wittiness Competes With Casual Disorientation
description: There were ominous signs that one was in for an evening of art that must be suffered for. But ''Middle of Nowhere,'' presented by the Unterwegstheater on Wednesday at the Kitchen, was a decidedly pleasant and provocative surprise.

title: Looking for That Good Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roy M. Fisher, 80, Journalist and Teacher
description: Roy M. Fisher, a former editor of The Chicago Daily News and former dean of the University of Missouri School of Journalism, died on Thursday at a hospice in Evanston, Ill. He was 80 and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: In Fight to Ward Off Olivetti, Telecom Italia Sweetens a Bid
description: Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's No. 1 phone company, has offered to buy out its cellular unit, Telecom Italia Mobile S.p.A., for 23 billion euros, or $24.8 billion, in cash rather than stock to win over investors in its battle against a takeover attempt by Olivetti S.p.A.

title: In California, the Numbers Tell the Story
description: Whites are now a minority in California. This change took place in 1998 but has not yet been made official because when the state Finance Department issued the latest figures last year, the numbers did not include the more than 500,000 immigrants waiting to be processed by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHBINDER, DOROTHY
description: BUCHBINDER-Dorothy. Most beloved mother of Carol and Rose (Jake). Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Doug, Cindy and Joy. Adored great-grandmother of Joshua, Jamie, Jordan, Nikki, Linnie and Sammy. Dear sister of Fay and Florette. She was a treasure to all she touched and her gifts are spread far and wide. Services 10:15 AM, on Wednesday, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRELL, MORTIMER
description: KRELL-Mortimer. Of Tenafly, NJ. On March 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Rita (nee Israel). Devoted father of Marla Krell-Cohen, Zelda Becourtney, and Ira Krell. Cherished father-in-law of Steven Cohen, Neil Becourtney, and Alix Botwin (future). Dear brother of David (Clare) Krell. Loving grandfather of Meryl, Samuel, and Ethan, and a niece and nephews. Services were held Sunday. The memorial period will be observed at the family residence. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the Columbia-Presbyterian Renal Transplant Department, Holy Name Hospital Dialysis Center, Teaneck, NJ, or Women's American ORT. For information, call Wien & Wien, 1-800322-0533.

title: Procedure Was Once To Protect The Police
description: The modern stop-and-frisk, as it is known by the police, stems from a 1968 Supreme Court decision, Terry v. Ohio. The court ruled that the police can pat a suspect down for weapons when the police ''reasonably'' believe that criminal activity may be afoot and the suspect may be armed. The ruling was largely intended to protect police officers from being attacked by the people they stopped.

title: Digital Commerce; Internet companies reinvent math, contending that each losing transaction succeeds as 'volume.'
description: THOUSANDS of companies, on line and off, are blossoming because of the Internet's fertile new soil for conducting commerce and serving customers. But the blush may be rapidly fading from the rose for many Internet-only businesses built on the increasingly dubious strategy that whatever millions of dollars they lose today, they will later ''make it up in volume.''

title: Petke Scores on a Header And MetroStars Get the Nod
description: The MetroStars have gone from losing the first three games in each of the first three years of Major League Soccer to winning the first two this season. Today's 1-0 triumph over the Columbus Crew on the natural grass at Giants Stadium marked the first time the MetroStars have won their home opener.

title: Media Talk; At Knight Ridder, The Chief Belies Tightfisted Image
description: When it comes to being tight with company money, few newspaper executives can match P. Anthony Ridder, the chief executive of Knight Ridder, the country's second-largest newspaper chain. For his relentless cost-cutting, he is known as ''Darth Ridder,'' a nickname he has joked about while demanding 20 percent profit margins.

title: Pepper Sets A Record And Ends Her Drought
description: Smashing scoring records for a Ladies Professional Golf Association major tournament while ending a two-and-a-half-year victory drought was worth celebrating, Dottie Pepper figured.

title: Suspended Pastor's Flock Voices Its Support
description: The flock turned out today to pray for its pastor, the Rev. Greg Dell, who has been suspended for officiating at the union of two gay men.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about events leading to the United States' decision to use force against Yugoslavia misstated the party affiliation of Senator John Warner of Virginia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: George William Staempfli, Gallery Owner, 89
description: George William Staempfli, founder of Staempfli Gallery in Manhattan, died on Thursday at the Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis, Md. He was 89.

title: Media Talk; A Magazine Checks Up on Its Investigators
description: It may not be in a magazine publisher's best interest to anger a man with close ties to Salvatore Gravano, the mob hit man who worked for John J. Gotti. But John F. Kennedy Jr., the publisher and editor in chief of George, and Richard Blow, its executive editor, have certainly annoyed Peter Maas, the author of ''Underboss: Sammy the Bull Gravano's Story of Life in the Mafia'' by holding up an article for more than eight months.

title: 2 Big Advertisers Consolidate Work
description: There have been two big account consolidations by two big advertisers.

title: A Team of Moscow Mediators Arrives in Yugoslavia With a Plan for Peace
description: A Russian delegation met here today with the United States special envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, before attempting to travel by road to neighboring Yugoslavia to present a peace plan to President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Knicks Fall Victim To a Blond Bombshell
description: Poor Kurt Thomas. He didn't even see it coming. One minute, he was battling for position under the basket. The next, he was gone -- ejected from the game for throwing Dennis Rodman to the floor.

title: Essay
description: You have to know when to hold 'em and when to fold 'em. On the issue of casino gambling -- its promotion of a false something-for-nothing philosophy, its corruption of both parties' politics with millions in Big Gambling cash -- I am folding my hand.

title: Serbia Forfeited Sovereignty Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUEDER, LOUISE G.
description: LUEDER-Louise G. Of New Rochelle, NY, on March 27, 1999. Graduate of Emma Willard School, Troy, NY, and Skidmore College. Former Chairman of the Board, Seabury Memorial Home, Mount Vernon, NY. Trustee of the Church of the Ascension. Member of the Westchester Women's Club and Orienta Beach Club. Daughter of the late Carl and Elsie Lueder. Sister of the late Helen Lueder. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 5-8 PM, Tuesday. Service at the Church of the Ascension, Mount Vernon, NY, on Wednesday, March 31, at 10 AM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Milosevic could be far more easily eliminated through the development of democracy here than through air strikes. Every crisis strengthens him.''

title: Job Cuts at Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company could reduce its staff by as much as 4,600 people, or 5 percent of its work force, as the bank ''eliminates redundant'' jobs. The severance-related costs could be as much as $280 million, said a spokesman, Larry Haeg. The costs would be covered in the $375 million charge Wells took in the fourth quarter for personnel expenses after the takeover of Wells by the Norwest Corporation in November, he said. The cuts will come from eliminating ''redundant headquarters, back office and other positions,'' Wells Fargo said in a note in its 1998 annual report to shareholders. The bank's current hiring freeze, ''natural turnover'' and expansion prospects should help keep the job loss down, Mr. Haeg said. About 700 positions have already been eliminated, he said.

title: A video process allows the insertion of brand-name products in TV shows already on film.
description: ANOTHER frontier is being crossed in the commercialization of culture as digital technology has been used for the first time to ''virtually'' place products in a prime-time television entertainment program watched by American viewers.

title: Council Offers Budget Plan, With Tax Cuts
description: Asserting that the Giuliani administration has underestimated city revenues for the next 15 months by more than $1 billion, the Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, proposed a broad package of tax cuts yesterday worth about $700 million. The contrasting revenue projection and the proposed tax cuts represent the Council's starting point in negotiating the next budget.

title: Patents; A company wins a seventh patent for specialized TV, stemming from one first sought in 1981.
description: LAST week a tiny Manhattan company received a patent that it says covers many aspects of pay-per-view television as well as the integration of Internet content into television programming.

title: INSIDE
description: Sale of ARCO Discussed

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Thursday about the reaction of some Hollywood filmmakers to the choice of ''Shakespeare in Love'' rather than ''Saving Private Ryan'' as the winner of the Academy Award for best film misstated the Army rank held by Tom Hanks in ''Saving Private Ryan.'' He was a captain, not a lieutenant.

title: Avery Wouldn't Hear No, Even From Duke's Coach
description: When William Avery was a junior in high school, Mike Krzyzewski told him the truth: No matter how wondrous his basketball talent, he did not have the grades to get into Duke. The young man walked out of the coach's office and told his mother, Terry, that he had found the school for him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GADDIS, JANE
description: GADDIS-Jane. The members of the Waverly Block Association mourn the passing of our beloved friend and neighbor, Jane, on March 27. Jane was a unique figure in our community. She attended community meetings, planted a small garden in Washington Square Park, tended the tree beds along Waverly Place, and chatted with just about everyone who walked by. We will be forever grateful for her devotion to the Block Association and to the people and organizations of the Greenwich Village community. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: City May Refuse Licenses To Over 70 Trash Haulers
description: Hoping to purge the last remnants of mob involvement in the garbage hauling industry, the city intends to refuse licenses to more than 70 haulers for showing a lack ''of honesty, integrity and good character,'' a regulator said Friday.

title: Mayor Hobbles CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgrade Curtails Independent Press
description: As NATO bombers pummel Yugoslavia, President Slobodan Milosevic pummels the country's independent press.

title: Officials Say Changes May Cut Police Unit's Effectiveness
description: As officers in the Street Crime Unit reported -- in uniform -- for duty yesterday, many law enforcement officials said that Police Commissioner Howard Safir's decision to overhaul the unit's operations would make it less controversial, but also less effective.

title: Serbia Forfeited Sovereignty Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Wednesday about the South by Southwest music convention held last week in Austin, Tex., misstated the status of a record deal by the group Radish. The group's contract was not terminated; it was transferred from Mercury to Island/Def Jam.

title: Revealing Untold Stories
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLONDMAN, JACK
description: BLONDMAN-Jack. Beloved uncle and brother-in-law. His quiet dignity set an example for us all. He will always be missed and fondly remembered. The Stein Family

title: 2 Days of Treasury Auctions This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a sale tomorrow of a 52-week bill and a 19-day cash-management bill.

title: International Venture to Offer On-Line System for Businesses
description: In an effort to move more business-to-business purchasing transactions to the Internet, a pioneer in the field plans to announce partnerships on Monday with two giant international telecommunications carriers to create a global trading network.

title: Doug Edelson, News Radio Correspondent, 75
description: Doug Edelson, a correspondent for 28 years for 1010 WINS, the New York news radio station, died on Friday at a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., hospital. He was 75 and lived in Florida and Pennsylvania after retiring from WINS in 1992. He died of a heart attack, his family said.

title: Compressed Data; Big and Small Booksellers Take Battle on Line
description: Ever since the first mega-bookstore rolled into the suburban strip mall, small independent booksellers have cried foul, accusing the chains of big-foot practices. Now the wailing can be heard in cyberspace.

title: Protests May Disrupt Louima Trial, Lawyers Say
description: Daily demonstrations planned for outside the Brooklyn court where jury selection is to begin today in the trial of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima could increase the chance that the trial will be delayed or moved out of New York City, lawyers for two of the officers said yesterday.

title: Morton Bryer, 82, Infectious Disease Expert
description: Dr. Morton S. Bryer, an expert in infectious diseases who helped develop antibiotics like Aureomycin as a young researcher, died on March 20 at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. A former resident of Manhattan, he was 82 and lived in Chatham, Mass.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: SERBIAN STRATEGY -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops; Serbs Try to Empty Disputed Province, NATO Aides Assert
description: The brutal Serbian campaign against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo appears aimed at emptying the province of a majority of its people and is on the verge of creating a monumental refugee crisis, NATO and American officials said today.

title: Another Look at One Acquainted With Fire and Ice
description: ROBERT FROST

title: Theodore McRae, 91, a Jazz Musician
description: Theodore (Teddy) McRae, a composer and arranger who worked with such jazz artists as Artie Shaw, Sy Oliver and Chick Webb, died on March 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Sports of The Times; Cheer: 'Go Williams,' And Both of Them Did
description: JUST when tennis fans thought they had seen everything, there were two sisters slugging away in the final of a major tournament, while their father sat in the stands scribbling words with a grease pencil on a hand-held message board, for all the world to see.

title: Weekend of Progress in New York City
description: This past weekend, New Yorkers at last glimpsed the possibility that some constructive change would come from the death of Amadou Diallo. Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced an overhaul of the Street Crimes Unit, including more minority officers and closer supervision. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani continued to meet with black leaders and said he wished he had done so earlier. The administration's steps signaled a welcome shift from defensiveness to bridge-building and structural reforms.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on Thursday about Web sites devoted to British antiquity misidentified the largest prehistoric mound in Europe. It is Silbury Hill, not Avebury. (Both are in England, near Stonehenge.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAUBARD, JOSEPHINE
description: GRAUBARD-Josephine. Wife of Sigmund. Mother of Sidney, Joyce Wald, and Frances L. Wolfe. Grandmother and great-grandmother. Visiting, Hirsch & Sons, 167th Street and Jerome Avenue, Tuesday, 7-9 PM.

title: Looking for That Good Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Look to Future, McGwire Says
description: It took the presence yesterday of Mark McGwire to enable the Mets to sell out a spring training game in Port St. Lucie, Fla., for the first time in two years.

title: She Was Blond. She Was in Trouble. And She Paid 3 Cents a Word.
description: There used to be a time when a person could make a decent living writing crime stories. Back then, a hard-working individual could earn 2 cents a word for a short story. Three cents, if he was exceptionally good. It beat polishing spittoons. Besides, it was fun.

title: Sports of The Times; An Old Story Worth Telling Ends Happily
description: UKARI FIGGS stepped up her defensive pressure out beyond the 3-point line and ripped the ball from Nicole Erickson's hands. It was late in the game, at the end of their careers. The ball may as well have been the championship trophy.

title: Tricky Path for Ambitious Series
description: After what only seems like 100 years of journalistic labors, ABC's 12-hour documentary project ''The Century'' will finally begin broadcasting tonight after one of the longest, most expensive and most convoluted odysseys of any single project in television history.

title: Equity and Convertible Offerings Scheduled
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Comcast Corporation's acquisition of Mediaone misstated the name of the law firm that represented Comcast. It is Davis Polk & Wardwell, not Davis Polk Wardell.

title: Lillian McMurry, Blues Producer, Dies at 77
description: Lillian Shedd McMurry, who stumbled on a cache of old blues records in 1949 and was so taken by the pure, haunting sound that within a year she had opened a recording studio, died on March 18 at a hospital near her home in Jackson, Miss. She was 77 and, as the founder of Trumpet Records, had been the first to record two giants of the Delta blues, Sonny Boy Williamson and Elmore James.

title: Anxiety in a Flourishing Market; Competition Worries Owners of Small Kosher Shops
description: A week before Passover, there is nowhere to park outside the Glatt Mart in Midwood, Brooklyn, not in front on Avenue M, not out back in the tiny lot, not for blocks around.

title: Super-Fast Computer Virus Heads Into the Workweek
description: With tens of thousands of computers thought to be affected already, corporations and network security professionals said today that they were bracing for the continued spread of the ''Melissa'' computer virus with the beginning of the workweek on Monday.

title: Dr. John Madden, 86, Innovator In the Field of Vascular Surgery
description: Dr. John L. Madden, whose groundbreaking work helped advance the field of vascular surgery, died Thursday at the Wartburg, a nursing home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 86, and had been living in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Microsoft's Settlement Talks Hinge On PC Makers
description: They will not be at the table on Tuesday when the Justice Department and state attorneys general are scheduled to meet with Microsoft in Washington for settlement talks. But the nation's personal computer makers -- and the Microsoft Corporation's relationship with them -- will be the main topic of discussion as the two sides warily approach each other to see if there is some way to settle the antitrust suit against Microsoft, according to lawyers close to the case.

title: A Leader Who Climbed the Ranks, as His Father Did, to Become the Chief of Staff
description: Gen. Michael Edward Ryan, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, is adamant that he is anything but a ''wild-eyed advocate for air power solving every military problem.'' Instead, he freely admits that he does not know whether the current air war over Yugoslavia will put an end to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's campaign of terror against the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo.

title: 2 Pianists at the Keyboard In a Work by a Homebody
description: The orphan of Schubert's last and most fruitful year is the F minor Fantasy, a piece not often heard because in one sense it was not meant to be heard at all. This breathtaking music, written for one piano and two pianists and played by Avner Arad and Albert Kim at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night, represents Schubert the musical homebody at his finest moment. Its ideal audience will number two, the two who are seated at the keyboard.

title: On the Lost Stealth Jet's Own Ground, Fighting Words and Empathy
description: Half a world away from the site in Yugoslavia where an American F-117 stealth bomber crashed, the flier's home base commander defended the warplane today as a ''premier weapon system,'' and vowed to send ''a couple dozen more,'' if asked.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESHINGER, JEFFERIE LORRAINE
description: LESHINGER-Jefferie Lorraine. On March 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Raymond. Devoted mother of Jodi, Marc, and stepmother of Raymond, Denise and Gregory. Cherished grandmother of Parker, Griffin, Harrison, Michael and James. Loving mother of Ruth. Dear sister of Stewart and Spencer. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd, corner of 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Purdue Completes Transfer of Power
description: As Purdue's Ukari Figgs and Stephanie White-McCarty hugged with tears in their eyes at one end of the court, a similar embrace was taking place several feet away in front of the Duke bench.

title: Scarsdale Upstarts End 70 Years of Discreet, Handpicked Rule
description: In most places, local politics can take on the air of a rugby scrum. In this affluent and image-conscious village, though, people are so allergic to partisan politics, they have devised an election system that seems more like a parlor game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IOVINO, DR. ANTHONY J.
description: IOVINO-Dr. Anthony J. March 27, 1999. Age 73. Retired professor, Long Island University, Brooklyn Center. Chairman of Biology Department; Director of the Science Division. An avid golfer, surf caster, and lifelong pigeon fancier. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of Robert. Fond father-inlaw of Noreen. Cherished grandfather of James Patrick. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11 AM, March 29, at Saint Rosalie's R.C. Church (Hampton Bays). Interment at Sacred Heart Cemetery, Southampton. Funeral services held at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 412 Willis Avenue, Williston Park, NY.

title: Balkan Policy, as Seen From a Former Insider-Dissenter
description: THE first NATO missiles and bombs were only a few hours from striking Serbian targets last week when James R. Hooper, once the State Department's senior dissenter on Balkan policy, sipped his coffee a few blocks from the White House and talked of ground troops likely to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, ANN
description: ROSEN-Ann. On March 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Loving mother of Robert and Emmett. Cherished grandmother of Eric. Dear sister of Harry Halpern. Graveside service Monday, 1:30 PM, Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops; Allies Shifting the Focus to Halting Atrocities Reported in Kosovo
description: Allied warplanes braved bad weather tonight to step up attacks on Yugoslav troops while NATO officials repeatedly accused Serbian forces of large-scale atrocities in Kosovo.

title: Rhythms Of Sticks And Hands
description: Dance and music from Senegal were celebrated by the vibrant Sing Sing Rhythms troupe on Friday night at the Florence Gould Hall within the weeklong series Homage to Senegal that was part of a broader event, Francophone Week.

title: Devils Squander Lead, but Unbeaten Road Streak Survives
description: From Martin Brodeur's perspective, the Devils played like winners tonight -- until the final five minutes of regulation.

title: Talented Teen-Ager to Compete Today
description: Not since Tracy Caulkins, an Olympic champion in 1984, and Donna de Varona, an Olympic champion in 1964, has the United States produced as multifaceted a swimmer as Natalie Coughlin.

title: Hip-Hop With Its Roots Laced Around Instruments
description: One of hip-hop's self-limiting rebellions, even as it becomes the best-selling form of popular music, is its performance ethic. Too many hip-hop shows are willfully confused melees, stop-and-start sing-along sessions with recorded backing tracks. One of the best ideas hatched by the Roots, a Philadelphia hip-hop collective that plays actual instruments, was to use hip-hop's chaotic concert ritual and turn it into a public workshop. It unpretentiously exposes the gears of the music and invites friends onstage to rap a song or two and plug their own records, without stage sets or light shows.

title: Sunset for Cape Town Vigilantes?
description: The police intelligence document that Superintendent Wicus Holtzhausen plucks from his briefcase is a warning that he is on a hit list.

title: Parents Know Better
description: Like most Americans, I'm glad to be reading less about partisan politics. But I'm dismayed to be reading more about partisan parenting.

title: Irabu's Effort Seems Lacking, So Yankees Push Pitchers Hard
description: Hideki Irabu's lackadaisical play on Saturday spurred coaches to conduct the Yankees' version of boot camp today, and 14 pitchers, including Irabu, went through an hourlong series of drills in single file, some bending over and gasping.

title: Russian Women Turning to Abortion Less Often
description: On a recent Tuesday morning when Women's Health Service No. 15 in central Moscow held its regular abortion clinic, the waiting room was empty. Of the half dozen cots in the recovery room, only one was filled.

title: Laughter And Horror In a Journey Of the Heart
description: Lisa Kron is not someone you would describe as the silent type. She is a lively, showy talker, a natural storyteller, and she has made an art out of being just that, with comic monologues about subjects like the horrors of high school reunions. It turns out, however, that Ms. Kron also knows about the holes in life that can't be filled by descriptive sentences and about the images that can never be captured in photographs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Computer Users Prepare For Spread of E-Mail Virus

title: Arrest of Milosevic Could End the War; Helping a Tyrant
description: To the Editor:

title: Sciences on the Fringe
description: To the Editor:

title: Assembly Approves Bill Providing Tax Refunds
description: The State Assembly passed a bill yesterday that would return about $120 in property taxes to the average homeowner starting this fall.

title: Metro Business; Barr Labs Is Joining Suit Against Eli Lilly
description: Barr Laboratories Inc. of Pomona, N.Y., one of the largest makers of generic drugs in the United States, is seeking to join Zeneca Group P.L.C.'s lawsuit accusing Eli Lilly & Company of illegally promoting its bone-protecting pill Evista.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMSON, JOHN W.
description: WILLIAMSON-John W. On March 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee Bradley), loving father of Paul B., Nancy Burns and the late John C., adored grandfather of Dylan Burns. Commander of the Catholic War Veterans of Our Lady of Good Council Post. Reposing Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 6317 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Visiting Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10:15 AM, St. Joan of Arc RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYATT, JUDSON A.V.
description: HYATT-Judson A.V. Of Lloyd Harbor on March 29, 1999. Columbia College, class of 1934. Former Trustee and Elder of Old First Church, Huntington. Beloved husband of Edna. Loving father of Andrew T., Carl A., James V., and Leslie A. Dear brother of Nancy H. Peattie. Cherished grandfather of six. Visitation 7-9PM, Tuesday at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Religious service 2pm, Wednesday at Old First Presbyterian Church of Huntington, 125 Main St, Huntington. Burial to follow, Huntington Rural Cemetery.

title: Arrest of Milosevic Could End the War; Russian Buffer Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fight for Life at the Other Philharmonic
description: ROBERT SPANO has just signed a contract to continue as music director of New York's other philharmonic for five more years.

title: Reeling Knicks Are Too Heavy for Ewing to Carry Alone
description: Sometimes, Patrick Ewing looks lonely, as if he has outlived all of his buddies. He does not have John Starks to chest-bump anymore or Charles Oakley to clear his dance floor around the basket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGINSKY, VICTOR
description: MAGINSKY-Victor. Beloved husband of the late Selma. Devoted father of Jacqueline MaginskyTierney & Robin. Loving brother of Rosalind, Diane, and the late Winifred. Cherished uncle and cousin. Services are today at 1 P.M., at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: A 70's Look With a 90's Persona
description: Kid Rock

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on March 18 about noise cancellation technology misstated the reduction in the magnitude of sound that would be achieved by going from 100 decibels to 85 decibels. Because decibels are measured on a logarithmic scale, the reduction would be 82 percent, not 15 percent.

title: A Critic Who Takes His Work Home
description: Husbands don't come much more critical than John Ruskin. ''You're not what I think a woman should be,'' he tells Effie, his wife of five years. She is ''insolent and willful,'' he says, and just to be sure there's no confusion, he adds: ''I don't like the way you look, sound or move.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about protests in Western Canada against a new gun control law misidentified the man in the picture. He is Paul F. Rogan, a gunsmith in Whitehorse, Yukon Territory, not Lyle Thompson, the vice president of the Whitehorse Rifle and Pistol Club.

title: Great One Adds Record To Collection
description: A few minutes before, during a Rangers power play, Wayne Gretzky had taken a good shot from a good spot but got beat by Islanders goalie Wade Flaherty. ''Darn,'' he said, or a word to that effect, as he winced and made a sharp gesture of frustration.

title: A Ball Game, Not a Breakthrough
description: Sunday's baseball game between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national team was a coup for the Clinton Administration's revamped Cuba policy of ''people to people'' contacts through cultural exchanges. But a small success like this game should not be seen as a step toward political freedom on the island.

title: Did Dr. Kevorkian Receive Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Symbolism in Action
description: More than a thousand men and women have been arrested for protesting police misconduct and brutality in the case of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed immigrant who was killed outside his Bronx apartment a few weeks ago. Some critics, including Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, have ridiculed the daily demonstrations at New York's Police Headquarters as a publicity stunt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, HAVEN
description: BLOOM-Haven. Haven, a sparkling, beloved member of our class family. Fran and Barry, cherished parents and friends. Our love to you. The Families of Haven's Episcopal Nursery School Class

title: The Sexual Journey Of a 12th Grader
description: ''Open Bodies,'' Sebastien Lifshitz's moody, finely nuanced portrait of a Parisian 12th grader beginning to explore his fluid sexuality is a movie that plays tricks with time so that the actual sequence of events doesn't crystallize until the very last minute. Early in the film, its boyish protagonist, Remi (Yasmine Belmadi), is shown meeting and having sex with Marc (Pierre-Loup Rajot), an older man whose possessiveness Remi instinctively recoils against.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, MARGARET (NEE STOECKEL)
description: BLANK-Margaret (nee Stoeckel) of North Bergen, formerly of West New York, NJ, on March 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Stefanie Lauer and Ernest Blank. Dear mother-inlaw of James L. Lauer. Loving grandmother of Michael Lauer and Ruth Lauer-Manenti and great-grandmother of Nathan and Daniel Lauer. Services Beth El Cemetery, Washington Twnshp, NJ, on Wednesday, March 31, at 10:30AM. For info: ''GuttermanMusicant'' 1-800-522-0588

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FANEUIL
description: ADAMS-Faneuil. Died peacefully at home, March 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Emiko, devoted father of Rebecca & Susannah. Memorial service Thursday, April 1, 1999 at 12 o'clock noon, U.N. Chapel, 1st Avenue & 44th Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Chess-in-theSchools, 353 West 46 Street, New York, New York 10036.

title: Arrest of Milosevic Could End the War; Policy on the Cheap
description: To the Editor:

title: Hubble's Infrared Picture Show: How Stars Are Born
description: Before its infrared camera shut down in November, the Hubble Space Telescope focused on an assortment of spiral galaxies for some of its last pictures in those invisible wavelengths, giving astronomers penetrating looks through thick galactic dust into the glowing hydrogen clouds where stars are being born.

title: Audio Book Club Agrees to Buy Rival
description: The Audio Book Club Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Audiobooks Direct, a unit of the Doubleday Direct Inc. subsidiary of Bertelsmann A.G., for undisclosed terms to become the world's leading provider of books on tape and compact disks.

title: Another Tack on Antifreeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Impressions
description: To the Editor:

title: Cartoon Caricatures
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Associates to Purchase a Rival
description: Computer Associates International Inc., the fourth-largest maker of software in the United States, agreed today to buy a rival, Platinum Technology International Inc., for about $3.5 billion in cash, bolstering its fledgling service business to help counter slower corporate sales.

title: 2 Mexican Banks to Plead Guilty in Laundering Case
description: Two of Mexico's biggest banks have agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges of money laundering, officials said today, bringing a swift end to the most important legal cases stemming from a major investigation into the movement of illegal drug profits.

title: Daily Protests End at Police Headquarters
description: After two weeks and more than 1,200 arrests, the last of the daily protests outside Police Headquarters that have placed the death of Amadou Diallo at the center of the city's political consciousness was held yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLGEL, MARSHALL J.
description: VOLGEL-Marshall J. Of Toms River, formerly of New York, on March 28. A star in the world of ''Shoe Biz'', he designed shoes for many entertainers and dignitaries. Visiting Tuesday 2-4PM, 7-9PM; services Wednesday 10am at ''The Family Owned'' Carmona-Bolen Home For Funerals, 412 Main Street, Toms River, New Jersey.

title: A Bullish Jerry Brown Barges On, Stepping on Toes
description: After three decades in politics, Jerry Brown knows how to relish the bombshell moments.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the transmission of voice calls using Internet technology misstated the location of the headquarters of Vocall Communications. It is in Mountainside, N.J., not Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALDESBEREA, MIGUEL R.
description: VALDESBEREA-Miguel R., Artist/Portraitist, died at the age of 62 in New York, March 25th of heart failure. He was born in Havana, Cuba, in 1936 and studied there at the San Mejandro Academy of Fine Arts, and in Spain at the San Fernando School of Fine Arts and Prado Museum in Madrid. In addition to his many private clients, he counted business leaders, government officials, deans of American Universities, and clergy among his clients. He is survived by his mother, Isolina Berea; his sisters, Gladys, Margarita, and Nancy; an aunt, Erlinda Solana-all of Miami, Florida. His father, Rogelio Valdes, is deceased. Service at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street at 10:30am, Wednesday, March 31, 1999. In lieu of flowers, contributions maay be sent to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Ave, New York, NY 10028; Attn: Mrs. Emily K. Rafferty, Senior Vice President for Development.

title: 'Mad Cow Disease' Seen in French Zoos
description: A large number of monkeys and lemurs in French zoos appear to be infected with the agent that causes ''mad cow disease,'' according to a provocative study published today in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: UTILICORP UNIT PLANS TO BUY WESTERN GAS STORAGE PLANT
description: Utilicorp United Inc. said yesterday that its Aquila Energy subsidiary had agreed to buy Western Gas Resources Storage Inc., a unit of Western Gas Resoures Inc., for $100 million in cash. Western Gas Resources Storage is a natural gas storage facility in Katy, on the Texas gulf coast, with capacity of 27.2 billion cubic feet. In 1998, Aquila was the second-largest wholesaler of natural gas in the United States and the third-largest of electric power. Utilicorp United is an international energy company based in Kansas City with annual sales of $12.6 billion.

title: Bringing Up Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: New Questions About Popular Fertilization Technique
description: A popular technique to help infertile men become fathers, injecting individual sperm into individual eggs, alters the fertilization process, researchers have found. They said there was no evidence so far that the technique affected babies conceived with it but they said the finding raised troubling questions of what doctors should tell infertile couples.

title: Olivetti Raises Hostile Bid For Big Rival
description: Olivetti S.p.A., Italy's No. 2 phone company, raised its hostile bid today for a bigger rival, Telecom Italia S.p.A., by 15 percent, to 60.4 billion euros, or about $64.7 billion.

title: Command, Control and Adrenaline, and Relief at Pilot's Rescue
description: The American pilots flying the attacks on Yugoslavia exchange few words, but probably no one reads their moods and fears more closely than a 32-year-old Air Force staff sergeant from Thorntown, Ind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRESTA, HON. THOMAS S., JUSTICE, SUPREME COURT, NYS (QUEENS CO.), RET.
description: AGRESTA-Hon. Thomas S., Justice, Supreme Court, NYS (Queens Co.), Ret., on March 27, 1999, in his 90th year, of Belle Terre, NY and Vero Beach, FL (formerly of Maspeth, Queens). Beloved husband of the late Anna (nee Zimatore). Devoted father of Adrienne A. Ciafardoni and Thomas S. Agresta, Jr. Grandfather of fourteen and great grandfather of nine. Reposing at Nolan & TaylorHowe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, NY. Funeral blessing Thursday, 10am, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. Hours Tuesday & Wednesday, 2-5, 7-9pm.

title: Could a Small Ground Force Carve Out Safe Havens?
description: If NATO nations were to order ground troops to Kosovo, the vanguard of a force of 30,000 to 40,000 troops could be assembled in days and would be sufficient to protect many refugees from further attack, according to several current and former American commanders.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Advance in Dow Is Matched By Other Share Measures
description: The Dow Jones industrial average's surge above 10,000 highlighted a session that saw broader market gauges move sharply higher, pushed by merger talk in the oil patch and continued strong demand for a relatively small group of big technology stocks.

title: Milosevic Goal Is Serb Enclave, NATO Declares
description: NATO officials said today that Slobodan Milosevic's goal in Kosovo was to carve out a Serb-only enclave in the province that he could hold onto after the fighting had ended.

title: NETTAXI TO BUY PLUS NET TO UPGRADE ON-LINE COMMERCE
description: Nettaxi Inc., a World Wide Web community, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Plus Net Inc., for about $70 million in stock to capitalize on Plus Net's advanced-search and comparison-shopping capabilities. Nettaxi said details of the transaction, including the total number of shares the company, which is based in Campbell, Calif., would issue, would be made final later this week. Plus Net, based in Los Angeles, brings Internet search, E-mail and commerce technologies to Nettaxi, which plans to offer its subscribers the option to buy and sell goods from personal Web sites they create through Nettaxi. Nettaxi's shares jumped $2.375, to $12.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, EVELYN
description: ZUCKERMAN-Evelyn. Adored wife of the late Phillip. Proud and loving mother to Howard & Roz, Rochelle & Leo Goldberg, Steven & Shelly. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. A high spirited woman with a contagious zest for living, a quick wit and generous heart that was used for both the benefit of her family and many Jewish causes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MORTON
description: GREEN-Morton. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi

title: NATO HUNTING FOR SERB FORCES; U.S. REPORTS SIGNS OF 'GENOCIDE'
description: NATO bombers hunted for Serbian troops in embattled Kosovo today and the Administration said evidence of ''genocide'' by Serbian forces was growing to include ''abhorrent and criminal action'' on a vast scale. The language was the State Department's strongest yet in denouncing Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Albanian-Americans Rally To Voice Support for Raids
description: Wrapping themselves in the flags of their homeland and of the country where they make their home, more than 3,000 Albanian-Americans marched from the United Nations to the Yugoslav Mission in New York yesterday, praising NATO's bombing campaign, which is intended to drive Yugoslav and Serbian troops out of Kosovo.

title: Police Say a Trail of Coins Led to Suspects
description: The police report from Staten Island sounded like a fairy tale written for a detective magazine: five men who robbed a grocery store were caught yesterday after officers followed a trail of coins back to their hideout in the woods.

title: $200 Million Wireless Deal Is Reported
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., seeking advanced wireless Internet links, is investing about $200 million in what is incongruously known as the wireless cable business, executives close to the plans said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Proof Positive That People See Colors With the Tongue
description: When it comes to colors, the English language is at no loss for words. Interior decorators and paint manufacturers, among others, are constantly coming up with ever more fanciful color names.

title: Jets Release Burger And Sign Norgard
description: Continuing to revamp their roster, the Jets released a starting offensive lineman yesterday and signed another lineman.

title: Tap, Tap, Tapping In Premieres
description: Peggy Spina Tap Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINDER, CANTOR JONAH
description: BINDER-Cantor Jonah. Beloved husband for 55 years of Claire. Devoted father of Dr. Paula and Dr. Alfred Stillman, Dr. Renee and Dr. Frank Jonellis, Dr. Jack and Dr. Martha Binder. Adored grandfather of Dr. Norman, Michael, David, Michelle, Rebecca and Daniel. Services are today, 1 P.M., at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' Brooklyn, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park.

title: Message of Hillaryno.com Is Yes to Giuliani
description: For several weeks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, have waged a kind of shadow campaign for the United States Senate. He is raising money and she is peppering people with questions, but both have refused to announce their intentions. It has all been so maddeningly . . . polite.

title: CBS Posts a Victory, Too
description: From the start of last night's final game, the CBS announcers understood that Connecticut had a chance, that a Duke victory was not a foregone conclusion. In the pre-game show, Greg Gumbel said it was the hoped-for matchup, a collision of teams that ''have it all'' and were the only ones that had been ranked No. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURGH, RABBI ALBERT
description: GINSBURGH-Rabbi Albert. Of Brookline, MA, March 28. Husband of Dr. Fruma (Winer). Father of Ann G. Hofkin of Long Lake, MN, Jean G. Kapcio of LaFayette, NY & Ellen G. Yuan of Dedham, MA. Grandfather of three & brother of Irene Levine and Dr. Sylvan Ginsburgh, both of Israel. Graveside services Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, New York, Wednesday, March 31, 1PM. Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Council Opposes Giuliani's Plan on Police Expansion
description: Two months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proudly proclaimed that he would intensify his war on crime by speeding up the hiring of 1,500 new police officers, the City Council vowed yesterday to fight the plan, saying it would rather move 500 officers from administrative jobs to the streets by 2001.

title: Corrections
description: The News Watch column in Circuits on Thursday misstated the cost of a new ICQ instant message service called Signaler, which notifies users of messages even if they are not on line. The service, from NECS, a subsidiary of the Bell South International Group, costs $9.95 per year, not per month.

title: Yeltsin Sends His Premier To Urge Serbs to Negotiate
description: Alarmed by the prospects of a widening war in the Balkans, President Boris N. Yeltsin dispatched Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov today on a high-risk mission to Belgrade Tuesday to coax President Slobodan Milosevic back to the negotiating table.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At the beginning it seemed very simple. Now, you don't know who's right and who's wrong. Both sides are human beings and both are suffering.''

title: Bank One Plans Job Cuts
description: The Bank One Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest bank, plans to cut as many as 2,200 jobs, or 2.4 percent of its work force, by the middle of next year as a result of its merger with the First Chicago NBD Corporation, a spokesman said.

title: Students Pull An All-Nighter
description: The University of Connecticut campus erupted in proud pandemonium early today, with hundreds of students lining up to toss wooden pallets on a huge bonfire to celebrate the school's upset of Duke in Monday's national basketball championship.

title: I.C.I. in Talks On Sale of Assets
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in disposal talks with several parties. I.C.I. said yesterday that the Huntsman Corporation of Houston was one of the companies with which it was talking, but it would not specify which industrial assets are being discussed.

title: Postcards From a Patchwork Season
description: Despite all the talk of joint ventures -- the revelation last week that Helmut Lang and Patrizio Bertelli of Prada were quietly putting their heads together, while everyone else in fashion was swayed by the drama of who would control Gucci -- the fall collections that recently ended in Europe and New York will go down as the most individualistic in many years.

title: Q & A
description: The Planetary Plane

title: Sales of New Homes Declined in February
description: New-home sales unexpectedly fell in February for a third consecutive month, suggesting that higher mortgage rates might prevent the housing market this year from matching the record pace of 1998, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 Salomon Executives Shifting to London
description: Ending months of speculation, Michael Klein, global head of the financial entrepreneurs practice at Salomon Smith Barney, is moving to London, where he and Edward Miller, a longtime Smith Barney executive, will jointly head European investment banking.

title: Are We Losers? Putting a Mating Theory to the Test
description: I am such a loser. According to a branch of biology known as evolutionary psychology, the human brain was designed to make mating decisions that insure an individual's genes will be passed along to the next generation. As a woman, these researchers believe, I should look for a man of high status who will invest all his money and goods in our kids. Knowing this theory, I have nonetheless chosen to spend the last decade with an artist, a man with no money and few goods beyond a bunch of paint brushes. Silly me.

title: WELLPOINT WANTS TO BUY COLORADO HEALTH INSURER
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc., based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., one of California's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that it was interested in buying Rocky Mountain Hospital and Medical Service for more than $200 million so it could do more business in Colorado. Rocky Mountain Hospital, the not-for-profit parent company of the health insurer Blue Cross Blue Shield of Colorado and Nevada, said earlier this month that it was considering merging with Anthem Inc. for about $165 million, including a donation of more than $100 million to a charitable foundation. Wellpoint's offer will probably be $200 million to $240 million, including a charitable donation of $140 million, a spokesman said. The merger plan was previously reported by The Denver Post and The Wall Street Journal.

title: UConn Proves It Can, and How
description: Richard Hamilton slowly climbed up the 8-foot ladder, savoring every step. Hamilton slowly snipped the net, savoring every slice. Hamilton slowly wrapped the net around his neck and waved to the delirious fans, savoring every wave. Hamilton was savoring a trip to heaven, hoops heaven.

title: Trying to Organize Globally, KPMG Plans to Consolidate Most Operations
description: KPMG L.L.P., the fifth-largest accounting firm, said yesterday that it would consolidate most of its operations into two regional groupings, as it seeks to transform a loose association of firms into a unified global business less than a week after its Canadian affiliate defected.

title: A Day for Baseball and Cigar Lovers
