description: ESPN could not have improved much on its telecast of Sunday's game between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban all-stars short of hiring Ted Koppel to be host of a town meeting about the production of deadened baseballs in Fidel Castro's Cuba.

title: Arrest of Milosevic Could End the War
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : The Grass Is Never Greener
description: Americans spend at least as much on lawn care  an estimated total of $30 billion a year  as they do on books. Lawns occupy more land than any other crop, including wheat and corn.

title: Triumph of Serenity Over Chaos
description: Practice may be the way to Carnegie Hall, as the old joke has it, but the details of the route can vary wildly. Han Yong, a 41-year-old Chinese composer whose imaginative ''Drifting Center (Samsara II)'' had its world premiere at Orpheus's concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, studied piano and composition in Xian, worked as a farmer during the Cultural Revolution and resumed his studies in Shanghai in 1978. He joined the faculty of the Shanghai Conservatory and had what appears to have been a flourishing career writing for film and television in the early 1980's. But when he moved to New York in 1987, he started over, delivering for Chinese restaurants and holding jobs with a fashion company and a music publisher before making contact with other Chinese expatriate composers and resuming his musical career in the mid-90's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, DR. JOHN LEO
description: MADDEN-Dr. John Leo. The members of the John L. Madden Surgical Society are saddened by the death of our beloved teacher. A distinguished master surgeon, teacher, researcher and author, he influenced the careers of many surgeons from all over the world. He was an excellent physician and a Compleat surgeon, but above all he was a tremendous human being and a perfect gentleman. His surgical family extend their deepest sympathy to his family and heartfelt gratitude for the privilege of having shared the life of Dr. Madden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBGOLD, SIDNEY
description: LIEBGOLD-Sidney, born 1901, in New York City, lately of Silver Springs, Md. A friend to all, beloved by his family, including the late Sara, Barbara and Harriet; cherished by Bruce, Susan, Randy and Dennis. A dedicated servant of the City of New York as an administrator at City College, he guided and encouraged generations of young people. Lifelong champion of civil and equal rights, with an unshakeable belief in his fellow human beings. Graveside service at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I., Tuesday, 2:30 PM.

title: Hockey East Boasts Three Semifinalists
description: Hockey East has its first-, second- and third-best teams, New Hampshire, Maine and Boston College, in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. That's rare. Only once before, since the event began 51 years ago, has one conference so dominated the conclusion of the championship competition.

title: Safeguarding Nuclear Secrets
description: Top officials of the Energy and Justice Departments and the Los Alamos National Laboratory were amazingly careless in their handling of a scientist suspected of stealing nuclear secrets for China, judging from two reports last week by The Times's James Risen.

title: Agencies Taking Donations for Refugees
description: The following agencies are accepting contributions for Kosovo refugee assistance:

title: Albany Leaders Do Little on Budget but Try to Fix Blame
description: With the start of the new fiscal year just three days away, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders did nothing to resolve their budget differences today and instead bickered over who was to blame for the stalemate.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS AGAIN. The dollar rose against Europe's single currency as continued Yugoslav warfare raised fear of worsening the Continent's already slow growth. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0735, down from $1.0769.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Closes Above 10,000, Reflecting Strong Economy

title: With Oil Cuts, Why Invite Outsiders?
description: Greater American access to Saudi Arabian petroleum, a Clinton Administration goal and the dream of oil companies, has now been put on indefinite hold, senior Saudi officials said after a new OPEC agreement was reached.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JEANETTE
description: LEVY-Jeanette. Of Woodside, Queens. A kind, loving soul, passed away March 28, 1999 after a brief illness. All donations to be made to the UJA Federation in her memory. She will be sorely missed. Her loving family

title: Microsoft Will Reorganize Into 5 Units
description: Heralding an era he referred to as the ''vision version 2.0,'' the Microsoft Corporation's president, Steven Ballmer, announced the reorganization of the company yesterday into five divisions that he suggested would act with some independence.

title: Did Dr. Kevorkian Receive Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMERING, ANNE
description: ZIMERING-Anne. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of Seth and Charles and mother-inlaw of Meryl. Cherished grandmother of Daryl, Michael, and Howard. Adored great grandmother of Kayla, Amanda, Megan, and Alyssa. Devoted sister of Milton Goldberg. Past President of Hadassah and the Sisterhood of Manhattan Beach Jewish Center. Services today, 1:30 PM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, SOL
description: HOFFMAN-Sol. UNITE mourns the untimely passing of Vice President Sol Hoffman. In his 45 years as the leader of ILGWU (now UNITE) affiliates in Pennsylvania, Ohio, New Jersey and Maryland, Sol combined a deep commitment to the workers he represented with a broad vision of social justice. His love for his union and the union ideal are his legacy. leaves Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife, Catherine, and his children, Florice and Simone. Memorial Services on Wednesday, March 31, at 12 Noon, at Gutterman-Musicant Chapel, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Sol Hoffman Scholarship Fund, c/o President's Office, William Paterson University, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne, NJ 07470. Jay Mazur, President Bruce Raynor, Secy-Treasurer Edgar Romney Edward Clark Executive Vice Presidents

title: Starks Is a Warrior and Having a Blast
description: The volcano finally blew 10 days ago, erupting at 9:37 P.M. in the fourth quarter of a game against Seattle. It promptly shook the timeout huddle of the Golden State Warriors.

title: The Wagner Story Isn't Music to This Wagner's Ears
description: In the basement office of Gottfried Wagner, there is only one portrait of a composer. It is a concert poster of Franz Lizst, who among other things was Richard Wagner's father-in-law. The only likeness of Gottfried Wagner's most illustrious ancestor is a tiny framed black-and-white sketch of a 19th-century couple in a Venetian gondola; the male silhouette figure in the picture is, according to Gottfried Wagner, Richard Wagner.

title: Oil vs. Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Operation Provides Relief From Hands That Sweat
description: Corey Makowy of the Hunt Valley region of Maryland loved school, but on square-dancing day he begged his mother to let him stay home. He knew no one would want to take his hand.

title: Accounts
description: * Dreamworks SKG, Universal City, Calif., to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of Omnicom Group, to handle its media account, which had been handled by Focus Media, Santa Monica, Calif. Billings were estimated at $85 million.

title: DANA AND GKN PLAN TO SWAP TRUCK-DRIVETRAIN PLANTS
description: The Dana Corporation, the second-largest United States maker of engine parts, and the British parts producer GKN P.L.C. plan to swap businesses that make drivetrain systems for all-wheel and four-wheel-drive vehicles. Dana, based in Toledo, Ohio, will exchange a unit that makes front-wheel parts for light trucks for GKN's business that makes rear-wheel systems for heavy trucks. GKN's unit has annual revenue of $350 million, while Dana's business has annual sales of $300 million. Dana will give up its plant in Columbia, S.C., and joint ventures in Argentina and Colombia, as well as a majority stake in its Brazilian joint venture with GKN, based in Worcestershire, England. GKN has the option to buy the remainder of its stake in the Brazilian business by Jan. 1 of next year.

title: Mother and Lawyer Charged in Sale of 10-Week-Old Baby
description: A Hungarian woman and her lawyer were charged today with selling her 10-week-old baby girl for $60,000 to a Middle Western couple whom they lured over the Internet, Nassau County prosecutors said.

title: Company's Plan to Privatize Angers Shareholders
description: Even in a raging bull market, some New York Stock Exchange companies wallow in neglect. A few, like dusty antiques in the attic, turn out to be gems.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''Among Giants,'' a story of daredevil working class Englishmen, misstated the occupation of the main characters in the movie ''The Full Monty.'' They are unemployed steelworkers, not miners.

title: Long After 'Lambs,' Dr. Lecter Is Returning
description: Hannibal the Cannibal is back. Dr. Hannibal Lecter, the flesh-eating villain of Thomas Harris's 1988 novel, ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' will continue his adventures in a sequel, ''Hannibal,'' delivered unexpectedly last Tuesday by Mr. Harris to his publisher, Delacorte Press.

title: French Official Backs 3-Bank Merger Plan
description: The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, approved the $37 billion hostile bid by Banque Nationale de Paris for Societe Generale S.A. and Paribas S.A. and urged the three institutions to hold talks on completing a deal.

title: Preservation Group Lists Endangered Historic Sites
description: An organization dedicated to preserving sites of historical interest around the state released a list of New Jersey's 10 most endangered historic places yesterday, including the Broad Street railroad station in Newark and the Stony Brook Bridge in Princeton.

title: New Breed of Fox as Tame as a Pussycat
description: Ordinarily the silver fox is a canny, elusive creature, quick to bite when cornered, and well nigh impossible to tame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MAXWELL E.
description: MILLER-Maxwell E. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Maxwell E. Miller, whose deep commitment to the Technion is reflected in his attainment of the rank of Technion Guardian and his status as an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors. Together with his wife Frieda, he was instrumental in establishing the Maxwell E. and Frieda Miller Dormitory. We extend condolences to his widow, children and grandchildren, and all members of the bereaved family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive VP Jonathan Sohnis, New York Metropolitan Region Chair Joseph Huber, New York Metropolitan Region Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENAN, JOHN
description: GREENAN-John. On March 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Soltz Greenan. Loving father of Thomas & MaryAnn. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, 6-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St., Wednesday, 9:15AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St., NY NY 10022 or the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56 St., NY NY 10019.

title: ASE TEST TO BUY 70 PERCENT OF ISE LABS FOR $98 MILLION
description: ASE Test Ltd., the world's largest independent chip-testing company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $98 million for a 70 percent stake in ISE Labs, a closely held Silicon Valley company that tests integrated circuits. ASE, based in Singapore, is a unit of Taiwan's Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc., the world's second-largest independent packager of integrated circuits. ISE Labs has offices in the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore. In January 1998, ASE became the first foreign-based business to be listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

title: Sports of The Times; No Mystery at the End: Known Factors, Not an X Factor, Won It
description: WILLIAM AVERY was in the somber Duke locker room last night rehashing the terrible ending to a great national championship game. Connecticut had ended Duke's incredible season with a 77-74 victory in one of those classic games and marathon efforts.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bomb, Talk, Deal
description: Now that NATO has made its point that it's serious about degrading the Serb army -- and President Slobodan Milosevic has made his point that you can pound, kill and curse the Serbs, but there's just one thing you can't do and that's make peace in the Balkans without them -- it's time to get back to the negotiating table before this situation spins out of control.

title: A Devastating Disorder, Beyond a Phase
description: Teen-agers fretting over how they look may not be just going through a phase. Some may be suffering from body dysmorphic disorder (B.D.D.), a severe preoccupation with an imagined or slight defect in appearance. This often secret and little recognized malady can lead sufferers to drop out of school, shun social contacts and even try suicide, say researchers at Brown University.

title: Guilt-Ridden Monitors Reflect on Pulling Out
description: For the 1,400 members of the Kosovo Verification Mission, whose job until recently was to try to keep a lid on the simmering hatreds of Kosovo, these are days of frustration and guilt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, MABEL V. (BRADY)
description: PATTERSON-Mabel V. (Brady), 94, of Topsfield, March 28. Formerly of NY, mother and motherin-law of Mary & David Lebet of Ipswich, Theresa & Joseph Visco of Somerville, NJ, Eugene Jr. & Ann Marie Patterson of Ballston Lake, NY, grandmother of thirteen, great grandmother of eight, aunt of John Brady of Sun City, CA & Patrick Brady of Woodhaven, NY. Funeral from the PetersonO'Donnell Funeral Home, 167 Maple St. (Route 62), Danvers, Wednesday at 9:15AM followed by a funeral Mass in St. Rose of Lima Church, Topsfield, 10AM. Visiting hour on Wednesday 8:15-9:15 AM. Burial in St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY Thursday at 1 PM. Expressions of sympathy to The Little Sisters of the Poor, Our Lady of Hope House, 1 Jeanne Jugan Lane, Latham, New York 12110.

title: U.S. Eases Stance on the Eviction of Landowners in Oneidas' Suit
description: The Federal Government moved yesterday to soften its support of the Oneida Indians' claim to 270,000 acres of land in central New York, saying it did not want to evict any private landowners from their homes.

title: Kodak Issues Rare Warning on Earnings
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, worried that analysts were ignoring the informal cautions it had been sounding about its first quarter, turned up the decibel level yesterday. In a radical departure for the traditionally secretive company, Kodak warned that its first-quarter earnings would come in below many analysts' expectations but gave detailed, and much rosier, forecasts for the rest of the year.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Does the Dow Measure Up?; Despite Growth of Rivals the Old Gauge Still Matters
description: It is a staple of the nightly news, of daily discussions at dry cleaners and doughnut shops, overheard in cell-phone conversations and in cocktail party chatter.

title: UConn Upsets Duke to Grab N.C.A.A. Title
description: There were 5.2 seconds left on the clock, and Duke, the team thought to be unbeatable, was about to be beaten.

title: Did Dr. Kevorkian Receive Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: People's Poet, Denying Crime, Is Convicted In South Africa
description: Mzwakhe Mbuli, a musician and writer known as the People's Poet of South Africa, was convicted of bank robbery today.

title: Purdue Is New on the Block But Looks Like a Champion
description: The final score was low, the fewest points in the history of the women's tournament final, but perhaps that was because the stakes have grown so high.

title: Executive Leaving Thompson Agency
description: John Geoghegan, the general manager of the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson, part of WPP Group P.L.C., is leaving as the agency brings in a new executive to head its Western operations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 20 about the climb of the Dow Jones industrial average toward 10,000 misidentified a building displaying the average on its electronic billboard. It was the News Corporation building, on the Avenue of the Americas at 48th Street, not the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter building.

title: Belgrade 'Targets' Find Unity 'From Heaven'
description: Along Belgrade's loveliest shopping street, Knez Mihajlova, groups of young men filled with anger and beer today completed the trashing of the American Center, the British Council, the Goethe Institute and the French Cultural Center, as scattered policemen watched and chatted among themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SHIRLEY
description: JACOBS-Shirley. Devoted wife to the late Abraham W., loving mother of Richard and June (Bowling), grandmother of David, best friend of Sam Kilimnik, beloved aunt and cousin, and mother hen to all at Commercial Bank of NY. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at Krtil Funeral Home, 1st Ave and 70 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRELL, MORTIMER
description: KRELL-Mortimer. The Officers, Directors and Trustees of Temple Emanu-El, Englewood, NJ are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and past President, Mort Krell. Mort was a devoted and deeply committed member of our congregation. Our condolences to his beloved wife Rita, his brother David, his children and grandchildren. A generous man of honesty and conviction. He will be greatly missed. Contributions may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Renal Transplant Department, the Holy Name Hospital Dialysis Center, Teaneck, New Jersey, or Women's American ORT.

title: Peanut-Allergy Vaccine Clears Mice Test
description: Jock Roy, 55, a businessman from Hanover, N.H., has suffered from peanut allergies ever since he bit into a peanut butter sandwich at a birthday party nearly 50 years ago. He described his reactions as beginning with a prickly sensation in the mouth and throat followed by a feeling of sickness and swelling of the throat and sinuses lasting up to four hours.

title: Drone Planes en Route
description: The United States has sent at least three pilotless drone planes known as Predators to the Balkans to photograph Serbian troops and defense systems and to document attacks against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Writers' Den Puts Squeeze on Typists
description: YOU don't need a military historian to tell you who is winning the typographical wars. You know the answer. Bit by bit -- byte by byte? -- computers have pushed typewriters to the same musty shelf where you'll find buggy whips, bottles of cod-liver oil and, any day now, New York City subway tokens.

title: Nursing Impressions
description: To the Editor:

title: Conductor Reaps Bright Blooms
description: Conductors generally know what their strengths are or at least what the public perceives as their strengths, and although some occasionally rebel against their reputations and try to play against type, most keep close to what works for them. Charles Dutoit has always been successful with early-20th-century showpieces, works that dazzle with bright hues and picturesque effects and that use volume to pack a visceral wallop. For his visit to the New York Philharmonic, which began on Thursday evening and ended Saturday, he did the sensible thing, which was to draw on that repertory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, JAMES G.
description: McNALLY-James G. Of New Paltz, NY and Red Hook, NY, died on March 21, 1999. He is survived by his father, Edward M. and his mother, Margery of Red Hook, NY, and his brother Edward A. and sister-in-law Glenna of Ridgefield, CT, and his brother Mark of Kingston, NY. James was founder and president of Home James, a painting and contracting firm in New Paltz. We will remember our beloved brother as a multi-talented, humorous man who contributed greatly to the lives of all he touched. He had an independent spirit that inspired his friends and relatives. We will miss him deeply. Edward and Glenna McNally

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKOFF, DORA
description: BOYKOFF-Dora. Of Los Angeles, CA, formerly of Boca Raton, FL and Jamaica Estates, NY. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel, devoted mother of Joan Baron & Carolyn Hittleman, loving grandmother of Michael and Jonathan Baron and Isabel Hittleman, caring sister of Oscar Goldberg and Ray Carroll. Services will be held at 1 PM at Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd (at 66 Avenue), Rego Park, NY.

title: Final 2 Results in Bridge At Vancouver Tourney
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals ended here Sunday night with a victory for a Texas squad in the Women's Team Championship. Robin Klar of Spring, Joan Jackson, Petra Hamman and Peggy Sutherlin, all of Dallas, Shawn Quinn of Katy, and Mildred Breed of Bryan, outdistanced a field that included many players who had won world titles.

title: Nickelodeon Narrows Review
description: Nickelodeon said yesterday that it had narrowed its review for its new branding account to six finalists. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Future of a Supermarket Has Village in an Uproar
description: Those who insist that big business always wins, who believe that concrete and asphalt are destined to inherit the earth, have never witnessed the power of well-placed raffia ribbons and certainly have never lived in a place like this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEAPHY, KATHLEEN (NEE REILLY)
description: HEAPHY-Kathleen (nee Reilly). Died at the age of 83 on March 29, 1999. Born in County Cavan, Ireland. Survived by two daughters, Brenda Brunelle and Rita Boyd, two grandchildren, Philip and Thomas, two sisters, Margaret Timoney and Annie Reynolds plus many loved nieces, nephews and cousins. Love of God was her sustenance and succor throughout her life; she is safely home in heaven. Funeral liturgy at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel RC Church, Tenafly, NJ Wednesday at 9:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visiting at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 So. Washington Ave, Bergenfield, NJ Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Unlikely Tool for Species Preservation: Warfare
description: Perhaps no exploration in American history has more famously combined intrepidity with scientific enterprise than the two-year expedition of Lewis and Clark from the Mississippi to the Pacific two centuries ago. The ecologist Daniel B. Botkin, in a 1995 book, called it ''the greatest wilderness trip ever recorded.''

title: By Design; Throwing Mules a Curve
description: Last spring's shoe was the mule or slide; as flat as a bedroom slipper. This year, the mule has been feminized with a curvy mid-high heel to wear with skirts and with cropped or long pants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JAMES MARKOE
description: ROBBINS-James Markoe, of Bedford, NY. Born October 9, 1903. Died at Northern Westchester Hospital Center on March 29, 1999. Mr. Robbins, a graduate of St. George's School, Middletown, RI and Princeton University, Class of 1926, grew up in Haverford, PA. An avid golfer, he was captain of his university team and a competitor in the U.S. Amateur. When Bobby Jones held the Number 1 ranking in amateur golf, Mr. Robbins was Number 14. He won both the Maine Open Championship and the Pennsylvania Amateur. He served as President of the New York Metropolitan Golf Association as well as a governor and officer of the Father-Son Golf Association. He was a longtime member of the U.S Seniors Golf Association of which he was both a governor and officer. His interests in education included the Harvey School, Katonah, New York, and the Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT of which he was Trustee. He was a member of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, the Nassau Club, the Princeton Club of New York, the Ekwanok Country Club of Manchester, Vermont. There is a FatherSon Tournament there named in his honor. He was also a longtime member of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford. He leaves his wife, Mary Brooks Robbins, two sons, Brooks Robbins of Hingham, MA., and James O. Robbins of Atlanta, GA, a daughter, Barbara Robbins Anderson of Frankfort, Germany, two stepsons, Thomas C. Schwartzburg of Berkeley, CA., and John A. Schwartzburg of Lawrenceville, NJ. He leaves ten grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. His first wife, Jane Brooks of Nyack, NY, died in 1942. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of one's own choice.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER PLUNGES. Copper prices posted their biggest decline in six weeks as record stockpiles indicated that production was outpacing demand. In New York, copper for May delivery fell 2.7 cents, to 62.45 cents a pound.

title: New Clinics Let Lesbian Patients Be Themselves; An Effort to Help a Group That Often Shuns Doctors
description: There's always an uneasiness when the doctor wants to talk about sex, a young woman said at a recent meeting of her lesbian support group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTH, NICHOLAS R.
description: HUTH-Nicholas R. On March 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Dorris (nee) Janowitz. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. Receiving visitors Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Religious service Wednesday, March 31, at 10:00 AM. Funeral immediately following. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association appreciated.

title: American Innovators Bracketing the Century
description: Donald Berman is a thorough, exciting and persuasive musician, and his piano recital at Merkin Hall last Tuesday night was memorable. His program consisted entirely of works by Americans, from Charles Ives and Carl Ruggles through to present-day composers. None of the music was familiar, and all of it was delivered with vitality. This was not music one has lived with, but it may need to be there as one goes on through life.

title: National Grid Posts $A 1.1 Billion Gain
description: National Grid P.L.C., a British utility company that has agreed to buy New England Electric System of the United States, said yesterday that it would post a net gain of $:677 million ($1.1 billion) after selling off part of its telecommunications unit and closing out interest-rate swaps. National Grid said it would record a net gain of $:713 million after placing 60 million shares in Energis P.L.C., its telecommunications unit. The company will also have a one-time charge of $:36 million from closing out $:415 million of interest-rate swaps.

title: Hekou Journal; Hidden China, a Swarm of Pimps and Pickpockets
description: Pert and smiley, with slaggy walk and jerky manner, Du Renming looks as amiable as an overgrown puppy.

title: BP and ARCO Said to Edge Toward Deal
description: BP Amoco P.L.C. is close to an agreement to acquire the Atlantic Richfield Company in a stock swap worth about $28 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: 2 in Computer Industry Are Holding Reviews
description: Two advertisers in the computer industry said yesterday that they were holding reviews for their accounts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Staff on Tenure Track Is Teaching Less at Yale, a Study Says
description: Universities across the country are increasingly using graduate students and adjunct faculty to replace more expensive tenure-track professors, and a new study by graduate students at Yale suggests that better-endowed universities are no exception.

title: Sports of The Times; Connecticut Survived The Best
description: JUST by being here, they were superior beings, the Huskies and the Dukies.

title: The Next Trick for Amazon.com: Auctions
description: Furthering its audacious ambition to be involved virtually any time anyone sells anything on the Internet, Amazon.com plans to let individuals and small businesses conduct auctions on its popular World Wide Web site.

title: Viag and Algroup Abandon Plan for Merger
description: Viag A.G., Germany's third-largest utility, and Algroup, the world's biggest maker of packaging for the drug industry, abandoned their $8.7 billion merger plan today because they could not agree on terms.

title: Americans Propel MetroStars
description: The MetroStars' victory over the Columbus Crew on Sunday brought more credibility to the league's American players. Not only because the MetroStars played without Tab Ramos, their best American player, and Mike Petke's powerful header for the game's only goal came off a free kick by Miles Joseph, another American, but also because the MetroStars used only one foreign player in the game, Ecuador's Eduardo Hurtado.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Dispute Over Student Activity Fee Reaches High Court
description: A nationwide dispute over student activity fees at public universities reached the Supreme Court today, as the Justices agreed to decide whether students have a constitutional right to keep their money from going to groups whose political message they find objectionable.

title: Did Dr. Kevorkian Receive Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gill Will Return To Starting Lineup
description: Kendall Gill has been asked to sacrifice much of his game for the good of the Nets over the past two years, so it came as little surprise when he asked Coach Don Casey to remove him from the starting lineup before Friday night's game against the Indiana Pacers. In a lost season, Gill hoped to provide a spark off the bench, waking the team and changing his own fortunes.

title: MORE ON THE CONFLICT
description: POWERLESS MONITORS -- For the 1,400 members of the Kosovo Verification Mission evacuated to Macedonia, these are days of frustration and guilt over the fate of 1,500 local staff members left behind. Page A9.

title: System Built To Ward Off Missile Attack Fails a Test
description: An experimental missile defense system failed its most basic test today for the sixth time, missing a missile launched at a New Mexico test site.

description: Assist to Bradley For Wife's Book

description: HORVITZ-Eva. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Abraham. Loving mother of Morton, David and Judith. Adored grandmother of nine grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, at 11:30 A.M. Tuesday.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNT, DR. LESTER A.
description: MOUNT-Dr. Lester A., of Bronxville, NY, died March 28th, 1999, following a brief illness. He was 89 years old. A native of Ohio, Dr. Mount graduated from the University of Cincinnati Medical School in 1935. He was a pioneer of neurosurgery, a career which began in 1936 until he retired in 1983. In 1941, he was appointed assistant in neurology, Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons and rose to the rank of professor of clinical neurosurgery. He was a leader in neurosurgery serving as president of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons in 1976 and the president of the Neurosurgical Society of America in 1961. His extensive interest in international neurosurgery led him to 6 continents. He served on Project HOPE as chief of neurosurgery in seven countries. His 58 publications were presented at medical meetings throughout the world. He has received numerous awards, chief among which are: The Cushing Medal for Distinguished Service in Neurosurgery and the Daniel Drake Award For Excellence in Medicine from the University of Cincinnati. Dr. Mount is survived by his three children, Philip, Melinda, and David, and two grandchildren, Alexander and Laurel. A memorial service will be held at 11AM, on Thursday, April 1, at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, New York.

title: Terror in Kosovo
description: Slobodan Milosevic has answered six days of NATO aerial attack with a vicious campaign of terror against the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo, creating a military and refugee crisis of major proportions. The United States and its European allies must respond with alacrity on both fronts, while giving Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov of Russia a chance to seek a diplomatic settlement when he travels to Belgrade today. Since the end of the cold war, NATO has not faced a greater test of its unity or ability to react effectively to a rapidly developing threat to European stability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, IVAN
description: MEYER-Ivan. The law firm of Ebenstein and Ebenstein mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Ivan Meyer, Esq. Mr. Meyer was of counsel to this law firm for over 40 years. Our condolences to his family.

description: To the Editor:

title: Trash Haulers Protest Licensing Procedures
description: A small group of garbage haulers and some of their customers held a rally on the steps of City Hall yesterday to protest the Giuliani administration's tactics in renewing licenses of commercial haulers.

title: Balanced Immune Response May Fight Ebola
description: The early moments after patients are infected with the feared Ebola virus may be the most important to their survival, researchers report this week in the journal Nature Medicine.

title: I.M.F. Relents on Aid to Russia, but U.S. Talks Tougher
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had agreed on ''a broad framework'' to resume financial aid to Russia, but American officials immediately warned that they would permit only enough support to keep Moscow from defaulting on international loans.

title: Langdon's Journey Is a Step Too Long
description: He, alone with Mike Krzyzewski, remembers when the bottom fell out at Duke, when the prospect of assembling a team that would streak toward tonight's national championship game and a slot among the greatest college basketball teams was as distant as the home he left behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDLENER, JASON CRAIG
description: REDLENER-Jason Craig. Our full hearts and deepest sympathies go out to Irwin and Karen and their family on the much too early loss of their son. We are just three of the so many who love you. Dan, Abbe and Jake Klores

title: Defense to Seek Ouster of Louima Jury Panel
description: After more than 600 prospective jurors filled out questionnaires yesterday to begin the jury selection process in the case of police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima, lawyers for the officers said they would ask the judge to dismiss the entire panel because some of its members gave interviews to reporters as they left the courthouse.

title: After Embryo Mix-Up, Couple Say They Will Give Up a Baby
description: Last April, Donna Fasano and Deborah Perry-Rogers arrived separately at a midtown Manhattan fertility clinic filled with hope and apprehension. Both women had tried without success for years to conceive a child. Both had the same doctor, and they had appointments on the same spring day to be implanted with fertilized eggs.

title: Paramedics Say Police Officers in Bronx Beat a Man in Custody
description: The police are investigating reports by Emergency Medical Service workers that a sergeant and several other officers beat a man in custody at the Bronx County Courthouse last Friday, a police official said yesterday.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Rugged Pair of Jeans

title: INSIDE
description: Assisted Suicide's Future

title: As Clock Ticks for Peace Pact, British and Irish Leaders Huddle
description: As an Easter deadline approached, Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland sought tonight to persuade Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders to compromise on a dispute that is threatening to collapse the peace effort here.

title: Digital Fingerprints Leave Clues to Creator of Internet Virus
description: Following the telltale digital fingerprints of the author of a rapidly spreading computer virus, a lone software detective has assembled a dossier suggesting that the virus writer has struck previously and that the programmer's activities are already well known to computer security experts.

title: Haunting What-If Left For Talented Cubans
description: The baseball commissioner and the owner of the Baltimore Orioles sit on either side of Fidel Castro for 11 innings, talking baseball like good buddies, and eat his food and drink his wine as he spends hours showing off his knowledge of the game. Other major league officials and team owners show off color pictures taken of them with the world's longest-running despot and can't wait to get home to display them for their friends.

title: Renault Shares Rise On Earnings Forecast
description: The shares of Renault S.A. rose yesterday after the company, France's No. 2 car maker, forecast its 37 percent stake in the debt-laden Nissan Motor Company would strongly improve earnings starting in 2001. Renault's shares rose 1.05 euros, to 35.05, after touching 36.43 ($40) earlier, after the company said it would invest $5.4 billion in Nissan. More than 2.4 million shares changed hands. Nissan's shares gained 5 yen, to 468 in Tokyo.

title: A Girlish Domestic Terrorist
description: For a first-rate line reading, count on Ellen Burstyn. ''I know you can't help thinking it's a home,'' she says, playing an eternally girlish Mary Tyrone to David Selby's guilt-ridden James in the Hartford Stage revival of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title: U.S. Reaches Settlement On Toxic Cleanup Costs
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it would recover some of the $4.6 million cost of its cleanup of mercury-tainted soil around a defunct backyard metal-refining operation in a residential neighborhood in Westchester County.

title: The Name Game At $7.50 a Share
description: Computer Literacy Inc., an on-line seller of technical books and manuals, jumped today after it changed its name to Fatbrain.com to attract more customers.

title: Concentric to Split Stock
description: The Concentric Network Corporation said today that it would split its shares two for one. The new shares will be issued on an unspecified date to shareholders of record as of April 30. Concentric, based in San Jose, provides Internet access, focusing on the business market. It had revenue of $82.8 million in 1998. Shares of Concentric Network closed today at $80.3125, up $13.3125, or 19.9 percent, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Lotto Sales Waning, Trenton Plans to Join Multistate Game
description: Faced with a steady erosion of ticket sales and player interest in its most popular lottery game, New Jersey has decided to enter a six-state lottery game in hopes of satisfying residents' dreams of bonanza jackpots.

title: Another Albany Budget Impasse
description: Two days before the start of a new fiscal year, Gov. George Pataki and the New York State Legislature are not even close to agreement on a new budget. Even worse, the progress made last year in opening up the budget process has been cast aside because of the inability of all parties to agree on basic revenue and cost estimates. As usual, few outsiders are paying attention, so the Governor and the lawmakers feel little pressure to compromise. In a switch from years past, the current impasse results from surplus, not scarcity, and squabbling over how best to spend money in a time of plenty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, ALISON
description: WEINGARTEN-Alison. 20, of Hartsdale, NY, on March 28th, 1999, of Leukemia. She is survived by her mother, Barbara, Michael Zinman, her sister, Marisa, her aunt and uncle, Gail and Floyd Tupper, and her father, Andrew of South Salem, NY. Funeral services Tuesday, at 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens following services. The family would like to express its deeply felt thanks and appreciation to the staff of 17 West and the ICU Unit at New York University Medical Center. Contributions to the Leukemia Society would be appreciated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Fashioning a Savior From a Demonized Milosevic
description: As reports of Yugoslav forces killing and evicting the ethnic Albanians emerge from Kosovo, a critical question has arisen for the West: at what point do brutal acts by Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, and the increasingly personal attacks on him by the West, make it impossible ever to negotiate with him again?

title: Executive Changes
description: BELL ATLANTIC CORP., New York, named Maura Breen, vice president for sales and service, as head of its long-distance unit. She succeeds Al Binford, who is joining Intermedia Communications, Tampa, Fla., as vice president for customer service delivery and operations.

title: Have Skis, Helicopter, Awe and Terror
description: Back a thousand years ago, as a fearless beginner on the groomed, hard-packed slopes of the Northeast, I seemed to favor the point-the-skis-downhill-and-crash-at-the-bottom approach. A few years later, after a moderately undistinguished college-racing career, that basic style remained intact with a brief, and aborted, attempt at an entirely new discipline in the Austrian Alps: deep-powder skiing. That attempt ended with a crash at the top of the mountain, not the bottom, and two broken skis.

title: DOW FINISHES DAY OVER 10,000 MARK FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: The Dow achieved a perfect 10 yesterday. Thousand, that is.

title: Art Agency's Ex-Head Sues City, Saying It Violated Charter
description: A former fund-raiser for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who renounced her support for him and quit her post with the city's Art Commission in a dispute over flagpoles in city parks sued the Giuliani administration yesterday, accusing officials of violating her rights and the City Charter.

title: E*Trade Acquiring Another Web Site
description: E*Trade Group, the No. 3 on-line brokerage firm, said today that it had agreed to acquire Clearstation Inc., a financial World Wide Web site with 90,000 registered members.

title: Sexual Abuse, When Men Are Victims
description: Researchers have learned a great deal in recent years about female victims of sexual abuse and its often tragic consequences. But much less is known about men who are sexually abused. How often does it happen? And what are its effects?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, BURT
description: ROSS-Burt. On March 26, age 85, at Twining Village, Holland, Pa. Beloved brother of Jerome D. Ross and brother-in-law of Henriette Lubart Ross of New York, uncle of Andrew Ross, New York, and Sarah Ross Mallery, North Hollywood, Calif. We love you and will greatly miss you.

description: IF it was a movie, it might have been called ''The Spy Who Got Knocked Cold.'' But it is reality, and Sony Pictures Entertainment suffered a defeat yesterday in a longstanding legal dispute with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc.

description: DAVID-Mollie. Beloved wife of the late Hy. Devoted mother of Dan and Margo, Mel and Jerry. Cherished grandmother of Butch, Hy, Michelle, Bruce, Marla and Adam. Graveside services Wednesday March 31, 1999, 11:30am at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave, Ridgewood, NY.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Shaky Yoshii Still Gets Pat on the Back
description: The spin, as usual, was positive.

title: Assisted-Suicide Advocates See Gains in Kevorkian Case
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian may be the nation's most visible and vocal advocate of assisted suicide. But many proponents of assisted suicide believe his murder conviction last week in the death of a seriously ill man could help them.

title: Recovering Torre Aids Recovering Strawberry
description: Recuperating in these first weeks after his surgery for prostate cancer, Yankees Manager Joe Torre is not responsible for the lineup or the pitching rotation or most of the day-to-day decisions. The sole official duty he maintains, it seems, is the handling of outfielder Darryl Strawberry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, DIONNE R.
description: SLATER-Dionne R. Of Locust Valley, LI, on March 27, 1999. Beloved wife of Alexander B. Mother of Henry L. Murray, Jr., Margaret M. Sullivan, John M. Murray, Catherine W. Murray, and her stepchildren Kathy S. Hart, Alexander B., Jr., and Serena S. Wilson. Sister of Mary Louise Smith. Grandmother of Linda, Michael, Catherine, Audrey, J. Morgan, Henry, Ryan, Kathleen and Alexis. Aunt of Bruce and Richard Smith. Service St. John's of Lattingtown on Wednesday, March 31, at 11 AM. Donations to Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx, NY, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Technical Problems Delay Weekend Flights at Dulles
description: First a radar dish at the edge of a runway quit. Then on the radar screens where the airplanes should have been a strange line appeared that ''looked like an EKG,'' one controller said. Finally the smell of smoke filled the control room. In all, four separate failures at Dulles International Airport led to the delay of more than 100 planes on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Reaching for Some Answers, Americans Betray Trust and Mistrust
description: Dilia Theodosakia can pinpoint the moment when her apprehension lifted and the bombing of Serbia, an operation she initially considered the perilous undertaking of a President she thoroughly distrusts, began to make sense.

title: A Homage To Soviet Creators
description: Tressor Dance Company

title: British Officials: 'Large Volume of Refugees Fleeing From Their Villages'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference on Kosovo by Foreign Secretary Robin Cook and Gen. Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of Britain's Defense Staff, in London yesterday as recorded by the British Government:

title: A Contraceptive Returns to the Market
description: The contraceptive sponge, once the most popular nonprescription birth-control device for women, could be available once more on drugstore shelves by fall.

title: Vague on Reforms, Nigeria's President-Elect Woos New York
description: The President-elect of Nigeria came to New York yesterday to say that his country, an international pariah for 16 years, is now headed firmly toward democratic rule, privatization of its huge oil industry and an end to decades of official corruption and severe human rights abuse.

title: Michael V. Aris, 53, Dies; Scholarly Husband of Laureate
description: It was as exotic an offer as a young college graduate could imagine. Michael Aris, freshly out of Durham University with an honors degree in modern history, was invited to become the private tutor of the children of the royal family of the remote Himalayan Kingdom of Bhutan.

title: A Bleak but Steamy Triangle
description: The best time to see Gyorgy Feher's film ''Passion'' would be right after having read ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' James M. Cain's 1934 novel, or after having seen Lana Turner and John Garfield in the 1946 film based on it. ''Passion'' (''Szenvedley'') is the Hungarian version of that story, but its form is poetry, not prose, so filmgoers waiting for the verbal level of the narrative will still be waiting at the end.

title: A Kosovo Family's Cry: 'Now We Have Nothing'
description: Lindalita Kryeziv and her husband, Alban, walked, tired, scared -- and suddenly homeless, broke and stateless -- over this scraggly border crossing early this afternoon, a tiny part of the ragged band of ethnic Albanians hounded out of Kosovo by Serbian forces and pouring into Albania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOIFER, SADIE
description: SOIFER-Sadie. On March 27, 1999. Graveside services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Beth el Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Doctors' Offices Turn Into Salesrooms
description: As Gary Pozsik waited in his doctor's examining room last April for the final results of his yearly physical examination, he knew he was in for yet another discussion of his high cholesterol and his treatment options. But when the familiar subject came up, Mr. Pozsik, 48, a radio journalist in Columbia, S.C., was startled by what he heard.

title: Mergers
description: Two interactive companies in San Francisco specializing in content aimed at gay men and lesbians, Online Partners.com Inc. and Pridecom Productions, are merging under the Online Partners name. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Love Letters Intertwined With History's Dispatches
description: WINSTON AND CLEMENTINE

title: Talking to Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Democrat For Nassau, In Fraud Case, Resigns Post
description: Stephen J. Sabbeth, who was convicted of bankruptcy fraud this month, announced today that he had submitted his resignation as chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, clearing the way for the election of a new party leader.

title: Russia's True Interests
description: Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov of Russia is due in Belgrade today, with the stated purpose of stopping NATO air strikes against Yugoslavia and laying the groundwork for a peaceful settlement of the crisis.

title: She Puts the Brakes on Light
description: Her hair is boyishly cropped, her clothes are casual, and while riding her bike around Cape Cod she could pass as a college freshman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINERVA, JACK G.
description: MINERVA-Jack G. On March 27, 1999. Retired N.Y.C.T.A., U.S. Army WWII veteran, recipient of the Purple Heart. Beloved husband of Teresa (Cuonzo), loving father of Mary and John Gilhooly, Daniel and Mindy Minerva, proud grandfather of Teresa and Jacqueline Gilhooly, Craig, Lindsay and Corey Minerva, dear brother of Dora Piscitelli, Nicholas and the late Maria Mercurio, Rose DeGiglio, Michael and Donato. Visiting Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 9:15 AM, Our Lady of Guadalupe Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTE, SARA CATHERINE
description: BUTTE-Sara Catherine. Died suddenly in her home on March 15, after a brief illness. Beloved aunt of Porter, Sharon and Geoff Gifford. Beloved great aunt of Carrah, Barrett, Gillian, Virginia, Armando, Geoff and Lindsay. Dear friend and sister-in-law of Pete Gifford. Loved and mourned by many other relatives and friends. Memorial service Saturday, April 10, 11am, All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington at 80th. Reception afterward. Memorial fund: All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave, NYC 10021, attention: Suzanne May.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRIMARK FINANCIAL CORP., Toronto, a mutual fund company, sold its retail trust banking business, Trimark Trust, to Toronto-Dominion Bank, for an undisclosed price.

title: Patterns
description: Maharishi Fights Back

title: Seeking Guilt, Finding Fame; German's Novel of Nazi Era Becomes a U.S. Best Seller
description: ''When I was 15, I got hepatitis.'' So begins Bernhard Schlink's novel ''The Reader,'' about a German student, Michael, who collapses on a sidewalk and is rescued by a woman more than twice his age. The two begin an affair. The woman, Hanna, calls Michael ''jungchen'' (''kid'') and continually asks him to read to her. Then suddenly she disappears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, KATE EDELMAN
description: NEUMAN-Kate Edelman. Of Sarasota, FL, on March 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Harry Edelman and the late Hyman Neuman. Devoted mother of Allan M. Edelman. Cherished mother-in-law of Mitzie. Loving grandmother of Randy and Robert and greatgrandmother of Jonathan, Jesse, and Benjamin. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, Tuesday, March 30, at 10 AM. Contributions to a favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Argentina Refuses to Extradite Ex-General Back to Paraguay
description: The Argentine Government today denied a request by the newly installed Paraguayan Government to extradite its former military chief. The former official is accused of having ordered the assassination of the Paraguayan Vice President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, HARRY L.
description: STILLMAN-Harry L. The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Harry L. Stillman, beloved husband of Alice. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Dr. Ira J. Gelb, President

title: Air War 'Long Way From Over,' Clark Warns : 5 Leaders in Kosovo 'Executed,' NATO Asserts
description: PARIS  The top NATO military commander warned Monday that the air war against Serbian forces in Yugoslavia was far from over as President Boris Yeltsin of Russia dispatched his prime minister to Belgrade to try to halt the fighting and as France also said that it was seeking a diplomatic solution.

title: Troubled Planet Hollywood Reduces Staff
description: The theme restaurant Planet Hollywood International Inc., hit by growing losses and sales declines, said yesterday that it had cut 14 percent of its corporate work force in an effort to reduce costs.

title: Compaq Enlisting Distributors in PC Strategy
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, the No. 1 maker of personal computers, said today that it would contract with its distributors to help build some PC's to order, a strategy aimed at cutting costs and giving sales a lift.

title: Breast Is Best for Babies, but Sometimes Mom Needs Help
description: A gay New York pediatrician has enlisted 30 nursing mothers to supply breast milk for the baby he and his partner have adopted. The baby, now five months old, is thriving on the donated milk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HELENE
description: GOLDENBERG - Helene. On March 29, 1999 at age 76. Loving wife of Israel, devoted mother to Ann and son-in-law Dr. Peter N. Perinchies, adoring grandmother to Rebecca, Lauren and David. Devoted sister, aunt and friend to many. Services will be held on Wednesday at 1 PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Lingerie or Hardware, It's a Heavy Burden
description: Willy Loman is the world's most famous failed salesman, but what did he sell? During the 50-year existence of ''Death of a Salesman,'' Arthur Miller's words have entranced audiences with Willy's inflated dreams for his sons, his muttering to himself, his bad driving, his affair, his malfunctioning refrigerator, his mortgage, his insurance payments and his suicide, all the while refusing to disclose what Willy lugged in his valises.

title: South Africans Wrestle With Their Past and Future
description: If Bill Moyers had contented himself with reporting on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa, that would have been a considerable contribution to American viewers' comprehension of the horrors of apartheid as well as wrenching television. But ''Facing the Truth'' goes further. In interviews with the black victims of white repression, Mr. Moyers inquires into the limits of forgiveness and the lure of forgetfulness, while his encounters with the former tormentors leave bitter questions of individual responsibility and punishment.

title: Living With Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESHINGER, JEFFERIE LORRAINE
description: LESHINGER-Jefferie Lorraine. On March 28th, 1999. Beloved wife of Raymond. Devoted mother of Jodi, Marc, and stepmother of Raymond, Denise and Gregory. Cherished grandmother of Parker, Griffin, Harrison, Michael and James. Loving daughter of Ruth. Dear sister of Stewart & Spencer. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard, corner of 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions.

title: Goldman Sachs To Take Stake In Wit Capital
description: Goldman Sachs Group, the venerable investment partnership that is planning an initial offering of its shares to the public, said yesterday that it would buy 22 percent of Wit Capital Group, a pioneer in using the Internet to sell stocks to individual investors.

title: Anita Nall Plans Her Comeback
description: Anita Nall had it all.

title: Bank Executive Gets 5 Years for Theft
description: A Nigerian bank executive who fled the United States after admitting to embezzling $175,000 from a now-defunct Maplewood bank was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison, Federal prosecutors said.

It was only last fall that stock markets in the United States and most other countries were reeling in fear of a possible worldwide recession. That it failed to appear is readily apparent from the fact that the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday closed above 10,000 for the first time -- an increase of more than 30 percent in less than seven months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAEMPFLI, GEORGE
description: STAEMPFLI-George. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their esteemed colleague who distinguished himself both as an artist and as a dealer of impeccable and independent taste. Our sympathy and condolences to his family. Richard Gray, Pres. Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin. V.P.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about two executives named by Salomon Smith Barney, part of Citigroup, to head its European investment banking referred incorrectly to the firm's London office. It is also named Salomon Smith Barney. The reference to ''Goldman'' was erroneous.

title: Parents Don't Always Know Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosovars Flee to Beat Serb Deadline of Death
description: In the darkness, the little villages in the rolling hills and river valleys around the northwestern Kosovo city of Djakovica emptied out this morning, with the residents rushing -- literally for their lives -- to beat the 5 A.M. deadline set by Serbian forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCON, FLORENCE
description: MESCON-Florence on March 27, 1999 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Richard and Michael. Dear mother in law of Miriam. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah. Adored sister of Shirley Leitstein and aunt of Robert, Alex and Bruce Leitstein. We will hold her in our loving memory forever. A graveside service will be held at 10:30am on Friday, April 2 at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: After Kosovo's 'Cleansing': Can Two Sides Ever Coexist?
description: The growing refugee crisis in Kosovo has left Clinton Administration and NATO officials wondering whether they will be able to achieve their goal of a peaceful settlement between Serbs and ethnic Albanians.

title: Diallo Family to Get Preview of Charges From the District Attorney
description: The parents of Amadou Diallo plan to meet with the Bronx District Attorney today to get a preview of the criminal charges that the grand jury voted to bring against the four New York City police officers who killed their son seven weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, STEPHEN DAVID
description: BECKER-Stephen David, 71. Of Miami, Florida passed away peacefully at the Miami Heart Institute on March 27, 1999. He fought long, hard, and well for the life he had. He is survived by his wife Mary, his three children Keir, Julie, and David, his sister Myra, & his three granddaughters, Olivia, Carly, and Maya. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, March 31 at 1 PM, at the Gregg L. Mason Funeral Home, 10936 NE 6th Avenue, Miami, FL. 33161.
