description: COMBAT

title: Some Bottled Water Is Called Unsafe
description: People who buy bottled water cannot be sure that it is purer or safer than tap water, an environmental advocacy group said in a report issued today after sampling 1,000 bottles of water sold under 103 brand names.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ABZUG, BELLA S.
description: ABZUG-Bella S. The Board of Directors and staff of the Women's Environment and Development Organization mourn the loss of our beloved and dynamic co-founder one year ago today. We extend our deepest sympathy to her daughters and family and renew our pledge to honor Bella's legacy to the world's women. Her many admirers and friends are invited to join us in carrying forward Bella's principled activism. For information about our Bella S. Abzug Women in Leadership Program, cochaired by Eve and Liz Abzug, contact WEDO, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York City 10017; 212973-0325, Fax 973-0335.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHOFF, HENRIETTA RUDERMAN
description: FISCHOFF-Henrietta Ruderman. On March 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Richard, Jay (Patty), Elliot (Debra) and Lynn. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Alexander and David. Graveside service March 31, 1999 at 11am Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel Cemetery, Riversville (Greenwich), Ct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHEK, MAX
description: REICHEK-Max. On March 30. Beloved husband of the late Bessie. Loving father of Dr. Nathaniel Reichek and Ruth Baron. Fatherin-law of Lesly Reichek and Robert Baron. Grandfather of Jennifer, Matthew and Raphael. Beloved uncle of Helen, Jesse, Morton, Naomi and Elissa. His enthusiasm for life and his love of beautiful things will be with us always. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, Wednesday March 31, 10:30 AM.

title: Short Fuses and Hot Hands, but Knicks Keep Cool
description: The nerve of Latrell Sprewell. No one else would have been so brazen as to swallow up a Reggie Miller miss and drive the length of the court like a getaway car bound for a police barricade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JAMES MARKOE
description: ROBBINS-James Markoe, of Bedford, NY. Born October 9, 1903. Died at Northern Westchester Hospital Center on March 29, 1999. Mr. Robbins, a graduate of St. George's School, Middletown, RI and Princeton University, Class of 1926, grew up in Haverford, PA. An avid golfer, he was captain of his university team and a competitor in the U.S. Amateur. When Bobby Jones held the Number 1 ranking in amateur golf, Mr. Robbins was Number 14. He won both the Maine Open Championship and the Pennsylvania Amateur. He served as President of the New York Metropolitan Golf Association as well as a governor and officer of the Father-Son Golf Association. He was a longtime member of the U.S Seniors Golf Association of which he was both a governor and officer. His interests in education included the Harvey School, Katonah, New York, and the Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT of which he was Trustee. He was a member of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, the Nassau Club, the Princeton Club of New York, the Ekwanok Country Club of Manchester, Vermont. There is a FatherSon Tournament there named in his honor. He was also a longtime member of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford. He leaves his wife, Mary Brooks Robbins, two sons, Brooks Robbins of Hingham, MA., and James O. Robbins of Atlanta, GA, a daughter, Barbara Robbins Anderson of Frankfort, Germany, two stepsons, Thomas C. Schwartzburg of Berkeley, CA., and John A. Schwartzburg of Lawrenceville, NJ. He leaves ten grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. His first wife, Jane Brooks of Nyack, NY, died in 1942. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of one's own choice.

title: Commercial Real Estate; How Airline Got a New Office for Next to Nothing
description: A rising market, some good timing and the willingness to take a chance has produced a happy result for China Airlines: a new office in New York that was largely paid for by other people.

title: U.N. Panel Seeks to Ease Suffering of Iraq's People
description: Concluding that Iraq has gone from ''relative affluence to massive poverty'' since economic sanctions were imposed against it after the 1991 Persian Gulf war, a new report to the Security Council recommends several steps aimed at alleviating its people's suffering.

title: Labor Warms Up for Workout on Budgets
description: New York State's labor unions flexed their muscles yesterday in a way not seen in years, distributing tens of thousands of leaflets in 11 cities and holding a large rally on Long Island -- all part of an effort to battle proposed state and Federal budgets backed by Republicans.

title: Renault May Send Vehicles to U.S. in a Nissan Wrapper
description: Having agreed last week to buy a little over a third of the Nissan Motor Company, Renault S.A. may start selling Renault cars under the Nissan name in the United States someday, but it has no plans to revive the Renault name in the American market, Renault's chairman and chief executive, Louis Schweitzer, said yesterday.

title: Crime-Fighting Isn't Only About Stark Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Professor's Dreams in Three Dimensions
description: The latest Imax tourist attraction is a giddy foray into three-dimensional imagery, one that traces the history of this technique and makes a case for its promising future. Of course that possible renaissance is closely linked to the prospects for 3-D Imax, the huge-screen format that puts viewers in special headgear and sends them grasping at the illusory visions that seem just out of reach. While Imax still remains more of an amusement park treat than a viable storytelling form, ''Encounter in the Third Dimension'' offers a nifty demonstration of what 3-D technology can do now.

title: Six Men Are Arrested In Gambling Operation
description: Six men have been arrested and charged with operating a $6 million-a-year gambling ring that stretched from Suffolk County to the Bronx, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGOR, IRVING
description: SAGOR-Irving. Of Portland, OR, formerly of Larchmont, NY, at age 81. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Robert and Richard. Proud grandfather of Emily, Eli, Ellisa and Emma. Built successful CPA practice in NYC. Founding Director and Financial Officer of Sony Corporation of America. Longtime trustee of Larchmont Temple and former member of Fairview Country Club. Irving's intellect, wit and generosity greatly enriched the lives of everyone whose path he crossed. We are all better people for having known him.

title: The Yankees Trade Holmes
description: The Yankees retrieved a prospect who got away tonight, reacquiring pitcher Ben Ford and another minor leaguer from the Arizona Diamondbacks in a trade for reliever Darren Holmes. Ford, 23, was taken from the Yanks in the 1997 expansion draft. Last year he went 2-5 with 13 saves and a 4.35 earned run average for Arizona's Class AAA affiliate; he also appeared in eight games for the Diamondbacks. Ford will probably be assigned to the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate at Columbus.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Restaurant Coddles 'Bib Set' Customers

title: On Campus; Diallo shooting exposes conflicting emotions in a race and ethnicity course at John Jay College.
description: Students at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice take more than a casual interest in the shooting of Amadou Diallo. Many of them are police officers or have friends who are, and they know the pressures the police are under on the street.

title: JIM BEAM AND EUROPEAN PARTNERS PLAN VENTURE
description: Fortune Brands Inc., based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that its Jim Beam Brands Worldwide unit had agreed to form a joint venture with Highland Distillers P.L.C. of Britain and Remy-Cointreau S.A. of France to sell and distribute wine and liquor outside the United States. Each of the three partners will invest $110 million in assets or cash and will own a third of the venture, which will be independent and have its headquarters in Amsterdam. The venture will have a combined volume exceeding 16 million cases and sales of about $1.3 billion.

title: Would You Like the Wine List? No, Just a Corkscrew
description: I WAS nervous as I approached Patroon, the clubby restaurant known for its fine American food and excellent but expensive wine list. In my bag I had a special bottle of my own, a cabernet sauvignon from Dunn Vineyards that had been aging for a decade. On this night, I hoped, I would drink it with dinner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICAPUA, MARIE
description: DiCAPUA - Marie. Lost her struggle with cancer after a valiant two year fight. Aided by her daughter Maria Sicurelli Wist, she searched for a cure and participated in experimental treatments all over the world. Through her illness she never lost hope that these experimental therapies would help others, always putting everyone before herself. A former N.Y.C. school teacher, she touched lives here and abroad that she probably never even realized. Fighting for two years without a complaint, always a smile and loving word of advice she left a void that can never be filled. Mommy, you will always be my life. You were my angel on earth. She is survived by her devoted parents Anthony and Carmela DiCapua, broken hearted children, Maria Sicurelli Wist, Camille Sicurelli, Dr. Robert Sicurelli and Anthony Sicurelli; a loving sister Lucy Hartnett and brother Peter DiCapua; eight adoring grandchildren; nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass today, 10:15 A.M., at Our Lady of Angels, 7320 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11209. Maria Sicurelli Wist Andrew Wist (loving son-in-law) Milton & Ariana Wist (grandchildren)

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first day of Passover and Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Microsoft Settlement Talks Start Amid Secrecy
description: Settlement talks began this afternoon between the Microsoft Corporation and the Federal and state authorities who filed antitrust charges against the company almost a year ago.

title: Joe Williams, Jazz Singer of Soulful Tone and Timing, Is Dead at 80
description: Joe Williams, whose urbane bass-baritone and suavely heartbroken songs made him one of the most important singers in jazz, died on Monday in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 80 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIANI, DANTE C.
description: FABIANI-Dante C. Retired President and member of the Board of Directors of Crane Co., New York, NY passed away Saturday, March 20, 1999 at the age of 81. He was born in Waterbury, Connecticut, the son of Rosato and Barbara Poscente Fabiani. He received his early education in Waterbury and graduated from Crosby High School in that city in 1934. A 1938 graduate of Tri-State University, Angola, Indiana, with a Bachelor of Science degree in Accounting, Mr. Fabiani made a lifelong commitment to his alma mater. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1967, served as Chairman of its Development Committee for eight years, and was awarded a Doctor of Business Administration degree in 1973. He was the first alumnus to Tri-State to serve as its Chairman of the Board of Trustees, a position he held from 1976 to 1979. After serving as Chairman he accepted the responsibility of chairing the endowment campaign to bring TriState into its second century with financial resources to ensure the university's solid position as a small private educational institution. In 1979 he was elected Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Trustees and was the 1980 commencement speaker. A strong believer in the free enterprise system, Mr. Fabiani often encouraged young people to work within this system to find ways to meet energy and natural resource needs, be willing and prepared to take educated risks with their own capital and skills in the future, and to strive to innovate new & better methods of production. Mr. Fabiani's career in corporate America began in 1938 and spanned more than fifty years. The early years included positions with Auburn Rubber Corp., General Electric Co., Continental Can Co., and Standard Products Co. He joined Townsend Co., New Brighton, PA, as a director and secretary-treasurer. At H.K. Porter, Pittsburgh, PA, he served as vice president/finance. He then went on to serve as director and vice president/finance at McDonnell Aircraft Corp., St. Louis, MO. In 1960 Mr. Fabiani joined Crane Co., as vice president and assumed the presidency and a directorship in 1961, positions he held continuously until his retirement in 1980. During his career and after retirement Mr. Fabiani continued to serve on many corporate boards. These included Crane Co., Textron Inc., Northview Corp., CF&I Steel Corp., Huttug Sash & Door Co., Cambrian & General Securities, p.l.c. and Pirelle Enterprises Corp. Mr. Fabiani is survived by his wife, Virginia Parnham Fabiani of Southbury, CT; two daughters, Barbara Henriques of Lee, MA., and Kathryn Bartholomew of Williamsport, PA; one son, James Fabiani of McLean, VA; & five granddaughters.

title: Longer Solvency for Medicare and Social Security
description: Relieving some of the political pressure for reform, the Government released new actuarial studies today extending the date at which Medicare can be expected to run out of money by seven years and Social Security insolvency by two years.

title: Plastic Wraps: To Worry or Not?
description: THE Eating Well column of Jan. 13, about the potential health hazards of some plastic wraps, raised many questions among readers about plastics in general. The column looked only at data from Consumers Union, which suggested that a component in some forms of wrap is an endocrine disrupter. Endocrine disrupters can mimic or interfere with hormones in the body and may cause breast cancer, birth defects, low sperm count and mental problems.

title: Catch Of the Day
description: ON April 1, French children tape cutouts in the shape of fish on the backs of unsuspecting schoolmates. The victims are ''poissons d'Avril,'' or April fish, the Gallic version of April fools.

title: Hillary Clinton, in Morocco, Says NATO Attack Aims at Stopping Bloodshed
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said tonight that the NATO bombing in Yugoslavia was necessary because of the Serbs had planned a ''campaign of massive and systematic destruction'' against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

title: Doomed At the Start, But Regal To the End
description: Movie stars, people we're used to seeing with foreheads the size of billboards, understandably tend to shrink before the footlights of live theater. The refreshing surprise in the uneasy new production of Ibsen's ''Hedda Gabler'' at the Geffen Playhouse here is how Annette Bening seems to expand as a presence in the title role.

title: Europe Approves AT&T Deal With British Partner
description: The AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. won European Union approval today for their planned $3 billion joint venture after AT&T agreed to reduce its British operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRESTA, HON. THOMAS S.
description: AGRESTA-Hon. Thomas S., Justice, Supreme Court, NYS (Queens Co.), Ret., on March 27, 1999, in his 90th year, of Belle Terre, NY and Vero Beach, FL (formerly of Maspeth, Queens). Beloved husband of the late Anna (nee Zimatore). Devoted father of Adrienne A. Ciafardoni and Thomas S. Agresta, Jr. Grandfather of fourteen and great grandfather of nine. Reposing at Nolan & TaylorHowe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, NY. Funeral blessing Thursday, 10AM, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers donations to the Memorial and Honor Program of St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, PO Box 3704, Memphis, TN 38173-0704 appreciated. Hours Wednesday, 2-5, and 7-9 PM.

title: Answering Mr. Milosevic
description: The failure of Russian peacemaking and the unabated Serbian assault on Kosovo yesterday left the United States and its NATO allies understandably frustrated. After a week of bombing raids, the alliance's air offensive against Serbia has not produced the quick capitulation by Slobodan Milosevic that President Clinton and European leaders hoped to see. As additional warplanes were ordered into combat this week, and tactics were adjusted to target Serbian army forces on the ground in Kosovo, it is reasonable to wonder if NATO commanders prepared a sufficiently intense and extensive aerial campaign.

title: NOTEBOOK; Accreditation Questioned
description: Jones International University broke new ground this month when it became what was believed to be the first completely on-line institution to be accredited by one of the country's six major regional accrediting associations. But the decision by the accrediting group, the Commission on Institutions of Higher Education of the North-Central Association of Colleges and Schools, swiftly encountered opposition.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Going Strong at 85

title: Crimes Court Not Ready To Punish Kosovo Violence
description: Since the bombing of Yugoslavia began, American officials have threatened to prosecute perpetrators of violence in Kosovo, but for that threat to be credible, changes must be made in the war crimes tribunal that would try them, American officials and human rights advocates say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNT, LESTER A.
description: MOUNT-Lester A., MD. Members of the Department of Neurological Surgery at the Neurological Institute of New York, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center note with sadness the death of Lester A. Mount. Dr. Mount spent his entire career at the Neurological Institute and was Acting Director of the Department of Neurological Surgery from 1972 to 1973. He was widely recognized as a master neurosurgeon, he was meticulous and bold and was a pioneer in the management of subarachnoid hemorrhage and intracranial aneurysms. He also served Project Hope as chief of neurosurgery and performed service for that organization in many countries. A kind and dignified gentleman, he was a superb teacher and scholar devoted to the Neurological Institute and the Medical Center. He was an advisor and friend to a multitude of medical students, trainees in neurosurgery and his colleagues. We extend deep condolences to his family. Robert A. Solomon, M.D. Chairman and Director Neurological Surgery New York Presbyterian Hospital Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, CLAIRE (NEE GRABOIS)
description: BRANDT-Claire (nee Grabois) on March 30th, 1999 at the age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Neil and Susan and Lawrence and Lois. Cherished grandmother of Michael & Minna, Richard, Heather, Brooke and Gary Fishkind, and Michelle. Proud great-grandmother of Zachary Brandt Fishkind. Funeral service Friday, 9 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: The Duke Fans Salute A Pair of Runners-Up
description: About 1,500 Duke loyalists went to Cameron Indoor Stadium today to welcome the men's and women's teams, which each lost in its respective National Collegiate Athletic Association title game.

title: All Duke's Players Have Are the Tracks of Their Tears
description: William Avery sobbed in Coach Mike Krzyzewski's arms, only to hear him repeat over and over, ''It's O.K., it's O.K.''

title: China's Dam Project
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hungrier Huskies
description: Clearly, the University of Connecticut's basketball players did not read the script for a Final Four tournament that everyone in St. Petersburg, Fla., was calling the Duke Invitational. Unfortunately for Duke, its players had memorized the script and come to believe in their own inevitability. So had Duke's semifinal opponent, Michigan State. On Saturday, the Spartans played aggressive defense but seemed rattled on offense and intimidated by Duke's reputation.

title: Graduate Teaching Assistants, Increasingly Burdened, Are Unionizing
description: When Elizabeth K. Shermer started the five-year process of earning a doctoral degree in medieval English from the University of California at Berkeley, her teaching responsibilities began almost immediately. Without any tutoring on how to teach, she was asked to lead a discussion group on Chaucer the next day.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column yesterday, about a dispute between Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. and Sony Pictures Entertainment over the James Bond movie franchise, described the ownership of MGM incorrectly. It is a publicly traded company, of which 90 percent is owned by Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Digital Commerce column in Business Day on Monday, about efforts to place a value on the traffic volume of various World Wide Web sites, misstated the amount of money raised by iVillage.com in its recent stock offering. The company raised $87.6 million, not $292 million, which was the value of the shares at the end of the first trading day.

title: Accounts
description: * Mothernature.com, Acton, Mass., to Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C., as the first agency to handle the consolidated noninteractive creative duties for the Internet retailer of vitamins and minerals. Billings were estimated at $8 million. Faber Media, New York, continues to handle media duties.

title: Business Travel; Priceline.com Stock Zooms In Offering
description: Priceline.com, the Web site that hired William Shatner of ''Star Trek'' as its pitchman, saw its stock price fly off to a distant galaxy in its first day of trading yesterday.

title: DiSarcina Out 3 to 4 Months
description: Gary DiSarcina's left forearm is injured more severely than first thought, and the Anaheim Angels shortstop will need surgery and miss three to four months of the regular season.

title: Compromise On Arms Proves Elusive In Ulster
description: After two days of intensive negotiations, Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland failed tonight to persuade Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders to compromise on the bitter dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Huskies Receive Blue-Carpet Treatment
description: The movie on the flight from Tampa, Fla., this morning was Monday night's game. The Connecticut basketball team's chartered plane landed at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, Conn., just as Duke's Trajan Langdon lost the ball in the final seconds, sealing the Huskies' 77-74 victory for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARE, JOHN PEYTON
description: WARE-John Peyton. Of Scarsdale, NY, on March 30, 1999 at age 77. Mr. Ware, a graduate of the Brooks School and Princeton University, served as a 1st Lt. in WWII and Korea, where he was awarded the Bronze Star. A pioneer in marketing paperback books, Mr. Ware worked for Pocket Books, Simon & Schuster, Reader's Digest and John Wiley & Sons and was honored by the Bureau of Independent Publishers and Distributors for ''Outstanding Service to the Industry and to Education.'' He was an avid sailor and co-author of eight editions of The Cruising Guide to the New England Coast. He was president of the American Platform Tennis Assn and was elected to its hall of fame; a Trustee of the American Yacht Club in Rye, NY; and elder of Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale; and a member of the University Glee Club of NY and Princeton Club of NY. Mr. Ware was the dear husband of Molly (Blanchard); devoted father and father-inlaw of Leslie Ware and Philip Caputo of Norwalk, CT and of Jennifer Ware and Stephen Ellis of Rowayton, CT; proud grandfather of Lindsay Ellis; and loving brother of E. Winslow Ware, Jr. of Richmond, VA. Donations in his memory may be made to Princeton University, Hitchcock Presbyterian Church or Mystic Seaport, Mystic, CT. A memorial service will be held, 11 AM Tues. April 6 at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

title: Slowdown in Growth Seen for Euro Zone
description: The combined economy of the 11 nations that adopted the European single currency in January is likely to expand less than expected because of dwindling exports to Asia and Latin America, a report to the European Commission said today.

title: In Restaurants, Sticker Shock
description: PITY, if you can, the wine lover with a taste for the most expensive wines available in New York restaurants. Prices for these top-quality wines differ so greatly from restaurant to restaurant that a customer keeping one eye on the budget could go into the wine-list equivalent of sticker shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, MARION
description: GRAHAM-Marion. Central Synagogue Sisterhood notes with sorrow the death of Marion Graham, a longtime member of our Board and a past Vice President. We extend condolences to her family. Central Synagogue Sisterhood Shirley Steinhauser, President

title: Even Milosevic Foes Criticize Western Media
description: Frustrated by the war propaganda that passes for news here, a small but significant minority of Serbs spend long hours every day watching satellite television, exchanging E-mail and surfing the Internet. But few find the Western version wholly convincing.

title: Milosevic Demands an End To Raids Before He'll Talk
description: Western governments today reaffirmed their policy of using force against Serbia after mediation by the Russian Prime Minister produced a flurry of ideas but no evidence of a breakthrough on Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HELENE
description: GOLDENBERG - Helene. On March 29, 1999 at age 76. Loving wife of Israel, devoted mother to Ann and son-in-law Dr. Peter N. Perinchief, adoring grandmother to Rebecca, Lauren and David. Devoted sister, aunt and friend to many. Services will be held today Wednesday at 1 PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Hershiser's Outing Reassuring to Mets
description: On a day the Mets were still looking for starting pitching, their latest acquisition proved he can still pitch. And quickly.

title: Presidential Hopefuls' First Race Is a Test of Fund-Raising Waters
description: Presidential candidates, who are always desperate for money, have been racing around the country even more feverishly in the last several days, hitting up contributors at back-to-back fund-raising events and twisting arms even tighter than usual.

title: (Musical) Notes From the (Paris) Underground
description: Near the end of ''The Underground Orchestra,'' Heddy Honigmann's moving documentary about exiled musicians living in Paris, an Argentine classical pianist, Miguel Angel Estrella, remembers the shattering events that drove him to leave his country when it was governed by a repressive military regime. Arrested and tortured, Mr. Estrella was accused of giving aid and comfort to anti-Government forces (the lower class, which his captors dismissed as ''scum'') simply because he played for the poor. The fact of his being a musician was deemed sufficient to stimulate a dangerous class consciousness.

title: Hunt Is Widened for Man Sought in Threats to Judge
description: The Essex County Prosecutor's office established a task force yesterday to find a man accused of threatening to kill a judge and an assistant prosecutor.

title: Refugee Flood Swamps Havens
description: The flow of refugees from Kosovo is overwhelming neighboring countries, leading to long delays at the borders and even orders to turn back. Ethnic Albanian refugees who fled Kosovo for Albania have been spilling into Macedonia, where border officials have turned them away, and the Deputy Prime Minister said the country could not cope with more refugees.

title: Honoring a Museum's Very Loyal Member
description: IN 1924, back in the days when the Metropolitan Museum of Art was a sleepy behemoth with grandees like Payne Whitney and Elihu Root on the board, a young woman studying for a masters' degree at Columbia University eagerly gave $10 to join the museum as a member. Today, 75 years later, Luise K. Addiss is still a member -- the only person, the Met says, who has been on the roster that long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATZ, JACK
description: SCHATZ-Jack. The family and friends of Jack Schatz mourn his passing on March 29, 1999. Graveside service will be held at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, N.Y. on Friday, April 2, at 11AM. Call Frank E. Campbell 212288-3500 for further information.

title: The Iran Precedent
description: Brian Williams should beware: This is how Ted Koppel began, in 1979, with a late-night show intended to provide news of the American hostages being held in Iran. ''ABC News Nightline'' has been on the air ever since.

description: The following agencies are accepting contributions for Kosovo refugee assistance:

title: Versatile Fritters For Spring
description: THE scallion pancake I've always made is similar to the kind served in Chinese restaurants. It is essentially bread.

title: Emachines Is Fourth in U.S. Sales of PC's
description: Emachines Inc., which makes personal computers costing less than $600, is now the fourth-largest PC maker in the United States retail market, according to industry figures.

description: How can setting a ratings record with a new show ever create a sticky dilemma for a television network?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHODOROV, RHEA
description: CHODOROV-Rhea. Died at home in Pomona, NY on March 28, 1999. She was 85. Rhea will be greatly missed by Jerome, her husband of 67 years, a daughter, Susan and many other family members and friends. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Association for the Vision Impaired, 260 Old Nyack Turnpike, Spring Valley NY 10977.

description: Some On-Line Donations Don't Make It to Charities

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about assertions by NATO officials that the President of Yugoslavia is trying to carve out a Serb-only enclave in Kosovo misspelled his surname. He is Slobodan Milosevic, not Milosevec.

title: Nasdaq May Extend Trading Until 9 P.M.
description: The Nasdaq stock market is considering whether to expand trading hours to as late as 9 P.M., its president, Alfred R. Berkeley 3d, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIAMPI, GIOTTO
description: CIAMPI-Giotto. Ciao! Dear Uncle Sam. I was born in 1902, in Florence, Italy, the cradle of the Renaissance. I came to you in 1927, taking with me a doctorate in Economics from the University of Rome, and lived in and loved New York City ever since. In 1939 I became an American citizen. With the Big Apple as a base, I traveled all over the world. Always glad to get back to my adopted home, and to my many friends from the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, the Metropolitan Opera, and the Metropolitan Club. During these many years I have had many ups and downs and have been both a spectator of and a participant in all the world events. I have truly lived the American Dream and the American Reality! But, now it is time for my mortal remains to go back to glorious little old Florence. Back into the past, back in the beautiful monumental Ciampi family Tomb, designed by my father, sculptor Alimondo, not far from Dante, Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo, and so many other great ones...But, I shall leave half my heart and soul with you, dear Uncle Sam, and my Calder American family, and the Murdocks, and the Banks and so many friends, whose affection has contributed so much to my life, here and in the world. San Miniato, in Florence, is a thousand year old Romanic church on a hill, from which tourists from all over the world admire the view of Florence, below. Porte Sante is a monumental cemetery, attached to the church. My family Tomb is right in the center, below the church. Come to say ''hello'' and we shall bless you from the ''al di la''...Memorial service at Frank Campbell, Madison at 81st, at 4 PM, April 7, 1999, reception following at Metropolitan Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, MOLLIE
description: DAVID-Mollie. Beloved wife of the late Hy. Devoted mother of Dan and Margo, Mel and Jerry. Cherished grandmother of Butch, Hy, Michelle, Bruce, Marla and Adam. Loving great grandmother of Brandon, Casey and Michael. Dear sister of David Mathathia, Anne Lerman and Esther Dastis. Graveside services Wednesday March 31, 1999, 11:30am at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave, Ridgewood, NY.

title: New Janitor Hurt in Fall Down an Elevator Shaft
description: A custodian on his first night on the job fell 45 feet down an elevator shaft in a midtown office building yesterday and was critically injured, the police said.

title: About New York; Trying to Save Spring's Soul From Auction
description: HARRY BUBBINS smiled at the season's first daffodils -- a burst of bright yellow blossoms perched atop rich green stems -- thriving in a community garden on East 138th Street and the Bruckner Expressway in Mott Haven. The Bronx garden's location -- a triangular lot that ages ago was a wreck -- was a testament to life's tenacity amid housing projects and a tangle of roads and highway ramps. Mr. Bubbins calls this plot, the southernmost garden in the South Bronx, the Liberated Zone.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FANEUIL
description: ADAMS-Faneuil. Died peacefully at home, March 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Emiko, devoted father of Rebecca & Susannah. Memorial service Thursday, April 1, 1999 at 12 o'clock noon, U.N. Chapel, 1st Avenue & 44th Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Chess-in-theSchools, 353 West 46 Street, New York, New York 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GHERARDI, DR. LINDA BUCH
description: GHERARDI-Dr. Linda Buch. March 31, 1996. Three years since you left us. We love you so. You are deeply remembered and sorely missed by all. Your loving family

description: For Greek Orthodox Easter

title: Repertory for Pettitte Is Complete Again
description: Andy Pettitte's on-again, off-again relationship with the cut fastball is on again. Pettitte, who strained his elbow throwing the high-torque pitch March 7, tossed a few cutters in a bullpen workout today for the first time since sustaining his injury.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Chez Louis, Encore

title: From the Seven Seas to New York Tables; From Auckland to Athens, A World Tour Fresh on the Plate
description: NEW YORKERS may take it for everyday. But the menu at a restaurant like Tropica is a global snapshot. There are conch from Mexico, John Dory from Australia and pompano from South America. A walk though a good fish market is no less extraordinary -- like an art exhibition with works collected from all over the world.

title: Long-Term Capital Expects To Start Repaying Rescuers
description: Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund that Wall Street firms saved from collapse during the turmoil in stock and bond markets last September, has recovered robustly and plans to start paying back its rescuers as early as June.

description: To the Editor:

description: Once Upon a Time In a Dark Psyche

title: Rising Concern Over Profits Sends Dow Below 10,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average retreated from its one-day perch above 10,000 yesterday on renewed concerns about corporate earnings, as other major market measures also slipped.

title: Goodbye, Thanks and Some Answers
description: BEFORE I go, a few answers to the questions everybody has been asking. No. Yes. And, the letters.

title: Career vs. Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Young Are
description: The major broadcast networks are wringing their hands about the loss of hordes of 18-to-34-year-old viewers this season -- at least 6 percent of that age group -- and even accuse Nielsen Media Research of faulty measurement (a charge Nielsen denies).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, FLORA MARTHA
description: ADLER-Flora Martha. Of Lakewood, NJ on Monday, March 29, 1999, age 95. Beloved wife of the late Carl, devoted mother of son Henry and daughter-in-law Joan, loving grandmother of Douglas, Julia and Lauren, and greatgrandchildren Max and Sam. Graveside today Wednesday, March 31, 1999, 1 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. For information contact Belkoff-Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Lakewood.

title: CRESTLINE BUYS 74% INTEREST IN MARRIOTT RESIDENCE INN
description: The Crestline Capital Corporation, a hotel leasing concern, acquired a 74 percent limited partnership interest in the Marriott Residence Inn USA L.P. from a private Japanese investor for $34.4 million. Crestline also took on $54.6 million in debt. The partnership owns a diversified portfolio of 11 properties in eight states under the name Residence Inn by Marriott. Crestline Capital, based in Bethesda, Md., was spun off by Host Marriott last December.

title: PALEX, A PALLET MAKER, TO BE BOUGHT BY GERMAN COMPANY
description: Palex Inc., the largest United States maker of industrial pallets, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the closely held International Food Container Organization of Germany and to form a new public company to expand its platform and container business internationally. Palex, which makes portable platforms used for cargo, will become part of a new company created in an initial public offering at the time of the acquisition. Palex shareholders will get shares representing 32 percent to 35 percent of the new company. The closely held Scholler Packaging Systems, the parent company of International Food Container, will own the rest. Palex is based in Houston and has 71 plants in the United States and Canada. Its shares fell $1.0625, to $7.5625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Finding the Will And a Way to Win
description: Latrell Sprewell hugged Patrick Ewing as if he had been reunited with a long-lost brother of 20 years. It was a cathartic moment that lasted perhaps five seconds, a player from the new regime, the other from the old guard, euphoric after staving off Reggie Miller and the Indiana Pacers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUITTMAN, HERMAN Z.
description: QUITTMAN-Herman Z. As the recipients of the Herman Z. Quittman Award for Professional Excellence in Jewish Communal Service, we are especially saddened by the passing of this exceptional leader whose commitment to Zionism, Israel, the Jewish people and the U.S. set a standard which we all seek to emulate. To his family and his extended family in Bnai Zion we extend our condolences and pray that they draw comfort from his legacy of service and achievement that benefitted so many. Phil Baum, Sam Cohen, Malcolm Hoenlein, Ernest Michel and Ben Saxe

title: Florida Details Wide Abuse At Agency for the Retarded
description: A state report has documented widespread neglect of patients and misuse of funds at an agency for the mentally retarded that was put under state supervision earlier this month.

title: Talks Are Abandoned On British Oil Merger
description: Enterprise Oil P.L.C., the largest oil exploration and production company in Britain, broke off talks yesterday to buy a smaller rival, Lasmo P.L.C., after failing to find enough cost savings to justify a deal.

title: Monterrey Journal; Beisbol, Si! But Can U.S. Players Drink the Water?
description: Major League Baseball's first season opener to be played outside the United States or Canada is scheduled for Monterrey on April 4. The game has aroused so much excitement that tickets sold out in three hours when they went on sale here last month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GODNICK, AUDREY
description: GODNICK-Audrey. On March 31, 1996. Three years ago. There will never be another like you

title: Requiem for the Middleweights; Ho-Hum Taurus Marks End of Midsize Sedan as Style's Pace Car
description: Remember the first Ford Taurus? When the car was introduced in late 1985, its smooth, aerodynamic curves shook up the design of midsize sedans. And despite fears that its radical look would turn off car buyers, sales took off almost immediately. Moreover, its success was one of the early signs of the resurgence of the Ford Motor Company, which today is at the brink of surpassing the General Motors Corporation as the largest auto maker in the world.

title: Authentic Mexican Fare, Way North of the Border
description: FOR years, New York has been known as a place where good Mexican food is rarer than a cheap three-bedroom apartment. Though the reputation lingers, the facts have changed. For a decade or so, Mexican immigrants have been flowing into New York, and their presence is apparent in the taquerias and stores that have opened in the small Mexican enclaves that dot the city.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Pepsi Bottling is a giant offering that could well fail to excite investors fixated on Internet stocks.
description: IN another environment, the initial public offering of the Pepsi Bottling Group might be one of the hottest stock deals of the year, driven by an international brand name and a consumer franchise with great opportunity to expand abroad.

title: Strangers in a Strange Land
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Hong Kong Court Tells 17 They Must Return to China
description: In a decision that reflects rising fears about a flood of immigrants from mainland China, a Hong Kong court today ruled against 17 mainland residents who had claimed the right to live here.

title: Fed Maintains Steady Stance In Rate Policy
description: The Federal Reserve's top officials left interest rates unchanged today, and passed up an opportunity to signal any concern about inflation.

title: Officers Are Said to Tell of Suspicions About Diallo
description: Some of the police officers who shot and killed Amadou Diallo have told associates that their attention was initially drawn to Mr. Diallo when they saw him standing on the stoop of a Bronx apartment building and thought they saw him peering into the window of a first-floor apartment, according to people with knowledge of the case.

title: Parents Don't Always Know Better
description: To the Editor:
