description: AFRICA

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DOW JONES & CO., New York, named Rick Stine managing editor of Dow Jones News Service, the financial news wire. Mr. Stine, who had been deputy managing editor, replaces Neal S. Lipschutz, who was appointed senior editor of Dow Jones Newswires for the Americas. Mr. Lipschutz, in turn, succeeds John C. Hitchcock, who was named managing director of Dow Jones Newswires for Latin America.

title: No Quick Chinese Entry Seen Into Trade Group
description: Dampening hopes for a quick agreement on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, American officials said today that ''difficult and complex issues remain across all areas of trade'' after a hurried visit here by the White House trade representative.

title: Sports of The Times; In Triumph, Calhoun Still Remembered
description: HE was at the top of his profession 10 feet high, technically, but a career's worth of success in cosmic measurement. In a moment like this, an egomaniac might blurt something about being king of the world, or dance around like the proverbial decapitated chicken.

title: A Taste Treasure From Davy Jones's Locker
description: IN a world in which ''new'' too often signifies merely a change in food packaging or processing, Nova Scotia sea parsley is floating against the tide. This marine vegetable is an anomaly of nature, not industry -- though it would not be showing up in stores now without a little help from human hands.

title: Yeltsin Wants To Stay Out Of Warfare In Yugoslavia
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin told Russian political leaders today that the country ''will not allow itself to be drawn into military conflict'' in Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, IRWIN
description: MILLER-Irwin of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Sabina. Father of John, Robert and Harriet, and stepfather of Eleanor and David. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Joshua, Paige, Jacob, Hannah and Valerie. He was a prominent attorney in Carle Place for many years and was active in the bridge community.

title: Kidder, Peabody in $2.5 Million Settlement
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has agreed to pay about $2.5 million to settle charges that it generated illegal profits from a 1993 financing transaction for the City of Tampa, Fla., regulators said today.

title: Fleshing Out Stories of Ship Denied Refuge From Hitler; Holocaust Museum Sleuths Seek to Trace the Fate Of Jewish Passengers Who Sought Freedom in Vain
description: In June 1939, Ilse Marcus was so tantalizingly close to the saving shores of the United States that she could see the palm trees of Miami.

title: THE CHEF
description: IT'S near the end of a satisfying and complex restaurant meal -- dessert time -- the moment when many diners find themselves in the quivering grip of ambivalence. Do you go for the sweetness your palate so clearly craves? Or fearing heaviness and excess, do you choose moderation and mutter, ''No, nothing for me''?

title: Owner of Bronx Tenements Misused Funds, Audit Finds
description: A real estate developer who has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for President Clinton and the Democratic Party has been accused by Federal officials of misappropriating $1.4 million from a troubled housing complex in the South Bronx even as the tenements fell apart.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES TO WRITE OFF COSTS OF $251 MILLION
description: Dominion Resources Inc., the owner of Virginia's largest power company, will take a $251 million first-quarter charge to write off costs for which it will not be reimbursed by customers in a deregulated market. The charge equals $1.29 a share. Analysts had expected to earn 77 cents a share. The company had net income of $139.5 million, or 72 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Virginia's Governor, James Gilmore, signed a law last week that begins opening the state's electricity market to competition in 2002 and caps rates through 2007. Shares of Dominion, based in Richmond, fell 75 cents yesterday, to $37.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Fighting in Balkans Forces Move to U.S.
description: Fearing that the NATO military action against Yugoslavia presented the threat of a terrorist act against the high-profile players involved in the first round of the Fed Cup, the International Tennis Federation confirmed yesterday that the April 17-18 event would be held in the United States rather than in Zagreb, Croatia.

title: MORE ON THE CONFLICT
description: ALLIED FRUSTRATION -- Hampered by overcast skies, NATO warplanes bombarded Yugoslav Army forces, airfields and supply depots around the clock. But after a week, they were still unable to knock out air defenses or check Serbia's offensive in Kosovo. Page A11.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO CONTINUES TO SLIDE. Warfare between NATO and Yugoslavia, which has tarnished Europe's economic outlook, buoyed the dollar. In New York, the single European currency settled at $1.0715, down from $1.0735.

title: The Hollywood Gospels
description: This being the week before Easter, reruns of biblical movies are spreading the Gospel according to Hollywood.

title: Over Easy, With a Dash Of Tradition
description: IN gentle pastels, ''Holiday Eggs'' by Georgeanne Brennan (Smithmark, $14.95), celebrates the egg as a symbol of springtime and renewal. Eggs are showcased not only in recipes, but also in clever seasonal crafts, including stunning Ukrainian Easter eggs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, SOL
description: HOFFMAN-Sol. UNITE mourns the untimely passing of Vice President Sol Hoffman. In his 45 years as the leader of ILGWU (now UNITE) affiliates in Pennsylvania, Ohio, New Jersey and Maryland, Sol combined a deep commitment to the workers he represented with a broad vision of social justice. His love for his union and the union ideal are his legacy. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife, Catherine, and his children, Florice and Simone. Memorial Services on Wednesday, March 31, at 12 Noon, at Gutterman-Musicant Chapel, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Sol Hoffman Scholarship Fund, c/o President's Office, William Paterson University, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne, NJ 07470. Jay Mazur, President Bruce Raynor, Secy-Treasurer Edgar Romney Edward Clark Executive Vice Presidents

title: Give Kosovars A Safe Haven; Serbs' Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot in Bayonne
description: An off-duty police officer in Bayonne, N.J., was shot in the abdomen yesterday, possibly with his own gun, as he tried to break up a fight in an apartment building, the police said.

title: Jury Awards $81 Million To Oregon Smoker's Family
description: A state jury in Portland, Ore., yesterday ordered the largest award in a smoking-related lawsuit, deciding that the Philip Morris Companies must pay $81 million to the family of a man who smoked Marlboro cigarettes for four decades before he died.

title: Wilkens Didn't Expect This Much Success
description: When Tom Wilkens was growing up in Middletown, N.J., and swimming for Christian Brothers Academy in nearby Lincroft, he never thought he would be ranked No. 1 in the world in a race that was not even his specialty.

title: Miller Signs With Vikings
description: Corey Miller, the 30-year-old linebacker who was told by the Giants he could probably never play football again because of a neck injury, signed a one-year deal with the Minnesota Vikings on Monday after three team doctors cleared him to play.

title: Iridium's Chief Financial Officer Quits
description: Iridium L.L.C., which runs the first satellite-based global telephone network, said on Monday that its chief financial officer, Roy Grant, had resigned and said banks had given it two more months to meet sales targets or risk defaulting on $800 million in financing.

title: Helped by Woman She Shot, Amy Fisher May Be Paroled
description: Amy Fisher, who has served nearly seven years in prison for the 1992 shooting of Mary Jo Buttafuoco, may soon be out on parole, thanks to the help of her victim, who now says she forgives Ms. Fisher.

title: Victims of War: The Jungle Gorillas, and Tourism
description: The wound on the old male's silver back, inflicted in a fight with another group of gorillas, looked like it was healing. He studied his fingertips. Two of the little ones raced up and down a tree, stripping loose a shower of leaves that fell to the jungle floor.

title: CMS to Build Pipeline
description: The CMS Energy Corporation, which owns a Michigan gas and electric utility, said today that it would build a $190 million pipeline to transport gas removed from coal in Wyoming and Montana. The pipeline will run from coal fields near Sheridan, Wyo., north into Montana, then southeast to Gillette, Wyo., where the gas will be transferred to interstate pipelines. Service will begin in November.

title: The Candidate Tied to the Decision
description: While some Republican Presidential candidates are trying to avoid the thorny subject of American involvement in Kosovo, Vice President Al Gore does not have that luxury.

title: Hillaryno.com Is Not Mud.com, But a Fund-Raiser, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the as-yet-undeclared Republican candidate for United States Senate, said yesterday that a Web site set up by his supporters was not intended as an attack on Hillary Rodham Clinton but rather as an effort to capitalize on the fund-raising opportunity presented by her potential Senate candidacy.

title: The Nets Extend Lease On Basement Apartment
description: It is happening slowly, like the drip of syrup from a maple tree. But after what the Nets have been through, that is reason enough to get excited.

title: Olsten to Pay $61 Million in Medicare Billing Case
description: The Olsten Corporation, a big provider of home health care and temporary office workers, said yesterday that it would pay $61 million, including $10 million in fines and penalties, to settle Federal investigations into Medicare billing practices.

title: U.N. Panel Is Told of Rights Violations at U.S. Women's Prisons
description: An independent fact-finder for the United Nations has said sexual misconduct by prison guards is common in women's prisons in the United States.

title: Metro Business; Part of the Garden Is Sold
description: Cablevision Systems, the cable television company, will buy the nearly 4 percent of Madison Square Garden that it does not already own for $87 million from Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide.

title: Schwarzkopf Declines To Head State Police
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the retired general who was the central commander in the Persian Gulf war, to fill the position of state police superintendent early this month, but he declined, administration officials said.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Economy Aids Medicare

title: Major Leagues Might Sell Ads On the Uniforms of the Players
description: Major League Baseball is considering selling small patches of advertising on the uniform sleeves of its players as a new way to increase team revenue.

title: Respectful Law Enforcement
description: Ever since Amadou Diallo was killed in a hail of 41 police bullets almost two months ago, the unarmed West African's death has become a racial benchmark in New York City. The shooting has provoked the arrests of more than 1,200 demonstrators at 1 Police Plaza. It has forced changes in police policies, including an overhaul of the Street Crimes Unit, where the four policemen worked, and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has made his first efforts to meet with black leaders and even hear out some of his most vocal critics.

title: Hospital Stay Revealed For Man in Train Killing
description: A man with a history of mental illness who is accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a subway train in January was released from a Manhattan hospital less than three weeks before the attack, defense lawyers revealed yesterday. The man, Andrew Goldstein, was hospitalized five other times in 1998 for treatment of schizophrenia.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. The shutdown of two nuclear power plants raised speculation that some utilities would burn more natural gas. In New York, natural gas jumped 9.7 cents, to $1.98 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: A Photo Album For an Acrobat

title: Cleaning Up Boxing
description: To the Editor:

title: An Argentine Passover, Then and Now
description: PASSOVER comes in the fall in the Southern Hemisphere, but even for a gaucho judio in the pampas, the eight-day holiday means what it does for most Jews in the United States: gefilte fish with horseradish, chicken soup with matzoh balls and roast chicken. But there, cooks are much more involved in the preparations. Only recently have they had access to store-bought Passover staples.

title: Give Kosovars A Safe Haven; Lincoln Brigade Model
description: To the Editor:

title: In Alabama, Senate Ends Bitter Rift Over Leader
description: After a month of fierce factional deadlock and ridicule, the Alabama Senate today found its way out of the procedural chaos that had prevented any legislation from being passed and threatened to paralyze state government.

title: 3 Rings Of Wows For All
description: In an age when television shrinks the globe and transports the world's wonders into the living room, the circus, like grand opera and kabuki, may exist more as an embodiment of cultural tradition and spectacle than as a source of novelty.

title: Give Kosovars A Safe Haven
description: To the Editor:

title: Will We Fail Kosovo's Refugees?
description: The scenes of desperate refugees pouring out of Kosovo, thousands by the hour, should come as no surprise. These people are not fleeing NATO's bombs; they are fleeing the troops of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, and his campaign to murder or forcibly expel the ethnic Albanians from their homeland.

title: UConn Finds Rich Off-Court Gains in Basketball Power
description: Just six years ago, after enduring yet another round of frustrating negotiations to get more money from the state legislature, Harry J. Hartley, then the president of the University of Connecticut, declared facetiously that he wanted to turn UConn into a prison because ''that's the only way I see to get assured of funding.''

title: Netanyahu's Absence of Outrage Over Atrocities Ignites a Debate
description: Criticized for his Government's muted response to the expulsion and killings of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today condemned mass murder by anyone in the conflict and said Israel would send aid to the refugees.

title: Bad Weather Hampers Bombers' Effectiveness, U.S. Says
description: Hampered by overcast skies today, NATO warplanes bombarded Serb army forces, airfields and supply depots around the clock but failed again to knock out air defenses or blunt Serbia's offensive in Kosovo.

title: The Reality Is All Virtual, And Densely Complicated
description: Action heroes speak volumes about the couch-potato audiences that they thrill. So it's understandable that ''The Matrix,'' a furious special-effects tornado directed by the imaginative brothers Andy and Larry Wachowski (''Bound''), couldn't care less about the spies, cowboys and Rambos of times gone by. Aiming their film squarely at a generation bred on comics and computers, the Wachowskis stylishly envision the ultimate in cyberescapism, creating a movie that captures the duality of life a la laptop. Though the wildest exploits befall this film's sleek hero, most of its reality is so virtual that characters spend long spells of time lying stock still with their eyes closed.

title: Two Avenues: Writing for and Against the Piano
description: Garrick Ohlsson, one of the best and busiest pianists, offered another installment of his Liszt series at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, this one using Beethoven as a foil. I'm not sure the two composers complement each other, but they are certainly a study in contrasts. Liszt's elaboration on Beethoven's song ''Adelaide'' set the tone. Liszt followed. Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata came after the intermission. Here were two kinds of music coming each from its own direction.

title: Taking a Look Into the Soul Of 'Susannah'
description: It's not often that composers live long enough to see their operas enter the repertory and to hear successive generations of singers perform them. Strauss, who died in 1949 at 84, was one of the few. Consider this: He coached the soprano Marie Wittich, who created the daunting role of Salome in 1905, and conducted the great Ljuba Welitsch in it nearly 40 years later.

title: U.S. Data May Understate Productivity Gains
description: After years of maintaining that its statistics on the labor productivity growth rate were generally reliable, the Government agency that produces the numbers now says they may be somewhat understated.

title: Equant Plans To Expand Its Global Data Service
description: Helping to expand the digital world to some of the globe's least-wired corners, Equant N.V. of the Netherlands plans to announce today that it will offer advanced data services in 25 additional territories and countries including Albania, Georgia and Papua New Guinea.

title: Blair's Anger Fuels Support for Strikes
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke today of ''unimaginable suffering and barbarism'' in Kosovo. Defense Minister George Robertson told of Balkan ''killing fields'' created by Serbian atrocities. Foreign Secretary Robin Cook referred to ''appalling brutality'' and ''genocide.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, NEAL, M.D.
description: KONECKY-Neal, M.D. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Dr. Neal Konecky. In his tragically brief career, he upheld our finest traditions of medical care and made an important contribution to our understanding of the role of homocysteine in the treatment of heart disease. To his parents, Howard and Anne Konecky, his brother, Alan Konecky, M.D., and his entire family, we offer our profound condolences over his untimely passing. Sigurd H. Ackerman, MD President Carlton Boxhill, MD President of the Medical Board Michael Lesch, MD Chairman, Dept of Medicine Jonathan Steinberg, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology

title: Connecticut's Road to the Title Proves to Be as Easy as 1, 2, 3
description: Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun knew his Huskies believed they were the best team in the nation. On the eve of Monday night's championship game, Calhoun gathered his players and brandished a stack of blue index cards that he had compiled on Duke this season. The blunt-talking coach told them emphatically and without bluster how the title game was going to play out.

title: GIVE AND TAKE: When Charity Begins on Line; Pitfalls for Internet Shoppers With Charitable Bent
description: As Americans become increasingly comfortable shopping on line, it is a pitch many succumb to: Buy an Elmo toy or a Stephen King novel through a given Web site, and part of the purchase price will go to the charity of your choice.

title: Parents Don't Always Know Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Gollin, Public Opinion Researcher, 68
description: Albert Gollin, a sociologist and public opinion researcher who earned an international reputation for his studies of newspaper advertising and readership trends, died March 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Exploring Rootlessness In the Journey of Migration

title: Giuliani Says Crackdown on Drunken Drivers Cuts Accidents
description: In the first month that the New York Police Department began seizing the cars of drunken drivers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, the program had been a successful deterrent, leading to drops in arrests for driving while intoxicated and in related automobile accidents.

title: Sports of The Times; Tommy John: Don't Set Target Date
description: EVER since a tendon from Tommy John's right forearm was transplanted to replace a ruptured ligament in his left elbow in 1974, the operation has been known as ''Tommy John surgery.'' Dozens of ballplayers, mostly pitchers, have needed it. Now the Cubs' phenom, Kerry Wood, needs it. So does Paul Wilson, the Mets' right-hander who is scheduled to be wheeled into surgery today.

title: When Mental Patients Are at Risk
description: When Federal officials in Washington shut down all animal and human experimentation at the nation's largest Veterans Affairs medical center last week in Los Angeles, it was a welcome sign that government agencies may no longer be willing to tolerate the potential abuse of mental patients by scientists in the name of drug research. The joint action by several different agencies halted 500 different experiments at V.A. hospitals and clinics in Los Angeles -- in the very city where the suicide of a patient at the beginning of the decade helped to trigger concerns about drug research.

title: Airline Use Found Hard For Disabled
description: Disabled air travelers are often mistreated by airline personnel and denied special accommodations including access to wheelchairs and escorts in violation of a 1986 law, according to a report by the National Council on Disability.

title: TECHNOLOGY SOLUTIONS WILL CUT JOBS IN REORGANIZATION
description: The Technology Solutions Company, a consulting concern, said yesterday that it would dismiss 300 workers as it cut costs and restructured its businesses and warned that its first-quarter profit would not meet expectations. The company said it would take a charge of as much as $12 million in the first quarter. The company had been expected to earn 10 cents a share, the average estimate of four analysts surveyed by First Call Corporation. Technology Solutions also said it would propose a plan to spin off one of its businesses to shareholders. Shares of Technology Solutions, which is based in Chicago, were unchanged yesterday in Nasdaq trading, at $6.9375, but the restructuring was announced after the close of trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, MILTON S.
description: GOULD-Milton S. The Officers, Employees and Members of The New York Hotel and Motel Trades Counsel, AFL-CIO, and Local 6, Hotel, Restaurant and Club Employees and Bartenders Union, AFL-CIO, extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of our deceased former lawyer and advisor. We will desperately miss his good counsel and wisdom, his wit and most importantly, his courage to take on any opponent, no matter how powerful or influential. God bless his soul. Peter Ward, President New York Hotel Trades Counsel AFL-CIO; Business Manager, Local 6 Hotel, Restaurant & Club Employees & Bartenders Union, AFL-CIO.

title: BROWN & SHARPE TO CLOSE PLANTS IN BRITAIN, REPORT LOSS
description: The Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, a maker of measuring devices, said yesterday that it would take a pretax first-quarter charge of about $20 million to close three British plants and dismiss 230 workers, mostly in Britain, to cut costs. The company, based in North Kingstown, R.I., also plans to restructure some custom-measurement businesses. The charge will result in a first-quarter loss. Last year, Brown & Sharpe rejected a $15.50-a-share buyout proposal from the Thermo Electron Corporation. Shares of Brown & Sharpe rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $5.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: From the Seven Seas to New York Tables; His Specialty: Oddest Sea Life This Side of Loch Ness
description: IT was a fine day for fish, a bad day for humans -- cold, wet and windy. After squeaking into a parking place near Grand Central Terminal, Patricio Osses jumped out of his white van and flashed a triumphant smile at Julian Alonzo, the executive chef at Cafe Centro. ''Man, I have got some ugly fish,'' he said, throwing open the back doors of the van.

title: Abovenet to Split Stock
description: The stock of Abovenet Communications Inc. rose more than 32 percent today after the company, a provider of Internet connectivity services, said it would split its shares 2 for 1. The split would double the number of shares, to 27.2 million, but halve the value of each. The new shares will be issued on May 7 to holders of record as of April 14. Shares of Abovenet closed at $106.8125, up $25.9375, on Nasdaq. Almost 3.9 million shares were traded.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Truffle Oil's Uses

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday about companies in Silicon Alley that have issued stock or plan to issue stock misstated details about several of them.

title: Clinton Says Milosevic Hurts Claim To Kosovo
description: President Clinton warned President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia today that he was increasingly jeopardizing his claim to keep Kosovo as a province of Yugoslavia with his assault on the ethnic Albanian population there.

title: Samaranch Declines To Speak Before Senate
description: The president of the International Olympic Committee has refused to testify before a United States Senate Committee hearing investigating the Salt Lake City bribery scandal that led to the expulsion of six I.O.C. members.

title: It's Like, You Know, Sonnets And Stuff
description: Among the crop of recent teen-age movies whose plots parody stories from classic literature, ''10 Things I Hate About You,'' a high-school ''Taming of the Shrew,'' tries the hardest of any to season its screenplay with authentic Shakespearean touches. Students in a writing class at Padua High School (somewhere around Seattle) are asked to create sonnets. There is an Elizabethan-theme prom that inspires some fancy hairdos and fetching costumes. And every now and then the banter among the characters incorporates actual Shakespearean quotations.

title: U.S. Moves Ahead on Radar For Wind Shear at Airports
description: Nearly 24 years after a crash near Kennedy International Airport alerted the world to the danger of wind shear, New York City is finally expected to get a new radar to spot the problem.

title: Officers Tied To Beating May Hire A Consultant
description: Lawyers for the police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima are considering hiring a professional jury consultant to help them decide which prospective jurors they should favor or oppose, people familiar with the defense planning said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEFOED, JEAN
description: KOEFOED-Jean. Owner of Be Seated, Inc. died March 29, 1999. Survived by husband Ove and son Carl and his wife Wendy; also Harriet and John Pinagian and Ruth and Cornelius Lorenzen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, JEROME
description: LEVINE-Jerome. Wayne, NJ on Monday, March 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Marion, devoted and loving father of Jeanne, Robert, Nancy and Lisabeth. Brother of Sandra Levy. Proud cherished grandfather of Trevor, Dylan, Lawrence, Daniel, Andrew and Emily. Services 11:30am today at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Rt 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAPIENT CORP., Cambridge, Mass., a maker of web software, acquired Adjacency Inc. of San Francisco, an Internet consulting firm, for $54 million in stock.

title: U S Airways Plans Buyback Of $500 Million in Stock
description: U S Airways Group, the sixth-largest airline in the United States, said today that it would buy back $500 million in stock to lift its lagging shares.

title: Literary Cubism for Eccentrics at a Seaside Hotel
description: OCEAN SEA

title: The Great One, Greater One, Greatest One
description: Those fans still in the building stood and cheered Wayne Gretzky Monday night in Madison Square Garden, chanting his name and clapping until their hands hurt as the scoreboard showed highlights of his magnificent 21-year career. With emotion, Gretzky waved thanks to the audience and then urged his coach and teammates to get back to the game. Although his goal broke a 1-1 tie late in the third period, many fans had already left, perhaps because the Rangers-Islanders game had been so sluggish, maybe because they wanted to watch the college basketball championship on television.

title: Court Deals Blow to Giuliani's Hospital Privatization Plan
description: In a decisive setback to the Giuliani administration's efforts to privatize New York City's public hospitals, the state's highest court ruled yesterday that city officials had overstepped their authority in trying to lease Coney Island Hospital to a private company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOENIG, CAROL
description: SHOENIG-Carol. Sisterhood of Park East Synagogue mourns the loss of the Sister of our Board Member, Barbara Kasell. Our sincere condolences to the family. Beverly Greenberg, President Polly Etkind-Hochberg, Chairman

title: Swapping Cha-Chas and Rap in Cuba
description: It was in the air: the thrill of the illicit and the new, the excitement of discovery and the charge of an encounter with idols. And it didn't take place on a baseball field.

title: Crime-Fighting Isn't Only About Stark Choices; Mayor's Great Success
description: To the Editor:

title: HILB, ROGAL & HAMILTON BUYING UNIT OF PHOENIX HOME LIFE
description: The Hilb, Rogal & Hamilton Company, an insurance broker, said yesterday that it would acquire the American Phoenix Corporation from the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company in a transaction worth almost $100 million. American Phoenix, a property and casualty insurance brokerage based in Hartford, had about $73 million in revenues in 1998. Hilb, based in Glen Allen, Va., will exchange about $49 million in cash, $32 million in convertible notes and one million shares of common stock for American Phoenix. Hilb and Phoenix will form a marketing relationship in which Hilb will distribute selected financial products of Phoenix. Shares in Hilb, Rogal & Hamilton fell 18.75 cents, to $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It doesn't matter what these companies do or how they are priced. Each new Internet I.P.O. is nothing more than red meat to the mad dogs.''

title: Common Ground On Social Security
description: As the debate over Social Security heats up, many are stressing differences between the proposals made by Congressional Republicans and those outlined by President Clinton in his State of the Union address in January. But those differences are not as great as they may seem -- and there is no reason that the White House can't find enough common ground with Congress to work out a plan that is politically palatable to both sides.

title: Curing Lamb's Inferiority Complex
description: WITH Easter and Passover upon us, and the first tender leaves emerging on the trees, the thoughts of many American cooks are turning to lamb. But not for long.

title: Genocide, as Defined by a 1951 U.N. Treaty
description: Genocide, which the State Department has accused Yugoslavia of committing in Kosovo, is one of the most emotion-laden words in diplomacy and international law.

title: Health Officials Investigating to Determine How Woman Got the Embryo of Another
description: In a case reverberating through the rapidly growing world of reproductive technology, the New York State Health Department has started an investigation into an embryo mix-up that caused a Staten Island woman who underwent in vitro fertilization to recently give birth to two boys, one black and one white.

title: For NATO, Doubts Nag
description: Increasingly dejected by the inability of their dazzling weapons to bring Slobodan Milosevic to heel and stop the ethnic purge of Kosovo, NATO leaders are struggling to figure out what to do next if the bombing does not work.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the funeral of the traditional King of the Asante people of Ghana misspelled his name. He was Otumfuo Opoku Ware II, not Otumfuo Opoko Ware II. The article also misstated the year Ghana gained independence from Britain in some copies. It was 1957, not 1960.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, EVELYN
description: ZUCKERMAN-Evelyn. Westchester Day School records with sorrow the passing of Evelyn Zuckerman, who with her late husband Phillip were among the zealous founders of our school. We extend warm condolences to their dear family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, PETER SAMUEL
description: KLEIN-Peter Samuel. On March 29, 1999. Beloved proprietor of Joseph Fischl Artist Supplies. He will be profoundly missed by all who knew him. Services Wednesday 11am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, KATHERINE
description: FARR-Katherine. Beloved wife of the late William Farr and the late Sidney Zweig. Beloved mother of Martin E. (Barbara) Zweig, The Money Manager from ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser''. Loving grandmother of Zack and Alex Zweig. Also survived by Mollie Zweig. Sister of Perry (Ethel) Schwartz. Services today in Detroit, MI. For information call the Ira Kaufman Chapel, 248-569-0020.

title: People
description: * Fred Seibert was named to the new post of president of MTV Networks Online, New York, part of the MTV Networks unit of Viacom Inc., to head the new unit that will oversee operations of all MTV World Wide Web sites. He had been president of Frederator Inc., Los Angeles, a television production company.

title: Video Lottery Game Dies In Stalemate Over Budget
description: As bickering over the state's budget stalemate grew more heated, state lawmakers today insured that Quick Draw, the video lottery game introduced less than four years ago, would come to an abrupt end Wednesday night.

title: Parents Don't Always Know Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, HOWARD C.
description: ISAACS-Howard C. Beloved husband of Judith. Devoted father of Steven and Mary Beth; Stuart and Yoon; & David & Eileen. Adoring grandfather of Jason Leigh and Brett. Dear brother of Benjamin and Barbara. Loving uncle of many nieces & nephews. Funeral services today at 10:30AM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Thwarted, NATO Agrees to Bomb Belgrade Sites
description: The United States and NATO agreed tonight to a stepped-up bombing campaign targeting government buildings in downtown Belgrade, two senior American officials said. The decision acknowledges that air strikes have failed so far to halt the Serbian assault on Kosovo or to damage the Serbian military sufficiently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINA, WILLIAM
description: MALINA-William. The Board of Directors and staff of Grand Street Settlement are saddened by the passing of William Malina, father of dedicated Board member, Robert S. Malina. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Malina family. John L. Furth, President Margarita Rosa, Exec. Director

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SHARES OF BINKS RISE AFTER IT REPORTS SUITORS' INTEREST
description: The Binks Sames Corporation, a maker of equipment for spray finishing and application of coatings, said yesterday that it had received unsolicited inquiries about the sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Binks rose $2.625, to $18.75, giving the company's stock a current total value of $55 million. The company, based in Franklin Park, Ill., said it had asked its financial adviser, William Blair & Company, to review the inquiries and explore ''strategic alternatives.'' Last August Illinois Tool Works agreed to buy assets accounting for half of Binks Sames's sales for about $106 million in cash and assumed liabilities, but the two companies could not resolve disagreements.

title: At Wit's End, A Neighbor Turns Back The Refugees
description: The flow of refugees from Kosovo is overwhelming neighboring countries, leading to long delays at the borders and at worst, orders to turn back.

title: Court Ends Confusion on Prosecuting Gunmen
description: The Federal offense of using a gun during ''any crime of violence'' may be prosecuted anywhere the underlying crime took place and not only where the gun itself was used, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Fueled by Market, Stock Funds Received $26.4 Billion in March
description: Investors poured about $26.4 billion into stock mutual funds in March, the biggest monthly inflow since last April, according to an industry research group.

title: Chinese Want More U.S. Films, Valenti Reports
description: Hollywood has received its first sign in years that China may be willing to allow more American films into its theaters, a movie industry leader said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, S. ROBERT (KOKI)
description: LEE-S. Robert (Koki). Born Zagreb, Yugoslavia, 1928, son of Irene and Leo Levy, died at home in NYC on Monday, March 29, 1999. Member of Fort Ontario group, Oswego, NY, invited as refugees by President Roosevelt in 1944. Served the Air Force. Loved and practiced law for 37 years. Mourned by Ginette Lee, Nancy Pindrus, and many friends.

title: Earle Palmer Buys Sullivan & Mulvaney
description: The Earle Palmer Brown Companies in New York has acquired Sullivan & Mulvaney Inc. in Stamford, Conn., a high-technology marketing communications agency with estimated revenue of $1.5 million from clients that include Citigroup and I.B.M. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Liberties; No Free War
description: It could be even more scary.
